column2: AARON-Edward I., beloved husband of Amelia, father of Doris Fulton, Louis J., Marjorie Fruhling and Arthur; devoted son of Sarah. Services at Walter B. Cooke, Inc., Funeral Home, 117 West 72d, Sunday, 8 P. M. Funeral Monday, 2 P. M. Cremation at Ferncliff.

Austro-German negotiations were reported to have ended today, but a communique will not be issued until tomorrow because at the last moment Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg refused a demand that all German newspapers be allowed to enter this country.

The long-dreaded grasshopper invasion of Nebraska's corn fields has started, O. S. Bare, State entomologist, said today. The wheat crop now being harvested has escaped without great damage, Mr. Bare said, but the pests were making headway in corn fields and were stripping oats.

Miss Millicent Hirsh of New York and Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, Texas, reached the final round of the women's Philadelphia and district grass court tennis singles championship at the Germantown Cricket Club today.
Miss Jane Douglas of the Rumson Country Club won the women's New Jersey Golf Association oneday tournament with a gross card of 89 at the Spring Lake Golf and Country Club today.

Dance orchestras are as the waves of the ocean; their popularity rises and falls from month to month. One Winter they may be the playthings of Society, in the upper case, playing for debutante parties, wedding receptions, or in the most select niches of the avenue.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Capt. Elmer J. Tangerman, FA-Res., 154 Luquer Road, Port Washington, L. I., Field Artillery Group, ordered to active duty, July 25, at Fort Bragg, N. C., for training in sound ranging. Captain Tangerman will rank from July 10, 1937. He will be relieved from duty Aug. 7.

Public Service Commissioner George R. Van Namee yesterday closed the commission's inquiry into methods and practices of the Western Union Telegraph Company and the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company in the handling and delivery of messages. The commission began the inquiry after receiving complaints of delays in transmission of telegraph messages.

A program of twelve Class A reature-length productions for release in this country next season will be announced today by Arthur A. Lee, vice president, at the second session of the Gaumont British sales convention in the St. Moritz Hotel. Among the stars who will be represented on the 1937-38 program are Jessie Matthews, Anna Neagle, Anna Lee and Nova Pilbeam.

A statement that business men must adopt "broad gauge" policies in line with those of their governments if they are to retain control of their own affairs was made by A. A. Berle Jr., Chamberlain of New York, in an address tonight before the University of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs.
New bond financing this week fell to the lowest volume for 1937 to date and was the smallest for any week since the one ended on Nov. 6, 1936, when offerings amounted to $450,000.

Only one of the Phillies reached second base today when Jim Turner, the 30-year-old freshman right-hander, gave the Bees their eleventh victory in their last thirteen starts by pitching a five-hitter for a 5-0 shutout.
A showplace on the New Jersey coast passed to new control in the purchase by Louis H. Burfeind, president of the Asbury Park and Ocean Grove Bank, of the Newman property at Interlaken.

Dudley W. Miller, at 31 Hotel Dr., Gedney Farms, Westchester, from Robert C. Bancker: John Small, at 28 Prescott Rd, White Plains, from estate of H. B. Slaugh; Chauncey B. Griffen, broker. C. M. Turner, at 513 Fairmont Ave, Westfield; H. A. Sterner, at 100 S. Martime Ave, Fanwood; George Friedl Jr.,

Melvin M. Rein, attorney, in 342 Madison Ave; Wellesley J. Seligman, importer, in 240 Madison Ave; Eastern Box Case Co. in 28-30 E 4th St; Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corp. broker. 1. H. Lubin, Inc; stationery and printing, In Fisk Building, 250 W 57th St; Carton Art Copy Service, Inc: commercial artists,
Marking its greatest production year since 1930, the Ford Motor Company today completed its onemillionth V-8 for the 1937 production season.

Cardinal Pacelli, whom some unofficial sources believe to be an emissary from Pope Pius to create a better understanding in France on behalf of the Spanish Insurgents, conferred today with Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos.

Turpentine firm, 341/4@341/2c; sales 178 barrels; receipts 590 barrels; shipments 50 barrels; stock 30,382 barrels. Resin firm, sales 738: receipts 2,091; shipments 1,881; stock 66,460. Quote: B to I, $7.871/2; K, M. $7.871/2; N. $7.90; WG, $7.90@$7.95; WW, X,$8.85.

To cease burning coffee by millions of tons each year, Brazil will offer every assistance to any chemical concern willing to establish here a plant with a bona fide process to convert its coffee surplus into commercial by-products, according to Fernando Costa, president of the National Coffee Department.

The Niagara Frontier Planning Board went on record today as opposing President Roosevelt's proposal to create "little TVA's," after their chairman called the scheme "a stab in the back" and an "underhanded way of putting over the St. Lawrence Seaway."

Two small boys walking at 8:30 A. M. yesterday along East Seventy-ninth Street in Brooklyn found t the body of Andrew Ingao, 30 years old, of 190 Madison Street, Manhattan, in a vacant lot 150 feet north of Glenwood Road.

Ambassador Charles Corbin's warning to the Non-Intervention Committee today that unless control of Spanish imports continued at sea and was reestablished along the Portuguese frontier the French Government would be obliged to refuse to be the only country subject to international control, is not, it is insisted here, by any means an empty threat.

A dispute between the management of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad and the Interstate Commerce Commission as to whether the value of the company is sufficient to justify the issuance of the bonds proposed by the management in its reorganization plan has brought a temporary halt to the reorganization proceedings, it was made known yesterday.

Emil Ludwig, exiled German author, who arrived here on June 16 to see President Roosevelt and gather impressions for his biography of Mr. Roosevelt, sailed yesterday for Paris on the French liner Ile de France. He is taking with him two note books filled with stenographic notes about the man he termed "the most loved and hated man in America."

The appointment of Thomas A. Morgan as chairman of the advisory committee on aviation of the New York World's Fair in 1939 was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corportion. He also announced the Other appointment of Miss Marcia Connor as fashion and color executive for the fair.
The Athletics and Red Sox played Tiger !nearly four hours today to reach Whitl a twelve-inning decision of 12 to 11 first for the Boston club. The struggle all th was the first of a five-game series.
The House joined the Senate today in authorizing construction this year of six auxiliary vessels for the navy. Officials have estimated the ships will cost $48,206,000.

The sixteen-story Printarts Building, 228-238 East Forty-fifth Street through the block to 237 East Forty-fourth Street, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms to the Vanderberg Realty Corporation, as plaintiff, for $$984,642.

Emlen T. Littell, former president of the Atlantic Funding Corporation of New York and for years active in the commercial banking field in New York and Baltimore, died at his home on Quaker Hill here today after a long illness.

Mrs. Edgar Stirling Auchincloss of 123 East Sixty-ninth Street and Keewaydin, Darien, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Katrina Auchincloss, to Royal Elting Mygatt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic E. Mygatt of this city and Washington. Conn.

Havemeyer Ave., (14-3828), n e cor of Haviland Ave., 33X105; Edward T. McCaffret, referse, to Jacob Wieland, 208 Mount Hope Pl. Merriam Ave., (9-2529), w s 120 s of 169th St., 37X100; American Museum of Natural History to Schafecraus Realty Corp., 332 E. 149th St.

Mrs. Robert A. Sewell of Brooklyn, N. Y., who is at her Summer home in Hancock, was a luncheon and bridge hostess at the Curtis Hotel here today in honor of the Misses Margaret E. and Harriet G. Duane of Brooklyn.

BAILEY, FLAVIUS JOSEPHUS (June 27). Estate, less than $5,000. To George Bailey, brother, Colonel Ridge Postoffice, Clarendon, Jamaica, B. W. I., $1,000; A. George Daly. friend, 131 Edgecombe Ave., $1,500; one other bequest. Garon A. Weaver, 2,460 7th Ave., executor.

Heat Deaths BARTH, FRED, 55, of 6 Gypsin Street, Far Rockaway-Collapsed while working at Pier 60, North River, and died of a hesrt attack. BENEDICT, DANIEL, 75, of 660 Dawson Street, the Bronx, was prostrated in a beer garden at 816 Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, and died a few minutes later. GORDON, GUSTAF, 58, of 40-08 Fortyseventh Avenue, Long Island City-Died on the street near his home.

China's reconstruction program has opened up opportunities for foreign exporters of railway and industrial equipment which British, German and other European nationals have been quick to seize, says the Far Eastern Survey of the American Council, Institute of Pacific Relations.

The Dobeckmun Company of Cleveland, manufacturers of cellophane products, announced yesterday that it had purchased from the Crown Zellerbach Corporation the properties of the Western Shellmar Products Company of Oakland, Calif.,

Crashing through with golf as blistering as the weather itself, Ray Billows of the Dutchess Club, up near Poughkeepsie, and Mark J. Stuart, one of the galaxy of stars "wearing the silks" of the home club, today finished 1-2 in the first 36 holes of the annual Sweetser Victory Cup event at the Winged Foot Club, one-time scene of the national open.

The Bulova Watch Company, Inc., and wholly owned subsidiaries in the fiscal year ended on March 31 earned $2,643,122 after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes, provision for doubtful notes and accounts receivable and $22,517 provision for Federal surtax on undistributed profits, according to a report issued yesterday.

Oak St., 29, 25.6x62; half interest, Libonia Torregrossa to Fred A. Torregrossa, 7,017 15th Ave, Brooklyn: mtg $7,000. 76th St., n s, 129 ft w of West End Ave, 22x102.2; 309 W 76th St, Inc, to Union Dime Savings Bank; mtg $21,500, held by bank.

The Museum of Modern Art, 14 West Forty-ninth Street, has announced the appointment of John McAndrew as curator of its department of architecture and industrial art. The appointment will become effective Sept. 1, 1937.

The westward survey for Atlantic air service was completed yesterday with impressive ease when Captain A. S. WILCOCKSON of Imperial Airways set the flying boat Caledonia down in the waters of Manhasset Bay, L. I., at the temporary base and terminal of Pan American Airways at Port Washington.

The Rev. Robert Anderson Jardine, the vicar who officiated at the Windsor wedding, will give a talk at the Convention Hall here tomorrow night as scheduled, but three local welfare agencies, at their own request, will not share the prooceds. as scheduled.

Cincinnati's Reds clouted three homers, good for five runs today, while the Cardinals made only one-Joe Medwick's eighteenth of the season; but a five-run eighth-inning rally gave St. Louis the victory, 8 to 7.
American fishermen, in telegrams received here from the Bristol Bay area of Alaska, contradict Japanese claims that their vessels are not fishing for salmon off the Alaska Coast.

A resumption of dividends on the common stock of the Phoenix Securities Corporation, consisting of 25 cents a share in cash plus oneseventieth of a share of Certainteed Products Corporation 6 per cent prior-preference stock for each Phoenix common share, was announced yesterday by Walter S. Mack Jr., president of the corporation.

The steel ingot producing capacity of the country has been increased by 289,500 gross tons annually since the end of 1936 by the installation of new facilities and enlargement of others, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
All Spanish Consuls in the United States were summoned by the Spanish Embassy to be here July 17, to pay homage to the Loyalists who have fallen.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
With a daily consumption of 110,000,000 gallons above normal Philadelphia was threatened today with a serious water shortage as the temperature rose above the 97-degree mark.

The six-story apartment house at 1,326-8 Commonwealth Avenue, the Bronx, which was sold by the State Mortgage Commission to Isidor Tankus, attorney, has been resold to Milton Newmark for cash over a first mortgage of $141,250.

Charles S. W. Packard, one of Philadelphia's best-known financiers, died at his home on Rittenhouse Square today after an illness of two years. He suffered a stroke about a year ago. He was 77 years old.

The sale of properties surrounding the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street was announced yesterday when the Wyeth estates disposed of the four four-story buildings at 129131 East Thirty-fourth Street and 242-244 Lexington Avenue.

Joseph F. Moss, former City Magistrate and justice of the Court of Special Sessions, died Thursday at the home of his sister, Mrs. Mary Alice Tully, 756 Union Street, Brooklyn, of a heart attack. He was 78 years old and lived at 329 East Eighteenth Street.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 7: COMMANDERS Carney, R. B., the Reid, to command the Sirius.

The thousand Republicans who made the long journey to College Point with the thermometer at 93 can scarcely have been surprised to learn from Mr. LA GUARDIA that he is willing to accept the Republican nomination if it is offered to him. They were, however,
The East River Savings Bank sold to an investor the six-story tenement house at 191 Stanton Street, adjoining the southeast corner of Attorney Street.

Lieutenant Howard J. Smith, from First Division to Thirteenth Division, assignment changed from desk duty to supervisor of plainclothes patrolmen. Patrolmen Dennis A. Honohan, from Precinct 25 to Precinct 48: Gustave J. Barringer, from Precinct 46 to Precinct 28; Thomas J. Connolly, from Precinct 47 to Precinct 30.

Captain Donald MacPhee of Oban, Scotland, navigating officer of T. O. M. Sopwith's Endeavour II, challenger for the America's Cup, who died at the Newport Hospital on Thursday, was buried this afternoon with all honors due his rank in the Seamen's Church Institute plot at Island Cemetery here after impressive funeral services in the Belmont Memorial Chapel of the cemetery.

Sales of copper were reported abroad yesterday at 14.05 cents a pound, c. i. f., the European base ports. Most business, however, was done between 14.10 and 14.20 cents. On Thursday, the low level was 14.20 cents.
The best balanced and the strongest Oxford-Cambridge team to reach these shores awaited tonight its international track and field meeting with the combined Yale and Harvard forces tomorrow.

Harsh words were directed today at William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, over his statement that the Committee for Industrial Organization had lost its steel strike because of "stupid blunders."
The stock market was generally on the advancing side today,. apparently responding constructively to Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's summing up of Great Britain's trade position.

A funeral service was conducted yesterday afternoon for Parmely W. Herrick, financier and son of the late Myron T. Herrick, former Ambassador to France, at St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at Seventy-first Street. Mr. Herrick died Wednesday after a long illness.

An action to test the validity of a magistrate's court rule denying traffic law violators the right to pay so-called service agencies a fee for paying their fines was instituted yesterday in Supreme Court. The rule, which applies only in cases where the personal appearance of the violators is not required, was put into effect last March 18.

To the disappointment of the many admirers his brilliant play had won for him since the opening of the International Chess Congress here three weeks ago, Samuel Reshevsky of New York, the United States champion, lost his adjourned game with E. Book of Finland in the final round today.
Andrew J. (Cy) Cummings, head of the Laurel race track organization and active in political affairs, died today at his home at Chevy Chase in his sixtieth year.
The AAA reports that off-shore areas used 3,190,350 tons of their 1937 sugar quotas of 4,798,430 tons in the first six months of this year.

Sussex drew closer to Yorkshire, leader in the English county cricket championship race, when rain prevented play in the match between the northern county and Middlesex today. Middlesex took first innings' points. Sussex yesterday trounced Worcestershire by nine wickets.

Hughes Ave., 2,019 (11-3069), Katharina Schwarz to Central Savings Bank, extends mtg to Feb. 5, 1942, at 5 per cent; $15,000. Charlotte St., 1,507 (11-2966), Charuth Realty Corp, to Menno Brown, trustee, White Plains, N. Y., extends mtg to May 1, 1942, at 5 per cent; $25,000.

State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews reported today that 173 plans for Upstate industrial buildings were submitted for approval to the State Department of Labor during June, representing a total investment of $2,393,990.

Another of the Southwest's famed two-gun peace officers-J. F. (Uncle Bud) Ledbetter, who often remarked, "I don't see how I ever kept from being killed," died last night in a hospital, unconscious after a long illness. His age was 84.

Stocks fluctuated narrowly and closed irregular in slowest trad-. ing in a week; turnover, 845,420 shares. All groups of bonds firm and dull in smallest turnover of the month; transactions, $7,413,200.

Mrs. Marguerite Fox Dolbow and Norman Driscoll, convicted in February, 1936, for the slaying of her husband at his Salem County farm, Aug. 2, 1935, will go to the electric chair the week of Aug. 15 under warrants signed today by Supreme Court Justice Ralph W. Donges in Camden.

The Pirtes pounded three Cub pitchers for nineteen hits and a 13 to 1 victory in their series opener today. Led by the Waner boys, Big and Little Poison, they clinched the game in the first inning with a two-run rally, and went on to climax their clouting with a ninerun spree on ten hits in the seventh.

King Carol left Bucharest incognito this morning and arrived in Belgrade this evening, where he will stay with his sister, Queen Mother Marie of Yugoslavia. It is believed he will go on to Vienna to serve as godfather for his nephew, Archduchess Ileana's son.

Awards totaling $85,000 against the New York Central Railroad in favor of Mr. and Mrs. Adolf C. E. Windmuller of Dobbs Ferry, Westchester County, were upheld unanimously yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.

Progress in consolidating the New York State properties of the Associated Gas and Electric System has made the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation one of the largest utility companies in the State, serving an area of about 19,000 square miles, or 40 per cent of the State's area, according to the annual report of the latter company for 1936, issued yesterday.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 3 amounted to 806,168 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company will reopen its Indiana Harbor plant, employing 7,000 men, within a few days, Frank Purnell, president of the company, stated today.

Miss Grace Armory's golf game was as hot as the blistering sun which scorched the Westchester Hills Golf Club course this morning as she won the annual women's invitation tournament with a 75 that comDletely eclipsed the rest of the field.
The South Texas Agricultural Workers Union appealed by telegraph today to Secretary Perkins for a Department of Labor mediator to settle differences between its members and cotton growers.

Fourteen former officials of the Harriman National Bank were released yesterday as defendants in a $6,800,000 accounting action entered by Frederick V. Goess, the bank's receiver, by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman.

The twentieth year of Camp Dix as a training area for citizen soldiers started today with the arrival here of 1,877 young men from New York, New Jersey and Delaware for thirty days' training in military citizenship, and other activities under supervision of regular army and Reserve Corps officers.

So Cotton is king again, not in the deep South but from Land's End to John O'Groat's House by Duncansby Head. Through the fog and the rain that rolled in off the North Sea, Handsome Henry, slick-haired, slim-waisted, whipped his willowy way around the old Carnoustie course and gained the British open crown.
Rear Admiral Charles P. Snyder, United States Navy, president of the Naval War College, and Mrs. Snyder were "at home" at President's House this afternoon. Admiral and Mrs.

The ninth annual Summer session of Union Theological Seminary will open on Monday with twenty courses, in conjunction with the thirty-eighth annual Summer session for students at Columbia University. Students will be taken on tours of the city to study social and economic trends and religious activities.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said tonight that she "hopes" her husband will not seek a third term. The statement came during a question-and-answer session which followed her address before the Franklin D. Roosevelt Home Club of Hyde Park.

The Rev. Fred V. Christ, pastor of the First English Lutheran Church at Pearl River, N. Y., for the last ten years, died here yesterday at the home of his brotherin-law, the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America. His age was 59.
A large audience heard Mrs. Charles de Kay, widow of the writer and critic, read a. series of original sketches tonight in the John Drew Memorial Theatre, Guild Hall.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 8 unless specified: At Lahaina, July 9: Cushing, Drayton, Lamson, Whippoorwill. At Funchal, July 9; Arkansas, New York, Wyoming.

The United States and China will embark immediately upon an expanded program of bartering gold and silver intended to have beneficial results for both nations and a stabilizing effect upon world currencies generally, Secretary Morgenthau and H. H. Kung, Chinese Finance Minister, announced in a joint statement this afternoon.

Charles N. Feidelson, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, said late today that the Atlanta Newspaper Guild and the Georgia Federation of Labor had. filed charges against The Atlanta Constitution following dismissal of six editorial employes.
Max Schmeling, arriving today from Berlin, said he "insisted" that Tommy Farr, British Empire heavyweight champion, should fight him before meeting the world champion, Joe Louis.
Dizzy Dean, ace of the Cardinal pitching staff, has more troubles. A sore big toe will keep him from taking his regular turn on the hill against the Reds Sunday.

Political, economic and social changes that might make ironclad restrictions on trust legacies unwise were considered in the will of Frank A. Vanderlip, financier and former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, filed for probate here today.

Patrick J. Haltigan, reading clerk in the House of Representatives, died last night. He was 74 years old. Mr. Haltigan's booming voice became nationally known at the 1924 Democratic convention in New York. For days during the SmithMcAdoo deadlock, he read off ballot after ballot-beginning each one with Alabama's 24 votes for her favorite son, Oscar Underwood.

Born with only one eye and with only a few traces of eyelash where the other eyelids should have been, a 3-year-old girl will soon undergo an operation at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital to equip her with an artificial eye.

The volume of trading leveled off in the bond market yesterday and the prices of listed obligations on the New York Stock Exchange were highly irregular with only occasional loans continuing in the advance.

58th St, 34 W; to 6-story tenement and store; The Alliance Realty Co. 115 Broadway, owner: Charles H. Lench, architect; cost, $25,000. 55th St, 49 W; to 5-story tenement and store; Eric Coupey, 6 St. Lukes P1, owner; E. J. Moeller, architect; cost, $9,000. 33d St, 156-8 E; to 4-story tenement; Mrs.

The marriage of Miss Anne Carol MacArthur, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nelson J. MacArthur of this city, to Walter J. Masterson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Masterson of Noroton, Conn., took place here this morning in the Church of SS. Peter and Paul.

The marriage of Miss Helen Sampson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Sampson of Mount Vernon, to Edward Arthur O'Neill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank James O'Neill, also of Mount Vernon, took place yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Peter and St. Paul in Fleetwood, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John McNamara.
Colonel .Jamuel P. Town, Past National Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic, died at his home here early this morning after several years of ill health. He was 91 years old.
The Browns dropped the opener of a four-game series to the White Sox today, 11 to 7, when the Chicago team piled up a total of eighteen hits off three St. Louis pitchers.
The Reichsbank's statement as of July 8 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:
Jacob Chaitkin, a New York attorney, bought an eight-room house on Lounsbury Road, Croton-onHudson, which was erected by the Westmanton Realty Corporation from plans by Harvey Stevenson, architect.

Miss Elizabeth Nigro, daughter of Mrs. James Nigro of 1,079 East Tenth Street, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Nigro, will be married to John Newton McKay, son of Mrs. Allen Baine McKay of Caledonia, N. Y., and the late Mr. McKay, this morning at the Nigro home.

Harry Lavine, World War veteran and president of the Sadye Victor Company, a millinery concern at 145 East Fifty-second Street, died Thursday at the Veterans Administration Facility, the Bronx, of a heart ailment and arteriosclerosis. Mr. Lavine, who lived at the East Fifty-second Street address, was 50 years old.

The silk and rayon dyeing and finishing industry, centered here, is in a "sick, demoralized condition," and only through the full cooperation of a majority of shop owners can remedies be properly applied, General Hugh S. Johnson, former head of the NRA, reported today.

General evening-up was under way in North American wheat markets today for the American and Canadian governments' reports, which were due after the close of trading, and this, combined with hedging pressure and stop-loss selling for traders who had placed selling orders somewhat under yesterday's final sales, resulted in a lower level of prices.

More than 200 newspaper men, radio commentators, newsreel men and magazine editors from all parts of the country were here tonight attending the annual three-day frolic of the National Headliners Club.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation and its subsidiaries, the Robins Dry Dock and Repair Company of Brooklyn and the Tietjen Lang Co. of Hoboken, were charged with unfair labor practices in a complaint filed before the National Labor Relations Board yesterday.

Goodrich, daughter of Mrs. Frank Edward Cone of this place and the late Dr. William Goodrich, was married to Arthur William Gregory Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Gregory of Hartford, here this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. William T. Hooper.

E. H. Dowell, district organizer here for the A. F. of L., said last night in a debate that the Department of Justice had in its possession checks totaling $750,000 from Communist sources to John L. Lewis to assist in organizing the C. I. O.

More than 6,000, or about 50 per cent, of the 11,800 WPA workers dismissed on June 30 have since applied for home relief, it was disclosed yesterday by Charlotte Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau. The rest,

Disciplinary action will be taken against all WPA teachers employed by the school system found guilty of disturbances in the recent demonstrations and riotings against WPA dismissals, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.

New York Stock Exchange authorities on July 22 will consider the proposed new partnership of Granbery, Marache Lord. The partners would be E. Carleton Granbery, Robert 0. Lord, Charles L. Cleveland, Herbert W. Marache, Virgil C. Sullivan and Clifford V. Brokaw Jr.
Berkeley T. Rulon-Miller, prominent in yachting and social circles, died here today at the age of 23. He was the son of the late J. Rulon-Miller and Mrs. George Blakiston.
Approval of the Brooklyn and Bronx extensions of the Independent City Subway along routes recommended by the Board of Transportation was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

Miss Alta Frances Judy of 270 West Eleventh Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Richard Judy of Ferguson, Mo., was married to Harold Nathan Graves Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Nathan Graves of Washington, yesterday afternoon at the home of Miss Elizabeth Jorzick, 45 East Ninth Street, formerly of Louisville, Ky., by the Rev. John C. Whiting of New York, a friend of the bride's family.

Harold S. Vanderbilt's America's Cup defender, Ranger, victor again today, was dealt a blow in her handling when the officials of the New York Yacht Club, which she will represent in the international match against T. O. M. Sopwith's challenger, Endeavour II, ruled against her Jibing with her parachute spinnaker set.

After an absence of six seasons, Fritz Reiner, the Hungarian conductor, returned to the Lewisohn Stadium last night, where he directed a concert attended by 2,500 persons. The former leader of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, who first appeared at the Stadium during the season of 1924, had just come back from England where he conducted several operas during the coronation festivities.
The Irish Free State Labor party, with thirteen members in the new Dail (Parliament), declared tonight it will pursue a policy of complete independence.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Discussion as to the selections of the teams for the All-Star baseball game each midsummer seems to wax stronger at the time when the game is played.

The United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association, Inc., announced yesterday, through its general secretary, Charles Ackerman, that its 1,100 East Bronx members had voted by 99 per cent majority to adopt allday Sunday closing on and after tomorrow.

The report yesterday of the Department of Agriculture on the condition of grain crops indicated that the output of cereals in the United States this year will approximate the average for 1928-32, both years inclusive.

The seven Chinese nurses who accompanied Frederick Snite Jr., infantile paralysis victim, on his 12,000-mile journey in an "iron lung" from Peiping to Chicago, set out to see the city yesterday morning and only the heat marred their enjoyment.

A special concert commemorating the anniversary of the birth in 1856 of Daniel Guggenheim, who died Sept. 28, 1930, was given last night on the Central Park Mall by the Goldman Band, Edwin Franko Goldman conductor.

Timothy O'Herliky, the oldest member of the County Cork Association and a regular participant in the St. Patrick's Day parade for the last sixty-two years, died yesterday at his home, 74-08 Fortyfirst Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens. His age was 85.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy was warmly praised yesterday by counsel for both sides for his patience in hearing evidence in the $20,000,000 accounting suit brought by minority stockholders against the Long Island Lighting Company.

The 3,000,000th automobile will pass over the Henry Hudson Parkway about 9 o'clock this morning, according to estimates of the Henry Hudson Parkway Authority. The driver of the car will receive a book of fifty tickets.

Mrs. Mary Stewart, the mother of Percy M. Stewart, head of the syndicate department of Kuhn, Loeb Co., died on Thursday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Louis E. Strong, Strongleigh Park, Lindenhurst, L. I., after a long illness. Her age was 79.
Naval searchers had little hope for the rescue of Amelia Earhart today, but their planes and ships continued to sweep the Phoenix Island area. They had one great trump card yet to play.

Kilkare Chief, handsome chestnut gelding owned by the Kilkare Farm of Mrs. Samuel Schiffer of Elberon, N. J., and ridden by his owner, today was awarded the Terre Haute Farm Challenge Trophy, leading cup event of the first day of the seventh annual Country Club Horse Show.
Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in June totaled $28,697,184,405, a gain of 11.6 per cent over the preceding month, but about the same volume as for June, 1936.
Three women and a man were killed this evening when their car was struck by an express train at the Newington Avenue crossing of the New Haven Railroad in this city.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Hartwell Titlar, daughter of Mrs. Albert Lewis Titlar of this place, and the late Mr. Titlar, to William Hunter Stevenson, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Stevenson, also of Yonkers, took place here tonight in the First Methodist Episcopal Church.

Tokyo's order to Ambassador Shigeru Kawagoe to abandon his journey to North China and return to Nanking from Tsingtao and a statement of Japanese grievances by General Seeichi Kita, military attache of the Japanese Embassy, show the gravity with which Japan regards the Lukouchiao clash, near Peiping, even though the firing has ceased under a truce designed to permit negotiations.

President Roosevelt outlined the labor relations policy of the government, stating at a press conference that Federal employes cannot strike and have limited collective bargaining privileges but can join any labor organization they wish to.
Immediate discharge of all aliens on WPA projects in Massachusetts was ordered today by Colonel John J. McDonough, State Administrator.

The seven Chinese nurses who accompanied Frederick Snite Jr., infantile paralysis victim, on his 12,000-mile journey in an "iron lung" from Peiping to Chicago, set out to see the city yesterday morning and only the heat marred their enjoyment.

A special concert commemorating the anniversary of the birth in 1856 of Daniel Guggenheim, who died Sept. 28, 1930, was given last night on the Central Park Mall by the Goldman Band, Edwin Franko Goldman conductor.

Seventeen Federal agencies awarded 187 supply contracts for a total value of $7,146,991 under the terms of the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on July 8, the Department of Labor announced today.
The different generations will respond to Dr. JOHN L. RICE'S hotweather bulletin according to their several
The Welsh Guards Band broadcasts a concert from London tonight at 8:15 o'clock over these stations: GSP, 15.31; GSO, 15.18; GSD, 11.75; GSB, 9.51 megacycles.
The imperative rapping of a gavel called the United States Senate to order at noon last Tuesday. Eighty-four Senators, dressed in Summer white or sport clothes, answered the roll.

More than a dozen homes in Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau Counties have recently been sold by the Mcrtgagees Realty Service, the real estate division of the Home Title Guaranty Company, acting as agent for individual and institutional investors.

ATTORNEY GENERAL HOMER A S. CUMMINGS, speaking over WABC's hook-up on Friday at 10:30 P. M., is scheduled to open a weekly discussion of national affairs by Cabinet members. The United States Marine Band will provide music before and after the speeches.

In a phenomenal demonstration of navigating a yacht 104 miles down Long Island Sound from Execution Light to Block Island, Daniel F. B. Hickey, former commodore of the New York Athletic Club, was the apparent winner tonight of the New York A. C.'s twenty-eighth annual Block Island cruiser race with his new yacht Danell.

I AM by no means certain that I, the present writer, am the correct person to be assessing American plays and their effect on English audiences. My contact with Americans began twenty years ago, in the last year of the war, with a squadron of the British Flying Corps in France.

LAST week we took up in these columns an inquiry into some of the sources and aims of abstract art, with emphasis on "non-objective" art owned by Solomon R. Guggenheim, the establishment of whose foundation had just been announced.
The Utility and Industrial Corporation reported yesterday net assets of $3,548,480 on June 30, based on market or estimated values for investments.

The Larchmont Yacht Club takes the center of the stage on Long Island Sound this week with its annual extravaganza, Larchmont Race Week, which opens on Saturday, and its 320-mile ocean race for cruising boats to and around Fire Island lightship beginning Tuesday.

Fresh in the wake of several other new motor cruiser races, which have been added to the season's yachting calendar, comes the announcement of plans completed yesterday by the Sands Point Y. C. for a unique power and sailing race on July 31.
Charles E. Hoyt, president of the South Norwalk Trust Company, died here today at his home, 44 Bayview Avenue, at the age of 69. His widow is the former Mary D. Smith.

THE story of "The Maldng of a Hero" is largely the story of Nicholas Ostrovlki himself, a blind, paralyzed and self-taught Soviet writer who died quite recently. To his countrymen Ostrovski was a hero, a living example of the ardor and the pertinacity they felt to be peculiarly their own.
A well-landscaped estate of sixteen acres with a large residence at Warwick, Orange County, formerly owned by J. J. Graeber, has been purchased by Arthur S. Lyon through W. C. Fuller, Warwick broker.

THE world of Hollywood Is a topsyturvy and restless microcosm, always dissatisfied with itself. Chaplin, the clown, wants to play large, tragic roles; Leslie Howard, Romeo and Hamlet, wants to be a comedian, and Max Reinhardt--most grandiose and most spectacular of modern
The Bay Head Yacht Club managers have planned a heavy weekly schedule for members with Tuesday a luncheon and bridge, Wednesday afternoon catboat races, Wednesday night bridge tournaments,

Bad manners more than any other factor are the cause of mounting automobile accident tolls in the United States, believes Dr. Frederic P. Woellner, Associate Professor of Education at the University of California at Los Angeles and member of a State accident prevention board, says the university.

The marriage of Miss Lucy M. Wheeler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Wheeler of this city, to Franklin Beardsley, son of Mrs. Charles W. Beardsley of Albany and the late Mr. Beardsley, took place here this afternoon in the chapel of St. Paul's Church.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today adoption of Form C-3 for registration under the Act of 1933 of American certificates issued against securities of foreign issuers deposited with an American depositary, as well as for registration of the foreign securities so deposited.

NEW YORK to London in twenty-four hours for passengers by air! It does not seem possible, of course, and yet the Pan American plane which flew the Atlantic early last week made the distance in about that flying time,

Miss Carrie Smith of this town has just begun her sixty-sixth consecutive year of uninterrupted employment at the Estey Organ plant here. When other employes learned the fact, they staged an informal celebration in the room where she works.

NEW PLAYS IN THE SUMMER THEATRES-With all but a few of the rural playhouses now open for business, the usual number are going in for the experimentation which is one of Summer's attributes. For these, the new bills of the week, the openings are tomorrow unless noted. A DOLL'S HOUSE, Thornton Wilder's new adaptation of Ibsen's play, with Ruth Gordon in the cast-Opera House, Central City, Col. (Saturday).

An effort to invoke interstate motor vehicle reciprocity agreements in labor complaints was made yesterday by Governor Har??ld G. Hoffman of New Jersey, directed at the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and particularly at the union's Local 807 of New York City.

Chinese are preparing for war with Japan because of the seriousness of the fighting between Chinese and Japanese troops near Peiping. High Chinese Government officials here doubt the possibility of localizing the conflict.

Governor Frank Murphy, rendering an accounting of his first six months in office before a Democratic State gathering at Mackinac Island tonight, declared that under his administration's guidance "there has been effected the most notable contribution to the cause of social justice ever accomplished by a government of Michigan."
SINCE Prince Fumimaro Konoye took the helm in Japan a month ago he has succeeded in restoring an atmosphere of reasonableness to the government and to the political situation.

George A. Gordon of New York, a career diplomat who has been Minister to Haiti, was appointed today to be Minister to The Netherlands, succeeding Grenville T. Emmet, who was recently named Minister to Austria.

Many suburban cellars that lie cold and damp and neglected during the Winter months come to life during the Summer, when they are made into grown-up playrooms. When it is almost too hot to move fast out-of-doors, a good part of the family entertainment goes on in cool retreats below ground.

BAR HARBOR, Maine.--The remainder of the month will be active on Mount Desert Island. The Kebo Valley Golf Club will hold the initial putting tournament of the season tomorrow. These weekly contests, attended by members of the Summer colony from most of the principal cities of the country, will consist of medal play, eighteen holes, and will continue each Monday afternoon until Sept. 13.

The first long shot of the Del Mar meeting romped home today when Miss Kathleen Hoffman's Crystal Speed won the second race to pay $64.40, $21.80 and $10 for $2 mutuel tickets. Crystal Speed covered the six furlongs in 1:14.

The trend of business was spotty last week, taking the country as a whole, due to seasonal influences and weather conditions. In some sections reports indicated that the high temperatures had a stimulating effect on trade, while in other areas the heat served to check the movement of merchandise.

No tourist with an interest in the dance can conceivably pass through San Francisco just as if it were any other city, look at what local performances it chances to afford at the moment, and let it go at that.
TWO items which, when related, bear a message to motorists and highway officials appear in the current bulletin of the Highway Research Board which the National Research Council has made public.

Miss Frances K. Durham, daughter of Mrs. Sara K. Durham of Orange, and William H. Schumann Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Schumann of East Orange, were married here today at the bride's former home, now the residence of her brother-in-law and sister, Mr.

PARIS. THE music season of Paris is being considerably prolonged by numerous concerts given under the auspices of the Paris Exposition. Added to these is the series of thirteen chamber music. and orchestral concerts, given by the International Society for Contemporary Music.

Although England, Germany and France have engaged in very comprehensive research programs since the World War, they have not as yet surpassed the application of science to industry as practiced in American laboratories, a group of American industrialists, who returned here last week from a six weeks' tour of foreign laboratories, agreed yesterday.

Members of the Westport Inn colonly will have guests aboard their yachts this week-end for cruises to points of historic interest along the Lake Champlain shores. Lewis Howland Brown of Manhasset and New York, who has taken the Elms cottage at the inn, will entertain aboard his yacht Sea Miss.

Eight years ago, one Robert Tyre Jones of Atlanta, then at the peak of his career, and one Senor Al Espinosa, a professional hailing from Chicago, tied for the United States open championship crown with 72hole totals of 294 over the west course of the Winged Foot Golf Club's great layout.
The First National Bank of Jersey City has been appointed agent of the voting trustees of the General Frigid Transportation Corporation common stock.

With the selection by the Verbank (N. Y.) Hunting and Fishing Club of Nov. 6 and 7 as the dates for its annual Fall meeting the schedule of Autumn field trials for pointers and setters in this section is about complete.
Weaver and De Shong vs. Gomez and Hadley. Boston at Philadelphia (2)-Wilson and McKain vs. Smith and Thomas. Cleveland at Detroit-Feller vs. Poffenberger.

The survival of daisy Medina, 38 years old, of 1,515 Madison Avenue, after her temperature .had reached 109 degrees at 7 P. M. Friday and had remained thereabouts for several hours, was hailed by Bellevue Hospital physicians last night as "an unprecedented occurrence."

There can no longer be doubt that the arrest of Protestant pastors and Catholic priests on political charges is not increasing the popularity of the National Socialist regime with the great mass of the German people and has created a minority of several millions that harbors a secret desire to be rid of that regime.

A letter defending the payment of a $350,000 farm benefit check to a large Southern farm corporation said today that the firm might have made $500,000 more if it had not cut acreage in the crop-reduction program.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his letter to THE TIMES of June 27, Guy Irving Burch admits interest in my "criticism" of the American Medical Association for its indirect, obscurely and cautiously worded recognition of positive contraception in medical practice. Mine is not a "criticism";
Supreme Court Justice Julius B. Perskie today authorized Asbury Park, N. J., to seek the approval of its creditors for its amended refunding plan, designed to refinance its $10,735,000 bonded debt.

The entrance to the twelve-story apartment building at 375 Park Avenue, covering the easterly block front between Fifty-second and Fifty-third Streets, is undergoing extensive renovations, chief of which is the creation of an island flower shop entirely surrounded by plate glass panels between large columns.

Miss Helene Rains, 12 - year - old member of the Women's Swimming Association and present holder of the junior national medley championship, added further to her laurels today in the title competition held over the fifty-five yard course in Zach's Bay at Jones Beach State Park.

AARON-Edward I., beloved husband of Amelia, father of Doris Fulton, Louis J., Marjorie Fruhling and Arthur; devoted son of Sarah. Services at Walter B. Cooke, Inc., Funeral Home, 117 West 72d. Sunday, 8 P. M. Funeral Monday, 2 P. M. Cremation at Ferncliff.

LENOX, Mass. - Most of the Berkshire garden clubs are cooperating with the Lenox Horticultural Society in support of the annual flower show at the Town Hall on Thursday and Friday. The Lenox Garden Club is to be in charge of decorative arrangements. There are 107 competitive classes open to all and twenty-two classes for amateurs, besides several noncompetitive classes. The Horticultural Society Bronze Medal will be awarded to any outstanding exhibit.

Miss Sanchia Doorly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Doorly of Weyford Court, was married here this morning in the Cathedral of the Incarnation to Charles J. Lundgren Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles J. Lundgren, also of Garden City.
The 150th anniversary of the passage of the famous ordinance of 1787 will be observed Tuesday with a special program on the steps of the Sub-Treasury Building, Broad and Wall Streets.

They had much talk of "the good old days" last Wednesday night in the home of Philip Tischler, a retail clothing merchant, at 2,460 Grand Avenue, the Bronx, where Mr. Tischler and a Spanish-American War buddy, Victor Jacobs, a private detective, of 2,722 Fourteenth Avenue, South, Jacksonville, Fla., had a reunion for the first time in thirty-nine years.

A recent survey by the public relations committee of the Federal Savings and Loan Associations in the Philadelphia district reveals an increasing demand for five or sixroom homes under the $4,000 price, particularly in the $3,000 field.

George Zengaras, popular GreekAmerican welterweight from the East Side, will meet Reuben Breese of Chicago in the star eight-round bout at the Coney Island Velodrome on Tuesday night. Breese, who will be making his first appearance in a local ring, holds victories over Davey Day and Joe Ghnouly.
STANLEY S. HOLMES VILLAGE, the $1,550,000 PWA slum-clearance project in Atlantic City, N. J., is now fully occupied, largely by former slum dwellers, officials of the PWA announced yesterday.

In her last race under the New York Yacht Club before she engages in the America's Cup match, Harold S. Vanderbilt's defender Ranger today again showed both her frontrunning and seemingly everlasting qualities.

New York City's fruit markets are teeming with activity. Dealers--ranging from those who operate air-cooled stores to those who peddle fruits from rolling carotinas in the hot streets--report a Summer boom in business.

Hearings on merchant marine labor problems are to begin this week in ten of the country's important ports. In an able article in the United States Naval Institute Proceedings for May some of these problems are discussed by Lieutenant JOHN G. STAPLER, United States Army (Reserve).

An increase in the sale of homes and several new construction projects in Brooklyn are reported by brokers. In the Brookshire Homes development on Bedford Avenue and Avenue V in the Flatbush section fourteen houses were sold, according to Samuel Match, head of the firm of Match Brothers, builders.
Plans to spend nearly $500,000 to improve the Willard Hotel in Washington, D. C., were announced last week by the Willard family, the owners, through H. P. Somerville, managing director.

Lieut. Gen. Kiyoshi Kazuki left by military plane at 11 A. M. for an unstated destination, bearing orders from General Gen Sugiyama, Minister of War, who had been in consultation with his highest colleagues in the War Office since 2 A. M.
Village officials here were arranging today to float a $2,500 bond issue to pay for the Spanish-American War veterans' long-discussed memorial statue in Summerfield Park.

Learning accomplished under a promise of monetary reward is more efficient than learning for which no reward is promised, Dr. George Forlano, Teachers College psychologist, disclosed yesterday in making public his studies on rewards and punishments conducted in four elementary schools of this city.

Miss Sidney McGiffert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julian McGiffert of Easton. Pa., has chosen Aug. 14 as the date for her marriage to Dr. William Whyte Watt, son of Dr. and Mrs. H. A. Watt of Glen Ridge.

Another day of broiling sun brought death to twenty-five persons in the metropolitan area yesterday and raised the nation-wide toll to nearly 150 deaths for the four successive days of an intense heat reaching from California to the Atlantic Coast.

A new sign hangs out on the road in front of Proctor Academy, Andover, N. H., this Summer. It proclaims the "Proctor Forge" and invites passers-by to purchase its products. Though the school is closed, one student puts In an eight-hour day making and selling wriought-irnn articles.

The marriage of Miss Candace Alig, daughter of Mrs. Otto Fidele Alig of this city and Des Moines, Iowa, and the late Mr. Alig, to Kelvin Cox Vanderlip, son of Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip of New York and Scarborough-on-Hudson, N. Y. and the late Mr. Vanderlip,

KRANTZ - KLEIN - Mr. Arthur Klein of 123 West 93d St. announces the marriage of his sister, Miriam, to Mr. Edward Krantz, on July 8, 1937. LANGRIDGE-HALL--Mrs. William Hall is happy to announce the marriage of her daughter, Felicie, to William Langridge Jr., July 4, at New Rochelle.

Miss Mary Johnston McCafferty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. McCafferty of Brooklyn, was married to Augustine Healy of New York yesterday morning in the Church of St. Rose of Lima in Brooklyn by the Rev. James Casey, who was also celebrant of the nuptial mass that followed.

John T. Underwood, typewriter manufacturer, who lived at 336 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, and who died last July 2, at his Summer home in Wianno, Mass., left cash bequests of $1,995,500 in his will filed yesterday in the office of Surrogate George A. Wingate, of Kings County.

Warner T. McGuinn, Negro Republican leader in Maryland for years and a well known lawyer who graduated in law at Yale, died today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Chauncey M. Harlee, wife of a physician in Philadelphia, with whom he had been visiting. His age was 74.

Miss Catherine Gremse, a Brooklyn school teacher, at exactly 9:41 yesterday morning had the distinction of being in the three millionth car which crossed the Henry Hudson Bridge, spanning the Bronx and Manhattan, it was announced by the Department of Parks.
Reporter-How did you enjoy your trip abroad? Cohan-Flifty-fifty. Reporter-What do you mean by fifty-fifty? Cohan--Saw fifty shows in fifty nights.
FICTION "A TROJAN ENDING." Laura Riding. (Random House.) August. "JANE OF LANTERN HILL." L. M. Montgomery. (Stokes.) August.

Father Divine's tired angels got back to New York at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, looking rather subdued after their two-day outing at the recently acquired "heaven" at Greenkill Park, near Kingston. They returned on the City of Keansburg, which docked at 132d Street, the same pier from which they had left on Thursday morning on the State of Delaware.

More than 300 leading contract bridge players of New England, together with a small but powerful contingent of players from the metropolitan area, are expected to attend the four-day session of the sixth annual Southern New
Captain Wallace Reed, veteran Canandiagua Lake steamboat pilot, believes that lake boats are coming back.

A bearish construction placed on the reports of the United States and Canadian Governments on the prospective wheat crop carried prices off 3 cents a bushel in North American markets during the early trading today, and for a time it looked as if they might duplicate the action of a year ago when quotations dropped 5 cents a bushel, the permissible limit.
Returning to New Zealand from Canton Island, to which it conveyed the New Zealand eclipse expedition, the sloop Wellington reports a strange British-American rivalry over the island.

Suspension of the Boston franchise was extended for one year by directors of the InternationalAmerican Hockey League at their Summer meeting today. The Boston team, formerly operated in the Canadian-American circuit by the National League Bruins as a farm team, was dropped last season by the parent club.

THAT happy insanity which marks Hollywood's semiprivate life is being turned to commercial use and the screen has become acutely aware of the charm of lunacy. "My Man Godfrey" convinced the town of the value of a deliberately disordered mind and this was followed by "Libeled Lady."

Rear Admiral Frank D. Berrien, U.S.N. (retired) and Mrs. Berrien of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Berrien, to James Ross Gillie, son of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Gillie of Douglaston, L. I.

Three hundred students have registered for the twentieth Summer session and seminars of the Smith College School for Social Work, which began Wednesday. Open only to graduates of approved colleges, the school is a highly specialized graduate school of psychiatric social work, which requires work in the field throughout two Winters and study at Smith during three Summer sessions.

Mrs. Sara Delano Roosevelt, mother of the United States President, sailed from here for Genoa tonight after visiting Naples and Pompeii. Mrs. Roosevelt, accompanied by her grandson John, is on a European vacation.

Loans and discounts of the fifteen largest banks in this city rose 6.2 per cent in the second quarter of this year and now stand 20.7 per cent above the level of a year ago, a compilation of their condition statements as of June 30 shows. Their combined loans and discounts on that date amounted to $4,361,733,000, against $4,107,047,000 on March 31, last, and $3,613,725,000 on June 30, 1936.
Stephen Paul, chief custodian of the House of Representatives, died yesterday of a heart attack at his residence in the Bellevue Hotel. His age was 52.

A case that reveals the legal obllgation of a landlord, who has retained some control over leased premises, to protect persons from injuries caused by the negligent opening of cellar doors, was decided recently by Justice James T. Hallinan in the Supreme Court, Queens County.

THIS is the time of year when Rangeland comes to town in the Western States. There's hardly a community from Prescott to Pocatello, from Salinas to Sheridan, that doesn't assume the colorful, swaggering atmosphere of a cow town of the old West.

The villages of Lungwangmiao and Tunghsinchuang were stormed and captured late last night by Japanese troops, according to a communique issued here by Japanese Army headquarters. The advance was made after a day of fighting with Chinese troops in violation of the truce that was to have ended clashes that began Wednesday.

To the Art Editors: THE true value of any object lies in our relation to it; not in the object itself, not in what we are, but in what we do to it, and in what it does to us. This seems true to me even from the spectator's standpoint.
Lon Warneke of the Cardinals went after his eleventh season victory today, but instead was charged with his fourth defeat as Cincinnati's Reds pummeled St. Louis for an 11-to-3 victory.

AT a time when some Berlin authorities seek to abolish the rhythmic stamp of the goose-step, a Leipzig professor has risen before a congress of health experts in Frankfort to denounce the whole gospel of what Rudyard Kipling's

James A. Farley, Democratic State and National Chairman, arrived here yesterday morning from Washington after an absence of a week and departed again in the afternoon for the West, where he will attend an Elks convention. Mr. Farley, it was learned, plans to away for about ten days.
Mrs. Robert McKim of Old Westbury won two of the four events at the special trotting matinee of the Nassau Driving Club at the Fair Grounds today.

Defying a scorching gun, the New Jersey-New YorkFiremen's Association went through with its annual parade this afternoon. At least fifty of the marchers collapsed from heat exhaustion and at least 1,000 others were forced to drop out of the procession long before it reached its destination.

Because the banks, which are at the same time chief customer and chief competitor, object to publicity, the business of collateral loans has grown to maturity in the dark. Today, after more than fifty years of steady development, it boasts an annual turnover of approximately $1,000,000,000, with a handful of brokers placing about a quarter of it.

Racing over an exceptionally calm course, S. N. Auerbach of Atlantic City captured the major speed boat honors on the opening day's program of the Maryland Yacht Club's annual star-spangled regatta today.
Pitcher Clint Brown not only played the part of rescuer for the White Sox today but also drove in the run which gave Chicago a 5-to-4 victory over the Browns in eleven innings.

THERE are 286 young women employed as hostesses and 105 men employed as stewards on American-operated airlines, according to the most recent reports from the lines to the Bureau of Air Commerce. Seven domestic airlines employ hostesses.

Miss Mary Dayton Glidden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Gallatin Glidden of Elizabeth, became the bride of Arthur Wellesley Patterson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wellesley Patterson Jr. of Roselle, in St. Luke's Episcopal Church here this afternoon. The ceremony was performed by Dr. Lyttleton E. Hubard, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church in Elizabeth, who was assisted by the Rev. Dr. Clarence S. Wood, rector of St. Luke's.

TWENTY-FIVE new world and international time and distance records have been achieved in a ten-day run on the track of the Montlhery autodrome, near Paris, by a team of four French women, driving a Ford V-8 with standard 85-horsepower engine.
Dominic Orgo, who had been in the florist business here for more than thirty years, and was active in civic and political affairs, died yesterday at the age of 67.

DAY after tomorrow up in Goshen a squadron of longlegged horses will be wheeling and circling around a starting line. They are manoeuvring for portion and a flying getaway exactly as racing yachts jibe and took before the starting gun.
New superintendents of the schools took office here and in New Rochelle this week and undertook to devise methods of reducing educational expenses.

Investigation shows that accounts of a famine which is supposed to be ravaging this populous province of China are largely exaggerated. While direst poverty exists, the situation is not much worse than it has been for years.
For twenty years Palestine, under British rule, has been a trouble spot. The reason is rivalry between the Arabs and the Jews, which has led to disorders.
Pravda, organ of the Communist party, declared today that Japan took advantage of Russia's sale of the Chinese Eastern Railway in 1935 to establish an espionage system in the Soviet Far East.

ATINTORETTO exhibition has been opened in Venice, to remain current for six months. The pictures have been left in the churches, schools and palaces where they belong, but are supplemented by loans, some of which come from Vienna, Berlin, Brussels and Budapest.

BASEBALL New York Yankees vs. Washington Senators, double-header, at Yankee Stadium, 161st Street and River Avenue, Bronx, 2 P.M. Brooklyn Dodgers vs. New York Giants, double-header, at Ebbets Field, Bedford Avenue and Sullivan Place, Brooklyn, 2:05 P. M.
Intercesion of Governor Murphy was sought tonight to settle a cleaning and dyeing strike and avert another walkout threatening to tie up much of Michigan's trucking facilities.
THIS book shares at least one quality with the works of T Mark Twain and of Henry Fielding. It leaves the reader with the conviction that if he met the author he would have a very good time.
Favorites ran true to form today in mixed foursome competition staged as a tune-up for the

WITHIN a space of about two years the Representative from the Twentieth Texas district has made himself a familiar figure on Capitol Hill, in Washington, and the name of Maverick must mean something to most newspaper readers.

For more than a year America's organized labor has been split into two warring camps, with the aggressive almost entirely on the side of the young and growing Committee for Industrial Organization. The split was emphasized last week when William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, attacked C. I. O. and declared that it had lost its steel strike.

The Rev. R. Anderson Jardine, the vicar who officiated at the wedding of the Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Wallis Warfield, delivered his first public lecture tonight at the Municipal Auditorium before an aurience of fewer than 150 persons.

The opinion that there is no real reason why investment banking houses could not, in some degree, be in connection with American investment trusts, as they are in England, was expressed by Floyd B. Odium, president of the Atlas Corporation, during hearings on investment trusts by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A sharp increase in sales of gray goods resulted last week in a volume on print cloths and related fabrics estimated at from 35,000,000 to 40,000,000 yards, which was the largest booked for any week in more than two months. Prices advanced from 1/4 to 1/2 cent a yard on the week.

THE "ether" over the Pacific has been one of the most active spots in the realm of radio during the past week with "Earhart" and her call letterm "KHAQQ" sputtering on the tongues of wireless. The hope of rescue lurked in the air as radio tossed its invisible life-lines out acrosss the Pacifio.

ARONSON--SHAMPAN-Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Shampan of 2 East 86th St. announce the betrothal of their daughter, Audrey, to Mr. Bernard Aronson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Aronson of 1,016 5th Ave. and 92 Ocean Ave., Deal, N. J.

The town of Harrison had an overabundance of Councilmen today and nobody-not even Conrad H. Sullivan, Town Attorney - knew what to do about it. Laws of the State provide that the town should have only four Councilmen, but there are five sitting on the board and each seems to have the proper credentials.

Seymour Alexander and Morton Alexander of the Trinity Club gained the semi-final round of the New York State one-wall handball doubles championship at the Farragut Pool in Brooklyn yesterday. They defeated Alexander Novick and Murray Shapiro of the Trinity Club, 21-9, 21-13.

Lieut. Col. Allan L. Reagan, retired New York National Guard officer, died tonight at his home here after an illness that had its inception when he suffered a stroke during a military review in December, 1934. His age was 73.

Year after year we have read as a penance rather than with any expectation of pleasure summaries in English newspapers of the remarks made by headmasters, old boys and visiting celebrities at the annual Speech Day of public schools.

Plans for the thirtieth annual Flower Show under the joint auspices of the Garden Club of Southampton and the Southampton Horticultural Society will be furthered this week by various meetings of the executive committee and the subcommittees as well as by the meeting of the entire Garden Club ot Southampton Wednesday morning.

Miss Eloise Leonie Tatroe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Marshall Tatroe of Old Greenwich, was married to Robert Emmett Hone, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Hone of Greenwich, in St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church, Greenwich, this morning. The Rev. Joseph A. Ganley officiated. A reception followed at the Pickwick Arms Hotel.

A board of officers is appointed to meet at Buffalo, N. Y., at the call of the president thereof, to examine such persons as may be properly ordered before it to determine their fitness for appointment or certificates of capacity in the Officers Reserve Corps.

Still imbued with the carnival spirit although their Washington Jamboree now is a thing of the past, some 7,000 Boy Scouts en route to their homes descended upon New York yesterday and, casually brushing aside the heat, went through a full day of sightseeing.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were fewer than in the preceding week, due to the Independence Day holiday. The announcements did not embrace any large refundings and were principally for small lots of bonds called to satisfy sinking fund requirements.
"Individual liberties seem to have flown" from the world, Frederick H. Stinchfield of Minneapolis, president of the American Bar Association, told the Indiana Bar Association here today.
Gold plaques for outstanding journalistic achievements in the last year were presented at the annual dinner of the National Headliners Club in the Hotel Traymore here tonight.
The Third National Skeet Championship tournament will be held at the Blue Rock Gun Club, Detroit, from Aug. 31 to Sept. 4. A field of 400 shooters is expected to take part in the competition.

The Mufti of Jerusalem, Haj Amin el Husseini, is meeting with early success in his efforts to arouse the Moslems of the world against the proposed partition of Palestine. The first reply came tonight from the government of Iraq. It reads:

The Morris White Properties Corporation of 362 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan, filed yesterday in the Federal Court, in Brooklyn, an application for reorganization under Section 77-b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

SHAKESPEARE'S prediction through Puck in a "Midsummer Night's Dream" that he would put a girdle around the earth in forty minutes becomes a fact tomorrow, when the first of a new series of Shakespearean plays will be flashed around the globe at the speed of light.

On July 18, 1936, a militarist revolt, which began in Spanish Morocco, spread to Spain. Reviews of the first year of the subsequent civil war follow, one by a correspondent stationed with the government forces and one by a correspondent with the Insurgents.

THE eighteenth century talked so much about reason that one might suppose it was a great novelty. And it probably was, when reason appeared in such extraordinary and improbable disguises. One result was Napoleon.

J. D. Wooster Lambert of this city and St. Louis, manufacturer of aeronautical supplies and chemical compounds, married Mrs. Mary Brown Turner of 21 East Ninetieth Street yesterday in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building.
Mrs. Otis A. Glazebrook and Miss Lucy Glazebrook of Staten Island have as guests at Camp Black Hawk on Lake Placid Mrs. Paris Scott Russell and Miss Barbara Collins of Staten Island.
Jack Rutherfurd of Port Washington, L. I., and Palm Beach, Fla., will try for a new gold cup one-mile speed record next week in the Havre de Grace Yacht Club's eighth annual regatta.

At least one woman in Vermont is obliged to keep internationally minded, for she lives in two countries at the same time. Mrs. J. C. Norris of Derby Line, Vt., and Rock Island, Que., seems to manage this unique situation without any considerable wear and tear on her nerves.

THE LITTLE BOY AND HIS HOUBBSE. By Stephen Bone and Mary Adshead. Test and colored pictures. Philadelphia: John C. Winston Company. $2. Syracuse evened its series with Jersey City at two apiece today in taking the fourth game, 6 to 4. The Chiefs batted Johnny Meketi out of the box in the fourth and picked up single counters at the expense of Mike Radon and Tom Delacruz in the sixth and ninth, respectively.

TRAVEL to Hawaii is reaching new highs. Formerly largely confined to Winter months, the tropical tour now attracts a year-round vacation crowd. Those demanding quick service between California and the Pacific islands use the Yankee Clipper.

TWO prerequisites are necessary to produce a non-fiction book that is destined to have more than passing interest-knowledge of the subject and ability to handle that subject in a manner that will make it interesting to others.
DURING the Federal Government's fiscal year which ended June 30 the Philatelic Agency at Washington sold $1,945,000 worth of unused postage stamps to collectors and dealers throughout the world.

After eight days without wind, the championship of the national model yacht races was awarded to Dr. Ernest P. Phillips today for his model yacht Dolphin, which was ahead last Tuesday, the only day when there was a wind for the finals.

THOSE Americans who pour into the Soviet Union this Summer will do well for themselves if they take a day Off from visiting factories and museums and go to the race track. There they will get a chance to see the Russian workers out for a good

Earnings of oil companies in the United States for the second quarter of 1937 are not likely to show a gain corresponding to that recorded in the first quarter over last year, according to World Petoleum, because of higher operating costs, including wage increases, which went into effect in the second quarter.
President Roosevelt signed today the Congressional Joint Resolution appropriating $3,000,000 for Federal participation in the New York World's Fair.
After fifty years of picking a baconand-beans existence out of the Lemhi County hills, two 75-year-old miners, Joe M. Denton and Benson Evans, struck rich silver ore.

The trustees of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for approval of a $28.172,650 issue of "tenyear secured 3 1/2 per cent certificates," which was ordered by a Federal court in Illinois in connection with the railroad's reorganization.

A court at Middelburg has decided that valuables from Bilbao, iSpain, aboard the British freighter Thorpehall, detained at Flushing, must be sequestrated in accordance with a request by several Spanish claimants to legitimate ownership.

Just because the Cafe de la Paix was closed this week does not mean either that France is on the verge of revolution or that the forty-hour week has definitely failed, although a good many persons, both American visitors and Frenchmen, are inclined to view the matter that way.

The Presbyterian Webb Memorial Chapel was the scene of the wedding today of Miss Beatrice Berry of this place to Andrew S. Hegeman of Glen Ridge. The Rev. John W. Parke, Presbyterian pastor, officiated.

The final portion of the old Kouwenhoven family estate in Astoria, Queens Borough, is being laid out in building lots for the erection of another large home group by N. K. Winston Co. That firm purchased the tract and additional acres about a year ago for development with medium-priced homes.

Miss Mary Hustace Hubbard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Thomas Hubbard Jr. of New York and this place, was married to Daniel Ellis Woodhull Jr. this afternoon in St. Ann's-by-the-Sea here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. George Clair St. John,

St. Mary's Episcopal Church in South Manchester, of which her father is rector, was the scene this afternoon of the marriage of Miss Caroline Neill, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. James Stuart Neill, to David Benton Crittenden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Eaton Crittenden of New Haven.
Public opinion has turned sharply against violent and coercive strike tactics, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States asserted today in its weekly review of business conditions.
The first product to be marketed by the Up-State New York Pharmaceutical Council to independent retailers is a razor blade called Pharma Tru-Temper, it was made Known here yesterday.
Official announcement was made by the State Department Loday that 16inch guns would be mounted on the two new 35,000-ton battleships that are to be laid down this year.

THE WOMEN: A British banker, Miss Gordon Holmes, was in New York last week to attend meetings of business and professional women. She told American women that they are "the only women in the world who are taken seriously." She added:

United States SENIOR MOTION PICTURE DIRECTOR, $3,800 A YEAR; MOTION PICTURE SPECIALIST, $3,200 A YEAR; JUNIOR MOTION PICTURE SPECIALIST, $2,600 A YEAR--Forest Service, Department of Agriculture, and Social Security Board.
