Former King Alfonso of Spain and former Queen Victoria appeared together formally tonight for the first time in six years, stimulating reports they were contemplating a reconciliation.

The case of the Biddle Purchasing Company of New York, the first proceeding under the one-year-old Robinson-Patman Act to reach the Federal Trade Commission for a decision. was argued before the commission today.

ALL out for-the World Labor Athletic Carnival at Randalls Island today! The label on the gathering is a bit bulky and seems to take in too much territory. World? All the competitors will be citizens of the world but most of them are residents of one country, the one so often referred to in sonorous tones in the halls of Congress as "these United States."

Invitations have been issued by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. H. Moody of a Westfield for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Barbara Moody, to John Baxter Weller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thoroas J. Weller of Chester, Pa.
Miss Mildred Elizabeth Fischer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Fischer of 108 Seneca Avenue, Bronxville, was married yesterday afternoon to Lieut.

Franklin Delano Roosevelt Jr. and his bride, the former Ethel du Pont, sailed on the liner Empress of Britain this afternoon for a trip to Europe. They boarded the vessel fifteen minutes before sailing time to shouts of a throng of spectators who called out "good luck."
Conceding that the current season has been one of the poorest in many years for linen suits, importers and others in the field hope to make a "comeback" in 1938, according to comment here yesterday.

There were several events on Independence Day in which American society in London figured. Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ogden celebrated the anniversary with a luncheon at Claridges, among their guests being Lord and Lady Bethel, Major Gen.

Shareholders of the Transamerica Corporation, at a special meeting held yesterday in Wilmington, Del., approved the distribution of about 58 per cent of the stock of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association and the reclassification of the corporation's 50,000,000 shares of no-par value, both issued and unissued, into 25,000,000 shares of the par value of $2 each.

On Friday the Terry-go-round broke down with a most awesome sound, but yesterday that greatest of baseball mechanics, King Carl Hubbell, put it all together again, while 7,436 Flatbush fans watched in mingled admiration and chagrin.

The following Foreign Service changes since July 2 were announced today by the State Department: Donald D. Edgar of Metuchen, N. J., Third Secretary of Legation at Cuidad Trujillo, Dominican Republic, assigned to Geneva as Consul.

NICE, France. RIVIERA swimming enthusiasts have discovered a new sport combining hunting, fishing, swimming, shooting and diving. By means of an ingenious underwater spring-loaded fishing gun they are making hauls of large edible fish to the amazement of expert fishermen who spend days on end with rod and net without catching anything larger than a sardine.

Settlement of a strike called on June 30 by the New York district council of the United Shoe Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, against La Valle, Inc., shoe manufacturers, of 632 Broadway, was announced yesterday by Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews.
Refinancing of mortgages totaling more than $10,000,000 for the Jacob Ruppert Realty Corporation was announced yesterday by the Wood, Dolson Company, agents in the deals.

WITH Summer in Washington and members of Congress reported to becoming more restless in anticipation of adjournment, indications are that no more radio legislation will be enacted at this session, according to radio observers in the national capital.

Miss Phyllis Eleanor Matthews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry V. Matthews of this city, was married this afternoon to Milton Harvey Clark, second lieutenant U.S.A. The ceremony was performed at the First Presbyterian Church here by the Rev. Dr. George H. Talbott, pastor of the church.

Strikes and lockouts in Canada showed a big increase in June compared with June, 1936, but were lower than in May, 1937. The Department of Labor issued a report tonight showing the number of strikes and lockouts in June

Mr. and Mrs. David Ferguson were dinner hosts this evening for their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Pettit of Princeton, N. J. Others present included Mr. and Mrs. R. L. Herron of Brooklyn and Mr. and Mrs. Harry Wykes Whitehall of Garden City.

Western New York rolled back the curtain of the years'today to commemorate two picturesque events of its early history. At Sea Breeze, the tread of marching feet recalled the invasion of the Irondequoit country by the Marquis Denonville and his French punitive expedition against the warlike Iroquois, 250 years ago.

Rubber is the latest material to be used for filling cavities in trees. Six grand old trees at Monticello, Jefferson's residence in Virginia, have recently been filled with rubber to insure their preservation for posterity.

The show windows of New York's large stores have long been stages on which the shifting drama of fashion is mirrored. The actors, or rather puppets, in that drama have been the manikin dummies, whose careers are now entering upon a new phase.

The President's Senate leaders, having convinced him that his original Federal Judiciary Bill could not pass, introduced a substitute this week with his approval-the Logan-Hatch compromise. Immediately there began in the Senate, not the "great national debate" which had been forecast, but a fusillade of "dead cats" and personalities between the Democratic supporters and opponents of enlargement of the Supreme Court.

The Aluminum Company of America was accused today of "interference and failure to bargain collectively" in connection with labor troubles at its Alcoa plant. Charles N. Feidelson, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, said the charge was signed by Fred Wetmore, president of the Aluminun Workers Union at the Tennessee plant, with whom he conferred.

The international chess masters tournament, in progress since June 16, was formally concluded today with a luncheon at the Kurhaus and the distribution of prizes, of which there were seven. Hans Kmoch of Vienna, the tournament director,

Dean John T. Madden announced yesterday the names of 156 students in the day division of New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance who had attained the honor roll for the second semester of the 1936-1937 academic year.

DR. KIRSOPP LAKE, Professor of History in Harvard University, and his wife, Dr. Silva Lake, instructor in biblical literature in Brown University. collaborate here in a book which gives the general basis of the modern study of the New Testament as it may be of interest and value to several different groups of students.

The San Jose polo team left for New York on the Munson liner Western World this afternoon to play in the United States. The team includes three of the players who won the Olympic championship -- Luis J. Duggan,

Miss. Jean E. May, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse May, was married to Glen A. Milliren, son of Mrs. ?? Alvin Milliren of Kane, Pa., this afternoon at the May residence have. The Rev. Charles R. Edgington, pastor of the Methodist Episcopal Church, performed the ceremony. The bride was given in marriage by her father.

Lieutenant Elmer L. Johansen, 41-year-old Reserve officer on active duty for the last ten years at the Great Lakes Naval Training Station's aviation reserve base at Glenview, was killed today in a plane crash at Techny, 3 miles northeast of the base.

Swathed in icepanks, for an operation, William H. Leinhardt, 31 years old, a Cincinnati policeman, completed a 2,000-mile airplane dash to a Cincinnati hospital late today to undergo an emergency operation for acute appendicitis.

A large waterfront plot at Lake Copake, near Copake, Columbia County, N. Y., has been purchased by Jacob Berman, Bronx realty operator. He is having plans prepared for the erection of a Summer residence. J. Edward Breuer acted as broker in the sale.

By the completion this week of experimental commercial flights across the Atlantic by Pan American Airways and Imperial Airways and the inauguration of an air mail service from Edmonton to White Horse in the Yukon, Canada has been brought many strides nearer the

Mad Money, from the Lemar Stock Farm Stable, at Lexington, Ky., qualified impressively for the $55,000 Arlington Futurity by winning the $4,000 Hyde Park Stakes before 20,000 sweltering spectators at Arlington Park today.

The award of contracts for the construction of three new ships for the Holland America Line was announced here yesterday. The line now has five ships under construction, the largest of which is the 33,000-ton liner Nieuw Amsterdam, which will enter the transatlantic service next May.
Pickets surrounded the office of The Decatur Heral Review tonight after a strike at 8 P. M. by editorial department employes who are members of the American Newspaper Guild.

The largest and finest collection of pictures, Bibles and other personal objects pertaining to the life of Dwight L. Moody is now on display here for the 10,000 visitors who have begun to arrive for the eight religious conferences to be held here this Summer, the centenary year of the birth of the founder of the Northfield Schools.

The recent shift of the former British Protectorate of Aden to the status of colony, turns attention to this small crescent of land on the tilted coast of Southwest Arabia, which, according to Kipling, looks to the soldiers homeward bound from India "like a barrick-stove that's not been lit for years and years.

Stench bombs were thrown and there was a brisk free-for-all fight between strike leaders and police outside Fouquet's Cafe in the Champs Elysees this evening, but service inside the cafe and even on the sidewalk continues.

TIJUANA, Mexico. HOLLYWOOD'S streets were deserted when we headed southward, down the coast, for a week-end in Old Mexico. The mockers were just warming up in greeting to the hot sun, but the streets were still cool.

Opening of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company plant in East Chicago under protection of the National Guard was predicted today when Governor M. Clifford Townsend of Indiana conferred with Elmer Straub, his adjutant general.

Spain and how new taxes will affeet the French working classes are the uppermost issues in the French Socialist Congress, which met here today. Underneath all discussion of these problems is the realization that after one year in power the Socialists have been compelled again to take second place to the Radical Socialists in the Popular Front.
President McAfee tonight welcomed the delegates to the Summer Institute for Social Progress at Wellesley College, which began a two-week conference.

While affairs in Western Europe, especially those touching Spain, have been going badly recently from a Soviet standpoint, Moscow is losing no opportunities to create good will in the countries bordering the Baltic Sea in order to checkmate German moves to make it a "Nazi Mediterranean."

The Athletics lost both ends of a double-header with the Red Sox today. The scores were 9-2 and 5-2, the second game going eleven innings. Boston pounded four homers in the opener behind the winning pitching of Lefty Grove,. who quit after five innings because of the heat.
HOLLYWOOD is teaching English to Latin America and Latin Americans are learning the lesson, whether they like it or not. But they seem to like it.

Small durable homes built on a large scale on cheap suburban land offer the best hope of solving the housing problem for families of low income, and the possibilities in this field provide a challenge to capital and labor and a possible method of taking up the slack in employment for many years to come.

Melio Bettina, 180, of Beacon, N. Y., knocked out Jimmy Wendes, 184, of New Bedford, Mass., tonight in the fifth round of their scheduled eight-round feature contest on a boxing card witnessed by an estimated 2,500 persons.
In Section 10 of today's TIMES the brief stories of those who were the Hundred Neediest six months ago are told in the comparative conditions of Then and Now.

Rallying with a style of attack that bewildered her opponent, Miss Millicent Hirsh of New York today won the Philadelphia and district women's grass court tennis singles by dethroning Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, Texas, in the final round at the Germantown C. C., 3-6, 6-2, 6-4.

The marriage of Miss Doris Eleanor Heydorn, niece of Mr. and Mrs. Luther T. Yeomans of this city, to Merrill Green Forrest. son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Forrest of East Orange, took place this evening in Kilburn Memorial Church, Newark.

While stocks of staples will show average increases of anywhere from 20 to'30 per cent as compared with a year ago, the semi-annual inventories being taken this month by retailers will reveal a material reduction in the size of stocks from their May and early June peaks, it was learned here yesterday.
Mrs. D. Crawford Clark of New York, who is leaving next week for Lake Champlain, entertained with a luncheon at her home, Greencourt, on Tuesday.

Fortythree Americans and several refugees of other nationalities were evacuated from Santander, Spain, today by the United States destroyer Kane, which sailed for St. Jeande-Luz, France, according to a report to the State Department from the destroyer.

THE plaudits and pageantry denied them in life are being bestowed upon the members of the first English colony in America here with the initial performances of Paul Green's pageantdrama "The Lost Colony," offered in connection with the 350th anniversary celebration of the first English settlement in America.

Driven by his owner, Gene Carpenter of this city, Hollyrood Perry, fast trotter making his local debut of the season, easily conquered Cynara in two straight heats for the outstanding performance of the regular Weequahic Park matinee today.
Business generally was on a small scale in the foreign exchange market here today and fluctuations were confined within narrow limits.

Burlesque and the strip tease became a thing of the past yesterday when the burlesque impresarios, whose theatres have been dark in recent weeks by city dictum, agreed to scrap the traditional routine and produce in its stead "variety revues."

Twenty-five mortgage issues were entirely liquidated in the month of June by the Mortgage Commission of the State of New York. They included the payment of both principal and interest to the various holders.

Doctors at Grasslands Hospital tonight worked to save the life of Dr. Alfred H. Stiebeling, 71, of 22 North Washington Avenue, Hartsdale, N. Y., who was found unconscious at 8 A. M. on the grave of a granddaughter, Lucia Wahle, in Kensico Cemetery.

Members of Ottawa's La Salle Hockey Club took a long lead tonight in Lake Placid's fourth annual Summer title series. With some 700 topcoated men and blanket-bundled women looking on, the La Salle sextet rolled up an 8-to-2 victory over the Volants of Hull, Ont., in the first of the two total-goal series games.

New York motor boat moguls heard yesterday that time trials are impending in England for Sir Malcolm Campbell's new single-step hydroplane Bluebird, which will, of course, be in the nature of unofficial and non-competitive attacks on Gar Wood's world straightaway record of 124.86 miles an hour.

Plans for construction of a channel from the southern end of Longlac to Lake Superior to provide for the passage of 250,000 cords of pulpwood annually were announced yesterday by the Ontario Hydro Electric Power Commission.
Investigation of the sale to corporations of the Democratic Campaign Book of 1936, autographed by President Roosevelt, was demanded today by Representative Snell of New York, the Republican leader.
A SERIES of vocal and instrumental concerts, free to students attending the Columbia University Summer Session will be given at the Juilliard Summer School of Music during the next six weeks.

Miss Doris Ruth McCartney, daughter of George R. McCartney of this place and the late Mrs. McCartney, has selected July 24 for the date of her marriage to Roy D. Grimmer Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Roy D. Grimmer, also of Garden City.

THE year's biggest used car selling campaign is on throughout the automobile industry. Dealers, heading into the Summer with their "tradein" stocks at a peak, are putting on extra pressure to cut down these stocks to a minimum by the time the 1938 new-car season arrives in the early Fall.

For diversity of bloom, this is agreed to be the most interesting time of the season at New York Botanical Garden. Flowers by the thousands, in borders and special plantings, are displaying their prolifia midsummer bloom.
Professor Ra h D. Beetle, a native of New Bedford, Mass., and for thirty years a mathematics teacher at Dartmouth College, died of a heart attack at his Summer camp here last night. His age was 51.

The marriage of Miss Mildred E. Carberry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Carberry of Pelham Manor, to Maurice Pierson Roche, son of Mrs. John W. Roche of Pelham Heights and the late Mr. Roche, took place this morning in St. Catherine's Church here. The Rev. Arthur Campbell performed the ceremony and was the celebrant of the nuptial mass which followed.

THE so-called Second International Music Congress, held at Florence in connection with the Maggio Musicale, assembled from many countries a representative gathering of composers, musicologists and critics,

The current fight over the procedure for nonintervention operations regarding Spain serves to emphasize more sharply than ever the conflict of the political aspirations of Europe that are now focused on the Iberian Peninsula.

AS the curtain falls on the last act of the opening perIformance of a war play a man is killed in one of the boxes. A shot has been fired as a part of the action of the play, and the first theory is that in some manner a loaded cartridge has been substituted for the usual blank.

ANOTHER of the famous "duck stamps" is now available at United States postoffices. The 1937 migratory bird-hunting stamp is slightly larger than a special delivery stamp and pictures five scaups, or "broadbills," near a typical feeding ground.

Thus, twenty years ago in the midst of the World War, wrote the British Foreign Secretary, Lord Balfour, to the Zionist leader, Lord Rothschild. The Balfour declaration, as it is now known, was an Allied bid for the support of world Jewry at a time when Russia had collapsed, Italy had retreated from Caporetto and German U-boats threatened on the high seas.

The twelve model homes recently opened in Kew Gardens Hills, L. I. near the Union Turnpike express station of the municipal subway system, have been visited by a large number of home owners and prospective buyers, reports George Reich, sales director of the property.

WHEN a Hollywood expatriate croons the joys of a return to Broadway no one is apt to take him very seriously, because history shows that he himself does not. History can stand over in a corner this morning with its face to the wall and hear it said that Fredric March and Florence Eldridge really expect to be here next season in a play by Talbot Jennings.

Conferences between the Minister of Education and the president of Doshishi University at Kyoto on a student demonstration against institutional policies today brought dismissal of eight students, suspension of six, reprimands for twelve and forced resignations by several faculty members.

IF the number of visitors to our national parks increases this Year as it did last-and early reports indicate that it willmore than 7,000,000 Americans will make or renew an acquaintance with some of the grandest and wildest scenery in the world,

More and more, garden lovers are becoming interested in the art of flower arrangement. The Japanese have evolved their conception of this art over several centuries. We of the West can hardly expect to have its mysteries made entirely plain all at once by means of a few short lectures.

Superbly handled over the outside course by Miss Charlotte Ives Montgomery, the veteran bay gelding Prince Charming II today won the Albee Trophy for the Claredda Farm of Mr. and Mrs. E. V. Quinn of Shrewsbury, N. J.

out of every five residents of Los Angeles County is receiving relief funds, Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, was informed today by the county supervisor, John Anson Ford, and the county superintendent of charities, Rex Thomson.

ABRAMSON-Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Abramson of 371 Fort Washington Ave. announce the birth of a son, on July 9, 1937, at Sydenham Hospital. ALEXANDER--Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Alexander (nee Renah Eichtersheimer) an. nounce the birth of a daughter, Ronny Judith, July 7. 1937.
HEAT DEATHS ARNIN. FREIDO, 62, of 114-50 127th Street, Ozone Park. Queens. Found dead in bed by his wife, Madeline. BOTTS. FRANK, 48, of 633 Hudson Street. Manhattan. Died at his home.

As two subsidiaries of the Todd Shipyards Corporation in Brooklyn and Hoboken continued yesterday their effort to break a C. I. O. strike, the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America revised its picketing strategy and discontinued its concentration of 1,000 pickets outside the Brooklyn plant.

Miss Margaret Jewitt Chamberlain, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lynn Closser Chamberlain of Maplewood, has chosen July 31 as the date of her wedding to Brewster Huntington Gere, son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Gere of Syracuse, N. Y.

Bucky Walters of the Phillies shut out the Bees 4 to 0 today on four hits for his ninth victory of the season. Walters hurled hitless ball for five innings during which only one Boston player, Debs Garms, reached first base. The first batter, he received a walk.

While State police were searching the Hudson River Valley section for him, Frank Miller, 47-year-old exconvict, was married in Jones Point on July 4 with a sergeant of the Bear Mountain police acting as best man.

Wireless reports here today indicated that love of amateur photography had lured Radio Operator V. M. Costner of the Matson steamship Golden Bear to death in the volcanic cataclysm at Rabaul, New Britain, in the Bismarck Archipelago.
Industries in New York State face a serious shortage of skilled workers, according to the Apprentice Training Council reporting today to the State Board of Regents on the result of a survey.

Miss Marion Patience Killian, daughter of Mrs. Annetta Browne Killian of the Prince George, formerely of Baltimore, and the late Guy Hinkle Killian, was married to William Normandie, also of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Normandie of Kansas City, Mo., at noon yesterday in the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev. Orin A. Griesmyer.

The first issue of Freehold, a real estate magazine, has just been published by the National Association of Real Estate Boards. It is of pocket size and carries no advertising. Publication will be on the first and fifteenth of each month.

Frank F. Brooks, president of the First National Bank of Pittsburgh, in a communication today to the council of administration of the Pennsylvania Bankers Association, said that recently enacted labor legislation signed by Governor Earle would interfere seriously with the operations of Pennsylvania banking institutions.

An amateur boxing tournament, sponsored by the Police Athletic League of the Juvenile Aid Bureau of the New York Police Department, Unit 9, will be held at the Queensboro Arena, Long Island City, tomorrow night, beginning at 8 o'clock.

The United States Naval Academy team has been declared the national intercollegiate small bore rifle champion. The results of the six sectional tournaments held some time ago were recently made known and show the Navy marksmen leading the entire field of thirty-nine teams by a 25-point margin.

The marriage of Miss Carol Steffens Rand, daughter of Mrs. Walter Edwards Rand of 127 East Fortysixth Street, and the late Mr. Rand, to Tyler Revere Stevens of New York, son of Mrs. Paul Revere Stevens of Portland, Me.,

THE truth can now be told about how "Yes, My Darling Daughter" got its name. The story has a moral, for it proves that playing poker is a pastime not entirely without an occasional advantage, and that the members of the Hoyle Club are not, as has been contended by some, including the members' wives, absolute wastrels.
Due to expanding business, David Cronheim of Newark will open a branch office next week in Paterson, N. J., and is planning several other branches for other parts of the State shortly.

Chasing bugs, carrying hurricane warnings to fishermen, sprinkling poison dust, searching for illicit distilleries and mapping farms are a few of the many uses to which airplanes are being put by the Federal Government.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Valette Woolsey of Glen Rock, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss F. Margery Woolsey, to Richard Frank Hardy, son of S. Frank Hardy of Trenton, N. J., and the late Mrs. Hardy.

John B. Renwick of Great Neck, L. I., hotel man and founder of Renwick's "jigger" shop in Princeton, N. J., the rendezvous of Princeton undergraduates since the close of the nineteenth century, died yesterday in the French Hospital after a short illness. He was 78 years old.

Probably but little thought was given to the vast and practically unexplored wilderness in the vicinity of the present Boulder Dam at the time when construction of this gigantic engineering feat was first conceived.
More than a score of witnesses were called today for the resumption on Monday of trials of the "Scottsboro" defendants, accused of an attack on two women.

School days will begin tomorrow on Morningside Heights for some 12,000 persons from this country and abroad who have converged on New York City to take part in the 1,067 courses offered at the largest Summer school in the world, the thirty-eighth Summer session of Columbia University.

Pensioned On their own applications. To take effect 12 midnight, July 13: PATROLMEN-Max E. Brudern, 24th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed July 8, 1912. To take effect 12 midnight, July 14: Edward Whalen, 1st Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Feb. 28, 1907.

Fifty-eight yachts, the largest fleet of the Summer season, gathered off the Speonk shore today to sail in the championship regatta of the Yacht Racing Squadron of the Country Club of Westhampton Beach.- The wind was southwest and of moderate strength, driving the craft over fairly long courses on Moriches Bay in excellent time.

Unemployment was reduced again last month, this time by 128,000 to a total of 649,000. At the corresponding date 1st year the figure was 1,035,000. There is now a lack of skilled workers in many trades. This is hindering industry, notably building. About one-third of the unemployed are unskilled.
MARCO POLO'S tales of the fabulous wealth of Cathay enflamed the cupidity of Europe, but the Turks' capture of Constantinople closed the only overland route to China.
In celebration of its twenty-fifth anniversary the Goldman Band will give two special programs this month under the direction of Edwin Franko Goldman, its founder and Conductor.

Governor Lehman and the Legislature were urged by a Westchester County grand jury this week to amend laws governing special elections and provide the same safeguards that prevail at general elections.

THE traveler and the hopeto-be traveler always have a legitimate claim upon the book lists. And when the dreams and plans of those two groups touch the British Isles they may know themselves to be fortunate in their reading matter. For Britons write a great deal about their own countries;

Miss Virginia Golden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Eugene Golden of this city, has completed plans for her wedding to Donald Frederick Kent, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Charles Kent of East Orange.

The captain and. crew of the Imperial Airways flying boat Caledonia, which completed a westward survey flight for North Atlantic passenger and mail service Friday, spent their first full day in New York City yesterday seeking refuge from the heat at the bottom of the Hotel Shelton swimming pool and on the top of the Empire State Building.
THE first part of the revised history of United States stamps of the nineteenth century has just been published by the Scott Stamp and Coin Company of this city.

Proof that educational radio broadcasting under government auspices can attract an enormous audience, interested enough to send in more than a thousand letters a day, has been submitted to President Roosevelt by John W. Studebaker, Commissioner of Education.

The League of Nations was denounced here today by Dr. Luigi Villari of the Italian Foreign Office as a breeder of wars and a potential menace to world peace, second only to the "false and most dangerous" Franco-Soviet pact. Dr.

F. M. Haines sailed Mariette to victory in the H-26 foot class in the Fishers Island Yacht Club regatta today. William H. Hubbard's Fairway was second and Arthur E. Whitney's Chance finished third. Chance has scored in three previous races.

Japan's westward march of empire to her "manifest destiny"hegemony in Eastern Asia-collided once again last week with the growing resistance of a rejuvenated China. With tension running high the outlook for peace in the Far East became uncertain.
The eighth annual women's open golf championship of Fairfield and Westchester Counties will be held tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday at the Lawrence Farms Golf Club, Mount Kisco.

Old Hundred, a historic residence built in Darien, Conn., in 1786 by Samuel Pennoyer, has passed into new hands. The place has been purchased by Mrs. Burkminster Marcy of Boston from Mrs. Thomas S. Holden. The deal was negotiated by Mabel S. Glass, broker.

Only ten gunners reported at the Jamaica Bay traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday. The winner was E. W. Voorhies, who had 47 out of a possible 50 targets. J. K. Voorhees took the second trophy with 45. A.

LETTERS continually reach this department requesting critical counsel and private hearings of individuals uncertain of their own talent, or dissatisfied with their teachers, or disappointed in their professional careers.
The Tome School football team of Port Deposit, Md., is slated to visit New York City next Fall to end its campaign by playing Horace Mann School for Boys on the latter's field on Nov. 19.

Realty investment buying has undergone some sharp changes as a result of depression experiences, points out I. Jerome Riker, president of the Riker Co. brokerage firm. The prudent buyer today, he declares, is not depending as much as in former years upon long-range possibilities for substantial profits as upon wise choice of property with evidence of immediate income.

A second challenge to the Democratic leaders to drive them from the fold was hurled in the Senate today by party opponents of the Compromise Judiciary Reorganization Bill as a new check of strength indicated a margin too close for comfort on either side.

One thousand Republicans, undaunted by heat and distance, beat a path through a remote quarter of Queens last week to the door of the Chisholm Mansion, the 1937 Summer City Hall. Some went by land, using subways, buses and automobiles; some by water, in motor boats and seaplanes.

IF something like Hollywood had existed 2,000 years ago, archaeologists would be sifting it out of the sands of the Roman riviera or the Grecian littoral gravel with spoons. One ancient canister of unblemished film, besides being a bitter pill for De Mille to swallow, might hold more of old Rome's dreams and realities, its grandeur and precious illusions and vernacular than Caesar's mrmloirs.
On leaving Halmstad harbor today the Ede, a forty-five-ton motor yacht belonging to Torsten Kreuger, brother of the late "match king," was destroyed by fire following an explosion.

On the eve of the anniversary of the conclusion of last year's Austro-German accord the commission of Austrian and German delegates which began its sessions on July 6 completed its work today with the issuance of a communique setting forth that it had discussed the pending problems relating to Austro-German cooperation with frankness and the desire to develop further understanding between the two States.

Calling attention to the additional conveniences to large numbers of Brooklyn and Queens residents through the new rapid transit facilities provided in the recent opening of the Brooklyn-Queens cross-town subway, Edward A. MacDougall, president of the Queensboro Corporation,

President Getulio Vargas inaugurated today the first section of the Brazilian Central Railway electrification. The work was done by the British Vickers firm, using American type steel cars and power furnished by the Rio de Janeiro Light and Power Company.

The heat wave seemingly took its toll of bond trading yesterday and, as a result, volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange tapered off to the lowest mark for a two-hour session since Aug. 4, 1928, when sales amounted to $2,594,000. With the obligations in all sections holding firm, although there was Bome spottiness at the close, transactions were only $2,828,000, compared with $4,700,900 on Saturday, June 26, the last previous half session.

Mr. and Mrs. Willard F. Place gave a cocktail party this afternoon at their summer home in honor of Miss Margaret Mabon, who, with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. S. Cliffton Mabon, is spending her first summer in East Hampton.

The recent Insurgent success on the Bilbao front has disrupted the morale of the Loyalists throughout Spain and "marks the beginning of the end of the Madrid Communist government," according to the Very Rev. Silvestre Sancho, rector of Santo Tomas University, Manila.

How tortuous has been the course of relations between Italy and Great Britain can best be appreciated by considering a few memorable dates which stand out as milestones on a road remarkable chiefly for its many twists and turns.

PIETRO MASCAGNI, the Italian opera composer, who is expected to visit America this Fall, remarked recently concerning his latest opera, "Nerone," that the character of the protagonist of that work had interested him for forty years.

Tense and determined, the two factions into which labor trouble has divided this town awaited expectantly the next move of Miss Ida M. Sledge, Memphis society woman and volunteer C. I. O. organizer, who early tonight left for Kosciusko declaring that she would return.

The Pollak Foundation, Newton, Mass., is making a study during the Summer months of the kind of national organization needed "to promote the consumer interest," and a report will be made in the Fall, it was learned here yesterday.

The Men's Garden Clubs of of America, a comparatively new organization, which, starting in the Midwest, has spread to the South and is now invading the East, have completed plans and program for their annual convention, to be held in Lancaster, Pa., next Friday and Saturday.

Gold in London was slightly cheaper yesterday, but held at the shipping parity with New York, making transfers of the metal here again unprofitable. The British quotation was 140s 3d, off 21/2d from the previous day. This was equal to $34.77 in United States funds, compared with $34.79 on Friday.

The Tigers and Indians divided their twin bill today, Detroit winning the first game, 12 to 11, and losing the second, 8 to 7. Eight home runs were made in the two contests. Hal Trosky, Cleveland first baseman, hit one four-bagger in the opener and two more in the second game.
The Oklahoma representatives, Gerin Cameron and Don McNeill, gained the final-round bracket of the Queens County tennis tourney yesterday on the courts of the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.
THAT bibliography may concern itself with live issues as well as living authors is evident from a piece in the June Bulletin of the New York Public Library.

Debits to individual accounts as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended July 7, which included only five business days, aggregated $9,414,000,000, or about the same as the total reported for the preceding week, and 11 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year, which also included only five business days.

Miss Margaret Pardee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs Fred Ward Pardee of this place, was married this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church here, to Howard Ward Beebe, son of Mrs. Howard Franklin Beebe of Brooklyn and East Hampton, L. I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edwin S. Carson.

Making all the pace and standing off challenge after challenge, C. S. Howard's handicap star, Seabiscuit, shouldered top weight of 126 pounds and yet decisively won the $25,025 Butler Handicap before 15,000 persons at Empire City yesterday.
Frank McGuigan, a Wilkes-Barre (Pa.) lawyer, died Friday night on his sixty-fourth birthday at the Hotel Pennsylvania of heart disease. He was stricken as his train neared New York.
Torrential rains and high winds struck the Wheeling area late today, wrecked homes, flooded business districts, paralyzed traffic and marooned hundreds.

THIS is the rush hour of the travel day. Now, in spite of wars and mutterings of war, the great round world lures more and more people, fascinated by the adventure of moving about on the face of it--finding in strange lands refreshment from the tedium and the troubles of their oWn.
Government communiques tonight reported continued successes in the drive against Insurgent lines west of Madrid and intense aerial activity without the loss of a single government plane.
The Right Rev. Abbot Ernest Helmstetter, senior abbot of the Benedictine order in the United States, died last night at St. Mary's Abbey here. He was 77 years old.

Dorothy Angley, 4-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Angley of 1,255 Brook Avenue, the Bronx, was taken to Bronx Hospital suffering from a compound fracture of the skull about 9 o'clock last night after she had fallen twentyfive feet to a rear courtyard from the bedroom of the Angleys' firstfloor apartment.

MR. PIRATE. By A. B. Shiffrin. 209 pp. New York: Mitchell Kennerley. $1.75. THIS little story, told with rare deftness and clothed with a reticent beauty, is called by the author a romance. But "Mr. Pirate" is romance only in the broader application of the term. Love is indeed the theme.

No drastic curtailment is anticipated in the Summer programs to be conducted by the WPA in association with the Board of Education, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday.

THE annual pageant at Itasca Park in Minnesota, held at the trickle of water that is the source of the Mississippi, is expected to attract more than 50,000 visitors during its performances on July 18 and Aug. 1 and 15.
While orthodox administration leaders have readily conceded that it will take about two weeks of debate on the Court Reorganization Bill before one can say that a genuine

Ceramic Art. Brooklyn Museum, until Sept. 7. A technical and historical presentation of ceramic art from primitive days onward. Decorated Rooms. Decorators Club, 745 Fifth Avenue, through the Summer. Photographs of latest work by members.

A number of Summer residents here have guests for the week-end. Mr. and Mrs. Harold Medina have as guests at To Windward, their home on the bay, Miss Betty Browne Strange of South Orange, N. J.; Eugene G. Grace Jr. of Bethlehem, Pa.; Standish Medina and his fiancee, Miss Hope Kiesewetter.

The regular fortnightly movement of State guardsmen started tonight as artillery troops moved to replace outgoing cavalry units at Pine an Camp. Tomorrow the infantrymen will get in motion to and from Camp Smith, ending a transfer of 5,500 guardsmen by motor truck and train.

William Frank James of Fulham, South London, use' to have a wife and a racing greyhound. Today he has a racing greyhound. Mrs. James told a magistrate her husband gambled and spent considerable time at dog tracks.

Getting lost at Playland, Westchester County's amusement park, is usually a pleasure for a child and some mothers are deliberately losing their offspring so the children may enjoy free entertainment at the park, officials complain.
The Baltimore Orioles won their first game of the season from the firstplace Newark Bears today by colelecting eighteen hits for a 13-to-5 victory.

Reports of discoveries by which it will be possible to communicate with the planets and to produce radium in unlimited quantity for ?? a pound were announced by Dr. Nikola Tesla yesterday at a lunch??on on his eighty-first birthday at which he was honored with high orders from the Yugoslav and Czechoslovak Governments.

AMONG the most spectacular discoveries recently made in the field of biology is the one relating to the existence of a "sculptor of life," who, when given the proper working conditions, fashions the aboriginal common "clay" of protoplasmic matter into the intricate organisms of the animal kingdom, from protozoa to man.
Shipments of finished steel products by the United States Steel Corporation's subsidiaries in June amounted to 1,268,550 gross tons, against 1,304,039 tons in May and 886,065 tons in June, 1936.

LONDON.-It will be just a year ago, next Sunday, that half a dozen Spanish generals, relying upon foreign aid that promptly came, set out to put down a revolution which had been gaining momentum since the fall of the monarchy and had led to constant terror by Left and Right in the preceding six months.

A general improvement in share prices, steadiness in bonds and a broad advance in commodities, notably in cotton and wheat, characterized the markets last week. Although buying in the security markets still retained a degree of cautiousness, it was remarked that market sentiment generally was somewhat better than the actual gains in prices.

Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin's Strabo, one of the best 3-year-olds in active competition drew the line fine for the third straight time today in winning the mile and an eighth of the $7,500 Diamond State Handicap at Delaware Park.

The third of a group of eight new city health centers, the lower West Side Center at 303 Ninth Avenue, will be dedicated at a civic luncheon Tuesday noon at which Mayor La Guardia will be the principal speaker, it was announced yesterday by Health Commissioner John L. Rice.

While higher prices still rule on the majority of homeware items, some types of merchandise are now being reduced from recent high levels as a means of halting the downward trend of sales which resulted from previous advances, it was indicated yesterday by a survey of the various industries which will show their Fall lines this week.

Two days after the amiable International Chamber of Commerce congress's discussion of the distinction between "political debts and debts of political origin," the Reich Statistical Bureau issued some data on the practical side of this question.

THE midyear report of the twenty-fifth year of theHundred Neediest Cases Fund is published on these pages today. It tells of the progress, since six months ago, of the 100 cases whose want was made known by THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 6, last.

The recent clash near Peiping between Japanese guards and troops of the Chinese Twenty-ninth Army is distinctly an act of aggression on the part of Japan, the Chinese Ambassador, Dr. C. T. Wang, told this correspondent yesterday.
The series of executions of alleged Japanese-inspired spies in Far Eastern divisions of the Transsiberian Railway emphasizes the importance of the Soviet Union's railways in the Far
President Albert Lebrun inaugurated the highest automobile road in Europe today, the Iseran Pass highway twining between mountain peaks with an altitude reaching 9,230 feet.

France will inform the London Non-Intervention Committee Monday morning in definite terms through Ambassador Charles Corbin, it was announced today at the Foreign Office, that on Tuesday morning she will suspend the right of search on the Franco-Spanish frontier by the ininternational control officers unless the land control along the Portuguese frontier is re-established.
Dorothy Darrell, 17-year-old American dancer friend of Harry Richman, singer, reached London today following her release from detention on the liner Berengaria at Southampton yesterday.
Mobile, Ala., has been selected as the site for a large plant of the Aluminum Ore Company, subsidiary of the Aluminum Company of America, it was revealed here today.

IT appears that the "thing" to do this season is to discuss farce. Not in terms of single occurrence, but as a cycle proposition, something to be taken as a balance for the sentiment commonly encountered in the cinema. We learned about it last week, at-of all places-a tidy little reception (cocktail party) for Miss Martha

THE proceedings at the annual conference of such bodies as the Publishers Association and the Associted Booksellers are, in the main, of little interest save to their own members. Reports of discussions of the '"net book agreement."

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 9 unless specified: At Seattle: Astoria, Indianapolis, Melville, Relief. LaHaima Roads to search area: Cushing, Drayton, Lamson, Lexington. At Annapolis: Cuyahoga, July 10: Potomac. LaHaima Roads to Pearl Harbor: Ramapo, Whippoorwill.

J. Edward Breuer will sell at auction next Saturday in Long Branch, N. J., 250 dwelling and waterfront lots to close out the holdings of the Kessto Corporation. The property was formerly owned by the late W. E. D. Stokes and has frontages on Atlantic and Long Branch Avenues.

The high percentage of child wives, in comparison with other sections of the nation, has been one of the causes of cultural retardation in family life in the Southeastern States, according to a survey reported yesterday by Bernice M. Moore and Margaret J. Hagood, research assistants in the Institute for Research in Social Science of the University of North Carolina.

KEEPING expenses within an estimated budget has always been an essential part of the work of the professional interior decorator, but the use of a budget by the layman has only recently been stressed.

The marriage of Miss Mary Lee, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lyndon E. Lee of Mount Vernon, N. Y. to Robert D. Brooks. son of Byron E. Brooks of Ithaca, N. Y., and the late Helen Townley Brooks, took place yesterday afternoon at the Oriental Beach Club, Mamaroneck.

William Picken, commodore of the Bay Shore Yacht Club, sailed his Star Class yacht High Seas into first place today in the first of a series of elimination races held by the international Star fleet of Great South Bay to select a crew to represent it in the forthcoming North Atlantic and international championships.

The Toronto Maple Leafs vaulted past the Syracuse Chiefs into fourth place today as they downed the Buffalo Bisons in both ends of a doubleheader. The Leafs won the first game 1-0 and the second 3--2.

Opening by the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia of a -new Mineral Hall embodying new methods of display was announced yesterday by Charles M. B. Cadwalader, the president. The new methods were developed by seven years of experimentation.

More inquiries for apartment space are being received this season by brokers in the Forest Hills and Kew Gardens localities of Long Island than was the case one year ago at this time, reports the Forest Hills-Kew Gardens Apartment Owners Association.
AT this time of year, when New York clubs conduct few tournaments, the thoughts of bridge players in the metropolitan district turn to the annual shore tournaments.

Although four of its components advanced, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has receded for the week ended July 3 to 106.7. Declines in three series more than offset the four gains. In the previous week the index was 107.5 and for the corresponding week last year 102.4

The period for the renewal of chauffeurs' licenses ended at noon yesterday and when the offices of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles, 80 Center Street, closed, officials estimated that "several thousand had renewed their permits."

MORNING EVENTS Class 40, Knock-Down and Out-First, Miss Muriel Cleland's b. g. Johnnie W.; second, Mrs. Harry Frank Jr.'s b. m. Alhaja; third, Mrs. Gordon Wright's b. g. Sonny; fourth, Jack Spratt's b. m. Joan; fifth, Dr. Andrew J. Jackson's ch. g. Vendonah.

Lammot du Pont of Wilmington, Del., recently won a reversal of a ruling by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue which held that he was not entitled to deductions aggregating $887,367 for losses in the years 1930 and 1931, it was learned today.

FOR motorists intending to ride the roads of New England this season the 1937 edition of Cabin Trails, which has been published for eight years, is now available. This booklet, which may be obtained for a three-cent stamp to cover mailing cost from the publisher, Ray A. Walker of Haverhill, Mass., has built up a reputation for accuracy.

Fines of 50 francs and 200 francs with joint damages of 10,000 francs to the plaintiff, Wladimir Poliakoff, were ordered to be paid by Marcel Stora and Georg Bernhard in the defamation suit heard in the Douzieme Chambre Correctionelle on June 22.

The fourteenth season of Sunday afternoon chamber music concerts of the South Mountain Association, in Pittsfield, Mass., will begin this afternoon, it was announced yesterday by Willem Willeke, its director. Other concerts of the series will take place July 18 and 25, and Aug. 1, 8, 15 and 29.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the name of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore, to select those of the greatest general interest.

ON any bright Sunday morning at this season a steady procession of eager voyagers pours across Forty-second Street from near-by subway and elevated stations to board the boat for an all-day excursion to Indian Point

Miss Annette Ruth Hallberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hallberg of this place, and Dr. Henry Gamble Dudley, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Dudley of Brooklyn, were married tonight at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Essex Fells.
AN Autumn series of educational programs planned for Latin American listeners will be inaugurated, probably in October, by the Pan American Union broadcasting through station WIXAL, Boston, Mass.

ALTHOUGH government dietitians complain that Americans do not eat enough fish, New Yorkers have a hearty appetite for sea food and at this season both the home cook and the diner-out turn their attention to fresh shellfish, which is abundant and reasonably cheap.
John Montague won temporary freedom from jail today on $10,000 bond as the State of New York demanded his extradition on a sevenyear-old robbery charge.

Miss Edith D. McCune, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. McCune of this place, was married to Joseph W. Kyser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Worth D. Kyser of Utica, at the home of the bride's parents this afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. John Lyon Caughey, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church.

THE story of the munition explosions on Black Tom Island in New York Harbor and at Kingsland, N. J., will be told in Captain Henry Landau's "The Enemy Within," which G. P. Putnam's Sons will publish on Aug. 27.
WITH the telecasts of the 1937 Wimbledon tennis matches the British Broadcasting Corporation has established what is called "another landmark in the history of television."
The seventh annual gathering of the Judson family's descendants was held a few days ago in this town, which had among its first settlers Lieutenant Joseph Judson and his son, John Judson.
With the annual national soaring contest closing tomorrow, pilots are making an extraordinary effort to achieve records, but lack of thermals today prevented outstanding performances.

WIMBLEDON, the tennis capital of the world, has again crowned an American as the supreme ruler of amateur tennis. When Baron Gottfried von Cramm of Germany was finally blasted from the center court a few days ago, J. Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., climbed to a throne previously occupied successively by William T. Tilden, William Johnston, Sidney Wood and Ellsworth Vines.

Those observers who reported months ago that the rivalry between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization would be much worse before it was better have proved to be correct.

Slain by a blow administered with a handmirror, a woman of about 35 was found tonight in her room at the fashionable Essex House Hotel on Broad Street. A man, with whom she had registered at the hotel more than two weeks ago, was unconscious in the room.

USE of the camera as a weapon of defense and an aid to crime detection is growing among amateurs. Following the lead of public officials and police, who now make wide use of both movie and still cameras in gathering criminal evidence, private citizens are discovering that they can protect their own interests through skillful use of the camera, and that evidence thus gathered is well-nigh incontrovertible.

To the Edition of The New York Times: The "bill to reorganize the judicial branch of the government" (S. 1392) was introduced by Senator Ashurst Feb. 8, 1937, and was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

With the World Labor Athletic Carnival today providing the initial feature-one-comparable to the national championships themselvesthree track and field meets of great importance will be crammed into the next eight days.
WHILE other vacationists paste Nassau and Riviera labels on their luggage, the adventurous visitor in New York can do considerable traveling within the city limits for one round nickel.

Tiger Jack Fox, Spokane light heavyweight who is seeking a chance at the crown now held by John Henry Lewis, will tackle Leo (Deacon) Kelly of Los Angeles in the feature bout at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night. The fight is routed over the championship distance of fifteen rounds, and the winner quite likely will be named by the New York State Athletic Commission as Lewis's foremost challenger.
KINGSTON. - Summer sunshine has brought back to Ulster County and the Cats kill region such throngs of vacationists that resorts report the biggest season since 1929.

A group of nine persons who formed, pursuant to a written agreement, a so-called syndicate to buy and sell a certain stock and whose operations consisted of eleven purchases and three sales over a period of eight months has been held for Federal income-tax purposes to be an association taxable as a corporation.

Fewer Corn Belt farmers than last year are participating in the 1937 AAA soil conservation program. The decrease will be from 10 to 15 per cent. Nebraska applications show that 62 per cent of the eligible crop land has been entered for participation, as compared with 71 per cent a year ago.

On the winged feet of their captain, A. Godfrey K. Brown, Oxford and Cambridge rode to their first victory over Yale and Harvard on American soil in sum-flooded Harvard Stadium today as the Britons turned back the home forces, 7 to 5.
The former post office at the corner of George and Albany Streets, New Brunswick, N. J., has been sold to private interests.

FROM William Blake's "The Book of The" comes the title for the biography of poor Mary Wollstonecraft iserable and beaten by a drunken father in her childhood, poor as poverty most of her life, ambitious beyond her talents,

Although it is to be small, with only members of the families and a few friends present, the wedding of Miss Elizabeth Van Antwerp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Trotter Van Antwerp of this city, to Lucius Beebe, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Russell

The Republic Pictures Corporation, a motion picture producer, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 1,316,000 shares of $1 par value capital stock including 261,000 shares reserved for

Four $500 prize scholarships have been awarded for 1937-38 to incoming students of Bard College, Columbia University's residential unit at Annandale-on-Hudson, it was announced yesterday by Glenn B. McClelland, director of admissions.

Somewhere between Fordham Road and the Brooklyn Bridge stations on the East Side I. R. T., Miss Anna Walsh, 30 years old of 2,934 Valentine Avenue, the Bronx, lost or was robbed of $8,125 in cash, she told police of the Oak Street Station yesterday morning.

NEWPORT, R. I.--From the boxes that have been taken and the number of season reservations made, it is apparent that many of the Summer colonists are looking forward to the opening of the Casino Theatre season on Tuesday night. The Actors Managers, Inc., the group that has managed the theatre the past two Summers, will present on that night the world premiere of a new English play. "Sweet Sorrow."
Mrs. Mildred Fuller Wallace, widow of Hugh Campbell Wallace, Ambassador to France following the World War, died Friday night at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, after a heart attack. Her age was 68.

Jamestown's city Council studied tonight a proposal to add a $1,500,000 gas plant to this upState city's municipal holdings, which already include water and electricity plants, a hospital and a market.
