DEDICATION of the new Mount San Jacinto State Park recently increased the public range of the California habit of making recreational use of mountains. Already the Angeles National Forest and the San Bernardino National Forest,

The United States Maritime Commission will launch its organized survey of wages and manning and working conditions in the maritime industry this week when Commissioner Thomas M. Woodward opens a public hearing at 45 Broadway on Tuesday.
Gifts to Cornell University in the last academic year amounted to $1,477,626.05, almost doubling donations received the previous year, George F. Rogalsky, university treasurer, reported today.

The marriage of Miss Elwyna Van Alen, daughter of T. Elwyn Van Alen of Mineola, and Gordon Sauerbrum of Jamaica, took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Creegan of this place. The Rev.
Five months after he had completed fifty years of medical practice here Dr. John Taylor Howell, father of Dr. Howell Jr of New York, died at his home here today at the age of 75.

William ' J. Gottlieb, executive vice president of the Automobile Club of New York, in a statement yesterday charged that the entire burden of reducing New York State's deficit had been placed upon the automobile-owning group.

CITY dwellers are fleeing to their favored haunts by the malt water and once again are taking up beach sports. For the next two months various this recreational activities, from the generally played court handball to their the revived practice of archery, will serve them as exercise when they will are not in the surf.
In the strike which forced The Seattle Star to suspend publication for a few days this week, the Northwest watched another phase of a struggle for control between two dominant labor leaders.
The galleries and rooms of the Art Association of Newport, on Bellevue Avenue, were the center of social activity this afternoon, especially for those members of the colony who are interested in art.
The first charity event of the season took place yesterday when a fashion show and tea in behalf of the Spring Lake Community House took place around the pool of the Bathing and Tennis Club. Mrs.

John Thal, 70-year-old leathergoods manufacturer, was shot in the left side about 10 A. M. yesterday when he attempted to fight off a Negro who had taken $7 from him in a hold-up in the hallway at 2,542 Seventh Avenue.

Colonel and Mrs. Spencer Cosby of Washington have come to the St. Regis. Miss Jean W. Stokes of the Plaza will leave this week for Whitefield, N. H. Mrs. Leland Sterry Jr., has arrived at the Weylin from Saratoga Springs.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Benjamin Davis of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Mfiss Geraldine Ruth Davis, to Dr. Winthrop Ford Watts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ford Watts of Salem, Mass.

Miss Agnes Morris of Bridgeport, Conn., president-elect of the American Dental Hygienists Association, will be guest of honor at a tea on Monday at the opening of the fourteenth annual meeting of the association at the Hotel Dennis here. The convention will continue to Friday.
The 100-acre estate with a thirteen-room house owned by Mrs. Julia E. Moody and H. LeRoy Jackson in Banbury, Conn., has been sold to a client of Green Green, Danbury brokers.

A one-man Arctic expedition left Boston the other day when Prentice G. Downes, 27-year-old school teacher, whose home is in Belmont, Mass., began a three-month journey that will take him ??00 miles north of the Arctic Circle and within 800 miles of the North Pole.

Studies in home owning conditions in urban localities throughout the country by the home owning committee of the United States Building and Loan League have revealed the fact that in many cities in the 10,000 to 50,000 population class, more homes are owned by wage earners than py the business and professional families.

George Gershwin, the composer, was near death in Cedars of Lebanon Hospital tonight. He was reported to be suffering from a brain tumor. The writer of half a hundred song hits was returned to the hospital early today after having been discharged from it only a few days ago.

Cited as evidence of an ebb in the flood tide of State anti-chain store tax legislation, the action of the Wisconsin Legislature in adjourning without acting on renewal of the State's levy on chains was hailed here yesterday by spokesmen for the chain systems.

Miss Ruth June Altschul, 19-yearold daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Altschul, 331 Fenimore Street, Brooklyn, a junior at New York University's Washington Square College, has received the University Alumnae Club's Angie V. Sutton Memorial Award.
When the mercury climbs into the 90's on the breezy summits where official thermometers are kept, and to no one knows what heights in the dizzy canyons below, and in the subway's thronged recesses;
The Yankees continued like the weather yesterday-hot and oppressive, as far as the Senators were concerned.

THE Silvermine Guild of Artists has made final plans for a music festival at Silvermine, Conn., at which seventy-five members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Jose Iturbi, will appear Aug. 20, according to an announcement made by John Vassos, president of the Guild.

The Olcott Yacht Club's two-boat team today held a commanding lead in the competition for the Snipe Class championship of upState New- York. The two Olcott craft were among the five able to negotiate a once-around tour of the triangular course in the first race of the series at Nine Mile Point on Lake Ontario.

MARCOS. A Mountain Boy of Mexico. By Melicent Humason Lee. Pictures in color by Berta end Rimer Hader. 80 pp. Chicago: Albert Whitman , Co. Junior Press Books. $2. THIS is, as Margery Bianco points out in her foreword, "a story as old as the hills and as new as each day's sunrise. * * * And it begins, "There was a boy who set out to seek his fortune.' "
Eighty carrier-salesmen, part of the corps of boys that distributes The Telegram and Gazette of Worcester, Mass., began a threeday tour of the city yesterday as guests of the newspaper.

Speedy Lew Hal, owned by Lloyd D. Clayton of Maplewood, Ohio, and driven by Harry Craig, subbing for the suspended Dr. H. M. Parshall, today swept to a two straight heat triumph in the $2,500 Judson Pace as the Grand Circuit races ended at North Randall.

Charles Allen Russell, former solicitor for the Federal Power Commission, died here today at the age of 61. He was special counsel on utility matters to Franklin D. Roosevelt when the latter was Governor of New York.

The Merchants Association has written to Senators Copeland and Wagner asking them to do "all in your power" to defeat the compromise Court Bill now pending. Senator Wagner is an advocate of the bill and Senator Copeland is an announced adversary.

Convinced that the amount of mail to be handled by the new North Atlantic air route will be "tremendous," Harllee Branch, Second Assistant Postmaster General, today expressed belief that the mail service on this route would pay for itself in the second year of operation and possibly the first.

SO far as creative novelty is concerned, fashion marks time in July; the Summer's contributions have been made, and the Autumn's are still secrets closely guarded. While sirens are cleaving the waves at the seashore the coverings they will don when, exhilarated, they return to town are being exhibited in sweltering showrooms.
An event that signifies to many the official opening of the Summer social season here will be the first subscription dinner dance at the Monmouth County Country Club on Friday.

An entire floor in Hampshire House, thirty-six-story apartment hotel nearing completion on Central Park South, has been finished and two model apartments have been furnished and opened for inspection of prospective tenants, Douglas L. Elliman Co., agents, announced yesterday.

More than 125,000 acres of land in Eastern and Southeastern Colorado are barren of grass and crops, the result of the most damaging grasshopper infestation in the State's history. The same situation prevails in small sections of New Mexico, Texas and Oklahoma.

To the Music Editor: IN THE NEW YORK TIMES for Sunday, June 27, appeared an ar ticle, "A Wagnerian Menu," which stated in part that "nobody seems to have occupied himself to any degree with the rather human question of what the creator of 'Tristan' and 'Meistersinger' liked to eat."

John Benn of Crestwood turned in two magnificent performances today at the County Tennis Club of Westchester to capture both the singles and doubles crowns in the juniors' division of the annual Westchester tennis championships.

Miss Alice Irene Moriarty, daughter of Mrs. Hugh Moriarty of Montclair, and the late Mr. Moriarty, was married today to Lester E. Reeve, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Lester Reeve of Essex Fells, in the home of her mother by Mgr. Timothy Donovan, pastor of Sacred Heart Church, Bloomfield.

Although no further industrial progress was made in Canada in June, in contrast with the records of preceding months, there was no downturn of seasonal proportions, nor is any marked slackening in view, according to A. E. Arscott, general manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce.

MANHATTAN SAQUI, MAURICE (May 11). Estate, less than $5,000. To Laura Lubin Saqui, widow. executrix, Woodmere, L. I. STERN. BENJAMIN (July 7). Estate, $1,000. To Carrie K. Stern, niece, executrix, 2,722 Cruger Ave., Bronx; three minor bequests.

Predicting that architecture will again play a leading part among the arts in the future, Professor Walter Gropius of Harvard University advocates that every assistance should be advanced to enable the coming generation of architects to assume such leadership.
It seems that rather than to solve the ArabJewish problem the Palestine Commission's report and recommendations served only to strengthen the argument that the Palestine question has no solution.

The United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, obtained certification today from the National Labor Relations Board as the exclusive collective bargaining agency for 11,500 East Pittsburgh employes of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.

The quick and effective assistance which a German shepherd dog named Flossie gave two policemen was disclosed yesterday morning whe:. two downcast young men shuffled across the platform in the line-up at police headquarters. Flossie was largely responsible for one of the men being in custody.

The marriage of Mrs. Jean Antoinette Clark of West New Brighton, S. I., widow of Roosevelt L. Clark, to Charles Duncan Cushman of New Brighton took place yesterday morning at the home of her aunt, Mrs. Edward Bronson King in West New Brighton.

Professor Charles I. Marvin of the University of Virginia and Mrs. Marvin have arrived from Charlottesville, Va., at the Marvin camp on the Upper Saranac Lake for the season.. With them are Mr. and Mrs. Sherwood Marvin of Warrenton, Va.
THAT stentorian bellow which can be heard at certain hours above the roar of Times Square traffic these days is not the Queen Mary's distant salute to the Lady of Liberty.

A new species of trees is being produced in Canada. D. A. Macdonald, assistant Dominion forester, said that experiments give promise of a new fast-growing, tough poplar tree specially suited to the needs of the paper and match industries.
In a few weeks New York City will be virtually eliminated as a favorite Gretna Green for out-of-town couples, who, in past years, at the rate of 10,000 a year, have been flocking here to be married.
Barney Welsh of Rockville, Md., the nation's sixteenth ranking tennis player, paced eight survivors into the quarter-final round of the Oyster Harbors Club's first invitation tournament today.
The White Mountains are having a gala week-end, with a round of events at hotels and Summer homes in honor of new arrivals.

Barrel-chested Glenn Cunningham ran 1,500 meters in a slow 3:58 today and nosed out Charlie Fenske of Wisconsin University by two yards in the feature event of the Erie Club's track and field games. Dennis Shore, South African quarter-mile king,
Midnight of Aug. 10, just a month from now, is the deadline for the filing of the complete slates of candidates for city and borough offices to be contested in the September primary elections.

EXTENSIVE road changes now being made by the Pennsylvania Department of High ways in the eastern part of the State will facilitate travel to the South and West from New York City and Central New York State.

Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, national tennis champion in 1935, will play in the annual invitation tournament of the Bathing and Tennis Club at Spring Lake, N. J. The event opens Tuesday morning and concludes July 18.

Home construction in New Jersey is far ahead of the 1936 volume, declares Thomas E. Colleton, FHA director for that State who reports that mortgage insurance commitments for new residential construction during the first six months of the present year exceeded the

By noon today 10,089,074 vehicles will have used the TriboroughBridge since it was opened to the public just one year ago, the Triborough Bridge Authority estimated yesterday. The estimate was based on results shown by the Authority's report covering the six months ended June 30, together with figures for the period from July 1 to July 8.

The Woodstock, a 400-room hotel at 127-139 West Forty-third Street, near Times Square, has been sold by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, according to an announcement yesterday by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers in the transaction.

NEW additions to City College's Hall of Patriots are the sculptured busts of Horace Greeley, Andrew Jackson, Samuel Morse and John Marshall, executed by Alexander Sambugnac, a WPA Federal Art Project sculptor.

AS a result of their activity in the Earhart hunt, radio ama teurs were told by J. B. Beadle, head of the amateur unit of the Federal Communications Commission, that an opportunity for a globe-girdling network is open to them for quick communication on an organized scale in time of emergency.
Miss Rachel C. Torrance, who did valuable work overseas in the World War as a nurse and nursing executive for the Red Cross, died yesterday of cancer in St. Luke's Hospital at the age of 50.

The ever-soaring temperature failed to dim the ardor of several hundred athletes of the Athletic Association of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, who competed in their annual field day and outing at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

Some encouragement to the public agencies and private interests seeking to have the Interstate Commerce Commission reconsider its determination of the metropolitan area around New York and other large cities for purposes of exemptions under the Motor Carrier Act,

Jubilation over the first victory in the fight for repeal of Section 213-A of the National Economy Act was apparent yesterday at headquarters of national organizations of women, many of whom have declared the clause as it relates to "discrimination" against women workers, one of the "most repugnant" ever voted.

The hundredth anniversary of the first recorded ascent of Mount Marcy, the highest peak in the State, will be celebrated Aug. 5. Several hundred persons interested in conservation and hiking are expected, after clambering along the various wilderness trails of the Adirondacks, to mass on the summit at 1 P. M. for a short ceremony.

ABOUT twenty thousand years ago the Atlantic Ocean, in an expansive mood, rolled in upon the east coast of this continent and pushed its way 125 miles up the ancient Hudson River to the New York of today.
THE taxi queues that used to encircle Broadway's various Hamlets, Othellos and Richard II's during the last season or so were, of course, in the regular tradition of good business.

A start was made this morning toward finding a compromise between the ItaloGerman and Anglo-French viewpoints about Spanish non-intervention when Sir Eric Drummond, the British Ambassador, called on Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Foreign Minister, and had a long conversation with him.

A list of 716 passengers sailed yesterday for San Francisco via Cuba, Colon and Acapulco on the Panama Pacific liner California. One of them was Lady Kingsford-Smith, widow of Sir Charles KingsfordSmith, Australian flier who was lost in November, 1935, during a flight from Allahabad, India, to Singapore with his co-pilot, J. T. Pethybridge.

As a result of industrial expansion and the growing need for residential accommodations in Linden, N. J., the first two large apartment buildings for that community will soon rise on sites which are being rezoned to permit multi-family construction.
George Herman (Babe) Ruth was overcome by the heat late this afternoon while playing in a four some at the Leewood Golf Club in Eastchester, near here.

The Reds announced today that Shortstop Eddie Miller has been recalled from Syracuse of the International League, and will report to the team tomorrow in St. Louis. Miller, who trained with the Reds at Tampa, Fla., played last year with Toronto.
Bayside (71)--Second round for President's Cup: Adam Cramer defeated H. McCarthy, 3 and 2; Max Williamson defeated Dr. I. Epstein, 5 and 4; Andy Mutlak defeated C. Hall, 1 up (27 holes).
A WAGNER festival in concert form will begin tomorrow night at the Stadium with a performance of "Das Rheingold," followed by "Die Walkuere" on Wednesday.

The opening of the new $800,000 bridge across Lake Champlain from Rouses Point, N. Y., to Alburg, Vt., next Friday will be an international event, according to plans announced by Mortimer Y. Ferris, chairman of the Lake Champlain Bridge Commission.
HERE is a labor novel with one eye cocked at the specter of fascism that it is a pleasure to recommend to all men of good-will sitting on the sidelines. It solves no problems.

Shooting three birdies on the first seven holes to take a six-hole lead, W. B. (Duff) McCullough of Philadelphia easily won the Pennsylvania State amateur golf championship today, beating his Philadelphia rival, Kean Donnelly, 6 and 5, in the 18-hole final at the Lancaster Country Club.
HERE are two volumes made up of letters, excerpts from approximately 5,000 letters, written by some 2,100 men. And these men represent a vertical section through the medical profession.

The battle royal between the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers of America over unionization of Ford employes got into full swing the past week with the testimony of witnesses in the National Labor Relations Board's hearing of charges against the Ford Company.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Barnett Collins of East Orange of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rebecca Louisa Collins, to Robert Behan Myers, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Emerson Myers of East Orange and Sea Girt.

In a letter to Mayor La Guardia, made public yesterday, Borough .President James J. Lyons of the Bronx urged speedy action to bring about construction of a Bronx Central station at Bronx Concourse and 149th Street, to serve about 3,000,000 persons in ??ritory within and adjoining the borough.
MEXICO, D. F.--The Mexican revolution has entered a new phase in which the government is establishing ironclad control over the entire national economy, both agricultural and industrial.

Tennis players representing the navy defeated the army today, 5 to 2, in the competition for the Leech Cup. The victory was the ninth in a row for the navy in the cup play. Navy won three singles and two doubles matches.

Miss Helen Alice Lesser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Lesser of this city was married this afternoon to George Coren Thistleton, son of the Rev. Alfred E. Thistleton and Mrs. Thistleton, also of East Orange. The ceremony, which took place in the First Congregational Church, was performed by the Rev. Carl Martenson.

WASHINGTON. A METHOD whereby air traffic at terminals can be speeded threefold is being worked out by those officials of the Bureau of Air Commerce concerned with operations. For many months airline operators, pilots and the bureau have been studying problems of air traffic control and its subdivisions, airways and airport traffic.
A roller-skating dinner party on Thursday night will inaugurate a series of weekly events to be held at the Atlantic Beach Club here throughout the Summer.

Each office in the new Corning Building, at Fifth Avenue and FiftySixth Street, will be provided with ts own air-mixing cabinet, which Will permit the occupant to select the temperature he finds most suitable for his comfort.

WITH the airlines of the United States expecting to carry 250,000 women passengers this year, the day of the woman air traveler has definitely arrived. Seven short years ago, when transcontinental transport service was celebrating its first birthday,

Growing acceptance as good mortgage risks of well-planned houses of modern design is indicated by Howard P. Vermilya, technical director of the Federal Housing Administration, in the July issue of The Architectural Record.

A break in a seeming deadlock between Chile and the United States over the possibility of negotiating a reciprocal trade agreement was indicated today after a conference by Desiderio Garcia, Sub-Secretary of the Treasury of Chile, who has been here several days discussing the subject with officials of the State Department.

A modification of the plan for the amalgamation of the Canadian Hydro-Electric Corporation, Ltd., and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Gatineau Power Company, will be proposed at a special meeting of shareholders on Thursday, according to G. Gordon Gale, president of the former concern.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted an exemption from the necessity of making a declaration in regard to the issuance of certain notes by the Detroit City Gas Company, a subsidiary of the American Light and Traction Company.

Creation of a State Board of Alienists to prevent killers such as Robert Irwin from escaping death in the electric chair by pleading insanity is recommended by Dr. Matthias Nicoll Jr., Westchester Health Commissioner.

Pope Pius XI will deliver his third radio message during 1937 at 7 A. M. today, when he speaks from his Summer residence, Castel Gandolfo, over the combined facilities of the WABC, WEAF and WJZ networks. A five-minute English translation will follow the Pontiff's address.

WHEN General "Silverspoon" Butler, as the Southerners called him took over New Orleans hate blazed hotly against the invaders. He welcomed it. therefore, as a harbinger of better understanding when two young women, smartly dressed,
The freighter Phyllis Soto arrived here this week from Taku Bar with 2,000 tons of Manchurian corn consigned to a concern in Oakland.

The ill-fated Hindenburg's sister ship, the LZ-130, now under construction here, will be rebuilt for helium and will not be launched until Spring. The frame for the passenger quarters, the lighting and electrical power plants which had been installed, have now been removed.
Placer gold mining in the Yukon Territory was increased last year, according to a bulletin from the-Federal Department of Mines, geological survey division.

RETAIL trade dropped in the hot wave last week although some sections of the country reported an accelerated demand for Summer goods. Clearance sale prices seemed to push volume ahead, particularly in the men's wear divisions.

Mrs. Thomas Ellwood Townsend of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Townsend, to the Rev. Frank Richard Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Williams of Knoxville, Tenn.

It is only two weeks off-that cruise to Newport for the America's Cup races-and skippers already are charting their courses. Pleasure craft from every anchorage will converge from all points of the compass on Narragansett Bay. Vacation periods have been planned long in advance, for there will be sightseeing to and from Newport and stop-offs along the way.

Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius N. Bliss Jr. and Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. McKim of Westbury and Aiken, S. C., were hosts today at an "old-fashioned picnic" under the historic trees that surround the race track at the Mineola Fair Grounds,

The debate on the new Court Bill has begun with the Administration's spokesmen in the Senate attempting to make "loyalty" the chief issue. Loyalty to what? Not to each member's conscience and to his personal responsibility of deciding for himself what he sincerely believes to be in the best interest of the country.

While chain store sales in June maintained a high level, the advance over last year moderated considerably, according to the monthly survey issued yesterday by Childs, Jeffries Thorndike. Sales for the first twenty-five chains reporting for last month totaled $256,740,329, an increase of $26,770,909, or 11.7 per cent over the same month a year ago.

Striking WPA workers, crying, "We all work or no one works!" threatened today to end the WPA program in South Bend and St. Joseph County. "The strike hourly grows more menacing," said William H. Jordan, district director, "and may bring an end to the WPA program."
A motion-picture film of the Memorial Day steel riot was confiscated and a woman and six men were arrested in a police squad raid last night.

Interest of retailers in all types of merchandise swung to Fall goods last week and, while great numbers of buyers were in the market, the peak of arrivals will be reached this week, according to the special report furnished THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buyers.

Three thousand children in New York City's most crowded districts will flock into sixteen Summer play schools affiliated with the Child Study Association tomorrow. Located in settlement houses, community centers, housing developments and school buildings in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx, the schools -will select those children who are most in need of allday care, whether for physical, economic, or emotional reasons.

Russian aviatioh leaders tonight disclosed plans to send two more airplanes off on attempted non-stop flights to the United States within a month, probably over the north polar regions. One plane is tuned up and ready to go; only rain has held it for several days in Moscow.

The Fayette County coal fields, scene of many bitter labor struggles, seemed destined today to witness a battle within labor ranks to break the "captive" mine strike of the United Mine Workers of America.

With a deaf ear turned to the call of the seashore or the mountains, eighty-eight business executives from all over the country embarked this week on a trip of "bus men's holiday" at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

The leading juvenile event of the Empire City meeting, the East View Stakes, will be run on Saturday at the Yonkers course, with a fine field in prospect. No less than 113 nominations have been received for the $2,500 added test to be run over the short six-furlong course, and it is probable that a capacity field will face the starter.

With major differences ironed out after an all-day conference between representatives of the joint board of the Cloakmakers Union and employer groups in the coat and suit industry, union leaders predicted last night that 35,000 workers,

MUFTI: The Public Order act, passed a few months ago by the British Parliament, bans political uniforms and semi-military organizations. It aimed to squelch Sir Oswald Mosley and his black-shirted British

The death of Louis Oliver Vaughn, 27-year-old Negro artist who was one of those dismissed from the WPA Art Project as of July 15, was caused by drowning, Thomas A. Gonzales, acting chief medical examiner, said yesterday after an autopsy.

This afternoon at 3:30 o'clock at Bethpage State Park, Farmingdale, L. I., the first prominent women's polo match in the metropolitan area will be played between picked teams representing the East and the Far West. Polo fans have already shown great advance interest in this unique event,

The select circle of unbeaten teams in the Eastern Polo League is due to be reduced this afternoon when two of the three unconquered combinations, First Division of Brooklyn and Evergreen Farms of Eatontown, N. J., meet at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation.
Divided viewpoints were noted yesterday on the question of higher shark-ups for retailers, generated by efforts under way in several lines to produce this result.

The Real Estate Board of Newark has been asked by the city of Newark to make an appraisal of all municipally owned or controlled property coming within the jurisdiction of the Department of Parks and Public Property, of which Joseph M. Byrne Jr. is director.

Duke University's annual Summer school for coaches will be held at the Durham, N. C., institution from July 26 to 31. The year's session is the seventh, and it will be conducted by Coach Wallace Wade and his assistants on the Duke staff.

Two Rochester errors and eight Montreal hits off Howard Krist gave Rabbit Maranville's Montreal Royals a 5-to-2 decision over the Rochester Wings here today and likewise an even break in their two-day series.

A man posing as a deputy sheriff tricked two vacation-bound West Philadelphia girls into giving him a "lift" in their automobile today and on the pretense of showing them a short cut to their destination, led them through a sparsely populated section of Mount Kehmor and robbed them of $235, their vacation money.
In the opening match of the Rumson Country Club 12-goal polo tournament played today on Herbert Memorial Field. Shrewsbury defeated General Howard S. Borden's Old Oaks team, 11 to 3.
Entertainments were held throughout the day for week-end guests at various estates in the Summer colony. Many went to the Beach Club during the morning.
The movement for "safe and sane" Fourth of July celebrations won a signal victory Monday when the New Jersey Anti-Fireworks Act met its first test and came through with flying colors.
The patrol ship Nascopie mailed today to mark a new place on Canada's map during a 10,000-mile cruise into Hudson Bay.

Little Jules Huot of Quebec, who packs a lot of golfing punch in his 130pound frame, outlasted a trio of sharpshooters from the United States through the ups and downs of the final thirty-six holes today to win the $4,000 General Brock open golf tournament.

Indications of a steadily increasing home demand are seen in the report just made by Russell Page, sales director of the "Easy-to-Own" Homes Organization who states that during the first five months this year sixty-six homes were sold for a total of $493,500. They were in Brooklyn, Queens Borough, Nassau and Westchester Counties.
WHITE MOUNTAINS, N. H.--The recreation program at the White Mountain resorts includes many outdoor sports new to this section. Swimming and water sports are leading in popularity.
Even head-hunters hitch-hike, said Dr. Frederick Meyer in relating experiences of seventeen years in medical work in the Philippines.

Plans have just been announced for the Westport Fair to be held on the grounds of the General Putnam Inn on the evenings of July 29, 30 and 31. The afternoon of the final day will be given over to diversions for children.

Donald Welch, assistant manager of the Niagara Falls Chamber of Commerce Convention and Visitors' Service Bureau, said today that no permit would be issued to Clifford Calverly of Sarasota, Fla., to walk across the falls on a tight rope to celebrate the anniversary of a similar feat performed by him forty-five years ago.

Here and there: Torrid days of the past week drove most city dwellers hither and yon seeking a cool spot. Yet one visitor dropped into the office to sing the praises of small-mouth bass. He was starting off on a Summer vacation and of course he intended to spend many days

Despite the heat and the temporary stoppage in the coat and suit industry, sufficient enthusiasm was generated in the women's apparel markets by the showings of initial Fall styles to warrant the belief that buyers will settle down to placing of substantial orders this week.
The new swimming pool of the Pelham Country Club here was officially opened tonight with swimming and diving exhibits, a fashion show and dance. More than 300 members and their guests attended.

With declines in both grain and stocks and with the absence of the aggressive buying operations that characterized Friday's session, prices on the Cotton Exchange were set back 14 to 17 points yesterday.

Public officials, realty interests and welfare groups continue to engage in what appears to be an almost fruitless debate over the questions of just how far government agencies should go in helping to finance or construct modern housing for families of low income,

The marriage of Miss Doris Eleanor Heydorn, niece of Mr. and Mrs. Luther T. Yeomans of this city, to Merrill Green Forrest. son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Forrest of East Orange, took place this evening in Kilburn Memorial Church, Newark.

The statement of the First National Bank of Boston for June 30 showed total deposits of $638,227,466 and total assets of $740,731,272, compared, respectively, with $639,830,621 and $744,264,217 on March 31, last. Cash on hand and due.

MONROE WHEELER (who, it will be remembered, organized the exhibition of books Illustrated by artists of our own time, which was held last season at the Museum of Modern Art) visited Picasso in connection with the assembling of material for that

Ninety-five yachts in ten classes sailed in the annual Barnegat Bay Y. R. A. championship regatta of the Ocean Gate Yacht Club today. The smaller craft, which raced in the morning, did not have the breeze that the afternoon classes enjoyed. As a result, after battling for several hours, none of the boats finished within the time limit.
HALF-dollars to commemorate the 300th anniversary of the original Norfolk (Va.) land grant and the 200th anniversary of the creation of Norfolk as a

Deeds filed during the past month in the New York County Register's office show 219 actual sales of Manhattan realty for June, as compared with 192 in May and 194 in June, 1936, according to an analysis prepared by the Real Estate Board of New York.

The Twentieth Century Fund, after a fifteen-month survey, made public a report yesterday urging that the Federal old age pension system be liberalized and terming old age payments to be made under the Social Security Act after 1942 generally "inadequate."

American youth's paramount need today is vocational training, according to the unanimous opinion expressed by 1,200 delegates to the "Model Congress of the United States" dispersing to their respective "constituencies" following a four-day convention in Milwaukee.

Raymond A. Streit, a resident of New Canaan for twenty-five years, died on Thursday night at his home here at the age of 79. Mr. Streit was graduated from Harvard in 1905 and was connected with the H. T. Carey Company of 50 Broadway, New York, for more than twenty-five years.

Riverdale Manor, Inc., Lawrence H. Sanders, president, owner of the Steiner estate in the Riverdale section of the West Bronx, has purchased the adjacent Charles Hensle property of three and one-half acres between Arlington and Independence Avenue,

Paul V. McNutt, United States High Commissioner for the Philippines, became involved in controversy with Filipino political factions today as an outgrowth of references to democracy in his Independence Day speech.

For the second time in three years Germany earned the right to meet the United States in the interzone final of the Davis Cup competition when the combination of Baron Gottfried von Cramm and Heinrich Henkel scored in the doubles today for the third straight victory over Czechoslovakia in the final round of the European competition.

Recent population statistics, according to Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate-Boards, indicate that there is a returning movement to the urban sections by many groups that were forced back to the farming areas during the depression period.
Two University of California students, Julius Heldman of the LOS Angeles Branch, and Robert Harman of Berkeley, became finalists today in the Middle Atlantic tennis tournament.
The Steel Workers Organizing Committee lost its skirmish with "Little Steel" because it failed to win public sympathy and support not only in the strike centers but in the nation at large.

Douglass G. Fonda, Orange, N. J., banker and sportsman, took a big lead for the New York State outboard championship and the Governor Lehman Trophy in the first day's program of the tenth anniversary motor boat regatta today.

The year which sees the twentieth anniversary of the Soviet regime, the inauguration of a new Constitution, and the adoption of a third Five-Year Plan would in any case be a landmark in Russian history.

The Rev. Harold I. Donnelly, Ph. D., of the Princeton Theological Seminary, died suddenly from an acute heart attack in his room at Auburn Theological Campus this morning. He was a guest professor at the Seminary Summer School.
Organization of Canadian workers into unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization seems likely to provide a leading issue if an Ontario provincial election is held this Fall.
HITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va.-This resort celebrates today the 129th anniversary of the construction of the first tavern ever built here in July, 1808.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and Dr. Alexis Carrel have gone beyond their "artificial heart" and have designed machines to test Dr. Carrel's theory that the life of living organs may be restored, The Sunday Express said today.

Miss Lola Elizabeth Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarke Lewis of South Orange, will be married July 31 to Frederick Charles Verinder, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Verinder of South Orange. The ceremony will be performed in First Presbyterian and Trinity Church here by the pastor, the Rev.

A proposal that general criminal law enforcement functions of the Secret Service division of the Treasury Department be merged into the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice has been made by the Brookings Institution in a report to the Senate Select Committee on Federal Government Reorganization, according to Senator Byrd, chairman.

No matter how large Alaska's tourist season is this Summer, it is doubtful if it will equal the one that began on July 18, 1897. On that day, just forty years ago, the news reached the world that there was gold-a great deal of gold--in the Yukon basin.

The seventeenth annual invitation tournament of the Lake Mohonk Tennis Club will get under way tomorrow on the clay courts of the club at Mohonk Lake, N. Y. Competition will be held in singles for men and women, men's doubles and mixed doubles.
WHEN General Manage Edward Johnson somewhat suddenly left these shores early in April during a Metropolitan Opera tour, he expected to be back by the end of last month or the early part of this.

Efforts to prevent any further price advances in 1938 sporting goods lines are now engrossing the attention of manufacturers, who are beginning to lay out the new ranges, according to comment in the local market yesterday.

The release for the first time by the Secretary of Agriculture of a detailed breakdown of quota figures for off-shore sugar entering the United States stresses the effect of the direct consumption quota plan now under review in Congress, according to P. A. Staples.
Glenn C. Lindsley of Marcellus donned the 1937 New York State amateur trapshooting crown today by shattering 200 clay targets in succession.

Rabbi Jacob Bienenfeld, who described himself as representing the Downtown Center, 99 Nassau Street, New York, received a jail sentence of twentyfive days at New Paltz for operating Minobi Camp without a permit from Dr. V. B. Dewit, the local health officer, the State Departsment of Health reported today.
France and Germany today agreed to return to normal trade relations. Two agreements, one defining future commercial relations and the other providing for payments, were signed at the Quai d'Orsay.

Thirty years ago the hired girl on the farm who could not "double in brass" with a milk bucket when the farmer had to start to town early behind Doll and Prince, the frisky bays, to arrive in time to practice his part of the Odd Fellows lodge meeting, did not stay long.

Stanley Reed, Federal Solicitor General, today recommended "compacts to regulate certain interstate activities" as a means of protecting States rights, but expressed grave doubts that such agreements could be consummated.

A recent opinion by Justice Wenzel of the Supreme Court, deciding a case tried in Brooklyn, clarifies, points out Louis Lande, attorney, the Mortgage Maratorium Laws in the provision stating that if the mortgagee could show that the mortgaged property during the six months prior to a court application produced a surplus over and above the taxes, interest and other carrying charges,

A plan for disposing of William K. Vanderbilt's Long Island Mo.tor Parkway bit by bit, as predicted recently by a spokesman for the five public agencies that accepted his offer of the property, was attacked yesterday by the Regional Plan Association, Inc., as "sabotage of a priceless chance to provide an imperatively needed general traffic express highway from the World's Fair to Farmingdale."

Predictions of many property owners and brokers on the West Side that with the many improvements along Riverside Drive and the covering of the New York Central Railroad tracks a return to residential popularity on that thoroughfare would be seen within a short time, have given clear evidences within the past year of being thoroughly verified.

Plans for settling additional thousands of Puerto Rican families on farm lands of their own have been worked out by the Insular Department of Agriculture and Commerce and are proposed as the next step in the extensive program of economic improvement, Governor Blanton Winship reported at Washington.

Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius N. Bliss Jr. and Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. McKim of Westbury and Aiken, S. C., were hosts today at an "old-fashioned picnic" under the historic trees that surround the race track at the Mineola Fair Grounds,

The Pittsfield Riding and Polo Club, of which Donald M. Weston is president, is arranging the eleventh annual horse show which will be held on the polo grounds at Holmesdale Friday and Saturday, July 30 and 31.

Commodore William B. Potts sailed his Barbara to victory in a point race over the South Shrewsbury River course today in a light southeast breeze. Seven other boats of the new Arrow class at the Rumson Country Club started. Judy. ?? by R. Thomas, was second. The summaries:

DOROTHEA DIX was one of that large number of reformers of the midnineteenth century who, in the words of Emerson, gave themselves to "a keener scrutiny of institutions, a sincere protesting against existing evils * * * a restless, prying,
A westbound freight train of the New Jersey Central was wrecked here shortly before 11 o'clock tonight, when one of the cars jumped the track just west of the Bound Brook station.

First of the seeded players to see action, William V. Winslow Jr. of South Orange, No. 1 man on the Princeton varsity and sixth in the draw here, was eliminated by Jack Van Maur of Ridgewood in the open tennis tourney which started at the Glen Ridge Club today.

Several thousand parents and friends of C. M. T. C. students enrolled here for a thirty-day training period are expected to visit the camp tomorrow at the invitation of Colonel Royden E. Beebe, commanding the Eighteenth Infantry, who is in charge of the C. M. T. C. activities.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Evans Hughes Jr. of Riverdale-on-Hudson, N. Y., have taken a Mansion House cottage here for the Summer. Mr. Hughes, son of the Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court, is president of the New York County Bar Association.

As the first anniversary of the civil war draws near, the belief is held in Nationalist territory that only a European war resulting from direct and open foreign intervention in Valencia's favor can prevent General Francisco Franco from winning a clearcut victory by Christmas at the latest-possibly before October.

Victor C. Anderson, magazine cover designer, illustrator and landscape artist, died here yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 195 Battle Avenue. Mr. Anderson, who was 55 years old, had been convalescing after an operation which he underwent on May 19.

Close of play scores in first class English cricket matches started today follow: Essex, 206 for four wickets (Taylor 86, Avery 55) vs. Sussex; at Colchester. Gloucestershire, 107 (Barnett 52, Mayer, seven wickets for 46 runs); Warwickshire, 213 for nine (Wyatt 65); at Birmingham.

Henry Cotton, the man nobody even pretends to know, is ready now to take his place alongside Harry Vardon, Walter Hagen and Bobby Jones among golf's immortals. It has been suspected for several years that Silent Henry belonged in that select circle.

Larry French muffled the Pirate bats in a three-hit pitching performance today to give Chicago a 2-to-0 victory, which squared the Pittsburgh series at one game apiece. A crowd of 8,000 saw the contest.
Colonel Charles Sumner Wentworth of 836 Plain Street, Stoughton, soldier and lumberman, died here this morning at the Homeopathic Hospital after an appenddicitis operation.
Five alienists called by the prosecution reported today that Albert Dyer, confessed slayer of three little Inglewood girls, was sane.
Thomas P. Reynolds, Virginia manager of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, died yesterday in a hospital here at the age of 64.

De Courcy Lawrence Hard Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. De Courcy L. Hard of Cedarhurst, L. I., married Miss Anne Kathryn Fitzsimmons, daughter of Mrs. Robert Fitzsimmons of Bray House, Dublin, Ireland, and the late Mr. Fitzsimmons, yesterday afternoon in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church, Far Rockaway.

The marriage of Miss Marian Miner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Stevens Miner of this place, to James Hobart Warner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hobart G. Warner of Newtown, Conn., took place here this afternoon in St. Peter's Church.

TYPICAL of the enterprise that has been stirring the Columbia Company of late is the engagement of the WPA band of Madrigal Singers who this month have been graduated from single disks to an album set in

The strange disappearance in November of Arthur Blanton and his son had a new turn today when the Sheriff of Cameron County had a special investigator for Willacy County arrested and put in jail here.

Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. of Oyster Bay has appointed Mrs. Harold W. Hastings of this city chairman of a committee planning for the entertainment of one hundred Girl Guides and Girl Scouts from twenty or more nations who will arrive in New York early in August.

Hillcrest Camp, a unit of the Girls' Service League establishment near Salisbury, Conn., will be the beneficiary of a fashion show to be held on Thursday at the Wake Robin Inn, Lakeville, Conn. Summer costumes will be displayed by the Misses Joan Curtiss,

PRECISELY a hundred years having passed since Queen 'Victoria's accession to the Throne, Laurence Housman's play, "Victoria Regina," has been licensed by the Lord Chamberlain for public performance in England, and was publicly performed at the beginning of this week.
Inconsequential as ten seconds may sometimes be in yacht racing, that scant margin on the' right side of the time limit was enough to give Caprice a victory in the Interclub Class today.

Mrs. William Clifton Dodd, the former Miss Isabella Ruth Eakin, retired missionary from the Siam Mission of the Presbyterian Church, U. S. A., died last Sunday in her home at Johnstown, a., according to a report yesterday by the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, here. She was 76 years old.
For the first time in many years amateur motor-paced bicycle races will be held tonight at the Coney island Velodrome. The amateur motor-paced event will be the feature attraction of the card.

Mr. and Mrs. John L. M. Rutherford gave a cocktail party at the Montauk Yacht Club this afternoon for the group of aviation enthusiasts here on the annual cruise of the Aviation Country Club, members of which are staying at Montauk Manor for three days.

Mrs. Anna Acker Kipp, 57-year-old widow, committed suicide last night or early today by drowning herself in Purdy's Lake, about 800 feet from her home on Croton Dam Road. Mr. and Mrs. John Searles, relatives with whom she lived, summoned police when the widow's collie dog returned from the direction of the lake this morning, carrying her pocketbook.

The system of pensions for railway workers recently established as a result of enactment of the Railroad Retirement and Railway Tax Laws affords the most comprehensive system for providing against age or disability in existence, according to the Association of American Railroads.

Southern railroads today petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission to reconsider its proposed lower freight rates on iron and steel between the North and South, holding that the new charges would cause them to lose more than $500,000 a year.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Gregory John Spohrer of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Jane Spohrer, to Robert McCullough Saville, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Saville of Maplewood.

The marriage or Miss Dora Harriett Kelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David John Kelly, to Charles Arthur Sullivan, son of Peter Sullivan of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Sullivan, took place here this morning in the Church of Our Lady of Mercy. The Rev. Thomas J. Corbett performed the ceremony and was the celebrant of the nuptial mass which followed.
The coming week finds the usual Summer crowd augmented by some 10,000 dentists and their wives here to attend the 79th annual convention of the American Dental Association.

Holding little hope for Amelia Earhart, navy fliers from the battleship Colorado scanned the Phoenix Islands today while the aircraft carrier Lexington with 300 aviators hurried on for a "last chance" survey of the South Pacific area, where she disappeared eight days ago.

Roy Harris,. 22-year-old surfman attached to the Ditch Plains Coast Guard Station, and Walter Bailey, 19, of Montauk, were injured fatally late last night when their automobile overturned and crashed into a telephone pole on Montauk Highway west of Montauk Village.
Secretary Roper said today that landings and take-offs at the Washington airport during the next sixty days "must remain a responsibility" of individual airline pilots.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Freybe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl E. Freybe of this place, to John King Roosa Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John King Roosa of Scarsdale, N. Y., took place at noon today in the garden of her parents' home.
Miss Evelyn Beyer has been appointed head teacher for the newly established nursery school of Sarah Lawrence College, here, it was announced today.

Wellinformed circles report that the government is about to place orders, probably in Europe, for the construction of two cruisers equipped with the latest-type guns to meet the demands of naval authorities, who stress that there must be no delay in strengthening the sea force.
With big hay and grain crops maturing and with prospects for large Fall crops, including potatoes, Oneida County farmers are worrying about the hired-man problem.
Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan signed today an order approving payment to creditors of the Jefferson Trust Company of Hoboken of a second dividend, one of 5 per cent, amounting to $99,734.

Former Municipal Court Justice Frederick Spiegelberg of 25 East Seventy-seventh Street died yesterday in the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a fortnight's illness which included an operation performed a week ago.

A prediction that the route along the New York Central's West Side tracks may eventually be built up industrially on the same scale as the right of way along Park Avenue is now developed residentially was made yesterday- by Frederick E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad.

The Holy Office tonight convicted the Rev. Father Raffaele Codipietro, a parish priest of Paganico Sabine, Diocese of Rieti, of "sacrilege" and excommunicated him on charges of faking a miracle in his church July 26, 1936.

The history of the British Empire contains many confessions of error and many sudden reversals of policy but none more sweeping than the partition of Palestine proposed by Earl Peel's royal commission and now approved by the British Government.

IF, as some historians assert, the early Dutch settlers got the bet ter of the bargain when the Indians sold them Manhattan Island for $24 and a few odd pieces of European jewelry, this is the year of retribution.

Fourteen houses in various sections of Long Island are under construction by N. Boyce Jenkins, builder. In Hempstead, he is building a group of ten houses on the Ingraham Estate on Front Street. They will sell in the $11,000 to [Pound]15,000 price range.

BIG goings on are going on these days. For the second time within the month we have been vouchsafed the excitement of a Lunt-Fontanne opening. That notable pair returned to give Angelenos a brief glimpse of themselves and company in "Amphitryon 38."
Members of the Princeton University Geology Department, engaging in field projects this Summer, will travel thousands of miles in Europe and North America.

Football fans throughout the nation start moving en masse from the stands to the coaches' bench tomorrow. Balloting opens to select the squad of collegiate aces to oppose the champion Green Bay Packers in the fourth annual all-star-professional battle at Soldier Field the night of Sept. 1-and from tomorrow on until the opening kick-off whistle the fans will be in complete charge.

PICTURES by artists of the last century, elder academicians, primitives and young modernists mingle in the Summer show of paintings and sculpture which opened last week at the Ferargil Galleries. Typical canvases by Homer, Ryder, Luke,

To provide the young architect with wider experience and knowledge in the arts of design. Dean Leopold Arnaud of the Columbia University School of Architecture announces that at the opening of the new academic year in the Fall a laboratory will be established for research in design correlation.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman signed an order yesterday requiring James B. Carey, president of the C. I. O. United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, and James Garry, president of Local 1,221 of the same organization, to appear before him tomorrow morning and show cause why they should not be restrained

President Roosevelt left today on a week-end cruise on Chesapeake Bay on the Presidential yacht Potomac for a trip combining business and pleasure. Leaving the White House in the forenoon, he motored to Annapolis, where he boarded the yacht.
The Pan-American Odontological Association was organized today at a meeting of representatives of thirty-three dental colleges in North and South America at the Hotel Chelsea.
ONE year ago today the Triborough Bridge, New York City's greatest single highway engineering project, was formally opened by President Roosevelt, Mayor La Guardia and a group of civic leaders.

Persons who have followed the rapid march of labor for the last four years under the encouragement of the New Deal will readily warn against drawing any conclusion from recent happenings that President Roosevelt and his administration are contemplating a change in their labor policy.

FROM SEDAN TO STRESA. By Victor L. and Marguerite Hall Aibjerg. 8vo. New York: D. Van Notrnd Co. 14.50. A history of Europe since 1870. THE GREATEST AMERICAN WOMAN. By Lloyd C. M. re. 8vo. New York: The Amerlean Historical Society, Inc. The life of Lucretia Mott, founder of the woman's rights movement in America and England.
Charles Elliott Peck, a member of the insurance brokerage firm of H. F. G. Wey Herrick, 25 Cedar Street, New York, died at his home here last night of a heart attack. He was 46 years old.
Mrs. Christian Heidt and her son, Vice Commodore William John Heidt 2d of Brielle, were hosts at a tea after the second weekly regatta at the Manasquan River Yacht Club this afternoon.
Miss Isabelle Hallin, 26-year-old high school teacher who is fighting to keep her job, collapsed today from "mental strain" and was ordered to a hospital.

With the Chandler bill to amend the Bankruptcy Law scheduled to come to the floor of the House of Representatives tomorrow or Tuesday, and with passage very likely, credit executives here said yesterday that its approval by the Senate depends on whether that body will remain in session after clearing up the Supreme Court legislation.

Wellinformed circles report that the government is about to place orders, probably in Europe, for the construction of two cruisers equipped with the latest-type guns to meet the demands of naval authorities, who stress that there must be no delay in strengthening the sea force.
With big hay and grain crops maturing and with prospects for large Fall crops, including potatoes, Oneida County farmers are worrying about the hired-man problem.
Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan signed today an order approving payment to creditors of the Jefferson Trust Company of Hoboken of a second dividend, one of 5 per cent, amounting to $99,734.

Former Municipal Court Justice Frederick Spiegelberg of 25 East Seventy-seventh Street died yesterday in the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a fortnight's illness which included an operation performed a week ago.

A prediction that the route along the New York Central's West Side tracks may eventually be built up industrially on the same scale as the right of way along Park Avenue is now developed residentially was made yesterday- by Frederick E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad.

The Holy Office tonight convicted the Rev. Father Raffaele Codipietro, a parish priest of Paganico Sabine, Diocese of Rieti, of "sacrilege" and excommunicated him on charges of faking a miracle in his church July 26, 1936.

The history of the British Empire contains many confessions of error and many sudden reversals of policy but none more sweeping than the partition of Palestine proposed by Earl Peel's royal commission and now approved by the British Government.

Disclosing heavy profits by municipally owned electric plants, the Public Service Commission of New York State has demanded recently, in what is considered to be the first action of such a broad nature, reductions of electric rates in more than a score of communities.

Mrs. Otto Hahn, president of the Home Makers Forum and of the Rainy Day Club of America, will discuss "Children's Rights" at the opening program tomorrow afternoon of the second week of the Chautauqua Woman's Club at Chautauqua, N. Y.

The marriage of Miss Louisa Sprague Munroe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Munroe of New York and Litchfield, to Ross Johnston Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frazer Harris of Harston, Chestnut Hill, Pa., took place this afternoon in St. Michael's Episcopal Church here.
The all-Russian program offered by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Fritz Reiner at the Lewisohn Stadium last night was heard by an enthusiastic audience of 4,500.

Miss Alice Redner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Redner of Highland Falls, N. Y., was married to Walter Wynne, son of John Wynne of Jamaica, Queens, yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Joseph Tytheridge.

President Roosevelt left today on a week-end cruise on Chesapeake Bay on the Presidential yacht Potomac for a trip combining business and pleasure. Leaving the White House in the forenoon, he motored to Annapolis, where he boarded the yacht.
The Pan-American Odontological Association was organized today at a meeting of representatives of thirty-three dental colleges in North and South America at the Hotel Chelsea.

Faithful Maud, 5-year-old mare owned by J. C. Long, captured the $1,000 Mazatlan Handicap today, romping the five and one-half furlongs in 1:05, only a fifth of a second off the track record set in 1930 by Nusakan Eight thousand fans saw the event.

There is no manner of connection between the cloud of red dust Dr. Howard Shapley discovers coloring the stars at the North Pole and the camp lately established by Soviet airmen at the top of the world. The blur in the sky is cosmic dust, perhaps the reflection of disturbances in other worlds than ours;

Dominating the finals of the Ohio State tennis tournament Frank Kovacs, 17-year-old star from Oakland, Calif., added his name to the list of Golden Gate netsters who have captured Ohio tennis laurels by winning the men's singles crown today.
In the face of bad weather forecasts another Soviet airplane took off from Moscow at 3:23 this morning [8:23 P. M. Sunday, New York time] on the adventurous route over the North Pole.

Musical activities of the Federal Music Project at the WPA Theatre of Music were resumed last night with a concert given by the Federal Symphony Orchestra, under Graham Harris, guest conductor, with Herma Menth, pianist, as soloist.
Four WPA recreation instructors, dropped from the Federal relief rolls on July 1, are voluntarily reporting for work six days a week at two Mount Kisco playgrounds, it- was learned today.

Reduction in steel tariffs has been heartily welcome to British steel producers. The duties were imposed when the industry was struggling desperately against the effects of the world depression and foreign competition, but in the remarkable change that in the last year has come over the steel industry, not only in this country but abroad, the renewed prosperity is threatened by a rapidly growing scarcity of material.

Julius Heldman, 17-year-old southpaw from the University of California at Los Angeles, today defeated Robert Harman, University of California, for the Middle States lawn tennis championship at the Germantown Cricket Club, 6--3, 6-2, 1-6, 2-6, 6-2.

Mrs. Genevieve Magee, widow of Walter Magee, formerly a Representative from the Syracuse area, died at Bellevue Hospital at 2:40 P. M. yesterday, about an hour after she had been taken to the hospital from the Hotel Willard, 262 West Seventy-sixth Street, where she became ill.
It is impossible to find out exactly, but fairly widespread opinion here is that the rate of the pound will be brought down to 125 francs.
The Pirates overcame rain and injury today to drop the Cubs, 3-2, in the rubber game of their three-day series.

A drive to close all grocery and delicatessen shops in the city On Sunday was under way yesterday. With police cooperation, two organizations, one economic and the other religious, were pushing the campaign.
The statement of the condition of the Banca di Napoll Trust Company of New York as of June 30, last, shows deposits of $17,113,251; resources, $21,058,268; cash items, $6,743,944;

Plans went forward today for reopening of steel plants, while the Committee for Industrial Organization's suit to enjoin the use of National Guardsmen in Ohio strike territory neared a showdown in Federal District Court at Columbus.

Again the smaller States of the Near and Middle East are setting an excellent example of international cooperation. The Balkan Entente, organized in February, 1934, by Turkey, Greece, Rumania and Yugoslavia, was followed last Thursday by the Middle Eastern Entente of four Moslem countriesTurkey, Iraq, Iran and Afghanistanconcluded through the signature of a pact of non-aggression, friendship and consultation.

Fully 1,000 persons who attended last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Fritz Reiner, left the Stadium when the storm arose and stood for half an hour outside the doors of the Great Hall of City College, waiting in the heavy downpour for some one to find the keys and let them in.

A sharp rise in net income in May and the first five months of this year, compared with the corresponding periods of last year, was revealed yesterday in the report of the New York Central Railroad Company, including all leased lines.

Donald Hawley of East Orange, tennis champion of New Jersey, won his fourth successive Mountain Lakes Club invitation title today by defeating John Curtiss, Cornell University mathematics instructor, 2-6, 7-5, 6-0, 6-4.

Six "enemy" airplanes which (theoretically) were attempting an aerial attack on the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation were declared wrecked by barrages from anti-aircraft guns of Battery B, Sixty-second Coast Artillery, Fort Totten, in a demonstration at 4 o'clock yesterday at the reservation.
Incorporation papers are on file in the Monroe County Clerk's office for The Rochester Daily Press Corportion, which is expected to print an afternoon paper.

Analyzing some phases of the building activity in New York City during the first half of this year, Myron L. Matthews of the Dow Service says that despite an increase of 151/2 per cent over the first half-year period of 1936 the figures this year fall short by about 10 per cent of the expected volume.

Miss Ida Sledge, 28-year-old society woman labor organizer, twice evicted from Tupelo in three weeks, claimed Federal protection today as a National Labor Relations Board witness and announced she would return here tonight on tomorrow.
The Monmouth County Country Club chalked up its fifth straight Eastern Polo League victory today by turning back the Fort Hamilton quartet, 11 to 7.

The need for better understanding between nations and individuals was stressed yesterday in a sermon by the Rev. Arthur Klep, pastor of the Immanuel Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Eighty-eighth Street.
The Baltimore Orioles divided today's double-header with Newark, the Bears winning the first, 11 to 10, but dropping the nightcap, 4 to 3.
Fellowships for study at Harvard University next year under the Department of Government's program or preparation for the public service have been awarded to six college graduates.

The failure of public officials to laws by the government itself must inevitably produce vigilante activities, the Rev. John Walter Houck, pastor of the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse at 175th Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

High Commissioner Paul V. McNutt held a conference with several Manila publishers on news reports of his Independence Day speech in which he was quoted as saying democracy in the Philippines was "only a matter of form and not of substance." His words had caused a public flare-up.
Canada apparently has achieved the draft of a new trade agreement with New Zealand to replace that negotiated at Ottaw- in 1932.

Marcia van Dresser, American soprano, died here today after a long illness. Born in Memphis, Tenn., Miss van Dresser attended the local schools and later studied music under Mrs. Robinson-Duff. Hermine Bosetti and Jean de Reszke.

Edward Eugene Loomis, former president of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company and recently chairman of the board and of the finance and executive committee, died today at his Summer home, Holiday Farm,

While congestion was apparent at times here last week in July oats, the near approach of the movement of the new grain caused some liquidation late in the week, and the close yesterday, at 42 cents a bushel, showed a net loss of 21/4 cents, compared with a week before.

Mrs. Mabel E. Bedell, Republican County Committee member for fourteen years and recently appointed Deputy Probation Officer of Suffolk County, died this afternoon at Dr. King's Hospital following an operation.
Two hundred and fifty Lambs held their annual "washing" on the grounds of the Percy Williams Home here today, making merry at aquatic events, field sports and golf.
Eudora Louise Graves, 2-year-old "infant wonder," counts up to 100, has a vocabulary of some 2,000 words and can recite nursery rhymes.

The experiment which seven of the former burlesque houses of the city are beginning today is certain to be watched with interest. Not too much importance Will be attached to the change in name from " burlesque houses " to " variety revues ": the principle of a rose by any other name applies here as elsewhere.

Jacob P. Muller, president of the J. P. Muller Advertising Agency, 512 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday in the New York Hospital from the effects of a series of strokes, the first of which occurred two and a half years ago. Mr. Muller, who lived in Elmhurst, Queens, was born in Germany sixty-three years ago.
Pension proposals will be considered at the annual encampment of the New York Department of Spanish War Veterans, which opened here tonight.
The little dog almost all of whose life was devoted to being ghost to another dog is dead. The demure cocker spaniel who took the

Bequests in New York City for philanthropic purposes totaled $69,204,755 in the first six months of this year, against $5,406,607 in the same period in 1936, according to a survey made public yesterday by the John Price Jones Corporation. Gifts in this city for the same 1937 period totaled $24,812,767, compared with $19,206,069 in the 1936 period.

Confirmation of Vatican reports that the Pope's health is better at present than it has been at any time since he was taken ill was obtained today when he broadcast an address over the Vatican wireless containing a blessing to thousands of Catholics gathered in Lisieux, France.

Ordinary revenue of the Dominion of Canada for June was $36,668,896 and special receipts brought the total to $36,977,726, compared with $33,601,440 for June, 1936, according to 'figures issued tonight by the Controller of the Treasury.

Scientific materialism and cut-throat business ethics have stilled the song of religious courage and aspiration, declared the Rev. Dr. Charles Reynblds Brown, dean emeritus of the Yale Divinity School, in a sermon yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

Five one-act plays, presented by children representing playgrounds in the five boroughs, were presented in competition yesterday on the Mall in Central Park. The affair, which drew nearly 500 spectators despite the heat, was the grand finale of a city-wide drama competition, in which some 275 playground units took part under the auspices of the Park Department.
Douglas G. Fonda, Orange, N. J., sportsman and outboard pilot extraordinary, made a clean sweep of the tenth anniversary Geneva Power Boat Regatta which ended today.

Referring to the Brazilian-United States trade negotiations, the trade press here quotes utterances in Rio de Janeiro to the effect that Brazil will turn its face more and more toward the United States and less toward Europe but comments that the United States will not be able to take Germany's place as a customer of Brazil.

While the average New Yorker merely mops his brow and prays for rain, those Broadway children who are most concerned with box-offices are beginning to get a little alarmed. Business in the theatre isn't what it was a week ago, and last Saturday night it was worse than in a long, long time, for despite each show's frantic boast of air-cooling, the public simply stayed home and had itself a shower.

Rear Admiral Adolphus Eugene Watson and Mrs. Watson have arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria from Washington. Mrs. George A. Gordon left the Ambassador yesterday for Washington to join her husband, the United States Minister to Haiti.
Although victorious in only one of the two heats, Edgar Dodson of Baltimore captured the unlimited event for speed boats, the feature of the Maryland Yacht Club's annual regatta which closed today.
Foreign ex change rates dropped considerably at the beginning of the week. Improvement in the franc rate, however, continued almost without interruption.

Akim (Durable Malloy) Tamiroff picks himself out of the elevator pit where "The King of Gamblers" left his broken body last week and scampers right back into the Criterion to play the charmingly sinister Mr. G. of "The Great Gambini."

Net assets of $51,702,642 have been reported by the Tri-Continental Corporation as of June 30, equivalent to $4,511.57 for each $1,000 of bank loans and debentures, to $265.27 a share of preferred stock, and to $10.32 a share on the common issue. Net assets as of Dec.

Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L. I., and Mrs. Frederick P. Davis of Providence fired three birdies at Miss Jean Bauer of Providence and Miss Virginia Guilfoil of Syracuse, N. Y., after rounding the turn, to win the annual best-ball exhibition, 5 and 3, today at the Shenecossett Country Club.
Soaring prices for hogs lost a large part of their influence on lard futures here last week, the continued slow reduction in supplies in cold storage being the main factor.
Police began a State-wide hunt today for Joseph Dumorad, 20, wanted for questioning in connection with the killing of a 16-year high school girl and orphan in the home where both lived.
Republican leaders of the five counties are expected to start conferences this week on whether they should designate Mayor La Guardia as the party's candidate for re-election.

Indefinite suspension of publication of the morning Decatur Herald and the afternoon Decatur Review was announced tonight by Edward Lindsay, editor, as a result of the strike begun by the American Newspaper Guild yesterday.
Richard C. du Pont of Wilmington tonight was declared American soaring champion, and received the $1,500 silver Evans trophy as the eighth annual soaring contest closed.

Decision on the sale of the Paramount studios in the center of Hollywood and the erection of a new $5,000,000 plant in the suburbs will be made in New York this week with the arrival there of Barney Balaban, president of Paramount Pictures, Inc., and Stanton Griffis, chairman of its executive committee, it was learned today.

Boy Scout luncheon of the British Club, Hotel Gotham, 12:30 P. M. Guests will include Sir Gerald Campbell, City Court Justice Charles W. Froessel, Percy Jackson, chairman of Manhattan Boy Scouts, and W. W. Pouch of the Boy Scout Foundation of New York.

The Fokine Ballet, featuring Patricia Bowman, appeared before an audience of 4,000 at Jones Beach Stadium last night. By a stroke of luck the storm did not start there until just after the performance was finished, so that the entire program was given as announced.

A man who had been struck by a bolt of lightning, but who appeared to have suffered no worse injuries than bruises of the forehead, coupled with partial amnesia, was taken to Morrisania Hospital in the Bronx during last night's storm.

Health conditions in the State in May, as reported today by Dr. J. V. De Porte, director of the Division of Vital Statistics of the State Health Department, indicated a decided rise in the birth rate and an exceptionally low mortality rate in many classifications.

There would be no more wars, according to Prime Minister Michael J. Savage of New Zealand, if the ablebodied men of the world were employed at decent salaries, because the workers would refuse to fight.

The American Federation of Investors, Inc., said today that enactment of the power development provisions of the Norris Regional Planning Bill would destroy "billions of dollars" of private investments and add heavily to the tax burden.

The Seattle Star management today renewed its invitation to striking American Newspaper Guild members to return to their jobs, but the Guild opened strike headquarters and gave no indication a settlement was in prospect. E. W.

The enlargement and improvement of the Saratoga race course, the oldest in the country, underwent official inspection today by the officers and directors of the Saratoga Association and members of the press.

With motor car production this year expected to reach the 5,000,000 mark, the second largest figure on record, advertising expenditures in the automotive field, including accessory makers, gasoline and oil companies and tire manufacturers, will come close to the 1929 figure, which, however, was exceeded by the 1930 advertising total, according to estimates in the industry.

ACHERLY--At her home, 210 Warburton Ave., Yonkers, Saturday, July 10, 1937, Carrie Pauline Dailey, wife of the late Orville B. Ackerly. Services private at Havey's Funeral Home, 107 North Broadway, Yonkers, Monday, July 12. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Kindly omit flowers.

The possibility of a strike on the B. M. T. system was revived yesterday when the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers served notice on the City Industrial Relations Board that it would "resist to the last" any effort to include the company's motormen in the collective bargaining referendum demanded by the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. 0. affiliate.

America can best stay out of war by keeping its armed forces within its own borders and by limiting the use of the American flag to government-owned ships, Major Gen. Smedley D. Butler, Marine Corps, retired, said today in dedicating a war memorial at Laurel Grove Memorial Park, Totowa Borough.
An impressive funeral was held this morning for the four victims of the explosion in the boiler room of the destroyer Almirante Villar yesterday morning while the ship was in Callao harbor.

24th St, 125-127 E. 45x98.9; Metropolitan Life Ins Co to Beechview Gardens, Inc, 50 Court St, Brooklyn, care I. Schneider ($75). 45th St, a s, 150 w of 2d Ave, 127x100.5, facing on 44th St, 30 ft; Isidore Faitt to Vanderburg Realty Corp. 32 Broadway, care of J. W. Collopy Jr, consideration $5.000, foreclosure; a first mtg of $1,050,000, as reduced.

The problem of what man shall do with the vast power that science has placed in his hanes was discussed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox, chaplain of Columbia University, at the first of the university's Summer session sermons in St. Paul's Chapel.

Marked advances for the cause of labor and civil liberties are stressed by the American Civil Liberties Union in its annual survey, published yesterday, on the status of civil liberties in this country.

A total of 727 conventions, trade exhibitions and selling shows held in this city during the twelve months ended on April 30 attracted an aggregate attendance of 550,000, according to the annual report of the convention bureau of the Merchants Association, made public yesterday.

MORNING EVENTS Class 61, Hunter Hacks-First, Mrs. Edward Lasker's ch. g. Fair Edgar; second, Mrs. Harry Frank Jr.'s b. g. Our Way; third, Miss Wilhelmine S. Kirby's ch. g. Easter Morning: fourth, Claredda Farm's ch. g. Vassal Star; fifth, Morton Govern's ch. g. Hard Lines.
Exports for the first four months of this year amounted to 878,985 tons, valued at 100,813,379 soles, the highest figure recorded for that period in ten years.

SHANGHAI--China warned Japan she would not tolerate increase of alien troops on her soil and infringement of her sovereignty, saying such actions would cause her to take "defensive measures." Large contingents of troops were moved northward. Page 1.

George Gershwin had a unique position in American music, one due in part to his wholly exceptional gifts and in part to a special set of circumstances which raised him in less than five years from the rank of a song plugger in Tin Pan Alley to that of a composer whose works invaded symphony concert programs and operatic auditoriums and made him internationally famous.
