A driving thunderstorm sent the mercury tumbling 12 degrees between 8:30 and 9 o'clock last night, giving the heat-oppressed the first real relief since the start of the five-day torrid wave that has scorched the nation from the West Coast to the Atlantic seaboard.
Members of the Aluminum Workers Union voted "almost unanimously" tonight to end their strike and return to work tomorrow morning at the fabricating mill of the Aluminum Company of America.

American European Securities Company: June 30-Based on market value, net assets were equal to $11.64 a share on 354,000 shares of common stock outstanding. Net profit first half of year was $167,879, after all charges and taxes and including a loss of $2,162 from the sale of securities.

First appointments to the medical board and staff of Welfare Hospital for the chronic sick, which will be a teaching and research center for Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, Cornell University Medical College and New York University College of Medicine, were announced yesterday by Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals.

(Figures in parentheses indicate par) Bayside (71)--First round for President's Cup: Dr. R. Pepino defeated H. Hoitz, 3 and 2; M. C. Girr defeated Robert Rome, 3 and 2. Brookville (72)--Medal play handicap, Class A: R. W. Dill, 80-8-72; A. Wright, 81-8-73. Class B: H. J. Murphy, 82-14-68; D. T. May, 95-22-73.

The seventh Annual Aviation Cruise ended this evening at the Montauk Yacht Club at Montauk, L. I,, when the amateur sportsman pilots of a score of planes taxied up to the shore, after a week-end spent cruising over Long Island and Cape Cod.

Several clashes occurred today between striking cafe employes and police on guard in front of the cafes trying to continue operation. Most of the trouble centered around the Montmartre section where strikers rushed cafes, overturning tables and upsetting glassware.

Rookie Lou Fette today bested the veteran Sylvester Johnson in a 13-inning pitching duel as the Bees scored a 1-to-0 victory in the second game of a doubleheader. In the opener the Phillies reached two Bee hurlers for sixteen hits to win, 10 to 4.

Mr, and Mrs. Walter Gurnee Dyer entertained at Farmlands today in observance of their wedding anniversary. Miss Aerielle Frazer entertained a large number of young friends with a luncheon at her home.

The week's stock market here was quiet, although the tendency was exceptionally firm. This was most apparent in the steels, machineries, textiles, minor breweries and securities of the real estate corporations, certain among the last-named netting sizable gains.

International peace is attainable, dependent only on the acceptance and application of the principle that States, no less than individuals, are bound by and must observe the basic moralities in their relations with each other, the Rev.

Anticipating prompt issuance of licenses today, or by tomorrow at the latest, the. owners of seven theatres that housed the now taboo burlesque were preparing yesterday to open for business with new "variety revues" as soon as the licenses were issued.
Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, disembarked here from the Conte di Savoia today for a tour of Italy. Authorities of the port welcomed her with a bouquet of orchids.

The Chaconne String Quartet, composed of Irving Fink and Leon Rudin, violins; Ernest Biel, viola, and Mark Skalmer, 'cello, will give a concert tonight at 8:30 o'clock in McMillin Academic Theatre, as a feature of the musical program of the Columbia University Summer Session.

The Ford Motor Company has awarded to the Koppers Company a contract for the construction of an additional battery of sixty-one coke ovens at Ford's River Rouge plant at Dearborn, Mich., it was announced yesterday.
Jersey City took both ends of a double-header with Syracuse today to earn a 4-to-2 edge for the sixgame series. The sccres were 6--3 and 3-2.

Free trips to Europe went begging on Capitol Hill today as a result of the court bill fight. A law provides that three Senators and three Representatives shall accompany the battle monuments commission, headed by General John J. Pershing, to Europe this Summer to dedicate monuments erected on World War battlefields.

No precise Information is available as to the amount of foreign exchange purchases negotiated by the equalization fund but the latest report of the Bank of France easily permits one to calculate the fiscal situation on July 1.

Professor Irving Fisher's Index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 92.9, which compares with 92.5 the week before, 92 two weeks before, 91.9 three weeks before and 92 four weeks before.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,851,374,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:
Stocks higher on week in slightly more active trading; turnover, 4,993,220 shares. All classes of bonds advanced moderately; transactions $37,870,300.

Approximately ninety contests in seven sports have been arranged for the University of Maryland athletes for the 1937-38 season. The sports involved are football, basketball, track, lacrosse, boxing, baseball and tennis, with the schedules practically complete for every one but the last named snort.
There is still a great need for the crusading spirit in the world, the Rev. Thornton B. Penfield Jr. declared in a sermon yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.

United States Minister George L. Messersmith, recalled to Washington to become Assistant Secretary of State, left Vienna today with his wife amid the general regrets of Austrians and the American colony.

JOHN T. McINTYRE has written another "conversation piece." His novel "Ferment" (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50) is a book of talk, with its language fresh made in the streets, the hole-incorner offices, the boarding houses, at the taxicab stands and in the cafeterias and workrooms of Philadelphia.

With thousands of Boy Scouts from the Washington Jamboree still swarming over the city and many of them showing alarming propensities for setting out on their own, the Boy Scout Guide Service at 2 Park Avenue remained one of the busiest spots in New York yesterday.
The government collected $1,132,295,725 more of internal taxes in the fiscal year ended June 30 than in the preceding fiscal year, Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, announced today.

An afternoon of baseball at Ebbets Field yesterday that started with a fist fight between Buddy Hassett and Cliff Melton ended in the falling dusk with Colonel Bill Terry's Giants victorious over the Dodgers in both ends of a doublebeader, 10-4 and 5-1.

A woman who had been strangled with one of her own stockings was found dead in bed in a room of the Hotel Courte at 15 East Twentyfirst Street yesterday. She appeared to be about 32 years old, five feet four inches tall, and 130 pounds in weight; had chestnut hair and a dark complexion.
Film friends rallied to the support of John Montague today as he awaited an extradition hearing on an Essex County (N. Y.) indictment charging him with a $700 robbery in 1930.

The Reds bowled over five Cardinal I pitchers for twenty-nine hits today, while two of their hurlers were doing a good shut-out job, enabling the Reds to take both games of a double-header, 6 to 0 and 7 to 0.
The Beehive Building Loan Association bought in at foreclosure the two-story brick dwelling at 36 Bayview Avenue, Jersey City, in satisfaction of a mortgage in the sum of $2,574.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

The South Shore Polo Club and the 101st Cavalry quartet of Huntington met in the inaugural clash of the Long Island Polo League today at Hazard Field, with the former reg. istering a 7-1 verdict. R. L. Meek's drive through the goal posts in the fourth prevented the Suffolk four from being blanked.

Making a clean sweep of the three doubles tests, the Travers Yacht Club tennis team of Hastings-onHudson downed the New York Athletic Club netmen, 6-3, on the latter's courts at Travers Island yesterday. The summaries:

After weeks of negotiation, collective agreements in the coat and suit industry, reached last Saturday, will be- formally signed this afternoon, ending the stoppage of 35,000 workers in more than 1,500 shops, in effect since last Thursday.
Delegates from Jewish communities in fourteen States will meet here tomorrow under the auspices of the American Jewish Congress to plan a program to aid the Jews of Poland.

Delayed press messages from Las Casas in the State of Chiapas report that Catholics on Friday reopened by force several churches and that on the following day Federal troops arrested eight on a charfPe of promoting riots.
While preparations were made for war in North China, high official circles expressed the belief that the clashes near Peiping would be speedily settled on local basis.

Conditions in the London gold market are as quiet now as they were turbulent before. Sales have been reduced greatly and one day this week the sterling price of gold actually stood at a premium on the United States parity.
William E. Dodge Stokes is visiting his aunt, Mrs. Anson Phelps Stokes, at Brook Farm, Stockbridge. Mrs. Stokes gave a picnic tonight on Bald Head Mountain.

Cotton prices made substantial advances last week on developments in the new domestic crop. A minor proportion of these gains was lost on Saturday, but the closing quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances for the week of 29 to 40 points.
Mrs. Caroline Goldsmith Childs, clubwoman and widow of State Senator John Lewis Childs, died yesterday at her home here, 91 Tulip Avenue, after a short illness. She was 70 years old.

Time was when the mountain wall separating France and Italy was a bastion, practically impregnable. It has never been seriously fortified. In the last war, owing to the immediate declaration of Italian neutrality, it was left open from the very outbreak of hostilities.
Miss Natalja Willard, whose marriage to Captain James C. White, U. S. A., Twelfth Infantry, will be one of the outstanding events in Newport next month.

Mrs. Dickson Watts, Mrs. Jules M. Elliott, in 230 E. 73d St.; Charles A. Kahl, in 39 5th Ave.; Mrs. Jean Starr Untermeyer, in 225 E. 73d St.; Harold Higginson, Richard E. Bright, in 302 W. 12th St.; Malcolm E. Wyckoff, Boyd A. Bennett, in 59 W. 12th St.; Harry C. Kane, in 150 W. 79th St.: Bing Bing. Inc.. broker.
Charles Esdale, actor, died on Saturday in St. Luke's Hospital of a complication of diseases. He was 64 years old and lived at 226 West Fiftieth Street.

Several hundred dismissed WPA workers will leave Irving Plaza, Irving Place and Fifteenth Street, at 11:30 A. M. today on the first of a series of "mass job hunts" through the financial and business districts Oscar R. Fuss, executive secretary of the City Projects Council, announced yesterday.

Threats to the lotus beds in Sodus Bay, on the south shores of Lake Ontario, caused by dock construction, by boats and by sight-seers picking the blooms, have brought an appeal for their preservation from Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner.

East Side apartment rental activity is continuing well into the Summer season, declares Douglas L. Elliman, head of the realty firm bearing his name, who reports that his organization closed 378 leases in the East Side residential area during the month of June.
Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:
The debate on the compromise Judiciary Reorganization Bill will enter its second week in the Senate tomorrow with both sides as determined to 'fight to a finish' as when they started.

Stuart Brooks, Inc., who will occupy the premises as a unit in its chain of ladies' shoe stores, leased the business building at 164-04 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, L. I., from the Jamaica Puntine Street Corporation. The aggregate rental on the long-term lease is reported as more than $200,000.

In one of the most thrilling polo contests witnessed at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn, Evergreen Farms of Eatontown, N. J., defeated the First Division four, 10--9, yesterday in a battle between unbeaten rivals in the Eastern League's low-goal competition.

A retirement system for Protestant Episcopal Church employes, who are excluded from the Federal social security system, is under contemplation by the Church Life Insurance Corporation, a subsidiary of the Church Pension Fund, of which William Fellowes Morgan is president and J. P. Morgan treasurer.
They sent the wrong kind of seed wheat to the colonists of the Matanuska Valley. Winter wheat instead of Spring wheat was parceled out to the government's colonists and planted by them.

After finishing fourth in the first race of a series conducted by the International Star Class fleet of Great South Bay to select a crew to represent it in the forthcoming North Atlantic and international championships, Horace Havemeyer Sr. today defeated William Picken, the leading point scorer. As a result Havemeyer now trails Picken by two points.

Steel makers continue to produce at the best rate permitted by circumstances so that they may complete orders already specified and reduce the present lag in deliveries, despite the expected decline in steel buying in the lighter lines, according to the magazine Steel.
A eulogy of the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, Brooklyn clergyman who died a year ago today, was read in more than 500 Protestant churches and synagogues throughout the borough yesterday.

From the pulpits of all German Confessional Protestant churches it was announced today that a united appeal had been made by the Lutheran Bishops and the Confessional Synods for an "honorable peace" with the National Socialist Government.
The Investors Syndicate of Minneapolis announces that resources have now passed the $100,000,000 mark, in celebration of the fortythird birthday of the company today.

The National Labor Relations Board's major case in the automobile industry, against the Ford Motor Company, will go into its second week tomorrow with witnesses for the board ready to support the complaint alleging violation of the Wagner act.
Jack Curley, a sports and amusement promoter for nearly forty years, died early today, following a heart attack, at his home on Station Road. He was 61 years old.

John D. Shibe, former president of the Philadelphia American League Baseball Club, died of pneumonia today at the Beeches Sanitarium. He suffered a nervous breakdown late last season and gave up the club presidency when his condition failed to improve.

THOMSON in his " Seasons " offers no comfort to those kept by duty in the Summer's heat; rather does he felicitate the man who has escaped it: Thrice happy he! who on the sunless side Of a romantic mountain, forestCrowned, Beneath the whole collected shade reclines;

George Gershwin, 38-year-old composer, died today at 10:35 A. M. at the Cedars of Lebanon Hospital. He succumbed five hours after being operated on for removal of a brain tumor. The operation was decided upon when the composer's condition became critical at midnight.
A doctor, two nurses and an attendant who were arrested by Brooklyn police Saturday night were arraigned in Felony Court yesterday on charges of performing illegal operations.
The United States will be an exporter of wheat In the 1937-38 season as the result of harvesting a crop this year in excess of domestic requirements for the first time since 1932.
A diplomatic protest will be made to Italy concerning the expulsion of an Austrian soccer team from that country, this correspondent learns.

A trio of metropolitan yac??tsmen who make winning a habit in longdistance cruiser races, and who seem to know tides and currents in Long Island Sound almost better than the fish themselves, were celebrating more nautical victories tonight.

Diplomats due today from Europe on the French liner Normandie include Raymond Brugere, French Minister to Canada; Felix Gordon Ordas, Spanish Ambassador to Mexico; M. Aristiguieta, Venezuelan Minister to Finland, and Manuel Moreno, attach of the Legation of Ecuador in Paris.

Leading representatives of all the world's Christian churches, except the Roman Catholic, will meet here tomorrow for the first time since 1925 to attempt to find ways to make religion a more unified and vital force in the everyday affairs of life.

Thirty-two reserve officers of the 424th Infantry (Light Tanks), part of the Seventy-seventh Division in the World War, entered Miller Field, New Dorp, S. I., yesterday afternoon for fourteen days of active duty.

The room in which Dr. Louis Wolf works at the State Fish Hatchery at Rome apparently has been a scene of more than customary activity. When trout, not only in the hatchery, but in other sections of the State die off from unknown reasons, it is Dr. Wolf's job to find the whys and wherefores of each a case.
William G. Littleton, retired banker and lawyer, died of a heart ailment today in Hahnemann Hospital after an illness of six weeks. His age was 69.

Apart from a decrease in the gold reserve, the return of the Bank of France for July 1 shows larger figures for bills discounted, loans against securities and against government bonds, and also for circulation-explainable by the requirements of a particularly difficult due date.

The Bureau of Municipal Research, in a statement issued today, asserted that Philadelphia city bonds would be selling at substantially higher prices "had not the city's credit been impaired by constant milking of its sinking funds, by operating on unbalanced budgets and fictitious estimates of revenue, by refusal to pay mandamuses and other obligations and by piling up a huge deficit."
A pair of goals by Frank Johnson in the last few minutes of the last period enabled the Burnt Mills Polo Club to break a tie and win by 6 to 4 over the Meadow four at Schley Field here.

Miss Elsie Petri, Women's Swimming Association star, successfully defended her championship in the senior metropolitan A. A. U. 220yard breast-stroke competition today. Miss Petri's performance was the high light of the program conducted under the auspices of the Women's Swimming Association and the Long Island State Park Commission in Zach's Bay.

The Federal Power Commission today announced the appointment of Leon M. Fuquay as secretary. Mr. Fuquay is 38 years old, and is a native of North Carolina. He is a graduate of the University of North Carolina and studied law at George Washington University.
Luncheons was given today at estates throughout the colony for Sunday guests. Mr. and Mrs. George L. Wrenn gave a large party at Zee-in-Duin, their place on the ocean.
The Boston Red Sox twice defeated the Athletics today in a double header enlivened by a near fight between Ben Chapman, Boston right fielder, and Umpire John Quinn.
Demand or money has been small' here this week, but late on Friday the day loan rate stiffened to 21/2 to 23/4 per cent. The Reichsbank's report dated
The Maritime Commission is formulating two programs to eliminate labor disputes from the American shipping industry, officials said today.
Denny Shute and Henry Cotton, probably the two most solemn golfers in the game, will start a 72-hole match for a prize of $2,500 tomorrow over the rolling Walton Heath course near London.

Spanish Government troops early today occupied Villanueva del Pardillo, about twelve miles west of Madrid, and took 600 more prisoners. This operation widened their salient and carried one step further the greatest government offensive of the civil war.

The police theory that Mrs. Al Handel, found dead beside her unconscious husband in a Newark hotel yesterday, was murdered was exploded today by Dr. Harrison S. Martland, Essex County Medical Examiner, following an autopsy.

An interim report of the taxation committee of the New York State Chamber of Commerce was made public yesterday declaring that the experience of the past year had confirmed the advance opinion of the chamber that the undistributed corporate profits tax would have "undesirable economic consequences in operation."

An industrial sales manager for New York City with the job of seeking new industries for the five boroughs was recommended yesterday by Charles E. Murphy in the final report of the eighteen-month industrial survey he undertook at the request of Controller Frank J. Taylor.

Rain and fog today reduced visibility here to 500 yards. The temperature was just at freezing, 32 degrees Fahrenheit. The camp was still about 100 miles from the Pole, at Lat. 88 degrees 32 minutes N. and Long, 10 degrees W.
The Devon Yacht Club on Gardiner's Bay has been a favorite resort, these torrid days, for out-ofdoor lunching and dining and watching the boat races, which are held two days each week.
Brooklyn and up-State infantrymen of the National Guard, numbering 2,300, forming the Fifty-third Brigade, commanded by Brig. Gen. Bernard W. Kearney, took over the Camp Smith cantonment here
The German wholesale price index on June 30 was 106.1, against 106 on June 23. The cost-of-living index for June was 125.3, against 125.1 in the preceding month.

Two men seeking relief from the heat outside Hamilton Fish Park at Pitt and Stanton Streets on the lower East Side were killed yesterday at 8:45 A. M., when a truck collided with a sedan at the crossing, then mounted the sidewalk out of control and ran them down.

Culture and decency can come only from within and not "by the dictum of some silly man imposing his will on the multitude," the Right Rev. Irving Peake Johnson, Bishop of Colorado, said yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Miss Margaret Ewing Finneran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emmet J. Finneran of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Lewis Jacquelin Lambert, son of Mrs. Henry C. Lambert of Bronxville, N. Y., and the late Mr. Lambert, on July 21 at the home of her parents here.

A season of Shubert productions consisting of operettas and musical comedies will be presented this Summer at Randalls Island Stadium by Fortune Gallo and William Caryl, beginning July 27 with "The Student Prince," it was announced yesterday.

Official statistics indicate that the new cereals crops will, at the best, be only middling. The government's policy is to replenish stocks of wheat and rye, thereby making it possible to reimpose the obligation on mills to maintain a two-month supply. This decree was suspended when shortages developed.

District Attorney William C. Dodge made public yesterday a preliminary report from Assistant District Attorney James J. Wilson on the recent investigation of the loan shark racket, through which more than 1,500 city employes, including policemen, firemen and workers in the Sanitation Department, were in danger of being victimized to the extent of about $750,000 through spurious confessions of judgment in the municipal courts.
The official Trade Research Institute predicts a continuation of improvement in world trade. In particular the forecast stresses rising imports by debtor countries.
The Chicago White Sox and the St. Louis Browns split a double bill before 20,000 fans today, the Browns taking the first game, 4 to 1, and then dropping the nightcap, 4 to 3.

Harold B. Thomas, vice president of the Centaur Company, makers of Fletcher's Castoria and Z. B. T. Baby Powder, has been named head of the company to succeed the late Frank A. Blair, according to announcement by Dr. William E. Weiss, chairman of the board of Sterling Products (Incorporated).

The action of the British Governdent in partitioning Palestine was defendedry Princeby the ad of the Department of Social Sciences, Kings College, Halifax, N. S., in a sermon yesterday at St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, Sixty-ninth Street near Broadway.
What is expected to become a struggle between the Roosevelt and conservative wings of the Democratic party of New Jersey was precipitated today with the announcement by Representative Elmer H. Wene

A motorist who was chased for a mile in Brooklyn as a drunken driver who had left the scene of two accidents, in which a woman was injured critically and two children were hurt slightly, was arrested about 11 o'clock last night at Third Avenue and Warren Street after nine shots had been fired by five pursuing patrolmen.

Gerard C. Podesta of Montclair, second seeded player, gained the quarter-finals of the Glen Ridge open tennis championship at the Glen Ridge Tennis Club today when he received a default and scored in two matches. He defeated George McCall of Arlington in the second round, 6-2, 6-2, and Robert Willett of Montclair in the third round, 6-1, 8-6.

The afternoon newspaper Globo published yesterday an exclusive interview, obtained by telephone from Washington, with Finance Minister Arthur de Souza Costa, who emphasized the great sympathy for Brazil that he had found in the United States.
With a six-run rally in the third featuring its attack, the New York Athletic Club nine conquered the Greenwich Village Club, 9 to 5. at Travers Island yesterday.
The Rev. Samuel Greenfield of the Isaiah Temple, Manhattan, died yesterday at his home, 423 West 120th Street, of injuries suffered in an automobile accident on June 4. He was 67 years old.

E. W. Hammons's Four Winds defeated a dozen rivals in the International One-Design Class race held today by the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. Bob Perkins placed second r with Picaroon, half a minute astern, and Bob Garland's Javelin was another ten seconds further back for third.

Gustav Gareis, an Evangelical assistant pastor who claims United States citizenship, was named defendant today in an immorality trial at Nuremberg. Together with four German youths he was charged with sex offenses. A verdict is expected tomorrow.

Mrs. Margaret Hewlett's spectacular forty-yard drive in 1:10 of an extra period enabled the Long Island Freebooters to defeat the California Ramblers, 7-6, in their intersectional women's polo contest today. A crowd of 6,000, the largest of the season for Bethpage State Park, witnessed the game.

More than fifty persons gathered today at the Pound Ridge Road home of Loomis Scofield, New Canaan's last surviving Civil War veteran, to mark his 92d birthday, which will be tomorrow. A delegation from Ella Bixby Post of the G. A. R. of New York City comes to celebrate Mr. Scofield's birthdays, and there were forty New Yorkers who arrived by bus today.
Hiram W. Evans, Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, asserted today the C. I. O. is "infested with Communists and the Klan will ride to wipe out communism."

Between six and twenty persons were killed and wounded in the upper Jezireh district Friday in a clash between troops and demonstrators demanding a separate mandate and dissociation from the Syrian Republic, advices reaching here today said.
Strike rioting broke out at gates of Republic Steel plant at Massillon, Ohio. Police fought rioters with tear gas. One man was reported killed Page 1.

The financial markets here appear to be at last definitely shaking themselves free from the depression which has overshadowed them since the beginning of the year. One by one the many adverse factors which have been experienced in painful succession are receding into the background, and with their elimination fundamentally sound conditions once again are getting a chance to exert their influence.

Donald McNeill of Oklahoma City triumphed over Gerin Cameron of Tulsa in the final match of the Queens County tennis tournament at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills yesterday. The score was 6-3, 1-6, 7-5.

Mrs. Janet Roper sticks close to her desk and never goes to sea, but she is widely known and highly regarded by seafaring men. She completes today the twenty-third year of her connection with the Seamen's Church Institute, and her forty-eighth year of work on behalf of seamen.
Two former American Ambassadors are among those who will discuss "Determinants of American Foreign Policy" at the Institute of World Affairs at the University of Maine July 21 and 22.

Christianity's outstanding characteristic, its extreme simplicity, combined with great spiritual depth, was emphasized yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Robert E. Speer, secretary of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, at a union service of four Flatbush churches at St. Mark's MethodistEpiscopal Church, Mark's Methodist Episcopal Church, Ocean Avenue and Beverly Road, Brooklyn.

Speculative interest in the grain markets fell off sharply last week, the average day's business on the Board' of Trade here being around 75,000,000 bushels, compared with slightly more than 91,000,000 bushels the preceding week.

In the major game at Innisfail Park yesterday, Offaly, senior hurling champion, defeated Cork, 28 to 6. Offaly was never threatened and at the half time was ahead, 16 to 1. The torrid temperature caused several players to fall from exhaustion.
Nazi financial and economics journals maintain that the export of rolling mill products, which, despite some shortage, exceeds the volume of the boom year, 1929, must be checked.

A sharp attack on John L. Lewis and the C. I. O. on the ground that Mr. Lewis and his organization pave "created rebellion within the ranks of labor at a time when labor was really coming into its own" was made yesterday by the Rev. Irvin C. Wise in a sermon at the Ainslie Street Presbyterian Church in Manhattan Avenue. Brooklyn.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 81 per cent of capacity, counting out the holiday, a rise of 6 points. This betterment was the result of resumption at mills that had been struck.
The European deadlock over Spain enters another week today without any hopeful indication that a solution is in sight.

The Charity Organization Society has sent out an S O S call, having first inquired of Dr. KIMBALL, the "weather man," to learn how long the hot weather might continue. A hot weather fund of $2,000 a day so long as the heat wave lasts is desperately needed.
Flashing a powerful defensive, the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club limited the Ox Ridge quartet from Darien, Conn., to one goal in each of the third and fifth sessions to triumph by 5-2 today.

Glenn Cunningham beat Archie San Romani in a 4:11.4 mile at the World Labor Athletic Carnival in the open-air furnace at Randalls Island Stadium yesterday, but the unheralded Elroy Robinson stole the show.

The American freighter Golden Bear lost one crew member but by heroic measures rescued 750 persons from imminent disaster when two great volcanic eruptions destroyed the town of Rabaul, New Britain, New Guinea, on May 29.
Samuel Untermyer, in a statement issued yesterday, criticized Governor Lehman for selecting a committee of forty-two persons to prepare material for the coming State Constitutional Convention.

The Weather Bureau, planning to look the next hurricane in the "eye," has 150 delicate instruments, attached to small balloons, ready to send from four stations to record the humidity, temperature and precipitation attending any hurricane that blows inland this season.
Joseph Fassler is in the Philadelphia office of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Alexander Eisemann Co. John Cambria will be in the Brooklyn office. Alfred Benjamin has joined William E. Lauer Co.
About sixty persons were killed today in a clash between bandits and troops on the outskirts of the town of Dolores Hidalgo in the State of GuanajAato.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company will distribute about July 20 approximately $1,170,000 to its employes as a result of the amendment to the Federal Pension Act for railroad employes, it was announced last night.

THE tall chap from green pastures was rambling along in conversation about the Land o' Goshen (N. Y.) and harness horses and the Grand Circuit and how the recent hot weather was mighty good for growing corn. Yes, sir, mighty good. Know the test for a growing corn crop? If it's tall enough to tie across a horse's back on the Fourth of July, the corn crop is coming along as it should.

Apprehension of damage to the new corn crop by intense heat and lack of additional moisture caused price advances in the staple last week and, despite the break in wheat, corn closed here yesterday with net gains of 2% to 31/8 cents a bushel, the former on the September position.

Col. Robert Todd Oliver, former Chief of the Army Dental Corps, died today in a Washington hospital at the age of 69. Dr. Oliver was born in Indianapolis. He served as dental surgeon and Professor of Or I Surgery of the Indiana Dental College now the School of Dentistry of the University of Indiana, and at one time was president of the Indiana State Board of Dental Examiners.

A large oil painting of President Roosevelt that had hung for two years in the place of honor at the entrance to the grill room in the Harvard Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street, has been removed and replaced with a painting of Langdon P. Marvin, a former law partner of Mr. Roosevelt and president of the Harvard Club from 1932 to 1936.

While the attention of buyers generally was centered in the new lines for Fall in the wholesale market here last week, substantial quantities of Summer merchandise were moved for special promotions, retail stocks were reduced as the result of the heat wave.

General Tsai Ting-kai, former commander of the Chinese Nineteenth Route Army, which withstood a Japanese attack at Shanghai in 1932, said today he was preparing to return to China because of the tense Chino-Japanese situation.

A fight for existence against "the devastating competition of chain stores" has been started among the retail and wholesale merchants of New York State by a Westchester County group that announced yesterday it had engaged Samuel Untermyer as general counsel.

As it emerges from the Senate committee, the Federal bill for establishing minimum wages and maximum hours is far less objectionable than the measure as originally drafted. The extent of the discretion granted to the proposed Labor Standards Board is greatly curtailed. Some of the blanks in the original measure are filled in.

100-Yard Dash-Won by Ben Johnson, New York Curb Exchange A. A.; L. Perrin Walker, New York A. C.. second; Herbert Thompson, New York Pioneer Club, third; Jack Weiershauser, San Francisco Olympic Club, fourth. Time--0:09.8. 120-Yard High Hurdles-Won by Forrest G. Towns, University of Georgia; Allan Tolmich, Wayne University, second; John M. Donovan, New York A. C., third; Robert D. Osgood, University of Michigan, fourth. Time-- :14.6.
One plant of the Consolidated Paper Corporation was tied up by a strike early today, but operations continued at two other of the company's St. Maurice River Valley mills despite the strike call.

R. H. Helsel of Long Island City bagged the doubles title in the New York State trapshooting meet today after a shoot-off with C. T. Jackson of Stormville. The rivals tied with 94 targets apiece out of 100, and Helsel went on to take the extra string with 23 out of 24..

As it emerges from the Senate committee, the Federal bill for establishing minimum wages and maximum hours is far less objectionable than the measure as originally drafted. The extent of the discretion granted to the proposed Labor Standards Board is greatly curtailed. Some of the blanks in the original measure are filled in.

Denouncing the so-called "compromise" bill which the House Agriculture Committee substituted for the administration's sugar proposals, Secretary Ickes asserted today that domestic sugar producers were being victimized by their own Washington lobbyists.

Barnegat Bay's fleet of International Star Class sloops sailed their fourth elimination race off the Seaside Park Yacht Club under unusual conditions today, with Wilson McNeely and Blakely Candlee bringing Star Dust home the victor over Charles Lucke Jr.'s Nick Nack.

The United States decision to arm two new battleships with 16-inch guns has caused no surprise here, writes the naval expert of The Times of London, but it has disappointed those who hoped that the conclusion of the London treaty of 1936 might inaugurate a reversal of the costly preference for great size in battleships.

With somewhat more than a week having passed since the franc was cut loose, developments, on the whole, in that period have accorded closely to the forecasts. No difficulty has been encountered in holding the franc-sterling rate just under 129.
In a polo match today on the new Shrewsbury Field, Rumson came from behind with a rally in the fifth chukker which netted four goals and defeated Shrewsbury, 13 to 10.

How bankers and investment houses can simplify and condense the prospectuses which they are required to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with security issues was explained today in an opinion by Harold H. Neff, director of the division of forms and regulations of the SEC.
In marked contrast to New York's heat wave, Argentina is shivering in the coldest weather of this Winter.

Chemnyco, Inc, chemicals, floor in 521 5th Ave; Automobile Manufacturers Association, Inc, in 386 Madison Ave: Associated Warehouses, Inc, in Vanderbilt Concourse Building, 52 Vanderbilt Ave; Cushman Wakefield, Inc, broker. Eisig Kramer, store, in 295 Columbus Ave; Meyer Steffens, Inc. broker.

Narcotics valued at $25,000 were stolen from the offices of the Wholesale Drug Specialists, Inc., on the fifth floor of the fourteen-story loft building at 30 West Fourteenth Street between 5:45 P. M. Friday and 8:15 A. M. Saturday, it was learned yesterday.

Prince Charming II, bay gelding owned by the Claredda Farm of Mr. and Mrs. E. V. Quinn of Shrewsbury, N. J., this afternoon was awarded the grand hunter championship of the seventh annual Country Club horse show, which came to a successful conclusion on the polo field of the Westchester Country Club.
Louise R. Baxter sold her eightroom Colonial home on Pelhamdale Avenue, Pelham, to Katharine F. Cory. The property was reported held at $20,000. Murray B. Parks was the broker in the deal.

One of the largest apartment house deals in the upper Manhattan area this season has been closed in the purchase by the Hillview Realty Corporation of the recently completed six-story structure at 195 Bennett Avenue, southeast corner of 190th Street.

A new edifice was dedicated yesterday morning for the St. Francis de Sales Roman Catholic Church, Beach 129th Street and Rockaway Beach Boulevard, Belle Harbor, Queens, by Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn.

Owing to the lull in the Spanish dispute and the good reports of business, sentiment was better in the stock market this week. Favorably received were the conclusion of the trade agreement with France, which terminates a two-year deadlock; also the agreement with Hungary and the foreign bondholders' acceptance of a cut in interest on Danzig loans, which, on the Boerse, had an effect on many stocks.

The giant British flying boat; Caledonia, recently flown westward across the Atlantic from Southampton, England, is scheduled to take off here at noon today on its return flight. The first stop will be at Boucherville, the seaplane base on the St. Lawrence River at Montreal, it was announced by Imperial Airways, Ltd.
Matthew van De Loo, 51 years old, senior assessor in the State Tax Department, and his wife were killed today in an automobile collision at suburban Loudonville.

An intensive course in defense against gas attacks will be given all candidates of the Citizens Military Training Camp here. Captain F. L. Padlon of the Chemical Warfare Reserves has arrived from Brooklyn to conduct the course.

Transatlantic passenger traffic has fulfilled the prohpecies of steamship executives, figures compiled by the Atlantic Passenger Conference showing that 316,082 persons were carried by the Atlantic ships in the first six months of the year.

Canada forged within sight of her first trophy at the coronation Bisley today with the announcement that Sergeant James Kier of Vancouver is tied with three English marksmen for the Clementi Smith Memorial aggregate, a challenge cup first presented in 1910.
Announcement was made today that Premier Benito Mussolini had approved plans for the construction of Italy's greatest combined seaplane and airport here, costing $6,000,000.

Mr. and Mrs. John Good of Westbury, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Louise Good, to Edward Lowndes Rhett, son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Rhett of Garden City, L. I.

To the Editor of The Nero York Times: During the current debate in the Senate on the Supreme Court issue, newspaper readers can well afford to omit perusal of the comics and curtail their interest in movie stars, sports and murders.
Fighting continued yesterday rand last night at the Yungting River, ten miles west of Peiping, between Japanese and Chinese troops.

A policeman won the praise of a doctor last night for his quick action in rescuing a 6-year-old boy from the bottom of the lake at 110th Street in Central Park and saving his life by applying resuscitation treatment.

Superbly mounted and flashing brilliant offensive team work, the unbeaten Old Westbury quartet, headed by Cecil Smith, galloped to a 15-4 victory over the Ramblers on International Field today to win the Meadow League division of the Meadow Brook Club Cups polo tourney.

Deeating the Union County Cricket Club of this city by 95 runs at rinanco Park today, the Hudson County eleven of the Brooklyn Cricket Club made further headway in the annual championship series of the New Jersey State Cricket League.

Aviators from the battleship Colorado tonight abandoned hope of finding Amelia Earhart and her navigator, Captain Frederick J. Noonan, in the Phoenix Island area after four days of scanning the islands from their three catapult planes.
Robert C. Pegg, 46 years old, a World War veteran and resident of this town, drowned last night while bathing in the south branch of the Raritan River near here.

Bourse, which was favorable earlier in the week, became hesitant when it became known that the fiscal decrees were imminent. The complete texts were not known yesterday, but the official summaries were sufficient to permit an estimate of the general scope of the pronouncements.

Darwin R. James, president of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities, will issue an appeal today for funds to support two camps. Regular subscribers have contributed $2,300 of the required $7,500, and the additional money is needed to maintain the camps through Labor Day.

Japanese Army headquarters here formally charges the Chinese Government with dangerously aggravating the situation by concentrating four crack divisions of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's troops in Northern Honan Province and simultaneously issuing orders to the Twenty-ninth Army in the Peiping area to offer strong resistance against the Japanese.

Seasonal holiday demands, trade activity and the turn of the half-year all contributed to a further large rise of almost [Pound]6,000,000 in the note circulation of the Bank of England in the week to a new high record of [Pound]494,425,000.

DEATHS ALDER, Miss JULIA, 63, of 115-30 204th Street, Queens Village: Died while being attended for heat prostration at her home. BEILING, PHILIP, 65, of 21-24 Fortyfifth Road, Long Island City, Queens. Died at home of heart attack induced by heat.
Herbert D. Brown of 1,130 Park Avenue, president of B. A. G. N. Williams, cut-stone contractors, died Saturday in St. Luke's Hospital, after a short illness, at the age of 63.
The seventy-ninth annual convention of the American Dental Association, opening tomorrow, will have a dental health exhibit open to the public for the first time in its history.

Aviators from the battleship Colorado tonight abandoned hope of finding Amelia Earhart and her navigator, Captain Frederick J. Noonan, in the Phoenix Island area after four days of scanning the islands from their three catapult planes.

Darwin R. James, president of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities, will issue an appeal today for funds to support two camps. Regular subscribers have contributed $2,300 of the required $7,500, and the additional money is needed to maintain the camps through Labor Day.

Japanese Army headquarters here formally charges the Chinese Government with dangerously aggravating the situation by concentrating four crack divisions of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's troops in Northern Honan Province and simultaneously issuing orders to the Twenty-ninth Army in the Peiping area to offer strong resistance against the Japanese.

Seasonal holiday demands, trade activity and the turn of the half-year all contributed to a further large rise of almost [Pound]6,000,000 in the note circulation of the Bank of England in the week to a new high record of [Pound]494,425,000.

DEATHS ALDER, Miss JULIA, 63, of 115-30 204th Street, Queens Village: Died while being attended for heat prostration at her home. BEILING, PHILIP, 65, of 21-24 Fortyfifth Road, Long Island City, Queens. Died at home of heart attack induced by heat.
Herbert D. Brown of 1,130 Park Avenue, president of B. A. G. N. Williams, cut-stone contractors, died Saturday in St. Luke's Hospital, after a short illness, at the age of 63.

Mrs. Parker Corning's Thanksgiving, who scored very impressively at Aqueduct recently, ran another sparkling race at Empire City yesterday in capturing the featured Tuxedo Purse and stamped himself as one of the up-and-coming 2-yearolder.

Silver Line Dye Works, Inc., hosiery, floor in 599-601 Broadway; Chromite Textile Printing Co., Inc., through Besley Co., two floors in 252-6 W 64th St; L. Isaacson Sons, Inc., boys' suits, in 11-13 W 30th St; Modernique Advertising and Display Corp., advertising, in 96 Madison Ave; Imperial Feather Co., Inc., through Hearn 45th St. Corp. in 17-19 W 34th St; Grid-Graph Sales Corp.. in 45 W 45th St; Cross Brown Co., broker.

Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of New York University, announced yesterday the award of seven graduate scholarships for 1937-1938 in the School of Education. Washington Square East, to students in six States.

Increases of millions of bushels in the production of potatoes and apples in New England this year were predicted today by the New England Crop Reporting Service of the Federal Department of Agriculture.
William J. McGuinness, 38-year-old tavern owner, was shot dead by an unidentified assailant at the door of his home here at 419 Main Street shortly after 1 A. M. today.
Stocks continued to advance and closed with leading shares up 1 to 4 points; turnover, 1,018,840 shares. United States Government bonds higher, other issues firm and mixed; transactions, $5,753,000.

Police and National Guardsmen closed C. I. 0. headquarters today and prohibited the formation of picket lines, following the clash last night between police and strikers in which two men were killed. Fifteen others, including three patrolmen, were injured.

Count Soyeshima, chairman of the International Olympic Committee; Dr. Frank Aydelotte, president of Swarthmore College, and Mrs. Aydelotte; Miss Alice Marble, American Women's tennis champion, and Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Garvan are among the passengers due here from Europe today on Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.

Miss Eleanor K. Roosevelt and Reverdy Wadsworth, whose engagement was announced in January, will be married on Sept. 4 in Skaneateles, N. Y., where the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Henry Latrobe Roosevelt, has a Summer home, Roosevelt Hall.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Dammann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Dammann of 440 Park Avenue, New York, and Cedar Knoll Farm, this place, to J. Lester Eisner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Lester Eisner of Red Bank, N. J., and New York, took place here this evening at the home of the bride's parents.

Charges that Poland's policy toward its Jewish population has made these people "the most oppressed and perhaps the most desperate groups of human beings in Europe," were laid before Secretary Hull today by a delegation from the American Jewish Congress.

Miss Dorothea Eleanor Novak, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Novak, this place, became the bride of Lieutenant Paul W. Scheidecker, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Anna Scheidecker of West New York, N. J., in St. Thomas Roman Catholic Church today. The Rev. William J. Blake, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

Despite increases in traffic accidents and persons injured in the past week-end, the figures covering the entire week declined as compared with those of the corresponding week last year, it was announced yesterday by Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler.

Arbitrageurs in Wa??l Street are puzzled over the slowness with which the old and new securities of the Baldwin Locomotive Works are assuming their proper price relationships. Either the new common is selling much too high, they declare, or the consolidated 6 per cent bonds and the old preferred are much too low.

Angered by the third sit-down strike in the offices of the Federal Theatre Project in as many weeks, William P. Farnsworth, local administrator, threatened yesterday to close the project if it "cannot function efficiently and without disorder."

Mrs. Thomas H. Blodgett and her guests, Mrs. Donald Richberg of Washington and Mrs. Albert Britt of Galesburg, III., were honored at a luncheon given today by Mrs. Charles Rockhill at Crane Hill, Great Barrington.

Front St, 74, 19.21/2x85.9; Joseph M. Edelson to Arbuckle Brothers, Old Slip Water St, consid $35,000, foreclosure. Eldridge St, 85, 25x100; Mortgage Commis sion Realty Corp to Henry Lichtig, trustee for investment holders, 21 E 40th St, ($1).

A one-story building in the former Michelin Tire Company plant at Milltown, N. J., has been leased to the Algro Knitting Mills, Inc., manufacturers and dyers of rayon knitted cloth. The structure features a sprinkler system and railroad siding and contains more than 47,000 square feet of space.

Proposals for remedying the "sick, demoralized condition" of the silk and rayon dyeing and finishing industry offered by General Hugh S. Johnson, former NRA administrator, have in general been approved by the majority of small units in the industry, but opposition is developing among some of the larger firms, it was reported in the silk goods market here yesterday.

The Senate crackled today with two more blistering attacks on the compromise Judiciary Reorganization Bill and the motives behind it as Democratic opponents returned to the fight after a week-end recess which failed to relieve any of the heat worked up over the issue.
Miss Jane Powell Patchett, whose engagement to Frank Hartley Shearer was announced recently by her aunt, Miss Florence Brill of Overbrook, Pa.

Retail prices have continued the uninterrupted advance which began a year ago at this time, with quotations last month moving up 0.4 per cent to the highest levels since March 1, 1931, according to the Fairchild Retail Price Index.

The Soviet plane carrying Pilot Mikhail Gromoff and two companions on an attempted record-breaking flight to an unannounced destination in the western part of the United States crossed the North Pole at 3:14 this morning Moscow time [8:14 last night New York time].
Lady Ida Sitwell, mother of the three famous literary Sitwells and herself one of the leading beauties of the Victorian era, died here today after a brief illness at the age of 68.
Talks that may lead to a reciprocal trade pact between the United States and New Zealand began today between Walter Nash, New Zealand's Minister of Finance, and Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

Governor Lehman of New York, Governor Hoffman of New Jersey and Sir Ronald C. Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, have been named as honorary referees for the eighth Oxford-Cambridge vs. Princeton-Cornell track meet in Palmer Stadium Saturday, according to the list of forty-six meet officials announced today.
The aircraft carrier Lexington lined her flying deck with planes and posted lookouts today, ready to launch her sixty-three aircraft in a final hunt for Amelia Earhart.

All operations on the Lehigh Valley Railroad will be suspended for two minutes at 12 noon (daylightsaving time) tomorrow at the time of the burial of Edward Eugene Loomis, former president of the railroad, at Elmira, N. Y. Mr. Loomis died on Sunday at Murray Hill, N. J., at the age of 72.

John Leppig, who was Mayor of Avenue A -for twenty-five years until he moved from the lower East Side ten months ago, died yesterday of a heart attack at his residence, 3,434 Tibbett Avenue, Riverdale. He was 53 year old.

Gold again sold yesterday at a premium over the New York shipping parity in the London bullion market, and, as a consequence, for the first time since May 1 no engagements of gold abroad for shipment here were reported to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The Irving Trust Company, trustee in bankruptcy for the International Match Corporation, reported yesterday it had received a bid for additional assets of the bankrupt estate from the International Match Realization Company, Ltd., of Bermuda, which a few weeks ago had made a firm offer of $6,500,000 for various non-American assets in the estate.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 9: Robert, Rear Admiral W. P., Bureau of Construction and Repair. Washington. D. C., to home, relieved from all active duty.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reports for the five months ended on May 31 a net income of $1,830,972 after all deductions, equivalent to $1.75 each on 1,045,278 shares of $100-par capital stock, compared with $2,229,599, or $2.13 a share, in the same period of 1936.
Melvin (Chick) Harbert, 22-yearold Battle Creek amateur golfer, shot rounds of 63 and 64 today for a thirty-six-hole score of 127 in the Michigan open golf tournament at Arbor Hills Country Club.

Yesterday's opener of the scheduled two-game series between the Bees and Dodgers at Ebbets Field was called off. The weather, although not particularly threatening at the hour of the postponement, later more than justified calling the unplayed game a wash-out.
Over the week-end the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals was kept busy answering calls of relief for horses prostrated by the heat, the society reported yesterday.

In digging around for a reason that might account for the fact that Erich Maria Remarque's "Three Comrades," despite enthusiastic reviews, has sold only one-tenth as well as did his earlier "All Quiet on the Western Front," Little, Brown, the publishers, discovered that a curious misunderstanding about the book has developed.
William L. Selmer, chief of the division of railroad engineering of the Transit Commission, died Sunday in the Neurological Hospital. He was in his early fifties.
The C. I. O. chartered a union of State, county and municipal employes; John L. Lewis said strikes would be against its policy. Page 1.

With optimism despite the present dangers to world peace, Dr. Samuel McCune Lindsay of New York and other speakers reaffirmed today before Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs their faith in the ultimate triumph of the conference method for adjustment of international differences without recourse to war.

Sales of copper were made abroad yesterday on a rising scale from 14.05 to 14.175 cents a pound, c. I. f., European base ports. On Saturday a few sales were made at 14.20 cents, but on Friday they were made at a low level of 14.05 cents.
Eddie Cool, Philadelphia lightweight, and Al Casimini. New York Italian, battled to a draw in the ten-round windup of a boxing show at the Arena tonight, held indoors because of threatening weather.

The Treasury's offering of the new 155day bills sold today at an average interest rate of 0.419 per cent, compared to a rate of 0.514 on the customary issue of 273-day bills sold at the same time, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.
Because Margaret Anglin, actress, contracted a cold yesterday, the Cape Playhouse here was unable, for the first time in eleven years, to put on its opening-night performance tonight.

Sam Francis, Nebraska's fullback last Fall, signed a contract today with the Chicago Bears of the National Football League. Francis, a 215pounder standing more than six feet, was practically a unanimous choice on the 1936 all-America eleven. The terms of his one-year document were not revealed.

Acting District Attorney Frederick L. Kopff of Brooklyn announced yesterday that his office had started proceedings for the extradition from London of Jayme Miara, alias James Kuperman, indicted in Kings County for the larceny of $33,000 from Isaac Freilich, a Brooklyn baker, on June 10, 1927. Mr. said that Miara was arrested by Scotland Yard police on a warrant filed with the State Department at Washington, D. C.
A bronze tablet memorializing the late Simeon H. Rollinson, former Mayor of this community, was unveiled tonight in the main lobby of the new Municipal Building here.

The Railway Express Agency will distribute approximately $2,320,000 to its employes in the next few weeks as a result of the recent amendment to the Railroad Retirement Act, it was announced here yesterday. It is stated that some 43,000 will share in the distribution.
Mildred Natwick was presented here tonight at the Westchester Playhouse in the role pf Miss Twitterton, the frightened spinster in "Busman's Honeymoon," a new detective comedy by Dorothy Sayers.
Reports from Pasajes, an Insurgent-held Spanish seaport near the French frontier, said today a crowd of cheering townspeople greeted the arrival of a tanker "kidnapped" from the Spanish Government.

Master Sergeant Edward Conrad of the Eighteenth Infantry, regimental supply sergeant for the C. M. T. C. here, breathed more easily today after successfully outfitting Abraham Ellman, 18 years old, of 2,407 Broadway, New York City, which was no easy job.

Crown Prince Simeon, Prince of Tirnova, was christened today in the chapel at the royal palace in the presence of the King and other members of the royal family, members of the Cabinet and high military and civil authorities.

A Grand Circuit racing meet will open tomorrow at E. Roland Harriman's Historic track and continue for four days, with four regular events on each card, as well as an amateur trot tomorrow and an exhibition by Greyhound Thursday.

AMONG the most painful of bores is he who, rolling his eyes, insists upon talking about the vintages and confections he has consumed. A menace who seems to have traveled everywhere, from Beaune to Helsinki to Nagasaki, he can spoil a good day more quickly than rain can.

Gravity's pull on one of the heaviest rock formations in the country, Iron Mine Hill in Cumberland, was being charted to day by the Federal Coast and Geodetic Survey. The object of the project, part of a nation-wide gravimetric study, was to shed new light on the forces of gravity and on the stresses and strains which gravity is causing on the earth's crust.

Workmen yesterday started reconditioning the interior of the Fifty-first Street Theatre, formerly the Hollywood, in preparation for the world premiere there next month of the Warners "The Life of Emile Zola," starring Paul Muni.

Benjamin Serlis, 48 years old, also known as Benjamin Seymour, a stockbroker, indicted in Wilmington, Del., for using the mails to defraud, and convicted in Seattle, Wash., for violating the Securities Exchange Act, was arrested yesterday morning when he arrived here from England aboard the American Trader.
The Securities and Exchange Commission received testimony today that investment trusts can function more efficiently if managements have some leeway in selecting their investments.

In a second long conversation with Premier Benito Mussolini and Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano this evening, George Lansbury, the British Laborite, obtained from the two Italian statesmen a conditional promise to meet representatives of all other powers if President Roosevelt can be prevailed on to convoke and take the chairmanship of a world conference to discuss the economic, financial and territorial problems at present separating nations.

Mutual Investment Fund-June 30: Net asset value, $14.94 a share, after expenses, dividends and reserves, against $15.03 per share on June 30, 1936. A distribution of 25 cents has been declared for the second quarter of 1937.
Wiliam Little Seddon, former vice president of the Seaboard Airline Railway, died yesterday at his home in Portsmouth following an illness of several months. His age was 74.

Of $1,981,000,690 in loans extended to banks and trust companies, including advances to aid in the liquidation or reorganization of closed banks, $1,812,375,135, or 91 per cent, had been repaid at the end of June, leaving but $168,625,555 outstanding, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today in its report to Congress covering the period from its establishment in February, 1932. to June 30. 1937.

Nine Rebel planes were brought down in one of the greatest aerial combats of the war today when Insurgent troops desperately but futilely counter attacked at Villanueva del Pardillo [about fifteen miles west by north of Madrid].

Ida Conquest, who had been leading woman for John Drew, Richard Mansfield and William Gillette and had appeared in a score of prominent roles in New York and London theatrical productions until her retirement from the stage in 1911, died on Sunday of a heart attack at her residence, 320 East Seventysecond Street. She was 61 years old.
Total milk production in the State during June was about 1.5 per cent higher than in June, 1936, the Department of Agriculture announced today.

Lou Meyer, only three-time winner of the 500-mile Memorial Day Speedway race, left today for Los Angeles with the avowed intention ot building a new race car to bring the Vanderbilt Cup back to this country.
The following deaths and prostrations from the heat, and drownings, were reported yesterday in the metropolitan area:

The morale of troops and civilians of Loyalist Spain is very high, according to two volunteers who have been serving with the Loyalist forces who are now here for lecture tours. They are Major Humberto Galleani of the Twelfth International Brigade of the Spanish People's Army and Captain-Adjutant Stephen Daduk, a former Brooklyn electrical worker serving with the Abraham Lincoln Battalion.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

James G. Conway, president of the New York Towboat Exchange, announced last night that he had summoned executives of the towboat lines operating in the New York port district to a conference tomorrow to consider conditions created by the refusal of union negotiators to accept terms submitted by the owners.
The Japanese civilian authorities are devoting their efforts to strengthening the national front in view of the North China situation.

The aggressive buying which sent cotton futures up $2 a bale on Thursday and Friday did not recur on Saturday or yesterday, and as a result prices on the Cotton Exchange here eased and closed with net losses of 1 to 5 points.
The docks at the naval fuel depot at Melville are to be used for the berthing of the larger Coast Guard cutters during the America's Cup races.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City professed yesterday to take little stock in the announcement that Representative Elmer H. Wene, House member from Vineland, would run for the Democratic nomination for Governor against United States Senator A. Harry Moore.

National guard armories will be available for use in canvassing the vote cast at the November election under the new proportional representation system, S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, was informed yesterday by Colonel Joseph A. S. Mundy, chief of staff of the New York State National Guard.

Despite allowance for the holiday, the daily average of 'automobile production declined more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index eased to 135.1 from 136.3. This compares with 102.3 for the week ending July 11, 1936.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn has upheld unanimously the decision of Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff that Conde Nast, New York publisher, has true ownership and valid title to a strip of lowland on Long Island Sound comprising part of the Nast estate at Sands Point, L. I.

After opening firm today stocks developed a slight weakness, due in some measure to the small volume of business. Nevertheless, most sections reflected recessions at the close. Gilt-edge issues were steady but the foreign loan list was dull.

The second polo tournament of the season at Meadow Brook is scheduled to get under way on Thursday, according to the draw announced at the club today. This is the annual twelve-goal tourney for the Hempstead Cups.

America this year is once more a land of plenty. The corn crop, according to the Government's latest estimate, will reach 2,572,000,000 bushels, compared with 1,529,000,000 in 1936. The Winter wheat crop will be the largest since 1931 and with that exception, the largest since the great yield of 1919.

Oliver Farm Equipment Company rights have been suspended from dealings on the New York Stock Exchange. The Bulova Watch Company, Inc., has notified the Stock Exchange that it proposes to eliminate 50,000 shares of $3.50 convertible preferred stock and to increase its common stock from 325,000 to 500,000 shares.

A day's output of milk from 6,000 cows will go into the manufacture of a six-ton Cheddar cheese to be exhibited at the State Fair in Syracuse Sept. 5 to 11, the State Department of Agriculture and Markets disclosed today.

The first of a series of "mass job hunts" conducted yesterday by dismissed WPA workers produced nothing more substantial for 250 marchers than a shower of water and paper clips from upper stories of the two buildings to which they went looking for private employment.

Mrs. James Brown Potter of Westbury has gone to Edgartown, Mass., for the rest of the Summer. Mrs. Lansing C. Holden has been joined at 14 East Sixtieth Street by her daughter-in-law, Mrs. Lansing C. Holden Jr. of Beverly Hills, Calif.

With a truly representative group occupying berths in the draw, play in the annual Eastern junior clay court tennis tournament started at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday, all five of the favored players who saw action coming through their inaugural tests successfully.

It appears possible that the local' theatre will be seeing two plays by Victor Wolfson next season. Already on the docket of Norman Bel Geddes is that one called "Lower Than Angels," and since the opening of his "Excursion" Mr.

Senator SMATHERS, picked for that honor by Mayor HAGUE, has turned against his patron and Senator MOORE, whom the former wishes to transfer from Washington to Trenton. Mr. MOORE is not an out-and-out Rooseveltian.
Lexicographers pondered today and laymen wondered if the Committee for Industrial Organization had joined the intelligentsia and started toying around with the language.

An all-brother tie for top honors in the amateur-pro best-ball tournament that acted as a preliminary to the Long Island open golf championship was broken up by the lastminute entrance of another brother at the Crescent A. C. today.

An application by the Public Service Company of Indiana for approval of the acquisition of all the capital stock of the Dresser Power Corporation, and one by the latter corporation for exemption from the necessity of making a declaration with respect to an issue of $1,700,000 principal amount of common capital stock of $100-par value and $5,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds will be the subject of a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday.

The firm of Charles W. Barber Son, Inc., has been established to deal in municipal and corporation securities, specializing in New Jersey issues. Charles W. Barber will be president and Russell G. Barber, vice president.
Secretary Morgenthau will sail July 24 from Los Angeles for a vacation in Hawaii, he announced this afternoon. "That is, unless something unforeseen should occur," he said.

Tomorrow will be the first anniversary of the assassination in Madrid of former Finance Minister Jose Calvo Sotelo. Extensive preparations are being made in Insurgent Spain for observance of this date.
Investing clients of Samuel Hurwitz have Purchased the following mortgages: In Manhattan, $21,500 on the six-story tenement house at 226 E 11th St, between 2d and 3d Aves.

The usual informal exchange views among European central bankers assembled here today for the monthly meeting of the board of the Bank for International Settlements showed sentiment on the French financial situation divided.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente granted yesterday a mandamus directing License Commissioner Paul Moss to renew the licenses of about 400 public porters, known as "black caps." Renewals had been refused on the ground that the porters gave visitors a bad impression of New York and acted as "steerers" for some hotels.

Dr. Frederick Martin Albers, a physician and surgeon, who had practiced in Brooklyn for more than thirty years, died on Sunday at his home, 131 Seventy-sixth Street, Brooklyn, after a two months' illness. His age was 55.

Big drums thundered all over Northern Ireland today when about 100,000 Orangemen paraded in full regalia to celebrate the 247th anniversary of the Battle of the Boyne. Belfast, which staged the biggest July 12 demonstration, was a riot of color.

With budgets 10 to 15 per cent larger than a year ago, homewares buyers shopped through trade shows in two local hotels yesterday placing liberal commitments for merchandise. Although they found prices in most lines up 5 to 10 per cent compared with Spring levels, the higher quotations proved no deterrent to the Fall buying.

Announcement has been made that there will be no Monday performances in the Summer season of Shubert-Gallo operettas to be given at the Municipal Stadium of Randalls Island beginning Tuesday evening, July 27, with the production of "The Student Prince."

The DeLand Holding Corporation reports the sale of a five-room brick bungalow on a 40 by 100 foot plot at 33 Benris Avenue, Franklin Square, L. I., to Henry Hahn, and of a seven-room brick bungalow on a plot of the same size at 27 Benris Avenue to Elbert L. Moore.

Continuing their efforts to break the strike of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. 0. affiliate, efforts which the union characterized as fruitless, shipyard owners reopened two more plants yesterday, resuming partial operation.

The British Government, it was learned on authority tonight, still is not in contact with any other government on a new plan for solving the deadlock over Spain. In fact, there is no new plan yet and only the vaguest ideas about the form it will take when prepared.
A laborers' bank of industrial credit will be created by decree in August according to an announcement by President Lazaro Cardenas during an interview granted to El Nacional.
Dr. Rodrigues Ottolengui, a well known dentist, and the author of mystery novels, died on Sunday at his home, 175 West Seventy-second Street, of a heart ailment and a stroke after a long illness.

Three former officers of the National Title Guaranty Company, convicted last December as conapirators in a mail fraud scheme and sentenced to a year and three months each in prison, were cleared yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.
Three Jersey City errors, an infield hit and a long fly gave the Newark Bears a 4-to-3 victory over the tailend Giants in the ninth inning at Ruppert Stadium tonight.

The Senate is a remarkable body, and its rules are no less so, as certain happenings today amply demonstrated. According to Senator O'Mahoney and other foes of the President's Court Bill, these rules have been invoked to "throttle" debate.

Advertising campaigns to promote the sale of apples are being planned by a number of grower groups. Newspapers in thirty important cities will carry the national apple advertising campaign sponsored by the Washington State Apple Advertising Commission for the 1937-38 crops.

Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Marquetand of this place and Mount Airy, Philadelphia, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Marquetand, to W. Ralph Hopkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hopkin, also of Ocean City, and Frankford, Philadelphia.
A report of the Department of Commerce, made public today, said Italy might have to import 700,000 to 800,000 tons of wheat to meet domestic requirements this year.

Trading in futures on the Commodity Exchange, Inc., for the six months to June 30 exceeded the volume for the entire year of 1936, according to figures made public yesterday. Contracts that changed hands on the Exchange in the first half of this year numbered 119,707, compared with 96,465 for the preceding twelve months. The increase in trading activities in the futures of all commodities is shown in the following table:

Services for Jack Curley, veteran sports promoter who died at his home early this morning, will be C held at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Chapel, 141-26 North Boulevard, Flushing, at 10 A. M. on Wednesday. Burial will be in Nassau Knolls, Port Washington, L. I.

The July 1 revision of the list of outstanding bonds legal for investment by savings banks in New York State, as reported by the State Banking Department, shows that eighty-seven individual issues with total face amount of $912,886,709 have been removed and that eightyone issues with a face amount of $925,356,994 have been added.
Spanish War veterans heard today that their national organization had a reserve fund of $100,000 invested ill government bonds to carry on until the last veteran dies.
Carl Boschwitz, widely known here and abroad as a dealer in government securities and bankers' bills, died suddenly yesterday in his office at 37 Wall Street. Mr.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today hailed as a notable labor victory an agreement obtained by street railway employes and bus drivers in Cincinnati under which substantial wage increases were granted.

Sixty-eight members of the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company from Boston took part today in celebrations marking the 400th anniversary of the regiment. The Honorable Artillery Company, which is reputed to be the oldest regiment in the world, was incorporated by King Henry VIII in 1537, but its history goes back even beyond that date.

The City of New York has sold to a syndicate formed by Henry Mandel a plot on the southwest corner of Church and Vesey Streets, part of the property acquired in the course of construction of the Eighth Avenue subway by the Board of Transportation.

Margaret A. Donnelly gave a mortgage to the Fourth Federal Savings and Loan Association for $20,000, payable $150 a month at 6 per cent, on the house on the north side of 45th St, 120 feet west of 3d Ave. 20x100.5 feet.
Joseph G. Rodgers, who was Sergeant-atArms of the House of Representatives in the last three Republican administrations, died this morning at the Emergency Hospital of a thrombosis.

The World Conference on Church, Community and State, called to discuss primarily new problems arising from modern conflicts between church and government, received at its opening session tonight graphic evidence of one such problem.

All railway lines in North China were disrupted yesterday and today by heavy troop movements, both Chinese and Japanese. The Tientsin-Shanghai Express, which was supposed to leave here shortly after 8 P. M. yesterday, was still at the East Station last midnight. This was probably due to Nanking troop movements.

Richard DePierro of New Rochelle won the fifth annual Westchester public links golf championship today at Saxon Woods. DePierro first had a 76 and a 77 on the final round for a total of 153 for the thirty-six holes, two strokes less than Charlie Warga of Peekskill, who finished second. The latter had a 75 after taking an 80 in the morning.

Dr. Harry J. Handelman, a Bronx physician, died Sunday night at his home, 1,000 Grand Concourse, of a heart attack. He was 48 years old. A native of Russia, Dr. Handelman came to this country in 1906.
Captain Hugo Dunkerley, aviator and editor of The Mombasa Times, was killed today in an automobile accident. He was the son of John Oxenham, novelist.

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, tennis star, has taken up residence at Glen Brook, Nev., on the shores of Lake Tahoe and admitted tonight in a telephone conversation that she contemplated action to divorce Frederick Moody, San Francisco broker.

Non-emergency operations were suspended in six hospitals during the heat wave as a precaution, Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, disclosed yesterday. This was to avoid fatalities due to collapse from the heat.
Vice Premier Lon Blum, reviewing to day the Socialist Party Congress and the tax measures of Georges Bonnet, Finance Minister, in relation to increases in railroad rates, said:
Walter Gordon, 20 years old, of Merrick, L. I., life guard at Jones Beach, was fatally injured in an automobile accident at Little East Neck Road and Montauk Highway, Babylon, early today.

In 1919 GEORGE GERSHWIN was playing songs for possible purchasers in music shops and beginning to succeed as a writer of popular music. Five years later symphony orchestras were bidding for first performances of his scores.

Criticism of the methods of the recently formed rackets bureau of District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan's office in Brooklyn was voiced yesterday by two attorneys appearing before Kings County Judge George W. Martin. They obtained permission to examine the minutes of the grand jury that indicted Sidney Gondelman, Brooklyn attorney, and his law clerk, David Leber, on charges of subornation of perjury.

Miss Madge Carrington Laidlaw, daughter of Loper Baird Laidlaw of Greenwich, Conn., will be married to William Herbert Wiley, son of Mrs. William Herbert Wiley of Greenwich and the late Dr. Wiley, on July 27 in Rye, N. Y.
Becalmed at sea for nineteen days and without food for almost a week, the captain and crew of the fishing schooner Holetown told a harrowing tale on their arrival here today.

Retired Engineer of Steam Frederick G. Ceder, formerly a member of Engine 222, residing at Monsey, N. Y., died Saturday, July 10. Funeral will take place from Charles Licht Funeral Parlors, 60-96 70th Ave., Ridgewood, L. I., Wednesday, July 14, at 2 P. M. Interment at Evergreen Cemetery.
Henry Samuel Demarest, manufacturer of mill supplies, died here yesterday at his home, 164 Fulton Avenue, after a long illness. He was 70 years old.
months. effective July 12. He will proceed to Headquarters Vancouver Barracks, CCC District, Vancouver Barracks, Washington for assignment. Lieutenant Schroeck will rank from July 21, 1936.

With more than fifty high school and college coaches from all over the country in attendance, a threeweek football coaching course opened at Teachers College, Columbia University, yesterday. The program, part of the Department of Physical Education's Summer Session, is being given under the direction of Dr. William L. Hughes.
