President Roosevelt vetoed today the bill recently passed by Congress which would have permitted borrowers from the Federal Land Banks to pay a lower rate of interest than that provided in their mortgage contracts. He based his veto on the fact that the measure would upset his budget for the fiscal year 1938 by $30,000,000.
Summoning a surprise witness in the trial of the Scottsboro case, Samuel Leibowitz, chief of defense counsel, predicted today a "major development" as he left here hurriedly for Birmingham.

All the Turkish newspapers give prominence to the messages exchanged between President Mustafa Kemal Ataturk and the rulers of Afghanistan, Iran and Iraq on the signature of the Asiatic pact at Teheran, and emphasize the significance of the new instrument in the promotion of peace and good-will in Western Asia.
Legislation to authorize $21,460,688 for construction and improvements at military posts in the United States, Hawaii and Panama received the approval of the House Military Committee today.

John Van A. MacMurray, American Ambassador to Turkey, will be chairman of the Joint Preparatory Committee on Philippine Affairs, it was announced at the White House today, President Roosevelt having approved his selection by the State Department.

The newspaper Djumhuriet publishes an article today about the situation in the Far East in which Japan is reminded that the Far East is not so distant and that other Asiatic countries may have something to say about Asiatic affairs in general.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Kean Leeds of this city of the marriage of their daughter, Miss Joan Leeds, to Donald Q. Quinby Ross. son of Mr. and Mrs.

Dr. Alice Salbmon, noted sociologist who has been described as "the Jane Addams of Germany," left Berlin a month ago today by order of the Nazi secret police, according to word received here yesterday.

The Federation Bank and Trust Company in its statement for June 30 reported total deposits of $11,228,775, against $11,410,262 on Dec. 31, the date of the last previous report. Total assets were $13,349,054, against $13,494,384 six months earlier.

Aggressive commission-house buying developed in wheat on the Board of Trade here today, following an early break which was largely attributed to hedging pressure, and prices advanced more than 2 cents a bushel from the inside figure before the buying movement ran its course.

Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare signalized her return to competition in the nineteenth annual women's invitation golf tournament of the Shenecossett Country Club after a year's absence by winning the medal today in the qualifying round.

The Earl of Wemyss, one of Scotland's largest landowners, died today at his seat, Gosford House, near here. He was 79 years old. Lord Wemyss, before succeeding his father as eleventh earl in 1914, sat in the House of Commons for twelve years.

David Adrian MacLeod, 'former president of D. C. Weeks Co., contractors, who have built some of New York's best-known buildings, died shortly before midnight yesterday in Nyack Hospital. Mr. MacLeod was 80 years old.

Miss Patricia Martin of New York made a dangerous swim yesterday through surf-pounded reefs to retrieve a submerged punt sighted off the south shore. It was believed the boat might be that of Gerald Lewis, 11 years old, who has been missing for ten days.

Funeral services for former Municipal Court Justice Frederick Spiegelberg, an authority on the landlord and tenant situation in New York, were held yesterday morning in the chapel of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixtyfifth Street. The Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman officiated.

Kid Chocolate, former world's featherweight champion, will clash with Young Chappie in the feature eight-round contest of Canarsie Stadium's boxing show tonight. Cuban Luis and Jack Martin have been matched for the semi-final, scheduled to go six rounds.
John Pratt Wilson, author and song writer, who began his career as librettist for the old Tivoli Opera House in San Francisco, died on Saturday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 76 years old.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 10 unless specified: Funchal, Madeira to Tor Bay, England, July 12: Arkansas, Wyoming. At Seattle: Barry, Brooks, California, Childs, Gilmer, Goff, Idaho, Reuben James, Memphis. Minneapolis, New Mexico, Nevada, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Tuscaloos, West Virginia, Williamson.

Fall merchandise claimed the full attention of buyers in the wholesale apparel and accessory markets yesterday. The retailers here for goods for immediate delivery expressed satisfaction with the volume of business on Summer apparel and said that last week's heat wave gave them an opportunity to clear remaining stocks of Summer goods.

Dr. John Grant Lyman, financial adventurer and race track plunger of twenty-five years ago, whose stock operations brought him into several conflicts with the law, died yesterday of a heart attack in his apartment at 740 Riverside Drive.

Customs officials who were busy yesterday afternoon examining the baggage of the passengers who landed from the French liner Normandie expressed their indignation at the recent ruling made by William H. McReynolds,
Senator Hatch, Democrat of New Mexico, described the administration's present Court Bill tonight "a much needed permanent reform.

Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich, present Westchester - Fairfield Association champion, started today after the Westchester open title in the tournament for which Mrs. Isaac Wheeler, well-known local golfer of many years standing, has been donating the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy for the past eight seasons.
Gilbert Kline, 22 months old, fell into Sanhican Creek while playing near his home at 30 Laolede Avenue today and floated downstream for three city blocks before he was rescued.

Aabs and Jews took new steps today in opposition to the British plan for carving Palestine into three parts. One hundred and fifty Moslem religious leaders issued a decree threatening excommunication for any Moslem who supported partition of the country.

Soaking rains that came too late for wheat in certain sections but which should be of benefit to feed crops fell over a wide area of Southern and Central Alberta during the week-end. The showers extended east from the mountains to Medicine Hat, and from Red Deer 150 miles south to High River, forty miles south of Calgary.

Ending a seven weeks' strike that had cost them over $2,000,000 in pay, more than 7,000 employes of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company's plant at East Chicago, Ind., were to begin their return to work at 7 A. M. tomorrow.

Prices on cloaks and suits will be advanced at least 5 per cent to meet the wage increase to workers which became effective with their return to work yesterday, Samuel Klein executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., and chairman of the Fair Trade Practice Commit tee of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, declared last night.

Striking out at critics of the Federal Desposit Insurance Corporation who have doubted its chances of success, Leo T. Crowley, its chairman, told the opening session of the North Carolina Bankers Conference in an address at the University of North Carolina tonight that "you are optimistic if you think any bank or the banking structure can survive a repetition of the 1933 crisis should the corporation fail in the meantime."

Straining at their anchors in this picturesque harbor tonight are a baker's dozen of the cream of America's ocean racers awaiting the start of the Larchmont Yacht Club's annual Fire Island race, which will start tomorrow at 11 A. M.

Commercial failures touched the lowest level in seventeen years in the five-day week ended July 8, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The total for the week was 108, the smallest for any similar period since the week ended July 8, 1920.

C. W. Loeber, division director of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that Dr. John Piccard had passed his examination for a license to operate an ultra-shortwave radio in his multiple-balloon aircraft.

The officers and many members of the Rhode Island Women's Republican Club were the guests of Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt at a tea given at Oakland Farm this afternoon, There was a large attendance from all parts of the State.
Secretary Morgenthau signed documents this morning giving effect to the new agreement under which the United States and China will barter gold and silver.
George Gershwin, noted American composer of modern music, will be honored Thursday in simultaneous memorial services here and in New York City.

The wholesale dollar volume of financing of new and used automobiles in the first five months of this year was $860,976,659, compared with $778,331,934 in the corresponding 1936 period, the Bureau of the Census reported today.
Denny Shute tonight was two holes down to Henry Cotton after playing the first half of their seventy-two-hole match for $2,500 on the old course at Walton Heath.

Manhattan Washington St, 703-11, and Perry St, 145-9 123.8x81xirregular; for 1-story offices and freight terminal; Maxwil Construction Corp, 300 Madison Ave, owner; Martine Wilson, architects; cost, $45,000. Greenwich Ave. 15, 20.2x75; for 1-story restaurant; Helen Robertson, 2,876 La Fontaine Ave, the Bronx, owner; Charles Kreymborg, architect; cost. $7,000.

The President's veto of the bill to extend the 3 1/2 per cent rate on Federal Land Bank loans is heartening for more than one reason. It reaffirms his aim to secure a balanced budget. It shows that he is determined not to yield to pressure even from the politically powerful farm groups when the demands of those groups are discriminatory and unjust.

Father Divine was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook to post a $20,000 bond within ten days to avoid the appointment of equity receivers for the temporal possessions of his Peace Missions.
Dr. Edgar J. Fisher of the Carnegie Institute of International Education'declared today before a Chautauqua institution audience that "the totalitarian State is World Public Enemy No. 1."

Utterly unmindful of an insufferable heat that had Baker Bowl sizzling like an oven, the Giants went to tremendous lengths today endeavoring to help Hal Schumacher negotiate a non-stop flight of nine full innings on the pitching mound, a feat Prince Hal has not accomplished since June 1.

Town officials of Mount Pleasant were rebuked today by Supreme Court Justice George H. Taylor Jr. for their business methods and their handling of town funds, but on a number of other charges, also filed by taxpayers, he found the officials innocent of illegal acts.
The Aluminum Company of America resumed plans today for a $15,000,000 expansion program at its Alcoa plant following the end of a strike by its workmen for increased wages.

The State inquiry to determine whether the increase of 1 cent whether the increase of 1 cent a quart in the retail price of milk in the metropolitan area two weeks ago involved monopolistic practices will begin this morning.

An elaborate program to impress visiting legionnaires with the "warmth and hospitality" of New York City is planned for the American Legion national convention here in Septeinber, Mayor La Guardia told the nineteenth annual convention of the Kings County Legion last night at its opening session in the Knights of Columbus clubhouse, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Louis Waldman's letter, printed in your July 4 issue, starts with two premises. First, Mr. Waldman says that most of the advocates of legislation designed to guarantee the responsibility of labor unions are endeavoring to embarrass those organizations. Second, he says that those who honestly advocate such legislation are not aware that unions are now fully responsible under the law.
Japan has made four drastic demands upon the Hopei-Chahar Political Council for a settlement of the North China hostilities. These demands, transmitted to the Nanking government from Peiping, are:

Frederick Gleason Corning, mining engineer, died of uremia poisoning yesterday in the Park West Hospital, 170 West Seventy-sixth Street, at the age of 81. He was still in active practice two months ago, when stricken.
This is the second dispatch from Mr. Matthews describing the Spanish Loyalist offensive in front of Madrid, which began July 5.

The four four-story tenement buildings forming the northwest corner of York Avenue and East Seventyseventh Street, known as 445-51 East Seventy-seventh Street and 1,453-55 York Avenue, have been sold by the New York Trust Company to Leo Silver.
Directors of the Union Oil Company of California declared a quarterly dividend of 30 cents a share to its stockholders.

Dr. William I. L. McGonigle of Freehold told the American Dental Association today that nagging children while they are eating, sex repression, and the modern strain of living might be the emotional causes of dental decay.

CARLSON, JOHN E. (Sept. 26, 1935). Gross assets, $14,982; net, $14,982. To wife, Alma S. Carlson. Chief assets, Stocks and bonds, $1,757; jointly owned property, $13,125; miscellaneous property, $100. George Pfeil, attorney, 27 William St., Manhattan.

Bronx residents dressed in shorts are pestering home owners in South Yonkers again. Four Yonkers supervisors complained today in asking Westchester County to build a high fence around Tibbets Brook Park and discourage non-residents from using that county picnic area and swimming resort.

The customary publicity is being given to a sentence passed today on a Catholic priest who united in marriage a "Christian Jew" and a non-Jewish German woman. The priest was convicted of "abetting racial defilement" and sentenced to three months in prison.

Miss Beatrice Presswood King, who, until her retirement in 1931, had been a public school teacher and principal in Brooklyn for forty-one years, died on Saturday at her home, 263 Cumberland Street, Brooklyn, after a long illness. She was 76 years old.

President Roosevelt sent to the Senate and House Agriculture Committees a letter on farm legislation; vetoed the bill extending existing interest rates on Federal Land Bank loans and laid the cornerstone of the new Apex Building which will house the Federal Trade Commission.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today that the Chinese Government again was seeking through the Export-Import Bank and exporters five-year credits that would permit them to make purchases in this country of railroad rolling stock, rails and textile machinery.

David O. Selznick, president of Selznick International Pictures, Inc., announced today production will begin immediately on a film depicting the history of The Associated Press and the part it has played in development of the free American press.

The Union Oil Company of California reported yesterday for the first half of 1937 a net income of $5,200,000 after charges, taxes and reserves for depreciation and depletion, equal to $1.11 each on the 4,666,270 shares of common capital stock outstanding.

Mr. and Mrs. Fred Irving Congleton of Beaver Run, N. J., formerly of Yonkers, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Congleton, to John Hallowell Ohly, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Henry Ohly of Brooklyn.

Miss Amelia Davison, member of a prominent early Long Island family and at one time an ardent campaigner for women's suffrage, died here today at the age of 80. Miss Davison was active during the women's suffrage movement when she and her two sisters, Miss Irene Davison and the late Susan Davison, both of this village, organized bands of suffragists on Long Island.

" Having a wonderful time" was a reality to 2,200 under-privileged children from 100 municipal playgrounds of the five New York boroughs who yesterday were taken on an all-day cruise and picnic up the Hudson, under supervision of the City Department of Parks.

Bernard D. Kelly, controller of the Hotels Statler Company, Inc., died early yesterday morning in the French Hospital, where he had been a patient for three weeks. He was born in Auburn, N. Y., 51 years ago. A sister, Elizabeth A. Kelly, survives.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull conveyed today to the diplomatic representatives of the Japanese and Chinese Governments here the hope of the United States Government that no war would break out in North China.

Acting Captain Leonard J. Preston, commander of Motorcycle Squad No. 2 in the Police Department in Brooklyn, and an expert on escort arrangements, died suddenly Sunday night at his Summer home, 222 Jefferson Street, Huntington Beach, L. I. Captain Preston, who was 52 years old, had been on the police force for thirty years.

James Roosevelt, son and secretary or the President, announced at the White House today plans for an experiment he hoped to get started in Massachusetts looking toward the re-employment of workers who would be removed from the rolls of the Works Progress Administration on July 15.

Monopoly and unfair methods of competition still constitute a menace to the conduct of honest business in this country, President Roosevelt said today in laying the cornerstone for a permanent building to house the Federal Trade Commission.
An agreement outlining a press truce between Austria and Germany was published here tonight. It is regarded as the most important outcome of the recent Austro-German mixed commission's meetings.

Between 20,000 and 25,000 Staten Island commuters living in the interior and on the east shore of the borough who depend on the six bus lines of the Tompkins Bus Corportion for transportation to the Municipal Ferry at St. George will be deprived of service today.

The stoppage of 35,000 cloak makers in more than 1,500 shops was ended yesterday with the signing of collective agreements between employer associations in the industry and the Joint Board of Cloakmakers Unions, as affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers.

John Roosevelt, son of President Roosevelt, was received today by Premier Mussolini and the two exchanged cordial good wishes. With Mr. Roosevelt were the three sons of United States Ambassador William Phillips -William, Draycon and Christopher-and the Ambassador's nephew, John Draycon. The envoy introduced them to the Premier.

Exports of paints and paint materials in May advanced slightly above the record level of the previous month to a total of $2,021,400, compared with shipments in May, 1936, valued at $1,573,000, representing a value gain of about 30 per cent, according to a report today by T. W. Delahanty of the Chemical Division, Department of Commerce.

Speaking as an individual, he said, and not as Secretary of the Treasury, Henry Morgenthau Jr. told newspaper men today that the consolidation of Federal police agencies, as recommended to the Senate Select Committee on Government Reorganization would be "dangerous."

If General Hugh Johnson becomes "czar" of the silk industry, Federal Court Judge William Clark offered today to become one of his sources of information in regard to some of the unsatisfactory conditions of the business. The jurist made the offer during a hearing on an application for reorganization by the Cliftonia Print and Dye Works of Clifton, under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Delaware, Lackwanna Western Railroad has reported net income for the five months ended on May 31, 1937, of $578,471, equal to 33 cents a share on 1,677,824 shares of $50-par value 'stock contrasted with a net loss of $410,607 in the same period in 1936. Net income for May was $114,038, against $35,921.

Ralph H. Tapscott, president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., was elected yesterday president of the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company, succeeding Frank W. Smith, who retired on June 30 under the utility system's age limit of, 70.

Three of the thirty-nine men and women members of the WPA Teachers Union who were arrested on the night of June 30 in the WPA Recreational Project offices at 167 West Sixty-fourth Street testified in their defense yesterday at their hearing before Magistrate Aurelio in the Felony Court on a charge of breaking into the premises and destroying property there.
Nearly 2,000 workers of Cleveland's four iron and steel companies, the plants of which were closed by a C. I. O. strike four weeks ago, will return to work Wednesday.

The New York City police are commended for a "more liberal attitude toward labor and public demonstrations" in the last year by the New York Civil Liberties Committee, an affiliate of the American Civil Liberties Union, in its annual report, made public yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Lewis L. Fawcett in Brooklyn granted a temporary injunction yesterday restraining the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, Local 13, affiliated with the C. I. 0., from picketing the Wheeler Shipyard, Inc., at Coney Island Creek and Cropsey Avenue, Brooklyn. Eugene M. Wheeler.

Harold Stern, orchestra leader, of 142 Coleridge Street, Brooklyn, filed a voluntary petition in bankruptcy yesterday in the Brooklyn Federal Court, listing liabilities of $23,187 and assets of $100 worth of clothing.

Mayor La Guardia decided yesterday to use a police radio car to supplement the services of John Peluso, his regular chauffeur who has been overworked since the Mayor established Summer headquarters in the Chisholm mansion in College Point, Queens.

China's imports of leaf tobacco increased more than three-fold in the first five months of 1937, compared with the corresponding period of 1936, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from the Assistant Commercial Attache in Shainghai.
A tworun rally in the eighth inning gave the Cardinals a 6-to-5 victory over the Pirates today in the opener of a two-game series.

FOR real excitement, sometimes with international complications, a sports fan has to go abroad. Things are pretty tame in this country. But take a quick glance back at some recent happenings on the Continent. The Admira soccer team of Vienna came back from Genoa on the double, with the players announcing that Premier Mussolini had banned their proposed collision with a Genoa team and chased them out of the country.

Wage increases persisted and employment gained in May despite widespread strikes, according to the July "Survey of Current Business," published by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce.
The lowest bid in the history of the United States Air Mail was offered today by Penneylvania-Central Air Lines of Pittsburgh for a new contract for carrying mail between Washington and Buffalo.

" Das Rheingold," first of five presentations of music-dramas in concert form that are to constitute a Wagner Festival under the direction of Fritz Reiner, was heard last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. The orchestra was that of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society.

Miss Katharine Goldthwaite Dorr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Goldthwaite Higginson Dorr of New York, was married to Dr. Dean Alexander Clark, son of Mrs. Charles Alexander Clark of St. Paul and the late Mr. Clark, this afternoon by the Rev. John A. Hutchison in the Brown Memorial Church here. Only members of the two families witnessed the ceremony.

Hooking up for the "rubber" duel between them, Yancey Christmas's Rough Time defeated A. C. Compton's Clingendaal by four lengths at level weights in the $2,000-added Suffolk Handicap, six-furlong feature at the opening of the Suffolk Downs Summer meeting today.

What our friends have to remember is that we Japanese do things in the Japanese way. This injunction of Prince KONOE, Japanese Premier, addressed through the Tokyo correspondent of THE TIMES to the American people, was deprived of its intended meaning and given an ironic twist, even before its publication here, by Japan's latest actions in China.

Residents of this city got their news from radio broadcasts or a strikers' newspaper today as a walkout of seventeen editorial employes, members of the American Newspaper Guild, forced suspension of The Herald-Review, Decatur's only daily paper.

The citizens' committee of strikeweary Johnstown announced tonight that more than seventy-five communities, civic organizations and groups had accepted invitations to meet here next Thursday to organize a national chain of citizens' committees.
Of the four thousand Boy Scouts who came to New York for the week-end, only a few lost their way,

The chief secretary to General Sung Cheh-yuan, chairman of the Hopei-Chahar Political Council and commander of China's Twentyninth Army, said yesterday there was no possibility of a return to normal in North China so long as Japanese troops remained south of the Great Wall.

What our friends have to remember is that we Japanese do things in the Japanese way. This injunction of Prince KONOE, Japanese Premier, addressed through the Tokyo correspondent of THE TIMES to the American people, was deprived of its intended meaning and given an ironic twist, even before its publication here, by Japan's latest actions in China.

Residents of this city got their news from radio broadcasts or a strikers' newspaper today as a walkout of seventeen editorial employes, members of the American Newspaper Guild, forced suspension of The Herald-Review, Decatur's only daily paper.

The citizens' committee of strikeweary Johnstown announced tonight that more than seventy-five communities, civic organizations and groups had accepted invitations to meet here next Thursday to organize a national chain of citizens' committees.

Witnesses told Trial, Examiner John T. Lindsay, presiding at a National Labor Relations Board hearing today, that Ford Motor Company service men beat them on a public highway within sight of motorists who were ordered "to get the hell out and mind your own business."
Of the four thousand Boy Scouts who came to New York for the week-end, only a few lost their way,

Charles H. Birnbaum, trading as Star Book and Novelty Company, Camden, N. J., has stipulated, according to an announcement today from the Federal Trade Commission, to discontinue representing that the herbs and roots he sells, or any combination thereof,
PEIPING--Further fighting took place outside the city as efforts were made to end the warfare. Japanese military officials demanded withdrawal of Chinese troops over a wide area west of Peiping.

Treacherous wickets gave bowlers the mastery in English cricket today and several matches were finished in two days. Warwickshire administered a real setback to the powerful Gloucestershire eleven, winning by an innings and 32 runs.
Offering will be made today by means of a prospectus through Amott, Baker Co., Inc., of 94,325 shares of new $1 par value capital stock of Sweet's Steel Company, Williamsport, Pa.

Judge Carl Foster in Superior Court today granted custody of her two younger daughters, Joan, 9, and Elizabeth, 8, to Mrs. Lydia Pedroja Simpson of New Haven, pending trial of the divorce action brought against her by Dr. George Gaylord Simpson of Stamford, palaeontologist of the American Museum of Natural History, New York.
Judge Paul Jones sentenced three men and two women to prison terms today for harboring Alvin Karpis gangsters following the Bremer kidnapping in St. Paul. All five pleaded guilty in Federal court.
A contingent of 244 Boy Scouts, part of an American delegation of 814, will sail tomorrow on the Aquitania to attend the Fifth International Boy Scout Jamboree at Bloomendaal-Vogelensang, Holland.

The plight of a Bronx baker who suspected .but could not prove that union officials and officers of a bakers' association were conspiring to drive him out of business because he cut prices was described yesterday at the bakery racket trial in Special Sessions.

An important decision concerning the whole Netherlands nation and part of Belgium will soon be taken by the Netherlands Government. It will Settle the crucial problem of the orthography of the Dutch language.
Acting on his own motion, Federal Judge William H. Holly appointed today Harry N. Gottlieb, attorney, a co-trustee for the Public Utilities Securities Corporation, known as Pusco.

Trading in the wholesale markets was the slowest in many months. Hardly a market was quotable in any class. The Kosher markets opened weak to lower under a very slow demand as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
The French Postoffice will create a special stamp issue to commemorate the dedication on Aug. 1 by the United

The International Longshoremen's Association, affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, rejected yesterday the proposal of spokesmen for John L. Lewis that it abandon its present status and accept a charter from the Committee for Industrial Organization.

General Milutin Neditch, chief of the Yugoslav general staff, arrived in Paris today for what army sources reported was a conference to strengthen military cooperation between France and her Little Entente allies. He was met by General Marie Gustave Gamelin, chief of the French general staff, and other officials.

Miss Dorothea Helen Banwell, daughter of Mrs. Herbert Banwell of this city, was married to the Rev. Howard Henry Hassinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hassinger, here this morning in St. Peter's Episcopal Church, of which the bridegroom is rector.

Bond values closed moderately higher yesterday following one of the quietest trading sessions on the New York Stock Exchange this year. Almost all groups participated, to some degree, in the improvement, although the sales volume receded to about $5,753,000, compared with $7,413,200 on last Friday.
Rain and wet grounds forced calling off a scheduled floodlight game between the Reds and the leagueleading Cubs tonight.

Without benefit of the words "burlesque" or "Minsky," three midtown theatres where the strip-tease had been the ultimate art until May 1 reopened yesterday afternoon within three hours of approval of their license applications by Commissioner Paul Moss.

Nineteen delicatessen store proprietors were fined $5 each in West Side Court yesterday for violating the Sunday law by selling foodstuffs between 10 A. M. and 4 P. M. Magistrate Anthony Burke warned the defendants that if violations were repeated he would invoke Section 2149 of the Penal Law providing for confiscation of merchandise by the police and its sale at public auction for charity.
The recent increase in fuel oil prices was necessitated by increased labor and transportation costs, according to G. Harvey Porter, managing director of the Oil Burner Institute.
With more waiters and other employes returning to work every day, the Paris hotel and restaurant strike shows signs of fizzling out just as the barber strike did two months ago.

A crowd of 300 children, sweltering in the heat, staged an effective sitdown strike at the intersection of Monmouth and Ninth Streets here today because the police shut off a sidewalk hydrant they had converted into a giant shower bath.
The city of Pittsburgh, Pa., will be in the market on Thursday with a new issue of $3,000,000 of generalimprovement notes. The notes will be dated July 1, 1937, and will mature on July 1, 1940.

Municipal Court Justice William Koch of Brooklyn, who was sworn in by Mayor La Guardia on July 1 to fill the vacancy created. by the death of Justice Charles H. Haubert, will be inducted tomorrow morning at the Seventh District Municipal Court, at Pennsylvania and Liberty Avenues, Brooklyn.

Johnny Kinder, young Plainfield, N. J., professional, with a par-shattering 69, paced a strong field over the Shawnee Country Club course today in the first eighteen holes of the twenty-first Shawnee open golf championship.

Because of the heavy increase in demand, which already had strengthened prices at important refining centers in the Southwest, the advance of 1/2 cent a gallon in the price of gasoline to be put into effect today by the domestic subsidiaries of the Standard Oil Company of New Jensey, had been expected.

Not only did C. D. Quaw, a New York angler, account for the fourth rod and reel broadbill catch at Montauk on Friday, but he followed this by landing the first white marlin to be brought into the Montauk Yacht Club this season.
The first cool weather in a week brought relief yesterday to sweltering New Yorkers and eased a heat wave that had turned almost the entire nation into a sizzling oven.

A luncheon conference of 100 corporation executives, called by a committee working in cooperation with the American Taxpayers League, was held yesterday at the Hotel Commodore to hear State Controller Morris S. Tremaine and Representative Emanuel Celler, New York Democrat, discuss taxation problems.

One of the very oldest colleges in the United States (established as an extension of King William's School in 1696)--St. John's College at Annapolis-is experiencing a renaissance and with all the courage and hopefulness of youth is setting forth to show what a small college of liberal arts can be in such a favoring environment, where in comparative retirement a revival of the ancient purposes of education may be attempted. The new president, Mr.

Services for Mrs. Elisabeth Stewart, known as "Aunt Lizzie" to hundreds in the congregations of the old Thirty-fourth Street Dutch Reformed Church and later the St. Nicholas Reformed Church, will be held today at 2:30 P. M. in the Presbyterian Home, 49 East Seventy-third Street, where she had lived for fifteen years. She died on Sunday at the age of 80.
Miss Lucy Beacco, 20 years old, a riding instructor at Stockbrldge, Mass.,

Tom Clarke, veteran engineer of the "Coronation Scot," crack train which brought King George VI and Queen Elizabeth from Edinburgh. had an investiture all to himself on the platform of Euston station today.

The new English-style residence at the southwest corner of Jane Street and Caterson Terrace, in the Manor Woods section of Hartsdale, Westchester County, has been sold to J. J. Mariner, who contemplates taking immediate occupancy.

Mrs. Adrian H. Larkin gave a dinner tonight at Les Alouettes, her home on Lake Agawam, for Mrs. James Barnes of Stoney Brook, Princeton, N. J., who is visiting Mr. and Mrs. Francis Rogers at Honeysuckle Cottage.

Weakened by the heavy rains, a ceiling on the fourth floor of a building that was being demolished at 100 Morningside Avenue collapsed yesterday injuring four laborers, one of them seriously. Four others who were working near-by rushed them to the street.

United States Ambassador Joseph E. Davies witnessed his first Red, Square spectacle today as 100,000 scantily-clad men and women athletes paraded past Joseph Stalin in the annual physical culture parade.

Twelve New York and New Jersey bus companies asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to set aside its order suspending the operation of a 25-cent bus fare between New York City and Hackensack, N. J.

Tremaine and Representative Emanuel Celler, New York Democrat, discuss taxation problems.

M. in the Presbyterian Home, 49 East Seventy-third Street, where she had lived for fifteen years. She died on Sunday at the age of 80.

Six members of the Oxford-Cambridge tennis team will arrive today on the Aquitania, for an extended tour. In the party will be G. T. Zarafi, F. M. Knott, G. Nicoleaidis and J. H. Wharton of Cambridge, and R. D. Riseley and W. M. Earle of Oxford. The team captain, J. D. Anderson of Oxford, will arrive later, The Associated Press reported.

It is the judicial opinion of Magistrate David L. Malbin, delivered yesterday in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, that ball playing in parks is a God-given right of boys and that older persons watching the games are there at their own peril.

Harry M. Lydenberg, director of the New York Public Library, expressed regret yesterday over the resignation of Keyes De Witt Metcalf, who will relinquish his post as chief of the reference department of the library to become director of libraries of Harvard University on Sept. 1.

Democratic leaders in the city, on the eve of a third general conference today on the Mayoralty situation, were still completely "up in the air" last night in their search for a candidate pleasing to all factions.

The new English-style residence at the southwest corner of Jane Street and Caterson Terrace, in the Manor Woods section of Hartsdale, Westchester County, has been sold to J. J. Mariner, who contemplates taking immediate occupancy.

Mrs. Adrian H. Larkin gave a dinner tonight at Les Alouettes, her home on Lake Agawam, for Mrs. James Barnes of Stoney Brook, Princeton, N. J., who is visiting Mr. and Mrs. Francis Rogers at Honeysuckle Cottage.

Weakened by the heavy rains, a ceiling on the fourth floor of a building that was being demolished at 100 Morningside Avenue collapsed yesterday injuring four laborers, one of them seriously. Four others who were working near-by rushed them to the street.

United States Ambassador Joseph E. Davies witnessed his first Red, Square spectacle today as 100,000 scantily-clad men and women athletes paraded past Joseph Stalin in the annual physical culture parade.

Twelve New York and New Jersey bus companies asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to set aside its order suspending the operation of a 25-cent bus fare between New York City and Hackensack, N. J.

Mrs. Kate Wolfe of Plattsburg, N. Y., widow of Louis Wolfe, retail shoe merchant of that city, died on Saturday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Irving Sherline, at 1,515 East Twenty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, after a short illness.

Tom Robbins, amateur from Grassy Sprain, and his professional partner, George McLean, put together a 32, 34-66 to win the best-ball honors in the weekly one-day tournament sponsored by the Westchester County Golf Association at the Leewood Golf Club today.

A new administration study of the housing situation directed particularly at reducing rents by attracting money now placed in savings banks into the field of -limited dividend housing construction, was disclosed today.

Alex Cameron Jr. of the Southampton Golf Club took the low net prize with a score of 80-12-8 in the regular Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament today over the Southampton Golf Club course.

Clean-cut victories still eluded the Canadian riflemen today, but excellent marksmanship has the men from the Dominion in tie shoots for the Alexandra Challenge Cup and The Daily Telegraph Silver Cup.

Four former Ford Motor Company employes, with twelve to fifteen years' experience in the automobile industry and varying terms of employment with Ford, told John T. Lindsay, trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board, today that they were dismissed after joining the union or after showing signs of union interest, although their work had been praised by their superiors as eminently satisfactory.

The last chapter in London's coronation bus strike, which was the most unpopular and most completely defeated strike in the history of the British. Trade Union movement, was written tonight when the Transport Workers Union expelled three strike leaders for alleged Communistic activities.

Solution of five major problems will be sought by retail china and glassware buyers during the coming year in cooperation with producers of this merchandise, it was decided yesterday at a luncheon meeting of buyers affiliated with the housewares, china and glassware group of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Dr. Ernest Gruening has resigned as head of the Puerto Rico Reconstruction Administration. President Roosevelt accepted his resignation today.

Major Green, convicted slayer of Mrs. Mary Harriet Case in her Jackson Heights apartment Jan. 11, is to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing during the week of Aug. 16, the Court of Appeals today having affirmed the conviction. The court wrote no opinion.

Favored by cooler weather and the arrival of many more buyers, placing of Fall orders for women's apparel gained appreciably here yesterday. The buyers who viewed lines of dresses and coats last week got down to the actual business of writing orders, with the question of obtaining prompt deliveries being an important factor.

New York City's millions, who had been mopping their brows and sweltering in the soaring temperatures of a near-record heat wave for six days, received a temporary breathing spell yesterday as somewhat cooler weather followed on the heels of the thunderstorm that swept the city Monday afternoon.
The Indians backed up Dennis Galehouse's seven-hit pitching with four double plays and just enough hitting today to defeat the White Sox, 2 to 1, in the only game played in the series.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Flied-By MEYER C. FOX, formerly a druggist, at 650 E. 156th St., residing at 835 Trinity Ave.-Liabilities $2,994; assets $10, exclusive of insurance and proceeds of sale under execution. CARMEL RAIMONDO, employe, 75 Jefferson Ave., White Plains-Liabilities $543: assets $25.

An extortion charge against William Monahan, 38 years old, of 708 West 192d Street, was dismissed yesterday by Justice Thomas C. Kadien in a habeas corpus proceeding in the special term of the Queens Supreme Court, Jamaica.

Emmett Dalton, final survivor of the notorious pitched battle in Coffeyville, Kan., which ended the terrorizing rides of the Dalton Gang of the early Nineties, died at his home here today after an eight-year illness. He was 66 years of age. He left a widow, the former Julia Johnson, of Bartlesville, Okla.

For the fifth time in the history of St. Louis's municipal opera a new musical production, the operetta "Salute to Spring" was given to the world last night. The premiere was attended by 9,700 persons at the open-air theatre in wooded and rolling Forest Park.

Thomas F. Dugan of the E. A. Cummings Post of the American Legion was unanimously elected Kings County commander last night at the closing session of the county convention at the Knights of Columbus Clubhouse,
Miss Virginia Enfield, fashion director of the American Enka Corporation, will sail today on the Aquitania to visit London and Paris.
Although the bond market gave signs yesterday of tiring from the recent broad upward movement, prices in the main body of investment issues held fairly steady with-in a narrow trading range.

New life insurance written last month was 7.4 per cent greater than in June, 1936, while the total for the first six months of this year rose 8.9 per cent above the corresponding period of 1936, according to the Association of Life Insurance Presidents, in a report to the United States Department of Commerce.

Proposal by the National Apparel Chain Stores that manufacturers of $4.75 dresses change their price bracket to $5.25 met opposition at a meeting yesterday at the offices of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group, 1,440 Broadway, where seventy-five of the largest producers failed to take definite action.

Funeral services for John B. Renwick, hotel man and founder of Renwick's "jigger shop" at Princeton, were held yesterday afternoon at Campbell's Funeral Chapel, Sixty-sixth Street and Broadway. Mr. Renwick, who was 78 years old, died Saturday.

Formation of the General Motor Overseas Corporation, reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission by General Motors Corporation, subscriber to and owner of the entire capital of the new company, concerns routine mechanical operations of the General Motors group abroad, officers said yesterday.

Formter Prince Bydy Mdivani, old Bolshevist leader in Georgia, who is alleged to have strayed into the Trotskyist fold, was executed with seven associates on charges of treason and terroristic conspiracy against the leaders of the Socialist State.

Workers in a factory at Mannheim voted to contribute five pfennigs each a week to send a certain number of comrates chosen by lot to the Tokyo Olympics. The company is contributing the same amount as the workers.
School elections were held yesterday in Long Island villages which did not ballot on education board members and school budgets in the Spring. The results were reported as follows:

Ludwig Bemelmans still clings to his primary literary love, books for children, but as soon as he can get around to it he plans to write "A Handy Guide to Dilettante Archaeological and Ethnological Exploration in South America," because he thinks such a volume would have phenomenal popularity in this country.
A formal letter was sent tonight by Federal Judge William Clark to General Hugh S. Johnson inviting him to confer on conditions in the silkrayon printing industry in the North Jersey sector.

Blunt warnings by eminent Protestant leaders that more than doctrinal utterances, adoption of resolutions and simple homilies are necessary to re-establish the church as an effective force in modern life marked today the beginning of actual work by the World Conference on Church, Community and State.
Stocks sagged and closed irregularly lower in less active trading; turnover, 849,110 shares. All groups of bonds steady and mixed; transactions, $6,451,000.
Newark breezed to a 9-1 decision over the lowly Jersey City Giants tonight behind splendid six-hit twirling by big Steve Sundra, who gained credit for his ninth consecutive victory of the season.
The city's five Democratic county organizations appeared headed for a break-up, possibly as thorough as that of 1933, as a result of an ultimatum issued yesterday by James J. Dooling, Tammany leader.

The Interstate Commerce Commission declined today to ratify the appointment of Vincent Dailey, former New York State manager of the Home Owners Loan Corporation and State Democratic Committeeman, as a trustee of the New York, Ontario Western Railroad, but it did ratify the appointment of Fred E. Lyford, assistant to the vice president of the Baldwin Locomotive Works.
The tax on undistributed earnings of corporations does not improve with age. On the contrary, its harmful results and lack of equity become daily more obvious.
After a lifetime of service to the German people, Dr. ALICE SALOMON, one of the world's most distinguished sociologists, has been expelled from the Reich by the secret police.

The shipyards of the world are engaged in the construction of 2,862,86O tons of commercial shipping, an increase of 430,809 tons, or 17.6 per cent in the last three months, according to the quarterly report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, which was published yesterday.

Matt Kowal, assistant professional of the Philmont Country Club, Philadelphia, spread-eagled the field at the halfway mark in the Shawnee open golf championship today by carding a brilliant 67, one stroke over the course record, and adding this scorching round to his sub-par 70 for a thirtysix hole total of 137, seven under par.
Mrs. Alexander Hamilton Rice, the former Eleanor Elkins, wife of the surgeon and explorer, died suddenly here this afternoon.

Annie's high spirits were bound to get her in trouble. First it was stealing rides in a dumbwaiter, then jumping seven-foot fences. She took the fence in back of her home yesterday, landed in a hole on the other side and started meowing.
With an attendance of 500 buyers setting a record for the first day's sessions, the eighth annual convention of the Boys Apparel Buyers Association began yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Owing to recent expansion in the real-estate market, Douglas Gibbons Co. has enlarged its quarters by taking a floor in 71 East Fiftyseventh Street, adjoining the main offices at 73 East Fifty-seventh Street.

A second mortgage for $2,500, payable $50 monthly at 3 per cent, was given by the 411 East 100th St. Realty Corp. to Vincenzo and Providenza Lemmo on the flat at 311 East 100th St., subject to a first mortgage for $17,000.

A majority of the 800 employes of the Reed Prince Manufacturing Company today repudiated the leadership of a C. I. 0. organizer who called them out on strike seven weeks ago and agreed to sign a contract offered by the company on June 2.

The Workers Alliance of America, which as the "union of the unemployed" is sponsor of the current wave of sit-down strikes and mass demonstrations against WPA dismissals, has instructed its national executive board to seek "closer association with the C. I. 0., organizationally. so that we may become an integral part of that great movement," it was revealed yesterday.

Miss Alice Marie Quinn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Quinn of this place, has selected July 31 as the date of her marriage to J. Peter Jaffe, son of Mrs. George E. Ratsey of Greacen Point, Mamaroneck. The ceremony will take place at the home here of the prospective bride's parents.

Gerin Cameron of Tulsa University, runner-up for the national intercollegiate tennis championship, was eliminated from the Spring Lake invitation tournament today as play started on the clay courts of the Bathing and Tennis Club with a field of sixty-four headed by Wilmer Allison.

Late tonight the Arab High Committee received a reply from Abdul-Aziz Ibn Saud, King of Saudi Arabia, to its recent cable asking the ruler's advice on the plan to partition Palestine. The message of Ibn Saud said:

Antnony William Hall, otherwise Apthony Tudor, who asserts that King George is "a usurper" and that he (Hall) is Great Britain's rightful sovereign, was fined [Pound]1 in the police court in Southend today.

As an aftermath to the question of the legality of Harold S. Vanderbilt jibing his Ranger without taking in his spinnaker, delegates of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound have been asked to vote on an amendment to the rules dealing with the question at a special meeting at the Larchmont Yacht Club next Wednesday.

1st Lieut. Joseph C. Weber, C.A.-Reg.. is relieved from further assignment and duty with CCC Co. 288, Camp Army-3 (N. J.). Fort Hancock, N. J., and will proceed on or about July 25 to CCC Co. 3212c, Camp SCS-3 (N. J.), Camp Dix, N. J.

An increase of close to 10 per cent over a year ago is being shown currently in the registrations of the arrival of buyers in the wholesale markets here. The attendance of store representatives is now approaching the seasonal peak, which is expected to be reached next week.

167TH ST, 494 E (9-2371), Delia A. Gruenstein to Ethel Morrison. 1,282 Stebbins Ave. 134TH ST (9-2317), n s. 100 w of Lincoln Ave, 25x200; Mogul Realty Co, Inc, to Bluma Savetsky, 2,791 University Ave.
A group headed by former President Pascual Ortiz Rubio obtained a concession from President Lazaro

Possible confirmation of astronomical indications, which are a part of ancient lore, that the six brilliant star "sisters" comprising the Pleiades, once numbered seven, was seen today as the result of studies by the Harvard Observatory.
The Dutch guilder assumed the spotlight yesterday in foreign exchange movements and advanced 101/2 points to a new high level for the year, 55.10 cents.

The state Board of Bar Examiners made public today the names of 152 candidates who passed the recent examination for admission to the practice of law as attorneys. There were 201 other members of the class who failed. The list of those successful follows:

Dr. Karl N. Llewellyn, chairman of the City Industrial Relations Board, and his two colleagues, whose work was recently taken over by the new State Industrial Relations Board, will receive distinguished service certificates from Mayor La Guardia at 10 o'clock on Friday morning in City Hall.

PEIPING--Continued clashes between Japanese and Chinese troops around Peiping were accompanied by an increase in tension in the city. An artillery duel shook the southern part of the city during the night. The Japanese Army was disposing its forces strategically and sending many reinforcements into the Peiping area. Page 1.
The Committee for Industrial Organization abandoned unexpectedly today a move to have Governor Martin L. Davey explain the use of National Guardsmen in the Ohio steel strike zone.

A further increase in deposits of Barclays Bank Limited of London, one of the "Big Five" banks of England, is disclosed in the statement of accounts as of June 30, made public here yesterday by its New York representative.

The Baltic republics of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania will not revise their present strict neutrality policy or adopt new orientation. This is the gist of a statement issued today by the Assistant Foreign Minister of Estonia in refutation of persistent rumors which increased after the recent visits to the Baltic countries of the Earl of Plymouth and Foreign Minister Richard J. Sandler of Sweden.

Through the eyes of Sam A. Scribner, newly designated executive secretary, the board of six which will govern the new "burlesque" has seen the first performances and if they accept his report the "variety" shows will get virtually a clean bill of health.

Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw gave a luncheon yesterday at Hazeldean, her home at Sands Point, Port Washington, L. I., for Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt. Other guests were Mrs. Theodore Weicker, Mrs. Charles H. Higgins, Mrs. Theodore Whitney Blake, Mrs. Frederic Van Lennep, Mrs. Raymond Brown, Mrs. Edward Sparrow, Mrs. Robert L. Macneil, Mrs. Arthur H. Scribner, Miss Elvira Wilson, Mrs. Claire Dana Mumford, Mrs. Christian R. Holmes, Mrs. Hicks Kelly and Mrs. Dana Converse Backus.
James H. Winford, pitcher for the St. Louis Cardinals, was operated upon today for an infected appendix. Dr. Gustave F. Berg said he was "fighting for his life."

THIS fellow Fette must be quite a pitcher. A big league freshman at 30 years of age, he may turn out to be a twenty-game winner this year. He turned in his tenth victory of the season for the Boston Bees on Sunday, when he beat the Phillies, 1-0, in thirteen innings.

George B. Alexander, who retired five years ago as head of George B. Alexander Sons, produce merchants of Washington Market in New York, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 33 Forest Avenue.

Mrs. Mary Tilton Hyde of New York, wife of Professor Charles Cheney Hyde of Columbia University, died at her Summer home, The Barnacle, today after a long illness. Her age was 62. Mr. Hyde is Professor of International Law at Columbia.

In affirming a decision of the Appellate Division, Second Department, that a declaratory judgment was not available to Percy Campbell Reed, proprietor and operator of a dog racing track at the Mineola Fair Grounds in Garden City, the Court of Appeals, with Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane writing the opinion, said today:

Miss Ida Sledge, a labor organizer, who said she had been twice escorted out of Tupelo, went to her home in Memphis today "for clean clothes" but said she would return tomorrow. She declared that garment workers here were being Mr. forced to join "company unions."

The decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court upholding Conde Nast's ownership of shorefront property which had been claimed by the town of North Hempstead was held In legal circles to have a wide bearing on ownership in the vicinity of the Nast property.

Steel ingot production ran at slightly higher than its previous rate last week, but only for four working days, and the adjusted index slumped to 100.6 from 113.2. It was 110.6 for the week ended July 11, 1936.

A new issue of $3,500,000 of Liquid Carbonic Corporation ten-year 4 per cent convertible sinking fund debentures will be marketed today by a syndicate comprising Munds, Winslow Potter; Spencer Trask Co.; Merrill, Lynch Co.; Cassatt Co.. Inc.. and associates.
An uncensored if optimistic report of conditions in Madrid and government Spain was given today by an American who had just returned from Madrid.

The Court of Appeals today unanimously reversed orders of the Appellate Division, First Department, which had denied New York City motions to dismiss the complaints in actions against the city's utility tax.
The State Tax Department reported today that assessed valuations of real estate in New Jersey for 1937 show a decrease of $74,047,522 from 1936.
Helen Spahr Chapman, a graduate of Smith College in 1923 and of the New York School of Social Work in 1937, died yesterday in the Flushing Hospital of pneumonia. She was 34 years old.

Holders of Hussmann-Ligonier Company common stock are to be offered the right to subscribe pro rata for 25,000 additional shares at $22.50 a share, the New York Curb Exchange has been informed. The date at which the stock will sell exrights will be announced later. Deliveries after July 16 and until further notice must carry due bills for the rights.

As custodian of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's FourYear Plan for the renovation of the national economy, Col. Gen. Hermann Goering decreed today a series of measures calling for a radical overhaul of the present administration of raw products and foreign trade.

Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission, emphasized yesterday the importance of continuing to keep the water along the southern shore of Long Island, from New York City to Fire Island Inlet, free of pollution as an essential for the continued success of the Jones Beach and Fire Island State Park developments.

JUNIOR SINGLES Second Round Robert Low, New York, defeated Harold Schein. New York, by default; Wilson Barnes, Providence, R. I., defeated Fayette White, Holyoke, Mass., 6-3, 6-4; William Gillespie, Scarborough, N. Y., defeated Joseph Greenberg, Brooklyn,

The House today overrode a Presidential veto of the Farm Loan Bill by the overwhelming vote of 260 to 98. The bill continues low interest rates on government farm mortgages despite President Roosevelt's objections that it would cost the government $52,000,000 and delay or hinder a balancing of the budget.

ASOBERING and almost Incredible story of English criminal law and procedure in the late eighteenth century is told in Sir Frank Douglas MacKinnon's "Grand Larceny" (Oxford, $3), an account of the trial of Mrs. Jr ne Leigh Perrot, Jane Austen's aunt, who was arrested, in 1799 on the charge of stealing goods from a retail shop.

A second Japanese - army - a tremendous force of civilian adventurers and fortune seekers who inevitably follow every penetrating advance of the Japanese military-is now concentrating in Tientsin in everincreasing numbers.

The Department of Commerce reported today that imports in June of gold into the United States, totaling $262,102,813, were the largest for any month since the gold sterilization program was started last December.
House members forced a forty-minute roll-call today on a $1,200-a-year janitorship. Representative Warren, chairman of the Accounts Committee, asked the janitorship for the House Education Committee.

At the annual meeting yesterday of Remington Rand, Inc., James H. Rand Jr., president, told the stockholders that a preliminary estimate put sales for June at $4,070,000, or 30.4 per cent more than the $3,122,279 in June, 1936.
A block of 59,327 shares of the common stock of Harvey Hubbell, Inc., manufacturers of electrical equipment, will be placed on the market today by Paul H. Davis Co. and H. M. Byllesby Co., Inc.

The heat wave up to last Saturday had no appreciable effect on the city's general death rate for the week, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday in his health-survey. With 1,299 deaths from all causes reported, the death rate was only 9.1 to 1,000 of population, as- compared with an average rate of 11.3 for the twenty-seven weeks since the first of the vear.

The American Republic Corporation, Houston, Texas, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 218,000 shares of $10 par value common stock for an aggregate amount of $3,270,120.

Argentina's exports for the first half of this year were the largest in the country's history, amounting to 11,278,154 tons, which was 87 per cent more than the volume in the corresponding period of last year and about 700,000 tons higher than the previous high record, set in 1927.
After an extended absence from newspapers dating back to 1929, the Dictaphone Sales Corporation will launch an advertising campaign in New York newspapers today.

Fighting an uphill battle for five periods against a three-goal handicap and a hard-riding polo team from Governors Island, the Monmouth County Country Club quartet, which is leading in the Eastern Polo League tournament, today eliminated the officers from the twelve-goal Rumson Country Club tournament by a 13-to-9 victory on Herbert Memorial Field.

The Rev. Charles Lee Mackey of Pleasantville died yesterday in the Northern Westchester Hospital at Mount Kisco. He had been an invalid since 1930, when he retired as pastor of the Sloatsburg (N. Y.) Methodist Episcopal Church. His age was 78.
Former Princess Erik of Denmark, who before here marriage was Miss Lois Booth of Ottawa, Ont., was married here yesterday to Thorkild Juelsberg, formerly her secretary.
The Court of Appeals ruled today that certificate holders of the Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company of Sullivan County have prior interest in uncertificated portions of mortgages.

The Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, through exercise of an option of 50,040 shares of capital stock, purchase of 26,591 shares from a shareholder and purchase of convertible income notes which were exchange for 31,292 shares more, has obtained 55.27 per cent control of Electromaster. Inc.
The United States Ambassador made an effort yesterday to obtain a special train for the evacuation of 100 American army people, who are scheduled to leave Chinwangtao on a transport sailing Friday.

The first pay checks carrying wage increases of from 10 to 25 per cent will go out this week to employes of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and the Third Avenue Railway System, it was announced yesterday by Austin Hogan, general secretary of the Transport Workers Union, which negotiated the pay increases.

Edward Zuccari, 20 years old, who says he lives at 600 Riverside Drive, was in the line-up at Police Headquarters yesterday for a few minutes because, as he was reported to have remarked, the best way to become a "G-man" or a detective is to prove you have the qualifications for the job.

" The Show Is On" is announced to close on Saturday night, and the word seems to be official. (The revue had been scheduled once before to depart, then was reprieved with the signing of. the Howard brothers.)

On the steps of the Sub-Treasury Building at Broad and Wall Streets, which marks the site where George Washington was inaugurated and Congress held its early sessions, a historical pageant was presented yesterday.
The Summer colony was largely represented in the capacity audience that filled the Casino Theater tonight for the opening of the eight-week theatrical season.
Leading mills making tropical worsteds have again delayed naming opening prices on their Spring, 1938, lines, and it is now planned to announce the new prices next Monday.

The Right Rev. Philip Charles Thurlow Crick, Assistant Bishop of Derby and former Bishop of Rockhampton, Australia, with a diocese of 223,000 square miles and 100,000 inhabitants, died in Chichester today at the age of 54.

A new paper, water and oil proof and air tight and made of Koroseal, a new synthetic elastic material recently developed in the laboratories of the B. F. Goodrich Company at Akron, Ohio, was announced yesterday by J. H. Connors, vice president and general manager.

Concluding their two-day stand in this steaming metropolis today, the Giants appeared to be very horizontal and out colder than anything within miles of the place when suddenly they blasted themselves out from behind the eight ball in a manner most amazing.

At a conference of the Commonwealth Council of Scientific and Industrial Research and the State Department of Agriculture it was announced that since 1930 Australia's production of usable tobacco had risen from 6 per cent to 25 per cent.

Although the $1,400 he found last Thursday in the Bronx would havel taken him to any Summer resort he chose, Henry Nathanson, 16 years old, of 1,817 Mohegan Avenue, just continued on his way to the neighborhood swimming pool, tossed the envelope into a locker with his sneakers and went swimming.

Miss Joan Day Pattinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. Graham Pattinson of this place, will be married here on July 27 in Christ Episcopal Church to Oscar T. Lawler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Lawler of Beverly Hills, Calif. The.ceremony will be followed by a reception at the Pattinson home.

Appointment of the Rev. Charles J. Woodbridge as editor of The Presbyterian Guardian, militant Fundamentalist periodical, was announced today by the Rev. Paul Woolley, president of the Guardian Corporation and a member of the faculty of Westminster Theological Seminary.

Mayor La Guardia will start a series of Summer lectures on New York City government and administration in the Summer City Hall at College Point at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon, when he will address eighteen college students.

When, at one point in his attack in the House today on the President's court legislation and its various substitutes, Representative Sumners said that other retirements of Supreme Court justices would follow the laying aside of the bill, he outlined what to many has seemed the best and the likeliest solution'of the controversy that has halted the wheels of Congress, embroiled the Democratic party and threatened Mr. Roosevelt's leadership.

Lending institutions have been receiving prices in liquidation of foreclosed properties that average approximately the same in relation to assessed value as prices obtained by private traders, according to an analysis made by the Real Estate Board of New York of the 1,080 "bona fide" realty transactions in Manhattan during the first half of 1937.

The time will come when, by the injection of some substance into the blood stream, women may be made sterile for two or three years, Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association, said yesterday.

Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford will give a dinner party at The Hedges on Friday evening before the op??0 play at the John Drew Memorial Theatre. Students of the Studio of Acting will present "The Crime at Blossom's," by Mordaunt Sharp, as the first in a series of four plays at the Guild Hall Theatre.
Johnny Bonito, 137, Bronx, outpointed Quentin Breese, 139, Manhattan, Kan., in the feature sixround bout before 5,000 persons at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night.

Despite generally improved business conditions, many home owners still are in distress over their mortgages, and the Municipal Committee for the Relief of Home Owners, with main offices at 149 Broadway, has been receiving an increasing number of calls for aid in ironing out home-financing problems, according to James N. MacLean, general chairman.
For the first time this year a ball game at Ebbets Field yesterday ended in the manner that is most warming to the hearts of all Flatbush boys-with a Brooklyn home run into Bedford Avenue.

The marriage of Miss Dorothea Nanette Lindenthal, daughter of Mrs. Edmund Lindenthal of White Plains and the late Mr. Lindenthal, to Stephen Marshall Fox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon S. Fox, also of White Plains, will take place Saturday afternoon at the Lindenthal home.

The Democratic Senators who are now carrying the brunt of the fight against the Administration's new Court Bill are keeping faith with two principles which are essential to the preservation of our system of democracy. They are fighting, first, for the independence of the judiciary.

While the British Government put the finishing touches to its compromise plan before circulating it to twenty-seven non-intervention States tomorrow, the news reached London via Rome that Portugal would soon restore international control of her land frontier with Spain.

A new market for motor buses and trolley buses was reported today by the Commerce Department in an announcement from the Premier of New South Wales, Australia. All tramways in Sydney are to be replaced by buses.

Royal Spencer, brown colt from Spencer out of Hollyrood Susan, owned by the Biery Farm of Butler, Pa., and driven by Charles Lacey, won the 2-year-old trot that featured the opening of the Grand Circuit meeting at Historic track today.

Premier Paul van Zeeland offered to resign today, but King Leopold refused to permit it. The offer came as a climax to a political crisis that had been brewing for months and as a result of which the Minister of Justice, Victor de la Veley, resigned yesterday.

Eleven more cases in which great sums of money were saved to taxpayers through use of personal holding companies and other devices permissible under the revenue laws were presented today to the Joint Congressional Tax Evasion Committee now making a study of how to close loopholes in the statutes and thus increase the government's revenue.

Salesand rentals of homes in Brooklyn were reported by brokers yesterday. For the Dime Savings Bank, the Charles Partridge Real Estate Company, Inc., sold dwellings as follows: 24 Seventh Avenue, to Delia Wyttig; 238 Berkeley Place, to J. Kelley;

With 8,000 applications already received by the Emergency Relief Bureau from dismissed WPA workers, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator, gave assurance yesterday that no further forced layoff would be necessary to cut the number of persons on work relief to 150,000 by tomorrow.

A tax lien for $23,711.55 covering an assessment on the income of Max Schmeling, German heavyweight fighter, for 1932 and 1933 was filed yesterday in Federal court by Joseph T. Higgins, Collector of Internal Revenue.

A dozen spokesmen of maritime labor, including union officials and seamen whose ships are in port, criticized living and working conditions on American vessels yesterday when the Maritime Commission started an investigation to determine recommendations as to basic wages, personnel and working conditions.

A series of defense motions to dismiss a $20,000,000 accounting suit against present and former officials of the Long Island Lighting Company were denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy. The suit was brought by several small stockholders.

Facing possible deportation, a German seaman on the New York Cuba Mail liner Orizaba, bound here from Veracruz, Mexico, leaped overboard Monday night about fifty miles off the Delaware Capes, and, with only a small plank to buoy him, headed toward what he thought was the New Jersey shore, though in reality he was swimming toward Europe.

For their exhibits at the New York World's Fair of 1939 the International Business Machines Corporation has signed a contract for 3,653 square feet of space in the Hall of Business Administration at a cost of $51,142, and John A. Roebling's Sons Company has contracted for 1,575 square feet in the Halls of Production at a cost of $20,286, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair.

Dr. H. H. Kung, Vice President of the Executive Yuan Vice Premier] and Finance Minister of China said yesterday in a statement to the press here that his country was ready to fight Japan to prevent further losses of territory. He has been in this country three weeks on an economic mission.

Miss Alice Regina Carroll, daughter of Justice and Mrs. Charles J. Carroll 'of '97' Norman Avenue, Brooklyn, has chosen the morning of July 27 for her marriage to Raymond John Pellman, son of Mrs. Bernard Pellman of Cincinnati and the late Mr. Pellman.

Directors of the General Tire and Rubber Company yesterday authorized the payment to stockholders of all accumulated dividends on the preferred stock, amounting to $7.50 a share, W. O'Neil, president, announced.
Claude Hildebrandt, 25, of Athens, is in the Bradford County jail at Towanda today accused by Police Chief Nobles of attempting to kill his wife by deliberately wrecking his automobile.
Representative J. Burrwood Daly of Philadelphia became an admiral today of the sea forces of Nebraska. A scroll and cap were presented to him at ceremonies in Speaker Bankhead's office.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,520,750 barrels, compared with 3,525,650 in the previous week, a decline of 4,900, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
The Ford Motor Company Rouge plant and twoscore other plants and branches throughout the country will close for the annual inventory and vacation period next Friday.

Contracts for motor vehicles to cost $820,997.79 were awarded by the War Department today as follows: Indian Motorcycle Company, Springfield, Mass.-26 motor cycles; 108 motorcycles with side car, $59,900.73.
The opening of the Syce Cup series for the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound had a definitely Larchmont trend today.

In dedicating the Lower West Side Health Center in Chelsea Park yesterday, Mayor La Guardia said it was strange that such a project should be referred to as "an a complishment." The work should have been started fifty years ago, he observed.
The stock markets continued quiet today,'but firmness -was prevalent generally, and some of the sections advanced. Gilt-edge issues were steady, while among the foreign loans French bonds were dull.
The towns school committee voted 3 to 2 tonight against reappointing Isabell-Hallin as a high school teacher and against granting her a public hearing on its action.
Dr. S. Dana Hubbard, dermatologist and member of the Board of Health here for forty years, died Monday night in New York Hospital, where he had been ill for two weeks. He wa. 68 years old.
Victor Laloux, director of the School of American Art at Fontainebleau, died at his Paris home today. He was 87 years old.

By JOSEPH P. DAY 90th St, 164-166 E, 2 5-story tenements. 60x100.8; Chase National Bank of New York against Clemence G. Lemle: due, $104,297; taxes, , $7,162: to plaintiff for $85,000. Norfolk St, 168, 5-story tenement and stores, 25x100; Dorothy C. McManus against Ralph Scognimillo; due, $15,325; to plaintiff for $14,000.

Turpentine firm, 350; sales, 295 barrels; receipts, 687 barrels; shipments, 30 barrels; stock, 31,624 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 851; receipts, 2,995: shipments, 1,743; stock, 64,974. Quote: B to M, $7.90; N, $7.90-.921/2; WG, $7.921/2; WW, X, $8.75.

Two ships of the Fall River Line were held at their piers last night by a strike of the National Maritime Union in protest against the alleged methods of the line in conducting a recent election at which its employes were asked to designate a labor bargaining agency.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are July 12 unless specified: At Chefoo: Blackhawk, Tulsa. At Ketchikan: Borie, Dallas, Long, Wasmuth, Zane. At La Haina: Lark, Tanager. Altair, at Pyramid Cove.

France's discontinuance of the nonintervention control on her southern frontier is interpreted here as the first frank admission by her Popular Front government that the Valencia regime has its full official sympathy and must be supported, preferably in concert with Britain but independently if diplomatic manoeuvring fails to bring about this desired Anglo-French agreement.

" Oh, look mother, isn't he cute!" cried the forty-pound girl yesterday afternoon as she pointed to Peter, the Bronx Zoo's 4,500-pound hippopotamus. That was the last straw for Peter the Great, already disappointed by the small turnout for his thirty-fourth birthday.

Apparently jubilant over a chance to return to work after forty-six days of strike idleness, most of the 7,000 employes of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company plant at East Chicago, Ind., went back to their jobs today.
Professor Henry Edward Armstrong, for sixty years an outstanding figure in British chemistry, died at Lewisham today at the age of 89.

Donald Hawley of Orange, top-seeded player, vanquished John Curtiss, Cornell instructor, for the second time in three days in a secondround match of the Glen Ridge open championship at the Glen Ridge Tennis Club today. Hawley scored over the New Yorker in the final of the Mountain Lakes tournament Sunday.
The Chase National Bank headed the successful banking group yesterday in the purchase of $1,400,000 of water and street improvement bonds of the City of Charlotte, N. C.

Delegates to the annual encampment of the New York State Department of United Spanish War Veterans unanimously nominated Clarence W. Burke of Schenectady for department commander today. The election will be held tomorrow. Joseph Roemhild of Buffalo was nominated for senior vice commander.

The Association of Workers in Public Relief Agencies, which claims 6,000 members among the employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau in this city, applied yesterday for affiliation with the newly chartered C. I. O. union of State, county and municipal employes.

Frank Stewart Bowes, originator of the formal arbitration procedure used by the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards and active in realty circles in the Oranges for more than thirty years, died yesterday at his Summer home in Point Pleasant, N. J. Mr. Bowes, who resided here, was in his fiftyfourth year.

J. P. Morgan, who has been at Matinecock Point, his home here on East Island in Long Island Sound, plans to sail on Monday on his yacht, the Corsair, for Southampton, England, from which port he will motor to Wall Hall, his estate in Watford, Herts.

Cabled acceptance of an invitation to play in the first annual $2,500 Plattsburg-Champlain open golf tournament has been received from Ralph Guldahl, United States open champion, it was announced yesterday.

The General Public Service Corporation reports a net asset value of $9,022,657 at June 30, equal to $180.45 per $100 of debentures, to $175.66 a share of preferred stock and to $2.59 a share of common stock, against $10,244,727 or $204.89 per $100 of debentures, $210.46 a share of preferred and $3.55 a common share at Dec. 31.

Banging his drives over 300 yards straight down the middle of the course and putting with a wizardry that left the huge gallery gasping, Henry Cotton, recently crowned British open golf champion, beat Denny Shute, American Professional Golfers Association titleholder, in their seventy-two hole match for $2,500 at the Walton Heath links today by 6 and 5.

Japanese troops and military supplies from Manchukuo continued flooding Tientsin's railway station yesterday. One train brought a detachment of Manchukuoans, believed to be a maintenance corps and labor unit.

Manhattan Alterations 7th Ave, 2,304-6; to two 5-story tenements and stores; Simon B. Bernstein, 15 E 40th St, owner; Charles B. Meyers, architect: cost $15,000. Suffolk St. 53; to 5-story tenement; Abraham Wald, 165 Penn St. Brooklyn, owner; Hugo Tausig, architect; cost $15,000.
I know an elm in Merryall That valley of delight hose leaves and nested branches Make lattices of light; Whose tower of green from far is seen Enrapturing the sight.
Every citizen who believes in peace, industrial or otherwise, will say amen to Mayor LA GUARDIA'S comments on the peace which has just been signed in the ladies' garment industry of New York City.
The Imperial Airways flying boat Caledonia completed the second leg of her return trip to England today, reaching here after a flight of seven hours and twenty-seven minutes from Montreal.
Continued drought in the Prairie Provinces indicates a 1937 wheat crop of not more than 170,000,000 bushels and sent wheat prices soaring today.
