Representative Silveira was released from prison last night following his successful appeal from conviction on charges of taking part in the revolt in November, 1935. The Appellate Court decided the evidence did not warrant a conviction.
Spanish Government forces drove powerfully tonight against bitter Insurgent opposition to push out their salients west of Madrid.
William Gilman Low and his daughter, Miss Rhoda Low, who have been at the Ambassador since their return from Newport, will sail today on the Aquitania, to pass the rest of the Summer abroad.

High Fleet, the champion 3-yearold filly of 1936, looked more like her old self yesterday at Empire City when she ran through the stretch to pass Rebellion and win rather easily by a length and a half at the end of five and three-quarters furlongs.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 10: REAR ADMIRAL Vernou, W. N., Crufsers, Battle Force, to duty as commandant of the 15th Naval District and additional duty as commanding officer, Naval Station, Balboa, C. Z.
In spite of the recent strength in the securities markets, the gyrations in the market for wheat continue more interesting to many traders. Reflecting crop uncertainties,
Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont scored an 82 today over the Rock Spring Club course to win the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament.

Retarded growth, inferiority complexes and "unfavorable social behavior" may be the result of the habit of sucking the thumb, common to "millions of American children," the seventy-ninth annual convention of the American Dental Association was told here today by Dr. Earl Swinehart of Baltimore. But scolding the children will only make matters worse, according to Dr. Swinehart, who reported on a fiveyear study of the question.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Anna B. Roberts, daughter, Utica, N. Y.; Ruth V. Blom, daughter, and Otto F. Blom, executors, children, 434 Audubon Ave., residue equally. GODDARD, MORRILL (July 1). Estate, more than $10,000. To Morrill Goddard Jr. and De Witt R. Goddard, son, 48 E. 73d St.,

The Rev. Henry Townsend Scudder, rector emeritus of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Tarrytown, N. Y., died yesterday at Essex, Conn., of cerebral thrombosis after an illness of- ten days, according to announcement here last night. He was born in this city eighty-two years ago.

Match play in the third annual women's Long Island Scotch foursome championship got under way at the Meadow Brook Club today, with all of the favored pairs advancing into tomorrow's quarter-final round.

The following having satisfactorily completed the course in the care and operation of motors and pumps used in this department, are hereby designated as chauffeurs and pump operators, and they are therefore qualified to be assigned to that duty in their respective companies or in any company to which they may be transferred, in preference to all other members who have not previously qualified:

" They Won't Forget," a Mervyn LeRoy production from the Ward Greene novel, "Death in the Deep South," will begin an engagement this morning at the Strand. Heading the cast are Claude Rains, Gloria Dickson, Edward Norris, Allyn Joslyn and Otto Kruger....

Jullo Alvarez del Vayo, former Spanish Loyalist Foreign Minister, charged today that visits of leaders of the Spanish Insurgent revolt to Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy constituted "a clear case of Italian intervention in Spain."
Threats of secession rumbled across the island again tonight, while fear of a food and milk shortage grew steadily among the 15,000 Summer visitors and 3,500 natives.

The Lyons Residence Bill for city employes became law yesterday as the Aldermanic branch of the Municipal Assembly voted, 52 to 1, to override the veto of Mayor La Guardia. The Board of Estimate had already passed the bill over the Mayor's veto.
The second annual tournament of the Eastern Association of Scientific Angling Clubs, sponsored by the Newark Bait and Fly Casting Club, will be held at Weequahic Park, Newark, on Saturday and Sunday.

Northern States Power Company of Minnesota and Subsidiaries-Twelve months ended May 31: Net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, $5,676,178, compared with a net of $4,747,596 in the twelve months ended on May 31, 1936; gross revenues aggregated $30,624,509, against $29,257,845.
The Russian transpolar monoplane was sighted at 10:25 P. M. [2:25 A. M. Wednesday, New York time] overhead here. Roseburg is about 300 miles north of San Francisco.

The Municipal Art Commission at its monthly meeting yesterday approved the general design of a bridge which will span Canal Street as part of the extension of the West Side Express Highway south to the Battery.

Plans for a new plant at North Beach which will treat sewage flowing into Flushing Bay were disclosed yesterday by the Department of Sanitation, which will advertise bids for the construction work this month.
Returning to the symphonic repertoire, Fritz Reiner conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in a colorful program last night at Lewisohn Stadium. A sizable audience was present.

Eight thousand supervisors and foremen on WPA construction projects will be notified this morning that they must bring their projects up to the standards of efficiency maintained in private industry or be replaced by relief officials who can.

Chick Harbert, 22-year-old Battle Creek amateur, won the Michigan open golf championship today with a 72-hole score of 268, beating par by 20 strokes. His only over-par round was his last, on which he shot 36. 38-74.

Several large sales in the lower West Side section featured the Manhattan deals yesterday. In the wholesale food market district, the two six-story business buildings at 468 Greenwich Street and 138-40 Watts Street were sold to Frederick Brown by the estate of Henry Kroger.

Fortune Gallo and J. J. Shubert presented Johann Strauss's work "A Wonderful Night," familiarly known in the late -nineteenth century as "Die Fledermaus," here tonight on the water stage on Zach's Bay. The work, the third in the season's schedule of operettas, was scheduled for last night, but rain was the deciding factor.

Prediction that the women's apparel business this Fall will be the best since 1929 was made last night by John Block, head of Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers, at a dinner at the St. Moritz Hotel, which was followed by a fashion show featuring many imports as well as American-made garments. The dinner was attended by 300 clients and their buyers.

President Roosevelt stated at a press conference that the navy is making a survey of its yards with a view to possible construction of auxiliary ships, and that a study of housing is being made with a view to reducing rents by attracting savings banks investors into the house building field.

William D. Camp of 24 Gramercy Place, New Rochelle, president of the Executive Service Corporation of 40 East Forty-ninth Street, which he founded in 1918, died yesterday morning in Bellevue Hospital after a fortnight's illness. He was 66.
Transfers and Assignments THIRD GRADE DETECTIVE--Luther E. Boyce, from 18th Division. M. O. D. D.. to 28th Precinct, designation as third grade detective revoked.

Normal service on all routes of the Tompkins bus lines on Staten Island was resumed for 20,000 Staten Island commuters yesterday at 4:30 P. M. by the line's principal competitor, the Staten Island Coach Company.

Abraham Kaufman of Brooklyn will command the regiment of 1,500 students in the Plattsburg camp tomorrow afternoon for a half-hour parade and review, with other picked fourth-year candidates also officerning the regiment in substitution for the commissioned staff of the 392d Infantry.

A strong appeal to the President and Congressional leaders to shelve the judiciary reorganization bill until next session was made today by Representative Sumners, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, who told the House that not only would the measure hopelessly split that body, but that it would be defeated if it came to a vote.

The New York Air Brake Company reported yesterday for the first half of this year a net income of $914,794 after deductions for depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, but before Federal surtax on undistributed profits.
The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a list of additional applications for registration as brokers and dealers in the overthe-counter market.

The Chancery Division today dismissed Syd Hulls's motion for an injunction restraining Tommy Farr, British Empire heavyweight boxing titleholder, from fighting Joe Louis before meeting Max Schmeling here.

Favorites competing in the Eastern junior clay court tennis championship at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills encountered unexpected difficulty in entering the quarter-final round yesterday as three of the ranking players found themselves eliminated and two were forced to battle through three sets before escaping defeat.
President Roosevelt was faced today with an ever-growing rebellion in Congress against the substitute proposal by which his leaders sought to save his plan to reorganize the Federal judiciary.
At a meeting yesterday of the directors of the Western Union Telegraph Company only routine business was transacted.

Unsuccessful in efforts for years to arrange private sale of her 317-acre estate, Holmwood, Mrs. Margaret Emerson, formerly Mrs. Alfred G. Vanderbilt, is to dispose of it by auction to the highest bidder in about ten days.

India is a natural market for mass production items in which this country specializes and proper promotional and advertising effort on the part of American manufacturers would result in a sharp gain in their sales there, Carl Hayden, supervisor of branches in India of the National City Bank of New York, told the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., at a luncheon meeting yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
The conviction of Emil G. Roschill on a charge of violating Section 54 of the State Insurance Law was upheld today by the Court of Appeals, Judge Irving Lehman being the lone dissenter.

Annual tour of Queens parks by the Park Association of New York City, Inc., and Queensborough Chamber of Commerce, starting from chamber headquarters, 24-16 Bridge Plaza South, Long Island City, 9:45 A. M. Reception by Mayor La Guardia at Summer City Hall, 10:30 A. M. Luncheon at the Amber Lantern Restaurant, 150-24 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, 1 P. M.

Five hundred service employes and maintenance men, members of the international teamsters and electrical workers unions, threatened a tie-up of the Bush Terminal warehouse section along the Brooklyn waterfront yesterday in a demand for increased wages, shorter hours and the closed shop.

Ben Chapman, Red Sox outfielder, was fined $50 and suspended for three days by William Harridge, president of the American League, today for threatening to punch Umpire John Quinn at Philadelphia Sunday.

Auditors closing the books of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, which was absorbed by the State Department of Social Welfare on July 1, discovered only one name yesterday in the column reserved for private contributions to the public unemployment relief fund.
By I. LINCOLN SEIDE Seymour Ave 3,329, 25x100; Mortgage Commission of N. Y. against Jennie Currier; due, $11,246; taxes, , $985 to plaintiff for $1,000.

With the 1936 champion, Charley Lacey of Lakeville, away in search of greater honors-honors he almost corralled when he finished only three strokes behind Henry Cotton, the winner, in the British open-it's an open race at the Crescent Athletic Club for his undefended Long Island open golf crown.

Isidore Schwartz, 37 years old, who gave the address 1,048 Sheridan Avenue, the Bronx, an inveterate fake job "fixer," was sent to Sing Sing yesterday by General Sessions Judge Donnellan for two and onehalf to five years.

Exceeding the volume of the boom period experienced in June and July, 1936, when bonus money spending was an important factor in sales, retail food and grocery business is running at least 10 per cent ahead of a year ago, the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc., reported yesterday.
Business leases announced yesterday by brokers indicated an active interest in space on Madison and Park Avenues. Ferdinand P. Wambegans, attorney, has taken quarters in 299 Madison Avenue;

A funeral service for Richard Prosser, senior member of the engineering and steel importing firm of Thomas Prosser Son of 15 Gold Street, New York, will be held at his home, 241 Chestnut Street, here, tomorrow at 4:30 P. M. Mr. Prosser, who was 72 years old, died at his Summer home in Weekapaug, R. I., yesterday after a short illness.
Male student bodies in German universities have been sent to the fields to help bring in Germany's sorely needed crop. All student's were called on late in the Spring to volunteer.
Oliver Law, Negro commander of the Abraham Lincoln Battalion, was among a small number of Americans killed storming Villanueva del Pardillo last Tuesday, it was learned today.
To white-haired Harry Parker, for forty-six years janitor of the Ways and Means Committee, the House gave today perhaps the most unusual ovation ever given a Negro by the national Legislature.

Gross assets, $33,818; $31,367. To Herman W. Ahrenholz, son, $16,197; Herman W. Ahrenholz, son, $16,197; Herman W. Ahrenholz, husband, $15,169. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $31,582. Edward P. Orrell Jr., attorney, 461 13th St., Brooklyn.

Payments on open-credit accounts receivable of department stores were made at a higher rate during May, 1937, than during the same month last year, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce announced today.

Sooner or later the German people will overthrow the Nazi regime, Dr. Carl Joachim Friedrich of Haryard predicted in an address at the Summer Institute for Social Progress at Wellesley today. He said that many Germans were sincere, but "deluded," and added that he would be "very much surprised if Ithe Hitler dictatorship lasts twenty years. that is, to 1953."

The New York Stock Exchange has applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission to strike from listing and registration on that Exchange the American shares of the General Italian Edison Electric Corporation, representing ordinary shares of capital stock and the underlying shares of capital stock of a par value of 200 lire. A hearing on the application has been called for Sept. 8.

An offer of settlement of the $5,500,000 Pacific Development Corporation Loan, so-called, held by various American banks and banking houses, was announced here yesterday by the Chinese Embassy on behalf of the Ministry of Finance. The original loan, in two-year 6 per sent notes, has been in default since Nov. 1, 1921.

Business failures declined in the retail and manufacturing groups, but increased in the wholesale division in the five business days ended July 8, compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:

Five methods to overcome price resistance by buyers were distilled yesterday from accounts of actual practices among manufacturers and retailers at a symposium held by the Sales Executive Club of New York at its weekly luncheon meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The Forty Ninert opened their fifth Summer theatre season in the White Mountains tonight with Noel Coward's "Private Lives." An enthusiastio audience crowded the Chase Barn Playhouse from its Metropolitan Opera chairs to its century-old rafters.

Armour Co. are willing to sell one of their Argentine subsidiaries, Frigorifico Armour de la Plata, to an association of Argentine cattlemen, "if they want to pay our price," R. H. Cabell, president of Armour Co., said today, in denying rumors that a deal has been closed.

A fleet of eleven speedy ocean racing yachts set sail in a light southeasterly this morning and headed down Long Island Sound on the outward leg of the Larchmont Yacht Club's annual Fire Island race for the historic Brooklyn Yacht Club Challenge Trophy.

Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, Miss Maureen Orcutt and Miss Jean Bauer, favorites in the nineteenth annual women's invitation golf tournament for the Griswold Cup at the Shenecossett Country Club, advanced into the quarter-finals today with easy first-round triumphs.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 13,000 including 2,500 directs.

A plan to liquidate Series A-1 mortgage certificates of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, under which investors in this series will receive "103 cents on the dollar," was announced yesterday by Joseph B. Miller, lawyer, of 40 Wall Street, who is trustee of the issue.

Stockholders of the Durham Duplex Razor Company yesterday voted approval of a plan put forth by the board of directors to sell the firm's factory properties in Jersey City to Alexander Block, trading as the Block Drug Company of Brooklyn.

Goerck St, 11, 24.11x100; 515 East 14th St Realty Corp to Emigrant Bank; mtg $8,625, held by bank. 122d St, 247-51 E, 42x101: Crow Holding Corp to Thistle Holding Corp. 152 W 42d St, c/o Robert Foster Co, Inc; mtg $32,000.

Daily average sales of variety stores for June were higher than for any vice month since June, 1929, and were only about 1 per cent below the figures for the month in that year, the Commerce Department announced today.
The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., today will advance the tank wagon price for all grades of gasoline from 1/2 to 1 cent a gallon at many New England points.

The Maritime Association and the New York Board of Trade announced yesterday that they had forwarded protests to Representative John J. Mansfield, chairman of the House Committee on Rivers and Harbors, against the proposal to take jurisdiction of the navigable waters of the nation from the army engineer corps.

On the basis of income and working life span statistics gathered by Professor Harold F. Clark, in charge of Educational Economics at Teachers College, Columbia University, it is now possible to predict how much a budding doctor, lawyer or architect is worth as an investment when he starts his profession.

Edgar L. Newhouse Sr., former chairman of the board of directors of American Refining and Smelting Company, died of pneumonia in Harbor Hospital yesterday afternoon at the age of 72 years. He had entered the hospital a week ago.

Dr. A. Maris Boggs, widely known woman educator and philanthropist, died last night in Jerusalem. Word of her death was received here by the Franciscan monastery from a companion traveler in the Holy Land.

Whatever may be said of our little community as a place in which to live, there is no denying that our friends, and others, in other parts of the country look upon it as an interesting place to visit.

After a speech by Oliver Stanley, new President of the Board of Trade, which had the unusual effect of causing Labor to withdraw its support of the measure, the House of Commons passed on second reading today the bill preparing for government ownership of all British coal mine royalties.

Diplomats leaving today for Europe on the French liner Normandie include Dr. H. H. Kung, Vice President and Finance Minister of China; Constantin Fotitch, Minister for Yugoslavia; Marc Peter, Minister for Switzerland; Mrs. Georges Bonnet, wife of the French Minister of Finance; Captain and Mrs. Georges Fayet and Edouard Asselin.

Filed here for probate with Surrogate Leone D. Howell today, the will of Supreme Court Justice Paul Bonynge, who died at Locust Valley, L. I., last Friday, bequeathed the property to the widow, Mrs. Anne C. Bonynge, and three sons.

The words of a man now dead, spoken under oath in court more than three years ago were used by the defense in the Scottsboro case today to refute the charge of Victoria Price that she was attacked by a gang of Negroes on a freight train between Stevenson and Paint Rock, Ala., on March 25, 1931.

Although somewhat disappointed at not winning the title .at Wimbledon, Miss Alice Marble, American tennis champion, was not too chagrined at her failure in discussing her trip on her return yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.

Driven to refuge by a sudden tropical storm, planes searching the lonely South Pacific Ocean for Amelia Earhart and Fred J. Noonan, lost eleven days off tiny Howland Island, returned to the giant airplane carrier U. S. S. Lexington late today after a futile morning foray in their "last chance" hunt.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Maybe it will help clear thinking in these confused times to go to Wisconsin. In Wausau the Marathon Electric Manufacturing Corporation has recently been having operating difficulties because of a fight between the International Association of Machinists (A. F. of L.) and the United Electrical and Radio Workers (C. I. O.).
Dr. John Wilbur Bartlett, a physician of 149 West Ninety-fourth Street, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after a brief illness. He was 80 years old.
Oscar Hubbard, retired member of the New York Police Department, who acted as an honor guard in 1885 when President Grant's body lay in state, died here on Saturday. He was 78 years old.
Funeral services for Jack Curley, sports and amusement promoter who died on Monday, will be held today at 10 A. M. in the Fairchild Sons Funeral Chapel, 141-26 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Queens.

The 35,000 cloakmakers who joined in the stoppage ordered last Thursday by the joint board of the Cloakmakers Union returned to their shops yesterday, in accordance with the collective agreements signed by the union with employer associations on Monday.
Japan insists on economic exploitation of North China and will use force if necessary to carry out her plan, authoritative sources said last night.

The Justice Department has accepted the resignation of Albert Levitt of Redding, Conn., as a special assistant to the Attorney General. A former Federal judge in the Virgin Islands, Mr. Levitt submitted his resignation last week and it will take effect Aug. 10.

Germany's attitude towaru treaty obligations, her present situation and what her own and other governments may be preparing to do about it were features of today's discussions before the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.
Communists and Rightists battled in a Paris suburb and in the city's square tonight on the eve of Bastile Day, France's "Fourth of July."

Ridiculing the Municipal Civil Service Commission for asking questions that would "stump an Einstein" in an examination for applicants to the Fire Department, Alderman Charles E. Keegan demanded yesterday an Aldermanic investigation of the commission.
With a severe condemnation of sit-down strikes, Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in Felony Court yesterday found thirty-nine WPA teachers guilty of charges of disorderly conduct.
Bishop Emmet Michael Walsh of Charleston, S. C., today urged the Ladies Catholic Benevolent Association to combat communism by "practising and making known the truths of religion."

Losing first-innings points to Essex at Colchester today, Sussex failed to gain ground on Yorkshire in the English county cricket championship. The Yorkists played a drawn game with the touring New Zealanders.

Whisky stored in bonded warehouses at the end of April totaled 421,000,000 gallons and will approximate 500,000,000 gallons by the end of the year, Wilford S. Alexander, Federal Alcohol Administrator, said today.

Dr. John Woolman Churchman, noted bacteriologist, surgeon, author and educator, died of a paralytic stroke yesterday in Amityville, L. I., after a four years' illness. His home was at 215 East Seventysecond Street. His age was 60.
Reports of crop damage in the United States and Canadian Northwest sent wheat futures soaring today with upturns of 5 to 6 cents a bushel recorded on the Board of Trade here, the latter on July.

The Childs Company will open today another unit in its chain restaurants at 263 West Forty-second Street. The new branch is the third to be opened in the midtown district this year, in what was described as a "$2,000,000 expansion program."

Employes of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and other affiliates of the Edison system whose salaries are less than $5,000 a year received yesterday the first increase in pay under the 5 per cent advance which was granted recently by the Edison management following the signing of a contract with the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an affiliate of the A. F. of L.
President David Toro resigned tonight and Colonel German Busch, Chief of the Army General Staff, immediately assumed the Presidency.

A group of seventy State Assemblymen, on a three-day sight-seeing tour of New York and Long Island, had dinner in the Marine Dining Room here tonight as the guests of J. Russel Sprague, Republican leader of Nassau County, and Assemblyman Leonard W. Hall of Nassau County:

The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 12: COLONELS Pritchett, H. H., (Inf.), Inspector General's Dept., one month and ten days leave, Aug. 1, with permission to visit foreign countries.

Representative Gus Kasch of Akron, champion bill introducer of the Ohio House, although none of his projects has ever become law, proposed a resolution late today urging President Roosevelt to accept nomination for a third term with John L. Lewis as his running mate.

Several lunchebns were given today for visitors at estates in the Summer colony. Mrs. William S. Gould was hostess at a luncheon at Grapevines for Mrs. Thomas B. Yuille, who is passing several weeks at the Irving.

Katherine Unger, who has been engaged in a Federal Theatre project in Newark, substituted for Pauline Frederick in the opening of "Her Majesty the Widow" at the Convention Hall Theatre on the Boardwalk here tonight.

Dr. Valeria H. Parker, former director of the Institute on Marriage and the Home of the Oranges, has accepted appointment as chairman of the Protective Committee of the New York World's Fair 1939, she disclosed here today.

Alex Rubenstein, former organizer for the United Cake, Pastry and Pie Bakers Association, testified yesterday at the bakery racket trial in Special Sessions that $600 had been paid by the association to union officials for picketing bakeries that cut prices.

The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding in the twelve Federal Reserve districts on June 30 was $364,203,843, a decrease of $21,592,124 from May 29 but an increase of $47,772,111 from the end of June last year, according to the monthly acceptance survey of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, issued yesterday.
Scores of railroad executives attended the funeral this afternoon of Edward E. Loomis, former president of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, who died at his Summer home, Holiday Farm. Sunday.

Following what was described as "a complete breakdown" on June 25 of negotiations between the representatives of fourteen rail unions and brotherhoods having a membership of close to 800,000 and a committee representing the railroad managements over the employes' demands for a 20-cent-an-hour increase, both sides agreed today to continue the negotiations.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment stating that the date of its proposed security offering would be July 16.

Judging on a basis of reorders, Doubleday, Doran estimates that Kenneth Roberts's "Northwest Passage" is selling at the rate of one copy a minute. The book was published on July 1 and has Fold 161,000 copies, including two Book-ofthe-Month Club editions.

A mortgage for $175,000 for ten years at 4 1/2 and 5 per cent has been made by a savings bank on the six-story apartment house at 1,210 Sherman Ave, northwest corner of 167th St. John J. Reynolds, broker, negotiated the deal for the M. M. Realty Corporstion, Louis Marks. president.

Dr. Alonzo Clark Hunt, 79 years old, of 625 Middlesex Avenue, Metuchen, was killed this afternoon when he accidentally discharged a shotgun while unpacking a trunk in the upper story of his Summer home here on Bridge Street. Dr.
Yesterday's heavy rain left the polo fields too heavy for tournament competition this afternoon at the Meadow Brook Club and forced a re-arrangement of the schedule in the Meadow Brook Cups.

Several sales of residences and acreage in various parts of Westchester County were reported yesterday. One of the deals involved more than fourteen acres on the west side of Hardscrabble Road in Chappaqua, sold by Helen M. Valentine to Guy Wellman, associated with the Standard Oil Company, who has just completed a large residence on adjoining property he owns.

Two more shipyards in Brooklyn resumed operation yesterday but with only partial success in the strike of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C. I. O. affiliate, now in its fifth week.
The capital's famous Japanese cherry trees, which attract thousands of visitors at blossom time, were reprieved today from the death sentence once decreed by the Jefferson Memorial Commission.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Norten Westervelt of this city, formerly of Newburgh, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Jane Westervelt, to Charles Varcoe Kay, son of Charles Winfield Kay of Walden, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Kay.
A "Hi-Li" contest will be a feature of the tea to be held this afternoon at the Coq Rouge, 65 East Fifty-sixth Street, under the auspices of the junior committee of the Josephine Home.

President Roosevelt disclosed today that, in anticipation of a possible boom in shipbuilding which might burden private yards, the Navy was making a survey of its own yards to determine the possibility of putting in extra ways and equipment for the construction of auxiliary vessels such as tankers and hospital ships.

When Sir THOMAS BODLEY, who had forsaken diplomacy " to set up his staff at the library door in Oxford," opened his library in 1603, it contained somewhat more than two thousand volumes. Since 1610 a copy of every book printed in England has been sent to the great Oxford repository.
Bookings and billings of the Mengel Company for June and six months, together with unfilled orders on June 30, compares with a year ago as follows:

At the funeral services for George Gershwin at 2 P. M. tomorrow in Temple Emanu-El, Sixty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue, the honorary pallbearers will be headed by Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia. The other names on the list announced last night were:

When the three-day annual medal score tournament for the Elizabeth Wheeler trophy had reached the two-thirds mark at the end of the morning play at the Lawrence Farms Golf Club today Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich, yesterday's first-round pace-setter, had a substantial fivestroke lead over Mrs. Edward Stevens of Round Hill in the runnerup position.

The marriage of Miss Claire Noel Kendall, daughter of Leonard Bullick Kendall of Sarasota, Fla., and the late Mrs. Kendall, to Jose Ossorio, son of Miguel Ossorio of Leed's Point, Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. Ossorio of Manila, P. I., took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.
Mayor LA GUARDIA a few weeks ago attended an out-of-town meeting and refused to put up at a hotel where a strike had

A hearing has been called for July 28 by the Securities and Exchange Commission on a declaration filed by the Kansas Electric Power Company, Lawrence, Kan., a subsidiary of the Middle West Corporation, covering an issue of $500,000 of first-mortgage bonds, Series A 31/2 per cent, due on Dec. 1, 1966.

Japanese officials in Shanghai today expressed satisfaction with Chinese authorities measures here to prevent Chino-Japanese clashes. They believe Shanghai will remain unaffected although they contend agitators are attempting to stir up trouble.

Willie Davis, 1331/2, Mexican lightweight, punched his way to victory over Petey Hayes, 128, East Side veteran, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Queensboro Arena last night. A crowd of 3,000 persons saw the battle, which was bitterly fought all the way.

The Socialist party announced yesterday that its central committee had designated Norman Thomas as the party's candidate for Mayor, with Murray Baron for President of the Council and Frank R. Crosswaith for Controller.

On the ground that the constitutional question is not the only one involved, the Court of Appeals dismissed without opinion today. an appeal from an order by Justice McCook upholding the constitutionality of the 1936 statute authorizing free transportation for private and parochial school pupils as well as pupils of public schools.

Charles S. Hart of New York was elected Grand Exalted Ruler of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks at its convention here today. He succeeds David Scholtz of Jacksonville, former Florida Governor. Mr. Hart was elected unanimously.
Divers have recovered the entire cargo of the Japanese pearling mothership that sank near here with a catch valued at [Pound]42,000.

Henry J. Winters of New York City today began active duty as acting director of the National Labor Relations Board for the Western New York region. He succeeds the Rev. John P. Boland, recently appointed head of the new State Labor Board, set up under the "little Wagner act."

A diplomatic approach by Great Britain to the United States in reference to the crisis in North China was followed today by clear intimations that the appeal for peace made yesterday by Secretary of State Cordell Hull to the diplomatic representatives of Japan and China was considered sufficient in the present circumstances.

With domestic consumption still running at record figures and the new crop not available in quantity for several weeks yet, mill price fixing of raw material held fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange within narrow limits yesterday.
Most of the United States delegates to the dedication of American battle monuments in Europe this Summer will sail from New York tomorrow on the steamer Manhattan.

Mrs. Marguerite Fox Dolbow filed today with the Court of Pardons a petition for commutation of her death sentence to life imprisonment. If clemency is denied, she will be the first woman in New Jersey to be put to death in the electric chair.
Vernon Kennedy accounted for his eighth pitching victory of the season today as the White Sox defeated the Athletics, 6 to 4, with the aid of a rainstorm which halted the game in the fifth inning.
Richard Dix in "The Devil Is Driving" and a short subject entitled "The Eagle's Vengeance" form the new program beginning this morning at the Rialto.

Three men received minor injuries shortly after 7 A. M. yesterday when the tug Morristown of the Lackawanna Railroad crashed into the side of the ferry Weehawken after she had left her Weehawken slip for the Cortlandt Street terminal in New York.

Virtually normal bus service was provided yesterday for the thousands of Staten Island residents inconvenienced on Tuesday when the buses operated by the Tompkins Bus Corporation were repossessed by their manufacturers and taken out of service.

Final details of the amendment to the plan of amalgamation of the Canadian Hydroelectric Corporation, Ltd., and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Gatineau Power Company, were announced yesterday by G. Gordon Gale, president of the Canadian corporation.

Thirsty German burghers had to gulp down their beers and tourists from all parts of the world were obliged to leave the tables hurriedly when all cafes, night clubs, restaurants, rathskellers and bierstueben were closed for 1 1/4 hours this morning.

For the second time in a few weeks our hats are off to Russian aviation. Following the path of their trail-blazing compatriots across the Pole, Pilot MIKHAIL GROMOFF, Co-Pilot ANDREY YUMASHEFF and Navigator SERGEI DANILIN have indeed set a mark for the world to shoot at.

Financial Independence Founders, Inc., of New York, an investment trust, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering trust certificates Series D, the total aggregate amount of the proposed cash offering being $14,000,000.
William Holmes, retired business manager of The Evening American, died today at his home in Orlando, Fla., it was learned here. He was 72 years old.

Vincenzo Bafaro, a prisoner in the Federal House of Detention, was indicted yesterday by the New York County grand jury in the alleged forgery of the Federal Government seal and the signature of Theodore C. Achilles, an executive in the State Department, to a fake power of attorney through which $2,700 was stolen from an estate here.

Jim Turner, the Bees' 30-year-old freshman twirler, knocked the Cubs out of first place today by holding them to five hits as he gained his ninth victory of the season in the series opener. The score was 2 to 1 and the triumph was the Bees' eighteenth in twenty-three starts.

Pensioned On their own applications: PATROLMEN-William C. Goehring, 103d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Nov. 5, 1910. Louis H. Petersen, 71st Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed May 4, 1908.

Miss Marjorie Harrison of Ausable, N. Y., will meet Mrs. C. H. Beecher of Burlington, and Mrs. H. Brandom Jones, Montpelier, will oppose Miss Lydia Barber, Brattleboro, in the semi-finals of the Vermont women's golf championships tomorrow.

The apartment house containing thirty-five suites at 7,311-21 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold to an investing client of Margaret K. Udell, attorney. Situated on a plot, 93 by 86 feet, the structure occupies the southeast corner of Seventyfourth Street and Fourth Avenue. Sale was subject to a mortgage of $86,250 held by the Williamsburgh Savings Bank.
A divorce was granted here today to Lucile R. Hamilton, wife of Professor Walton H. Hamilton of Yale.

Dr. Cordero Reyes, Foreign Minister, said today that Nicaragua sought commercial treaties with other Central American republics because of a desire to promote friendship and to wipe out barriers obstructing free commerce.
The dollar was stronger in foreign exchange yesterday, but gold in London continued to command a premium over its New York shipping parity.

Despite overcast skies that occasionally sprinkled the crowds along the sideboards, Tommy Hitchcock led Jock Whitney's Greentree team into action against Stewart Iglehart's Aiken Knights in a postponed Meadow League game tonight.

Mrs. Walter Gurnee Dyer tonight was honored on her twenty-seventh birthday anniversary by her mother, Mrs. C. Ledyard Blair, and Mr. Blair at a cabaret entertainment and supper party at Honeysuckle Lodge. She and Mr. Dyer were greeted by about 100 of their friends of the Summer colony.
Ten thousand horse racing fans celebrated Bastile Day this afternoon by breaking up the Pont Vivaux racetrack near herb, wrecking betting booths, stands and everything.
Pope Plus received Miss Rachel McDowell, editor of religious news for THE NEW YORK TIMES, at Castel Gandolfo today.

Robert H. Jackson, Assistant Attorney General, wrote to the Joint Congressional Committee on Tax Evasion today, asserting that Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was a conscientious taxpayer who had not sought to evade payment of taxes from her radio broadcasting income, and he suggested that Representative Hamilton Fish's charges be dropped.

Sharply criticizing "bankers who tried to be brewers," Federal Judge John P. Barnes awarded today the Prima Brewing Company of Chicago $569,895 on its claim for damages against the Harris Trust and Savings Bank me and the First National Bank of Chicago.
Governor Carl E. Bailey expressed the sorrow of an entire State today when news of the death of the senior Senator from Arkansas reached here, and paid the following tribute to him:

The British compromise proposals for resolving the non-intervention crisis were prominently displayed in the press but authoritative comment was lacking. At the Foreign Office it was announced that pending careful study of the British plan the German position could not be stated.
Offering will be made today of 450,000 shares of 41/2 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock of $100 par value, of the American Rolling Mill Company, by a banking group composed of W. E.

If New Jersey salt water anglers need an incentive to spur them on, the Beach Haven Tuna Club is supplying the impetus by way of a prize fishing competition. Only those fishing along the New Jersey coast can claim any of the awards, but an angler's residence does not prevent him from competing.
Pittsburgh at New York-Blanton vs. Melton. Cincinnati at Brooklyn-Derringer vs. Hamlin. Chicago at Boston-Carleton vs. Bush. St. Louis at Philadelphia (2)Warneke and Harrell vs. Walters and Johnson.

J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, well-known criminal lawyer, and eleven other individuals were indicted yesterday as the leaders of a ring that is alleged to have dominated the policy racket in this city by force from 1930 until last January, and to have reaped a gross revenue of $100,000,000 annually from it.

The Evergreen Farms team of the1 Monmouth Country Club, Eatontown, N. J., which is tied for the lead in the Eastern Polo League tournament and figures as one of the finalists in the twelve-goal Rumson Country Club tourney, was upset today by a rejuvenated Rumson quartet, 9 to 5. It was Evergreen's first defeat of the season.

Co-education has been abolished in Greek schools by government decree as immoral and contrary to the ideals of a Nationalist totalitarian State. This is the first move in the general scheme planned by the government in its effort to guide youth toward the ideals of nationalism and absolute discipline it deems necessary.

Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association, sailed yesterday with his wife and two children to attend meetings of the British Medical Association as official delegate from the American group. The British congress will be held in Belfast July 20 to 24.

Bernard M. Baruch canceled a sailing on the Normandie scheduled for noon yesterday, on learning of the death of Senator Robinson, and left instead for Washington. The two men, close friends, had expected to meet in Europe after the adjournment of Congress.

Stricken suddenly while on a vacation in Los Gatos, Simon Katten, a retired merchant and father-inlaw of Mischa Elman, the violinist, died early today at the age of 82. He had been a resident of San Francisco for more than fifty years, and until his retirement ten years ago a member of the firm of Bauer Brothers.

Canada today qualified seven or eight men for the second stage Friday of the King's Prize, the classic of the empire meeting of military riflemen. Sergeant C. W. Harvey of the Hertfordshire yeomany won the bronze cross for leadership in the first stage of the King's, posting a fine 103 out of a possible 105.
the Furness Prince liner Southern Prince, bound for Buenos Aires from New York, was rammed late today in the River Plate by the British freighter Elstree Grange.

The prospects of Federal economy are not helped by the action of the House in overriding the President's veto of the Farm Loan Bill by the overwhelming vote of 260 to 98. The President's veto message on the merits of the case was thoroughly convincing.

Lefty Lee Grissom's pitching earned him another victory at Ebbets Field yesterday as the Reds staged a ninth-inning rally to break a deadlock and beat the Dodgers, 5-3. But his ferocious manner of trying to cross home plate precipitated a small riot, and for a brief time threatened his physical wellbeing.

Residential properties in Manhattan furnished the largest share of the day's activity in real estate. A large multi-family dwelling in Yorkville and a number of properties on the upper West Side were among the parcels changing hands.
Miss Marsyl Stokes will make her debut this Summer at Newport, where she is passing the season with her mother, Mrs. Henry Drummond-Wolff at Oak Haven, their villa.

It appeared likely today that the finalists of 1935-Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Philadelphia and Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R. I.-would meet in the final of the nineteenth annual women's invitation golf tournament for the Griswold Cup over the links of the Shenecossett Country Club Friday.

Captain John E. Murphy, master of the Dollar liner President Van Buren, reported when the ship docked in Hoboken yesterday that a seaman stricken with appendicitis had undergone a successful operation in stormy seas 1,200 miles out of New York.

The Oxford University Press has become the publisher of the English translations of the art books of the Pahidon Verlag of Vienna, It was announced yesterday. Eleven titles are in prospect for the early Fall, including "The Civilization of the Renaissance in Italy," by Jacob Burckhardt, and "The Paintings of Rembrandt." edited by A. Bredius.

A contract for what will be the world's longest complete communications system has been placed by the Soviet government with Standard Telephones and Cables, Ltd., British subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, according to an announcement yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Giraud van Nest Foster, who have been at the Pierre since returning from their plantation in Wilson, La., left yesterday for Lenox, Mass., to join his father, Giraud Foster, at Bellefontaine. Mrs. Henry Latrobe Roosevelt and Miss Eleanor K. Roosevelt of Washington are at the Ritz-Carlton.
A $17,000 51-year-old hunting lodge, principal building at Camp Mann, on White Lake, was in ashes today, destroyed by a spectacular fire which imperiled 362 New York City Boy Scouts late last night.

The Jersey City Giants took both ends of a double-header from the league-leading Newark Bears at Roosevelt Stadium today, winning the first, 7 to 0, and the second by 2 to 1 when Glen Gabler, Jersey City pitcher, drove a single through the box with the bases full in the eighth stanza of a scheduled seveninning battle.
Senator Joseph T. Robinson of Arkansas, Democratic leader in the Senate for fifteen years and a member since 1913, was found dead of a heart attack early today at his home.

Associates of Senator Joseph Taylor Robinson in both branches of Congress paid tribute today to his leadership and courage. Many of those who had served with him a major portion of the thirty-seven years of his official life in Washington expressed as well a feeling of deep personal loss.
Willard H. Dow, president of, the Dow Chemical Company, told stockholders today at their annual meeting that earnings in the last year were $4.17 each on 945,000 shares of outstanding common stock.

Applications for Social Security account numbers had been filed by 4,292,366 persons in this State on June 30, when the Postoffice Department turned the task of registration over to the Social Socurity Board, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the board, announced yesterday.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University and chairman of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, is returning today on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen with Mrs. Butler after attending conferences in Geneva, Paris and London.

A world record for 3-year-old trotters over a half-mile oval was made today at Historic Track as Mr. Watt, son of Dillon Axworthy and Palestrina defeated Freckles, by Guy Day and Lookaway Express, in two out of three heats in the Tuxedo Stake. Both are owned by H. Stacey Smith of Short Hills, N. J.

A new theological seminary, putting emphasis upon fundamentalism and the doctrine of premillennialism, will be opened "somewhere in the Philadelphia area" in October, was announced tonight by the new board of directors, consisting at present of fifteen members.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente yesterday rejected a claim for $2,000,000 extra compensation made by the Oakdale Contracting Company, Inc., for constructing the section of the Eighth Avenue subway which runs from Third to Eighth Street under Sixth Avenue.
Julius L. Meier, former Governor of Oregon, died here today at the age of 62. He had been in poor health for some time.
The campaign to cut work relief rolls to 1,600,000 persons by tomorrow is 150,000 short of the goal, according to government officials.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 13: MAJOR GENERAL Embick, S. D., Deputy Chief of Staff, one month leave, July 22. with permission to visit foreign countries.

Bowing to determined opposition from Wall Street brokerage houses, the New York Stock Exchange's special committee on commissions, headed by E. A. Pierce, has amended the report recommending higher rates, which it submitted on July 1.

With the dismissal of 2,847 persons from the five WPA Federal Arts Projects scheduled to become effective today, William P. Farnsworth, administrative officer of the Federal Theatre Project, was instructed by WPA executives in Washington not to defer the dismissal of 1,709 workers from his project for any reason.

A committee of eight leading educators has been appointed by Will H. Hays to go over 15,000 sound film "shorts" lying in the vaults of Hollywood motion picture companies and select those of educational value which can be used in the school curriculum, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Mark A. May, chairman of the committee and director of the Institute of Human Relations at Yale University.
Vice President Garner, who returned to his home here several weeks ago, said tonight that he did not know if the death of Senator Robinson would cause him to return to the nation's capital.

Announcement was made here late last night of the death yesterday in Irvington-on-Hudson of Charles Over Cornelius, architect, who has been associate curator of American art in the Metropolitan Museum since 1925. Mr. Cornelius, whose city residence was at 17 East Eighty-fourth Street, was born in Sewickley, Pa., forty-six years ago.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Dannenbaum of Melrose Park have announced the engagement of their daughter Miss Sue Gimbel Dannenbaum, to Dr. Ephraim A. Speiser, Orientalist and Professor of Semitics at the University of Pennsylvania.

Sanders B. Altmayer, retired real estate broker who was instrumental in bringing bus service to several important crosstown streets in Manhattan, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his home, 47 East Eighty-eighth Street, after a long illness. Mr. Altmayer was 88 years old.

One of the pretenders to the French crown, self-styled Henri de Bourbon, Duke of Normandy, died here today at the age of 69. He was the grandson of the man known as Karl Wilhelm Naundorff, who claimed to be the Dauphin who escaped from prison after the execution of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette.

Loyalty to his party leadership, together with forceful and fearless methods in making this loyalty effective, were the distinguishing characteristics of Senator Joseph T. Robinson. For years he sank his personal views and ambitions in the faithful support of two highly divergent leaders--both leaders, successively, of the Democratic party.

Employment in factories in this State declined two-tenths of 1 per cent from mid-May to mid-June and payrolls for the period showed "very little change," Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, reported today.

The report of the United Corporation for the second quarter of this year shows a net income, after current expenses and taxes, of $2,662,669, which was equal after preferred dividend requirements to 51/2 cents each on 14,529,324 shares of common stock outstanding on June 30.
A Spanish priest said today that Alaskan missionaries never should mention hell to Eskimos because the natives might decide they would want to go there to keep warm.

Governor Lehman, who is now at Hot Springs, Va., has sent the following telegram to Mrs. Joseph T. Robinson: "I am inexpressibly shocked and grieved to hear of the untimely passing of your husband. Senator Robinson was a wonderful man and a splendid public servant.

The flying boat Pan American Clipper III landed here today, completing the first leg of her return flight from Southampton, England, to the United States. The Clipper was expected to take off for Botwood, Nfld., tomorrow.

After early gains of 1 to 3 points lead by steel issues, stocks reacted and closed irregular; ??urnover , 1,038,090 shares. United States Government bonds higher; other issues firm and mixed; transactions, $6,869,000.

Henry A. Bornsecheuer, a Democratic leader for the last fifteen years, died of acute indigestion at his home, 87-30 188th Street, Hollis, Tuesday night at the age of 56. Mr. Bornscheuer entered the city service as a civil service employee in 1904, served for a while on the Board of Elections, then in the Department of Taxes, and in 1909 was transferred to the Queens Borough President's office.

Machine-gun fire echoed and reechoed last night against the vaulted roof of the armory at Twentysixth Street and Lexington Avenue in salute to members of the Father Duffy Chapter of the Rainbow Division Veterans of the 165th Infantry.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued an order revoking the registration of Frank B. Hamlin, 580 Fifth Avenue, New York, as a dealer on over-the-counter markets.

The possibility that one of the hockey teams now representing Montreal will be transferred to another city was made known yesterday as a result of the two-hour meeting of the governors of the National Hockey League at the Hotel Commodore.

A bill declaring that the public works obligations contracted by the Machado regime are illegal and repudiating the entire debt with the exception of a $40,000,000 bond issue in the hands of American and Cuban investors, to be paid under certain conditions, was presented to the House of Representatives yesterday by Representative Gabriel Landa, a Nationalist from Havana Province.

China's national government is hastening troops to concentration points, avowedly determined to resist what the Chinese believe is a Japanese effort to dominate the northern provinces of Hopei and Chahar.

Discharged Ford Motor Company employes testified at the National Labor Relations Board hearing today that service men maintained an espionage system against union activities in the Rouge plant, "snooped around" listening to what the employes said during their work and at the lunch hour, and had complete authority to pull employes "off the line," regardless of the foremen.

If it could ever be said of a good soldier in the ranks of party regularity that he died with his boots on, in the thick of battle, that epitaph belongs to JOSEPH T. ROBINSON of Arkansas. Only a week ago he was opening the debate in the Senate on the new Supreme Court Bill.

President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Hull sent messages of congratulation to Michael Gromoff at San Jacinto, Calif., today on the successful completion of the second Russian flight to the United States by way of the North Pole.

Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich new holds both available Westchester-Fairfield golf titles, the closed association crown, which she won in match play several weeks ago, and the open medal play laurels, which she took by virtue of an 82 in the third round of the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy event at the Lawrence Farms Golf Club today.

Sale of two plots upon which new homes will be erected featured the realty deals in Long Island reported by brokers yesterday. Also involved was an industrial building in Long Island City which was leased to a mantel and accessories manufacturer.
The Peterson bill, proposing a rival method to that of the administration for solving the farm tenancy problem, was reported favorably today by the House Public Lands Committee.

The receivers for the Wabash Railway Company, which has been in equity receivership since Dec. 1, 1931, filed yesterday a plan of reorganization for that carrier with the United States Court for the Eastern District of Missouri.

Blueberries, rather than barbed wire, held up the army's attack today. Higher officers of the National Guard, wondering at the tardiness of infantry units simulating an attack in the course of their two weeks' training period, began an investigation.
How the record-breaking Soviet fliers, with little or no knowledge of the English language, communicated regularly with English-speaking Americans en route was explained today.

On one day last week one of his initialed editorial writers was singing the glories of scenes in Kansas which "for " sheer exquisiteness equal anything " this world affords." More particularly a sunset as seen from the summit of Jacob's Motnd is described as " fairly crying aloud for a painter."

Carl Y. Withers, head of the State Department of Banking and Insurance, reported today that in the last year approximately $2,250,000 of liquidated assets of six insurance companies under his supervision was distributed to more than 7,000 creditors.

Active work to create a Christian fellowship that would allay nationalistic feeling was advocated today as the surest road to peace by prominent church and lay delegates participating in the World Conference on Church, Community and State.

The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows: In the Cotton Belt temperatures were mostly moderate and rather widespread showers occurred. In general, the weather continued satisfactory and cotton made good progress with conditions favorable for holding the weevils in check in most sections except parts of the Southwest.

The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today unlisted trading privileges in odd lots in fifteen securities, all registered and listed on either the New York Stock or New York Curb Exchanges, to the Boston Stock Exchange, but denied a request that the same privileges be extended in respect to round-lot trading, or trading in lots of 100 shares or more.
St. Ann's Ave, 347, 5-story tenement, 25x100 irregular; Kneeland Holding Corp. against Isidor Blank; due, $16,605; taxes, , $1,554; to plaintiff for $1,00O.

Trading again slow, with forced sales numerous. All classes were weak to lower. Cooler weather showing very little reaction as yet either in traefa or kosher markets. Accumulations of most classes fairly liberal in both slaughter houses and wholesale markets as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
Edward B. Smith Co. will offer today 50,000 shares of $4.50 cumulative preferred stock, series A, no par value, of the Monsanto Chemical Company. The stock will be priced at $101.50.
Mrs. Julia Marshall Foster, widow of Frederic de Puyster Foster, lawyer, died here today in the house on East Lake Road which she had occupied since 1890.

Announcement was made here last night that Mrs. Jessica Lake McMullin of this city, formerly of Chicago, died yesterday in a hospital in London while on the way to visit her daughter, Mrs. Charlotte Robertson, at the latter's home in Edinburgh.

The marriage of Miss Evelyn Dorothea Scheu, daughter of Mrs. Peter Carl Scheu of Scarsdale and the late Mr. Scheu, to Moses Hoge Crighton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Moses H. Crighton of Richmond, Va., took place here this afternoon in the Dutch Reformed Church. The ceremony was performed in the presence of near relatives by the rector, the Rev. John Henderson Powell.

Abandonment for this session of the court reorganization bill and early adjournment of Congress swiftly became the main objectives of formidable groups in both chambers today after the death of Senator Robinson.
The Yankees' unbroken string of victories stretched to eight, their longest in several years, as the world champions crushed the Tigers, 10 to 2, today before 16,000 fans at Navin Field.

With a streamer around the wall proclaiming that "Frontiers of States are not always frontiers of peoples," a self-styled "Congress of European National Minorities" began a twoday conference today in a hall only a stone's throw from the British Foreign Office.

In a unanimous decision the Court of Appeals has reversed the Appellate Division and several surrogates and declared that in determining the State inheritance tax full exemption is to be allowed for each of the decedent's children.

Coordinated efforts to improve the average profit showing of boys' wear departments and to work out plans giving the consumer more information on merchandise through fabric identification and labeling were urged yesterday by Harold W. Brightman, general merchandise manager of L. Bamberger Co., Newark, in an address at the annual convention of the Boys' Apparel Buyers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

King George and Queen Elizabeth paid an official visit to South Wales today, covering some of the ground in the distressed areas that was trod by King Edward VIII shortly before his abdication, which some still think was linked in some way with his criticism, spoken and implied, against the government for not having done more to alleviate distress.

The common sense of a doorman |of the Manhattan, Towers Hotel, 2,166 Broadway, was brought into play yesterday afternoon a few split seconds too late to save Mrs. Bertha Johnson, 56 years old, a cook employed in an adjoining apartment house, from fatal injuries.

The Syce Cup series for the women's sailing championship of LongIsland Sound has developed into a three-cornered battle among Miss Sylvia Shethar of American, Miss Margery Bavier of Larchmont and Mrs. Willis D. Wood of Cold Spring Harbor.

Speaking in simple words, Mayor La Guardia and Civil Service Commissioners James E. Finegan and Paul J. Kern replied yesterday to the scoffing attack by Alderman Charles E. Keegan on the commission's examination for firemen by declaring that even though the questions baffled Aldermen they were not too difficult for firemen.

Following is the text of the British proposal for the continuation of international control of Spain: Reconstruction of Supervision First, supervision of traffic entering Spain by sea: A. The system of placing observers on ships visiting ports is to be continued.

Board of Trade figures for June follow: Total imports, [Pound]88,110,000; exports of British products, [Pound]44,370,000; re-exports, [Pound]7,120,000; total exports, [Pound]51,490,000; excess of imports, f36,620,000.
Senator Robinson, in his last speech in the Senate, urging passage of the compromise Court Reorganization Bill, closed with "Goodbye."

The shock of Senator Robinson's death was evident when the Senate convened at noon. The bitter court fight was forgotten and all eyes were focused on the empty chair in the first row on the Democratic side.

Memories of a half century ago, when families of wealth and social position claimed all of the fashionable Murray Hill section of Manhattan for their handsome private homes, were revived yesterday with the announcement. of one of the largest realty deals to be consummated in that changed neighborhood in many years.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued an order granting, under specified conditions, exemption from certain provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935 to the Middle West Utilities Company of Canada, Ltd., a subsidiary of the Middle West Corporation, and to the Canadian company's subsidiaries, the Great Lakes Power Company, Ltd.; the National Utilities Corporation, Ltd.;

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of Oscar A. Bigler in THE TIMES of July 13, doubts my conclusions on the responsibility of unions under the law, and raises certain questions which I desire to answer briefly. May I also touch upon some questions raised by Walter Gordon Merritt in his letter published with mine on July 4?

Among the deals in Westchester reported yesterday was the sale by Peter B. Olney Jr. of his forty-twoacre estate with ten-room house in Yorktown Heights. Daniel Rochford, associated with 'Time Magazine, purchased the property.
Congressional leaders will try tomorrow to get through conference reports on the Interior and Non-Military Appropriation Bills. which were not completed at the beginning of this fiscal year.
For the second attraction of the season at the Cape Playhouse, Raymond Moore presented last night a romantic comedy, "Marriage Royal," by Robert Wallsten.

Senator Robinson was found dead of a heart attack in his apartment. President Roosevelt issued a statement paying tribute to the Senator and sent messages of condolence to Mrs. Robinson and the Governor of Arkansas.

Quiet campaigns for the Senate leadership post which had been under way ever since it became generally assumed that Senator Robinson would be elevated to the Supreme Court burst into full flame today with the Arkansan's death.
The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today a petition of the Port of New York Authority for reargument in the New York City commercial zone case.

Pleading for reunion with his mother, sisters, brothers and dog in Detroit, 7-yearold Colin Fraser, kept from Detroit by immigration laws and housed temporarily at the Children's Aid Society. shelter here, has written a letter to President Roosevelt.
Stephen P. M. Tasker, a marine engineer who won honors as an explorer and naval officer, died at his home in Wynnewood today in his sixty-third year.
A bill to require thorough medical examinations of all applicants for marriage licenses will be offered by Senator Desmond of Newburgh.

A survey of building construction in the twenty cities in the United States where greatest construction activity is shown discloses striking evidences of industrial recovery in this country, according to the Structural Clay Products Institute of Washington, which conducted the study.

Walter, Gay, dean of American artists in Paris, died today at Chateau du Breau, Seine et Marne. He was 81 years old. Mr. Gay was noted for his paintings of interiors and stilllifes, his works having been purchased by the Luxembourg Museum and other French national collections.
Senator Joseph T. Robinson often told his friends that his wife was "a better politician than me."

The dilemma of the Department of Hospitals on what to do with 150 mentally defective children housed in the old St. Mark's Hospital in East Eleventh Street over protests by residents of the neighborhood was solved yesterday by the State Department of Mental Hygiene when Commissioner Frederick W. Parsons informed Hospital Commissioner Dr. S. S. Goldwater that his department would take care of them.

Two more strikes in the shipping industry were threatened yesterday as unions affiliated with rival maritime councils and with the C. I. O. and American Federation of Labor made charges of unfair practices.
The Census Bureau reported today that the domestic cotton industry had established an all-time high record for consumption, although this sea son has a month to run.

The world airplane distance record broken yesterday by the Russian fliers in command of Mikhail Gromoff was established in August, 1933, by the French fliers, Lieutenant Maurice Rossi and Paul Codos, who made a flight of 5,653.5 miles from New York to Rayak, Syria.

Mayor La Guardia expressed the hope yesterday that New York City would gain majority representation in both branches of the State Legislature as a result of the constitutional convention to be held next year.
Dr. Isadore L. Green, one of the early women medical practitioners and for several years the oldest practicing physician in the State, died today at a hospital here. Her age was 91.

Backing and filling by the Stock Exchange on the question of charging higher commissions draws attention to the fact that, despite the growing popularity of low-priced issues, due to lower franchise and transfer taxes, the commission on the high-priced issues is much more favorable to the speculator.

Jack Brown, at 210 Beach 32d St, for Title Guarantee and Trust Co.; Louis Bellings, at 166 Beach 34th St, for Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co.; Joseph Adler. at 436c Beach 38th St; Louis Friedman. at 2,522 Collier St, for Edward Schacher; Cecilia Cohan, at 424 Beach 38th St, for Title Guarantee and Trust Co; all in Edgemere. L. I.

The average operating rate of the steel industry 'has moved up this week to 83 per cent of capacity with the resumption of work at all of the major plants that were affected by strikes, according to the weekly summary of The Iron Age.

The Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company had a net profit of $5,631,469 in the first half of this year after deducting depreciation, Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed income, according to the preliminary report yesterday.

The decision of President Arturo Alessandri this afternoon to refuse to accept the resignations of members of his Cabinet, who had expressed a desire to withdraw from the government last Monday has ended a Cabinet crisis here.

Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club and the New York State Association, sailed yester on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania bound for Stockholm, where he will join the four other members of the United States team in defense of the HamiltonRussell Trophy, emblem of the international chess championship, July 31 to Aug. 15.

The American people are threatened with political totalitarianism as a result of government invasion of business, Dr. Horace M. Kallen, Professor of Philosophy and Psychology at the new School for Social Research in New York City, told the Summer Cooperative Institute at Massachusetts State College today.
The French Liner Normandie sailed yesterday with 1,688 passengers. More than 5,000 visitors added to the excitement of the heavy sailing and the ship's entire

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 13; unless specified: At Search Area: Cushing, Drayton, Lamson, Lexington. At Humpback Bay: Dallas, Long. Arctic, San Francisco to Seattle. Borie, at Yes Bay. Charleston, at Balboa. Chicago, at Yakutat. Cormorant, Kittyhawk to Washington Yard, July 14.

President Roosevelt is deeply apprehensive of dangerous developments in the crises presented by the civil war in Spain and the Chino-Japanese dispute-so much that the reports from both those fronts were the controlling factor in his decision not to go to Little Rock, Ark., to attend the funeral of Senator Robinson, it was learned tonight.

The formation of Martin Chambers to conduct a general bond business was announced yesterday by Durno Chambers and Leonard A. Martin. The new firm, which will specialize in government and municipal bonds, will have offices at 120 Broadway.

A strangely chosen and incoherently assembled series of excerpts from "Die Walkuere" was presented last night at the second of the five events scheduled in the curfive events scheduled at the Lewrent Wagner festival at the Lewisohn Stadium.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith was directly in the center of the political picture yesterday, using his personal influence to obtain the Democratic nomination for Mayor for Surrogate James A. Foley or United States Senator Royal S. Copeland.

Members of rival C. I. O. and A. F. of L. unions were locked tonight inside the plant of the Heintz Manufacturing Company, builder of automobile parts, after the factory had been closed by a sit-down strike called by the C. I. O. faction.
Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday that 90,000 city employes would receive today their first pay checks reflecting the increases recently voted by the Board of Estimate.
General Yang Hu-chen, Chinese military leader who arrived in San Francisco today, said China, "as a matter of life or death," must fight Japan in the present crisis.

A plan for assisting employes deairing to undertake and complete approved courses of study in vocational education was announced yesterday by the Seagram Distillers Corporation. Under the plan the industrial relations department of the corporation will extend advice and financial assistance to employes desiring to pursue a course of study.
Dennis Kavanaugh, who was president of the Security Life Insurance Company for twenty-eight years, died here yesterday in the Maryland General Hospital.
Provisional agreement between the Polish and German Governments regarding Upper Silesia was announced today and is chiefly notable because all the major disputed questions are left in abeyance.
Mary McCormic, grand opera singer who rose to fame under the sponsorship of Samuel Insull, won an uncontested divorce today from her fourth husband, Homer V. Johannsen.

Electric power production declined last week because of the holiday, but the daily average was higher, and the adjusted index has advanced to 107.0 from 105.3. This compares with 103.2 for the week ended July 11, 1936.
Sir Thomas Myles. prominent Irish surgeon, died here tonight at the age of 80. He was honorary surgeon to the King in Ireland.

The Chinese Central News Agency said today 700 Japanese troops clashed last night with the Chinese garrison at Lofa, thirty miles northeast of Tientsin on the railway to Peiping, after a day of comparative quiet.

MANHATTAN ALBUS, MARGARET T. (July 8). Estate, more than $10,000. To Mary Theresa Sherwood, daughter, executrix, 3 East Ave., Larchmont, N. Y., residue; three specific bequests. BLUM, DAVID (June 30). Estate, more than $10,000. To Annie Blum, widow, 640 West End Ave., life estate in residue, with right to invade principal under specifci circumstances:

Miss Bette Perry Edgar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Arthur Edgar of Bryn Mawr, has completed plans for her marriage to John Dorrance Warriner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Dexter Warriner of this city and of Fernheim, Montrose, which is to take place on Sept. 9 in the Church of the Redeemer, Bryn Mawr.
Miss Mildred Huston, youngest daughter of Claudius Hart Huston. former chairman of the Republican National Committee, was married here today to Alexander Lucian Dade of Tulsa. Okla.
Thomas E. Elder, 54, retired dean of Mt. Hermon School, was indicted today by a Franklin County grand jury on charges of as- at sault with intent to murder S. Allen Norton, former school cashier.

Radio broadcasts tonight said Soviet Russia was wildly elated and thrilled over the record-breaking 6,700-mile flight made by Mikhail Gromoff and two companions over the top of the world to San Jacinto, Calif.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on July 3 totaled 308,744,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.
Unless unforeseen setbacks develop, State fruit of virtually all varieties except grapes will be a bumper crop this year, the Department of Agriculture said today.

Caomer members and others in the official life of Washington joined today to pay tribute to Senator Robinson. His service was characterized as conscientious, capable and faithful, and an exceptional contribution to the betterment of human society.

Telegrams urging defeat of President Roosevelt's court program were sent today by George L. Markland Jr., president of the Philadelphia Board of Trade, to twelve Senators still uncommitted on the plan. The telegrams read:

Although the Robinson-Patman act has been in force for about a year, manufacturers and retailers attending the furniture show in the American Furniture Mart today expressed confusion over their rights under this legislation.
George W. Alger, impartial chairman of the building service industry in the garment area, has rendered a decision finding the Building Service Employes Union.

Eddie Dowling, musical comedy star, sailed yesterday for London, where he will seek an English-Irish cast for the Abbey Players' prize vehicle, "Shadows in Substance," which he will produce in New York next Winter. He was accompanied on the United States liner Manhattan by Mrs. Dowling.

Scotties-an even dozen of them, each well-matured and equipped with good healthy lungs and a real talent for getting under one's feet--have haunted the days and nights of Mrs. Alverda Marion since Monday. In the daytime they bark, she says, and. at night she dreams of them.

The struggle for freedom of the press has shifted through the sweep of history from the governmental to the economic front, Oscar L. Chapman, Assistant Secretary of the Interior, declared last night in a nation-wide broadcast from Washington over the Columbia Broadcasting System's network.

Compulsory arbitration has not stopped and cannot effectively prevent strikes in democratic countries, Colston E. Warne of the Department of Economics at Amherst told the Summer Institute for Social Progress at Wellesley today.

Organization of all radio performers is being undertaken by the titles Actors Equity Association through a newly formed radio division, it was announced yesterday by Alfred Harding of the Equity organization.
Colonel Mills drove in five runs and the Boston Red Sox moved into second place in the American League by defeating the St. Louis Browns today, 15 to 6.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 12: Bermer, Lt. G. R., Jr., to duty as assistant fire-control officer on the Nevada. Bowman, Jr. Lt. M. F., cruisers, scouting force, to the Brooklyn and on board when commissioned. Wickens, Jr. Lt. J. L., to the Texas, instead of Receiving Ship at New York.

SOMEBODY said the other day that Clarence DeMar, the printer, preacher, teacher and veteran marathoner, had heaved half a brick at the A. A. U., which is an honored custom among athletes when they can't think of anything else to do at the moment.
Rear Admiral Yancey S. Williams, commanding the Special Service Squadron, transferred his flag to the new flagship, the Charlestoh, from the Omaha today.

General or national advertising registered the largest gain, 9.5 per cent, in newspaper linage during June, according to Media Records figures for fifty-two cities, with a total of 22,774,952 lines, as against 20,802,046 for the like month of last year. The total advertising gain was 4.1 per cent, with automotive showing the only loss.
Albert Drake De Lanoy, 33, a New York insurance broker, won an uncontested divorce today from Mrs. Celeste de Lanoy on grounds of cruelty.

A permanent mortgage of $147,500 with interest at 41/2 per cent for 5 years and 5 per cent for 5 years has been placed by Jacob Emil Leitner for a corporation headed by Philip Krumholz on the apartment house nearing completion at the northwest corner of Park Terrace West and 215th St.
President Roosevelt today appointed Edward J. Flynn, New York Secretary of State, as the United States Commissioner for the 1939 New York World's Fair.
Mayor La Guardia conferred with several of his commissioners on departmental affairs at the Summer City Hall in College Point yesterday.

SAMUEL GOLDWYN is the living image of Hollywood. He is to Hollywood what King Arthur was to the age of the knights. As the perfect flower of that city in this time, a cycle of legend has grown up about him. The proper interpretation of the Goldwyn legend called for an Alva Johnston or a Walt Disney. Alva Johnston got to Goldwyn first.

The problem of choosing between Bryan M. Grant of Atlanta or Frankie Parker of Milwaukee to play the second singles match for the United States against Germany in the Davis Cup interzone final starting Saturday is

Seamen supplemented oral testimony with photographs descriptive of living and working conditions on American merchant ships when the Maritime Commission resumed its Inquiry yesterday morning at the Federal Building, 45 Broadway.
