Emil Rieve, president of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers, announced today an agreement with the Full-Fashioned Hosiery Manufacturers of America, Inc., providing wage increases of 8 to 10 per cent for 50.000 union workers.

Beginning with the first of January, 1938, the city government of New York cannot fill any appointive post with a first-class man unless the candidate has been for at least three years resident within the city limits.

A military ceremony was performed in the Herzegovinian village of Bileca at which the American military attach presented the Distinguished Service Medal to 80-year-old Mrs. Ilinka Kilidard, whose son was killed in the war.

A charge that the Board of Education is spending 25 to 40 per cent more on its building contracts than is necessary because of its union labor policy, with an added cost to the city of thousands of dollars. was made yesterday at the Summer meeting of the board at 500 Park Avenue.
A Federal grand jury indicted nine men today for allegedly obstructing the mails at strike-bound steel plants in Ohio.

Members of the Summer colony and their guests filled Parrish Memorial Hall tonight when the Southampton Players, under the direction of Theodore St. John, opened their first season here with the presentation of "Pleasure Cruise," an English comedy by Austen Alilen.

The total deposits of the twentythree mutual savings banks in New Jersey amounted on June 30 to $311,279,780, a record high and an increase of $4,474,136 over the amount reported for Jan. 1, according to an announcement yesterday by Frederick W. Shelley, president of the New Jersey Savings Banks Association and secretary and treasurer of the Morris County Savings Bank of Morristown, N. J.

Lying on the ground with his head tied to the exhaust pipe of his automobile, the body of Arthur H. Klein of 28 Kensington Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., was found this afternoon in Old Mill Lane near Route 9W at West Haverstraw.

Fifteen members of the American Battle Monuments Commission sailed yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan to attend the dedication of fourteen monuments in France, one in Belgium and one in England.

Mrs. Reba Mundell Nicholson White, wife of William Wallace White, New York lawyer, Paraguayan Consul General in the United States and former Mayor of Pelham, died yesterday at their home here, 300 Loring Avenue, after a long illness.

Valentine Before Grand Jury Twenty-seven witnesses, including Police Commissioner Valentine, appeared yesterday before the special rackets grand jury in Brooklyn which is investigating the police charity fraud wherein persons have solicited money by representing themselves as working for the police department of Island Park. L. I.

Miss Cecile Valentine Hodgman, daughter of Mrs. Gertrude V. Hodgman of Glen Brook, will be married on Aug. 20 to Will Robinson Clapp, son of Mrs. Stuart Harold Clapp of East Orange, N. J., and the late Major Clapp.

Tiger Jack Fox of Spokane, Wash., One of tge chief contenders for the light-heavyweight championship held by John Henry Lewis, will meet deacon Leo Kelly of Los Angeles to night in the fifteen-round bout that will feature another of the series of populat-priced boxing shows at Madison Square Garden.
John O. Jamison Sr., for many years with G. M. P. Murphy Co., brokers and investment bankers, died last night in his home here at the age of 60.

Senator Copeland of New York, the only physician in the Senate, warned Senator Robinson to "go slow" and told him he was taking grave chances with his life on Tuesday of last week, the day the Democratic leader opened the debate on the Compromise Court Reorganization Bill.
Lawson Little, former British and American amateur champion, won the twenty-first playing of the Shawnee open golf championship today, climbing from thirteenth place to finish on top.

Bert Acosta, aviator who flew across the Atlantic Ocean with Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, was back in the Nassau County jail here today on complaint of his wife, Helen, of Rockville Center, who charged him with failing to support his minor child.

Of the five seeded players who saw action in the Eastern junior clay court tennis championship yesterday all but one advanced to the semi-final round at the West Side club in Forest Hills. The lone seeded entrant eliminated was Marvin Kantrowitz, ranked fifth in the competition and rated among the stars at Texas University, where he has just comnleted his freshman year.

A Federal statutory court in Brooklyn denied yesterday the application of Percy Campbell Reed, proprietor of the Nassau Kennel Club, for a temporary injunction restraining State and county officials from interfering with the operation of a dog-racing track at Mineola, L. I.

The number of dry goods wholesale buyers arriving in the market here this week was disappointing to both selling houses and resident offices. The latter ascribed various reasons for the failure of buyers to come into the market, but the principal factor, all agreed, was the fact that most wholesalers have moderate stocks of goods on hand and are inclined to await further developments in the dry goods trade before laying down commitments.

Orders booked by the J. G. Brill Company in the six months ended on June 30 amounted to $4,758,888, a gain of 711/2 per cent over the $2,773,106 in the first half of last year, according to Charles J. Hardy, president.

More significant than the sensational clashes between Chinese and Japanese soldiers, broken truces followed by renewal of local fighting, and the movement of considerable numbers of troops by both sides to the troubled Peiping area during the past week are the renewed demands of Japan.

The long-discussed plan to supply the "missing link" in the Atlantic Inland Waterways system by constructing a canal across New Jersey to connect the ports of New York and Philadelphia was assailed and defended today at a ninehour hearing before a special board of army engineers.

Dr. Alice Salomon, noted sociologist, who was expelled a month ago, received a summons early last month to call at the headquarters of the secret State police to give an explanation of her frequent trips abroad.

More than 13,000 members of the American Newspaper Guild will have an opportunity soon to vote in a referendum on the recent affiliation of the Guild with the C. I. O. and extension of its jurisdiction to include office workers employed by newspapers.

Mrs. Emma A. Fox, 90-year-old authority on parliamentary law, alighted from an airplane at Lambert-St. Louis Airport last night, one of the first arrivals for the national convention of Pi Omicron sorority, which opened here today.
Robert Ley, leader of the German Labor Front, speaking at a gathering here yesterday, said:
Senator Robinson's will be the fourteenth state funeral held in the Senate Chamber since the Civil War. Senate records listed the others as:

Ellsworth Bunker, chairman of the United States Cane Sugar Refiners Association, declared yesterday that subsidized Hawaiian and Puerto Rican refined-sugar expansion would destroy the unsubsidized American sugar-refining industry and throw American workmen out of jobs.
The seventh annual "Send a Child to :amp This Summer" campaign was launched yesterday by the Children's Welfare Federation, an organization composed of 259 churches, welfare and community centers.

Immediate retirement of the Pittsburgh United Corporation, the old Oil Well Supply Company, through a switch in the securities which will enable the Peoples-Pittsburgh Trust Company, as trustee, to redeem Pittsburgh United's preferred stock was ordered today by Judge Elder W. Marshall.

Due to continued disagreement concerning the music rights for "How Long Brethren" and Charles Weidman's departure from the cast of "Candide," these WPA Federal Dance Theatre productions will not open tonight at the Maxine Elliott Theatre as previously announced.

An upper level for the Henry Hudson Bridge and improved roadway facilities through Inwood Hill Park and Spuyten Duyvil seemed assured yesterday with the announcement by the Henry Hudson Parkway Authority that it had successfully completed the issuance of $2,000,000 in new 3 1/2 per cent sinking fund bonds.

Friends of Isabelle Hallin, Saugus High School teacher, rallied to her aid tonight as the young woman remained "badly shaken" at the refusal of a majority of the school committee to hold a public hearing of ouster charges against her.

Miss Peggy Pardee, daughter of Mrs. M. Eyerman Pardee and Schuyler Pardee of Greenwich and New York has completed plans for her marriage to Edmund Gilmour Anderson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund G. Anderson of Larchmont, N. Y.

MANHATTAN COGSWELL, CORA (March 15, 1936). Gross assets, $4,444,653; net, $4,266,548. To Florence Pearl Browning and Elzabeth Browning, sisters, one-half residue each; Paul E. Whitten, $25,000; Charles E. Austin, chauffeur, and Captain Thomas Rose, annuities of $600 each: several other bequests. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $3,407,391. Paul Endicott Whitten, attorney, 28 W. 44th St.

Rain and poor flying conditions kept Merrill K. Riddick grounded here today after he had completed the first lap, ten miles, of a projected 35,000-mile flivver plane flight from Blasdell to Bombay, India.

The Reich Building Inspection Department issued an ordinance today under which iron, steel and wood are not to be used for building materials except in cases of extreme necessity, and wood only for roofing. Stone or concrete may be used in all construction work, substituting for the other materials, of which there is an acute shortage.

Defying the sweeping injunction issued by Supreme Court Justice Lewis L. Fawcett, striking members of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C. I. 0. affiliate, continued yesterday to picket the Wheeler shipyard, West Seventeenth Street and Coney Island Creek, Brooklyn.

A collective bargaining referendum for operating employes of the B. M. T. system will be held during the week of July 25, the City Industrial Relations Board announced yesterday. The exact date, as well as the place of the election, will be announced soon.

Turpentine firm, 33 c.; sales, 226 barrels; receipts, 577 barrels shipments, 86 barrels; stock, 32,115 barrels. Resin steady; sales, 445 barrels; receipts, 1,913 barrels; shipments, 225 barrels; stock, 66,662 barrels. Quote: B to N, $7.871/2; WG, $7.95; WW, X, $8.70.

Authoritative sources tonight reported that fifty of the sixty-seven Americans aboard the passenger ship Ciudad de Barcelona when the vessel was sunk May 30 were rescued and now are fighting for the Madrid-Valencia Government.

Covering of July obligations before trading in them ceases at noon tomorrow strengthened the spot month on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and, after eliminating the discount, left July and October at the same figure with the list unchanged to 8 points higher than on Tuesday.
Supervised Shares, Inc., reported yesterday total net assets on June 30, at market prices, of $11,256,736, equal to $13.33 a share on the 844,157 shares outstanding on that date.

The seventy-ninth annual convention of the American Dental Association here heard two attacks today on what the speakers called the "orgy" of tooth extraction as a remedy for general ills or infections in other parts of the body.

Hopes that peace with China can be preserved are growing stronger. The governing factor still is Nanking's attitude toward Japan's insistence that the dispute be settled with the North China authorities as a local incident.
The British Boxing Board of Control today officially denied that it recognized Max Schmeling of Germany as heavyweight champion of the world.
The national mediation board prepared tonight to intervene in the threatened nation-wide railroad strike.
In the feature match of the Lake Mohonk invitation tennis tournament today Richard M. Dorson overcame the severe service of J. Norman Anderson, Dartmouth ace, in a three-set contest.

Advances of $1 to $3 in coats and suits in the $22.75 to $32.75 ranges ??ill be necessary because of higher wages and increased prices for furs and rates for fur processing, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of manufacturers representing 90 per cent of the production in that field, at the offices of the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board.
Behind the disappearance of a valuable piece of Japanese art from the Newark Museum yesterday is the story of an effort by probation officers to cure an 11-year-old boy of delinquency.

Kingman Brewster of Vineyard Haven, Mass., advanced to the third round today in defense of the Prince of Wales Trophy, emblematic of international junior yacht racing supremacy. He sailed a Acadian Class sloop on Lake Milo, with Edward A. Robie as his crew.
A United Kingdom team of senior golfers won an international triangular tournament over the Royal Lytham and St. Annes

Arkansas Natural Gas Corporation and Subsidiaries-Three months ended March 31: Net income, after all expenses and taxes, $1,398,339, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 14 cents a combined common share, against a net of $1,815,552, or 19 cents a combined common share, in the three months ended on March 31, 1936.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

The Indians opened a two-weeks visit in their home park today by defeating Washington, 11 to 3, in the opener of a three-game series. Hal Trosky, Cleveland first baseman, hit his eighteenth home run of the season in the fourth inning, immediately after Earl Averill knocked out his ninth with Roy Hughes on base.

The Rev. Thomas J. McCluskey, former president of Fordham University, died at 10:30 o'clock Tuesday night in St. Vincent's Hospital at Seventh Avenue and Eleventh Street. He had completed fifty-six years of priesthood and was 79 years old.

In fierce equatorial heat fliers of the Lexington continued today their increasingly hopeless search in the South Pacific Ocean for Amelia Earhart and Frederick J. Noonan, navigator of her plane, missing twelve days on a world-girdling flight.

Here are events in the life of Senator Robinson: Aug. 26, 1872-Born in Lonoke, Ark. 1894-Elected to State Assembly. 1895-Admitted to the bar. 1902-Chosen to the Fifty-eighth Congress as a member of the House and remained through the Sixty-second.

7th Ave, 2,061-2,065, 7-story apartment and stores, 60x105; Lewalt 'Realty Corp against 309 W. 106th St. Corp; due, $23,180, subject to mortgage of $93,000; to plaintiff for $115,000. Rose St, 57, 5-story loft, 23x89 irregular; Bowery Savings Bank against Marguerite M. Ogilvie; due, $15,854; taxes, , $549; to plaintiff for $12,500.

Although he complained of not feeling very well, Senator Robinson posed for a sketch yesterday, and, as he leaned back in a great leather chair, he spoke of some of the things which were happening in the Senate Chamber.
North American newsprint production in June totaled 419,183 tons, an increase of 40,674 tons over that reported for the same month last year, the Newsprint Service Bureau reports.

A number of firms engaged in the apparel industry were listed among the lessees of new quarters for business purposes reported yesterday. Weber Weber, Inc., haberdashers, who have been operating a shop in the ground floor of the RCA Building West in Rockefeller Center, have taken an additional store on the street level in Nine Rockefeller Plaza which they will open about Aug. 1.

Paul Newton of the University of California and Julius Heldman of U. C. L. A. were eliminated from the Spring Lake invitation tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club today as all of the favorites with the exception of Wilmer
Fifty thousand Michigan truck drivers and helpers were called out on a general strike last midnight, but its effectiveness could not be determined early today.

Reynolds du Pont today sailed Crenthoza to victory by 29 seconds over Chance, sailed by Gordon Murphy, in the H-23-foot class of the Wednesday Fishers Island Yacht Club regatta. George Haines, in Mariette. was a close third.

Although Chino-Japanese negotiations continued both in Tientsin and Peiping, inner circles realized the magnitude of the basic issues involved and the utter divergence of aims of both sides and were convinced all parleys must be barren of permanent results.

The expected freight revenues for 1937 of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad were fixed at $48,000,000, an increase of $1,800,000 over the original estimate submitted in January, according to the revised budget estimate filed by the trustees with the Federal District Court in New Haven.
There is nothing wrong with the French Army. War Minister Edouard Daladier showed it today to the people of Paris and to foreigners who attended this annual celebration of the taking of the Bastille.

A plan of recapitalization for the Wheeling Steel Corporation, which provides for the elimination of accumulated dividends on the 6 per cent preferred stock, was approved at a special meeting of stockholders yesterday.

A court order approving a plan of reorganization for the $2,736,000 mortgage 6 per cent bonds secured by the fifteen-story Alden Apartment Hotel at Central Park West and Eighty-second Street has been signed by Supreme Court Justice Church, it was learned yesterday.
James Roosevelt said tonight that court decisions of the past were among the causes for present labor difficulties.

Mr. and Mrs. Soreno Lund of the Waumbek, Jefferson, gave a theatre party at Chase Barn Theatre, Whitefield. tonight. Mrs. Lewis Morris entertained there in honor of her house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Willard Cox and Davison Brown of New York.
Mayor La Guardia telephoned from his office in the Summer City Hall yesterday to Magistrate Alfred H. Lindau.

The third trial of Clarence Norris since he and eight other Negroes were arrested for an alleged attack on two young women in 1931 was rushed to a speedy conclusion today with the State demanding his death and the defense demanding acquittal, but subtly suggesting to the jurors that they could find him guilty without sending him to the electric chair.

Miss Cynthia Yeteve Hart, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. E. Belden Hart of East Orange and Washington, was married tonight to John L. Butler, son of Mrs. Cora Butler of Upper Montclair, at the home of the bridegroom's brother-in-law and sister, Dr. and Mrs. Hunter E. Harvey, also of Upper Montclair.

Under a gray, murky sky that occasionally sprinkled a few drops of rain on the venerable Henry Fabian's velvety lawns, the Giants yesterday opened their third home operations of the year against their mighty foes from the West, and forthwith put on a performance that shone with rare brilliance despite its drab setting.
The State Civil Service Employes Association, which has 15,000 members, through a letter today from its president, Charles A. Brind Jr., warned John L. Lewis to keep his hands off.
Funeral services for Ida Conquest, retired actress, who died Sunday at the age of 61, were held yesterday morning in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today two rules under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 dealing with relationships between foreign subsidiaries which obtain exemption under Section 3b of the act and other companies of the same holding company system.

Driving on powerfully to the surprise of most observers, A. H. Waterman's Count Stone yesterday captured the Pocantico Handicap at Empire City by a length and a half, with Jesting, the odds-on favorite, beaten off.
While North American wheat prices dipped at the opening today, due to the failure of Liverpool to fully reflect the upturn on Tuesday, at no time could the market halve been called weak.

General Francisco Franco announced that the enemy's offensive on the Madrid front already had ended in complete failure when he received the foreign press correspondents today in his general headquarters.
Two of the favored combinations in the Women's Long Island Golf Association third annual Scotch foursome championship were eliminated in the quarter-final round today at Meadow Brook.

The need for more adequate funds to maintain the city's vastly enlarged and improved park system was impressed upon civic leaders yesterday on the annual tour of Queens parks under the auspices .of the Park Association of New York City and the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce.
William H. Schriver, the last veteran of the Civil War in the town of Cortlandt, died here at his home last night after an illness of several days from heat prostration. He was 89 years old.

Criticism of the proposed contract between the city and the Foreign Trade Zone Operating Corporation, under which the city would employ the corporation as its agent to operate the foreign trade zone at Stapleton, S. I., was expressed yesterday in an interim report made public by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

The golfer from Syracuse who takes his automobile trailer wherever he goes to play, Bill Holt, of the Bellevue Country Club, duplicated his first round in the national open by scoring a 70 over the east course at Oak Hill today in the qualifying round of the fifteenth annual New York State amateur championship to become the medalist.

It took thirty-four years to do it, but a postcard mailed in Cranbury. N. J., finally reached its destination five miles away. The card, postmarked Feb. 24, 1903, was sent by W. H. Johnson to George D. Van Derveer of near-by Dayton.

The British proposals for solving the deadlock over Spain finally were completed this morning and laid before the House of Commons this evening after being circulated to the twentysix other nations concerned.

22d St, n s. 354.71/2 e of 1st Ave, 70.41/2x 98.9; trustees' will of Carlo A. Almone to Aimone Realty Corp, 51 Chambers St, care of H. A. Cone; mtg, $25,000. Amsterdam Ave, 62, 25x100; Walter Dickinson and wife to Rulin Realty Corp, 50 Court St, Brooklyn, care of J. Levenson ($12).
The Eastern States Association of Dealers in Oil and Gas Interest, Inc., has been formed to operate in eighteen Eastern States and the District of Columbia.

Harry T. McCosker of 28 Chester Court, Brooklyn, hanged himself with a leather belt today in his room at Bloomingdale Hospital, an institution here for mental patients. He was 44 years old and unmarried.
New houses are going up here at the rate of forty a week-so the city arranged today for Northerners to see more pictures of bathing beauties next Winter than ever before.

Harold Brightman, general merchandise manager of Bamberger's, and R. D. Jenkins, vice president of the International Silk Guild, will be principal speakers at a fashion and silk merchandise forum to be held next Tuesday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel under the auspices of the International Silk Guild.
Indignation mounted in this art colony today against a "blue law" forbidding Sunday business in art shops, as seven keepers of such shops prepared to face court tomorrow for alleged violations.

A program calling for cooperative effort to establish merchandise standards, set up uniform classifications of items so as to facilitate comparison of operating results, and study reasons for failure of most retail housewares departments to operate profitably was adopted yesterday by the housewares, china and glassware merchandise group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The report from the Harvard Observatory in yesterday's TIMES concerning the Pleiades recalls the questioning of JOB by the voice in the whirlwind: "Canst thou bind the cluster of the Pleiades?" Science is answering that

Retail deliveries in the metropolitan and adjacent suburban areas showed a decrease of 1 per cent for the week ended July 10, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. For the four weeks ended on that date there was a gain of 4 per cent in the number of packages handled by the delivery organization.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Bridgford Rikel, younger daughter of Mrs; Charles Edward Rikel Jr. and the late Mr. Rikel, to John Thomas Brown, son of John Brown of Glenwood and the late Mrs. Brown, took place this evening in the Sea Cliff Methodist Episcopal Church.

Members of St. John's University Auxiliary held their Summer party yesterday at the Lido Country Club. Luncheon was preceded by a musical program, presented by Paul Martin, organist, and bridge and swimming were features of the aftarnoon.

The report of the Banca Commerciale Italiana Trust Companyw of New York for June 30 showed total deposits of $12,474,023; total assets of $16,245,897; capital and surplus of $2,750,000, and special reserves and undivided profits of $107,661.
Dick McKee of Miami led the way into the semi-finals of the Pennsylvania State junior tennis championships today, beating William Turner of Washington, 6-3, 6-2.

Frederick E. Ziegler, 35 years old, former treasurer of the defunct William von Bremen Company, Inc., surrendered yesterday to the District Attorney on a grand larceny indictment and was released later in General Sessions in $2,500 bail for pleading today.

President Federico Paez today informed Minister of the Government Aurelio Bayas that the' constitutional convention for which elections have just been held will be held on Aug. 10 as originally planned.

Try-outs and time trials for members of both the Oxford-Cambridge and Princeton-Cornell squads held the center of the stage today in Palmer Stadium as both units concluded arduous training and prepared to taper off for the eighth renewal of their rivalry on Saturday.

President Roosevelt issued this statement today on learning of the death of Senator Robinson: In the face of a dispensation so swift in its coming and so tragic in the loss it brings to the nation we bow in sorrow. A pillar of strength is gone. A soldier has fallen with face to the battle.

Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, declared yesterday before sailing for Europe on the French liner Normandie that this country was approaching its era of greatest prosperity, but he warned the nation's business men to adjust their views to a longer range and accept the elemental principle that they must contribute to the buying power of their workers.
The Commodity Exchange Administration announced today newregulations to "tighten up" government control over futures trading in farm products.

Two trust funds having an aggregate present value of about $5,880,000 were established in 1921 for the eventual benefit of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute at Troy, N. Y., by Mrs. Cora L. Cogswell, a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday disclosed. These gifts are almost equal to the institute's present $6,000,000 endowment.
Frangois-Poncet in a Bastile day speech at the French Embassy here today before the French colony strongly protested against the attitude of the German press toward France.
Members of the Benedictine Order from various parts of the nation were among the many clergymen at funeral services today for the Right Rev. Abbot Ernest Helmstetter of St. Mary's Abbey.

New Yorkers temporarily abandoned shirtsleeves, linen suits and other 'hot-weather garb for warmer garments yesterday as subnormal temperatures for the day continued the welcome break in the near-record heat wave under which the city had sweltered for six days.

Miss Naon Juan Craft, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Clinton Craft of Coral Gables, Fla., and Baltimore, was married here today to H. Riall Jackson, son of Mayor Howard W. Jackson of Baltimore, and Mrs. Jackson.
The law limiting corporate holdings of Puerto Rican lands to 500 acres an moved a step nearer a test yesterday following the decision of the insular Supreme Court that it had jurisdiction.

A $15,000 mortgage on 79 Avenue A, held by the Central Savings Bank from the 79 Avenue A Realty Cor., Martin Jaffe, treasurer, was extended to July 1, 1942, $50 to be paid off quarterly, and the interest rate is reduced from 5 per cent to 4 per cent for the first three years, and 41/2 for the last two years.
Yale University's golf team scored the first victory of its English tour today, defeating a team captained by Lieutenant Stark, St. Andrews University coach, 10 to 6, in an unofficial match.

FIRST MILITARY AREA So much of Paragraph 7, Special Order 41, July 9, 1937, as reads "391st Infantry," is amended to read 390th Infantry. Capt. Otis Purvis, Fin. Res.. Finance Department, Plattsburg Barracks, N. Y., recently released to this headquarters for assignment, is assigned to the 1215th Service Unit.

Simon Miller of New York, third in the draw, was eliminated by Jack Behr of Hastings, N. Y., today from the Glen Ridge open tennis championship. The score of the second round match was 5-7, 12-10, 6-2.

The Board of Education has announced the following appointments: HIGH SCHOOL TEACHERS GEORGE WASHINGTON HIGH SCHOOLMilton Zinar. Edna Tristram Heald. HAAREN-Isabel E. McGarry, Harold H. Dycke, Harry G. Bruce. HIGH SCHOOL OF COMMERCE-Ellen B. Pettit. MUSIC AND ART-Chester Coleman. STRAUBENMULLER TEXTILE--Rosalind Wolford. WADLEIGH-Grace Perrucci, Florence E. Aronson.

War "rackets" were denounced by Major Gen. Smedley D. Butler, U.S.M.C., retired, and peace "rackets" by Mrs. Vinton Earl Sisson, national defense chairman of the Daughters of the American Revolution, in addresses delivered at today's meeting of the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs.

Pension tax refunds will be made soon to officers and employes of the New York Central system covering deductions heretofore made from their salaries under the Railroad Retirement Act of 1936, F. E. Williamson, president, announced yesterday.

Six tracts of land owned Dy the Percy A. and William G. Rockefeller estates on Midwood Road, in the Deer Park section of Greenwich, have been sold to Isabel R. Lincoln, deeds filed in the town clerk's office, Greenwich, disclosed today.

Dr. F. Lovell Bixby, Assistant Director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, has resigned, effective Sept. 20, to join the staff of the Osborne Association in New York, Attorney General Cummings announced today.

The bloodless coup in Bolivia last night that ousted Provisional President David Toro and put into his place 33-year-old Lieut. Col. German Busch, chief of the General Staff, was a rising by younger officers against older officers,

THEY WON'T FORGET, from Ward Greene's novel, "Death in the Deep South;" screen play by Aben Handel and Robert Rossen; directed and produced by Mervyn LeRoy; released by Warner Brothers. At the Strand.

Recognizing the interest which is being displayed in the commodity markets by traders as well as Exchange houses and their clients, the New York Stock Exchange firm of Maloney, Anderson Block has made arrangements for a weekly series of informative talks, dealing with various individual commodities by leaders in their respective fields, according to an announcement yesterday.

161st St. (9-2474), s e cor of Gerard Ave. 91x111; Anne Mink to Flame Realty Corp, 165 Broadway; mtg $16,000. Waldo Ave (13-3414D). e s, 225 ft n of 238th St, 125x100; Natorp Realty Corp to Abram Adolph, 121 W 69th St. Harrison Ave (11-2868), w s, 100 ft s of Morton Pl, 108x106; Bermark Corp to Atlas Estates, Inc, 292 Madison Ave; mt $172.900.

A fresh sign that the magnetic forces which compel political affairs to rotate around an axis are not equally compelling in the domain of sport was supplied tonight by a new deflection in Austro-Italian sporting events from the prescribed BerlinRome axis.
Mayor La Guardia interpreted yesterday the action of the Board of Aldermen in reducing the water rates 50 per cent as a "refusal" to rive home owners any reduction.

The first tidings of the Larchmont Yacht Club's 320-mile ocean race to Fire Island and return brought word today that three of the eleven entrants had abandoned the Brooklyn Challenge Trophy event in a heavy blow near the eastern end of Long Island Sound last night.
The chances are good that before long we shall be told that the average earnings of an unskilled laborer in this country are

Formal announcement that State Senator Clifford R. Powell of Burlington County will oppose State Senator Lester H. Clee of Essex County for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination will be made tomorrow, his friends said tonight.

Sheriff Percy G. Egglefield of Essex County and Sergeant Paul McGinnis andHenry C. Durand of the State police will leave for Los Angeles on Monday in an effort to bring M. Leverne Moore, otherwise known as James Montague, to answer to an indictment against him for robbery at Jay in 1930.
Except for the more apparent trend toward moderately lower prices, there was very little change in the general character of bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Civil and military forces of Massachusetts were set in motion tonight to aid marooned Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard, as an all-day conference at the State House, called in an attempt to settle a two-day strike on steamers serving the islands, broke up in a deadlock just before midnight. Negotiations will be resumed at 2 P. M. tomorrow.
The New York Curb Exchange has listed 117,696 shares of Gilehrist Company common capital stook, no par value;
The British Government kept an anxious watch over the situation in North China today, although the tension between Japan and China was considered here to be less serious than before.

Sixteen warehouse buildings, comprising Bush Terminal and covering the area bounded by Third Avenue, Thirty-second Street, Forty-eighth Street and the waterfront in Brooklyn, were tied up yesterday by the continued strike of 800 service and

Two bills recently introduced in Congress by Senator McAdoo, "designed to permit branch banking anywhere within Federal Reserve Districts and to allow transformation of existing chains into branch systems," were criticized severely here tonight by Dr. Luther A.

Mrs. Grosvenor Nicholas and Miss Maud W. Van Rensselaer jointly Lo gave a large tea party yesterday in the Spanish Room of the Atlantic Beach Club. Their guests included Mrs. Henry Iselin, Mrs. Jose Aymar Camprubi, Mrs. John C. Greenleaf, Mrs. Garrett A. Brownback,

A magistrate's court ban on socalled service bureaus which, for a fee, will appear in court and pay fines for motorists accused of minor traffic violations not requiring a personal appearance, was upheld yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Edward J. McGoldrick.

Two Strike-closed mines of the Republic Steel Corporation resumed operations today despite more than 200 pickets. Superintendent J. C. Laick of the Davidson and Trotter Mines said that more than 200 of the normal payroll of 549 had returned to the pits after petitioning Governor Earle for protection.

The Victor Chemical Works, Chicago, has entered into an agreement with F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., investment banking firm, covering the sale of 75,000 shares of stock of the company, according to an announcement yesterday by August Kochs, president.

Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the City's Emergency Relief Bureau, plans to resign that post early next month, it was reported yesterday. The report said she was to become head of Hull more House in Chicago, founded by the late Jane Addams.

Senator Robinson was the tenth Senator and the twenty-third prominent Federal official to die during the administration of President Roosevelt. In addition, Thomas J. Walsh of Montana, Attorney General-designate, died on March 3, 1933, and Mrs. Harold L. Ickes, wife of the Secretary of the Interior, was killed in an automobile accident on Sept. 1, 1935.
Close of play scores English first-class cricket matches started today: Surrey 444 for six wickets (Squires 133, Barling 120 not out, Gregory 51); vs. Warwickshire, at the Oval.
The second crew of Soviet aviators to fly non-stop from Moscow to the United States by way of the North Pole landed in a cow pasture near March Field today with a world distance record.
Police and observers testified today that steel strikers carried guns and clubs and began the fighting in the Memorial Day riot which cost ten lives.

The most noteworthy feature of American business conditions recently has been the ability of industrial production and trade activity to move steadily ahead with almost full disregard for the continuing flow of items of bad news, says Colonel Leonard P. Ayres,
THE GREAT GOLDWYN, by Alva Johnston. (Random House, $1.50.) A biography of the motion picture producer.

Arthur Penzo of Yonkers, a 33year-old Auburn prison convict who confessed to a keeper last November that he had slain a man in 1935 and buried his body in Yonkers woods, was sentenced here today by County Judge Gerald Nolan to twenty years to life for seconddegree murder.
Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., headed the successful banking syndicate yesterday in the purchase of a new issue of $5,000,000 of State of Louisiana highway bonds.

Preliminary plans were filed yesterday on behalf of the Brooklyn Savings Bank and the Everett N. Garnsey Company at 56 West Forty-fifth Street, Manhattan, for the erection of a 236-family apartment house in Brooklyn at an estimated cost of $2,800,000.
Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, opposed today the use of "idle gold" for retirement of part of the public debt.

Gustav Nassauer, 65 years old, of 56 East Eighty-seventh Street, waived examination in the Felony Court yesterday as Magistrate Aurelio was about to hold a hearing on a charge that he stole $200,000 worth of oil paintings and two manuscripts of plays, valued at $2,000, from Mrs. Maris Warrington, an art collector, last January.

The body of George Gershwin, American composer, who died Sunday in Hollywood, will arrive here this morning for funeral services at 2 P. M. in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street. Ira Gershwin, the composer's brother, arrived yesterday at Newark airport for the services.

Lectures in jazz will be included in the general music curriculum at the University Heights Center of New York University during the Fall semester, it was announced yesterday by Professor Alfred M. Greenfield, administrative chairman of music of University College.

Arthur Penzo of Yonkers, a 33year-old Auburn prison convict who confessed to a keeper last November that he had slain a man in 1935 and buried his body in Yonkers woods, was sentenced here today by County Judge Gerald Nolan to twenty years to life for seconddegree murder.
Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., headed the successful banking syndicate yesterday in the purchase of a new issue of $5,000,000 of State of Louisiana highway bonds.

The Court of Appeals in a brief memorandum handed down yesterday, disposed of a $3.000,000 case and at the same time gave its reasoning so that the City of New York will be spared from defending similar actions.

Preliminary plans were filed yesterday on behalf of the Brooklyn Savings Bank and the Everett N. Garnsey Company at 56 West Forty-fifth Street, Manhattan, for the erection of a 236-family apartment house in Brooklyn at an estimated cost of $2,800,000.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 7,000, including 1,000 directs. Market uneven, butchers from 240 pounds down, 10-20c higher than Wednesday's average, spots up more;

Representatives of citizens' groups and industries from a dozen States, summoned to Johnstown to find a "common ground" in the present labor strife, projected today a national committee dedicated to the preservation of the "inalienable constitutional right to work."

International labor unions striving for recognition by the Consolidated Paper Corporation tossed into its Three Rivers dispute today a threat to strike in all Quebec's "open shop" pulp and paper mills.

Price changes in steel products imported here were reflected in figures made public today by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce for May. In that month, this country imported 39,877 gross tons of semifinished and finished steel products, valued at $2,271,192, compared with 56,484 tons valued at $2,709,526 in April.

T. O. M. Sopwith, British sportsman and challenger for the America's Cup, and Mrs. Sopwith were honor guests at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Michael M. van Beuren at Gray Craig tonight. Mr. ana Mrs. Sopwith have been joined on their yacht Philante by Mrs. Sopwith's sister, Lady Leon, and Lady Gore, the latter joining Sir Ralph Gore.

James A. Dunn, special master, said. today he would recommend a divorce decree be granted Henry Hud Ileston Rogers Jr. of New York, son of the late Standard Oil executive. Dunn said he found the testimony supported Mr. Rogers's statement that his wife, the former Jirginia Lincoln of Cleveland, desert ed him.

Dispatches from Washington and London indicating there was little prospect of joint or separate American and British intervention in the Chino-Japanese crisis tonight caused acute disappointment in Chinese official quarters.
The War Department announced today a $175,000 allotment for harbor improvement work in New York Harbor.

Presentation of distinguished service certificates to Dr. Karl N. Llewellyn, Dr. Anna Rosenberg and Arthur S. Meyer by Mayor La Guardia, City Hall, 10 A. M. Presentation of bust to Postmaster Albert Goldman by Bronx Council Boy Scouts of America, at General Postoffice, Thirty-third Street and Eighth Avenue, 11 A. M.
Two arrests marked the opening of a campaign here this afternoon by the C. I. O. to organize 3,700 employes in the Ford assembly plant on River Road.

The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania reported yesterday a net gain of 44,610 telephones in service during the first half of this year, bringing the total number of instruments in use at the end of the period to 1,179,275, a figure only 8 per cent below the previous high record.

Mickey Mouse, the naive movie and comic strip character, whose saucy antics and strange assortment of friends have made millions of children and grown-ups chuckle, has been placed on the recommended reading list of New York City's elementary schools for the coming year, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, revealed yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Catherine F. Lehman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Lehman of this city, to Harold J. Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius H. Levy, also of New York, took place last night at Temple Emanu-EI. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman.

Valentine Ave, 2,262; 4-story tenement, 85.7x31.6 irregular; Ray Reuben, executor, against B. C. Nieberg Realty Co.; due, $30,134; to plaintiff for $25,000. Boston Rd, 1,861; 73x142.3 irregular; Mortgage Commission of New York against Wandell Realty Co.; due, $29,078; taxes, $3.384; to plaintiff for $1,000.

A ten-day display of its new Fall line of pajamas, robes, sport shirts and underwear, which is being shown both to the trade and to the public, was opened yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania by the B. V. D. Co., Inc., marking the first time that the public has been admitted to an advance trade showing.

The 276 guards at Sing Sing went on a six-day, forty-eight-hour week today, the result of years of agitation. The guards at the prison have worked seven days a week since it was founded 112 years ago.

The State Board of Conservation and Development announced today the gift to New Jersey of 230 acres of land in Warren County by Marcy P. and August W. Stephens of Summit. The site will be known as Stephens State Park.
Samual J. Neslin, one of the leaders of the silk printing industry here, died of a heart attack early today at the Hotel Lincoln in New York.
John Edward Raisbeck, who established the firm of Raisbeck Co., printers, here in 1888, died today at the age of 75.
A supper dance will be given tomorrow evening at the Smithtown Country Club for members and their guests. Lawrence Smith Butler is chairman of the floor committee.
State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews reported today "very little change" in payrolls in New York's factories from mid-May to mid-June, although employment dropped 0.2 per cent.

Opening this morning at the Roxy is "Super Sleuth," an R.-K.-O. comedy-mystery, with a cast including Ann Sothern, Jack Oakie, Eduardo Ciannelli, Alan Bruce, Edgar Kennedy, Joan Woodbury and Bradley Page. As an added feature the Roxy will show the Twentieth Century-Fox-Movietone News Technicolor pictures of the coronation of George VI.

Following minor weaknesses in the forenoon, the stock market steadied yesterday and showed quiet strength in the late trading, finishing irregularly higher. Steel issues made the best gains, as a group, with United States Steel reaching a new high level on the recovery at 116 1/8.

Spokesmen of American sailors and maritime radio operators continued their pleas for improved conditions at sea and higher wages yesterday when the Maritime Commission's investigation of the merchant marine went into its third day at the Federal Building, 45 Broadway.

The Brazilian Democratic Union, composed of twenty-eight political parties representing fourteen States, applied to the Superior Electoral Tribunal today for registration as a national political party under the presidency of Armando de Salles Oliveira. It is backing him for the Presidency of Brazil.

Almost $500,000 will be refunded to farmers and stockmen trading in the Kansas City Stock Yards since July, 1933, by a decision of the Federal Dis? trict Court, which has a second time upheld the Secretary of Agriculture in reducing by about 12 per cent, rates charged by livestock commission firms operating in the yards, the Department of Agriculture said today.

A furother increase in the general level of wholesale prices during the week ended on July 10 was announced today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index, based on the 1926 average as 100, rose to 87.7, compared with 87.2 the preceding week and 80.3 a year ago.

Increases of deliveries of sugar for consumption in June, compared with June of last year, and also for the January-June period, cornpared with the same period last year, were shown in preliminary figures made public today by the Sugar Section of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.
A heavy course caused postponement of today's Grand Circuit program at Historic Track.
Reorganization of WPA payroll procedure will save $420,000 a year in administrative costs, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday.

The Board of Higher Education meeting yesterday afternoon in ex ecutive session at the temporary' offices of the Queens City College 2 Park Avenue, approved the plans specifications and contracts for the furnishing, repairing and landscape ing of the new institution, which is to open this Fall.

The dollar advanced slightly yesterday in foreign exchange, but gold in London continued to command a premium over its New York shipping parity and no engagements of gold abroad for shipment here were reported.

A stockholders' meeting of the Ralston Steel Car Company has been called for Monday to act on a proposed plan of capital readjustment under which dividend accumulations on the preferred stock would be paid off, the common stock reclassified and the way paved for resumption of dividends on the common stock.

The Federal Trade Commission said today that Roy J. Troutman, Shamokin, Pa., trading as G. E. Laboratories and as Great Eastern Laboratories, had entered into a stipulation to discontinue unfair methods of competition in the sale of a Dr. Bayer's Horehound Cough Balsam, a cough medicine.

Presentation of awards for the "most meritorious contributions to the advancement of the boys' and students' clothing industry" were made at a banquet last night which closed the annual convention of the Boys Apparel Buyers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Because of the severe and prolonged drought, the yield of the principal grain crops in the prairie provinces of Canada this year will be lower than for several years, the Bank of Montreal says in its current crop report.

A substantial return-flow of hollday currency from circulation, combined with other factors, increased member- bank reserve balances $101,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve statistics published yesterday.

The Yankees battered the Tigers into defeat by 13 to 6 before 22,500 saddened Detroit fans today at Navin Field and stretched their winning streak to nine games, the longest spurt the Ruppert forces have enjoyed since 1933.

The Rev. C. E. Newton, 51 years old, a Baptist minister, confessed tonight that he slew Mrs. Dennis Kelly, 45, for many years his friend and parishioner at Paris, Mo., early Tuesday and threw her body into the Mississippi River.
Collective bargaining with Uncle Sam to protect fishing rights granted Pacific Northwest Indians in half-forgotten treaties was sought today by a committee of tribesmen on an organizing drive.

Six building and permanent loans have been placed by Maguire Mullowney, brokers, on Brooklyn buildings now under construction at a total cost of $1,535,000. The structures involved and their cost are: North side of Lincoln PI, 100 ft w of Eighth Ave, $320,000; w s of E 10th St, 200 ft north Ave H, $305,000; w s of E 13th St, 200 ft n of Ave R. S3.00,000;

Miss Muriel J. Wasch, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Milton G. Wasch, was married to Herbert S. Camitta, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Camitta Jr. of Philadelphia, yesterday morning at the home of her parents, 85 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Dr. Sidney S. Tedesche.
Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that he favors drastic taxation of non-resident aliens who have investments in this country.
Dr. and Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer gave a dinner tonight at Leelands for Mrs. Charles Frothingham Leland of Boston, who arrived today to pass several days with them.
The Cubs bounced back into first place in the National League today by taking the Bees' pitching apart for a 5-to-1 victory. Dropped out of the lead by yesterday's defeat,
The Rev. Patrick William Brown, 73-year-old Associate Professor of History at Catholic University, died today in St. Agnes Hospital in Baltimore.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, in a letter to President W. S. Knudsen of General Motors Corporation, today replied to the corporation's letter of June 29, asking that the C. I. O. union furnish assurances against unauthorized strikes before joint negotiations for modification of the present agreement opened.
Dr. Walther Simons, former Foreign Minister and former president of the German Supreme Court, died today at his home in Nowawes, near here. His age was 75.

Despite wide fluctuations in several lines of economic activity, business in the Pittsburgh district last week remained unchanged for the third consecutive week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

Raoul E. Desvernine, counsel of the United States Steel Corporation, asserted tonight that the Wage and Hour Bill now before Congress was "the most complete control over labor and industry ever proposed." He told the Wellesley Institute for Social Progress that the measure would "destroy free enterprise."

During the week ended July 14 member bank reserve balances increased $101,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $67,000,000 in money in circulation, $7,000,000 in Treasury cash,

Dr. Monroe Davis Eatdn, for the past year Associate Professor of Bacteriology and Immunology at the Washington University School of Medicine, has resigned to accept a post with the International Health Board of the Rockefeller Foundation of New York.
Thirty-six individuals and six corporations were named in an indictment handed up yesterday by the Federal grand jury to Judge Robert A. Inch in the United States District Court in Brooklyn.

Horace Borchsenius Mann, former consulting architect in industrial housing for the United States Shipping Board and the United States Army and an architect in this city for more than forty years, died early this morning of a heart attack in his home, 210 Madison Avenue.
FISHING AROUND THE WORLD, by Leander J. McCormick. (Scribner, $5.) Unusual experiences in four continents. JAPANESE LADY IN EUROPE, by Haruko Ichikawa. (Dutton, $2.50.) A travel diary.

2d Ave, 1,990, 25x100; Kare E. Boran to Angelo Basile, 154 E 106th St; consideration, $3,000, plus taxes and liens. Columbus Ave, n w cor of 106th St, 25.11x100; Mary Louise Quackenbush to Zephyr Holding Corp, 615 Columbus Ave ($45). Washington St, s e cor of Hubert St, 75x79.9; Bankers Trust Co to Berjen Realty Corp, 8 Washington Ave, Brooklyn ($60).

Twenty-five years of ehanging New York life have completely shifted the setting of the famous murder of Herman Rosenthal, fo,r which four gunmen and Polide Lieutenant Charles Becker were executed. Travelers who get off the Crosscountry buses today as usual at the Midtown Terminal on Forty-third Street, east of Broadway, to hur into a restaurant now known as Rosoff's, of the Cadillac Hotel, will find no historical reminder.

Ten charitable and religious institutions share in one-tenth of the estate of Mrs. Edith Minturn Phelps Stokes, wife of I. N. Phelps Stokes, president of the Municipal Art Commission. Mrs. Stokes died June 12. last.

The track and field forces of Oxford and Cambridge Universities created a mild sensation in this track-minded town today by extending through this afternoon their strenuous practice sessions for Saturday's meet, while members of the Princeton-Cornell contingent romped through light workouts.

Price movements of commodity futures here were mixed yesterday in moderate activity. Rubber, silk, hide, coffee and lead futures gained, while sugar, tin, zinc, cottonseed oil, cocoa and pepper futures lost ground.

Professional cricketers proved too strong for amateurs in the Gentlemen-Players match concluded at Lord's today. The contest was a low-scoring affair, with the Players victorious by an eightwicket margin.

The Daily Herald published a story today telling of new fortifications said to have been built in Spanish Insurgent territory behind GibralA correspondent from the Laborite newspaper, writing under a Gibraltar dateline, asserted that heavy guns emplaced under the supervision of German technical experts now stretch for fifteen miles along the coast from Algeciras toward Tarifa.
Mrs. Augusta C. Winkhaus, widow of Frederick Winkhaus, died on Wednesday at Katonah, N. Y. She lived at 1,185 Park Avenue and was in her seventy-ninth year.

Elias Zonberg, furs, in 789 Madison Ave; George Fellan, flowers, in 135 E 34th St; Cyril Willmott, in 137 E 43d St; William Three Heller, dresses, in 18 E 55th St; Edwin J. Kerr Co, printing; H. A. Envelope Co, in 410 Pearl St: C. J. Lockwood,
New Jersey's drinkers, if alcoholic beverage tax returns may be accepted as a barometer, drank more of everything in the last year except strong still wines.

Defending champion Tommy Goodwin's third hole-in-one in two years was the feature of the first two rounds of the fifteenth annual New York State amateur championship over Oak Hill's east course today. He scored his ace on the 186-yard third hole,

Anthony J. Schipper, who entered the employ of the Ford Motor Company on Dec. 13, 1934, testified at the National Labor Relations Board hearing today that he decided it was safe to talk unionism when the Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of the Wagner act.

A study by the Police Department's ballistic experts of the markings on a bullet found in the body of a hold-up victim and the faintly etched lines in the barrel of a .38 calibre pistol seized' in a robbery three months later resulted yesterday in the arraignment in the County Court in Brooklyn of a 19-year-old boy on a first-degree murder indictment.

Plans have been made for the geophysical and geological examination of the 325,000 acres of the holdings of California Lands, Inc., a subsidiary of the Transamerica Corporation, it was announced yesterday by John M. Grant, president of the parent organization.

The fate of the British proposals for ending the deadlock over Spain remained as much in doubt tonight, on the eve of the meeting of the Non-Intervention Committee to which they will be presented, as it was yesterday when they were announced.

The report of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, including its twenty-five principal telephone subsidiaries, for the three months ended May 31 shows a consolidated net income, after all expenses and charges, of $50,759,600.
A Vartanian, flight coordinator for the Soviet Government, said here tonight that his country's aviators' next goal might be a world flight via the North and South Poles.

The State Highway Patrol announced tonight Baird H. Markham Jr., son of a New York oil executive, was released four miles west of here by prison fugitives, who kidnapped him earlier in the day. He was unharmed.

Patrick J. Lynes of this city has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Margaret M. Lynes, to John H. Heigl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Heigl of Utica, N. Y. Miss Lynes's mother was the late Josephine Murray Lynes.

Forty minutes after two Negroes and the younger sister of one had been found guilty of first-degree murder, the men had been sentenced to the electric chair and the girl to life imprisonment and they were on their way to the State Prison at Trenton this evening.

Archbishop John T. McNicholas of the Cincinnati Catholic archdiocese dedared today that "some sitting in our courts of justice, even the supreme tribunal of the United States, reject the very idea of natural law." He added:

The report of the Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $10,841,574, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges.

There is a remembered prayer of ROWLAND WILLIAMS which would be especially appropriate for repetition by the great church council now sitting in Oxford representing hundreds of Christian denominations of the earth:

William Gilbert Broadway, retired New York wholesale cotton goods merchant, who was long prominent here in the old firm of Smith, Hogg Co., 115 Worth Street, died on Tuesday in Hinckley, Me., after a long illness which had' caused his retirement early this year.

When Upper Silesia was divided between Germany and Poland on the basis of the plebiscite of 1921, nationalists of both countries were bitterly dissatisfied with the settlement, the Germans because the Poles were awarded threefourths of the mines and other natural wealth of the area, the Poles because about two-thirds of the territory itself was allotted to the Germans.

Mrs. Mary Donovan Hapgood, C. I. O. organizer, was arrested with six others in the picket line at the Reed Prince Manufacturing Company plant today, and soon the union organizer, Martin J. Walsh, ended the seven weeks' strike.

With the formal submission yesterday of Miss Charlotte E. Carr's resignation as executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau, to become effective Aug. 1, some of Mayor La Guardia's closest advisers on relief began urging the selection in her place of Conrad Van Hyning,
Chinese police armed with razor straps today kept a steady stream of refugees pouring into this city in line.
Eduardo Santos, aspirant for the Liberal party nomination for President, favors a policy of protection for Colombia industries, according to a statement in a speech he made recently in Medellin.

Fall buying activity in the women's apparel and accessory lines continued brisk this week, with the arrivals of buyers yesterday reported as notably heavy. Orders in dress and coat lines so far are at least as large as last year at this time, with indications being that the peak of arrivals of store representatives next week will push business well above 1936.

Tailored or sports apparel in "soft" types formed the bulk of a collection of "back-to-college" fashions displayed yesterday under the direction of Kay Silver, fashion editor, at the. offices of Mademoiselle, 1 East Fifty-seventh Street, before an audience of about 200 department store and specialty shop buyers.

Mrs. Eliza A. Marache, widow of Theodore, Harold of Garden City, of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Blake Brothers Co., died last night after an illness of six months in her home, 881 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn.

A ring prized highly by its owner was recovered from forty feet of water in Upper St. Regis Lake by Kenneth Gray, a State policeman, after it was lost by Miss Catherine Parker of Baltimore, camper in the lake colony.

Edwin M. Van Voorhees, In 105 E 53d St: Roger P. Conant. in 123 E 53d St; Samuel Rose, in 381 Park Ave; Frank E. West Jr. in 105 E 53d St; Brett Wyckoff, brokers. Milton Kupfer, David Mayer, Ann Bryson, Leo Siegel, Doris E. Want, in the Oliver Cromwell, 12 W 72d St; S. H. Riesner Co. broker.

Wheat prices here were on the downgrade today, because of highly beneficial rains in parts of the Provinces of Alberta and Saskatchewan and a break of 2 3/4 to 4 1/4 cents a bushel in futures in Liverpool.

For the second week, Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau announced today a double issue of $50,000,000 bills, half of them the usual 273day bills and the others 148-day bills, falling due Dec. 16 in accordance with the Treasury's new policy of fixing the maturities in such a way as to relieve any jolting of the market by withdrawals for quarterly income tax payments.
Col. William O. Smith, Quartermaster Corps, New York, N. Y., to Camp Dix, N. J.. for temporary duty in connection with Organized Reserves activities at that station, July 18.

Led by Wilmer Allison of Austin, Tex-as, former national champion, the four top favorites came through to the semi-finals of the Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament today at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

The American Social Hygiene Association must raise at least $300,000 annually to meet increased demands upon its services, Dr. William F. Snow, general director of the association, announced yesterday.

Argentina's nimble soccer team, led by Angel Lafcirara and J. Sarlauga, defeated the United States, 9-1, tonight. The victors held a 3-0 lead over the American champions, the Highlanders of Trenton, N. J., at halftime in their Pan-American battle before 10,000 fans.
Mrs. Ella Julia Earl, wife of Dr. Edgar H. Earl, a retired physician of Brooklyn, N. Y., died today. She had come here two years ago from Brooklyn with her husband.

A funeral service for Dr. John W. Churchman, noted bacteriologist, surgeon and educator, who died on Tuesday after a long illness, was conducted yesterday morning at the funeral establishment of James E. McLarney Son, Inc., Sixty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue.

The scheduled ten-round bout between Billy Ketchell of Millville, N. J., and Steve Dudas of New York was postponed again today because of rain. The fight, origin ally scheduled to be held Wednesday night, will go on tomorrow night.

Richard J. Daly, 42 years old, of 15 Watkins Place, New Rochelle, was indicted today by the Westchester County grand jury on two counts of first degree grand larceny. He is president of the investment firm of Richard J. Daly Co., which formerly had offices in the Peoples National Bank Building here.

In the week ended yesterday awards for engineering construction totaled $59,437,000 for a gain of 39 per cent over the 1936 week, when the figure was $42,689,000, according to the Engineering NewsRecord.

Distillers who use a "drinking scene" theme in their advertising will have to get a new idea for their West Virginia campaigns. The State Liquor Control Commission banned, after Sept. 1, the "representation of a person with glass, bottle, or other container in hand or near by, or drinking or preparing to drink in any manner."

Federal control of wages and hours was debated tonight before the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs by Senator Hugo L. Black, sponsor in the Senate of this proposed expansion of the power to regulate commerce, and James A. Emery, counsel for the National Association of Manufacturers, who is opposed to it.

The Department of Commerce announced today that 122,072,393 pounds of coffee, valued at $11,236,444, was imported into the United States in May. Imports of Brazilian coffee amounted to 59,263,172 pounds and Colombian shipments were 33,181,519 pounds.

Albert R. Knight of Lansdowne, former executive of an oil company, was arrested today on a charge that he had plotted to burn three of his daughters to death and collect $120,000 in accident insurance he held on their lives.

The Indians scored their third straight victory today by defeating the Senators, 6 to 2, with the aid of a five run drive in the fifth inning which included Hal Trosky's nineteenth ta's home run of the season.

Lumber production increased last week, but allowance for the holiday caused a disproportionate spurt in the daily average against a steady seasonal trend, and it has been decided to fix the index for the week at an arbitrary figure of 97.5.

Fears of weevil damage, which had been an important factor in the cotton market recently, were decidedly lessened by the tenor of the weekly weather summary, with three days hot, dry weather in most sections of the belt, so that prices on the Cotton Exchange broke sharply yesterday.

Eddie Lopeskey's eyes gleamed mischievously across the lunch table at the orphanage Monday and shone in anticipation as he received slight nods from two of his fellow-orphans, Johnnie Waltenberg and Andy Scarpuli. All was ready for the break for 'freedom.
The National Cylinder Gas Company of Chicago has announced here that it had acquired voting control of the Carbo-Oxygen Company. The Benedum Trees interests of this city had held control.
Members of the Mount Desert Gardien Club attended a luncheon at Villa Roma here today, after which a number of the private flower gardiens were visited.

In THE TIMES of July 12 I read with deepest interest the final report of the eighteen-month industrial survey which has just been completed by Charles E. Murphy. I think it a most admirable and workmanlike statement which should go far toward redeveloping the industrial status of New York.

Basic Dolomite, Inc., Cleveland, Ohion, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 140,000 shares of common stock, the proceeds from the sale of which will be used to redeem bonds, pay rentals and for working capital.

Prince Paul, Yugoslav Regent; Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch and other Cabinet members were threatened today by the Serbian Orthodox Church Synod with excommunication if they supported the Vatican concordat, now under discussion in Parliament.

First Round Bill Holt defeated Fred Purchase, 5 and 4; Vince Schuster defeated D. Bodell. 4 and 3; W. Meany Jr. defeated L. Ribner, 5 and 4; Jack Raines Sr. won from S. Ross by default; B. McInerney defeated A. Zimmerman, 1 up (20 holes); B. Drexilius defeated B. Stark, 2 and 1; D. Ward defeated D. Govern, 1 up: R. Billows defeated W. Van Ben Schoten, 2 and 1.

In his letter to Senator BARKLEY, insisting upon the enactment of the Supreme Court Bill at this session, President ROOSEVELT says that a majority of both houses should be able to "agree on method and reach a vote" before Congress adjourns.

The city of San Francisco, Calif., has invited tenders for two new issues of bonds, aggregating $1,357,000, award of which will be made on July 26. The financing will consist of $810,000 of 4 per cent water bonds and $547,000 of 4 per cent sewer bonds. Both issues will mature serially on Dec. 1, 1937 to 1963.
James J. Dooling, Tammany leader, in conference yesterday with the other Democratic county leaders, adhered to his demand that the Mayoralty nominee be United States Senator Royal S. Copeland.

Australia won the famed Kolapore Cup and young Lieutenant G. A. Matchett of Hamilton, Ont., captured the Duke of Gloucester's prize in today's features of the Empire meeting of the National Rifle Association.

A charge of third-degree assault against Enzo Fiermonte, former prizefighter and husband of Mrs. Madeline Force Astor Dick Fiermonte. was withdrawn yesterday in Flushing Court after Mr. Fiermonte, through his attorney, offered an apology to the complainant, John Drennan, a newspaper photographer.

John Doe, ubiquitous mystery man, turned up at the outing of Aldermen and reporters yesterday and won the Democratic nomination for Mayor in a race held on the track of the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island.

To the Guldahls, Nelsons, Sneads and others of their ilk now on the way home from England with the Ryder Cup in their possession, a warning: Beware of a tall, angular man who plays golf with a cloverbud protruding from the corner of his mouth.

ARCHIBALD MacLEISH'S "The Fall of the City" dramatized the eternal dictator, hollow and triumphant, the everyman of the iron men. That play, published after a brilliant broadcast last Spring, presented the core of the matter with considerable force and eloquence.

THE gentle rain was falling and the Pittsburgh Pirates were taking their ease in their inn. Paul (Big Poison) Waner wasn't saying much for two good reasons, one being that he never says much and the other that it hurts him to talk just now. What few words he uttered came in a low hoarse whisper.
The official stamp of accuracy as a weather forecaster waz given to St. Swithin-for the time being at least-by the Weather Bureau yesterday.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
The former Kathryn F. Whitney house recently sold to Bradley Gaylord is located at 213 East Sixtysecond Street, and not 203 East Sixty-second Street, as previously incorrectly reported.
Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, who brought his wife to the medicinal baths here for treatment, tonight was described by his physician as suffering from "a slight cerebral thrombosis."

The season's longest losing streak, compiled by the Athletics and stretching to fifteen straight games, ended today as Connie Mack's team halted the White Sox, 2 to 1. During their long period of the defeats the Pladelphians played one tie.

Earle Bailie, head of the country's largest investment management corporation, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today he was not opposed to regulations prohibiting pyramided investment companies.

Mrs. William R. Maloney has called a meeting for tomorrow at her Summer home for chairmen of the various attractions at the fortyyear-old village fair, to be held on Friday afternoon, July 30. Proceeds of the fair care for East Hampton's trees and greens.

A new official spokesman at the Japanese Army headquarters here, who had just arrived from Tokyo, said yesterday that if negotiations for a settlement of the Peiping situation were unsuccessful the Japanese Army would move forward and smash by overwhelming force the hostile elements outside the beleaguered city.
Reorganization of the Prussian Academy of Arts Was decreed today by Colonel Gen. Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Prime Minister of Prussia and chief lieutenant to Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, seven times winner of the Griswold Cup in the Shenecossett women's invitation tournament, was eliminated in the semi-finals ofthe nineteenth annual competition today by Miss Helen Waterhouse of Providence, R. I.

A word of praise for the male American leg was expressed yesterday by James W. Gerard, former United States Ambassador to Germany, who returned belatedly after attending the coronation of King George VI as one of the American representatives appointed by President Roosevelt.

The Roosevelt Savings Bank of Brooklyn has made the following recent sales in that borough: One-family houses, 1,932 Bergen Street to G. Bruccolori and 1,757 East Third Street to A. Vetri; two-family houses, 283 Cooper Street to M. Brown, 731 Putnam Avenue to M. Buscemt, 4,010 Avenue D to C. Anderson, 406 Bainbridge Street to C. Assemblia, 151 Eldert, Street to C. Pischotta and 952 East Ninety-fifth Street to A. Saso.

A direct attack on the idea of a national church as proposed in Germany was opened today with the World Conference on Church, Community and State by Emil Brunner, noted professor of theology of the University of Zurich.

Rhinelander Ave (15-4278), n w cor of Seminole Ave, 100x100: also Seminole Ave, s w cor of Pawnee P1., 100x100; Reymont Realty Corp to Dale Housing Corp, 119 W 25th St. Mulford Ave (15-4191), e s, 487 s of Morris Park Ave, 37x95: Giuseppe Abbruzzese to Mary Ferrara, 1,832 Mulford Ave. Cauldwell Ave (10-2628), e s, 386 s of 156th St, 55x107; Bernhard Mayer Estate, Inc, to Ethel Morrison, 1,282 Stebbins Ave.

A nose finish, with the camera catching the inside horse, Night Bud, as the winner, enlivened a rain-swept card at Empire City yesterday. Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's Night Bud just made the grade in a thrilling finish with Miss E. G. Rand's Sun Lamp to capture the featured Manursing Purse.

Robert Backus, chairman of the Nantucket Board of Selectmen, flew back here from Boston tonight with assurance from Governor Hurley that "something drastic will happen" if the steamboat strike, which is ruining the island's Summer-resort business, isn't soon ended.

New York's 1937 harvest of hay, potatoes, corn, Winter wheat and barley will be greater than in 1936, with a resultant demand for more farm labor, the State Agriculture Department predicted today. The forecasts were contained in the July 1 report of crop conditions, issued jointly with the Federal Department of Agriculture.

MANHATTAN GUGGENHEIMER, SEYMOUR S. (July 19, 1936). Gross assets, $264,745; net, $205,698. To Clara Guggenheimer, mother; Rita Guggenheimer, sister, $5,000 each; Blanche S. Guggenheimer, widow, residue. Chief assets, miscellaneous property, $138,017.. Sperry Yankauer, attorneys, 285 Madison Ave.

A paucity of business today on the stock market was reflected in the closing prices; most quotations being moderately lower. Gilt-edge issues, nevertheless, were relatively well maintained, although the foreign were quiet.
The Rev. Herbert C. Crosier of Center Moriches, L. I.. died this afternoon at his camp at Hunter, N. Y.

Daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural communities for June were about 11 1/2 per cent higher in dollar volume than for any month since 1929, the Department of Commerce announced today.
The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended July 14 were announced today: Prall, Commander W. M., promoted to Captain (Engineering).

Modern home architecture will appear "barbaric" when compared with the beauty, comfort and cheapness of the jig-saw houses destined to spring up within the next thirty years, Harvey Wiley Corbett, New York architect, declared yesterday in an address on "Modern Architecture" at Columbia University.

After one close and another one-sided semi-final match, the third annual women's Long Island Golf Association Scotch foursome tournament reached the final stage at the Meadow Brook Club today, with Miss Grace Amory and Miss Audrey Phipps winners of the first and Mrs. Thomas R. Rudel

The Davis Cup forces of the United States and Germany, between rain showers today, had their final hard workouts for the interzone final matches, which start Saturday. Every member of both squads finished the drill sound as a bell.

Appeal to the National Mediation Board was taken today by the fourteen non-operating railroad unions, with 800,000 members, which have been conferring here for three days on their request for a wage increase of 20 cents an hour.

Tiger Jack Fox, Spokane (Wash.) light-heavyweight, advanced a step nearer a match with John Henry Lewis for the latter's 175-pound championship of the world' by stopping Leo (Deacon) Kelly of Los Angeles, at Madison Square Garden last night.

Miss Janet Alice Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Smith, will be married to Gerald Hughes Phipps, son of the former United States Senator and Mrs. Lawrence Phipps of Denver, on the afternoon of Sent. 24 in St. Thomas Church.

Provision was made by Congress today for continued operation of the Interior Department until Aug. 1, necessitated because the conference report on that department's 1938 Supply Bill was not completely agreed to by the House.

War Glory, one of Man o' War's famous sons, now 7 years old, made a show of four rivals in the Greenville Purse, featured event today at Delaware Park, despite a tendency to bear out all through the running of the mile and a sixteenth number.
The Bureau of Fisheries announced today that on June 15 cold-storage holdings of fish products were 4 per cent greater than a year ago and 35 per cent over the five-year average.
Superior Court Judge William Tell Aggeler died today of a heart attack at Buellton, Calif., while on a vacation with his wife. He was 70 years old.

Miss Alice Warner of the Greenwich County Club won the low gross award in a one-day medal play handicap eighteen-hole tournament played over the course of the Greenwich Country Club today with a score of 89.
Mr. and Mrs. Russell Gilbert of this city and Brookville, L. I., will give a dance on Sept. 11 in their Long Island home for their debutante daughter, Miss Jane Gilbert.
President Roosevelt sent a letter to Senator Barkley insisting that the fight for passage on the Courts Reorganization Bill should continue.

Beef and veal cuts continued to move slowly. Demand for other classes improved slightly. Lamb prices were weak to lower, and some fresh beef and pork prices were lower; prices otherwise were steady to weak. Kosher business continued extremely slow, and the small amount of trade which developed (an off-kosher day) was mostly in lamb at weak prices, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney, president of the Amateur Athletic Union, announced yesterday the incorporation in Albany of a national organization formed by prominent Protestants, Catholics and'Jews to promote better understanding among racial and creedal groups.
Making his first appearance In the show ring since Devon, King Vulture proved today that he is about as fit as at any time in his career.

A scene which after six and one-half years has grown familiar was enacted today in the Morgan County court house, where another Scottsboro cast defendant was convicted of rape and condemned to death in the electric chair.

Morris Rothenberg, Zionist leader, praised Mayor La Guardia yesterday as "the outstanding Mayor of our time" when Mr. Rothenberg was sworn in as a city magistrate yesterday in the Summer City Hall at College Point.
The body of a 25-year-old gangster, who was out on bail on a robbery charge, was found yesterday afternoon lying face downward in the rear of an automobile in front

When our quick-tempered Mayor goes out of his way to praise the "vision, courage and energy" of his fiery Park Commissioner we can be certain that he is not dissembling. He knows effective work when he sees it, and the work of Commissioner MOSES has been so effective that, with the aid of Federal funds, our park facilities have trebled within three years.

Connecticut residents who buy liquor in New York-for delivery to their homes will face arrest for violation of a provision of the State's new Liquor Tax Law, William H. Hackett, State Tax Commissioner, said today.
