Ethel Leginska, pianist and conductor, said on her return yesterday on the Bremen that she planned to return to concert piano work, but had not yet arranged a definite tour.
President Roosevelt tonight reassumed personal leadership of the fight for his judiciary reorganization program in the Senate.

A compromise has been reached in a controversy between trustees for defaulted mortgage-certificate and bond issues of the New York Title and Mortgage Company and the State Superintendent of Insurance over servicing charges for administering the mortgages, it was announced yesterday in Supreme Court.

If war in Europe or the Far East is avoided and if present bumper crop prospects are realized, resulting in a farm income from $1,500,000,000 to $2,000,000,000 greater than last year, "Fall trade will exceed the most optimistic expectations," Frederick Hanssen, president of the Thomas Gibson Investment Service, Inc., predicted yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Association of Buying Offices, Inc., in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Chinese banks, including the Central Bank of China, which is owned by the central government, were reported today to have shipped out more than $100,000,000 in gold and silver to the British colony of Hongkong, presumably for safekeeping in the event of war with Japan.

A nominating committee has been appointed to select officers of the National Security Traders Association for the fiscal year beginning on Oct. 1 next. Lawrence S. Pulliam of Weeden Co., Los Angeles, is chairman of the committee, which includes also Herbert M. May of Herbert M. May Co., New York;

Minority stockholders told the Securties and Exchange Commission today that they could prove the International Paper and Power Company had obtained stockholders' approval of its recent plan of recapitalization by creating a "fake" deficit. Representatives of the company disputed the veracity of the testimony.

Price changes were moderate for the most part in the last week, and largely offset each other, The Annalist's price index being unchanged at 95.3 per cent of the 1926 average. Wheat and corn were lower, along with barley, hogs, lambs, eggs, silk ant rubber, while steers and cows, beef, lard, cotton, hides and zinc made advances.
A steel bridge a half-mile long will be opened here tomorrow, spanning Lake Champlain and connecting this town with Rouses Point. N. Y.

Discussions are in progress looking to the reduction of a substantial part of the New York bank loans of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, as well as the anticipation of part of the company's debt maturities of Jan. 1, 1939, it was learned in Wall Street yesterday.
Hummel-Ross Fibre Corporation $5-par common stock has been admitted to listing by the New York Curb Exchange.

More than 4,000 employes of the Horn Hardart chain of cafeterias, confectionery and pastry stores will begin voting today at the Washington Irving High School, Sixteenth Street and Irving Place, to determine whether they wish to be represented in collective bargaining by two unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

A threatened strike of shore gangs, comprising men employed in the repair and upkeep of ships during their stay in port, was averted yesterday at a conference of leaders of rival unions at the office of Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association.

J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced yesterday the completion of the liquidation of thirty-four receiverships during June, 1937. This makes a total of 709 receiverships finally closed or restored to solvency since the "banking holiday" of March, 1933.
Fifteen hundred sweltering sailors labored on today toward the finale of their quest of the South Seas for Amelia Earhart and Frederick J. Noonan, her navigator.

The Transport Workers Union, affiliated with the C. I. O., filed yesterday with the State Labor Board a petition asking for a bargaining-agency election for the 3,200 employes of the Parmelee taxicab system, which some weeks ago announced it planned to sign a three-year contract with a rival American Federation of Labor union.
Although Canadian regulations call for the employment of a Canadian guide while fishing Ontario waters, the law will not be enforced, Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne has just announced.

ACKERMAN-Ruth (nee -Corday), darling mother ot Lee and Lester. adored sister of Charlotte Ollendorff, Elsie Arnsetam Jerome and Adelaide Corday. Services Friday, 11 A. M., Riverside Parlors, 76th and Amsterdam. St. Louis papers please copy. ALTMAYER-Sanders B., in his eightyninth year, beloved husband of the late Hannah, devoted father of Hattie Erdman, Leon S. Altmayer, Beatrice Nathan, Madeline Kahn. Services July 16, 11 o'clock, Temple Emanu-El Chapel, 5th Ave., 65th.
Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said on his return from Europe yesterday that if he had his way he would draft former Governor Alfred E. Smith for the Mayoralty race.

Governor Frank Murphy predicted today a quick settlement of a strike which reduced sharply the number of trucks operating between Michigan cities and instructed State police to keep the highways open while the strike is in progress.

The Yale University golf team today defeated St. Andrews University, 8 to 6, over the old St. Andrews course. The Americans lost this morning's foursomes, 3 to 2, but in the afternoon captured six of the ten singles matches and halved one.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 14: MAJOR GENERALS. Kromer, L. B., chief of Cavalry, one month leave, July 15. Westover, O., chief of the Air Corps, one day leave, July 14.

With bright patches of sunlight flooding down through high, broken clouds, the Pan American Clipper dropped her mooring lines at 2:10 o'clock New York time this afternoon and drifted out into the deep water channel between Foynes Island and the shore.

Education Minister Bernhard Rust tonight appointed Dr. Karl Bosch, chairman of the German Dye Trust, as president of the Kaiser Wilheim Society for the Advancement of Science, Germany's foremost scientific institution.
Henry J. Collinge, a resident here for the last fifty-five years, died today of a heart attack at his Summer home in Farmington, Me. His age was 69.

R. S. Reynolds, president of the Reynolds Metals Company, has announced to stockholders a proposal to offer one new share at $17 for each share now held. The offering involves 64,019 shares and will be made to stockholders of record July 23. The rights will expire Aug. 12, 1937.

An offer to lend any funds necessary to finance whatever additional share of Winnipeg's relief costs the Provincial government may assume for the rest of this year was wired today by Charles Dunning, Finance Minister, to Premier John Bracken.

Mayor Robert E. Greenwood sent a telegram today to Senator Wheeler of Montana rebuking him for his remarks made yesterday that President Roosevelt should abandon his plans to force the Supreme Court bill through Congress, because of Senator Robinson's death.

A strike leader, testifying at the inquest into ten deaths in the Memorial Day steel riot, described today an attack along military lines which he said was planned to "establish a strong picket line" at the Republic Steel Corporation's Grand Crosping plant.

Yesterday State Senator POWELL of Burlington County, who for several days seemed to feel that the water was too cold, plunged in boldly. Personally conducted by Governor HOFFMAN and what is left of the Hoffman organization, he will be a candidate for Governor in the Republican primaries against Senator CLEE of Essex.
Mrs. Eunice Massett Wright, wife of Otis Wright, a resident here sixty years, died this morning at her home.
Walter (Rink) Barrington, New York mining engineer and former Ohio State football player, died at his home tonight of heart disease. His age was 50. He had been ill six weeks.
The engagement of Miss Nancy Newberry, daughter of Mrs. Elsie Newberry of this place, to Dr. Milton Randolph Ross of this city, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Ross of Newark, was announced yesterday.

Six engineering contracts amounting to $965,529 were awarded by the War Department today as follows: Taylor Dredging Company, Jersey City, N. J., for dredging Raritan River to Arthur Kill cut-off channell, New Jersey, $87,885.
The Japanese Embassy spokesman said last night: It is not our purpose to convert all of North China into a greater East Hopei.

Steel shares strong in otherwise irregularly higher market; turnover, 737,060 shares, second slowest trading of the month. United States Government bonds strong, other issues irregular; transactions, $6,687,000.
The Congressional Tax Inquiry Committee decided today that no individuals mentioned as tax avoiders would be called to testify, and Chairman Doughton said none had volunteered to testify.

Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, returned on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen yesterday after a brief visit to Paris, where he joined his family. Mrs. Quezon and their three children came back with him yesterday and they plan to sail from San Francisco late in July for their home.

Manufacturers of coats and suits in the $22.75-$32.75 range, who approved a general advance of from $1 to $3 a garment, at a meeting on Wednesday, will hold a meeting at the Governor Clinton Hotel this afternoon to discuss the effect of the increase upon the stability of the industry, it was announced yesterday by Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

The charge of "neglect of duty." on which Lieutenant John J. Martin, H. and L. 158, was tried before Francis X. Giaccone, Deputy Fire Commissioner, on July 7, 1936, found guilty and sentence susended, is hereby dismissed.

An editor, a producer, two playwrights and a dramatic critic will, decide what promising young dramatists are to receive the five scholarships of $1,000 each which John Golden offered at the American; Theatre Council Convention last May.

Senator Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, filed a one-man minority report today in the Senate condemning the decision of a special committee not to pursue further its investigation of charges that the postoffice has taken sides with the C. I. O. in recent labor disputes.

One big inning, in which Manager Joe Cronin's homer accounted for two runs, wasn't enough for the Red Sox today and the Browns took second game of the series, 5-3. Boston scored all its runs in the third.

A warehouse from which twentyfour-hour service can be given to retailers of floor coverings will be opened Aug. 1 by the Trorlicht Dunker Carpet Company, wholesale distributers for Alexander Smith and C. M. Masland rugs and carpets, it was announced yesterday.

William Shanahan, 33 years old, a WPA worker, who gave the address 422 East Eighty-second Street, was sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday for seven to fourteen years by Judge Streit in General Sessions on a guilty plea to a manslaughter charge.

Several of the strangest-looking animals to invade the metropolitan area in recent years made their debuts yesterday at the Central Park and Prospect Park Zoos, but it remained for the tiny dik-dik, Tom Thumb of the antelope world, to steal the show at the Brooklyn menagerie.
The official news bureau published a report from a Karlsruhe newspaper, the Fuehrer, to the effect that a number of American planes had been delivered to the Valencia government.

The increasing gravity of developments in the Far East preoccupies the State Department and is watched with such anxiety in the White House that the President, it is reported, has given up his week-end cruise and his plans to attend the funeral of Senator ROBINson at Little stock in order to keep in close touch with the situation.

William A. Lloyd, who is in charge of the Western section, Division of Cooperative Extension of the Department of Agriculture, has been designated to serve as technical adviser to the Joint Preparatory Committee of American and Philippine Experts, which, sails from San Francisco for Manila, July 24. Mr.
The Polish-German convention providing for a special regime in Upper Silesia under League of Nations supervision expired today and will not be renewed.

The third anniversary of the Park Department War Memorial Playgrounds will be observed today in Manhattan in William McCray Park, 138th Street near Fifth Avenue, at 10 A. M. and in Joseph C. Sauer Park, East Twelfth Street near Avenue A, at 3 P. M., it was announced yesterday.

Charles D. Barney Co., New York Stock Exchange members, have announced the opening of a branch office in Bethlehem, Pa., under the management of Edgar McC. Ulman. Ezra M. Stiles will act as assistant manager.

Thirty-five bars or gold weighing fifty pounds each have been discovered near Piedra Candela in Chiriqui Province by employes of a Canadian mining company that is reworking mines in the Veraguas district operated by Spanish colonials.

The Minneapolis Millers virtually dominate the fourth annual American Association all-star team which will battle the Columbus Red Birds here the night of July 27, five of the Millers having been named to berths by the league's chapter of baseball writers.

Exchanges of views on the proposals by the British Government concerning the Spanish situation, presented to the countries represented on the NonIntervention Committee, still were progressing actively between Rome and Berlin at a late hour this evening and were expected to continue far into the night.

The Railway and Lignt Securtties Company reports a net asset value of $264.80 to each $100 of collateral trust bonds, $311.89 a share of preferred stock and $27.45 a common share as of June 30, 1937, compared with $287.37, $354.59 and $32.98, respectively, on Dec. 31. On June 30, 1936, the asset values were similarly, $268.64, $319.16 and $28.39.

With the business outlook for the balance of the year clearing up favorably, large advertisers are now giving their approval to Fall advertising budgets, after showing some hesitancy about them, reports among agencies here indicated yesterday.
Miss Margaret E. Smith died last night at her home here after a long illness at the age of 94.

Wage increases totaling $5,000,000 annually were granted yesterday to 30,000 workers in an agreement signed between the Full Fashioned Hosiery Manufacturers, Inc., and the American Federation of Hostery Workers.

A new queen reigned over Long Island Sound today as 17-year-old Miss Sylvia (Rusty) Shethar valiantly protected her slim advantage in the last two races to bring the Syce Cup, symbolical of the women's sailing championship of these waters, to the American Yacht Club.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission, it was announced yesterday, will study a suggestion made by Mayor La Guardia that a new grade, to be known as junior operating engineer, be set up in the city service.

Figures for odd-lot trading on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on July 10, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed a continuation of the trend in which shares purchased exceeded those sold.

Leaving a note pinned on the doorwarning his 15-year-old daughter not to enter, Dr. Morris S. Halpern, former resident physician at the Brooklyn Hebrew Home and Hospital for the Aged, attempted suicide by gas yesterday morning in his furnished room at 53 Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn. He is in Methodist Episcopal Hospital in a critical condition.
Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes, long an ardent hiker, takes a three-mile walk daily while resting from the cares of the Supreme Court.

History teachers from all parts of the Reich have been ordered to meet at Baireuth to undergo a special Summer course in the presentation of their subjects according to National Socialist ideas. The courses will be given by functionaries of the National Socialist Teachers League.

After Assistant District Attorney John L. MacDonnell told Judge Donnellan in General Sessions yesterday of a pending plot by two gunmen for a general outbreak from the Bellevue Hospital prison ward the pair pleaded guilty to third-degree robbery instead of standing trial on a first-degree robbery indictment.
Mrs. Harriet Truxell Marsh, wife of Dr. Daniel L,. Marsh, president of Boston University, died early today of a heart attack at the family Summer home in Marshfield at the age of 54.

Yesterday's trading in Manhattan real estate included a variety of properties. A large business building in the fur district changed hands, and several of the residential parcels sold will undergo extensive alterations.

The Cuban Government has invited the Government of the United States to attend the Second Pan-American Coffee Conference at Havana, starting Aug. 9, it was announced today. The agenda includes studies of production, consumption and distribution of coffee throughout the world.

The Court of Appeals opened today a new source of revenue for the State of Maryland in its decision to remove exemptions of certain Baltimore City bonds and Maryland corporations' stocks in computing the value of the stock of corporations in the State for tax purposes.

New hope for avoiding pain in tooth filling was given to persons with sensitive teeth today when a new formula for a dental anesthetic, in the form of both paste and liquid, was announced here at the seventy-ninth annual convention of the American Dental Association by Dr. Harold A. Osserman of New York.
Fresh enthusiasm in the market for United States Government bonds was the feature of an otherwise listless trading session in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

TOKYO--Troops from Japan proper have gone to North China Word was received that China was rushing many troop trains north and that anti-Japanese feeling was erupting all over the country. Provisional Governors were warned to guard against air raids and aid mobilization if necessary Page 1.

A strike that doesn't happen is rarely news. For this reason little has been heard of New York City's Industrial Relations Board, whichhas just gone out of business with the creation of the new State Board of Mediation.

Preliminary consideration was given by President Roosevelt today in conferences with advisers on foreign affairs to United States policy as it might be influenced by a war between China and Japan, and by more serious developments in the Spanish situation.

An effort to bring Senator Robert F. Wagner into the group opposing the administration's reorganization Court Bill was begun yesterday by the National Committee to Uphold Constitutional Government, having headquarters at 205 East Forty-second Street.

The marriage of Miss Marietta Carolyn Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Davis of this place, to Paul Westcott Mulford, son of Mrs. Elmer D. Mulford and the late Mr. Mulford of Bridgeton, took place today at the bride's home.

Consolidation of the Canadian Hydro-Electric Corporation, Ltd., and the Gatineau Power Company, Ltd., was approved at a meeting of the shareholders of the former company here today. The vote of the first preferred shares was 76,667 for and 15,858 against.

With the sudden easing of the heavy inflow of gold to the United States at a time when the Treasury is arranging to distribute some of its troublesome $1,182,859,721 stock of "sterilized" gold to aid the domestic currencies of other nations, speculation was renewed today as to the effect of Soviet Russia's booming gold production on whatever of stabilization may be attained.

State Senator Clifford R. Powell of Burlington County announced formally today his candidacy for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination, and Governor Hoffman endorsed him. Both moves were considered certainties several weeks ago.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday, although slightly below the preceding week, registered an increase over the corresponding period of last year. This was the first time in three weeks that better figures over 1936 had been reported.

Chauncey Clark Woodworth, former perfumery manufacturer and banker of Rochester, N. Y., who for the last ten years had been living in Palm Beach, Fla., died yesterday of pneumonia in the Park Lane Hotel after an illness of several days. His age was 53.

Investigation of sabotage on the United States liner President Roosevelt during a recent stay in port has been undertaken by Federal authorities, the New York City police and seamen's union officials, it was learned yesterday.

A proposal that members of the Cabinet "shall" sit with Congress to take part in debate over matters affecting their departments was made today by Representative Thom of Ohio, in the form of a resolution.
August H. Landwehr, co-founder of the Holland Furnace Company, died in a sanitarium here today. His age was 57. He formed the company at Holland, Mich., in 1906 with his father-in-law, John Kolla.

A bridge tea took place this afternoon at the Lake George Club, sponsored by the American Association of University Women for its scholarship fund. Mrs. William B. Woodbury and Mrs. Romney C. Patterson headed the committee in charge.

Miss Margaret Mallory, daughter of Commodore and Mrs. Clifford D. Mallory of Greenwich, who was to have sailed for home on July 13, has lengthened her stay abroad owing to the illness of her companion, Miss Susan Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Hall of Greenwich. Miss Hall was stricken with appendicitis last Friday and is in a Berlin hospital.
The Browns announced today the release of pitchers Al Thomas and Fred (Sheriff) Blake and the signing of Bill Strickland, batting practice hurler, as a regular pitcher.

City Judge Jacob A. Bernsteini refused today to order a woman to surrender her wedding ring to a creditor in a judgment suit. although the City Marshal's office reported the ring was the only asset that could be found.

While settlement children inside Greenwich House were celebrating the third birthday of the Federal Marionette Theatre yesterday afternoon, a group of dismissed puppet workers, protesting against the curtailment of their WPA project, paced in the lobby outside, wearing their "pink slips" and signs which read: "We, too, are celebrating. Our birthday present is a dismissal slip."
Senator Hattie Caraway of Arkansas, through the death of Senator Robinson, became today the first woman to serve any State as its senior Senator. It was the fifth "first" to her credit.
The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended July 13 were announced today: Walker, Major J. T., headquarters, Washington, D. C., to Marine Barracks, Quantico Va.
Twenty men were crushed and burned to death in an explosion in the Glendora Coal Company's Baker mine near this city, and nine others were injured, three of them so seriously that they may not live.

A prowler was seen in the Trinity Church Cemetery at 153d Street and Amsterdam Avenue at 10;30 o'clock last night after three headstones had been overturned in an act of vandalism, but the intruder escaped before a score of policemen could surround the area.
Under cover of a cloud bank the Rebel air force tried one of its rare daytime raids over Madrid this afternoon and paid for its daring by losing six combat planes to the government's one.

A total of 2,204,571 shares, or 25.33 per cent, of the common stock of the United States Steel Corporation outstanding at June 30 was held in brokers' names, representing an increase of 45,277 shares over the 2,159,294 common shares, or 24.81 per cent, held by brokers on March 31.

Sixteen-year-old Rachel Renard, known to thousands of Canadian war veterans as "the beautiful girl" who sold postcards and other souvenirs at the Canadian war memorial ever since it was dedicated last year, has been murdered.

Stone Webster, Inc., and the Houdaille - Hershey Corporation joined today the long list of large corporations which have reported pay raises to their executives in the last year to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

What reader of English novels, what erstwhile sojourner in England, does not feel that something as British as strong tea and kippers has disappeared with the closing of Mudie's Library? If not the first of all subscription libraries, Mudie's was far and away the most celebrated.

Kelly, Nason Winsten, Inc., of 30 Rockefeller Plaza, New York, will be the advertising agency for the Bureau of State Publicity, according to Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner, under whose supervision the bureau operates.

The Council of Foreign Bondholders and the League Loans Committee have announced that the Greek Government has undertaken to send representatives to London to resume direct and unrestricted negotiations on a final settlement of service of the Greek external debt, including payment of coupons which have fallen due since March 31, 1937, according to advices from the League Loans Committee in London by Speyer Co.

Mrs. H. K. Stern of Hartford and L. J. Cassara of New London tonight brought back to New England the mixed pair title of the Southern New England contract bridge championships. Second at the end of the afternoon session, they staged a Garrison finish in the evening to total 304- points and lead Mrs. David Burwick of Worcester, Mass., and James A. Silin of Boston by 3% points.
Former Governor J. M. Futrell issued a statement today asserting that Mrs. Joseph T. Robinson is the "logical successor to her distinguished husband for his unexpired term."

Trade practice rules governing the millinery industry in the metropolitan area of New York and New Jersey were promulgated yesterday by the Millinery Stabilization Commission, Inc., at a meeting of about 200 manufacturers at the Hotel Astor.
Mrs. Dorothy Ludington Whitney obtained a divorce yesterday from William Whitney at Minden, Nev., on the ground of mental cruelty. The agreement provides for support of the two children.

A farm bill intended to embody the objectives urged by President Roosevelt in a recent letter to the chairmen of the Agriculture Committees of Congress was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Pope of Idaho and Senator McGill of Kansas.

A total of 1,901 men and women from 44 States and 11 foreign countries and United States possessions are enrolled in the Harvard Summer School this year, it was announced tonight. Last year the registration of the school was 2,141.

Charging that the Church of England had inspired "forces" hostile to him in the United States to persuade American charities to drop sponsorship of his lectures, the Rev. Robert Anderson Jardine, who officiated at the marriage of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, promised last night to "blow off the lid"

The Chattanooga News said Noel Beddow of Birmingham, regional director of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee of the C. I. O., and L. J. Smith, Federal labor conciliator, were "escorted" out of Cleveland, Tenn., today by sixteen "business and professional men."

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and his bride arrived here today on the Empress of Britain for the beginning of their European honeymoon. They were met by United States Consul Augustus Ostertag, who helped them with the formalities of landing their car, in which they plan to tour the Continent.

When Mary Louise Quackenbush of Old Bennington, Vt., sold to the Zephyr Holding Corp, Frank Malatzky, president, the flats on the n w cor of Columbus Ave and 106th St for $45,000, she took back a purchase money mtg for $35,000, payable 5 years hence at 5 per cent.

E. J. Eagen, regional attorney for the National Labor Relations Board, served a complaint today on The Seattle Star, charging unfair labor practices against members of the American Newspaper Guild. He set a hearing for July 26.

George Lansbury returned from Rome today with a message that Premier Benito Mussolini did not want war with Great Britain or any other nation. The veteran pacifist, who had interviewed Chancellor Adolf Hitler and President Franklin D. Roosevelt previously during his self-appointed mission to improve the peace prospects of the world, added his own comment:

The Hamburg-American liner New York arrives today from Germany and Channel ports, bringing among her passengers Dr. Friedrich Geisler, youth leader, who is in charge of a group of sixty German boys and girls who will pass vacations in Eastern camps.
A war between Japan and China would be a "bloody brawl," according to views held here, and the outcome would be uncertain. Much would depend upon the strategy of the opposing forces.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, francs:

Commercial flying time between Santiago and New York is being cut down to two and one-half days, beginning tomorrow, it is announced here by the Pan American-Grace Airways after a long study of the route along the west coast of South America.

Additional refundings to employes as a result of the enactment of the new Railroad Pension Act, which repealed the act of 1935, were announced yesterday. The Pennsylvania Railroad System is refunding approximately $7,000,000, the completion of which is expected within the next ten days.

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company announced yesterday that a $12,000,000 enlargement and improvement program was being launched in the southern part of New Jersey to increase generating and transmission facilities throughout the State.
The S. and H. Realty Company has sold to the Berghoff Realty Company the Berghoff building on Twenty-second Street, Bayonne. The building has been used for years by the District Court of Bayonne.

A member of the American Federation of Labor since 1919, the Actors Equity Association declared its allegiance yesterday to that organization as opposed to the C. I. O. in any struggle that may take place between the two groups for power in the theatre.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler expressed regret on the death of Senator Robinson on his return yesterday from Europe. The president of Columbia University said that the entire world was following the American fight on court reorganization.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler expressed regret on the death of Senator Robinson on his return yesterday from Europe. The president of Columbia University said that the entire world was following the American fight on court reorganization.

Various companies have reported changes in reacquired stock to the New York Stock Exchange. Among the more important shifts were Allied Stores Corporation 5 per cent preferred, from 200 shares to 2,113 shares; Armour Co. (Illinois) 7 per cent preferred, 4,992 to none; Armour Co. (Delaware) 7 per cent preferred, 22,684 to 23.047; Atlas Corporation common,

A special meeting of stockholders of the Lufkin Rule Company of Saginaw, Mich., has been called for July 26 to approve an increase in the company's authorized common stock of 500,000 shares, to facilitate a two-for-one split in the common stock.

A policeman and his 1-year-old son were shot accidentally last night when the policeman's service revolver went off while he was cleaning it in the kitchen of his home in Brooklyn. Both were taken to Kings County Hospital with flesh wounds not regarded as serious.

Atlas Mills, Inc., New York rayon and silk jobbers, was ordered today by the National Labor Relations Board to reinstate with back pay ten employes discharged for union activities, to permit five additional employes the right of union activity, and to recognize Local 2,269 of the Textile House Workers Union for purposes of collective bargaining.

Because of increasing violence in the strike of shipyard workers, which entered its second month yesterday, the police in Brooklyn announced last night that additional precautions would be taken to guard non-striking workers on their way to their jobs and prevent clashes with pickets and sympathizers.

A charge that long and excessive hours, especially for drivers, prevail in the trucking industry was made today in a report presented to the Interstate Commerce Commission by R. W. Snow, examiner for the commission.

The national convention of the Federation of Flat Glass Workers withdrew a resolution late today barring all reporters not paid-up members of the American Newspaper Guild. A statement, signed by John O'Shea, chairman, and Harry Minnick, secretary of the Committee for Industrial Organization affiliate, stated:

The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered the cancellation of switching charges filed for the Richmond yard district by the Southern, Atlantic Coast Line, the Chesapeake Ohio, the Richmond, Fredericksburg Potomac and the Seaboard Air Line Railroads.

The statement that capitalism is based upon "the law of the jungle" and its inevitable outcome is "war and destruction" was made by Anthony Lehner, director of the Cooperative Training School at the American People's Schools in New York City before the Summer cooperative institute at the Massachusetts State College today.

The Mordkin Ballet will perform tonight and tomorrow night at Lewisohn Stadium. The program, the same for both nights, will feature the ballet "The Goldfish," choreography and direction by Mikhail Mordkin. Eugene Fuerst will conduct the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

The trend of world industry and commerce was somewhat uncertain in May, with the hesitation due, apparently, to weakness in commodity prices since the end of March, according to the monthly review of foreign economic conditions in the Midsummer Review and Forecast Number of The Annalist.

David Lamson, who wrote "We Who Are About to Die," an account of his experiences in the condemned row of a California prison, has now written a novel about a man convicted of murder on circumstantial evidence. It is entitled "Whirlpool" and will soon be published by Scribner.
My Dear Alben: I am glad you called my attention to certain events of yesterday and today. Lest there be any misunderstanding in regard to judicial reform, please let me clarify the situation.

A. P. Herbert, Member of Parliament and author, won one of his greatest triumphs today in his long battle to liberalize the British divorce laws and end what he himself has called a state of "holy deadlock."

Mr. and Mrs. Alvah M. Baylis of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Miriam Baylis, to Robert Munshower Skelton, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Skelton of Indiana, Pa.

Mrs. Edwin S. Marston of 303 Lexington Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mrs. Edna Marston Beeckman of Newport, widow of R. Livingston Beeckman, one-time Governor of Rhode Island, to Archibald Gourlay Thacher of this city and Glen Cove, L. I., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Thacher of Boston.

The Berkshire Garden Center at Stockbridge and five garden clubs are cooperating with the Lenox Horticultural Society in the annual twoday flower show which was opened this afternoon at Lenox Town Hall.

An increase of about 6,000 in the number of employes of 200 iron and steel producing companies is reported by the American Iron and Steel Institute for May, with 522,000 employed in that month against 516,000 in April.

Consumption of crude rubber by manufacturers in the United States during June is estimated to be 51,798 long tons, which compares with 51,733 long tons in May, and with 52,772 long tons (revised figure) for June, 1936, the Rubber Manufacturers Association reports.

The marriage of Miss Olive Beatrice Franck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Peter Franck of Brooklyn, to F. Seymour Barr of Plainfield, N. J., son of Mrs. Thomas M. Barr and the late Mr. Barr, formerly of Brooklyn, took place yesterday morning in the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn.

A newly formed advisory committee of historical and patriotic societies for the New York World's Fair in 1939 decided yesterday afternoon to seek the cooperation of all the historical and patriotic societies throughout the country in the organization of a national committee to aid in presenting the achievements of the American people since Colonial times. .
Simple funeral services were held yesterday for George Gershwin, composer. Nearly 3,500 persons crowded into Temple Emanu-E1, at Sixty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue.

Neither the Civil Service Law nor the State Retirement Act applies to the constitutional convention, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. ruled today. He pointed out that all public and judicial officers, except Sheriffs, were eligible as delegates and where a public official was selected as a delegate he would be entitled to the additional $2,500 compensation.

Operations of the Underwood, Elliott-Fisher Company in the first half of 1937 resulted in a consolidated net ihcome of $2,576,409 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, but before provision for surtax on undistributed earnings, according to the preliminary statement announced yesterday.

The Drummer, owned by W. Carr, was favorite at 10 to 1 tonight in a callover of odds for the Steward's Cup, to be run at Goodwood on July 27. King's Lrap entered' by Major D. McCalmont, and George Here, the property of G. W. Hands, were quoted at 100-6.

Miss Helene Macy, daughter of Mrs. Alfred Macy of 159 East Fiftyseventh Street and the late Mr. Macy, was married quietly in a civil service in Fort Lee, N. J., yesterday to Richard Alan Walsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Bernard Walsh, also of this city.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred Glenn of Rockville Centre, L. I., of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Winifred Francis Glenn, to Ensign John Robert Middleton Jr., U. S. N., son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Middleton of Sebastian. Fla. The wedding will take place on Aug. 9 in St. George's Church, Hempstead, L. I.

Operating revenues in June of ninety-three Class I railroads, representing 81.2 per cent of the total rail operating income, amounted to $280,287,565, according to preliminary reports, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday.
It is pleasant to discover how many good people know of the late dog-actor Flush and the fine book which VIRGINIA WOOLF wrote about the original Flush of Wimpole Street.

John Thomas Toler, circulation manager of The Atlanta Constitution since 1911 and a founder and former president of the International Circulation Managers Association, died at a hospital here today after a short illness. His age was 70.

Business activity in June showed a substantial decrease largely because of a drop in durable goods production as a result of strikes. The iron and steel industries were hardest hit. The movement of freight, after allowance for seasonal fluctuations, also was reduced, miscellaneous loadings dropping sharply. Automobile production was curtailed.

The collection of $980,190.59 in behalf of injured workmen during the first six months of 1937, from employers who were bankrupt or failed to carry workmen's compensation insurance and from insolvent insurance companies, was reported yesterday to John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General, by the Labor Bureau attached to his office.

While Commissioner Valentine grimly announced that every one of the 18,340 members of the Police Department, including himself, had been enlisted in the search for J. Richard (Dixie) Davis and seven other men indicted as policy racketeers, two of the alleged members of the ring were arraigned yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora.

When Defending Champion Johnny Fischer, gangling sharp-shooter from Cincinnati, reports at the Alderwood Country Club in Portland, Ore., on Aug. 23 to put his United States amateur golf crown on the line, he will be facing a parblistering firing squad drawn largely from States west of the Alleghenies.

The Cardinals' pitching woes finally have Same Breadon, president of the St. Louis club, in the wailing seat. Breadon said today the Cardinals are seeking help for their faltering hurling staff, and then added, "But where are we going to get anybody?"

The Lafayette National Bank, trustee for the mortgage certificate holders concerned, has sold the fivestory brick store and apartment building at 34-50 Forty-first Street, on the corner of Thirty-fifth Avenue, Long Island City, to En Realty, Inc., for investment.

MANHATTAN BJORKSTEN, MARTHA STRICKLAND (May 5). Estate, $15,000. To Charles Hobart Strickland, brother, petitioner, 375 Riverside Drive. COHEN, NINA SEEMAN (June 29). Estate, more than $10,000. To Miriam Cohen, daughter, 320 West End Ave., $10,000 and one-third residue; Helen R. Rosenthal, daughter, 22 Bank St., and Julian S. Cohen, son, executor, 260 West End Ave., one-third each. Benno Cohen, husband, executor, 320 West End Ave.

Standards in banking have seen a great improvement in recent years as a result of conferences and institutes such as the one being held here, Dr. Harold Stonier, national educational director of the American Institute of Banking and the American Bankers Association, told the North Carolina bankers' conference tonight.

Dr. Clement Oscar Kleber of West Highland Avenue, president of the Clifton Chemical Laboratory and noted for his treatises on and research work in the field of essential oils and aromatic chemicals, died at his home last night. He was 74 years old.

Their "hope" that they soon may be able to merge the Pere Marquette Railroad physically with the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad system, and soon thereafter to take in the Nickel Plate Road, also as part of the C. O., was expressed here today by Robert R. Young and Frank F. Kolbe.

The theft of a jewel case containing gems valued at $15,000 from an automobile parked near the Plaza Hotel last night, was reported to the police early this morning by William 'V. C. Ruxton, former New York stock broker who now lives at Wraxall Manor, Dorchester, England.

Three matches are slated to be played in the Eastern Polo League championship tournament on Sunday, with the Governors Island Yellows facing the unbeaten Monmouth County Country Club quartet in the main test at Morris Field, Governors Island.
Miss Jane Tinsley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Jenkins Tinsley of Roland Park, will be married to Harry Forest Swope Jr. in the early Autumn.

The Basque delegation withdrew in anger today from the so-called "Congress of European National Minorities" which is holding a two-day conference here. "This is not a minorities congress but a Pan-German congress," shouted Antonio la Bayen, leader of the Basque group, as he stalked from the congress hall.

Two Pennsylvania members of Congress proposed today a four-year plan to stabilize the anthracite industry under the supervision of the Federal Government. A bill by Senator Guffey and Representative Boland would, in effect, extend to hard coal the principles of the Guffey-Vinson Act Governing the bituminous industry.

Dr. Clement Oscar Kleber of West Highland Avenue, president of the Clifton Chemical Laboratory and noted for his treatises on and research work in the field of essential oils and aromatic chemicals, died at his home last night. He was 74 years old.

Their "hope" that they soon may be able to merge the Pere Marquette Railroad physically with the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad system, and soon thereafter to take in the Nickel Plate Road, also as part of the C. O., was expressed here today by Robert R. Young and Frank F. Kolbe.

The theft of a jewel case containing gems valued at $15,000 from an automobile parked near the Plaza Hotel last night, was reported to the police early this morning by William 'V. C. Ruxton, former New York stock broker who now lives at Wraxall Manor, Dorchester, England.

An agreement was signed today by Henry Morgenthau, Secretary of the Treasury, and Arthur de Souza Costa, Finance Minister of Brazil, after negotiations covering four weeks, under which the United States will make available to Brazil gold in an amount up to $60,000,000 for the protection of Brazilian currency against exchange fluctuation.

The school superintendent's recommendation that Miss Isabelle Hallin, 26year-old storm center of a town battle, be retained on the high school faculty was made public today by the teacher's lawyer on the eve of a defense meeting arranged by her friends.

Ink-throwing is the latest weapon to be used in the war between hotel and cafe workers and their employers. The strikers charged a cafe on the Place St. Augustin today and threw ink on the terrace customers to drive them away, and similar tactics were used elsewhere.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date.

Accounts of conversations overheard by detectives who had tapped the telephone line of the United Cake, Pastry and Pie Bakers Association were finally placed in the record at the bakery racket trial in Special Sessions yesterday over the bitter objections of defense counsel who had previously. succeeded in excluding them.
Morris Wagner, father of Charles A. Wagner, literary editor of The Daily Mirror, died early yesterday in his sleep at his home, 136 Waverly Place. His age was 57.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 15, unless specified: At Ketchikan, July 14: Borie, Trever, Zane. Tacoma to Portland: Marblehead, Richmond, Trenton. At Yakutat: Northampton, Salt Lake City. Acushnet, at Yorktown.

The whole Soviet Union is filled with pride today at the triumph of Mikhail Gromoff and his two associates in flying over the North Pole to the very southern boundary of the United States for a new distance aviation record.

Joseph C. Rovensky, head of the foreign department of the Chase National Bank, emphasized yesterday the opportunities available for business and industry in South American countries at a luncheon of the Rotary Club in the Hotel Commodore.
Three hundred State employes who work in offices in this city voted last night to affiliate with the newly chartered C. I. O. union of State, county and municipal workers.

The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $1,920,000 in equipment certificates at 3 3/4 per cent, to mature in fifteen annual payments commencing on Aug. 1, 1938.
Morris Wagner, father of Charles A. Wagner, literary editor of The Daily Mirror, died early yesterday in his sleep at his home, 136 Waverly Place. His age was 57.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 15, unless specified: At Ketchikan, July 14: Borie, Trever, Zane. Tacoma to Portland: Marblehead, Richmond, Trenton. At Yakutat: Northampton, Salt Lake City. Acushnet, at Yorktown.

The whole Soviet Union is filled with pride today at the triumph of Mikhail Gromoff and his two associates in flying over the North Pole to the very southern boundary of the United States for a new distance aviation record.

Joseph C. Rovensky, head of the foreign department of the Chase National Bank, emphasized yesterday the opportunities available for business and industry in South American countries at a luncheon of the Rotary Club in the Hotel Commodore.
Three hundred State employes who work in offices in this city voted last night to affiliate with the newly chartered C. I. O. union of State, county and municipal workers.

The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $1,920,000 in equipment certificates at 3 3/4 per cent, to mature in fifteen annual payments commencing on Aug. 1, 1938.

Baseball warfare in the metropolitan area of the National League's torrid pennant race came to a dead stop yesterday when rain caused postponement of the second game of the Giants-Pirates series at the Polo Grounds as wel as the conflict between the Dodgers and Reds at Ebbets Field.

Gains in wholesale prices, bank clearings and common stock prices were responsible for the rise in the Canadian economic index to 109.6 for the week ended on July 10 from 108.3 for the previous week, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics said today.

The elimination of Robert Low, top-seeded entrant and holder of the national interscholastic title, by Joseph Fishbach in a stirring three-set match featured yesterday's competition in the Eastern junior clay court tournament at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, as play advanced to the final bracket. The score was 4-6, 6-3, 6-2.

Armour Co. of Delaware won today their suit to recover from the Federal Government money paid in processing taxes on coconut oil in 1984. Federal Judge John P. Barnes, who heard the case without a jury, awarded the company a refund of $172,962.

Canadian wheat exports of 12,180,000 bushels in June were less than half the 25,763,000 bushels exported in June, 1936, according to a report today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics. The value was $15,441,000, compared with $19,682,000.

A new record for privately owned planes for the 520-mile nonstop flight from Detroit to Roosevelt Field was set this afternoon by Pilot Edward S. Maloney and CoPilot Harold Seymour, both of Roosevelt Field.

Susan Ertz, the English novelist, has written a fictional account of Betsy Patterson, the Baltimore girl who married Jerome Bonaparte, Napoleon's younger brother. The title is, "No More Hearts to Break," and Appleton-Century will publish it in the Fall.

Suspension of new rate schedules filed recently by the Rochester Telephone Corporation was ordered today by the Public Service Commission, which will conduct a public hearing on July 28 before Commissioner Maurice C. Burritt in Rochester.

Albert R. Knight, former oil company executive, accused of plotting the death by fire of his three unmarried daughters, to profit by insurance on their lives, asserted in the Delaware County jail at Media today that all of his insurance transactions had been "carried on openly and in good faith."
Tibor Serly, young Hungarian-American composer of New York City, won great applause tonight as he conducted the Budapest Philharmonic Orchestra.
Dr. Lloyd O. Thompson died at his home on Deerfield Lane early today of a heart ailment at the age of 67. Dr. Thompson was born in Cornish Flat, N. H., the son of the late Sidney and Laura Thompson.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow; HOGS Receipts 5.000, including 1,500 directs. Hogs from 225 pounds down scarce, active 15-25 higher than Thursday's average;

Mrs. Marie Martyn, 38 years old, of 12 Third Place, Brooklyn, was killed instantly at 6:15 this morning, and her husband Robert, 53, was critically injured, when their automobile which Hudson County police said Mrs. Martyn was driving, was in a head-on collision with a car of 363 Johnson Avenue, Newark, on Pulaski Skyway near the Kearny ramp.
In Chaco peace conference circles here it is believed that the change in government in Bolivia will have no effect on the peace negotiations.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Mitchell Righter, daughter of Mrs. Thomas McNair Righter of this place, and Princeton, N. J., to Albridge Clinton Smith 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albridge C. Smith of South Orange, N. J., took place here this afternoon in Grace Church.
Eight of the best juveniles in training have been named for this afternoon's East View Stakes, main event of the Empire City meeting for horses of this age.
Members of the City Industrial Relations Board, which went out of existence yesterday, received certificates of distinguished service yesterday morning from Mayor La Guardia at City Hall.

The National Labor Relations Board served upon the Republic Steel Corporation today a complaint alleging intimidation and coercion of its employes and ordered the company to appear at a hearing here next Wednesday.
Possibility of the United States publishers being called on to pay $60 a ton for newsprint from the Province of Quebec next year, despite a reported agreement on $50, was reported tonight.

Detectives of the West Forty-seventh Street police station yesterday began an extensive canvass of the pawnshops in New York in an effort to recover the stolen jewelry of Mrs. William V. C. Ruxton, wife of William V. C. Ruxton, former Stock Exchange executive.

The writer of the accompanying letter is Professor of Physiography in Columbia University. He served as confidential adviser to President Wilson and as chief of the Division of Boundary Geography at the Paris Peace Conference. During President Roosevelt's first term he conducted, at the request of the Bureau of the Budget, an extended investigation of Federal surveying and mapping agencies.

Coster St, 643 (10-2765D); Audica Properties, Inc, to Free Synagogue, 40 W 68th St; 5 years, 5 per cent; $12,000. Cruger Ave (15-4319), e ?? 367 ft ?? of Pelham Pkwy S, 167x100; Dora Smolowitz to Felix A. Muldoon, trustee, 164 Bush St, Bronx; installments, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent; $250,250.

Properties on the West Side of Manhattan, including several threeand-four-story private dwellings and a site upon which the buyer will erect a trucking depot, comprised yesterday's report of realty transactions.

A new mining development is under way at Rankin Inlet, on the west coast of Hudson Bay, 250 miles south of the Arctic Circle, The Winnipeg Free Press said today. Minerals discovered comprise nickel, platinum, gold and copper.

Howard F. Dugan has been appointed vice president in charge of sales and advertising of the Hotels Statler Company, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Mrs. E. M. Statler, chairman of the board. "A wider and more intensive sales and advertising campaign," Mrs. Statler said, "will accompany the extensive improvement program now being carried on throughout the Statler Hotel properties."

Plans for extensive advertising campaigns for the Fall and Christmas season are now under preparation by various perfume and cosmetic manufacturers, who have started to show their new ranges or will introduce them within the next month. Many of the budgets are scheduled to be 5 to 15 per cent higher than they were a year ago, it was said.
The Meadow Brook Club polo tournament committee yesterday decided to move the final for the Meadow Brook Club Cups from today to tomorrow, with the game to start on International Field at 4:30
Joseph N. Knox, director of the Old Age Welfare Commission and head of the unemployment relief program, died of a heart attack tonight at his home. He was 57 years old.

Dr. Thomas A. Gonzales, acting chief medical examiner of the city since the death of Chief Medical Examiner Charles Norris in 1935, obtained by far the highest grades in a two-man examination for the vacant post held Thursday, it was announced yesterday by the Municipal Civil Service Commission.
" Every company is entitled to the fruits of its own enterprise," in the opinion of Francis R. Stark, general counsel for the Western Union Telegraph Company.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 15: BRIGADIER GENERALS Halstead. L. to command First Brigade with station at New York, N. Y., effective upon completion present tour foreign service in the Panama Canal Dept.

A consistent competitor for the British amateur golf championship Mr. Balfour-Melville was runner-up once and reached the semi-finals on four other occasions, besides his victory in 1895. He was captain of the Honorary Company of Edinburgh Golfers in 1902 and 1903 and was captain of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club from 1906 to 1907.

A plea by James Roosevelt that Massachusetts publishers give the unemplayed free space in their advertising columns today headlined a conference called by the President's son to spur the industrial absorption of 35,000 discharged WPA workers in this State.

Mr. and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. arrived in Paris from Caen last night and lost no time in exploring Parisian night life. Shortly after midnight they appeared at an American midtown cabaret with a party of friends.

Thirteen men who served as officials of three separate mortgage bond companies scored court victories yesterday. The Appellate Division reversed the convictions of three and sustained a lower court ruling freeing three others, of criminal liability.

Yesterday Judge Fetherston told me about the situation and I said I could not be a candidate without the unanimous support of county leaders. I said this on the supposition that the air would be cleared by my selfelimination and that there would be an immediate agreement on the Mayoralty.
the Red Sox held tight to second place in the American League by taking the odd game of a series of three from the Browns today, 6 to 4, while members of the 1922 Mound City team looked on.
Influenced by the most favorable weather experienced at this season in several years, prices on the Cotton Exchange lost ground again yesterday and closed with losses of 3 to 9 points.

Russia and Germany will have the right to build a small number of 10,000-ton cruisers in the next six years under the terms of the new Anglo-Russian and Anglo-German naval treaties to be signed in the London Foreign Office tomorrow morning.

The United States Army briefly took over virtual control of Tientsin's principal railway station this morning and the platforms were cleared of most of the Japanese guards when a special train left Tientsin at 9:30 for Chingwangtao carrying more than 160 American men, women and children.

The "Festival of German Art" that is to precede the dedication of a new art gallery here Sunday by Chancellor Adolf Hitler opened today with much speech-making in this city, which by the Fuehrer's decree has received the honorary title of "City of German Art."

The Wharton Northern Railroad Company applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to abandon one and onefourth miles of single-track line from Wharton Junction in Jefferson Township to a point near Wharton Station in the Borough of Wharton, Morris County, N. J.
Jessurun and Venturi Draw

England and other parts of the United Kingdom are showing a decided liking for women's wear made in this country, according to a report to the Commerce Department from Edward B. Lawson, Trade Commissioner at London.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works and subsidiary companies, including the Midvale Company, received orders amounting to $2,585,080 in June, compared with $3,229,571 in June, 1936, the company announced yesterday.
Railway companies and elevator and grain interests joined issue today before the Board of Railway Commissioners on the question of demurrage charges on grain cars at terminal elevators.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "There is a better tone in the wool market and a slightly better business has resulted, following the settlement of the woolhandlers' strike, especially in Australian merinos, which are stronger.

The Committee on Federal Legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, which issued an adverse report on President Roosevelt's original judiciary reform bill, made public yesterday a report denouncing the substitute bill now before Congress as a "subversive" measure.

Rainy weather affected retail trade here somewhat this week, resulting in a spotty sales showing. Department store executives estimated dollar volume showed an increase of about 2 to 3 per cent over the comparative 1936 week, with typical Summer merchandise and clearance items faring well.
Daniel Doran of Schenectady, N. Y., an agent of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company for thirty-seven years, died here last night at the home of his daughter, Mrs. George A. McDonald.

ALLEN ETHEL T. (June 8). Estate $10, 00. To Elizabeth Campbell, 29 E. 29th St., $2,000; eight others receive bequests of cash or personalty; The House of the Holy Comforter, Church Home for Incurables, the Salvation Army and the Little Missionary's Day Nursery, one-third residue each. City Bank Farmers Trust Co., 22 William St., executor.

Aluminium Ltd. of la, affiliate of the Aluminum Company of America, transacts business in New York City, and is therefore within the jurisdiction of the Federal court here, Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell ruled yesterday, declining to set aside service of a complaint filed by the government in its anti-trust action against the Canadian company.

John D. Archbold's old New York Forty Vixen III, sloop rigged, was established as winner of the Fire Island Trophy, and Henry Sear's Actaea, although third on corrected time in the small fleet, carried the Brooklyn Challenge Cup to the Indian Harbor Yacht Club as the

Commodity futures were generally higher yesterday in moderate activity on the local markets. Rubber and silk futures were lower. In the cash markets, all the grains, flour, cocoa, lard, tins and hides advanced, but rubber, silk, printcloths, cotton, eggs and butter declined.

To the list of distinguished dancers who have appeared at the Lewisohn Stadium must now be added the name of Mikhail Mordkin, for last night he presented himself and his young company there for the first time.
Col. John P. Dubb, Infantry, will proceed about July 13, Newark. N. J., to Pine Camp N.Y., and Fort Niagara, N. Y., in turn, for temporary duty in connection with organized Reserves activities.

Walter Davies (Rink) Barrington, coal research engineer and an executive of the Consolidation Coal Company, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, died last night at his home, 19 Bellegrove Drive, Upper Montclair, of a heart ailment. He was 51 years old.

Local department stores announced yesterday that for the last week they have been suspending shipments of liquor to Connecticut customers. The suspension will continue, it was said, until the new State Tax Law there has been clarified.
Seven Canadians are in the select circle of the "King's Hundred," who fire tomorrow in the final stage for the King's Prize, classic climax of the empire meeting of the National Rifle Association.
Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club announced yesterday the signing of two fights on his proposed all-championship program at the Polo Grounds, Sept. 17.

Sheldon E. Prentice of Rumson this afternoon for the second time won the H. L. Herbert Cup and thereby gained permanent possession of the trophy that annually has been offered at the Monmouth County Horse Show to honor the memory of the father of American polo.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church will be the preacher tomorrow afternoon at, 4 o'clock at a vesper service at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, for Summer students. Negro graduates of colleges and universities will attend an annual university day program at 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon at St. James Presbyterian Church,

Esquire-Coronet, Inc., filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its pending statement for the registration of 150,000 shares of capital stock of the company, naming Lawrence Stern Co., Inc., as the principal underwriter, according to a statement here by David A. Smart, president.

There will be no discrimination in favor of women when it comes to claiming exemption from jury duty in New York, Attorney General Bennett Jr. ruled today in an opinion declaring that similar certificates must be filed by both sexes in seeking release.

In a unanimous decision, the Appellate Division reversed yesterday an $85,000 judgment awarded William S. Hart, two-gun hero of the silent films, and his sister against the United Artists Corporation. A new trial of the action was ordered.

Mrs. Herbert Shipman entertained at luncheon yesterday in the outdoor Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton. Her guests included Mrs. Frederic N. Watriss, Mrs. Dwight Fiske and Miss Brenda D. D. Frazier.
BEYOND HUMANISM, by Charles Hartshorne. (Willett, Clark, $2.50.) This is a book for philosophers, theologians and laymen seriously interested in those subjects. There are three movements,
One Spanish youth paid with his life for trying to desert from the army and to escape the war by swimming the Bidassoa River into France this morning.
A little girl snipped a ribbon today and traffic flowed for the first time over the new $800,000 mile-long bridge spanning Lake Champlain between this village and Alburg, Vt.

The Italian section of Harlem was turned over to carnival yesterday as 100,000 Italian-Americans gathered from Eastern States for the fifty-second annual celebration of the Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, at 115th Street just west of Pleasant Avenue.

All import quota restrictions and prohibitions, increased import duties on ninety-one tariff items and reduced duties on 131 items, have been abolished by the Turkish Government, through a decree of July 15, according to a cablegram received in the Department of Commerce from Commercial Attache Julian E. Gillespie, Istambul.
An entire Doukhobor family of five were drowned in the waters of the Columbia River last night when their rowboat overturned.
The underlying character of bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was little changed from that prevailing most of the week.

Miss Augusta Virmond Morgan, daughter of Mrs. Frederick Charles Morgan of this place and the late Mr. Morgan, was married here tonight in the First Presbyterian Church to Walter Lyon Boese, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Boese of Shore Acres, Mamaroneck, N. Y.

The engagement was announced today of Miss Margaret Campbell Geddes, daughter of Sir Auckland Campbell Geddes, former British Ambassador to Washington, and Prince Ludwig of Hesse, great-grandson of Queen Victoria.

Among the residences in Westchester reported yesterday by brokers as having been sold was that of Hermann G. Place, vice president of the Chase National Bank, on Apawamis Avenue, Rye. Mrs. Peter Greig, present occupant and lessee of the dwelling, is the purchaser.

Treasure gold bars reported discovered in the Province of Chiriqui yesterday were not found on the property of the Canadian Mining Corporation but by three independent prospectorsEmerson Thorpe, an American;

Lieut. Gen. Kanichiro Tashiro, who until a week ago was commander of the Japanese military forces in North China, died in a Japanese military hospital at Tientsin today of pneumonia and heart disease.
The one-family residence at 1,795 Kentucky Avenue, North Bergen, N. J., was purchased for occupancy by William J. Earl. The structure is a five-room bungalow and has a private garage at the rear.

Government troops today made a short surprise thrust toward Ciempozuelos, about twenty miles south of Madrid on the Jarama River front, aided by an armored train. A slight advance was made and the position was consolidated.
One of two veteran pitchers released by the Browns got another hurling job almost immediately. Al Thomas, 36, was signed today by the Red Sox. He was released yesterday.

American Cigar Company common and preferred stock, $100 par value, and Federal Bake Shops, Inc., common stock, no par value, have been removed from listing by the New York Curb Exchange. All three had been suspended since July 15, 1935, due to the failure of the issuers to register the securities under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont, New Jersey State champion, won her second tournament within a week when she scored an 82 today over the Suburban Club course to win the women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day event. At Rock Spring last Tuesday the State titleholder captured a Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tourney with a similar score.

The identity and character of The Knickerbocker Press, recently merged with The Albany Evening News, will prevail in the successor publication, The Knickerbocker Press-Albany Evening News, according to B. J. Lewis, editorial director of the combined newspapers.

Morgenthau Corp. M. Morgenthau Jr, president. has arranged an extension of the first mortgage of $41,550 on the five-story apartment at 646 E 236th St. the Bronx, for five years for Benjamin Werner. Roeser-Feltner, Inc, represented the owner and Cruikshank Co, the Stuyvesant Square Hospital. the mortgage holders.

Greyhound's exhibition mile in 1:59 3/4 a new world record for a trotter over a half-mile track and the gray gelding's thirteenth world record, was the feature event of today's Grand Circuit racing meeting at the Historic Track.

Under a program to promote sports, the State of Durango, Mexico, will turn over to its newly created Department of Physical Culture all funds from the sale of special permits to sell alcoholic beverages after regular hours, E. W. Eaton, United States Vice Consul at Durango, has notified the Department of Commerce.

Billy Dear and Charley Whitehead, Forsgate Country Club entry, scored a 69, two under par, today to win the qualifying medal in the fifth annual New Jersey State amateur best-ball golf championship. Each contributed a pair of birdies in the par-shattering round.

Here and there: Hot weather reflection: There will be no fishing through the ice at Sacandaga Reservoir this Winter.....Not according to the new regulations announced yesterday by the Conservation Department.
The British proposals for reconciling rival plans to end the deadlock over Spain were accepted by the NonIntervention Committee today as a basis for discussion.

The New York Cocoa Exchange, which has been located in the former Munson-Beaver Building at 8092 Beaver Street for many years has arranged for larger quarters there under a plan which will result in extensive alterations to the ground floor of the building.

Daniel Shaw, who served with the New York Police Department for forty-six years before he retired in 1934, died yesterday at his home, 130-16 Rockaway Beach Boulevard, Belle Harbor, Queens, after an illness of seven months. He was 73 years old.

Mayor La Guardia started a new bus route yesterday from the Summer City Hall in College Point to Jamaica, an eight and a half-mile route over which buses will run every twelve minutes at a five-centfare.

The Third Reich's Summer capital was established today with the opening of the new Chancellery near Berchtesgaden, within walking distance of Berghof, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's chalet in the Bavarian Alps. Dr.

The Department of Parks announced yesterday the opening of two new playgrounds and two new buildings this morning. The playgrounds are at 179th Place, north of Jamaica Avenue, and at Sayres Avenue, between 172d Street and Merrick Boulevard, in St. Albans Memorial Park, Queens.

Foremen of the Ford Motor Company supervised the distribution of application blanks in the Ford Brotherhood of America, Inc., an alleged company union, according to testimony at the National Labor Relations Board hearing today.
Samuel Seabury, special counsel to the Board of Estimate in transit matters, including unification of rapid transit lines, resigned yesterday after three and one-half years of unsalaried service.

At the meeting of the Garden Club of Lake George yesterday at the home of Mrs. Ralph Bixby, plans were made to have a garden visiting day on Aug. 17, when gardens of the estates along the Bolton Road will be open to the public, followed by tea at the Lake George Club.
Armstrong Maltbie of Brooklyn, president of the insurance adjusting firm of Miller Maltbie of New York, died here today following a long illness. His age was 82.

M. J. Cashal, vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, American Federation of Labor, announced last night that he had signed a contract with Sheffield Farms, Inc., providing for a wage increase of $2 a week for nearly 6,000 members of the union employed by Sheffield.

President Roosevelt, it was announced today, signed yesterday the eight treaties and conventions and the protocol which were adopted at Buenos Aires by the Inter-American Peace Conference and were recently approved by the United States Senate.

Mrs. Rose Hofkin Cowan, Philadelphia, won the women's Delaware State clay court tennis championship today by beating Miss Madge Harshaw of Philadelphia, 6-3, 1-6, 8-6. Bob Kamrath of the University of Texas scored an upset victory over Louis Wetherell of
Thomas H. Sadler, who had been manager of the Morrison Hotel since 1931, died today at his home of an ailment that confined him to his bed a month ago. He was 51 years old.

Shouting "Hands off China" and carrying placards urging Americans to "rally to the support of China," thirty members of the American Friends of the Chinese People paraded in front of the building at 500 Fifth Avenue, where the Japanese Consulate is located, from noon until 1 o'clock yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Katherine Knerr of this city, daughter of Mrs. Alice Stimmel Knerr of Fargo, N. D., and Frank Owen Knerr, also of Fargo, to Donald Kinney Angell, son of Mrs. Walter H. Angell of Brooklyn and Cortland, N. Y., and the late Mr. Angell, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Ascension. The Rev. Frederick W. Cooper performed the ceremony.
The Yankee winning streak came to an end on Navin Field today just when the champions seemed on the brink of presenting Manager Joe McCarthy with the longest string of successes of his regime.
The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has sold its share interest in the Standard-Nobel w Polsce Spolka Akcyjna, operating in Poland, to the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc.

Progressive development of the program already started to prevent wars by and between the Pan-American republics, and implementing of the Kellogg Pact as the first step in the creation of international safeguards,

Edison Hedges, a speed boat driving legislator, set a new mark for Class B inboard runabouts today at the annual Havre de Grace regatta, completing a measured mile run at an average speed of 35.468 miles per hour.

Japanese military authorities warned the nation tonight that the preservation of peace in China was becoming hopeless. Official sources said the situation in the vicinity of Peiping was more precarious than at any time since Japanese and Chinese forces first clashed there ten days ago.

Two men, who the police said had been on a drinking spree for several days, were held in St. George, S. I., police headquarters last night accused of conspiring to kill Richmond County Judge Thomas F. Cosgrove.

The Ecuadoran Cabinet resigned tonight after a long conference with President Federico Paez and a new one was immediately appointed. The President designated Colonel Hector Salgado as Minister of Government and Carlos Manuel Larrea to the Foreign Office.

President Roosevelt and his supporters in the Senate moved forward today with plans to renew the drive for passage of the compromise Judiciary Reorganization Bill, in keeping with the spirit of the letter in which the President last night told Senator Barkley the fight must go on.

One of the most telling arguments against nudism is that the less that is publicly seen of the average figure, the better off the public will be. Observations on bathing beaches support this contention.

Miss Rita Helen Wick, daughter of Anton E. Wick of St. Paul, Minn., was married this morning to Milton E. Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Harris of this place. The ceremony was performed by Common Pleas Judge Daniel J. Brennan in his chambers in Newark.
The big event of the week--and it likely would be big even if it weren't the Summer--was the appearance of a trained horse at the Messrs. Rockefeller's Rainbow Room.

The Cabinet resigned unexpectedly today over the question of agrarian subsidies. An alternative coalition would be difficult so it is probable former Premier Milan Hodza will be asked to form a newCabinet or a Cabinet of officials will be formed as a temporary measure.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company called today for redemption on Aug. 25 of all its 31/2 per cent convertible debentures stillremaining outstanding, amounting to approximately $5,200,000, at par and accrued interest, plus a premium of 4 per cent.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders oday, dated July 14: CAPTAIN ofquist, E. A., Naval War College. Newport, R. I., to Ninth Naval District, Great Lakes, III., as Chief of Staff and Aide.
England's Davis Cup team today took a lead of three matches to one in its informal meet with Australia. The score stood 2 to 0 in Britain's favor yesterday. C. R.

Lawyers and others who participated in the reorganization of the Flatbush-Nevins Corporation, owner of the Fox Theatre in Brooklyn, received yesterday allowances for fees and disbursements amounting to $132,781 from Federal Judge William Bondy.

The National Maritime Union announoed yesterday that a drive had been started for the organization of pursers and incidental help on all ships operating from ports on the Atlantic and the Gulf of Mexico. About 1,000 pursers and 500 other employes, including barbers, clerks, beauty-parlor operators and other ship staff, would be eligible, it was said.

An investing group consisting of Dr. Moses Spatt, Leon G. Wertheimer and George J. Wise, and acting under the name of the Wispa Realty Corporation, has purchased the apartment and store building at 8,606 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn. Charles Goldenberg represented the Centichel Corporation, the seller. Archibald Godlstein represented the purchasers.

Leather sales of the Allied Kid Company for its fiscal year ended on June 30 amounted to $11,086,337. This compares with $9,581,416 for the previous twelve months, with a considerable part of the increase resulting from higher prices based on the increased cost of raw materials.
Mrs. Ella Barnes Watson, widow of Judge Winslow Charles Watson of Plattsburg, N. Y., died today at the Union Memorial Hospital after a long illness. Her age was 82.

A youth and a girl who had clung to a buoy in lower New York Bay for three hours after abandoning a rowboat in which they were being carried out to sea, were rescued yesterday evening by the Sandy Hook, a steamship operated by the Central Railroad of New Jersey.
The ultra-chic in the hairdresser's art will be seen here at the annual convention of the German members of that calling. Of chief interest this year is a competition for wigmakers.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Following their plea of guilty yesterday to an indictment for theft from private letter boxes, Judge Robert A. Inch, in the Federal court, in Brooklyn, sentenced Joseph Berger, 27 years old, of 331 Sackman Street, to a term of three years in jail and a fine of $100.

The fourth series of wool auctions close today with a firm tone, 7,256 bales being offered, of which 5,989 were sold. The number of withdrawals during the auctions did not materially affect the market and the home trade was a heavy buyer of all grades.

The conviction of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania was upheld yesterday in a unanimous decision by the Appellate Division while United States Supreme Court Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo closed one of the routes by which Lucania's case might have been taken to that court.

The Briggs Manufacturing Company has told its stocholders that the Motor Products Corporation, hecause of pressure from its minority stockholders, has dropped its efforts to obtain proxies in favor of a merger of the two companies. and that the plan will not be ratified at the special Motor Products meeting called for July 22.

A quick glance at the anchorage off the Larchmont Yacht Club today would not have led one to suspect that the biggest yachting carnival on Long Island Sound, the club's thirty-ninth annual race week, was one day ahead.
