Making her first competitive appearance in the East in three years, Miss Helen Hicks, former holder of many titles in the metropolitan district, showed the way to a record field of 202 in the third annual Gedney Farm women's invitation golf tournament today.

It is an old tradition of the law that every accused person is entitled to counsel. If the prisoner appears without a lawyer it is the duty of the court to appoint one to represent him, and it is the duty of the appointee, as an officer of the court, to see that his client's legitimate interests are not jeopardized.

Andrew J. Lord, president of Lord, Abbett Co., has issued a statement drawing a connection between the sale of investment fund shares and the volume of odd-lot trading, which has been reported for the past year or more.
A study of equatorial winds and currents sent naval aviators farther northward today in the closing phase of their South Seas search for Amelia Earhart.
Proper obstetrical care should cut the high mortality among newborn infants and their mothers in two, statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company asserted yesterday.

An urgent plea for the immediate reinstatement of "thousands of competent and desperately needy" persons who are being dismissed from Works Progress Administration roils "without any chance of employment in private industry" is being made to members of Congress by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians in New York City.

Week-end entertaining began in earnest tonight with the arrival of many guests. Mr. and Mrs. Luis M. de las Rivas, who have as their guests for the week-end Mr. and Mrs. Vadim Makaroff, gave an informal dinner at their apartment. Colonel and Mrs. Francis L. V. Hoppin entertained with a dinner at Auton House in honor of their guests, Mr. and Mrs. Victor Loew.

147th St. 228-234 W, 6-story apartment, 166 6x99.11; Amic Realty Corp against West 147th Street Realty Co; due, $41.678; taxes. , $1,000; subject to mortgage of $171,000; to plaintiff for $172,000. By DAVID B. KUNSTLER 5th St. 741 E, 6-story tenement, 34.6x97; Manufacturers Trust Co against Joseph D. Rohrilch; due, $23,828; subject to mortgage of $34,000; to plaintiff for $38.000.
Emil Salay, who underwrote the flight of George Endres and Alexander Magyar from the United States to Hungary in 1931, died in a hospital here yesterday at the age of 64. He was a native of Hungary.
Earle Bailie, head of the Tri-Continental Corporation, suggested to the Securities and Exchange Commission today the creation of a Federal Bureau of Examination and Audits for investment companies.

Secretary Morgenthau today ordered the Procurement Division of the Treasury to refer all cases of collusive bidding to the Department of Justice. His order, issued following receipt of an opinion from the Attorney General, read as follows:
The Board of Estimate adopted plans yesterday for the new $3,350,000 Central Needle Trades High School in Manhattan, after adding $650,000 to the original estimated cost of $2,700,000.

William Woodward's 1936 St. Leger winner, Boswell, one of the country's best stayers, today captured the Eclipse Stakes at Sandown Park. Taking the lead two furlongs from home, he defeated five seasoned campaigners, including the 1-to-3 oddson favorite, Lord Astor's Rhodes Scholar.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order revoking the registration as a broker or dealer in the over-the-counter markets of Henry Friedlander, Spokane, Wash., doing business as Henry Friedlander Co.,

Sales in retail stores during June totaled $3,400,000,000, registering a slight increase over the sales volume of June, 1936, which was stimulated by bonus payments to World War veterans, according to calculations made public today by the American Retail Federation.

A ninth-inning onslaught, during which they shelled two pitchers to cover, gave Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers a 6-5 triumph over the Reds at Ebbets Field yesterday and an even break in the abbreviated series.

On the eve of the first anniversary of the outbreak, July 18, of the garrison revolt which developed into the present involved conflict in Spain, Great Britain continues to lead in international efforts to prevent the spread of the war beyond the Pyrenees.

The Federal Government was asked to investigate the formal opening tomorrow of Nordland, a recreational camp for boys and girls at Andover, N. J., following charges here yesterday by the NonSectarian League that the camp was under Nazi control and its operations illegal.

Plans for a two-story addition to St. Thomas private school, at 114-16 West Fifty-sixth Street, Manhattan, were among the projects submitted by architects yesterday. A large number of proposals for alterations to tenement buildings also were included in the list, which follows:

The determination of Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, to expel job-dodgers and unemployables from the work relief force in this city was strengthened yesterday when he received a report showing that 80,829 workers among the 174,478 listed on June 24 had been on the Federal relief rolls since the WPA was created in August, 1935.
Ernest Sutter of Tulane, national intercollegiate champion, gained the final round of the Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament today at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

Holders of bonds and certificates of deposit representing the obligations of Broward County, Fla., and Broward County Road and Bridge District No. 3 have received notification from the Broward County Bondholders Association that refunding bonds under the terms of the plan dated Dec. 16, 1935, will be ready for delivery on July 20, 1937.

Edgar F. Tierney and his TNT bidding teammates from Springfield, Mass., tonight won the team of four title in the Southern New England bridge championships with a blasting finish after an afternoon of fine play.

Mrs. Mary Ellen Leary, this city's oldest resident, died today at the age of 104 at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Reuben A. Patterson. She came to the United States from Ireland ninety-six years ago.
The Pan-American skiing competition will begin tomorrow at Farellones Fields, fifty miles from Santiago on the flanks of the Andes, at an altitude of 8,000 feet.

The Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig, minister of the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, Seventy-seventh Street, west of Broadway, will sail on the Statendam next Tuesday for Holland to attend in August a meeting of the board of directors of the Leyden Pilgrim

Newark had to travel ten innings before battering out a 10-to-6 decision over the Bisons tonight before 7,500 fans. Joe Beggs, who succeeded Kemp Wicker on the mound as Buffalo tied the count with two out in the ninth, gained credit for the victory, his tenth in a row and thirteenth of the season.

Mrs. Rose Titus Samsel, 30 years old, of 7 Martin Street, South River, was sentenced to serve eight to ten years in State's prison today when she pleaded guilty to second degree murder before Judge Adrian Lyon in Quarter Sessions Court here.

The daily average of cotton-mill activity declined last week, but due to the difficulty of establishing seasonal factors in a holiday week the index has been set at 138.0. The index for the previous week has been revised to the same figure, 138.0. It was 129.1 for the week ended July 11, 1936.

Congress has appropriated more than $7,500,000,000 this year for Federal expenditures, committee records showed today. This includes an estimated $133,298,999 for the Interior Department, which the House may cut to some extent before giving final approval next week.

Dr. Abram Coralnik, associate editor of the Jewish Day, 183 East Broadway, a Yiddish-language daily newspaper, and a well -known writer and Zionist leader, died yesterday of a heart ailment at the Mount Kisco (N. Y.) Hospital after a long illness. Dr. Coralnik, who lived at 533 West 112th Street, was 54 years old.
The American Red Cross today sent $10,000 to Secretary of State Cordell Hull to be used in evacuating remaining American citizens from the war zones in Spain.

Turpentine firm, 331/2c; sales, 210 barrels; receipts 452 barrels; shipments, 532 barrels; stock, 32,287 barrels. Resin firm; sale, 763; receipts, 1,838; shipments, 2,264; stock, 65,474. Quote-B to WG. $7.80; WW, X, $8.65.

The Westchester Lighting Company has been authorized by the Public Service Commission to change the stated value of its capital stock from $50 to $44 and to reduce its capital from $41,800,000 to $36,784,000.

Rated as "better than average" in buying volume and largest of all July markets in attendance, the midsummer furniture show will close its twoweek run tomorrow afternoon at the American Furniture Mart.

From The Herald Tribune (Rep.). The bad temper of President Roosevelt's letter to Senator Barkley can be excused on the ground of the weather. Not even an airconditioned White House and a yacht on the Potomac can make Washington a place for calmness and good nature in midsummer.

Retaining the teams with which they conquered their opponents in their respective parts of the tennis world, Germany and the United States tomorrow will begin the interzone final match which is expected to determine not only which has the right to challenge Great Britain but the ultimate custodian of the Davis Cup.

The Rev. Thomas Coyle, pastor of the Westhampton Presbyterian Church, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Martha Foster Coyle, to John Hart Ely, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ely of Short Hills, N. J., and Black Hall.

Premier Prince Fumimaro Konoe, who is ill, directed Japan's course in the Chinese crisis today from his bed, but was cheered by the arrival of his son, Fumitaka Konoe, from Princeton in the United States.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

The Kansas State Legislature has selected the cottonwood as the official State tree. The St. Louis Globe Democrat, not entirely satisfied with its own State tree-the haw tree, which produces the beautiful State flower but bears fruit that is the refuge of an injurious pest--looks with great favor and with some envy upon its neighbor's tree, as if it were the tree of the knowledge of good and evil.

The total assets of the 10,299 State-supervised banks in the country on Dec. 31, last, were $38,652,726,000. This figure represents a gain of 8.2 per cent over the total as at the end of 1935, according to a survey just issued by the committee on State bank research of the State Bank Division of the American Bankers Association.
A proposal to pardon Thomas J. Mooney by constitutional amendment reached the Attorney General's office today.
The Rev. Henry T. Regan, a member of the Augustinian order for more than fifty years, died at Villanova College today after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

Trading continued to improve and there was more business yesterday morning than any day this week. Most classes were steady with Thursday's close and some salesmen were holding lamb at higher prices. All kosher markets opened higher regardless of the Jewish holiday, "Fast of Ab," as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Rochester turned back the Jersey City Giants, 3-2, tonight in an International League game. A tworun rally in the seventh inning decided the contest. The Giants scored once in the fifth to tie the score and took the lead in the sixth.

The concert of the City Amateur Symphony Orchestra, Municipal Court Justice Leopold Prince, conductor, to be given tonight on the Mall at Central Park, will feature a composition by Sascha London, a member of the orchestra. Mr. London, a German refugee who came to this country three years ago, will conduct his own work, entitled "The Duel of Life and Death."

The bloodiest clash between police and strikers in the shipyards strike, now entering its second month, ended late yesterday afternoon in the injury of three policemen and five shipyard strikers. One striker was taken to the hospital. As a result of the clash nine strikers were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct.
More than 1,000 children from Protestant daily vacation Bible schools in the five boroughs and communities on Long Island and in Westchester County and Northern

Peiping is Japan's for the taking if she wants it. From here to Tientsin and the sea the Japanese Army has unchallenged lines of communication. At Tungchow, only twelve miles from Peiping's main eastern gate, the writer found the only body of Chinese troops in the entire distance, consisting of one battalion of the Twenty-ninth Army, not exceeding 500 -men.

A start will be made soon in a British air service across the South Atlantic route. The government announced today that it had entrusted the service to one of the smaller companies of British Airways, Ltd.
William G. Hippler, editor of the Saturday magazine and book section of The Buffalo Evening News, died last night at his Summer home on the Lake Road.

New construction covering all classes of work totaled $318,137,100 in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains during June, it was learned yesterday. This tops by 8 per cent the previous high in building since recovery, which was recorded for July, 1936.

Mr. and Mrs. John W. Herbert gave a dinner with dancing tonight in the new Merry-Go-Round Room of the Seven Ponds Inn. The guests were seated at small tables decorated with garden flowers. During the evening there were divertissements.

By rejecting definitely and to all appearances finally the advice of those in his own party who have urged him to withdraw his Supreme Court plan, President ROOSEVELT has involved himself in a situation from which it is difficult to believe that he can emerge with profit.
Great Britain's annual finance bill, calling for [Pound]198,000,000 for armaments, today passed the House of Commons by a vote of 171 to 95.

Grover A. Whalen and Royal S. Copeland will fight it out in the Democratic primaries for the nomination for Mayor, it was announced officially late yesterday afternoon. Mr. Whalen goes in as the candidate of the Brooklyn, the Bronx, Queens and Richmond organizations, whose leaders are the political representatives of the New Deal in New York City.
Count Felix von Luckner sailed today for Aruba, off the Venezuelan coast, aboard his small schooner, the Seeteufel.

Dire penalties, among them retroactive collection of unpaid taxes far back into dim and forgotten years, were promised for tax dodgers today by Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, when the Finance Bill, implementing the budget proposals, was passed on its third reading in the House of Commons by a vote of 171 to 95.

Exports increased in May to all grand divisions except Oceania over May, 1936, and imports increased from all grand divisions, the Commerce Department reported today in its monthly summary of foreign trade by countries.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher in training in day secondary other than junior high schools, in the subjects indicated, be issued, as of July 14, 1937, to the following applicants who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefor:

For a time it looked as if both the heat wave and the Giants would do a grand comeback at the Polo Grounds yesterday as Colonel Bill Terry's perspiring troops strove to regain first place in the National League.

Stocks closed irregularly lower in less active trading; turnover, 704,280 shares. All groups of bonds firm and dull; transactions, $6,616,000. Curb Exchange Market steady and mixed; 172,725 shares traded. Bonds irregular; sales, $1,280,000.

THERE should be more than a spot of sport and a dash of fun down in Palmer Stadium today. It's the eighth running of a double entry track and field meet under two flags. The athletes of Oxford and Cambridge for the Union Jack; the athletes of Princeton and Cornell for the Stars and Stripes. Or John Bull vs. Uncle Sam on the flat, over the hurdles and twice around the field.
Lieutenant Cameron Winslow, U. S. N., and Mrs. Winslow of Woodmere gave a dinner dance tonight at the Atlantic Beach Club to celebrate their third wedding anniversary and the birthday of the host.
In history the Americans who fought and died for Spain on July 9, as on Feb. 27, will provide a great and sorrowful chapter.
The first issue of the newly combined The Literary Digest and Review of Reviews has appeared, cartrying the title The Digest. The periodical will be published weekly.
A project for the establishment of a naval reserve auxiliary, to be composed of yacht owners all over the country, has just been undertaken by the Navy Department, it was learned today.

Trustees of the Union Church of Palisade announced yesterday that three suits filed against the church in connection with the ousting of the former pastor, the Rev. Vincent G. Burns, had been settled.
The Holland-America liner Statendam, arriving from Rotterdam, Boulogne and Southampton, has as passengers Dr. Edward K. Barsky, who has been chief of the American hospitals in Spain.

Damages of $387,712.40 must be paid by the city to the Rapid Transit Subway Construction Company, a subsidiary of the Interborough Rapid Transit Commission, according to a ruling made yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente.

Movies were recommended today as a curative for pupils with bad eyesight by Dr. Harry J. Baker, director of the psychological clinic in Detroit public schools. Moving pictures seen through a special kind of eyeglass help children with enlarged "blind spots," he said.
Senator Robert F. Wagner dedared his confidence last night that the collective bargaining act bearing his name would not be vitally changed or "mutilated."

Sosthenes Behn, president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, announced yesterday afternoon that an underwriting agreement had been made with Swiss bankers to underwrite $9,150,000 of an issue of approximately $30,000,000 of debentures of the United River Plate Telephone Company, Ltd., a foreign subsidiary.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Teele Foale, daughter of Mrs. Myrtle Teele Foale of this city, to Kenneth B. Tuttle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Tuttle of Darien, took place today. The Rev. Gerald A. Cunningham performed the ceremony at the bride's home.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 10 amounted to 682,205 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced to-day.

Thirty-four of the thirty-nine men and women found guilty of disorderly conduct last Tuesday in the Felony Court for disorders June 30 in the WPA recreational projects unit in West Sixty-fourth Street were freed yesterday by Magistrate Aurelio on suspended sentences of fines of $10 each or five-day jail terms.

Edward W. Byron, former owner of the Byron Tire Company and for the last five years head of the Connecticut Wheel and Rim Company of this city, died here yesterday after a short illness. He was 43 years old.

The resignation of Police Commissioner Frank Foran, the first of three demanded by a grand jury investigating graft charges, was given to Mayor Rossi today. Theodore J. Roche, president of the commission, and the third commissioner, Frank Sykes, declined to say whether they would resign.

Mr. and Mrs. Irving S. Broun of 330 East Forty-eighth Street have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Almeda Broun, to William Henry Seward Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Seward of Auburn, N. Y.

Following a week of firm prices, cotton turned reactionary on Thursday and since then has declined about $2.50 a bale. Favorable weather conditions in the Cotton Belt and reports of increased acreage in other countries have been the important factors in the decline.
Harold C. Hart, president of the Nash New England Company, died yesterday at the age of 49. Born in Hartford, Conn., he began his career with the Pope Hartford Company.
From a valued contributor comes a collection of useful thoughts "in the event of another heat wave,"

Supplementing the deal between an AngloNetherland banking syndicate and a British export group reported in these dispatches yesterday, under which Germany is to obtain minerals from Northern Spain and General Francisco Franco goods other than munitions and actual armaments, the Berlin correspondent of The Daily Telegraph of London makes the interesting prediction that a trade agreement between Germany and the Franco regime in Spain is likely to be signed next week.
An unannounced but not altogether unexpected closing tonight will be that of "Excursion," which will have been seen 114 times at the Vanderbilt Theatre.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petition TIN PAN ALLEY, INC., restaurant, 60 W. 52d St.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankrutcy Law listing liabilities of $10,957 and assets of $11,350. Petitions Flled-Against KEYSTONE FISH CO., INC., 29 Peck Slip.--By St. Martin Fisheries, for $245: Atchafalaya Fish Co., $182; R. F. Le Count, $560. p

United States Marshal John J. Kelly turned auctioneer in the Federal Building yesterday and netted $8,410. for the government in the sale of Swiss watch movements, a whole watch and twenty-five rolls of cloth.

With last week's six-day scorcher still fresh in their memories, as many New Yorkers as could took refuge behind the doors of air-conditioned establishments or fled to beaches yesterday as the temperature rose to 89 degrees at 3 P. M. and stayed just a point lower for four hours.

Captain John Logan, head of the Volunteers of America and prominent in charity activities here, said today in explaining the Volunteers' withdrawal of sponsorship of the Rev. R. Anderson Jardine's lecture here Thursday:

Ave C, n w cor Houston St. 58x52; Bertha Abrahams to Joseph Erdos, 42 Ave B ($30). Essex St, 103, 25.7x88.1; C. Herbert Vonhof to Libby Fashion Stores Realty Corp., 105 Essex St: $5,000 ($18). 19th St, 410-412 W, 50x92; Redrock Realty Corp to Graymoor Realty Corp, 565 5th Ave, c/o Steinmetz Stone; mtg.. $42,803 ($1).

Victory by four wickets over Hampshire lengthened Yorkshire's lead in the English county cricket championship today. Sussex, the runner-up, lost ground when held to a first innings margin over Nottinghamshire.

Faring poorly on only two holes, T. Suffern Tailer Jr., former metropolitan amateur champion, today carded a 74 to lead the field of ninety-one starters in the qualifying round of the annual Rockaway Hunting Club invitation golf tourney.
Governor Murphy announced tonight that he had called a conference between Michigan truck operators and their striking employes tomorrow.

Mysteriously shot and wounded twice in his Em??line Street home at about ??:25 o'clock this morning, Dr. George W. Webster, 39-year-old physician, died an hour later in the Homeopathic Hospital, where he was chief of the obstetrical department.

Newsprint production in Canada for the first six months of this year reached a high record, with an increase of 19.7 per cent over the same period last year, according to a statement issued today by the Newsprint Association of Canada.
The White Sox reached Bud Thomas and Lynn Nelson for eighteen hits today to beat the Athletics, 9 to 4, in the final of the series.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 882,000 bales, against 860,000 a week ago, 901,000 two weeks ago, 886,000 three weeks ago and 758,000 a year ago; of which American 315,000 bales, against 325,000 a week ago, 340,000 two weeks ago, 352,000 three weeks ago and 278,000 a year ago.

The American Superpower Corporation reports a net asset value of $33,703,506 at June 30, equal after priority for 194,724 first-preferred shares at $100 a share to $58.80 a share on 235,207 preference shares,on which dividends accrued since April 1, 1932, are $31.50 per share.
Four of Uncle Sam's top-flight sprinters took charge of the sixty-meter trial heats in the first track event of the Pan-American Games tonight but a Brazilian comet bobbed up as a real threat.
Stuart G. Knight of Schenectady was named temporarily today as acting head of the Law Bureau of the State Department of Taxation and Finance. He succeeds Seth T. Cole, who resigned.

Mayor La Guardia shook hands yesterday with Frank Brown, a diminutive Negro from Oklahoma of City who is a college graduate at 19 and wants to study business administration in a post-graduate course at New York University.
Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, announced yesterday the opening of bids for a contract for test borings on the line of the proposed bulkhead along Shore Road, Brooklyn.

The Washington unit of the American Newspaper Guild tonight defied Heywood, Broun, national guild president, and voted to push its campaign for a referendum on the question of affiliation with the Committee for Industrial Organization.

William J. Paynter, pioneer merchant here and a founder of the First National Bank of this borough, was found dead of a gunshot wound at his home this morning. He was 87 years old and had been in ill health.

With stock exchange circles occupied largely with the last day of the account, business continued on a small scale today. Gilt-edge securities, nevertheless, maintained their recent allround improvement, but bonds in the foreign section again were uncertain, reflecting the reaction here to, the Far Eastern disturbances.

I have been receiving from many sources inquiries and suggestions arising out of disturbed situations in various parts of the world. Unquestionably there are in a number of regions tensions and strains which on their face involve only countries that are near neighbors but which in ultimate analysis are of inevitable concern to the whole world.

The Times Sales Company, 1,524 Chestnut Street, Philadelphia, and Edward B. Seegar and William Heim, officers of the respondent concern, were today ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to stop certain unfair methods of competition in the sale of encyclopedia, revision and research services and magazine subscriptions.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission appealed yesterday to Associate Justice Albert Cohn of the Appellate Division for the suspension, pending a formal appeal, of an injunction order restraining it from proceeding with an examination of candidates for second-grade clerk.

A steamship strike which had cut off transportation to the Summer resort islands of Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard for four days and brought threats of "secession" was settled early today in an agreement signed at the State House.

Judge John E. Mack of Poughkeepsie, lifelong political associate of President Roosevelt, expressed the belief today that the Chief Executive would not seek a third term. He nominated Mr. Roosevelt for President at the Chicago and Philadelphia conventions.

Trading in butter, eggs, cheese and potat?? futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in the first half of the year reached the largest volume fo?? any corresponding period since 193?? with the exception of 1935 the Exchange announced today.

Lou Fette, the Bees' sensational freshman, limited the pace-setting Cubs to three hits, two of which were extremely scratchy, today while recording his eleventh victory in fourteen starts. The score was 6-1.

Miss Florence Elizabeth Gale, a native of Lake George and a piano teacher in New York City for more than forty years, died last night at the home here of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Koch, where she had been residing for the last two months. Her age was 77.

Unfilled orders of the Mesta Machine Company on June 30 reached the highest level in the company's history; at more than $24,000,000, compared with about $18,000,000 at the start of the year, and $10,500,000 at this time last year.

Sentences were suspended yesterday in Special Sessions on Irving J. Rudow, president of the B. B. Clothing Company at 162 Fifth Avenue, and Albert Turner, a former member of the concern, for filing false returns to the State Income Tax Department, after Thomas E. Dewey, special rackets prosecutor, told Justices Bayes, Salomon and Kozicke they had given him "valuable information on criminal matters of high importance to the administration of justice."
In addition to the $1,000,000 super fireboat soon to be built for the Fire Department, other new equipment to cost about $400,000 will be purchased in the near future, it was announced yesterday.

After having her hull cleaned, polished and made ready for her next races, Harold S. Vanderbilt's America's Cup defending sloop Ranger returned from Bristol today. At the same time her owner returned from New York aboard the Vara.

The United States Pipe and Foundry Company reported yesterday a net profit of $1,356,860 for the first half of this year. This was after depreciation, estimated Federal income taxes and other deductions, but before provision for surtax on undistributed earnings.

Leslie BalfourMelville, one of the greatest allround sportsmen Scotland has ever produced and believed to be the last surviving golfer who played the peerless young Tom Morris, died suddenly at North Berwick today at the age of 83. His greatest golf success was in winning the British amateur championship in 1895 after a memorable match with John Ball.

After more than twenty-five years of service to his government, Sir Benjamin was knighted in 1928. His public career began in 1902 when he went to South Africa as trade commissioner, and although he continued to call himself a consulting engineer his greatest services in the years since were in the fields of economics, trade and labor.

Al Roth, New York lightweight, stopped Joe Marciente of Canada in six rounds of their eight-round bout at the Rockaway Arena last night, The Associated Press reported. Marciente suffered a severe cut over his left eye when he was dropped for a count of nine in the second round.
The Indians won their fourth straight game today by defeating the Senators, 11 to 5, blasting their former team-mate, Wesley Ferrell, from the mound in the fourth inning.

Beginning today, no parking will be allowed on either side of Rockaway Beach Boulevard from Eightyfourth Street to 116th Street between noon and midnight on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, it was announced yesterday at police headquarters.

Born on the lower East Side not far from the birthplace of Alfred E. Smith, Grover A. Whalen has become an outstanding example of the opportunities afforded those who come from "the sidewalks of New York."

In the United States District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania, Pittsburgh, Federal Judge R. M. Gibson granted yesterday consented injunctions in two cases at the request of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Sir Benjamin Howell Morgan, consulting engineer who played an influential part in the economic history of the British Empire during the last thirty years, died today at Putney at the age of 62.

Total volume in round lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on June 19 increased substantially, compared with the week ended on June 12, and member trading for own account rose with the greater activity,

Mr. and Mrs. John Bryant Butler of Riverdale have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Patricia Butler, to Andrew John Corbett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Stephen Corbett, also of Riverdale.
The nation's capital said farewell to Senator Joseph T. Robinson today in a simple but impressive funeral service attended by President Roosevelt, the members of his Cabinet and other dignitaries.

Louis B. Mayer, vice president in charge of production for MetroGoldwyn-Mayer, sails today on the Rex to supervise the opening of the company's studios in England. He is accompanied by Ben Thau, production aide, and Howard Strickling, chief of the studio's West Coast publicity department.

The massive calm of the Rock of Gibraltar in its exposed and isolated position on the Mediterranean war front is not disturbed by reports of the construction of big-gun emplacements by Spanish Insurgents on all sides of the British garrison.

The Superior Court ruled here today that Mae West is the wife of Frank Wallace and that she had to pay the costs of the suit he filed to prove it. Judge Robert Kenny closed the case by his ruling that the "Diamond Lil" of the movies has been Mrs. Frank Wallace since 1911.

A fresh spasm of weakness overtook the French franc yesterday, causing it to fall to 3.82 1/4, cents, a new low on the current movement and the cheapest quotation for France's currency since December, 1926. The exchange closed at 3.82 3/8 cents, off 5 9-16 points from the previous day.
Ardent opponent of the New Deal, Dr. Royal S. Copeland, senior Senator of New York State, is among the leaders in the Senate opposing President Roosevelt's Supreme Court plan.

Miss Jean Bauer today won the Griswold Cup for the third time in four years by beating Miss Helen Waterhouse, 4 and 3, in the allProvidence final of the nineteenth annual women's invitation golf tournament at the Shenecossett Country Club. The cup must be won five times for permanent possession.

Except for the marketing of a new issue of $3,500,000 of Liquid Carbonic Corporation ten-year convertible 4 per cent debentures, new bond financing this week was again restricted to the tax-exempt field. State and municipal flotations, however, were more numerous and in larger volume than during the preceding period, with ten issues, aggregating $10,899,000, bringing the total of bond placements for the week to $14.399,000.

History repeated itself in the semifinals of the New York State amateur golf championship at the Oak Hill Country Club today when Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie, the "Cinderella Man" of two years ago, defeated Bill Holt of Syracuse, 1 up, to gain the final against Tommy Goodwin, Winged Foot star, who won from Murray Dailey of Oak Hill. 2 and 1.

Almost within the shadow of the hill upon which Marconi listened for the first feeble clicks of the transatlantic radio, not far from the spot from which intrepid .Alcock and Brown eighteen years ago took off for the first flight across the Atlantic Ocean, the Pan American Clipper rides at anchor tonight in a sheltered cove off the Bay of Exploits.
The sensational advance in wheat prices since June 21 is estimated to have increased the income of Winter wheat farmers more than $100,000,000.

Mrs. Dora Sturm Lang, founderpresident of the Queensboro Workers For and With the Blind, now the Queensboro Home for the Blind, Inc., died Thursday night at her home, 95-12 Ninety-fifth Avenue, Richmond Hill, after a long illness at the age of 69.

Dr. Herbert Weir Smyth, Eliot Professor Emeritus of Greek Literature at Harvard University, died this morning following an operation in the Bar Harbor Hospital. His age was 79 and his home was at 15 Albert Avenue, Cambridge.

Mrs. Pierce Butler of Washington, accompanied by her daughter, Miss Margaret Butler, is at the St. Regis. Miss Margaret Mixter, who earlier in the season visited her mother, Mrs. Kilpatrick Mixter, in England. will leave the Carlyle today for a ranch in Wyoming.

Youth had its day yesterday afternoon when three 5-week-old puppies and their proud Spitz mother nosed out such favorites as garter snakes, a lizard, turtles, a red-headed kitten and a clay giraffe to win first prize in the annual pet show of the Educational Alliance, East Side settlement house, at 197 East Broadway.

On Feb. 5, 1937, the President transmitted to Congress a message upon the judiciary, with which he submitted a letter from the Attorney General and a draft of a proposed bill, which was later introduced in the House of Representatives as H. R. 4417 and in the Senate as S. 1392.

Against the old golfing adage that 2 up and 5 to go never wins, Miss Grace Amory and Miss Audrey Phipps shrugged a nonchalant shoulder today and proceeded to win two of the next three holes, to take the women's Long Island Scotch foursome final from Mrs. Thomas R. Rudel and Mrs. Henry March, 4 and 2.

At least 175 persons were injured, thirty-three of whom were taken to the Atlantic City Hospital, when fire destroyed the gasoline storage plant of the Pure Oil Company at Virginia and Adriatic Avenues here today.
Trapped in a closed sedan as it backed off a dock into the Hudson River here, Fred McCormack, 22, died by drowning this forenoon.

The production index of the German textile industry for 1936 has risen to 98.4 per cent of the 1928 level and is now about the same as in 1934, according to a report to the Commerce Department from J. F. Huddleston, counsel at Dresden.

Brokers yesterday reported long lists of lessees of new apartments, reflecting a continuance of the brisk demand noted in recent weeks from persons selecting suites for Fall occupancy. The list follows:
Approximately 1,000 guests attended a "house-warming" yesterday at the new offices of the Dictaphone Sales Corporation at 420 Lexington Avenue.

The joint legislative committee to study budget and fiscal affairs, of which Assemblyman Abbot Low Moffat is chairman, held an executive session yesterday in the Bar Association Building to discuss its agenda.

About 500 children took part yesterday in the celebration of the third anniversary of two Park Department War Memorial Playgrounds in Manhattan, named, like others in the city, for men killed in action in the World War.

An estate of "under $5,000" in real estate and "under $5,000" in personalty is disposed of under the will of John Curley, also known as Jack Curley, promoter and showman who died at Great Neck on July 12.

The "Toonerville Trolley" won't run again after Monday, except in the newspaper cartoon. Unofficial word was received here this afternoon that the Westchester Electric Railroad Company had received permission from the Public Service Commission in Albany to substitute buses for the one-man trolley cars that inspired the drawings of Fontaine Fox, who formerly lived here.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $6,589,900, to be represented by one State and forty-five municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $14,000,807 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $31,837,670.
Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, urged today that both industrialists and labor unions stick wholeheartedly to their collective bargaining agreements.

Graphic descriptions of the broad gap between the church's function of creating a perfect brotherhood of mankind and conditions as they really are, marked today the closing sessions of the first week of the World Conference on Church, Community and State.

The Adjutant General released the following orders today: COMMISSIONS Cascio, 1st Lt. Don D., assigned to 27th Division Aviation for further assignment to 102d Observation Squadron. Isacke, 2d Lt. Clement F., assigned to 102d Quartermaster Corps for assignment to Company B
Net income of the Pennsylvania Railroad for the five months to May 31, last, amounted to $9,675,356 after taxes and charges, the company reported yesterday.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 15 unless specified: At San Diego: Altair, Cincinnati, Lamberton. Ketehikan to Wrangell: Borie, Trever, Zane. Seattle to Portland: Brooks, Fox, Golf, Indianapolis, Reuben James, Memphis, Minneapols. Quincy. Tuscalooa.

Members of the Oxford-Cambridge tennis team began an extensive playing tour in this country today by winning four of six mingles matches from the Rockaway Hunting Club netmen as competition for the Prince of Wales Cup opened on the club's grass courts.
A series of four plays by the Studio Players in the John Drew Memorial Theatre was opened tc night, with "The Crime at Blossome's " by Mordaunt Sharp.

Coincident with large scale Japanese military preparations throughout the countryside to the south and southwest of Peiping, the Japanese rushed arrangements for the defense of the Japanese Embassy, which probably will be the concentration point for Japanese nationals in the event of war.
ON HIS OWN APPLICATION Lieutenant Henry Harris, 6th Division, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed March 25, 1912.

G. Preston Scott, formerly manager of the Adams Hotel in New York and the Warwick Hotel in Philadelphia, and R. E. Ulman, formerly of Sharp Nassoit, are now connected with the rental department of Clement E. Merowit Co. Hugh Lehnaker has rejoined

Prominent clergymen and laymen of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York were among the several hundred persons who attended a mass of requiem yesterday for the Rev. Thomas J. McCluskey, former president of Fordham University, in the Church of St. Francis Xavier in West Sixteenth Street.

While buying of Fall merchandise continued to gather momentum in the wholesale markets, retail distribution was uneven this week, although most of the leading centers recorded gains of 2 to 5 per cent over the volume for the previous week, according to the review issued yesterday Dy Dun Bradstreet. Inc.

For his twenty years of "loyalty and untiring devotion" to the Boy Scout movement as vice president of the Bronx Council and associate chairman of the campaign committee, Postmaster Albert Goldman received yesterday an eighteen-inch bronze statuette of a typical Boy Scout from former Health Commissioner Shirley Wynne, representing the executive board of the Boy Scout Foundation.
The motorship Sun and the freighter Gulf Star crashed together five miles south of Sombrero Light, about fifty miles east of Key West and about 125 miles south of Miami early today.

Cook Gload, Inc., have sold for the Free Sons of Israel the threestory dwelling at 84-22 122d Street, Richmond Hill North, Queens. The house contains nine rooms and two baths, there is a two-car garage attached, and after alterations are completed Elizabeth Unser, the buyer, will occupy it.

With a victory over Yale and Harvard already to its credit, the combined Oxford-Cambridge track and field team will encounter much more stubborn opposition tomorrow on the lightning fast Palmer Stadium cinders when it engages Princeton and Cornell in the eighth and rubber match of their series.
Five hundred employes of the Kling Furniture Company walked out on strike today and closed the company's five factories in Chautauqua County.
John L. Kennelly, for twenty-four years an employee in the admiralty division of the Corporation Counsel of the City of New York, died in St. Luke's Hospital Thursday after a short illness.

The Cardinals took both ends of a double-header with the Phillies today by scores of 10-3 and 18-10. The second game went ten innings. Si Johnson was the winner while Bucky Walters was the loser in both contests.

Educational leaders yesterday vigorously assailed the Lyons Residence Bill requiring municipal employes to live within the city limits and threatened court action if it is construed to apply to teachers.

When blonde Ruth Grummon, 9 1/2 years old, of 421 West 162d Street, paid a 10-cent admission charge yesterday afternoon at the Highbridge Pool, at 173d Street and Amsterdam Avenue, she automatically became the 1,000,000th patron of the Park Department's twelve outdoor pools since their re-opening May 29, and the possessor of a balsa wood surfboard, a gift of the department.

Representative Costello of California introduced in the House this week a resolution calling for creation of a joint Congressional committee to study all pending bills affecting World War veterans and their dependents, and to make recommendations looking to a more efficient and economical operation of the Veterans' Administration.

The three four-story apartments, each containing nine suites, known as 255-61-65 East 237th Street, the Bronx, have been purchased by a corporation Controlled by Louis Schleifer from Woodlawn Heights Realty, Inc. The houses stand on plots 44 by 100 feet. David L. Wolfson was attorney for the buyer and Jacob G. Zaks for the seller.

The American Legion 1937 Convention Corporation of New York City, which is arranging for the Legion national convention from Sept. 20 to 23, announced yesterday the election of Colonel William J. Donovan as general counsel and member of the board of directors.

Japan and China were urged by implication to compose the North China crisis peacefully by Secretary of State Cordell Hull tonight in a statement of American foreign policy after China had appealed to the United States and thirteen other governments in identic memoranda in the name of the Nine-Power treaty, the Kellogg pact and the covenant of the League of Nations for their assistance in encouraging peace.

BARRY, RICHARD (Jan. 3, 1937). Gross assets. $90.624; net, $5,955. To brother, John T. Barry. Chief assets. real estate, $90,000; mortgages, note. cash and insurance. $514; transfers, $109. Rice Maguire. attorneys, 122 E. 42d St., Manhattan.
The word is that RKO Radio is making practically nothing but comedy these days and, if they're all as good as "Super-Sleuth," the new one at the Roxy, it will be all right with me.

A course in the practical operation of a zoo is being conducted for college students by the Staten Island Zoological Society, 640 Broadway, West New Brighton, it was announced yesterday by Carol Stryker, the director.

Germany's first unfavorable trade balance in more than two years was reported today for June. The favorable trade balance, which has been steadily declining in recent months, finally disappeared entirely, leaving, instead, an import excess of 23,000,000 reichsmark.
Mayor La Guardia bore down with a heavy hand yesterday on rowdyism and gangsterism at Orchard Beach Park, the new bathing beach opened a year ago near City Island in the Bronx.
Frank Morrison, secretary of the American Federation of Labor, said today that its membership had increased 652,000 since John L. Lewis's ten C. I. O. unions were suspended last September.

To sports Etditor of The New York Times: It's beginning to appear that no major league baseball game is quite complete without a good free-for-all fight. This is no letter of condemnation. I'm for it--provided all these fights are the real thing!

Merchants throughout Harlem suspended business for fifteen minutes shortly after noon yesterday in support of a protest against WPA payroll reductions staged in their midst by the City Projects Council and the Workers Alliance.

United in a move to protect their interests in the event of Philippine independence, American exporters yesterday launched a drive to finance a fight for modification of the act under which the islands will be freed. The exporters are insisting upon special reciprocal trade...
BAR HARBOR, Me., July 17.-- Mrs. Johnston de Forest and her daughter, Miss Priscilla de Forest of New York, are here visiting Miss Harriet V.C. Ogden at Okeden for a fortnight.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 17 (AP). --A four-hit pitching performance by Howard Krist in the nightcap gave the Rochester Red Wings a double victory over Jersey City today. Krist gained a 3-to-2 verdict over. Glen Gabler after Norbert Kleinke and Tony Kaufmann bested...

NEW ALBANY, Ind., July 17 (AP). --At 78 Everett Sylvester, former circus acrobat, sprints daily over his own cinder track. "I took up running for exercise when I was 68," he said. "I may have to give it up when I get old."

THE gay old city of Cremonia is unusually dressed up this year, and is receiving many visitors. Flags are afloat over her candy-striped palaces, banners are flung upon her turreted walls. From a slope overlooking the great Plain of Lombardy, in...

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 17.--The American team of skiing champions has been witnessing since yesterday one of the most severe snowstorms to strike this country in many years. The snow was accompanied today by rain and hurricane winds.

Exchange conditions in Central and South America continued to improve during the quarter just closed, according to the survey of credits and collections in Latin-American markets, completed yesterday by the foreign department of the National Association of Credit Men.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 17 (AP).-- When residents of Maple Avenue complained of the racket being made by starlings in the neighborhood, a squad of police marksmen, led by Captain William A. Giesa, embarked on a starling hunt and brought down 600 of the birds in a single night.

A hundred of the "best books of ancient and modern thought," ranging from Plato to Marx, will form the basis of the brand new curriculum which is being planned this Summer for one of the oldest colleges in the United States, St. John's College at Annapolis.

EDWARD WEISMILLER is the poet chosen for 1936 to be printed in the Yale Series of Younger Poets. He is 21, was born in Wisconsin and is now a junior in Corneli College. Mr. Weismiller is not so interesting a poet as Muriel Rukeyser...

SHORT-WAVE stations W2XAD and W2XAF at Schenectady, N.Y., will be among the strong est in the world upon completion of a new 100-kilowatt transmitter in the early part of next year. Permission to erect the transmitter has been granted the General Electric...

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16.--Appointment of Harry Bridges as Western regional director of the Committee for Industrial Organization is already being used by critics and enemies of the committee to bolster their statement that it is an "ultra-radical" if not "communistic"...

BASED on the experience of the Hudson Motor Car Company, an ever-growing group of drivers are ready and willing to dispense with the gearshift lever in favor of a more modern method of control plus the advantages of a clear front compartment.

TWO new land receiving stations, extending marine radiotelephone service already estab lished in New York and Boston harbors, have been placed in service, according to an announcement of the New York Telephone Company.

MUNICH, Germany, July 17.--Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the Minister of Propaganda, in an impassioned attack today on art criticism in Germany during the post-war era, blamed Jewish critics for causing art to decline and degenerate until National Socialism arose wrathfully...

Mortimer Lanzit, executive director of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, in a statement issued yesterday, attacked the proposed increase in the $2.87 dress range to $3.25 as "unwise and unsound" from both industrial and commercial standpoints.

A daily symposium on "Unifying Influences in a Democracy" will feature the Williamstown Institute of Human Relations, to be held on the campus of Williams College, Williamstown, Mass., from Aug. 29 to sept. 3, Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, director of the institute, announced yesterday.

HYANNIS, Mass.--Sports continue to hold the spotlight in the Cape Cod Summer colo nies. Most active of all the sports groups are the yacht clubs, which are scheduled to start many of their interclub series shortly. Continuing the custom of the last...
A model community will rise in Oregon from the ashes of a disastrous fire which swept through Bandon-by-the-Sea, an industrial town with a population of about 1,500, about a year ago.

MEXICO, D.F., July 17.--The payment of salaries by checks instead of cash caused a strike today of workers at the Mexican Telephone Company, a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company. All service was stopped at noon.

A delightful article in the Travel Section of today's TIMES invites all readers to the gay old city of Cremona, where is being celebrated the two hundredth anniversary of the death of STRADIVARI, who "brought the violin "to its highest perfection and left Cre"mona an imperishable name."

CLEVELAND, July 17.--With no winning streak of their own to worry about, the Yanks snapped a Cleveland string today at League Park before 12,000 fans. Off to a 3-0 lead in three innings, a margin that was intact at the end of the fifth, the champions saw...

MOSCOW, July 17.--Preparations are in full swing now for the elections to be held this Fall--the first under the new Constitution's provisions for the secret ballot and equality of rural and urban representation.
CLEARING its docket of ... pending applications, Broadcasting Division the Federal Communication Commission during the past was granted permits for construction eleven new stations.
BEEBE, Ark., July 17.--Death by lightning came at almost the same hour yesterday to three Detroit children vacationing with Southern relatives at widely separated points.

A series of eight programs, comprising fourteen films, was ennounced yesterday by the Museum of Modern Art Film Library for circulation during the Fall season to museums, colleges and film study groups throughout the country.

SMALL paintings by American artists have been assembled for the July show at the Kraushaar Galleries. Included in the exhibition are canvases by Louis Bouche, Richard Lahey, John Sloan, George Luks, Gifford Beal, Reynolds Beal, Ernest Lawson, Ann Brockman...

WHEN the 1938 edition of the American standard stamp catalogue is published, a few months hence, four French colonies in Africa--philately's Chad, Gabon, Middle Congo and Ubangi--will disappear from its pages except historically.
VICTOR, N.Y., July 17.--Lipstick served as war paint and firecrackers for gunfire as the French General Denonville's battle with the Seneca Indians was re-enacted here today.

NICE, July 17.--Mrs. Harriet Chalmers Adams, explorer, died here today. Her husband, George Pierce Adams, was at her bedside.

LONDON, July 17.--The French franc continued today its dotvnward trend in the foreign exchange market here, falling rapidly at the opening from 130 to 132 1/8 to the pound, but it recovered later, closing at 122.

South Brooklyn residents who have threatened to stage a bathtowel march on the Summer City Hall at College Point, Queens, fail "to make any sense," in the opinion of Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, who defended work being done on municipal baths at President Street and Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, in a letter sent over the week-end to Alderman William O'Reilly of 472 Butler Street.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the thirty-nine weeks ended on May 29 a net profit of $5,561,032 after all deductions but before providing for possible surtax on undistributed profits. The profit was equal to $53.93 each on 103,107 preferred shares, on which arrears on June 1 were $20.21 1/4 a share,

Seml-Final Round--Williamson Pell Jr., Apawamis, and Milton P. Warner, Woodway, defeated V. E. Cooley, Apawamis, and Henry C. Flower, Round Hill, 1 up (twenty holes); Townsend Wainwright, Apawamis, and John W. Lewis, Round Hill, defeated Curtis Berrien, Apawamis, and John Wing, unattached, 4 and 2. Final Round-Pell and Warner defeated Wainwright and Lewis, 1 up (nineteen holes).

The Committee for Industrial Organization does not intend to enter the building service field, according to assurances given yesterday by Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers and a leader in the C. I. O., to James J. Bambrick, president of Local 32B of the Building Service Employes Union, which is affiliated with the A. F. of L.

Dr. Percy Gardner, Professor Emeritus of Classical Archaeology at Oxford University, died at Oxford today at the age of 90. Having begun his career as an expert on ancient coins at the British Museum,
It is the irony of Mr. ROOSEVELT'S fight on the Supreme Court that the driving force behind it is supposed to be popular

White, Weld Co., fiscal agent for Oslo Light Works, formerly Oslo Gas and Electricity Works, 5 per cent bonds, due March 1, 1963, has drawn for redemption through operation of the sinking fund $87, 000 of this issue. The drawn bonds will become due and payable on Sept. 1 next at par and accrued interest.
Federal Judge Julian W. Mack has given up a European trip to expedite the settlement of important issues in the receivership of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Fonda, Johnstown Gloversville Railroad Company had a deficit of $2,324 in June, compared with a deficit of $12,460 for the same month last year, according to a statement issued by J. Ledlie Hees, trustee.

Fred J. Noonan, Amelia Earhart's 44-year-old navigator on her attempt tQ fly around the world, was a master mariner with twenty-two years of ocean travel behind him, a former transport pilot and one of the foremost authorities on aerial navigation.

Brig. Gen. Frank K. Fergusson, commanding officer of the Sixtysecond Coast Artillery, died yesterday morning in his quarters at Fort Totten, Bayside, Queens. He was 63 years old. Death was believed caused by a heart attack.

Impelled to issue a statement after seeing published reports that he would soon be dismissed, Dr. Tyler Dennett, president of Williams College since 1934, announced tonight that he had resigned a month ago and that his resignation had been accepted on July 9 at a meeting of the board of trustees in New York.
Offerings to the public will be made today of a new issue of $1,500,000 of city of Richmond, Va., 3 per cent public-improvement bonds by a banking group comprising Blvth Co., Inc.;

Three times this week the Dutch equalization fund reduced by 1/8 cent the guilder's peg to the dollar, getting the ratio down to 1.81 1/2 to the dollar, because of the combined influences of weakness of the United States currency and strength of the guilder.

Mike Cestone, Montclair letter carrier, and Roy Corey, his Branch Brook partner, today won the fifth annual New Jersey State amateur best-ball golf championship when they defeated Don Morano and E. W. Holmberg of the Forest Hill Field Club, 5 and 3, in an eighteenhole final at the Rock Spring Club.

Mayor William H. Williams of Belleville will wed Miss Lucile Slocum Joseph, teacher of French in the Bloomfield (N. J.) High School, on Aug. 12, the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Oscar L. Joseph of Paterson, N. J., parents of the bride-to-be, announced today.

A renewal of neutral efforts to make peace in Spain was urged in a statement signed by prominent Americans and released yesterday by the Department of International Justice and Goodwill of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.

Christ would be a labor leader if he were alive today and would be in the forefront of any movement to provide healthful recreation and to rid the screen of indecent pictures, the Rev. John B. Delaunay declared yesterday in a sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral. More than 2,500 visitors and parishioners heard Father Delaunay, dean of men at Portland University, Oregon, who is preaching at the cathedral this month.

Varied entertainments were held today for Sunday guests. Judge and Mrs. Edward Ridley Finch gave a luncheon at the Southampton Beach Club for the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Suffragan Bishop of New York, who conducted the services this morning at St. Andrew's Dune Church and who passed Sunday with Judge and Mrs. Finch at Little Sunswyck.

Monroe St, 249, 26.8x943; Roosevelt Savings Bank to Jean Wolf, 237 Utica Ave, Brooklyn. ($33.) Lexington Ave, 1,653; Henry Kopf to Edith Banar, 32-75 44th St, Long Island City. (75 cents.) 7th Ave, 1,838, 33.6x100; Benjamin Bernstein to Greenwax Realty Co, Inc, 521 5th Ave, c/o Morris Remson. ($36.)
Immediate removal from New York of Henry Gerke, charged by the government with being a "backer" of a large scale liquor smuggling ring, was asked today by the United States Attorney's office.

The 6,000 acres of the Camp Upton military reservation will be opened as public hunting grounds as a result of an agreement made with the War Department giving the State Conservation Department limited jurisdiction over the land. Camp Upton is located in the town of Brookhaven, Suffolk County, L. I., and the reservation affords "fairly good quail, pheasant and rabbit territory," it is stated.

Lack of religious faith reflects itself in social life in a breakdown of law and order, the Rev. John Walter Houck, the pastor, said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse and 175th Street, the Bronx. Godlessness, he held, "means unbelief in religion and lawlessness in our social life."

A total of 1,052 New York City candidates for the Civilian Conservation Corps will be examined by army medical officers today at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street. Tomorrow eighty-two ex-service men, who have been certified
Mrs. Harry L. Rollins and Leighton Rollins gave a tea in the water garden at Greycroft this afternoon in honor of Miss Josephine Hull, star of "You Can't Take It With You."

For those who are mathematically minded or who like to jot down figures on a pad and then have an answer ready almost by the time you have finished reading them the problem, the following bit of data is recommended.

At the Montauk Yacht Club tonight Mr. and Mrs. C. H. Ferris gave a dinner for friends who are with them on their yacht, Penguin. Captain Harold A. White of East Hampton also entertained at dinner, and Mr. and Mrs. Louis R. Wasey, who are at their lake shore estate, gave a luncheon.

George Wallace Jr. of New Brunswick, N. J., 25-year-old auto racing driver, was killed and two spectators injured in the crash of Wallace's car against an inside rail in the feature race at the Bucks County fair grounds today.

Prudential Investors, Inc., reports for the six months ended on June 30, 1937, net income, excluding profits from securities sold, of $188,251, which, after dividends of $138,888 paid and accrued on the $6preferred stock, amounted to $49,363 available for the common stock, according to the semi-annual report issued to stockholders by J. M. Miller-Aichholz, president.

Senator Antonio R. Barcelo, head of the Liberal party and an independence advocate, in a statement today said that he is not in favor of a plebiscite on the statehood and independence issue now because independence would be defeated.

TIENTSIN--Japanese Army leaders in North China announced that General Sung Cheh-yuan, commander of the Chinese Twenty-ninth Army, had accepted their demands in an oral agreement and had promised to withdraw his troops from the trouble zone.

Lieut. Col. German Busch, chief of the army general staff and new President of Bolivia, told assembled officials today the army forced Colonel David Toro to resign as President because of his "negligence."

Miss Constance Alden Baker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Sherman Baker of Maplewood, has selected Sept. 18 for her marriage to Jay Tongate Rodgers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur T. Rodgers of Maplewood. The ceremony will be performed in Morrow Memorial Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. John E. Charlton.

The Old Westbury poloists remained undefeated in the current season tonight, possessors of the historic Meadow Brook Club Cups, presented to them by Mrs. C. V. Whitney, wife of their captain, after the hardest sort of final match for the club championship in which the Foxhunters rode stirrup to stirrup with them for four periods, finally to lose by 12 to 10.
Because Germany, Italy and Britain are adding a demand for sulphite pulp for munitions manufacture to an increased requirement of the commodity for ordinary commercial uses, a world shortage impends.

Miss Earlene White, postmistress of the United States Senate, was revealed today as the only active candidate in the field for the presidency of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women as the first few hundred delegates arrived for the biennial convention, opening here tomorrow.

Miss Sonya Stokowski of New York, daughter of Leopold Stokowski and Mrs. Olga Samaroff Stokowski, who is passing the Summer at her mother's residence in Seal Harbor, was hostess at tea today at the Jordan Pond house, Seal Harbor, to a group that included Miss Laura Blair and Miss Margot Finletter of New Yonrk.
Benny Leonard, former pugilist and undefeated retired champion, will open today his new restaurant in the five-story building at 174 West Seventy-second Street, near Broadway.

Bilingual money-printed in both English and French-will appear in tellers' cages at the Bank of Canada tomorrow. The current stock of 1935 bank notes will be withdrawn gradually from circulation as they are worn out and turned into the bank for cancellation.

Construction of two playgrounds in Stuyvesant Park at Fifteenth Street and Second Avenue has been barred permanently by the Court of Appeals in a decision sustaining lower court rulings restraining Park Commissioner Robert Moses from using that area for recreation areas.

The British steel industry is gravely concerned over the fact that virtually all shipments of iron ore from Bilbao, Spain, have been cut off since its capture by the Rebels a month ago, it became known tonight.

More than 5,000 persons attended an outdoor celebration last night at Midland Park, Grant City, S. I., in honor of the seventy-fifth birthday of Ella Reeve Bloor. Arranged by members of the Communist party, the celebration for "Mother" Bloor-the name under which she is best known-drew persons from the five boroughs, as well as from Cleveland, Detroit, Hartford, Newark and Trenton.

The Federal Theatre Project's return to the Broadway area, scheduled for tomorrow night with the allNegro musical "Swing It," is off for a couple of days-until Thursday, at the Adelphi. Official explanation: costume trouble.

Melvin C. Hutson, circuit solicitor of the judicial district of which Morgan County is a part, said today that he was eager to clear the docket of the remaining trials in the Scottsboro cases in which nine Negroes are accused of attacking two white girls on a freight train six and a half years ago.

The Economist's Index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on July 14 at 85, compared with 84.3 a fortnight before, 84.2 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

The man who is essentially religious and high-minded is the one who is up-to-date, not the person who pursues every passing fad and fashion, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, the pastor, asserted yesterday morning in his sermon at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 120th Street. Speaking on "The Dignity of Being Up-toDate," he said:

Mrs. John Jay White of 122 East Seventy-sixth Street, New York, who had been prominent in various movements for women's rights and international peace, died here today at her home, The Kedge, after an illness of several weeks.
John W. O'Leary of Chicago, an official of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said today that machines had increased rather than decreased employment.

Eddie Morgan, old-time featherweight boxer, died today at the Philadelphia General Hospital of complications aggravated by the heat. His age was 43. Once rated among the cleverest men in the British Isles, he came to this country in 1911 to seek the featherweight title.
The Rev. Frank Landon Humphreys, author, chaplain and former canon of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, died here early today after an illness of six months. He was 79 years old.

Steelmakers give the most positive evidence of belief in continued strength and expectation of renewed buying after the usual Summer slackness, as demonstrated by the snapping back of production promptly after the removal of the labor blockade, the magazine Steel says this week.

The Governor of Chiriqui Province left by airplane yesterday withGaston J. Von Steck, who, with an American and German, claims the discovery of eighty gold ingots in a mine abandoned in colonial times.

Total obligations for public relief in the United States were about $12,000,000 less in March than in that month last year, and about $11,000,000 less in February than in February, 1936, the Social Security Board reported today.

A ten-fold increase in existing birth-control clinics to 3,000 is recommended by Mrs. Margaret Sanger, birth-control leader, in a report on the seven years' work of the National Committee on Federal Legislation for Birth Control, which will be issued today by the organization's executive committee.
The United States Employment Service placed 224,692 persons in jobs with private industry in June, 81.9 per cent more than in June, 1936, Secretary of Labor Perkins announced today.

The little book that bears this title is designed expressly for seamen who, in the course of their vocation, visit ports to which they are usually strangers or with whose seafronts alone they are acquainted. Naturally, there must be constant revision, for to be useful the handbook must be accurate.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler announced today that in future works of art that were not immediately comprehensible to the average German or that exemplified what he termed "artistic bolshevism" would be suppressed.

The Trans-Lux Movies Corporation has leased from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company a theatre which lessor is to erect on a plot on the southwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Fifty-second Street. The theatre building will be on the southerly portion of the plot,
A United States oil company executive told an Oxford Movement house party today that he had solved labor troubles an his fleet of oil tankers by applying religious principles to the group.

Banishment of worry and care from the world would lead to serenity and happiness, the Rev. Dr. John J. McIlvaine, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of New Castle, Pa., said yesterday morning in a sermon in the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twentieth Street. Prayer, he declared, is the best way to bring about this banishment.

After dropping their eleventh straight game to Newark when the league leaders beat them, 12 to 4, in the opener, the Bisons finally proved the Bears are not entirely invincible by gaining a 6-to-5 verdiet in the abbreviated nightcap of a double-header today.
The vanguard of foreign tennis aces, who will participate in the extensive Eastern grass court schedule winding up with the national tournament at Forest Hills next September, will arrive this week.

A brief survey of representative naval opinion here seems to show that the service welcomes the provisions of the new Naval Officers' Promotion Bill, which was recently introduced by Representative Vinson of Georgia.

One section of the revised Federal Hours and Wages Bill, evidently not considered especially noteworthy by the committee that drafted it, is none the less important both in itself and for what it indicates regarding the nature and possible consequences of the measure as a whole. This is Section 8 (c):

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ware Eaton entertained at a picnic supper tonight in a grove at Indian Cave, Monterey. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Sumner Edmands, Miss Patricia Edmands, Joseph Turner, Dr. August Raggi, Mr. and Mrs. Maro Tribuno and Mr. and Mrs. John Tribuno.
The death list in the wreck of the Calcutta express reached 107 today as authorities continued their investigation of one of the worst rail disasters in India's history.

The Bethpage Shamrocks of Farmingdale, L. I., met defeat, 5--4, at the hands of a Squadron C combination today. The home outfit registered all its goals in the first half of the match, getting two in each of the first and second periods and another one in the third.

The Rev. Joseph E. Lennon, dean of Teachers College of Fordham University, announced yesterday that four-year scholarships to the college had been awarded to Margaret Mary Kennedy of 471 West 165th Street and Harriet Antoine Martiri of 23 Hyatt Avenue, Yonkers. The scholarships have a value of $1,000 each.

During the Summer American citizens are using $500,000,000 worth of outdoor recreational facilities constructed in connection with the Works Progress Administration program, Harry L. Hopkins, administrator, announced today.

Police Sergeant Edward F. Tucker while off duty early today strolled out of a restaurant at 1,001 Broad Street in time to notice a young man trying to start a car. Tucker watched for a few minutes and then asked:

The Reds today took two games from the Bees behind rookie pitchers, 4 to 1 and 1 to 0. Right-hander Ray (Peaches) Davis set the home club down with five hits and then Lee Grissom, a lean left-hander, shut out the Bees on two hits.
From a purely financial point of view, there was no reason this week for the securities market to be upset. Results of the Socialist Party Congress, however, were awaited with some anxiety.

The situation in Yugoslavia with regard to the struggle of the Orthodox Church to prevent the government from carrying out its plan of forcing through the ratification of the concordat before the end of the month is so serious that it is hardly an exaggeration to speak of the "holy war" proclaimed by the national church against the Stoyadinovitch government.
Fritz Reiner returned to the podium of the Lewisohn Stadium last night to conduct the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra in a lengthy and varied program. An audience of 4,000 persons was on hand.

The launching of a campaign to obtain $100,000 for development of the west end of Roosevelt Memorial Park as an athletic field was announced today by Wyllys Rossiter Betts, chairman of a citizens' committee of 300.

Goodness is often feeble and dull because it has elements of coldness and doubt, the Rev. Dr. Charles R. Brown, dean emeritus of Yale Divinity School, declared in a sermon here yesterday. He urged a more positive moral attitude to achieve joy. Preaching at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, he said:
The Cunard White Star motorship Britannic arrived yesterday from the Channel ports with 535 passengers, of whom 201 were in the cabin class.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 83 per cent of capacity, up 2 points from the rate of last week after the holiday.
Great Britain's steel output in June amounted to 1,106,400 tons, compared with 1,047,300 in May, 965,900 in June, 1936, and the high record of 1,109,500 in March.

More dollars are rolling into the farmer's pockets this year than in any years since 1929. Department of Agriculture economists delved into statistics today and calculated that the 1937 cash income of farmers would be around $9,500,000.000.
Noble Kizer, athletic director and head football coach at Purdue University, was rushed to St. Elizabeth's Hospital today in what was described as a "serious" condition.

The Building Service Employes Union, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, threatened to call a strike within twenty-four hours in all buildings whose operators decline to sign a labor contract with the organization.

Only five weeks out of Sing Sing after serving seven and a half years for burglary, Wyman Jennings, 37 years old, a Negro, of 275 West 144th Street, known as "Cat's Eye," was again in difficulties with the law yesterday, this time on a charge of suspicion of burglary.

Representative Hamilton Fish asked Secretary Morgenthau in a letter made public today whether the Treasury ever had officially ruled that an individual might turn over directly to charitable institutions any moneys earned and thus avoid payment of an income tax upon such sums.
The German capital market is more active and new industrial bonds are being issued. The total of industrial bonds issued in the half-year to June 30 was 250,000,000 marks.

More than a dozen men bathers on the beach of the Municipal Bathing Pavilion were asked to put on tops to their bathing suits when they made an attempt to disregard the ruling that no topless suits would be allowed.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Katharine Preuss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Preuss of Richmond Hill, Queens, to Lieutenant Thomas D. Neier, U.S.A.. of Queens Village.

William A. Parshall, Corporation Counsel of Port Jervis for twentyfive years, died here last night at the age of 72. A native of Walden, N. Y., he prepared for college at the Port Jervis High School, was graduated from Yale in 1888 and the Albany Law School in 1890 and had practiced here since his admission to the bar.

Squelching a five-run rally in the seventh and last inning, the Rea Wings barely managed to squeeze out an 8-to-7 victory over the Jersey City Giants in the nightcap of today's double-header. The Wings dropped the first game to Ben Cantwell, 5 to 0.

A remarkable performance by Dick Floyd, No. 3 for the invaders, featured a thrilling 7-6 victory scored by the South Shore Polo Club of Cedarhurst, L. I., over the Blind Brook Esquires in their Easttern League match today at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club. He accounted for all of the goals made by the Long Islanders except the two allotted by handicap.
Airplane sleeper service with only three stops between New York and the West Coast will be started tomorrow by United Air Lines. Eight new planes are to be added to the United fleet.

The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board handled 429 industrial disputes during June, of which 115, involving 42,448 workers, were adjusted, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director, reported yesterday. She said 244 new cases were received during the month.

Humanity must admit the light of God into its deliberations and disinfect its great structure with the sunlight of truth if the world is to be cured from its disease, the Rev. Worcester Perkins declared yesterday before the congregation in the Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Wall Street and Broadway.
The White Sox took both ends of a doubleheader from the Red Sox before 30,000 fans today, winning the first game 6 to 5 in ten innings and the second 1 to 0.

Joan Keane, 2 years old, was found early yesterday morning locked in a stairwell at the top of Public School 126, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, after having been missing for thirty-five hours while about seventy-five detectives and policemen combed the section for her.

The Davega Stores Corporation, through its operating organization, Davega-City Radio, Inc., has leased from the Henry Phipps Estates the ground floor store on the Fiftieth Street corner of Madison Square Garden on the west side of Eighth Avenue between Forty-ninth

Father Divine is feeling right well these days, he has informed a disciple who is in jail here. John West Hunt, convicted of violating the Mann Act, said that Father Divine had reminded him in a letter that the sentence "was not as severe as it might have been," and that the letter concluded:
Senator a Borah of Idaho proposed today that the Senate, before resuming its court fight, join the House in overriding President Roosevelt's veto of low interest rates on Federal farm loans.

Seconds separated the first three yachts today in the fourth of a series of six elimination events to select a crew to represent the Great South Bay international Star fleet in the forthcoming world and North Atlantic Coast championships.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral and vicar general of the Archdiocese of New York, blessed and laid the cornerstone yesterday for the new St. Valentine's Roman Catholic Church under construction on 221st Street near Barnes Avenue, the Bronx.
Details of the program of the Fashion and Silk Merchandise Forum which will be held tomorrow under the auspices of the International Silk Guild were announced yesterday by that organization.

Seldom wavering during the match, T. Suffern (Tommy) Tailer of Piping Rock, former metropolitan amateur champion, today won the Rockaway Hunting Club's annual invitation golf tourney with a wellearned triumph over Carl W. Timpson by 4 and 3.
