The Army Air Corps has bought a new fighter so radical in design, so strong in striking power and of such exceptional performance both in climb and speed that entirely new tactics are to be devised to use it to the best advantage.
The stock markets here have fallen into a state of pronounced stagnation, from which there is little hope for change until after the holiday period that now is getting into full swing.

Heavier promotional campaigns on home furnishings lines were seen here yesterday as necessary for Fall to facilitate consumer acceptance of the 10 to 15 per cent price advance at retail on this merchandise.

Whether the church will resume a dominant place in world affairs will depend in large part upon the success of the Universal Conference on Christian Life and Work now being held in Oxford, Professor Samuel H. Prince, of King's University, Halifax, N. S., said yesterday in an address at St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, Sixty-ninth Street and Broadway.

Miss Helen Germaine, Manhattan, and Mrs. Ingrid Lakatos, also of Manhattan, seeded first and second, respectively, reached the final round of the metropolitan public parks women's singles tennis tourney yesterday at Walker Park, West Brighton, S. I.

Ted is going to have a home in the country. Clarence Gottman, a farmer, seeing a police dog by the roadside today anxiously scanning every passing automobile, stopped. He found a note, in a woman's handwriting attached to the dog's collar. It read:

Harvesting of the new oats crop, while delayed by rains in certain sections, has made considerable progress and a material increase movement is expected this week. Reports indicate that yield in Central Illinois are above expectations.
The annual convention of officials of Weights and Measures Department of the State of New York will be held tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday at the Hotel Commodore. Mayor La Guardia,

A major test of Protestant church unity will be precipitated tomorrow when the delegates from all parts of the world to the Conference on Church, Community and State begin drafting a pronouncement on the Christian attitude toward war.

Two crack spelling teams, one representing the Girl Scouts, the other the Y. M. C. A., spelled to a draw yesterday in a contest at Station WABC broadcast over a coastto-coast radio network. The sixteen members of each team were picked by earlier competitions from all parts of the city. Ages of the participants ranged from 10 to 14.

Ten pitchers took plenty of punishment today-with honors nearly evenand when it was all over the Browns and the Athletics had broken even in a double-header. St. Louis captured the first contest, 10 to 6, while Philadelphia bounced back to take the second, 7 to 6.

Herold H. Reinecke, in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation office here, reported that agents had arrested Raymond Driscoll, under indictment in New Jersey and Pennsylvania for bank robberies, in the home of relatives at Gary early today.

Limerick and the Jersey Rangers played an 11-to-ll tie in a senior hurling game at Innisfail Park yesterday afternoon before 1,500 persons. In a junior game of gaelic football which preceded the hurling contest the Gaelic Americans defeated Yonkers, 25 to 3.

Margaret C., beloved wife of Oscar F., a resident of Yonkers, N. Y., for over forty years; born in Roscommon. Ireland. Survived by a brother and sister. Burial Calvary Cemetery. English papers please copy. BAYER--July 17, 1937, Nancy Hammond, beloved wife of the late Captain Charles Bayer, Sandy Hook pilot.

Mr. and Mrs. Morgan Belmont of 434 East Fifty-seventh Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Mason Belmont, to Ellsworth N. bailey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Layton Bailey of 21 East Ninety-fourth Street.

The United States and Germany, playing presumably to see who will beat Great Britain for the Davis Cup, will send their doubles teams out on Wimbledon's famed center court tomorrow to break the 1-1 tie in the interzone final.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a few days Spain will enter upon the second year of its civil war. May I, through your columns, ask for peace? I am only too painfully aware of the difficulties that stand in the way.

Magistrate Anna M. Kross in Harlem Court yesterday ordered sixteen men said to have been patrons of a raided disorderly house to undergo a physical examination by the Board of Health before appearing in court again on Wednesday.

Speculative interest in the wheat market here expanded considerably last week,aggregate sales of all futures on the Board of Trade being 348,014,000 bushels, almost 62,000,000 in excess of the previous week and almost 73,000,000 more than in the corresponding period in 1936.
Production and domestic consumption of petroleum led the field for United States minerals in 1936 and established a new high record, the Bureau of Mines reported today.

Several American ship lines operating in the domestic trade routes would face ruin if obliged to increase their wages and other operating costs, according to the American Steamship Owners Association.

Eel, sailed by Mrs. Charles E. Lucke Jr., of Cranford, and Donald Sayia of Montclair, today placed second in the fifth and final race of the Barnegat Bay International Star Class eliminations and as a resuit won the series.

More than 2,500 persons attended a funeral service yesterday for Dr. Abram Coralnik, associate editor of The Jewish Day, Yiddish-language daily newspaper. A well-known writer and Zionist leader, he died last Friday of a heart ailment at the Mount Kisco (N. Y.) Hospital at the age of 54.

More adequate compensation for city laboratory technicians was urged yesterday in letters made public by the City Affairs Committee, addressed to Health Commissioner John L. Rice and Hospitals Commissioner S. S. Goldwater.

Senator Wagner of New. York asserted, in a statement issued today, that the tine for study of the housing problem had passed and that it now was time for immediate action. He urged passage of the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill providing for public subsidies for low-cost housing projects.
The outlook for German crops is uncertain. The latest monthly report shows that the Winter wheat, Winter rye, barley and most of the root crops improved in June.

Henry Nordman, 69 years old, of Sparta, was burned to death and four persons were injured when the machine in which Nordman was riding collided with a car driven by Mrs. Althea Buckley, 33 years old, of 79 North Sussex Street, Dover, this morning at North Sussex and McFarland Streets.
William Green summoned the American Federation of Labor's executive council today to meet Aug. 21 in Atlantic City, N. J., to prepare a Fall campaign against John L. Lewis.

One of the largest crowds of the season gathered at Bailey's 'Beach this morning, but many hurried away early because of luncheon parties. Among those entertaining were Mrs. H. B. H. Ripley at Beachbound, Mrs. Reginald Norman at Belair, Miss Julia A. Berwind at the Elms, the Misses Wetmore

The Oxford-Cambridge tennis team continued along the victory path today, registering a 5-to4 triumph over a squad of Harvard and Yale graduates in a special round-robin series of nine doubles matches contested on the grass courts of the Rockaway Hunting Club.

Lowell Limpus, William A. Blake, Emanuel B. Cohen, Lawrence L. Strauss, Edward C. Seward, Rose C. Silleck, Babette S. Shakman, in Essex House, 160 Central Park S. Martin de Bothelo, in 340 Park Ave; Dr. Louis Longman, Dr. Lester Tuchman, in 895 Park Ave; Albert J. Mendes, in 136 E 36th St; Mrs. Clyde Y. Rutherford, in 346 E 52d St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, broker.

Gold imports in Great Britain in June amounted to [pound]32,016,371, making the total for the first half of this year [pound]167,931,230, against [pound]98,968,176 in the same period of 1986. Exports of the metal last month were [pound]27,725,792, bringing the half-year total to [pound]136,641,280.

Edward Krueger, manager of the safe deposit vaults of the Bank of Manhattan Company, Broadway and Havemeyer Street, Brooklyn, died Saturday of pneumonia at his home, 89-14 113th Street, Richmond Hill. He was born in Germany eighty-two years ago and had resided in Richmond Hill more than thirty-five years.
Although the banks here have reported the withdrawal of buying orders for stocks pending a decision on Anthony Eden's scheme for Spain, the securities market here this week was predominantly firm.

Ilmari, Salminen, Finnish Olympic runner, claimed world records in the 10,000 meters and six miles today after running the former in 30:05.6 and the latter in 29:08.4 at Kouvola. He made both marks in the same race.

Opening doors to opportunity is a specialty of religion, the Rev. Dr. Ray Freeman Jenney of the Park Central Presbyterian Church, Syracuse, N. Y., declared yesterday morning at a union service of five Brooklyn Heights churches, held at the First Presbyterian Church, Henry Street near Clark Street.

The great weakness of the Christian religion lies in the lack of the vital experience that Christ is alive, according to the Rev. Carlos G. Fuller, who preached the sermon at the Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church, 1,885 University Avenue, yesterday.
Alvin F. Fix, Democratio leader in York for many years and Deputy Secretary of the Commonwealth, died at his home here today after a short illness. He was 60 years old.

Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, who has been : described as the supreme pontiff of German neopaganism, has revealed that the National Socialist church policy aims at the slow but steady absorption of Christianity.

More than 3,000 business office workers, admitted to the American Newspaper Guild since the Guild's recent convention at St. Louis voted to affiliate with the C. I. O. will not participate in the national referendum on the question of their admission, Heywood Broun, president of the Guild, said here today.

Alfred M. Landon of Kansas was a guest today at the home of Hill Blackett of Winnetka, advertising executive, who was a director of public relations for the Republican National Committee during the 1936 Presidential campaign.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 92.5, which compares with 92.9 a week ago, 92.5 two weeks ago, 92 three weeks ago and 91.9 four weeks ago.

Jack A. Dryfoos, former chairman of the board of trustees of the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, of which he had been a member for eighteen years, died of a heart attack Saturday afternoon at his home, 77 Park Avenue, at the age of 52.

Delegates to a special session of the Railway Equipment Local Union, sponsored by the Committee for Industrial Organization, voted today against striking at this time at the Westinghouse Air Brake Company's plant in suburban Wilmerding.

Staging a gallant uphill fight after being 3 down at the ninth hole, the team of Williamson Pell Jr. and Milton P. Warner came through on the nineteenth to annex the premier honors in the renewed Apawamis Country Club invitation golf tournament today.
Dr. Jean Piccard's first flight in his novel craft, buoyed by multiple balloons, terminated in a hazardous tree-top, landing early today.

Although buyers in the wholesale market last week expressed enthusiasm regarding the variety and appeal of Fall apparel, purchasing was cautious and generally covered only requirements for early Fall selling. Activity was satisfactory on better dresses, although the demand for Fall silk styles met with some degree of scarcity, which is being remedied as new items are added to lines.

The rise in sterling which has followed the devaluation of the franc seems to be nearing its end. Some appreciation in the pound was inevitable after the events that had overwhelmed the franc, but the principal cause, the repatriation of French funds, already is losing its potency.

Two men who had clung to an overturned boat in Delaware Bay for sixteen hours were rescued by a passing motorboat about 9 o'clock this morning and brought to the Coast Guard base here semi-conscious. A companion who tried to swim to shore is believed to have drowned.

A field test for officers of the Sixtyfirst Cavalry Division, metropolitan area, was held at the Round Hill Stables today. The course was over twelve miles of open country, including twelve obstacles, such as fences and stone walls and a ford across the Byram River. It was the first of the kind ever held in this section.

Scoring a total of 32 points, the New York Pioneer Club athletes annexed the team crown at the annual Manhattan Athletic League track and field championships at the Castle Hill Athletic Park in the Bronx yesterday.

NEIL H. SWANSON enlisted in the Indian Wars several years ago with his novel "The Judas Tree." Readers who turn to history for romance and excitement only, talked of him as an American Stevenson, said that "The Judas Tree" was the best historical extravaganza written since the death of R. L. S.
Chester Alan Arthur, internationally known sportsman, art connoisseur, social leader and son of the late President Arthur, died today from a heart attack at his home here. His age was 72.

William Randall of 1,022 East Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, emplayed as a pressman by THE NEW YORK TIMES for the last ten years, died Saturday afternoon. His widow, the former Dorothy Fey; his mother, Mrs. Eliza Randall; a sister, Alice Randall, and two brothers, George and Alfred Randall, survive.

A one-man sit-down strike by the Rev. J. H. Ellis, pastor of the Haven Negro Methodist Church, until his congregation contributes $1,000 to refinance the church indebtedness brought a few protests today, cash nevertheless.

In a dolefully persuasive volume entitled " Progress and Catastrophe," STANLEY CASSON says: "Of all the inge"nious inventions of the human brain, "perhaps agriculture alone cannot be "turned to the destruction of the hu"man species."

A new of trade between the United States and Brazil may be opened by the mission to Washington of Arthur de Souza Costa, Brazilian Finance Minister, it was said today by Acting Finance Minister Villela.

The first signs of Arctic Winter cheered the Soviet North Pole camp today, easing the fear that the ice floe upon which it was encamped would break. The temperature dropped below freezing, to 30.2 degrees Fahrenheit, and snow fell.

The industrial building at 147-149 Thomas Street, Newark, N. J., was leased to Dari-Land Food Products, Inc., which will use the plant for the distribution of all types of dairy products. Sophie M. E. Beisel is the lessor. Louis Schlesinger, Inc., was the broker.

The best of the nation's trotters and pacers, led by a world's record-holder, Greyhound, were at the Old Orchard Beach mile track tonight awaiting the start tomorrow of two weeks of Grand Circuit racing.

The Grimesless Dodgers were no help to the Giants and certainly useless to themselves as they disappointed the 18,560 Flatbush fans who paid to see them cavort with the Cubs at Ebbets Field yesterday.

The observance of "visitors' day" by the 106th Infantry of Brooklyn, featured by sports events and a review for its chaplain, Captain Charles H. Webb, who will have reached retirement age of 64 on Aug. 20, attracted more than 5,000 visitors to Camp Smith today.
Speculative interest in the corn market here last week was relatively light, trade interest being centered on the wheat market.

Miss Nellie M. McGovern, who retired in January, 1934, after teaching in the New York public schools for thirty-five years, died yesterday at her residence, 224 East 237th Street, following a long illness, at the age of 63.

The first intimation that political as well as criminal charges may be brought against Henry G. Yagoda, former head of the political police, now awaiting trial, came today in a Pravda editorial calling him a "traitor."

" The Student Prince," the first of the Shubert productions to be presented at Randalls Island Stadium this season by Fortune Gallo and the New York Park Department, opens July 27 and will be followed the next week by Rudolf Friml's "The Firefly."

Merian C. Cooper has resigned as vice president of Selznick International to become a producer for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, it was announced over the reek-end. This development, in addition to indicating a further widening of the production ranks of MGM, is interpreted as an indication that Metro may join in the trend toward films in color.

Southern Blvd, 2,401 (11-3115); Luma Corp to Workmen's Mutual Life Insurance Society, Inc, 227 East 84th St; 5 years, interest as per bond, $22,500. Kelly St, 1,029 (10-2705); Min Davis Realty Corp to Guaranty Trust Co; 5 years, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent. $42,000.

Ralph M. Easley, chairman of the executive council of the National Civic Federation, made public yesterday a letter to President Roosevelt charging that members of the Communist party, avowed supporters of the Communist movement, and the left-wing Workers Alliance, an organization of unemployed, controlled the personnel and supervision of the Federal writers and theatre projects.

Loaded with more than 20,000 specimens of fishes, birds and reptiles, collected for the Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences during a six-month scientific expedition in the South Seas, George Vanderbilt's chartered yacht, the Cressida, returned to its home dock at Jacobs Shipyard on City Island yesterday afternoon.

The 1937 award for the best country newspaper correspondence will go to Finlay Petrie of Opal, Wyo. it was announced yesterday through The Associated Press by Wheeler McMillen, editor of Country Home Magazine, which sponsors the annual prize for "crossroads" journalism.

While Long Island Sound's famed weather showed what it can do when it r ally tries, Cornelius Shields took time out from his International One-Design sloop and from the afterguard of the Class J Yankee to sail Rebel, his brother Paul's Six-Meter, to a convincing triumph today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's special regatta.

The police arrested Steven Debreczeni today, charging he had tried to imitate William Tell but had had a bad aim. They said Debreczeni had tried to shoot an apple from the head of Joseph Szollosi at a rifle club meeting. Szollosi was wounded in the forehead.
The new Church Street Annex of the Postoffice will be opened on Oct. 4, Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday. The new building is in Church Street at Barclay Street.

The only hope of the world today is through acceptance of the principles of Jesus Christ, declared the Rev. Dr. Ralph H. Long in a sermon yesterday at the Lutheran-Advent Church, Broadway and Ninety-third Street. Dr. Long is executive secretary of the National Lutheran Council.

As a site for the construction of a large apartment house, an investing client of the Mandola Realty Company purchased from the Bank of New York and Trust Company the southerly block front on Avenue V between Homecrest Avenue and .Thirteenth Street, in the lower Flatbush section of Brooklyn. H.

Mrs. Frank W. Smith, former Democratic State Committeewoman, died yesterday at her home here following a brief illness. She was prominent in Warren County Democratic circles for many years. She was the widow of Frank W. Smith, Supervisor and banker of Warrensburg, who died in 1931.

Mr. and Mrs. Victor Garrett of New Brighton,' S. I., and Edgartown, Mass., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Mrs. Irene M. Garrett Emerson, to David Cabot Forbes of Milton, Mass. The ceremony was performed Saturday in Reno, Nev., in the presence of the bride's mother.
Following the death of Mrs. Dorothy May Garland, 31, a lawyer, last night in Hollywood Hospital, police have arrested Kay Tutwiler, 29, a minor film player, on a charge of suspicion of murder.

Developments within Tammany Hall this week were regarded last night as likely to govern the course of the coming Mayoralty campaign. The attitude taken by a majority of the district leaders will decide whether United States Senator Royal S. Copeland will stay in the Mayoralty race, it was believed. Mr. Copeland is the choice of Tammany Leader James J. Dooling.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, sharply assailed Heywood Broun, president of the American Newspaper Guild, in a statement today in which he said that Mr. Broun had "sold down the river" the newspaper men of the country and, in taking the Guild into the C. I. O., had been "inspired by some very astute Moscow-trained revolutionaries."

Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin will return from Europe Thursday on the Europa, and will go to Saratoga Springs after a stay at the Ambassador. Mr. and Mrs. A. Jacques Allez have returned to the St. Regis from Newport, to remain until they sail for Paris Saturday on the Champlain.

Finance Minister Georges Bonnet, who was busy all day with his financial advisers, tonight issued a statement to bolster the franc and weakening rentes. A series of measures, he declared, were in preparation to work economies and cut all extra budgetary expenditures except the essential defense program.

The end of Federal deficits was unanimously recommended in a report made public yesterday by the committee on government credit of the Twentieth Century Fund. The committee, chosen to represent a cross-section of American opinion, was headed by Oswald W. Knauth, president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation,

George Barton French, retired broker and railroad president, died suddenly last night of a heart attack at Darena, his country place here. He was 73 years old. Apparently in good health and spirits, Mr. French had passed the afternoon at the National Golf Links of America with Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, who was his classmate for two years at Columbia College fifty-five years ago.

Special exercises will be held in all Park Department playgrounds of Manhattan, Brooklyn, Bronx and Richmond tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock as the first move in a campaign to encourage more children to become regular patrons of the playgrounds, it was announced yesterday.
Argentina won the Pan-American Games triangular soccer tourney tonight with an 8-1 victory over Canada in the final game. Angel La Ferrara, 19-year-old center forward, scored four goals.

Additional transactions in equity securities of corporations by officers, directors and principal stockholders for May, with some transactions in earlier months for which delayed reports were received, were made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Frank G.Logan, art patron and founder of the grain and stock brokerage house of- Logan - Bryan, died this morning of a heart attack at his home. He was 85 years old.

Offering to the public will be made today by means of a prospectus, through Rawls Co., Inc., and Watson White, of a new issue of 20,000 shares of $1.25 convertible cumulative preferred stock of $15 par value of Kane's, Inc., of Boston.

An attempt to film the aurora borealis in color will be made by an expedition headed by Dr. Thomas H. Johnson, assistant director of the Bartol Research Foundation, of the Franklin Institute, which leaves this week for Hudson Bay.
Cotton prices turned downward last week, after having registered advances in the previous period. At the close on Saturday they were virtually at the same level as four weeks before.

William Sherman Weitzell, for forty-eight years in the business office of The Chattanooga Times before retiring in 1933 after many years as business manager, died this afternoon at his home here. He had been in ill health several years. His age was 70.

" Although our relations have been friendly I hope that the single battalion of the Twenty-ninth Army at present garrisoned here will withdraw," said Yin Ju-keng, East Hopei's chief executive, yesterdary. "We hope for peace, but in the event of hostilities it will be necessary that this force be disarmed."
Arthur H. Beaudry, New York City attorney, has purchased the five-story American basement residence at 59 East Sixty-sixth Street from the estate of Joseph E. Sterrett. The house occupies a plot 20

War and peace were President Manuel Azana's major themes today as he spoke before the members of his government and invited guests in the university amphitheatre commemorating the first anniversary of the republic's fight for its life against "foreign invaders."
The Soviet press treated the Chino-Japanese crisis in North China today with unaccustomed caution and official newspapers refrained from their usual fiery attacks on Japanese policy.

An audience estimated at more than 30,000 persons hear the concert given last night by the Goldman Band, under Edwin Franko Goldman, on the Mall in Central Park. Dr. Goldman said, when seen after the concert, that the attendance was the largest he had witnessed at any of the concerts he ever had conducted there.
Dr. Leslie Verne Case, retired Superintendent of Schools here, died at his home on Grove Street yesterday after a short illness. He was 62 years old.

The capture of the Candleston Castle, the second British steamer to be seized by Spanish Insurgents near Santander in a week, was announced by the British Admiralty, tonight. She was captured inside Spanish territorial waters at 7 o'clock Saturday morning and was taken to Ferrol, it was said.

Twenty-five cars of an eighty-fivecar freight train of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad were derailed and many overturned late last night when the train struck a broken rail one mile west of here. No one was injured.

While increased attention to the contamination of waters in the metropolitan area has been given in the last eight years by the States and communities affected, much work still remains to be done, the Regional Plan Association declared in a statement yesterday.

When war broke out in Spain no one would have predicted that a year later it would have taken a toll of lives estimated at 500,000, involved Europe in a series of major crises, and that still the two sides would be deadlocked in a desperate contest for Madrid.

There should be no sugar legislation until the international sugar agreement has had "an opportunity to work out," Clarence R. Bitting, largest sugar producer in Florida, stated today in letters sent to each member of the House and Senate.

The first rulings under the one-year-old Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission, with the issuance of orders to cease and desist in two cases and dismissal of two others.

A dwelling estimated to cost $21,000 is being erected for D. H. Lahn in the Colonial Village home community at Wilmot Woods, in the Scarsdale-Heathcote section of Westchester County, by the Haring Blumenthal Realty Corporation, developers of the property.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt and Herbert Bayard Swope Jr. jointly gave a party last night at the dinner and supper dance at the Sands Point Bath Club here. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Philip Ammidown, Mr.' and Mrs. Robert Brandt, Miss Gloria Baker, Miss Alice Leone Moats, Horace Kelland, David and Randolph Hearst and William Powell.

Miss Ethel C. Taylor, nationally known child welfare worker, died yesterday at her home here after a short illness. She was 46 years old. Miss Taylor, who for the last eight years had been head of the child welfare department of the New York School of Social Work, was born in Brooklyn and was graduated from Goucher College in 1913.

For every dollar spent for public construction in the first six months of 1937, $1.70 was spent for private construction, according to a report of the F. W. Dodge Corporation to the Public Works Administration made public today.

Fred L. Jacklitsch, former National League catcher and baseball coach at Amherst College and Rutgers University, died yesterday at his home, 139-36 226th Street, Laurelton, queens. He was 61 years old.
B. W. Huebsch, editor for The Viking Press, contributes an article entitled "Footnotes to a Publisher's Life," in the Summer issue of The Colophon, a Quarterly for Bookmen, published today.
The Jones Beach Water Ballet will be presented as a special attraction of the Shubert production of Cole Porter's "Gay Divorcee," which opens tonight at Jones Beach Stadium.

Passengers due today from London on the American Merchant of the United States Lines include Mr. and Mrs. Harvey D. Best, Mrs. Harry D. Johnson, Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Langdon, Miss Hannah Langdon, Mrs. J. H. Kerr, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Mattice and Commander and Mrs. C. A. Baker.
Once delayed by a sit-down strike, the Watkins Glen outboard regatta was finally completed late tonight with Jimmy Mullen of Richmond, Va., winning six trophies.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:
Dizzy Dean opined tonight it might be another ten days before he's back in the Cardinals' line-up and said his sore toe was so swollen "I can't get my shoe on."

It remains to be seen whether the Democratic party in this city will be put to the test of a fight in the primarines. Senator COPELAND, who at first expressed himself as unwilling to enter the lists " without the unanimous support" of all five county leaders, has now found the persuasion of a single one of them to be sufficient.

The hitting power in the shoulders of Joe DiMaggio proved greater than the throwing power in the mighty right arm of the sensational Bob Feller at Municipal Stadium today as the Yankees turned back the Indians for the second straight time before one of the season's largest baseball gatherings.

Wilmer Allison's first week of play in the East since last year was crowned with success today, in spite of the handicap of a sore arm. After a faltering start, the former national tennis champion volleyed his way to victory over Ernest Sutter of New Orleans, national intercollegiate titleholder from Tulane,

Dr. H. Parker Willis, one of the creators of the Federal Reserve System and a banking authority of international standing, died early yesterday at his Summer home at Oak Bluffs, Martha's Vineyard, Mass. He was 62 years old.
John Watts is with H. C. Wainwright Co., and he will be admitted to general partnership in the firm on Aug. 2. Edward F. Van Tassel Jr. is in the public utility bond department of Bear, Stearns Co.

In the first two sessions this week there was no change on the Bourse. While weak on Monday, quotations hardened on Tuesday's opening but prices receded again yesterday and continued falling all through today's session.

The strong First Division four, with Major J. A. Nichols again showing the way, gained its ninth victory in ten times out and the fourth in as many starts over Fort Hamilton yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn. Nichols tallied six times as the First Division triumphed by 10-7.

Doubts as to fundamental religious beliefs are among the ills most seriously harassing men's souls today, doubts that amount to agnosticism rather than atheism, the Rev. Cecil C. Hine, the pastor, said yesterday morning in his sermon in the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Our Saviour's Atonement, 189th Street and Bennett Avenue.

Within the next few weeks control of the Board of Higher Education is expected to pass into the hands of the Fusion regime for the first time since Mayor La Guardia took office, it was learned yesterday.

Actresses in two Passion Plays met in Tallula, near here, this week end and compared their interpretations of the role of Mary, the mother of Jesus. They are Mrs. Clara Koogle of Bloomington, who plays the Virgin Mary in this city's religious drama, and Miss Anna Rutz

(Figures in parentheses indicate par) Arrow Brook (70)-Final round for PresIdent's Trophy, first flight: Herman Yorks defeated Harry Parker. 2 and 1 (thirtysix holes): second flight: Irving Goodfield defeated Harry Feldman, 1 up (thirty-six holes). Kickers' handicap: J. Goldstein, 98-28-70; A. Wormser, 98--25--73; L. Wormser, 98-25-73; L. Stein, 91-16-75.

Jules Barthoux, French archaeologist, has just completed a successful expedition into Yemen during which he claims to have identified the ancient city of Sheba, according to a Havas News Agency dispatch from Sana.

Virtues, when carried to extremes, become vices, making justice senile, turning caution into unnecessary suspicion, and economy into niggardliness, the Rev. Ralph W. Sockman said yesterday at Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, in a sermon entitled "Life's Temperate Zone."

The engagement of Miss Caroline C. Sherman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Sherman of this place, to Oscar E. Lanford, son of Mrs. Ruth E. Lanford of Louisa County, Va., has been announced by her parents.
Central City's annual Play Festival found stern competition for attention today from a wholly unexpected source, the storied Hope diamond owned by Mrs. Evalyn Walsh McLean of Washington.

The progress of the Jewish race toward an ideal has enabled it to overcome persecution and destruction and to march to the fulfillment of the ideal, Rabbi Morris Lichtenstein said in an address yesterday morning at the Jewish Science Society. 150 West Eight-fifth Street.

Frank Bowden moved a round ahead of the field in the Eastern clay court singles tennis championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights club after winning two gruelling matches. The veteran New Yorker advanced to the fifth round by turning back G. H. Cox of New York, 6-3, 8-6, then rallying to overcome Harry Heffner of Washington. 5-7. 6-3 8-6.

A report from Peiping in yesterday's TIMES states that there has been no diminution in the traffic in narcotics. A flurry of raids was made after the revelations at Geneva of conditions in the Japanese concession at Tientsin, but what was done was negligible in view of the immensity of the problem.

Divided into two parts by the National holiday, Bastille Day, on Wednesday, this week counted as only four days. Business on the Bourse was very slack but quotations fluctuated widely, as they did also on the foreign exchange market. Internal politics again is responsible for such movements.
Norland, the 150-acre camp for boys and girls established by the American-German Bund of New Jersey, was opened today with a picnic for some 10,000 GermanAmericans.

The General Foods Corporation has acquired the Snow King Baking Powder Company, Cincinnati, manufacturer of Snow King and Dairy Maid baking powder. Marling Lillard, vice president of the Snow King company, will join the General Foods organization.

The United States Navy gave Amelia Earhart up for dead at sunset today, when it announced an end to the vast South Pacific hunt for the aviator and ordered the return of the giant aircraft carrier Lexington to her base at San Diego, Calif.
Sir Oswald Mosley, the British fascist leader was struck by a stone as police rushed him to a street car tonight to protect him against anti-Fascists who broke up his address at Southampton common.

Mrs. Ellen Livingston McHugh, one of the oldest women in Queens, died yesterday in her home at 139-07 Thirty-fourth Avenue, Flushing. She was born in Ireland ninety-two years ago, came to this country fifty years ago and had resided in Queens the last twelve years.

According to Ann Watkins, his agent, Sinclair Lewis has just completed his first work of fiction since the publication of "It Can't Happen Here." It is a story of "the younger generation in warfare with its elders." The title is "The Prodigal Parents."
The Rev. Dr. George Frederick Clover, who was pastor and superintendent of St. Lake's Hospital, New York, from 1900 until 1914, died at his Summer home here today at the age of 71.

Canneries in some of the South Jersey rural centers. will open ahead of regular schedule this week to take care of the glut of early tomatoes, with the bottom out of the market in the big cities for the fresh product.

Greater security for the investing public is assured under a complete reorganization of methods used by the Pennsylvania Securities Commission to prevent the sale of worthless stocks and bonds, according to a report submitted to Governor Earle by Dr. Luther A. Harr, State Secretary of Banking, and made public by the Governor today.
More than a score of persons in Queens telephoned THE NEW YORK TIMES early this morning reporting that their houses had been shaken by an "earthquake," accompanied by a distant rumbling.

The police announced tonight that they had eliminated doubt that it was to Dr. George W. Webster that cab drivers twice delivered sandwiches in early morning trips to his home in the week before he was slain and while Mrs. Webster and their daughter were at the family's Summer home at Misquamicut. The announcement came a few hours after the burial of Dr. Webster in Swan Point Cemetery.

Nicaragua is willing to sign a treaty permitting United States to ship troops and materials over the newly completed railroad from Lake Nicaragua to the Pacific Coast in case of emergency if the United States Government, in turn, will provide the $2,500,000 to $3,000,000 estimated to be necessary to canalize the San Juan River from the Atlantic to the same lake to permit the passage of big ships.

The world wheat price mounted to new high levels for the season last week, as the result of general speculative and other buying based on reports indicating that a downward revision would be necessary in the estimated United States and Canadian Spring wheat crops, because of drought damage earlier in the season and the ravages of black rust.
Behind the heavy batting of the veteran Barney McLaughlin, the New York A. C. routed the New York State Police nine, 13-4, yesterday at Travers Island in a freehitting contest.

Light receipts of hogs in the West are being reflected in decreasing stocks of lard in cold storage, but the reduction here in the first two days of this week aggregated only 3,617,000 pounds, leaving a total of 112,154,000 pounds on hand at the close of business on July 14, compared with 57,750,000 pounds on the same date in 1936.

Brampton Homes, Inc., William P. Hahn, builder, has purchased forty lots on 226th Street and 138th Avenue, Laurelton, Queens. The property is in the center of the old town of Laurelton, half way .between the railroad station and the Merrick Road.
Municipal boat trip for the League of Mothers Clubs of the United Neighborhood Houses, aboard the Colonel Clayton, leaving Pier A, Battery Place, 9:30 A. M.

Nearly a third of the city's population spent yesterday at near-by beaches, as seeking relief from the heat became a midsummer habit. In contrast to previous week-ends, however, the weather was pleasantly mild with a temperature range between 71 and 82 and the cooling breezes of a gentle north wind.

All houses here were beflagged today to mark the birthday of the Croat leader, Dr. Vladimir Matchek. For the first time the Croats' military organization, the Peasant Defense Corps, which is declared to have been raised for purposes of self-defense against the Serbs, appeared in military formation and displayed its excellent training and discipline.

Oliver Owen Kuhn, managing editor of The Washington Star, chairman of the executive committee of the Associated Press Managing Editors' Association and well-known radio figure, died this morning at Emergency Hospital. He was 51 years old.
The Oklahoma Natural Gas Company has acquired part of the Greater Seminole system of the Independent Natural Gas Company in various counties throughout Oklahoma, it was announced yesterday.

The weeK's stock market here was relatively active, and prices, on the whole, advanced. Heavy buying and sizable gains, nevertheless, were confined to a mere handful of specialties, among which were some of the preceding week's favorites.

The first anniversary of the civil war was commemorated today with what appears to have been the greatest battle yet fought on the ground and with an aerial combat in which twentythree Rebel planes were shot down, while the government lost four.

Philip Sotter, a founder and former secretary of the Sotter Brothers Boiler Works, Pottstown, died at his home here tonight of a heart attack. He was 77 years old. Born in Reading, he moved to Pottstown at an early age, and with three brothers opened the boiler works in 1879. He retired in 1918.
Paced by the brilliant play of 18year-old Bobby Johnson, the Burnt Mills Polo Club defeated the Rumson Ramblers at Schley Field today, 6-4. It was the third straight triumph for Burnt Mills.
The Japanese Government announced officially today that heavy concentrations of Chinese troops had been made near Peiping, constituting a direct act of aggression again Japan.

Gliding into a gentle westerly breeze, the Pan American Clipper alighted smoothly on Manhasset Bay here at 1:21 P. M. today, completing successfully its pathfinding flight from New York to Southampton, England, and return.

John O. Powers, president of the John O. Powers Company, advertising agents, 220 East Forty-second Street, died Saturday at his home, 246 Grant Avenue, Nutley, N. J., at the age of 68. His widow, Ada Weigel Powers; two daughters, Mrs.

The Treasury's new issue of short-term bills sold this week at an average price of 0.397 per cent interest, compared with 0.419 per cent for the first $50,000,000 issue of the bills which sold last Monday, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.
The disappearance of Amelia Earhart and her navigator, Frederick J. Noonan, in the equatorial Pacific seventeen days ago was officially set down tonight as one of aviation's mysteries.

The interne who accompanied Dr. George W. Webster to the hospital after he was shot at his home early Friday and a nurse who attended him just before he died insisted tonight that he did not recognize his assailant and that robbery, not revenge or jealously, was the probable motive.

The conflict between the administration of Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch and the Serbian Orthodox Church over ratification of the concordat with the Vatican came to a climax this evening when the police, armed with rifles, bayonets and truncheons, charged and broke up a religious procession.

J. P. Morgan sailed just before midnight tonight on his yacht Corsair for a four months' stay in the British Isles. Mr. Morgan, accompanied by his son-in-law, Paul G. Pennoyer of Locust Valley, L. I., boarded a tender at the Morgan private dock and went out to the anchored yacht shortly before night fell.

The French Franc continued yesterday to fall to quotations that were cheaper than had been seen in more than ten years. For a time the currency rallied, reaching as high as 3.79 1/8 cents, but the climb was short-lived and the exchange slumped again until it touched 3.75 1/4 cents. It closed at 3.75 5/8 cents, off 1 point net.

My dear Senator Wagner: I am writing to you as a citizen of the State of New York, which you represent in the United States Senate, to voice my opposition to the Court Bill and to express the hope that you will vote against it.

Two leading members of the bar here congratulated Governor Lehman yesterday on his stand against the Roosevelt Court Bill. Charles C. Burlingham, former president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, said:

Two men who were injured on the early morning of last July 8 in a fight with the police after their alleged hold-up of a grill at Columbus Avenue and Sixty-second Street were discharged from the prison ward at Bellevue Hospital yesterday and arraigned in the Felony Court.

Assemblyman James V. Mangano, who was accused by Park Commisioner Robert Moses of making a 'personal and political issue" out of the Park Department's failure o reopen the bathhouse at President Street and Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, accused Mr. Moses

President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman have been the political Damon and Pythias of New York State for eight years. First brought together when they ran on the same ticket in 1928, President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman had bound their political fortunes together on all major issues ever since until yesterday when the Governor came out openly for the first time against a major Roosevelt objective.

Peter Doelger Brewing Corporation has initiated a merchandising tie-up with the Hobby Guild of America, whereby the brewery is offering "Hobby Enjoyment Guides" to its customers. At the same time, the Hobby Guild of America will

Cole Porter's musical comedy "Gay Divorce," the fourth in the season's schedule of Shubert productions, was revived here tonight on the water stage on Zach's Bay by Fortune Gallo. On the shores of the

Mrs. Esther Tompkins Carpenter, a descendant of Daniel D. Tompkins, who was Governor of the State, 1807-17, and Vice President of the United States, 1817-25, died here last night at her home at the age of 87. Surviving are her

Net assets of the Adams Express Company, based on market values as of June 30, amounted to $45,148,748, equal to $21.07 a share on the common stock, according to a detailed statement of operations for the first six months of 1937 and made public yesterday.
Two Brooklyn women accused of "selling" city jobs for from $85 to $200 were found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions, Brooklyn. The court set July 29 for sentence.

The Metropolitan Motor Carriers conference, Newark, N. J., asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for a rehearing of proceedings which set up a proposed motor carrier zone for the New York metropolitan area. Operators in the

In the first six months of 1937 Canadian exports to the United States jumped 38.3 per cent compared with the first half of last year, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics said today. Exports reached $230,769,000, against $166,836,000 a year before.
Because beavers took up housekeeping in a near-by river, all traffic on a part of the Heenan Highway between Kenora and Fort Frances has been halted since Friday.
More than 2,300 persons, one of the largest crowds ever to take part in the annual affair, sailed up the Hudson to Bear Mountain yesterday on the annual outing of the Police Department Honor Legion.

A nation-wide effort to direct the force of public opinion against the Roosevelt administration's move to reorganize the Supreme Court was announced yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

Vocational aptitude tests are useless for vocational guidance purposes, Dr. Harry D. Kitson, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday as he held current hocuss pocus" guidance methods up to ridicule in a speech before Summer-session students at the Morningside institution.
Dizzy Dean left tonight aboard a Big Four fast train for Boston, where he said he would report to Manager Frank Frisch of the Cardinals tomorrow night.

King George VI was admitted into honorary membership in the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company .of Massachusetts today, following ceremonies which marked the close of a series of celebrations commemomating the 400th anniversary of the founding of the parent organization -the British Honorable Artillery Company - during the reign of Henry VIII.

Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, was asked yesterday afternoon by a committee of five internes to increase the budget of his department to include annual salaries of $1,000 for the 650 internes serving on the staffs of the city hospitals.

Harry Holt, amateur from the Crescent A. C., and Ferdy Catropa, one of the golfing twins from the Peninsula Golf Club, tied Bill Tobin of Lakeville and Al Broach of Bethpage with identical scores of 34, 32-66 in the Long Island P. G. A. amateur-pro tournament at the St. Albans Golf Club yesterday.

From a neutral and comparatively passive policy advocating the election and appointment of feminine officeholders, the National Federation of Business and Professional Women was plunged tonight into active championship of elected and appointed women in public posts in every community where a unit of the organization exists.

Traffic accidents, deaths and injuries in the city were fewer last week-end and during the entire week than they were in the corresponding period last year, Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler announced yesterday.
The thud of the falling franc, which on Saturday touched the lowest point in eleven years, is an ominous reminder that the French financial dilemma is far from solved. The energetic action
William L'Estrange Millman, an actor, who last appeared on the New York stage in 1933 in "Forsaking All Others," died here today after a brief illness. He was born in Canada fifty-four years ago.

Offering will be made today of 45,000 shares of the American Stamping Company common stock of $2-par value, at $6.50 a share, by a banking syndicate comprising Paul W. Cleveland Co., Inc., Chicago; Murdoch, Dearth White, Inc., Des Moines, and Festus J. Wade Jr. Co., St. Louis.

Harold Gatty, New Zealand aerial navigator who flew around the world with Wiley Post in 1931, will be married today in New York City to Miss Fenna Bolderhey of Amsterdam, the Netherlands, it was learned yesterday. Mr. Gatty, who
A meeting was arranged today between the Chinese Foreign Minister, Dr. Wang Chung-hui, and Shinrokuro Hidaka, the Japanese Charge d'Affaires, in a new effort to find a peace formula in North China.

Campaigns for enactment or Federal anti-lynching legislation and for increased economic opportunities for Negroes were the principal activities of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People last year, according to the association's annual report, released yesterday at its offices, 69 Fifth Avenue.

Testimony that veteran Ford Motor Company employes, some of whom had served twelve to twenty-six years, had been dismissed for union activity was put in the record today before Trial Examiner John T. Lindsay at a hearing of the National Labor Relations Board.

Three men made a pilgrimage yesterday afternoon to the treeshaded grave in Woodlawn Cemetery of John Purroy Mitchel, the Fusion Mayor of New York from 1914 to 1918. Born July 19, 1870, Mayor Mitchel was killed July 6, 1918, in an airplane accident while serving in the Army Air Corps as a major.

Miss Charlotte Emily Smith, daughter of Alfred Gilbert Smith of Khakum Wood, Round Hill, Greenwich, has completed plans for her marriage to Donald Andrews Bristol of New York. The ceremony will take place in Rosemary Hall Chapel here on Sept. 11 and will be followed by a reception at the Smith home.

Frank Monroe, character actor, died yesterday in the Southside Hospital, Bay Shore, L. I., of a complication of diseases. He was 73 years old and had been a guest at the Percy Williams Home at East Islip.

Great Britain took to the air today in an attempt to solve her motor highway problem. Minister of Transport Leslie Burgin, with a staff of technical experts, took a plane at Croydon Airdrome for a 500-mile survey of the nation's main traffic arteries. He planned to fly low over the busy Great North Road from London to the Scottish border and back again, studying the danger points where the road is narrow and twisting.

The Fall River Chamber of Commerce, in an effort to save the Fall River Line, sought today to arrange a conference between officials of the New England Steamship Company, operators of the line, and the National Maritime Union, C. I. O. affiliate, which called a strike on the vessels a week ago.
Many attended the simple funeral service held here this afternoon for George Barton French, retired broker and railroad president, who died suddenly Saturday night at Darena, his Southampton home.
Noble E. Kizer, Purdue athletic director and head football coach who is seriously ill in a local hospital, showed "encouraging signs of improvement" this afternoon, the attending physician said.

A strike of the more than 5,000 building trades workers now employed on Federal construction in this city appeared a possibility tonight as members of the local painters' union began to walk out on projects handled by the procurement division of the Treasury, in sympathy with painters who struck at Internal Revenue buildings.
The report of the Electric Bond and Share Company for the twelve 00months ended on June 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $10,017,399 after expenses, taxes other charges. This figure, after

Legal advisers of the Secretary of Treasury are preparing formal replies to Representative Fish, who asked whether the Bureau of Internal Revenue had announced a general ruling that taxpayers might omit statements of contributions to charities, and to Representative Dirksen, who wrote questioning the recent monetary agreement with China, Secretary Morgenthau said this afternoon.

Max Hirsch, an official of the bakers' union, who had been relied on as an important prosecution witness at the bakery racket trial, has disappeared some time since last Tuesday, although he was under subpoena to take the stand, it was disclosed yesterday when the trial was resumed in Special Sessions.

The sale of a mortgage on property of the Westchester Embassy Golf Club, North Castle, for $130,000 was authorized today by Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme in acting upon an application made by mortgage rehabilitation trustees.

The Marine Midland Trust Company of New York was authorized yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission to intervene in the application of the trustees of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway for authority to issue certificates of indebtedness.
The capture of two British freighters by Spanish Insurgent warships blockading Bay of Biscay ports drew protests today from the British Foreign Office.

An Increase of about 25 per cent in the Fall advertising program of the I. B. Kleinert Rubber Company, to feature dress shields, Braforms, sanitary goods, Softex products, shower curtains and other products, was announced by Ralph K. Guinzburg, president, at the opening session of the company's annual sales convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

The slight shocks that jarred homes and other buildings in nearby Queens and Nassau County just before midnight Sunday were due not to an explosion or fireworks celebration, as previously supposed, but to a slight earthquake. Dr. L.
The Blue Ridge Corporation reported yesterday net assets as of June 30 of $44,386,501, after provision for normal Federal income tax on unrealized appreciation of investments. This was equivalent
Leon Toole drove Royal Napoleon to victory in two straight heats today, the best of ten whirls that opened a two-week Grand Circuit meet at the rebuilt track here.

Popular writers paint many a horrible picture of the effects of new inventions in creating unemployment, and in the days of the technocrats a large section of the American public was on the verge of accepting these pictures.

Economies amounting to $500,000 in the conduct of the business of the WPA in New York City have been effected in the fiscal year ended June 30, 1937, it was disclosed by the annual report submitted to Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA administrator, by Richard Mueser, chief clerk of the WPA.

Presentation of Finance Minister Georges Bonnet's economy program to the French Cabinet today required complicated consultations, as the fate of the Chautemps government depends on the success of these measures.

Financing of two taxpayer buildings to occupy a blockfront in the Bronx featured realty activity in that borough yesterday. The J. D. Construction Corporation obtained a loan of $37,500 for erection of a one-story building to contain eleven stores at the southwest corner of Boston Road and Wilson Avenue, a plot 150 by 121 feet. Ramapo Estates, Inc., acted as broker in the transaction.

New tariffs recently placed in effect in Ecuador were reported to the Deapartment of Commerce today by cable from Consul General Dayle C. McDonough, Guayaquil. Rates were reduced on a number of items,

The Rev. George Kemp Ward, one of the oldest alumni of Princeton University and credited with having played a major part in-the selection of orange and black as the university's colors, died at his home here yesterday in his ninetieth year.
Mrs. Marion C. Keleher of New York obtained a divorce here today from Arthur C. F. Keleher on grounds of cruelty. They were married on April 26, 1927, in New York City.

Colonel Lester Baker, military attache of the United States Embassy here, was decorated, today with the Brazilian Order of the Southern Cross by the Brazilian Ambassador, acting in the name of President Getulio Vargas.
The Government has accepted the designation of Don Jose Maria Cavero y Goicorrotea, Duke of Bailen, as Minister of the government of General Francisco Franco, Insurgent chief in Spain.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has been engaged by Samuel Goldwyn to write a series of advertisements in behalf of the forthcoming "Stella Dallas" which will reach the screen in two weeks.

The Inland Steel Company began presentation of evidence at the National Labor Relations Board hearing today against the charges of unfair labor practices brought by the Steel Workers Organizing Committee.

Mayor La Guardia was informed yesterday by a committee of the Milk Consumers Protective Committee that moves were under way to increase the cost of milk to consumers without giving a corresponding increase to up-State dairy farmers.

Heywood Broun, president of the American Newspaper Guild, struck back yesterday at William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in their battle of words over leadership of the guild and its switch from the federation to the C. I. O.

Miss Kitty Cheatham. internal ionally known for her recitals of children's folksongs, which she made famous for a generation, is sailing on the Europa on Friday to deliver an address at International Women's Week at Budapest, which opens on Aug. 5.

The triple inducement of Fritz Reiner, conductor, Ray Lev, pianist, and cool, clear weather drew an audience of nearly 4,000 to Lewisohn Stadium last night. Miss Lev. appearing directly after the intermission, offered a sturdy reading of Schumann's A minor Concerto. She was recalled to the stage three times, and was finally obliged to play a solo as an encore.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman gave a dinner tonight at the "Little White House," as his Summer home is known, in honor of four Passaic men whose sea skiff took the Governor and fifteen other persons, including his wife and two of his daughters, from a burning yacht off Asbury Park, July 4.

The Southern Pacific Company and Transportation System Companies, excluding operations of solely controlled affiliated companies, yesterday reported a net operating income $2,505,753 for June, compared with $3,318,142 in June, 1936. Net operating income

Mrs. Christine Byron Knapp, who conducted a private school for girls in Elizabeth for twenty years until her retirement in 1905, died here yesterday at the home of her son, Edgar A. Knapp, at the age of 89. Another son, Arthur W. Knapp of Bayside, N. Y., also survives.
The Bergen Apartments, at 359-61 West Side Avenue, on the corner of Grant Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., have been sold by the Provident Institution for Savings to the P. S. Holding Corporation.

-One woman was killed, a man and woman are not expected to live, and four other persons were seriously injured in a head-on automobile crash here early today on the Montauk Highway between West Sayville and Oakdale.

The Equity Corporation and the Consolidated Funds Corporation, both of Jersey City, have filed posteffective amendments to registration statements originally filed in 1934 under the Securities Act of 1933, in connection with proceedings by the Securities and Exchange Commission, instituted last month, questioning the adequacy or certain data.

The Long Island Lighting Company's "cost-plus" contract with E. L. Philips Co. was invalid from its inception because it never received the support of a majority of the Long Island's directors, counsel for plaintiffs in a $20,000,000 stockholders' suit declared yesterday in a brief filed with Supreme Court Justice Aaron Levy.
Mrs. Milly Hill of South Gate, Ky., set a national record today as the fifty-seventh annual target meeting of the National Archery Association opened on the Franklin and Marshall Academy campus.

Miss Candace Alig, daughter of Mrs. Otto Fidele Alig of 1,070 Park Avenue and Des Moines and the late Mr. Alig, was married to Kelvin Cox Vanderlip, son of Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip of Beechwood, Scarborough-on-Hudson, and the late Mr. Vanderlip, yesterday in the chapel of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

In the death of H. PARKER WILLIS the country has lost one of its foremost authorities on banking, one of its ablest economic thinkers and one of its most pungent controversialists. His career reflects his amazing fund of energy:

The semi-courageous attempt of John State, 9 years old, of 11 Lembeck Avenue, to climb what is said to be the tallest and oldest tree in the city ended ingloriously here tonight when John was rescued from a swaying limb by a police emergency squad.

A police statement issued here today said increased activity had been noted in seeking recruits in the Netherlands for the Spanish Government Army since France suspended international control of her Spanish border.

A trial shipment of grapefruit and oranges from Brazil was not well received in Canada, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from Commercial Attache H. M. Bankhead at Ottawa, made public

Mrs. Charles S. Bromley's 3-yearold Sunphantom, whose last race was a futile effort far behind War Admiral in the Chesapeake Stakes at Havre de Grace on April 24, gave the players a shock at Empire City yesterday. This chestnut son of Genie galloped home an easy winner in- the featured Verplanck Handicap and rewarded the few who had backed him at 15 to 1.

Commander Winfield Liggett Jr., U.S.N. (retired), an authority on the game of bridge, who had been in the front rank of American players for nearly twenty years, died yesterday in the Naval Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 56 years old.

With prices up 5 to 10 per cent compared with Spring quotations, Fall lines of lamps and lamp shades were opened at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday. More than 450 buyers, 20 per cent more than appeared on the opening day of the last Fall show, registered yesterday.

Sussex kept close behind Yorkshire, leader of the English county cricket championship, by virtue of a victory over Kent today by an innings and 133 runs. Middlesex. overcame Gloucestershire by eight wickets and Glamorgan sprang a surprise by Defeating the strong Essex eleven by five wickets. Warwickshire fell before Derbyshire, the champion county, by five wickets.

One of the greatest difficulties in negotiating the Anglo-Soviet and Anglo-German naval agreements, it was revealed here today, was a Russian demand that Soviet Far Eastern warships be exempted from the provisions for limitation of the type of vessels and for advance notification to Britain of building programs.

Sheriff Percy T. Egglefield will leave tomorrow for Los Angeles in an attempt to gain custody of John Montague, golfer, whom Essex County authorities believe to be Verne Moore, wanted here since 1930 for a $600 hold-up. He will bear extradition papers signed last week by Acting Governor Bray.
Crowds hurrying to work this morning paused to watch a man climbing the 315-foot tower of the City Hall, where he hung out a red flag with the words "bread, work and freedom" on a lightning rod.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a news article in THE TIMES today Edward A. Filene is quoted as saying: "Employers make no greater error than to assume that wages come out of profits. The fact is profits come out of wages. I can offer to pay double wages to increase the buying power of our employes, provided other business men do the same."
Albert Lowther, who was active in fraternal organizations and church work, died at his home here today after a week's illness. His age was 79.
Breaking his long silence tonight, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek informed the Chinese nation of the grave possibilities in the situation resulting from the fighting at Lukouchiao.

Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, former national champion, had a day of rest as the forty-fifth annual Longwood Bowl tennis tournament, one of the nation's oldest, opened today. The top-seeded Allison, who won the final at Spring Lake, N. J., yesterday, went into the second round on the default of Modesto Alloo of Berkeley, Calif.

" Enjoy your studies" is the theme of the sixteenth annual Summer educational book exhibit, which opened yesterday in the gymnasium of Columbia University. A record number of fifty-four exhibitors are displaying 30,000 books at the show, which is expected to attract more than 12,000 visitors before it closes on Aug. 6, according to John Van Dyke, who is in charge.

Two Soviet flying explorers prepared today to search the Arctic for a mystery island marked on maps as Sannikoff Land. They are Pilot Ivan Cheregitchni and Navigator Shtedenko, who came to this Eastern Siberian city from Krasnoyarsk, in South Central Siberia, in the plane N-10.

Mr. and Mrs. Victor Wesley of this Place have announced the engagement of their elder daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Wesley, to Wallace Crawford De Klyn, son of Mrs. Harriet Ryan, also of Norwalk, and grandson of the late William F. De Klyn.
Gold bars discovered at a?? abandoned mine on the Rio Piedr?? Candela are being brought over th?? Santa Maria Mountains to Bugaba?? by pack train, according to a repor?? to police headquarters.

Tom Kerrigan and James A. Ward of Siwanoy combined for a superb 65, seven strokes under par, to win the pro-amateur best-ball event, the feature of the Westchester Golf Association's one-day tournament at the Sunningdale Country Club today.

Three policed men testified today that they shot in defense of their own lives in the Memorial Day riot, when C. I. O. steel strikers and their sympathizers marched toward the plant of the Republic Steel Corporation in South Chicago.

Henry Armstrong, Los Angeles featherweight, scored a technical knockout victory over Lew Massey of Philadelphia before 7,000 persons at Dexter Park last night. Massey was completely outclassed and badly beaten after 1:20 of the fourth round of their scheduled ten-round meeting and Referee Artie McGovern intervened to save the loser from further unnecessary punishment.

Several deals in Staten Island realty have been reported by the John A. Lynch Company, Inc., brokers. A plot on Park Court and Revere Street, Silver Lake West, was sold by Charles English to Rose Lehrhaupt. On Douglas Road
Elias Berman, retired building contractor, died yesterday in the Beth-El Hospital, Brooklyn, after a brief illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 128-22 Liberty Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens.
The delegation of Russian journalists invited to come here as a result of the Finnish Government's desire to open diplomatic relations with Moscow, arrived today on a good-will tour.

The Giants allowed themselves to become weighted down by the utter futility of things at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Out there on the mound a fellow named Silas Johnson was doing a lot of tantalizing pitching.
Development of a new peanut oil, the external application of which, it is hoped, may benefit infantile paralysis victims, was announced here today by Dr. George Washington Carver, Negro scientist.
President Roosevelt conferred with Attorney General Cummings, Senator Black and others on his legislative program; discussed

Chester Cornelius Washburn died at his home here last night on the eve of his wedding anniversary. His age was 55. He was connected for many years with the signal maintenance department of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company and had been a lifelong resident of Greenwich.
Proprietors of the Lenox Shoe Company, scene of labor conflict since June 28, offered today, with reservations, to turn over the plant for operation by employes on a cooperative basis.

George Sauer, former All-America football star at the University of Nebraska, today was appointed head football coach at the University of New Hampshire. His selection as assistant professor in the department of physical education and athletics was announced by Fred Englehardt, president of the university, who said the appointment would run one year.

Premier Maurice Duplessis announced today that no export of wood cut on crown lands would be permitted in Quebec and that the government would allow no new newsprint mills to be constructed in the Province.
The London rights of "Room Service" have gone to Jack Waller of that city, and very likely Mr. Waller would be pleased to have George Abbott go over and stage it for him. If Mr. Abbott does,

Nelson W. Howard, patent lawyer and retired vice president of the United Shoe Machinery Corporation, with which he was associated for thirty-six years, died in Hollywood, Fla., yesterday in his sixty-fourth year.
The strike of 500 maintenance workers, carpenters and warehouse employes of the Bush Terminal Buildings Company of Brooklyn was settled yesterday and the men returned to work. It was announced

Let us begin by saying the worst that can be said about AMELIA EARHART. She was no feminine LINDBERGH, flying oceans with the precision of a transport pilot. She was no scientific flier, as those last pathetic messages picked up by the Itasca on July 2 showed: " We must be on you but can" not see you. Gas is running low.

The White Sox staged a four-run uprising in the eighth inning today to give them a 6-to-4 victory and a clean sweep of the four-game series with the Red Sox. Going into the eighth behind, 4 to 2, the Chicago team drove Johnny Marcum from the box and continued the four-hit assault against Tommy Thomas and Rube Walberg.

Although buying activity was relatively slow at the opening of the Fall Corset Show at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday, arrival of buyers during the day resulted in more general purchasing, and officials said indications pointed to a record attendance by the end of the show.

Spokesmen for the Federal theatre and writers' projects were reluctant "to dignify with an answer" yesterday the criticism released against the projects by Ralph M. Easley, chairman of the executive council of the National Civic Federation.

As had happened on previous declines slightly below the 12-cent level, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange developed resistance to pressure yesterday and ended with losses of only 1 to 3 points. Foreign and domestic liquidation carried all months below the 12cent figure for the first time since the official acreage report.
The Insurgents maintain the first year of Spain's civil war has ended with the collapse of the most ambitious attempt the government forces have yet made to take the offensive on the Madrid front.

The Cremo Brewing Company, Inc., New Britain, Conn., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 85,300 shares of $5-par value capital stock, of which 70,000 shares would be reserved for the exercise of warrants by stockholders at $6 a share

Fireman first grade Dominick J. Cervinl of H. and L. 26 died July 18. Funeral will take place from premises 456 E. 141st St., Borough of the Bronx, at 9:30 A. M. Wednesday, July 21. Interment at Calvary. Cemetery.

Business failures throughout the United States totaled 152 for the week ended July 15, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure compares with 108 for the five-day week ended July 8 and with 136 for the corresponding week last year.
Mrs. Charles de Kay gave a tea today for a company of forty at Abrigada, her home, in honor of her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Barbour of New York.

The whereabouts of Johnny Broaca, Yankee hurler, who disappeared some time between Friday's game in Detroit and yesterday's second game against the Indians without a word to Joe McCarthy, team leader, continued to be a mystery today.
John F. Montgomery, United States Minister to Hungary, and Mrs. Montgomery, who were at the Pierre, have gone to the Cascades, their Summer home in Manchester, Vt.

Passengers arriving from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria include Countess Nicholas Neirouth, Sir William and Lady Sowden, R. L. Pree, M. P.; Mr. and Mrs. C. Braxton Valentine, Mrs. Harold Jacoby, Mrs. Charles B. Cochrane, Mrs. Eric PendrillSmith, Major B. Heckstall-Smith, Miss Virginia Hunt, Dr. Roy A. Terry and Tommy Farr, British heavyweight champion.

In more forthright language than he has ever used officially before, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden warned Italy in the House of Commons today that Britain would fight, if necessary, to defend her interests in the Mediterranean Sea and along the road to India.

Bonds were firm to slightly higher yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in another exceedingly dull trading session. Persistent strength in United States Government obligations was a feature, while improvement in certain sections of the railroad list, particularly secondary issues, stood out in the corporate section. Total transactions in all bonds amounted to $5,788,500, and compared with $6,616,000 on last Friday.
A year's campaign against "wildcat" stock schemes, waged by the Pennsylvania Securities Commission, disclosed fourteen cases of fraud, Governor Earle announced today.
Major Gen. Sir William George Bertram Boyce, director of transport during the World War, died at his home here today. His age was 69. He served in the South African War.

The Toronto Maple Leafs upset the pace-setting Newark Bears, 6 to 3, tonight in the first of a four-game series, behind the effective flinging of Earl Caldwell, who scattered an even dozen Bruin blows.

ABOARD CONGRESSIONAL TRAIN, Returning to Washington From Robinson Funeral, July 19.Word that Governor Lehman had taken an open stand against President Roosevelt's Court Bill was received with scarcely concealed disappointment today among administration spokesmen, who for three days aboard this train have attempted to devise some strategy that would save the proposal from defeat.

The Yankees completed the decimation of Steve O'Neill's pitching staff today as they won, 8-5, and swept clean a three-game series with the Indians. The freshman of the squad showed the champions the way as 7,000 looked on at League Park.
A further clarification of the Nanking government's intentions has been asked by Shinrokuro Hidaka, the Japanese Charge d'Affaires at Nanking, on his own initiative.

The exceptionally low value of United States exports in 1936 compared with 1929 "reflects perhaps the most outstanding change in world trade which has occurred since that year." according to the League of

Entering the winner's circle for the third time today, Jockey Ken McCombs brought D. J. Sullivan 3d's Trina home by a neck in the Revere Handicap, mile and one-sixteenth feature of the Suffolk Downs program, to pay 19-5.

Black rust reports had comparatively little effect on wheat prices in North American markets today and appeared to have lost their appeal to the speculative public. While some of the messages from the United States Northwest indicated there had been heavy damage, others said losses might not be as severe as had been expected. Weather conditions

The Tigers collected thirteen hits off two Washington pitchers today, defeating the Senators, 8 to 4, to sweep the three-game series. Poffenberger, Tiger rookie hurler, was in trouble several times but managed to pull through to score his sixth victory of the season.

Bids for 3,065,450 yards of cotton textiles for the Works Progress Administration will be opened July 27, the procurement division of the Treasury announced today. Shipments must be completed from the point

William Armstrong Perry of Westport. Conn., geologist and fiction writer, told yesterday on his return from Paramaribo aboard the steamship Stuyvesant of the Royal Netherlands Company how he and six other survivors of a plane crash in the South American jungle had spent fifteen days under great hardship before their rescue.

More than 300 persons, attending an open-air anarchist meeting in Union Square yesterday, heard members of the Anarchist Federation of America and the United Libertarian Organizations condemn the Communists of Spain for their "underhanded double dealing." Although an occasional "boo" from individuals in the crowd indicated Communist sympathy, the detail of twenty patrolmen had no difficulty in keeping order.

Early development of a copper deposit near San Luis Obispo, Calif., is seen by mining men in the announcement here that the Morro Bay Company of Utah has been formed by Ogden C. Chase, who is credited with the organization of the Rio into copper enterprises at Mountain City, Nev.
Transatlantic issues furnished the only outstanding strong spot in a quiet stock market session today. Both United States Steel and International Nickel forged ahead.
The four-story apartment houses at 2,523 Church Avenue and 30-32 Willow Place were sold by the South Brooklyn Savings Bank to Kings County Estates, Inc., Milton Lefenfeld, president.
Protestant leaders gathered here for the World Conference of Church, Community and State today drew forceful attention to the suppression of the Evangelical Church in Germany.

Miss Violet Margaret Catty, elder daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Douglas Catty of Highfields Farm, near here, will be married to Brian Hutton Dulanty, son of John W. Dulanty, High Commissioner in London for the Irish Free State,

The possibility of a renewal of last Summer's campaign to improve the street manners of the city's dog population became apparent yesterday when Magistrate Charles Soloman, sitting in Flatbush Court, fined two persons for failure to exercise proper supervision over their pets.

Declaring a sit-down strike of leather goods workers "Unamerican and communistic," Judge Harry S. McDevitt of the Common Pleas Court issued a preliminary injunction today, ordering the ejection of 204 sit-downers from the plant of the McNeely Price Company.

" Lysistrata" was presented here this evening at the Westchester Playhouse before a capacity audience. The production required the largest cast assembled in the theatre this Summer. There were forty in speaking parts and twenty in a ballet. The cast was headed by Vera Allen, and included Myron McCormick, Phyllis Welch, Elizabeth Love, Walter Klavun, Phyllis Langner, Rachel Sewall, LeslieGorall and Carl Rodgers.
Union miners employed in the steelowned "captive" mine of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company near here appealed tonight to their international board to call off a strike order.

Premier Duplessis declared today that closed shops would not be tolerated in Quebec Province. Workers, whether they belong to international or national Catholic unions, will have perfect freedom to work at reasonable wages and under satisfactory conditions, but without outside interference being tolerated.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 14: An increase of $76,000,000 in

The Pirates defeated the Phillies today by a score of 6 to 5 to break even in the four-game series. It was a see-saw battle from the start. The Phillies scored three runs in the first inning only to have the Pirates knot the count with another trio in the second.
