Many young women of the Summer colony headed by Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems are active in the plans for the second annual gala dinner dance of the Hamptons in--behalf of Camp Grant at Baiting Hollow, L. I., which will take place Friday at Canoe Place Inn.

The Misses Josephine San Filippo of Brooklyn and Judith Lachenbruch of Pleasantville, N. Y., seeded first and second respectively, reached the quarter-final round as play in the junior girls' open tennis tournament started at the Great Neck Country Club today.

Harold Riegelman, Thomas J. Curran and Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d were designated last night as the Republican candidates for delegates to the State Constitutional Convention from the Seventeenth Senatorial District, which includes the "silk-stocking" Fifteenth Assembly Diserict.

Although the immediate tension centers on the intentions of General Sung Cheh-yuan in Peiping as to whether he can force all the elements of his Twenty-ninth Army to carry out the terms pledged to the Japanese the fundamental elements of the North China problem loom ever larger.

Operations in the steel industry are scheduled at 82.5 per cent of ingot capacity for this week, as against 82.7 per cent last week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The decrease amounts to 0.2 points, or 0.24 per cent of the rate of operations, which a month ago were at 75.9 per cent.

The light cruiser Omaha went aground off Castle Island Light at the approach to Crooked Island passage in the Bahamas at 3:55 o'clock this morning and naval and Coast Guard vessels were dispatched immediately to her assistance.

Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau bade farewell to Washington and monetary affairs this afternoon as he boarded a train for the West. He is to sail from Los Angeles for Honolulu on Saturday and will return to Washington about Sept. 5.
The proposal of railway companies to charge demurrage on grain cars at terminal elevators has been rejected, the Board of Railway Commissioners announced today.
Sales of electric fans this season set a new record for the electrical appliance industry and have exceeded 1929 volume by 5 to 10 per cent, manufacturers reported yesterday. With volume running
The report of the Lawyers Trust Company for June 30 showed total deposits of $37,860,170 and total assets of $42,214,474, compared, respectively, with $42,466,549 and $46,896,188 on March 31 last.

Members of the Tammany Hall executive committee held several conferences yesterday on means of averting what many of the district leaders believe will be a disastrous primary fight, if James J. Dooling, Tammany leader, insists on supporting Senator Royal S. Copeland for the Democratic Mayoralty nomination.

Unexpected, and apparently well organized, opposition to the pending reorganization plan for the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company sprang to life yesterday with the announced formation of a protective committee representing several institutional bondholders.
Party leaders in Arkansas squared off today for a finish fight over selection of a candidate to succeed Joseph T. Robinson in the United States Senate.
Negotiations are well under way between bankers and officials of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for the sale of $28,000,000 of Triborough Bridge 4 per cent bonds, it was disclosed yesterday.

The number of Protestant pastors under arrest is again increasing. Three Confessional Synod pastors in Potsdam were arrested during the week-end or taking up collections at the altar steps for the synod's work.

Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan told the National Conference of State Liquor Administrators tonight that "the American conception of decency, morality and respect of government is far more important than a billion dollars' worth of revenue."

Acting as delegate with full powers of the State Labor Relations Board under the Doyle-Neustein act, the City Industrial Relations Board ruled yesterday against the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, when it decided that the 1,200 motormen and signalmen employed by the B. M. T. shall be excluded from an election of the company's employes.
Benjamin Kronenberg, an attorney, of 270 Broadway, Manhattan, was appointed receiver of the Tompkins Bus Corporation yesterday by Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn.

Mrs. George L. Austin of Hartford sank a deuce on the twentieth hole against Mrs. Charles Eastman of Greenwich on the Brooklawn Country Club links today to give the Connecticut Women's Golf Association team a 9 1/2-to-8 1/2 victory over the Westchester-Fairfield women's golf team.
The national Lumber Manufacturers Association said today that lumber production in the week ended on fuly 10 was 25 per cent larger than new business booked and 19 per ent above reported shipments.

Applicants for enrollment in the Citizens Military Training Camp are in much better physical condition than the average young men examined for service during the World War, Colonel David A. Kraker said today in releasing results of tests held here.

A protective committee representing holders of bonds of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company was organized yesterday and announced immediately afterward that it would wage a "determined fight" against the proposed plan of reorganization when it came before the Interstate Commerce Commission for a hearing today.

Edward B. Freyfogle, president of Rockland County Typographical Union 914 and manager of The Rockland County Messenger, 91 year-old weekly newspaper here, died today in Good Samaritan Hospital at Suffern, N.Y., at the age of 41.

An application by the Narragansett Electric Company for exemption from the necessity of filing a declaration to cover the sale of 40,000 shares of common capital stock of $50-par value to the Rhode Island Public Service Company for $2,000,000 has been approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

George M. Speaker, Utica lawyer, died today at his home here after an illness of two weeks. His age was 65. Mr. Speaker was born in Williamsport, Pa., a son of Charles F. and Priscilla Marsden Speaker.

At high noon yesterday it was decided to phone the Frisch homestead at New Rochelle. No sooner said than done. "Hello, the Frisch farm? Is that man still breathing ?" "He's not here. He didn't come home last night."

Frank Vileno. of Fenway, a veteran of eleven years of golf at the ripe old age of 18, paired a 78 and a 75 to win the annual Westchester County caddie championship today at the Knollwood Country Club, but his total of 153 was not quite enough to take outright possession of the crown.

An example of how a large oldlaw tenement building on the lower East Side can be converted into a modern elevator apartment house and made to pay for itself was given yesterday by B. M. Sylvan, architect.

Under the influence of recent motion picture presentations, many of which have featured dancing, there has been such a tremendous rise in public interest in this form of recreation that more than 6,000,000 adults and children are now enrolled in dancing schools, Donald Grant, vice president of the Dancing Teachers Business Association, reported yesterday at the opening of the annual convention of that organization.
The Century Ribbon Mills denied yesterday that it had made an agreement with the Textile Workers Organizing Committee for its five mills in Pennsylvania and one in Bronxville. Sidney Hillman,

A bomb that exploded late last night at the gate of Colonel Adam Koc's country house, blowing to bits the man carrying it, is believed to have been prepared by a terrorist organization of the illegal National Radical (Fascist) party.

Measured and back in the water, Ranger, the America's Cup defender, and Endeavour II, the English challenger, were here again today for their final sailing tryouts prior to their match for the cup starting a week from next Saturday.

Miss Violet Margaret Catty, elder daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh douglas Catty of Highfields Farm, near here, will be married to Brian Hutton Dulanty, son of John W. Dulanty, High Comissioner in London for the Irish Free State,
If today's reading taste means anything it means that the American people has decidedly not listened to President ROOSEVELT.
William Allen White, in an editorial in his Emporia Gazette today, suggested Mayor Fiorella La Guardia of New York for 1940 Republican Presidential consideration.

Carl M. Snyder has joined the executive staff of National Hotel Management Co., Inc., effective yesterday, it was announced by Ralph Hitz, president. James Talcott, Inc., has been appointed factor for Van Riper Fabrics, Paterson, N. J., manufacturers of upholstery fabrics.

Clinton Street was enlivened yesterday by a brisk monkey chase. The monkey was much better equipped for fast travel in the East Side fire-escape jungle than the pursuing agent of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, but the pursued paused to sneer at his pursuer once too often. The agent caught it in a pigeon net.

Among the organizations reported yesterday to have leased commercial space was the National Council of Women of the United States, Inc., the coordinating body for eighteen national groups with a total membership of several million women.
Thirty-three athletes, composing three teams, were selected by the Amateur Athletic Union yesterday to tour Japan and European countries this Summer, The Associated Press reported.
Dr. Jean Piccard gave thought tonight to improvements for his next multi-balloon aircraft, with a flight into the stratosphere considered a possibility.

Commenting on Governor Lehman's letter to Senator Wagner, Bainbridge Colby said today at Bemus Point, N. Y.: "As a statement of the Governor's opposition to the court-packing endeavors of the President, the letter is timely and gratifying. It does credit to Governor Lehman's intelligence and public conscience, as well as to his political courage.

Young Chappie of Albany is expected to hold a slight advantage in weight when he faces Kid Chocolate, former featherweight champion, in the main bout of eight rounds at the Canarsie Stadium tonight. In a previous meeting, Kid...

The first sign of a let-up in the prosecution of nine Negroes arrested six and a half years ago on a charge of attacking two white girls on a Southern Railway freight train came today in Morgan County Court when the State agreed to waive the death penalty in the case of Andy Wright.

The cost of testing experimental legislation was shown today when J. L. Kraft, president of the Kraft-Phenix Cheese Corporation, said the company spent almost $100,000 in defending itself against charges of price discrimination under the Robinson-Patman Act.

Trading was slow in the wholesale markets yesterday morning. Slaughterhouse business was also slow up to early afternoon. The lamb market was slightly stronger and some fresh pork cuts higher. Some steer cuts were sharply lower and some sales bull meat lower. The markets otherwise showed little change. Early trading in Kosher meats indicated all classes to be higher as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Angelo Catalino, 9 years old, of 405 East 125th Street, and Fannie Rezulli, 14, of 423 East 122d Street, were drowned this afternoon when they waded into the thirty-foot channel of Merrick Creek at Whaleneck Road here. The children,
Five hours before he was to appear at the District Attorney's office to be interrogated about an alleged $5,300 shortage from the Meridian Pictures Corporation of 1,270 Sixth Avenue,

Barnegat Bay and Lake Chautauqua had it out today. over the Mantoloking Yacht Club course in the first of three races to determine the easterin team which will race on the last three days of the week against the Inland Lake Yacht Racing Association. Hirondelle of the
Carl George Meyers, retired engineer known to veteran railroaders as "Pan-American Charlie," died this afternoon at his home here. He was 77 years old.

Sonata, owned by R. R. Williams of Detroit, led a fleet of twenty-three yachts across the finish line at 5:11 o'clock (Eastern standard time), this afternoon in the annual Port Huron-to-Mackinac Island yacht race.

David O. Selznick told the Board of Tax Appeals today that his gross earnings from four pictures which he produced for Metro-GoldwynMayer during 1934 were $208,000. The pictures were "Dinner at Eight," "Dancing Lady," "Viva Villa," and "Manhattan Melodrama."

Seventeen-year-old Joey Fishbach, St. John's University freshman, accounted for the first major upset in the Eastern clay court tennis championship at the Jackson Heights Club yesterday when he routed Paul Newton of Berkeley, Calif., the fourth-seeded player, in a three-set fourth-round struggle. Fishbach, the Eastern junior titleholder, rallied to win at 2-6, 6-2, 6-0.

Ben Parola and Henry Attis of Blue Hill today won the New Jersey P. G. A. pro-amateur tournament over the Homestead Country Club course with a seven-under-par card of 65. Parola, Blue Hill pro, registered a 77 with his own ball, and Attis, former caddie champion at Rivervale, turned in a 74.

Surprising their friends, Miss Helene Anne McAdoo, 21-year-old cousin of Senator William G. McAdoo, was married to Louis E. Jennings, motion-picture camera man, on Saturday at Gardnerville, Nev., it was learned today.
The question whether William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, is to be expelled from the United Mine Workers is likely to be decided tomorrow.
Carnarvon, a colt that seems to have inherited the blinding speed of his sire, Prince of Wales, bounded over six furlongs at Delaware Park to equal the track record in the Amstel Purse today.

Samuel Goodhartz, an American citizen of Polish-Jewish extraction, in an interview yesterday at the Hotel Grand, told the story of his and his daughter's imprisonment in Germany, where he served almost two years in jail and where fines totaling $3,200 were imposed on him.

While Captain Harold E. Gray and his crew of Atlantic survey fliers rested yesterday preparatory to planning new route exploratory flights in that field, it became known that Pan American Airways had begun to put in operation accelerated schedules in the Caribbean and South American areas which bring the Canal Zone within twenty-four hours and Buenos Aires within three and a half days of New York.

On the heels of a recommendation by the Brookings Institution that law enforcement units of the Treasury Department be merged with the Bureau of Investigation, Department of Justice, Secretary Morgenthau today announced a series of two-week training periods for all Treasury Department enforcement units.
The sale of a fifty-foot right-of-way, about 4,000 feet long, by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey to the Central Railroad of New Jersey for trackage to serve 700 acres of land
Magistrate Sylvester Sabbatino warned a youthful married couple in Bridge Plaza Court, Brooklyn, yesterday that patience was necessary in a wife and that gallantry should be shown by a husband.
A record number of ninety-eight players entered the second in a series of weekly putting tournaments held at the Kebo Valley Golf Club today.

In one of the most glorious doubles matches in Davis Cup history, Don Budge and Gene Mako today defeated Baron Gottfried von Cramm and Heinrich Henkel to give the United States a lead of 2---which ought to be good enough -over Germany in the interzone final.

James Roosevelt's plan for the re-employment of the 35,000 WPA workers who have been laid off in Massachusetts was scrapped today by his own committee, over which he presided today at the Parker House.

The fact that retailers are meeting a price firmness in coats and suits that was somewhat unexpected is one of the contributing factors to the hesitancy in the Fall apparel market, according to manufacturers here yesterday. In the upper price

James G. Stahlman, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, told the National Editorial Association today that "the world has gone haywire," and declared that "unless the press of America fulfills its high mission in the days that are ahead, we, too, will find that we have gone the way of the rest."
The German Government has accepted the Hullda Souza Costa declaration on American-Brazilian trade as a challenge and issued a counter-challenge tonight through the Official News Service.

Allen L. Woodworth has been elected president of the United CigarWhelan Stores Corporation, the reorganized United Cigar Stores Company of America, it was announced yesterday. He formerly was with the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc.

The indications are for cloudy weather today and for generally fair weather tomorrow. Little change in temperature is expected, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock (E. S. T.) last night.

It has been President ROOSEVELT'S contention that opposition to his Supreme Court plan has come " from substantially the same elements" which have opposed him on other issues in the past. This argument, which failed to

For the second time in the thirtynine-year history of the Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week, the number of starters topped the 300 mark today. This time there were 335 for the second day of point-scoring competition in Long Island Sound's greatest sailing extravaganza, twenty-four fewer than the all-time record set in th opener Saturday.

Mr. and Mrs. George D. Widener have returned here from Newport to prepare for the opening of the home of Dr. Alexander Hamilton Rice before his arrival on the Europa Aug. 9 with the body of his wife, Mrs. Eleanor Elkins Rice, mother of Mr. Widener, who died recently in Paris.

" An exhibition of degenerate art" was opened here today. It contains numerous examples of paintings and sculptures of the period from 1918 to 1933-the fifteen years that National Socialists call "our era of shame."

The National City Bank has been appointed registrar for 532,197 shares of $5-par common stock of the General Tire and Rubber Company. Poor's Publishing Company is opening a branch office in the Hospital Trust Building, Providence, R. I., Arthur E. Carlson, who represents the company in Rhode Island, is the local manager.
Mrs. Sara Peters Downing of New York gave a luncheon in honor of her aunt, Miss Grace Peters of Newark, N. J.,- today at Terrace Inn, North Egremont.

Lawrence Dallin (Dal) Clawson, a motion-picture photographer for more than thirty years and a founder of the American Society of Cinematographers, died early Sunday of an intestinal malady in the Englewood (N. J.) Hospital, within an hour after the death of his mother, Mrs. Mary Jones Clawson, in Salt Lake City. He was 51 years old.

It was learned at the office of John J. Raskob here yesterday that he has become a farmer, although he admits knowing nothing about farming. The farm he is backing is spread over 286,000 acres of New Mexico.

Through Alex Rose, its executive secretary, the American Labor party, which warmly supported Governor Lehman for re-election, yesterday deplored the Governor's action "in joining the foes of the President's court reform program."

The Nassau-Suffolk Symphony, a WPA Federal Music Project unit conducted by Christos Vrionides, will be heard at Long Beach tonight; Rockville Center, tomorrow; Hofstra College, Hempstead, Thursday, and Babylon, Friday.

Anna Mae Turner, 21 years old, of Schenectady, former wife of Bo Weinberg, alleged aide of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, was married here this afternoon to Martin Anthony May, 37, of 16 Parkview Place.

A working agreement is in force among Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras for mutual protection against disturbing elements "coming across the borders," President Tiburcio Carias Andino revealed in an Interview here. He stressed that no formal treaty existed.

Roosevelt for nearly three hours, Attorney General Cummings emerged from the President's office with this statement: "We discussed the whole legislative program involving all the important matters that are in suspense and how we are going to work them out."
Alex Pisciotta, Deputy Commissioner of Public Markets, Weights and Measures, issued a warning to the public yesterday to beware of short-weight deliveries by dishonest and irresponsible coal dealers.

FIRST ROUND George Counts, Oklahoma City, defeated Donald H. Neill, Philadelphia, 6-4, 6-1, 6-3; Malcolm Weinstein, Philadelphia, defeated Edward (Lefty) Brown, Waco, Texas, 6-1, 6-3, 6-1; Edward (Moe) Brown, Waco, Texas, defeated Walter D'Arcy, Rensselaer, N. Y., 6-0, 6-3, 6-4; George Parks, Miami, defeated Richard O'Shaughnessy, Buffalo, N. Y., 6-0, 6-0. 6-1; Jim Ford, Miami, defeated Clifton H. Bainard, Kenmore High, 6-1, 6-0. 6-0.

Guglielmo Marconi's father wanted him to study music in Bologna after he was graduated from the university there in 1895, but the young man had grown interested in the practical possibilities of certain invisible electric waves.

More than 200 relief workers dropped from WPA rolls resumed their "mass job hunt" yesterday only to learn that the waiting list of applicants already was long and that they should file applications the same as others seeking employment.

The Finsler comet became visible to the naked eye early today. Traveling a path from Perseus, where it has appeared between the big dipper and the north star, the comet will reach its maximum brilliance on Aug. 7.
The Starnes bill, prohibiting use of Federal funds after next Dec. 31 to employ aliens on government jobs, was passed by the House today and sent to the Senate.

Bill Terry might repeat his famous query of three years ago, "Are the Dodgers still in the league?" and do it with some bitterness today. For yesterday the ill-starred Grimes troupe completed a calamitous cycle against the Cubs by going down before the league leaders for the fourth straight time, and in a manner that drew no cheers from the 2.401 fans who paid to see the debacle.
Van Lingle Mungo, Dodgers' ailing ace hurler, stayed out of uniform yesterday and was started through a course of medical examinations in an effort to determine what's wrong with him.

Following are salient passages of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's survey of foreign affairs in the House of Commons today: The situation in the Far East is so confused and anxious that it is difficult to describe it in precise terms.
A two-story building for manufacturing and stores will be erected at 720 Madison Avenue, according to plans filed yesterday. Other filings included various alterations in Manhattan.

Hearings on charges that the Robins Dry Dock and Repair Company of Brooklyn and the Tietjen Lang Dry Dock Company of Hoboken, both subsidiaries of the Todd Shipbuilding Corporation, maintained company unions in violation of the National Labor Relations Act were begun yesterday by the National Labor Relations Board in the Federal Building, Christopher and Washington Streets. Frank Bloom, trial examiner, presided.

Seeded players, led by defending champion Robert Low of Wallingford, Conn., came through the first two rounds unscathed today in the national junior interscholastic tennis championships at the Merion Cricket Club.

Should the Senate reach a voting stage today or in the near future on the President's judiciary legislation, every eye will be fixed with more interest on Senator Wagner than on any other member of the legislative body. Senator Wagner has been decidedly uncomfortable since his constituency has revealed such heavy opposition to the court measures.

Twenty thousand men and women crowded into Madison Square Garden last night and nearly 2,000 more demonstrated briefly in the surrounding streets, in connection with a meeting arranged by supporters of the Valencia government to mark the first anniversary of the outbreak of civil war in Spain.

A three-run scoring spurt against Fabian Kowalik in the third inning proved enough to give the Jersey City Giants a 3-to-2 triumph over the Bisons in the opener of a threegame series tonight. Two of the tallies were unearned.
Danzig's large shipbuilding industry is now being extensively used for war preparations by Germany and her allies.

Independent hardware retailers were urged to combat competition with modern merchandising methods and planned newspaper adverrising campaigns by Hugh C. Ross, retiring president of the National Retail Hardware Association,

The completion of a series of trade agreement providing for the restoration of normal commercial relations between Germany and that part of Spain now under the authority of the government of General Francisco Franco, Insurgent chief, was announced officially today.

Swinging around the circuit, catches of big game fish and bluefish were conspicuous by their absence over the week-end. Going down the line, highlights of the activities at a few of the fishing centers developed the following: Montauk--Although the broadbill fleet was in action, few swordfish were sighted. Some of the veterans believe this is an "in-between time."

The National Cash Register Company and subsidiaries announced yesterday that the net profit for the second quarter of 1937 amounted to $1,185,838 after deductions for depreciation, Federal and foreign income taxes and other charges.
Sir George Mills McKay, co-founder and honorary treasurer of the English Speaking Union, died here today after a brief illness. He would have celebrated his sixty-eighth birthday tomorrow.

No objections have be ~n filed in the Westchester County Surrogate's Court to the proposed distribution of the estate of the late John D. Rockefeller in accordance with his will and its codicils, although the time for submitting objections will expire at 10 A. M. tomorrow.

James H. McCabe was appointed manager of the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, succeeding Frank A. Duggan, who was recently advanced to the position of executive vice president in charge of hotel operations for Hotels Statler Company, Inc. Mr. McCabe rejoins

Two of the officers of the chicken truckers' union who are to go on trial next Monday on a charge of embezzling union funds confronted a mass meeting of union members last night and received an ovation.

Mr. and Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs are planning to entertain at Rosecliff on Saturday with music and dancing. The party will be one of the feature entertainments of the night, as Saturday marks the closing of the International College Tennis

A large dog went on a sit-down strike last night in the laundry of Nathan Chodorow at 133 East Forty-fifth Street and refused to budge for an hour and a half until two policemen and a dozen onlookers were able to persuade it to leave.
Two New York Curb Exchange seats have been sold for $19,000 each, down $800 from the previous sale and the lowest figure recorded since March 15, 1935, when a membership changed hands at $12,000.

Lashing out at the Roosevelt administration's policy of spending money we haven't got," Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey urged yesterday "a return to the principles that have made America great before we go so far as to completely destroy the American incentive to work."

Despite a three-hour delay, caused by a balky condenser on the Colonel Clayton, a boatload of mothers and children from New York's tenement districts sailed off yesterday afternoon on the first of a new Summer series of municipal excursions.

Clayton Martin, known in Harlem and in Negro communities throughout the country as "the Prophet," died in Harlem Hospital Saturday morning, it became known yesterday. He was 86 years old. Death was due to natural causes.

The West on a magnificent scale is again intriguing the cinema. Planning to outdo in spectacle and lavishness such epics as "Covered Wagon," "Iron Horse" and "Cimarron," Walter Wanger today disclosed plans for a color offering, "California," by Grover Jones, which will be budgeted at $2,000,000.
Automobile production increased last week, but daily average output declined more than seasonally and the adjusted index has receded to 131.7 from 135.1. It was 96.7 for the week ended July 18, 1936.

It will soon be two years since these parts were treated to their last earthquake but one. Monday's disturbance soon after midnight was of the mildest type; earthquake preferred is the only kind we take any stock in. Lisbon's,

A total of 172,861 tourists visited Cuba durng the fiscal year ended June 30, a number far greater than for any year during the past eleven years and exceeding by 10,000 the previous record of 162,347 in the fiscal

After yesterday's fierce fighting, which has had no equal in Spain's civil war, both sides struggled with less energy today as they gathered strength for the crucial activity of the next few days. All the effort the Insurgents

Mr. and Mrs. Israel Weinberg of 345 West Eighty-eighth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Weinberg, to J. Richard Siegel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Siegel, also of New York.

A young couple, married only last February, were found dead last night in their three-room apartment on the second floor of a twofamily house at 53-57 Sixty-fifth Place, Ridgewood Plateau, Queens. There were no marks of violence apparent but the cause of death remained unexplained pending an autopsy.

George S. Parker, who rose from telegrapher ?o head of the Parker Pen Com??any, which he founded, died today ??t the Billings Memorial Hospital ??fter an illness of two months. He was 73 years old and lived at Janes??ille, Wis., home office of the com??any.

Funeral services for Daniel Shaw of Belle Harbor, Queens, detective of the New York Police Department, were held yesterday morning in the Church of St. Francis de Sales, Beach 129th Street and Rockaway Beach Boulevard, Belle Harbor. The Rev. Thomas Ford, curate of the church, officiated.

THE trouble with most short stories is that they are too long. They are festooned with local color. The same point-that the hero has a resoundingly quiet sense of humor or that the heroine appreciates a man of seven-thousandword tenacity-is made over and over again.

Robert Barr's six-meter sloop Aphrodite, from the Royal Canadian Yacht Club at Toronto, won the first race of a challenge match on Lake Ontario for the George Cup from Raymond Lee's defender Mist of the Olcott Yacht Club, today.

Sales of Fall and holiday lines of fancy towels have been better than selling agents anticipated in the two weeks since they were introduced, sales executives reported yesterday. Road men have booked substantial business in both bulk and sets.
The New York State Planning Council in a statement issued here today emphasized the "tremendous losses to the public resulting from premature subdivision."

" Halo" hats, the latest in feminine headgear, were banned today as "inadequate" for wear in Catholic churches of Louisville. Father E. E. Willett, pastor of St. James Catholic Church and vicar-general of the Louisville Diocese, frowned on the open crown top pieces, expressing doubt that the hats were adequate head covering under the church laws.

The National Maritime Union, which was organized last May in protest against the policies of the International Seamens Union, met yesterday at the Manhattan Opera House, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street, preparatory to the opening of its first annual convention this morning.

Governor Lehman came out today in opposition to the Supreme Court Reorganization Bill of his close personal and political friend, President Roosevelt. He urged Senator Wagner to vote against the measure, which he felt would create a "greatly dangerous precedent."

Captain Charles B. Scully, Red Cross life-saving director, declared yesterday that more lives are lost in the waters of the New York area than in any other place in the civilized world. He spoke at Manhattan and Brighton Beaches at the opening of a campaign of the Brooklyn Red Cross for water safety.

The first day of the international ski competition taking place on Los Farallones snowfields, on the flanks of the Andes opposite Santiago, proved favorable to the United States team. Turning out early yesterday when the first rays of the sun topped the Andean peaks towering 20,000 feet into space, the Americans were in good condition when the slalom race commenced over the 500-meter track, zigzagged with red and blue flags.
Cincinnati at New York--Derringer vs. Melton. Pittsburgh at Brooklyn--Blanton vs. Butcher. Chicago at Philadelphia-Lee vs. LaMaster. St. Louis at Boston--Haines or Weiland vs. Fette or Bush.
Beginning of the second week of active retail buying for Fall yesterday found the number of buyers arriving in New York markets almost equal to the heavy influx of last week. Price changes in the

A new series of books planned to "intensify the joy, the understanding, and the values of life in the country, and give useful, practical information and guidance as well," is announced by Farrar Rinehart and The Countryman Press.

For about ten minutes yesterday morning what resembled a snowstorm raged at Madison Avenue and Forty-first Street as an explosion of a sixteen-inch main sent steam and debris fifty feet into the air and caused two manhole covers to dance grotesquely on the pavement.

A revival of plans for a Hudson River bridge from Weehawken, N. J., to the neighborhood of Fifty-seventh Street in New York City today brought about the first meeting in five years between President Roosevelt and James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York.

Three very rare insectivor animals of the species Solenodon paradoxus were received by the Central Park Zoo yesterday, and immediately went into retirement under a pile of straw in the elephant house.

Dr. Mary E. Woolley is ready to move from Mount Holyoke College, of which she was president for thirty-seven years, to a life of active retirement in which she will read intensively, write and work for world peace.

Mrs. H. O. Lichtenwalter and H. O. Lichtenwalter Jr. of Canoe Brook won the third annual motherand-son metropolitan championship tournament at the Westchester Hills Golf Club today with a fine round of 76-8-68. This bit of scoring was good for both low gross and low net, with only the former of the prizes going to the winners.

It is reported in Havana that a plan has been placed before the President of tuba calling for the establishment of a factory for the manufacture of electricc incandescent lamp bulbs, and that the plan, if enacted, would

A second plan for reorganizing the Utilities Power and Light Corporation-a utility holding company whose assets amounted at one time to $400,000,000-was submitted today to Federal Judge William H. Holly by Robert N. Golding, counsel for a group of debenture holders.

Press photos today depict the extent of the riots in Sao Paulo yesterday during the march of 20,000 Integralistas, when shooting broke out and heavy police reinforcements were dispatched to quell the disturbance. The pictures show bodies lying in the streets.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward K. Roberts of Simsbury have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Knight Roberts, to Dr. Thomas Thegen of Penobscot, Me., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Thegen of Camden, N. J.

Two Southern schoolboys and an Easterner struggled successfully through three gruelling quarterfinal-round matches in the national junior interscholastic tennis championships at the Merion Cricket Club today.

The marriage of Miss Marjcrie Hall to George Richard Turner, son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Turner of Chadwick House, has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Clarence V. Hall of Newcastle, Ind. The ceremony took place on June 27 at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Hall, the Rev. Robert Cope officiating.

Opening the annual national convention of the Ancient Order of Hibernians here today, the Most Rev. James A. Griffin, Bishop of the Springfield (Ill.) diocese of the Roman Catholic Church, bitterly attacked communism, stating that it would establish society upon hate and blind evolutionary force.
The Tigers defeated the Red Sox, 10 to 9, in the tenth inning of their freehitting game today. The teams collected 32 hits-16 apiece-for a total of 60 bases.
The War Department liberalized today its regulations on assignment of reserve officers to duty with the CCC to obtain greater efficiency in operations.

Lengthening the school day from five to seven or eight hours to enable children to develop hobbies, play games and participate in physical exercise after they have finished their regular schoolroom work was advocated yesterday by Dr. George D. Strayer, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University.

Congress met today at its second regular session in four months, with the House majority favoring the nomination of Eduardo Santos, Liberal candidate for President, at the next convention. The Senate was unchanged, although a number of Radical members of the last Congress failed of reelection.

Democratic bills for county government reform were introduced yesterday at a meeting of the Board of Aldermen by Alderman Timothy J. Sullivan, majority leader. The bills were referred to the Municipal Assembly's Joint Committee on County Consolidation, where similar bills offered by Alderman Newbold Morris have languished for more than a year, and others offered by Brooklyn Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll for several months.
Governor Hoffman of New Jersey, motoring to this Lancaster County town for an American Legion convention today, came in contact with two labor disputes.

There seemed to be some confusion yesterday about the reports from Hollywood that Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt would write a series of advertisements to be used in national magazines as part of the advertising campaign for Samuel Goldwyn's production of "Stella Dallas."

Clay Ave, 1.378 (11-2887); Joshua Koeningsberg, referee, to North Side Savings Bank. Groes Ave. 1,196 (14-3748): Joseph Langellotti to Home Owners Loan Corp. Gleason Ave, 2,158 (14-3811); Maria Giardina to Francesca Giardina, 2.158 Gleason Ave. Carroll St, 81 (18-5629): Arthur J. McBride, referee, to Frances M. Reiss, 84 Reynold St.

Senator Borah said today that the Western beet growers "frankly want and need" new legislation to extend the Jones-Costigan act's sugar quota system and revive benefit payments to producers. In a telegram to Clarence R. Bitting, Florida sugar producer, he rejected Mr. Bitting's suggestion

Execution of twenty-four more alleged "Trotskyist and Japanese terrorist spies and wreckers" was reported from the Soviet Far East today. The Khabarovsk (Siberia) court that sentenced them accused them of sabotage along the Trans-Siberian Railroad.
Representations were being made today in behalf of Bermuda to the United States Government to have the embargo on the trans-shipments of meat from United States ports lifted temporarily.

County Judge Jonathan D. Wilson today set aside a first degree robbery conviction returned by an Orange County Court jury in December against George Phillips of New York City, accused of participation in the $14,000 Pine Bush bank robbery on May 11, 1936.

Chief of Police Alex Rosenswaike and Lieutenant Harry Yale, both of the Island Park (L. I.) Police Department, and seven co-defendants were arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions, Brooklyn, on a charge of conspiracy to obtain money under false pretenses by operating a charity scheme in which several thousand persons were victimized All the defendants pleaded nol guilty and were held in bail for trial Oct. 4.

Several rentals in the apartment house now under construction at 5 Riverside Drive featured the contracts for residential space reported yesterday. Among those taking space in the structure is General Charles G. Blakeslee, former State Public Service Commissioner, and now brigadier general commanding the Ninety-third Brigade, New York National Guard. The full list of rentals follows:

The closing day of the Pan-American ski competition gave the American team another overwhelming victory in a difficult race down hill over a five-mile track, which sixteen competitors covered in a brilliant performance but not in record time, owing to the condition of the snow.

Buying activity improved at the corset show yesterday at the Hotel McAlpin, as buyers arrived here in large numbers. The greatest pickup in business over Monday was noted at the displays of the larger manufacturers, where orders were booked in satisfactory volume.

Twenty-two persons were injured tonight, several seriously, when two trains of a roller coaster were in collision in Riverview Park, a Northwest Side amusement resort. All the injured were taken to the North Avenue Hospital.
William Green said today that the American Federation of Labor intended to set up eventually a new union of newspaper editorial room employee.

The United States Steel Corporation reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission today that it paid $166,862 to Myron C. Taylor, chairman of its board, last year. W. A. Irvin, president, received $130,310.

The government will decide soon, possibly this week, what the policy of the Canadian Wheat Board will be regarding the corning wheat crop. J. R. Murray, Winnipeg, chairman of the board, today met the wheat committee of the Cabinet, and the committee will shortly submit its recommendations.

In a hearing room packed with lawyers and others representing divergent groups of creditors and security holders, E. G. Buckland, chairman of the board, and three other officials of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad presented its reorganization plan today to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 17: COMMANDERS Eckert, G. A.. Med. Corps, Pearl Harbor to Portsmouth, Va. Lineberry, W. T., Med. Corps, Philadelphia, to the Relief. Haeberle, F. E., Construction Corps, previous orders modified, to Navy Yard, Philadelphia.
The Yankees stumbled through a doubleheader with the Browns at Sportsman's Park by way of celebrating the completion of the first half of their championship schedule today.
The Census Bureau announced today that the cotton-spinning industry operated at 137.0 per cent of capacity in June, compared with 137.7 per cent in May this year and 111.0 per cent in June last year.

A quick resale of an upper East Side property was made yesterday by Samuel Brener, the operator. Last week Mr. Brener bought from the Alliance Realty Company the nine-story apartment house at 10 East Eighty-fifth Street, near Fifth Avenue.

The Lincoln Trust Company sold to Nathan Levine the two-and-onehalf story dwelling at 114 West Thirty-third Street, Bayonne, N. J. Margaret D. Jaffe purchased from Celia Davis the northeast corner of Bergen and Forest Streets, Kearny.

There is an old but just now timely story of the hotel employee who remained on the job after the rest of the kitchen force.had walked out on strike. The manager approached him hopefully--perhaps with this remnant he could still save the day. " What do you do? " he asked.

E. T. Meredith entertained with a dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for Mr. and Mrs. A. Thayer Jaccaci, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Compton, Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Taylor, Mr. and Mrs. William Price, Mr. and Mrs. Randolph Paul and Miss Consuelo Flowerton.

With the aid of Thomas E. Dewey, special rackets prosecutor, who has placed many food racketeers behind bars, most of the rackets in the commodity markets have now been eliminated, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Public Markets, Weights and Measures, declared yesterday.

Fire destroyed the old World War base hospital here today, wiping out one of the last temporary structures remaining from those war-torn days. Starting at 9:30 A. M. in the upper floor of the base hospital, which has been used as a dispensary and examining room for Reserve officers,

The Rutgers-Princeton football game will be played at Palmer Stadium on Oct. 23 as originally scheduled and not at New Brunswick, Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of Princeton athletics, announced today.

Magistrate David L. Malbin criticized the Coney Island police yesterday for arresting peddlers instead of issuing summonses. The magistrate pointed out that departmental regulations permitted the issuance of summonses in most of the cases involved.

Mr. and Mrs. Wladimir W. Bouimistrow and the latter's daughter, Miss C. Fontaine Fahnestock, arrived on the Westernland and are at the Plaza. Mrs. Gould Shaw and her daughter, Miss Penelope Shaw, have come to the Ritz Tower from Warrenton, Va.

Two New York officials have been in Cleveland since last Friday checking up on the activities in this city of Robert Irwin, facing trial this Fall for the Gedeon slaying, for the purpose, they said today, of obtaining evidence to attack a defense plea of insanity.
The great Insurgent counter-offensive is declared thoroughly smashed. It was almost possible to say as much yesterday, although the biggest battle of the civil war was still raging Sunday.
Opening prices for Spring lines of tropical worsteds and gabardines were announced yesterday by the American Woolen Company and are expected to be followed quite generally by other mills.

A memorial concert dedicated to George Gershwin will be given Monday evening, Aug. 9, at Lewisohn Stadium, it was announced yesterday. The concert is under the sponsorship of a committee, now being organized, which will include Irving Berlin, Jerome Kern,

New profit possibilities are opened to New England textile mills by chemical treatments imparting valuable new properties to cotton goods, according to Walter M. Scott, textile expert of a firm of Boston chemical consultants. Textile manufacturers think of cotton as a finished product of nature's handiwork which cannot be improved, Dr. Scott says.

Death Announced Retired Fireman William Delaney, formerly a member of Engine 52, residing at 63 W. 183d St., Bronx. died July 18. Baseball A baseball game has been arranged between a municipal team representing the City of Philadelphia and a municipal team representing the City of New York to be held at the Polo Grounds at 2 P. M. Saturday, Aug. 7.

The Very Rev. Brother Ambrose, a former Baltimore Christian brother, has been elected superior general of the Xaverian Order, according to an announcement at provincial headquarters of the order here. The Baltimore Catholic Review stated that the election was held in Bruges, Belgium.

THOSE bulletins from Wimbledon yesterday gave a lot of tennis fans a ghastly fright. They were resigned to receiving word that Bitsy Grant had succumbed to Herr Heinrich Henkel, the "fast-ball pitcher" of Der Vaterland. They say this Henkel hits a serve the way Muscles Medwick massages a curve.

Miss Katharine Lockwood Chapman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Andrew Chapman of this ge city, was married today in the First Presbyterian Church here to Herbert Cadogan Francis of Nashville, Tenn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Francis Sr. of Newcastle, Pa. Dr. John L. Caughey officiated. Mrs.
The strike that closed many Parisian boulevard restaurants ended tonight when operators and employes signed an agreement revising the work week.

The Longchamps chain of restaurants has leased approximately 30,000 square feet of space in the Paragon Building, on the northwest corner of Murray Street and Broadway, for an eleventh unit, which it is said will be the largest restaurant in New York City.

The expressions of regret at the death of Guglielmo Marconi yester day were as widespread as the radio structure that has been buil?? on his practical pioneer work. Scientists whose researches have developed radio from the uncertain dot-dash telegraph of forty years ago to the present prospect of television paid tribute to Marconi's continuing contributions in the field which he dramatically opened.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts--12,000 including 2,000 directs. The market closing was active, around 5-10 lower than Monday's average. Part of early decline was regained.

Marquis Guglielmo Marconi died of a heart attack at 3:45 this morning, after an illness of only a few hours. He was 63. [Marquis Marconi's death was reported in the last edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday.]

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, principal subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, yesterday reaffirmed prices of its principal rolled products for the fourth quarter of this year covering all deliveries up to Dec. 31.
Secretary MORGENTHAU thinks competition among the secret service agencies of various Federal departments is a good thing,

From such widely separated points as Bimini and Nova Scotia come accounts of giant rod and reel catches. One of New York's noted anglers, Michael Lerner, has added his twenty-eighth blue marlin to his string at Bimini.

A lawn fete at Harbour Court, home of Mrs. Nicholas Brown, was held this afternoon and evening to aid Emmanuel Church. Other benefits were a sale of articles under the auspices of the Disabled ExServicemen's Exchange. Inc.,

Celestin Durand of the Garden City Golf Club, always one of the last players to start out in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day tournaments, brought in a score of 36, 35-71 to tie Karl Karch of Idlewild for the low gross honors at the Woodmere Club today.
Four games today started the second of the league tournaments of the Meadow Brook Club, the 12-goal Hempstead Cups tournament, with action on four of the club fields.

Guglielmo Marconi's experiments will be continued by a small staff of experts he built up over a period of many years. They are under the direction of the Belgian engineer Matthieu with financing by the Italian Marconi Company.

" Japan will find it impossible to accede to the conditions and proposals of General Chiang Kaishek [Nanking government leader]," a Japanese Embassy spokesman at Tientsin announced early yesterday evening.

As the trade expected, the United States Steel Corporation's principal subsidiary has reaffirmed present steel prices for all principal rolled products for the fourth quarter, so that the higher prices introduced in March will remain in effect to the end of the year.

Donald Budge defeated Baron Gottfried von Cramm today, 6-8, 5-7, 6-4, 6-2, 8-6, in a match which will be forever memorable in every land where lawn tennis is played. In doing so, the California redhead not only brought the United States within striking distance of the Davis Cup, for ten long years in alien hands, but vindicated his fighting ability inherited from his Scottish ancestors.

Magistrate Charles Solomon suspended sentence in Flatbush Court yesterday on two men and a young woman whom he found guilty of disorderly conduct in picketing the home of Representative Marcellus Evans at 305 East Fourth Street, Brooklyn, on the night of May 14.

The Internal Revenue Bureau announced refunds today of $152,176.06, abatements of $87,630.72 and credits of $67,058.76, an aggregate of $306,865.54 in connection with overassessments levied against taxpayers.

By a policy of forcing the use of a barter system, German traders are making this densely populated but, tiny Central American country absorb an increasing volume of German goods. As German sales soar here in the geographical backyard of the United States, American sales threaten to fall off.

The Polish Diet in an extraordinary session tonight confirmed the government's action in accepting the apology of Archbishop Sapieha, Metropolitan of Crakow, for transferring Marshal Pilsudki's coffin from its crypt in Wawel Cathedral to the Silver Bell Tower, but at the same time it placed on record the fact that full satisfaction has not been given to the marshal's family and the Polish people by this prelate who insulted the President.

Next week apparently will give the Summer theatres of the East their biggest chance for mild experimentation, for in addition to the new plays earlier announced there are now three further starters in the rural sweepstakes. They are:

Estate, $5,000. To Howard A. Brooke, son, executor, Portaubeck, N. J., reisdue. BROWN, HERBERT D. (July 10). Estate, more than $10,000. To Edith Williams Brown, widow, executrix, 1,130 Park Ave., residue.

" False and misleading" advertising of the price of automobiles has been charged against the General Motors Corporation and Ford Motor Company by the Federal Trade Commission, the commission announced today. The companies have twenty days from service of the complaints to answer to charges.

Hesitancy among manufacturers of popular price dresses, based on reports the chains will not support the proposed $3.25 range in place of the present price line of $2.87%, led yesterday to an agreement to take a poll of the thirty-six members of the National Association of Apparel Chains.

Attorney General Edward J. Daly today gave embattled residents of the Saugatuck Valley section of Weston, including Webb Waldron and Stuart Chase, the economist, no hope in their fight against the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company's move to condemn 5,000 acres of land in the valley touching Weston and Redding.

The wedding of Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, rector of Trinity Church here, and Miss Mary Kent Blagden of Philadelphia will take place on Sept. 4 at Saranac, N. Y., the bride's Summer home, it was learned today.

Russell Hoogerhyde of Clarenton Hills, Ill., took the lead today as the men's first York Round in the fifty-seventh annual target meeting of the National Archery Association was completed. His score was 752 points with 132 arrows. C. J. Weese, Newark, N. J., placed second with 710 with 132.

The violence which accompanied C. I. O. activities in connection with the steel strike confirmed Inland Steel executives in their refusal to sign a contract with the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, according to Wilfred Sykes, assistant to P. D.

The report of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System for the fiscal year ended June 30, subject to audit and final adjustment, shows a net income of $4,508,462 after all deductions including a $648,000 reserve for amortization of leasehold investment under Contract No. 4, but before provision for possible surtax on undistributed profits, as compared with $4,997,588 the year before, after a reserve of $610,000 for leasehold amortization.

Clinton Ave. 2,075 (11-3095): Young Israel Synagogue of Tremont to Joseph A. Muldoon, 1.239 Madison Ave; 5 years, 5 per cent; S20,000. Mount Hope P1, 215 (11-2804): 1,815 Monroe Ave Corp to Charles Elenberg, 1,645 Grand Concourse; Installments, 6 per cent; $50,000.

All employes of Browne Vintners Company, Inc., and its subsidiary companies have been given life insurance policies ranging from $1,000 to $5,000 under a new plan announced by the liquor distributing house yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your account in THE TIMES this morning of a letter from Ralph M. Easley, chairman of the executive council of the National Civic Federation, to President Roosevelt contains a list of charges against the Federal Writers Project, to which the following facts about the up-State New York project are offered in reply:

Rose St, 57, 23 ft front; Millard Ellison to Bowery Savings Bank; consideration $12,500, foreclosure. 4th St, 104-106 E, 37.6x96.2; 104-6 East Fourth St Realty Corp to Sagamore Holdings, Inc, 570 7th Ave, c/o Struckler Levine ($52). 107th St, 324 W, 25x101; Vanderbilt Ave Realty Corp to Karlopat Realty Corp, 405 Lexington Ave: mtg $25,000 held by grantee.

What occurred at the meeting of the London NonIntervention Committee today should go a long way toward dispelling the illusions of those who believe that the antagonistic policies regarding Spain followed by France and Great Britain on the one hand and Germany and Italy on the other can be prevented from clashing.
Australia- recorded her fifth victory since 1907 in the empire match for military marksmen today, scoring over teams from Canada, Great Britain and India.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,557,950 barrels, compared with 3,520,750 in the previous week, an increase of 37,200, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Paine, Webber Co. and Estabrook Co. were awarded yesterday $1,200,000 of 2 3/4 per cent equipment trust certificates of the Spokane, Portland Seattle Railroad Company on a bid of 102.222.

A strike of towboat employes, to be effective Aug. 1, was threatened yesterday afternoon by William Bradley, an official of the maritime union controlling the towboat men, when a committee of owners announced that new wages and working conditions could not be made effective for about six weeks.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Gretchen Rose, daughter of Mrs. Katherine T. Rose of this city and the late Oscar Rosenberger of Detroit, to Gerard Richardson of Paris, which took place on July 15 in London.

Miss Marie Louise Butts, daughter of Major and Mrs. George Whitfield Butts of Sunny Lawn, Wynnewood, was married this morning to Herbert Forrest Stratton, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Joseph Stratton of Overbrook.
Opposition to the proposed partitioning of Palestine was expressed today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in an indignant statement to the press.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 19 unless specified: At Puget Sound Yard: Arctic, West Virginia. At Petersburg: Borie, Trever, Zane. At Tacoma: California. Nevada, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Tennessee. At West Point, July 20: Erie, Jacob Jones, Manley.

Leading from start to finish in a three-horse field, the filly Broad Ripple, owned by Mrs. R. A. Van Clief, yesterday captured the Fordham Handicap at Empire City, where horses are getting scarcer and scarcer with the waning days of the meeting.

One man was killed and three others were injured in a fire that started shortly before 9:30 o'clock last night on the second floor of a five-story tenement at the southeast corner of Tenth Avenue and Thirtyfifth Street, and spread to an adjoining building before the flames were brought under control.

Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett, swimming star who was barred from the last Olympics, said today she had discussed a divorce with her orchestra leader husband, Arthur Jarrett, now appearing at the Dallas Exposition in Texas.
Dramatic examples of radio's contributions to safety on the sea were brought to mind yesterday by the death of Marquis Guglielmo Marconi, inventor of the wireless, on Monday night in Rome.

William Carrington Stettinius, former chairman of the Maryland Advisory Commission on Public Works, who was associated with the Baltimore branch of the New York Stock Exchange firm of C. D. Barney Co., died here this afternoon in the Johns Hopkins Hospital after an illness of several weeks of uremic poisoning. He was 41 years old.

Melvin C. Hutson, circuit solicitor of Morgan County, told the jury in the Scottsboro case today that he wanted Andy Wright, a Negro accused of attacking Victoria Price, punished not by death in the electric chair but by life imprisonment.

James C. Dunn, chief of the European Division of the State Department, was appointed today adviser on political relations for the department and Jay Pierrepont Moffatt was designated to succeed him as chief of the European Division. Both are career diplomats.
The German press marked today the fourth anniversary of the signing of the Reich's Concordat with the Vatican with renewed attacks on Catholic prelates and policies.

Women's organizations in the Peiping pledged today that "two hundred million women in China will urge their husbands and instruct their sons to abandon the hearth of home and take to the field to resist Japanese aggression."
Improvement of airways at a cost of about $5,000,000 by modernizing present aids to navigation and providing new facilities were announced today by the Bureau of Air Commerce.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation and the Consolidated Coppermines Corporation have signed a new contract for the smelting of ore produced by Consolidated Coppermines at the rate of 6,000 tons daily in Kennecott's smelter in Nevada, it was announced here yesterday.
Hundreds of telegrams reached the Executive chamber today as a result of Governor Lehman's letter to Senator Wagner, urging him to oppose President Roosevelt's court reorganization plan.

President Roosevelt granted unconditional pardons today to Anthony Labrizetta, 34, and George Sargent, 39, of Akron, who have been imprisoned more than a year for a $125,000 mail robbery which Federal officers now attribute to the Karpis gang.

Four of the five defendants in the bakery racket trial were convicted of conspiracy yesterday by Justices William R. Bayes, Max Salomon and Bernard A. Kozicke of the Court of Special Sessions. They are liable to indeterminate terms of not more than three years in the penitentiary.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Norma Lillian Crandall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Crandall of Overbrook, to John Whitfield Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Taylor of Glen Ridge, N. J., which will take place on July 31 in the Congregational Church, Berlin, N. H.
Jacob P. Epstein, often the subject of attack and the center of controversy artistic circles, appears to have suffered defeat in his latest tilt with officials of the Southern Rhodesian government.

The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday declined below that for the preceding week and the corresponding week of last year, according to the listings published in THE TIMES.

Cincinnati at New York-Hollingsworth vs. Castleman. Pittsburgh at Brooklyn-Bowman vs. Henshaw. Chicago at Philadelphia (2)-Lee and French vs. Johnson and Passeau. St. Louis at Boston (2)-Dean and Haines vs. Fette and Macfayden.

President Roosevelt said today that he saw no reason for invoking the neutrality laws in the Chino-Japanese crisis as yet. The situation there had not developed to a point where the question of invoking the embargoes of the act must be faced, he said.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today granted to the Philadelphia Stock Exchange unlisted-trading privileges in odd lots in the no-par common stock of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the $1-par common stock of the Studebaker Corporation, but denied the Exchange the trading privileges in round lots, or lots of eleven shares or more.
Dr. R. A. Millikan, president of the California Institute of Technology and internationally known scientist, had the following to say today on Marconi's death:
An average Toledo (Ohio) citizen now has $35 in cash more than he had at this time last year, according to reports published by State and national banks,

" Political and propagandistic activity" in the Federal dance project here was decried yesterday by the Dancing Teachers Business Association in a resolution adopted at its convention at the Park Central Hotel.

While the French franc fell further yesterday to cheaper prices than it had known in nearly eleven years, the pound sterling, the guilder and other important currency units moved strongly against the dollar with a uniformity that seemed to reflect the withdrawal from this market of some of the European "hot money" held here.

Sales of properties in the Bronx reported yesterday were marked by a deal for an apartment house completed recently in the Mosholu Parkway section. An investor bought from Samuel Derfner, builder, the six-story elevator apartment house at 55 West Mosholu Parkway, between Gates Place and Gun Hill Road.

United States, Canadian and European radio leaders and persons formerely associated with Guglielmo Marconi paid tributes yesterday to the "Father of Radio" through the medium made possible by the foresight and researches of the Italian inventor.

Ranger, the America's Cup defender, is to race the first Endeavour before the America's Cup match. With T. O. M. Sopwith, and those associated with him in the challenger Endeavour II, asserting that the newer English yacht is slightly faster than the former challenger,

For a while today it looked as though the Larchmont Yacht Club's thirty-ninth annual race week would be favored by a real, rail-down breeze, a rarity this season, but the 325 starters ultimately wound up with the Sound in another of its perverse moods.

A banking group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,225,000 of certificates of indebtedness of the State of Minnesota, on a bid of 100.178 for 2s. The certificates will be dated July 30, 1937, and mature on July 30, 1942.

The working population of the United States would have to work seven days a week steadily for more than ten months to pay off the public debt with its daily wage earnings, a research staff of the Twentieth Century Fund reported yesterday.

All indications from Detroit and other manufacturing centers now point to an automobile production for 1937 of 5,000,000 units-a total contemplated in estimates early in the year but for a time thought to be unlikely because of serious disruption of manufacturing schedules through strikes.

The body of Irma Louise Pradier, 35-year-old domestic worker at Mount Sinai Hospital, who had resigned from her job on Monday to be married, was found at 6 o'clock yesterday morning near the curbstone in a lonely section of the Harlem River Speedway, near 165th Street. She had been shot twice, through the abdomen and over the heart.

Pete Traxler, Oklahoma desperado, and one of his companions in a break from a Texas prison farm, escaped into the Washita River bottoms late today after a battle with a posse of about 100 officers in which Traxler's wife was captured. None of the posse was wounded.

The Astor Theatre will be relighted tonight for the premiere of Paramount's musical epic of the oil industry, "High, Wide and Handsome," which will be shown thereafter twice daily on a reserved-seat basis.

Members of the P. R. T. Employes Union, recognized by the trustees of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company as bargaining agent for 9,300 employes, voted today for union officers. Factional disputes assured spirited contests for all posts.
" On the 20th I am going away," Guglielmo Marconi wrote shortly before his death. Vatican officials disclosed his possible premonition that the end was near.

Bruce Coltart, Wooderest, N. J., professional, who led the field by five strokes at the half-way point, will meet Leonard Dodson, Springfield, Mo., in a play-off tomorrow for the Philadelphia open golf title.
This city became a transcontinental air terminus for the first time today when two passenger planes of United Airlines left Central Airport on westward trips and two others arrived from the West.

WASHIGTON, July 20.--The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 19: COLONELS Harris. C. T. Jr., Ordnance Dept., detailed as member of Joint Army and Navy Board for the purpose of considering specifications for manufacture and test of gun forgings, , vice Col. J. E. Munroe. Ordnance. deceased.

A strong trend toward luxury silks for Fall and the eventual return of silk to its former predominating position as "queen" of textile fibers, through renewed emphasis on quality standards and better merchandising, were predicted yesterday at the first Fashion and Silk Merchandise Forum held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel under the auspices of the International Silk Guild.

The all-conquering track forces of Oxford and Cambridge Universities scored an easy victory late today over the Hamilton Olympic Club and its borrowed athletes, while the British captain, Arthur G. K. Brown, suffered the first defeat of his North American visit.

CONVERSATION AT MIDNIGHT, by Edna St. Vincent Millay. (Harper, $2.) A sequence of poems. NOTHING IS SAFE, by E. M. Delafield. (Harper, $2.50.) A novel concerned with divorce. THE MAN WHO WAS MURDERED Twice, by Robert H. Leltfred. (Green Circle, $2.) A mystery.

Franklin I. Badgley of Flossmoor, Ill., in charge of the industrial relations department of Swift Co., died last night of a heart attack in the Billings Hospital after an illness of two years. He was 50 years old.

Mayor La Guardia, wisecracking in the style of his predecessor, James J. Walker, formally opened yesterday the world's largest openair stage-which is also a stage on wheels-at the Randalls Island Stadium.

William S. Knudsen, president of the General Motors Corporation, answered yesterday a letter from Homer Martin, president of the International Union, United Automobile Workers of America, parts of which were published in Sunday's newspapers.

John L. Lewis announced tonight that William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor and former secretary-treasurer of the United Mine Workers, would be put on trial before the miners' executive board this week on a charge of "dual unionism."

Coming back strongly in his afternoon round with a par 70, Pat Paldino of Mount Vernon registered a 148 for thirty-six holes to capture the honors in the annual Westchester County caddie masters championship tournament at the Knollwood Country Club today.

Two more Brooklyn shipyards, the Crane plant at the foot of Twenty-seventh Street and the Morse yard, Fifty-sixth Street, both operated by the United Shipyards, Inc., opened yesterday as employers in the shipyard strike, which affects more than a score of plants in the New York-New Jersey area, continued their efforts to break the tie-up.

otherwise John Buchan, historian and novelist-who is going to the Arctic for the Summer, has submitted to his American publishers, Houghton Mifflin, the final draft of his biography of Augustus. The book will be published in the Fall.

The metropolitan milk bargaining agency met here this afternoon and fortyfive official delegates of the 122 dairymen present voted to recommend to the agency's board of directors that the August price of fluid milk be $2.35 per hundred pounds.
Byron M. Huyler, former Mayor of Tenafly and president of the Tenafly Trust Company, died today of a stomach ailment at his home in Cresskill. He had been ill three years. His age was 59.
At least ten persons were injured in a battle which followed attempts of pickets to halt two maintenance employes driving into the N. G. Taylor Tinplate Company plant early today.
William H. Hamilton, president and treasurer of Hamilton Co., New Haven's largest women's dress shop, died today at his home here. He was 73 years old.

Mr. EDEN'S statement on foreign policy is interesting on many counts, and not least because it furnishes a striking example of how variously the same speech may be construed by emphasizing Oe passage above another.

The new Building Code for the city, which had been held in committee for more than four years, was passed by the Board of Aldermen yesterday by a vote of 45 to 9. The code will go to Mayor La Guardia, and if signed by him will become effective Jan. 1, 1938, replacing a code adopted in 1916.

A larger than seasonal gain took place in steel ingot production last week, and the adjusted index spurted to 124.6 from 113.2 (revised). This was the highest point since the week ended April 3, and compares with 104.2 for the week ended July 18, 1936.

The chorus line is almost the only line that should give pause to the mature woman job seeker, the personnel director of a large department store told delegates to the convention of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women here tonight.
The British Government repeated today its determination to make the partition of Palestine effective and to deal sternly with any disorders which may occur there.

Lazard Freres Co., Inc., has prepared a financial study of the tate of New Hampshire. The banking firm points out that the State's general fund for the 1935-36 fiscal year was more than $100,000 above the deficiency loans contracted in that period, and that the fund's cash deficit was reduced to $157,529 by June 30, 1936, compared with $933,675 a year earlier.
The Forty Niners opened Edward Chodorov's modern thriller, "Kind Lady," tonight as their second production of the Summer at the Chase Barn Playhouse.

The British Government won 371 cases against income tax dodgers within the year, it was revealed today. According to a statement by the Committee of Public Accounts the total amount involved in these cases of evasion and fraud during the fiscal year 1935-6 was [Pound]5,188,000.
Stocks closed at new high levels of movement, with motor and rail shares strong features; turnover 1,999,000 shares. All groups of bonds firm and mixed; transactions, $7,702,000.

Three hundred persons were present at the funeral services yesterday morning for Brig. Gen. Frank K. Fergusson, commanding officer of the Sixty-second Coast Artillery Corps at Fort Totten, who died on Sunday from a hemorrhage.
The British Government has decided to spend [Pound]13,000 to modernize the official residence of its Prime Minister at 10 Downing Street, often called the most uncomfortable house in London.

The outstanding feature in the quietly firm stock markets today was renewed activity in international issues. Although the best prices were not maintained, United States Steel and International Nickel closed higher in the strong overseas section.

Amplifying a published interview, President Manuel L. Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth said tonight that the terms of the Independence Act empowering Congress to change economic relations between the Philippines and the United States were a major cause for his request to President Roosevelt for independence by 1938.

From Washington comes word that the Supreme Court plan may be laid aside for the present session. If this report is corroborated by the developments of the next few days a great victory will have been won for the independence of the judiciary and the maintenance of the American system of checks and balances.

The yacht, Hi-Esmaro, with her owners, Mr. and Mrs. H. Edward Manville aboard, arrived here today. In the party were Mr. and Mrs. E. Victor Loew, who will occupy the cottage Sea Fox for the Summer, and Colonel and Mrs. too Francis L. V. Hoppin.

President Roosevelt conferred with Vice President Garner and Senators Harrison, Barkley and Pittman on the legislative situation, signed the War Department non-military appropriation bill, received a delegation of American members of the Arab National League and denied at a press conference that the navy's search for Amelia Earhart had been costly.

Surrogate William J. Shells of Westchester County marked the will and codicils of the late John D. Rockefeller for probate today, subject to the taking of proof of execution from witnesses whose signatures appear on the documents.

Chauncey W. Johnson of Beucler Place, here, was 104 years old today, and among those who came to his, home to congratulate him was Mrs. Kate Huyler of Main Street, also this place, who was 101 on July 5. Mr. Johnson lives with his daughter, Mrs. F. Stearns Edick.

Constructed with WPA funds at a cost of $80,000, the George Washington Monument Park, informally referred to as an annex of the F. H. La Guardia Playground, at the Brooklyn Plaza of the Williamsburg Bridge, was dedicated yesterday morning.

The report of the Schenley Distillers Corporation for the first six months of 1937, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $3,408,671 after providing for interest, depreciation, Federal income and capital stock taxes, but before allowing for surtax on undistributed profits.

Edward Swann leased to a client of Alberti Ramano, brokers, the three-story dwelling at 263 West Sixteenth Street. The four-story building containing sixteen rooms at 124 West Seventy-first Street was leased by Eric W. Hunt Co. to Frank Sales.

Ernest Sutter of New Orleans, national intercollegiate champion from Tulane and runner-up to Wilmer Allison at Spring Lake, was eliminated from the Eastern clay court championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, Queens.

Mrs. Thomas F. C. Frost, the former Peggy Larimer, grandniece of Andrew W. Mellon, passed three hours and a half in Yorkville Court yesterday before her attorneys and Magistrate Anna M. Kross could persuade Samuel Cohen, process server, to withdraw an action for simple assault he had brought against Mrs. Frost, charging that she struck him when he attempted to serve a summons on May 27.

Count Giulio Marconi, only son of Guglieimo Marconi, inventor of the wireless, who came to this country to do radio work at the suggestion of his father, made a brief statement here yesterday concerning his father's sudden death.
The Royal Canadian Yacht Club's Aphrodite took back home today the international George Cup for sixmeter sloops by defeating the American defender Mist for the second time in two days.

Alarm, voiced insistently in the House of Commons tonight, largely by Winston Churchill and Sir Roger Keyes during a debate on the London Naval Treaty Bill, that Britain had been committed to 14-inch guns while the other nations were building 16-inch guns, drew from the government spokesman an implied admission that Britain herself was considering building ships to be armed with 16-inch guns.

A water-rotted piece of the rudder of the Bounty, on which occurred the famous mutiny in 1789 and which was beached and burned in a cove off Pitcairn Island, was presented yesterday afternoon to the Corinthians, a club of business men sailors and navigators, at a luncheon at the Downtown Harvard Luncheon Club, 56 Beaver Street.

A four-story apartment house will be erected on a plot 125 by 150 feet on Prospect Avenue, 148 feet east of Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, which has just been sold by Adelaide C. Thomas to a building concern. The firm of William H. Marquand's Son was the broker in the deal.

J. Irving Fowler 56, banker and former publisher of The Glens Falls Post-Star and Times, died at his home here tonight. He resigned as treasurer and general manager of the Glens Falls Post Company, publishers of the two newspapers, April 12. 1928.

Broadened activity brought about a rather general advance in bond values yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading pace was stepped up to a turnover of $7,702,000, the heaviest volume since July 8, and compared with $5,788,500 on Monday.
Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, Premier of the Nanking Government, participated in a council of state for the first time tonight since the clashes with Japan in North China.

The twenty largest banks in the United State's increased their loans nearly $1,000,000,000 and decreased their holdings of United States Government securities by slightly more than that amount in the year to June 30, according to a summary of their condition statements for the mid year prepared by The American Banker.

Adrian Gips, member of the board of directors of the Holland-America Line, sailed yesterday on the liner Statendam after a visit here during which he inspected company offices and surveyed business conditions.
Senator Borah said today that the way was cleared for Senate action Thursday on President Roosevelt's veto of lower farm loan interest rates.

The first of two concerts in bration of the twenty-fifth versary of the Goldman band was presented last night in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, before an audience of 13,000. The second concert wil be given tonight on the mall in Central Park.
Two American women were kicked and shoved, they told the United States Embassy today, by Japanese sentries on guard before the Japanese Embassy.
