Once more the Non-Intervention Committee drifted rapidly toward the rocks today, less than a week after all the delegates had accepted the British compromise plan as a basis for discussion.

The fashion group of Great Britain held its second show today, when nine of London's leading young designers exhibited about seventy-five models. The show was held primarily for American buyers who have stopped off in London to see what is new here before going on to Paris for the openings there.

Dr. Eric M. Matsner, medical director of the American Birth Control League and executive secretary of the National Medical Council on Birth Control, sailed yesterday on the Holland-America liner Statendam to confer with European birth control authorities.

Harold Gatty, aeronautical navl gator, took off on a flight over the matrimonial seas yesterday from Mayor La Guardia's Summer City Hall, where he was married to Miss Fenna Bolderhey of Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

Several luncheons were given today, among them that of Mrs. Elisabeth Horne at Solterra. Mrs. Horne's son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Voss of Atlanta Hall Farm, Monkton, Md., will join her this week for a visit.

Fourteen interstate bus lines operating over the George Washington Bridge here have been authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission to increase fare schedules starting tomorrow morning, according to notices posted today by all the companies. The increases will range from 5 to 15 cents on one-way trips.
Sixteen men were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Newark last month in connection with gold stock sales, it was announced here today at the office of United States District Attorney John J. Quinn.

The man to whom Great Britain looks to win the world's heavyweight championship came to New York yesterday. Tommy Farr, the young Welsh boxer who sprang from oblivion to international fame three months ago by outpointing Max Baer in a London ring, debarked from the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria surrounded by a coterie of greeters that would have done a visiting potentate proud.

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., July 20.-- Testimony of a master mariner, Bowdoin A. Lermond, 50, of Portland, Me., that he "hauled 42 degrees and then two more degrees" failed today to save him from a $150 fine for dangerous driving.

Thornton Lee defeated Wes Ferrell in a teninning pitchers' duel today when Luke Appling's single with the bases loaded in the tenth gave the bases loaded gave the White Sox a 1-to-3 victory over the Senators.

President Roosevelt today denied that the search for Amelia Earhart and her navigator, Fred Noonan, had cost the navy a large sum of money. In reply to a question at his press conference regarding criticisms of the cost of the search voiced in the House, Mr. Roosevelt explained in detail why the search was felt to represent no extra cost to the taxpayers.

Mrs. Henry March of North Shore, playing up to her best game, led a record field of 118 starters home by one stroke by posting 41, 39-80 today in a one day event of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association over the well-groomed links of the Women's National ,Golf and Tennis Club.

The Rev. R. Newton Salter of Maplewood, who founded the Congregational Church of Union, N. J., fiftythree years ago and had been its pastor ever since, died today in the Orange Memorial Hospital after a week's illness of an abdominal ailment. He was 84 years old.

Israel Ariel, 54 years old, a silk manufacturer of 183 Jackson Street, this morning drove his son, Dr. Irving Ariel, to the Paterson General Hospital, where the young man is an interne, and then started to drive to Pompton.

A steel caisson, measuring 52 by 42 feet, will be floated up the Hudson River this morning and placed in position to be sunk at West Thirty-ninth Street, where it will be used in the construction of the second tube of the new Lincoln

Mrs. Edward Parsons Davis of this city and Great Barrington, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eleanore Davis, to Pemberton Hutchinson Lincoln of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Lincoln of Elkhorn. W. Va.

A single unearned run was the total offensive damage done in the second meeting between the Bisons and Jersey Giants tonight, but it was sufficient to give the visitors a 1-0 victory over the weak hitting Schalk forces.

LENOX, Mass., July 20.--Giraud Foster gave a birthday dinner party tonight at Bellefontaine, Lenox, in compliment to his daughter-in-law, Mrs. Giraud van Nest Foster, who, with her husband, arrived recently from their plantation near Baton Rouge, La.

For the longest time things moved very serenely at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The air was cool, the Reds were even cooler and with the Giants, thanks to some very effective pitching by Cliff Melton, running smartly in front, 2 to 1, Colonel Bill Terry seemed not to have a care in the world as the struggle swung into the ninth.

Guglielmo Marconi's life was marked by four great climaxes: First, the first flash of the wireless spark across the garden of his home in Bologna in 1895; second, the first transatlantic signal in December, 1901; third, the S O S and the heroic role played by wireless in the Titanic disaster in 1912; fourth, development of short waves, the vacuum tube and radiophone during the World War.

PATROLMEN-William Grief, from 5th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, N. Y. County, for 1 day. Edward J. Bogan, from 62d Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, Kings County, for 3 days.

Harry Balsamo, 1601/2 pounds, of Harlem, knocked out Gasper La Rosa, 159, of Canarsie, in the last stanza of their eight-round bout at the Queensboro Arena in Long Island City last night. A crowd of 4,000 saw the battle.
Two Cleveland home runs, one of them Hal Trosky's twentieth of the season, were wasted today as the Philadelphia Athletics won the hardslugging opener of the four-game series, 7 to 5.
William (Billy) Dee, who said he was the first baseball pitcher to throw a curve ball, died at his home here today after a short illness. He was 73 years old.

Lewisohn Stadium's Wagner Festival in concert form last night proceeded to its third chapter with the presentation of excerpts from "Siegfried." This was the first performance that was not threatened or marred by rain, and its attendance--estimated at 5,500--was the largest thus far.

The appeal made quietly in Manhattan by a group of leading citizens headed by James G. Blaine, president of the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York, for $250,000 to supplement the funds of hard-pressed welfare agencies in Brooklyn, Queens and Richmond, has fallen far short of its goal.

Dr. Lee de Forest, nationally known as the "father of radio," today issued the following statement on Marconi's death: "To Guglielmo Marconi - unquestionably belongs the credit of first transmitting telegraphic signals through space without wires.

Mayor La Guardia, suggested by William Allen White, Kansas editor, as a possible Republican Presidential nominee in 1940, found time yesterday in the course of his round of duties at the Summer City Hall in College Point, Queens, to make known that his appreciation, if not his hopes, had been aroused by Mr. White's statements.

A woman social observer told the National Conference of State Liquor Administrators today that "prohibition children"-American youth who grew up during the Eighteenth Amendment's lifetimedrank little themselves and disapproved of excessive drinking.
The Yonkers Common Council passed tonight a new and more specific ordinance forbidding the wearing of scanty attire on the streets of the city. The vote was 10 to 2.
WASHINGTON, July 20.--Thirteen Democratic Senators, serving first terms, have sent this letter to Senator Norris, who is ill at his Summer home at Waupaca, Wis.:

Matching women's par, 37, for the first nine, Mrs. Percy Uris of Mount Vernon conquered Miss Alice McPhee, 7 and 6, in the second round of match play in the women's invitation golf tournament at Briar Hills today and gained the semi-final round.

The first wireless message sent from the Old World to the New when Marconi opened his regular transatlantic service via Clifden, Ireland, and Glace Bay, Nova Scotia, on Oct. 17, 1907, was one to THE NEW YORK TIMES from its London correspondent.

Three armed bandits held up Abraham S. Hirschman, office manager of the Cordiano Can Company, 80 Thirty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday at Fiftieth Street and Third Avenue, Brooklyn, and robbed him of a $1,548 payroll that he had withdrawn from the Brooklyn Trust Company, 5,101 Fourth Avenue, a few minutes before. The robbery was executed with skill and dispatch.

An assertion that there would always be war so long as might was permitted to crush justice was made by Dr. Malaku E. Bayen, physician to Haile Selassie, before the Institute for Social Progress at Wellesley tonight.
Four masked white men took two Negro youths from the county jail, four blocks from the Capitol, and shot them to death early today.

Reporting almost a 50 per cent gain in business for the year ended on June 30, compared with the previous year, directors of the OwensIllinois Glass Company approved today plans for continuation of th expansion program.

Members of a police emergency squad got into a fine lather yesterday afternoon after they had spent fifteen minutes trying to free a 5-year-old boy whose knee was wedged between a wall and a marble pillar at 551 West 178th Street.

Senator Wagner of New York suddenly abandoned plans to issue a reply tonight to the letter written him from Albany yesterday by Governor Lehman urging him to vote against the court reorganization bill.

55th St, 14 E: to 5-story and penthouse tenement and stores; Dorothy G. Whitlock. Hewlett, L. I., owner; Polhemus Coffin, architects; cost 815,000. 116th St, 214 W; to 5-story tenement and store: Peter Doelger, Inc, premises, owner; S. Walter Katz, architect; cost $4.500. Fulton St, 212: to 2-story stores; Joseph W. Evans, 150 Broadway, owner; Charles N. and Selig Whinston, architects; cost $10,000.

HALL, THOMAS C. (May 27, 1936). Gross assets, $83,301: net, $78,508. To Bolton Hall, brother, Emily Hall Wheelock, sister, three-tenths residue each; Baronin Carl Von Englehardt, four-tenths residue. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $82,915. Mitchell Van Winkle, attorneys, 350 Madison Ave.
By its victory over the Germans, the American tennis team has taken what most observers agreed was probably its greatest hurdle on the way to the Davis Cup.

The Newark Bears mauled the Toronto Maple Leafs, 10-4, tonight in the second game of their series, pounding Mike Meola and Joe Mulligan for fourteen safeties while Marius Russo scattered ten blows effectively for his fifth victory.

The auction sale of the Hotel Drake, twenty-story structure at the corner of Fifty-sixth Street and Park Avenue, which was scheduled for yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms has been postponed until Oct. 5 at the request of the Chase National Bank, corporate trustee and plaintiff in the action. Details of completed Manhattan sales follow:

An organization which had its origins in a progressive bloc of the Daughters of the American Revolution is being formed to oppose that society's conservative views, Mrs. Julia Church Kolar of 37-44 Sixtyfirst Street, Woodside, Queens, announced yesterday.

A policeman was shot in the arm and his assailant was critically wounded by another policeman after a chase through the congested East New York section of Brooklyn yesterday. A woman bystander, caught in the exchange of bullets, received a superficial wound.

Hurley G. Hust, national advertising director for the ice industry, yesterday announced the reappointment of Donahue Co., Inc., as advertising counsel for the association's national advertising campaign. In view of the success of the past year's program, no radical changes are contemplated in the general structure of the advertising plan. he said.
The New York County Lawyers Association announced yesterday that its committee on the Municipal Court had endorsed for re-election eleven Municipal Court justices completing full terms on the bench.

Sir Percy Bates, chairman of the Cunard White Star Line, who with his family is one of the chief stock owners of the company, is sailing today on the Berengaria with Lady Bates after a fishing trip in Canada.
Thomas S. Dillon, Mayor of this borough, died this morning in Fitkin Hospital, Asbury Park. He was in his seventy-first year.

James E. Finegan, president, and his two fellow members of the Municipal Civil Service Commission were adjudged in contempt of court yesterday for preparing to disregard a mandamus order directing them to cancel an examination of nearly 35,000 candidates for secondgrade clerk scheduled for Friday.
Nearly 180 members of the crew of the Fall River liner Priscilla were aboard the ship last night as she lay at Pier 14, North River, while fellow union members tried to get food and supplies to them.

Although the "white wings" go about their duties clad in somber olive drab they will have acquired a militant dignity within the next few weeks, when the rank and file will begin addressing their superiors as "chief," "captain" or "lieutenant."

Mayor La Guardia told 100 members of the Brooklyn Kiwanis Club yesterday afternoon that he had been elected to give this city "an efficient, non-partisan administration" and that he would continue to do so whether the politicians liked it or not.

A study of the relationship between actual sales of real estate and foreclosures in the period from Jan 1, 1934, to the present reveals that a complete reversal has taken place, according to the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc.

Hirondelle, skippered by Britton Chance of the host club, again defeated the Lake Chautauqua representative Ghost in the semi-finals of the series to select the Eastern team for the national Class E sloop championship held over the lower Mantoloking Yacht Club course today.

A report that President Roosevelt had agreed with Vice President Garner and a group of Congressional advisers to shelve for the present the controversial Supreme Court enlargement provisions of his judiciary reorganization program in the interest of party harmony gained wide credence in Washington tonight.

Dr. George M. Dott, dentist, in 342 Madison Ave.: Maurice H. Mally, air filtering, in 299 Madison Ave.; Hellman Press, in 231 W. 39th St.; the Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corp., broker. George Friedes, tailor, store at 451 Amsterdam Ave; Eight Ave Tailoring Corp, store at 899 8th Ave.; Henry Lee, laundry.
Stocks of raw wool on June 26 amounted to 215,105,000 pounds, compared with 214,522,000 on June 27, 1936, the Census Bureau reported today.
The heat wave hastened the deaths of hundreds of persons with chronic illnesses, it was shown yesterday by statistics issued by the Health Deapartment for the week ended July 17.

Services of the Metropolitan Federation of Daily Vacation Bible Schools, St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fiftythird Street, 11 A. M. Theme: "Living as Christians in the World Today."

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following Reserve officers is ordered to active duty July 25 at Governors Island, N. Y., for training at this headquarters in connection with the 1st Army C. P. X., Headquarters Second Corps Area, Governors Island, N. Y.:

Realty financing announced Yesterday included loans on properties in the Bronx and Queens. A first mortgage loan of $110,000 at 4 1/2 per cent has been obtained by the Reft Holding Company, Jacob Wacht, president, on the sixstory apartment house it completed recently at 320 East 197th Street, the Bronx. E. Osborn Smith, Inc., negotiated the loan.

R. H. Goffe Jr. won the Nyackers' Special in Class A of the New York A. C. one-day golf event today with a 79 gross over the par 71 layout. A 9 handicap gave him a 70 net. Dr. R. L. Blackmon was second with a gross of 81, which, with a handicap of 9, gave him a net of 72.

Purchase of a large investment property in the Washington Square section was announced yesterday when the eleven-story store and loft building at 24-26 Waverly Place was sold by Mrs. Charles Remsen to the City Real Estate Company. The structure occupies a plot 60 by 100 feet at the southwest corner of Greene Street and was sold for $250,000.
The Central Hanover Bank Trust Co. has been appointed registrar for 230,000 shares of common capital stock of $5 par of the Harrisburg Steel Corporation, Harrisburg, Pa.
The chief complaint against many nurses, Miss May Kennedy of New York told the International Nurses' Congress today, is that they cannot get along with people.

Business activity in Great Britain reached a new record high level in May, according to the National Industrial Conference Board, which announced yesterday that world industrial production advanced during that month.

Justifiable homicide" was the verdict of a coroner's jury today in reporting that the deaths of ten men in the Memorial Day riot in South Chicago were due to the attempt of the armed mob of C. I. O. strikers to force their way through police lines, "apparently intending to enter the plant of the Republic Steel Corporation."

George Lansbury, veteran British Labor leader, disclosed today Guglielmo Marconi, inventor of the wireless, who died at Rome today, had told him in an interview ten days ago he was deeply worried because "the world's scientific genius was being used to create weapons of destruction."
Canada's long occupied position as major exporter of wheat, grain traders said, today, may be assumed by the United States this year.
For the second day in succession violent street scenes took place in Belgrade. Tonight the police fired on Serbian Orthodox crowds and charged them with fixed bayonets.

A court cannot undertake to "set up standards of taste" for the public, Magistrate Anna M. Kross declared yesterday in Yorkville Court in dismissing a charge of presenting an indecent performance brought on April 10 against Edward Goodman, 40 years old,

United States SENIOR EDUCATIONAL ANALYST (TESTS AND MEASUREMENTS), $4,600 a year. Educational Analyst (Tests and Measurements), $3,800. Extension Service, Office of Cooperative Extension Work, Department of Agriculture. Applications must be on file not later than August 16, if received from States other than those named below;

The demand for veal cuts improved slightly, other classes continued to move slowly. Slaughterers are reducing the kill of most classes. Price trends were mixed. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef prices to be sharply higher, veal steady, lamb strong to $1 higher, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The National Labor Relations Board declared today that the Oregon State Conciliation Board displayed "flagrant bias" in favor of the Oregon Worsted Company of Portland, Ore., during efforts to settle a strike last Winter.

Public offering of 70,000 shares of Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company prior preferred stock of no-par value, at an aggregate price of $3,500,000, will be made today by an underwriting group comprising the Lee Higginson Corporation, Hayden, Stone Co., Brown Harriman Co., Inc., Goldman, Sachs Co. and J. A. Sisto Co.
Directors of the Burroughs Adding Machine Company yesterday voted an increase on the dividend with the declaration of 25 cents a share. On June 5, a dividend of 20 cents was disbursed.

The upturn in North American wheat markets which has been under way for a month, in which time prices advanced 23 1/8 to 37 cents a bushel, ran into selling today with a break of as much as 5 cents a bushel in leading markets.

Mrs. Frederick Kellogg Hollister gave a luncheon and a bridge today at the Maidstone Club. Her guests included Mrs. William Whittingham Battie, Mrs. E. L. Southern, Mrs. Roger Lewis, Mrs. Robert Appleton, Mrs. James T. Lee, Mrs. Charles Carscallen, Mrs. John L.
The former Rothwell M. Sheriff estate, on Feeks Lane, Lattingtown, L. I., has been purchased and is being occupied by Robert O. Bacon Jr. of New York. There are fifteen acres in the tract.

Captain James Mollison, British aviator, on a holiday visit here, said in a Rotary Club luncheon address today that he was through with pioneer flying and intended to settle down in business in Scotland, taking over his mother's factory.

Payrolls in New York's construction industry increased 11 per cent last month, aided materially by the seasonal upswing in highway building, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, said tonight. At the same time, the number of workers employed on construction projects advanced 8 per cent.
After a hearing today on the request of producers that prices be increased to last Winter's level, the State Milk Control Board said a decision would be given soon, possibly tomorrow.
The schooner General A. W. Greeley, carrying the MacGregor Arctic expedition, left this afternoon for the final dash into the Arctic.

Influenced by a sharp break in wheat and beneficial rainfall in Northern Texas, trading on the Cotton Exchange turned an early improvement into a 30-point decline yesterday which left the list with net losses of 11 to 15 points.

A winner in two straight heats, William N. Reynolds's bay colt Scovere, with Ben White at the reins, captured the $3,421 National Stake for 2-year-old trotters in the Grand Circuit meeting to day. Scover's best time was 2:06 1/2 in the second heat.

All foreign-born residents who have not yet become citizens were urged yesterday to avail themselves of the free naturalization aid services of the WPA-Adult Education Progam of the Board of Education by S. Alexander Shear, program director.
The battle begun by President Roosevelt for reorganization of the Supreme Court has lasted for more than five months, with the following as the high points in the conflict:

Ignoring a break in wheat futures and declines in other grains and in cotton, the share market continued its recovery with considerable vigor. Many leading stocks, notably motors and rails, rose 1 to 4 points on the day.

Yesterday was Henry Anton Manush's thirty-sixth birthday and, with some timely aid from Jack Winsett, the veteran outfielder celebrated it fittingly by giving the Dodgers a 2-1 victory over the Pirates in the tenth inning at Ebbets Field.

A third operation was performed on Monday in the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital to make as nearly normal as possible the appearance of a 3-year-old girl born with only one eye. In the third operation, which was probably the last, the surgeon deepened the socket, placed in it a glass ball and sewed over the ball tissues to keep it in place.

The marriage of Mrs. Hazel Bissett O'Brien, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Bissett of this city and Cleveland, to Verne Standish Warriner, son of Mrs. Verne Standish Warriner of Denver and the late Mr. Warriner, took place yesterday afternoon in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The New York Stock Exchange committee on stock list has authorized the listing of $25,000,000 of New York Telephone Company refunding mortgage 3 1/4 per cent Series B bonds due in 1967; $4,000,000 of ten-year 4 1/2 per cent debentures due in 1947; 450,000 shares of American Rolling Mill Company 4 1/2 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock.
Surrey, Worcestershire and Hampshire won full victories in first-class county cricket matches ended t day. The scores:

Robert W. Castles of 466 Highland Avenue, manager of the factory branch of the Allen Wales Adding Machine Company at 76 Varick Street, New York, died today in the Orange Memorial Hospital, after a week's illness of pneumonia, at the age of 45.

Four New York firms or individuals have entered into stipulations with the Federal Trade Commission by agreeing to discontinue false and misleading advertising in connection with the interstate sale of medicinal preparations, it was announced by the commission today.
A Common Pleas judge ruled today that the Ford Motor Company and eight individuals must face trial for the beating of United Automobile Workers near gates of the Rouge plant May 26.

The cruiser Omaha was still aground today off Castle Island Light in the Bahamas, where she stuck on shoals yesterday, according to reports to the Navy Department. The sea continued smooth, and there was no danger to personnel.

SOME ONE is always putting a headstone and a wreath on the art of conversation. Yet--art or not art--it seems to survive. Edna St. Vincent Millay gives it a good deal of pungent life and variety in "Conversation at Midnight" (Harper's, $2), a dramatic dialogue in verse that is unquestionably her best and soundest book since she first came up the Shropshire ladder.

Arrangements have been completed between the Ever-Plastics Corporation and Leigh Chandler Co., Inc., for the purchase by the latter investment firm of 36,000 shares of common stock of the corporation for public offering at $1.50 a share, it was announced yesterday by R. M. van Lennep,
An increase of $4,514,186 in the State's alcoholic beverage tax collections in the fiscal year ended June 30 was reported today by Mark Graves, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance.
The St. Louis, Cardinals gave Lefty Bob Weiland ragged support today when the Boston Bees, aided by unearned runs, captured the series opener by a 5-3 margin after being outhit, 10-8.

The casualty list of favorites in the second day's play in the fortyfifth annual Longwood Bowl invitation net tournament and the first day's competition in the women's singles was almost negligible, only two seeded players being beaten at the Longwood Cricket Club today.

Should Congress get down to a vote on a modified version of the Robinson-LoganHatch Court Bill substitute-as the envoys are now trying to arrange-or set it aside for the present session and then adjourn to meet in special session the middle of next October, there would probably descend upon the embattled factions a peace so welcome that the Democratic party will seem almost to be reunited.

Virtually all of the twenty-seven stockholders of the A. B. See Elevator Company are expected to attend a meeting to be held at 10 A. M. today to vote on the proposal to sell the company to the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company and to determine a plan to distribute among the stockholders the 10,000 Westinghouse common shares, currently worth $1,523,750, receivable if the sale is consummated.
Dozens of Guernicas bombed until not a stone remains upon a stone; hundreds of thousands of Spaniards brutally killed, including an uncounted number of women and children;

A ravenous horde of crickets, entrenched in the vicinity of Tenth and Vine Streets, North Camden, and increasing in numbers "by millions and millions" daily, according to residents, had city officials worried today.

Seven hundred persons attended funeral services for Henry M. Brundage, former vice president of the Consolidated Gas Company, now the Consolidated Edison Company, which were held this afternoon at the North Baptist Church.
Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner of New York State, assailed last night the Johnstown "constitutional right to work" movement, implying that it was not motivated by sincerity.
The father of radio, without whom the world would not be what it is today, has died," was the headline in ParisSoir today over the report of the death of Guglielmo Marconi.

In Britain, where Guglielmo Marconi registered his first patent, when only 22, and from then on did most of his commercial experimenting and company flotations, the inventor's death has caused deep sorrow among the wide circle of men who were his close companions in his rise to fame.
Plans for the Pan-American automobile race, scheduled to be held at the Roosevelt Raceway at Westbury, L. I., on Labor Day, were abandoned yesterday, it was announced.
The diplomatic conflict with Nanking was thrown into the background today by fears that major fighting might break out in the trouble zone in North China.

The United Chocolate Workers Union charged tonight that the Hummelstown National Bank had threatened to foreclose a mortgage on Indian Echo Cave Park at Hummelstown, three miles from here, unless the owner withdrew permission for a union mass meeting there Thursday.

Bids were received yesterday by the Henry Hudson Parkway Authority for the grading of the new highway that will run through Inwood Hill Park to connect with the upper level of the Henry Hudson Bridge.

Guglielmo Marconi guided radio to the gateway of television. In his forty-three years of experimenting and developing wireless he erected important sign-posts that now point the way for the television engineers.

An agreement was reached today on a new Cabinet which will be appointed tomorrow with Dr. Milan Hodza continuing as Premier. Other Cabinet members will be unchanged, except that the Finance Minister, Dr. Josef Kalfus, will be replaced provisionally by Dr. Emil Franke, Minister of Education.

Business failures increased sharply in the week ended July 15 in the retail group in comparison with the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:

The chances of United States Senator Royal S. Copeland receiving the Tammany designation for Mayor grew slimmer and slimmer yesterday, despite his selection for that post by James J. Dooling, Tammany leader.

Another master magician has gone. In the Middle Ages his countryman, VIRGIL, was popularly famous as an enchanter even more than a poet. The Tower of Poldhu has in its way a sort of association with the Castle of the Egg at Naples. Distant as we are from the old childish tales, we are surrounded by mysteries and wonders.

Outspoken in their criticism of the attitude of the British golfing fans, the American Ryder Cup players, bringing with them the trophy they traveled overseas to win, arrived in New York yesterday aboard the Berengaria of the Cunard White Star Line.

The closed shop is unlawful, a contract providing for a closed shop is unlawful and unenforceable and picketing for a closed shop also is unlawful, Vice Chancellor Maja Leon Berry ruled here today in Chancery Court.

The Very Rev. James A. Burns announced here tonight the re-election of the Rev. John F. O'Hara as president of the University of Notre Dame for a second three-year term. Action was by the Provincial Council of the Congregation of Holy Cross.

Labor difficulties flared again yesterday in the shipping industry as rival unions announced the success of programs for the development of their membership in a contest between groups favorable to the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Mr. and Mrs. Norris Taylor of Bethlehem and Harrisburg, Pa., have announced the coming marriage of their daughter, Miss Ruth Alberta Taylor, to Charles W. Hutton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace C. Hutton of this city.

The General Electric Company, in its semi-annual report announced yesterday by Gerard Swope, president, showed a net income of $26,293,604 for the first six months of 1937 after expenses, interest, taxes and other charges.

Alfred B. Kastor, 52, of New York, was in Norwalk Hospital today suffering from knife wounds which State Policeman Frank Bozentka said were self-inflicted. Hospital authorities reported that likelihood of recovery was "slight."

Fidelity Fund, Inc.--June 30: Net asset value $26.18 a share for 166,004 shares, compared with $26.97 on 131,024 shares on June 30, 1936. A special dividend of $2.50 a share was paid on Dec. 10, 1936. Net income for the first half of 1937 was $26,397 and net gain from sale of securities totaled $75,919.

Miss Marta Aspegren, daughter of Herman Aspegren, Swedish vice consul, and Mrs. Aspegren, was married yesterday to Dr. Ralph Chandler Parker Jr. of Boston, son of Captain Ralph Chandler Parker, U.S.N., and Mrs. Parker of Batavia, N. Y., formerly of Newport, R. I., in the Church of the Good Shepherd, Meadowbrook.
Lord Tweedsmuir and his party left here today for the start of his adventure into the Arctic, the longest journey ever made by the King's personal representative in Canada.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens manipulated the levers of a giant steam shovel to break ground yesterday morning at 111th Street and Fifty-first Avenue, Flushing, Queens, for the first section of the $5,000,000 sewer system to be installed in preparation for the World's Fair.
The fact that Dr. George W. Webster made his will less than fortyeight hours before he was murdered was confirmed today when the brief document was filed in Probate Court here.
Finland's Yacht Club has decided to participate in the international races at Oyster Bay, L. I.,
Demands for a party primary to nominate a successor to Senator Joseph T. Robinson won increased backing today from a group of business and professional men.

Fewer hogs but heavier ones will be marketed next Fall and Winter compared with the corresponding period a year earlier, according to a Summer outlook report released today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

The Civil Service Reform Association, 521 Fifth Avenue, announced yesterday it had written a letter to Budget Director Leo J. McDermott urging a substantial increase in the appropriation for the Municipal Civil Service Commission to enable the commission not only to meet its present needs but also to adopt a broader and more modern system of civil service administration.

An intensive campaign to organize the B. M. T. motormen, signalmen and towermen was started yesterday by the Transport Workers Union, an affiliate of the C. I. O., following the ruling by the City Industrial Relations Board that these classes of employes could not participate in the collective bargaining election set for next week.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler sent to Premier Benito Mussolini today a telegram expressing his condolences on Marquis Guglielmo Marconi's death. The telegram follows:

Former United States Senator William M. Calder of Brooklyn sent a four-page letter yesterday to the 4,000 members of the Kings County Republican Committee urging them to support Mayor La Guardia for renomination and re-election.

The Union Pacific Railroad showed in its report for June, published yesterday, a net operating income of $1,190,712, compared with $1,797,973 for the same month in 1936. For the six months ended on June 30 the net operating income was $5,331,986,

An eight-day vigil by detectives in the subway station of the B. M. T. Fourteenth Street crosstown line to Canarsie, under the Union Square station, ended last night with the arrest of a man for assaulting a 23year-old woman in the subway on July 12.
PEIPING--After the Chinese were reported to have opened fire, Japanese troops heavily shelled the Wanping barracks and the Marco Polo Bridge west of Peiping for two hours, doing heavy damage.

Export clearances of Canadian wheat in the week ended on July 16, were 2,204,000 bushels, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today, an increase of 394,000 over the previous week, but a drop of 2,657,000 from the corresponding week of 1936.

A plot to extort money from at least two local business men by threatening to bomb them and dash acid in the faces of their children has led to the arrest of the brother of a Jersey City patrolman and the search for an ex-convict, It was disclosed here today by Chief of Police Harry Walsh.

For an indicated consideration of $52,000 the premises at 104-6 E 4th St were sold by the 104-6 E 4th St Realty Corp to Sagamore Holdings, Inc, Charles Struckler, vice president, the latter giving back a purchase money mortgage for $41.000, due in five years at 4 to 5 per cent. Sagamore also gave to Brewster Properties, Inc, a second mortgage for $6,050. at 6 per cent.

Former United States Senator William M. Calder of Brooklyn sent a four-page letter yesterday to the 4,000 members of the Kings County Republican Committee urging them to support Mayor La Guardia for renomination and re-election.

The Union Pacific Railroad showed in its report for June, published yesterday, a net operating income of $1,190,712, compared with $1,797,973 for the same month in 1936. For the six months ended on June 30 the net operating income was $5,331,986,

An eight-day vigil by detectives in the subway station of the B. M. T. Fourteenth Street crosstown line to Canarsie, under the Union Square station, ended last night with the arrest of a man for assaulting a 23year-old woman in the subway on July 12.
PEIPING--After the Chinese were reported to have opened fire, Japanese troops heavily shelled the Wanping barracks and the Marco Polo Bridge west of Peiping for two hours, doing heavy damage.

Export clearances of Canadian wheat in the week ended on July 16, were 2,204,000 bushels, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today, an increase of 394,000 over the previous week, but a drop of 2,657,000 from the corresponding week of 1936.

A plot to extort money from at least two local business men by threatening to bomb them and dash acid in the faces of their children has led to the arrest of the brother of a Jersey City patrolman and the search for an ex-convict, It was disclosed here today by Chief of Police Harry Walsh.

For an indicated consideration of $52,000 the premises at 104-6 E 4th St were sold by the 104-6 E 4th St Realty Corp to Sagamore Holdings, Inc, Charles Struckler, vice president, the latter giving back a purchase money mortgage for $41.000, due in five years at 4 to 5 per cent. Sagamore also gave to Brewster Properties, Inc, a second mortgage for $6,050. at 6 per cent.

The American Equities Company is advising its shareholders by letter that they will benefit by the 871/2-cent dividend declared on July 9 on the $3.50 prior preferred stock of the International Utilities Corporation if they deposit their assents to the conversion plan before the offer expires on July 31.

Captain William L. Robbins, one of the few remaining packet skippers of Long Island, and his wife were guests of honor this evening at a dinner at the home of their son-inlaw and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. James Young, on their sixty-sixth wedding anniversary.

A call to churches to take a strong, responsible and guiding part in the economic life of nations and communities constituted today the first official general act of the World Conferences on Church, Community and State.

To his drastic increase in taxation of ten days ago Finance Minister Georges Bonnet added today a drastic cut in public expenditure in his efforts to reach budgetary equilibrium and keep France stable. He obtained the consent of a Ministerial council, presided over by President Albert Lebrun, to his program.

John J. Drew, formerly in the real estate department of the Empire City Savings Bank, is with Nehring Brothers, Inc., in their mortgage department. Installation of air-conditioning in the seven public dining rooms of the Hotel Astor has been completed and plans are being made to aircondition the banquet and meeting rooms.

Dr. James Phinney Baxter 3d, Professor of History and master of Adams House at Harvard University, was unanimously named to succeed Dr. Tyler Dennett as president of Williams College, at a meeting of the executive committee of the Williams board of trustees here today.

One hundred and fifty employes of Fry Products, Inc., the plant of which was closed by their boss this morning after they had voted to stand by their union, changed their minds later today and voted to return to work tomorrow.
Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden announced today that the impending Anglo-Japanese discussions in London had been postponed because of the tension between Japan and China.

Safety at sea on American vessels and the preservation of the merchant marine of the United States are being threatened by "the subversive tactics of radical and Communist elements" among seamen, Captain Edward C. Holden Jr., general chairman of the Marine Section of the National Safety Council, said yesterday.

The ten-story Woodmere apartment and the four-story house adjoining, forming the parcel 3,458-70 Broadway, on the northeast corner of 141st Street, were sold yesterday at auction to the plaintiff, the Franklin Savings Bank, on a bid of $360,000.
Mr. and Mrs. Peter Zalewski of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeannette Regina Zalewski, to Edmund Sieminski, son of Henry Sieminski of Jersey City.
Charles E. Ellis, a manufacturer of photographic films, with offices in New York, died in his sleep last night of a heart attack at his home here. He was 57 years old.

Arthur Vanderree of the St. George Dragon Club won the New York A. A. U. 100-meter back stroke championship, one of the features of the swimming meet at the Ravenhall A. C. pool in Coney Island last night.

Following a final conference of representatives of various utility groups and city fiscal officers, the State Tax Commission made public today the rules and regulations which are to govern the new State Utilities Tax Law enacted by the last Legislature.

With the defending champion eliminated in straight sets, attention will focus on his conqueror, M. C. Hopper of Tulsa, Okla., in the semi-finals of the national junior interscholastic tennis championships tomorrow.

56th St, 303 E, 20x100.5; Joseph Roth to Nathan Deutsch, 922 Bronx Park South, Bronx; mtg $12,000 ($1). 130th St, s s, 193.9 ft e of 7th Ave, 18.9x100; executors of will of Constance L Griffith to Clarendon A Griffith and Violet a Ponce, 158 W 130th St (40 cents). 1st Ave, s w cor 106th St, 60.11x104.4; James Dean Allen to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp; consideration $1,000; foreclosure.

Mayor La Guardia received yesterday what he said was the greatest honor of his life. It was a plaque presented by blind, crippled, aged and infirm persons who live at the city's poorhouse on Welfare Island.

A temporary injunction restraining the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, from picketing stores selling Ansley Radio Corporation products was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Edward J. McGoldrick. At the same time he refused to enjoin the union from picketing the Ansley company's plant.

Miss Anne Cole Putnam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George William Putnam of this place, was married today to Frederick Grant Butterworth Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Grant Butterworth of Upper Montclair.

Mrs. Mary Miller Connell, widow of former Representative Richard Connell of New York and mother of Richard Connell, short story and screen scenario writer, died late Tuesday night of a heart attack at her residence, the Hotel Earle, Washington Square. She was 82 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. R. Foster Reynolds gave a dinner last night at the Mount Washington, Bretton Woods. Mr. and Mrs. William B. Symmes Jr. of New York are expected soon at their farmhouse in Franconia. Mr. and Mrs. H. H. Pike and family of New York are at White Wings, Sugar Hill.

In the park that was the scene of many earlier triumphs which stamped him as one of the greatest baseball players in history, Rogers Hornsby today came to the end of his reign as manager of the St. Louis Browns.

One person was killed instantly and another is in a critical condition as a result of an automobile accident in which a roadster carrying five passengers was in collision with a truck at the Plainfield Avenue and Route 25 intersection in Raritan Township late last night.
Leslie Brooks Rowley, legal authority on banking and a member of one of Madison's prominent families, died early today after an illness of less than three weeks. He was 72 years old.

A newly found box containing seventeen .45-calibre pistol cartridges was a major clue tonight in the investigation into the slaying of Dr. George W. Webster. Three bullets were missing from the box. Dr. Webster was shot twice with bullets of the caliber.

Failure of United States customs officials to grant final liquidation on merchandise imported from Germany under barter arrangements worked out last Winter and approved by the government here is causing widespread uneasiness among American importers, Heinrich Freytag, acting secretary of the Board of Trade for GermanAmerican Commerce, Inc., admitted yesterday.

The dazzling captain of Oxford-Cambridge's track team, Arthur Godfrey Brown, recovered from a crushing fall tonight to win a dual track meet against a surprisingly powerful Toronto West End Y. M. C. A. team by a margin of seven first places to six.
Magistrate Gustav Wieboldt of the Queens Traffic Court dismissed yesterday the charge of driving without an operator's license which had been made against Enzo Fiermonte,

The $10,000 bail under which Albert R. Knight of Lansdowne, former oil company executive, had been held on a charge of plotting to burn three of his daughters to death to collect $120,000 insurance was cut in half by Judge Albert D. MacDade in the County Court today at a hearing on a writ of habeas corpus.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan area scored an increase of 6 per cent for the week ended July 17, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. For the four weeks ended on that date there was a gain of 2 per cent in the number of packages handled.

The newspaper Hochi reported today from Tientsin that an alleged attempt to assassinate Shigeru Kawagoe, the Japanese Ambassador to China, and the Mayor of Tientsin had been frustrated by Japanese consular police.
WASHINGTON, July 21.--The administration drive to push through Congress President Roosevelt's plan for changing the Supreme Court appeared tonight to have completely collapsed.

Battalion Chief Thomas F. J. Powell, 5h Battalion, died July 20. The funeral will take place from his late residence, 105-20 193d St., Hollis, at 9:30 A. M., Friday, July 23. Interment at St. John's Cemetery, Queens.

Residents of Barcelona are suffering from a shortage of staple foods, according to three refugees who arrived yesterday on the American Export liner Excambion. The three passengers, Mrs. Balbina Font and her twin daughters, Mercedes and Marie Pepa Font, 20,
MARCONI'S death comes a few days after the publication of the big report on technology and invention at Washington and underlines an interesting point suggested in that document.

Market eased and closed fractionally lower with steel shares weakest; turnover, 981,460 shares. United States Government bonds irregularly higher, Japanese issues rallied, other bonds firm and mixed; transactions, $7,438,000.

Miss Florence Carolyn Fedderman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Menson Fedderman of this place, was married here tonight in the Westfield Presbyterian Church to William Brown Plunkett, son of State Senator and Mrs. Theodore R. Plunkett of Adams, Mass., by the Rev. William C. Finch.
Five of the ten leading candidates for the $30,000 added Arlington Classic Stakes to be decided at Arlington Park Saturday reeled off final trials today.

Orderly tennis procedure was disrupted for the first time in the Longwood Bowl tournament today when third-seeded Dick Murphy of Boston, the southpaw Massachusetts titleholder and 1933 winner, tired after a marathon first set and bowed to Norbett Burgess of Chicago, 11-9, 6--0, in a third-round match.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday at the Summer City Hall in Queens that he would approve the new building code adopted by the Board of Aldermen on Tuesday. The Mayor said he did not believe the code was perfect but added that the only way to find the defects and jokers was to give it a trial.

There is increasing reason to believe that the Supreme Court section of the Court Reorganization Bill cannot and will not be adopted at the present session. Opposition from within the President's own party has blocked the way. The result is not only a setback for a plan which threatened the independence of the judicial branch of the Government.

Miss Jean A. Tenney from Clear Springs, Md., was crowned national women's champion today at the fifty-seventh annual target session of the National Archery Association. Her grand total was 1,926 points.

Members of the United States skiing team returned here this morning after completing their brilliant victories in the Pan-American competition that took place on Los Farellones snowfields on the flanks of Mount Colorado, 10,000 feet above sea level.
Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt are to entertain a large group with a supper party, with music and dancing, at their Portsmouth home, Oakland Farm, on July 30.
The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, was designated last night by the employes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company to act as their sole agency for collective bargaining with the management.

The Goldman Band, Edwin Franko Goldman conductor, celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of its founding with a concert given last night on the Central Park Mall. The audience occupied every available seat in the field, on the benches in the surrounding aisles, and crowded the aisles themselves.

Ignoring the Department of Agriculture and the AAA, which have heretofore performed the function, the House Agricultural Committee issued a call today to national farm organizations to attend a legislative conference Tuesday to draw up a "united-front" farm relief program to replace invalidated sections of the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

Charles Sampson Kelley died today at his home here, two weeks before his ninety-first birthday. He had continued to work daily at his office in the brokerage house of Sanford Kelley, the firm he had headed since 1894, until his illness.
The Paul Hammond Co. has arranged for the Improved New York Properties Corp. a mortgage loan of $200,000 at 4 per cent on the 1-story taxpayer on the southwest corner of Broadway and 93d St.
Gross assets, $70,554; net, $66.483. To Elizabeth Lenehan, sister, residue. Chief assets, transfers, $38,086. Daniel J. Tobin, attorney, 5 Beekman St.
Members of the Catholic Church obtained a temporary injunction today restraining Angel la Garda, government property custodian, from seizing church property here for seventy-two hours.

Gross premiums of the Maryland Casualty Company for the first half of 1937 amounted to $15,768,994, a gain of $957,206 from the corresponding period of 1936, Silliman Evans, chairman, announced yesterday.

Samuel Goldwyn, motion-picture producer, today amplified a statement credited to him, that Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, had been employed to write advertising for one of his pictures.

History, great romances and current events are the prime factors in shaping the trends of fashion, Helen Virginia Meyer, fashion historian, declared yesterday in a lecture before 1,000 students at Teachers College, Columbia University.

The first of a series of six races between the East and Midwest took place today over the Mantoloking Yacht Club course to determine a national champion in the Class E sloops which originated with the Inland Lakes Yacht Racing As- sociation of Minnesota and Wisconsin.

Edward Lamb, co-counsel for the Committee for Industrial Organization, called Governor Davey the "No 1 Judas or scab in American labor history" as the C. I. 0. com pleted its testimony late today in a suit against the use of troops in the steel strike.

St. St.Elmo's fire flowing about the giant hull was assigned as the probable cause of the Hindenburg disaster in a report on the Department of Commerce hearings made public today by Secretary Roper. St. Elmo's fire is the common name for the electrical phenomenon brush discharge.

A much-traveled golf professional, Leonard Dodson, Springfield, Mo., came up today with the Philadelphia open golf championship, won by a single stroke over Bruce Coltart, Woodcrest, N. J., in an eighteen-hole play-off.
Two fishermen today claimed a 12-pound sturgeon came up out of the depths of Lake Erie to snap at an outboard motor, missed his target and landed helpless in their boat.

Charles F. Kettering, vice president of the General Motors Corporation, warned the American Society of Civil Engineers today that by 1960 motor vehicle registrations would exceed 37,000,000, including 6,000,000 trucks, an increase of 50 per cent over present figures.

Citing the heavy losses to the milmery industry because of the ravages of style piracy, the Millinery Stabilization Commission, Inc., through John M. Keating, general counsel, has filed a petition as amicus curiae with the Federal Trade Commission, requesting that body to vacate the cease and desist order issued against the Millinery Quality Guild, Inc.

Great Britain, expecting every American to do more than his duty, appealed today to Henry Wilfred (Bunny) Austin for a modern miracle in the Davis Cup challenge round against the United States starting Saturday. All they are asking of the little Cambridge artist is to stop Don Budge, which is vaguely like asking him to stop the Spanish war.
The board of directors of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., authorized yesterday an offering to stockholders of one new share for each ten shares now held, at a price to be specified later.

The fall of the French franc continued unchecked yesterday and carried that exchange down to 3.71 3/4 cents, the lowest level for the last eleven years. The closing quotation, 3.71 7/8 cents, showed a net loss of 2 7/8 points from the previous day. In contrast to the franc,

Helen Vyse, formerly head of the home budget department of Wanamaker's store here, has been named general manager of the firm of Mrs. Perry Tiffany and Neil Martin, consuiting decorators, 122 East Sixtyfourth Street.

At a special meeting of the United Specialties Company stockholders authorized the issuance of 25,000 shares of $1.40 no-par cumulative convertible preferred stock and approved an amendment increasing the authorized common stock to 250,000 shares from 207,375.

Union leaders moved tonight to tighten the strikes of produce truckers and meat packers which tied up butter, egg and staple food deliveries to Buffalo grocery stores. Between 950 and 1,000 truckers went out at the Niagara Frontier Food Terminal and the Elk Street Market, the major Western New York produce distribution plants.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 21 (Canadian Press).-- Captain Freeman Hatfield was committed by Magistrate Glenn Strike today to stand trial at "the next court of competent jurisdiction" on a charge of obtaining money from the Government of Canada by false pretenses.

The net profit of Remington Rand, Inc., and subsidiaries for the quarter ended on June 30 last, totaled $1,470,168, the largest earnings for that period in the history of the company, according to a report yesterday by James H. Rand Jr., president.

A Mississippi political quarrel apparently decided the election in which Senator Barkley of Kentucky was chosen Democratic leader of the Senate today. Senator Bilbo, Democrat of Mississippi, disclosed that he voted for Mr. Barkley against his own colleague, Senator Harrison.

Construction work on the twelvemillion-dollar westerly express highway approach to the Bronx end of the Triborough Bridge has already brought about a transformation of the area between 134th and 135th Streets westward from Cypress Avenue and the bridge.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed upon the eligible list of holders of licenses for service in day high schools the names of the following applicants, who have been granted licenses, as indicated;

The National Labor Relations Boardissued a complaint today against the National Electrio Products Company of Ambridge, charging that the company coerced and intimidated employes into joining a union affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.
President Juan D. Arosemena confirmed yesterday the discovery of a cache of 120 gold bars weighing fifty pounds each by three prospectors near the Costa Rican border.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 19: CAPTAIN Chadwick, D. V., Norfolk Navy Yard, Portsmouth, Va., to home in October and relieved from all active duty.

Miss Sylvia Shethar added her second piece of silverware to the American Yacht Club's collection inside of a week today as 148 boatloads of lads and lassies, all under 18, took over Race Week for their twelfth annual junior regatta.

The Indianapolis motor speedway lifted today all fuel restrictions for the running of next year's 500-mile automobile race-an open invitation for foreign drivers and cars to challenge the supremacy of American drivers over the local two and onehalf mile track.

By action of the Board of Superintendents, Dr. William A. Clarke, principal of the John Adams High School, Queens, will be reprimanded officially for his "general supervisory attitude, "Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday.

The receivers of the Wabash Railway -Company will pay today 80 per cent of the face amount of coupons on the following bonds: First mortgage 5s of the company, coupon due on May 1; Detroit Chicagon extension 5s, coupon due on July 1; Des Moines division 4s, coupon due on July 1;

Public offering will be made today of 49,700 shares of common stock of the Harrisburg Steel Corporation by a group headed by D. M. S. Hegarty Co., Inc. The stock is priced at $13.75 a share, was acquired from stockholders and does not represent new financing on the part of the company.

This is the night the Federal Theatre Project descends on the Adelphi, offering therein the all-Negro musical comedy "Swing It." Some forty players will be singing and dancing a Mississippi River story for which Cecil Mack supplied the book, Milton Reddie and Eubie Blake the music, Mr. Reddie and Mr. Mack the lyrics.

FOR an alert and lively travel report see "Japanese Lady in Europe" (Dutton, $2.50), by Haruko Ichikawa. The book is written with great informality of style. It was intended for a Japanese audience. The views of the Western world are expressed with all possible frankness. and they are fresh and yeasty, good to sample.

TIENTSIN, China, July 21.--The Fifteenth United States Infantry was ordered today to stand by under full war packs to defend American citizens and interests. In event of emergency, one of the tasks of the American troops would be to keep open the railroad to the eastern seaport of Chinwangtao.

Challenging "the right of any majority to determine the political views of the members" of the granted American Newspaper Guild, Walter Lippmann has informed the Newspaper Guild of New York, with which he is affiliated, that he will not pay his membership dues "as long as the American Newspaper

A substantial part of the dollar balances which Japan has acquired in the past few months through the shipment of gold to this country has been used for the purchase of sterling exchange, it became known yesterday in the foreign exchange market.

Mayor D. R. Newton viewed with satisfaction today the results of his drive to rid Milan of "loafers." The main street was busier and there were fewer whittlers sitsing in front of stores swapping yarns.

In spite of the presence of substantial backlogs in some products and the fact that plants which were recently affected by strikes have increased their output over that of a week ago, the seasonal lull in new steel business is beginning to have an effect on operations, according to The Iron Age.
Little headway was made by bonds in trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The total volume was $7,438,000, compared with $7,702,000 on Tuesday.
A sharp break in cotton prices in Liverpool and the eighth consecutive favorable weekly weather report brought another decline in prices on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday.

The Trotting Horse Club of America received a cable yesterday from Givo Maiani of Milan, Italy, owner of Muscletone, saying that the Aug. 10 date set for the match race between his American-bred trotter and Greyhound, king of America's trotters, at Good Time Park, Goshen, N. Y., is impracticable, The Associated Press reported.

Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn signed an order yesterday directing that the first of a series of hearings under Section 21-A of the Federal Bankruptcy Law, in connection with the involuntary bankruptcy petition of the Tompkins Bus Corporation of Staten Island, be held today at 2 P. M. in the office of Sidney Lesser, an attorney, at 26 Court Street, Brooklyn.

WHEN the horses go into the paddock for saddling at Empire City-or at Belmont or Saratoga, for that matter-there are eleven men looking them over to make sure that there are no mistakes or substitutions, deliberate or accidental. All horses must be positively identified before the paddock judge gives the command:

The deadlock in the Non-Intervention Committee became more serious today as the fundamental nature of the dis agreement became more apparent. In reality it is the old deadlock that the British thought they had broken by their compromise plan of last week.

Canadian wheat in store for the week ended on July 16 showed a decline of more than 2,500,000 bushels from the previous week and a drop of almost 97,000,000 compared with the same week in 1936, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.
The practice of jibing spinnakers without taking them in was made legal in Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound races at a special meeting of delegates at the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

The Yard Workers Union, characterized as a company union of the Robins Drydock and Repair Company, foot of Dwight Street, Brooklyn, was formed at meetings held in a company garage on company time, according to testimony given yesterday by Jackson Welden, president of the union, at a hearing of the National Labor Relations Board in the Federal Building, Washington and Christopher Streets.

William Harprecht, 50 years old, of 2,043 Linden Street, Ridgewood, Queens, employed as night watchman by Parke, Davis Co., chemical manufacturers, at 181 Hudson Street, was found badly beaten and tied with ropes early yesterday morning in the basement of the building. He was taken to the Beekman Street Hospital.

TIENTSIN, China, Thursday, July22.--Alleviation of the tension southwest of Peiping, which was expected after an announcement that the anti-Japanese Thirty-seventh Division of General. Sung Cheh-yuan's army had been ordered to withdraw, failed to materialize today, for these forces, instead of retiring, ...

Notice of appeal was filed today with the Court of Errors and Appeals from a temporary injunction issued by Vice Chancellor Maja Leon Berry restraining picketing by strikers at the International Ticket Company here on the ground that it is unlawful to strike for a closed shop. The notice was filed by Meyer Semel,

The sale and closing of subscription books on an offering of $28,000,000 of Triborough Bridge Authority 4 per cent revenue bonds was announced last night by Dillon, Read Co., head of the underwriting group.

The State Racing Commission and five organizations authorized to conduct horse racing in New York State were named yesterday in an action brought by Joseph F. Meyers, operator of a dog race track in Orangeburg, N. Y., who charged that horse racers had instigated a State drive to close dog race tracks.

There was a 7.4 per cent increase in the production of electric energy in Argentina in 1936, compared with 1935, according to a report to the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce from the American commercial attache in Buenos Aires.

St. Lawrence AVe., 1,331, dwelling, 25x100; Home Owners Loan Corp. against Jacob Krisberg; due, $9,563; taxes, , $1,016; to plaintiff for $1,500. By HENRY BRADY Brook Ave., 506, 5-story brick tenement and stores, 25x98; Central Savings Bank of N. Y. against Mary Altin; due, $18,475; to plaintiff for $1,000.

The entire Mayoralty situation hinged last night on the meeting of the Tammany Hall executive committee at Tammany Hall tonight. James J. Dooling, Tammany leader, executed a quick political coup late yesterday afternoon by

A German military airplane crashed into a regiment of marching soldiers during maneouvres near Flensborg on the Danish-German frontier today. One private and two Danish tourists who happened to be passing the troops were killed and more than thirty soldiers were injured.

A new issue of $1,324,000 of refunding bonds of the Orleans Levee District (Louisiana) yesterday was awarded to a group headed by the Whitney National Bank of New Orleans on a bid of 100 for $1,235,000 as 4s and $89,000 as 3 3/4s. The bonds are dated Sept. 1 and will mature serially on Sept. 1, 1942 to 1973.
Benjamin P. Holbrook of Cambridge, a news editor of The Globe who had been with the paper forty-four years, died today at the Phillips House, Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 71 years old.

Electing to come through a narrow opening on the rail, apprentice Albert Cubitt sent Master Lad to the front in the early stretch and held sway thereafter to win the six-furlong Red Clay Handicap at Delaware Park today.

William Leroy Emmet, ten rooms, in 141 E 72d St; Richard Storra Childs, through Douglas L. Elliman Co. Inc. in 901 Lexington Ave; Dr. Ejnar Hansen, in 1,050 Park Ave; Jean L. Artur, in 427 Park Ave; Beatrice L. Renwick, Inc, broker.

About forty government sympathizers were executed in Algeciras and La Linea last night by Insurgents for pulling down red and gold flags Sunday during the celebration of the first anniversary of the war.

A bill liberalizing pensions of veterans and nurses who served during the Spanish-American War, the Philippine insurrection and the China relief expedition was passed today by the House and sent to the.Senate.

Funeral services for the Rev. Dr. George Frederick Clover, former pastor and superintendent of St. Luke's Hospital, were held yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Dr. Clover died at his Summer home at Norfolk, Conn., Monday at the age of 71.
Alben William Barkley, new majority leader of the United States Senate, has been a strong supporter of the policies of President Roosevelt ever since the New Deal came into power in Washington.

The British women's Wightman Cup tennis team, consisting of the Misses Kay Stammers, Mary Hardwick, Freda James, Joan Ingram, Evelyn Dearman and Margot Lumb, sailed for the United States today aboard the Queen Mary.

Miss Mary Radford Henry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Henry, will be married to Howard Brooker Seeley, son of Robert Seeley, on Aug. 14 in the first Methodist Episcopal Church. The Rev. Fred Hoskins, pastor of the United Church, will perform the ceremony,

The dry campaign included in Mexico's six-year plan, which so far has been carried on mainly on the basis of propaganda with a few measures and regulations enforced, will soon enter a new stage as the Health Department has drafted an "Anti-Alcoholic Bill" to be enforced by President Lazaro Cardenas before the new Legislature convenes Sept. 1.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 21.-- Miss Florence McLean of Grassy Sprain, daughter of George McLean, professional at the club, carried on the golfing traditions of the family today by capturing the women's invitation tournament at Briar Hills.

Wheat futures fluctuated in an erratic manner today, but showed a better undertone. There were several sharp dips as a result of scattered liquidation induced by weakness in Liverpool and by the favorable construction placed on the Weather Bureau's weekly crop summary.

There were 135 strikes, involving 41,944 persons, in effect in New York State during June, according to a report issued yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner. Of these, 47, With 23,800 workers, had not been settled by the end of the month.

Three men are in the North Country Community Hospital at Glen Cove after being burned shortly before noon today when the boat on which they were cruising in North Shore waters caught fire following an explosion of the gasoline tank.

A bill has been submitted to the Legislature of the Province of Entre Rios, Argentina, authorizing the issue of a loan of 57,000,000 pesos in 4 1/2 per cent bonds with 1 per cent cumulative amortization, according to a cablegram received yesterday by the Argentine Information Bureau here.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler today received the new Soviet Ambassador, Konstantin Jurieniew, at Obersalzburg without the customary military honors given in Berlin. Answering the Soviet diplomat's customary greetings Hitler made a hardly to be misunderstood reference to non-intervention. He said:

Opposition to the cancellation by the United States of any European war debts and a demand for a strict neutrality policy were expressed in resolutions adopted today by the Ancient Order of Hibernians in convention at the Hotel Chelsea here.
There were fresh demonstrations tonight in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, against the proposed ratification of the concordat with the Vatican, according to reports received here.

Completion of the $25,000,000 construction program of the National Steel Corporation at the plant of its Detroit subsidiary, the Great Lakes Steel Corporation, will almost triple the ingot capacity with which National Steel started when it was organized in 1929, Ernest T. Weir, chairman, announced yesterday.

Sir Percy Bates, chairman of the Cunard White Star Line, sailed for England yesterday on the Berengaria with Lady Bates after a fishing trip in Canada. Sir Percy said the Queen Mary had been equipped with four new propellers.

Broadway will see five new pictures today: Jean Harlow's last for Metro, "Saratoga," in which she co-stars with Clark Gable, is the newcomer at the Capitol....RKO's dramatization of the career of Jim Fisk will be presented by the Radio City Music Hall under the title "The Toast of New York."

Accusations of incompetence and unproductivity against the WPA Writers Project, made on Monday by Ralph M. Easley of New York in a letter to President Roosevelt, were denied today by Henry G. Alsberg, chief of the project, in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Basil Wagner, president of the Maryland State Golf Association and prominent in insurance, club and social circles, died here today at the age of 58. He was for years president of the A. G. Alford Sporting Goods Company and later became associated with the insurance firm of Warfield-Roloson, Inc., with which he was connected at his death.

Glenn D. Gilbert, bursar of the University of Wisconsin for more than twenty years and for the last four years an accountant for the State Public Service Commission, died last night after an illness of three months. He was 58 years old.

Vincent Rinkunas, 16 years old, of 128 North Fourth Street, Brooklyn, was killed by a policeman yesterday while he and a companion were fleeing after an attempt to break into a house at 128 Sullivan Place, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. The companion was arrested and identified as Marion Spebel, also 16, of 195 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.

Young women drink less regularly and in smaller amounts than young men, they incline more to mixed drinks, do less drinking in bars and restaurants and are more likely to drink because "others do," but their taste for hard liquor is about the same as the young men's and they have increased their drinking in the last two years more than have the voung men.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens drove yesterday from Miller Field, S. I., to Camp Dix, N. J., in one of the army's newest light tanks. Mr. Harvey, who is a lieutenant colonel in the United States Army Reserve, was observation officer on the trip made by five tanks of the First Tank Company, First Division of the United States Army, stationed at Miller Field.

I would like to offer my favorable comment upon the editorial that appeared in a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES under the caption "Strikes That Didn't Happen." In this editorial you take cognizance of one fact that many of your readers have overlooked -namely, that Mayor La Guardia's attitude toward labor disputes has undergone a decided change since the early days of his administration which witnessed the badly handled taxicab strike.

Fighting it out all the way down the stretch, C. M. Willock's Toro Lee defeated Miss A. Doris's Sorceress by a head in the $2,500 added Pocahontas Handicap, six furlong stake at Suf- 23 folk Downs today, to pay $10.40 for $2.

A proposal to lower the import rail rates at Boston to a parity with the New York and Portland rates has been submitted by railroads to the New England Freight Association, it was reported today to the Boston Port Investigation Commission at the State House.

Two days ago James Quinn, 29year-old motion-picture operator, of 80 Haven Avenue, who is a motor boat enthusiast and inventor in his spare time, proudly announced to his fellow-boatmen along the Hudson River in the vicinity of Dyckman Street that he had perfected a home-made diving outfit that would rank with the best.

Dr. Stephen S. Wise, president of the Zionist Organization of America and national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria for Europe with Mrs. Wise.

Vice President Garner admitted today that fishing the cool streams around Uvalde, Texas, appealed to him more than presiding over the Senate during midsummer. "I told the boss (meaning President Roosevelt) yesterday," he said this morning, "'I'm glad to see you and the rest of my friends, but I'd lie if I told you I was glad to be back.'"

The Maple Leafs beat the pace-setting Newark Bears twice tonight, 3-2 and 2-1. Atley Donald was saved from his first defeat in the opener as the Bears rallied for two runs in the last frame of the seven-inning twilight game to knot the count.

The daily average of electric power production increased last week when a decline was seasonal, and the adjusted index advanced to 109.0, the highest figure since the week ended Feb. 27. It was 107.0 in the previous week, and 104.9 in the week ended July 18, 1936.

An assertion that "State socialism controlled by a dictatorship" would be the result of an attempt to end unemployment by centralized planning was made today by Professor Hudson B. Hastings of Yale in an address before the Institute for Social Progress as Wellesley.

Nearly 200 Dutchess County neighbors of President Roosevelt heard Representative Hamilton Fish charge the Chief Executive tonight with taking advantage of legal income-tax loopholes in the administration of his Hyde Park estate and at the same time suggest that Congress prohibit absentee landlords or owners from deducting losses and depreciation on farms on which they do little or no work.

Edward Capobianco of 69 MacDougal Street was freed again yesterday of a charge of being a fugitive from justice by Supreme Court Justice Edward J. McGoldrick. He had been arrested at the request of Richmond, Va., authorities who are investigating a $12,000 hold-up at the Virginia Electric and Power Company there on June 21.

The Bronx County Trust Company sold to the Randall Construction Corporation the six-story elevator apartment house on a plot 80 by 100 feet at 1,401 University Avenue through the same brokers. The building contains 123 rooms laid out in apartments of three, four and five rooms and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $107,000.

After he had been pronounced dead apparently of natural causes, detectives of the East Fifth Street station discovered yesterday morning that Louis Amorelli, 28 years old, had been shot. Searching his clothing for identification at the station house, they found four bullet wounds in the man's back.

The report of United States and Foreign Securities Corporation for the first half of 1937 shows net assets of $49,829,195 on June 30, after normal Federal income taxes, equal to about $237 a share on 210,000 first preferred shares, compared with $56,635,000, or $269 a share, at Dec. 31.
Estate, more than $10,000. To Ida Beck, widow, 241 Central Park West, $2,500 and life estate in residue; Alice Lehmann, niece, executrix, 40 W. 86th St., remainder interest.

Dr. Josiah Payne Thornley of 136 West Seventieth Street, a specialist in diseases of the skin, who had practiced in this city for the last forty years, died yesterday morning in the Presbyterian Hospital of bronchial pneumonia after an illness of four days. He was born in Torresdale, Pa., seventy years ago.

The oil riches of the Soviet Union are growing like a falry tale giant," said Academician Ivan M. Gubkin, Russia's most distinguished geologist, today at the opening session of the International Congress of Geology, at which 2,500 geologists, 400 of whom are foreign, gathered.
Eamon de Valera was reelected President of the Executive Council today by a vote of 82 to 52 when the new Dail Eireann met for its first session since the general election.
Clyde Pangborn, American aviator detained two days for entering Soviet Russia without a passport visa, said tonight he and Representative William I. Sirovich of New York

Strang Ave (17-4979), n c cor of Ely AVe. 50x100; Thomas Magazzu to Carmela ``Gianninoto, 3,437 Seymour Ave. St Raymond Ave. 2,415 (15-3992): Eila Carney to William J. De Paul, 1,551 Parker St. Mace Ave, 1,120 (16-4453); Bronx County Builders, Inc., to Samuel Spahn, 3,437 Corsa Ave.

Two cool-headed hostages of a pair of fugitive convicts caught their kidnappers off guard today, grabbed their weapons and shot them down, making a dramatic end to a week's hunt by nearly 1,000 officers with bloodhounds.

The agreement that settled the strike in Paris hotels, cafes and restaurants was a compromise in which the employers gained distribution of the fortyhour week over six days and the right to work the personnel overtime.

Mr. and Mrs. Lee S. Crandall of Larchmont, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sylvia Harwood Crandall, to John Leonard Dudley 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Leonard Dudley of Pleasantville.
The Red Sox, aided by Jimmy Foxx's twentyfirst and twenty-second home runs of the season, snapped the fivegame winning streak of the Tigers today with a 10-3 victory.

The five-story St. Gregory apartment at 9-11 Rochelle Terrace, Mount Vernon, Westchester County, has been purchased by Irving W. Karpf through his 1233 Corporation. The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, the seller, took back a mortgage of $70,000 for ten years at 41/2 per cent. Robert D.

Maximilianu Litwin, 42-year-old dress manufacturer with offices at 498 Seventh Avenue, was killed yesterday morning in a fall from a window of his tenth-floor apartment at 375 Park Avenue at Fifty-second Street.

Enlargement of the staff of the Civil Service Commission to provide more examiners for candidates for scientific, technical and professional positions with the government was recommended as a possible immediate improvement in Federal personnel work by the Brookings Institution, in a report to the Senate Reorganization Committee, made public today.

The marriage of Miss Alice Estells Boyce, daughter of former Municipal Court Justice George H. Boyce and Mrs. Boyce of 62 Greenway Terrace, Forest Hills, Queens, to Jose Enrique Berumen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Enrique A. Berumen of Kew Gardens, took place last night in the Church-in-the-Gardens, Forest Hills.

The Jewish Sabbath Alliance of America made public yesterday correspondence with Commissioner Valentine in which the Sunday closing of food shops in the city was assailed on behalf of those who close on the seventh day Sabbath, from Friday sundown to Saturday sundown.
