Efforts of more than 200 dismissed Federal Theatre Project workers to obtain jobs in a mass job hunt proved unsuccessful again yesterday. The group met at the Union Methodist Episcopal Church, 229 West Forty-eighth Street, and then marched to offices of RadioKeith-Orpheum and the Grand National Film Corporation at 1,270 Sixth Avenue.

The largest distribution of alcoholic beverage tax receipts since prohibition ended was announced today by the State Controller, Morris S. Tremaine, who said that $4,261,899.68 had been sent to the counties as a result of the collections for the quarter ending June 30.
For ten years Carl W. Schlachter has been paying taxes on a piece of property he never owned, all because a map was wrong.

Suits against the C. I. O., its affiliated textile union and several other labor organizations and individuals were filed today, asking $400,000 damages for deaths and injuries suffered during a labor disturbance here last Summer.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 20: LIEUTENANT COLONEL Perrine, N. S., General Staff Corps (Inf.) (National Guard of the United States), relieved from assignment and duty at War Department General Staff, Washington, D. C., to sail from New York about Oct. 20 for San Francisco, thence to Amarillo, Texas, his home, reverting to inactive status Nov. 11.
Work was resumed today at Fry Products, Inc., where the boss twice has gone on strike, and the new peace was greeted with plans for company expansion.

About 2,100 children from daily vacation Bible schools of the metropolitan area marched down Fifth Avenue from Central Park yesterday morning to attend the annual church service for them at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fiftythird Street.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on July 10 totaled 307,255,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

By an almost unanimous vote early this morning the House of Commons declined to commit itself at this time to the partition of Palestine. Rather than carry the partition scheme to a vote, in which the Labor and Liberal parties and a smbll group of Conservatives might have opposed it in principle,

CANBERRA, Austrlia, July 19.--Two years ago the Commonwealth government appointed a royal commission to consider the desirability of changing Australia's monetary banking systems following many criticisms of policies of trading banks during the depression.

The Rev. Francis L. Carr, rector of the Catholic Church of Our Lady of Victory, West Philadelphia, died of heart disease today in his seventyeighth year. He had been in the priesthood for forty-nine years.

Mrs. Susan Bertha Carrington, widow of Eben Omar Carrington of Montclair, died here today in the Meyers Sanitarium at the age of 95. She is survived by three sons, Dr. Thomas Carrington, Omar H. and C. Frederick Carrington, and two daughters, Mrs. Mae C. Strang and Miss B. Corol Carrington.

Germany, whose military understanding with Japan has raised hopes in connection with the part she might play in a Chino-Japanese war, voiced her sympathy today with the attitude of the United States in the Far Eastern crisis through Dr. Hans H. Dieckhoff, her Ambassador to the United States.

All occupants but one on a crowded handcar on a railroad line under construction between Lower California and the State of Sonora either were killed or injured when the car was overturned on a downgrade curve.
Munitions manufacturers and international bankers, Dr. R. L. Morrow of the University of Maine told the Institute of World Affairs here today, are the results, not the causes, of war systems.

A transatlantic flight, unusual in that it had not been announced in advance, was apparently under way last night. The British steamship Ranee reported to the Radio Marine Corporation that it had sighted a plane at 7:04 P. M. 500 miles off Cape Race, Nfld., headed east. Its navigation lights were plainly visible but its identification numbers were not.

Georgia moved today to place a copy of the Bible in the hands of every school child in the State. A newly appointed State Board of Education unanimously approved a suggestion by Governor E. D. Rivers that 1,000,000 copies of the King James version be purchased.

The four-story brick apartment at 670 Grand Street, Jersey City, N. J., has been sold by the Excelsior Mutual Building and Loan Association to the P S Holding Corporation. This house occupies a plot 37.5 by 100 feet and contains sixteen fourroom apartments.
Behind excellent pitching by Bill Harris, the Bisons tonight pounded out a 9-to-4 victory over the Jersey City Giants for their lone decision in the three-game series.

The first of seven Rockport artists charged with violation of the Sunday laws by keeping their shops open on Sunday was found guilty today by Judge Lincoln S. Simonds. He is Arthur C. Smith of the Bearskin Neck Gallery. An appeal was taken.
Cincinnati at New York-Grissom vs. Schumacher. Pittsburgh at Brooklyn-Lucas vs. Henshaw. St. Louis at Boston-Harrell vs. MacFayden. Chicago at Philadelphia-Shoun vs. Passeau.

Mrs. John M. Scott of Philadelphia died at her Summer residence, Strath-Eden, this morning of angina. Mrs. Scott was born in Philadelphia, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Barker, a prominent iQuaker family.

The State Department was informed today by Nelson T. Johnson, United States Ambassador to China, that the commander of the Japanese Embassy guard in Peiping had officially expressed regrets to the commander of the United States Embassy guard for the incident in which Japanese soldiers on Monday evening kicked and shoved Mrs. Helen R. Jones of Detroit and Miss Carol Lathrop of this city.

During the last school year, 10,669 licenses were granted to applicants for teaching and supervisory positions in the New York City school system, Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg, chairman of the board of examiners, revealed yesterday in his annual report to Dr. Harold G. Campbell, superintendent of schools.

The Kelvinator Company, manufacturers of electric refrigerators, have leased the four-story concrete building on the northeast corner of Pearson Place and Twenty-seventh Street, Long Island City. The structure contains approximately 60,000 square feet of space, is built to sustain heavy loads and is served by a Long Island Railroad siding.

Scheduling a newspaper campaign in fifteen large cities and several smaller ones along the Atlantic seaboard, the Baltimore Club Distilling Company yesterday began efforts to expand its market in that region for its two American blended whiskies, Baltimore Club "Private Vat" and Baltimore Club "Special Reserve."

Establishing a precedent in relations between buyers and sellers of merchandise in the department store field, the associate council of the vendors' relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association yesterday asked coat and suit buyers of retail stores to give due consideration to the "justifiable price advances" now being made on coat and suit orders for Fall.

The Committee on Court Houses of the New York Criminal Courts Bar Association, in a report made public yesterday, insisted that runners, steerers and fixers who infest the Criminal Courts Building, preying on defendants and their relatives, should be driven out immediately by the police.

With both men seeking a welterweight title meeting with Barney Ross, Ceferino Garcia and Bobby Pacho will collide tonight in the feature fifteen-round bout in Madison Square Garden. Because of his more impressive gymnasium workouts, Pacho has been installed a slight favorite.

Trading in beef continued slow and prices were steady to sharply lower. The lamb supply was very light and prices higher. Veal sold steady to higher and fresh pork cuts uneven. Kosher veal and lamb opened higher, beef steady, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Mrs. Jane Leavens, a communicant of Plymouth Church on Brooklyn Heights in the days of Henry Ward Beecher, died yesterday morning at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Alice Farrell of Islip, L. I. Mrs. Leavens, 87 years old, was the widow of James Leavens, who served as chaplain of the Eleventh Mounted Rifles, a Brooklyn regiment, in the Civil War.

Bids for the purchase of the twenty-three-story Manhattan Towers Hotel at Broadway and Seventysixth Street will be opened on Aug. 5, according to Edwin R. Wolff, an attorney for the trustees, who said the latter received many inquiries about the property yesterday following publication of an advertisement inviting the bids.

The C. I. O. was chosen collective bargaining agent for employes of the National Sugar Refining Company's local plant by a vote of 696 to 128 in an election conducted today by the National Labor Relations Board.
Dr. Edward K. Barsky, formerly associate attending surgeon of Beth Israel Hospital, who recently supervised the establishment of six American hospitals behind the Loylist lines in Spain,

The British Government hoped to see a trade treaty negotiated with the United States, but primarily it must find a sound basis which would not conflict with the broader tenets of empire policy, Viscount Halifax, the Lord President of the Council, declared in the House of Lords today.
A comprehensive study of New York's fiscal setup will be undertaken not later than Aug. 15 by a joint legislative committee created for that

A large audience filled Parrish Memorial Hall tonight when members of the Southampton Players under the direction of Donald Blackwell, guest director, opened their second production for this season with the presentation of "Our Betters," a comedy by Somerset Maugham.

Exercising for the first time his right to avoid sending to the electric chair a man convicted of firstdegree murder by a jury that recommended mercy, County Judge Gerald Nolan of Westchester County today sentenced Novio Santoro, 24 years old, a Yonkers caddy, to life imprisonment.

The marriage of Miss Marjory Mayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Charles Mayer of Forest Hills, L. I., to Henry Hewlett Tredwell Jr., son of Henry H. Tredwell of Haddington, East Williston, L. I.,

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld.-This city's "coronation iceberg" still floated a short distance off the harbor mouth today, a rare spectacle of glistening white under a blazing sun that has kept temperatures above the 80-degree mark almost consistently for weeks.

The huge steel caisson which will be used in boring the north tube of the Lincoln Tunnel under the Hudson River from Manhattan to Weehawken, N. J., was floated to its berth at the foot of West Thirtyninth Street yesterday.

The stock markets were quietly firm today and, although the movements were small, prices generally were better. Gilt-edge issues drooped as a result of idleness, while among the foreign loans French bonds made a strong recovery and Japanese and Chinese issues were better.

Their battle front so badly riddled that at the finish Bill Terry's usually sleek-looking machine seemed to be operating with a spare tire for a steering wheel, the Giants fought very heroically at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Side-wheelers and side-whiskers go together in the memory. We dimly see our first Fall River captain, commodore by courtesy, burly, gruff, resplendent in blue and gold, with hanging gardens on his face. His was the majesty that befitted the commander of a "floating palace," the Queen Mary of the Sound. The boats grew more and more "palatial."

The National Stake for 3-year-old trotters went into a fourth heat "in the Grand Circuit racing today before Gunar, a bay colt, clinched what harness horsemen considered a preview of the Hambletonian.

The charm of Princess Margaret Rose have been set to music in a suite for strings and harp composed by Dennis Stoll, son of Sir Oswald Stoll, motion picture theatre owner. The Princess, younger daughter of King George and Queen Elizabeth, will be 7 on Aug. 21.
At last night's interval in Lewisohn Stadium's Wagner Festival, Fritz Reiner conducted a purely symphonic program before an audience estimated at more than 3,000.

THOMAS E. DEWEY and his aides, working with quiet efficiency and unresting thoroughness, continue to pile up their brilliant record. With the conviction just secured of four of the five defendants in the bakery racket trial, Mr. DEWEY'S office has now secured altogether the amazing result of sixtyeight convictions out of seventy cases brought to trial.
ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL HISTORY OF MEDIEVAL EUROPE, by Henri Pirenee. (Harcourt, Brace, $2.) A scholarly survey.

The second concert of the current Brahms series of the Federal Music Project was given at the WPA Theatre of Music last night. Due to the recent hunger strike a month had elapsed since the date originally set for this event and certain changes had been made in the program in the interim.

Professor George S. Miller, assistant to the president of Tufts College since 1916, was named acting president by the executive committee of the board of trustees today to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Dr. John A. Cousens.

Walter Hagen today came to the assistance of those members of his Ryder Cup team who, by a few thoughtless sentences to ship news reporters on their arrival in New York yesterday, have swept away all the happy memories of their recent visit here and caused deep resentment and anger among all British sportsmen.

A registration statement covering 50,000 shares of the common stock of Furniture Shops of America, Inc., will be filed soon with the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was announced yesterday. The stock will represent new financing by the company and Eugene J. Hynes Co., Inc., will be the principal underwriter.
Louis Bromfield will arrive on the Europa today with the manuscript of his new novel, "The Rain Came." Harpers will publish the book in October.

Exiling of scholars for racial, religious and political reasons is gaining momentum in many other countries besides Germany, according to a report of the Society for the Protection of Science and Learning, which will be issued here tomorrow.

Dr. Thomas A. Gonzales, who recently qualified for the post of chief medical examiner in a civil service examination, was sworn in by Mayor La Guardia yesterday at the Summer City Hall in College Point, Queens.

The fifth place Boston Bees whacked the St. Louis Cardinals twice today with a pair of stellar pitching performances, 5 to 1, in eleven innings, and 2 to 1, and moved within four games of the first-division Redbirds.

The Waitera, Waitresses and Cooks Union called a "customer sit-down" today in a downtown restaurant. Just before the noon rush hour 100 persons entered the restaurant. Each bought a cup of coffee and sat down. When regular patrons arrived all the available chairs were occupied.

Senator Wagner, replying today to Governor Lehman's plea that he oppose the pending court change bill, wrote that while he shared the feeling that the independence of the judiciary must be maintained,

Passengers arriving today from Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Europa include Lincoln Ellsworth, polar explorer, with Mrs. Ellsworth; Lady Vivien Gabriel, Louis Bromfield, author, with Mrs. Bromfield; Douglas H. Gordon, editor of The Norfolk Ledger-Dispatch; Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin, Mrs.

OILER-$1,380 a year. Custodial Service, Postoffice Department, New York, N. Y. Applications must be on file with the district manager, Second U. S. Civil Service District, Federal Building. Christopher St., New York, N. Y., not later than July 26.

While former tenants of the building were attempting to salvage what was left of their furniture, a protest meeting was held last night by the Chelsea Tenants League in front of the five-story tenement at 464 West Thirty-fifth Street where one man was killed and three were injured in a fire Tuesday night.

Persecution of Lutheran clergy in Russian Ingria still continues relentlessly, declared Dean S. Laurikkala, chairman of the Ingrian Lutheran Synod, who was recently deported with his family from the parish where he had worked continuously since 1909.

Mrs. Emma Maria Davis, a leader in women's organizations here, died today at her home at the age of 85. She was the widow of Franklin Truman Davis, former head of the undertaking firm of Burr Davis Son.
Private funeral services will be conducted tomorrow afternoon at his home for William N. Dykman, senior member of the law firm of Cullen Dykman, who died yesterday after a short illness.

A change of location by the New York State National Guardsmen for staging its simulated battles while engaged in field problems off the Camp Smith reservation has brought up a problem not scheduled, that of appeasing the ire of the residents in the vicinity of the "battle" fields, who are opposed to the early morning noise made by the firing of blank cartridges by the soldiers.
Organization plans for a new A. F. of L. union of newspaper men were announced today by John Fitzpatrick, presdent of the Chicago Federation of Labor.

Three former beer truck drivers for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer were in the line-up at police headquarters yesterday following their arrest late Tuesday night on charges of vagrancy. Later in the day they were discharged by Magistrate Raphael Murphy in Bronx Felony Court.

Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a store and office structure in Eighth Avenue and various alterations. Other plans were filed for buildings in the Bronx and Brooklyn. The plans follow:

Department of Justice agents and New York police were enlisted tolay in the search for the author of extortionn notes which threatened death or injury to at least three business men in Hudson County. The suspect is believed by police to be a former resident of Hoboken.

A special expediting court of three judges of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals gave the Federal Government permission today to proceed in the Federal courts of New York against the Aluminum Company of America for alleged violations of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.
An offering will be made to the public today of an issue of $25,000,000 general mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds of the Westchester Lighting Company by a banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc.

Seven sit-in strikes conducted by home-relief clients were called off yesterday after an agreement was reached between representatives of the Workers Alliance, an organization of unemployed, and officials of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

The French Foreign Office, it is reported here, will shortly appoint a sticcessor to Georges Bonnet as Ambassador to Washington. This appointment is expected to result in a reshuffling of diplomatic posts.

Improved business conditions will help push employers' contributions to New York's unemployment insurance fund over $100,000,000 by Jan. 1 , or about $10,000,000 more than originally estimated, the State Labor Department said tonight.

The Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association embarked on the novelty of a Scotch foursome championship tournament at Bonnie Briar today and by way of making everything even more novel decided to stage qualifying round and match play over a ninehole route.

Mrs. Stella M. Crater believes that her husband, Supreme Court Justice Joseph Force Crater, who disappeared Aug. 6, 1930, was murdered because of his political career as a judge and a member of Tammany Hall, according to a copyrighted interview published in The New York World-Telegram.

Fifty-two army trucks and other vehicles, carrying 320 men and about fourteen officers under command of Major Stephen Sherrill, left Fort Monmouth, N. J., yesterday morning on one of the longest "marches" ever made in this country.

Finance Minister Georges Bonnet today obtained the approval of the council of the Bank of France for a new contract between the bank and State providing for the creation of a fund to support the franc. Much curiosity has been expressed in financial circles over this feature of the restoration program.

Governor Earle, who recently urged a third term for President Roosevelt, denounced Governor Lehman of New York today as disloyal because of his opposition to the administration's Supreme Court Reform Bill.

It is twenty-one years since New York City treated itself to a complete new building code. During that period there have been great changes in matrials, in methods of construction and in prevailing ideas as to the kinds of buildings we ought to have.
Irving M. Felt, vice president of the Adams Express Company, has been elected a director of the Lone Star Cement Corporation to fill a vacancy created by the death of Parmely W. Herrick.

William F. Raynor, 18 years old, of The Ridge, a village near here, was drowned about 8:30 this evening in Artist's Lake. On a moonlight bathing party with several other boys and girls, the youth went down without being noticed by his companions.

Fifteen members of the American Battle Monuments Commission arrived in Paris this morning. They are the first contingent of guests of the commission and official representatives of the United States Government. They have come to assist General John J. Pershing in dedicating American battle monuments in France, Belgium, England and Gibraltar.

The conviction is strong now that under any leadership the Browns remain the same. Jim Bottomley celebrated his first day at the helm in Sportsman's Park today, but Imade the mistake of selecting a day on which an obscure Yankee staged a cele bration of his own.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved an application by the International Hydroelectric System, a voluntary association or trust established under the laws of Massachusetts, for permission to acquire 1,439,020 common shares of the Gatineau Power Company of Quebec, all the properties of which are in Canada.

A witness at the Ford Motor Company hearing before the National Labor Relations Board today testified that Harry H. Bennett, personnel director of the Ford Company, complimented participants in the May 26 riot at the gate of the company for their "good work."

An increasing volume of retail trade, built on women's patronage, has tripled the number of positions held by women in that field in the last decade, according to Dr. Charles M. Edwards Jr., Assistant Professor of Retailing at New York University. Dr. Edwards discussed tonight for the delegates to the convention of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women here feminine advancement in a major phase of their professional activities.

A luncheon was given yesterday in the Garden of the Ambassador by Mrs. Neville Monroe Hopkins for Mrs. Sumner W. Taylor of Douglaston, L. I. The other guests included Mrs. Richard A. May, Mrs. Frank Weir K. Baker and Miss Diana Taylor. With Mrs. James J. Tanyan for luncheon there were Mrs. Alfred Smith, Mrs. John R. Murphy, Mrs. Harold J. McCarthy and Miss Lillian Ryan.

A strike of the crews of the Seatrain Lines, which transports loaded freight cars between New York and New Orleans by way of Havana, was settled yesterday at a conference at the office of Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board.
Tommy Farr, British heavyweight boxing champion, set up training quarters on the Atlantic ocean front today for his championship bout with Joe ?? ouis Aug. 26 at the Yankee Stadium in New York.

Dr. C. F. McClintic, warden of the State penitentiary, appealed today for help to rid himself of 2,200 birds. The warden, who is head of the West Virginia Wild Life League, obtained eight mallard duck eggs in 1934. Five hatched. Last year there were 161 eggs and today more than 2,200 ducks are-quacking about the prison farm.

The Bolivian Legation here gave out today the text of a message received from La Paz, Bolivian capital, according to which the new government headed by Colonel German Busch has made a formal declaration that the Bolivian Army is not governing the country with any political party and that support comes from all quarters.

After early irregularity, the stock market had to contend with profittaking in moderate volume yesterday. The closing was easier. Steel issues and other industrials in recent favor showed the principal declines.

President Roosevelt's resignation from the presidency of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York, a post he has held continuously since 1922, was communicated yesterday to the executive board of that organization at a meeting in the Midday Club, 25 Broad Street.

Sixto Escobar, world bantamweight champion, registered a technical knockout over Georgie Holmes of Brooklyn in the third of a scheduled ten-round bout at Dyckman Oval last night. Referee Pete Hartley called a halt after thirty-six seconds of the session had elapsed.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the following additional applications from New York City for registration as brokers or dealers in the over-thecounter market (symbols-S., sole proprietor; P., partnership; C.,

A call for a strike vote was issued yesterday by Local 302 of the Cafeteria Employes Union to the 3,000 employes of Horn Hardart's forty-four cafeterias in this city. The vote will be taken at 8:30 P. M. tomorrow at Palm Garden Hall, 306 West Fifty-second Street.

Ninth-inning rallies brought victory to the Indians today in both game of a double-header with the Athletics. The scores were 9-8 and 8-r. Bob Feller, Iowa schoolboy fireball hurler, was credited with his first victory of the season in the curtain raiser when he went to the mound for Cleveland in the final inning.

Princess Juliana and Prince Bernhard received today one of the most unusual presents ever given to a young couple. It was a huge stone weighing about three and a half tons, which arrived at their palace at Soestdyk,
Dr. Eben Alden, one of the oldest active medical practitioners in the State, died at his home here today. He was 85 years old.

The Appellate Division, Third Department, today held unanimously and without opinion that the Communist party emblem shall not appear on the ballot at the November election, sustaining the decision of Supreme Court Justice Schenck.
Miss Audrey Phipps of Piping Rock walked off with all of the honors today in the women's Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament at the Deepdale Golf Club.

Members of the World's Fair committee of the Board of Estimate met yesterday in Mayor La Guardia's office in the Summer City Hall at College Point in an effort to decide whether the proposed spur from the Queens Boulevard line of the city subway to the World Fair should be permanent or temporary.

WASHINGTON, July 21.--Senator Barkley of Kentucky was elected by the Democrats of the Senate today to be their leader, replacing Senator Robinson, who had held the post for fifteen years up to the time of his death last week.

Mayor Henry S. Wheeler tonight said that officials of the New York, | New Haven Hartford Railroad had assured him they were "considering adequate rail service" to replace the transportation facilities formerly offered by the Fall River boats, which have landed here for nearly 100 years.

Filling the creel: Block Island, an active center for commercial swordfishing boats, was treated to a rarity on Tuesday when Lewis E. Pierson, chairman of the board of directors of the Irving Trust Company, brought in a broadbill caught with rod and reel.

Another colorful chapter of American history-the discovery of the Pennsylvania oil fields and the bitter struggle for their control-has been set to music and retold in vividly cinematic terms by Paramount's "High, Wide and Handsome," which had its premiere at the Astor last night and seems destined to continue for months on a two-a-day basis.

The purchase of the A. B. See Elevator Company by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company was ratified by the See stockholders at a meeting yesterday. They are to receive in payment 10,000 Westinghouse common shares currently worth $1,523,750.

After delegates to the annual convention of the National Maritime Union had adopted resolutions yesterday afternoon urging the removal from office of Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission, because he owned 1,500 shares of stock in Todd Shipyards Corporation they reversed their position last night and gave him a "clean bill of health."

Mayor La Guardia, who was nominated for national leadership as "the modern Abraham Lincoln" by William Allen White on Tuesday, indicated yesterday his confidence that he would continue to lead from New York's City Hall for the next four years.
Julian Bell, one of the most promising of the younger British poets, is reported to have been fatally wounded while driving an ambulance at Madrid. He was 28 years old.

The marriage of Miss Grayce Naylor Winship, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Oliver Winship of Flushing, Queens, to Chester Frederick Leonard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Leonard, also of Flushing, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Christ Church, Sixtieth Street and Park Avenue. The Rev. Dr. Ralph Sockman, the pastor, performed the ceremony.
Jimmy DeShong limited the White Sox to six hits today to give the Senators x 7-3 victory for their first triumph in their last eleven games. More than 8,000 fans saw the contest.

The Japanese and Chinese Government? were no nearer an agreement today on the North China crisis despite an important conference yesterday between Foreign Minister Koki Hirota and Hsu Shih-ying, the Chinese Ambassador.

Although President Roosevelt' continued espousal of his Supreme Court program is a catastrophic move politically, his agitation for changes in the judicial system has stamped him as a great educator, according to Dr. Lyman Bryson, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University.

A public offering of $200,000 principal amount of convertible 6 per cent debentures with warrants attached and a block of $1 par value common stock of the National Tool Company of Cleveland, Ohio, will be made today by means of a prospectus by F. J. Young Co., Inc.

National Sample Card Co, Inc. in 418-22 Broadway; Betty Levin, beauty parlor, in 820 Madison Ave; Potter, Hamilton Co, Inc, broker. Louis Massry, lingerie and linen. through L. J. Phillips Co, store in 1,355 Sixth Ave; Morris Corn. ladies handbags, through Duff Conger, Inc. in 972 Lexington Ave; Butt, Gilliam McVay, Inc, broker.

Middleweight Champion Freddie Steele of Tacoma, Wash., scored an eight-round technical knockout over Charles (Hobo) Williams of Alexandria, Va., in a scheduled tenround non-title contest tonight at Griffith Stadium. The bout was stopped after 2:56 of the eighth round. Steele weighed 159 and Williams 161.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:
The economic plan submitted by James H. Edwards, financial expert retained by the government, contemplates a more powerful commission. for the control of exchange transactions.
Philadelphia proved an easy hurdle for the league-leading Cubs in their race for the National League pennant today. Chicago won both ends of a double-header before 10,000 fans, 4-1 and 6-0.
Cameron of the Ford Motor Company made a scathing attack on the National Labor Relations Board today in an address before the National Editorial Association.

Justice Bergan of the Supreme Court will conduct a trial term here on Aug. 2 to determine the issues in the action of William J. Sheils, Surrogate of Westchester County, who appeals from an order dismissing a complaint in which he sought a declaratory judgment fixing his status as Surrogate, the Appellate Division directed today.
A couple of minor miracles were performed at Ebbets Field yesterday and Burleigh Grimes still was pinching himself occasionally during the evening to make sure he was awake.

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals upheld today imposition of more than $2,000,000 in taxes on the income of a Florida holding company, practically all of whose stock was owned by Alfred I. du Pont and members of his family.

Stanley W. Switter, chief of police of Massillon, Ohio, told the National Labor Relations Board today, at the opening of hearings on the complaint against the Republio Steel Corporation for alleged violation of the Wagner act, that General William E. Marlin, head of the National Guard of Ohio, had urged him to appoint additional men to the police force from a list which included employes of the steel company.
Cameron of the Ford Motor Company made a scathing attack on the National Labor Relations Board today in an address before the National Editorial Association.

Justice Bergan of the Supreme Court will conduct a trial term here on Aug. 2 to determine the issues in the action of William J. Sheils, Surrogate of Westchester County, who appeals from an order dismissing a complaint in which he sought a declaratory judgment fixing his status as Surrogate, the Appellate Division directed today.

A race against death ended in failure this afternoon when hope was abandoned for the life of May Retzer, 13 years old, of 362 Cypress Avenue, the Bronx, who was drowned at Camp Kinderland, Sylvan Lake, shortly before noon. At 3 o'clock this afternoon, after three hours of efforts to restore life, physicians pronounced her dead.

WASHINGTON,July 21.--Now that the dominant anti-Court Bill leaders in the Senate, without any apparent furother obstruction from the President, seem on the verge of working out a judiciary bill which will represent a legislative defeat for him on every point affecting the Supreme Court, the political community is turning its mind to the possible consequences.
Judge Edwin C. Dickenson in Superior Court today granted to the Mitchell Dairy Company of Bridgeport, a Borden subsidiary, the right to sell milk, cream, , in paper containers without extra charge.

Greece, Turkey and a number of other small countries on the Mediterranean and in Central Europe have switched their buying activities from Germany and England to the United States in the last sixty days, according to officials of export trade groups yesterday.

The House Labor Committee voted today to include local retail store employes among those whose working conditions would be subject to Federal regulation under the Wages and Hours Bill. This brings its bill into line with that of the Senate Labor Committee, which originally Included retail employes.

E. H. H. Simmons, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange Law Committee, has addressed a letter to the membership of the trading body, urging that suggestions regarding the proposal to charge higher commissions be made to the law committee on or before July 26, as it hopes to report to the governing committee on July 28.
Spanish Insurgent sources reported today a reconciliation between Generalissimo Francisco Franco and JosE Maria Gil Robles, Catholic leader and former War Minister.
Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, estimated today that Federal agents saved taxpayers $7 during the fiscal year 1937 for every dollar expended by the bureau.

Bequests of $25,000 each were made to Harvard University "for the maintenance of athletic sports," to the Harvard Club of New York and to the Roxbury Latin School, West Roxbury, Mass., by Thomas W. Slocum, former dry goods commission merchant, whose will was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
A scroll was presented to Controller Frank J. Taylor yesterday by a committee of firemen for the part he played in having municipal civil service salaries restored to the 1932 level.
Refusal of lumbermen and dealers in building materials to recognize a newly organized millworkers' union brought construction to a virtual standstill here today.

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months to June 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, of $25,377,500.

A $270,000 mortgage held by the Union Dime Savings Bank on 155 W 57th St from the 57th St Realty Corp, Edgar A. Levy, president, was extended to May 1, 1940, 41/2, per cent. Frances E. Mirick assigned to Marietta Marino a mortgage for $8,000 on 2,128 2d Ave.

Stockholders of the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation voted at their adjourned annual meeting yesterday to amend the company's charter to permit the utility to extend its territory of operation and to increase the preferred stock to 500,000 shares from 300,000 shares.

Preliminary estimates of the operations of the New York Central Railroad for the first six months of 1937 place net income at approximately $6,500,000, compared with $360,864 for the corresponding period last year.

A new attempt to get judicial sanction for service bureaus organized to represent motorists in traffic court for a fee was made yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer. The Traffic Service Bureau holds that its activities have been illegally and unreasonably banned by Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr.

Department store trade during the first half of July in the metropolitan area showed an increase of 3.5 per cent, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday. The gain for New York and Brooklyn stores for the period was 3.3 per cent, while that for Northern New Jersey establishments was 4.7 per cent.

Having liquldated the Rebel counter-offensive, the Loyalists today resumed their efforts to take Villafranca del Castillo, managing to advance a few kilometers toward it after starting from Villanueva del Pardillo.
The Health Department pressed forward today in its efforts to find a haven for hay fever sufferers within the State.

Radio's short waves, which Guglielmo Marconi first offered to the world in dot-dash form as a lightninglike communication system, flashed out of the dusk from the Eternal City yesterday to toll his requiem across the hemispheres.

In the grounds of the Ford Rotunda, the "Roads of the World," comprising materials from eighteen famous highways, was opened to the public today. The materials consist of stones, slabs and soil. The dedication of the "roads" was witnessed by consular officers of countries represented in the roads, also many good roads officials.
Miss Helen Webster, daughter of David Locke Webster, Stanford University Professor of Physics, was married today to Paul Feeley, head of the plastic art department of Cooper Union, New York.

Miss Margaret Ewing Finneran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emmett J. Finneran of this place was married to Lewis Jacquelin Lambert, son of Mrs. Henry C. Lambert of Bronxville, this afternoon at the home of her parents.

Mr. and Mrs. John Livingston Thomas, who have returned to 140 East Eighty-eighth Street after a visit to California and Utah, will leave soon to pass the rest of the Summer at the Atlantic Beach Club.

The marriage of Mrs. Marjory Stearns Hubbard, daughter of Mrs. Frederick Kimball Stearns of Beverley Hills, Calif., and the late Mr. Stearns, to Hermann Richardson, son of Mrs. Emma Meyer Richardson of San Francisco and Dr. George Henry Richardson also of San Francisco, took place here last night in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

The unrest among oil workers in Mexico again has resulted in a strike which started last midnight against the Mexican Eagle Oil Company, a subsidiary of Royal Dutch Shell, in refineries at Tampico and Atzapotzalco, a suburb of this city,

The British Admiralty announced today that a practice charge dropped by the destroyer Wolfhound to signal a British submarine off Portland while a German U-boat passed near by led to erroneous reports that the German craft had been halted.
Harry W. Colmery of Topeka, Kan., National Commander of the American Legion, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria for the dedication of seven large war monuments next month.

The full meaning of Hungary's return to a regime monarchical in nearly everything save name is not yet manifest. The legislation passed unanimously by the Council of Deputies recently increases the power and prerogatives of Admiral NICHOLAS HORTHY, confers upon him life tenure as Regent, and fixes the method of determining his successor.

While no definite expansion program has been determined, according to the registration statement for R. H. Macy Co., Inc., common shares, to be offered to stockholders on a one-for-ten basis, the statement says that "assuming a reasonable dividend policy," a reduction in working capital is to be expected over the next year.

A Morgan County jury, which was barred by law from sending Andy Wright, a defendant in the Scottsboro cases, to the electric chair, condemned him today to ninety-nine years' imprisonment. Judge W. W. Callahan, to whose entire charge to the jury Samuel Leibowitz,

President Roosevelt conferred with Senators Barkley and Harrison on pending legislation and transacted routine business. The Senate was in recess; the Democratic caucus elected Senator Barkley as majority leader to succeed the late Senator Robinson.
Representative Dies of Texas asked today a Congressional investigation of what he called un-American activities, including those of Nazis, Fascists, Communists and White Russians in this country.
Movements of vessels follow; all dates are July 20 unless specified: At Balboa: Babbitt, Bushnell, Charleston, Taylor. At Taku Harbor: Boric, Trever, Zane. Westpoint to Fort Bond Bay, July 21:
Seventeen American track and field aces, comprising two squads which will see action in European meets, sailed for England yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow HOGS Receipts 9,000 including 2,500 directs. Market generally 10-15 cents higher than Tuesday's average: spots late 15-20 cents higher; top $12.85; not much above $12.75. Bulk good and choice 180-250 pounds, $12.50.75; 150-170 pounds, $12.15-.65; most good packing sows 290-500 pounds, $10.25-$11; lightweights to $11.10 and better. Shippers, 2,000; estimated holdover, 1,500.

More than 10,000 shoe workers in this city will participate in a vote to be taken on Wednesday under the supervision of the National Labor Relations Board to determine union affiliation. The contest will be between the Boot and Shoe Workers Union, A. F. of L. affiliate,

The State Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission gave support today to the activities of the Foreign Bondholders' Protective Council, Inc., of which J. Reuben Clark, a former UnderSecretary of State, is president,

Many people, first and last, have managed to disagree with Senator GEORGE WILLIAM NORRIS, some for what would seem to be good reasons and others for very bad reasons. NORRIS has never been anybody's yes man. Long ago he broke with his Republican colleagues and was permanently deprived of control over Nebraska patronage.

Italian life came Italian life came to a standstill for about an hour and a half this evening while the last tribute of affection and admiration was being paid in Rome to Marquis Gugllelmo Marconi. Persons from all walks of life joined in honoring the man who was one of the greatest prides of contemporary Italy.
The baseball teams representing the Yale Club and the Harvard Club battled to a 2-to-2 ten-inning tie in their annual contest at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.
RED BANK, N.J., July 21.--The theft of $7,000 in jewelry from two homes on Navesink River Road in Middletown Township early last week was reported today by Monmouth County detectives.
Representatives of the world's Protestant churches, meeting here in the Conference on Church, Community and State, denounced today the suppression of national minorities by some governments

Extension of Canada's diplomatic relationships to include the naming of High Commissioners to sister dominions and the Irish Free State and the establishment of a legation in the Belgian capital are being considered by the Canadian Government, and an announcement is expected soon.

Rudyard Kipling's "Wee Willie Winkle," as transferred to the screen by Director John Ford for Twentieth Century-Fox, will open an engagement this morning at the Roxy. Shirley Temple and Victor McLaglen are the principals in a large cast including C. Aubrey Smith, June Lang, Michael Whalen, Cesar Romero, Constance Collier and Douglas Scott.
Temperatures rose in many parts of the country today. J. R. Lloyd, forecaster at the Chicago station of the Weather Bureau, reported temperatures generally were above normal and would go higher.
The Bees pulled within three games of a first division berth today when Danny MacFayden pitched them to a 2-0 victory that swept the four-game series with the Cardinals.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date.

Martin Popper, attorney, of 475 Fifth Avenue, filed suit yesterday in Federal court to. compel Harold Stein, director of the Music, Writers and Art Projects of the WPA, and Audrey MacMahon, director of the Federal Arts Project, to reinstate Ann Himmel and Nunzio Laspina, his clients, who have been dropped from the WPA rolls.

The Tammany executive committee threw down the gauntlet last night to the Democratic leaders of the four other counties of the city and the Roosevelt administration and adopted a resolution designating United States Senator Royal S. Copeland as the Tammany candidate for the party nomination for Mayor by a vote of 1511-12 to 8 5-12.

Mrs. John G. M. Glessner gave a large tea and cocktail party for members of the Littleton, Sugar Hill and Franconia colonies at The Ledges here. Mrs. Chauncey L. Waddell and her son of New York, who joined her parents, Chief Justice and Mrs.

Trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad filed today a petition in the Federal court here seeking permission to abandon the Fall River Line and the New Haven Line of the New England Steamship Company, a railroad subsidiary, and to sell nine steamboats.
Archbishop Alfred George Edwards, first primate of the Church of Wales, died at St. Asaph, North Wales, tonight at the age of 88.

Nearly 19,000 applications have been received by the New York City Housing Authority for apartments in the Williamsburg Housing Project which the PWA is constructing at a cost of $13,500,000, it was learned yesterday.

I talked today with Harold E. Dahl, a tall, sinewy, fair American aviator whose plane was shot down on the Madrid front July 12. He had flown about four months as a volunteer for the Valencia government. The warden of Salamanca's provincial prison left us alone for two hours in his office.

Antoine Watteau's drawing of a woman's head brought a record price of [Pound]5,800 at Sothebys today. The work, which is part of a famous French collection formed by the late Comte Greffulhe, was the most expensive item in the sale, which realized a total of [Pound]41,000.

The first half-year reports of several of the large companies are expected to be issued soon. The earnings report of the Chrysler Corporation, as well as a dividend declaration, is scheduled for announceI ment at the close of the market today.

The Phillies punctured Clyde Shoun's tight pitching in the eighth inning today with a seven-run barrage that carried Chicago to defeat, 7 to 4, and dashed the Cubs' hopes of strengthening their National League lead.

Urging a close study of the present social order, Cardinal Villeneuve told FrenchCanadian delegates to La Semaine Sociale that "liberty of the press in modern society "grants newspaper men the opportunity to poison as well as falsify public opinion without any hindrance."

Louis Bromfield, American novelist, who has been abroad for two and a half years, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa to complete his new book, "The Rains Came," which he said will be published by Harper Brothers in October.

Miss Mary Daingerfield, heiress to a $2,000,000 estate, who fled from the jurisdiction of Virginia last April soon before being adjudged insane. was allowed $825 a month for living expenses by Judge William P. Wools in Corporation Court here.

Movements in the livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 10,000 head, including 2,500 directs; mostly 10-15 cents higher than yesterday's average. Top, $12.90; bulk good and choice 180-260 pounds, $12.50-.85; 150170 pounds, S12.35-.75; 270-340 pounds,

King Pharamond, a promising 2-year-old from the barn of Ral Parr, made good the hard way for the favorite players in the Royal Blue Purse at Delaware Park today. "Hours the best," as the horsemen say, the speedy son of Pharamond II overcame obstacles to score by a length and a half.

General Francisco Franco's economic policy and supplies are contrasted with Valencia's to the latter's disadvantage in a leading article in the Frankfurter Zeitung. While General Franco has succeeded in maintaining the value of his peseta, says a correspondent of the newspaper writing from Salamanca, Valencia is feverishly issuing inflated paper pesetas.

The Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company declared yesterday out of surplus income for the six months ended June 30, an installment of 13/4 per cent on its 5 per cent adjustment income bonds, payable on Oct. 1. A similar amount was paid on April 1, last.

Both consumers and legitimate business dealers are being victimized by false and unethical advertising, particularly in the smaller communities of the State, Laurence J. Gaurnier, City Sealer of Ithaca, yesterday told the closing session of the thirty-first annual convention of the New York State Association of Sealers of Weights and Measures at the Hotel Commodore.

American Business Shares, Inc.Six months to June 30: Total assets on June 30, $7,532,414, ineluding investments at market values, against $7,715,143 on Dec. 31. During the period cash dividends of $115,510 were received and profits of $236,168 were taken on investments. Distributions to stockholders were $318,406.

IT begins to appear that what our victorious Ryder Cup pro golfers should have had when they arrived back here was a stunning reception at least, stunning enough to leave them speechless. They played well at Southport but when they tripped off the boat here they pitched right into a trap.

The one-eyed horse, Pass 'Em By, who had won four in a row at Agawam Park, is dead as the result of an accident in the featured event at Empire City yesterday and Sammy Renick, one of the bestknown riders in the East, is temporarily on the ground because of bruises suffered when Pass 'Em By ran up on the heels of another horse, stumbled, and threw the jockey headlong.
Dominated by Mrs. Harry Frank Jr's splendid brown gelding Clifton's Beau, the second annual Jersey Shore horse show opened today at William Buchsbaum's spacious Boxwood Farm.

President Roosevelt conferred with Edward J. Flynn of the New York City World's Fair and sent to the Senate the nomination of James L. Houghteling to be Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization.

Dr. James Ramsay Hunt, Internationally known organic neurologist and Professor of Neurology at the Columbia University School of Medicine, died today at Mount Holly Farm, his home here, after a long illness. He was 63 years old.
Mayor La Guardia pledged his aid yesterday for the 550 internes in city hospitals who are seeking annual salaries of $1,000 each in place of their present compensation of $15 a month.
Two Southerners, Billy Gillespie of Atlanta and Billy McGehee of New Orleans, will meet tomorrow for the national junior interscholastic tennis championship in a match at the Merion Cricket Club.

Miss A. May Howard of Los Angeles entertained with a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Joan Pattinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. Graham Pattinson of Greenwich, Conn., and Oscar Thom Lawler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Lawler of Los

President Roosevelt declared tonight that it is not within the province of reactionaries to put obstacles in the way of orderly development. He made the statement in a letter congratulating the National Broadcasting Company upon the opening of new studios in Washington.

Miss Mary Virginia Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. D. Thompson, was married to Thomas Williams Graves, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Williams Graves of Wilson, N. C., tonight at the home of the bride's parents here.

All bathing beaches in the metropolitan area for which permits have been issued by the Health Department are safe for bathing, Health Commissioner John L. Rice said yesterday. Departmental bacteriological and epidemiological tests have shown this to be true, he explained.
The Treasury's fund of "sterilized" gold decreased between Monday and Tuesday for the first time since the sterilization fund was established on Dec. 21.

The president of a Committee for Industrial Organization union announced today that a contract he had signed with a Boston manufacturer contained a clause which he said was 'designed to permit the discharge of any employee indulging in "antiAmerican activities."

Rebuffed in continued attempts to win reappointment as teacher at Saugus High School, Miss Isabelle Hallin began a $10,000 suit today against Mrs. Charles B. McDuffee, opponent of the teacher's reinstatement and wife of a minister.

Marquis Guglielmo Marconi left his entire fortune, the total of which is not yet known, but is believed to amount to about $25,000,000, to his widow and his four children, three of whom were born of his first marriage and one of his second.

For the second week in succession commodities moved last week in a narrow range. Price declines in most of the grains and in cotton, beef and lamb caused a slight decline in The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices.

Leonard H. Anthony, for the last fifteen years Superintendent of Public Buildings here, died today at Block Island, where he was endeavoring to regain strength after an illness that afflicted him sixteen months ago. His age was 66.

The executive committee of the Brooklyn Democratic organization yesterday afternoon unanimously endorsed the action of four of the five county leaders in designating Grover A. Whalen for Mayor, Max J. Schneider for Council President, and Frank J. Taylor for Controller. The selection of a Democratio designee for Borough President was postponed until next week. The meeting was held in the Jefferson Building.
The grand encampment of Knights Templar adopted a resolution denouncing communism at the triennial national conclave today and elected Mark Norris of Grand Rapids, Mich., Most Eminent Grand Master.

Broad Hollow and the Cyclones maintained unbroken records to stay at the top of the standing in the two divisions of the Hempstead Cups polo tournament at Meadow Brook Club today. Each added its second victory of the league competition to the lists, the Cyclones holding the lead in the Red Brook League and Broad Hollow continuing to pace the Blue Meadow League.
Dusty Hanover, a bay colt, kicked his dust into the eyes of four of the nation's best 3-yearold pacers to win the $2,967 National Stake in a Grand Circuit brush today.

Two mortgages held by the Metropolitan Savings Bank from the Lougen Realty Corp, Louis Gennis, president, have been consolidated as a single lien for $32,000 on 335-37 E 108th St, and extended to July 1, 1942, 4 1/2 per cent. The Central Savings Bank extended to July 19, 1947. a consolidated mortgage for $26,000 on 405 E 69th St, 405 E 69th St, Inc., Abraham J. Bebarfald, president, owner.

Sports relations between France and Belgium became strained today as the entire Belgian team resigned from the bicycle race known as the Tour of France, in which one of its men, Sylvere Maes, held the lead.

Consional leaders are discussing an early adjournment of the session, regardless of the state of administration legislation. There appeared tonight to be strong sentiment; however, for attempting to enact at least the major items of President Roosevelt's legislative program if these could be pushed through without undue controversy.

A duty of 5 shillings has been placed upon all pigs imported into the Irish Free State, the American Consul at Dublin has reported to the Commerce Department. The reason is that there has been a noticeable decrease in pig production in the Free State, and therefore curers have had to import porkers from Northern Ireland.
The fighting on the Sierra front west of Madrid has reached one of those temporary deadlocks which in minor positions are attacked and counterattacked but the general situation remains the same.
Mayor LA GUARDIA includes in his prospectus of good works for the next four years the replacement of the

Shareholders, bondholders and unsecured creditors of the Follansbee Brothers Company are being notified today of the details of the reorganization plan approved on Tuesday by the United States District Court of the Western District of Pennsylvania, under which the company will be reconstituted as the Follansbee Steel Corporation.

A miscarriage of justice which meant tragedy to a once well-to-do farmer is revealed in the decision of the State Court of Appeals that Lloyd Lewis of Victor is innocent of arson, for which he served three and one-half years in Auburn prison.

Major David S. Barry, U. S. M. C., and Mrs. Barry are expected to arrive at the Plaza today from Shields, Pa., where they have been the guests of Mrs. James B. Oliver. Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Robert Jr. of Washington are at the Ritz-Carlton.

Fighting back desperately after being on the verge of defeat by the surprising Norbert Burgess of Chicago, Gilbert Hunt, the Washington, D. C., sharpshooter, came through to victory by 5-7, 6-4, 9-7, today and entered the semifinals of the forty-fifth annual Longwood Bowl tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club.

Pennsylvania will be without a Chief Executive during the next six weeks. Governor Earle will depart next week for a vacation in Austria, France and Ireland. Under the State Constitution no official is authorized to act for him during absence from the State and he has arranged to be advised through department officials of any problem requiring his attention.

The following is the detailed vote of the Tammany Executive Committee on the resolution designating Senator Royal S. Copeland for Mayor, Frank J. Prial for Controller and Samuel Levy for President of the Council:

Three new types of German Army planes will compete in the international aviation meeting opening in Zurich tomorrow with entries from eleven States. Majorgen Ernst Udet, chief of the technical section of the German air forces and Germany's best known stunt flier, will try for a speed record with a low-winged pursuit plane-the BF. 109, designed by Messerschmidt of the Bavarian Airplane Works at Augsburg.

The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed trustee, registrar paying agent, conversion agent and sinking-fund' agent for an issue of $3,500,000 principal amount tenyear 4 per cent convertible sinkingfund debentures dated June 15, 1937, due on June 15, 1947, issued under the indenture of the Liquid Carbonic Corporation.

Miss Ida Sledge of Memphis, organizer for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, returned here today to renew her efforts to organize employes in three Tupelo plants. She said she was "escorted" from town twice and "warned" not to return.

After a heavy blow on Wednesday that kept boats in port, offshore fishing improved along the New Jersey coast yesterday. Boatmen in the vicinity of Beach Haven have been paying more attention to bay fishing, for although the weakfish are not running to any great size, they have continued to be plentiful. Prospective bluefishermen, however. have had to mark time.

The Board of Superintendents adopted a resolution yesterday urging the Board of Education to amend the maternity leave by-law to permit teachers to remain away from duty for eighteen months instead of two years.
The first decision upholding the amended Agricultural Adjustment Act in the country was handed down today by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here.

Dr. Charles Henry Mills, director of the School of Music of the University of Wisconsin since 1914 and a former concert organist, pianist and operatic conductor, died at his home here today after a short illness. His age was 64.

Mainly as a result of the loss reported by this city, bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday declined 0.3 per cent from the corresponding week a year ago. The turnover for the twenty-two principal cities throughout the nation was $5,711,211,000, as compared with $5,731,232,000 last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. In a similar comparison a week ago there was a gain of 15.8 per cent.

A recommendation that the national debt be reduced by an average of $1,000,000,000 a year during the next ten years and the forecast that new taxes probably would be needed to achieve this goal of a balanced budget in 1938 was made yesterday by the Committee on Government Credit of the Twentieth Century Fund.
Though London's Charles B. Cochran says he went to California chiefly "to get sunshine and complete my education by seeing Hoilywood," theatrical bees are buzzing in the Cochran bonnet. In short,

The marriage of Miss Jeannette Adair Ricketts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Boyd Ricketts of Rockville Center, to William C. Walser 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. Walser of Pasadena, Calif., took place here tonight in the Cathedral of the Incarnation.

Connecticut Light and Power Company-Twelve months to June 30: Net income after all expenses and charges, $4,654,907, equal, after preferred charges, to $3.54 a common share, compared with a net of $4,581,451, or $3.29 a share, similarly to June 30, 1936. Gross revenues during the period aggregated $19,287,139, against $18,206,654.

Right in the middle of July the Federal Theatre has set down a new show, "Swing It," which last evening bounded its way over the stage of the Adelphi. A fortnight ago Broadway was saying no more Project in the Times Square area, and there it was, already engaged in the hazards of musical comedy and doing all right, too.
M. E. Anderson, a Fairbanks bus driver, won $25 by guessing the exact minute at which the steamship Alaska's whistle would blow as it approached Cordova yesterday.

With the vote in the Senate yesterday a great threat to the independence of the judiciary has now been set aside. It is on this threat that public attention has been focused, naturally and properly, throughout the whole course of the controversy over the Court Bill.

A portrait of Thomas Jefferson done by his friend Thaddeus Kosciuszko, the Polish patriot who fought for the Colonies in the Revolution, was shown to President Roosevelt today by Count Jerzy Potocki, the Polish Ambassador.

Trading was fair to slow. The lamb slaughter continued light and the market advanced another dollar. Other classes of traefa meats were mostly unchanged, excepting a small supply of calf sold strong above the market earlier this week. Kosher business was confined largely to lamb at higher prices. as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry E. Miller of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Miller, to L. Kingsley Smith, son of Mrs. Lewis J. Smith of Hempstead, L. I., and the late Supreme Court Justice Smith.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Walter Gordon Merritt, answering the arguments of Louis Waldman, contends that under our Anti-Injunction Law labor unions are given immunities not enjoyed by the rest of the community, for the reason that they are "not responsible for the unlawful acts of

The wheat market resumed its downward movement today after a brief showing of strength in the early trading and prices dropped as much as 5 cents a bushel in North American markets before short covering checked the recession.
The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company will put into effect on Aug. 1 a retirement and insurance plan for its 2,500 employes, it was announced yesterday by William S. Gray Jr., president.

Fifteen thousand men, women and children carrying placards marched through the city today to the Ministry of Justice to ask for Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares to intercede in freeing Pedro Ernesto Baptista, former Mayor of Rio de Janeiro, who was arrested following the November, 1935, Leftist revolt.

Word was received here of the death tonight of Dr. J. A. W. Haas, president emeritus of Muhlenberg College, at Lake Minnewaska, N. Y., where he and Mrs. Haas were spending the Summer. He was 74 years old.

Without even bothering to read "Robber Barons," the "Book of Daniel Drew" or the yellowed clippings in THE TIMES files, we would not have hesitated to impugn in advance the accuracy of the Jim Fisk biography which RKO-Radio presented at the Music Hall yesterday under the somewhat flattering designation, "The Toast of New York."

Ceferino Garcia earned the right to fight for the world's welterweight championship by knocking out Bobby Pacho, durable Los Angeles Mexican, in the feature bout scheduled for fifteen rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.
Russ Hoogerhyde, Clarenton Hills, Ill., today won the men's national title at the fifty-seventh annual target meet of the National Archery Association with a total score of 2,865 points.

About fifty mothers and their eighty-odd children swarmed into the Tombs Court yesterday for the arraignment of Rabbi Jacob Bienenfeld, 49 years old, head of the Downtown Center at 99 Nassau Street, accused of the theft of $25 about two weeks ago from the uncle of a little girl the rabbi had promised to send to a Summer camp at New Paltz, N. Y.

Young Miss Betsy McLeod of the Buffalo Country Club marched into the semi-finals of the annual championship of the Women's Golf Association of Western New York today by defeating the medalist, 19year-old Miss Jean Ramaker of the Monroe Golf Club, in a nineteenhole battle at Oak Hill Country Club.

Walter L. Pate, a little apprehensive lest his tennis timber-especially Don Budge-get too fine an edge, sent his lads through putting practice tonight on a neighboring golf green. But Budge, invincible even there, sank putts from all corners to garner everybody's pennies.

The City Hall Park Association, Inc., a group of citizens and property owners interested in the City Hall area, was formed yesterday at a meeting at the Bankers Club, according to an announcement by Albert C. Vinal, former general traffic supervisor of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Resumption of partial interest fe payments to foreign holders of sixty-five issues of Hungarian municipal, ecclesiastical and private longterm bonds will be announced today in a communique of the Cash Office of Foreign Credits, Budapest.
Half-dressed men and women ran from homes and hotels, frame buildings swayed and merchandise tumbled to floors as a strong earthquake struck Fairbanks and the Alaskan interior today.

A troop train of soldiers of the Chinese Thirty-seventh Division left Peiping last night for the south. The soldiers were replaced by 600 men from the 132d Division. The beginning of the withdrawal of the anti-Japanese Thirty-seventn Division from Peiping was greeted with relief by the Japanese authorities, who said the danger of hostillties in and around the city was rapidly subsiding.

Jess Sweetser of New York, former British amateur golf champion, shot a 74 today, two over par, and tied young Bobby Knowles Jr. of Brookline, Mass., and Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N. Y., for medal honors in the Newport Country Club's eleventh invitation golf tournament.

Less whisky was produced in the United States during the fiscal year ended June 30 than in the previous fiscal year, but considerably more was withdrawn for consumption, the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Bureau of Internal Revenue reported today.
One million Western New York residents looked forward tonight to a shortage in basic foods as twin strikes gripped the Buffalo wholesale butter and egg and meat packing industries.

The plan proposed by Robert R. Young, head of the syndicate now in control of the Alleghany Corporation, the top holding company of the vast network of railroads and other enterprises built up by the Van Sweringen Brothers,
Two 11-year-old Brooklyn boys, both ice men's sons, were honored at Brooklyn police headquarters yesterday for their honesty in returning a pocketbook, containing $164.80, they had found.

Francis William Robert Boreel of Los Angeles, Calif., was believed today to have fallen heir to an ancient English baronetcy. Debrett's Peerage, an authentic listing of the British nobility, indicates that Mr. Boreel is heir to the title of the late Sir Jacob Boreel, who died July 16 at Overeen, The Netherlands.

Mrs. Rebecca Fox Riggs of 840 Park Avenue died at her home last night after an illness of several months. She was 86 years old. Funeral services will be held at 2 P. M. tomorrow at Grace Church, Broadway and Tenth Street.

Joseph (Jo-Jo) Aveta, said by Federal investigators to have smuggled $250,000 worth of narcotics into this country during the last seven years of his operations as a "big shot racketeer," received a prison sentence of sixteen years yesterday after a jury had found him and two confederates guilty of shipping forty pounds of gum opium to the United States last April aboard the President Harding.

The Interstate Commerce Commission granted today the petition of Vincent Dailey, New York State Democratic committeeman, for a rehearing on its refusal to ratify his appointment as one of the two trustees of the New York, Ontario Western, now in process of reorganization.

State Senator Clifford R. Powell of Burlington, Governor Hoffman's choice for the Republican nomination for Governor, engaged today in a personal clash with supporters of his opponent, State Senator Lester H. Clee of Essex, when the right to take part in an outing attended by 2,500 Passaic County Republicans in honor of Senator Clee was refused to Mr. Powell.

The Wholesale Dry Goods Workers Union, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, was fined $250 yesterday for violating a 1936 injunction. Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, who imposed the fine, indicated that if the fine were not paid he would jail officials of the union.

Included in the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday was a lease for fourteen rooms in 31 East Seventy-second Street taken by W. Breckenridge Stringer. Bryne Bowman, Inc., negotiated the transaction. Other leases resorted:
A decline of $90,000,000 in the excess reserves of member banks to $870,000,000 was reported for the week ended on Wednesday in the statement of the Federal Reserve System, issued yesterday.

Despite Japanese threats that a "purge" of Chinese universities and middle schools in North China would be demanded under the Lukouchiao agreement, the leaders of various educational institutions here are holding their ground, waiting for the storm to break and following Nanking's instructions to "maintain" calm and not remove southward.

The Bridgeport Paper Company, Brooklyn, N. Y., and Bridgeport, Conn., has taken over the plant at Ashland, N. H., left vacant by the Continental Bag and Paper Company, Laurence M. Meyer, industrial agent of the State Planning and Development Commission, announced today.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Gaston Paul Cambreleng of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Madeleine M. Cambreleng, to Alexander C. Thomson, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Thomson, also of Orange.

The touring New Zealand cricketers recorded their second victory over Scotland today, winning a two-day match by an innings and 52 runs. Declaring their innings at 259 runs for eight wickets, the Antipodeans dismissed their opponents for 53 and 154.

The list of the Hamburg American liner Hamburg, due today from the Channel ports, includes Mr. and Mrs. Oscar A. Geier, Dr. Anton Wagner, Dr. Hans Meinrath, Mr. and Mrs. Walther Sauer, Miss Dorothy A. Rutherford, Dr. Karl Brauns, D. M. Martin, Mrs. H. B. Bowl, Mrs. A. S. Slater, George Nixon, T. C. Gary, Dr. W. R. Brown, Mrs. W. M. Taylor, Mr. and Mrs. T. H. Chilton and C. H. Schurr.

Rogers Hornsby was dismissed as manager of the Browns on the strength of a clause in his contract which, President Don Barnes said, gave them the right to cancel the contract for "certain things Hornsby did off the fieldd."

Banana planters have petitioned President Federico Paez and the Ministry of Public Welfare to assist them to obtain higher prices for the fruit. They contend the price of 1 sucre 50 centavos per bunch was set when the exchange was 6 sucres to the dollar.

Miss Jadwiga Jedrzejowska, Polish tennis champion and conqueror of Miss Alice Marble at Wimbledon, arrived last night on the United States liner Washington for her first appearance on American courts. She said she would compete in the Eastern invitation tournaments and go to Los Angeles and San Francisco after the women's national singles matches at Forest Hills in September.

The Federal program of cutting farm production was defended today "as an emergency measure" by Dr. Percy W. Bidwell, chairman of the Department of Economics at the University of Buffalo, in an address before the Institute for Social Progress at Wellesley.
Instead of being held for Sunday duty to lure large crowds through the box office, fireball tosser Bob Feller was ticketed tonight as a starting pitcher every fifth day.
Professor Ernst Karl Johann Heinrich Voss, for thirty-five years a member of the German Department of the University of Wisconsin, died of a heart attack here today. He was 76 years old.
Supreme Court Justice William D. Dowling made a decision of State-wide interest today, the first to uphold the assessment of penalties under the Cooperative Corporation Law.

A constitutional amendment to carry into effect President Roosevelt's court plan, regardless of legislative action, was urged by Secretary Ickes today. He said that he would like to see both legislation and an amendment, and expressed the hope that some Congressional steps would be taken at the present session.

James L. Houghteling, investment broker, was nominated today by President Roosevelt as Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization in the Department of Labor, to succeed Daniel W. MacCormick, who died seven months ago.

Sol A. Rosenblatt was inducted yesterday as impartial chairman for the coat and suit industry under the terms of the new collective agreement at a ceremony in the Hotel Governor Clinton. Mr. Rosenblatt, former NRA administrator, has been impartial chairman of the

Mrs. Charles Edward Merrill gave a dinner and bridge tonight at the Orchard for Mrs. Charles Tracy Barney, Mrs. Goodhue Livingston, Mrs. Henry F. du Pont, Mrs. Arthur B. Claflin, Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson, Mrs. George F. Vietor, Mrs. Albert F. Jaeckel, Mrs. Kimball G. Colby,

City officials expressed surprise tonight at the nature of the report made by the La Follette Civil Liberties Committee to the United States Senate, condemning the Chicago police for their methods of suppressing the Memorial Day riot.

After hearing a committee of the Workers Alliance, which called on him at the Summer City Hall at College Point yesterday, Mayor La Guardia agreed to present to the United States Conference of Mayors, of which he is chairman, the question of WPA discharges and protection of WPA employes dropped from the payroll without prospect of employment in private industry.

Further advances in the cost of farm products, and a sharp rise in hides and leather products, sent the general level of wholesale prices up again in the week ended on July 17, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics in a statement today.

New York Stock Exchange membership of the late Charles P. Noyes has been transferred to Samuel T. Hubbard Jr. of Hubbard Brothers Co.; that of Juan M. Ceballos has been transferred to Garrow T. Geer Jr. of Ceballos Geer.

Arrest of a sun-bronzed youth, working on a Wyoming ranch, as a suspect in the June bombings at the Republic Steel Company's Warren (Ohio) plant was disclosed today as two officers started back to Ohio with him.

A verdict of accidental shooting was reported today by County Physician C. A. Brokaw after an investigation of the death last night of Stuart C. Adams, 54 years old, financial adviser to the New York brokerage firm of Jackson Curtis, who was killed by a .22-caliber rifle bullet in the basement of his home at 107 Summit Avenue.

Reports of an unusually high condition of the growing crop exerted a depressing effect on prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. A combination of liquidation, professional selling and hedging operations carried December below 11 1/2 cents a pound at one time, but a 10-point rally in the last hour left the list unchanged to 4 points lower.

In trouble during most of the early running, Houghton P. Metcalf's 2-year-old Roman Lady took the longest way around to come from behind and win the Nantasket Handicap, today's five-and-one-half-furlong feature at Suffolk Downs, by a length over R. W. Collins's Don Lopez to pay $3.80.
After holding unchanged for three weeks, business in the Pittsburgh district, showed a pronounced gain last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

Miss Mercedes Madden of Jamaica Plain, Mass., won the women's singles final in the twentyfifth annual Lake Placid Club tennis tournament today. She scored over Miss Marietta Arquindeau of Glenbrook, Conn., 6-4, 6-4.

The Senate late today voted unanimously for repeal of the so-called married persons clause of the Economy Act. The House already has passed the repeal bill and it now goes to President Roosevelt for his signature.

Mrs. Mary Eggleston Cushman Darte, wife of Major George L. Darte of this city, died Tuesday night at their summer residence in Urbanna. Mrs. Darte, a daughter of John Paul Cushman of Albany, had lived for years in New York City.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today figures on oddlot trading on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on July 17, which showed that again customers' orders to buy exceeded such orders to sell. For the week securities bought in odd lots had a market value of $38,419,975, or $5,297,501 more than those sold, and 118,993 shares were bought on balance.

The engagement of Miss Eleanor Rose Berresford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur William Berresford of 50 Central Park West, to John McClusky Blayney Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John McClusky Blayney of St. Louis, has been announced by her parents.

The long debated question as to whether the word "crepe" should be used in reference to a fabric other than one made from silk appeared destined for official solution yesterday when Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., announced it would not accept a stipulation offered by

Marked strength in local traction issues yesterday was the feature of an otherwise exceedingly dull trading session in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. Aside New York Stock Exchange. Aside from the issuance of another call for tenders of the Interborough 5s, traders could find no specific explanation for the brisk advance of all the I. R. T.'s as well as obligations of Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit and Manhattan Railway.
