For the first time in twenty years New York City shows a loss in its school population, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, disclosed yesterday in submitting the statistical section of his thirty-eighth annual report to the Board of Education.

Still teaming up in exceptionally fine style, Mrs. Henry Dietrich of Gedney Farm and Mrs. Emmet Whalen of Westchester Hills played sub-par golf to win the Scotch foursome championship of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association today at Bonnie Briar.

Tommy Farr set up training headquarters at Long Branch, N. J., yesterday, for his fight with the world's heavyweight champion, Joe Louis, whom he will meet at the Yankee Stadium on Aug. 26. The Welshman will start working hard tomorrow, under the direction of his trainer, Tom Evans.
Joseph J. Harding, business man of Emporia, Va., died yesterday at a hospital here. He was 49 years old.
President Rossevelt today vetoed a joint resolution reopening the claim of William K. Richardson based on alleged infringement of an artillery patent by the Federal Government.

All who deplored and opposed the Royal Commission's scheme for the partition of Palestine were immensely heartened today by the events in the House of Commons last night when the government suddenly left the whole problem to be decided later after "adequate inquiry."
In the first German newspaper comment on the defeat of the court reorganization plan in the Senate, the Lokal Anzeiger places itself wholly on the side of President Roosevelt.

A cocktail jacket knitted of black rayon yarn and gold thread was one of the unusual items displayed by Bernhard Ulmann Company, Inc., manufacturers of knitting yarns and art needlework supplies, at a fashion show held at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel yesterday under the

Laurance S. Rockefeller, in a private transaction, is taking over the New York Stock Exchange memberships of his late grandfather, John D. Rockefeller. The Ex- full change's committee on admissions will ballot on the deal on Aug. 5.
Miss Rebecca C. Longstreth, a member of the board of managers of Swarthmore College for fifty years, died last night at her home in Haverford, Pa.
Tired but happy, 525 Negro mothers and children of Columbus Hill aid Harlem yesterday evening returned to their tenement homes thoroughly convinced that this was a swell world after all.

Henry H. Rogers received an uncontested divorce today from the former Virginia Lincoln of Cleveland. Mr. Rogers said his wife deserted him four years ago at Berne, Switzerland. Mrs. Rogers wrote here denying the allegation, but saying she would not testify.

A group of holders of securities of the New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway Company, and having through its control an interest in the International Great Northern Railroad, in a petition to the Interstate Commerce Commission asked today for

Four contests, two involving unbeaten quartets, will comprise Sunday's program of the Eastern Polo League. Monmouth County Country Club will go after its sixth straight circuit verdict when it encounters the Governors Island Blues at. Morris Memorial Field, while the Evergreen Farms four, unbeaten in four starts, will play host to the Governors Island Yellows at Eatontown, N. J.

Four blook fronts, comprising forty lots on the east and west sides of Parsons Boulevard, including the four corners of Twenty-ninth Avenue, the four co?srs of Twentyninth Road, and the two corners of Twenty-eighth Avenue, Flushing,

William O. Lucas, a former WPA employee, who resigned to take a position as publicity agent with the National Civic Federation, said yesterday that suggestions appearing in the press that he was not an American citizen were erroneous.

The fourth performance of the Wagner festival series at Lewisohn Stadium last night consisted of excerpts from "Goetterdaemmerung. This concluding offering in the outdoor "Ring" cycle attracted the largest audience of the tetralogy, the number of persons present being estimated at 7,000.

Droves of Japanese beetles, so voracious they will tackle anything except steel and concrete, are invading the metropolitan area. The beetle armies, which often travel four miles a day, are doing the most damage in Long Island Northern New Jersey and Southern Westchester County.
Miss Sarah Parker Koppelman has selected Oct. 9 as the date for her marriage to William Bradford Banks, son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Banks of this city.
The Tigers took the series from Boston, two games to one, with a 19-hit assault on four pitchers today for a 17-to-4 victory in the final game.
Disorders again broke out this evening in Belgrade in the neighborhood of St. Sava Church.

The creation of a fusion steering committee, known as the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee, headed by Samuel Seabury and Charles C. Burlingham, to back the candidacy of Mayor La Guardia, was announced yesterday following a conference of Fusion leaders at the City Club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street.

Evidence of the growing interest in the black pepper market on the New York Produce Exchange is seen in the increasing number of important Wall Street houses that have joined the clearing association in the black pepper futures.

The activities of two objecting minority groups have been responsible for the delay in reorganization proceedings in the Standard Gas and Electric Company, according to a letter being sent today to note and debenture holders by the McRoberts protective committee.
Business was virtually suspended here today as hundreds of Newport residents and tourists watched Charles B. Brown of Memphis, deep-sea diver, begin a hunt for White River's mysterious "monster."

King Carol of Rumania, visiting London incognito, called on Queen Mary today at her residence, Marlborough House. Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden made what was termed a "courtesy call" on Carol earlier. Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain saw him last night.

Home runs were even between the Pirates and the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday, but that was the only department of the game in which Burleigh Grimes's faltering heroes matched the aroused Buccaneers, who romped away with a 10-1 victory in the final of the series.

The Madison Square branch of the Public National Bank and Trust Company of New York, which has been at its present location for seventeen years, will move into new quarters at 1,107 Broadway, on the northwest corner of Broadway and Twentyfourth Street, about Feb. 1, 1938.

After falling further to the cheapest levels in eleven years, the French franc yesterday found itself supported by demand from private sources for the first time in nine days. The franc dropped to 3.71 3/8 cents, but it rallied as high as 3.74 1/4 cents and closed at 3.74 cents, up 2 1/3 points net.

Stocks closed firm and slightly higher after 1 to 3 1/2 point gains in leading industrial issues; turnover, 955,780 shares. Local traction issues strong, United States Government and other bonds steady; transactions, $6,686,000.
A joint legislative committee to revise and recodify New York's insurance laws will receive $7,500 although Governor Lehman vetoed an appropriation for the work.

Representative O'Connell of Montana introduced a. bill in the House today aiming at interstate regulation of goods produced under conditions exposing employes to the hazard of silicosis and related dust diseases.

Police tonight definitely eliminated a friend of Dr. George E. Webster from suspicion in his murder and concentrated on a search for a man seen boarding a street car near the doctor's home soon after his murder der on July 16.

Ground was broken yesterday morning on the site of Flushing Meadow Park for the first building of the 1939 World's Fair to be used for other than commercial or administrative purposes. Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, and Deputy Controller Milton Solomon dedicated an area of 90,000 square feet as a Temple of Peace under sponsorship of war veterans throughout the nation.

The leaders in the balloting to name a team of 1936 college senior football stars to meet the Green Bay Packers in the annual all-star game at Soldier Field Sept. 1 were announced today. They are as follows:

Mrs. Mary Jacobson, wife of Abraham Jacobson, an officer in the National Guard for twenty-two years and mill representative for upholstery concerns throughout the United States, died of a heart attack yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital at the age of 67. Mrs. Jacobson lived in the Hotel Chelsea.

Arrangements for the immediate payment of $7,742,687, representing a sixmonth installment of delinquent interest on bonds of the Missouri Pacific Railroad and two of its subsidiaries, were being made today by Guy A. Thompson, trustee.

The candidates of the Citizens Military Training Camp woke this morning at 5:15 to the marching tunes of their crack fifty-piece regimental band. Almost simultaneously with the blowing of reveille by the camp bugler the band, led by its drum major, Sergeant Robert E. Whelan, marched in formation back and forth on each company street.

Joseph Hamberger, better known to dozens of ball players and intimates as Babe, yesterday was appointed road secretary of the Brooklyn Baseball Club and will take over his new duties with the departure of the club on its third Western trip Sunday night.

Frederick K. Wing, chief engineer of thQ Niagara Frontier Planning Board, told the House Rivers and Harbors Committee today that legislation to establish regional power and conservation agencies could result in creation of a new form of government.

Fernando de los Rios, Spanish Ambassador to the United States, returned yesterday on the French liner Champlain from the conference in Spain, which was attended, he said, by Spanish Ambassadors from all over the world.

For a Prime Minister whom the soothsayers depicted as ruling with an iron hand, NEVILLE CHAMBERLAIN has shown himself remarkably pliant in the face of adverse circumstances. He bowed before the storm of opposition that greeted one of his pet taxation bills.
Among the deals in Brooklyn reported yesterday were three sales negotiated by Samuel Hurwitz, broker. All purchasers are investing clients. Details of the transactions are as follows:

American women can get all the style and quality they require in American-made hats, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday as representatives of 800 millinery manufacturers signed a fair trade practice agreement in his office at the Summer City Hall in Queens.

The Senate overrode President Roosevelt's veto of the bill to continue in effect existing reductions in interest on mortgage loans made by the Federal Land Banks. The vote was 71 to 19, eleven more than the required two-thirds majority.
It was Eddie Brannick's birthday, and perhaps that may explain why the Giants, dramatists at heart, withheld their choicest number until the very last at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
Foreign Office experts vindicated their reputation for getting around the most difficult problems today by drafting an ingenious solution of the latest deadlock of the Non-Intervention Committee.

The British Government's benefit payments to oats and barley farmers will not be called a "subsidy," because, in the words of Lord Hastings, their ardent champion in the House of Lords today, "they dislike being held up to the country as mendicants in receipt of charity."

Reduction of more than $4,000,000 in Bank of Canada deposits on July 21 from July 14 was shown in the weekly statement issued today. Deposits were $194,515,205, compared with $198,699,772. This was principally due to a cut in deposits of chartered banks from $184,391,395 to $131,324,863.
Mrs. W. Barton Eddison of Ardsleyon-the-Hudson was hostess at a large tea this afternoon for fifty guests from Northeast Harbor, Seal Harbor and Bar Harbor at her Summer home, Cove End in Northeast.

Although several advertising agencies have submitted copy for a proposed advertising campaign by toilet goods interests in defense of fair trade laws, no action is expected to be taken until early in September, according to comment here yesterday.

The liners Siboney and Borinquen sailed last evening for Caribbean ports four to five hours late after a strike of their crews in sympathy with demands of the American Radio Telegraphists Association had held them at their piers since early afternoon.

Five acres of land owned by Yale University, the former John W Sterling estate on John Street, Round Hill, Greenwich, together with a Colonial house, barn, stable and men's living quarters in the rear, has been sold to H. R.

The following team of amateur boxers was named yesterday by the Amateur Athletic Union to represent the United States in the PanAmerican Exposition boxing tournament at Dallas, Aug. 13, 14 and 15, in which the American boys will meet lads from South and Central America:

In addition to the Writers Project guide books now being published, a new series of guide books is planned. Under the general title "Longmans New American Guide Books," and the editorship of Blackburn Sims, the projected series is announced today by Longmans, Green, publishers. There will be five volumes. The first will appear early next Spring.

The Treasury will offer two $50,000,000 note series on Monday, one issue being 142-day bills maturing on Dec. 17 and the other a 273-day issue maturning on April 27, the Acting Secretary of the Treasury announced this afternoon.

Price movements of commodity futures here were mixed yesterday in moderate activity. Rubber, hide, cottonseed oil and sugar futures gained, while cocoa, copper, tin, lead, coffee and cottonseed oil contracts declined.

The constitutional convention of the National Maritime Union, representing about 35,000 seamen along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts, voted yesterday afternoon to recommend that the union be affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Space has been leased by the Frank G. Shattuck Company for a new Schrafft's store at 566 Main Street, running through to Center Street, New Rochelle, Westchester. The site is at present occupied by the Ferguson Department Store Building, which has stood for near-ly half a century.

A move to obtain the voluntary cooperation of chartered banks in steps designed to establish a social credit system is being made "as a preliminary measure in preparation for the session of the Legislature that is to take place on Aug. 3," it was announced here by Premier Aberhart.

For confidence in the sincerity of his effort to put in order the French financial tangle. Georges Bonnet, Finance Minister, made a personal appeal today through American and British newspaper men when he received them at the Ministry of Finance. He said he did not insist that his efforts would succeed, for success demanded factors outside the control of his ministry.

The Ford Motor Company offered evidence before a National Labor Relations Board hearing today aimed to support its assertion that auto union organizers were trespassing on Ford property during the May rioting, which started when they sought to distribute circulars at the gates of the Dearborn plant.
Announcement has been made by Lieutenant John Sperle, U. S. N., and Mrs. Sperle of Washington, D. C., of the marriage of their daughter, Miss Audrey Lea Sperle, to Carl A. Williams,

Alexander Pompez, a West Indian Negro who is regarded by Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets, as one of the key figures in the $100,000,000-a-year policy racket, lost yesterday the first round of-his fight to avoid extradition from Mexico City, where he was arrested at Mr. Dewey's request last March.

The Page-Madden Company of Brooklyn, manufacturer of porcelain for the textile trade, has awarded to Schweers Smith a contract for the erection of a factory building in Second Street, between Hampton and Hudson Streets, Mineola,

C. M. Chester, chairman of the board of the General Foods Corporation, announced that net earnings in the first six months of 1937 amounted to $6,868,923 after all charges and provisions for taxes. The earnings are equivalent to $1.31 a share and compare with $6,843,928, or $1.30 a share, in the corresponding half of last year.

Japanese military activity in the American defense sector of the diplomatic quarter here was protested today by Colonel Marston, Commandant of the United States Embassy guard, in a call upon the Japanese Commandant.

Pete Scalzo and Johnny Pena, West Side featherweights, fought to a slashing draw in the main event of eight rounds at the Fort Hamilton Arena last night in Brooklyn. A crowd of 6,000 was on edge throughout as the two battlers went at it with hammer and tongs. There were no knockdowns.

The wedding of Miss Estelle L. Rose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond S. Rose of Greenwich and New York, and Sherman Van Dien Stewart of Ridgewood, N. J., will take place at the Greenwich home of the prospective bride on July 31, at noon. The Rev. Dr.
Sonny Fraser, husky young defending champion, led the way into the semi-finals of the Atlantic Coast golf championship with two easy victories today.

The tale of the discovery of bars of gold worth $3,000,000 in the wilds of Panama took another sensational turn today when one of the supposed discoverers committed suicide. As a result there is doubt of such a find.

The report of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company for the first half of this year, released for publication today, shows a net income of $7,696,701 after charges and taxes, equal, after dividend requirements on the preferred stock, to 99 cents a share on the 6,343,468 common shares outstanding.

Contracts awarded for engineering construction during the week ended yesterday amounted to $30,695,000. According to The Engineering News-Record, this was the lowest weekly total recorded in 1937, and it is attributed to the few contracts made for large projects and a decrease in the total number of awards. Last year's total for the corresponding week was $50,992,000.
The Jersey City Giants lost their twenty-fifth one-run decision of the campaign tonight when they dropped a 6-5 verdict to the Toronto Maple Leafs in ten innings.

Four witnesses, an organizer and three members of the C. I. O., told the National Labor Relations Board today that about fifteen Massillon (Ohio) policemen, including men who had just been sworn in, opened gunfire without provocation on about 125 steel strikers in and about the C. I. O. headquarters on the night of July 11. Three men died from wounds.

A mass moving task will result In the transfer of 1,622 families from all parts of the city to the new Williamsburg Housing Project in Brooklyn, beginning about Sept. 1, was being planned yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority.

The State Health Department announced today that there were 5,354 marriages in New Jersey last month, an increase of nearly 15 per cent over June, 1936, and an all-time high for any month. The record heretofore had been 4,879 weddings in June, 1929.

State and Federal employment services found jobs for 103,954 persons in private industry in New York State in the first half of 1937, a record for any six months' period, the State Labor Department reported tonight.
Roscoe G. Norton, former postmaster of Otter Lake and for several years the operator of Otter Lake Hotel, died yesterday in a hospital here after an operation.

The weather, which has been unkind to so many functions in King George's short reign, smiled this afternoon on the garden party at Buckingham Palace that officially closed the London coronation season.

The Labor Anti-Injunction League of Essex County was formed here this afternoon by six A. F. of L. and six C. I. O. unions, with the object of financing appeals from labor injunctions now pending or issued in the future.

The Division of Protocol and Conferences of the State Department was divided today by Secretary Hull as a further step in his reorganization of the department, and George T. Summerlin, Minister to Panama, was appointed chief of a new Division of Protocol.

Miss Virginia Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Asbury Davis of Guilford, was married to E. Gillet Boyce, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Graham Boyce, this evening in the garden of her parents' home. Her uncle, the Rev. Kingman Handy, officiated.

The twenty-eight family apartment house with three stores at 205-7 Twenty-second Street, at the corner. of Broadway, West New York, N. J., has been sold by the Colonial Building-Loan Association, James Billington president, to Anna Budke.

The Treasury's procurement division asked today for bids on 1,720,750 yards of textiles for delivery on Aug. 25. The bids are to be opened on July 30. The specifications follow: 509-T-7-30, seersucker woven pattern 3-ounce, 28,500 yards; 510-T, colored sheeting 48x48, 93,800 yards: 511-T. pique 10x66.

The National Investors Corporation has advised stockholders that the offer permitting them since April 1 to subscribe to stock at asset value without payment of any premium or other costs will expire at the close of business on Aug. 16 in view of arrangements for public distribution of stock.

Hopes that the crisis in North China will end peacefully and speedily are now strong here. The withdrawal of the Chinese Thirty-seventh Division from its points of contact with Japanese troops is proceeding on a large scale, thus removing the main source of immediate danger in North China.
The surrender by the Senate leadership of President Roosevelt's plan for changing the Supreme Court at this session of Congress was made formal and complete at 2:55 o'clock this afternoon.

Robert Irwin, confessed triple slayer, was described as apparently sane by persons who associated with him during his eighty-three day stay in Cleveland, detectives who aided New York investigators said today.

A tentative slate of candidates for the new City Council to be elected under proportional representation was put forward last night at a meeting of the executive committee of the American Labor party. It follows:
Congress will give attention in the next few days to a project for the sale of land rights in Magallanes Province in order to get funds for the purchase of material for army and navy aviation.
Since 1933 the Bavarian churches have received 140,000,000 marks from the government of that State, according to an article appearing in the current issue of General Erich Ludendorff's magazine.

Taking advantage of the Securities and Exchange Commission's provision. that the names of subsidiaries need not be reported if disclosure is "deemed detrimental to the interest of security holders," Loew's, Inc., withheld the specification of fifty-three such units from its most recent report.

PAT HARRISON'S first Congress was the Sixty-second; ALBEN W. BARKLEY'S the Sixty-third. The Mississippian is an older soldier than the Kentuckian by only two years of service. Mr. HARRISON was transferred to the other body in 1919; Mr. BARKLEY in 1927.

Ernie Dusek, 228, Omaha, threw Abe Coleman, 205, Los Angeles, with a body slam and hold in 32:41 of the wind-up match of a wrestling show at the Queensboro Stadium last night, The Associated Press reported.
Isaia Aisenstadt, Russian revolutionary and one of the four founders of the Rus- F sian Jewish labor movement, died here today at the age of 71.

This town is decorated with flags and garlands in readiness for the Wagner festival opening tomorrow under the Fuehrer's patronage. Hitler, accompanied by a number of other high party officials, is expected to arrive here tomorrow afternoon to attend the opening ceremonies and the performance of "Parsifal."

The freighter Dorothy Luckenbach, loaded with a million and a half feet of lumber and 500 tons of general cargo, was tied up at the municipal wharf here today with her crew refusing to unload because of local labor trouble.

Thomas E. Elder, 57, of Alton, N. H., former dean of Mount Hermon School for Boys at Northfield, went on trial this afternoon in the Superior Court here before Justice Thomas J. Hammond of Northampton, Mass., on an indictment charging assault with intent to murder Stephen Allen Norton, 66. erstwhile treasurer of the school, the night of May 25 this year.

The Lexington Foundation, Inc., New York City, an investment trust, has filed a registration statement under provisions of the Securities Act of 1933 covering Lexington Foundation contract certificates

Central Park was the scene yesterday of what might have looked like a modern re-enactment of the Pied Piper's procession with the children of Hamlin. There were, however, several important differences.

Steady purchasing of Fall apparel and accessories continued during the week, as showings of initial Fall lines were completed here. The early peak of buyers' arrivals has now been passed and the consensus is that store representatives are covering "normal requirements" for the start of the retail season.

Scoring heavily in the second half, the Central Queens Y. M. C. A. team of Jamaica gained the final round of the annual metropolitan A. A. U. water polo championship tournament last night by defeating the Twenty-third Street Y. M. C. A., 26--10, in the Rockaways Playland Pool. Rockaway Beach.

Violence flared out again yesterday in the shipyard strike in Brooklyn as Mayor La Guardia, on demand of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, ordered an investigation of charges of police brutality against pickets at the Robins Drydock and Repair Company.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson yesterday denied a motion made by counsel for Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney, the former Gertrude Vanderbilt, for dismissal of the government's action to collect taxes on profits realized through the sale of the old Vanderbilt mansion at Fifty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue.

An appeal from the order issued against the Biddle Purchasing Company by the Federal Trade Commission for alleged violation of the brokerage provision of the Robinson-Patman act will be taken immediately, the company announced yesterday.

Merton Lindeke has resigned as associate buyer of furniture for Ludwig Baumann to join Lit Brothers, Philadelphia. The Brooks Shoe Manufacturing Company has acquired control of the H. W. Merriam Shoe Company, Baltimore, manufacturers of Pedicraft Shoes.

Information from the Provinces indicates that serious damage has been caused by gales and storms extending from Port Talcahuano as far as the Chiloe Islands, on the route to the Magallanes. Telegraph lines are down at many points in the vicinity of Chillan and Concencion.

Revival of the Sewing Institute, a non-profit organization for the promotion of home sewing, and the launching of the initial campaign by five leading San Francisco stores, was announced here yesterday. F. W. Howe of Pratt Institute has been named president of the institute; H. H. Benington, L.
The conference report in the $133,000,000 Interior Department Supply Bill for 1938 was approved today by the House, and sent back to the Senate for final action.
The business pace continued slack today on the stock market although most sections were quietly firm. Gilt-edge issues improved, and renewed strength was a feature among Chinese and Japanese bonds.

The minute anything starts to get picturesque in this country there seem to be only two choices as to what to do with it. We can (a) abolish it, or (b) make a museum piece of it. So the day may arrive when we shall have a pushcart wing in the Metropolitan Museum, with samples of carts,

Severe censure of the Chicago Police Department for the conduct of its members during the Memorial Day clash with strikers and strike sympathizers at the Republic Steel Company's plant on the outskirts

American Eagle Fire Insurance Company--June 30: Total assets, $15,417,531, against $16,307,620 at the end of 1936; net surplus, $10,216,014, against $11,120,330; investments, $13,696,457, compared with $14,616,420, based on National Association of Insurance Commissioners valuations.

A midtown property was acquired yesterday by Frederick Brown, operator, who bought from the estate of Martin Erdmann the fivestory residence at 57-59 East Fiftyfifth Street, between Madison and Park Avenues.

The indefatigable Mr. CHURCHILL has had some harsh words to say in the House of Commons about naval treaties in general and British battleship design in particular. He declared--with his-tongue in his cheek, we suspect-that British designers had not been able to solve the problem of

Down in West Seventeenth Street children were playing baseball in the streets last night, dodging autos and roller-skating on the sidewalks. In marked contrast, another group of youngsters sat in front of tents, singing songs and laughing at riddies. Yet the two scenes were only a few hundred feet apart.

" White in the moon the long road lies" Steel tracks, relentless steel, That glitter in the moon, that guide The grinding wheel; Is it enough to hold a black Living thing to a stern course? Over you rushes through the night
The Newark Bears opened a series tonight by scoring a 2-1 victory over the Royals and further extending their long lead over second-place Montreal.

The Columbus unit of the American Newspaper Guild accused Heywood Broun, Guild president, in a telegraphed protest tonight of "attempts to draw a red herring across the trail of a perfectly orderly and legal proposal."

Forty American Boy Scouts in England on their way to the international jamboree in the Netherlands are turning the British countryside upside down in a search for their mascot-a baby alligator two feet long.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., will forward today to shareholders of the $6 and $7 preferred stock of its affiliate, the New York Steam Corporation, a formal offering for the exchange of Consolidated Edison i $5-preferred stock for the steam company's preferred issues.

Fabyan R. Saxe, formerly with Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., and the Manufacturers Trust Company, who recently became associated with R. B. Wattley Company, Inc., has been elected vice president of that company.
John Whitlow Wyatt, aided by Hal Trosky's twenty-second and twentythird home runs of the season, hurled a four-hit 5-to-1 triumph over the Athletics today in his first start for the Indians.
Shipments of pneumatic casings in May amounted to 5,374,654 units, compared with 5,560,453 in April and 5,833,333 in May. 1936, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association.

Asserting that the business and goodwill of his hotel, the Manx, has been destroyed by what he calls the uncontrolled action of mobs, Harvey M. Toy filed a demand today for $250.500 damages against the city.

With a month remaining in which to make sales, leading metropolitan clothing stores reported yesterday that they have only incomplete assortments of tropical worsted and gabardine suits and that sales of Summer clothing this season have run very sharply ahead of last year.

Declaring that Mayor La Guardia's record "of consistent and sincere activity in behalf of the wageearners of the city" has earned him the support of all trade unionists, George Meany, president of the New York State Federation of Labor, announced yesterday afternoon that he would actively support the Mayor in his fight for re-election.
Earnings of the Pennsylvania Railroad for the remainder of the year will be credited with the excess accruals for the pay-roll tax in the first five months of the year.

Lumber production increased last week, and the adjusted index spurted to 102.7, its highest point since the week ended June 28, 1930. It was 97.0 for the previous week, and 79.8 for the week ended July 18, 1936.

Julius Heldman of California, national junior titleholder, was eliminated from the Eastern clay court championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club. In a tightly fought match that had the gallery tingling with suspense to the last shot, Donald McNeill of Oklahoma, national junior indoor champion, overcame the lefthanded Hollywood youngster to gain a place in the semi-final round. The score was 6-2, 4-6, 8-6.
Here is the text of the memorandum, displayed to the Senate today by Senator Logan, Democrat, of Kentucky, and representing the agreement on a new bill to take the place of the Roosevelt measure:
Dave Albritton, tall Ohio State athlete, who has been flirting with a leap of 6 feet 10 inches or better, will jump off in two weeks to his third continent.

Most of the buildings of the bankrupt Passaic Print Works on South Street were destroyed by fire this afternoon. The blaze caused an estimated loss of $25,000 and injuries to two firemen. The cause of the fire has not been determined. Authorities are investigating a report that acetylene torches were being used to dismantle machinery in one of the buildings.

The securities and Exchange Commission, at a hearing today before Examiner Richard Townsend, received evidence in proceedings to determine whether post-effective amendments filed recently by the Equity Corporation and the Consolidated Funds Corporation to registration statements filed in 1934 under the Securities Act of 1933 should be permitted to become effective and the proceedings terminated or stop orders issued.

John Edelman, C. I. O. director for the Philadelphia district, and four of his assistants were escorted from Hershey by four State motor patrolmen early this morning after a crowd of about thirty persons had besieged them in the headquarters of the Chocolate Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate.

Vicirua Price, telling her sordid story of a mass attack by nine Negroes before the eleventh jury to sit in judgment in the Scottsboro cases, spent an uncomfortable morning on the witness stand today under a Icross-examination by Samuel Leibowitz, defense attorney.
Colonel Clarence O. Sherrill, City Manager of Cincinnati, Ohio, called on Mayor La Guardia at the Summer City Hall in College Point yesterday and chatted about mutual problems of administration.

Although retail concerns in New York City curtailed their forces 0.8 per cent from May to June, they paid out 0.4 per cent more in wages, salaries and commissions, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, revealed today. These changes,

Reduction in the number of commitments of children for delinquency and consequent saving in the cost of institutional care; a rise in the number of Family Court cases settled without trial, and heavy increases in the amounts collected from individuals for the support of dependents, were announced yesterday by Presiding Justice
The official German criticism of the American and Brazilian trade agreement is followed up editorially in today's Frankfurter Zeitung, which comments bitterly in extended references.
" Glory be to God!" exclaimed Senator Johnson of California today when, in answer to his question, Senator Logan said of future judiciary legislation at this session: "The Supreme Court is out."

Ulen Co. and subsidiaries report earnings of $6,857 for the second quarter of 1937 before adjustments to surplus and after surplus adjustments a net profit of $146,722 because of the inclusion of $158,075 interest on Poland bonds
Miss Joan Curtice Bickford, daughter of Frederic E. Bickford of this place and the late Mrs. Bickford, will be married here on Saturday afternoon in Christ Church to Russell Morley Wickett,

Reaction set in for the Browns today at Sportsman's Park and the Yankees tasted a double dose of misfortune. They slipped up on a sweep of the series with the team thrust upon Jim Bottomley, taking one of their worst drubbings of the year, 13 to 4, and they lost the services of Irving (Bump) Hadley for an indefinite period.
Diving into South Plainfield Lake to aid his brother, Albert Keisling, 6 years old, Richard Keisling, 9, was drowned with the younger boy here today. Neither lad could swim.

Anton Von Bernuth, top-seeded entrant from New York, will seek another leg on the New Hampshire State-White Mountains tennis championship trophy when he engages Robert H. Decker, Brookline, Mass., in the final tomorrow.

The trustees of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company announced yesterday that they would buy on and after Aug. 16 at not more than the face value and without interest subsequent to their respective maturities, the following additional past due and current equipment obligations:

Charles W. Foster, former Fire Commissioner of Pelham Fire District No. 1, and former president of the Westchester County Volunteer Firemen's Association, died today in the Mount Vernon Hospital at the age of 75. He resided here. Surviving are his widow, Mrs.
The shelving of President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the Supreme Court brought to a climax one of the greatest political struggles since the fight over slavery.

Two Albino frogs, whose creamy white skin and bulging pink eyes make them as much a rarity in the animal kingdom as quintuplets are to the human race, were brought yesterday to New York by C. C. Moler of Hagerstown, Md., as gifts for the American Museum of Natural History.

Two men were arrested last night by detectives of the Fourth Avenue station, Brooklyn, for the robbery of a $1,548 payroll from Abraham S. Hirschman, office manager of the Cordiano Can Company, 80 Thirty-ninth Street, Brooklyn. Mr.

Forty editorial employes of The Seattle PostIntelligencer, all members of the American Newspaper Guild, announced today that they had refused to pay dues and assessments to the Guild because of its present policies.

A seven-point agreement requiring authorization of orders by retailers banning the purchase of socalled ash-can hats and outlawing the furnishing of hat bodies to manufacturers or contractors has been entered into between the New York Buyers Association, Inc., comprising commission resident buyers,

Conquest of Mount Lucania, highest mountain hitherto unclimbed in North America, was announced today by Bradford Washburn Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., and Robert H. Bates of Philadelphia, on their arrival here by plane from Burwash Landing in the Canadian Yukon.
The Federal Home Loan Bank System celebrated its fifth anniversary today by arranging a new sale of securities to finance the rising tide of residential construction.

District Attorney William C. Dodge announced yesterday that he had written to Mrs. Stella M. Crater asking her whether she would come to his office for questioning about published statements that she believed her husband, Supreme Court Justice Joseph F.

Senator Nye, Republican of North Dakota, asserted in a statement issued today, that the National Labor Relations Board "seems to have gone out of its way to demonstrate to the public that it is a partisan body rather than a judicial institution."

Opposition to the sugar legislation pending in Congress was expressed today by Secretary Ickes, who accused Eastern Seaboard refiners of trying to dominate the measure for their own benefit and attempting through this alleged pressure to set up trade barriers against a "large group of American citizens" in Hawaii, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

Mr. and Mrs. T. O. M. Sopwith were the guests of honor at a large dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Vladimir Behr tonight. There were also other members of the English yachting contingent, now in port, among the guests. Mr. and Mrs.
Freddie Steele, the world's middleweight boxing champion who scored a technical knockout over Charles (Hobo) Williams here last night, says he'll quit the ring in two years--and go to college.

Prohibition has been established at the North Pole, although inadvertently and much against the will of the four Soviet explorers who are floating around on an ice floe making scientific observations.

A brother and sister who have not seen each other for fifty years were reunited yesterday on the Italian Line pier, at West Fifty-second Street, shortly after the Saturnia docked from Mediterranean ports. Mrs. Bertha Crane, 69- year - old widow, arrived on the liner from her home in Johannesburg, South Africa, and was greeted on the pier by Abraham Palastrant, 63, a tailor, of Dorchester, Mass.

Record Thursday of the Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week, as the fourth day of the event has been known in the past, failed to produce a larger-fleet than the 359 craft last Saturday, but 321 were out this afternoon, so the old record of 293 a year ago again was surpassed.
Freddie Steele, the world's middleweight boxing champion who scored a technical knockout over Charles (Hobo) Williams here last night, says he'll quit the ring in two years--and go to college.

Prohibition has been established at the North Pole, although inadvertently and much against the will of the four Soviet explorers who are floating around on an ice floe making scientific observations.

A brother and sister who have not seen each other for fifty years were reunited yesterday on the Italian Line pier, at West Fifty-second Street, shortly after the Saturnia docked from Mediterranean ports. Mrs. Bertha Crane, 69- year - old widow, arrived on the liner from her home in Johannesburg, South Africa, and was greeted on the pier by Abraham Palastrant, 63, a tailor, of Dorchester, Mass.

Record Thursday of the Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week, as the fourth day of the event has been known in the past, failed to produce a larger-fleet than the 359 craft last Saturday, but 321 were out this afternoon, so the old record of 293 a year ago again was surpassed.

Marshal Henri Petain, who with General John J. Pershing was a guest of honor at the American Club today, read a touching letter from the Mayor of the impoverished village of Oreilla in the Pyranees Orientales, telling how the inhabitants had raised a sum of about $1 for a monument France is now planning to the American Expeditionary Force.

The growth of coal production in the Soviet Union since the Bolsheviki gained power was told in detail today before the second session of the International Congress of Geology by Professor M. M. Prigorovsky, chief of the army of geologists who are constantly finding new fields for exploitation.

Riegel Paper Corporation of New York has purchased a timber tract of 130,000 acres from Waccamaw Lumber Company in Columbus and Brunswick Counties, and will build pulp mills employing at first 500 or more men, and additional workers when a paper-manufacturing plant is built later on the property.

Representative Citron asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation today to "investigate at once" the so-called "Nazi military training camps being established at Andover, N. J., and other places." Camp Nordland at Andover has been set up by the German-American Bund.

QUEEN VICTORIA got a good start in this century as a symbol of rectitude; she may end it as a punctuation mark. Her vast reign is useful in defining eras, epochs, ages, or what have you. Every year there is a new covey of books with her name in the titles.

Market conditions in the liquefied natural gas industry, which supplies fuel to customers beyond the reach of piped gas lines, showed a marked improvement in the first half of this year in the territory of the Atlantic States Gas Company, Inc., it reported yesterday.

Retired Fireman Thomas J. Wall, formerly a member of Engine 88, residing at 151 Huntabridge Road, Yonkers, N. Y., died July 20. Funeral will take place from Walter Cooke Funeral Parlors, 190th St. and Jerome Av., Bronx, at 9:15 A. M. Friday, July 23. Interment at St. Raymond Cemetery. The Deputy Chief of the 7th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.

The skippers of the Barnegat Bay Y. R. A. showed plenty of open water to the representatives of the Inland Lakes Y. R. A. of Minnesota and Wisconsin today to take the lead in the national series for Class E sloops.

The Independence of the church from the observance of any laws that restrict its functions of teaching and preaching was declared today by spokesmen for Protestant Churches in the World Conference on Church, Community and State.

George Messersmith, career diplomat in the American foreign service for the last twenty-three years, returned yesterday on the United States liner Washington en route to Washington, where he will receive appointment as Assistant Secretary of the Department of State.

The Lamley Realty Company leased the five-story building at 158 Bowery, between Broome and Delancey Streets, to the Majestic Kitchen and Bar Equipment Company for offices and showrooms. Jerome Tanenbaum was the broker.
One hundred persons attended an outdoor community supper tonight at Glencrannie Farm, the Richmond estate of Mr. and Mrs. Shaun Kelly, for the benefit of the Congregational Church.

Lincoln Ellsworth, Antarctic explorer, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa with Mrs. Ellsworth from their home in Switzerland. He said he had not made definite plans about his next expedition to the Antarctic and would not have any statement to make until early in September.

The America's Cup defender Ranger and the challenger Endeavour II were looked over as they lay at their moorings in Brenton's Cove late today by the members of the Cruising Club of America, who arrived from Block Island on their annual cruise.

The Police Department had a mystery of its own on its hands yesterday. Officials spent a confusing afternoon trying to discover why the phone numbers of two station houses-one in Queens and another in Brooklyn-had been kept secret from New York's citizenry. They did not make much headway on the mystery, but did get an assur- formed ance from the telephone company that the situation would be cor rected.

Alfred Duff Cooper, First Lord of the Admiralty, issued a sharp declaration on the Spanish Civil War in the House of Commons tonight in a heated exchange over Britain's policy on evacuation of refugees from Santander.

The Wagner-Steagall Low-Cost Housing and Slum Clearance Bill was recommended to the Senate for passage by the Committee on Education and Labor today, and Senator Barkley, the majority leader, expressed the opinion that it would pass in a day or two after it was made the pending business next week.

Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Marburg of Baltimore entertained with a luncheon at their estate, Bide Awhile, today in honor of Colonel Wyndham W. T. Torr, military attache of the British Embassy, and Mrs. Torr. The guests included Prince and Princess Burhaneddin and their son, Prince Osman, of Washington;
Motorists crossing the Brooklyn Bridge on the Brooklyn-bound roadway were abruptly halted at 8:30 o'clock last night as an automobile ahead of them stopped suddenly.

Miss Aurilla Virginia Drew, former manager of the Baptist Home of Philadelphia, died yesterday at her home in Oakmont in her seventy-fourth year. She was a daughter of William Bartlett Drew, a Philadelphia merchant, and was a descendant of Captain William Drew, who served on General Washington's staff.

Peru's policy in regulating retail costs of imported pharmaceutical specialties has resulted in striking reductions in the price to the consumer of various articles, notably those from Germany and France, according to reports to the Commerce Department's Chemical Division.
Karl Pannaci of Kansas City and Douglas Fonda of Orange, N. J., were at the top of the heap today after the first day's racing in the third annual Mohawk River power boat regatta.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Acquisition and operation of the Union Traction Company of Kansas by the Union Electric Railway Company and the issuance of several series of stocks and bonds by Union Electric was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Among the returning expatriates include Bayard Veiller. He has sold his home in Santa Monica and is headed back in the general direction, at least, of the scene of such Veiller triumphs as "The Thirteenth Chair" and "The Trial of Mary Dugan."
Chicago at New York-Lee vs. Melton. St. Louis at Brooklyn-Weiland vs. Butcher. Cincinnati at Philadelphia-Schott vs. Johnson. Pittsburgh at Boston-Blanton or Brandt vs. Turner.
More than 125 person attended the second in the series of dances at the Riverside Yacht Club tonight, for members of the younger set from 12 to 17 years of age.

Turpentine firm, 33 1/4c; sales 244 barrels; receipts 453 barrels; shipments 10 barrels; stock 32,975 barrels. Resin firm: sales 273: receipts 1,666; no shipments; stock 71,449. Quote: B to K. $7.85; M, $7.85-87 1/2; N, WG, $7.87 1/2; WW, X, $8.70.

Directors of the Life Savers Corportion declared yesterday an extra dividend of 40 cents a share, together with the regular quarterly distribution of 40 cents. At the meeting Edward J. Noble was elected chairman of the board; Oscar T. Kappes, president; Robert P. Noble, executive vice president;

Viscountees Astor, American-born Member of Parliament, became a Companion of Honor today at a private investiture by King George. The King also conferred on Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, chief economic adviser to the British Government, the rank of a Knight Grand Cross of the Order of St. Michael and St. George.
An initial outlay of 90,000,000 pesos was decided on today for the purchase abroad of planes and other aviation material, in accordance with plans for the modernization of Chile's military forces,

Yesterday was an eventful day in the life of the family of Samuel Fassler, Manhattan Building Commissioner. It was his nineteenth wedding anniversary, his wife's and daughter's birthday and the day on which the daughter announced her engagement.

A small Buddhist shrine, stolen ten days ago from the Newark Museum, was returned to the institution today by the aunt of a 12-yearold boy, who had used it for a toy. The shrine, which was insured for $1,000, was taken from the museum by an 11-year-old delinquent youth.

Derek C. Brooks, at 16 Edgewood Ave, Larchmont: William H. Hobey, at 19 Dogwood Dr, Scarsdale; Westchester rentals by Cushman Wakefield, Inc. Walter Duhy, at 98 Union Ave, Mamaroneck, from Joseph Acampora; Peter C. Doern Jr., Inc., broker. A. E. Brendel, in 67 Halstead Pl, Rye; Harris Sherman, in 9 Charlotte St, Rye; M. Taxin. in 10 Hix Ave, Rye; A. Sixas,

Directors of the Chrysler Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $3.50 a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 10 to stock of record of Aug. 10, compared with $2 a share paid on June 11 and $1.50 paid on March 11, or a total of $7 a share thus far in 1937.

While retail trade showed gains in all of the leading centers of distributionthis week, buying for the Fall season proceeded at a slower rate in the principal wholesale markets, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Because the navy as a whole is a contented, well-disciplined and generally efficient service, it is rare that what are usually its minor internal troubles become a source of external discussion and irritation.
A group of defiant Protestant Confessional Synod pastors sent letters to the German secret police today anbouncing their continued disobedience of Nazi church decrees.

Overriding demands from some factions that a special primary be called, the Democratic State Committee today nominated Governor Carl E. Bailey to be Joseph T. Robinson's successor in the United States Senate.

Harry Kaufman, pianist, will be soloist in the "Rhapsody in Blue" with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in the Gershwin memorial concert on Aug. 9 at Lewisohn Stadium. Alexander Smallens will conduct.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 8,000, including 2,500 directs. Hogs from 230 pounds down, 10c-15c higher than Thursday's average; heavier butchers and sows steady to 10c lower; top, $13;

Richard Bennett, the actor, who is now unemployed and lives at the Hotel Westover, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal court, listing liabilities of $6,157, $800 of which is owed to Joan Bennett, his daughter, the motionpicture actress.
The Rev. Charles Jaynes Jr., 7 years old, was ordained minister today, described by the Rev. G. B. Drake as the "youngest in the world." He lives in Riverside, Calif.

Employes of the National Fuel Gas Company and eleven subsidiaries are assured of an adequate income upon retirement through a plan of group annuities supplementing old-age benefits provided in the Social Security Act,

Joseph Ziluca, architect, representing the Elweed Realty Corporation of New York, has signed a contract for the erection of a new six-story thirty-family penthouse apartment building to stand in Elweed Place here at the rear of the present Greenwich Towers Apartments.

Cincinnati defeated the Phillies today in the opening game of the series, 6 to 3. Baxter Jordan hit the second ball pitched by Bucky Walters over the right-field fence and from that point the Reds never were headed.

Chief of Police Thomas Carroll, for more than thirty-seven years in the Syracuse Bureau of Police and SCHI head of the department the last two and a half years, died today at his home after having been in poor health for months. He was 63 years old.

Showing automobile models of modern trend, many of which were arranged for engines in the rear and all streamlined, boys of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania received honors and cash awards here yesterday in the annual Fisher Body Craftsman's Guild competition.

Mrs. T. Halsted Myers of the Savoy-Plaza will leave today for Waterville, Me. Mrs. Thomas W. Miller and her daughter, Miss Georgina T. Miller, have arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria from Wilmington, Del. Mrs. Howard S. Evans of Pittsburgh has left the Plaza for Hyannis, Mass.
The Argentine Information Bureau here has received the regular fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for July 15, which shows the following changes in paper pesos:
A statement that the White House had been informed that present prospects indicated a cotton crop of 14,500,000 bales caused a sharp break in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday.

Amid deafening cheers, cries of glee and wails of despair,- the three happiest--and the seventy-one unhappiest--children in New York City were chosen yesterday afternoon. In material outlay it took only two dolls and a teddy bear to make these three the happiest children in the city, but spiritually there was a greater reward.

Three hundred and twenty-seven out of a total of 355 teachers who viewed two showings of the Paramount newsreel of the Memorial Day riot in South Chicago, in which ten strikers met their death, disagreed with the vote of a Chicago coroner's jury that the killings constituted "justifiable homicide," it was revealed yesterday in a poll taken at Teachers College, Columbia University.

Constructive activity continued in the stock market today with the volume of business on a fair scale. Gilt-edge securities went ahead on yesterday's strength and both Japanese and Chinese issues rose sharply.

United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corp. Allen L. Woodworth president. gave a trust mtge for $6,000,000 to Manufacturers Trust Co to secure that amount of 5 per cent sinking fund bonds which are due Oct 1, 1952, on the s w cor of Christopher St and 7th Ave, 26x29.4x irreg, and on various parcels in Michigan,

The body of Marquis Guglielmo Marconi, who gave the world wireless telegraphy, was placed today in the family vault of the Marconis as Italy honored him with a state funeral. Three hundred thousand residents of this university and industrial city, his birthplace, paid their last respects as the cortege moved to the fourteenth century monastery where final rites were held.

The most significant movements in a somewhat more active bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange were on the upside. Conspicuous in this movement were the obligations of local traction companies, and those of the United States Government.

A generally firm tone prevailed in the stock market yesterday, with strength in the early trading and irregularity later. At the closing, leading industrial issues were up irregularly, utilities were higher although mostly by fractions, and advances and declines in the railway section of the list were about a stand-off.

Officials of many municipalities are viewing with "growing concern" the widespread demand upon their water supply by increasing installations of the type of air-conditioning apparatus which discharges water into sewerage systems, the Marketing Research Division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce reported today.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator, was served yesterday with a Federal court order restraining him from continuing the dismissal of aliens from the rolls of the WPA. Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard signed the order, returnable next Tuesday morning at 10:30 o'clock before Federal Judge John C. Knox.

Wild Bill Mehlhorn of Louisville, Ky., toured the Medinah Country Club's No. 3 course two under par today to take the lead in the first round of Chicago's $10,000 open golf carnival. Wild Bill, who has been close lots of times but hasn't had much luck in winning major tournaments, knocked a stroke off regulation figures for each nine holes, finishing with 35, 35-70, for the only subpar score in a long day of shooting.

Anning S. Prall, Federal Communications Commission chairman, died at his Summer home here today of a heart attack as he arose from bed. He was 66 years old. Mr. Prall had been ill for more than a week. His widow and a son, W. Mortimer Prall, were with him when he died.

The New York Stock Exchange received notice today that the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce had not given its approval to the proposed consolidation of the Alleghany Corporation, top holding company of the so-called Van Sweringen system, and the Chesapeake Corporation, another of the holding companies within the Van Sweringen network.

With the Supreme Court issue definitely settled for this session, and possibly for many sessions, the time has come to express the hope that a happier chapter lies ahead and that the bitterness of a great controversy may be soon forgotten.

Jesse W. Sweetser of New York, who won the British amateur golf championship nearly a decade ago, today marched through two opponents to reach the semi-finals of the Newport Country Club's invitation golf tournament.
Oyster growers in Long Island Sound should plant shells at once if they desire to collect spat, the technical name by which baby oysters are known, the Bureau of Fisheries strongly urged today.

Already sufficiently depressed by the loss of Fred Perry, who is now a professional tennis player, Great Britain's defenders of the Davis Cup were saddened further today by the luck of the draw, which pits Henry Wilfred (Bunny) Austin against Frank Parker and Charles Edgar Hare against Donald Budge.

A squadron of seven ships of the Midshipmen's Costal Cruising Detachment docked yesterday noon at the foot of West Thirty-third Street, Hudson River. Their course in recent days led them to strange places, on an errand having more to do with make-believe than naval tactics.

Maryland and Queen Anne's County will receive about $67,000 in taxes from John J. Raskob, former national Democratic chairman, under a compromise settlement today with the State Tax Commission over his intangible taxable personal property for 1934 and 1935.

Serious criticism of Puerto Rico's exclusive insurance fund, in which all employers are compelled to insure employes-the criticism resulting from greatly increased rates for the second year-caused the Industrial Commission today to suspend the new rates pending hearings.
Gross assets, $8,020; net, $5,430. To William H. Chamberlain and Roy H. Chamberlain, sons, one-half residue, each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $5,968. Howard N. Deyo, attornev. 64 Water St.

An apartment of eleven rooms and four baths in 911 Park Avenue has been leased by Jerome H. Remick Jr., of the Michigan Alkali Company, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., and Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., cobrokers, according to a report of the latter firm.

Six men were arrested in New York City yesterday as members of a ring of auto thieves that dismantled stolen cars and sold the parts rather than the cars intact. The police believe that the arrests will clear up the disappearance of scores of medium priced automobiles in recent months. In many recent instances the police have been unable to track the stolen cars.

222d St. (17-4836); n s, 105 ft w of Barnes Ave. 50x89; N. Y. City Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church to Board of Managers of the Diocesan Missionary and Church Extension Society of the Protestant Episcopal Church, at Amsterdam Ave and 110th St. Virginia Ave (14-3787); e s, 53 ft s of Chatterton Ave. 50x101; Bank of N. Y.

The Laborers' National Bank for the development of industry has been created by decree, aiming at the extension of credit facilities to groups of workers organized in cooperative societies needing financial support, or starting new industrial activities.

Acceptance of an offer of the presidency of the United States Trust Company of Newark by F. Randolph Dunn, cashier of the Lincoln National Bank here, was announced today by officials of the trust company.
A new authorization by the State Banking Department permitting J. P. Morgan Co. of New York to continue in business has just been issued, the department bulletin announced today.

James' G. Blaine, Vincent Cullen and James R. Trowbridge were permitted today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to intervene in opposition to an application by the trustees of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company to issue a $28,172,650 of ten-year, secured 3 1/2 per cent certificates of indebtedness.

Wage increases, a closed shop and other benefits for the 1,800 employes of Ludwig Baumann, 500 Eighth Avenue, operator of seven furniture stores in the metropolitan area, were announced yesterday by Max Meyer, named a month ago to arbitrate a labor dispute between the company and its employes.

On a mounting surge of enthusiasm for feminine equality with men, delegates to the convention of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women suspended the rules of routine procedure here today and climaxed their biennial meeting with an epochal series of actions.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company, including both subway and elevated divisions, carried 1,010,973,824 passengers in the sys them's fiscal year ended on June 30 according to the report filed yesterday by Thomas E. Murray Jr. receiver, with Federal Circuit Judge Julian W. Mack.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that $82,051,000 of its 2 per cent notes which matured on July 1 were exchanged by holders on that date at par for an equal amount of 1 1/2 per cent notes

Based on preliminary figures, the consolidated net income of the Texas Corporation in the first half of this year was approximately $27,000,000, or $2.48 a share on the capital stock, including the recent issue of additional shares, T. Rieber, chairman, said yesterday in connection with the declaration
English visitors to the Paris Exposition are writing letters to the London papers protesting against the inadequacy of the British Pavilion to represent Great Britain in an international show.

Avenging two early season setbacks, Gilbert Hunt of Washington conquered Bob Harman of Berkeley, Calif., seeded second, at the Longwood Cricket Club today and won the right to meet Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, top-seeded player in the final for the Longwood bowl. Hunt scored in five sets, 4-6, 7-5, 5-7, 6-1, 6-0.

Mrs. Elsie Baas Goeller, wife of Robert A. Goeller, Long Island Sound yachtsman, died at her home, 84 Edgewood Avenue, here today after a long illness. Her age was 48. Mrs. Goeller, a native of New York, was a member of the Larchmont Women's Club and the Larchmont Garden Club.

Two speedy 3-year-olds from the EastPompoon and Flying Scot-are the one, two choices for tomorrow's $30,000 added Classic Stakes at Arlington Park. Eight thoroughbreds were named tonight for the rich event, which will be run for the ninth time.

King Leopold in an open letter congratulating Premier Paul van Zeeland on the results of his mission to Washington and London made an earnest plea today for the creation of an international organization to solve the world's economic problems.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 21: CAPTAIN Baker, G. E., Washington, D. C., to duty with the Argentine Navy Dept., Buenos Aires, Argentina.
Adjournment of Congress by Aug. 14 at the latest, and if possible by Aug. 7, became the goal of the administration leadership today.

THE new novel by David Lamson is called "Whirlpool" (Scribner, $2.50). It is about a man who was condemned to die for a murder that never occurred. I already have heard Lamson criticized, by a pre-publication reader, for "exploiting" his own experiences, and expect to hear such criticism again.

Bishop Francis J. McCconnell of the New York Area of the Methodist Episcopal Church is one of a group of delegates of the Methodist Episcopal Church who will attend the second decennial World Conference on Faith and Order in Edinburgh, Scotland, Aug. 3 to 18.

Apathetic bidding yesterday marked the public auction of seized and abandoned goods in the United States Customs seizure room, 201 Varick Street, when twenty-two lots, composed largely of liquors, were offered to a small gathering of bidders for a total cost just short of $32,000.

The Tennessee Electric Power Company of Chattanooga, a subsidiary of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and the most active private power company in the immediate area of the Tennessee Vallev Authority.
Permission was given today by the Congressional Tax Avoidance Committee to any of its own members to examine the tax returns of James Roosevelt, the President's son, and Secretary Morgenthau.

Mr. and Mrs. Ludolph Henry Conklin of Basking Ridge, N. J., gave a dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for Miss Blanche Belcher, granddaughter of Mrs. Zachariah Belcher of Far Hills, N. J., and for their niece, Miss Sally Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Gilbert Brown of Newark.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., will continue its own pension and insurance plan for the next two years along with the requirements of the Federal Social Security Act, according to an announcement to employees yesterday by John A. Brown, Socony's president.

A provisional council of C. I. O. unions in North Jersey was formed here tonight at a meeting of 400 delegates representing fifty C. I. O. affiliates, with 57,000 workers. The meeting was held at local C. I. O. headquarters, 81 Academy Street.

The second Youth Conference of the Baptist World Alliance will be held on Aug. 8-13 in Zurich, Switzerland, with Baptists from many countries present. Auxiliary meetings are planned to be held in the Netherlands and West Germany.
Cards were sent out from Brooklyn Republican headquarters yesterday informing the 3,500 members of the county committee there would be a meeting in Kismet Temple, Herkimer Street, Thursday night.

The unfortunate controversy over the Supreme Court is due, primarily, to a defect in the Constitution itself. Of the three powers of government, legislative, executive and judicial, the first two stem directly from the people. The Supreme Court, however, stems from appointments by the Executive, under the supervision of a portion of the legislative branch.

The Newark Bears added another game to their long International League lead tonight by shutting out the Royals, 10--0. The Bears pounded two pitchers for fifteen hits, including home runs by Dahlgren, Keller, McQuinn and Gleeson and a triple by Seeds. Vito Tamulis, meanwhile, held the Royals to six hits and helped in the attack with three singles.

The eight-room, two-family dwelling at 235 Thirty-second Street, in the Woodcliff section of North Bergen, N. J., has been sold by William E. Lewis to Pasquallna DeGregorio. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

Play in the eleventh international tennis tournament between a team representing Oxford and Cambridge Universities of England and Harvard and Yale resulted in a threeall deadlock at the Newport Casino today.

John W. Dowling, insurance man and wellknown Utican, died here today at his home of heart disease. Mr. Dowling for thirty-seven years was connected with the John Hancock Mutual Insurance Company of Boston and at the time-of his death was district manager.

Basque refugee boys, armed with table knives and sticks, fought policemen in the village of Brechfa, Wales, tonight. After rioting in the village yesterday, the boys tonight took barrels of tar left by road repairers to form a barricade against the police.

Authorities declared today they had broken up an extensive plot to assassinate prominent persons in this British mandated territory. Two Palestinian Arabs and a Transjordanian were arrested in the house of the latter last night,
The German Government today imposed a special tax on eligible males who fail to serve in the military forces "to penalize men who continue to make money while their brothers serve the country."

The marriage of Miss Alvina Margaret Dow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay L. Dow of this city and Lake Mohawk, to Royal E. Cleveland, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Willard Cleveland of East Orange, took place this evening in Munn Avenue Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Carl Martenson, pastor of the Grove Street Congregational Church, East Orange, officiated.

Operation of seventy New York City transient and residential hotels during the first half of this year, as shown by a compilation made by a hotel auditing firm, showed a rise of 9 per cent in dollar volume of room sales over the same period of 1936,

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 23.--W. Roy Manny's Night Wind, a one-design 12-meter sloop, scored a victory by a margin of 12 minutes and 28 seconds over the International Twelves today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's race-week regatta. It was an example of what can happen in a yacht race when two competitors get into action against each other and let a third get away.

A Ford Motor Company policeman testified today that union organizers mounted a highway overpass at the Ford Dearborn plant, where they were beaten May 26, after being warned that it was private property.

Samuel Foreman, 37 years old, of 341 West Thirtieth Street, alleged to have been an ally of the murdered Dutch Schultz in the Harlem policy racket several years ago, began a deferred penitentiary sentence of not less than three years yesterday.

Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring, women's Eastern champion, added another event to her string of conquests when she captured the Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament today with a card of 79.

Mr. and Mrs. Frost M. Wheeler of this city have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Ann Wheeler, to Allen Skinner Hubbard Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Skinner Hubbard of New York and Colebrook, Conn. The ceremony took place on Wednesday in Bedford Hills. N. Y.

Mrs. Sarah T. McLean, who died Sept. 10, 1934, left a net estate of $3,844,502, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday by Deputy Tax Commisisoner Jacob Manicoff. The bulk of the estate goes to two daughters and three grandchildren.

Joseph A. Leslie, former carpenter's mate on the steamship President Harding, whose testimony against Joseph (Jo-Jo) Aveta and two others in an opium-smuggling plot resulted Thursday in their conviction, received a suspended sentence yesterday when he pleaded guilty before Federal Judge Sidney C. Mize. Judge Mize will sentence

The National Headquarters of the American Legion has authorized the use of its emblem in connection with news articles in any news- 7 paper and has prohibited its use as part of any advertisement, it was made known yesterday. The action was taken in connection with the convention to be held here from Sent. 20 to 23.

Because of the road's "willful, deliberate and persistent violation of the Federal Motor Carrier Act," Harry Holden of Idaho, comprising Joint Board 49 of the Interstate Commerce Commission, today recommended that the commission deny an application by the Union Pacific Railroad Company to operate buses between Shoshone and Ketchum, Idaho, and between Ketchum and Sun Valley Lodge, which the railroad operates in the Sawtooth Mountains.

Contracts totaling $190,785 for the construction of various works were awarded by the Bureau of Yards and Docks of the Navy Department today, as follows: Boiler plant equipment and piping at the Naval Academy (Hospital), awarded to William F. Kirwan, Baltimore, for $28,700.

Two gunmen held up three employes of the Superior Cabinet Corporation, 3,611 Fourteenth Avenue, near Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, in an elevator in -the building yesterday at 1:45 P. M. and took a $3,856 payroll, which had just been drawn from a neighborhood bank.

Samuel Untermyer will sail today on the Swedish American liner Gripsholm for a thirty-four-day cruise to Scandinavia, the Baltio States and Russia. Others listed for this ship are G. Hilmer Lundbeck, Mrs. M. Tackaberry McAdoo, Imre de Josika-Herzog, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Saltonstall, Judge and Mrs. Robert H. Winn, Dorothy Bacon, Judge and Mrs. William Gary Knowles, Dr. and Mrs. Nicolai Sokoloff and Mr. and Mrs. Clarence A. Southerland.

The six-story elevator apartment house at 2,766 Barnes Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Isadore B. Geller, operator, through Samuel Goldstein, broker. Held at $170,000, the house occupies a plot 100 by 100 feet and contains 166 rooms laid out in fifty-four apartments.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 17 amounted to 770,075 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 87,870 cars, or 12.9 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 49,716 cars, or 6.9 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 177,408 cars,

Lewis S. Strauss, philanthropist of Richmond, Va., and a director of the Savings Bank of Richmond, died here last night in the Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness. Mr. Strauss, whose age was 69, had been for many years active in various charitable organizations in Virginia.

A delegation of Argentina's best skiers arrived today to compete in the Pan-American events taking place at Farellones del Colorado snowfield, where the United States team was in action for a week, sweeping all the trophies at stake.

The American Institute of Accountants announced yesterday that leaders in the profession of public accounting in England, Canada, Ireland, Mexico, Holland and Germany have accepted invitations to attend the observance of the fiftieth anniversary of the institute at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel from Oct.
BERLIN, July 23.--The United States Senate's rejection of Supreme Court expansion continued to afford material for German press comment. The Hamburger Fremdenblatt observes:

A 214-run victory over Worcestershire today enabled Middlesex to narrow the margin held by Yorkshire and Sussex at the top of the English county cricket competition. Middlesex 248 and 275 for four wickets, declared; Worcestershire 156 and 153 (Smith five for 61), at Lord's.

Charles C. Pettijohn Jr., recent winner of New York State and Westchester County junior golf titles, disclosed today he had received a letter of congratulation from President Roosevelt this week. The letter said:
William E. Dodd, Ambassador to Germany, will sail tomorrow for a two months' leave of absence in this country, at the end of which he will return to his post.

Bids for 1,228,500 yards of textiles were invited today by the Treasury Procurement Division, for delivery Aug. 30. The bids are to be opened Aug. 3, and are for the following lots of textiles: 520-T-8-3, plisse crepe, 28.5 minimum, 75x50,

Many members of the Summer colony and their week-end guests attended the second dinner dance of the Hamptons for the benefit of Camp Grant, at Baiting Hollow, L. I., which was held tonight at Canoe Place Inn. Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems headed the junior committee and Mrs. Albert F. Jaeckel was chairman of the patroness committee.

What is described as an authoritative analysis of German finances since the Nazis came into control is announced for publication next week by Houghton Mifflin. The volume is entitled "Germany: The Last Four Years" and is the work of a group of economists who use the collective pen name "Germanicus."

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $11,329,315, to be represented by one State and thirty-nine municipalities. This compares with the revised total of only $6,989,900 for last week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $29,882,999.
Japanese headquarters here announced that some of its soldiers in the front lines in North China bathed today for the first time in sixteen days. The long wait was not by choice.

Seven young people, the youngest 7, the oldest 29, were burned to death in their wrecked car here early today as the driver of the truck which struck them stood by, unable to extricate them. B. B. King, the truck driver, was able to pull only 7-year-old David Manning from the car before flames spread by gasoline from the car's crushed tank drove him from the automobile.

The Very Rev. Samuel Falle, dean of Jersey since 1906, died today. He was 83. Dean Falle was a native of the Island of Jersey, although he passed about thirty years in various parts of England after his ordination in 1877. He had been honorary canon of Winchester since 1915.

A sealed Hydrographic bottle containing a passenger list on one of the trips of the Gold Star Mothers to the war cemeteries in France in May, 1931, has been recovered at Cayo Esquival del Sur, Cuba, the State Department was informed today by Harold S. Tewell, United States Consul at Havana.
Some twenty-five attorneys dropped from the legal department of the local WPA in recent payroll reductions started a mass job-hunt yesterday and wound up at the office of Mayor La Guardia.

Fifty-seven golfers are slated to play over the Rock Spring Club course in West Orange, N. J., on Tuesday in the metropolitan district sectional qualifying round for the coming national amateur championship.

The eightieth birthday of Dr. Albert Shaw, veteran editor and author, found him convalescing yesterday from a streptococcus throat infection in his home at Hastingson-Hudson, but he was eager to become active in his newest venture, The Digest, on a full-time basis.
The government's decision to revalue the gold reserves of the Bank of Japan, the official bank of issue, and to increase the book value of the metal almost three-fold was made public today.

Although the French franc again lost ground yesterday in the foreign exchange market here, it once more showed signs of the resistance which had developed on Thursday and managed, for the first time in about ten days, to avoid making a "new low."

Changes in partnerships have been announced as follows: H. Allen Wardle, Exchange member of Hubbard Bros. Co., retired as of July 22; Betsey C. Gwathmey, special partner, admitted to E. A. Pierce Co.; Milton Wasserman and Hana Goldstein (special), admitted as partners in Schatzkin, Loewi Co.
