On their way to work late yesterday afternoon, workers of the Robins Dry Dock and Repair Company, Erie Basin, Brooklyn, in seven automobiles, were attacked with stones and other missiles by about twenty-five men opposite Greenwood Cemetery, several miles from the plant.

There were 35,028,682 telephones in use throughout the world in 1936, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. This figure, it was said, was within 1 per cent of the total reached in 1931, the peak year.

Joseph W. Losey, a stage director, of 21 East Sixty-seventh Street, New York, and Elizabeth Hawes Jester of Ridgewood, N. J., were married here this afternoon by Justice of the Peace Theodore Wruck. Attending the couple were Lewis Webster Jones and Barbara Jones of Bennington.

A luncheon was given yesterday by Mrs. Samuel R. Campbell of Utica, N. Y., on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis. Her guests included Mrs. Archibald D. Russell and Miss Louise Russell of this city, and Mrs. Holbrook Calder, Miss Theodora Westcott and John and Samuel Campbell of Utica.

Asserting that "labor is directly concerned in preserving the stability of the industry," Isidpre Nagler, general manager of the Joint Board of Cloak, Suit, Skirt and Reefer Makers Union, in a communication sent yesterday to Harold W. Brightman,

With the appointment of the United States Advertising Corporation as its advertising agency, the Hayes Body Corporation, Grand Rapids, Mich., yesterday announced plans for an extensive advertising campaign to promote the sale of its electrically welded, all-steel, safety trailers. Newspapers, consumer and trade magazines, radio and direct mail will be used in the drive.

From the well-known title by Rudyard Kipling and a story by a couple of other fellows, Twentieth Century-Fox's "Wee Willie Winkie" (at the Roxy) permits the dimpled Shirley Temple to unloose her celebrated charms upon the rebellious Pathans in the Khyber Pass zone.

Two yachtsmen today found the body of Miss Janet Wohlsen, 18, who had been missing since she went fishing two days ago. The body was floating on the surface of the water near where she disappeared. There were no marks of violence on it.

A rollicking band of Cubs breezed Into the Polo Grounds yesterday and in a spirit of boisterous fun forthwith produced some astounding results. It was ladies' day, a record gathering of 25,000 was on hand and Gabby Hartnett, manager pro tem of the front-running Chicagoans, exuded good cheer in all directions.

Twenty feet of mud halted Naval Diver C. B. Brown's third invasion of White River today in search of Arkansas' mysterious "monster." Aides pulled the Memphis man to the surface from muck and weeds of the river bed after an hour's hunt failed to disclose a trace of the creature. He saw only a big catfish and a heavy log.

Two consistent winners in the show ring this season appeared to be well on their way to championships today at the close of the second day of the Jersey Shore Horse Show on the grounds of the BoxwoodFarm.

A Russian ballet festival was held this afternoon at Gray Craig, home of Mr. and Mrs. Michael M. van Beuren, for the benefit of the Newport country branch of the Rhode Island Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. The event also marked the formal opening of the new outdoor Summer theatre garden on the van Beuren estate.

Mrs. Clara Alice Hunsicker Murray, widow of Bishop John Gardner Murray, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States from 1925 to his death in October, 1929, died today at her home here. Her age was 72.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 22 unless specified: At San Pedro: Gannet, Brazos. Pinola, Argonne, July 23. At Coco Solo: Bushnell, S-31, 32, 44 and 45. At New York, July 23: Claxton, Drayton, Erie, Jacob Jones, Monley, Roper, J. F. Talbott.
Three New York concerns have stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue "false and misleading representations in advertising their products," the commission announced today.

Robert H. Decker of Brookline, Mass., today won the New Hampshire State-White Mountains tennis title by defeating Anton Von Bernuth, top-seeded New New Yorker, after five sizzling sets. The score was 2-6, 3-6, 6-4, 6-1, 6-2.

The report of the Standard Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries, exclusive of the Deep Rock Oil Company and the Beaver Valley Traction Company, for the five months ended on May 31, shows a net income of $2,477,070, after interest, depreciation, amortization, taxes and other charges.

At a five-hour conference, presided over by Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, representatives of the union and the company reached a virtual settlement of the walkout at the Apex Hosiery Mills, which began eighty days ago.

Services will be discontinued after tomorrow until Fall in a few churches in the city. The Rev. Dr. L. Sale-Harrison of Australia, who has been guest preacher this month at the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street, will end a series of sermons there tomorrow night.

Following a conference with representatives of the Horn Hardart restaurant chain, Local 302 of the Cafeteria Workers Union and Local 87 of the Bakery Workers Union, Father John P. Boland, chairman of the State Labor Relations Board, announced that employers and employes had agreed to take no precipitate action in their dispute pending another conference next Wednesday.

Arthur Godfrey Brown of Great Britain tonight smashed a Canadian quarter-mile record that had stood for twentyeight years, as the Oxford-Cambridge track and field team swept to easy victory over a Quebec outfit, eleven first places to two.

Two boys, 4 and 5 years old, who were turned over to the police Thursday night when they were discovered wandering in the vicinity of Willis Avenue and 142d Street, the Bronx. were still unidentified last night.
Today Superior Court Judge Carl Foster ruled theatre "bank nights" in Connecticut illegal. Acting in a test case, Judge Foster fined David Magliori, manager of a Windsor Locks theatre, $13.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor and former secretary-treasurer of the United Mine Workers of America, will be tried by the miners' biennial convention in January on a charge of aiding and abetting a "dual" union, the Progressive Miners of America.

The House joined unanimously today with the Senate in sending to the White House a bill creating a national cancer institute in the Public Health Service to conduct research into the causes of the disease and to coordinate efforts of other agencies in attacking it.

Ralph Guldahl, America's national open golf champion, the main speaker in criticism of British sportsmanship among the recently returned United States Ryder Cup squad, said today his remarks had been misinterpreted.

Price movements of commodity futures were mixed yesterday in moderate activity on the markets here. Rubber fell sharply, with tin, domestic sugar, coffee and cocoa futures also lower. Copper, hides and pepper futures were higher. On the cash market wheat, oats, flour, lard, silk and hides advanced, but corn, rye, cocoa, tins, cotton and rubber fell.
The following Ununiformed Firemen shall be directed to report to the Chief Medical Officer, at these headquarters, at 12 noon, on date specified above their names:

Mrs. Delia Spencer Caton Field, widow of Marshall Field, Chicago merchant, died tonight of pneumonia at her Summer home at Pride's Crossing. Her age was 84. Mrs. Field came to her Summer estate from Washington a month ago. She had been in poor health for several months.

Net premiums written by the United States Casualty Company for the first half of 1937 amounted to $3,189,836, compared with $2,783,321 for the 1936 period, a gain of 14.6 per cent. The company earned $2,899,600 in premiums, against $2,559,341, ? ain of 13.3 per cent.

Clearence Wolf, banker, manufacturer and former State Senator, died of a heart ailment today in the Jewish Hospital after an illness of six weeks. He was 77. Mr. Wolf was president of Wolf Brothers Co., a private banking house, which he and four brothers founded in 1899.

New York "will do itself proud" in entertaining members of the American Legion when the veterans' organization comes here for its national convention beginning Sept. 20, Mayor La Guardia said last night.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mildred Seiken, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Seiken of this city, to Louis M. Gothelf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Gothelf of Brooklyn.

The Protestant church leaders and lay members who tried to write a statement of principles regarding war revealed today that they were unable to outline a clear-cut course of action to guide Christians in that emergency. Their report was adopted tonight by the World Conference on Church, Community and State as the best possible statement on the subject.

While the stalemate continued in the Sierra sector the Rebels have been making a spectacular advance on the Teruel front, where they seem to have driven westward about fifteen miles from Albarracin to Guadalaviar.

Tomorrow night will begin another Salzburg Music Festival--the last inthe present Festspielhaus before its radical renovation. Beethoven's "Fidelio," conducted by Arturo Toscanini, will, as last year, be the opening ceremony.

James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has asked the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., to endeavor to work out some plan whereby to aid dealers whose capital might temporarily become impaired by trading in the over-the-counter market in securities on a when-issued basis.

The petroleum outlook was described as the brightest it has been in a decade by W. S. Farish, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, before sailing last night on the Europa for Europe. "The prospects are for a satisfactory year both in the United States and in the more important foreign markets," he said.

WASHINGTON, July 23.--Two major unions of the John L. Lewis group turned on the Roosevelt administration in surprise statements today, accusing it of indifference to "flagrant and wanton violations" of the rights of the steel strikers and of failure to act against law violations by the big steel companies.

Morrison Shafroth, chief counsel for the Bureau of Internal Revenue, denied today that the Commissioner of Internal Revenue had erred in assessing the Associated Gas and Electric Company, New York, $1,023,721 and $647,895 for alleged deficiencies in income taxes for 1927 and 1928 respectively.

The House of Representatives approved last night the electoral code which provides for elections next Jan. 9. The Constituent Assembly is scheduled to meet next March. The elections will be for half of the lower house in accordance with the constitutional provision that half of the Representatives elected in January, 1936, shall serve two years, the rest four years.

The City of Pittsburgh, Pa., will be in the market on July 29 with a new issue of $3,000,000 of notes, to be dated July 1, and maturing July 1, 1940. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 2 1/2 per cent. The city also announced yesterday that tenders would be considered on Sept. 21 for an issue of $1,500,000 of school-district bonds. Details of this financing will be announced later.

The gross public debt of the United States amounted to $436.39 per capital on June 30, 1937, according to an estimate made by the National Industrial Conference Board, which points out that as recently as June 30, 1929, the per capital public debt was only $277.23. The latest figure is based on a total public debt of slightly more than $56,000,000,000.

Dr. William Stewart Young, one of the, founders of Occidental College here, died at his home today of a heart attack. He celebrated his seventy-eighth birthday less than two weeks ago by making a telephone call to Shanghai, China, to speak with a son, Dr. Arthur N. Young, financial adviser to the Chinese Government.

The American Bureau of Shipping, which supervises the construction and classification of American ships in a fashion similar to that of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, completed its seventy-fifth year yesterday. A luncheon attended by leaders of American shipping was held at the India House, to mark the anniversary.

Twenty-one persons were injured, two of them seriously, in a spectacular collision at Rockaway Beach yesterday morning between a bus operated by the Green Bus Lines, Inc., and a gasoline truck owned by the Sun Oil Company.

The international executive committee of the American Newspaper Guild will meet at 10 o'clock this morning at the organization's headquarters, 1,560 Broadway, to consider a referendum among the national membership on the, Guild's recent action at St. Louis to affiliate with the C. I. O.

Miss Catherine Beury Ayars, daughter of Mrs. Edward J. Ayars of this place and the late Mr. Ayare, was married to Harold Wellington Borden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd R. Borden of Rahway, at the First Presbyterian Church here this afternoon.
A regulation prohibiting industrial banks from paying interest on demand deposits was adopted by the New York State Banking Board at the first meeting ever held here.

Money obtained from the successful contest of a will or from a settlement is not profit and therefore is not taxable as income, Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe ruled yesterday, ordering the government to refund $65,055 collected from Munro L. Lyeth, grandson of Mary Beecher Longyear, who died March 14, 1934, leaving an estate of $3,000,000.

A resale near Knickerbocker Village was negotiated by Samuel Hurwitz, broker, who sold the fivestory flat for twenty families at 95 Monroe Street for Philip Feinman and Sarah M. Hurwitz. The house was sold for cash and will be altered to comply with the Multiple Dwelling Law.

According to reports published in the ?? Ilustrado today, numerous retired officers of the Chilean Army will leave shortly to take part in the Spanish conflict in the employ of the Valencia government.

Percy A. Hill, prominent American rice planter and writer, was slain at his plantation house at Munoz Nuevagija, 250 miles north of Manila, by a gang of ten Filipino marauders who stole a sum of money and household effects and escaped in an automobile.

As a protest against the high prices they have to pay wholesalers for meat, owners of 5,000 kosher meat and poultry stores in New York have voted to close indefinitely, and have appointed a committee to set the date of closing, Samuel Jacobi, secretary of the Federation of Kosher Butchers, disclosed yesterday.

An increase in operating expenses, compared with 1936, and a drop in the rate of increase in gross revenues caused a marked fall in the combined net earnings of the first ten railroads to report for June.

Fundamental Investors, Inc. (Delaware)-Six months to June 30: Profit after ordinary taxes and expenses, $103,887, exclusive of $177,535 net profit from sales of securities which was credited to earned surplus account.

High Commissioner Paul V. McNutt released today the officially approved procedure for communications between foreign consulates and the Philippine Commonwealth Government. When first promulgated, the suggested method caused a furor in the Commonwealth.

Retail sales of automobiles from May to June showed a somewhat more than seasonal decline, as indicated by the preliminary adjusted index figure, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce announced today.

Detroit and Philadelphia broke even in their twin bill today, the Athletics overwhelming the Tigers, 16-4, in the first game and losing the second, 9-8, in the eleventh inning. The invaders collected 17 hits off four Bengal hurlers, Auker, Coffman, Rowe and Russell, in the opener, while Detroit got to Kelley for only six.
It will be Seabiscuit, the handicap champion, against the field today in the $11,000 Yonkers Handicap, closing-day feature at Empire City, where six were named overnight for the main event.

Retail trade improved here during the week, the showing for a number of stores being the best thus far in July. The increases for individual establishments ranged up to 10 per cent, with executives estimating the average gain for local department stores at from- 5 to per cent.

A temporary injunction, effective for thirty days, restraining the State police and Nassau County authorities from interfering with dog races conducted by the Nassau Kennel Club at Mineola, L. I., was granted yesterday by Federal Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Brooklyn.

With the Board of Higher Education expected shortly to come under liberal-Fusion control as a result of four pending appointments by Mayor La Guardia, extensive changes in the municipal collegiate structure are being considered, it was learned yesterday.

A group of brokers attacked provisions of the Commodity Exchange Act of 1936 in the Supreme Court today. They challenged the constitutionality of the act, which regulates trading in futures on the commodities Exchanges,

LONDON, July 23.--Only the formality of the King's assent next week is needed before Britain's archaic divorce laws are liberalized and the state of "Holy Deadlock" in this country becomes a thing of the past. The act will be effective on Jan. 1, 1938.

Fritz Reiner made his final appearance of the week last night at Lewisohn Stadium, conducting the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra before an audience estimated at close to 3,000. The evening's music began with the Handel-Wuellner Overture in D major, and the Brahms Second Symphony, also in D. The Good Friday Music from Wagner's "Parsifal" came next,

Unless all indications fail, the wheat crop of the United States will be the most valuable since 1927, when it brought more than $1,000,000,000, and this country will be the world's largest exporter of wheat, with 175,000,000 bushels for foreign markets, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today.

The Senate Agriculture Committee rebelled unanimously today against farm legislation lobbyists, and decided to recommend no more agricultural legislation until its members had had a chance to consult the dirt farmers of the country.

American and other foreign communities in North China read with consternation the proposal of Representative Hamilton Fish for the immediate removal of American armed forces from Tientsin and Peiping and the withdrawal of United States naval craft from Chinese waters.

Dr. Edward Francis of the United States Public Health Service, who has been seriously ill a number of times as the result of dangerous experiments with disease organisms in his laboratory in Washington, is at the Marine Hospital here slowly recovering from relapsing fever, with which he became infected from the California tick.

Disappointment that the Canadian Wheat Board would continue its policy and not buy during the coming crop year unless the staple fell below 90 cents a bushel, was voiced here today by officials of the Alberta Wheat Pool and the United Farmers of Alberta.
The end of the Court Bill battle will enable three Senators to sail next week to dedicate American battle monuments in France.

More than 150 firemen attended the funeral yesterday for Battalion Chief Thomas F. J. Powell of the Fifth Battalion, whose home was at 105-20 193d Street, Hollis, Queens. Burial was in St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village. He died on Tuesday.

Mr. and Mrs. John Kirkland Weeks gave a children's party this afternoon at their home to celebrate the birthdays of their son and daughter, John and Sewall Weeks. The guests included Nina and Judith Walker, Stuart Carr, Mary Bishop, Diana Stone, Joy Spalding, Teddy Gay, Raymond De Voe Jr., Ralph Steiner, Daniel Beebe, Hope Plummer, Ernest H. Rice Jr.,

Chief Hogsett hurled 5-hit ball today. while the Browns collected 18 safeties off three Washington pitchers for an 8-to-0 triumph. The Browns' pitcher also hit his first home run of the season in the 5-run second inning, driving in Tom Carey.

Because two exceptionally well dressed men "just didn't look right" to Detective Thomas Cox and started to run as he walked toward them, the police arrested four men yesterday and charged they had beaten and robbed wealthy women after luring them to hotels on the pretext of meeting influential persons.

The House in a rebellious mood rejected the conference report today on the $60,000,000 naval auxiliary craft building program. The vote was 225 to 86. The report now goes back to the conferees, who will try to reach a new agreement.

Barnegat Bay yachts won both morning and afternoon races in the national championship series for Class E sloops today and piled up such a wide point lead that the sixth and last contest scheduled for tomorrow against the three crews representing the Inland Lakes Yachting Association of Minnesota and Wiscon in was canceled.

PATROLMEN-William C. Wood, from 19th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, N. Y. County, for 5 days. Henry S. Halpin, from 44th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, Bronx County, for 3 days. Edward J. Bogan, from 62d Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, Kings County, for 2 days.

A surance and related problems proposal to erect a $160,000 memorial in the Canal Zone to Major Gen. George W. Goethals, who played a leading part in building the Panama Canal, was approved today by the Senate Military Committee. The committee recommended enactment of a bill approved by the War Deapartment and the Budget Bureau to carry out recommendations of a memorial commission, headed by General John J. Pershing.

Major Francisco Mendieta, formerly in chage of the Quartermaster Department of the National Guard, has been named director of the National Bank, with residence in New York. He will pursue econimic studies for the Nicaraguan Government, either in Wahsington or New York.

Our readers may be anxious to know what came of WILLIAM ALLEN WHITE'S prayer for rain which was quoted a few days ago. He asked, it will be remembered, for another inch and, if possible, "all in one gully-washing shower "-and before the 15th of July.

Mayor La Guardia charged last night that the announced intention of Senator Royal S. Copeland, choice of the majority of the Tammany executive committee for the Democratic Mayoralty nomination, to seek the Republican nomination indicated an alliance between the Republican party and Tammany Hall.

Judge Carroll C. Hincks in the Federal court today signed an order authorizing the trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to pay a $300,000 semi-annual installment of interest which became due May 1 on the New York,

Furniture Shops of America, Inc., Grand Rapids, Mich., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 to cover 775,790 shares of $1-par-value common stock, of which 500,000 shares will be offered through underwriters first at $2.50 a share and later at the market. Of the remaining shares,

Despite the failure of his proposal for reorganization of the Federal judiciary, President Roosevelt feels that its very agitation caused the Supreme Court to reverse its position, and so advanced the country part way toward the original objectives of the bill.
One of the few instances of survival from the bite of a ferde-lance, one of the tropic's most poisonous snakes, was reported by physicians today.

A witness declared before the National Labor Relations Board today that six hours before patrolmen and special deputies of the Massillon, Ohio, police force shot into a crowd of men at headquarters of the Committee for Industrial Organization on July 11 last, one of the special officers, a foreman employed by the Republic Steel Corporation, told a companion:
Members of the Court of Appeals will come to Albany Tuesday to hear arguments and decide whether the Communist party has the right to enter the September primaries with its designations.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 855,000 bales, against 882,000 a week ago, 860,000 two weeks ago, 901,000 three weeks ago and 740,000 a year ago; of which American 301,000 bales, against 315,000 a week ago, 325,000 two weeks ago, 340,000 three weeks ago and 273,000 a year ago.

Estate, more than $10,000. To the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America, Maryknoll, N. Y., and Marquette League, 105 E. 22d St., $2,000 each: Servants of Relief for Incurable Cancer, Hawthorne, N. Y., $1,000; Sisters of St. Ursula of the Blessed Virgin, 463 W. 142d St., Missionary Sisters of the Third Order of St.

A few days ago a coroner's jury in Cook County, after an investigation of the deaths of ten men in the Memorial Day riot in South Chicago, brought in a verdict exonerating the police, ascribing the "justifiable homicides" to the attempt of an armed mob of C. I. O. strikers to force its way through police

The Soviet purge has taken a new turn into the field of youth training, it was disclosed today in an unexpected announcement that eight important officials of the Young Communist (Komsomol) organization had been removed for corrupting Soviet young people toward Troskyism and other heresies in order to use the youths for "criminal purposes."

C. I. O. and A. F. of L. lieutenants, bitter rivals on other fronts, joined hands here today in clamping down a virtual food embargo to enforce demands for a closed shop in packing plants and wholsesale warehouses.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted an economy program under which in the fiscal year 1938 no general promotions will be considered and vacancies left unfilled when this is considered in accord with efficient administrative work.

Fulton Ave, 1,171-73 (10-2609); Alfan Properties, Inc, to Central Savings Bank; de-mand, interest as per bonds; $31,500. Holland Ave (16-4569), w s, 100 ft s of Burke Ave, 116x100; Bessie Handler to State Mortgage Commission; installments, 4 to 5 per cent; $130,600.
President Roosevelt, taking the view that the controversy over reorganization of the Supreme Court changed the position of the court on many important pieces of legislation such as Social Security,

The Senate passed today the retail-pricemaintenance rider which Senator Tydings had attached to the Tax Bill for the District of Columbia and sent the measure to the House for possible concurrence in this and other amendments.

Leases of three town houses on the East Side were announced yesterday by Potter, Hamilton Co., Inc., brokers. They leased for Philip A. S. Franklin the five-story English basement dwelling at 11 East Sixtysixth Street to James Ryan for occupancy.

Today is the 154th anniversary of the birth of General Simon Bolivar, Latin-American liberator. In many countries celebrations will be held, A scheduled observance here today will be the laying of wreaths on the Bolivar monument in Central Park near West Eighty-third Street by the International League for Bolivarian Action at 8:45 A. M.

Ten thousand schools have been opened in government territory during the last few months, Jesus Hernandez, Minister of Education, said today. The problem of seeing that Madrid children go to school again is fast being solved, Mr. Hernandez added.

The Borden Company will contest any new regulations made by S. McLean Buckingham, State Milk Administrator, to maintain the price of milk in paper containers at 1 cent more than milk in glass bottles.

PEIPING, China, Saturday, July 24.--A Japanese spokesman admitted today that Japan probably would find it necessary "very soon" to demand the withdrawal of Nanking troops from southern Hopei, where they are continuing to concentrate in considerable numbers.

St. Mary's College, the little school made famous by Edward Patrick (Slip) Madigan and his football teams, was sold at auction today because it had not paid the interest on its $1,370,500 bonded indebtedness since 1934. Gerald Levin and Leland Groezinger made the only bid, $411,150.

The best sustained plant safety record in its history was reported yesterday by General Motors Corporation. During a safety contest sponsored by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board, which ran from Dec. 1, 1936, to June 30, last, the corporation had only 4.56 accidents for each 1,000,000 hours worked, resulting in only .511 day lost for each 1,000 hours worked.
Colston E. Warne, Professor of Economics and head of the Consumers Union at Amherst, attacked the administration today for "evading" the issue of distribution of wealth and income.

5th Ave. 2,064, 25x100: Eileen S. Pfeiffer to 2,064 Fifth Ave Realty Corp. 200 W 135th St, c/o A. L. Dingle; mtg $7,500 ($2). Maiden Lane, 85, 25.8x62.5; Myra A. Blum to Pauline H. Rosenberg, Great Neck (quitclaim). Hester St, 183-85. 42.1x99.10 1/2; Ralph O. L. Fay to Emigrant Bank; consideration $1.000. foreclosure.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 23--A group of fewer than 2,000 school children who have an "I. Q." of 180 and above will furnish tomorrow's social and technological geniuses, Professor Harvey W. Zorbaugh, director of New York University's Clinic for the Social Adjustment of the Gifted, told the Vassar Euthenics Institute tonight.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market. as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

The fourth-place Red Sox chased Willis Hudlin from the mound in the third inning today and won the series opener from the Indians, 6 to 2. The invaders battered the dean of the tribe's mound corps for nine hits, including five doubles,

Declaring that "I noticed in one of the New York papers this morning an article entitled 'Roosevelt Bars Fish from '39 Fair Board,' " Representative Hamilton Fish lashed out tonight against the President in a speech at the annual Putnam County Republican Committee meeting here.
The three-story private dwelling at 870 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, close to Prospect Park, has been sold by Charles L. Bussing to a prominent attorney, a client of L. L. Yearsley, for occupancy.

Billy Gillespie, 16-year-old Atlantan and a student at Scarsborough (N. Y.) School, captured the national junior interscholastic tennis championship today. He was defeated in the final round last year.
Mark Arie, 55-year-old marksman from Champaign, Ill., today captured the $4,000 open handicap event at the

With supplies of all classes light, trading improved. Steer hindquarter cuts were mostly unchanged. Forequarter cuts were sharply higher. Veal, calf and lamb were sharply higher, fresh pork cuts steady to higher. All kosher markets opened sharply higher as reported by the United States Deapartment of Agriculture.

Total volume and member trading for own account in round lots on the New York Stock Exchange declined substantially in the week ended on June 26 compared with the previous week, but the percentage of volume represented by member trading
In the main, Chrysler earnings for the second quarter exceeded expectations, and the dividend of $3.50 a share was 75 cents to $1 over Wall Street guesses early this week.
With confidence apparently widespread that there will be no war with China, Japanese attention turned tonight to the opening of a two-week special session of Parliament and to home affairs.

Rogers Hornsby, discharged manager of the Browns, surrendered his contract, which did not expire until the end of the 1938 season, and settled his claim against the American League club tonight for a sum estimated at from $7,500 to $10,000.
To those sportsmen interested in the Sandy Hook Bay breakwater project, W. E. Willis, the committee secretary, has forwarded some explanatory data with an argument or two.

The Yankee big guns spoke a noisy message against the White Sox at Comiskey Park today before a ladies' day throng of 42,000, but it lacked a note of finality. Three home runs, two triples and a double stood out in a thirteen-hit attack which whistled about the ears of John Whitehead for eight innings and finally moved the lumbering Texan off the hill in the ninth.

Charles B. Wilson, a pioneer in the automobile industry, died today at his home in Bloomfield Hills after an extended illness at the age of 65. With his brother, David R. Wilson, he was one of the founders of the Wilson Foundry and Machine Company of Pontiac.
Frank David Chase, a widely known architect and specialist in industrial plant production and construction, died today in his home at Evanston, Ill. His age was 60.

The fourth international aviation meeting opened at Zurich's Dubendorf Airfield today with new highs both for competitors and nations entered and with excellent weather prospects. There are 310 competitors from thirteen European nations, against 247 from eleven countries in 1932.

" Melodies on Parade," a musical review of the Gay Nineties, will be presented by the Caravan Theatre at Roosevelt Park, Manhattan, tonight. In Brooklyn, at Thomas Jefferson Field, "The Emperdr's New Clothes" will be the attraction, and in Richmond "Tons of Money" will be staged at Wolf's Pond Park.

The Citizens Committee organized in Johnstown, Pa., as a result of the steel strike there and dedicated to the "preservation of the inalienable constitutional right to work," after an all-day executive meeting yesterday in the Prince George Hotel, 14 East Twenty-eighth Street, announced plans to widen the scope of its work nationally.

Real estate trading centered in the West Side yesterday when housing properties proved attractive to investors. The activity also was marked by resales. The Franklin Savings Bank sold to an investing client of Mullen Woods, Inc.,
Richard F. Hyland, former Stanford University football star, and Miss Lou Landsburgh of New York, were married here last night.

As any Greenwich Villager will tell you--for they are a proud lotlife below Fourteenth Street is selfsufficient, including the life after dark. Especially the life after dark, perhaps. Your true Villager can take the uptown spots or leave them alone-they are too remote for easy knowing.

Dr. Henry S. Blank, offices in 178 E 70th St, through Culver Hollyday Co. Arthur Silver, printer, in 45 E 20th St; Manllio Co, in 576 5th Ave; E. De Grandmont, Inc, corset material, in 20 W 37th St; Review of Reviews Corp, in 114-16 E. 16th St, through Cross Brown; Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, Inc, brokers.

An Irish setter that aided in finding the body of a boy drowning victim received the plaudits of the city police department and its lifeguard master. The setter, Pete, dived into a quarry a block from the swimming pool where Douglas McManus, its master, was searching for the body of Nicholas Arvonio, 18, who drowned yesterday.

The Franklin D. Roosevelts Jr., on their wedding trip, missed a provincial welcome here. The local Prefect had ready a gift of old-vintage brandy, the largest hotel was decorated with American flags and flowers, and the citizenry assembled, last night.

Frederik Stahlberg, musician and composer and for many years musical director at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studios, died today at his home here. At one time he was assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic and first violinist in the Pittsburgh Symphony.

Two parades enlivened the convention of Business and Professional Women at Atlantic City. One was a procession showing the costumes worn by women since they broke into the business world. The farm woman in red calico and the first typist in crinoline led up through the mannish styles

Christian Edward Baker, Civil War veteran and father of Harry H. Baker, former Mayor of Norwood, died at his home here today. He was 91 years old. Mr. Baker, one of the last remaining Civil War veterans in this section, had met President Abraham Lincoln.

The ousted Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia was 46 years old today, and he observed the second of his birthdays in exile at this English resort with a quiet family party. His two sons, his daughter and the Empress were with him.

The first two of a series of Law Film Classics planned by the Film Foundation of America, Inc., of Boston, have been completed, one presenting Joseph Henry Beale, Royall Professor of Law at Harvard, in a half-hour discussion on jurisdiction for divorce and the other a discussion by Samuel Williston,
The championship ratings committee of the National Boxing Association recognized Max Schmeling today as No. 1 contender for the heavyweight championship held by Joe Louis.

Shortly after the lower house of Parliament had ratified the Yugoslav-Vatican concordat late last night it was announced that Patriarch Varnava of the Serbian Orthodox Church, who had fought against the measure, had died.

Miss Katherine Steele Beecher of this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lyman Beecher of Asheville, N. C., was married here yesterday afternoon in the chantry of Grace Church to John Steuart Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wylie Gemmell Wilson of Elizabeth, N. J. The Rev. E. Felix Kloman performed the ceremony in the presence of the two families and a few friends.

Friscomite, twelfth in the first mile of the Pine Tree Trot at the Grand Circuit meeting today, made a fast recovery to capture the next two whirls and the race. The bay horse from the Anita Arden Homestead Stable of Goshen, N. Y., trotted the winning heats in 2:04 1/4 and 2:04 with Dickerson in the sulky.

With one expedient after another failing to break the deadlock over non-intervention, the British Government to-. day finally hit upon the device of a written questionnaire, which probably will be submitted to the various governments early next week.

The Mayors of Fall River, New Bedford and Newport, R. I., today agreed to combine their efforts toward effecting resumption of service of the Fall River Line, which suspended operations after a strike last week.
More than 9,000 persons crowded this small community today to witness the celebration of the 114th anniversary of the birth of Mormonism at Hill Cumorah, near here.
Princess JULIANA and her husband, according to an Amsterdam special dispatch in this paper, have received from the citizens

An unemployment census in the State is suggested by Senator Desmond of Newburgh, who says that this could be accomplished in one day by the State Labor Department and with volunteer help. He suggests that such a survey be taken on Labor Day, much after the plan of the World War draft registration.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Chicago,, South Shore South Bend Railroad Company to issue $7,851,400 in stocks and bonds and 122,000 shares of no-par value common stock in connection with its reorganization.

District Attorney William C. Dodge announced last night that he had sent Assistant District Attorney James T. Neary to Belgrade Lakes, Me., to question Mrs. Stella M. Crater, wife of the missing Supreme Court justice, Joseph F. Crater, concerning a statement recently attributed to her that Tammany politicians blocked the investigation which followed the disappearance of the justice.

With the arrest early today of Charles Glover, 28 years old, a small-time racketeer and an exconvict, police officials here believed they had broken up the extortion plot in which at least three Hudson County business men had been threatened with death, bombings and disfigurement with acid.
Believing his son was suffering from an incurable malady, Dr. Guy Shearman Peterkin, a prominent urologist, shot the youth dead in a "mercy slaying" and then killed himself in his office here.
Jersey City rallied to beat Toronto, 5-4, tonight as Eddie Wilson drove a three-bagger in the twelfth inning and scored the deciding tally on Joe Dwyer's single.

Leading stocks eased slightly and closed irregular, after higher opening; turnover, 909,000 shares. United States Government and local traction bonds strong, other issues steady; transactions, $7,869,000.
Jesse (Pop) Haines yesterday celebrated his forty-fourth birthday one day late at Ebbets Field by'pitching his first complete game of the season, to score a 4-1 Cardinal victory over the Dodgers.

Bernard Meyer, New York sugar, broker for thirty years, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 57. Widely known as Barney Meyer in the sugar business,he had offices at 120 Wall Street. Surviving are two brothers, Joseph on Meyer of Brooklyn and Theodore Meyer of Passaic, N. J.,

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. E. Bishop Mumford of this city of the engagement of Mrs. Mumford's daughter, Miss Eileen Bingham Booker, to Thurston Greene of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Greene of Montclair, N. J.

Slender Charlie Mayo lead a field of seventy qualifiers in the annual Leewood. Golf Club invitation tournament today with a very workmanlike 35, 37-72, one shot over par. The newest business-man golfer had a two-stroke lead on Jack Creavy of Hickory and George 0. Tamblyn of Hudson River.

Two offerings of new major bond Issues, one in the tax-exempt field and the other in the public utility category, lifted the volume of new bond financing this week to $60,795,000, as compared with only $14,399,000 in new issues placed last week. During this week a year ago $63,778,000 in new bonds were placed on the market.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Conflicting factors in the situation have made the wool market somewhat irregular but the fundamental soundness of raw wool keeps prices very steady and efforts to break down prices have brought little success. Prices, west and east, are firm, as a rule, with trading more or less sporadic.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey yesterday signed a formal order making final his recently announced approval of a reorganization plan for the Roxy Theatres Corporation, owner of the Roxy Theatre, Seventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

The Bureau of Navigation and Marine Inspection has failed to provide enough certificates of efficiency to American seamen who require them to obtain employment, it was charged by the constitutional convention of the National Maritime Union yesterday afternoon.

Wheat prices fluctuated in a rather violent manner on the Board of Trade here today, within a range of around 3 cents a bushel. A firmer start in sympathy with Liverpool was followed by a decline to a new low level on a downturn in sympathy with a sharp break in July corn. A good class of buying then developed and started a rally.

A jury which heard Samuel Leibowitz of New York attack the State's case in the Scottsboro trials as a frameup, and ridicule the proceedings before Judge W. W. Callahan as a mockery of justice, retired this afternoon to weigh the guilt or innocence of Charlie Weems, one of nine Negroes accused of attacking Victoria Price, a white woman.

New York State postmasters and postal supervisors, in convention here, were advised today by Albert Goldman, postmaster of New York City, to start legal proceedings, "after a fair warning," against violators of the postal lottery laws.

The wise metropolitan mother this Summer will advise her daughter, and also her son and other members of the family, to hang their clothes on hickory limbs or anything else that may be handy, but not to go into any water not recommended by the Board of Health.

Signor F. Bishop has purchased for occupancy the two-story stucco dwelling at 292 East Chester Street, Valley Stream, L. I., from the Jamaica Savings Bank through the Lewis H. May Company, broker. The new Colonial-type brick house on Sealy Drive, Lawrence,
The House Banking Committee recommended today that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation be permitted to waive the double liability of stockholders in State banks under certain conditions.
On June 30, 1937, the gross public debt of the United States amounted to $436.39 per capital, according to an estimate released yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.
The Pere Marquette Railway, controlled by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, reported yesterday for the first six months of this year a net income of $1,091,785 after taxes and charges.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Recently John Cameron wrote a letter to THE TIMES in regard to the scant consideration given him one day when, after being informed there would be a game at the Yankee Stadium, he arrived there to find the no-game sign hanging out despite the fact that the sun shone.

Stephen Allen Norton, retired cashier of the Mount Hermon School for Boys, where Headmaster Elliott Speer was murdered in 1934, today told a Superior Court jury here that Thomas E. Elder, former dean of the school, assaulted him with a gun.
James Harper Hopper, a Civil War veteran and a former commander of Winchester Post, G. A. R., died. suddenly yesterday in his home at 612 Madison Street, Brooklyn. He was 93 years old.

Manhattan Alterations Norfolk St, 149-51, to two 6-story tenements and stores; Manchester Construction Corp. 1,819 Broadway, owner; Samuel Roth, architect; cost, $10.000. 36th St, 161-3 E, to 4-story tenement; 163 E. 36th St Corp, premises, owner; J. M. Berlinger, architect; cost, $5,000.

Joseph T. Clark, chief editorial writer of The Toronto Daily Star for nearly forty years, died today at his Summer home at GoHome Bay, Muskoga district. He was 70 years old and active until a week ago, when he suffered a heart attack.

John McDiarmid of Princeton, seventh in the national ranking; Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore., and Frank Bowden of New York gained the three remaining brackets in the semi-finals of the Eastern claycourt championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor and the Duchess's aunt, Mrs. D. Buchanan Merryman of Washington, D. C., arrived safely tonight at the Mayr-Melnhof hunting lodge in Fuschl, near Salzburg, after a minor traffic accident.

Madison Ave. 31, 4-story stone, 24.8x100; Bank for Savings in the City of New York against Thirty-One Madison Avenue Realty Corp: due, $103,110; taxes, , $100; to plaintiff for $60,000. Marble Hill Ave. 50-56, 2 2-story and 1 3-story frame dwellings, 112.5x100: Clara Eisenbrand against Emma A. Havens;

The Baireuth Festival opened here today with Chancellor Hitler's triumphal entrance. The Fuehrer rode from Haus Wahnfried through rows of Storm Troopers, crowds of townsfolk and visitors to the Princes Portal of the Festival hall, where he was received by Winifred Wagner.
Cotton-mill activity increased less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index receded to 134.0 from 138.0. It was 118.2 for the week ended July 18, 1936.

Word has been received here of the marriage of Miss Henrietta Nancy Hale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Warren K. Hale of Montreal, to William Hugh Coverdale Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Coverdale of 1,020 Fifth Avenue, this city, and Kingston, Ont., which took place last Saturday in the Church of St. James the Apostle, Montreal.

Dr. Max Euwe today won his adjourned games against Dr. Alexandre Alekhine and Herr Saemish in the migratory four-master chess tournament. The world champion forced Alekhine to resign after the thirty-seventh move in their game from the third round and won from Saemish, who was pressed for time, after the forty-fourth move.

THAT broth of a boy-o, Charles Leo Hartnett, called Gabby and also Leo the Lion, came strolling out of a room in which the Cubs were holding a little pre-game conference before advancing on the Polo Grounds yesterday. He's the head man now, is Leo the Lion, since Karl Johann Grimm came down with sciatica.

Lyn wood (Schoolboy) Rowe, the Detroit Tigers' ailing pitcher, will hurl no more this season. Manager Mickey Cochrane, who watched Rowe's futile efforts against the Athletics Thursday from the press box, said today after a conference with Acting Manager Del Baker and Coach Cy Perkins that Rowe probably would leave soon for his home in El Dorado, Ark.
Sales of Government House Rum, product of the Virgin Islands enterprise inaugurated under the New Deal, are going steadily ahead.

If figures on production and delivery for the first five months of 1937 are true indexes, the American aircraft manufacturing industry will reach a $100,000,000 production goal by the end of this year-the largest in its history-C. G. Taylor, president of the Taylor Young Airplane Company, predicted yesterday.

Deeating Paterson by 48 runs on the Stevens Institute Athletic Field today, the Hudson County eleven of the Brooklyn Cricket Club forced the Paterson C. C. back into second place and assumed the lead in the annual championship series of the New Jersey State Cricket League. The totals were 126 for Brooklyn and 78 for Paterson.
Led by Chuck Klein and Morrie Arnovich, the Phillies scored ten runs in the sixth, seventh and eighth innings today to hand the Cincinnati Reds a 13-to-11 setback in the Second game of the series.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Gruver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elbert A. Gruver of Chestnut Hill, to Victor Hicks of Flushing, Queens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Hicks of of Newberg, Ore., took place this morning at the home of her parents.

United States Senator William H. Smathers, Democrat, of New Jersey, today announced that he would give a dinner for the "freshmen" Democratic Senators at the Hotel Willard in Washington next Tuesday night.

FOR more than a decade the problem of weeding out persons who register motor vehicles under fictitious addresses has faced the State of New York. And from time to time individuals and organizations have come forward to urge such action and to submit plans for carrying out the task.

While 200 striking shipyard workers jeered and shouted from picket lines, more than 1,000 workers in 200 automobiles and 100 more afoot reported for work under heavy police escort yesterday morning at the United Dry Dock plant, foot of Fifty-sixth Street, Brooklyn.
Governor Oscar Teran of Chiriqui Province was dismissed from office today in what was believed to be a sequel to the treasure hunt in that province.

THE hitch-hiker, that dusty footed wanderer of American highways who has been out lawed in one State after another, has at last achieved a backhanded kind of revenge which no doubt will lighten many a mile of his travels.

Three convicts armed with knives escaped from Rockview penitentiary today in an automobile taken from a college student. They cut through a temporary wire fence surrounding the unwalled prison which houses Pennsylvania's electric chair, leaped into a guard's automobile which was being washed in a garage and sped away.

Energetic administration of what she terms a "mandate from the delegates" of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women will be the dominating feature of her two-year tenure of office, Miss Earlene White, newly elected head of the organization, said here today.
Mrs. Anna Linquist, who was well known here for her philanthropic activities, died last night at her shore home in suburban Woodmont. Funeral services will be held Monday afternoon.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Alice Corneille, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Corneille of this place, to Michael Hart Cardozo 4th, son of Ernest A. Cardozo of New York and the late Mrs. Emily R. Cardozo.
Price changes in the women's garment industry continued an outstanding highlight of last week's developments and evoked varying comments from trade association executives.
Once more it has been shown that "bluff is an element seldom absent from Oriental diplomacy," but bluff last week came near being converted into bloody realities.

Women and minors employed in the wearing-apparel industry and allied occupations in Rhode Island should be paid no lower than 35 cents an hour, a minimum-wage board recommended today to Thomas F. McMahon. State Director of Labor.

POOR COLLINS." he has been called by biographers, for his life was as unhappy as that of a poet too often is; and his treatment by contemporaries was as shabby as one frequently finds in the case of an outstanding creator.

That the Mediterranean basinfor generations "the theatre of countless conflicting interests"-is the crux of the contemporary European problem was demonstrated once again last week when Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, warned that Britain would fight, if necessary, to protect her interests around that inland sea.

CONQUERED: Mount Lucania, which rises 17,150 feet near the AlaskanCanadian boundary, has at last been scaled, it became known last week. On July 9 an expedition sponsored by the Harvard Institute of Geographical Exploration and the New England Museum of Natural History reached the summit.
All this week at the Country Club qualifying rounds for the men's club championship golf tournament are being played. Tonight another band concert will take place on the New London Green.
VACATIONISTS may enjoy another time-saving route to popular playgrounds when the North Atlantic air service inaugurates regular passenger trips between Eastern Canada and New York.

Miss Isabel Tuomey, 19, a student from the University of Minnesota, arrived yesterday morning for a week's visit in the city awarded for her essay writing ability by the Panhellenic House Association. She was the second prize winner in a national contest among undergraduates on the subject:

The eve of the third anniversary of Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss's murder in the Nazi putsch of July 25, 1934, was marked today by the first parade appearance of the new Austrian Storm Corps, which is designed to fulfill the same role as the Hitler Elite Guards in Germany.

To the Radio Editor: Unquestionably the worst public nuisance in New York today is our neighbors' radios. During the Summer everybody's windows are necessarily wide open and the broadcasts that come blaring simultaneously out of so many different windows - turn whole neighborhoods into bedlam.

Television may ultimately effect a complete change in methods of educating children and adults, and may revolutionize the present school systems of the country, the President's National Resources Committee reported last week.

Leo Fischer, executive secretary of the American Guild of Musical Artists, Inc., says that negotiations have been under way for some time between the Guild and the radio division of the Actors Equity Association with a view to conducting an organization drive among workers in all branches of radio.
NOMINATION: Emporia, Kan., has a population of about 14,000 . Its newspaper, The Emporia Gazette, has a circulation of about 6,000. But the editor, William Allen White,

BY the end of this year $85,000,000 worth of air-conditioning apparatus will have been sold, an increase of 60 per cent over the sales of 1936. Optimists predict that by 1945 the annual sales will amount to $350,000,000 and that no office building or factory and / no home costing more than $6,000 will be I. / without its year-round air-conditioning plant.

TYPICAL of July, the current batch of single vocal disks is fair average run of the mill. The majority are from singers who have been appearing with more or less regularity in recent lists, but two names are new and a third may be so regarded.

Statisticians of the Social Security Board, who have taken over the work of charting the trends and cost of relief in the United States, disclosed this week that the aggregate of local, State and Federal expenditures for relief is lower this year than for the same period last year.

Miss Cornelia Lines More, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry G. More of this place, and Robert Derwood Tew of Pittsburgh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Derwood Tew of Haddonfield, N. J., were married here this afternoon in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church.

The Guilds Committee for Federal Writers Publications, Inc., announced yesterday that "Italians in New York," the first of a series of nationality survey books in course of compilation by the Federal Writers Project, had been completed and would be on the early Fall publication list of Random House.

The annual soapbox derby conducted by R. H. Macy Co. will be held on the Harlem River Speedway, north from 155th Street, Manhattan, near the Polo Grounds, next Tuesday, it was announced yesterday. Vehicular traffic will be barred from the Speedway during the boys' races.

After she had traveled by automobile from Englishtown, N. J., despite a bullet wound through her chest, Stella Barodzyn, 15 years old, of 543 East Thirteenth Street, was admitted to Bellevue Hospital at 7:30 o'clock last night. Physicians described her condition as serious.

The engagement of Miss Kathleen Elizabeth Boyce, daughter of Mrs. George A. Richter of Boonton Park, to Christopher James McCulloch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter McCulloch of New York, has been announced.

SUMMER symphony in the Roman Forum has become one of the popular institutions in this country. On Wednesday and Saturday evenings, from late June to late August, eager throngs flock to the basilica of Maxentius to hear favorite conductors amid suggestive art surroundings in the open air.

A suggescion that the Duke of Windsor shirked his duty as Edward VIII to keep a date last September with his present wife, then Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, drew a belated denial today from Lord Provost Edward Watt of Aberdeen.

WASHINGTON.-In the costs of printing The Congressional Record, the Treasury might save a great deal of money if the present session of Congress came to an early adjournment. On an average, it costs $55 to print a page of The Record, and many an issue, with the appendix, runs well over 100 pages.
Scientists from the State Agriculture Department and Cornell University are attempting here to determine what causes Payne's Lake water to be poisonous for cattle at some times of the year.

MORE than 20,000 miles of Federal and State airways will be improved through the modernization program announced last week in Washington by the Bureau of Air Commerce. New radio and lighting facilities will mark the airways for the guidance of airmen from the Atlantic to the Pacific Coast, and along the northern and southern boundaries of the country.

The marriage of Miss Anne Bramhall Miles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Miles of Rumson and New York, to Robert Shippee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl C. Shippee of Rumson, took place here at noon today in the ballroom of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, of which her father was president for many years. The Rev. William Calvin Colby, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Rumson, performed the ceremony.

Brokers in many home sections in Bergen County, N. J., report that the present Summer has been the busiest both in respect to sales and building activity that has been experienced for many years. In the Englewood and Teaneck areas and ever farther north in and around Dumont home construction is being well maintained, and there is a steady demand for medium-priced dwellings.

Dave Margolis, the defending champion, survived the second round of the national one-wall handball championship tournament yesterday by defeating Anthony Racaniello of the home club on the Ravenhall courts. Margolis, representing the Kennedy Club, won by the score of 21-11, 21-9.

WASHINGTON.-If deposited in the new National Archives Building, the mass of documents and papers now being received by the General Accounting Office will exhaust all the space in the structure in ten years, Harvey C. Mansfield warns in a report published by the President's Committee on Administrative Management.

THE George Abbott office is doing something about it, faithfully, consistently and, one might add, feverishly. A sample of a reply: "Dothan,, Ala., is a city of, 20,000 with a large trade territory to draw from- within a fifty-mile area in Alabama, Flor-. ida and Georgia.

AS the latest in a long series of contributions to science and industry. Charles Franklin Kettering, who in 1911 invented the self-starter for automobiles, now is sponsoring a profoundly significant research into the nature of chlorophyll,
The Bees today combined a long-distance hitting attack with five-hit pitching by Jim Turner to defeat the Pirates, 9 to 0, for the Bees' fifth consecutive victory.

Twenty-one years ago the Japanese beetle made its first appearance in New Jersey. It lost no time in making itself a nuisance and a curse. In half a dozen years or so it covered a territory of 2,500 square miles. Since some time in June it has been raiding New Jersey.

Rosenna, a little 3-year-old daughter of The Satrap, paid big dividends to the chief stockholder of Delaware Park today when she carried the silks of William duPont's Foxcatcher Farms to a surprise victory in the $10,000 added Newcastle Handicap, closing feature of the inaugural meeting.

Fourteen hundred returning regular army officers, men and members of their families from Hawaii and the Panama Canal Zone will land at the Brooklyn Army Base, Fifty-eighth Street and First Avenue, when the U. S. A. transport Republic, largest of the army's passenger-carrying vessels, docks tomorrow morning at 8:15 o'clock.

Suggestions for a "minimum program" to advance the ideals of democracy were made by members of the Wellesley Institute for Social Progress today at a panel discussion which ended the two-week conference.

Slum areas contain three distinct districts having varying stages of possible construction, and any plans for slum removal should take that fact into consideration, declares James Felt, head of the realty board bearing his name.

Bolstered by a fine century by Leonard Hutton, youthful Yorkshire first-wicket player, England's revamped eleven tallied 358 runs for nine wickets against New Zealand in the second cricket test match at Old Trafford today.
RADIO showmen, convinced that "the play's the thing" for the Summer air, continue to book more dramatic productions for August's sultry "ether."

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. R. Thomas Watts Jr. of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Watts, to John Overton Henderson of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Brosius Henderson of Washington, and Trivium, Bedford County, Va.

Two thousand striking meat packers and wholesale grocery truck drivers reached a twenty-four-hour truce with their employers tonight after a four-day strike, but the agreement provided no alleviation of a food shortage caused by the strike tie-up.

An appeal to voters to use care and discrimination in signing petitions for would-be candidates for the City Council on the ground that opponents of the new city charter and proportional representation were seeking to packk the ballot" with the names of hundreds of candidates and thus bring proportional representation into disrepute was issued yesterday by Samuel K. Maccabee, chairman of the Civic Policy Association.

Accompanied by guides who will "tote" their canoes across the oldtime "carries" linking the lakes and waterways, once the only means of entrance to the Adirondack wilderness, members of the St. Regis camp colony next weekend will join in another picnic outing featuring the Summer life on the St. Regis chain of lakes.

IN London, in Palestine, in Geneva, in New York and elsewhere a 400-page volume in a blue paper cover is being carefully studied and criti cized line by line. It is the recent report of the Royal Commission on Palestine which makes farreaching proposals for the future status and government of that country and the adjoining Arabian territories.

Milton Solomon Day was observed at Manhattan Beach yesterday by members of tire Democratic Veterans Organization of the city. Among the 40,000 persons who exhausted locker facilities by early afternoon were more than 15,000 veterans and their families.

PROFESSOR ARTHUR MAYER, the eminent educator of Times Square, stood at the subway entrance of the Rialto Theatre skeptically scrutinizing a huge billboard which blazoned forth the slogan "Crime Doesn'tO Pay." Inside the theatre the patrons stood five rows deep, fascinated by trailers plugging one .of Professor Mayer's screen presentations entitled "Hollywood Cowboy."

This afternoon at St. John's Episcopal Church Miss Rose Whitman, daughter of Mrs. Chatfield Whitman of Boston and Manchester and Hendricks Hallett Whitman of Old Greenwich, Conn., became the bride of Channing Frothingham Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Channing Frothingham of Boston. The Rev. Bradford H. Burnham, rector of the church, officiated.

Saturday night the Lake George Show Boat will inaugurate the August social season with a gala ball. W. B. Woodbury, president of the Lake George Association, announced today that the annual meeting of the association will be held at the Lake George Club on Monday, Aug. 16.

By breaking fifty straight targets R. H. Helsel was the winner of the Lewis class shoot over the Jamaica Bay traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday. H. A. Kludt, with 43, took the trophy in the second class. A doubles event went to D. S. Wegg. He had 18 out of a possible 24 targets.

William T. Cobb, twice Governor of Maine, died at his home here today after a long illness. He was 80 years old. Mr. Cobb was elected Governor in 1904 and re-elected in 1906. In later years he refused the Republican nomination for United States Senator. President Hoover appointed him, in 1932, to head a Maine committee against hoarding money.

Through streets draped with black flags, throngs in mourning and the air heavy with incense the body of Patriarch Varnava was taken for the last time this evening to Belgrade Cathedral, where it will lie in State.

The reaction in utility circles to that part of the report of President Roosevelt's National Resources Committee on "Technological Trends and National Policy" which was devoted to present-day problems surrounding the power and light industry was favorable as well as spontaneous and undivided.

A July Festival, the first of a series of dinner dances arranged by a committee of patronesses from the North and South Shores for debutantes of this and future seasons and for young married members of society, will be held here at the Atlantic Beach Club on Wednesday.

The Wenjo Realty Corporation has just completed at 1,417 Parker Street, in the Unionport section of the Bronx, a brick two-family house on a plot fronting 25 feet. The lot is 125 feet in depth, providing facilities for a rear garden and a twocar garage.

The marriage of Miss Doris Ruth McCartney, daughter of George R. McCartney of this place and the late Mrs. McCartney, to Roy Durell Grimmer Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Roy D. Grimmer, also of Garden City, took place here this afternoon in the Cathedral of the Incarnation. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frederic F. Bush.

The National Labor Relations Board, created less than two years ago "to diminish the causes of labor disputes," has had a busy time. Since the Supreme Court last April upheld the Wagner act, more than 3,000 new cases have been filed with the board; approximately 2,000 cases are now pending.
Stanton M. Berkey, 22, of Detroit and Mrs. Margaret Campbell of Columbia, S. C., were killed in an automobile accident near here today. Seven other persons were injured.

Mr. and Mrs. John W. Richmond of this city gave a supper dance tonight at the Westchester Country Club in Rye at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Jeannette Richmond, who also celebrated her birthday, to Walter Jennings Gano Jr., also of Mount Vernon.

With the Hotel Flagler, Fallsburgh, N. Y., filled to capacity with 800 week-end guests, the waiters, waitresses and bus boys went on a sitdown strike at 6 o'clock tonight, disrupting the service and causing general consternation among the guests and management.

While Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey prepares his case against J. Richard (Dixie) Davis and eleven other alleged leaders of the $100,000,000-a-year policy racket the game flourishes in Harlem and other sections of the city where
Scoring one goal in each of the six periods of play, Rumson defeated the Elephants today on Herbert Memorial Field at Rumson Country Club in a closely contested polo match by a score of 6 to 5.

The strike of building laborers, which has lasted four weeks, ended this morning when the union voted to go back to work Monday, accepting an arbitration offer of the Greenwich Contractors and Builders Association.

While realty and business interests are watching the construction progress in the World's Fair grounds, near Flushing, with keen interest and are preparing for a great volume of renewed activity during the period of the fair, residents in the immediate vicinity, points out Edward A. MacDougall, president of the Queensboro Corporation, are looking ahead to the time when the fair grounds will be permanently laid out and dedicated as the Flushing Meadows Park.
Postmaster General Farley addressed a rally of 14,000 Democrats here today, and within forty-five minutes after his arrival boarded his train and was en route to Chicago.
John Tevis Harwood, formerly vice president and general manager of the Roland Park Company, died here last night in Union Memorial Hospital after an illness of several months. His age was 75.

Two 20-year-old youths, who were said to have been caught in the act of looting a parked automobile in front of 145 West Forty-ninth Street yesterday afternoon, were being held on charges of grand larceny at Police Headquarters last night pending possible action against them by Buffalo police.

Lou Gehrig undertook single-handed today to check the amazing tailspin into which the Yankees have unaccountably fallen, but he was not quite equal to the task, and the champions, in the second skirmish of the crucial series with the inspired White Sox, went down to their third straight defeat before 22,500 fans, 6 to 5, in ten innings.

Society members, both young and old, this season have forsaken the North Shore beaches adjoining their estates in favor of private swimming pools. Many parties that formerly were held on the sand at the shore are now staged with the central setting of the pool in the garden.

Miss Mary Sharkey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Sharkey of East Orange, and Joseph Francis Boylan of Baltimore, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Boylan, were married this morning in the Church of Our Lady of the Most Blessed Sacrament here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Stafford A. Blake.
IT rather looks as though Barre Lyndon will take the place of Edgar Wallace in the London theatre. The methods of the two writers are dissimilar, but the effect is much the same.

With steel production at or approaching the highest levels in history in most important countries of the world, under the pressure of rearmament and industrial modernization, there has been brisk competition for iron ore and other raw materials of steel-making.

Certain plant diseases seem to be Inevitable in warm, moist midsummer weather. Rose black spot will flourish, unless forestalled with weekly sprays or dusts; phlox in shady corners will almost mvariably get its white coating of mildew, unless frequently dusted with sulphur.

Calling attention to the fact that last Thursday was the fifth anniversary of the signing of the Federal Home Loan Bank Act, Frank O. Schneider, a director of the United States Building and Loan League, says that the five-year job of coordinating the scattered units of the business has been done effectively. More than 3,800 institutions are now bank members.

The Southern rail carriers today petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to intervene in the case of Scott Brothers, Inc., of New York, in which Division 5 set a precedent by ruling that railroad pick-up and delivery services were subject to the Motor Carrier Act, sometimes known as Part II of the Interstate Commerce Act.

Despite the drought and the damage to the crop by black rust in certain areas, indications are that the United States this year will have a wheat yield that will compare favorably with the 932,000,000 bushels produced in 1931.

As little as $1.11 a week will provide a proper, wholesome and nutritious diet for a baby, it has just been disclosed by a series of nutrition studies made by the Department of Health to help mothers of limited incomes and to cooperate with the Home Relief Bureau.

Foreign cotton interests evidently were disturbed by the White House statement that farm legislation had become imperative in view of prospects of a 14,500,000-bale crop and prices abroad declined $2 a bale yesterday. Weakness in foreign quotations. with subsequent heavy liquidation here, forced prices on the Cotton Exchange off $1.50 a bale, with December below 11 cents at one time.

Cecil Hanover, owned and driven by Dr. W. F. Vail of Greenwich, Conn., easily won the Class B trot at the Driving Park today. In the Class C trot and pace Bishop Hanover, owned by Mrs. William D. Kraft of White Plains, was the victor in two of three heats.
WITH his production of "A Doll's House" luring the cstomers up Central City's rocky road to the Opera House, Jed Harris late last week went about the business of being an International Producer.

Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Van Sinderen of 40 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, and Washington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Van Sinderen, to Chauncey Fox Howe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Harrison Howe of Buffalo.

" Follow the herring fleet!" is a call sent out every year in Scotland and is responded to by lassies who follow the herring fishers round the country's coastline to cure the catch. The job is dirty, but it offers as compensation a golden opportunity for travel to girls who would never otherwise get out of some isoanlated len.
MR. DEUTSCH'S attention is centered mainly on the history of psychiatry in America, and his emphasis within this span appears to be placed on the sociological and hygienic aspects of the subject.
AHITHERTO unknown romance in the life of Robert Browning is revealed in a book which Frederick A. Stokes Company is to publish on Sept 9. "Robert Browning and Julia Wedgwood:

Increased transit facilities in Brooklyn will soon cause additional real estate activity in that borough, predicts I. Jerome Riker, broker, in pointing out the advantages resulting from the new crosstown subway and the Marine Park Bridge
The Citizens Military Training Camp regiment here will honor American war veterans tomorrow in the seoond formal review and .parade of this year's training season.

HERE is another novel about divorce-a subject which may seem to many readers of contemporary fiction to have been treated pretty thoroughly already. Not often, however, has it been approached by a novelist of E. M. Delafield's skill and intuition.
W. L. Hardin of Atlanta, Ga., was elected president of the Gideons International Society at the thirtyeighth annual convention of the group in the Hotel Monterey here today.
Japan's most ambitious aerial attempt. a non-stop flight from Tokyo to New York, in an all-Japanese designed and built "wonder plane," is expected to be launched in the near future.
Mrs. Julie Rive-King, Chicago pianist who was one of the latest surviving pupils of Franz Liszt, died today at a private nursing home here. She was 82 years old.

NEXT Wednesday evening George King Raudenbush, founder and director of the Harrisburg Symphony Orchestra, will make his New York debut at Lewisohn Stadium. Mr. Raudenbush, born in Pennsylvania, started his career as a violinist.

Gross value of mineral production in the Province of British Columbia in the first half of 1937 was $36,383,540, an increase of $12,661,241 or 53.4 per cent over the same period in 1936, according to a review of the mining industry compiled by the government and released this week.
This community will celebrate its annual holiday on Aug. 28, when the Smithtown Horse Show will be held at Fifty Acre Field in St. James under the auspices of the Smithtown Club.

To the Art Editor: ALTHOUGH a member of the Philadelphia Art Alliance, and having seen the -exhibition -of non-objective paintings, I did not have the pleasure of hearing Baroness Rebay when she spoke.
A dispute in the State Democratic party over selection of a nominee to succeed Senator Joseph T. Robinson brought the name of his widow to the forefront today as a possible independent candidate.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Nichols of West Newton, Mass., and Walpole, N. H., have announced to friends here the engagement of Nichols's daughter, Miss Marjorie Nichols, to Alexander Humphrey Beard of this city, son of Mrs. James W. Beard of Larchmont, at N. Y., and the late Mr. Beard.
The engagement of Miss May Nora Shaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Shaw of this place, to William A. Shea, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ashley P. Shea of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents.

THE prospect that the United States may shortly have a West Coast short-wave station designed to broadcast to the Far East was enhanced this Week as Examiner George H. Hill recoMmended to the Federal Communications Commission that an application of General Electric Company be granted.

Recent changes in the Florida angling laws were reported today by Frank T. Bell, Commissioner of the United States Bureau of Fisheries. Certain among the new laws have been advocated by the United States Bureau of Fisheries for some time, particularly one which provides a closed season on black bass, it was made known.

For the first time in forty-four years the defender of the America's Cup was built elsewhere from the Herreshoff Yard in Bristol, R. I., on the shore of Narragansett Bay. Starting with the Vigilant, in 1893, the Defender, Columbia, Reliance, Resolute and Rainbow all were constructed there.

For the first time in six years new homes built during 1936 in 310 leading cities exceeded the requirements of the estimated population increase in those cities, E. C. Crabb, executive vice president of the Investors Syndicate, Minneapolis, revealed yesterday.
One of the most important outdoor events of the Shelter Island season will be the fourth annual water carnival, to be held at the New Prospect Beach Club, on Aug. 7.

Paul Kerby, British conductor, made his first appearance of the season with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium last night before an audience of 6,500. Mr. Kerby had arranged a program which, with the exception of the Cesar Franck symphony,

Sheriff Percy T. Egglefield of Essex County, N. Y., and two husky State troopers arrived today to take John Montague back to face a seven-year-old robbery charge. "We're taking no chances," said the 150-pound Sheriff, who told of reading about Montague's strongman feats. "Monte's a powerful boy."

An Empire City track record set a generation ago went into the discard yesterday as Mrs. C. S. Howard's champion, Seabiscuit, sped the mile and a sixteenth of the Yonkers Handicap in 1:441-5 before 15,000 persons.
Turquoise and blanket bedecked Navajo headmen threatened rebellion against the white man's government today and sounded warnings against proposed reduction of their grazing stock.
JUST as his vast and tangled investment enterprise is about to burst like the bubble that it is, Lionel Ballantine is murdered.

There's many a head undergoing a terrific scratching in Washington this week-end as political thinkers attempt to "dope out" the answer to the all-absorbing question: Why was President Roosevelt beaten in the court fight?

The Royals won their second game in ten with Newark this season by scoring a 6-4 victory today. The Bears still lead in the current series, two games to one, but their first-place margin was reduced to eighteen and one-half games.
