Sharp debate marked the fifth day of the constitutional convention of the National Maritime Union when delegates attempted yesterday to draft a constitution under which seamen on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts and the Great Lakes would be governed.

Brazil's economic progress in the coming five years will amaze the world, V. F. Boucas, financial adviser to the Brazilian Government and member of the mission which accompanied Arthur de Souza Costa, Brazilian Finance Minister, to this country to discuss trade problems of the two countries and negotiate the establishment of a $60,000,000 currency stabilization fund, told THE TIMES yesterday.

MUTRALS which suggest the background of an industry are becoming popular as office decorations. A great variety of techniques and materials are used, for the modern mural artist does not confine himself to the traditional wall surfaces. Sheets of veneer with the graining showing in some parts of the picture, cork, linoleum and glass are some of the new backgrounds.

The Easy-to-Own Homes Organization sold eighty-five properties with a sales value of $606,035 during the first six months this year, Russell Page, sales director, announced at a recent meeting at the Hotel Croyden of representatives of ten cooperating brokerage concerns.

Potpourri: Fisherman's sidelight: Biloxi, Miss., claims it has some 500 boats employed in "shrimping." In addition to native Americans in this industry are many of French-Acadian and Slavonian ancestry. A religious custom calls for the blessing of the shrimp boats, which are usually two-masted schooners. They travel from three to thirty-five miles into the Gulf of Mexico.

American statesmen have frequently stated that a general war in any part of the world would severely injur?? the interests of the United States, even though we succeeded in remaining neutral. This is particularly true of a war in the Orient.

Racing for the July cups under the burgee of the Yacht Racing Squadron of the Country Club of Westhampton Beach came to an end today on Moriches Bay. The wind was southwest and of moderate strength, sending the craft over the championship courses of the Speonk Shore in good time.

After all these years of glasses raised high down at Mory's, and voices too, a cloud thick with legal billows has settled down on the copyright of Yale's ancient "Whiffenpoof Song." Baa! Baa! Baa! Yesterday the Federal Court was requested to see through it.

Mrs. Harry Frank Jr.'s veteran bay gelding Clifton's Beau, who had scored in all but one of the classes in which he competed, captured the hunter championship at the close of the Jersey Shore Horse Show at the Boxwood Farm today. Smoulder, owned by Harry H. Hess, took the reserve award.
Harry E. Elder, placement bureau director for Indiana State Teachers College, studied tonight an order for a "jack-of-all-trades" school teacher.

Gene Sarazen of Brookfield Center, Conn., George Smith of Chicago and Harry Adams of Nashville reached the halfway post in Chicago's $10,000 open golf tournament today in a three-way tie for first place.

On their way to manoeuvres at Pine Camp, Great Bend, the Seventh Regiment of the 107th Infantry, New York National Guard, marched down Park Avenue shortly after midnight last night to entrain at Grand Central Terminal.

With the season well launched, the Block Island calendar of activities is lengthening. Sponsored by the Athletic Association, baseball games will be played at the Spring House Field Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday of each week, the postponed games being scheduled for Thursdays.
Everett Warner and Will How Foote both received the William 0. Goodman Memorial Award in the Lyme Art Association's exhibition of paintings and sculpture, current until Aug. 29 at Old Lyme.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Danehy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael L. Danehy of this city, was married to Richard C. Goodwin, son of Thomas J. Goodwin of Hastings and the late Mrs. Goodwin, this morning in St. Bernard's Church here.
The underwater hunt for White River's reputed "monster" terminated abruptly today when C. B. Brown, a professional diver, decided against further explorations on the floor of the deep river.

An unusual program of music education for the blind is being introduced this month at Camp Lighthouse, the Summer children's camp maintained by the New York Association for the Blind at Barnegat Bay, Waretown, N. J. There,

Greyhound, America's fastest trotter, with a mark of 1:57 1/4, will attempt to lower Peter Manning's fifteen-year-old world record of 1:59 2/4 on Aug. 10, the day preceding the renewal of the rich Hambletonian at Good Time Park.

Inconsistency was charged to the National Labor Relations Board today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, which, in an analysis of more than 200 formal rulings by the board, said that these decisions had not provided definite interpretations so that employers could understand the extent of their obligations and rights under the Wagner act.
Warrior's Husband, Julian Thompson's comedy of the legendary Amazons, adapted for an hour broadcast by the Radio Playhouse Acting Company WNYC, 12 noon.

An apology is due Onkel Franz Frisch for having referred to his Cardinals as the almost gasless Gas House Gang. Yesterday the tough lads from the other side of the Mississippi River gave the Dodgers the worse beating suffered by any team in the National League this season, clubbing them into submission by the humiliating count of 20 to 2.

The Bay Ridge Savings and Loan Association of Brooklyn has received a certificate of insurance protecting savings of investors up to $5,000 on each account from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, according to an official announcement today.

Mr. and Mrs. Ansel Phelps are at Mount Kinoe in Maine. Patrick J. Hurley, former Secretary of War, has arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria from Washington. Mrs. Elgin R. L. Gould of the Westbury is at Roland Park, Baltimore.
Douglas Fonda, Orange, N. J., broker-sportsman, continued his domination in the third annual Amsterdam power-boat regatta today to emerge victorious with a twoday total of 2,969 points.

The United States and Great Britain divided the opening two singles matches of the Davis Cup challenge round at Wimbledon. After Henry Wilfred (Bunny) Austin, main hope of the defending British team, had routed Frank Parker, 6-3, 6-2, 7-5, Don Budge, American ace, took the measure of Charles Edgar Hare,

Buyers of building plots at recent auction sales held by T. Edward Breuer at Babylon Pines and Oak Hills, L. I., included Walter S. O'Niel, Herbert N. Smith, Christopher Schaeffner, Fannie Tavolicci, James Doyle, Peter Foley, Martin Small, Henry Kennedy of New York City and Charles Miller,

Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their week-end house parties attended the Midsummer Ball tonight at the Southampton Beach Club. White floodlights simulating moonlight illuminated the breakers in front of the clubhouse, and blue floodlights were used in the lighting of the pool off the rear terrace.

Near the banks of Oconaluftee there is a natural amphitheatreacross whose green floor is moving, this Summer, a vivid picture of Cherokee Indian history from 1540-the time of De Soto-to the present day.

After early irregularity yesterday stocks closed firm and generally higher. Gains carried the steel, motor and utility groups into high levels for the current movement. Despite the fact that a large number of traders were absent from the "floor" for the week-end, trading was on a slightly heavier scale.
Swift mail planes streaking across Alaskan skies are putting an end to one of the Postoffice Department's most picturesque servicesmail-carrying dog sleds.

Donald Hume, Brooklyn College star, who has been the tournament sensation thus far, eliminated two rivals to move into the semi-final round of the annual Metropolitan Public Parks tennis singles championship competition yesterday at Forest Park in Woodhaven.

President Roosevelt will promote at least twenty-six army officers to the rank of major general or brigadier general during the next year. A survey of the army's high command today showed that, in addition to three major generals who will retire this Fall, seven of the army's twenty-one major generals and nine brigadier generals will retire upon reaching the age of 64 next year.

Charm of Oakledge, well-styled chestnut mare owned by Mr. and Mrs. Roger A. Young of White Plains, N. Y., had to be content with the reserve ribbon in the three-gaited championship sweepstakes closing the annual horse show here today.

The Misses Sallie Mellon, Anne Gay and Marion Geer, Mrs. Dwight F. Davis Jr. and Mrs. August Belmont Jr. are shown on the beach at Southampton, pictured above in the center, while Miss Peggy Stevenson is on her way to the beach. Mrs. Kenneth O'Brien is in her garden at Chateaubrien, where she is passing the Summer with her family.

Completion this Summer of a $10,000,000 campus expansion program at the University of Texas and plans for a wide extension of its courses to "average citizens" in the Fall forecast a new era for education in this State, university authorities stated today.
Foreign Secretary Carlos Manuel Larrea is preparing a reply to the proposal of the Peruvian commissioners to refer the boundary question to The Hague.
This spa assumed a gay appearance this week-end as cottagers coming for the racing season augmented the throngs here for the long season.

Summer activities are in full swing in this Green Mountain resort, with golf, riding, tennis, swimming and boating as the leading occupations. Several week-end commuters are making use of the Equinox Airport this season and many visiting planes are seen here during the week. The new sport of faldboating, introduced to Manchester by Roland Palmedo, has proved popular, especially on the fast waters of the Battenkill between here and Arlington.

It was ninety years ago that the Bay State, a brand-new steamer, the largest and fastest on Long Island Sound, sailed from Fall River, Mass., for New York, opening a service that Bostonians and New Yorkers found pleasing as generation followed generation.

The Maidstone Club's annual twoday men's invitation doubles tournament started today with Sidney B. Wood Jr., former Wimbledon champion and Davis Cup player, teamed with J. Gilbert Hall of Orange, N. J., ranked No. 10 nationally, as top-seeded players.

The Building Employes Industrial Union of America announced yesterday through its general organizer, Joseph Zack, that it would hold a mass meeting at the Manhattan Opera House, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street, Thursday evening. to vote on C.I.O. affiliation.
A voluntary petition in bankruptcy was filed in Federal court yesterday by Max Rudnick, former burlesque producer, of 173 West Seventy-eighth Street.

Heading down the Sound, steering courses up from the Chesapeake, Delaware River and the Barnegat waterways, and converging from Boston, Maine ports and Buzzards Bay is an enormous flotilla of yachts this week, bound, of course, for Newport and the cup races.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Alker of Sands Point, L. I., are house guests of Mr. and Mrs. William Van Alstyne of New York at Beech Hill, the Van Alstyne estate here. Mrs. T. J. Van Aystyne of Albany also is the guest of her son and daughter-in-law.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended July 21, aggregated $8,908,000,000, or slightly above the total reported for the preceding week and 2 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

A group of more than 2,500 musical instruments, ranging from harmonicas to organs, is to be shown at the Music Trade Convention, which will open tomorrow at the Hotel New Yorker. The exhibit will be open to the general public on Thursday .

The promotion of democratic control within labor unions rather than government regulation is advocated as the remedy for labor racketeering and other existing evils of industrial disputes in a report by the subcommittee on labor unions of the City Club of New York. The report was made public yesterday by Richard S. Childs.

Exploding out of a trap at the seventeenth hole, when defeat seemed imminent, Charlie Mayo Jr. of Lido saved his match with Jimmy Lee in the Leewood Golf Club invitation tournament today and moved into the semi-final round on the heels of a 1-up victory.

EVEN the least informed layman has probably long realized, in a vague fashion, that the modern school must prepare its pupils to meet new needs in changing ways of existence, to shoulder new responsibilities in citizenship, to go not quite helpless toward an adult world which is so largely mechanized.

THE glamour of Hollywood, on which radio, magazines and manufacturers have capitalized for years, finally is being employed by the screen for its own profit. The public has shown a peculiar susceptibility to anything bearing the name of Hollywood. It has been placed on all manner of products.

ORDERS for thirty-two of its in-line engines have been received by the Menasco Engineering Company from the Ryan Aeronautical Company of San Diego. Both the 125 and 150 horsepower types are included, and delivery is expected within ninety days.
Lulu Strong, from the Indianapolis Stables of Leo C. McNamara, streaked to victory in the $600 2:12 pace today, feature race of the program closing the first week's Grand Circuit meeting.
High fiscal officials indicated today that few rises in pay promotions or new jobs would be given to Federal employes in this fiscal year.

The Old Greenwich Garden Club will hold its annual flower show on Sept. 15 at the June Binney Memorial Parish House. Mrs. A. M. Morris of Rocky Point is chairman of the show committee, assisted by Mrs. Edwin Binney Jr., Mrs. Gilbert 3. Bogart, Mrs. George C. Case, Mrs. Kenneth Coffin, Mrs. M. C. Davidson, Mrs. James M. Farrar, Mrs. Will H. Farrell, Mrs. Allan F. Kitchel and Mrs. Walter Koempel.
Striking the eye of all who witness the America's Cup match will be the bulging sails of the contesting yachts. There will be larger spreads of canvas than there were the last time.

ONE of the attractive hidden garden spots in the Park Avenue area below Fifty-ninth Street may be seen in the rear yard of the apartment house at 417 Park Avenue, southeast corner of Fifty-fifth Street.

Three gains more than offset four losses in THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity, which has advanced to 110.1, a recovery high, for the week ended July 17. It was 109.7 for the previous week and 100.5 for the corresponding week last year.

The regular regatta of the Sayville Yacht Club was sailed today with the Domino Yacht Club of East Patchogue acting as host instead. Sixty boats participated and the regatta committee was assisted by such sailing veterans as Judge Albert Van Winklen of Bay Shore, Joseph W. Lawrence of Babylon and Nathaniel Norton of Sayville.
ABOUT-To change from one tack on the wind to the other. ABAFT-Toward the stern, or between the object named and the stern. AFT-Near the stern. ALOFT-Up the mast or stay; above the deck.

CONSIDERABLE spottiness in retail trade throughout the country was again in evidence last week. Several areas fared well, but in others sales volume showed little or no increase over the comparative period a year ago.

Albert W. Noonan, technical director of the National Association of Assessing Officers, calls attention to the fact that the State Tax Commission of Missouri in its recent report strongly urged that the State University establish and conduct a course in valuation and appraisal of real estate.
Pompoon, second to War Admiral in both the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, was just another race horse to 30,000 sweltering spectators at Arlington Park today.

Shocked by reports of terrible suffering among thousands of migratory families in the San Joaquin Valley, where they are said to be menaced by starvation and disease and without shelter from the broiling sun, California newspapers and public officials are calling upon Governor Merriam to take the initiative in a new attempt to come to grips with the problem of indigent transients.

The marriage of Miss Jeanette Clarke Dickie of New York, daughter of Walter Scott Dickie of Pittsfield, Mass., to Archibald Fleming Bogle, also of New York, son of the Very Rev. and Mrs. Andrew N. Bogle of Edinburgh, Scotland, took place here this afternoon at the Summer home of Mr. and Mrs. Grinnell Martin, cousins of the bridegroom.

The writer of the following letter is senior United States Senator from Alabama and chairman of the Senate Committee on Education and Labor. He is one of the authors of the Black - Connery Wages - and - Hours Bill, now awaiting action by the Senate. His co-author was the late Representative William P. Connery Jr. of Massachusetts.

The maladjustment between the Marxist theory of the "withering away" of the State and the Stalinist practice of the "highest development of the State, is matched in the international field by a corresponding maladjustment between the old Bolshevist slogan of "world revolution" and the Stalinist slogan of "socialism in a single country."

A fifteen-mile breeze today sent Harold S. Vanderbilt's undefeated America's Cup contender Ranger and Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee on a hurriedly called unofficial in which there were no formal records kept.
Health officers began a mass attack here today on the syphilis plague by polling Chicagoans on the question of submitting to free secret blood tests by family doctors.
Those who come to Cape Cod to view its old houses are expected to be interested in the news that two beautiful old dwellings, one in Yarmouth and ne at Barnstable,

Sydney S. Bowman, close friend of George Palmer Putnam, announced today a reward of $2,000 for any information which would "definitely clear up the mystery" surrounding the disappearance of Amelia Earhart and her navigator, Captain Fred No??nan.

Herbert S. Lester, "the king of San Miguel Island," has gone back to his little domain after a fortnight here, to carry on the lonesome but muscle and health building life begun at the close of the World War.
A wad of $520 in bills will buy a lot of lollypops, but when an 8-year-old lad pulled the wad out yesterday and peeled off a ten-spot for a onecent lollypop he got not candy but, a Policeman.
Deep down in an anthracite coal mine of the last century, when the men stopped work for lunch, a fiddle-smuggled into the mine without the boss' knowledge earlier in the day-could be heard.

The long-gathering storm clouds that have burst over Yugoslavia this week as a result of the efforts of Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch and Father Anton Korosetch, the Minister of the Interior, to force through ratification of a concordat with the Vatican reveal that the already unpopular Stoyadinovitch regime has aroused the bitterest religious and political passions in Serbia.

A peace pact was signed today, ending a five-week-old sit-down strike at the Robeson-Rochester Corporation. The agreement was signed by attorneys representing the Iron, Steel and Tin Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate; the Robeson-Rochester Employes Association and the company.

The United Mine Workers called off a strike today in one of Southwestern Pennsylvania's largest "captive" mines, leading to reports that the union would end strikes in all steelcompany-owned pits except those of the Republic Steel Corporation.

Last month brought an increase of 54 per cent in the business of the cooperative banks of Massachusetts over the business of June of last year, Warner M. Allen, executive secretary of the Massachusetts Cooperative Bank League, reported today.

Mrs. Ethel M. Burbank, wife of Lieutenant Lyman H. Burbank, post commander at the Eggerts Crossing Armory of the 112th Field Artillery in Lawrence Township, near here, was found dead today in her automobile in a field about 600 feet from the reservation.

A six-pound new-born baby boy who could not breathe normally was saved yesterday by members of Fire Rescue Squad 3, aiding Dr. Leonard S. Rakow, the attending physician, in the Mount Eden Maeternity Hospital at 199 Mount Eden Avenue, the Bronx.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Richard Thaddeus Doughtie of Helena, Ark., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Stanton Doughtie, to Dr. James McRae Bethea of this city and South Carolina.

A new interpretation of "interstate commerce" that was said to show "the need for the enactment of the Miller-Tydings bill" in resale price maintenance and clarification of the graduated discount and price differential issues under the Robinson-Patman act were cited here yesterday by trade and legal authorities as resulting from the dismissal by the Federal Trade Commission of the complaints in the Kraft-Phenix Cheese Corporation and the Montgomery Ward-Bird Son, Inc., cases.

One of the greatest mass migrations of young people in history will get under way Thursday when the first of eight ships chartered by the British Boy Scout Association, each carrying 1,000 Scouts, will sail for the international jamboree in the Netherlands.

The Eklutna government school for Indians has decided to cease pumping "culture" into the natives and to concentrate on teaching dog breeding and reindeer farming to help them wrest a living from the Northland.

The serious knitters who stuck to she craft after its spectacular popularity passed now make up a group of consistent devotees who knit themselves two or more outfits a year. Knitting is no longer just a craze. Shop folk say it has found its level and has become a staple interest,
Woman-and her new Fall clothes-will become a matter of bright importance here next week and early in August as women's wear buyers from the forty-eight States congregate for the Fall apparel markets.

SOUTHAMPTON-The thirtieth annual flower show of the Garden Club of Southampton and the Southampton Horticultural Society will be held next Wednesday and Thursday in the auditorium of the parochial school in Hill Street. Artistic settings have been planned for the display of the many exhibits and novel competitions that generally feature the exhibition.

A reorganization plan for the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., sponsored by the bondholders' representative committee headed by Joseph P. Ripley and approved by the preferred stockholders' protective committee headed by Lieut.
WITH upward of 2,000,000 people spending their Sundays at beaches near New York City, interest centers again on the condition of metropolitan waters and on progress made to end sewage pollution.

A neighborhood improvement act has just been adopted by the State of Michigan. According to the National Association of Real Estate Boards, this is the first act of its kind to be created in the United States. It had the strong support of the Michigan Real Estate Association.

Dr. Henry Nehemiah Dodge, the oldest dentist in New Jersey, who had practised here and in New York for more than half a century, died in his home here today at the age of 94. For the last two years he had been an invalid.

The marriage of Miss Virginia D. Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Murphy of Richmond Hill, Queens, to Peter E. Duffy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter E. Duffy of Butler, Pa., will take place on Saturday morning in the Church of the Holy Child Jesus, Richmond Hill.
Here are the chief events in the Scottsboro case: 1931 March 25-Nine Negroes arrested at Paint Rock, Ala., charged with attacking two white girls on a freight train.

The Latin-American population of New York yesterday joined in celebrating the 154th anniversary of the birth of the great South American liberator, Simon Bolivar. The festivities, which began at 8:45 A. M. with the laying of a wreath at the base of Bolivar's statue in Central Park,

RECIPE for a good tennis dish: First catch the Hare. Don Budge attended to that. Unless the California redhead loses an arm or breaks a leg, the big silver bowl known as the Davis Cup is just about marked for shipment from Wimbledon-on-the-Underground to Bagdadon-the-Subway, as 0. Henry called it.

Here in the heart of the Adirondacks, where all-year activities have a habit of overlapping one another, events of this week will be inaugurated by a garden party and tea for about 200 members of the Garden Club of Lake Placid
The Navy Department reported today that another unsuccessful attempt was made last night to float the 7,050-ton light cruiser Omaha, aground at Castle Island Light in the Bahama Islands.

Miss Eleanor Pinder Blaney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Edwin Blaney of this place, was married here this afternoon in the First Universalist Church to William Gibbs Bates, son of Mrs. Sophie L. Bates, also of Salem, and William P. Bates of Danvers, Mass.
Liberalization of England's divorce laws made it probable today that more divorce court judges would be needed to handle the impending flood of cases.
Two additional "triple insulated" model homes, one in New Jersey and one in Westchester County, will be opened for public inspection in the metropolitan area this week.

Miss Stella Rothacker, 42 years old, of 8,022 Broadway; Elmhurst, Queens, died here tonight in Nassau Hospital of injuries received earlier in the evening in an automobile accident on Old County Road, Carle Place, L. I. Four other persons were seriously injured.

Root pruning is a more or less mysterious phrase to any gardener who feels none too certain about the principles of pruning top growth. Root pruning has a defnite value for shy blooming shrubs and vines, specifically the wistaria and trumpet-creeper.

Miss Melroa Paul, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Paul of this city, was married to Matthew F. Hunter of Roselle, son of Mrs. Robert Hunter of England, this morning in James Methodist Episcopal Church here.
Alice heard her little friend put down the morning paper and sigh happily. She waited for the good news.

A new private residence constructed to be fire, sound, vermin and termite proof has just been completed at the southwest corner of 136th Street and Rockaway Beach Boulevard, Belle Harbor, L. I., by the Borbel Realty Company from plans by O. I. Silverstone, architect.

A sharp rally in the dollar provided the feature in the foreign exchange market here today. The development was attributed to the improved situation in the Far East, with a cessation of sales of currency against Japanese gold exports.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, dc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

Miss Anna Yavor, 24 years old, of 201 Sherman Street, Perth Amboy, was drowned late this afternoon while swimming in Raritan Bay, near Morgan. Members of the Morgan Rescue Squad grappled for the body without success.
This week the popular Midsummer Tennis Tournament takes place on the Casino courts, with the first rounds of men's and women's singles tomorrow, subsequent rounds in singles.

JAMES STILL was born among the hills of Alabama, where he spent his life until he moved into the Kentucky hills. Thus Mr. Still is a Southern mountaineer, born and bred; important facts. Some years since Mr. Still, who is now but 25 years of age, began to write verses.
Three thousand bags of coffee have been handed to the German concern of Theodore Wille Co. for shipment to Germany for experimental work in the extraction of coffee by-products.

The Joint Welfare and Educational Council of Physiotherapists, which is comprised of all actively practising, licensed and registered physiotherapists in New York State, held its first annual convention yesterday at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. About 200 attended.

Buyers visiting the New York wholesale market last week generally concentrated their purchases in the better price groups, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by MeGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buyers.

The following Foreign Service changes since July 17 were announced today by the State Department: The assignment of Carlos J. Warner of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, as Consul and Second Secretary of Legation at Vienna, Austria, has been canceled. Hugh S. Fullerton of Springfield, Ohio. Consul at Paris, has been designated First Secretary of Embassy at Paris and will serve in a dual capacity.

The marriage of Miss Mabel Virginia Dewar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert D. Dewar of this place, to Robert Warner Morrell, son of R. W. Morrell, also of Garden City, and the late Mrs. Morrell, will take place on Aug. 7 in New York.

ASTOR-High, Wide and Handsome: Irene Dunne. CAMEO-U. S. S. R.-1937, Russian documentary. CAPITOL-Saratoga: Jean Harlow, Clark Gable. CINE ROMA-Lady of Paradise, Italian. GLOBE-Armored Car: Cesar Romero. LOEW'S STATE-Married Before Breakfast: Robert Young. MUSIC HALL-Toast of New York: Edward Arnold; Stella Dallas, Barbara Stanwyck, Thursday.

St. Anthony's kindergarten class of 150 likes its Summer session so much that it went on strike for longer school hours. The Rev. Edward F. Conlin, pastor of St. Anthony's Church, negotiated a settlement yesterday at a picnic conference. The agreement provides a seven-and-a-half-hour day on Tuesdays and Thursday and regular three-hour sessions on other days.
An expenditure of $25,391,007 has been made by the Red Cross in the flood relief work in the Ohio and Mississippi Valleys, according to a preliminary report issued today.

The New York City school system, through its annual report, "All the Children," has been instrumental in changing the format and contents of school reports all over the,country, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday.

Langdon W. Post, chairman of the New York Housing Authority and Tenement House Commissioner, has been appointed a member of a committee recently created by the National Association of Housing Officials of Chicago to work out a satisfactory formula for transferring the management of projects from the PWA to qualified local authorities. Director Howard A.

Manoeuvres in the Non-Intervention Committee which led to another deadlock this week throw an indirect but illuminating light upon the still illdefined relations of the major European powers at this confusing transitional stage in world affairs when the air is full of bluff and diplomacy is full of feints and neither words nor actions can be taken at face value.
FIRST steps in coach modernization programs were virtually completed this month by the New York Central and the Pennsylvania.

German shipbuilders are wary of foreign observers and refuse admittance to visitors who are in search of information on German methods, according to Oscar Olson, superintendent engineer of the United States Lines. Mr. Olson returned Thursday on the liner Washington from a six-week visit abroad during which he inspected shipyards in Oslo and Conenhagen.

Miss Dorothy Adams Peck, daughter of William E. Peck and the late Mrs. Peck, became the bride of Nelson Downs Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Downs, at the Downs home here this afternoon. The Rev. John H. Grant, pastor of the First Church of Christ, officiated.

Rosecliff, on Bellevue Avenue, long the Summer home of the late Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs and the center of much social activity when she was alive, came back to its own tonight. Once more it was the mecca of guests from dinner parties in different parts of the colony.

The marriage of Miss Janet Henwood, daughter of Mrs. Henry G. Henwood of this city and the late Mr. Henwood, to Robert R. Henry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence J. Henry of Chicago, took place this afternoon in All Souls Unitarian Church here. The Rev. Frank Harwood of Keyport, N. J., performed the ceremony.

The municipal campaign of 1937 is likely to go down in the local records as "the Campaign of Confusion." For there exists, at the present time, a confusion of issues, parties and candidates that has never been known before-and politicians hope nothing like it ever will occur again.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with a great deal of interest in THE TIMES of July 11 a letter in which the Rev. Ignatius W. Cox takes issue with me concerning a subject that most people will agree is of vital importance to the nation.

A Highland County jury tonight convicted Glenn Perkins, union striker at the plant of the Industrial Rayon Corporation, of assault and battery while a member of a mob and fixed his punishment at four years in the State penitentiary. Perkins was a member of Local 2,214, Synthetic Yarn Federation, C. I. O. affiliate.

While the J yachts are marking time for the big match at Newport their smaller sisters, the Six Meters, are awaiting the start of trials to select defenders of two of the most important trophies in the small boat field-the Scandinavian Gold Cup and the Seawanhaka Cup.
Mrs. Harold Dahl of Champaign, Ill., today enlisted the help of the United States Embassy in Paris for her husband, held in a Spanish Insurgent jail.

Sponsored by the local district of the National Socialist party, an elaborate antiSemitic exhibition will be held in Munich in the Fall, it was announced today. The exhibition, described as "a great political show," will be officially designated "The Eternal Jew."

The annual Summer national championship bridge tournament of the American Bridge League will be held here Aug. 2-8. The mixed team-of-four contest will be held on the afternoons of Aug. 2 and 3. The title is held by Louis J. Haddad and Mrs. Paul of New York, Mrs. Paul D. Parcells of Chicago, Mrs. Eliot Evans of Evanston, Ill., and John D. McPherran of Philadelphia.

A campaign to promote better human relations concepts in the schools and colleges of this country will be undertaken in the coming year by the National Conference of Jews and Christians, its director, Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, announced yesterday.

Dr. Marston Taylor Bogert, Professor of Organic Chemistry at Columbia University, has been elected an Honorary Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, Scotland, it was announced yesterday by Columbia authorities.

With the opening of the grouse hunting season in Scotland scheduled for Aug. 12, interest centers at Balmoral Castle, where the King and Queen, accompanied by the small Princesses, will spend the long holiday.

Homer Martin, international president of the United Automobile Workers of America, told a mass meeting here tonight: "We're not fighting General Motors any more; we're boosting General Motors because the more cars that are sold the more money the laboring man should receive."
The Hornell Public Library has acquired a Civil War lieutenant's gold shoulder bar and a pencil case once owned by Russell Tuttle, pioneer Hornellsville newspaper man.
The municipal docks are experiencing their busiest season in many years with pleasure craft here from many sections of the country.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Uihlein of New York will give a Garden Day reception tomorrow afternoon at Camp Birchwood, their Summer place on Lake Placid, for 200 members of the Garden Club of Lake Placid. Mrs. Milton L. Bernstein of New York, president of the club, will assist them.

Staple lines of cotton goods have sold in only minor quantities during the last two weeks and some weakness in prices has developed. Specialty lines, however, have begun to move in fairly good volume for Fall and selling agents said yesterday they were encouraged by the initial takings of such merchandise by both wholesalers and retailers.

Real estate is steadily improving and in the opinion of Charles F. Noyes, head of the firm bearing his name, values will increase during the next few years. He states that, while present prices are low, many substantial transactions are being closed, indicating that conditions are better.

Launching an aggressive campaign to attract business to the city-operated foreign trade zone on Staten Island, the Department of Docks yesterday began distribution of thousands of posters advertising the free port's facilities.

In late June the prospect throughout the hard red Spring wheat region was brilliant. Then came two weeks of hot, muggy weather and winds from the southwest bearing the spores of the dread black-stem rust.

The west redoubt of Fort Clinton at Bear Mountain in Palisades Interstate Park has been restored practically to its condition on Oct. 6, 1777, when the American garrison was driven out by British forces under Sir Henry Clinton, according to an announcement yesterday from the Palisades Interstate Park Commission.

The report of the General Telephone Corporation and subsidiaries for the year to June 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, of $1,336,021, compared with a net income of $1,081,585 in the year to June 30, 1936.

While on vacation in the Italian Alps in 1894 Marconi caught the idea of signaling through space with electromagnetic waves, and in 1895 wireless sputtered its first signal across the garden of his home at Bologna. At the age of 21 he triumphed where noted scientists had failed when he connected the apparatus to an elevated aerial and "grounded" the instruments.

" The duty and responsibility of removing obstructions that interfere with the legitimate flow of business belongs to Congress." Congressman Emanuel Celler of New York thus addressed the House of Representatives in the introduction of his recent bill seeking to amend the tax on undistributed corporate net earnings (H. R. 7550).

In the building industry and in realty circles generally the most important factor of the week was the adoption by the Board of Aldermen of the new Building Code, which has been under consideration by that board for nearly five years.

The Wildroot Company, Inc., Buffalo, has stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue certain "misleading advertising practices" in connection with the sale of a hair tonic and shampoo, the commission announced today.
Seven State police officers were named by Major John A. Warner, Superintendent, to attend for a second year the Traffic Officers' Training School at Harvard University, from Aug. 16 to 28.
Paris gave King Leopold an enthusiastic welcome when he came here today to preside at the closing ceremonies of Belgian week at the Paris Exposition.

Not even a couple of blowouts sufficed to throw Gabby Hartnett and his trail-blazing Cubs out of their pennant stride yesterday as the onrushing Chicagoans thundered over the Polo Grounds course to score their second straight crushing victory over the Giants.

General principles to govern the contents of the legislation for the lower Federal courts which will take the place of President Roosevelt's Judiciary Reorganization Bill and the later compromise introduced by Senators Logan and Hatch, were agreed upon today by the eight members of the subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee charged with drafting a new proposal.

MORE than half the car owners in the United States are operating automobiles which were purchased as used cars. This expansion of the used car market is held to account for the fact that automobile ownership has been extending steadily into the low-income groups so that now, according to the American Petroleum Industries Committee, more than 12,000,000 car-owning families have incomes of from $20 to $30 a week.
Those land-locked yachting enthusiasts whose calendars call for a sojourn at sea to follow the America's Cup races off Newport will find an acute problem on their hands this week.

The engagement of Miss Anita Dechtiar, daughter of Max Dechtiar of this city and the late Mrs. Dechtiar, to Dr. D. Alfred Dantes, son of Mrs. Bella Saal also of New York and the late Dr. Max Dantes, has been announced by her father.
Two of amateur golf's most durable campaigners, ex-champions both, fell by the wayside in the second round of the top-flight match play in the Bald Peak tournament today.
EVERY now and again the suggestion is made that publishers should establish among themselves some kind of registration bureau to prevent the inconvenience caused by the duplication of book titles.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Percy Austen Tomes of 446 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, and Stockbridge, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Isabel Tomes, to Paul Sanford Lee Seward of Brooklyn, son of Mrs. Rees E. McDuffie of Sachem's Head, Conn., and the late Edward C. Seward.

Bootlegging did not go out with prohibition. It is still with us to a considerable extent, although Federal tax officials express confidence that it is definitely on the wane. Recently a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn indicted thirty-six Individuals and six corporations from New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania on charges of participating in the largest bootleg ring discovered since repeal.
A Gay Nineties ball on Aug. 21 as an added social feature of the Summer here was announced this week. Women of the camp and cottage colony will organize many house parties for that week-end.

Miss Grace Tolley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Tolley of West Orange, was married to G. Edward Zdenek, son of Joseph Zdenek of Milford, this afternoon in Ridgeview Community Church here, the Rev. R. Lloyd Roberts, pastor of St. Cloud Presbyterian Church, West Orange, officiating.

A return to elaboration features the new Fall millinery lines, according to the Millinery Stabilization Commission. which says retailers welcome the trend heartily, as the variety of silhouettes will make it possible to sell more hats.
The Lindsay Cup races are being sailed today and tomorrow in Vineyard Haven, following upon elimination races between Edgartown and Nantucket last Thursday and Friday.

The Building of Arts, situated at the foot of Cadillac Mountain, was the scene today of the annual flower show sponsored by the Garden Club of Mount Desert, the club of the Summer colony on the is- M land, and open to any garden club member of the island and near-by Summer colonies.

Sheriff's deputies rode into Aravaipa Canyon today in a manhunt which reminds one of the old West. The hunt was spurred by the filing of charges in what officers said was a renewal of the old "haunted corral" feud. Joe Towner and Bill Wheeler, ranchers, were accused of assault with intent to kill as the outgrowth of a gun battle in the mountainous ranch lands.

Rental advances averaging 10 per cent and 6 per cent as the first mortgage interest rate in the majority of cities are reported by the National Association of Real Estate Boards in its twenty-ninth annual survey of realty market conditions throughout the country.
A home-made contraption that cost $10-the inventors called it a "hooperdozer" -harvested a bushel of grasshoppers an hour and was credited today with saving a soybean field at Shirley, near here.

JORIS IVENS, the aware little Dutchman who is continuing, through the medium of the documentary motion picture, the art tradition of the Dutch and the Flemings in realism, is currently in Manhattan, back from having shown his latest film, "The Spanish Earth," to President Roosevelt and to Hollywood.
Fred H. Hallbruegge, 54 years old, whose temperature after a heat stroke registered 112 degrees, is expected to recover, his physician said today.

Miss Joan Ordway of New York gave a dinner last night at the Hay Harbor Club for eighteen. The second in the Hay Harbor Club's series of fortnightly dances for the younger set was held last night. This afternoon a buffet luncheon sponsored by the club was held on the club porch.
More than 2,000 families in New York City and vicinity, who formerely paid rent, purchased homes through the FHA since Jan. 1, announces Thomas G. Grace, State director.

On this first day of the Davis Cup challenge round, a Saturday, it was expected that the center court here would be filled to overflowing, but, although there were only between 11,000 and 12,000 spectators on hand as against Wimbledon's 15,000, it was an excited and enthusiastic crowd.

Miss Jessie Middleton Cuthbert McPherson, daughter of Mrs. William L. McPherson of 250 Riverside Drive, New York, and the late Mr. McPherson, was married here this morning to David J. Orgain, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Orgain, also of New York.
Villagers, artists and Summer folk are preparing for the annual country fair, to be presented by the Woodstock Library next Thursday on the large lawn adjoining the building.

The Skipper, in the midst of the worst political and party storm this generation has known, last week jettisoned some cargo. Convinced of the necessity by his mates and crew, President Roosevelt allowed the Court Bill to be dropped overboard.

NEXT Sunday honors will be paid to A. E. F. heroes in France, when the first of the shrines for which the American Battle Monuments Commission has appropriated $175,000 will be dedicated at Montfaucon. Here Franco-American troops were victorious in September, 1918.

An offering of between $20,000,000 and $25,000,000 debentures of the Federal Home Loan Bank System is expected within the next week. This will mark the second entrance into the open market by the system since its organization in 1932.

ALMOST concurrently with the beginning of the second year of the Spanish civil war the publishers of the American stamp catalogue have decided to give official recognition to 149 pieces of postal paper printed in Spain between July 18 and Dec. 31. 1936.

WITH the performance of "Tristan und Isolde" Tuesday comes the end of the current Wagner Festival at the Stadium. This program also marks the last appearance this season of Fritz Reiner. The fifth conductor to be heard this Summer at the Stadium is George King Raudenbush, who directs his opening program Wednesday night.
The coming week on Mount Desert Island and the neighboring resorts of Northeast Harbor and Seal Harbor will be marked by four sports events in which many Summer residents will participate.

It is of timely interest to note that while church unity on a world scale is being discussed by the delegates of many denominations at the conference in Oxford, a specific instance of church amity is being furnished at our national capital.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Arthur Margrett of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Caroline Margrett, to Stewart Thames, son of Mrs. Gustav B. Thames of Mobile, Ala., and the late Mr. Thames.

Mrs. Stella Crater told New York police here today she could give them no further information in their reopening of the investigation of the disappearance of her husband, Justice Joseph Force Crater, seven years ago.
WALTER WANGER has ordered his accounting department to write into the ledger book a budget of $2,000,000 for a Technicolor epic to be known simply as "California."
MOST of Hollywood's fan mail finds its way rapidly into the baling machine, after harried secretaries have done the right thing by the correspondents-the right thing usually being a signed picture.

More than 10,000 employes of the B. M. T. will vote this week in an election to determine who shall represent them in collective bargaining with the subway management. Behind this action is a movement already well under way
Stocks closed firm, with industrial shares at the best levels of the movement; turnover, 505,790 shares. United States Government and other bonds steady and quiet; transactions, $2,732,500.

Charles F. Breitung of Shore Acres, Mamaroneck, N. Y., vice president and treasurer of the Thermal Electric Company of New Haven, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a week's illness. He was 70 years old.

Midsummer lethargy, together with the increasing tendency for many traders to start their weekends on Friday night, resulted in little life to the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Rev. Diego Bennati of the Italian Capuchin Fathers of New York City will preach a sermon in Italian at a solemn high mass tomorrow marking the traditional feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel in Roseto, the Italian borough adjoining this city.

With war clouds gathering ominously in Northeastern Asia, Great Britain is rapidly pushing ahead plans to transform this colonial trading post into a self-sustaining link in her world-girdling chain of empire defenses.

TO remind its citizens that the children of Italian colonies need aid, Rome has issued ten new postage values and six air mails. All stamps bear the Italian coat of arms and the inscription "Mostra Colonie Estive e Assistenza all' tnfanzia."

Two Spanish girls who had been invited to the United States by the North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy as part of a campaign for funds to relieve Basque refugee children returned to their homes today saying they had been barred.

The young Broadhollow team clinched the Blue Meadow League branch honors of the Hempstead Cups polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today, but the Red Brook League was thrown into a threeway tie when the Santa Barbara four of California upset the Cyclones and Delhi came through to victory over Great Neck.

The large vacant plot near White Plains Road and 242d Street, -Bronx, formerly the property of the late August J. Kimmerle, will be sold at auction on Wednesday in the Bronx salesroom by Joseph P. Day, auctioneer. The sale, which will be at a price not less than $40,000, will be- under the supervision of Oscar Aronson, referee.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in somewhat larger volume than in the preceding week, but the total continued well below the weekly aggregates called for prepayment earlier in the year. Foreign bonds led in the amounts called last week, and, with the exception of two small lots marked for payment in July, the retirements were posted for future months.
ABOUT halfway down on the great mid-continent trunk Highway that runs from Winnipeg to San Antonio and on to Mexico City stands the pleasant old Great Plains city of St. Joseph, Mo.

The New York Yankees all but completed arrangements yesterday whereby they will gain control of their third Class AA baseball farm, the Kansas City Blues of the American Association, The Associated Press reported.
Hearings by the Federal Trade Commission in three cases are scheduled for New York during the coming week, one being the price-maintenance case against Seagrams-Distillers Corporation on Monday.
The Labor Department's commissioner of statistics reported today that workers' families in five Pennsylvania cities spend an average of 32 to 36 cents of every dollar for food.

HAVANA.-What ultimate effect will the policy of the Cuban Government tending toward elimination of foreigners from participation in the commercial and industrial life of the island have on relations with the United States? That question is being asked by many thoughtful Cubans here, inasmuch as negotiations for removal of the reciprocity treaty between Cuba and the United States, which expires next September, are soon to get under way.
The special flag of the National Geographic Society flies today from the 17,150-foot peak of Mount Lucania amid the drifting snow and the ice of what was the highest unclimbed peak in North America.
THIS Summer's play festivalthe sixth annual one at the historic old Opera House has gone serious, as it does every so often.

FANATICISM is one of the most destructive forces known to man; equally pernicious whether aligned on the side of good or evil. The religious fanaticism of the Inquisition was as fruitful of human suffering and as extirpative of cultural values as the anti-religious fevers rampant today.

The opening on Monday of the fiftieth annual invitation tennis tournament of the Sea Bright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club will set in motion a round of social activities that will continue until after the final match on Saturday.

The marine union of the International Longshoremen's Association, which embraces employes of the towboat lines operating in the New York port district, will have a mass meeting tonight at 8 o'clock at Beethoven Hall.

A story of an attack by five savage sharks which rocked his dory and nearly threw him into the sea while he was trying to land a 400-pound swordfish was told by Charles Mozart of Vineyard Haven when the swordfishing schooner Liberty reached the fish pier with thirty big broadbills in her hold.

An ebb in the flood of anti-chain tax measures actually enacted during the recent sessions of State legislatures is shown in a statistical survey just completed by a leading chain merchandising organization here.
American amateur wrestlers triumphed over a Japanese team in the final matches of the Japanese-American international championships today. ?? five out of seven victories, before a huge crowd.

T. Suffern Tailer of this city and New York, former metropolitan titleholder, repeated is victory of last season in the eleventh annual invitation golf tournament of the Newport Country Club today, defeating Tommy Goodwin of New York in the final round, 2 and 1.
The third annual exhibition of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club at Darien, Conn., Saturday will mark the resumption of what promises to be a highly successful show season.

The Manursing Island Club was the scene tonight of a dinner dance. The hosts were Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Manny, Mr. and Mrs. H. F. G. Wey Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Arthur McCain, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene de Bronkart, Mr. and Mrs. Monroe Maltby, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Ward, Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Waite and Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Neild,

FOLLOWING the first event of the Summer season here (which was a show of paintings and sculpture selected by jury, current between June 26 and July 15) the Woodstock Art Gallery now offers an exhibition composed of work by directors of the Woodstock Art Association. It opened July 17 and will remain through Aug. 12.

The old paddle wheeler Priscilla of the Fall River Line moved slowly up the East River at noon yesterday, making what will probably be her last voyage along the route she followed for nearly forty years.

THE increasing number of books about military policy in general and American military policy in particular is a good sign, since at all times every one is concerned with that important question and most of all in disturbed periods like our own.

It was announced today that the Czech Minister to Berlin, Dr. V. Mastny, called the attention of the Wilhelmstrasse to the hostile attitude of the German press, particularly the Voelkische Beobachter, which is calculated to disturb the relations between the two countries.

The unsolved murder three years ago of Dr. Elliott Speer, headmaster of the Mount Hermon School, is still being investigated by State authorities, who are scrutinizing closely the testimony being offered in the assault trial of Thomas Edwin Elder, former dean of the school.

THIS week an old duel is to be revived off Newport the long, long attempt of British yachtsmen to take back to England the cup lifted by the yacht America in 1851. It is a clumsy old mug and far from artistic, but it is, of all sporting trophies, the most coveted.

Judge George J. Trauth of Gretna, La., said today that he had performed a marriage ceremony June 22 for Miss Cherry Blossom Preisser, New York revue dancer, and David J. Hopkins, son of Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator.

Bids of $71,675 and $73,175, respectively, for the steel cargo vessels Pacific Hemlock and Pacific Pine of the Federal Government's "idle merchant fleet" now tied up at Seattle, received from C. E. Dant, president of the States Steamship Company of Portland, Ore., were accepted today by the Maritime Commission.

Addressing a Town Hall audience here tonight in celebration of the defeat of the plan to reorganize the Supreme Court, Miss Cathrine Curtis of New York, national chairman of the Women's National Committee for Hands Off the Supreme Court, who was the principal speaker, read this telegram from Senator Burke of Nebraska:
The Countess of Cardigan, 33-year-old wife of the Marquess of Ailesbury's son and heir, crashed to her death tonight from a seventh-floor window of the Savoy Hotel.
Two men accused of possessing twenty counterfeit $5 bills were held in $25,000 bail each by United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein in Brooklyn yesterday.

An oddity in railroad transactions appeared among the records of the Interstate Commerce Commission today when the Beaufort Morehead Railroad Company applied for permission to buy the Beaufort extension of the Norfolk Southern Railroad Company for $12,850.
TRADITION so old that it has become venerable has identified the printer of the encyclopedic "Catholicon" of Joannes Balbus with Gutenberg.
A succession of record-breaking trade shows here in the last month has led manufacturers in practically all houseware lines to the conclusion that a Fall season of exceptional activity lies ahead.

With the A opening of the fiftieth annual invitation tournament of the Seabright Tennis Club scheduled to start at Seabright tomorrow the attention of the Summer shore colony will be turned to the outstanding matches to be staged during the six days of play.

THIS little volume, comprising a series in the Well Lectures on American Citizenship delivered at the University of North Carolina, deals with the impact of technology and of corporations on American life and with the question of controlling and directing the forces which they embrace in such way as to provide a balanced economy in this country.

The will of Mrs. Florence Pullman Lowden, who died on July 5 at her farm home near Oregon, III., was filed for probate today. Her husband, Frank O. Lowden, wartime Governor of Illinois, is the beneficiary until the time of his death, after which the income of the estate will be paid to the couple's four children.

Miss Genevieve Josephine Oliver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. Oliver of 27 Clifton Place, Brooklyn, has chosen the morning of Aug. 28 for her marriage to VW. Walter Longley. son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Longley, also of Brooklyn. The ceremony will take place in Queen of All Saints Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn, and will be performed by the Rev. William Cullen.

A pick-up in industrial activity this Fall will carry the total of those gainfully employed back to the highest level since pre-depression times, the business survey committee-of the National Association of Purchasing Agents predicted yesterday in its monthly report on July business conditions.

With thirty-seven stakes down for decision-more than one a day-the month-long meeting of the Saratoga Association at the historic upState course will begin tomorrow to run thirty racing days until Aug. 28, during which time approximately $400,000 will be distributed to horsemen.

It is twenty-one years since the Japanese beetle entered the United States through Nvew Jersey as a stowaway in- nursery stock. Fifteen kinds of parasites and two sorts of wasps, besides several poisons, have been used to quell its n litancy, but this Summer it is doing more damage then ever-to roses, fruits, plants, crops and tree foliage.

The honor system, started by the State of Pennsylvania at its prize fishing hole along Spring Creek, is teaching the anglers to "throw 'em back." They call the hole "fisherman's paradise," but it is just as much a paradise for the fish, because they stand at least a six-to-one chance of being taken unharmed from the hook and returned to the water.
Scattered liquidation continued in the grain markets today. but it was by no means as heavy as of late and the aggregate turnover was said by brokers to have been the smallest in some time.

SUMMER time is increasingly becoming camp time for Boy Scouts. The latest annual report shows that 235,980 Scouts attended council- conducted camps last year, as compared with 217,342 in 1935, and these figures do not take into account short-term and overnight camping outside regular camps.

Some few are left to bring the leader home, To lay his precious banner in his hand, To whisper gravely all the things he planned Till black wings whirred. Down in the fetid loam, Face down they lie again and feel the earth Answer as if the earth can understand

Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford gave a dinner tonight at The Hedges for W. Francklyn Paris. Mr. and Mrs. Domenico Mortellito entertained with a tea and preview for 200 this afternoon in the South Gallery at Guild Hall.

THE very name given to this particular type of art is charming. A "conversa tion piece"' calls up at once piquant images; promises the intimate glimpse that can often tell us so much more than could the most elaborate of formal statements; in a word, invites with a kind of gentle urgency.

The Sunday closing dispute between the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association, Inc., and the Metropolitan Delicatessen Merchants Association will be submitted to arbitration before Major William J. Mack, designated arbitrator by Mayor La Guardia, it was announced yesterday by Charles Ackerman, secretary of the independent -group.

Entry of large numbers of United States and European immigrants into Palestine in recent years has greatly increased the demand for imported drugs and pharmaceuticals, according to George Wadsworth, Consul General at Jerusalem, in a report made public today by the chemical division of the Department of Commerce.
SERGE KOUSSEVITZKY, who returns this week to America to conduct the concerts of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival, said interesting things about conducting to an interviewer of The Atlantic Monthly.

Out off the rugged coast of Newport, R. I., the sixteenth match for the America's Cup, 86-year-old yachting trophy, will get under way next Saturday. Starting sixty-seven years ago, Englishmen, Scots, Irishmen and Canadians have striven to take away the filigreed silver prize captured by the schooner America in a race around the Isle of Wight, off the south of England.
A brisk rally in the pound sterling, following the decline on Friday, was the feature of an otherwise quiet foreign exchange market yesterday. Opening at $4.96 3/4,
King George is considering making his first airplane flight since he came to the throne seven and one-half months ago, an official announcement tonight said.

New perspectives for political formations. in France were opened last night when Maurice Thorez, Communist leader, announced to his party's central committee that the Communists next Tuesday would propose united action by the Communist and Socialist parties.

Renewal of the demand that specific responsibilities and duties be imposed by law upon labor unions, and that they be made by statute more easily amenable to judicial process, has followed the recent labor disturbances in the automobile, steel and other industries.
THE wild chipmunk presumably has adapted Darwin's famous phrase to make it read "the survival of the most suspiciouis"if the experience of one amateur photographer is to be considered a criterion.

The President has taken a terrible beating from the Senate in the controversy over enlarging the Supreme Court. He staked his leadership upon this "objective" and he had to permit the complete surrender of his leaders--for this session at least-to the combination of Democrats and Republicans who refused to follow him.

THE admirers of Miss Millay's early "personality" poems and the designed perfectitude of her later sonnets may not take easily to this new book of hers. It is a sparkling piece of writing, worldly, mature, objective and dramatic; but it is extremely irregular in form and obviously quite inconclusive in its argument.

As commodities, notably wheat and cotton, moved lower on the week, the stock market extended its recovery and bonds did well. Corporate reports covering secondquarter earnings came to hand in volume and, in the main, made a good showing.

Miss Cynthia-Mary Spencer, daughter of Mrs. Kingsland Spencer of this place, and the late Mr. Spencer, was married to John Van Voorheis Cockcroft, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Cockcroft, this afternoon at the home of her mother here.

VIRGINIA, cooperating in the bicentennial celebration of the founding of Richmond, to come to a climax in September, hopes at the same time to bring to final solution her own three-hundred-year-old problem of providing an adequate, safe and accessible home for the State's archives.

The Hercules Powder Company reported yesterday for the first six months of this year net earnings of $3,037,012 after depreciation and Federal taxes. This was equal to $4.70 a share on an average of 590,722 shares of outstanding common stock after payment of $262,464 of preferred dividends. In the first six months of last year $2.51 a share was earned on an average of 583,865 shares of common stock.

Explaining some of the mortgage functions of the Federal Housing Administration, Administrator Stewart McDonald points out that the FRA is an insuring agency which does not compete with private enterprise and especially with such lending institutions which deal in insured mortgages.

First indications of the extent to which staple underwear lines for Spring will be advanced over last Spring became available last week when some of the chain store buyers were able to place business with their accustomed sources at moderate increases.

Arriving from Boston on an airplane to which she was carried in a wheel chair, Mrs. Elizabeth J. Williams, 35-year-old divorcee, of Narragansett, R. 1., came to Police Headquarters to look at the four men suspected of beating and robbing her on Wednesday night of jewelry valued at more than $6,000.
SEGAON, India.-The Mahatma reached over his legs, crossed before him on the floor. He grasped my hand firmly like any good Tammany politician.

BEGINNING today the twothousandth anniversary of the -birth of Rome's first Emperor, Augustus, will be observed with rites of commemoration at La Turbie, in the south of France, where the Tower of Augustus, reared as-a peace memorial-in what wasR then a Roman province, has been restored through the-generosity of Edward Tuck.

Resolutions condemning the candidacy of James E. Branigan for Tammany leadership in the Seventh district were adopted yesterday by the joint executive board of Local 32-B, Building Service Employes International Union.

Declaring that his action was not barred by Federal Court proceedings started against him, District Attorney George V. Dorsey of Rockland County tonight raided and closed the dog races at the Orangeburg Kennel Club track, and arrested the operator.

King Saxon, the stallion racing critics said could not come back, broke his second track record in eight days in winning the featured $1,000 Oceanside Handicap today. Despite a 124-pound burden, King Saxon ran the six furlongs in 1:11, clipping four-fifths of a second off the mark he established last Saturday, his first start since he was injured last Winter.
Premier Benito Mussolini's own newspaper, Popolo d'Italia, today listed numerous international "fictions" said some day would be "overhelmed by reality."
SINCE the days of Jean-Henri Fabre much has been learned about the life and habits of the bee, most romantic and useful of insects.

A decline of 2 per cent in the dollar volume of retail financing of new passenger automobiles for June, compared with June, 1936, but an increase of 65 per cent compared with June, 1935, is shown in preliminary estimates by the Department of Commerce.

A question of residence blocked a decision today on Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett's suit to release from garnishee $1,135 of her last two weeks' salary as a swimmer and singer at the Great Lakes Exposition.

Local political interest centered yesterday in whether Mayor F. H. La Guardia or Senator Royal S. Copeland, Tammany candidate for the Democratic nomination, would receive organization support for the Republican nomination for Mayor.

The Federal Labor Board ruled tonight that the strike of Mexican Aviation Company employes was non-existent, compelling the strikers to return to work at once. It is expected that service will be resumed tomorrow.

Launching of the Federal vocational training projects authorized under the George-Deen act, with a budget of $1,298,000 authorized in the Interior Department appropriations bill will command widespread interest in the retail field, according to Otho J. Hicks, manager of the personnel group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
The prices of haircuts, half soles on shoes and dozens of similar services by trades heretofore regulated by the State become a matter of discretion with the operators after midnight tonight.

Application blanks are now ready at the offices of the Tenement House Department, 346 Broadway, for owners of old-law tenements who wish to have such buildings repaired under the rules and regulations set up by the Board of Estimate for the administration of the $500,000 old-law tenement revolving fund.
The board of exports for agricultural products announced today that plans were well advanced for the exportation of the bulk of Chilean wines to Germany.

William A. Julian, whose name adorns the nation's currency, would like to find fifty bills that do not bear his autograph. "All of them are of the $10,000 variety," said Mr. Julian, Treasurer of the United States.

ONCE more fashion is high-hatting us. It seems to be an autumnal mood that anticipates the fur invasion. Fur neckpieces and big brims are poor companions. The upstarts are a considerable relief from the cartwheels that have flopped in the Summer breezes.

AMERICANS are participating to a larger measure than ever before in this year's Salzburg festival. Today Artur Rodzinski, the American conductor, directs the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra in the first of a series of eight concerts. by that organization, which will be led subsequently by Hans Knappertsbusch, Bruno Walter, Arturo Toscanini and Wilhelm Furtwaengler.

Despite rising costs in building material and labor construction throughout the nation Is making substantial progress, according to a mid-year survey of forty-four States compiled by Robert D. Steele, statistician for the National Association of Building Trades Employers, of Chicago.

Victory for Activated Sludge, Inc., of Chicago, holder of patents on purification of sewage, in its suit against the Chicago Sanitary District for infringement of the patents, would cost the city nearly $7,500,000, it was estimated today by counsel for the company.

BRUSSELS.-The City of Antwerp has won its case against the proprietors of the house where Peter Paul Rubens lived and worked, in the Rue Rubens, not far from the Meir, Antwerp, and will convert the property into a museum in time for his anniversary next year.

NO democratic government can by force of law entirely eliminate strife from private industry. During the World War, in the face of the unity of our national endeavor, there were more strikes than at any previous period in our history. In England, despite the longer experience in labor relations, there are usually in progress more strikes per capital than in this country.
Count Otto Hagenburg of Germany look an easy first over nine rivals in acrobatic flying at the fourth international aviation meeting here today.

While admitting that real estate recovery during the past two years has been of a moderate nature, Colonel Douglas I. McKay, president of the New York Title Insurance Company, declares that present market conditions offer exceptional opportunities for investment buying.
MR. EDWIN FRANKO GOLDMAN is hard at work trying to formulate definite plans for regular Sunday afternoon indoor concerts of the Goldman Band in this city throughout the forthcoming season.

FRANCE makes ready to entertain the universe. During the last few years she has given priority to the utilitarian. Arts were subventioned with an eye dropper (in the ordinary budget they only obtain 0.33 per cent, which probably goes to art schools where soiled casts of the Venus de Milo and Vitellius remain the eternal models).
This quiet hamlet has set out to make a national shrine of the rambling, two-story boyhood home of James Whitcomb Riley, painterpoet.

President Lazaro Cardenas has issued instructions to officials to speed land grants to farmers in districts where those scheduled to receive properties have been killed or per??cuted "by bandits' armies, by landowners and other enemies of the agrarian movement."

Transit unification remains the city's most important problem and one which cannot be solved by the present administration, Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel to the Transit Commission, declared yesterday.

Traffic on Forty-second Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue was tied up yesterday afternoon for thirty-five minutes while firemen fought a stubborn blaze in the Rapid Shoe Repairing Company on the ground floor of a threestory loft building at 206 West Forty-second Street.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James J. Devine of Pelham, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Devine, to George Byron Smith 2d of this city, son of the late Mrs. Vera Smith Wolf.

Faced with threats of private and official investigations from several sources, Nordland, the GermanAmerican Bund camp at Andover, N. J., prepared last night for another all-day program today, at which 3,000 visitors were expected.

The East All-Star college combination, slated to face the New York Football Giants at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 8 for The New York Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund, was boosted to thirteen today as Andy Kerr, coach of the All-Stars, announced the acquisition of three University of Pennylvania players.

The development of cotton production under Japanese auspices will get under way here in Costa Rica this year, whatever the outcome of the trip the Costa Rican Finance Minister, Raul Gurdian, is taking to Japan in August under the auspices of the Japanese Exporters Association.
Lady Luck, 7-year-old chestnut Morgan mare owned by Paul Adams of Chester, Vt., tonight won the Green Mountain Horse Association's 100-mile trial ride which ended here.

Judge Thomas H. Stapleton ruled in a divorce case hearing in Probate Court this week a court may do many things to a husband who does not treat his wife right, but that it cannot compel him to make his wife happy.

MANY new ideas for motor car design are coming out of the model car design contest of the Fisher Body Craftsman's Guild, which is now in its final stages for 1937. It is believed that the designs submitted afford some clue to what the public is thinking about, so far as the automobile of the future is concerned.

The awarding of fourteen scholarships for study at Fordham College, Bronx Division, was announced yesterday by the Rev. Charles J. Deane, vice president of Fordham University and dean of studies of Fordham College, Bronx Division. All the scholarships are for four years of study, beginning with the Fall term this year.

Miss Alice J. Green, daughter of the late George L. Green of Westfield. became the bride of James E. Donnelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Donnelly of Roselle, in St. Joseph's Catholic Church, Roselle, this afternoon.

The value of building permits issued last month in 1,437 cities with a population of 2,500 or over declined 5 per cent from June, 1936, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins announced yesterday. The value was $149,694,089.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Louise Snedeker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Lendon Snedeker of 429 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, to Robert Morgan Parker, son of Dr. William Huntington Parker and Mrs. Isabel Cady Parker of Providence, R. I., took place here this afternoon at 1 St. Andrew's Lane, where the bride's family is staying.
TELEVISION in London is celebrating its first year on the air this month, although the first public demonstrations were not made until the Olympia Radio Exhibition in August, 1936.

IT is learned from official sources that the Postoffice Department is considering an American Indian totem pole as the central design of the Alaskan stamp which will be a unit of the forthcoming series to publicize the United States possessions-Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.

SINCE 1923, when 16-millimeter motion-picture equipment became available, an army of 100,000 home moviemakers has grown up, using millions of feet of film annually. The presence of 8,806 projectors in local school systems and of thousands of others in churches, clubs, community centers and homes has given rise to a badiy organized but hyper-active business.

After a varied career of seventeen years in the Patent Office, involving six interference with other inventors, the basic patent (No. 2,087,795) on the use of polarized light for eliminating automobile headlight glare has just been granted to Lewis W. Chubb, director of research for the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, East Pittsburgh, Pa.

IN the universal disappointment at the failure of the navy's intensive efforts to find and rescue Amelia Earhart and her navigator, Fred J. Noonan, the efforts themselves have escaped the notice that they deserve, according to Washington observers who are intensely interested in the nation's air defense.

Brig. Gen. Walter K. Wilson is due to arrive here today to assume command of the Second Coast Artillery District, comprising the harbor defenses of Delaware, Sandy Hook and Eastern and Southern New York. His headquarters will be at 641 Washington Street.
HIS parents had named him Abraham Lincoln Anrkrorn. but along the Southwestern b o r d e r country he had come to be known as Blur Ankrom-king of the corpsemakers. He had not sought that distinction.
A thrilling encounter on the West River near Samshui occurred last evening when pirates attempted to seize the Chinese steamer Tinsang.

Word has been received here of the approaching marriage of Miss Kathleen Constance Gowen, daughter of Brig. Gen. James B. Gowen, U. S. A. (retired), and Mrs. Gowen of Schofield Barracks, Oahu, Territory of Hawaii, to Lieutenant James Martin Worthington, U.S.A., son of Lieut. Col.
Ten of this city's largest retail stores were closed today by a strike of the Clerks Union, an American Federation of Labor affiliate. No department stores of importance were left open.

The administration's proposed program for the reorganization of the Civil Service was attacked today by Representative Martin of Massachusetts, chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee, as a raid designed to put 840,000 Federal jobs under the control of the Democratic party for patronage uses in the 1938 elections.
The League Against War and Fascism yesterday challenged the National Citizens Committee recently famed in Johnstown, Pa., to prove that it was not a Fascist organization.

John McDiarmid of the Princeton faculty, the seventh ranking player of the country, and Donald McNeill of Oklahoma, national junior indoor champion, will meet at 2 o'clock this afternoon for the Eastern clay court title at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.
Eleven freshman scholarships totaling $2, 080 in value have been awarded by Stevens Institute of Technology. The winners and the scholarship values are:
Non-striking truck drivers of the Supplee-Wills-Jones Milk Company recruited their wives as guards today after four men were taken from their trucks and beaten in clashes with striking employes.

A dinner and dance were given by Municipal Court Justice Leopold Prince at the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park last night for the members of the City Amateur Symphony Orchestra, of which he is the conductor.
