Violence marking the strike of drivers of the Supplee-Wills-Jones Milk Company resulted today in injuries to four men and in the arrest of eighteen others.

A SCIENTIFIC study on the relationship between motor vehicle accidents and driver fatigue is being planned by the Interstate Commerce Commission. This study is not to be carried out by the commission, but will be made under the supervision of scientists and experts in other branches of the government.

THE old rock of Dutch Calvinism has caught the lightning again. Not long ago it was rumored that Crown Princess Juliana and her husband, Prince Bernhard, had traveled on Sunday, had even entered cafes on Sunday. Calvinists were scandalized.

The music festival opened tonight with a performance of Beethoven's "Fidelio" under Arturo Toscanini which far surpassed last year's presentation of the same work. It was heard by an immense and uncommonly brilliant audience which included the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, Margot Asquith and a large number of other notables.

Terroristic methods used against members of the city's foreign-born population to force them to buy lottery tickets were charged today in the arrest of Carmello Montelbano, 38, described by police as the local agent for a gang of lottery racketeers operating from New York and Newark.

The marriage of Miss Thelma A. Page, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry DeB. Page of Chatham, to Alan Van Orden Day, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Day, also of this place, took place today in Stanley Congregational Church. The Rev.

Miss Rodeene Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roderick Lee Johnston of this place, will be married to Oliver Arnold Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. O. Chester Johnson, also of Plainfield, next Saturday morning in All Saints Church, Millington, N. J. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Willis Parker.

There is still plenty of time for sowing seeds of biennials and perennials, yet it is none too soon to make preparations therefore. Among biennials to be planted during the next few weeks are pansies, forgetme-nots, wallflowers, sweet williams, foxglove, chieranthus, erysimum, campanulas and Iceland poppies.

Unless there is a turnover in the nine matches to be played tomorrow, the cup offered by Bernon S. Prentice for the biennial tennis competition between teams representing Oxford-Cambridge and Yale-Harvard is going back to England again. Yale-Harvard now hold the cup, having won it abroad two years ago.

Removal of New York's slum population to a 500-acre development between the Queensboro Bridge and Astoria is a cheaper and generally more desirable solution to the slum problem than rehabilitating the dwellings on the lower East Side, according to William Lescaze, skyscraper architect, who completed a series of lectures on "Contemporary Architecture" yesterday at Columbia University.

Approval of the objectives and accomplishments of the National Youth Administration's program of aid to needy college students is expressed by the membership of the Association of American Colleges in the report of a survey made public yesterday by Dr. H. C. Jaquith, president of Illinois College.

The undergraduate who is elected to membership in Phi Beta Kappa at a liberal arts university, thereby gaining the designation of "Grind," is probably more active in extracurricular activities than fellow students meeting graduation requirements with less hard won grades, according to a survey of the 1936-37 undergraduate membership of Princeton University's chapter of the national honorary society.

TELEVISION, looming on the horizon of the arts and sciences as a vast new in dustry combining much that is Hollywood with broadcasting, is a "natural" chapter in the recent 450,000-word report by the National Resources Committee to President Roosevelt.

Army fliers surveyed two wrecked planes today and wondered what to do with Julius Balmut, 16 years old, who, police said, was responsible for the $10,000 to $15,000 damage. Balmut was in the county jail.

All times referred to in these instructions are daylight saving time. Conditions The races will be sailed under the "Conditions Governing the Races for the America's Cup, 1937," agreed upon by the Royal Yacht Squadron and the New York Yacht Club.

Through Governor Paulo Ramos, the State of Maranhao, Brazil, is announcing an offer to make a 50 per cent cash payment on four unpaid coupons of its external secured sinking-fund 7 per cent gold bonds of 1928.
The Cabinet, after long deliberation, decided today that Salvador should resign at once from the League of Nations. The press generally applauds the action.

A wave of self-criticism by Soviet officials, invited by Joseph Stalin, brought charges of corruption today against the Foreign Trade Commissariat and a newspaper. Sergei Sudin, Vice Commissar for Foreign Trade, accused his own department of "carelessness, mismanagement, dishonesty and criminal wrecking of Soviet interests."
J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that the public need not fear that a national police organization will be established.

The Academy of Natural Sciences announces that two botanical expeditions have been sent to the Western United States to collect specimens for its museum, which already possesses more than 700,000 botanical items.

Brunete changed hands today in a series of smashing attacks and counterattacks that first drove the Loyalists completely out of their positions and then after dark carried them back into the important town on the southern tip of the government's new salient. The Insurgents still retained part of it.

ONE would have to travel back a long way in history to find a moment when the destinies of the human race were passing through narrower and more dangerous straits than in our present day. In imminent danger of being lost forever is the most precious possession of man, on which his future depends, or, at any rate, without which his future is worthless.

The most important factor which is keeping the realty sales volume in Bergen County, N. J., at a high peak at the present time, declares Alexander Summer, Teaneck broker, is the improved motor-bus transportation service.
The A. Y. Cornell Summer School of Music, which is open at St. Faith's School this season, will give a public concert at the Casino in Congress Park Thursday.
AMERICAN humor, developing in the nineteenth century, found its most fertile field in the American character. But the cultivation of that field took time.

Mr. and Mrs. Enos Wilder of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Wilder, to John Day Hegeman, son of Mrs. Myra D. Hegeman of Shippan Point, Stamford, and of John C. Hegeman of Larchmont, N. Y.

EACH Summer some ten million of New York's normally resident seven million, in pursuit of pleasure at Coney Island, Staten island, or Weehawken, wish the ferry would turn against the tide and tradition and head for the open sea. That longing is as much a part of the metropolitan make-up as is Radio City, and it is the theme upon which Victor Wolfhon has based "Excursion."

Importing of "strip-tease" dancers to lure employes from union meetings was charged in a complaint filed here today by Philip G. Phillips, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, against the Clover Fork Coal Company of Kitts, Harlan County, Ky.

S. Ashton Clark Jr. of Ridgewood, who carded a sub-par 68, and his partner, Robert Sickley, had a bestball card of 66 today to lead at the end of the first round in the third annual Cedar Ridge Country Club invitation golf tournament for the William T. Baird Jr. trophy. The tournament is a thirty-six-hole medal play best-ball event in which an invited star is paired with a member of the Cedar Ridge club.
President Anastasio Somoza announces that the directorate of the Nicaraguan National Bank, composed entirely of Nicaraguans, will be reorganized to give posts to three Americans.

Raul Navarro, a merchant and importer of Ciudad Trujillo, Dominican Republic, was killed yesterday afternoon when he fell from a fifth story window in the apartment of Dr. Joseph A. Gonzales at 129 West Seventy-fourth Street. The police listed the death as a suicide.

Norman H. Adelson of 115 West Eighty-sixth Street has announced the engagement of his sister, Miss Miriam Lucille Adelson, to W. Howard' Trowbridge, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Trowbridge of Nutley, N. J.

Sports visitors from foreign lands not only are welcome, but they also prove to be interesting to the American spectator. Certainly the arrival of Miss Jadwiga Jedrzejowska, the Polish tennis champion, is not the exception to this general rule.

ONE of the strangest companies in theatrical history is rehearsing this Summer at Vassar College with a cast composed of forty men and women of the Federal Theatre, who come from almost every State in the Union.

Among the residents of New York and vicinity who are at the Skytop Club Tor the week-end are Mr. and Mrs. Samuel T. Callaway, Mr. and Mrs. Nobel McConnell and A. S. Fedde, all of New York; Dr. and Mrs. Robert T. Wheeler of Brooklyn and Dr. and Mrs. Warren T. Titus of Glen Cove, L. I.

Mrs. Mary Brokaw Madison, widow of Neil Madison, died suddenly at her home, 84 Boston Post Road, last night. She was 73 years old. Born in Bound Brook, N. J., she was the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Brokaw. She had been a resident of Greenwich for the last thirty-three years.

Dr. Cyrus Adler, chairman of the Army and Navy Committee of the Jewish Welfare Board, announced yesterday that Jews serving in the army, navy, Ciliviaan Conservation Corps, Coast Guard service and Bureau of Navigation would receive furloughs enabling them to observe the High Holy Days and the Day of Atonement. The High Holy Days;

Opposition to a bill now in Congress, under the terms of which a national mortgage moratorium against the foreclosure of homes would be created, was expressed yesterday by the Brooklyn Real Estate Board.

Art O. Hedquist of Stapleton, S. I., was elected commander of the Richmond County American Legion at the annual convention yesterday at the Cromwell Recreation Center, Pier 6, Tompkinsville, S. I. Mr. Hedquist succeeds William Lamb of St. George, the retiring commander.

With the final action of expressing the indignation of Protestant churches toward the policy of church suppression by Germany, the World Conference on Church, Community and State closed tonight its two weeks of discussion of vital world problems.

A warning that coronary occlusion, "the disease of the intelligentsia," which caused the death of Senator Robinson, was the product of nervous strain and worry as much as of Physical condition was given to Congress today by Dr. George W. Calver, the Capitol physician.

Recognizing that an appreciation of music and the theatre is necessary part of a liberal education, Franklin and Marshall College will offer a series of cultural activities as part of its regular college program beginning this Fall.

The junior tennis tournament, for boys and girls under 18 years, will start on Monday at the Crawford House, Crawford Notch. This follows upon the thirty-second annual tournament for adults, which ends there today.
In an interview today Yotaro Sugimura, the newly arrived Japanese Ambassador to France, spoke of strengthening and extending the 1907 France-Japanese Treaty on Pacific possessions.

Mrs. Emil Denemark's War Minstrel drove to a nose victory at Suffolk Downs today in the $10,000 added Yankee Handicap to equal the track record for a mile and three-sixteenths. A camera finish decided, for the 3year-old gelded son of Royal Minstrel swept under the wire under a blanket with H. P. Metcalf's High Velocity.
WASHINGTON-American Indians are the fastest growing population group in the United States today, John Collier, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, recently told a House committee. The Indian population,

The Eastern Yacht Club annual regatta drew a fleet of twenty-nine boats today with the Class Q Robin taking the Puritan Cup for the fourth time, twice as the Norm, and twice now as the Robin. This year she is owned by Francis E. Waterman, with Richard S. Thayer as skipper.

In an opinion handed down today by Vice Chancellor Malcolm G. Buchanan five children of the late Mrs. Lillie S. Curtis of Summit were barred from sharing in her $175,000 estate. Mrs. Curtis was the widow of William H. Curtis, secretary at one time to the late John D. Rockefeller Sr.
Four Negro youths, who for six and onehalf years have lived in the shadow of the electric chair, were set free here today in a dramatic finale of the famous Scottsboro case.

SINCE men have fished for the joy of fishing and not for the sale of their catch, they have argued endlessly over the fighting qualities of their favorite quarry. In the matter of salt-water fishing the arguments have often ended in victory for the angler who could shout the loudest and hit the hardest.

The Commander-in-Chief of the Danish air fleet, Colonel C. C. J. Foerslev, has been arrested in Sicily by Fascist militia on suspicion of espionage. Colonel Foerslev was on a hiking vacation trip with his wife. The militiamen regarded them as tramps, disliked their cameras and put them in jail.

The Social Security Board has certified to the United States Treasury payment of $3,331,293 to New York State for its old-age benefit program, it was announced here yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, New York Regional Director of the board.

The iris is one f the oldest and one of the most admired of garden flowers. The Etruscans, who were highly civilized long before Rome was founded, devoted parts of their fine gardens to the "rainbow florwer."

MANY readers may still recoil at being reminded of the time, not so long ago, when the investor was pictured as potentially the most fortunate creature of all, for he could, so he was told, gain unlirnited wealth by a judicious use of limited resources if he only followed the lead of the captains of industry and finance.

Activities of the Federal Music Project throughout the country the next few weeks include the presentation of operas in a dozen cities, it was announced yesterday by Ellen S. Woodward, WPA assistant administrator in charge of women's and professional subjects.

The discovery of an Anarchist center in the city of Valdivia, where investigation brought to light a network of contacts with foreign organizations operating in South America, has set the police on the track of a number of similar groups, it is reported.

THE principal contract bridge tournament of the Summer, if not of the year, will begin Monday, Aug. 2, at Asbury Park, N. J. Dating from 1928, the Asbury Park Tournament has been conducted since 1930 by the American Bridge League. It consistently attracts the largest bridge-playing crowd which turns out for tournaments, the entry lists including players from the Middle West and in some years from the Pacific Coast and Europe.
Vines, so universally used for covering walls, are apt in a comparatively short while, unless very severely trained, to completely curtain the wall.

A movement was started by the Royal Academy of Science today to make a national monument of the late Marquis Guglielmo Marconi's yacht Elettra, on which the noted wireless inventor carried on most of his recent experiments.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Andrews of the Gotham, this city, and Englewood, N. J., have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Theodosia Burr Andrews, to Earl Seaton Neal, son of Mrs. Helen A. Neal of Berkeley, Calif. The marriage will take place Sept. 2.

The Taxpayers party, incorporated recently to protect the interests of property owners in the political field, will hold its first mass meeting next Wednesday in the Hotel Newton, Broadway and Ninety-fourth Street.

Whereas 171,458 workers left WPA projects from April to May, 106,530 who did not have jobs in April were taken on in May, so that the net decline in WPA employment was only 64,928, it was indicated in a set of statistics made public today by Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator.

In a fortnight's work by day and by night here Protestant leaders from all parts of the world have undertaken programs which, if carried out to the fullest extent, would constitute a revolution in the churches themselves as well as in their relation to humanity.

Captain F. R. Merritt of 313 Woodcliff Avenue, Freeport, L. I., and his nephew, Timothy Merritt, 12, were rescued by Coast Guardsmen today fifteen miles out in the Atlantic, after they had tossed about for eleven hours in a disabled cabin cruiser.

FROM strategic points along the thirty-mile course, a corps of radio announcers on land, at sea and in the air will broadcast a description of the start, progress and finish of the America's Cup races off Newport, R. I., starting July 31.

The engagement of Miss Miriam Greene, daughter of Mrs. William John Greene of this place and the late Lieut. Col. Greene, to Donald Joseph Hurley of Stoneham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius J. Hurley of Gardner, Mass., has been announced by her mother.

During the first four months of this year 2,671 Jews were aided in emigrating from Germany by agencies subsidized by the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, it was announced yesterday. This figure does not include those who were able to leave without aid.

IN an interestingly reasoned, very provocative, and-for a work of research-rather well written book, Lord Raglan advances a most interesting theory which should annoy poets and romanticists, stimulate scholars, and cause any historian who is 'won over to it to revise very thoroughly his approach.

With the favored Alick Girard Jr. of Southampton, Duane Tower of Niagara Falls and Medalist F. H. (Hike) Gouverneur of Belleair, Fla., all eliminated, the first annual Monroe Golf Club invitation tournament today resolved itself into a four-cornered contest among Rochester amateurs.

IN a foreword to "The Xscent of Nanda Devi" that very eminent authority on mounain climbing, Dr. T. G. Longstaff, says: "In the opinion of competent judges the achievement narrated in the following pages is the finest mountain ascent yet made, either in the EIimalavas or anywhere else.

With a fleet of 342 starters today, the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week came to a close, having broken all records for the numbers of contestants. The top figure for one day last year was 293. The six racing sessions for the weekly prizes starting last Saturday brought out on the several days 361 yachts, 335, 325, 321, 306 and 342 for a total of 1,990.

The marriage of Miss Mary Van Dusen Morrison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charler E. Morrison of this place, to Edgar G. Gibby of Roselle, N. J., took place this afternoon in All Saints Church. The Rev. William Grimme, rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, and the Rev. Alexander R. McKechnie of All Saints performed the ceremony.

Whether the British Royal Commission's recommendations for the partition of Palestine will be modified rests with the League of Nations and the British Parliament, but whatever they decide, one thing is certainthe partition proposal has caused a change in the situation here that may earn for the commission the gratitude of Jews and Arabs despite their protests against the plan.

Spy. sailed by Earl T. Van Sciver of the Island Heights Yacht Club, scored a smashing victory today in the historic Rodman Wanamaker Trophy race for catboats, and Britton Chance of the Mantoloking Yacht Club won the Class E Sloop contest, annexing the Wanamaker Cup in its group.

About seventy-five members of the Workers Alliance and the Teachers Union ended a fortyeight-hour "death watch" at 10 o'clock yesterday morning held at the headquarters of the local WPA, 70 Columbus Avenue, protesting against recent reductions in WPA rolls.

Announcement has been made by the Rev. and Mrs. Truman Heminway of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Honora Mary Heminway, to Raphael Pumpelly 3d, eldest son of Mr. and Mrs. Raphael Pumpelly of New York.
Rallying in the late stages of both games Toronto registered a double triumph over Jersey City today, winning the first game, 7-2, and the second, 6-5.

Cracksmen made off with a new "burglar-proof" safe from the branch offices of the Rubel Ice Corporation, 120 Mangin Street, on the lower East Side, some time Friday night. The theft was discovered shortly after midnight yesterday by the night manager.

Dr. and Mrs. Merrill N. Foote and their daughter, Miss Shirley Foote, have as their guests for the week-end at Grey Dunes, their home here, Miss Nancy Strange of South Orange, N. J.; Miss Mary Stanton of Rye, N. Y.; Henry Bertram, Andrew McCullaugh and Laurence Kammer.
Harry Wesson of Ware has been driving the same Stevens Duryea automobile for twenty six years and says that he expects it will see active service for several years more.

THE Three Choirs Festival will be held at Gloucester, England, in September, directed by Herbert Sumsion. The festival opens Sept. 7 with a performance of Mendelssohn's "Elijah" in the morning and of Elgar's "The Dream of Gerontius" at night.

As was to be expected from the draw, which placed the No. 1 players of their respective sides against the No. 2 representatives, Don Budge, American ace, defeated Charles Edgar Hare and Frank Parker lost to Henry Wilfred (Bunny) Austin, main hope of the defending British, in straight sets today in the opening matches of the Davis Cup challenge round.

While there were indications of the usual seasonal letdown in business activity in some sections of the country last week, reports in general from most of the leading trade centers continued favorable.
John M. Cassin, 38, of 119 Lecato Avenue, Audubon, N. J., was killed and Jean Highat, 27, of Somerville, was seriously injured today in an automobile crash.

Reeling off three fast miles, Hollyrood Perry, trotting gelding owned and driven by Eugene Carpenter of this city, won the Class A event for the outstanding performance of the Weequahic Park matinee today.

The Profile Golf Club here held its weekly tea today. Among those attending were Miss Mary Anne Vietor, Miss Alice Vietor, Alan Vietor, Mr. and Mrs. Tracy Voorhees, John Voorhees, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Poole, Nicholas and William Poole, Mr. and Mrs. John F. O'Brien, Miss Kathleen and Francis F. O'Brien, Miss Patricia Pike, Curtis Green, John Munday of London, Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Edge, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Sweeney and Miss Martha Sweeney.
Miss Adele LeB. Alsop, who is at the Red House, Tyringham, has fixed Sept. 11 as the date of her marriage to Henry A. C. Howard of Penrith, England.

Miss Joan Curtice Bickford, daughter of Frederick E. Bickford of this place and the late Mrs. Bickford, was married here this afternoon in Christ Church to Russell Morley Wickett, son of Mrs. Hedessa Wickett Cordley of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Sir Morley Wickett of Toronto, by the Rev. Francis J. H. Coffin.

The Japan-China crisis has become a factor in the proposed sale of three American ships to Japan's steel and iron scrap interests. The question was raised in Federal Court before Judge St. Sure when Sidney M. Hauptman, trustee for the Charles Nelson Company,

UMAR brought delight and invitation in his "Bag o' Tales" four years ago, and now "From Umar's Pack" comes the fourth book of ancient stories, retold for children to read or to listen to. Neither Miss Power's work of selection and editing, nor Miss Bayley's vivacious decoration, needs any introduction in itself.

FOLLOWING the lead or their more eminent precursors in the field of zoological classification, the WPA Federal Writers Project in New York City have compiled a volume preparing the layman for a visit to any large municipal zoo.

The marriage of Miss Lucia Harriett Sickles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Edgar Sickles of Newark, to E. Roland Anderson, formerly of East Orange, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eric H. Anderson of Bloomfield, took place this morning in the rectory of Christ Reformed Church here.

Accusing the Earle administration of establishing a system of political espionage in Philadelphia by tapping telephone wires of city employes, Mayor S. Davis Wilson angrily announced today that he would run for Governor next year "to meet this challenge."

SPECIAL silver and bronze medals have been struck by the Rochester Numismatic Association commemorating the 250th anniversary of the invasion of the French Army and Indian allies under the leadership of the Marquis de Denonville into the Seneca district.
Led by Donald Hawley of Orange, the defending titleholder, all six seeded players to see action in the North New Jersey net championships advanced at the Westfield Tennis Club today.

Japanese Army leaders are angered by the arrival here yesterday of General Hsiung Pin, vice chief of the Chinese general staff, who was alleged by them to have come to deliver a "pep talk" to the Chinese military leaders in the Peiping district.

A Department of Human Relations, to study tensions, frictions and conflicts arising from differences of race and nationality, background, class, culture and religion, is to be organized at the University of Newark in September.

World production of refined lead in June amounted to 147,157 tons, exclusive of Spain's output, compared with 157,930 in May, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. The total world production for the six months ended on June 30 was 893,804 tons. Lead production in the United States in June was 37,321 tons, bringing total output for the first half of 1937 to 239,052 tons.

Modern art in the sense the world has known it during the last two decades has now followed Marxism, the old religions, freedom of speech and press, and various conventions, including the old German form of greeting, into the Nazi ash can.

REVIVALS IN THE SUMMER THEATRES-And this is the list of plays, aside from the new ones, which are being shown during the week. Openings are tomorrow unless indicated. New York A BILL OF DIVORCEMENT, with Percy Waram-County Theatre, Suffern. AT MRS. BEAM'S, with Frances Farmer-Westchester Playhouse, Mount Kisco. NED McCOBB'S DAUGHTER-Starlight Theatre, Pawling.

Miss Betty Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton S. Brown of this place, has set Sept. 16 as the date for her marriage to William E. U. Udal, son of M. and Mrs. William Udal of Weymouth, Dorset, England.

An opportunity to operate under service conditions over an important and little-known strategic area of the Pacific probably was the most important by-product of the navy's extensive search for Amelia Earhart, it was pointed out yesterday.

New York looks for reduced quo-I tations on several sorts of produce. This will be due to increased re-' ceipts, in turn the consequence of favorable growing weather on the farms. Many fruits are apparently heading for a fall in price. Melons, led by the watermelon,

GUGTLIELMO MARCONI left radio as a legacy to mankind. Marconi heard the first whisper-like sputter of wireless in the Italian air over his father's estate at Bologna in 1895, and lived until 1937 to hear the stentorian "'spark" become a universal tongue that talked around the globe.

Clarence Faulkner of Whitehall, Ga., was the lone graduate of the University High School here yesterday. He was class prophet, historian, salutatorian, valedictorian and the member voted most likely to succeed.

Vendetta, derived from the Latin vindicta, revenge, is the Italian word for the blood feuds which until recent years prevailed in Corsica; under a custom requiring the nearest relative of a slain man to take vengeance, families remained embattled for generations.

A book entitled "Apartment House Rental, Investment and Management," has just been published by Prentice-Hall, Inc., New York City. It is designed as an aid to real estate men and apartment house owners and prospective investors in such dwellings. J. R. McGonagle is the author.

The Paisley pattern, one of fashion's favorites this season, traces its Scots name by devious route and reopens a forgotten chapter in history. The beautifully blended design originated in Cashmere, India, whose natives made a specialty of exquisite wraps, hand-woven from the fine long fleece of the Cashmere goat. Into every garment, covered with almost fairylike tracery, went years of patient toil and skill.

Guaranteed mortgage certificate holders have reorganized their own holdings, under the recent provision of the law which makes it possible when 100 per cent consent is secured, in the total sum of $7,543,737, the State Mortgage Commission reported yesterday.

The Alaska salmon fishing and canning industry, the product of which is worth about $42,000,000 a year, is "seriously threatened" by Japanese activities off the coast, Frank T. Bell, Commissioner of the Bureau of Fisheries declared today.

The international executive committee of the American Newspaper Guild held an all-day executive session yesterday, discussing the demand of the Columbus (Ohio) Guild for a membership referendum on the question of affiliation with the C. I. O. and on other actions taken at the recent St. Louis convention.

The Esso Bayonne, a 12,900-ton oil tanker built for the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, was launched this morning at the plant of the Federal Ship Building and Dry Dock Company here. The tanker is one of eight contracted for in a $13,000,000 building program.

ON the first floor of a brown stone building in Philadelphia the private banking firm of Jay Cooke Co. opened for business on Jan. 1, 1861. Quickly the firm grew and prospered until the name of Jay Cooke had become a household word. Then suddenly, on Sept. 18, 1873, the firm closed its doors forever, a crash precipitating a major financial panic.

THE annual Ford-Lincoln automobile show, usually staged in a midtown hotel concurrently with the national automobile show at Grand Central Palace, will be held this year in the Ford company's remodeled five-story building at 1,710 Broadway, according to a recent announcement.

Summer art colonies along the Massachusetts coast from Provincetown to Newburyport have been anxiously watching the attempt of Rockport's "stony-hearted" Selectmen to enforce the Sunday law in regard to art exhibitions, gift shoppers and other semi-esthetic, semi-commercial enterprises.
Wilson College announces the following are among the winners of scholarships established under the will of Dr. William Curran of Philadelphia:
Pierre S. du Pont 3d today sailed Nitramon to victory by 78 seconds over Chance, sailed by Arthur E. Whitney, in the H-23-foot class at the regular Saturday Fishers Island Yacht Club regatta.
Professor Alfred D. Sheffield of Wellesley, who spent many years in China, has received from Generalissimo and Mme. Chiang Kai-shek an account of the kidnapping of the Generalissimo on Dec. 12.

After a final inspection at Camp Smith today the members of the 106th Infantry of Brooklyn and the 105th Infantry of Troy, composing the Fifty-third Brigade, commanded by Brig. Gen. Bernard W. Kearney, were mustered out and paid off, their annual two weeks' training at an end.

The marriage of Mrs. Marie Striker Farrington of this city, daughter of the late Ellsworth L. Striker and the late Mrs. Florence Secor Striker, to Hugh E. McLaughlin, also of New York, son of the late Colonel and Mrs. J. Fairfax McLaughlin, took place here last night in the Church of St. Francis of Assisi. The Rev. Michael D. Lopez performed the ceremony in the presence of the two families.

Backed by enthusiastic support from yachtsmen and sports fishermen, a group of residents of Atlantic Highlands, N. J., and vicinity last week launched the grand finale of a movement that has been under way quietly and modestly for several years to establish a breakwater in Sandy Hook Bay to provide shelter and protection for as many as 1,000 pleasure craft and commercial party boats.

The Wagner-Steagall bill for low-cost housing and slum clearance, as reported to the Senate by its Education and Labor Committee, differs from previous housing bills in that it requires elimination of "unsafe or unsanitary dwellings," Senator Walsh pointed out today.

Dean Frank H. Sommer of the New York University School of Law announced yesterday the names of forty students, including three girls, who have been named winners of prizes and honors for excellence in scholarship in the 1936-1937 academic year. Thirty-five are residents of this city. The prize winners were:

Herculean efforts by Right Fielder Beau Bell, whose eighth and ninth homers tied the score for St. Louis in each game, went for naught today as the Browns' pitchers collapsed, enabling the Senators to take both ends of a doubleheader by the same score, 6 to 5.

Realty deals in metropolitan area announced yesterday were featured by the sale of a large housing property in Westchester County. A syndicate headed by Harry Hoberman bought from the builders the garden apartments and stores at 1 South Broadway, White Plains. There are 237 rooms laid out in seventy-five apartments in the building, which was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $520,000 held by the Excelsior Savings Bank.

Georges Bonnet, still the titular French Ambassador to Washington, but Acting Minister of Finance in France, leaned back in his chair behind his Ministerial desk in the old palace of the Tuileries and sighed.
Two residents of an unspecified border district were guillotined today, convicted of betraying military secrets to some foreign power.

Peruvian gold production in 1936 amounted 4,740 kilograms, valued at $5,334,315 (United States currency), this being the highest figure recorded in the republican era and an increase of 1,293 kilograms over 1935.

More than 200 college and high school students are spending their vacations this Summer at hard work without pay, under the auspices of the Volunteer Work Camps of the American Friends Service Committee.

HALF a year ago Carl Burckhardt was chosen to fill the important post of League of Nations Commissioner for the city of Danzig. A native of Basle, Switzerland, he is by his personality eminently fitted for this position.

The Right Rev. William Appleton Lawrence, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Western Massachusetts, has come from Bar Harbor, Me., to participate in the 175th anniversary celebration of St. James Church in Great Barrington, which will be observed tomorrow.

Arthur de Souza Costa, Minister of Finance of Brazil, yesterday denied charges printed recently in the German Frankfurter Zeitungto the effect that the recently concluded trade agreement between the United States and Brazil was unfair. He was interviewed at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton.

If the low rate of business failures shown during the first half of the year is continued, the 1937 total, with one exception, will be the smallest since 1894, when compilations were first started, according to a survey here yesterday.

In the sixth regular matinee of the Nassau Driving Club all the races were won in two straight heats at the Mineola Fair Grounds today. Alexandria, bay mare, driven by A. Seaman, took the first heat after a close battle with Dr. Watts, bay gelding driven by C. N. Bliss Jr.

After two years of preparation we are off for the first great flight from Russia to the United States via the North Pole. Factory smoke stacks flash by, and our engine roars with full power, as Pilot Valery Chkaloff steers our mighty plane gradually upward.

NEW proof has been provided as to what happens when a millionaire builds an opera house as a present for his wife and starts something different in opera that has socialites and music lovers alike scrambling for tickets.

As soon as the farmer has finished cutting his hay he and the hired man take a hand at the brush. Beside the road and along the margins of his fields it is stubbornly crowding his free domain. For the land is trying to return to its original state; and cultivation of the fields, like cultivation of the mind, is an endless labor.

ANY suspicion that Newport is reserved or inhospitable to the stranger is due for revision this year. Disproof will be found in the welcome prepared for the visitors drawn by the International Yacht Races, beginning next Saturday.

Civilian sailors from five communities in up-State New York embarked on a training cruise yesterday morning at the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn. Seven destroyers, built for service in the World War, will carry the 525 reservists to Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, and return to this port on Aug. 6.

NOW that the heated season is upon us, the Philistines are having another go at Mr. Epstein. This has been one of the favorite hot-weather sports of British Philistines for something like thirty years.

Analysis of real estate cycles and statistics on city growth for the 100year period from 1837 to 1937 has enabled the Federal Housing Administration to substitute reasoned judgment for guesswork in mortgage - lending operations, states James S. Taylor, associate director of the economics and statistics division.

This year marks the twentieth anniversary of the inception of the reforestation project which has transformed the region surrounding the Oradell Reservoir in Bergen County, N. J., into a well-wooded tract, protecting the water supply of a population exceeding 400,000.

This is to be international yachting week. Next Friday night will find guests in practically every one of the Summer homes of the city, guests who have gathered to witness the sailing of one or more of the races for the America's Cup.
Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe submitted an application for voluntary retirement tonight to Walter 0. Briggs, president of the Detroit Tigers.

Police boarded the Spanish freighter Baurdo today when crew members, sympathetic to the Spanish Government, mutinied and tried to force the captain and ship's officers, friendly to the Rebel cause, to take the ship to a governmentheld Spanish port.
CERTAIN correspondents apprise this column that it did not give George Gershwin his due last Sunday. One claims that his music was underestimated.

HOLLYWOOD offers no more intriguing sport than stalking the elusive choreographer (or dance director, as he is locally known) through the jungle of studios. It is a difficult sport for the huntsman at large; indeed, a choreographer hunt is quite impossible without the cooperation of the gentlemen from the various publicity departments.

THE author of this dramatic Revolutionary biography warns us that, as was the case with the doughty Colonel Smith himself when he wrote the story of his captivity among the Indians, he "apprehends a great part of it will be viewed as fable or romance."

Arthur (Tootsie) Herbert, alleged head of the live-poultry racket in New York City, and two other poultry-union officials will go on trial tomorrow before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora and a jury in Supreme Court on charges of embezzling funds from the Chicken Drivers, Chauffeurs and Helpers Union, Local 167.

The Joseph P. Day Management Corporation reports a 100 per cent rental of all available space in two buildings under that management at 39-41 West Thirty-second Street and 209-13 West Forty-eighth Street, respectively.

St. Elmo's fire, on which was put the blame this week for the explosion which killed thirty-six voyagers on the Hindenburg, is a phenomenon which mariners often have noted on their masts and rigging during stormy weather.

HEREWITH a sternapxamination of the separate and then the joint records of John Murray and Allen Boretz, whose combination of typewriters produced the "Room Serv'ice" which George Abbott has lodged at the Cort Theatre.
The New Jersey delegation of the Ancient Order of Hibernians reelected officers here today at the close of the annual convention in the Hotel Jefferson.
Judge Walter C. Lindley of the Federal district court indicated today a hearing Wednesday on contempt citations against ten Committee for Industrial Organization members would be held in Chicago.

The 125th anniversary of the Clark family in the sewing-thread business was celebrated last night in the Montclair Country Club here with a dinner to John B. Clark, president of the Clark Thread Company, given by executives of the company and its affiliates.

" PINK SLIP" exhibition, made up of work by about seventy artists recently dismissed from the WPA Federal Art Project, opened last week at the A. C. A. Gallery in Eighth Street, where it may be visited until the end of the month.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dwight Hilles have as their guests at Seatuck Lodge, their home here on the bay in Remsenburg, their daughter, Mrs. George Reynolds of Pittsfield, Mass., and her children.

Wilmer Allison, the wily Texan, successfully concluded his quest to retire the Longwood Bowl when he scored a smashing Tictory over Gilbert Hunt of Washington, D. C., 2-6, 6-3, 6-0, 6-4, in the final of the forty-fifth annual tournament today in the Sheafe Memorial Stadium of the Longwood Cricket Club.
Acting on a ruling of Registrar Frank A. Goodwin, William E. Heaton, State aviation inspector, today halted scheduled trials of five gasoline-powered model airplanes at Bowles Airport.

BUFFALO, N. Y.-With the completion this Fall of sodium vapor lamps along five miles of Route 5 near here, and nine miles along Route 11 near Syracuse, New York will take the lead among all States for the most mileage of highways illuminated with the new orangeglow safety lights.

This year's cup series is the third since boat-for-boat competition was adopted in 1871 that the yachts have not raced on time allowance, the first being the match between Enterprise and Shamrock V in 1930 and the second the 1934 match between Rainbow and Endeavour.
The Indians defeated the Red Sox today, 6 to 5, in the eleventh inning to even their series when Roy Hughes, running for Pitcher Joe Heving, slid across the plate after a fly by Roy Weatherly.

A protest against the addition by the Senate of the Miller-Tydings Retail Price Maintenance Bill as a rider on the District of Columbia Tax Bill was made today by Representative Celler of New York. Mr. Celler expressed resentment that the House would now be unable to vote directly on the bill on its own merits.

Dr. George H. Parker, who retired from the Harvard University faculty two years ago, is studying fish to find out how nerves affect human temperament. The 72-year-old former Professor of Zoology, tall, tanned and bearded, is working in a laboratory at the Oceanographic Institution.
Joining in fishing parties arranged by members of the Ausable Club for next week will be several of the women guests who have been active in the sport during the week.

HOMEWARD bound on the last lap of our six months' journey, and very wistful about it. Good-bye at last to Hollywood. We spent the last day there lolling on the margin of our tiled pool, where young movie players and press agents clowned in the hot sun. Then a round of "ghost," the word game. Movie stars are not good spellers.

An ambitious urban plan for opening new streets, avenues and boulevards, some up to 100 feet wide, at an estimated cost of $15,000,000; demolition of hundreds of buildings and boring of two tunnels has been approved, and the work will be begun immediately by the newly appointed Rio de Janeiro Federal Commissioner, Henrique Dodsworth.
Manhattan Island was depicted as the cradle of the brewing industry in the New World yesterday in a statement from the United Brewers Industrial Foundation.
The voting trust which has dominated the corporate affairs of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company for the last fifteen years will be dissolved soon, it was said yesterday.

Thirteen Washington golfers and one from British Columbia qualified yesterday to enter the national amateur tournament to be held at Portland next month. Only Marvin (Bud) Ward of Olympia was able to break par. Ward shot two 70s. Par is 71.

Miss Adelaide Merrill Drew, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Almus Drew of Camp Rich, Milton, Vt., and Bradenton, Fla., was married here this afternoon in All Saints' Chapel to Edward Landon, son of Mrs. Charles Baldwin Landon of Milton, and the late Mr. Landon. The Right Rev. Vedder Van Dyck, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Vermont, performed the ceremony in the presence of relatives and a few friends.
THE author of this book is a Scotch botanist who was commissioned in the Summer of 1935 to collect specimens of Alaskan flora for the Kew Gardens and ethnological specimens for Cambridge University.
WILLIAM BECKFORD is one of those creatures of history who, from what is eccentric and outrageous in their lives, outlive their betters.
State clubwomen have unveiled a monument marking the grave here of "Aunt Harriet" Tubman, heroine of the "underground railroad" of pre-Civil War days.

IT is a misfortune to mankind that these books and others like them should have to be described as timely. They discuss the problem of war, and of both of them it may be said that the object is to shed light without engendering heat.

The Merchants Association announced yesterday that Senator Moore of New Jersey had introduced a bill in the Senate to amend the Federal Motor Carrier Act so that the definition of the metropolitan district of New York given by the Bureau of the Census would be accepted in the administration of the act.
IN search of unexplored by-paths in their trend to specialization, a few stamp collectors have dis covered in ships'letters a fascinating field of original coversstamped and unstamped.

IT is a misfortune to mankind that these books and others like them should have to be described as timely. They discuss the problem of war, and of both of them it may be said that the object is to shed light without engendering heat.
The voting trust which has dominated the corporate affairs of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company for the last fifteen years will be dissolved soon, it was said yesterday.

The series of festival concerts began at the Mozarteum this morning. Artur Rodzinski, who caught on so quickly here last Summer and whose recent sensational success in Vienna is still reverberating in Austrian musical circles, conducted.

The week's markets here were quiet, but, despite considerable profit-taking, the average quotations for securities were more than maintained. A bull factor on the Boerse was the pronouncement of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's private organ, Deutscher Wolkswirt, against extremist demands for expropriatory taxes on business.
MEA CULPA, by Louis-Ferdinand Celine. (Little, Brown, $2.) Two essays. ON GILBERT HEAD: MAINE DAYS, by Elizabeth Etnier. (Little, Brown, $2.50.) Life on a small Maine Island. An intimate diary.

WASHINGTON, July 25.--The Agricultural Adjustment Administration's report for 1936, made public today, showed that cash farm income reached $8,100,000,000, or about twice as much as in 1932, and that the AAA received applications for grants under the Soil Conservation Act from farmers covering 67 per cent of the total crop land of the United States.
The Good Neighbor League announced yesterday that Dr. Stanley High had resigned as its executive director and that the organization had been reincorporated to enlarge its program and membership.

Mayor La Guardia has told his intimate advisers that he does not want the Republican nomination, it was learned yesterday, but would prefer to run for re-election as the candidate of the American Labor party, with the endorsement of the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee, the City Fusion party and other independent groups.

The National Bureau of Casualty an Surety Underwriters has announced revisions in the manual of glass insurance, effective today. Higher rates are effective in Gary, Ind.; Portsmouth and Youngstown, Ohio; Dallas and Fort Worth, Texas: Hampton, Newport News. Roanoke, Salem, Portsmouth and Norfolk, Va.; all of West Virginia except Charleston; Milwaukee County, Racine, and Superior, Wis.
The general tendency was better on the Bourse this week. French rentes were particularly favored, some recording advances of six or seven points.

The dollar value of sales on all registered securities exchanges in the first six months of 1937 exceeded the total in the same period of last year by 5.6 per cent, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
Argentina is far ahead of schedule on a fifteen-year road-building program designed to give the nation a modern communications system. It is to cost about $162,000,000.

While all types of alcoholic liquors, backed by extensive promotional campaigns, appeared to have registered substantial gains in the city during the Summer, the largest percentage increases have been made by rum, according to comment here yesterday. Although actual figures

A woman was killed and nine persons injured near here early this afternoon in an automobile collision on the White Horse Pike. The dead woman, Mrs. Mary Ziegler, 34 years old. of 352 Kerper Street, Philadelphia, was the mother of three children.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Progressive educators everywhere have stressed the significance of kindergarten work. Accordingly I earnestly suggest that the World Fair should contain a model, up-to-date kindergarten building, surrounded by trees, fruit and flower-bearing shrubs and plants and a children's garden showing the young visitors how to sow flowers and vegetable seeds, and cultivate the plants.
28th St, s s. 100 ft e of 6th Ave. 99x98.9: 50 W 28th St Corp to Irving J. Adamson, 1,024 Trinity Ave, Bronx; mtg, $507,500 (50 cents).

" The Church of Christ will never succeed in converting the world," the Rev. Dr. John H. McComb, pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, Broadway and 114th Street, said in his evening sermon yesterday. "Nevertheless, it is our duty to evangelize it-to tell all men.
Albert F. Granser Jr., a retired New York policeman, died at his home, 97-42 106th Street, Richmond Hill, on Saturday evening after a brief illness. He was a member of
A South Shore Polo Club four composed of Charley Bernuth, Arthur Kaye, Bernie Blausen and Martin Christensen vanquished the

A 5year-old boy was dead and his mother and two other children were in critical condition from gas poisoning tonight after they had been found lying unconscious in the kitchen of their apartment at 249-08 Jericho Turnpike, Bellerose.
Activities on the usual Sunday scale continued at the near-by German-American camps yesterday, but they were restricted largely to swimming, beer-drinking and relaxing generally.

Lloyd (Whitey) Moore, right-handed pitcher farmed out by the Cincinnati Reds, joined the International League Hall of Fame tonight by pitching a no-hit, no-run game to give the Chiefs a 1-to-0 victory over the Jersey City Giants.
From the mountains to the seacoast, Southerners are "Big Appling." The dance is a combination of the old-fashioned square dance and the modern "swing."
Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's and Womrath's:

Charles Cohen, attorney for the raided dog race track of the Orangeburg Kennel Club, said today he expected to obtain a temporary Federal injunction and predicted the track would be open again tomorrow night.

Extreme idleness prevails in the security markets here but this is scarcely surprising in view of the lack of any progress in clarifying the European situation, the uncertainties in the Far East and the fact that the holiday season now is in full swing.

The first of the four concerts of the Federal Music Project's delayed Wagner series was given before an audience of good size at the WPA Theatre of Music last night Each of these events was designed to deal with a definite period in the composer's career, with the music chosen for performance arranged in chronological sequence. But, due to unforeseen circumstances, this intention could not be carried out fully with the opening program.

The Christian Church faces decadence unless its leaders develop the "undying enthusiasm" of Communist and Fascist disciples, the Rev. Dr. Frank A. Hunger declared in a guest sermon yesterday at the Fort Washington Presbyterian Church, Broadway and 174th Street.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25.--Mayor S. Davis Wilson not only declined today to apologize to Governor Earle for his charges that the Administration had set up a political espionage system here as a plot against the municipal regime but he in turn called upon the Governor to offer apologies to the Mayor and the citizens of Philadelphia.

Joseph R. Brodsky, counsel for the State Committee of the Communist party, announced yesterday that an appeal on the refusal of the Secretary of State to accept designating petitions of the Communist party would be heard at a special session of the Court of Appeals at Albany tomorrow.
A shortage of stocks and bonds prevailed here this week and, despite profit-taking sales, on the whole the market was firm until today, when declines were shown.
A mother and three daughters were burned to death early today in a fire in their home. Her husband and three young sons escaped by jumping from a second-story window.
EDGAR F. HIGGINS Jr., radio news editor, 68 W. 10th St.-Liabilities $660; no assets. SAM. POLAND, 67 Park Ave., Monticello-. Liabilities $5,267; no assets except insurance.

Miss Frances O'Brien, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. O'Brien of Albany, was married to George Newcomb Stainsby, son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Stainsby of Glens Falls, yesterday in the garden of the bride's Summer home here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Orr of Amsterdam.
The movement of commodities by motor truck in June reflected a continued gain in the business, according to figures made public today by the American Trucking Associations, Inc.

In a further slump this week the value of the French franc in relation to the pound sterling touched its lowest level since November, 1926. Varying views are expressed here concerning the drastic economies that are proposed for balancing the French budget.

Japanese airplanes bombed the Chinese barracks at Langfang, strategic midway point on the railway between Tientsin and Peiping, this morning in what may prove to be the spark to set off large-scale hostilities in North China.

Another hot day yesterday rounded out a perfect week-end for visitors to the shore and country. As though in consideration for returning office workers, the weather man promised cooling showers today and a let-up of high temperatures.

Dribbling the ball seventy yards for a score in 1:10 of a "sudden death" period, Shaw Robinson brought a revised Knaves quartet a 7-6 verdict over the Shamrocks in a contest between Bethpage Polo Club quartets today at Bethpage State Park.
Treasury officials reported tonight that they had increased tax claims against the Associated Gas and Electric system by about $4,000,000 to about $55,000,000.

Regulation of collection agencies to keep them within their legitimate field and prohibit them from doing the work of lawyers is called for in a statement of principles adopted by a committee of lawyers representing the State Bar Association, it was announced here today.
Mrs. Dumont Foote has arrived at the Westbury from Blue Hill, Me., where she visited Dr. and Mrs. John Moorhead.

Patrick J. Pagan, president of District 5 of the United Mine Workers of America, said today that all strikebound. "captive" coal mines of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation probably would resume normal operations this week.
Jean Borotra, the tennis player, married yesterday Mrs. Mabel Barrechin, the former Miss de Forest, according to The London Daily Mail's Paris edition. The ceremony, which took

The National Labor Relations Board, in the case of Harry G. Beck of Baltimore, trading as Rocks Express Company, today ordered reinstatement of four employes held to have been discharged for. labor union activities.
El Mundo today announced the conformation of the execution of a young Puerto Rican student, Carmelo del Gardo, by Spanish Rebels.
Members of the crew of a New Orleans banana steamship reported to have "mutinied" last night as the ship lay at anchor in the Mississippi River today described their action as a "sit-down" strike.
Mrs. Nora Remsberg, 57, widow of Elmer Remsberg, a dentist, was found hanged in the basement of her home this morning. Her son, Henry,
June Howard-Tripp, the former Lady Inverclyde, announced at a party at the Casino here yesterday her engagement to Edward Hillman, wellknown Beverly Hills (Calif.) polo player.
After a trial spin, T. O. M. Sopwith took Endeavour II to Bristol today for a final grooming before the first of the America's Cup races next Saturday.

An outdoor memorial mass celebrated at the entrance to the fourcentury-old Porta Coeli Church today marked the anniversary of the landing of American troops in 1898. Bishop Aloysius J. Willinger prayed for the repose of the souls both of Americans and of Spaniards who lost their lives in that conflict.

Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn presided at a mass yesterday morning at St. Gertrude's Church, Beach Channel Drive and Beach Thirty-eighth Street, Far Rockaway, Queens, celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the dedication of its edifice.

Money rates here tended lower this week and the Gold Discount Bank has succeeded in prolonging its promissory note liabilities. The bank's balance sheets for June 30, however, indicate that the last Reich loan strained credit.

Through new taxation and reduced expenditures, the total of which will reach 25,000,000,000 francs, the budgets for 1937-38 will be balanced and the amount France's Treasury will have to borrow to cover extraordinary expenditures forecast for 1938 will be reduced from 47,000,000,000 francs to 22,000,000,000.

Although generous orders were placed in the wholesale market here last week on better merchandise, a decided trend toward conservatism was noted, and buyers were reluctant to cover requirements for more than four to six weeks of the Fall season. Costume suits were

Governor Gleissner of Upper Austria, in a speech delivered at Wels today, announced that severe reprisals would be taken for the recent Nazi demonstration there during a gathering of Austro-German war veterans.

After pounding five St. Louis pitchers unmercifully in the opener of a double-header today, the Senators kept right on blasting and captured the final, 15 to 5. The Senators won the first game, 16 to 10.
Mr. and Mrs. Eugene du Pont entertained today. Guests included their son and daughter, Nicholas S. and Aimee du Pont and their houseguests, Walter Wickes and Genevieve Estes.

The week-end was crowded with entertainments in the leading Berkshire resort towns. More than 300 were present at the combined Stockbridge golf tournament ball and horse show ball at the Stockbridge Golf Club last night.

Political opponents of Governor Carl E. Bailey waited today for definite word from Mrs. Ewilda Gertrude Robinson whether she would run as an independent candidate against the 42-year-old Chief Executive in a special election to succeed her late husband, Senator Joseph T. Robinson. No announcement was

Pursuant to an agreement with Irving J. Adamson the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co extended a mortgage for $507,500 on 44-50 W 28th St to Apr. 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent. Mr. Adamson then transferred this property back to the 50 W 28th Corp, Wilfred J. Byrne, vice president.

Miss Margaret Church, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Church of Montclair, N. J., was married to James Daly, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Daly of New York, in the Unitarian Church here last night. The bride was escorted by
Under the pressure of a growing movement for quick adjournment, both houses of Congress will convene tomorrow with a number of important measures waiting action.

The Phillies and Reds divided a double-header today before 7,000. Cincinnati took the first game, 13 to 3, and the Quakers the nightcap, 7 to 3. Gaining momentum as the game wore on, the Reds turned the opener into a rout, slugging three Philadelphia pitchers, Johnson, Mulcahy and Crawford, for seventeen hits.
Ralph Ferro, 52 years old, who was shot while resisting a hold-up in his drug store at 107 Court Street, Brooklyn, on July 5 died yesterday in Long Island College.

While Mr. and Mrs. W. Deering Howe, two daughters, eighteen servants and two German shepherd dogs slept, a super-quiet prowler stole $1,800 in cash and three gold cigarette cases valued at $200 each from the twenty-five room Howe mansion on Tappan Road here between 1:30 and 7:30 o'clock this morning.

The army expressed willingness today to give "serious consideration" to poison gas which J. Leon Prenn, chemistry student at Iowa State College, says he has perfected. Prenn believes it will destroy gas masks. "We are not going to
The estate of Claus Spreckles Sr., whose wealth dwindled from millions to a truck worth $20, was recorded as settled today in court files.

IT was getting along toward closing time at Empire City and Racing Secretary John Blanks Ouachita Steam Navigation Company Campbell-his full name according to his assistant, Francis P. Dunne-was telling of preparations for moving on to Saratoga. He already had his boat anchored in the river up at Schuylerville. He thought it would be a fine meeting, this
Freeport will sponsor an aquatic parade of sport fishing and commercial boats on Sunday which will be reviewed at Zachs Bay, Jones Beach, by Commissioner Robert Moses.

Assistant Chief Inspector John A. Lyons, in charge of the Detective Bureau at Police Headquarters, talked over the telephone yesterday afternoon with his assistant, Captain Conrad Rothengast, at Belgrade Lakes, Me., where he went on Friday to interrogate Mrs. Stella M. Crater, wife of Joseph Foree Crater, the missing Supreme Court justice.
A king acting as spokesman for his Government is unusual enough at a time when royalties keep their thrones by playing a strictly symbolic role.
Lefty Grove, veteran Red Sox southpaw, subdued the Indians, 4 to 1, today in a game that rain halted in the fifth inning.
A 17-year-old girl was burned to death and seven persons were injured early today when fire destroyed a two-story frame house in the rear of 84 Old Bergen Avenue.

Although building plans in Great Britain in June showed a further reduction, the general state of trade remains satisfactory. All heavy industries continue active, railway receipts continue to expand, shipping and freight are still rising in volume,

Miss Gloria Callen, youthful star of the Women's Swimming Association, today enhanced her reputation as one of the coming young mermaids of the East by winning the senior metropolitan 880-yard freestyle championship in the A. A. U. aquatic carnival at the Lido Country Club.
Representative Hamilton Fish today stated that the proposed partition of palestine by the British Government was "an amazing suggestion and a deliberate breach of trust"

Taxable real property in the State was $30,254,215,911 in 1936, as compared to $30,476,616,979 in 1935, the new State equalization table shows. It was made public today by Mark Graves, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance.

Panama will not in any way impede the immediate entrance of United States armed forces into the country under the new join treaty if this should become necessary for wartime defense of the Panama Canal, according to President Juan D. Arosemena.

June was the record business month for the nation's commercial air lines, the Air Transport Association of America reported today. Revenue passenger-miles flown amounted to 41,180,337, compared with the previous high record of 40,104,800 miles, in July, 1936.
English conservatism about divorce may be reasonably defended not only on religious and moral grounds but for its contrast with American laxity.

Only Christ can save man from the destruction that is bound to result from the civil wars being waged in each personality, according to the Rev. Ralph Hartley, who preached the sermon at the Fort George Presbyterian Church, St. Nicholas Avenue and 186th Street yesterday.
(Figures in parentheses indicate par) Bayside (71)--Semi-final round for President's Cup: J. Mandell defeated R. Pepino, 1 up (27 holes); G. Hiers defeated R. Main, 6 and 4.
Julius Brittlebank, 78 years old, of Charleston, S. C., died today in Queens Hospital, where he was taken last night after becoming ill on the Dollar liner President Polk.

Paul Kerby made his second appearance of the season as conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium last night. His program began with a fanfare that was followed by Elgar's "Land of Hope and Glory," which contributions were announced as "a gesture of friendship and good-will during the present British coronation season." The attendance was 3,000.

Music in heaven is supplied by a choir of angels and we are safe in surmising that the celestial orchestra is using a rhythm but loosely related to modern swing, declared the Rev. John B. Delaunay yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company and its subsidiaries report, for the twelve months ended on June 30, a net income of $2,970,105, after charges, but before provision for the undistributed-profits tax. This compares with a net profit

Wilson McNeely's Star Dust, last year's Chesapeake Bay champion, won today's contest for International Star Class sloops over the triangular course off the Seaside Park Y. C. Clifford Grover Jr.'s Teaser, which set the pace most of the way, trailed at the finish by only four seconds after a prolonged luffing duel.

Polo's high-goal players began preparations for the coming national championships today with a fast game on International Field. An Old Westbury team consisting of Ivor Balding, Earle Hopping, Stewart Iglehart and Eric Tyrrell-Martin just managed to stand off the determined bid of an Aknusti outfit on which Elbridge and Robert Gerry, Tommy Hitchcock and Robert Strawbridge played.

Representatives of the American Federation of Musicians, A. F. of L. affiliate, will meet today with spokesmen for the Columbia, National and Mutual broadcasting systeams to discuss the union's proposal for restricting the use of recordings on the air and in restaurants and movie theatres.

It was reported in highly reliable quarters tonight that armed Spanish Rebel trawlers had seized the Soviet motorship Varlaam Avanesov in the Strait of Gibraltar this evening and taken her to Ceuta, Morocco, where the cargo was being discharged. [The Varlaam Avanesov is a 6,557ton vessel, which was built in Sweden in 1932.]

A civilization of mutual service was discussed as the world's ideal yesterday morning by the Right Rev. Irving Peake Johnson, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Colorado, in his sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

One cannot read the pronouncements of the conference of the 800 church and lay leaders in Oxford without feeling that it will be included among the most significant councils of the Christian churches. Its voice will be heard around

" The American pulpit must be awake and alert if it hopes to influence the thought and life of American men and women," declared the Rev. John Walter Houck, pastor of Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse at 175th Street, the Bronx, in a sermon preached there yesterday.
Sir Charles Saunders, whose Marquis wheat caused many to call Western Canada "the granary of the world," died quietly at his home here today. He had been in poor

The Yankees went from the ridiculous to the sublime today, nose-dived again to the farcical and had to be content with a split of the double-header with the White Sox on wind-swept, paper-littered Comiskey Park before a capacity gathering of 50,000.
A debacle in the July delivery of corn, with the price dropping 22 1/2 cents from the high level on Tuesday to the low on Friday, was outstanding in trading in that grain here last week.

For the fourth consecutive week, the stock market continued to advance, with industrial shares leading at the highest levels of the current movement. Second-quarter reports announced to date have been exceptionally good, although the profit margin in some instances has been cut slightly.

Miss Irene Simon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Simon of this city, was married yesterday at the Ambassador to Morton R. Tolleris, son of Judge and Mrs. Charles Tolleris, also of this city, by the Rev. Dr. Abraham Feinberg.

Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, chief custodian and director of all activities connected with the National Socialist Weltanschauung (philosophy), denied categorically today that he had issued "encyclicals" to party leaders calling for the extermination of the Christian church in Germany and its substitution by neo-paganism.

The Wages and Hours Bill now before Congress, as revised in committee, is subject to the same objections as the original measure, according to a report of a special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

One of the most upsetting factors in the "spiritual experience of our day," according to the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in a sermon yesterday at the Riverside Church, "is the disturbing fear that religious insights and faiths are poetic rather than factual-that they are romantic rather than rational-the creatures of our wishful imagination rather than of our careful investigation.

The harvesting of rye has proceeded favorably to date, but cutting of the wheat crop has been retarded by weather conditions. As a result the new wheat will not be on the market for several weeks yet. Meanwhile,

" America as the world's greatest arena for the exercise of ambition and the traditional home of selfmade men and women is rapidly becoming a fading memory," declared the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Prince, Professor of Economics in the University of King's College, Halifax, N. S., in his sermon at St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, West Sixty-ninth Street near Broadway, yesterday.

Amos Pinchot, liberal leader who broke with the New Deal last year, declared in an open letter to President Roosevelt, made public yesterday, that the three major measures he has sent to Congress since his re-election would, if enacted, "throw the country into fascism in a fortnight."

Fiscal officials-passed the word today that President Roosevelt might instruct government credit agencies to tighten their lending and collection policies in an effort to balance the budget this fiscal year.
After having spent five months in Europe King Farouk returned this morning, four days prior to his investiture as King of Egypt. The 17-year
The old Seventh Regiment, Manhattan's 107th Infantry, commanded by Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, entered Pine Camp at Great Bend today for the first time in a decade.

The Governors Island Blues, led by W. H. (Billy) Nichols, provided the biggest upset thus far in the second annual Eastern Polo League championship by defeating the Monmouth County Country Club four, 8--7, yesterday at Morris Memorial Field.

Two major unions identified with the C. I. O. have turned on the Roosevelt Administration, accusing it of indifference to "flagrant and wanton violations" of the rights of strikers, and of failure to enforce the law against employers in the steel industry.

The marriage of Miss Sarah Goldberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Goldberg of 1,800 Albemarle Road, Brooklyn, to Abraham M. Lowenthal, son of Mrs. Ethel Abramowitz Lowenthal, also of Brooklyn, and the late Michael Lowenthal, took place here yesterday afternoon in the North Garden of the Astor.
The South Shore Polo Club spotted the Squadron C Yellows of Huntington, L. I., six goals and then proceeded to beat them, 10-8, today at Hazard Field.

Lawrence Stern Co., Inc., will offer today 75,000 shares of capital stock of Esquire-Coronet, Inc., at $16 a share. This does not constitute new financing by the company, but represents the sale by present holders of 75,000 shares out of 500,000 outstanding.
Judge James Joseph Kelly of the Superior Court died early this morning in Mercy Hospital after a blood transfusion failed to strengthen him.

A number of the members of the debutante group, headed by Miss Marsyl Stokes, who is to be introduced next Saturday night, attended the international tennis tournament today at the Casino. Late in the afternoon a tea was given in honor of the visiting college tennis players by Mrs. James Laurens Van Alen at Wakehurst.

Most of those who have looked into the housing situation in the United States will agree, first, that the housing needs of the lower income groups cannot be met without some form of public subsidy; second, that

While inability of the British steel industry to keep pace with current demands arises from a shortage of raw materials such as coke, scrap steel and iron ore, it is the latter which presents the most serious problem.

Led by Roger Lapebie, the French cycle team today won the thirty-first Tour de France, one of the year's chief sporting events. The race, a 2,775mile circle around France, started June 30 with ninety-eight of Europe's blue ribbon cyclists participating.

There was a round of entertainment throughout the day for weekend guests at various estates. Mrs. Charles Edward Merrill gave a supper party tonight at the Orchard for Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hoving, who arrived this week for the season. Among the other guests were
David Hopkins, 22-year-old son of Harry Hopkins, WPA Administrator, confirmed a report tonight that he and Cherry Preisser, 19-year-old dancer, were married June 22 at Gretna, La.

Swank jewelry and accessories for men for Fall and holiday merchandising, featuring a new package idea, will be shown to the trade this week at the company's branch offices here and in other cities by its representatives.

The two-story building at 160 East Twenty-third Street, near Third Avenue, has been sold by the estate of Arnett G. Smith to the 423 Realty Corporation, represented by Parker, Chapin Flattau. The sale, the first involving the property in sixty-eight years, was negotiated by the M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company, as broker.

The Committee for Industrial Organization will use its Pacific Coast longshore organization in challenging the control of Joseph P. Ryan over longshoremen in Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico ports, according to persons active in the C. I. O. movement locally.

Miss Doris Edwards Payne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edwards Payne of Maplewood, has chosen Aug. 7 for her marriage to Robert Simmonds Carr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Simmonds Carr, also of Maplewood. The ceremony,

When John Steinbeck, author of "Of Mice and Men," returns here in mid-August, he will find, according to his publishers, Covici, Priede, that his new book "The Red Pony," to appear in a limited edition Sept. 24, has been completely sold out. The orders that

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 82 per cent of capacity, down 1 point from the rate of the preceding week. The average in the first six months of the year was about 85 per cent.

After rescuing four persons from an overturned sailboat off Kings Point buoy at the mouth of Manhasset Bay, Vivian Burnett, writer and editor and the original "Little Lord Fauntleroy," collapsed at the helm of his yawl Delight III this afternoon and died suddenly.

The record of business in the United States for the first half of 1937 was one of continued recovery in the face of several rather serious obstacles, including strikes, floods, currency instability, an unsettled political outlook and a highly disturbed situation abroad, according to the Guaranty Survey, monthly business review published by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

Mrs. Ella Burt Hanzsche, prominent in Lutheran Church organizations of the country and secretary to the late Ross Winans, builder of Russian railroads, died last night at her home. She was 84 years old.

Charles A. Bostwick, head of C. A. Bostwick, Inc., advertising agency at 400 Madison Avenue, died suddenly yesterday morning of apoplexy at-his residence, 212 East Forty-eighth Street, at the age of 57.
New York residents will have their first opportunity to view the inside of the nation's largest lowrent and slum-clearance housing project today at non.

The weekly average of French wholesale prices on July 3 was 571. This compared with 537 on June 26, before the second devaluation of the franc. The index of world prices of twenty-two raw materials in terms of gold was 54.8, compared with 54.9 the previous week.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,569,449,400. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:
After weeks of negotiations, with salary differences the point at issue, Ruby Keeler has signed with RKO for two pictures a year.

The effect on the world at large of the defeat of the President's plan to enlarge the Supreme Court is very slight indeed, so slight as to demonstrate that a major issue in the United States interests other countries far less than a constitutional debate of similar importance in a great European State would interest this country.
Mrs. Hilda Pheips Hammond, chairman of the Women's Committee of Louisiana, once the foe of the late Huey Long, asked Congress again today to investigate the election of Senator John H. Overton.

Cesare Franco, a musician who had played for thirty-seven years with the orchestras of various opera companies in this country, died on Saturday in the Medical Center after two weeks' illness of pneumonia. His-age was 70.
Fireman Joseph R. O'Keefe died suddenly last night at the headquarters of Engine Company 62, at 3,431 White Plains Avenue, the Bronx, soon after he had reported for duty at 6 o'clock. His age was 53.

According to The Daily Herald, General Francisco Franco, Insurgent leader in Spain, is dissatisfied with the help from Germany and Italy and "very secretly, through private channels, he has sent word to certain quarters in Paris that on certain conditions he would be prepared to break with Rome and Berlin and dismiss the German and Italian auxiliaries."

John Lehman of 676 Riverside Drive, who was an assistant corporation counsel for fifteen years until his resignation in 1927, died yesterday in the Home for Incurables in the Bronx after a prolonged illness.
George E. Philo, former State Assemblyman, died last night of pneumonia at his home here after an illness of one week. His age was 79.

Exercises commemorating the fifty-second anniversary of the death of General U. S. Grant were held yesterday afternoon at his tomb at 122d Street and Riverside Drive. The memorial service was under the supervision of Mrs. Laura B. Prisk, who is known as the "Mother of National Flag Day." About 300 persons attended.

There is considerable mystification in London over the weakness recently displayed here by the United States dollar. The decline probably was attributable to a combination of circumstances rather than to any single influence.

Three Boston youths were fatally hurt' and a fourth seriously injured early today when their light automobile went out of control on the old Lowell Road, skidded off a curve and overturned against a tree with such force that the body was ripped off the chassis.
