Lard prices were on the down-grade here last week on selling induced mainly by the drastic decline in corn, which has materially improved the feeding ratio between that grain and hogs. Closing trades on lard

A preventive treatment against poliomyelitis, or infantile paralysis, which may prove effective in the event of another epidemic of the disease, was described in a statement issued yesterday by the medical information bureau of the New York Academy of Medicine.

Rookle Atley Donald's winning. streak of fourteen straight games ended today when the Montreal Royals clubbed him out of the box and defeated the Newark Bears, 9 to 3, in the first game of a double-header.

Two of the oldest retail concerns doing business in downtown Manhattan were involved in a real estate transaction that came to light over the week-end. In the deal a drug company that was formed almost a century ago sold to a men's furnishing concern with a record of fifty years in business the sevenstory store and loft building at 412414 Sixth Avenue, between Eighth and Ninth Streets, in the Greenwich Village section.

Mr. and Mrs. Levin Rothwick Marshall Jr. of New York gave a dinner last night in the Terrace Dining Room of the Sands Point Bath Club for Mr. and Mrs. Hulbert Bassett of Westbury. Other guests were Mrs. Louis J. Francke and Howard Townsend Jr.
George Lansbury met Signor Marconi ten days before the great inventor's death. Marconi said it was a terrible
Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Army Chief of Staff, made public today the first details of the three-year plan with which he hopes to bring about the economic and social reconstruction of Cuba.

The final rounds of the men's invitation tennis doubles at the Maidstone Club today attracted a large crowd when Jiro Yamagishi and Fumiteru Nakano, Japanese players, met Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York and J. Gilbert Hall of Orange, N. J.

BERLIN, July 25.--The Rev. Walter Niemoeller, younger brother of the Rev. Martin Niemoeller, Protestant opposition leader, was arrested today by the secret political police after preaching three sermons in two Protestant Confessional churches In Dahlem.

" Leave them laughing when you say good-bye" seemed to have been the motto of the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday, and they almost made good on it, but not quite. After playing with the Cardinals for twenty-three innings they wound up the bizarre proceedings with the first game won in eleven innings, 6--5, and the second one only a 7-7 draw of twelve frames.

Dr. and Mrs. James Ralph McGaughy of this city have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Lucile McGaughy, to George A. McGarrity, son of Mr. and Mrs. William James McGarrity of Youngstown, Ohio, which took place Saturday afternoon in the Broadway Presbyterian Church.

Miss Sheila Emmet, with her aunt, Miss Eva D. Dahlgren, strolling on the beach at Newport, where she is passing the Summer with her grandmother, Mrs. Drexel Dahlgren, at Champ Soleil, and where she will make her debut next

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 92.3, which compares with 92.5 a week ago, 92.9 two weeks ago, 92.5 three weeks ago and 92 four weeks ago.

Negotiators failed to reach an immediate settlement tonight in the strike here of 2,000 food handlers, and union leaders prepared to resume the embargo that has tied up Buffalo's staple grocery supply for five days.

David Lasser, president of the Workers Alliance of America, stated today that sixty-six Representatives and thirteen Senators had announced support of the Schwellenbach-Allen resolution, which provides that Works Progress Administration workers who cannot find work in private industry at prevailing wages shall not be dropped from WPA rolls except for cause.

Plans for a "lie-down" strike among about eighty-five college and university students, employed in the cornfields by the branch plant here of the Pioneer Hi-Bred Company of Des Moines which Secretary Wallace serves in an advisory capacity, fell through today after a split in their ranks.

Miss Elisabeth Howard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Howard of Farmington, and Henry Parker Jones of Beaufort, S. C., son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Dudley Jones of Clinton, S. C., were married yesterday afternoon in the Congregational Church here by the Rev. Quincy Blakely.

The four Negro boys freed by Alabama in the Scottsboro case will arrive at Pennsylvania Station, New York, at 9:25 o'clock (Eastern daylight time) tomorrow aboard the Cincinnati Limited with their lawyer, Samuel Leibowitz, who after a four-year court battle, has been credited with saving all but one of nine Negro prisoners from death. That defendant, sentenced to death a few days ago, may receive a commutation of this penalty, Mr. Leibowitz believes.

Signing of a tentative contract ended today a strike of Flagler Hotel employes which began with a dining room sit-down yesterday. The terms of the contract, announced by Emmanuel Saget, attorney for the hotel, and Miss Ernesta Kaye, organizer for the Hotel and Restaurant Workers Alliance, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, called for a closed shop, union recognition and the reinstatement of five men and three women who were discharged on Friday.
The laying of "aerial minefields" to counter raiding airplanes by means of parent rockets is now undergoing tests on one of the government's proving grounds in South Wales.
Arthur F. Tubridy is now in the municipal bond-trading department of Lobdell Co. Strauss Bros. have installed a direct wire to Chicago.

The authorities here are inclined to minimize the importance of Spanish iron ore in its relationship to German requirements. The view is taken that the problem has been exaggerated because of its political aspects.
While the Italian sovereigns looked on today as witnesses, Signora Maria Bertuzzi, wife of a navy yard worker, named Italy's newest battleship, the Vittorio Veneto in Trieste.

Building construction in the metropolitan area in the first half of this year amounted to $250,014,700, a gain of 46 per cent over the total of $171,146,500 in the first six months of 1936, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

The ballots on the last of the ships of the Black Diamond Line involved in a Labor Board poll to determine the union which will represent unlicensed personnel in labor negotiations are being counted by the staff of the regional board, according to Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director.

Replying to reasons enumerated in a recent magazine article as to why many persons do not go to church, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, said such criticisms of the church were not new and the church should face them realistically whenever they arise.

Mrs. Dorothy Orr Ohmeis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Devereaux Orr, was married here to Henry A. Schatzkin of New York, son of S. Milton Schatzkin, this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Efram Fishoff of Temple Merriam, Long Branch.

Although he finished second today in the final of a series of six elimination races conducted by the International Star Class fleet of Great South Bay to select a representative for the forthcoming world championships at Port Washington, Horace Havemeyer Sr. triumphed by 4 points over William H. Picken, who finished first.

A sweeping victory has been won by General Francisco Franco's army in the Brunete sector of the Madrid front. Brunete and most of the area captured by the Government forces in the spectacular smashing opening of their big push early this month have been reoccupied by the Insurgents.

At least sixty-five persons were killed and 150 injured today when eight Insurgent planes carried out a terrific dawn raid on Barcelona. The planes showered bombs on the city for an hour and machinegunned citizens as they ran for safety.
Army officers active in the service and occupying five of the seven Cabinet posts in Ecuador issued a manifesto today explaining their position in the government, according to the Telegrafo.
New York State Conservation Department officials said tonight that a bill before Congress gave the opportunity to obtain $150,000 annually for a long-planned farm-game program in the State.

The annual meeting of the historic Saratoga Association at the oldest course in the country will begin tomorrow with seventy-three horses named for the seven-race program which will inaugurate the thirty-day session. Ten, including

Observers interested in that sort of thing today may see the first signs of the approaching theatrical season. For over at the Center Theatre they will begin rehearsals of "Virginia," the musical romance of Colonial days for which Laurence Stallings and Owen Davis fashioned a book and Arthur Schwartz the music.
Sweeping to seven straight victories over first division clubs, the Bees today took a double-header from the Pirates.

The Social Security Board had assigned social security account numbers to 29,954,821 individuals by June 30, the board announced today. About 4,000,000 applications for account numbers were received during the second quarter, ending June 30, at 171 field offices.

Ten suspicious fires in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn in the last month were explained late last night in the Sheepshead Bay police station when William Coughlin, 11 years old, told how he and a 12year-old chum had set them "for the kick of seeing the fire engines roll."
Physicians announced today that the consort of Prince Pu Chieh, heir presumptive to the throne of Manchukuo, was expecting the birth of a child early next year.
Buster Logan, 1936 Olympic bike rider and senior Alpine Wheelman, captured the national senior dirttrack championship today in a onemile run-off at Weequahic Park.

Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commanding the Second Corps Area, accompanied by his aide, Captain Lawrence K. Ladue, will be at Plattsburg Barracks tomorrow for aninspection of the citizens' military training camp.

Mrs. John Ritchie, descendant of a Dutch family which settled on Long Island in 1745, died yesterday in the Mather Memorial Hospital at Port Jefferson, following a brief illness. She was 75 years old. Mrs.

A list of corporations and individuals in New York and New Jersey who bought souvenir books of the 1936 Democratic National Convention, bearing the autograph of President Roosevelt, was made public today by Representative Robert L. Bacon of New York, a member of the Republican Congressional Committee. The list showed total purchases in the two States amounting to $165,380.

Seven thousand physicians were asked today by Dr. Louis Schmidt, head of Mayor Edward J. Kelly's Committee for Control of Venereal Disease, to enlist in Chicago's first mass attack on the syphilis plague.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:
DETROIT, JUly 25 (AP).--The Tigers defeated the Athletics, 12 to 9, today in a wild game called in the sixth inning after Detroit had scored two runs on wild pitches.

Forest (Spec) Towns, Olympic champion and holder of all existing hurdling records of the world, will marry tomorrow on the athletic field of the University of Georgia a classmate, Miss Martha Eberhardt of Carlton, Ga.
Northern New York dairymen heard today that they could expect a New York City consumers' boycott as aid to any fight they might make for higher milk prices.
One of the 200 formally clad patrons of The Pines, exclusive private club here, brought a whistle with him last night, but the management did not know it.

Premier Camille Chautemps and Interior Minister Marx Dormoy insisted in political speeches today that their respective parties, the Radical Socialist and Socialist, remained more than ever faithful to the Popular Front. Mr.

Jiro Yamagishi and Fumiteru Nakano, Japan's No. 1 and 3 ranking players, defeated Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York, former Wimbledon champion, and J. Gilbert Hall of Orange, N. J., in the final round of the Maidstone Club's annual invitation doubles today, 6-1. 4-6. 7-5. 3-6. 6-3.
Discovery of the largest barabara ever found in Alaska was reported today by Dr. Ales Hrdlicka, the anthropologist.

The Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway Company reports a net deficit of $3,196,965 for the six months ended on June 30, compared with a net deficit of $3,211,453 for the first six months of 1936. It is noted that since there

Most of the yachtsmen who usually find their relaxation racing on Long Island Sound today relaxed from racing and remained ashore, judging from the number that started in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's special regatta.

Preparatory to defending the Seabright Bowl this week at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club, John McDiarmid of Princeton won the Eastern clay court championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

Germany took its second event in the international aviation meet here today when Karl Francke easily won the speed race from Charles Gardner of Britain after motor trouble caused Major Gen. Ernst Udet to withdraw in the first lap.

Confining all its scoring to two innings, the New York Athletic Club topped the Trenton Baseball Club, 7-5, yesterday at Travers Island. The Winged Foot nine pushed across five runs in the seventh and then added two in the next session for its triumph.

" Frederika," this week's bill at the Jones Beach Stadium, opens tonight, with Robert Chisholm and Diana Gaylen heading the cast. Maria del Carmen, Spanish dancer, will appear in the entr'acte divertissements.
The Army League Committee launched a campaign today for 47,000 recruits and 1,000 officers to build Great Britain's army to "the minimum margin of safety."

Consolidation of the Federal Theatre Project with Federal Project 1, also known as the Four-Arts Project, and the assignment of Harold Stein, administrative assistant of Federal Project 1, to make a nation-wide survey of the Federal art project, were announced tonight.

Tom Barry, leader of the Irish Republican Army, was under arrest today after having been in hiding for more than a year. He was seized by police last night as he was leaving a wedding party at a Cork . hotel.

Violent price fluctuations, which usually are associated with sensational crop-damage reports, were the feature of the wheat market here last week, and these precipitated a situation to be long remembered by grain traders.

" Educational programs and teaching methods of many churches in the United States are radically wrong," declared the Rev. Jule Ayers, assistant minister of Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, in a sermon there yesterday morning.
Firing of 12-inch railway mortars is scheduled here between 3 and 7 P. M. Tuesday, and authorities issued the following description of the "danger zone."

William W. Coriell of this city, a retired official of several large textile companies, died late last night in a hotel at Harwich, Mass., where he was passing the Summer with his wife, Emma Buckle Coriell, and his daughter, Betty Coriell.

The Joint Council of Drivers and Sweepers, representing the street cleaning employes of the Department of Saiditation, yesterday addressed a letter to Commissioner William F. Carey, head of the deapartment, asking his support for a 10 per cent wage increase for the employes each year for the next three years.

Rudolf Caracciola, driving a Mercedes-Benz, today won Germany's Grand Prix automobile race on the Nuerburg ring, driving the 501 kilometers (311.121 miles) in three hours, 46.10 minutes before a crowd of 350,000.

Severing relationship with the United Textile Workers Union of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, more than 8,000 Canadian textile workers joined the Trades and Labor Congress of Canada at a conference here yesterday.

How little Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch's forcing of the ratification of the Concordat through Parliament Friday really has done toward ending the opposition was shown today when the Bishops of the Orthodox Church signed an order excommunicating every orthodox member of the government or parliament who had worked for or voted for ratification.

By taking six of nine matches, the Yale and Harvard tennis teams defeated Oxford and Cambridge of England and retained the Bernon S. Prentice Cup today as the eleventh international university tournament came to a close on the Newport Casino courts.

The current Soviet purge moved with full force today into the field of journalism with an editorial announcement by Pravda, Communist party organ, that all enemies "must be mercilessly thrown out of newspapers, magazines and publishing houses," to purify the press, which Joseph Stalin has called "the strongest and sharpest weapon of the Communist party."

Miss Eleanor Crosby has selected Saturday, Aug. 21, for her wedding to Arthur C. Stevens, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. J. Stevens of Ithaca, N. Y., the ceremony to take place at the Clinton Summer home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Crosby.

The new State Labor Relations Board will swing into its administration of New York State's "Little Wagner Act" on Aug. 2, with the opening of regional offices in Albany and Buffalo, the Rev. Dr. John P. Boland, its chairman, announced today.

Never trailing at any stage, Charles H. Mayo Jr., former Long Island amateur golf champion, today conquered Ralph Strafaci of Shore View, 2 up, in the eighteen-hole final of the Leewood invitation tournament.

Louis Brenner has been named to succeed Isidore Sobeloff as director of the New York office of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver, it was announced yesterday by Paul Felix Warburg, chairman of the local committee.

The Miniter Realty Corporation sold to Loomis J. Grossman the two-story taxpayer on a plot 80 by 100 feet at 1,101-5 Avenue U, corner Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, through the David Jaret Company. The terms were cash over a first mortgage of $122,000.

TOMORROW the drinks will be on the house! But it is never tomorrow. Tomorrow will never come. That is the key to the opinions on Russia and communism expressed by Louis-Ferdinand Celine, author of "Journey to the End of the Night," in his essay, "Mea Culpa" (Little, Brown, $2).

Twenty-two priests, most of them ordained recently, left here tonight for duty in the Orient following departure ceremonies attended. by relatives and friends at the Maryknoll Seminary of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America.
The index of German wholesale prices on July 14 was 106.4, against 106.3 on July 7, and 106.1 on June 30.
The National Labor Relations Board's trial examiner in the Ford Motor Company hearing said today sessions would be speeded up starting Monday, when they begin their fourth and possibly last week.

Stephen J. Cushing Jr. of 90 South Second Street, Brooklyn, was elected chairman of the Long Island Chapter of the Knight of Columbus at the forty-first annual meeting, held yesterday afternoon in the K. of C. Institute, 81 Hanson Place, Brooklyn. He was Past District
Phil Gottron, a little gunner from Fremont, Ohio, won the amateur championship event today in the international trapshooting tournament with 199 successful shots out of 200.

In keeping with its most ambitious athletic program in history, Princeton this Spring conferred 275 athletic awards on the members and managers of twenty teams in seven branches of sport, according to the list released today by the University Athletic Association.

Jesus should never be thought of as a reformer but as the embodiment of the best qualities of a true friend, the Rev. E. Felix Kloman said yesterday in a sermon at Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street.

TWO Unidentified Sail boats which passed Manistee, Mich., at 8 P.M., Eastern Standard time, but had not arrived here at 11:30, apparently were leading the annual Chicago- to Mackinac race on Lake Michigan tonight.

The international executive board of the American Newspaper Guild announced yesterday it had voted unanimously to approve a referendum on C. I. O. affiliation and other actions taken at the recent St. Louis convention, provided the questions as presented by the Columbus, Ohio, unit were rephrased by that unit so that they would be "properly drafted and capable of application" and "within the spirit" of the original motions.
June was characterized yesterday as a record month here from the standpoint of vital statistics by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Records in the Health Department.

Sir Henry and Lady Brackenburg, Sir Harry and Lady Hague, Lady Audrey Stanley, Sir Richard Jute and Diwann Bahadur Nn Ayyanger, Chief Secretary of Mysore, India, are among the passengers due today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.
There have been disturbing rumors concerning the condition of the Old Man of the Mountain in the Franconia Notch of the White Mountains.

The county reform bills introduced last week by Alderman Timothy J. Sullivan, Manhattan Democrat, not only continue but actually extend political control of county government and jobs, the Citizens Budget Commission charged yesterday.
Chancellor Hitler attended the second performance of the Wagner festival here today. "Lohengrin" was presented, with Heinz Tietjen conducting.

California Water Service Company--Year ended June 30: Income of $1,254,026 after operating expense, maintenance and taxes, but before interest and depreciation, compared with $1,091,934 for the year ended June 30, 1936.

Civilization is on the verge of collapse because we are neglecting God in our national life-to such an extent in fact, that it means inevitable disaster-according to the Rev. Dr. Norman M. Guy, professor at Drew University, Madison, N. J., who preached at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, Eightysixth Street and West End Avenue, yesterday morning.

Forgetting for the moment, at least, their various aches and ailments as well as the severe trouncings they had been forced to receive on the two previous afternoons, the Giants did a most magnificent piece of rallying at the Polo Grounds yesterday to confound the Cubs, a gathering of 21,000 and perhaps even themselves.

Squire Gene Sarazen, the farmer-golfer from Brookfield Center, Conn., brought to a golden climax another great comeback drive today by conquering a brilliant field in the $10,000 Chicago open tournament with a 72hole total of 290 strokes.

Thomas Edwin Elder, 57-year-old former dean of Mount Hermon School, will open his defense against an assault charge made by Stephen Allen Norton, the school's retired cashier, in Superior Court here tomorrow.
Dr. Rufus A. White, a clergyman prominent in Chicago religious, social and civic work for nearly half a century, died today. For forty-four years until
Business executives and union leaders clashed verbally today over whether closing of Tacoma's largest department stores is a strike or a lockout.

The United States Davis Cuppers, tied with three matches to go, will send Don Budge and Gene Mako onto Wimbledon's famed center court against C. R. D. Tuckey and F. H. D. Wilde of Great Britain tomorrow in the battle for the vital challenge round doubles point.

No apprehension exists among steelmakers in view of the slower rate of buying, compared with earlier months the magazine Steel says today. The current rate is considered excellent for the time of year, and a steady flow of business is better than the rush for tonnage that was a feature in the Spring, the journal maintains.

The building of the First Church of Christ, Scientist, at Mamaroneck and Maple Avenues, was dedicated today at three identical services conducted at 11 A. M., 3:30 P. M. and 8 P. M. About 1,000 members and guests attended.

Herbert P. Burke of 68-12 Burns Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, yachting editor of The New York American for the last five years, died early yesterday in Bellevue Hospital of injuries received on Wednesday when a truck and trailer were in collision with his automobile in Jackson Heights, Queens.

Captain and Mrs. Harold A. White of East Hampton, who had been on a fishing trip on their yacht Mongoose, gave a dinner tonight at the Montauk Yacht Club. Mr. and Mrs. Alois S. Menschik gave a dinner there for ten.

Stocks higher for the fourth consecutive week; industrial shares strongest; turnover, 5,500,810 shares. United States Government issues and local traction bonds higher; others steady; transactions, $38,216,000.
Mike Cestone, co-holder of the New Jersey best-ball amateur golf championship, paired with Johnny Birkhofer to win the third annual Cedar Ridge Country Club invitation tournament today. Cestone and

The Archbishop of Canterbury broke a tradition of the Church of England today by celebrating communion for members of all Christian denominations at the World Conference on Church, Community and State.
More than 2,000 persons visited the seven vessels in the midshipmen's coastal cruising detachment at the foot of West Thirty-third Street between 1 and 5 P. M. yesterday. There are six destroyers.

With prospects of an exceptionally large crop in the United States, together with advices of increased acreage and the outlook for increased production abroad, the cotton market registered an unusually large decline last week.

Local police, in conjunction with Federal Secret Service men, took into custody today a Puerto Rican describing himself as the Rev. Dr. William West, about 40 years old, who they said had been threatening in a series of letters to President Roosevelt to "disrupt the Democratic party."
A group including Mitchell, Herrick Co., Riter Co., Otis Co., and Kalman Co. will offer today two classes of stock of the Reliance Steel Corporation, Cleveland.
The necessity for complete agreement with the will of God was stressed by the Rev. Richard Lief in a sermon yesterday morning in St. George's Episcopal Church, Sixteenth Street, east of Third Avenue.

Officials of General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers of America completed preliminary negotiations tonight for a conference to start tomorrow, but there was a difference of opinion about the agenda.

The plan for reorganization of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, filed several days ago by trustees for the subsidiary corporations, Webster Securities and Public Utility Service, was approved today as properly filed by Federal Judge William H. Holly.
The WPA and the city did $20,100 worth of work on private proparty here. John Kresl, Street Commissioner, started to fill in a dump believing it belonged to the city.
Major Gen. Ernest Udet of Germany escaped uninjured today in what was perhaps his closest brush with death when his racing monoplane cut through a 30,000-volt railway trolley in a blinding flash.

The three four-story flats at 413-15 Ninth Avenue and 403 West Thirty-third Street, forming an ell around the northwest corner, have been sold to Irving 0. Freedman. The houses are on plots of 39.9 by 100 feet on Ninth Avenue and 25 by 19.9 feet on Thirty-third Street.
Stocks closed firm at irregularly lower levels in dull trading; turnover, 896,210 shares. United States Government bonds generally higher, other issues steady; transactions, $5,289,500.
John Montague came into court today on charges of participating in a New York robbery and greeted three Eastern officers with the remark, "Well, boys, glad to see you."

Fraulein Gerta Taro, a German news photographer, was injured fatally in an accident at the front yesterday when a tank swerved and struck her as she was standing on an automobile's running board. Ted Allen, a Canadian newspaper man who came here with the American volunteers last Winter, received minor injuries in the same accident.

A committee to draft proposed reforms to State laws affecting sex offenders was appointed today by former State Senator Walter W. Westall, president of the Westchester County Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

Abatement of claims for $193,600 against Aktiebolaget Kreuger Toll of New York and a credit of $144,634 in favor of the Rubel Corporation of Brooklyn, in connection with income tax over-assessments, were announced today by the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

Luncheons were given today on many estates. Mr. and Mrs. Archibald M. Brown were hosts at the Studio, their place on the ocean, for Mrs. Gordon Auchincloss, who motored over from Ronda, her home in Locust Valley; Mrs. Philip Livermore of Dois Joli, Jericho, L. I., who has joined Mrs. Lucius Wilmerding for a visit, and Mrs. Lewis Spencer Morris.

Dr. Jacob Diner, founder and first dean of the Fordham Universary College of Pharmacy and nationally known in pharmaceutical circles, died at a sanitarium at Amityville, L. I., Sunday. He was 67 years old and lived at 175 West Seventy-sixth Street.

The sale of newspapers and magazines and even mail as junk by postal employes was disclosed here today by the police with the arrest of three persons, following an investigation of complaints of lost mail at one ot this city's postal substations.
Cardinal Prince, E. J. Baker's bay horse, did a two-minute mile around the kite track here today in winning the $1,000 Old Orchard pace in three straight heats.

Nine jurors were selected yesterday in the Supreme Court for the trial of Arthur (Tootsie) Herbert, reputedly the czar of the poultry racket, and two others on charges of embezzling $32,958 from the treasury of Local 167 of the Chicken Drivers, Chauffeurs and Helpers Union. The remaining three jurors and two alternates are to be seelected today.

Jack Walter Allanach, 4 1/2-yearold boy who is traveling alone on a 6,000-mile journey, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, just about half way on his trip to join his parents at Santa Paula, Calif.
Charges of homicide against Gerlando Butero, 42 years old, of 1,225 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, were dismissed yesterday by Magistrate Matthew J. Troy in Felony Court, Brooklyn.

The Rev. Gordon Chilson Reardon, minister of the Church of Our Father of the First Universalist Society at 415 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, since 1934, announced yesterday that he had forwarded his resignation to the board of trustees of the society. He cited the financial condition of the church in giving the reasons for his resignation.

Disturbing effects of last week's White House statement that information pointed to a crop of 14,500,000 bales were witnessed again on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday when a break of nearly $2 a bale carried quotations below 11 cents a pound to the lowest figures of the entire cotton year, and the list ended with losses of 20 to 27 points.

Miles Fallon and John Weinhold, Kings County deputy sheriffs, went out into the streets surrounding Kings County Court during the noon recess yesterday to recruit eight more men for a jury to try Paul Sinacore, a 27year-old taxicab driver, charged with first-degree robbery.
Canadian newsprint exports in June reached $11,401,000, almost $2,000,000 above exports of $9,816,000 in June, 1936, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.
Proxy rules under the Public Utility Act with reference to registered holding companies and their subsidiaries were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Two private residences in Yorkville have been acquired by the Frank G. Shattuck Company, operator of the Schrafft's chain of restaurants, as a site for a new unit in the system, it was announced yesterday.

Nine members of the New York Police Department were commended yesterday by Abram W. Skidmore, chief of the Nassau County Police Department, for their assistance in the arrest of Josef Sroczynski, "the unlatched window burglar," who pleaded guilty to a series of crimes that had baffled the police for more than six years.

An informal attempt was made yesterday to find out what various corporation heads did with the Democratic National Convention souvenir books that were sold to them at $250 a copy to meet a Roosevelt campaign deficit of about $850,000 after the 1936 election.
The rain which fell late this afternoon caused the postponement of the Hempstead Cups polo roundrobin which was to have decided the winner of the Red Brook League.
The State Milk Control Board ordered today an increase of 1 cent a quart for grades A and B milk, effective Aug. 1. Prices for pints to consumers will not be affected.

The Treasury's new $50,000,000 issue of short-term bills sold today at an average interest rate of 0.372 per cent compared to an average rate of 0.397 per cent for the issue sold last week, Roswell Magill, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, announced tonight.

The Pan American Clipper will take off tomorrow from Port Washington on a second exploratory flight across the Atlantic to map weather and flying conditions and test route facilities, Pan American Airways announced last night. The time of take-off will not be determined until this evening after a study of the weather map.

Bond Goodwin, Inc., and C. B. Ewart Co., Inc., head a selling group which is offering 38,000 shares of United States Plywood Corporation $1.50 cumulative convertible preferred stock and 53,475 shares of common stock, the former priced at $25 and the latter at $17 a share.
Major Murray Addison Cobb, general staff member during the World War and socially prominent in this city and Washington, died today in Bryn Mawr Hospital after an illness of several weeks.

The former Metropolitan Opera tenor Tito Schipa declared today he had received congratulatory messages from high Fascist officials for his defiance of the Lord Mayor of Sydney's ban on Fascist salutes.

MANHATTAN DUFF, ALEXANDER (June 21). Estate, $750. To Sarah Duff, widow, executrix, 609 W. 191st St., residue. FLAMMER, CHARLES A. (June 24). Estate, more than $10,000. To Students Art Association, City College, Lenox Hill Hospital, West Side Hospital and Dispensary, Evangelical Luthuran Church

Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn said yesterday that the hearings on petitions for allowances sought by trustees and others in connection with the reorganization of the $50,000,000 Bush Terminal Corporation and the Bush Terminal Buildings Company, a subsidiary, were unnecessary.

A delegation of the Daughters of the American Revolution were the honored guests of the Citizens Military Training Camp Regiment here today, in the fourth event of the twentieth anniversary of the founding of Camp Dix as a military training center.
Because of a heavy shower which fell just before the scheduled curtain time, the performance of the operetta "Frederika" was postponed tonight by the Long Island State Park Commission.

Net income of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., for the second quarter of 1937 amounted to $23,822,888, and was equal, after dividends on the debenture stock, to $2.07 a share on 11,035,037 shares of common stock, compared with $16,013,346, or $1.30 a share, in the first quarter, and with $23,978,189, or $2.06 a share, in the second quarter of 1936.

Renewing his attacks on alleged Nazi activities in this country, Representative Dickstein of New York urged the House today to adopt the Dies resolution providing an inquiry into un-American activities of foreign agents.
John Joseph Hughes Jr. of New York, accompanied by two German wardens, left today for Bremerhaven, where he will board the Bremen tomorrow for New York.
Frederick William Mercer of Summit, N. J., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Gertrude Ann Mercer, to Arnold Kunrad Kvam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Kvam of Sioux City, Iowa.

Dr. Elizabeth Balch Holmes, widow of Franklin Sawyer Holmes of Brooklyn, electrical engineer, died yesterday at Oakland, N. J., after an illness of eight weeks. A graduate of Wellesley College and the Women's Medical College of New York. Dr.
Liquidation continued in the grain markets today, with wheat breaking as much as 4 cents a bushel before the decline was checked, while corn was off more than 4 cents and oats 2 cents.

According to word from Albany, Conservation Commissioner Osborne is heartily in favor of the bill before Congress which provides for joint activity on the part of Federal and State agencies seeking a restoration of wildlife.

Cowing six persons in the office of Frederick Opolinsky, a produce dealer, at 374 Washington Street, three armed men escaped at 12:45 P. M. yesterday with more than $1,500, the day's receipts, a short time before an armored car was to take it to the bank.

The three Soviet aviators who were first to fly over the North Pole to America-Valery Chkaloff, Georgi Baidukoff and Alexander Beliakoff-arrived home today and received a triumphant ovation from government officials, famous brother aviators and the Moscow populace.
Mrs. Emma H. de Zouche Anderson, a feature writer on the old New York World and a pioneer in the women's suffrage movement, died today at her apartment in the Park Hotel.
Steel strikers and workers battled day and night at Republic's Cleveland plant; one dead, forty injured. Page 1.
Federal Judge John C. Knox yesterday refused to enjoin State authorities from interfering with the operation of a dog race track at Orangeburg, N. Y.

The engagement and approaching marriage of Mrs. Reeve Snowden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Livingston Reeve of 455 East Fiftyfirst Street, to Arthur J. Sullivan, son of Mrs. H. W. Davis of Winthrop, Mass., and the late D. J. Sullivan, has been announced by her parents.

Major Gen. Samuel Storrow Sumner, retired United States Army cavalry officer and veteran of the Civil and Spanish-American wars and the Chinese Boxer rebellion, died at his home in Brookline today of heart disease at the age of 95. He was a native of Carlisle, Pa.
The Bureau ?? Navigation released the following order, today, dated July 23: COMMANDER Klein, G. C., United Shipyards, Inc., New York, N. C., to Navy Yard, Philadelphia, Pa.
Nottinghamshire's unbeaten record in county cricket was broken today by Derbyshire, titleholder last year. The Midlanders overwhelmed Nottinghamshire by an innings and 23 runs.

Mike Jacobs's plans to stage a world welterweight championship fight between Barney Ross and Ceferino Garcia received a setback yesterday when he failed to come to terms with George Parnassus, Garcia's manager.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator, branded as "fatuous twaddle" yesterday additional charges of irregularities in his organization made by Ralph M. Easley, chairman of the executive council of the National Civic Federation in an open letter to President Roosevelt.

Daily average retail sales in small towns and rural sections in June of this year, as compared with June, 1936, showed a larger increase in the eastern section of the country than in other parts, the Department of Commerce reported today.
J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, completed twenty years of service with the Justice Department today.
Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Mrs. Woodward Vietor of the Drake, accompanied by Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Brokaw and Mr. and Mrs. Lee Warren James, will sail tomorrow on the Queen Mary. After passing the grouse shooting season at Fetterosso Castle, Scotland, they will return to New York in the Autumn.

The Rev. R. Ethan Allen, a direct descendant of Ethan Allen, Vermont patriot, and known to residents of the Roxbury section as the friend of the poor for his humanitarian works, until illness laid him low last year, has advertised for a pastorate to sustain his family and "carry on the work of God."
Reynolds Metals Company rights have been admitted to dealings on the New York Stock Exchange. "When issued" rights have been suspended from dealings.
Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur B. Ruthrauff of Highlow Farm, Red Bank, entertained at a party this afternoon on Mr. Ruthrauff's fiftieth birthday. More than 200 guests were invited.

Thirty men, commanders of various posts of the American Legion, Veterans of Foreign Wars, Irish War Veterans, Jewish War Veterans and the Order of the Purple Heart, meeting here tonight at 61 Bergen Street, adopted two resolutions calling for investigations of Camp Nordland, in Sussex County.

Consulate General of Esthonia, in 9 Rockefeller Plaza, Rockfeller Center. Reisman, Rothman Corp, girls coats. additional space in 252 W 37th St; Julius Nelson Corp, ladies coats and suits, two additional floors in 257 W 37th St; Max Harnick, broker.

Chevalier Burdett of 27 Orowoc Place, Freeport, L. I., says he swam in many a hard race for a silver cup when he was an undergraduate at the University of Alabama several years ago, but none of them compared with the one he swam last night across Great South Bay.
The preliminary General Motors Corporation earnings report for the second quarter, due to be made public today under previous schedules, will appear tomorrow instead.

Three specially furnished apartments of the PWA Williamsburg houses, the country's largest lowrent and slum-clearance project, in Brooklyn, were opened to inspection yesterday afternoon by the public and various officials, including Langdon W. Post, chairman of the Housing Authority. The apartments, two three-room and one four-room, are in Building 12 at 180 Maujer Street.

Proof that Premier Camille Chautemps means what he says about maintaining public order and keeping up production was furnished today when the Government acted to break up obstructions on the principal waterways of France caused by striking barge crews and owners.
Womep employes of the Pennstate Cigar Company reclined in front of the plant gates today to prevent trucks moving machinery from the plant.

The growing drive to adjourn the Congress session took a fresh spurt forward today as Senator Ashurst announced to his colleagues that the new substitute for President Roosevelt's court bill was about ready.
Though they have Seaverge open, Mr. and Mrs. G. Huntington Hart- ford will spend much of their time this Summer aboard the square rigger Joseph Conrad, which they have bought.
A new step forward in the presentation of open-air operetta on a large scale will be taken tonight with the opening of "The Student Prince" on the new movable stage in the Randalls Island Stadium.

Renewed discussion of Great Britain's war debt to the United States was aroused today with notice from Laborite William Leach that he would ask Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in the House of Commons on Tuesday whether he would consider a new settlement plan.

Despite early assurances that farmers would not be affected by the Black wages and hours bill, "many thousands of canning plants, cotton gins, creameries, fruit and vegetable packers, compresses, oil mills, grain elevators and such industries will have codes of wages

Frances Farmer, new star of the motion pictures, was presented with Mildred Natwick tonight at the Westchester Playhouse in "At Mrs. Beam's," a comedy of English boarding house life, by C. K. Munro. Three hundred persons attended.

William Null Jr., 21 years old, of 9 West Garfield Avenue, here, was arraigned on a charge of murder in the first degree before Recorder William P. Irwin this afternoon and was held without bail for the grand jury.
There were 721 accidents on the steam railroads of the country in April, according to figures published today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. This was an increase of 123 from April, 1936.
Representative 'Shannon of Missouri said today he was going to retire from Congress at the end of his present term, because he was disgusted.

Miss Madge Carrington Laidlaw, daughter of Loper Laidlaw of Greenwich and the late Mrs. Alice Carrington Laidlaw, was married to William H. Wiley, also of Greenwhich, in Christ Episcopal Church at Rye, N. Y., this afternoon. Only the immediate family were present, owing to the illness of the bridegroom's mother, Mrs. William H. Wiley. The wedding took place a day sooner than had originally been intended.

The decision of Magistrate Anna M. Kross in Yorkville court last week that the judiciary cannot undertake to "set up standards of taste" in connection with supposedly indecent theatrical performances was criticized yesterday in an open letter to the magistrate by George A. Timone, advocate of the New York Chapter of the Knights of Columbus.

Movements of vessels follow. All dates are July 24 unless specified: At Norfolk Yard, Nitro, July 26; Acushnet. At Portland. Salt Lake City, Arctic. New York Yard to sea, Badger, Tattnall, July 25; Decatur, Dickerson, Leary, Tillman.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 21: Increases of $19,000,000

Despite the heavy traffic of the last week-end, there was a sharp decline in automobile accidents in the city and the number of persons killed and injured, as compared with the corresponding period of 1936, it was announced yesterday by the police.

Phenomenal rip tides swept in upon 100,000 bathers this afternoon and swept out again with scores of them, starting a panic along ninety miles of beach from Newport, south of Los Angeles, to Malibu, on the north.
Charlotte furniture dealers, visiting the midsummer furniture market now in full swing in the milliondollar furniture exposition building at High Point, N. C., report wooden furniture most in demand.

New high records for deposits and number of depositors were established by mutual savings institutions in this country in the first six months of 1937, according to the mid-year analysis of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, issued yesterday.

An official search for a Brooklyn man who disappeared sixteen years ago was started yesterday after his Mother, Mrs. Katie Daniel of 37 Coleridge Street, Brooklyn, decided that she could not carry on the Search alone and needed help.
Annual Red Star Ranger soapbox derby promoted by R. H. Macy Co., Harlem River Speedway and 155th Street, 11:30 A. M.

Mrs. Katherine Bliss Boker, daughter of Mrs. Walter Phelps Bliss of New York, was married here to Taylor Scott Hardin of Newstead, Va., well-known sportsman, this afternoon at the home of Dryden Kuser, former New Jersey State Senator.

Buying activity in the local apparel markets was brisk yesterday, as quite a few buyers remained in town from last week. A decided note of caution, however, was in evidence, with most retail representatives holding their budgets down.
Tonight's performance of "Falstaff" was the greatest the present reviewer has experienced in more than thirty hearings of the work.

Four of the nine contesting sixmeter yachts came through to gain qualifying places in the trial series to select a defender for the Gold Cup and Seawanhaka Cup by their performances today in the first two elimination tests off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

A group of witnesses for the Ford Motor Company denied at a National Labor Relations Board hearing today that employes had been discharged because of union activity, as charged in the complaint against the company.

Plans were filed yesterday for the erection of a two-story building covering the entire east blockfront on Eight Avenue between 124th and 125th Streets, at an estimated cost of $180,000. The building has a frontage of 200.10 feet on Eighth Avenue and 100 feet on each of the two streets.

Funeral services will be held at 4 P. M. tomorrow at his home in Plandome, L. I., for Vivian Burnett, writer, editor and musical composer, son of the late novelist, Frances Hodgson Burnett, who died of a heart attack on his yacht Sunday afternoon, after helping in the rescue of four people from Manhasset Bay.

President Roosevelt is planning to go to Roanoke Island, N. C., first English settlement in America, to participate Aug. 18 in ceremonies commemorating the three-hundred-andfiftieth anniversary of the birth of Virginia Dare, the first child to be born of English parentage in the New World.

The American Jewish Historical Society, Broadway and 122d Street, has received as a gift from its president, Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach, a collection of about 600 volumes of Yiddish periodicals and books, in memory of his mother, Mrs. Isabella H. Rosenbach, one of the founders of the society in 1892.

Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring, 1935 titleholder, and Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont, the defending champion, tied for the lead today at the end of the first round in the fifty-four hole New Jersey shore medal play tournament.

Railroad reports for June issued yesterday showed increased gross and net returns for the month compared with June, 1936, the gains in many cases being enlarged through credits for amounts deducted under the former railway pension law.

The State trooper who tapped a wire to listen in on the home telephone of Mayor S. Davis Wilson's secretary was fortified with a memorandum which in effect accused the Mayor, his secretary, Louis W. Wilgarde, and a political lieutenant, Joseph A. Donoghue, of being beneficiaries of a three-way split of gambling house protection money.
A thunderstorm at 4:30 P. M. yesterday and a shift in the wind caused a 17-degree drop in the temperature after oppressive, sultry weather had resulted in one death and three prostrations.

To Fire Hazard School The following-named members shall be directed to report at the Fire Hazard Inspectors' School, 32-02 Queens Blvd., Long Island City, at 10:30 A. M., on the dates specified: Group 1, Platoon 1, Aug. 5, 11, 17, 23, 30.
John B. Kelly, chairman of the Democratio City Committee, and Matthew H. McCloskey, his co-leader, agreed today on the following slate of Democratic nominations for four municipal offices:

Pedro Montanez, 136 1/2, scored a clean one-round knockout over Wesley Ramey, 135, in the feature bout of a card tonight. Two minutes and 40 seconds after the first bell sounded the Puerto Rican star flashed a left hook that sent the Grand Rapids (Mich.) lightweight to the canvas. Ramey landed on his back.

The Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn, through its attorney, Benjamin C. Ribman, asked Supreme Court Justice Albert Conway yesterday for atemporary injunction restraining Local 171, Hospital Employes Union of Greater New York, from calling a strike at the hospital or permitting its members to picket or carry "untruthful" signs in the neighborhood of the hospital or the homes of its directors or staff members.
Mayor Wilson's new financial advisory commission began its survey of city finances today with the appointment of two technical experts to direct the investigation.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Fritz Reiner's direction, declared a field day for home talent at last night's concert, forced by rain from Lewisohn Stadium to the Great Hall of City College.

Business failures throughout the United States totaled 148 for the week ended July 22, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. This figure compares with 152 in the previous week and 141 in the corresponding week last year.

Camp High Point Park, operated by the New Jersey Commission for the Blind, was officially opened here today with ceremonies attended by State, county and local officials. The camp will accommodate about sixty underprivileged blind boys and Girls this Summer. It is the first of its kind in New Jersey.

Tacoma's ten largest department stores remained closed today with pickets the only sign of life along their two-block front. Nine stores failed to open Saturday after clerks had gone on strike at the other one Friday.

The engagement of Miss Katherine Wilder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Enos Wilder of Stamford, to John Day Hegeman, son of Mrs. Myra D. Hegeman of Shippan Point, Stamford, and John C. Hegeman of Larchmont, N. Y., was announced by her parents at a tea given yesterday at the Apawamis Beach Club, Rye, N. Y., by Mr. Hegeman's father and stepmother.

In the first six months of this year, Argentina had a favorable balance of trade amounting to 739,901,000 pesos, or about $246,700,000, compared with 184,362.000 pesos, or $61,500,000, correspondingly in 1936, according to cabled dispatches yesterday to the Argentine

Miss Kathleen O'Brien, who will depart with Justice and Mrs. F. O'Brien on Thursday for Europe, gave a dinner today at Pecketts. Miss Louise Conklin of White Plains, N. Y., also entertained there at dinner. Mr. and Mrs. Albert N.
Dr. Stanley High, former Roosevelt administration adviser, said tonight he has resigned as executive director of the Good Neighbor League because his "usefulness in that job is at an end."

The first step was taken today toward lifting the embargo on the movement of scrap iron and steel to the seaboard from the interior in which most of the important rail carriers serving Atlantic and Gulf ports have taken part.
An even half dozen of Great Britain's Wightman Cup tennis players arrived yesterday aboard the Queen Mary of the Cunard White Star Line. but they didn't linger long in New York's sultry atmosphere.

CANTON, Mass., July 26 (AP).--With a stiff wind sending the scores skyrocketing, 22-year-old Edward P. Martin of the Sandy Burr Club, Wayland, played rounds of 74 and 76 over the difficult Blue Hill Country Club course to win the New England sectional qualifying round for the national amateur golf tournament at Portland, Ore., next month.

Trading opened fair to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were strong to slightly higher and most of the major cuts were higher. Veal cuts were strong to higher and lamb cuts sharply higher. Fresh pork cuts were also stronger. Kosher meats opened steady to somewhat below last Friday's sharply higher markets as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
Charles Alexander Korbly, Representative in Congress from Indiana from 1909 to 1915, died here today after an illness of several weeks, at the age of 66.
Fannie Hurst, the novelist, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary accompanied by her husband, Jacques Danielson, after spending several weeks abroad.

Stockholders of the Lufkin Rule Company, meeting in Saginaw, Mich., approved yesterday an increase in the authorized common stock to 500,000 shares of $5 par value to provide for a two-for-one split-up of the present common shares, and the sale of an additional 16,000 common shares, the proceeds to be applied to the redemption of 21,638 outstanding preferred shares.

Senator Borah says that a better name for the Administration's "evernormal granary" would be "the ever-empty granary." He so characterized in the Senate today the plan of Secretary Wallace to store surplus crops against lean years.

Joseph Cawley, a 55-year-old farm laborer, shot and killed himself here today after inflicting three bullet wounds in his wife's hand in an argument which arose because she had bobbed her hair, according to Coroner Clarence S. Roberts Jr.

Sharp increases in both national and retail advertising of pianos and other musical instruments for the balance of the year were predicted yesterday at the opening of the thirty-sixth annual Music Industries Convention at the Hotel New Yorker.

In Washington a weary Congress, badgered by the heat and apparently uncertain of its own intentions in the matter of adjournment, is now weighing the question whether to proceed to the consideration of several measures whose enactment at this session is still desired by the Administration.

A new short-wave service in six languages to Europe, South and Central America and other parts of the world was started yesterday over the National Broadcasting Company's short - wave station W3XAL, at Bound Brook, N. J., when two directional-beam antennas were put into service.
The anti - lynching bill, a measure which has divided Democratic forces In Congress, as did the judiciary reorganization bill, narrowly missed passage in the Senate today.

For the first time in the history of the Lake Yacht Racing Association, the Freeman Cup race from here to Rochester was postponed today on account of weather. A southwest wind varying from 26 to 36 miles whipped the water into heavy waves outside the harbor.

Featuring a gallant stand by A. W. Hadlee and Captain M. L. Page, New Zealand hit 281 runs in reply to England's first innings score of 358 for nine wickets declared in the second test match between the countries today.
Formation of an association to conduct a State-wide campaign against "unfair competition" from chain stores, was announced here yesterday by Victor H. Lawn, executive secretary of the new group.

Although she described the labor situation as "very healthy," Secretary Perkins disclosed today that a survey of reports from about 107,000 establishments showed that there were approximately 46,000 fewer employed workers in June, this year, than in May, while weekly payrolls decreased $2,100,000 in the combined manufacturing and nonmanufacturing industries that are included in the survey.
Cornelius Edward Rorke, veteran hotel man, died yesterday of a heart attack at East Patchogue, L. I., in the house where he was born. His age was 76.

The biggest picketing demonstration since the strike of some 12,000 shipyard workers in the New YorkNew Jersey area began, more than five weeks ago, was staged at closing time yesterday. afternoon in front of the plant of the- Robins Drydock and Repair Company in Brooklyn by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C. I. O. affiliate.

Charles E. Nicholson, from whose fertile board four of Great Britain's America's Cup challengers have sprung, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to watch his latest creation, Endeavour II, in her match with Ranger off Newport.
The United States Circuit Court of Appeals reversed yesterday a judge ment for $258,000 rendered by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert in favor of F. W. Woolworth Company against the United States.

Fifteen minutes after sending police and detectives to another part of the city on a false alarm, three or four bandits held up the Atwells Avenue branch of the Industrial Trust Company this afternoon and escaped with $3,850.

Mrs. Sadie J. O'Brien, who has been superintendent of nurses at the Harlem Hospital since she organized the school of nursing there in 1923, died at the hospital yesterday morning after a brief illness at the age of 55.

By the will of William Carrington Stettinius, Baltimore financier, which was filed incourt here today, all his personal property, except cash, is left to his widow. The remainder of his estate is to be held in trust for her. No estimate of the value of the estate was given.
John W. Fraser, president of the Roosevelt Savings Bank and a director of the Brooklyn Trust Company, has been elected a director of the Morris Plan Industrial Bank of New York.

Captain J. C. Townley arrived yesterday in command of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary for the fourth consecutive voyage, relieving Commodore Reginald V. Peel, who is in the Channel Islands recovering from an illness.
Police dusted off today a law used occasionally back in grand pa's day and took two youngsters into custody for horse stealing.

E. A. Rasmuson, president of the Bank of Alaska, predicted that platinum production in Alaska might upset the world market by 1938. "Production this year will be much larger than last," Mr. Rasmuson said.

Charles F. Lovejoy, auditor, in a report filed with the clerk of Federal District Court, disagreed today with claims of William T. Snow of Boston that J. P. Morgan Co. had promised to repay a $250,000 loan by his father, the late Frederic E. Snow.

More than 400 law enforcement officials are expected to attend the annual convention of the New York State Association of Chiefs of Police opening today at the Hotel Astor. The convention will continue through Thursday.
PEIPING, Tuesday, July 27.--Japanese troops were attacked by Chinese soldiers at the Southwest Gate of Peiping last night, increasing the danger of a Japanese attempt to sieze the former capital.
LFifteen "incorrigible" Basque refugee youths, who were responsible for terrorism in the camp at Brechfa, Carmar- he then, Wales, last week, will be sent back to Spain, it was announced tonight.

Magistrate Farrell refused in Felony Court yesterday to fix bail when he held two youths, Dominic Grieco, 20 years old, of 233 Nassau Street, and James Zeni, 19, of 162 High Street, both Brooklyn, for the grand jury on an attempted hold-up charge.
The Japanese Government fears that a major armed conflict between Japanese and Chinese in North China is now unavoidable.

The State Education Department announced the names today of 145 students in the State who had passed the examinations conducted June 14-18 for Cornell scholarships. Each scholarship entitles the holder to a reduction of $200 a year from the regular tuition charges.

The three-year plan sponsored by'Colonel Fulgencio Batista in Cuba for social and economic reconstruction will be achieved "within the democratic frame which will be determined by the Cuban people through their delegates to the Constituent Assembly," the Cuban Embassy said in a statement today.

Rain caused the postponement of the 12-round bout between Tony Galento of Newark and Al Ettore, Philadelphia heavyweight. scheduled at the Nutley (N. J.) Velodrome last night. The contest will be held tonight.

Mrs. Julia Morris Addison Roosevelt, wife of George Emlen Roosevelt, investment banker and distant relative of President Roosevelt, died early yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. Mrs. Roosevelt, who was 48 years old, had been ill for a month.
George Bernard Shaw celebrated his eighty-first birthday today, his undimmed vitality giving the lie to his own hint of a year ago that it was about time he started his obituary.

Finding it more advantageous to carry out its proposed refunding program in its own market than in New York, the city of Buenos Aires, Argentina, withdrew yesterday the registration statement it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the issuance of $13,500,000 of 4 1/2 per cent bonds.
The soundless, but fervent rendition of "The Star-Spangled Banner" tonight opened the triennial meeting of the National Association of the Deaf. Three thousand men, women and children attended.
President Roosevelt discussed today at a White House conference the possibility of government subsidies for international airlines, similar to the subsidies now being granted to steamship companies.

Frank Choynake, 16 years old, of 193 Pershing Avenue, was killed today when he fell from the roof of a three-story brick building at 454 Clinton Avenue, adjoining his home. The boy and his brother, George, 13, had gone to the roof to fly a kite.
The "Niebelungen Ring" began today with a performance of "Rheingold" which Furtwaengler conducted in the presence of Chancellor Hitler. Rudolph Bockel sang

In an effort to control prices and prevent speculation on the Shanghai exchanges, the Chinese Ministry of Industries has fixed maximum prices for wheat and flour, according to a radio report to the Bureau of Ariculture Economics made public today.

With the formation last night of a general council of 500 delegates to represent the Alteration Plumbers, Steamfitters and Helpers Union in negotiating with employers regarding higher wages and general working conditions, union officials asserted that the 1,400 members would not hesitate to strike if its demands were not met.
Pastor Walter Niemoeller, brother of the Rev. Martin Niemoeller, Protestant opposition leader, who was arrested Yesterday after having preached three times at Dahlem, was released this evening.

Dan Galgano, professional at Gedney Farm, and his partner, Robert Hanlon of the same club, compiled a fine 66 to take first honors in the pro-amateur best-ball golf tournament held today at the Fenway Golf Club under the auspices of the Westchester County Golf Association.

Josephus Daniels, United States Ambassador to Mexico; Representative J. Walter Lambeth of North Carolina, and Brig. Gen. Benedict Crowell, who arrived here yesterday, were guests today at a luncheon given in their honor by Guglielmo di Palma-Castiglione, acting director of the International Labor Office.

Nathan C. Lewis, retired commission merchant and brother of Municipal Court Justice David C. Lewis, died on Sunday at his home, 621 West 172d Street, after a long illness. Born in New York, Mr. Lewis was 54 years old.

State Treasurer William H. Albright reported today that State funds on deposit in New Jersey banks on June 30, the end of the fiscal year, amounted to $53,766,571, of which $34,324,968 was in Trenton banks.

All radio stations in the United States, numbering approximately 700, and ships at sea observed a minute of silence at noon yesterday in tribute to Anning S. Prall, late chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. Before the silent period Mr. Prall was eulogized, and then for one minute all transmitters were still.
The Yankees limped home last evening, glad to be back on hospitable soil after their harrowing experience in the four-game series with the White Sox, which closed their latest invasion of the West.

John H. Van Ness, one of the founders of Maplewood, who would have been 95 years old on Oct. 20, died today in the Orange Memorial Hospital after an operation. He lived in the 105-year-old house at 6 Van Ness

Ernst von Delius, who won fourth place in the Vanderbilt Cup races at Westbury, L. I., early this month, died today of injuries received in an auto race accident at Nuremberg yesterday. Von Delius's car skidded and catapulted .off the race track, throwing him clear of the machine.

Thomas Kiernan of the law firm of White Case, attorneys for Seagram Distillers Corporation, called two witnesses yesterday before the Federal Trade Commission hearing at 45 Broadway to defend the corporation's policy in trying to stop price-cutting of liquors.
Secretary Hull was informed today by Dr. C. T. Wang, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, of the seriousness with which the Nanking Government views the latest developments in North China.
Justice was not blind in the Scottsboro case. She saw more than the simple and somewhat incredible story of nine Negroes attacking two white women on a Memphis-bound freight train six years ago.

Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation's unfilled orders on July 1 were 81 per cent greater than a year ago, and were at the highest level in seventeen years, H. C. Beaver, president, said yesterday. Principal plants of the corporation at Harrison and Newark, N. J., and Buffalo, N. Y., are operating at a high percentage of capacity, and the Holyoke (Mass.) plant, which recently reopened, is expanding its output.

MANHATTAN BRYANT, CHARLES W. (Nov. 4, 1936). Gross assets, $26,616 net, $14,219. To Ada J. Bryant, widow, and Henry H. Bryant, foster father. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $14,061. Saul J. Cutler, attorney, 50 Court St., Brooklyn.

226th St, 962 E (17-4861); Bronx Savings Bank to Josephine De Rosa, 820 E 230th St. Clinton Ave, 1,969 (11-3092); Irene M Keating to Eva Koledo, 668 E 179th St. Kingsbridge Rd, 239 E (13-3293); North Side Savings Bank to 239 E Kingsbridge Road Corp, 1,134 Castle Hill Ave; mtg, $138.000.

The Saratoga race meeting opened today with a severe electrical storm. One horse was killed and eight were knocked unconscious by a bolt of lightning that struck in the far corner of the grounds adjoining the back stretch.

The Labor party, one of whose fundamental principles has been a radical reduction in military expenditures, offered no opposition tonight when the House of Commons completed, the last formalities connected with the start of Britain's [Pound]1,500,000,000 rearmament program.

The Sun Oil Company reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $4,376,371 after interest, depreciation, including surtaxes on undistributed profits, depletion and taxes, equal, after dividend requirements on the preferred stock, to $1.90 a share on the 2,144,929 nopar shares of common stock.

Godfrey L. Cabot, Inc., has ordered twenty covered hopper cars from the American Car and Foundry Company, according to Railway Age. The Hercules Powder Company has ordered four tank cars from the General American Transportation Corporation.

The large and well-known golfing family from Westchester, the Turnesas, made its Long Island debut today in the person of brother Joe as the Long Island Golf Association held another of its amateur-professional one-day tournaments at the Rockville Country Club.
Leewood Hills, Inc., sold to Arthur R. Orth the seven-room dwelling at 14 Knollwood Road, in the Leewood Hills section of Eastchester, N. Y. The Roemer, Kenny Comrpany was the broker.
With Lloyd Brown, George Uhle and Bob Feller taking turns on the mound, the Indians blanked Wilkes-Barre's New York-Pennsylvania League team, 5 to 0, in an exhibition game before 5,500 today.

Pensioned On their own application: LIEUTENANT-Michael J. A. Gleeson, Telegraph Bureau, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed June 8, 1901. PATROLMAN--Edward H. Pruschen, 48th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Jan. 14, 1910.

Officials of the United Automobile Workers Union found themselves today the recipients of demands from thirtyfive headquarters stenographers and office girls drafted on lines similar to those the union has been presenting to employers.

If the row in Yugoslavia over the ratification by the Chamber of Deputies of a concordat with the Vatican raged with the same bitterness in any Western State, it would cause general alarm as a symptom of civil war.

The Interstate Commerce Commission decided today that rates being charged for railroad transportation of coal from certain areas in Virginia to the Chicago district were "unduly prejudicial" and ordered that they be suspended.

Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, announced that approximately 1,200 applications for restaurant liquor licenses in New York City and surrounding counties were received during the two-week period ending July 15.

At twenty-eight golf clubs from West Orange, N. J., to Honolulu and from Madison, Wis., to Tampa, Fla., 550 amateurs today will battle for 173 places in the national amateur golf championship, to be played Aug. 23 to 28 at the Alderwood Country Club in Portland, Ore.

George S. Messersmith took the oath of office today as Assistant Secretary of State, a post to which he was appointed when serving as Minister to Austria. He has been designated a member of the boards of Foreign Service Personnel, of Examiners for the Foreign Service and the Foreign Service Officers Training School Board.

George W. Anger et al assigned to Tillie Fleischer a mortgage for $34,000 on 144146 Norfolk St. The Bankers Trust Co, as trustee, sold to the Marjo Holding Corp, Abraham. Schwab, secretary, the plot on the s s of 6th St. 110 ft w of Avenue C, 64x97, for $25,000, taking back a purchase money mortgage for $20,000, payable five years hence at 4 per cent, with $50 paid off quarterly.

THE Giants probably will look alive again when Daredevil Dick Bartell gets back in the game. He's the magneto man of the Polo Grounds outfit. He furnishes the spark. Wally Berger has jumped his batting average about 40 points since he draped himself in a Giant uniform. He's an example of what the well-dressed man will hit.
The English team of C. R. D. Tuckey and F. H. D. Wilde did more than one had a right to expect of them in winning the third set of their Davis Cup doubles match today from Gene Mako and Donald Budge.

Lehman Brothers headed the successful banking group yesterday in the purchase of an issue of $6,000,000 of short-term notes of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, paying a premium of $13.13 for 0:59 per cent notes.
The stock market generally was strong today, with the outstanding advances among home industrials. Gilt-edge issues continued firm, with French and Brazilian loans upside leaders among the foreign.

Many persons of social consequence saw the racing season inaugurated here this afternoon. The clubhouse, grandstand and terrace restaurants were thronged by the largest first-day attendance since 1929, in spite of a heavy thunderstorm which broke in early afternoon.
A contract has been placed with General Dredging Contractors of Montreal to complete deepening of the St. Lawrence ship channel at a cost of about $11,500,000.

Peter Pappas Jr., 10 years old, of 64 Betty Avenue, Providence, R. I., who disappeared at 2 P. M. yesterday from the Bridge Tavern, atop the Palisades at Fort Lee, was found dead tonight, lodged against a rock on the face of the cliff, about 100 feet below its summit.

Raymond Massey, English actor, was stricken ill today while working on a motion picture set and taken to the Good Samaritan Hospital, where physicians diagnosed his ailment as a blood clot of the leg, technically known as phlebitis.

MEDFORD, Mass., July 26 (AP).--Little Amy Morrissey, niece of Amelia Earhart, lost in the Pacific while flying around the world, today received a birthday present which was mailed by Miss Earhart when she was in Bombay, six Oriental bracelets made of gold and spun glass.

The Hungarian Government has provided foreign currencies sufficient to meet 50 per cent of the interest due on Aug. 1, on the State loan of the kingdom of Hungary, 1924, according to Speyer Co., American fiscal agents.
Control of the municipal water and electric works of Canton, China, has been taken over by the municipal government, the Commercial Attache in Shanghai advised the Department of Commerce today.

Two entrants in the annual Chicago to Mackinac yacht race were sighted at Sleeping Bear, south of here today. The sloop Rubaiyat, owned by Commodore Nathaniel Rubinkam, Chicago, and reported off Frankfort, Mich., was believed to be the leading boat and presumably the one which had passed Sleeping Bear. The Rubaiyat wa, the 1936 winner in the cruising division.

Paced by Dave Harris's three home runs, the Montreal Royals defeated the Jersey City Giants, 9-3, tonight in the opener of their four-game series. The slugging "Sheriff" had a single besides his home runs for a perfect night at bat.

The Farmers and Merchants National Bank of Matawan has sold to G. Luther Cox of New York ?? farm of 120 acres west of Route 34, Holmdel, N. J. The property adjoins the farm bought recently by Frederick Frelinghuysen and was acquired through the Joseph G. McCue Agency, which also sold for Daniel McCormick the Sugar Loaf Hill Farm of 106 acres at Phalanx, near Lincroft, to Ildon R. Blackburn of South Orange.

The Federal Power Commission asserted today in a letter to Senator Pope, chairman of the subcommittee that took testimony on the Regional Conservation Bill, that the electrical industry probably would continue to be "a dependable consumer of bituminous coal for years to come."

The National Maritime Union scored an overwhelming victory in its first official contest with the International Seamen's Union to determine the bargaining agency of unlicensed personnel of ship lines operating from Atlantic and Gulf ports, the Labor Relations Board announced yesterday.

Following consummation of the reorganization plan of Follansbee Brothers Company and the creation of a new company, Follansbee Steel Corporation, the court has ordered rights to subscribe to 70,000 new common shares to be mailed Aug. 7 to stockholders of record Aug. 3, with the rights to expire Aug. 30.

The radio, frequently regarded as a dangerous rival to the playing of music in the home, is creating a renaissance in the public love for good music which may bring with it "the golden age" of the piano, L. P. Bull of Chicago, president of the National Piano Manufacturers Association of America, declared yesterday at the thirty-sixth annual convention of the National Association of Music Merchants.

William T. Fetherston, Democratic chairman of Richmond County, was chosen unanimously by the county executive committee last night as the party candidate for Richmond Borough President. He was also re-elected county leader.

With the exception of one or two group movements, trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was devoid of general interest and prices fluctuated irregularly within narrow limits in exceedingly light trading.
Representative Rankin of Mississippi accused the Labor Relations Board today of "conspiring with communistic influences to destroy Southern industries."

Edwin M. Slote, attorney for petitioning creditors, obtained an order yesterday from Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn directing the Yellow Manufacturing Credit Company, a finance unit, to show cause why it should not be restrained from selling fifty-eight buses of the Tompkins Bus Company of Staten Island.

Uncorking the fastest six furlongs on an American track this year, the Motor City Stable's Appealing won the Belle Isle purse at Suffolk Downs in 1:09 3-5 today by six lengths over Mrs. F. Rossiter's Marson to pay $3.20.
Gloversville's league-leading team in the Canadian-American loop staged a slugfest today to defeat the Pirates of the National League in an exhibition game, 11 to 8.
Thirty-one seasoned campaigners were named today as probable starters in tomorrow's Stewards' Cup Handicap at six furlongs.

Police Lieutenant Fred A. Lowe, 60 years old, attached to Traffic L in Brooklyn, was killed at about 7 P. M. today on Jerusalem Avenue at the Southern State Parkway Bridge, when the automobile in which he was driving alone apparently passed out of control during a heavy rainstorm.
The navy's light cruiser Omaha remained stuck in the sand today at Castle Island light in the Bahamas.
Whether Mayor La Guardia will receive organization support for the Republican nomination for Mayor. and whether he will enter the primary of that party without it will be determined by Friday night.

AND SO VICTORIA, by Vaughan Wilkins. (Macmillan, $2.50.) A historical novel. SUGAR IN THE AIR, by E. C. Large. (Scribner, $2.50.) A satire. GERMANY: THE LAST FOUR YEARS, by "Germanicus." (Houghton Mifflin, $1.75.) An examination of the German budget.
At least one way of taking a forthcoming season's pulse is to note the new plays that are making the rounds, or are about to, and here are some of them:
The Duchess of Kent and her two small children escaped unharmed tonight after a collision in which the royal automobile's windows were smashed and its side was crushed.

In order to make room for Ben Cantwell, the pitcher who was ordered last night to report to the Giants here tomorrow after he had won twelve games and lost seven for the Jersey City farm in the International League, Manager Bill Terry will have to release one of the players now on the New York roster.

Two youths who were suspected of a series of automobile burglaries over the week-end from Buffalo to this city were taken back to that city yesterday by Detectives Mack and McGuire of the Buffalo force to face charges of the theft of two traveling bags, containing $2,500 in valuables, last Friday.

The Mansfield bill, creating an authority to administer the new Bonneville hydro-electric and navigation project in Washingten and Oregon on the Columbia River, was passed today by the House without a record vote and sent to the Senate.

The period for circulating nominating petitions for Councilman under proportional representation began yesterday and will continue until Oct. 5, the Board of Elections announced. The petitions must contain not fewer than 2,000 valid signatures.
