The Non-Intervention Committee found itself tonight back in exactly the same place it was on July 16 when all twenty-seven nations accepted the British compromise plan as a basis for discussion. All that has happened since then--first the stubborn dispute over procedure, then the frantic efforts of the British to find a way outmight just as well not have taken place.

John Luther Maddux of this city and Los Angeles, a pioneer executive in commercial air transport companies, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack at his New York residence, 956 Fifth Avenue, after an illness of six days. He was 49 years old on July 15.

A party of 228 high school and college students from the Carolinas, Georgia and Florida, on a tour of Mexico, came to Mexico City today in an attempt to adjust a misunderstanding over the use of a federal school near here as a lodging.
Ten four-motored "flying-fortress" airplanes were ordered today by the War Department from the Boeing Aircraft Company of Seattle.

Department store stocks of merchandise on hand at the end of June again were heavy, with increases running as high as 90.2 per cent over a year ago, according to compilations for large stores in the metropolitan area issued yesterday
A farmer was shot and three non-striking workers and a picket were injured today as violence broke out for the second time in three days at the Connellsville mines of the Republic Steel Corporation.
Dr. Henry F. Cutler, retired headmaster at the Mount Hermon School for Boys in Northfield, today testified that Thomas E. Elder had threatened violence to S. Allen Norton six years ago.
Nathan Mann, hard-hitting New Haven heavyweight, will tackle Abe Feldman of the East Side in the star bout of ten rounds at the Queensboro Arena tonight.

A 10,000 square-foot plot of land containing a large dwelling at the southwest corner of Metropolitan Avenue and Lefferts Boulevard, Kew Gardens, Queens, has been sold by Katherine O'Connell to a client of Julius Zieser, attorney.
The text of Foreign Minister Koki Hirota's speech before a special session of the Imperial Diet today, as given out here by the Consulate General of Japan, follows:

Charlie Grimm, who left the Cubs in Boston on a stretcher ten days ago, came back to Chicago today, driving an automobile to assume command of his club in the opening game of the series with the Dodgers tomorrow.

ADRAIN-Mrs. Robert, widow of Senator Robert Adrain, on Sunday, July 25. at the Middlesex General Hospital, New Brunswick, N. J., at the age of 76. Mrs. Adrain is survived by a daughter, Jean Livingston Koch: a son. Robert Adrain, and three grandchildren, William R. Dorman, Bonder K. Hiscoe, Muriel K. Scholl, and a great-grandson, William Rawlins Livingston Dorman. Funeral services Wednesday, 2 P. M., at her home, in New Brunswick, N. J.

Mrs. Mary Ryan, 87 years old, fell downstairs and was killed early today at her home, 21 Cambridge Avenue, seven hours after she had been in an automobile accident which resulted in the arrest of her daughter, Margaret, on a charge of driving while intoxicated.

Randall H. Hagner of 2,339 S Street, Northwest, Washington, D. C., one of the leading realty men of the capital, died last night of bronchial pneumonia in the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, where he had been a patient since July 20. He was 57 years old.

Hubert Trinkle, Hoosier State champion, and Walter W. Lane, both of Anderson, Ind., won the national senior doubles horseshoe pitching title tonight in the closing event of the national senior A. A. U. tournament.

Holders of more than 98 per cent' of all allowed claims against General Theatres Equipment, Inc., have deposited their securities and claims under the plan of reorganization, Edward C. Delafield, head of the committee, announced yesterday.

A 6,000-gallon still, described as one of the largest discovered in the city since the repeal of the prohibition amendment, was seized by the police yesterday on the two top floors of a five-story building at 537 West Fifty-third Street, after neighbors had complained of smelling alcohol.

The Chase National Bank is offering at public auction today, through Adrian H. Muller ons, 18 Vesey Street, New York, all of the collateral securing a loan of $500,000 to the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago on Jan. 9, 1932 and defaulted in the Insull collapse.
In spectacular clashes west of Madrid today the Loyalists shot down five Rebel planes and lost none. Included in this success was the rare feat of one plane's shooting down another in night combat.

Salaries and wages of officers and employes of the Federal Works Progress Administration are not to be included in "gross income" for purposes of taxation by the State of New York, Attorney General Bennett ruled today in answer to an inquiry-from Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner.

Charles C. Lane, 62 years old, who would have been retired Aug. 1, after thirty-four years as secretarytreasurer of the Dime Savings Institution in Newark, hanged himself today in the cellar of his home here, according to the police.

Stocks of crude oil and its products on the Pacific Coast at the end of June were 124,719,911 barrels, a decrease of 310,338, since May 31, according to the American Petroleum Institute. From Jan. 1 to June 30, oil stocks on the Pacific Coast have declined 6,623,825 barrels.

Mrs. Catherine Mullaly, mother of the Rev. Charles J. Mullaly, S. J., national director of the Apostleship of Prayer and editor of the Jesuit magazine The Messenger of the Sacred Heart, died here today at the home of her daughter, Mrs. William B. Woods of 305 Birkwood Place. She was 89 years old.

The first of a series of weekly study groups designed to give the women of New York State, who will become eligible for jury duty Sept. 1 under a bill passed by the last Legislature, an insight into the workings of the courts and their duties as jurors was held last night at the Hotel Lincoln by the Women's National Democratic Club. Forty women attended.

A collie dog, the pet of George Courtot of this city, went yachting yesterday with his master and friends down Narragansett Bay. Somewhere off Conimicut Light, five and a half miles away, the dog disappeared overboard and was given up for dead.
Automobile production declined more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index slumped to 99.7 from 131.7. This compares with 103.1 for the week ended July 25, 1936.

The list of the French liner Ile de France, due today from Havre via Southampton, includes Serge Koussevitzky, orchestra conductor, with Mrs. Koussevitzky; Colonel and Mrs. Nelson Morris, Mrs. Thomas Mann, Mgr. George J. Casey, Molly Picon, Jewish actress; Mrs. Sylvia Henrotin, French tennis player;

Trailing the field during the early running, Phillip Reilly's Warfellow, ridden by Jockey Sidney Hebert, turned on speed swinging into the stretch at Arlington today and won the Algonquin Purse at one mile by two and one-half lengths.
Judge Emmet H. Wilson of the Superior Court ruled today that the right of labor to picket a place of business existed only when there was a bona fide labor dispute.

The old Postoffice Building on Broad Street between Raymond Boulevard and Academy Street has been sold for $2,133,333 to the Harrison Central Corporation, 110 West Fortyseventh Street, New York, according to word received here today from the Treasury Department in Washington.
Reports of phenomenal grain yields from the harvest, which is now almost completed in the southern regions and is well along in others, are now pouring into Moscow.
Buddie, 2-year-old German shepherd dog, which was sentenced to death for biting folks in Yeadon, a Philadelphia suburb, received a new lease on life today, on a farm in New Jersey.

A moving haze which shifted into a brisk south wind and freshened up to a velocity of around forty miles an hour, greeted the fleet of thirty boats from the Eastern Yacht Club as the first leg of their annual cruise was completed here today.

A 6 per cent dividend. payable Aug. 1 on the corporation's outstanding preferred stock valued at approximately $1,000,000, has been declared by the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., it was learned yesterday.
Mrs. Lea McI. Luquer of Mount Kisco, N. Y., entertained with luncheon at the Bar Harbor Club today in honor of Mrs. Paul Burnham Moffett, who has just returned from Australia and India.

Announcement has been made by Miss Eleanor B. Lenane of 310 Riverside Drive of the engagement of her niece, Miss Madeleine Marie Lenane, to Sylvester Wilson Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Murphy of Fieldston, this city.

Davey Day, speedy Chicago fighter, had too much power for Johnny Durso of Louisville, Ky., tonight, and won a technical knockout in the sixth round of a scheduled ten-round bout at Marigold Gardens Arena.
Local Chinese authorities opened a "million copper campaign" to contribute to the support of the Twenty-ninth Chinese Army, embroiled with the Japanese in North China for the past three weeks.

A sub-commission of the commission of inquiry investigating the charges against Leon Trotsky in the Moscow trials met yesterday at the offices of Local 48 of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, 231 East Fourteenth Street, and heard several witnesses who gave testimony on important points bearing on the charges.

Miss Marie Stark, a dismissed WPA adult education teacher, threw Mayor La Guardia's Summer City Hall at College Point into turmoil yesterday, struck Patrolman Edward Vitale in the left eye with a telephone and finally won an assurance of assistance from the Mayor himself.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to express my appreciation of the space you have given to the matter of the Royal Commission's report on Palestine in your editorial, and finally in your publication of the letter of Dr. Judah L. Magnes.

An institute of local and State government, which will be supported during the first six years by a gift of $240,000 received from an anonymous source, has been established at the University of Pennsylvania.

William West, 47 years old, of Leeds Place, charged with sending several threatening letters to President Roosevelt, was committed to the Atlantic County Hospital at Northfield today for mental observation.
The four freed Scottsboro defendants arrived at Pennsylvania Station at 9:25 yesterday morning and by 6 P. M. their rehabilitation had a good start.
If the world could be shocked out of any tolerance for war, or for governmental policies and systems that make for war, surely the spectacle of Spain would do it.

The manuscript of a new work by George Santayana, author of "The Last Puritan," has been received by Scribner's. The new work will be called "The Realm of Truth." It will continue the philosophical series begun in "The Realm of Essence," and "The Realm of Matter." The book will be published in the Fall.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed--By LOUIS FERMAGLICH, trading as Ferm Pharmacy, 110 West 79th St.-Liabilities, $6,611; assets, $150, plus insurance. IDEAL IMPORTING CO, INC., foods and novelties, 1,505 Third Ave.-Liabilities, $37,390; assets, $12,000 (both estimated).

Manufacturers of fur-trimmed coats and suits now quoted at $6.75 will meet today at the office of the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board to discuss a stabilization program. The meeting follows action last week by manufacturers
The body of Frank Tucci, 12 years old, was found late tonight hanging from a rafter in the basement of his home, 123 South Eighth Avenue, by his father, Antonio, a local tailor.

Although playing far below their usual form, Donald Budge and Gene Mako defeated C. R. D. Tuckey and F. H. D. Wilde of Great Britain today to bring the United States within one match of regaining the Davis Cup which she lost to France in 1927. The scores were 6-3, 7-5, 7-9, 12-10.
Tammany Hall, already rent by factional differences, was thrown into further confusion yesterday by the death of its leader. James J. Dooling.

Police invoked a new city picketing ordinance today in arresting three State C. I. O. officials as the N. G. Taylor tin plate mill, a Republic Steel subsidiary, opened for the first time since closed by the strike May 26.

The American Association All-stars, gathered from seven clubs, boast a batting and pitching edge for tomorrow night's fourth annual allstar contest. The Columbus Red Birds, the hosts, have some of the heaviest hitters and headiest hurlers in the league.
Bodies of thirty persons had been taken tonight from the ruins in Veracruz and Puebla States, where a heavy earthquake last night plunged cities into darkness.
Representatives of the major milk distributors, at a meeting yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Pennsylvania, announced the terms on which they will buy milk from the producers during August.
The sudden death of James J. Dooling evoked yesterday many expressions of praise for his abilities and of sympathy to members of his family. They follow:

Ralph H. Tapscott, president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York was elected yesterday president of the Brooklyn Edison Company, to succeed Frank W. Smith, who retired from all executive posts with the Consolidated System upon reaching the retirement age of 70.

Included in the long list of apartment rentals reported yesterday was one for ten rooms at 340 East Seventy-second Street taken by Thomas P. Fowler Jr. of Eastman, Dillon Co. through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.
Net income of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and its affiliated companies in the twelve months through June amounted to $38,282,456.

Quebec's four-man golfing squad, led by the brilliant play of Phil Farley, today won the interProvincial amateur team championship and possession of the Willingdon Cup, held for the last year by British Columbia.
Thirty years ago it would have been easier to understand Vivian Burnett's brave struggle to live down a painful past.

The sixteen-story apartment building, comprising the entire block front between Ninety-fourth and Ninety-fifth Streets and Central Park West, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. The Bank of New York and Trust Company, trustee and plaintiff in the action, bought in the property for $2,402,000. The sale was subject to a mortgage of $2,397,000.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following Chemical Warfare Service Reserve officers is ordered to active duty, July 25, at Edgewood Arsenal, Md., for training: Col. Joseph D. Sears, 425 Franklin St., Bloomfield, N. J.

Conferences of representatives of the American Federation of Musicians and spokesmen for major broadcasting companies and manufacturers of records and transcriptions were begun yesterday at the offices of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, on the union's demand for curtailment of the use of mechanical music in broadcasting studios, theatres and restaurants.

Reports that Mrs. William Ellery Leonard had fled for the second time from the "phobic prison" of her 61-year-old husband, the University of Wisconsin poet-professor, were confirmed today by Herman W. Sachtjen.
William Westbrook, 49, an Ogdensburg paper manufacturer, brought his yacht to a dock in one of the worst Hudson Valley storms this year and dropped dead on deck.

Mr. and Mrs. William Fischer of Brooklyn and Edgemere, Queens, have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Florence Zelda Fischer, to Morton Holzman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Holzman of Jamaica, Queens.
A new cartoon character of more ambitious proportions than Mickey Mouse is about to emerge from the Walt Disney plant.

The Williamsport Grays, of the New York-Pennsylvania league, hammered three of the Athletics' pitchers for fourteen hits and defeated the American leaguers, 6 to 2, in an exhibition game tonight. George Turbeville, Bud Thomas and Ed Smith, former Grays, pitched for the Athletics.

The fifty-five steel workers dropped last week for staging an unauthorized sit-down strike in the Brackenridge mill of the Allegheny Steel Company, will not be re-employed until their ring leaders have been identified, under an agreement reached today between spokesmen for the Steel Workers Organizing Committee and company officials.

James F. A. Clark of Newport, R. I., a special partner in the Stock Exchange firm of Shields Co., had a net estate of $3,692,415, according to a transfer-tax appraisal filed yesterday. He died Dec. 9, 1935, at the age of 68.

Representatives of the wholesale distributors in the stationers' trade have requested the Federal Trade Commission to sponsor a trade practice conference to consider and adopt trade practice rules, the commission announced today.

Mrs. Carrie B. Ochs, widow of William B. Ochs, and mother of the late Lee A. Ochs, pioneer motion picture exhibitor, died early yesterday morning in her apartment in the Whitehall Hotel, 250 West 100th Street, after a long illness. Her age was 80.

Striking wholesale grocery truck drivers late today rejected a twelve-point compromise offering to them a modified closed shop, and renewed enforcement of their delivery stoppage that left many stores without provisions.

Tammany is a scramble of factions. Civil war rages. Conspiracies, rebellions, truces, shifting alliances have been the order of the day for some years. Mr. Dooling, head of the committee that sought to dethrone Mr.
To the general surprise in Belgrade, Prince Paul, the Chief Regent, suddenly left the Yugoslav capital today, returning to Slovenia.

Fitz William Sargent, since 1902 chief engineer of the American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company of New York, died on Sunday night at his home in Mahwah, N. J., after a long illness, at the age of 78. His wife, Harriet Barnes Sargent; a daughter, Mrs. Leroy S. Green,
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days.

Preston Delano, governor of the Federal Home Loan Bank System, will announce the offering today of $28,000,000 of one-year 1 1/4 per cent consolidated debentures, Series B, of the Federal Home Loan Banks.

Several luncheon parties were given yesterday in the outdoor Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton. Among the hostesses was Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Pell, whose guests were Mrs. Edward T. H. Talmadge, Mrs. Jorge Andre and Mrs. Reginald T. Townsend.

Endeavour II, T. O. M. Sopwith's America's Cup challenger, and Ranger, Harold S. Vanderbilt's defender, which will meet in the first race of the international match on Saturday, were at the Herreshoff Yard today for the final grooming of their underbodies.
The renewal of Far Eastern sales against gold transactions yesterday caused a further decline in the dollar in terms of the principal foreign currencies.
The Minister of Government has announced the establishment of a Government Press Bureau in accordance with the instructions of President Maximiliano Hernandes Martinez.
BERLIN, July 26 (AP).--The Reichsbank's statement as of July 23 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Frank O. Glenn of 125 Stratford Road, Brooklyn, was chosen yesterday as the twelfth member of the jury to hear the evidence at the second trial of Fred J. Hull, who is charged with first-degree murder in the death of Samuel Drukman on the night of March 3, 1935.

The election in which 10,500 B. M. T. workers will choose between the Independent Traction Workers Union and the Transport Workers Union, affiliate of the C. I. O., as their collective bargaining agent, will be held Saturday in the Brooklyn Technical High School, De Kalb Avenue and Fort Greene Place.

James J. Dooling, leader of Tammany Hall, died yesterday morning at his Summer home, 214 Beach 134th Street, Belle Harbor, Queens, less than four days after he had attained his first real victory as Tammany leader. He was 44 years old.

Favored singles players withstood wind and rain that marked the opening of play today to enter the third round in the Canadian lawn tennis championships at the Toronto Cricket Club. Only one of twelve seeded stars was eliminated from the men's singles.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 24: MAJOR GENERAL Conley, E. T., the Adjutant General, ten days' leave, July 26.

A tactical advantage to the bondholders of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., is seen as the result of the prompt decision taken by the Supreme Court of Ontario late last week directing that a meeting of bondholders be called for Oct. 15 in Toronto to consider the reorganization plan sponsored by the Joseph P. Ripley bondholders' representative committee and the preferred stockholders' committee headed by Lieut. Col. Herbert Molson.

Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations, told the House Naval Committee today that his department could not recommend, at this time, further expenditures for building and operation of dirigibles for military purposes.
This West African Negro republic; which originated in the efforts of American philanthropists to provide a home for freed slaves, celebrated its ninetieth anniversary today.

George Bruce Cortelyou, who served as secretary for three Presidents of the United States, quietly celebrated his seventy-fifth birthday anniversary today. Returning to his home in Huntington Bay Village after a full day at his office in New York, Mr. Cortelyou appeared a trifle tired this evening, but said he was feeling well. No formal observance of his birthday had been planned, he said.
Carriers and General Corporation--Report for June 30 showed total assets of $8,109,740, compared with $9.359,416 on Dec. 31 and $8,207,674 on June 30, 1936.

Bill Urbanski, shortstop of the Boston Bees for a time this Spring, today applied to Judge Kenesaw M. Landis, High Commissioner of Baseball, to be placed on the voluntary retired list, Club Secretary John Quinn said.

WASHINGTON, July 26.--A tentative decision to increase income taxes and surtax rates on personal holding companies to prevent them from being used as a means to escape taxation was made today by the Joint Congressional Tax Avoidance Committee.

Announcement was made today that a licensing agreement had been entered into between Farnsworth Television, Incorporated, and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company whereby each grants extensive rights under its patents to the other.
A special memorial tribute to Guglielmo Marconi was broadcast for the Italian-American population of New York City yesterday over Station WOV.

A barrage of thirteen hits, five of them in the seventh inning when six runs were scored, enabled Rochester to turn back the Newark Bears tonight, 8 to 4, as 7,236 customers paid their way into Red Wing Stadium to celebrate Tony Kaufmann night.

THE romantic historical novelists -- whose books have naturally been enormously popular in rootless and depressed years--continue to flourish. At their best they give history a new vitality through memorable characters. At their worst they muddle it inordinately. They contribute nothing whatever to the development of the novel, though they deal spaciously with the spirit of courageous adventure.

Jack Espey, general manager of the Redskins of the National Football League, said today he had signed four players, including Riley Smith, former all-America quarterback of Alabama, and Sam Busick, former Ohio State end.
Mrs. Sara Delano Roosevelt, mother of President Roosevelt, decided today to extend her stay at Salzburg. She had expected to leave Wednesday, but now plans to remain here at least a week.

Colonel E. M. House, wartime adviser of President Wilson and a close friend of President Roosevelt, observed his seventy-ninth birthday quietly at his Summer home today, his activities restricted by a slight illness.

District Attorney William C. Dodge received by air mail yesterday a report from Assistant District Attorney James T. Neary on his recent interrogation of Mrs. Stella Crater, wife of the missing Supreme Court Justice, Joseph Force Crater, at her Summer home at Belgrade Lakes, Me.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton gave a dinner for forty followed by backgammon last night. Albert J. Pardridge won at backgammon, Mrs. David Stone coming next. Mr. and Mrs. Appleton have as their guests Mrs. A. M. Conway and Miss Gordon Conway of Paris and Pierre Barbey of Tuxedo.

Hundreds of Catholics who were traveling in this vicinity today came to St. Christopher's Shrine Church to have their automobiles blessed. It was the annual feast day of St. Christopher, the patron saint of all travelers, and not only pleasure cars but automobiles from the New York State Police and Nassau County and village police were blessed.
Magistrate Jeanette C. Brill, a believer in the dignity of the courts, instructed policemen appearing before the bench in Coney Island Court yesterday to keep their coats on.

Albert Benjamin Clark, who had practiced law at Lee for fifty-seven years, died today of pneumonia at his home. Mr. Clark was born in Sheffield eighty-three years ago and was graduated from the South Berkshire Institute at New Marlboro.
Magistrate Jeanette C. Brill, a believer in the dignity of the courts, instructed policemen appearing before the bench in Coney Island Court yesterday to keep their coats on.

Albert Benjamin Clark, who had practiced law at Lee for fifty-seven years, died today of pneumonia at his home. Mr. Clark was born in Sheffield eighty-three years ago and was graduated from the South Berkshire Institute at New Marlboro.

Announcement was made today that a licensing agreement had been entered into between Farnsworth Television, Incorporated, and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company whereby each grants extensive rights under its patents to the other.
A special memorial tribute to Guglielmo Marconi was broadcast for the Italian-American population of New York City yesterday over Station WOV.

A barrage of thirteen hits, five of them in the seventh inning when six runs were scored, enabled Rochester to turn back the Newark Bears tonight, 8 to 4, as 7,236 customers paid their way into Red Wing Stadium to celebrate Tony Kaufmann night.
Mrs. Sara Delano Roosevelt, mother of President Roosevelt, decided today to extend her stay at Salzburg. She had expected to leave Wednesday, but now plans to remain here at least a week.

Colonel E. M. House, wartime adviser of President Wilson and a close friend of President Roosevelt, observed his seventy-ninth birthday quietly at his Summer home today, his activities restricted by a slight illness.

Representatives Bacon and Snell and the other Republicans who are continuing the agitation over the sale by the Democratic National Committee of the souvenir National Convention books, including some autographed by the President, are performing a valuable public service.

After a lapse of more than a decade, the Davis Cup, prime trophy of international tennis since 1900, returns to the United States. Led by the devastating Donald Budge of California, who has lost only four sets in match play this year, the American team routed

A term of seven and one-half to fifteen years in Sing Sing was meted out today to Thomas Coldwell, 50 years old, a Negro, of 47 North Village Avenue, Rockville Centre, by Judge Cortland A. Johnson of the Nassau County Court. Coldwell was accused of contributing to the death of Thomas Cronert, also of Rockville Centre, a delegate to the county Legion convention.

Approval has been given by the Securities and Exchange Commission to the proposal of the Eastern Shore Gas Corporation of Delaware to acquire all the stock of two subsidiaries now held by the public, the commission announced today. Exchanges of other stock will be made.

Several leases in the Park Avenue and the East Fifties sections featured the many contracts for residential space reported yesterday. Among those reported as having taken space was Mrs. Bruce Payne, an executive of Bergdorf Goodman, who leased a terraced apartment at 40 East Fifty-second Street through Pease Elliman, Inc. The full list follows:
General Francisco Franco's soldiers battled to the outskirts of Villanueva de la Canada today, leaving two government brigades wrecked in their path, Insurgent advices said tonight.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on July 17 totaled 307,139,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the previous week this total represented a net decrease
The National Editorial Association board of directors voted today to join a committee from eleven other publishers organizations in opposing the closed shop proposal of the American Newspaper Guild.

President Roosevelt defended today his National Labor Relations Board, which members of Congress have declared was leaning toward communism and being biased in favor of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Dr. Guillermo Patterson y de Jauregui, Cuban Ambassador to Mexico and career diplomat, died early this morning of a cerebral hemorrhage at the home of his daughter in the Vedado residential district. He was born here sixty-nine years ago.

Frankie Parker had the greatest Davis Cup thrill today, for it was his victory over Charles Hare that won the cup for the United States. Unlike his tennis Saturday against Bunny Austin, his game today was impeccable-sure, powerful and decisive.

A 5 per cent increase in railway passenger fares effective Oct. 1 was announced today by all roads. Thus the basic fares will exceed the rate in the United States, which for a year has been at about the same level as the British charges.

A first mortgage loan of $205,000 for five years has been placed by the Haggstrom-Callen-Davis Company for the Nelwin Realty Corporation, Harold Litwin, president, on the new apartment house at 60-70 Seaman Avenue, near Academy Street.

The election of Eduardo Santos, recently nominated for President of Colombia by the Liberal party without opposition, now apparently is assured. Dario Echandia, leftist Liberal leader, has cabled his followers in a manner that has been interpreted as a withdrawal of his candidacy.

Mrs. Bartholomew J. Barry gave a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Adolph Schwarzman, Mrs. Wallace Grove, Mrs. J. K. Robinson and Miss Elaine B. Barry. In the luncheon party there of Mrs. Arthur M. Hurd were Mrs. Reginald Oakie, Mrs. James Lakeman Ward and Mrs. J. Herbert Claiborne.

The stage is now set for the declaration of the first common dividend of the United States Steel Corporation since March, 1932. The corporation has now declared out of earnings for the calendar year ended on June 30 a total of 25 1/4 per cent, or $90,970,977, in preferred dividends, and has eliminated the arrears of 18 1/4 per cent.

The New York State merchant marine schoolship Empire State arrived here with one more aboard than when she left the United States--a young Swedish cook's mate named Johanson, who suffered an attack of appendicitis aboard the Swedish motorship Axel Johnson in mid-Atlantic.
An appropriation of $28,650 made by the Anne Brown Alumnae Association to establish scholarships at Barnard College for deserving young women was voided yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J.

President Roosevelt told at a press conference of plans to build up the Naval Reserve, replied to charges of partiality against the National Labor Relations Board and said that he had asked Attorney General Cummings for an opinion as to the legality of a recess appointment of a Supreme Court justice to succeed Justice Van Devanter.

Known for a generation as the graveyard of favorites, especially when the track is slow or muddy, Saratoga's threat to form today was turned back in the Mohegan Purse, when the Chilean invader, Caballero II, scored at 9-to-10.

One hundred and two boy drivers of "automobiles" made of soap boxes and baby carriage wheels competed yesterday in the first Red Star Ranger Soap Box Derby, conducted by R. H. Macy Co. The Department of Parks and the Police Department cooperated in conducting the event, held on a down-hill course on the Harlem River Speedwav at 155th Street.

The defending holder of the Seabright Bowl and a former champion of Wimbledon were added today to the heavy list of casualties in the fiftieth anniversary invitation tennis tournament at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

The Pan American Clipper III, under command of Captain Harold E. Gray, will leave Port Washington, L. I., at 7 A. M. today on the first leg of its second eastward survey flight over the North Atlantic. It will fly to Botwood, Nfld., by way of Shediac, N. B., remaining overnight at the Newfoundland base. The take-off for Foynes,
A proclamation by Eliot Ness, Safety Director, prohibited tonight any assemblies in the riot-torn district fronting the Republic Steel Corporation's Corrigan-McKinney plant.

Judge Carroll C. Hincks in Federal court here this afternoon granted a petition of the trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to abandon operation of the ninety-year-old Fall River Line and the New Haven line of the New England Steamship Company, a railroad subsidiary, and to sell nine steamboats.

Henry C. Turner, president of the Board of Education, chatted yesterday with a group of substitute teachers on the porch of the Summer City Hall and told them they might realize their objective of equal pay with regular teachers after the next city budget was adopted.

Extending the arrangements previously in force as to European and Far Eastern services, the Cunard White Star Line, it was disclosed yesterday, will become passenger agent for the Imperial Airways service between New York and Bermuda.
Motor vehicle fatalities in the United States dropped 3 per cent in June while motorists increased their mileage 9 per cent, the National Safety Council revealed today.

Representative Dickstein, New York, Democrat, appealing to the House for an investigation of alleged Nazi activities in the United States, listed in the Congressional Record today the names of fortysix persons whom he described as "expert spies and agitators."

GOVERNORS ISLAND 1st Lt. Walter J. Wenzel, QM-Res., 320 Grafton Ave., Newark, N. J., 403d Quartermaster Regiment, is ordered to active duty, July 25. at Governors Island, N. Y., for training at this headquarters in connection with the 1st Army C. P. X., Headquarters Second Corps Area. He will be relieved from active duty Aug. 7.

With only nine cases of infantile paralysis reported in the city for July, considered a barometer month for that disease, Health Commissioner John L. Rice said yesterday that "the prevalence of the disease is very low and there seems no likelihood of any outbreak this year."

Mr. and Mrs. Lewis C. Weldin of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Weldin, to Russell F. Perkins, son of Mrs. Homer G. Perkins of New Haven, Conn., and the late Mr. Perkins. The announcement was made known at a bridge party given at the Weldin home this afternoon.

Specs Erskine drove Angel Child, bay mare, to a 2-1-1 victory in the Nelson Trot, top event of today's Grand Circuit card. Dr. A. O. Taylor's Maysville, Ky., entry also produced the day's best mile -- 2:02 1/2 -- in the third heat, Calumet Evelyn, world champion double-gaited racer from the McConville Brothers' Ogdensburg, N. Y., stable, was second.

Enthusiasm for music is spreading so rapidly among the children of the nation that more than 2,000,000 boys and girls are now playing in school bands, according to Fred A. Holtz, president of the National Association of Band Instrument Manufacturers.

The preliminary series to determine the defending Six-Meter yachts for the Gold Cup and the Seawanhaka Cup ended today with six of the nine contesting craft eligible to continue in the final trial races and a seventh a possibility pending decision on a protest.
The State Department announced today a list of United States citizens, as registered with the department, residing in Peiping, China. They included:

Joseph Sroczski, 54 years old, who said he lived at the Hotel Claridge, Manhattan, was sentenced to serve fifteen to thirty years in Sing Sing prison by Judge Cortland A. Johnson in Nassau County Court today on two second-degree burglary indictments.

Japanese policy is directed solely toward the realization of stability in Eastern Asia through conciliation and cooperation between Japan, Manchukuo and China, and by stopping the Communist invasion of the Orient.
It is proper enough to speak of the battle over the Supreme Court as a crisis. The outcome is a great victory or defeat,
Denouncing the alleged abuse of prisoners under the Georgia penal system, Governor Hurley today refused to sign papers providing for sending back James Cunningham,
Newark blasted the offerings of three Rochester pitchers for fifteen hits tonight to record its seventysecond victory of the season, beating the Red Wings, 10 to 5.

Building of a new dirigible to take the place of the Los Angeles was urged before the House Committee on Naval Affairs by Admiral A. B. Cook, chief of the navy's Bureau of Aeronautics, and Commander Charles E. Rosendahl.

A result of the excommunication of Orthodox Serbian members of the Yugoslav Government and Deputies who voted for ratification of the concordat with the Vatican was seen in Bel grade today when the daughter of one of these Deputies-Mlle. Lukaroch--was informed that her marriage could not take place as announced since she and every member of her father's family fell under the ban.

For the past fifteen years Mrs. Anna Bass Carpenter, one of the oldest residents of this town, has acted as the unofficial mother to the boys attending the Citizens' Military Training Camp here at Madison Barracks, and her restaurant with its tempting menu of home-cooked pies and other delicacies has become an established part of the camp.
Lloyd's reported today the capture by Spanish Insurgents of the 2,539-ton British steamer Mirupanu, which was bound from Rotterdam for the Spanish Government port of Gijon.

Salvatore Vento, son of a fish peddler of the lower East Side, received yesterday the George Lane Nichols Medal for Good Sportsmanship, awarded annually to a 12-year-old boy enrolled in one of the seven centers maintained in tenement neighborhoods by the Children's Aid Society.

Under a new pension plan agreed to yesterday by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company management and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, the company will repay to 12,500 employes approximately $2,000,000 and for thirty years will pay $675,000
Louis Blaustein of Baltimore, a leading figure in the petroleum industry, died here today in the Hotel Shelburne. He was 68 years old. He suffered a cerebral hemorrhage last Tuesday.

Admiral of the Fleet Sir Somerset Gough-Calthorpe, who, as wartime commander-in-chief of the allied Mediterranean fleet, signed, with Rauf Bey, the armistice between the Allies and Turkey, died today at his home on the Isle of Wight at the age of 72.

Dollar volume of food movement over retail counters in July is running about 10 per cent above that of last July, despite the fact that markets were stimulated in July, 1936, by threats of drought in the mid-West and release of soldiers' bonus money, the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc., announced yesterday.

Striking a passer-by in his descent, Jack Backer, 52 years old, fell or jumped at 9:40 o'clock last night from the roof of a four-story building at 675 Lexington Avenue, at Fifty-sixth Street, and was killed.

An examination today of the appraisal of the more than $3,000,000 estate left by J. Henry Roraback revealed that the Republican leader had more than two-thirds of his property in the Connecticut Light and Power Company, which he headed for so many years.

A large, sandy-haired dog of uncertain ancestry has attached himself to the Citizens Military Training Camp here without enrollment or approval. He is a self-appointed mascot of the camp and apparently deems

A strike of engineers on two ships of the American West African Line, which was called a week ago by the Marine Engineers Beneficial As- nei sociation, spread yesterday to deck officers, radio men and unlicensed personnel and a third ship was involved. Five more of the line's ships may be affected if settlement is not reached, according to union officials.

Two consistent eighteen-hole rounds, netting 72 and 71 respectively for 143, today gave Willie Turnesa top honors as fifty-three golfers competed at Rock Spring in the metropolitan district's qualifying test for the national amateur championship.

Thomas E. Elder, former dean of the Mount Hermon School for Boys, denied today that he had assailed an old colleague with a gun in a new rendering of the old picture of the strong New England man living steadfast in the shadow of his God.
Bill Werber's two-bagger, scoring Moses and Finney in the eighth, gave Philadelphia an uphill triumph, 4 to 3, over the Indians in the opener of a three-game series today.

Charles W. Baker, who was of the fourth generation of his family to serve in the United States Life Saving Service, which in 1913 was merged with the Revenue Cutter Service into the United States Coast Guard, died this morning of a heart ailment in his home here. He was 76 years old.

Magistrate Harry G. Andrews, in West Side Court, yesterday freed two WPA guards who had been arrested on charges of assault growing out of the ejection of three cripples from WPA headquarters, 70 Columbus Avenue, on July 1.

Joe Louis and Tommy Farr, who will clash for the former's world heavyweight championship at the Yankee Stadium on Aug. 26, met for the first time yesterday. The rival warriors appeared at the headquarters of the New York State Athletic Commission to sign formal articles for their battle, and there they were presented to each other by Major Gen. John J. Phelan, chairman of the board.

Turpentine firm. 32 1/4C@33C sales 64 barrels; receipts 711 barrels; shipments 150 barrels; stock 34,334 barrels. Resin firm; sales 1,063; receipts 4,373; shipments 2,360: stock 71,053. Quote: B to WG, $7.80; WW, X, $8.60.

The Real Estate Association of the State of New York is to make a survey of ways and means of tapering off the mortgage foreclosure moratorium and the deficiency judgments on bonds or other evidences of indebtedness secured by mortgages on real property.

The policy of the New York City police in dealing with labor disturbances was laid down yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at the Hotel Astor, in the opening session of the annual convention of Chiefs of Police of this State.

Mrs. Ancell H. Ball entertained members of the Garden Club of East Hampton and their guests this afternoon at her home in Water Mill. Dr. Edith Roberts of Vassar College spoke. Mrs. George Roberts is president of the Garden Club.

Strikes and other aspects of labor unrest in the steel mills affected production in most manufacturing industries and at mines in June, it is disclosed in a summary of general business and financial conditions made publio today by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System.

Lester W. Herzog, State Administrator of the WPA, declared today that investigation following a New York news dispatch to the effect that WPA employment of potential farm labor in Oneida County was imperiling crops there showed there was no foundation for the statement.

Sister Ildefonse Lambing, whose brother, the late Rev. Andrew A. Lambing, wrote a history of the Pittsburgh Diocese of the Roman Catholic Church, died at Seton Hill College, Greensburg, today, at the age of 84.
Off to race against the first Endeavour tomorrow, Harold S. Vanderbilt's America's Cup defender Ranger sailed out of Narragansett Bay this afternoon bound for Buzzards Bay.

After undertaking a campaign earlier this month to organize all radio performers, the Actors Equity Assooiation surrendered jurisdiction in that field yesterday to the Associated Actors and Artists of America.

The Ten Eyck Hotel was inconvenienced tonight by a strike of employes called by the International Hotel and Restaurant Employes, following the ending of negotiations which have been in progress several days.

Nathan D. Lapham of Geneva, District Attorney for Ontario County for twenty-one years, today received the unanimous endorsement of the Ontario County Republican Committee for the position of Supreme Court Justice from the Seventh Judicial District.

George Morvan, 25-year-old house painter of North Drive, Huntington Station, L. I., charged with seconddegree assault for mistreatment of his 4-year-old daughter, Joan, pleaded guilty in Queens County Court yesterday and immediately was sentenced to two and one-half to five years by County Judge Charles S. Colden.

The largest number of Chinese residents of Havana ever carried on a single ship by the Grace Line arrived yesterday on the liner Santa Lucia en route to California where they will take ship for China.

MANHATTAN FARLEY. MARGARET J. (Aug. 7. 1936). Gross assets, $33,764; net, $30,225. To John L. Farley, James W. and Edward V. Farley, brothers: Mary Griffin, sister, one-fourth residue each. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, etc., $31,179. Felix A. Muldoon, attorney, 111 B'way.

Montreal and Jersey City divided a double-header tonight, the visitors taking the first game by 12--7 and the Royals capturing the second contest, 8--6. Mike Meketi spaced seven hits in the seven-inning opener for his second victory of the season. Phil Weintraub and Jack Redmond helped his cause by pounding out homers.

While Peiping, entirely cut off by rail, highway, telephone and telegraph, awaits today's surrender of the Chinese garrison or an attack from the Japanese Army, Tientsin eagerly awaits word from Nanking, but the silence continues.
Lee Grissom, 24- year - old southpaw, earned his tenth victory today as the Reds defeated the Bees, 3 to 2, in a sensational ninth-inning.

" To hunt and cultivate profitable customers" and "to handle unprofitable customers as economically as possible" are the only two ways by which selling costs can be reduced, Paul T. Cherington, of Cherington Roper, marketing consultants, yesterday told the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York.

Republican organization support for Mayor La Guardia remained in doubt last night; The Mayor had given no indication that he would accept as running mates Joseph D. McGoldrick and Alderman Newbold Morris, the candidates for Controller and President of the Council of Kenneth E. Simpson, New York County Chairman.
All of Premier Benito Mussolini's efforts have not succeeded in getting his newspaper, Popolo d'Italia, up to the circulation level of its principal rival, the Corriere della Sera.
The text of the Senate Bill to reform procedure in the lower courts, as completed today by the Judiciary Committee, is as follows:
The Aluminum Company of America won today the right to appeal to the Supreme Court in its fight to prevent the government from proceeding with a dissolution suit in the Federal courts of New York.
Four thousand special police moved into Belfast today to help line the twelve-mile route along which King George and Queen Elizabeth will travel tomorrow on their coronation visit.
SHADOW ON THE LAND: SYPHILIS, by Thomas Parran. (Reynal Hitchcock, $2.50.) The Surgeon General explains the necessity behind his campaign.

Holcombe Ward, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, and Bernon S. Prentice, president of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club, joined with the players competing here in hailing the victory at Wimbledon that brings the Davis Cup back to the United States after an absence of ten years.

One man was burned to death and more than a score were injured, eight of them seriously, in a fire which, shortly before midnight last night, swept the second and third floors of the Home Hotel, at 15 Bowery, a five-story lodging house occupied by men, most of them aged.

Serge Koussevitzky, Russian orchestra conductor, returned yesterday on the Ile de France after a two months' vacation in France and Switzerland. Mrs. Koussevitzky accompanied him. The musician said he would go at once to Stockbridge to conduct the Berkshire Musical Festival, which opens on Aug. 5.

Representative Edith Nourse Rogers, Republican, of Lowell, Mass., said in the House today that statements made by Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, on "economic liberalism" were not the views of the people of the United States.

The manufacturers and the union in the flint glass industry agreed today to a 10 per cent rise in wage scales and unlimited "term work" in the machine press department in the Pittsburgh and Wheeling areas at their annual collective bargaining conference here.

Reinforced by the flaming spirit of Blondy Ryan, who once fired the Giants into a pennant with the help of a spike wound and a football shinguard, Colonel Bill Terry's shellriddled troops made a terrific bid today to make a successful start on their third venture in the West this year.

Walker St, 88-90; 7-story loft and store building, 49.3x82.7 irregular; East River Savings Bank against Andora Realty Corp; due, $76,723; to plaintiff for $25,000. By HENRY BRADY Canal St, 302; 5-story loft and store building, 18.8x62.9; Woodlawn Cemetery against 302 Canal Street Corp; due, $27,678; taxes, etc., $50; to plaintiff for $21,000.
Many Rumson homes are crowded with house guests during tennis week, a great many being players participating in the matches on the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

More than 300 persons yesterday morning attended funeral services for Dr. Jacob Diner, founder and first dean of Fordham University College of Pharmacy, at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Seventysixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Following a loss of nearly $9 a bale in less than three weeks, prices on the Cotton Exchange rallied yesterday and under active covering ended around the top with net gains of 22 to 33 points. Buying was stimulated by reports that cooperative associations had sent urgent requests to Southern representatives in Congress not to adjourn before doing something for cotton.

C. J. Carmody hung up the low net score in the one-day golf tournament of the Advertising Club of New York at the North Hills Golf Club yesterday, with 91-25-66. Low gross went to Gil Tompkins, who had a 75, and Carl Eiser took I the low net for the nine holes of the morning round with 44-11-38.

A new deadlock over wage increase demands tonight extended Buffalo's food strike into its second week. After negotiations had reached a compromise settlement of a "closedshop-or-nothing" ultimatum delivered by 1,000 striking wholesale grocery truck drivers, believed to be the only point at issue, union representatives broached the new wage demands.
In a hotly contested six-round feature bout at the Coliseum last night Johnny Rinaldi outpointed Augie Gonzales of Puerto Rico. The victor weighed 134 pounds and his rival 133.
Mrs. Charlotte Markham Kanellos, wife of Vassos Kanellos, Greek dancer, died today of a streptococcus infection at the home of her mother, Mrs. H. L. Markham, at the age of 45.

Captain David Hamilton, 36 years old, and Fireman Charles Tiscornia, 47, were dismissed from the Fire Department here today after a departmental trial which resulted from their recent arrest for the theft of gasoline from the department repair shop. Hamilton, who was in charge of the repair shop, pleaded guilty to the charge of neglect of duty. Tiscornia declared himself not guilty.

A goal by Clarence (Buddy) Combs in the last minute of play gave the newly organized Evergreen Farms polo squad a 9-to-8 victory over a picked Monmouth County Country Club team led by George Oliver and Adam Gimbel today. The line-up:

Robert S. Saunders, an assistant engineer of the Board of Transportation, World War veteran and lieutenant commander in the New York Naval Militia and the United States Naval Reserve, died of a heart ailment on Monday at his home in Douglas Road, Emerson Hill. Stapleton. S. I. Lieut. Comdr.

The report of the North American Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months to June 30, which is to be mailed to shareholders today, shows a net income, after all expenses and charges, of $19,076,402, equal after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.01 a share on the outstanding common stock.

The U. S. Tire Dealers Mutual Corporation will launch an extensive advertising campaign on its latest product, the U. S. Tire, a popular price number, built as a companion to U. S. Royal and U. S. Royal Master, in full color pages in three nationally distributed newspaper magazines in August.

One rebellion in several years seems to be the limit for the Dodgers in Wrigley Field. They went right back to normalcy today as they dropped the opener against the league-leading Cubs, 5-2, and descended into a sixth-place tie with the winning Reds.

Five ers Sept. 1 under the floodlights at Soldier Field in the fourth annual all-star charity game. The nation's football fans, who cast 5,036,466 votes in selecting the squad of 65 players, decided that Gaynell Tinsley, Louisiana State end;

In honor of George Foster Peabody, who today observed his eighty-sixth birthday anniversary, an hour of music was given at Yaddo this afternoon by Mr. and Mrs. Quincy Porter, heads of the Department of Music of Vassar College, at the violin and viola, and John Duke, head of the Department of Music of Smith College, at the piano.

Sales reported by brokers yesterday indicated a demand for multifamily buildings in upper Manhattan. An investor bought from the Norman-Lila Estate, Inc., operators, the six-story apartment house on a plot 140 by 100 feet at 60 to 66 Thayer Street, southwest corner of Sherman Avenue, in the Dyckman Street section.

The Pirates celebrated their return home today by defeating Philadelphia, 4 to 1. The veteran Red Lucas limited the Phillies to six hits, In the seventh inning the Phillies collected two of their hits, Scharein's double and Atwood's single accounting for their tally.
The Browns opened Manager Jim Bottomley's first Eastern invasion today with an 8-5 victory over the Red Sox. Lou Koupal pitched the route for St. Louis and allowed nine scattered hits.

Stocks fluctuated narrowly and closed firm with leading shares fractionally lower; turnover, 939,510 shares. United States Government obligations generally lower, other bonds steady; transactions, $6,535, 600.

With a brilliant no-hit, no-run performance achieved by Ken Ash in the seveninning opening game providing the big feature, the Bisons registered two shutout victories over the Syracuse Chiefs tonight, 2 to 0 and 7 to 0.

A tip from an unofficial source to the effect that Virgil F. (Bert) Effinger, reputed head of the Black Legion, is hiding somewhere in Queens County yesterday led New York police to ask Detroit authorities whether Effinger was a fugitive from that city.

" I have returned to find my country in a difficult situation, but in shape to overcome all obstacles," Georges Bonnet, Finance Minister, said today, expressing his satisfaction at being able to speak to the American public through THE NEW YORK TIMES. "Thanks to the wonderful powers of recuperation that France always shows in times of crisis, I have been able to take useful action."

With witnesses testifying they had received from the Seagram Distillers Corporation "suggested price lists" for the sale of its liquors, testimony in defense of the corporation was continued yesterday before the Federal Trade Commission hearing at 45 Broadway.

Mayor La Guardia officially dedicated the open-air dance area in Colonial Park in Harlem last night. Nearly 5,000 Negroes attended the dedication, and cheered heartily when the Mayor raised his hand before the microphone in the new band-shell, and said, "Let the dance go on!"

The New York Stock Exchange authorized yesterday the listing of 20,000 additional shares of the capital stock of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, bringing the total authorized shares of the company listed to 15,545,175.

If the Sino-Japanese situation in the Far East becomes actual war, it will present the familiar picture of a military colossus, with feet of clay, pitted against a militant pigmy, well-trained and well-armed. A compilation of numerical military forces under arms would appear to be overwhelmingly in favor of China, but the superiority would not extend beyond the realm of

The Maritime Commission invited bids today on fifteen vessels of its laidup fleet, these to be opened here Aug. 31. The vessels were offered to the public either for scrapping or operation exclusively in foreign waters.

Bernard F. Gimbel on May 1 held 144,190 shares or 14.84 per cent of the common stock of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and Lehman Brothers held 107,059 shares or 11.02 per cent, according to a report by Gimbel Brothers filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
It was a wan smile of recognition that Detective Cesare Bonanno bestowed upon Stanley Duda, 15 years old, of 89 Butler Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.

By a decree issued today the government requisitioned all German wheat and rye crops for this year. The grain is to be used to safeguard the nation's bread supply, and for that purpose only. The oats and barley crops are unaffected.

Reporting a decline of $22,377,272 in the earnings of the General Motors Corporation for the second quarter of 1937 as compared with the period in 1936, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board, in a report issued yesterday ascribed the loss to the "inability of union leadership to control their own followers."

Vice Chancellor Vivian M. Lewis, in a decision rendered here today, authorized the Hudson County National Bank of Jersey City, the New Jersey administrator of the estate of the late Ivar Kreuger, match manufacturer, to accept $8,500 from Anders Jordahl and his wife, Mary D. Jordahl of New York.

England took the lead in the three-game test cricket series with New Zealand today, winning the second match by 130 runs. The first late last month resulted in a draw and the final contest is scheduled to start at The Oval, London, Aug. 14.
Former Poice Commissioner 'George V. McLaughlin was reappointed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as vice chairman of the Tri-Borough Bridge Authority for a three-year term, without salary.

When 1,500 Mexicans conduct a sitdown, or kneel-down, strike in a church at Nogales to prevent the execution of a Government order to close the edifice, and when the entire class of an American kindergarten stages a sitdown for longer school hours, it shows how paradoxical is the character of man.

" Fly Away Home" was presented tonight before a sellout audience at the Chase Barn Playhouse by the Forty Niners as their play of the Summer season. Howard Fischer, in the Thomas Mitchell role, and Jane Gordon, Catharine Montgomery, Bobby Sawyer and Richard Mackay, as his precious children, headed the cast of the Dorothy Bennett-Irving White domestic comedy.

Hope that the pair of German transatlantic planes would be ready by mid-August for their first crossing to the United States was expressed here today before he returned to the Hamburg plant by Dr. Richard Vogt, chief designer of the craft. He was traveling with Helmut Wasa Rodig, who will pilot one of the planes.

County Clerks and Commissioners of Jurors, at the opening of the 1938 budget hearings yesterday before Kenneth Dayton, Assistant Budget Director, presented estimates calling for substantially larger appropriations, which for the most part were for salary increases. While some of the county offices will be affected by reorganizations, the estimates submitted ignored these changes, which are intended to effect economies in government.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy completely exonerated yesterday Ellis L. Phillips and other officials and directors of the Long Island Lighting Company of wasting the corporation's assets and unjustly enriching themselves at its expense. The charges were made in a $20,000,000 accounting suit brought by minority stockholders.

" Tristan und Isolde" in concert form, the fifth and last presentation of the Lewisohn Stadium Wagner Festival under the direction of Fritz Reiner, was heard last night by 12,000 persons, for whom this, of all the master's music-dramas, has unique lure. Add to the inducements Mr. Reiner's last appearance at the Stadium, and a cool, balmy evenine.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company was defeated yesterday in its legal fight to obtain control of the $84,000,000 Jersey Central Power and Light Company without any additional outlay of cash, Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook ruled that it had no right to demand a pro-rata distribution of Jersey Central stock to holders of defaulted National Public Service Corporation debentures for which the stock is collateral.
Presentation of baby spoons by Deputy Health Commissioner William H. Best Williamsburg-Greenpoint Health Center, 151 Maujer Street, Brooklyn, 10 A. M.
All news from North China as reflected in the Japanese press and official dispatches reveals an atmosphere similar to that of the Boxer movement in 1900.

Anti-American propaganda in the German press is amazing, Albert Grzesinski, former Prussian Minister of the Interior, who was ousted by Franz von Papen when the latter was Chancellor, declared in an interview yesterday upon his arrival on the French liner Ile de France.

Japan gradually has been extending her occupation of China since the SinoJapanese War of 1894. Following are steps in the occupation: 1894--As a result of the Sino-Japanese War, Japan annexed Formosa and prepared for the annexation of Korea through Chinese recognition of the independence of that province.

William Forbes Morgan Jr. and Miss Marie Newsom of Shawnee, Okla., obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building, and said they would be married on Aug 7 in Calvary Episcopal Church. Gramercy Park North.

Citing his record as chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee on legislation affecting the interests of seamen and his attitude toward strikes in the shipping industry in the last two years, the National Maritime Union voted yesterday to oppose Senator Royal S.

Revision of Michigan's Industrial Relations Act, with elimination of the section forbidding picketing by nonemployes of a struck plant, is one of the objectives of the special session of the Legislature to be convened by Governor Frank Murphy on Friday.

Stanley Allen Martin Jr., 29 years old, married, father of a son 2 years old, drove up to two policemen in Flushing, Queens, at daybreak yesterday with a dead woman limp in the cabriolet seat beside him. He told them the woman was ill.

The Morning Post, the oldest daily newspaper in the British Empire, has been sold to Lord Camrose, owner of The Daily Telegraph, and probably will be merged next month after 165 years of continuous publication.

Molly Picon, New York actress, returned yesterday on the French liner He de France from a successful vaudeville concert tour through South Africa, South America and Europe, traveling 50,000 miles by sea and land singing in English, French, Yiddish and Spanish.

Senator Duffy introduced in the Senate today an amendment to the Revenue Act of 1936 to permit credit against undistributed profits for expenditures incurred during the taxable year in construction of plant or purchase of new equipment. His prime purpose, he said, was to stimulate the durable goods industry.

According to cablegrams from London, A. J. Cronin's new novel, "The Citadel." is causing a flurry in London. Gollancz, the publisher, reports printings of 40,000 copies, an unusually large English edition. The novel will be published here by Little, Brown in September.
Wrecking crews began today the demolition of buildings for 400 feet along the north side of Nassau Street to make way for Princeton's new $4,500,000 civic square, now under construction.

A giant crow, crazed by a shotgun wound in its foot, swooped into an automobile on the Flemington Road tonight and so furiously attacked a passenger and the driver that the car was wrecked and both men were injured.
Presilent Roosevelt today disclosed an Administration plan to build up the Naval Reserve by offering free training to youths of college and high school age.

Taking advantage of the newly enacted State law, the Glen Cove City Council fixed tonight a tax of 1 per cent on the gross incomes of six local public utilities. The proceeds, which are expected to be $25,000 a year, must be used exclusively for relief.

A code of fair trade and practice rules for the silk and rayon dyeing, finishing and printing industry, intended for adoption by the Federal Trade Commission, was given approval here today by representatives of over seventy-five companies attending a hearing before agents of the commission.

Setting a fast pace for the adjournment drive in Congress, the Senate Judiciary Committee today unanimously approved and ordered reported the bill for "procedural" reforms in the lower Federal courts.

Fundamental Investors, Inc.--Six months to June 30: Net income from all sources, after expenses and taxes, $281,423. This figure included $177,535 net profit from sale of securities and rights, without provision for Federal income taxes, credited directly to earned surplus account.

If suspicion is the quality which "haunts the guilty mind," then there are a lot of bad consciences in the Administration and in Congress as this session of the national legislature draws to its close. Under an outward appearance of truce observers can easily discover among the Democrats a prevailing lack of confidence in one another which extends further, as between man and man, than it has for a long time.

A deal near St. James Park, the Bronx, was announced yesterday by David S. Meister, who bought the two apartment houses at 2,600 and 2,608 Creston Avenue, southeast corner of 193d Street. The latter is a six-story elevator house on a plot 121 by 112 feet and has apartments for fifty-three families. The other is a five-and-a-half-story apartment house on a plot 129 by 112 feet and houses the same number of families.

China's efforts to serve peace with Japan are at an end and the responsibility for future developments in North China is Nippon's, a statement by a spokesman for the Foreign Minister at Nanking declared last night.

Agnes L. Egbert assigned to Alkmene Buyukas a mortgage for $12,500 on 112 W. 134th St. The Mortgage Commission, as trustee for certificate holders guaranteed by the Lawyers Mortgage Co., has extended these three mortgages: $63,500 on 22 Pike St (Wintrude Realty Co., Inc. (Jacob Shapiro, president, owner) to March 3, 1940, 3 1/2 per cent; $160,000 on 22-34 Arden St, Nedra Realty Corp., Joseph Rudinsky, president,
Drafting of a bill employing the "pressure system" on various corporate devices, in order to prevent their use as tax loopholes, engaged the Joint Congressional Committee on Tax Avoidance today.

The remarkable feat of shooting down a Junkers bomber in the middle of the night was repeated on the Sierra front west of Madrid early this morning by a Loyalist flier under almost exactly similar circumstances.

Mrs. William de Wilder Atkinson gave a dinner tonight at Ballyshear for her debutante daughter, Miss Nancy Van Vleck, who celebrated her seventeenth birthday. Miss Van Vleck will be introduced formally to society at a dinner dance Dec. 23 at the WaldorfAstoria.

Coast Guard cutters sought tonight to round up the last stragglers in the annual Chicago-toMackinac yacht race. Three of the racing craft remained somewhere on storm-tossed Lake Michigantwo of them unreported since the race began Saturday.

" Shadow on the Land: Syphilis" is the title of a book by Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General, United States Public Health Service, pubwished today by Reynal Hitchcock. Dr. Parran dedicated the book to Governor Herbert H. Lehman.

Two of the four biggest guns near Gibraltar have already been dismantled by Spanish Rebel authorities, Sir Thomas Inskip, Minister for Coordination of Defense, told the House of Commons tonight during a debate in which Winston Churchill and other members showed renewed anxiety over a possible threat at the entrance of the Mediterranean.

A bill to prevent parties at interest or their attorneys in bankruptcy proceedings from making agreements as to fees of receivers, trustees or employes of receiverships was introduced today by Senator Borah.

Too busy to be interviewed, General Ballington Booth, Commanderin-Chief and founder in 1896 of the Volunteers of America, faced serenely today at his Summer home here the fact that tomorrow would be the eightieth anniversary of his birth.

A requiem mass will be sung at 10 A. M. today in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, for Captain Berthold C. E. Ackerman, merchant marine master and World War veteran.

Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Robert Moses agreed yesterday on a proposed ordinance regulating signs, parking spaces and amusements in the area surrounding the World's Fair site in Flushing Meadows, and the Mayor sent the ordinance to the Board of Estimate for approval.

Eight House of Commons attendants carried today as many large bundles of papers into the chamber, while J. C. M. Guy, Conservative member, read a formal paper introduring into the record a petition signed by 1,000,000 persons asking pensions for spinsters at the age of 55.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,576,400 barrels, compared with S,557,950 in the preceding week, an increase of 18,450, according o the American Petroleum Institute.

Startled scanners of seriate S's said surfeit of sibilance seemed certainn" for students seeking to read the Rev. J. P. Cargile's 13,000word novelette in which each word begins with the nineteenth letter of the alphabet.

The desire of many members of Congress to get away from Washington as soon as possible is obvio?? understandable. The weather is hot. The session has been long. The controversy over the Supreme Court has ruffled tempers and exhausted patience. All this, however, does not constitute a sufficient reason for legislating at top speed on matters of importance, merely for the sake of hastening an adjournment.

The Smithsonian Institution has thought it worth while to inquire into the meanings of the names of Indian origin that have been given to States. It is a quest that may have little or no practical value, but it is of interest to know with what the scattered aboriginal inhabitants of these vast stretches of field and forest,

Dr. Emeline Place Hayward, daughter of Mrs. J. Kilbourne Hayward of 201 West Eighty-ninth Street, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard North in St. Agnes Chapel, West Ninety-first Street, by the Rev. Alonzo Wood.

Plans are completed for the marriage of Miss Katherine A. Wilmarth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin L. C. Wilmarth of Glens Falls, to William J. Holding of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Claude J. Holding of Albany and Lake George.

Mr. and Mrs. Snowden A. Fahnestock will give a dinner at Ker Arvor on Saturday night before the ball which Mr. Fahnestock's sister, Mrs. Henry Drummond-Wolff, will give at the home of Mrs. William Fahnestock, to introduce her daughter, Miss Marsyl Stokes. Mr. and Mrs.

Many parties are being given here and among those tonight was a buffet dinner at which Mr. and Mrs. Luther A. Wait of Palm Beach honored their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Presbrey of New York and Greenwich, Conn.

The Census Bureau announced today 290,406 tons of linseed were crushed in the quarter ended on June 30, compared with 144,709 in the same period a year ago. Linseed oil produced totaled 206,511,823 pounds, compared with 100,118,519 a year ago.

The House passed one of four Government reorganization bills today to give the President six executive assistants at $10,000 a year each, after a partisan debate that started off spiritedly, grew facetious and finally ended in good-natured raillery.

The National Labor Relations Board has filed a complaint requiring Western Union officials to show at a hearing Aug. 5 that they are not guilty of "interfering with, dominating and controlling" the Association of Western Union Employes, a union including most of its employes.

Representative Snell of New York, House minority leader, sent a letter today to Attorney General Cummings, in which he asked whether the Department of Justice was making an inquiry to determine whether the Democratic National Committee violated the Corrupt Practices Act in selling souvenir convention books to corporations.

The First National Bank, 2 Wall Street, was authorized to complete the administration of the estate of the late George F. Baker Sr., former chairman of the board of that institution, in an order signed yesterday by Surrogate James A.

The House Agriculture Committee ordered eleventh-hour executive hearings on general farm legislation today, but its chairman asserted that prospects were "not especially bright" for enactment this year.

Louis J. Colombo Sr., chief attorney for the Ford Motor Company, told John T. Lindsay, trial examiner, at a National Labor Relations Board hearing today, that he was being treated "like a horse thief." The trial examiner, who had jumped from his seat and had advanced toward the lawyer, shouted back that "bulldozing" would not get Mr. Colombo anywhere.

Debate began in the Senate today on the Black-Connery bill for the regulation of hours, wages and child labor and almost no opposition was expressed on the floor during the session. Unless some new obstacle should arise, leaders on both sides expect to see the bill passed tomorrow.

It develops that "World Cruise," the musical show Jack Curtis and Charles Allen will produce, is the one formerly planned by Mr. Curtis and Herman Shumlin. And now-as then-it calls for the services of Lou Holtz and the singer named Hildegarde in leading roles.

Louis Lipsky, vice president of the Eternal Road Distributing Corporation, the company that owns all rights to Fritz Werfel's play, "The Eternal Road," filed a petition yesterday in Federal Court asking permission to reorganize under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act.
An unprecedented wave- of subscriptions from small communities in every section of the United States, which appeared when the books on the $28,000,000 of consolidated

Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Bullock left the Pierre yesterday for The Columns, their Summer home in Royalston, Mass. Mrs. Harold Money of Baltimore and her daughter, Miss Diane Franchot, are at the St. Regis. Mr. and Mrs. Howard Kellogg of Buffalo are at the Waldorf-Astoria.
A few words of encouragement to the anglers patiently waiting for a run of bluefish are contained in a note from Leo B. Travers of the Manasquan River Marlin and Tuna Club, Brielle, N. J.

Ten years of striving and of hopes that were a??ed again and again had their fulfillment on the center court at Wimbledon today when Frankie Parker and Donald Budge of the United States won their mingles matches and regained the Davis Cup from Great Britain by the decisive margin of 4 to 1.

EVERY year, when the hot enough for you? days roll around, the annual debate on Summer reading is poked up briskly. It's not really much of a debate. An imaginary straw man takes most of the punches. This is the one-sided way it usually goes:

Mayor La Guardia, dedicating yesterday the $238;000 WilliamsburgGreenpoint Health Center at 151 Maujer Street, Brooklyn, the fourth to be opened recently by the city, declared that the city was "not engaged in competition with the medical profession, but in return for that we expect the full, unlimited cooperation of the medical profession" in the public health and disease-prevention work.

At the auction salesroom of A. H. Muller Son yesterday afternoon the collateral behind a loan of $500,000 made in 1932 to the Corporation Securities Company, part of the now defunct "Insull empire," was bid in by the Chase National Bank.

IT was Frank Parker who made a team match of it by clinching the Davis Cup victory for the United States expeditionary forces at Wimbledon but it's Don Budge who deserves custody of the Cup. The Red Terror of Tennis certainly hit the heights this season.

Granted another chance by the tie into which Santa Barbara's defeat of the Cyclones last week had thrown the league, the Delhi polo team took full advantage 'of the situation today to gallop through a round-robin on Phipps Field and win the Red Brook League branch of the Hempstead Cups tournament in the Meadow Brook competition.

Payments to farmers in all parts of the country under the 1936 agricultural conservation program and county, State and national administrative costs prior to July 1, 1937, totaled about $400,000,000, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today.

Brief funeral services were held yesterday afternoon for Anning S. Prall, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, who died on Friday in Boothbay Harbor, Me. More than 1,000 persons were present at the Staten Island Reformed Church on Richmond Avenue, Port Richmond. They included statesmen, bankers, industrialists, State, city and county officials and men and women in all walks of life.

The Kings County Savings Bank sold to Diomede Omindola the twofamily dwelling at 2,483 Coney Island Avenue. Brooklyn, through Slomka Brothers, Inc., brokers, who also sold the one-family house at 1,905 Seventy-eighth Street for Irving Pollack and the dwelling at 44 Bay Twenty-third Street for Mildred Schwartz to Mary Galsband.

Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania and United States Senators F. Ryan Duffy of Wisconsin, Ernest W. Gibson of Vermont and Richard Russell of Georgia are sailing today for Europe on the steamship Washington of the United States Lines.
Federal Judge John C. Knox yesterday denied motions for reinstatement of discharged WPA workers. "There is a question," Judge Knox wrote, "if the courts can become supervisors of the supervisors."
No official pallbearers will be chosen for the funeral of the late James J. Dooling, Tammany leader, because his family feels that among his host of friends some might be overlooked.
The four Negro youths treed Saturday after six years of imprisonment in the Scottsboro case spent an uneventful day yesterday in the office of their attorney, Samuel S. Leibowitz, at 225 Broadway.

The semi-annual report of the National Lead Company, made public yesterday, showed a net profit of $5,192,266 after Federal income taxes, depreciation, depletion and other charges. This was equal, after dividends on A and B preferred stocks, to $1.36 each on 3,095,100 shares of $10-par common stock, excluding shares held in the treasury.

Memorial services were held this afternoon at his residence, Bentleigh, in Plandome, for Vivian Burnett, composer, editor and author and son of the late Mrs. Frances Hodgson Burnett, novelist, who died of a heart attack on Sunday afternoon aboard his yacht Delight in Manhasset Bay after saving two men and two women from drowning when their boat capsized.

Public offering will be made today by Halgarten Co. of 26,000 outstanding shares of 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $5 par value, and 100,000 outstanding shares of class A stock, of $1 par value, of Thomas J.
