Lipton, Inc., Hoboken, N. J., a subsidiary of Unilever, Ltd., through Lipton, Ltd., an English corporation.

It is clear that there are many things that distinguish man in a state of nature from, let us say, man in the State of New York, or a state of grace, or a Communist State or a Fascist State. Pondering the subject deeply during these warmish Summer days,

The directors of the United States Steel Corporation yesterday eliminated the remaining dividend arrears on the 7' per cent preferred stock by declaring a dividend of 1 1/4 per cent on account of arrears in addition to the regular requirements of 1 3/4 per cent for the second quarter of this year. Both disbursements are payable on Aug. 30.

The War Department issued the following orders today dated July 26: LIEUTENANT COLONEL Frink, J. L., Q. M. C.. 1 day extension of leave. MAJORS Levy, R. M., the Adjutant General's Department, two days leave, July 31. Prather, V. L.. Q. M. C., 3 months and 16 days leave, Aug. 14.

The Communist party "ceased to be a party" after the Gubernatorial election of 1936, the Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today when it affirmed without costs the decision of Justice Schenck and the affirmance by the Appellate Division.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Like every law, the Wagner Labor Act has its letter and its spirit. It is the spirit that shocks the American public. That spirit does not fit in the American scheme and, to all appearances, our public will never accept it.

Mrs. De Witt Untermeyer of Hollywood stroked her way into a two-way tie for the lead in the New Jersey women's shore golf tournament today when she shot a sparkling 79 in the second day's play at the Rumson Country Club.
A solemn requiem mass for Marchese Guglielmo Marconi, inventor of wireless telegraphy, was sung yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral in the presence of nearly 5,000 persons. Marconi died on July 20.

Returns by fifty-one Class I railways, representing about 70 per cent of the industry, show that credits taken from accruals under the Railway Pension Law of 1935 resulted in an aggregate net gain in June for the group which would not have been obtained if the credits had not been taken.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 26 unless specified: Balboa to Cristobal, July 27; Babbitt, Taylor. At Port Angeles: Broome, Hopkins, Melville, Williamson. New York to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Claxton, Erie, Fairfax, Jacob Jones, Manley Roper J. F. Talbott.

A complaint alleging unlawful conspiracy to fix and maintain uniform minimum prices was issued today by the Federal Trade Commission against Covered Button and Buckle Creators, Inc., its officers and directors, and approximately 150 member companies engaged in producing and selling upwards of 90 per cent of buttons, buckles and novelties produced in the United States.

Mr. and Mrs. Milton C. Weingarten of this place have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Carol Enid Weingarten, to Richard H. Henschel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Henschel of East Orange. The ceremony was performed by a justice of the peace last Thursday in Bennington, Vt. Mr. and Mrs. Richard Solomon of Albany, N. Y., were the witnesses.

The low bid submitted for 100 new steel cars for the city's Independent Subway System was $41,950 a car, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday. This was $1,575 more per car than the low bid offered on other cars last March, an increase attributed to the steel industry strikes.

William Aldrich's yacht Valiant, sailing in Class K and M, led the Eastern Yacht Club fleet across Cape Cod Bay from Provincetown to the entrance of Cape Cod Canal today. The fleet was towed through the canal to this point, where the next leg of the cruise, to Vineyard Haven, will be started tomorrow.

Mickey Cochrane returned to the management of the Tigers yesterday for the first time since an errant pitch cracked his skull in three places last May 25, but his choice of a day to resume the leadership was an unhappy one.

The Rivoh Theatre will reopen sooner than was expected, on Tuesday, in fact, with "You Can't Have Everything," a Twentieth CenturyFox musical comedy, with Don Ameche, Alice Faye and the Ritz Brothers. When the house closed Tuesday night the -anagement expected it would remain dark until Aug. 17, when Samuel Goldwyn's version of "Dead End" will be ready for Broadway.

George W. Fennell, bank official and head of George Fennell Co., operators of furniture stores in Mount Vernon and the Bronx, died here today at his home on Orienta Point at the age of 59. He had been ill since he underwent an operation in April, 1936.

Subscriptions for a $60,000,000 issue of 1 per cent Series B collateral trust notes, in denominations of $5,000 or multiples thereof, will be received by the Commodity Credit Corporation, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, announced today. The notes, dated Aug. 2, will mature on May 2, 1938.
Leading from flag fall to finish, C. S. Madison's James N. won the Saratoga Purse, six-furlong feature at Suffolk Downs today and paid $7.40 for $2 in the mutuels.
Herbert Wilcox, British film producer, arrived yesterday from London in the French liner Ile de France to show the English motion picture, "Victoria the Great."

The members of Chicken Drivers, Chauffeurs and Helpers Union, Local 167, repeatedly voted to assess themselves sums ranging from $15 to $50 in addition to their regular dues to meet the expenses of litigation, but instead of using the money for this purpose officers of the union converted $32,953 of it to their own use, it was charged yesterday in the Supreme Court.

The Tarpon Springs Club 1, one of the first of Florida's Townsend organizations, is going to return its charter to the Chicago headquarters. The 500 members voted unanimously to take the action because they felt that Dr. F. E. Townsend,

Transfer PATROLMAN-Nathan Chezar, from 40th Precinct to 3d Division, assigned to duty in plain clothes. Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANTS--John F. McNamara, Traffic P, assigned in command, for 47 days, from 8 A. M., July 25, 1937, during absence of captain on vacation and with leave.

Henry Armstrong of Hollywood, Calif., Negro lightweight, knocked out Benny Bass of Philadelphia tonight in 2 minutes 35 seconds of the fourth of their scheduled ten-round bout. Armstrong weighed 130 pounds and Bass 134.

Theodore Bunker, president of the Arcola Country Club here, announced today the six-day caddie strike had been settled and the caddies won all their demands except the request for $1.25 a round for singles.

Postmaster General Farley greeted Wisconsin Democracy tonight, as an antidote to the dejection that has been more or less general in the State party since President Roosevelt took the two La Follette brothers on a yachting trip last week-end, and Senator La Follette, foe of the home folks in the party, appeared as Administration spokesman.

The board of directors of the Tygart Valley Federal Resettlement Project announced early today that 120 of its 152 workers would strike at 8 A. M. Twenty workers will continue at their jobs and two remained neutral.

More than 10,000 workers in the shoe and slipper industries in this city will vote today in an election to be conducted by the National Labor Relations Board to determine their desire in representation for collective bargaining.

The last Chinese defenders between Peiping's eastern walls and Tientsin were so effectively removed this morning by Japanese airplane bombs, artillery and machine guns that there is nothing left except tangled, shattered barracks containing a few grimed Chinese soldiers who are too dazed for the Japanese to deign to notice.

A banking group headed by the Bankers Trust Company and including the National City Bank, Edward B. Smith Co. and Blyth Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,500,000 of debt-equalization bonds of the city of Syracuse, N. Y., in a sale marked by keen bidding on the part of about ten groups.

The Manufacturers Trust Company is transfer agent for 297,144 shares of $5 par common stock of Outboard, Marine and Manufacturing Company. Joseph G. MacIntyre has become associated with Gearhart Lichtenstein.

Paced by Omaha's stocky Johnny Goodman and little-known Ed Kingsley of Magna, Utah, favorites almost without exception survived the qualifying rounds yesterday as the starting field for the national amateur golf championship was completed on twenty-eight scattered courses.
Steel ingot production was higher last week, but the increase was less than seasonal and the adjusted index eased to 123.2 from 124.6. For the week ended July 25, 1936, it stood at 105.2.

Joseph M. Lyman, managing editor of The Hampshire Gazette and local representative of The Associated Press, died tonight, having failed to recover consciousness after a cerebral hemmorhage suffered Sunday.

The Pan-American Society observed the 154th anniversary of the birth of Simon Bolivar yesterday with ceremonies at the statue of the "Father of Pan-Americanism" in Central Park at Eighty-third Stret. Before the outdoor exercises the society gave a luncheon for the Consul General of the Bolivian Republics at the Hotel Bolivar, 230 Central Park West.

An agreement signed today gives 500,000 engineering workers three shillings a week Increase in pay in two stages, one week's annual holiday with pay and an increase in overtime pay. These men are the backbone of the armament industry in which for many weeks there have been rumblings of unrest, particularly in the aircraft section.

More than 500 persons, the majority women and members of the Tenants League of Greater New York, staged a demonstration yesterday in front of a four-family house at 2,851 West Twenty-fifth Street, Coney Island, to protest the eviction of a family of four from an apartment in that building.

Mr. and Mrs. Arden M. Robbins of New York entertained with a luncheon today at their Summer residence, Wildacre, in honor of Mr. and Mrs. E. Victor Loew. The guests included Mr. and Mrs. William McNair, Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Barret, Mr. and Mrs. F. Hamilton McCormick Goodhart, Dr. James B. Murphy and Miss Zelina Clark.

Amicable settlement of the majority of complaints closed by the National Labor Relations Board here from Oct. 1, 1936, to June 30 was reported yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the board, in an analysis of the records.

Complaints of the treatment of Polish minorities in Germany were made today in the Sejm during a debate on several bills connected with the expiration of the Upper Silesian convention. Upper Silesian Deputies voted against and criticized the bill that grants to Germans certain rights such as the use of their own language in law courts.
Word was received in Yonkers today of the death on Sunday, in Stigliano, Italy, of the Rev. Michael Sarubbi, founder and pastor for thirty-eight years of St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church here.

Operators who were impressed with the development of the European demand for United States hard Winter wheat and took the buying side yesterday on the belief further business was impending were rewarded today by reports that an additional 750,000 bushels had been sold abroad overnight.

That intangible thing known as a "guilty conscience," coupled with an equally indefinable thing known as a "hunch," brought Albert Baker, 27 years old, into the lineup at Police Headquarters yesterday and resulted in his being held for the Philadelphia police. Baker is wanted in that city for questioning in the murder of Morris Spiegel, a race-track man in 1934.

The marriage of Miss Alice Regina Carroll, daughter of Municipal Court Justice and Mrs. Charles J. Carroll of Brooklyn and Highland Mills, N. Y., to Raymond John Pellman, son of Mrs. Bernard Pellman of Cincinnati and the late Mr. Pellman, took place yesterday morning in the Church of St. Antony of Padua, Brooklyn.

President Roosevelt redefined today the rules governing publication of his remarks at press conferences. Basically, he retained the four categories of treatment that have been in effect since he entered the White House.

Three Nashville plants of the Washington Manufacturing Company, which is involved in a National Labor Relations Board hearing, will be disposed of and not reopened, according to George H. Armistead, attorney for the company.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente declared unconstitutional yesterday the provision of the Livingston Act which directs the Municipal Civil Service Commission to give to applicants for jobs in the city welfare service a higher rating for experience in the Emergency Relief Bureau than for experience in other public or private agencies.

Dr. Henry S. Drinker of Merion Road, Merion, Pa., died of a heart attack today at his Summer home here after a brief illness. He was born eighty-seven years ago in Hong Kong, China, and was president of Lehigh University from 1905 to 1920.

The Alleghany Corporation and its controlled Chesapeake Corporation withdrew yesterday applications for the listing of two classes of securities on the New York Stock Exchange which had been made in furtherance of a plan to eliminate the Alleghany Corporation from the railway holding structure established by the late Van ?? brothers.

With the first three horses running neck and neck over the final yards, Ralph B. Strassburger's 3-year-old colt Firozepore today won the ninetyfourth running of the Stewards Cup Handicap in the most exciting finish since Golden Sun and Lord Annadale raced a dead heat in 1914.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York City sold to Thomas A. Halleran, attorney, the two-story dwelling at 26 Wildwood Drive, Great Neck, L. I. This is a ten-room house on a plot 200 by 200 feet. It was held at $40,000 and was sold through the Halleran Agency.

Further declines in Sino-Japanese bonds as a result of the disturbances in the Far East featured an otherwise irregular market today. Gilt-edge stocks meanwhile advanced, while European bonds were inactive except for the German issues, which declined.

James F. McBride of 310 Mortimer Avenue died this morning in the Hackensack Hospital, after an illness of two months, in his sixtyeighth year. He was vice president and secretary of Edward Smith Co., paint and varnish manufacturers of Long Island City, New York.
Buddy Myer's ninth-inning single brought Washington a 6-to-5 victory over the White Sox today with a fifth consecutive triumph.

Only one player from the United States won a first-round match in the Canadian amateur golf championship today, but the real threat will come tomorrow when Fred Haas Jr. of New Orleans opens the defense of his title won last year at Winnipeg.

A warm sun today dispelled the mists that followed Monday's thunder storms and permitted a continuance of operettas "over the water and under the stars" here. A crowd of more than 11.000 persons filled every seat in the Jones Beach Stadium at Zach's Bay for the opening of Franz Lehar's operetta "Frederika." that had been scheduled to start a week's engagement Monday night.

The intervention of President Roosevelt in the strike of more than 12,000 shipyard workers in the port of New York, now more than six weeks old, was requested yesterday in a telegram sent to the White House by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C. I. O. affiliate.

The Chinese central government at Nanking was reported today to be massing troops for movement to the north. The Pukow railroad station, across the Yangtze River from Nanking, was the concentration point for the troops moving to the north. Their numbers and destination were concealed as a military secret.

Fortune Gallo, director of the San Carlo Opera Company, with the cooperation of Robert Moses, Commissioner of New York parks, launched the second season of Shubert production of operettas last night at the Randalls Island Stadium with a performance of Sigmund Romberg's "The Student Prince," a popular musical play of the yesteryear.

Prince and Princess Chichibu of Japan, who represented Emperor Hirohito at the Coronation of King George VI in England and are now touring Europe, visited the League of Nations Palace and the International Labor Office here today. At the League palace they were, welcomed by Deputy Secretary General Sean Lester and at the I. L. O. by Acting Director G. E. di Palma Castiglione.
Confronted with a situation frankly recognized as the most serious in China for many years, the United States, Great Britain and France have made urgent direct appeals to China and Japan for peace.

Action on the report of the New York Stock Exchange special committee on commissions is scheduled to be taken today by the law committee. In response to a request by the latter committee's chairman, E. H. H. Simmons, members turned in 250 letters of comment on the proposals to increase commissions. It is understood that these ranged from outright condemnation to sug?? for minor changes.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 24: Stapler, Capt- J. T. G., the Tennessee, to Asiatic Station. Acuff, Lt. Comdr. J. T., the Texas, to command the Herbert. Curtin, Lt. N. R., Washington, D. C., to the Somers and on board as Gunnery officer When commissioned.

With Young Bill Reese of Atlanta, Ga., turning in an unexpected victory over Marcel Rainville, veteran Canadian Davis Cup star, four players from the United States joined as many from Canada in the quarterfinal round of the Canadian lawn tennis championship today.

The three Soviet fliers who recently broke the world's non-stop distance record with a trans-Polar flight of 6,262 miles between Moscow and San Jacinto, Calif., will arrive at Newark airport this morning at 10:20 o'clock (daylight saving time), and, taking off almost immediately, will continue to North Beach airport, Queens, where they are scheduled to land at 11:50 o'clock.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., in a preliminary report for the second quarter, ended July 3, estimates consolidated earnings, after all charges, including interest, Federal taxes, depreciation and reserves but before undistributed profits taxes, as $1,307,000.

BAUMANN--Cecelia, wife of the late William Baumann, daughter of the late Lippman Samuels and Fanny Cohn, and sister of the late Moses Samuels, Samuel, Harry and Flora Cohn. Services at her late residence. 72 East 90th St., Thursday, 11 A. M. Interment Salem Fields Cemetery.

Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a six-story apartment house to accommodate sixty families in East Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, at a cost of $200,000. Other projects in the borough call for seven stores in Coney Island Avenue costing $15,000 and a home in Falmouth Street to cost $12,000.
An extra police guard was stationed today at the home of Mayor S. Davis Wilson as a result, the Mayor said, of threats made against him by persons whose identity he did not disclose.

The opening this afternoon of the auction at Mrs. Margaret Emerson's estate, Holmwood, attracted more than 3,500 persons, of whom not more than 500 were able to crowd into the living room of the fortyseven-room house where the selling took place, with Brill Brill, Inc.,

Miss Joan Day Pattinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. Graham Pattinson of Bayberry Brow, this place, was married here this afternoon in Christ Church to Oscar T. Lawler, son of Mr. arid Mrs. Oscar Lawler Df Beverly Hills, Calif., by the Rev. Dr. H. Edgar Hammond.

The number of visiting buyers registered in the wholesale market during the week ended yesterday fell below that for the preceding week for the corresponding week of last year by a small margin, according to the listings published in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week numbered 1,066, as against 1,272 in the previous week and 1,089 in the similar period last year. Buyers reporting in town yesterday were 494 as against 652 last Tuesday.

Copper consumption outside of the United States in April, May and June averaged 137,090 metric tons monthly, compared with a monthly average of 105,270 in the corresponding period last year, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics.

The five-story tenement house at 408 East Eighty-eighth Street was sold by the estate of Jeanette Wilhelm to a client of Alexander Newman, broker. It is 25 by 100 feet and was sold subject to a mortgage of $10,000 held by a savings bank. George Sauer Sons, Inc., were the brokers.
Fumitaka Konoe, a student at Princeton University, son of the new Premier, Prince Fumimaro Konoe, made his debut as a reporter today by writing this comment on his father's maiden speech to the Diet:

Nathan Mann, New Haven heavyweight, easily gained the decision over Abe Feldman of the East Side in the feature ten-round bout at the Queensboro Arena last night. A crowd of 5,000 saw Mann win decisively. The New Haven boxer weighed 186 and Feldman 1791/2..

The Labor Department estimated today that 4,500,000 man-days of work were lost last month because of strikes. A preliminary survey showed that 575 strikes started during June, that 300 were in progress June 1 and that 530 ended during the month.

New orders of fabricated structural steel booked during June showed a sharp increase over the preceding month and the same month last year. Contracts closed last month were estimated at 169,792 tons, compared with 121,481 tons in May, and with 132,387 tons in June, 1936,

TIENTSIN -- Severe hostilities around Peiping were reported, with the Japanese capturing Nanyuan, south of the city and pushing back a Chinese force. The Chinese reported recapturing that objective in a counterattack. Page 1.

The Minimum Wage Board for the Laundry Industry, appointed several weeks ago by State Labor Commissioner John J. Toohey Jr., recommended today that three zones be created and that minimum rates range from 33 down to 26 cents an hour, with a forty-hour week.

In dismissing charges against forty-two men who had been arrested while picketing the restaurant at the Central Park Zoo, Magistrate Anna Kross held yesterday that the pickets did not violate the local ordinance which forbids the exhibition of "any sign or placard" in a public park without a permit.
Herbie Katz, 168, of Brownsville, gained an eight-round decision over Cuban Luis, 171 1/2, of Cuba, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Canarsie Arena in Brooklyn last night.

Mayor La Guardia signed the new building code yesterday, following its recent adoption by the Board of Aldermen. Frankly looking at the code as an experimental piece of legislation, the Mayor plans to proceed until its flaws appear.
Dr. Edward Francis, who contracted relapsing fever while studying the disease in public health laboratories in Washington, is making even his cure an opportunity for more study.

The output of gold, silver, copper, lead and zinc from Colorado ores and gravels in 1936, in terms of recovered and estimated recoverable metals was 366,607 ounces of gold, 5,902,776 ounces of silver, 17,730,000 pounds of copper, 14,534,000 pounds of lead, and 2,344,000 pounds of zinc, according to Charles W. Henderson and A. J. Martin of the United States Bureau of Mines.
Tony Galento, the idol of Newark's fight followers, scored the most important victory of his ring career by stopping the rugged Al Ettore of Philadelphia at the Velodrome tonight.

President Roosevelt conferred with Congressional leaders on the preadjournment legislative program with Sidney Hillman on wages and hours legislation and with Edward O'Neal and Harold Smith, farm leaders, on the farm bill.

Cables, telegrams and letters protesting against the proposed partitioning of Palestine are pouring in to the League of Nations from all parts of the world. Hundreds of protests, many of which are from Jewish or Arab organizations in the United States, have been received so far.

The Westchester County Democratic Committee will meet at the Grace Church parish house here tomorrow night to designate fifteen candidates for the Fall primary. William Cronin, committee chairman, said all candidates have been agreed upon by party leaders and

Japanese warships began shelling the North China port of Taku today, the navy office announced, after the Chinese garrison fired at a destroyer. Army forces joined with an unnamed number of warships in the offensive at the port.

Business sentiment was considerably improved this month as the result of the check in labor disturbances, according to the report issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. Business activity continued the downward trend which was in evidence since December of last year, the report points out.

Mrs. Florence B. Walter, who died July 12, 1935, at the Hotel St. Regis, left a net estate of $5,157,847, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The principal beneficiaries are William I. Walter, the husband, and Miss Phyllis W. Goodhart, a granddaughter.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 10,000, including 2,000 direct. The market was mostly 10 cents lower than Tuesday's average and spots were off more late in the day. Packing sows steady to 10 cents lower: bulk good and choice, 180-225 Bounds. $12.60-S12.90: ton [Pound]13.
Eight persons, including George F. (Jack) Hill, former Dartmouth star and honor graduate, were killed and two persons were seriously injured in three automobile accidents in New England today.

Zelig Tygel, executive director of the Federation of Polish Jews of America, sailed for Europe yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. He is going to Antwerp to help make arrangements for the- second world conference of the World Federation of Polish Jews Abroad, to be held in that city Aug. 22 to 24.

Formation of a "Rum Institute," modeled on the lines of the Distilled Spirits Institute, is planned for early Fall by a score or more of producers of both domestic and imported rums, Joseph Kraus of American Spirits, Inc., announced yesterday. Invitations are to be sent to

Rumors that the price of gasoline is about to be increased have led to hoarding on such a scale that there is great shortage of the product throughout Italy. All Standard Oil and Shell pumps have been closed for the last two days and will remain shut until Aug. 1, when a new supply will be available.

The price of rye was up 20 marks a ton today as a result of the scarcity that preceded the Government's action yesterday in requisitioning the entire German rye and wheat crops. Grain prices in Germany have long been held substantially higher than those of the world market.

All boats in the Chicago-toMackinac yacht race were accounted for today with the arrival of the sloop Victory, which had been unheard from for seventy-two hours. The 40-year-old sailboat, one of the few craft to finish the race over Lake Michigan through gale and fog, apparently was undamaged by the trip.

General Ballington Booth observed his eightieth birthday by resting at his home here today, conserving his strength for the work of expanding the Volunteers of America, of which he is Commander in Chief and founder.

The entire Orthodox Church-not only that of Serbia-is mourning the death of Patriarch Varnava. The Bulgarian Archbishop Paul arrived today in Belgrade at the head of a deputation from the Bulgarian Church.

PROBABLY it wouldn't be exactly what the doctor ordered, but if those Detroit Tigers could gather themselves for a good long winning streak it would be good for what ails Gordon Stanley Cochrane. Ten straight for the Tigers would be better than three weeks at the seashore for Black Mike.

James J. Mattern, Texas aviator, who is planning a non-stop flight from California to Moscow over the North Pole, appealed to Secretary Roper this morning to rescind the Commerce Department's order refusing permission to make the flight.

The formation of a committee for holders of Cleveland Terminals Building Company 6 per cent firstmortgage leasehold bonds due in 1941 was announced yesterday. The members are Frank R. Bailey of Williams, Bailey -Benjamin, chairman; Charles E. Stoltz and Ralph W. Vogell.
A homesteaders' strike stopped construction work today at the Tygart Valley Federal Resettlement community as the strikers protested what their leaders called inefficient management.

The Public Buildings Department in Washington advertised today for bids to make Le Roy's new postoffice pleasing to its citizens. When completed several months ago, the postoffice, which was lower than surrounding buildings, was called "squatty" by residents, who asked that it be fixed.

Seventh annual luncheon of the Jackson Heights Merchants Association, Schrafft's, 37-24 Eighty-second Street, Jackson Heights, 1 P. M. Speakers: Mayor La Guardia, William Graham, Edward F. Hosinger, John S. Adikes, Edward A. MacDougall, Frank O'Hara.

The recent Insurgent offensive in the Albarracin sector gained control of 1,000 square kilometers [386 square miles] of territory, eleven small towns including Royuela and an important government supply station in this mountainous area.

Roanke Island has been restored by the WPA, and on Aug. 18 President Roosevelt will take part in commemorating Virginia Dare's 350th birthday. The story of Roanoke and the little child has been effectively told by JamesTruslow Adams in the Dictionary of American Biography in an article which is not too long to be reprinted here verbatim and in extenso:

Settlement of the inheritance tax case of the Richard B. Mellon estate, announced today by Governor Earle before sailing from New York for Europe, will mean that several thousand employes in State institutions will receive pay increases.

A total of $4,141 was obtained today at the second day's auction of furnishings in the Summer home of Mrs. Margaret Emerson at Holmwood, making a two-day aggregate of $9,121. Selling was on the lawn south of the house and the crowd was estimated at more than 3,000, composed largely of dealers and collectors.
The Red Sox were forced to come from behind twice today to down Jim Bottomley's fighting Browns, 5-4, in the last of the ninth inning.

Edward Paynter, 34-yearold Lancashire professional, topped off his eleven-year cricket career today with a smashing 322-run score against Sussex in a county championship match. Heavy scoring featured most contests started today, and another triple century was registered by R. H. Moore, captain of Hampshire, who made 316 against Warwickshire. Moore's previous high was 159, hit against Essex in 1933.

Among the apartment leases reported yesterday by brokers ivas one for the twelve-room and fourbath suite in the cooperative building at 1,030 Fifth Avenue, by Ralph Gascoigne Brown. Albert B. Ashforth Co., Inc., and the Madison Realty.. Company were co-brokers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: William J. Wilgus Jr., in the remoteness of Vermont, cannot judge the motives which promoted the "average solid Americans" of Johnstown to call upon their usual civic leaders, the business and professional men of this city, to take measures against "a mob running berserk." I sincerely hope Mr. Wilgus

Estate, $60,000. To Jeanne Manden, sister. 175 Riverside Dr., residue. Samuel J. Siegel, 1,160 Park Ave., executor. McDONOUGH, ANNIE EJ (Feb. 8, 1936). Estate, less than $1,000. To Mary McDonough, daughter, executrix, 455 W. 18th St. residue; three minor bequests.

The report of the North American Utility Securities Corporation for the first half of this year, published yesterday, shows a net income, exclusive of credits or charges arising from sales of securities and realization of foreign loans, of $133,233, compared with a net of $132,859 in the first six months of last year.

The old home of the Madison Avenue Methodist Church at Madison Avenue and Sixtieth Street was bid in at auction yesterday by the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Corporation for $600,000. The sale was held to satisfy a judgment of $1,360,976 and taxes and other liens of $11,661, the Christ Church Methodist Episcopal of New York City, as the congregation now is known, appearing as a defendant.

Miss Mary Ellen Plantiff, daughter of Mrs. Gaston Plantiff of 37 East Sixty-fourth Street, was married to Homer L. Loomis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Homer L. Loomis of 470 Park Avenue, on Monday, in Elkton, Md., her mother announced yesterday.

Except for a mild rally in United States Government long-term bonds, trading yesterday in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange was little changed from the preceding day. Values throughout the domestic corporate list were generally lower on the average.
The Pirates pounced on Claude Passeau and four other Philadelphia pitchers today to take the second of their three-game series, 6 to 4. Big Jim Weaver started for the
Clifford A. Owens, president of seven industrial concerns producing excavating machinery and tractors, died here late today of uremic poisoning. He was 54.

Three buildings have been stolen here. Waymouth Finn, a real estate broker, discovered the "theft" when he took a prospective customer to the Walnut Hills section to inspect the structures, which he valued at $12,000.

J. Spencer Weed, president of the National Horse Show Association, sailed yesterday on the United States liner Washington to attend the Dublin Horse Show. While overseas Mr. Weed will confer with representatives of several foreign military jumping teams expected to come here for the national exhibition in Madison Square Garden Nov. 3-10.

The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today under date of July 26: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS McCrary. A. B., Naval Gun Factory, Navy Yard, Washington, D C.. to Navy Yard, Washington, D. C. Richison, F. A., Navy Yard. Mare Island, Calif., to Naval Hospital, San Diego, about Dec. 16.

The county auditor of Milwaukee, County, Wis., announced yesterday that action would be taken on Aug. 3 concerning the issuance of $2,000,000 of relief bonds. The County Board, it was explained, is still debating whether to issue one-year bonds, optional in six months, or to market the issue as nine-year serial bonds.

One of the most active movements in outdoor circles during the past few months has been the agitation for a breakwater to be constructed in Sandy Hook Bay at Atlantic Highlands, N. J., which, if approved, would convert this delightful fishing and boating center into a mecca for sportsmen of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.
The Government announced today that the Rev. Martin Niemoeller, one of the most noted Protestant leaders, had been indicted on four charges and would be tried before the Emergency Court.

Senator Nyo told the Senate today he had been reliably informed that Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, was insisting that the Apex Hosiery Mills of Philadelphia bargain with representatives of the Committee for Industrial Organization after the employes had overwhelmingly voted against that labor body.

Faced with the serious problem of rerouting northbound traffic from the present terminus of the Eastern State Parkway at Gayhead, south of this city, to a point on the New York-Albany Post Road north of here, State officials are working on a plan to build a new by-pass.
About 100 delegates to the State convention of the Allied Printing Trades Council walked out of the Hotel Ten Eyck tonight in sympathy with union employes who struck yesterday for higher wages.

John White Howell, who was associated with the late Thomas Alva Edison in the development of the incandescent lamp, died yesterday of pneumonia in the Harkness Pavilion of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Mr. Howell, who was 79 years old, lived in Newark.

An important increase in Chile's exports of nitrate of soda in the year ended on June 30, as compared with the preceding twelve months, was disclosed today in figures brought to the attention of the Ministry of Finance. The statement covers shipments to different ports.

Isidor Kerr, a member of the bankrupt firm of Kerr Steinberg, furriers,. of 512 Seventh Avenue, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on the charge that he committed perjury on July 7 and 14 during his testimony before Referee Peter B. Olney.

The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, which under the chairmanship of Senator Wheeler is investigating railway holding companies, has sent to brokers a questionnaire to disclose the names of stockholders of the Alleghany Corporation on July 15, when they bought the stock and what they paid for it.
Governor Frank F. Merriam said today that he would hold the extradition hearing for John Montague, Hollywood's golfing genius, here on Monday.
Congressional leaders abandoned today all attempts to pass legislation at this session to stabilize general farm prices.

Leading stocks weakened in final hour andclosed lower with losses of 1 to 3 points; turnover, 865,610 shares. United States government bonds higher in quiet trading; other issues irregular; transactions, $6,415,600.

After several weeks of resting near Pachuaca, Leon Trotsky, exiled Russian leader, returned yesterday to Coyoacan, Mexico City, where he has been staying at the residence of Diego Rivera since his arrival in Mexico.

Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood handed down a decision yesterday in the long-pending Bergen Beach condemnation proceedings under which Corporation Counsel Paul Windels asserted a total of $3,200,000 was saved to the city.

After four hours of heated argument before Major William J. Mack, designated as arbitrator by Mayor La Guardia, a temporary agreement was reached yesterday in the Sunday closing dispute between the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association, Inc., and the Metropolitan
The flaming spirit of Blondie Ryan finally ignited the whole Giant team today, and the result was quite a conflagration. It seared the Cardinals for
The Pan American Clipper III landed in Botwood Harbor this afternoon, completing the first leg of an experimental flight between Port Washington, L. I., and Foynes, Ireland.

Argentina has proposed to all governments with which it maintains diplomatic relationship that they enter into a multilateral treaty which would recognize the right of political asylum as a principle of international law.

Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the thirtieth annual flower show which opened this afternoon in the auditorium of the parochial school under the joint auspices of the Garden Club of Southampton and the Southampton Horticultural Society.

More than 5,000,000 gridiron fans, about 75,000 of whom will be here as witnesses, have picked the array of 1936 college aces they expect to conquer the National League champion Green Bay Packers in the fourth annual all-star game at Soldier Field Sept. 1.

The question of whether the immunity of a diplomatic agent extends to his personal servants has arisen between the German Ambassador and the Turkish Government. The Ambassador's German chauffeur was recently driving the Charge d'Affaires here when the car knocked down and killed a woman. The Turkish courts have
An increase of $1,469,153 was shown today in the Canadian Pacific Railway Company's net earnings of $8,260,153 for the six months ended on June 30,
James V, Rank's 4- Year -- Old Epigram, heavily backed at 5 to 1, today won the 111 the running of the Goodwood Stakes, handicap race over two miles and three furlongs.

The Army's new sub-stratosphere plane arrived at Wright Field, air corps experimental depot, late today and established what officers said war a new record for flying time between Burbank, Calif., and Dayton-9 hours and 20 minutes.

Completing his first month in office, Holton V. Noyes, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, declared today in a prepared statement that the farmers should receive a minimum of $2 a hundred pounds the year round for their milk.

Magistrate Henry H. Curran, director of the National Economy League, said yesterday before sailing with Mrs. Curran for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary that he believed Mayor La Guardia would win Republican support in the Mayoralty campaign this Autumn. "I am quite sure,"

A garden apartment property in the Marble Hill section of Manhattan changed.hands yesterday when the Norman-Lila Estates, Inc., operators, bought from the builders the five-story building at 26 Fort Charles Place, near Marble Hill Avenue. It contains nineteen suites and occupies a plot 50 by 70 feet.

Funeral services for James J. Dooling, leader of Tammany Hall, will be conducted this morning at a 10 o'clock requiem mass at the Church of the Holy Cross in West Forty-second Street, which Mr. Dooling attended since he was a boy.

Miss Judith Russell today sailed Katydid to victory over George Haines's Mariette in the H-23-foot Class of the Wednesday Fishers Island Yacht Club regatta. The victory, Katydid's first of the season, marked Miss Russell's first start. Gordon Murphy's Chance was a close third.
Thomas E. Elder, former dean of the Mount Hermon School for Boys, was declared by the jury tonight not guilty of a murderous assault upon Stephen Allen Norton, former cashier of the school.

The official Chinese Central News Agency reported today that Japanese troops had forced their way inside Peiping's ancient walls and were fighting a heavy battle with the Chinese garrison within the city.
The Dodgers dropped from a tie for sixth with the Reds into seventh place as they went down to a second straight defeat against the pace-setting Cubs, 7-5, today.

The New York City Omnibus Corporation, operator of the largest bus network in Manhattan, signed a preferential shop agreement yesterday with the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate. The contract, running to Jan. 1, 1939, provides also for wage rises, ranging from 10 to 18 per cent, for the company's 1,800 employes engaged in operation and maintenance of its fleet of buses.

The acts of incendiarism and sabotage that marred the visit of King George and Queen Elizabeth to Belfast were described today by The Times as "childish and spiteful demonstrations obviously designed as much to embarrass the King as to advertise the hostility of the Irish Republican Army to the loyalists of the north."

Being the Mayor of New York Is only a little more trying on the patience than being a cab driver, Mayor La Guardia told ninety-five taxi drivers who came to the Summer City Hall yesterday to receive commendation bars and cash awards for aiding the police during the last year.

The Aquarium has a new 50,000gallon fresh water reservoir with complete pumping equipment, constructed as a WPA project, but it cannot be used because the supply pipe between the reservoir and the fish tanks has so many bends in it the pumps are not equal to drawing water through it.

Arthur (Tootsie) Herbert, business agent for the Chicken Drivers Union, ordered the closing out of two of the union's bank accounts and the virtual depletion of the third, and had the resulting $39,805 in cash placed in a safe deposit vault to which he and another union official alone had access, according to testimony in the Supreme Court yesterday.

The grand total of all benefits paid to war veterans from the Revolution through the World War, including peace-time pensions to retired and disabled soldiers, amounted to $21,993,632,266.78 as of May 31, 1937, it was revealed today by the Veterans Administration.

The annual report of the Madison Square Garden Corporation and wholly owned subsidiaries, announced today by John Reed Kilpatrick, president, shows a net income for the year ended on May 31 of $348,274 after all charges and provision for Federal normal income and excess profits taxes and surtax on undistributed earnings.

On Friday, Aug. 6, at 5 P. M., Mrs. Florence Dibble of Newburyport, Mass., will attempt to establish a world record of one hour in a twenty-mile race against time with her road coach, the Valiant, drawn by four fast trotters.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that the city would not accept work now being done on three city ferryboats at the Staten Island plant of the United Shipyards Company until the work had been passed by city inspectors.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Sargent Jr. of Cedarhurst gave a dinner tonight at the Atlantic Beach Club during the dance in the patio. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Ames Bramwell, Miss Nora McBurney, Sterling Adams, Oakley Brooks and Pendleton Lewis.

2d Lt. Marcus A. Mullen, F.A.-Res., 7 Calton Rd., New Rochelle, N. Y., is relived from assignment to the Field Artillery Group and is assigned to the 2d Battalion, 25th Field Artillery (RA). 1st Lt. Erwin H. Hassemer, Fin.-Res., 166 W. 96th St., New York, N. Y.,

Everything is in readiness for the annual village fair, to be held on the Newtown Lane playground Friday afternoon. Proceeds will be devoted to care of East Hampton's fine old elms and village greens. Mrs. William R. Maloney is general chairman for the fair.

Replying to repeated protests against his rulings by Louis S. Colombo Sr., counsel for the Ford Motor Company, John T. Lindsay, presiding at the National Labor Relations Board hearing on charges that the Wagner Act was violated by the Ford company, announced today that it was necessary to allow hearsay testimony in the record in order to get at the facts.

King George VI and Queen Elizabeth, making their first visit to Ulster since their coronation, received today a hearty and tumultuous welcome, which was marred by the explosion of a bomb in a street a short distance from where the sovereigns were standing.
Admiral Sir Francis Hyde, first officer of the Royal Australian Navy to become an admiral, died today of bronchial pneumonia. He was 60 years old.

Vesey St, 53, 25x82; Fannie Aronowltz to Agency Realty and Mortgage Co, 43 Cedar St, care E. J. West, mtgs $60,000 ($1). Greenwich St, 503-505, 44-75; Slowmach Realty Corp. to Melvin English, 34 Rathburn Ave. White Plains ($1). 101st St. 208 E, 27.6x100.8; Fanny Kite to Elizabeth Weinberg, 287 Leslie St. Newark, N. J.; mtg $12,500 (deed dated Feb 21, 1936).

The applications of C. Walter Randall and James Van Siclen, reorganization trustees of the Bush Terminal Company, for final allowances amounting to $125,000 were denied in a memorandum handed down yesterday by Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn.
Charles H. Cleaves, Rockport civic leader and trustee of many private and public institutions, died today of heart disease at his home. His age was 60 years.
A three-straight victory in the $800 Grand Circuit 3year-old trot today made De Sota, owned by Sports Promoter Paul Bowser, an outstanding favorite to take the Hambletonian Stake at Goshen Aug. 11.
A demand that the Rochester Telephone Corporation reduce its rates to subscribers, rather than increase the charger, was filed with the Public Service Commission today by two civic organizations.

Miss Blanche Potter has sold her estate at State Street and Durston Avenue, Ossining, Westchester County, to Edgar Thomas of Croton-on-Hudson. There are three acres of land, and the buildings consist of a large residence, a greenhouse, stables and garage. I. C. Hotaling was the broker.

The rising cost of newsprint is causing concern to companies bound by longterm contracts to certain groups of newspapers here. Today, a meeting was held of members of the Newspaper Society (representing more than 1,000 provincial newspapers) who hold contracts with the Bowater-Lloyd Company for newsprint in 1938.

The Joint Congressional Tax Avoidance Committee today shelved any further consideration of the controversy growing out of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's $30,000 donation to charity from radio broadcasts in 1934, upon which no tax was paid.

Tiger Jack Fox, Spokane lightheavyweight, proved too hard a hitter for Leo (Red) Bruce in their scheduled ten-round feature bout before 4,000 at Dyckman Oval last night. Bruce lasted only 2:41 of the first round, Referee Jim Crowley stopping the fight. Bruce had been floored three times, once from a left to the body and twice by rights to the jaw. Fox weighed 176 3/4,

A decline was registered In electric power production last week when both seasonal and long-term factors called for an increase, and the adjusted index has receded to 106.5 from 109.0. For the week ended July 25. 1936, it stood at 104.0.
Mrs. Emory Thompson Miller of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret H. Fonville, to Dr. John Boyd Coates, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Boyd Coates of Glenside, Pa.
Complications arose in both Senate and House today on the Black-Connery Wages and Hours Bill. Senate action on the measure became tangled in a raging argument on the National Labor Relations Act.
The MacGregor Expedition was at Lat. 57 degrees N., Long. 60 deagrees W. today. The temperature was 42 degrees. The Greely's location was northeast of Labrador.

Sadao Miyazaki, a seaman of the Japanese naval landing party here, whose disappearance and alleged kidnapping on Saturday night provoked a Japanese military demonstration and acute tension in Shanghai, turned up yesterday in Nanking a self-confessed deserter.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation has done a considerably improved business in both its natural gas and electric services during the second quarter of this year, Philip Gossler, chairman of the board, said yesterday as he sailed on the Queen Mary for a month's sojourn in Scotland and England.
Joseph Lee of Beacon Hill, a national authority on recreation, died today of pneumonia after a brief illness at his Summer home in Cohasset in his seventy-fifth year.

United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew and J. L. Dodds, counselor of the British Embassy, saw Foreign Minister Koki Hirota yesterday separately and on instructions from their respective governments expressed concern over the latest developments, which in the British Government's view carry grave risks of a general war.

Ralph Jonas, New York financier, today told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he and his associates refused an offer of $90,000,000 for about a million shares of Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation stock in August, 1929, after Mr. Jonas objected to some of the company's expansion policies.

BAYER, SAMUEL (July 18, 1936). Gross assets, $27,957; net, $16,461. To Isidore, Alexander and Mortimer Bayer, sons; Annie Bayer and Bertha Liberman, daughters, one-sixth residue each; Marwin I. Bayer, Jean, Ruth and Abba Bayer, grandchildren, equal shares in one-sixth residue. Chief assets, mortgages, notes,
Dr. James E. West, chief Scout executive of the Boy Scouts of America, announced seven changes last night in the executive staff, to increase efficiency of the service to 1,081,438 boys and leaders.

Transfer of the regular membership of Maurice W. Uhlmann to Richard W. McGuire, in care of Reich Co., and that of M. Charles Hoffman to Mark J. Stuart of Marqusee, Stuart Co. has been approved by the New York Curb Exchange.

A "wedding" between two types of music, the classics and jazz, is creating a new and expanding native art which is rapidly becoming the most popular form of music for millions of Americans, M. H. Berlin, president of the Chicago Musical Instrument Company, declared yesterday at the thirty-sixth annual convention of the National Association of Music Merchants at the Hotel New Yorker.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are July 27 unless specified: At Vladivostok, July 28: Alden, Barker, Paul Jones, Whipple. At Cristobal: Babbitt, Charleston, Taylor. At Vancouver. B. C.: Cincinnati, Humnhrevs. Kine Lawrence. Sands.

Coveted honors were conferred today on 9 of the 1,800 students of the Citizens Military Training Camp here by Colonel Royden E. Beebe, Eighteenth Infantry commander and director of C. M. T. C. activities.

Barney Ross and Ceferino Garcia signed articles yesterday whereby Ross will defend his welterweight title in one of the array of championship fights Mike Jacobs will stage at the Polo Grounds Sept. 17. As a result, the suspension of Ross by the State Athletic Commission is expected to be lifted, since this action meets the requirements of the commission.

Playing before their largest home crowd of the season, 10,481 fans, the Red Wings swept both ends of a double-header from the league-leading Newark Bears tonight, 5 to 3 and 3 to 1. It was only the third double-header the Bruins lost this year.

Chinese peasants, who had remained inactive and apparently indifferent to Japanese penetration of their countryside, were aroused to fury and action last night, probably by defeated Chinese troops, and passed all the hours of darkness digging at least seventy trench trucktraps across the Tientsin-Peiping highway. For a fifty-mile stretch,

George T. Sandalls of North Tarrytown, N. Y., died on Monday of a heart attack at Llandudno, Wales, while on a tour with his wife and daughter, Marion. A son, George T. Sandalis Jr. of Tarrytown, also survives.

The report of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company for the first half of this year, published yesterday, showed a net income of $919,977 after all expenses and charges, including deduction for interest on revenues in suspense.

After a five-year hunt, Herman W. Seidell, 25 years old, of 42 Waldorf Avenue, was arrested today for the murder of George Butler, Bridgeport taxi driver, slain in his cab on Snakehill, Fairfield, on July 30, 1932.

Ceremonies to mark the last run of the original "Toonerville Trolley" were arranged here today by village officials. The ramshackle vehicle, which was the inspiration for Fontaine Fox's cartoons, will rattle for the last time over its two miles of rails shortly after midnight Saturday.

The two solenodonts (odd-colored mammals with prolonged snout and nine-ineh tail and an appetite for birds and insects) which were a gift from General Rafael L. Trujillo, President of the Dominican Republic, to Mayor La Guardia, arrived yesterday at the zoo in Barrett Park, West New Brighton, S. I., which is operated by the Staten Island Zoological Society.
Herbert S. Downs, manager of the Bank Relations Department of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died late Tuesday night. He was 63 years old, and made his home at 15 Clark Street, Brooklyn.

Ray (Peaches) Davis pitched the Reds today to their second consecutive victory over the Bees, 6 to 1. The Bees' run came in the seventh on one of two walks Davis issued, a double by Gene Mooreone of four straight hits he gotand an error.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Butler Allen of Chestnut Hill of the engagement of their daughter, Miss lone Allen, to John Bancroft 3d of Wilmington, Del., son of Mrs. Hermann Rouff of Munich, Germany, and John Bancroft Jr. of Rockford, Wilmington.

Trustees for the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to abandon 15.16 miles of railroad on its Hartford and Connecticut Western division between Griffins, Conn., and Agawam, Mass.

Miss Virginia Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Nelson Street of 22 East Thirty-sixth Street, has completed plans for her marriage to Ivy L. Lee Jr., son of Mrs. Ivy Lee, also of this city, and the late Mr. Lee, which will take place on Aug. 14 in the Church of the Incarnation.

I HAVE read intensively and extensively for a number of years, and the two first novels than I have liked best are "Paths of Glory," by Hymphrey Cobb, which was published back in the Summer of 1935 by the Viking Press, and "The Anointed," by Clyde Brion Davis, which is published today by Farrar Rinehart.

River and harbor allocations totaling $25,951,230 authorized in the non-military section of the War Department Appropriation Bill for the fiscal year begun July 1, were approved today by Secretary Woodring.

Ten persons were injured and an undetermined number were killed when the Amazon River boat Jose Antunes, loaded with gasoline, exploded while entering the Tapajoz River. Late last night reports were received at Para that the boat, carrying thirty-seven passengers and a crew of sixteen, had blown up and that all on board were killed.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy and Mrs. Levy and Francis A. Madden, assistant district attorney of Kings County, are among the passengers leaving today for Europe on the French liner Ile de France.
THE ANOINTED, by Clyde Brion Davis. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50.) An unusual novel. HIGHLAND RIVER, by Neil H. Gunn. (Lippincott, $2.50.) A story of a scientist's life in novel form.
Hugh S. Rice, associate in astronomy at the American Museum of Natural History, saw the largest sunspots he had ever seen from his Spuyten Duyvil home on Tuesday evening, without benefit of glasses.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe signed yesterday an order confirming his approval of the plan of reorganization of the Manati Sugar Corporation. The plan, originally evolved last October, was modified on June 24, 1937.

Almost overnight the Salzburg Festival went from the sublime to the pedestrian. The author of this dedine was chiefly Hans Knappertsbusch, who yesterday conducted in the Festspielhaus, where he is a newcomer, one of the dullest performances imaginable of "Der Rosenkavalier" and this evening at the Mozarteum a Beethoven concert consisting of the Fourth and Seventh Symphonies.

Passengers arriving and departing here on the Atlantic liners have often complained at the annoyance they are subjected to from autograph hunters, mostly young girls, working in groups of six to nine on board the ships and on the piers.

Miss Margaret Haley of New York City is the winner of the 1937 Yale Series of Younger Poets contest, Stephen Vincent Benet, editor of the series, announced today. A volume of Miss Haley's poems, under the title "The Gardener Mind," will be published by Yale University Press in the Fall. Miss Haley, a graduate of Bryn Mawr, is a painter as well as a writer.

Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec, in a speech at the reopening of the pulp and paper industry here today, said that the Provincial government had received proposals for building new pulp and paper mills to cost $30,000,000 to $35,000,000.

Plans for the last of five city health and teaching centers were filed with the Manhattan Department of Buildings yesterday. The six-story building, to cost $275,000, will be constructed at Twenty-fifth Street and First Avenue and will be conducted in cooperation with the New York University School of Medicine.

Talk of a new American revolution, Tom M. Girdler said today, is "a lot of bunk." The chairman of the Republic Steel Company, a leader of industrial opposition to the Committee for Industrial Organization, told newsmen also that he believed John L. Lewis was "all done."
The Athletics clubbed three Cleveland pitchers, including Bob Feller, for seventeen hits today and defeated the Indians by 11 to 7. The victory was the second straight over the Tribe.

No date has been set for the threatened "strike" of kosher butcher store owners as a protest against the high prices they have to pay wholesalers for meat, Samuel Jacobi, secretary of the Federation of Kosher Butchers, said yesterday.

Charles (Mickey) Norman 3d, "veteran" smoker and tobacco connoisseur, was 1 up on the neighborhood children who helped him celebrate his sixth birthday today at his home here. With the other children, Mickey wholeheartedly attacked the layer cake, watermelon, peanuts and soda water provided for the special occasion.

On today's schedule of new films list the Rialto with "It Can't Last Forever," played by Ralph Bellamy, Betty Furness and Robert Armstrong, and the Palace with "Born Reckless," a melodrama with Rochelle Hudson, Brian Donlevy, Barton MacLane and Robert Kent.
Striking truck drivers tonight unanimously ratified a compromise contract reached with wholesale grocery merchants and ended the most serious phase of Buffalo's eight-day food embargo.

With the sharp increase in demand for men's lightweight clothing this Summer, several new suitings lines introduced in the last few weeks may develop into national advertisers on a fairly large scale. Latest company to bring out a new suitings line is the Celanese Corporation of America, which this week introduced a wide range including both cut acetate staple mixtures and cut acetate filament mixtures.

Another creditor added today to the woes of Baroness Maude B. Von Leidersdorff, heir to a $750,000 fortune, and her husband, Baron John Von Leidersdorff, when he obtained from Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis an order holding them in contempt of court for not paying $700 due for work on their Harrison estate.

Aneroid, at 2 to 5, Sailor Beware, 7 to 10, and Pumpkin, 3 to 5, all went down to defeat today as Saratoga sustained its reputation of being the graveyard of favorites. The track, which saw the defeat of Man o?? War and other champions, once more lived up to its reputation.

A dinner was given last night by Mr. and Mrs. S. Sloan Colt of Tuxedo Park in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Amory S. Carhart, Mr. and Mrs. Allan McLane, Mrs. Graziella Maduro, Miss Luisa Parraga, Willard D. Litt and Bulkeley Wells.

The entire first class of the Military Academy, 300 strong, left here this evening on the army transport St. Mihiel for the annual trip to the Infantry Training School at Fort Benning, Ga. The cadets will arrive in Savannah about 7 P. M. Saturday, when they will immediately take trucks provided by the Sixtysixth Infantry for the remainder of the journey.

Favorable earnings for the three and six months through June continued to be reported yesterday by the independent steel companies. In the corresponding six months of National Steel Corporation earned $11,708,896 after all charges, except provision for Federal surtax on undistributed profits.

The Goldman Band will present a series of Fall and Winter concerts at Kismet Temple, 92 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, beginning in October, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman, conductor. The band,

Postmaster General Farley made a "good-will swing" through South Central Illinois today, dedicated two postoffices and ended his tour at Salem with an address at the Marion County Soldiers and Sailors Reunion.

After hearing arguments in his office yesterday, in which Arthur Garfield Hays, representing about twenty-five small coal dealers, and representatives of the larger coal companies presented divergent views, Mayor La Guardia signed a new city ordinance aimed at stopping the flow of bootleg coal from the Pennsylvania mines into New York City.
The British cruiser Apollo landed marines here today to enforce order after many hours of rioting had taken at least six lives and seen twenty-one persons inured.
A $3,000 bracelet, set with' thirteen marquis diamonds, was a plaything for dogs nearly twenty-four hours before some one found it today.

Almost 3,000 Chinese living in the metropolitan area have voted in the past few days on their choice of three American-Chinese delegates to the constitutional convention to be held in China in November, Lin Pai-ya, editor of The Chinese Nationalist Daily Newspaper, of New York, has received the most votes.

Mrs. Florence Jackson, Queens matron who was strangled to death in Bayside early Tuesday morning with her own dress belt, had asked her attorney twenty-four hours before, it was learned yesterday, to begin divorce proceedings in her behalf.

Winter wheat harvest is now completed practically everywhere, except in some parts of the Northwest. Threshing advanced under favorable weather conditions in most of the Ohio and Mississippi Valley, but there was some delay by rains in Eastern Kansas and Northeastern Oklahoma, with some wheat sprouting in shock; combining was also delayed in West Central Illinois, where there were a few reports of shocks moulding.
The Kremlin trying hard now to reassure onest executives and engineers rho have lost morale as a result of he purge of alleged wreckers from idustrial ranks.

Two men who pleaded guilty to indictments charging them with attempting to dominate the garment district trucking business by violence were sentenced yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook. Their indictments resulted

Paul Y. Anderson, Washington correspondent of The St. Louis PostDispatch, called upon William Green tonight to correct an alleged misquotation in a press statement. Mr. Green's statement, comprising an attack on Heywood Broun, president of the American Newspaper Guild, contained the following sentence:

ON THEIR OWN APPLICATION Patrolmen John Mulrane, 23d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed July 6, 1912. Cornelius Carroll, 28th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 11, 1901. John W. Creamer, 70th Precinct, at $1.500 per annum. Appointed Jan. 17, 1908.

The War Department issued the following orders today, dated July 27: COLONELS Dravo, C. A., Inf., orders relieving him from duty with the 8th Infantry, Fort Moultrie, S. C., about Sept. 1, amended to be effctive about Oct. 1,

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Harding Colton of 27 East Sixty-second Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Bain Colton, to Walter Edward Schwab. son of Mrs. Henry Schwab of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Schwab.

The engagement of Miss Elisabeth Cary McAneny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George McAneny of 120 East Seventy-fifth Street, to James Alexander Hetherington 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Fenton Hetherington of Bound Brook, N. J., has been announced by her parents.

The renewed improvement in Anglo-Italian relations became apparent today following Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's hour-and-a-half talk with Count Dino Grandi, the Italian Envoy, yesterday when the two men reviewed most of the outstanding difficulties now keeping the two countries apart.

The National Labor Relations Board today ordered an election by secret ballot at the Mergenthaler Linotype Company in Brooklyn, which employs about 1,600 workers. The order was issued as the result of a petition filed by Linotype Local No. 1,222, United Electrical and Radio Workers of America.

While fair trade practice rules have been temporarily suspended by the Belt Association, whose manufacturer members cater to the cutting-up trade, they will be revived either by the required addition of the membership to 80 per cent of the trade by Sept. 1 or

Turning on slender Vernon Kennedy with a heavy attack, Washington scored an 11-to-8 triumph over Chicago today. It was the Senators' second straight victory over Chicago and the first time this year the Senators took a series from the White Sox as Washington's
Alexander R. McKim, retired consulting engineer of Marblehead, died at the Mary Alley Hospital, Marblehead, today at the age of 74.

Approximately 10,000 workers emplayed in making boots, shoes, slippers and heels in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens votea yesterday in a National Labor Relations Board election to determine the union that will represent them in collective bargaining.

The Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation announced early today that it had contracted. to buy four Canadian subsidiaries of the United, States Steel Corporation-the Canadian Steel Corporation, Ltd., Ojibway, Ont.; Canadian Bridge Company, Ltd., Walkerville, Ont.; Essex Terminal Railway Company, in the Walkerville-Windsor area of Ontario, and Canadian Steel Lands, Ltd., Ojibway.

A $25,000,000 trust mortgage, one of the largest ever made in Westchester County, was recorded today in the County Register's office here. The Westchester Lighting Company gave the lien to the City Bank Farmers Trust Company of New York as security for a new bond issue.

Lightning causing an internal explosion was responsible for the air disaster to the Netherland KLM Douglas airliner which crashed today twelve miles south of Brussels, killing fifteen passengers and members of the crew, among whom were three Americans.

William Henry Costelloe, a research engineer in the Bell Laboratories in New York, died last night of a heart attack while relating an anecdote to a group of friends at the honre of Dr. Frederick Burnett, New Jersey State Alcoholic Beverage Commissioner, in South Orange.

Principal attention was directed by President Roosevelt and Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, in the SinoJapanese crisis today to the safety of Americans in Peiping, where all preparations, according to Mr. Hull, have been made for their evacuation to the coast. A decision,

Cleveland threatened tonight to put its entire police force on double shifts to quell a wave of assaults and window-smashing near the Republic Steel Corporation's Corrigan-McKinney plant and in other strike areas.

Old Lady Luck dropped right out of the sky and into the pockets of four spectators in a crowd of 12,000 at Arlington Park today. Into the pockets of each of the four went the sum of $3,439, because they were successful in the daily double, picking the winner of the first two races. Many Stings at 15 to 1 took the first race and Young Agnes, 59 to 1, captured the second;
The one-story building at 316-18 Twelfth Street, running through to 317-19 Thirteenth Street, Union City, N. J., has been sold by the Trust Company of New Jersey to the I, M Construction Company.

The current distrust of foreigners, no matter what their nationality, now is resulting in the denial of entry to scores of tourists, including many Americans, who have paid for Russian trips and who have obtained Soviet visas, after their arrival at a Soviet port.

Tuned to concert pitch, Harold S. Vanderbilt's America's Cup defender, Ranger, raced out here today from over at Mattapoisett on Buzzards Bay and defeated the first English Endeavour by 9 minutes and 30 seconds over 37 1/2 miles. It was a truly astounding performance. Their meeting,

A proposal that tax proceedings against William Randolph Hearst be assigned on the circuit calendar for hearings at New York City was made today to the Board of Tax Appeals by Morrison Shafroth, chief counsel of the Bureau of Internal Revenue. Such a step, Mr. Shafroth said, would obviate the calling of many witnesses to Washington.
The third concert of the Brahms series given by the Federal Music Project was heard last night at the Theatre of Music by a small but appreciative audience.

A speeding up of work on the Merritt Highway, cutting time on several major contracts from 300 to 100 days, is planned by Robert A. Hurley, director of the State Public Works Department, as a result of a survey.
The Jersey City Giants pounded Marvin Duke for fifteen hits today, but they couldn't get them when they counted, and the Royals took the game, 6 to 5, for a 3-1 series triumph.

Plans for a survey of the Mortgage Foreclosure Moratorium and Deficiency Judgments Laws were outlined today at a meeting of the legislative committee of which Senator Joseph D. Nunan Jr. of Queens is chairman. The plans contemplate sending to real estate interests and banks in the State a questionnaire to obtain

The outrages that marred Belfast's roaring welcome were not directed against the smiling and imperturbable young King and Queen, the first British sovereigns to set foot on Irish soil since the island was officially divided. The only incident that occurred near the scene of the celebration was the explosion of a bomb a short distance from the route of the procession.

Billy Beauhuld, Jersey City lightweight and former amateur champion, will meet Paul Junior of Lewiston, Me., at Madison Square Garden tonight in a ten-round bout that will feature a card of forty-four rounds of boxing.

Information from Magallanes, southernmost city in the world and capital of Chile's distant territory, discloses that heavy snow storms in the last few weeks have buried roads, causing suspension of all traffic and blocking export shipments of frozen meat, livestock and wool. The snow is reported to be

By an amendment to its rules, the governing committee of th??. New York Stock Exchange prohibited yesterday bids below the price of the best established bid and offers above the price of the best established offer. Other changes in the rule, which establishes priority of bids and offers on the floor of the Stock Exchange, generally have the effect of clarifying former rules and business practices.

Miss Emma W. Dearborn, a writer, was killed by a plunge from a balcony adjoining her twelfthfloor apartment in the Peter Cooper Apartment Hotel, 130 East Thirtyninth Street, late last night. She was 60 years old. The police reported that she "fell or jumped."

George King Raudenbush made his New York debut as conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium last night. It cannot be said that Mr. Raudenbush felt quite secure and at home in his new surroundings.
President Roosevelt and his Congressional leaders agreed tonight upon a five-point legislative program which they hope to push through despite the growing movement for adjournment of Congress.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange declined 12 to 15 points yesterday. Around 11 cents a pound the market seemed to meet sufficient buying power to absorb the volume of hedges now appearing from spot quarters so that fluctuations held within narrower limits.
Spotty improvement in the steel industry has been sufficient to convince the trade that the bottom of the midsummer recession has been reached, according to The Iron Age. There has been no pronounced

A new drug, found effective against meningitis, is equally effective against the dangerous and deadly gas bacillus. Dr. Harold R. Bohlman of the Johns Hopkins Hospital reported in the Journal of the American Medical Association today.

James Ethel Denton, peaceful Asher (Okla.) oil pumper who just nine days ago assumed the heritage of Wild Bill Hickok and other guardians of the peace of the wild West in slaying one escaped convict gunman and wounding another, arrived in New York yesterday "to speak his piece" on a radio program last night.

Ways and means to wipe out the deficit and reorganize the Republican party will be discussed by John M. Hamilton, national chairman; former Governor Landon and other leaders when they meet at Topeka Friday.

Reserved off the pace most of the way, C. Shockley's Sahri II today qualified handsomely for the $50,000 Massachusetts Handicap by coming from behind to win the Hannah Dustin Handicap, mile and one-sixteenth feature for fillies and mares at Suffolk Downs. Sahri II scored by

Current improvement in consumer response to August fur and home furnishings promotions is bringing gains of 7 to 15 per cent over a year ago, although a slow start of these sales in some sections has made for a spotty average showing, it was reported yesterday by retail executives and resident buying officials.

Last year's final was re-enacted in a quarter-final match of the North Jersey tennis championship today when Donald Hawley of Orange, seeded first, defeated Eddie de Gray of Brooklyn, 6-2, 5-7, 7-5, at the Westfield Tennis Club.

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today expressed the British Government's "warm appreciation" of King Leopold's recent letter to Premier Paul van Zeeland of Belgium advocating international tariff reforms, but did not bind the British Government.

Jacob Gottlieb, 25, of 402 Grand Street, Brooklyn, is in Clinton County jail here after waiving examination last night on charges of smuggling into the United States twenty pounds of heroin, with a retail value set at $100,000. He was held in bail of $25,000 for a hearing on Tuesday.
The First National Bank of Jersey City has been appointed cotransfer agent for the common stock of the Southwest Natural Gas Company.

Operations in the grain markets were somewhat curtailed today because of fear of untoward developments in the July deliveries, trading in which was to cease at the close of the day. July wheat fluctuated in an erratic manner, but advanced sharply as the result of a last-minute rush of short covering and closed on the Board of Trade here at an average of 2 7/8 cents a bushel higher. The top level, however,

Police officials seemed angered yesterday by persistent rumors that in their search for the murderer of Irma Louise Pradier they were giving consideration to the possibility that he might be found in the ranks of Troop C of the city's mounted police.

The three-story business building at 395 Bridge Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Anne Levine to a client of the Brown Company. The building, which stands on a lot 20 by 100 feet, will be demolished by the buyer upon the expiration of existing leases, and a new two-story structure erected in its place.

The statement of the Air Reduction Company, Inc., for the three months ended on June 30, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $2,289,498 after all charges and estimated Federal taxes, the largest quarterly earnings in the history of the company. This is equivalent to 90 cents a share on the 2,542,602 shares of capital stock outstanding.

Asserting he spoke upon the "highest authority," Representative Celler of New York said today the Administration had not withdrawn its opposition to the Miller-Tydings Retail Prices Bill, which the Senate attached as a rider to the District of Columbia Tax Bill'last week.

Magistrate Myles A. Paige, remembering yesterday how large numbers of his race once fled to the North for sanctuary, chaminpioned the cause of Mrs. Dottie Morris, who was arraigned before him in Yorkville Court, charged with the abduction of her own son from his father's house in Fayetteville, N. C. Mrs. Morris, with hero

Representative Rankin's attack upon the National Labor Relations Board was characterized here today by Emil Rieve, international president of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers, as a "smoke screen" to cover an alleged conspiracy by persons in Mr. Rankin's own State, Mississippi, to "destroy Northern industry."

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first half of 1937 a net income of $11,331,772 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. This was equal, under the participating provisions of the shares, to $4.25 each on combined 79,974 shares of $50-par 7 per cent preferred and 2,586,341 shares of $50-par common stock.

154th St, 428 E (9-2375); Charles W. Grainger to Lucia Pinnisi, 2,550 W 15th St. Brooklyn. Grote St, 770 (11-3100): 770 Grote St Corp to Shaberg Realty Corp, 349 E 149th St; mtg S52,500. Grand Concourse (12-3311) w s, 118 ft. s Van Cortlandt Ave. 25x81: City of New York to 3,201 Grand Concourse Realty Corp, 3,201 Grand Concourse. Corrp. 3.201 Grand Concourse.
The Navy Department announced today the purchase of four twin-engined S-43 type Sikorsky flying boats from the Sikorsky Division of the United Aircraft Corporation, at Hartford Conn.

Lord Camrose's purchase of The Morning Post is taken to be for the purpose of merging it with The Daily Telegraph, its Conservative rival which he has made so successful. The Morning Post has been hard up for some years; and the Berry family, of which Lord Camrose is the head, if the greatest is also the least objectionable of "newspaper trusts."

The administration of relief must be carried on "honestly and humanely" until there is a better economic adjustment, Mayor La Guardia' declared last night at a testimonial dinner given by the Supervisors Association of the Emergency Relief Bureau for Miss Charlotte EI. Carr, who retires on Aug. 1 as director of the bureau.
