His name was often and affectionately shortened to "Joe Lee," which so pronounced had in it the suggestion of joy in living. He was the incarnation of the philosophy of play in its many definitions. He was known as "the father of the play movement in America." An officer of the Playground

A new union of Chrysler Corporation employes-the Independent Association of Chrysler Employes-was announced today by PLilip di Falco, the organization's secretary. Di Falco declared the union had 26,000 members. "We do not intend to affiliate with any union," he said.

While truck drivers for contract haulers of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company continued their strike today, five trucks belonging to one of the contractors were burned in their garage, with a loss estimated at more than $5.000. Police said the fire apparently was of incendiary origin.

The San Jose polo team arrived from Argentina yesterday aboard the Munson liner Western World and by 2 o'clock in the afternoon was settled down in its Long Island quarters at Westbury, ready for this year's attempt to win the highest honors of the American game.
Mrs. Elizabeth Carey, mother of the Republican leader and former Common Pleas Judge Robert Carey, died yesterday at her home, 630 Bergen Avenue.

Payment of fees and allowances totalling about $482,000 was approved yesterday by Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard in an order which brought to completion reorganization proceedings for the New York Railways Corporation.

Robert T. Murray of Montreal, fighting for recognition as the best Canadian player since Jack Wright deserted the courts, came forward today with a brilliant rally to reach the semi-finals of the Canadian lawn tennis championships.

Henry Ford, granting one of his rare interviews, commented tonight on the eve of his seventy-fourth birthday, on the "present mess," predicted it would do the country "more good than most people expect," and observed that disillusionment was a splendid teacher.
Mrs. Margaret Milne, member of a socially prominent Philadelphia family, died today at Manchester, N. H., where she was visiting. She was the widow of David Milne.

Agreement on a Fusion ticket acceptable to a majority of organization Republicans seemed nearer last night than it has been since Kenneth F. Simpson, New York County chairman, suggested Joseph D. McGoldrick and Alderman Newbold Morris as candidates for Controller and President of the Council.

After four hours of heated argument before Major William J. Mack, designated as arbitrator by Mayor La Guardia, a temporary agreement was reached yesterday in the Sunday closing dispute between the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association, Inc., and the Metropolitan

The latest of the Navy Department's periodical "Summaries of Comparative Naval Data," released yesterday, reveals the staggering scope of the world naval race. At least 353 menof-war of the five principal categories are known to be building in the shipyards of six sea powers.

Several leases in the Madison Avenue section featured the contracts for commercial space reported yesterday. Among those taking leases on that avenue were furniture manufacturers, milliners and a waste paper removal concern. Details of the leases follow:

Buster Keaton, former comedy star, was ordered to pay $100 a month for the support of his sons, Joseph and Robert, in a new order filed in Superior Court here today. In an earlier order Mr. Keaton was instructed to pay his former wife, Natalie Talmadge Keaton, $300 for the support and education of his boys, but he pleaded that his income had been greatly reduced.
The Congressional sugar group agreed today upon a determined fight for a sugar control bill despite opposition by the Administration.
Thomas F. Connors, superintendent of the Yonkers Public Bath and Swimming Pool, and a former deputy sheriff of Westchester County, died here today in St. John's Riverside Hospital.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and adjacent suburban areas increased 17 per cent for the week ended July 24, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The gain is the largest for any weekly period since April 17, the Easter trade peak of this year.

Dr. rving Fisher, Yale University Proessor of Political Economy, pointed oday to Sweden's system of manged currency as 'an antidote for economic depressions and asserted hat unless a similar system were adopted for this country another repression was inevitable.
More than fifteen months in advance of the Gubernatorial election Mayor S. Davis Wilson carried his bid for the Governorship into the anthracite region today.

The Camden, County Chamber of Commerce has appealed to President Roosevelt for "fair consideration" of the problem facing persons employed in private ship-building plants because of "the apparent attitude of the Federal Government."

Because recent decisions under the Robinson-Patman Anti-PriceDiscrimination Act "appear to have nullified the prime purpose for .which the law was written," dry goods wholesalers in the next few months probably will bring some pressure to bear upon manufactur- HITS ers who sell at equal prices either

With a view to having a judging array including the best known experts in this country the Westminster Kennel Club has announced an imposing list of names for its sixty-second annual exhibition at Madison Square Garden next Feb. 10, 11 and 12.

The upward trend in the export of farm implements since 1932 is continuing, the Department of Commerce said today. Shipments in the first four months of 1937 were valued at $20,841,799, an increase of 60 per cent from last year.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor arrived here by train this evening for a week's stay. A large crowd, including many members of the British and American colonies, greeted them.

The French Stabilization Fund, in an apparent effort to give impetus to general business, turned yesterday to operations in the franc futures market and as a result the discount on ninety-day francs narrowed to 13 points, a drop of 1 1/2 points from Tuesday.

An advisory committee to aid all New York municipalities in arranging the collection of an emergency 1 per cent levy on the gross income of public utilities was named today by the State Conference of Mayors.
Mrs. De Witt Untermeyer, home club star, today captured the eighth annual New Jersey shore tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association with a 54-hole score of 241.

The advance of $1 a ton in steel scrap prices at Pittsburgh yesterday and of 50 cents at Chicago is taken as an indication of renewed buying by the steel mills. Prices now are about $3 a ton above the low level reached a little more than a month ago. In spite of the

Courageously springing into a lion's cage armed only with a whip and a short iron bar, Miss Renee Somer, 16-year-old menagerie attendant, saved Harold Davidson, famous ex-rector of Stiffkey, from virtually certain death tonight.
The Yankees touched a season's low yesterday at the Stadium in the matter of hits and suffered the natural consequences before a paid attendance of 13,443 and about 6,000 youthful guests.

A heart attack, induced by the fright he suffered in stepping into water beyond his depth when he knew he could not swim, was held responsible for the death this afternoon of James Rollar, 35 years old, of 639 Hudson Avenue, West New York, N. J. Mr. Rollar, an electrician, was bathing in Lake Lefferts with his wife.

Fred Haas Jr. of New Orleans, the defending champion, swept into the fourth round of the Canadian amateur golf championship today with victories over Russ Case of Vancouver and Guy Rolland of Montreal.

Johnny Kinder, Plainfield Country Club professional, and Charley Whitehead, former State amateur golf champion, today put together rounds of 68 and 67 for a best-ball total of 135 to win the pro-amateur prelude to the New Jersey State open championship which starts here tomorrow at the Shackamaxon Country Club.

Mikhail Gromoff, Andrey Yumasheff and Sergei Danilin, who established a world non-stop flight record from Moscow to San Jacinto, Calif., a distance of 6,262 miles, arrived at North Beach Municipal Airport yesterday and immediately went to see Mayor La Guardia at the Summer City Hall at College Point, Queens.
Bullets from the gun of an unidentified assailant killed Anthony Ruggeri, 46-year-old Greenfield grocer, and sent Patrolman J. Richard Laurie to a hospital critically wounded.

The most attractive semi-final program of matches offered here in recent years will be staged tomorrow on the turf courts of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club. Wilmer Allison of Austin, national champion in 1935; Frank Shields of Hollywood, runner-up for the American and Wimbledon titles; Robert

Kennedy Randall Jr., seeded second, moved ahead of the field into the semi-final round of the Staten Island men's singles championship at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, S. I., yesterday by defeating Ray Lyon, seeded eighth, 6-1, 6-1.

Turpentine firm, 32%c; sales,.155 barrels; receipts, 575 barrels; shipments, 27 barrels; stock, 34,882 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 977; receipts, 3,061; shipments, 125; stock, 73,989. Quote: B, to 1, $7.75; K, $7.771A; M, N, $7.80; WG, $7.823h; WW, X, $8.65.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against FIT WELL FUR CO., INC.. 236 W. 27th St.-By Brickner Bernfeld, Inc., on a claim for upward of $500. MOVIE PUBLICATIONS, INC., 369 Lexington Ave.-By Murray M. Miller, for $3,250; Wholesale Board of Trade of the New York Institute of Wine Spirit Distributors, Inc., $50; Clarence P. Goldberg, $3,539.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against FIT WELL FUR CO., INC.. 236 W. 27th St.-By Brickner Bernfeld, Inc., on a claim for upward of $500. MOVIE PUBLICATIONS, INC., 369 Lexington Ave.-By Murray M. Miller, for $3,250; Wholesale Board of Trade of the New York Institute of Wine Spirit Distributors, Inc., $50; Clarence P. Goldberg, $3,539.

While believing that the theatre of the Sino-Japanese conflict for the time being is confined to the North Hopeh area high Chinese officials said last night that the fullest Nanking military support was being marshaled to back up the Chinese troops in North China.

The commercial division of the Valley Forge Flag Company has appointed Ralph Heymann as district manager in the metropolitan area here. The Irving C. Krewson Corporation, resident buyers, have been named to represent the Louis Fashion Shops in Milford, Framingham, Marlboro and Whitinsville, Mass.

Traffic policemen in New York City must be "reasonable," according to Harold Fowler, First Deputy Police Commissioner in charge of traffic. He explained "our theory" yesterday in the Hotel Astor at the second day of the annual convention of chiefs of police of this State.

The redoubtable Corny Shields sailed Rebel, the new six-meter owned by his brother Paul, to a clean-cut triumph this morning in the only completed race of the final trials to determine the defenders of the Gold Cup and Seawanhaka Cup.

Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has been appointed trustee of Empire Refining Company first mortgage 5 1/2 per cent bonds, due on July 1, 1947. authorized in the amount of $9,630,000. The bank also has been appointed registrar of 67,000 shares of United CigarWhelan Stores Corporation cumulative $5 preferred stock.

Robert H. Whitelaw, former Senator from Missouri, died in a Blytheville hospital last night at the age of 80. Mr. Whitelaw moved here from Cape Girardeau, Mo., five years ago. A native of Virginia, he moved to Cape Girardeau when in his youth.

By drawing his last game with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, with whom he will contest a return match for the world chess championship in October, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, the present titleholder, today emerged as victor in the fourcornered masters' tourney, winding up with a score of 4-2.
Pope Pius sent a special blessing today to the Knights of Columbus of the United States, referring to the organization as "good fighters for the faith and for the church."

The disappearance of Edward Byrne, 23-year-old clerk at the local branch of Wilson Co., meat packing firm, was assumed to be voluntary today when an envelope, believed to have been addressed in his handwriting and enclosing checks valued at $1,700, was delivered to the plant at 693 Henderson Street.

General Frank R. Schwengel, vice president of the Seagram Distillers Corporation, giving defense testimony yesterday at the Federal Trade Commission hearing at 45 Broadway, said that Seagram's distribute "suggested price lists" largely through its wholesalers, because "nobody knew how to determine prices," especially in the earl days after the repeal of prohibition.

Miss Eva M. Tully, for more than twenty-five years a teacher in New York public schools, died Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. A graduate of-the Flushing High School and the Jamaica Normal School, she studied for her prosession also in Italy and at Cornell University.
Oscar J. Friedman, one of Chicago's early automobile manufacturers, died today at his home here. He was 71 years old.

John J. Quinlan, manager of the Prospect House and Cedar Grove Hotel at Lake Bomoseen, Vt., and vice president of the New England Hotel Association, died yesterday in the North Hudson Hospital, Weehawken, N. J. He was 4? years old.

Henry Clews Jr., American sculptor, died at Lausanne, Switzerland, today. Son of Bank Founder Relatives of Mr. Clews said here last night he had been seriously ill with septicaemia for three weeks. His health had been poor for two years.

A dinner dance for fifty young people was given by Mrs. Hugh D. Auchincloss at her home, Hammersmith Farm, tonight. Mrs. Auchincloss has some of her grandchildren visiting her, as well as other guests, and the party was arranged for them.

Fireman Ist grade Michael Policastro,H. L. 142. Charge 1: Failing to pay in. Charge 2: Neglect of duty. (Neglected to Charge 2: Neglect of duty ,Neglected to notify his commanding officer of his inabilty to report for duty at time required). Guilty. Reprimand. Charge 3: Absent without leave. Guilty. Fined two days.

Having $2,334 in the bank, besides a few dollars in his pocket, Boleslaw Czerwinski, 35 years old, who said he lived at 403 East Seventeenth Street, chose yesterday to go to jail for ten day rather than pay a fine of $10 imposed by Magistrate Myles Paige in Yorkville Court.

The publicity committee of the New Jersey Council, which received an appropriation of $150,000 to advertise the commercial and recreational advantages of New Jersey, received a number of suggestions from publicity experts today, among them a proposal from Governor Hoffman for a State song.
Recommendations of the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange that the following securities be listed were adopted yesterday by the governing committee: $25,000,000 Koppers

The last dance programs of the Lewisohn Stadium season will be given tonight and tomorrow night by the Philadelphia Ballet Company, who will present the first local performance of "The Sleeping Beauty," a three-act ballet.

Savings banks figured prominently as the sellers of housing properties in Manhattan reported yesterday. A deal in the Madison Square section involving an extensive alternation project was announced by Meller Shalita, Inc., brokers, who sold the five dwellings at 107, 109, 111, 113 and 115 East Twenty-sixth Street for the Boradway Savings Bank to the East Twenty-sixth Street Realty Company.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Godridge of New Rochelle, N. Y., gave a supper party tonight in the Crawford Notch Canteen at which guests were Mrs. Hubbell Rowland, Mr. and Mrs. James D. Pyle, Mrs. Vivian Leftwich, Mrs. Daniel Tyler, Thomas H. Dugan and Nicholas Avierino.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Ewing Hope of 43 East Seventieth Street sailed yesterday on the Washington for a motor trip in Ireland. Later they will go to Scotland, returning to this country in September. Mrs. Charles B. Wainwright, who has been at 14 East Sixtieth Street since arriving from Waterloo Cottage, her home in Bermuda, has left to join her mother, Mrs. Samuel Wakeman Andrews, in South Kortright, N. Y.

The stock markets here continued strong today. Gilt-edge issues showed further improvement, while Chinese end Japanese bonds continued to recline. Among other foreign loans, Brazilian and German issues improved.

Federal Judge A. W. Johnson confirmed today the sale of the Williamsport (Pa.) Wire Rope Company to the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for "at least $3,000,000. He dismissed exceptions made by New York banks which hold mortgages and represent bondholders.

The Rev. Dr. William H. Kephart of 415 East 143d Street, who has been pastor of the North New York Congregational Church, East 143d Street near Willis Avenue, the Bronx, for more than forty years, died yesterday in the Lutheran Hospital, the Bronx, after a fortnight's illness of diabetes and pneumonia.

The victorious American Davis Cuppers, having a whole day to kill and nothing to do but see all of England, spent part of it touring an American razor-blade factory. This scarcely seemed an adequate reward for their recent accomplishments, but it was Don Budge's idea and anything "Bullseye" says now goes.

Efforts to work out the problems resulting from "when issued" trading over the counter in securities of the Baldwin Locomotive Works brought were made yesterday at a special meeting of the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., called by Nevil Ford of the First Boston Corporation, chairman of District Committee 15. Firms which will have to deliver Baldwin stock at the settlement date were represented.

A Navy Department tabulation of the world's comparative sea-power disclosed today Great Britain was far ahead of other nations. The British Navy now consists of 285 warships of 1,216,398 tons, the figures showed.

Henry J. White and J. Halperin, Inc, have closed loans aggregating $109,200 for Levitt Sons on thirteen houses under construction in Starthmore-in-Westchester, and have arranged financing for that entire community.

The Foreign Department was informed today that four Mexican members of the crew of the Spanish munitions ship Mar Cantabrico, captured by the Insurgent cruiser Canarias off Spain in February, had been executed at El Ferror for "rebellion."

A six-story health clinic will be' erected by the Department of Hospitals at First Avenue and East Twenty-fifth Street, according to plans filed yesterday. It will occupy a plot 99.11 by 49.2 feet at the northwest corner and will cost $275,000.

Two five-story apartment houses occupying the square block bounded by the Grand Concourse, Ryer Avenue, East 184th Street and Field Place, the Bronx, were sold by Henry Lichtig, trustee, through David Mintz-Carl Jaffe, Inc., brokers. The buildings contain 293 rooms laid out in sixty-three apartments and three stores.

The marriage of Miss Gloria Finck of 145 East Fifty-second Street, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Finck, to William Chauncey Sloan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Adam Sloan of Glenwood, Yonkers, took place yesterday afternoon in Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman.

The State Department announced today the "gentlemen's agreement" between the United States and Japan limiting Japanese cotton piece goods exports to the Philippine Island will be continued for another year.

Samuel S. Leibowitz, chief defense counsel in the Scottsboro trials, will discuss "The Inside of the Scottsboro Case" in a broadcast from a rally at the Hippodrome tonight at 9:45 o'clock over Station WMCA. The rally will be held to continue the fight for the freedom of the five defendants who have not been released.

Among next week's Summer theatre bills are these: "Mary's Other Husband," instead of the new play, "Hidden Door," at the Starlight Theatre, Pawling, N. Y .... "The New Moon" on Thursday at the 'Theatre-in-theWoods, Norwalk, Conn.. .. "The

The strike of seamen already in effect on three ships of the American West African Line spread yesterday to the passenger and freight ship Pastores of the Colombian Line when a demand of the National Maritime Union for a closed shop agreement was rejected.
Mrs. Patrick J. Kenny of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Judith Ann Kenny, to Robert Ryan McBride, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter W. McBride of Adams, Mass.

TIENTSIN-After Japanese planes had bombed several towns around Peiping, the Chinese staged a surprise attack at Tientsin, Japa, nese army base. As the war front spread rapidly the Chinese reported having destroyed bridges at two places and were said to have retaken some positions. Page 1.

Judge and Mrs. Charles Platt Williams of this place have announced the engagement of their elder daughter, Mrs. Ellen Susan Williams Stalter, to Captain John Beauchamp Gordon-Duff of the Rifle Brigade, British Army.

Ten tourists and three members of the cruise staff on the HollandAmerica liner Rotterdam could not get permisison to land in the Soviet Union when the vessel docked at Leningrad July 24 on a northern cruise, it was learned yesterday.

The Grays Harbor Pulp and Paper Company of San Francisco, producer of bleached sulphite pulps, has filed registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 244,662 shares of preferred stock valued at $8,807,832 to be offered to holders of common stock on an exchange basis, and 244,662 shares of $1 par common stock to be reserved for conversion of the preferred, the commission announced today.

Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANT - Patrick Crotty, from Bridge District to Traffic L, assignment to desk duty continued. PATROLMEN-From precincts indicated to 4th Division, assigned to duty in plain clothes:

" Too busy" to give his birthday much thought, Henry Ford plans no special observance tomorrow, when he will be 74 years old. But he is looking forward eagerly, he said today, to his golden wedding anniversary next Spring.

Arthur C. Kaufman, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and head of the company's Philadelphia store, said on his return from Europe yesterday that business conditions abroad were on an upward trend and that expansion of some of the concern's foreign offices would be necessary.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Capt. William E. C. Washburn, Engr.Res.. having received the necessary treatment at the Station Hospital. Fort Jay, N. Y. will proceed to his proper station CCC Co. 3263C, Camp SP-17, Leicester, N. Y., for duty.

The New York City Police Department will be ??ready to employ twoway radio on police cars within six months," according to an address here yesterday by Gerald S. Morris, superintendent of the communications bureau.

Mrs. Sara Smith Comstock, for twenty-one years president of the Sterling Widows Home here, and for the past eight years honorary president, died today at her home, after a long illness. Her age was 83. Her late husband, George Comstock, was for many years a partner of the Comstock-Willett Company, wholesale grocers here.

Four amendments to the rules and constitution of the New York Curb Exchange were announced yesterday. The change in the rules will become effective on Aug. 12. The constitutional amendments will come into force on the same date, unless disapproved by a majority vote of the regular membership.
John W. Ehrentreu, 29 years old, a New York attorney, died here today in the Lawrence Hospital of a fractured skull, suffered last evening when he was thrown from a horse. Mr. Ehrentreu was riding
The report of the United Gas Improvement Company and subsidiaries for the first half of this year shows a net income, after all expenses and charges, of $15,813,815.

With the participation yesterday of the Twenty-sixth and Fortieth Chinese armies in an attack against Japanese troops in the Tientsin area hope of localizing the North China fighting apparently dwindled considerably.
Mrs. Isabelle Pickslay Mulligan of Yonkers, the wife of Ralph R. Mulligan, an advertising man in New York, died today in St. John's Riverside Hospital after a long illness.

Doubt as to the enthusiasm of organized labor for the Black-Connery Wages and Hours Bill gave impetus today to a growing movement to recommit or defeat the measure, and thereby added a new threat to the remainder of the Administration's legislative program.

A bold and brilliant defense by the sparse home forces failed today as expected and England's Wightman Cup team won all four places in the women's singles isemi-finals of the Canadian lawn Tennis championships.

Effective this week, Maxon, Inc., Detroit advertising agency, has been appointed to direct advertising for Gillette razors and blades, Auto Strop and Probak razors and blades, and Gillette brushless shaving cream, according to an announcement yesterday by C. S. Stampleman, president of the Gillette Safety Razor Company, Boston.

With the notable exception of cotton, most commodities last week were marked by small price changes and dull trading, according to The Annalist. The Annalist index of wholesale commodity prices was unchanged at 95.2 (1926=100).
Mr. Harold Denny informs THE TIMES in a wireless dispatch from Moscow that the Russians are beginning to find that jails and firing squads are not the best means of promoting efficiency.

JACOB ASKENZER, cutter, 1,974 Lafontaine Ave.-Liabilitles, $3,430; no assets. SAMUEL H. DENDER, physician, 780 West End Ave.-Liabilities, $28,583; no assets except insurance. HENRY ERVING DEXTER, salesman, Yonkers.- Liabilities, 5,570; no assets.

The profit reported by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for the second quarter was somewhat better than expected, in view of the closing by strike of the Cambria plant for a fairly long period, and even the Republic Steel result was viewed as pretty good when the difficulties surmounted by that company were considered, according to steel men. On the other hand,

The heaviest planes in Japan's North China army systematically and unhurriedly devastated yesterday a large area of this city, China's second largest trade and commercial metropolis. Chinese officers declared "thousands of noncombatant men, women and children were killed or wounded."

The purchase of the building at 1,080 Lexington Avenue, northwest corner of Seventy-sixth Street, by the Lenox Hill Hospital was announced yesterday by L. J. Phillips Co., brokers in the deal. It rounds out the hospital's holdings at this point and gives it control of the square block bounded by Lexington and Park Avenues, Seventy-sixth and Seventy-seventh Streets.
Two rounds of upsets and sensational golf simmered down tonight to the certainty of an allCanadian final for the 1937 amateur golfing championship of Canada.

Congress has been in session for about seven months. That is a long time. It is midsummer. The Summer climate of Washington is enervating even when it is not stiflingly hot. The spirits of members have been wearied by controversy. For all these reasons they want to go home. But the fact remains that,

Stanley A. Martin Jr., unemployed salesman who is alleged to have signed a statement confessing that he strangled Mrs. Florence Jackson in Whitestone, Queens, last Tuesday morning, pleaded not guilty in Queens Felony Court yesterday, but waived examination. He was held for the grand jury.

Brokers' reports of apartment rentals yesterday indicated a continuance of the brisk activity which has been noted in recent weeks. One of the larger leases reported was with Charles D. Wetmore of Warren Wetmore, architects, who took a ten-room and four-bath
The New York Hippodrome Opera Company yesterday announced the postponement of its Fall season until Friday evening, Aug. 27.
Her master's voice, even on the telephone, spells new life for Lassie, 7-year-old collie owned by R. A. Warren, who went to a Toronto hospital for an operation.

King George VI, who heretofore has displayed little interest in yacht racing, is contemplating the construction of a big yacht for next year's regattas, it is understood here, and the result of the Americas Cup series off Newport, R. I., may materially influence his decision regarding the size and type of the boat.

The Cabin Holding Corn, Benjamin Bernstein, president, sold to Dominick Matera the loft building at 17 Leonard St for a consideration indicated as $7,000, taking back a purchase-money mortgage for $3,500, payable in five years at 5 per cent.

A new constitutional law, designed to reintroduce parliamentary conditions in the Republic of Estonia after more than two years of semidictatorial regime under President Konstantin Paets and General Laidoner, was passed today by the National Assembly's two chambers in a joint session.
Uncle Sam paid a year's rent--$1--today to George J. Marott, Indianapolis merchant and hotel owner, for a five-story building occupied by the regional offices of the Resettlement Administration.

Frank P. Corrigan, Minister to El Salvador, was appointed by President Roosevelt today Minister to Panama to succeed George T. Summerlin, recently named chief of the Division of Protocol in the State Department. Robert Frazer, consul general in London, was appointed Minister to El Salvador.

The House passed a resolution today directing the army engineers to submit a comprehensive plan for flood control which Congress may use in authorizing a program to control all major streams of the country.

Frank D. Reilly, retired New York silk merchant and formerly active as a choir singer there, died yesterday at his home here at 765 Valley Road, as the result of a fall in his home several weeks ago. Mr. Reilly, a native of Dublin, Ireland, was 81 years old. He was the uncle of Mrs. Joseph G. Wolber of Montclair, wife of Circuit Court Judge Wolber, who is a former State Senator.
The Senate Committee on Governmental Reorganization scheduled today a ten-day series of public hearings on the President's program. The hearings will begin Monday.

The B. M. T. served notice yesterday that it must receive a higher fare on its rapid transit lines or some reduction in city taxes, if it is to meet higher labor costs on its general transportation system in ?? and Manhattan.

Miss Louise Younkers Gottschall, daughter of Simon Gottschall of 230 Central Park West and the late Mrs. Rebecca Younkers Gottschall, was married yesterday noon in the Jansen Suite of the WaldorfAstoria to Mortimer Feuer, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Feuer, also of this city.

The 26,000 shares of 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $25 par value and 100,000 shares of Class A stock of $1 par value of Thomas J. Lipton, Inc., Hoboken, N. J., offered on Wednesday by Hallgarten Co., have been sold and the subscription books closed, it was announced yesterday by the bankers.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended July 29 were announced today: Fleming, Major H. M. H., Norfolk Navy Yard, Va., to Marine Corps Schools, Senlor Course, Quantico, Va. Gloeckner, Major G. L., detailed as Acting Quartermaster. Aug. 1.
A further decrease of $60,000,000 in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in the week ended on Wednesday, was reported yesterday.

Addressing the seventh annual luncheon of the Jackson Heights Merchants Association yesterday, Mayor La Guardia assailed foes of city planning who had "willfully and viciously misrepresented" this program to the residents ol Queens. He also invited New York
Mayor S. Davis Wilson, who registered as a nonpartisan for the Presidential election last year, announced today that he would pursue the same course for this Fall's municipal election.

The menacing figure of Totem crept into the picture today as the trial series to select defending six-meter yachts for the Gold Cup and Seawanhaka Cup entered its final stages. Showing for the first time
VILLENEUVE-ST.-GEORGES, France, Friday, July30.--Railway officials today announced that twenty-five persons were killed and fifty injured when a Paris-St. Etienne express was derailed near here.

Trading was only fair to slow on the bulk of steer hindquarter cuts. Other steer cuts. as well as other classes, were in fair to good demand. Price trends were stronger throughout. Kosher business was confined largely to lamb at stronger prices, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Irving Reynolds, a partner in the law firm of Mudge, Stern, Williams Tucker, of 20 Pine Street, made yesterday a successful bid of $996,000 for the controlling interests in Federal Match Corporation and Union Match Company, which were offered for sale before Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee, by the Irving Trust Company, as trustee in bankruptcy for International Match Corporation.
Mr. and Mrs. E. Magawly Banon opened their home, Lily Pond Park, tonight for the final in the series of chamber music concerts arranged by Mrs. Lewis A. Armistead. There was a large attendance.

Miss Sara Brevoort Peet, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Creighton Peet of this place, was married to Leicester Sargent Lewis of Bryn Mawr, Pa., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred Lewis of Philadelphia, today at the Peet home here.

In the course of a brief ceremony before both Houses of Parliament this morning Farouk became the first King to ascend the throne of modern, independent Egypt. He is the first independent ruler of Egypt since the days of the Pharaohs.

Miss Eleanor G. Evans, former superintendent of nurses at the Union Memorial Hospital, died yesterday, at the home of her sister, Mrs. C. A. Miller, in Martinsburg, W. Va. In 1926 Miss Evans won a citation and a medal from the French Government for her work as supervisor in the Rockefeller War Hospital in New York, where American soldiers, returned from France, received the Carrel-Dakin treatment for infected wounds.

Miss Louise Joan Cerabone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Cerabone of this place and Riverdale, N. Y., was married this morning in St. Denis Roman Catholic Church, Sylvan Lake, N. Y., to Dr. Anthony Miles Pernetti. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Dunnigan.

Miss Dorothy Shelby Siems gave a large party tonight at the performance of "Ten Minute Alibi," the current production of the Southampton Players at Parrish Memorial Hall, for a group who assisted her on the junior committee for the dinner dance of the Hamptons, held recently for the benefit of Camp Grant.
Ragged fielding in the ninth inning cost the Athletics a third straight victory over Cleveland today, two infield errors by Parker and Finney giving the Indians two runs and a 5-4 triumph.

Sir William Younger, former Member of Parliament, died yesterday at Auchen Castle, his seat here. He was 75 years old. Sir William sat in the House of Commons as a Conservative from 1895 to 1906, but switched to the Liberals on the protection issue and was elected as a Liberal in the Campbell-Bannerman landslide of 1906.

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended July 28 were announced today: LIEUTENANTS Thompson, C. W.. the Antietam, to temporary duty with the Chicago Division. Whitfield, E. C., the Dione, to the Antletam, as commanding officer.

Secretary Woodring made allotments totaling $94,478,201 today from this year's rivers and harbors appropriation. The allotments included these: Cape Cod Canal, $3,500,000; Boston Harbor, $900,000; Fall River Harbor, $18,000; Weymouth Fore River, $232,500.

Twenty-one awards to students in the Harvard Law School, with stipends totaling $9,000, were announced by the university today. The scholarships and the recipients were: Bernheimer Scholarship - Melvin Richter of Dorchester, Mass.

General Frank R. Schwengel, continuing his defense testimony for Seagram Distillers Corporation, of which he is vice president, at the Federal Trade Commission hearing at 45 Broadway, expressed doubt yesterday that spurious liquor was sold by retail package stores that cut their prices.
At midnight tomorrow, Saturday, the most celebrated piece of contemporary rolling stock in America will depart on its final journey.

Sir George Noble, Scottish sportsman, died today at his home in this racing center. He was 78 years old and had been seriously ill for several weeks. Sir George, second Baronet of Ardmore, was the oldest surviving son of Sir Andrew Noble, munitions manufacturer and expert on ordnance.

Bank clearings for the week ended on last Wednesday exceeded those in the same week last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The total for the week was slightly below the previous week, compared with an abrupt decline reported a year ago.

Miss Marion Jean Reid, daughter of Edwin B. Reid of North Plainfield, and Charles R. Thiers, son of Mrs. William J. R. Thiers of Plainfield and the late Mr. Thiers, were married last night in Holy Cross Episcopal Church by the Rev. H. Lewis Smith, rector.

Leonard St, 17, 25x91; Cabin Holding Corp to Dominick Matera, 6,420 15th Ave. Brooklyn ($7). Essex St. 115-17, 47.4x87.6; Nicholas Pecora to trustee will of Nathan Federgreen, care of Lafayette National Bank, Brooklyn; consideration $1.000: foreclosure.
In the seclusion of a rustic camp here Justice Samuel I. Rosenman, a State Supreme Court Justice, is compiling the speeches made by President Roosevelt.

Periodic health examinations for all members of the teaching and supervising staff of the city were recommended yesterday by Dr. Emil Altman, chief medical examiner of the New York City school system, in his annual report to Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.
Further improvement in the prices paid for United States Government obligations was the feature of another exceedingly dull trading session in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Billy Beauhuld, Jersey City's undefeated lightweight, added one more triumph to his string last night when he defeated Paul Junior, rugged battler from Lewiston, Me., in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.

Until he has conclusive evidence of the death of Amelia Earhart, George Palmer Putnam, her husband, will not believe her dead, Mr. Putnam said when he arrived in New York yesterday afternoon from Los Angeles.

Jewels valued at more than $40,000 are missing from the Summer home here of Mrs. J. J. O'Brien of Detroit. Mrs. O'Brien found the gems gone Monday when she went to the jewel box to get a string of pearls for an evening function, it is said.

The man who has been the object of no little criticism because he chose to engage in what he calls "comparative sailing" between the America's Cup challenger Endeavour II and the original Endeavour today answered his critics.

The greatest animation reigned in Camp Vogelenzang, near Haarlem, as Boy Scouts began to arrive from abroad by the hundreds. Among today's arrivals were 750 Americans, who came in two groups with their leader, E. G. Anderson.

The Bees salvaged the final of the three-game series, 2 to 1, from the man, driving in a ninth-inning run. Jim Turner allowed the Reds only four hits and did not issue a pass. It was Boston's twenty-third victory in the last thirty-three starts.
Deposits with the Bank of Canada rose to $196,254,294 on July 28 from $194,515,205 on July 21, according to the weekly statement issued today.
The Board of Directors of the Tygart Valley Association, leaders of strikers at the Federal Government's $1,000,000 Tygart Homestead project, refused today to return to work.

Miss Margaret Mitchell, daughter of Leeds Mitchell of Chicago and of Mrs. Day Mitchell of New York, was married here this afternoon to Barrett Wendell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barrett Wendell Jr., also of Chicago, at the Summer home of her father on Brant Point.

Premier Benito Mussolini celebrated his fifty-fourth birthday today. By a curious coincidence it is also the anniversary of King Humbert's assassination. As a result all flags were at half-mast throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, July 29.--The American and other foreign governments are trying to negotiate an armistice of four or five days in North China for the purpose of evacuating all foreign nationals from the danger zone, it was indicated tonight by a source close to the Administration.

Mrs. Virginia Lincoln Rogers of Cleveland today announced her approaching marriage to Alfred Waters of Pittsburgh. Mrs. Rogers until last week was the wife of Henry Huddleston Rogers 3d, son of Colonel H. H. Rogers who died several years ago leaving a twenty-milliondollar Standard Oil fortune.

Miss Marjorie Varick Pell, daughter of Mrs. Twachtman Pell of this place and Richard Varick Pell of New York, has chosen the afternoon of Sept. 4 for her marriage to L. Emery Katzenbach 2d, son of Mrs. L. Emery Katzenbach of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Katzenbach.

Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday, after a conference with Thomas E. Murray Jr., Federal receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, a compromise agreement by which the city will save nearly $240,000 on two judgments recently obtained by a company subsidiary in the Supreme Court.

Less attention than it deserves has been paid in this country to the example set by Austria in gradually working her way out of the system of exchange control which is choking international trade and strangling free enterprise in many of the nations of Europe, particularly in her immediate neighborhood.

Odd-lot coming meeting. The interests of transactions by odd-lot dealers and specialists in stocks, rights and warrants on the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday were reported today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, as follows:

Defying all adverse criticism, the fates and the Cubs, Burleigh Grimes started another odd Dodger line-up today that featured Buddy Hassett in center field and, to everybody's astonishment, walloped the league leaders by a 10-2 count.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Adrienne Charles, daughter of Mrs. M. de Peyster Charles of this place and James M. Charles of New York, to Charles Henry Classen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Washington Classen of Roland Park, Baltimore, which will take place here the afternoon of Aug. 20 on the lawn of The Cedars, the home which the bride-elect's mother has taken for the Summer.

A net income, after all expenses and charges, of $3,293,755 is reported by the Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months to June 30. This compares with a net of $2,474,689 in the year to June 30, 1936, and is an increase of $819,065.
A large scale drive to wipe out malaria and other contagious diseases in Chile's northernmost port of Arica on the Peruvian frontier will begin soon, according to orders issued today.

A dividend of $1.50 a share was declared yesterday on the common stock of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for the second quarter of 1937, compared with $1 a share paid on June 15 and with $1.50 a share paid on Dec. 24, 1936.

Under the most - favored - nation clause of the Anglo-Costa Rican trade treaty, Great Britain requested the same tariff reductions as those granted by Costa Rica to the United States in the trade treaty that becomes effective Aug. 3. Therefore, the Government announced today that it would concede reductions not only to Great Britain but also to Germany, France and Italy, which ?? unconditional most-favored-nation treaties with Costa Rica.

J. P. Meehan's Campillo won the Rho Pi Phi purse, six-furlong main event at Suffolk Downs today, by a length and a half and paid $7.40 for $2 in the mutuels. The Tall Tree Stable's Mansco was second, a nose in front of Mrs. C. Crane's Ladfield, while Mrs. C. C. Winters's Odd Blue was fourth. Mansco paid $7.80
The six-story apartment house for twenty-seven families at 935 Ogden Avenue, adjoining the corner of 167th Street, the Bronx, was bought by David S. Meister from a client of John R. .Jones, attorney.

Arthur C. Kaufman, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and head of the company's Philadelphia store, said on his return from Europe yesterday that business conditions abroad were on an upward trend and that expansion of some of the concern's foreign offices would be necessary.
Jimmy Foxx's third homer in three days and his twenty-sixth of the season gave the Red Sox their winning margin over the Browns today, 5 to 3, and enabled them to take the series, two games to one.

Charges that sabotage was committed on army airplanes which if undiscovered would have rendered bombing devices inoperative, were made today by Douglas Aircraft Company officials before the National Labor Relations Board.

The three young women who won major prizes, a trip to Europe, in a fashion contest, on the basis of the best home-made dress, arrived here yesterday. They are Miss Ruthann Burns, 20, a sophomore of the University of Nebraska; Miss Ruth Mackey Burnett, 20-year-old salesgirl at J. L. Hudson's department store in Detroit, and Miss Isabelle Judkins of Glendale, Calif., who is 24, chief flying hostess of a large commercial airline in the West.

Dr. Belle Reynolds, Civil War and Philippines occupation veteran, the first woman commissioned a major in the United States Army, will be buried here tomorrow with military honors. She died yesterday at the Hotel Gregson as she was preparing to celebrate her ninety-seventh birthday. Her health had been failing for several months, the only serious illness of her life.

With more buyers returning home and fewer arriving here, the pace of initial Fall buying activity eased in the local markets this week. The consensus in women's apparel lines is that while the early business on the average has shown a slight gain over last year in dollar volume, the number of units now on order is under this time in 1936.
The British Navy has won its biggest battle since the World War and has obtained control of all naval air services which had been directed by the Air Ministry.
The 1937 bright-leaf tobacco crop of South Georgia and North Florida went on the auction block today. Millions of pounds of the leaf were offered as the auctions began.

Dr. Walter Goodnow Everett, Professor Emeritus of Philosophy at Brown University and often a lecturer at the University of Calfornia, died of pneumonia today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Alexander Meiklejohn, in Berkeley.
Legislation granting Federal approval to continuation of the interstate compact to conserve oil and gas was sent to the White House today.

" The voting trust which has dominated the corporate affairs of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company for fifteen years has not been operating legally for the last five years," it was asserted yesterday by Ernest A. Bigelow of the law firm of Bigelow Beatty.

The American Gas and Electric Company has authorized the expenditure of approximately $4,000,000 for the extension of facilities of the Twin Branch generating station of the Indiana and Michigan Electric Company to meet the growing load of the utility in Indiana and Michigan.

President Roosevelt discussed proposed sugar legislation with a group of Senators and Representatives, heard Agriculture Department officials outline a new drought prevention plan, conferred with Representative Celler on the Miller-Tydings bill and received from Senator Guffey an invitation to attend Constitutidn Day ceremonies in Philadelphia on Sept. 17.

Board of Elections offices in the five boroughs will remain open all night on primary day, Sept. 16, to avoid a possible repetition of what happened last year when eight Queens election inspectors left their official tallies at a Democratic clubhouse, S. Howard Cohen, president of the board, announced yesterday.

Lieutenant Paul W. Caraway, son of Senator Hattie W. Caraway of Arkansas, was listed today by the State Department as among the Americans at Tientsin, China, scene of an air raid and other fighting in the Sino-Japanese conflict.

Samuel Kronsky Co. has arranged for the 164 East Fifty-ninth Street Corporation, Murray Weisman, president, a first mortgage of $1,180,000 at 4 per cent on the twostory store and office building on the southwest corner of Fifty-ninth Street and Third Avenue, with the New York Life Insurance Company.

Mrs. Darwin P. Kingsley gave -a luncheon and bridge today at the Maidstone Arms. Mrs. Arnold Edgerton also was a luncheon hostess there. Mr. and Mrs. H. Hartley Ramsay and their sons have arrived at the Arms from Narragansett.

Bo Molenda, former Michigan fullback, has been signed to another one-year contract as assistant coach of the New York football Giants, according to an announcement yesterday by President John V. Mara. It will be Molenda's
Great Britain has given Japan to understand that she will disapprove of the severance of any more provinces from China, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden indicated in the House of Commons today.
Business in the Pittsburgh district last week lost most of the ground gained in the week ended July 17, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

Further disagreement and delay appeared in store for the Non-Intervention Committee tonight as written comments on the British compromise plan were received from twentytwo of the twenty-seven governments concerned.

THE NEWEST BOARD If the Wages-and-Hours Bill which is now before the Senate is passed by both branches in substantially its present form, there will be created in Washington a new board of five members who will need the wisdom of as many Solomons. They will be members of the Labor Standards Board, charged with the responsibility of fixing minimum wages and maximum hours for industries engaged in interstate commerce.

The old-time delicatessen store has gone and in its place has come a combination grocery-dairy-appetizer - vegetable - food shop, selling everything from sliced bologna to pancake flour, an "expert" in this field, who has been a proprietor of delicatessen stores for seventeen years lamented yesterday.

The statement of the Commercial Credit Company for the six months ended on June 30, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $7,100,275 after expenses, interest, reserves for losses and taxes, exclusive of the Federal surtax on undistributed profits.
The Irish uprising in 1921 provides the background for Desmond Hurst's English-made production, "Ourselves Alone," opening this morning at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. It is played by John

Hard pressed by the Czechs, Adolf Hitler's new air force won today the 567-kilometer [352-mile] Alpine circuit for three-plane military patrols. For the sixth time this tenday international aviation meeting heard "Deutschland" mark a German victory.

" Whereas, there will be a number of prominent Republicans whose names will be entered in the Republican primary for city and borough elective offices, "And, whereas, enrolled Republicans are in a mood to determine these matters for themselves,

Supreme Court Justice Albert Conway in Brooklyn signed yesterday an order permitting Mr. and Mrs. Harry Stringer of 217a Thirtyfourth Street, Brooklyn, to attend last night's session of the Kings County Republican Committee in Kismet Temple as members of the county committee.

That the Communist party would support Mayor La Guardia in the coming elections through a "united front" with the American Labor party was implied last night by Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party, in a radio address over Station WQXR.
Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh for a second time paid a flying visit today to his friend and scientific collaborator, Dr. Alexis Carrel. In his plane Colonel

Crowds hurrying along John Street on their way to offices in the financial district stopped short about 9 o'clock yesterday morning when they saw a man dangling sixteen stories above them at a window of the twenty-eight-story building at 111 John Street.

The Petroleum Corporation of America reported that the net asset value of its 2,000,000 shares held by the public on June 30 was $22.91 a share, against $18.17 a share a year previously and $23.94 on Dec. 31, last. Huntington D. Sheldon, president, said the directors contemplated continuing this year to disburse dividends approximating the net income.

Henry Reed Hatfield of Philadelphia entertained with a dinner this evening in honor of Mrs. Horace Francine and Charles P. Fox. Other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Henry O. Tallmadge, Lee Gron and Miss Bell Gurnee.

A bid of $20,000 made for the forty-sevenroom house, the gymnasium, stables, two cottages and 154 acres of land at Mrs. Margaret Emerson's estate, Holmwood, was rejected at the estate auction here today.

Results of a recent test conducted by the grocery products division of General Mills, Inc., Minneapolis, revealed an interesting angle to the problem of featuring a sale of more than one package at a time as against advertising the price of a single package.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a six-story factory in West Broadway to cost $80,000. Plans for several alterations in Manhattan and Brooklyn also were filed.

Two large apartment buildings changed hands in auction sales of Manhattan realty yesterday. The six-story Nathan Hale apartment, on the southeast corner of 181st Street and Fort Washington Avenue, was bid in for $388,000 by the Chase National Bank, as plaintiff, to satisfy a judgment against the Goodale Real Estate Corporation in the amount of $503,926 and taxes and other liens of $41,983.

Compilation of statements and information, obtained by the bondholders' representative committee of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company during preparation of the reorganization plan, contains an announcement by G. T. Clarkson, receiver and manager, that earnings for the first half of 1937 amount to $2,100,000, before depreciation and bond interest, but after interest on receivers' certificates, compared with $766,698 for the first six months of 1936.

Maritime leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the C.I.O. clashed yesterday over charges that the International Longshoremen's Association had interfered in the employment of seamen on ships on which the National Maritime Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, had called a strike.
Sugar group leaders in Congress said that a conference with President Roosevelt today failed to break a deadlock with the Administration over sugar control legislation.

Delhi continued its gallop through the field in the Hempstead Cups tournament of the Meadow Brook Club today, following up its playoff victory in its branch of the league with a 10-3 triumph over Broad Hollow, winner in the other half.

Senator Rush D. Holt of West Virginia has announced the engagement of his sister, Miss Jane Holt, to Ralph K. Chase, Washington lawyer. Miss Holt said the wedding probably would be in "the early Fall."

The Pan American flipper III took off from Botwood Harbor at 6:05 P. M. (Eastern daylight time) today on its second eastward transatlantic flight in preparation for a regular commercial air service between Europe and America.

Another extension of time, until this afternoon, was granted yesterday by the National Labor Relations Board to the Todd Shipyards Corporation and its subsidiaries to enable it to check on figures presented by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C. I. O. affiliate, designed to show that it has a majority of the employes of the Robins Drydock and Repair Company and the Tietjen Lang Company.

A demand that Attorney General Albert A. Carmichael of Alabama use his influence to have four of the five Scottsboro defendants still in jail freed within two years, to fulfill a compromise agreement made early this year, was made last night by Samuel S. Leibowitz, defense attorney, in a broadcast address before a rally in the Hippodrome.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, announced yesterday that it had signed contracts with forty-nine operators of taxicab fleets employing a total of about 10,000 drivers and mechanics. The agreements include all of the large fleets except the Parmelee Transportation System, which has 3,200 employes.

A plea of "justifiable speeding" was entered by Prosecutor C. Lloyd Fisher of Hunterdon County today when he was arraigned here on a charge of driving fifty miles an hour in Union County on July 3. The prosecutor was a member of defense counsel in the Hauptmann case.

IT was only recently that Premier Mussolini gave the Admira soccer team of Vienna the official heave-ho out of Italy, and now, from even farther off, there comes additional evidence that soccer is a game that causes angry passions to rise.

Several luncheons were given today by the Summer colony, preceding the races. Mr. and Mrs. Roland Douglas of New York entertained at the Gideon Putnam for Mr. and Mrs. Frank Vance Storrs and Mr. and Mrs. Carl E. Shuster of New York.
Bits of wreckage miles off Thatcher's Island marked the spot tonight where the Gloucester fishing schooner Natalie Hammond sank early today after her crew of seventeen had taken to their dories.

A contract for the construction of a two-story office building at 125-35 East Eighty-seventh Street and 1,294 Lexington Avenue has been awarded to the George A. Fuller Company by Emanuel Ornstein, according to Brown's Letters.

Lieut. Comdr. Raymond Osgood Brackett, U.S.N.R., decorated for war service by the governments of France and Belgium, died today at the home here of his daughter, Mrs. George N. Ricker. Commander Brackett, who had lived in Marblehead, was a Past National Vice Commander in the American Legion.

Stocks closed firm at irregularly lower levels in slowest trading of the month; turnover, 610,765 shares. United States Government loans fractionally higher, other bonds steady and mixed; transactions, $6,169,500.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date.
The Leviathan, largest ship ever to carry the American flag, may end her days as a floating Winter hotel in the harbor of San Juan, Puerto Rico, if negotiations now in progress are successful.

Recalling the days when the original "Toonerville Trolley" was a community institution in Pelham, James (Old Jim) Bailey, 86, of the Bronx, original. "skipper" on the Pelham Manor line which inspired Fontaine Fox's famous cartoon, regretfully viewed yesterday the impending abandonment of the trolley line and made plans to attend the "last ride."

A new world record for parachute jumps was claimed today by K. F. Kaitanoff for a leap from an altitude of 9,800 meters (about 32,150 feet). Kaitanoff is one of the leading Soviet parachutists. The Government organ Izvestia said his feat was an experiment in the possibilities of high jumps in wartime.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, known to have been an adviser of James J. Dooling, the late leader of Tammany, and to have had a large part in putting forward Senator Royal S. Copeland as the Tammany candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, moved more openly yesterday Into Tammanyaffairs.
Two hundred guests attended a dance given by the board of governors at the Seabright Tennis Club last night as a feature of the current tennis tournament.

Three steeplechase jockeys wound up in the hospital with broken bones, a horse was killed, and an 8-to-1 shot was victorious in the Shannon River Purse as the odds-on favorite ran out of the course to contribute further to Saratoga's exciting upsets before a society-sprinkled crowd today.

With five teams entered, the national junior polo championship will get under way tomorrow at the Narragansett Polo Club in Narragansett Pier, Rhode Island. The opening game of the championship, which ranks next in importance to the open, will be between San Mateo of California, led by Lindsay Howard and including Billy Post at back, and the Narragansett Pier team of Gerry Dempsey, on which Ray Guest is riding at back.
Japan will have the greatest wheat crop in her history this year if the Ministry of Agriculture and forestry's forecast of 49,182,000 bushels proves correct.

Formation of Granbery, Marache Lord to conduct a general investment business was announced yesterday to become effective next Monday following the dissolution of Granbery, Safford Co. and the reconstitution of Craigmyle, Marache Co. as Craigmyle Co. on July 31.

Two weeks' test of the fair-trade practice rules for the millinery industry has resulted in general observance and a much healthier spirit in the trade, it was reported yesterday by Oliver W. Pearson, executive director of the Millinery Stabilization Commission, which sponsored the regulation.

The American Metal Company, Ltd., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the second quarter, showing a net profit of $1,135,900 after deductions for interest, depreciation, depletion and Federal income taxes, but before surtax on undistributed earnings.

A plan for the interchange of planes in airline operation by United Air Lines and Western Air Express was submitted today to the Postoffice Department at a hearing before Karl A. Crowley, solicitor. If approved, the plan may result in revolutionary changes in the country's airline system.

Class I railroads of the United States had a net railway operating income of $297,341,777 in the first six months this year, the Association of American Railroads reported today, based on information from 138 such carriers. The figure was 24.9 per

A threat that the Japanese China Fleet would be compelled "to take steps necessary for carrying out its duty" if the Chinese authorities failed to prevent an extension of the anti-Japanese movement in Central and South China was contained in a communique issued here last night by Vice Admiral Kiyoshi Hasegawa, the fleet's commander.

Mayor La Guardia accepted last night as his running-mates on a Fusion ticket Joseph D. McGoldrick for Controller and Alderman Newbold Morris for President of the Council, whose selection he at first opposed.
Governor Murphy vetoed the recently enacted Industrial Relations Bill tonight after the Senate had refused to pave the way for reconsideration of the measure and the inclusion of important changes.
Farmers in this vicinity reported today that the army worm, a great destroyer of crops, is again eating its way through Steuben County farms after an absence of forty-two years.

Contrary to general belief, Britain has no law which requires unions faithfully to carry out their contracts with employers. Nevertheless, owing to the deep-rooted respect for law and order in this country as well as the fact that highly competent union leaders require their membership to strike or return to work without questioning commands, instances of broken pledges are extremely rare.

The annual tea for the benefit of the Bolton Landing Health Center was held this afternoon at the Sagamore Golf Club. Mrs. William G. Beckers was hostess, assisted by Mrs. Leon P. Janinet, Mrs. Edwin B. Jenks and Miss Helen Simpson. Dr. Gillespie Meron spoke, giving a resume of the work accomplished for the underprivileged school children during the last year.

The Board of Tax Appeals absolved the Utilities Trading and Securities Corporation, New York; Matthew C. Brush and a dozen other Wall Street figures today from $1,609,334 income tax liability for 1928 as transferees of the Barnsdall Corporation class A stock and warrant syndicate.
Governor Murphy of Michigan will be a week-end guest of President Roosevelt, either at the White House or aboard the Presidential yacht Potomac.

Yesterday, as Chinese artillery and Japanese bombs were destroying some of the finest sections of Tientsin and Chinese troops under Japanese pressure were evacuating Peiping, the Japanese Government brusquely rejected the appeals of the United States and Great Britain for peace. No "interference"

Middlesex strengthened its hold on third place in the English county cricket competition today with an innings and one run victory over Worcestershire. Hampshire came through with the only other triumph of the day, defeating Warwickshire by an innings and 143.
Two Brooklyn women found guilty on July 19 of "selling" city jobs for $85 to $200 were sentenced to workhouse terms yesterday in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn.

MR. TENNYSON said flatly that kind hearts are superior to coronets. But that, you remember, did not stop him from becoming a baron, when Gladstone gave him the chance, with a seat in the House of Lords. Dixon Wecter makes pretty much the same point about citizens of this Republic who have democratic ideas and patrician opportunities in the course of "The Saga of American Society" (Scribner, $4).

Miss Florence Wiebke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wiebke of this place, was married to Edward Frank Seitz Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Frank Seitz of Rye, this evening in the Church of St. James the Less here. The Rev.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 8,000 including 1,000 directs. Market generally 10-15 higher than Wednesday's average; spots up more on weight averages of 210 pounds down; top 13.10;

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $3,000,000 of mediumterm notes of the city of Pittsburgh, Pa., on a bid of 100.087 for 1.60s. The notes, dated July 1, 1937, and maturing on July 1, 1940, were reoffered at a price to yield 1.45 per cent to maturity.

Secretary Perkins tonight announced that manufacturers of cotton garments will be required to pay a minimum wage of 37.5 cents an hour to make them eligible for Government contracts under the Walsh-Healey act.

Sizable recoveries were registered among foreign bonds on the stock market today. Chinese and Japanese issues were especially well bought. In addition to the Far Easterns, Brazilian obligations and Germans improved. French obligations held steady. Gilt-edge stocks, too, were generally firm.

The taxi driver leads a hard life and has many faults. He prowls through the city's jungle like a primeval hunter, though his intent is to miss the fleeting pedestrian and perhaps make a customer of him rather than to kill him. He is apt to be around when he is not wanted and somewhere else at other times. He knows the corners where he
Construction of what is intended to be the world's tallest skyscraper was under way today in the heart of Moscow.

June sales of reporting wholesale firms in this district averaged 9.7 per cent higher than last year, a smaller increase than in the previous month, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve agent here. The gain was the smallest since last November.

The first private end of July crop estimate, which indicated 15,610,000 bales, sent prices 1/4 cent a pound lower yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and left the list with net losses of 23 to 27 points. Under active liquidation and reselling of contracts covered earlier this week,

Sir Hubert Wilkins, polar explorer, will arrive today on the Hamburg-American liner Hansa. Others on the liner, coming from Hamburg, Bremen, Southampton and Cherbourg, include Mr. and Mrs. William J. Wells, Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Schmidt, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Burke, Mr. and Mrs. Herman Muhlenbrook, Mr. and Mrs. John H. Gans, Mrs. James Walsh Pennypacker, Stanley Smith, G. G. Nicholson, Mrs. Ethel Chapman and Mrs. Karl Biederlack.

C. I. O pickets patrolled three strike-closed packing plants today as union and company leaders planned a peace conference tomorrow. At the same time the wholesale food jobbers after an eight-day strike of truck drivers worked feverishly to fill a rush of retail orders. One house reported that

Trailing at 2-4 and 0-30 in the fifth set, Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, made a last whirlwind stand to snatch victory from Frank Shields of Hollywood today in the semi-finals of the fiftieth anniversary tournament o? the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

Miss Alice Kocher, daughter of Victor Kocher of Port Chester, N. Y., was married tonight to Walter Joseph Hanson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew 0. Hanson of Salem, Mass., formerly of Greenwich, in the Church of Our Lady of Mercy, Port Chester. The Rev. Hugh Gilmartin, the pastor, officiated.

Maurice Bouilloux-Lafont, former Minister to Monaco and former Vice President of the French Chamber of Deputies, died today at the age of 62. He was selected by France to put things in order in Monaco, where there had been political and financial trouble.

Mrs. Elmer Swanson, 47, and Mrs. Kermit Mason, 45, sisters, went picnicking together this afternoon and returned tonight to their respective homes. Mrs. Mason climbed into her car and drove downtown to meet her husband when he was through work, and so did Mrs. Swanson.

The Giants tackled the Cardinals in the final and deciding struggle of their threegame series today with a do-or-die spirit, and while it is perfectly true they did not perish in the attempt, it is equally correct to say they accomplished little of material benefit.

James J. Dooling was buried yesterday under a spreading maple on a grass-covered slope in Old Calvary Cemetery in Queens. The young leader of Tammany Hall, stricken when only 44 years old, was buried near the grave of his noted predecessor, Charles F. Murphy, after more than 10,000 persons had gathered for the funeral services in his home parish on the West Side.

Mrs. Nancy Schoonmaker, writer and former suffragist leader, of Woodstock, was designated today by Democratic leaders of the Twentyseventh New York 'Congressional District to succeed the late Representative Philip A. Goodwin of Coxsackie.

Net profit of the Yellow Truck and Coach Manufacturing Company for the first half of 1937 amounted to $1,576,649, equal, regular preferred dividend requirements, to 36 cents a share on 2,999,989 combined Class A and B common stocks, compared with $2,174,431, or 78 cents a share on 2,100,000 combined A and B common shares, in the 1936 period.

As a means of controlling jingoism the Home Office has tightened its censorship of plays, films and revues which have been assuming a warlike tone. A film drama, "Unscrupulous China," has been banned. Another called "Onward Imperial Army" had 200 feet cut out.
Following a Summer of intensive experiment and research, the Commerce Department announced today that an improved type of "de-icer" is to be used on the country's airlines the coming season.

Lew Hal today hung up his second 2:12 pace victory of the Grand Circuit's two-week meet on the track here. Driven by his owner, Dr. Hugh Parshall, the plucky bay stallion won the first heat, broke in the second, losing to Sep Palin's Lone Ace, and came back to win the third. Fastest time, however, was

Robert K. Straus, son of the late Jesse Isidor Straus, former Ambassador to France, announced yesterday that he was circulating a petition seeking designation on the City Fusion and American Labor party tickets for nomination to the City Council.

Minnie Rothstein has sold the five-story brick apartment at- 219 Varet Street, Brooklyn, to a client of Samuel Hurwitz for cash. The house has accommodations for fifteen families and stands on a plot 27 by 100 feet. It carries an assessment of $18,000.
The State has the power to reduce tolls on the Mid-Hudson and Rip Van Winkle Bridges at Poughkeepsie and Catskill, Attorney General Bennett ruled in an opinion today.

Mr. and Mrs. John J. Emery of Cincinnati are at the Savoy-Plaza. Mr. and Mrs. Frank G. Thomson have arrived at the Weylin from Devon, Pa. Lieutenant John Cogswell Oakes, U. S. A., and Mrs. Oakes of Fort Sill, Okla., are at the St. Regis.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

After an in camera hearing, requiring less than two hours, Mme. Magda de Fontanges, who shot and wounded former Ambassador Charles de Chambrun, at Gare du Nord, March 17, was found guilty today of assault and battery by the Tenth Police Court.
The navy's light cruiser Omaha aground ten days in the Bahamas was floated today through the corn bined efforts of tugs, beach gea?? and artificial waves kicked up by five destroyers.

The War Deapartment issued the following orders today dated July 28: COLONELS White, C. H., Infantry, Boston, Mass., to 29th Infantry, Fort Benning, Ga., about Sept. 15. Myers, D. L., General Staff Corps, 1 month and 26 days leave, Aug. 4.
British railways are making considerable headway toward winning back some of the passenger traffic lost during recent years to roadtransport companies.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Purves Guthrie of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Meriam Guthrie, to Gerald R. Wright, son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Wright of Elkton, Ky.

MANHATTAN BAXTER, WILLIAM C. (Jan. 3, 1932). Gross assets. $17,342; net, $11,063. To Malcolm H. Baxter, Warren P. and James E. Baxter, grandchildren, equal shares in residue. Chief assets, mortgages, notes. , $16,892. Otho S. Bowling, attorney, 233 Broadway.

Asserting that the United States, of all nations, had permitted the worst abuse of its coinage, Representative Cochran of Missouri reported a bill today to the House which he said would "end this racket" of commemorative coins.
The Kings County Republican Committee in a stormy meeting at Kismet Temple, Brooklyn, last night withheld endorsement of Mayor La Guardia as the Republican candidate for renomination as Mayor.

The former bank building at 3 Main Street, near Getty Square, Yonkers, has been sold by Thomas Hawley to the Deus Realty Corporation through John J. Reynolds, broker. Assessed at $136,000, the property was sold subject to a first mortgage of $50,000.

MANHATTAN DUGDALE, HARVEY HENRY (July 19). Estate, $1,000. To Hazel Leone Dugdale, widow, executrix, 5 Prospect Pl., residue. FERGUSON, HARRY (June 27). Estate, more than $10,000. To Louis Ferguson, brother, executor, 230 Central Park West, residue.

First Baseman Dolph Camilli and Catcher Earl Grace contributed a pair of home runs today that overcame a Pirate lead and gave the Phillies an 11-7 victory in the final game of a series of three. The Pirates won the first two.

Dr. Edwin Fazon Osborn of Kalamazoo, Baptist minister, lecturer and author of many religious books, died today at the age of 77 in the home of his daughter, Mrs. Robert S. Tubbs in Grand Rapids, where he had been ill six weeks.

Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Hospital Commissioner, reported yesterday to the Board of Estimate that enactment of the Burke bill, which would provide salaries of $1,000 a year plus board and lodging for internes in city hospitals would add $500,000 a year to his departmental budget.

The 1936 London naval treaty among the United States, France and Great Britain went into force today as instruments of ratification by the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and India were deposited at the Foreign Office.

The Philadelphia Ballet under the direction of Catherine Littlefield, last night succeeded in making dance history, at least in the statistical sense, by presenting at Lewisohn Stadium New York's first performance of the famous Tchaikovsky ballet, "The Sleeping Beauty," in its complete form.

Red Rogue and Jokester, who finished one-two in the sixth event on the turf were disqualified for running out of the course as they neared the finish. line at Arlington Park today in the mile and a sixteenth journey.
The Queens County Savings Bank has sold the two-story apartment and store building on the southeast corner of Northern Boulevard and 109th Street, Corona, Queens, to A. J. Friedman. The plot is 67.48

Application of the corporate methods of saving money throughh refinancing of bonded indebtedness with lower interest-bearing securities to the field of municipal financing is being demonstrated by residents of the Florida Everglades.
Henry Ashton Jennings of Greene Farms, president of Jennings Brothers Manufacturing Company of Bridgeport, Conn., died this morning in Bridgeport Hospital after a short illness. He was 65 years old.

Just as the America's Cup advance situation seemed to place the defender Ranger in an unbeatable position, the whole thing appeared to be dumped today into an unfathomable state when the English Endeavour, challenger of three years ago, defeated the Ranger in the squadron run of the Eastern Yacht Club from Vineyard Haven, out on the island of Martha's Vineyard, to this port.

At least two persons died last night as fire swept a 2,378-ton steamship, bound for Norfolk with more than 100 passengers and a crew of fifty, as it rounded the mouth of the Patapsco River into Chesapeake Bay, about fourteen miles from here.

A Chinese and a Japanese Girl Scout traveling together from the Orient will arrive at Grand Central Station on Sunday evening as the first of the delegation from twentysix foreign countries who will attend the first international Girl Scout encampment at Camp Andree near Briarcliff Manor.

Detectives investigating the murder of Irma Louise Pradier, French domestic, who was found shot to death on the Harlem Speedway at 165th Street the morning of July 20, broadcast a meagre description yesterday of the man they think might have killed her.

Orders placed by buyers in the wool goods market this week were restricted, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. In the men's wear division, it is stated, scattered fill-in ordering of Fall goods appeared, although a better volume was reported done in 1938 Summer tropical lines.

The chef at the New York Athletic Club had his work cut out for him yesterday. In fact, before evening he was thoroughly convinced that all the current comment about hunger strikes certainly did not apply to the vicinity of ventral Park South.

The nine-room dwelling at 200 Avenue A, on the corner of North Street, Bayonne, N. J., has been sold by Arthur H. Ferber to Grace, P. Harker. The house is on a plot 107 by 167 feet. Roberson Roberson were attorneys for the seller and R. B. Sanborn for the buyer. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

The Sierra front west of Madrid was so quiet today for the third day that it almost gave the appearance of a truce, save for one brief period in the morning when the Insurgents made a sharp but fruitless attack against a small position east of Villanueva de la Canada.

The heavy flow of gold across the Pacific from Japan shows no signs of abating, and with imports received at San Francisco for the week ended on Wednesday at approximately $12,667,000, an additional engagement of $5,600,000 for shipment to the United States was reported to the Federal Reserve Bank here yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia's name was cheered and mention of Senator Royal S. Copeland and Grover A. Whalen, Democratic Mayoralty designees, was booed last night at the first convention of the Bronx County Committee of the American Labor party at Elsmere Hall, 284 East 170th Street, the Bronx.

Lieut. Gen. Kiyoshi Katsuki, Commander-in-Chief of the Japanese armies in North China, has evidently badly extended himself and appears to have committed serious errors of military and political judgment.
George J. Schell, chief architect for Daniel H. Burnham Co., and designer of many downtown buildings here, died Wednesday in his home here after an illness of three months. His age was 69.

Victor Ghezzi, Deal professional who was runner-up last year, forged into the lead at the end of the first round in the New Jersey open golf championship today at the Shackamaxon Country Club. Ghezzi clipped four strokes from par, going out in 34 and coming back in the same figure.
