Fire in the elevator shaft on the Senate side of the Capitol put two elevators out of commission today. The blaze was confined to the shaft and all the wiring was burned out, so the elevators will be useless for several days.
The final measures in Finance Minister Georges Bonnet's program for reducing expenses are to be passed at tomorrow's Cabinet meeting.

A provision intended to make Hollywood offer an opening in America to British films as an offset to the [Pound]9,000,000 which Great Britain pays annually for American pictures is included among the Government's proposals for continuance for another ten years of the Cinematograph Films Act. The proposals rest partly on

To the Editor of The New York Times: Senator Wagner's article on the National Labor Relations Act in THE NEW YORE TIMES Magazine last Sunday is a commendable contribution. Especially timely is the condemnation of resort by labor to violence or to violation of employers' property rights; and urging "recourse to the instrumentalities of the law." In self-interest, labor should heed

Harold Mandly of Wethersfield, Conn., the 1935 New England amateur golf champion, today qualified for the second-round match play at Ekwanok by defeating F. J. Warren of Newton, Mass., 3 and 2. Charlie Round of Providence, yesterday's medalist with a thirty-sixhole total of 142, was another victor with a 5-and-4 decision over Roy Moore of Waterville. Me.

Chain stores are using their purchasing power in a manner that small units cannot withstand, Isidore Nagler, general manager of the Joint Board of Cloakmakers Unions of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, declared yesterday at meetings of manufacturers of coats and suits now priced at $11.75 and $7.75 at the offices of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 27: Lockwood, Cmdr. C. A., Jr., Submarine Div. 13, to Naval Operations, Washington, D. C. Lineberry, Cmdr. W. T., Med. Corps, Philadelphia, Pa., to the Relief. Lewis, Lt. Cmdr. M. L., the Gamble, to Naval Academy.

The Rev. William Banks Rogers, S. J., who was president of Marquette University here in the closing years of the last century, died late yesterday at Milford Novitiate, Milford, Ohio, it was announced at Marquette University today. He was 79 years old. After serving here he became president of St. Louis University.

Despite a few minor clashes in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, due largely to the tense feeling of the crowds and their fear of attack by the police, and a more serious affray in Sarajevo where a woman was killed and about fifty persons injured, the critical day of the Patriarch's funeral passed more quietly than expected.

A number of units in the various buildings in Rockefeller Center were included in the commercial space leased, according to brokers' announcements yesterday. The H. J. Heinz Company of Pittsburgh, manufacturers of food products, took office space in the RCA Building.

Bill Dickey made one hit for tile Yankees yesterday at the Stadium in the farewell clash with Mickey Cochrane's Tigers, but the blow carried a victory message that was sweet music to the ears of Marse Joe McCarthy.

The Ford Motor Company rested its case late this afternoon in the hearing on charges of violation of the Wagner act and unfair labor practices, with a demand that the charges be dismissed. This was rejected by John T. Lindsay, trial examiner.

A robber escaped with $600 about 4:30 yesterday afternoon after he had held up two women employes of the Metropolitan Personal Loan Corporation, 125 East Twenty-third Street, between Fourth and Lexington Avenues. At pistol point he ordered the women to go into a rear room after he had removed the money from a drawer, and warned them not to make an outcry. Then he fled down a flight of stairs.

PEIPING, China, Friday, July 30.--Several hundred Japanese troops were besieged yesterday in their barracks at Tungchow, the East Hopeh capital, by supposedly pro-Japanese troops who suddenly were turned on them.
Frank Silvio of the New York A. C. scored a stunning upset today by beating Johnny Coulson of the Toronto Argos, in the senior quarter-mile final as the Royal Canadian Henley got under way.

During the week ended July 28, member bank reserve balances decreased $82,000,000. The reduction in member bank reserves resulted from increases of $20,000,000 in Treasury cash other than inactive gold, $44,000,000 in Treasury deposits with
Harry Balsamo, 162, Harlem, knocked out Tiger Roy Williams, 165, Chicago, in 1:05 of the second round of the scheduled ten-round main event last night at the Fort Hamilton Arena before 4,000.

In the week ended yesterday awards for engineering construction amounted to $47,393,000, for a gain of 31 per cent over the corresponding week of 1936, when the figure was $34,600,000, according to The Engineering News-Record.

The C. I. O. won a decisive victory in the poll of employes of the shoe and allied industries conducted by the National Labor Relations Board in seventy-nine plants in this city, figures announced by the board disclosed yesterday.
Representative Dickstein, Democrat, of New York, put in the Congressional Record today the names of "leaders and Nazi agitators" in four Connecticut cities and Staten Island, N. Y.

Scientific study forecasts a drop of 40,000,000 in population in the eleven North and Northwestern nations of Europe in the next two generations, it was declared at the International Congress on Population Problems, which opened here today.

Though such plans are always subject to change, the local company of "Brother Rat" expects to open a road tour on Sept. 6 in Providence, which must mean that it will be ending its comfortable run at the Biltmore on Sept. 4.

The Spanish Navy tonight reported submarine attacks on five Spanish Government vessels. The steamer Anduzmendi was stated to have been in French waters when an attacker opened fire, damaging the vessel.

Morris Epstein, 30 years old, of 240 West Forty-eighth Street, a clothing salesman, was arrested last night at the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street, on a charge of felonious assault when a meeting of 500 members of the Retail Clothing Salesmen Union, Local 1,106, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, ended up in a fight.

Government employes will be forbidden to wear green shirts, which are the uniform of the Brazilian Integralistas [Fascists], or any party insignia under a bill introduced in the House of Representatives today.

The Governor's second reception at the "Little White House" here today was the occasion for the formal opening of the Republican Gubernatorial campaign of State Senator Clifford R. Powell of Burlington County.
Lumber production declined last week when an increase was seasonal, and the adjusted index has receded to 91.2 from 102.7. This compares with 84.9 for the week ended July 25, 1936.

After a fifteen-hour conference presided over by Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, an agreement was signed at 4:30 o'clock this morning ending the twelve-week strike at the Apex Hosiery Company's mill.

The Senate adopted a resolution today directing its Agriculture Committee to investigate the activities of the American Cotton Cooperative Association "in connection with the grading, stapling, reconcentration and marketing of cotton financed

The Sheriffs of the five counties of the city submitted their budgetary requests for 1938 yesterday to Kenneth Dayton, assistant budget director. Each Sheriff asked a larger appropriation than was granted in 1937 and each ignored the fact that his office soon might be eliminated.

Three members of the Philadelphia Board of Education were subpoenaed today to appear before the Shapiro Legislative Committee tomorrow to submit a copy of recommendations dealing with the city's school system as prepared by Dr. George A. Works of the University of Chicago, head of a survey committee.

Effective yesterday, the New York Stock Exchange membership of Bertram S. Rosenbaum was transferred to Paul Sperling of Ernst Co. and that of Archibald Douglas Jr. was transferred to William F. Reilly of Laird Co.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 28 unless specified: At Naval Operating Base Norfolk, July 29; Claxton, Erie, Fairfax, Jacob Jones, Manley, Roper, J. F. Talbott. Tor Bay to Hampton Roads, July 29; Arkansas, Wyoming.

Nathan M. Ohrbach, president of Ohrbach's, Inc., returned on the Conte di Savoia of the Italian Line from a business tour that took him through England, France, Italy and Switzerland. He said he had been impressed by the increasing "style consciousness" of London women, who are buying more American dresses than ever before.

More than a decade ago readers of poetry were commenting on the writings of a 9-year-old girl in Brooklyn named Nathalia Crane. Today another Brooklyn girl, only slightly older, is writing verse with an insight which belies her years. Katharine Carasso, who will be 14 on the last day of August, is the author of "Crystal Arabesques," a book of seventy -poems to be published next week.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick B. Platt entertained with a dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis in celebration of the latter's birthday. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Victor Kranick, Mr. and Mrs. Boyd Curtis and James G. Hunter.

Kenneth Roberts's "Northwest Passage" sold twice as many copies in the first four days of this week as in all last week, Doubleday, Doran reports. The novel is now in its 181st thousand. A new edition will go to the presses on Monday.

The New York Athletic Club sextet, national A. A. U. champion, added the Metropolitan A. A. U. soft-ball water polo crown to its list last night by conquering the Central Queens Y. M. C. A., 25 to 14, in the final of the annual tournament in the Rockaways' Playland Pool, Rockaway Beach.

Hard on the heels of a statement by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek that the Chinese Government would now put into operation "its comprehensive plan to lead the nation in a struggle to the bitter end," it was reported this morning that Central Government troops were being sent to the North China battle area.

Thornton Lee of the White Sox won a pitchers' duel with Wes Ferrell today, shutting out the Senators, 2 to 0. The White Sox victory carried them into second place in the American League and halted Washington's six-game winning streak.

Anson Perina of Irvington, N. J., Princeton University freshman, has been awarded a major six-inch letter for shattering the Nassau broad jump record in the recent PrincetonCornell and Oxford-Cambridge track meet, it was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.
Bruce Elliott Maguire of Wynnewood has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Jean Elliott Maguire, to J. Coleman McKeon, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John McKeon of Woodleigh, Wynnewood.

The marriage of Mrs. Emma Lawrence Robins, daughter of Mrs. Bartholomew Jacob of New York, to Joseph R. Busk, also of that city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. Busk of Litchfield, Conn., took place here this afternoon at the home of her brother, Lawrence Jacob 2d.

A bitter fignt in the Democratic primaries on Staten Island was assured last night when the Democratic Organization of Richmond County, Inc., which is opposed to William T. Fetherston, regular Democratic county leader, unanimously adopted a resolution endorsing the city ticket headed by Senator Royal S. Copeland and designated a complete county slate.

Chinese here see in the reported formation of a "peace maintenance commission' 'at ePiping an embryonic puppet regime under Japanese control. They recall that the appearance of such commissions is a routine procedure for initiating puppet governments when the Japanese conquer new Chinese territory.

Western railroads plan to increase their firstclass fares for the first time since 1933, it was announced today. Effective on Oct. 31, member roads of the Western Association of Railway Executives will institute first-class thirty-day round-trip fares at the rate of 2 1/4 cents a mile in place of the current rate of 2 cents for such round trip tickets.
George William Kruse of 39 West Eighty-eighth Street died of heart disease Wednesday after an illness of one month in his home. His age was 69.

Two suits for a total of $1,000 damages were instituted in Tenth District Municipal Court yesterday against the owners of the Hotel Theresa, largest hotel in Harlem, on the ground that the hotel had refused accommodations to Negro guests, although a white person who applied immediately afterward got a room.

A. Gordon Smith's colt Fearless Fox today defeated Sir Abe Bailey's heavily backed Cecil by two lengths to win the 113th renewal of the Goodwood Cup, oldest of the Goodwood handicaps and first run in 1812.

Emerson James Hankinson, inventor and real estate developer, died Tuesday at his home here. His age was 71. Mr. Hankinson was born in Trenton, N. J., and moved to Poughkeepsie in 1887. For several years he was a general foreman of the Lown cooperage plant.

The Westchester County Democratic Committee-held its annual convention here tonight, designating its candidates for the Fall primary and unanimously endorsing the Administrations of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman. The 350 committeemen met in

Wholesale prices of farm products dropped abruptly in the week ended on July 24, causing a slight recession in the general level, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's composite

Testimony that one of the State's principal witnesses has been guarded by the police night and day for more than six months; that a ledger card showing a deposit of more than $20,000 mysteriously disappeared from a bank's records, and that the books of the Chicken Drivers Union likewise mysteriously vanished was brought out at the poultry racket trial in the Supreme Court yesterday.
Mrs. Jennie Mapes Shipley, wife of Dr. Alfred E. Shipley, Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Hospitals, died yesterday at her home, 665 St. Marks Avenue, Brooklyn.

Henry Ford will be 74 today and Mussolini was 54 yesterday. To both these country boys who made good in the city-and both retain the rustic flavor-a birthday is just another day. Ford yesterday talked to reporters about backward politics and stupid business, and Mussolini reviewed a squadron of the Adriatic Fleet.
Max D. Steuer, New York lawyer, declared yesterday that he was convinced that the missing Justice Joseph Force Crater was dead and that the recent re-awakening of the case was useless.
Payment of alimony and separate maintenance is reaching the proportions of a $10,000,000 annual item in the economic life of Los Angeles County.
William O. Gosselin died today in the Aurora Hotel, which he owned. He was 65 years old. Born in Hudson Falls, N. Y., Mr. Gosselin was brought to Illinois at the age of 7.

Grim Atlas palms his world in iron fist, Expands his biceps with a turn of wrist, Measures a pause for its obscure assistance, Arches brute strength against abysmal distance, Lunges and hurls, then stands relaxed and spent As cosmic aeons lapse to incident...Who in this vast arena dares to say That he saw Atlas throw the world away?
Avenue, Bidra. Edwin Stevens of the GreenRich C. C. captured the low gross prize with an 82 in the FairfieldWestchester women's one-day golf tournament on the Brooklawn C. C. inks today.

The statement of the Morris Plan Industrial Bank of New York for June 30 shows total resources of $37,474,776, compared with $35,730,832 on Dec. 31 last, with surplus and undivided profits $624,872, against $637,796.
Frederic Prokosch, author of "The Asiatics," has won the Harper prize of $7,500 with his second novel, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Prokosch calls the prize-winner "The Seven Who Fled."

Fourteen acres of unimproved land on the Searingtown Road, adjoining the east side of the Long Island Motor Parkway, have been sold to an investing client of L'Ecluse, Washburn Co. by Long Island Motor Parkway, Inc., whose president and principal stockholder, William K. Vanderbilt, recently offered the parkway right-of-way as a gift to the Long Island State Park Commission.

Outstanding in the cup matches are two record performances as far as time goes over the cup courses in the international racing. That for the windward and leeward course of thirty miles was established by the defender Vigilant in 1893. She covered the distance in 3 hours 24 minutes 39 seconds, a feat that has never been equaled. That was off Sandy Hook.
Behind the five-hit pitching of Wayne LaMaster, the Phillies won a floodlight contest from the Reds tonight, 1 to 0, and dropped them into seventh place. They had been tied with Brooklyn for sixth.

Light Horse Harry Cooper made his favorite golfing terrain, the Keller course, do a few tricks for him today to fashion a par-breaking 33, 35-68, and a one-stroke lead over Pat Sawyer of Minneapolis, in the opening round of St. Paul's eighth annual $5,000 open tournament.
Natives watched today while sharks swung gradually closer to a thirty-five-foot whale, stranded in shallow, water near here. The mammal, sensing its

New minimum wage scales established by Secretary Perkins for mills to become eligible for Government contracts will bring advances in payrolls of the underwear industry but are not likely to influence scales in the majority of cotton garment factories, a survey of trade opinion indicated here yesterday.

An audience of 6,500 attended the second local performance of the ballet, "The Sleeping Beauty," given last night at Lewisohn Stadium by the Philadelphia Ballet Company, under the direction of Catherine Littlefield, premiere danseuse.

No airplanes are going to dodge down out of the heavens and stir up the sailing winds if the Coast Guard can prevent it-and it probably can. Two flying guardsmen in their own service planes will be aloft beginning tomorrow, and on board the flagship cutter Sebaco, with powerful binoculars, will be S. L. Willits, a supervising inspector from the Bureau of Air Commerce.

Appointments The following ununiformed firemen, having completed their probationary period of three months satisfactorily, are appointed as firemen, fourth grade, with compensalion each at the rate of $2,000 per annum:

The Board of Estimate unanimously adopted yesterday a resolution put forward by Aldermanic President William F. Brunner, calling for the passage of the Schwellenbach - Allen resolution which would protect WPA employes from dismissal which would force them into "an already glutted labor market."

Leon N. Southmayd, a promotion director who restored to cycling during the last sixteen years much of its earlier popularity, died here last night in the Lawrence Hospital after an illness of four weeks.
A $50,000,000 issue of discount bills lifted the public debt to a new peak of $36,707,757,744 on July 28, according to a Treasury summary issued today.

George C. White, Palm Beach (Fla.) real estate man, World War veteran and sportsman, died or Thursday here at Shannon Lodge, a sanitarium, after a two-year illness. Mr. White, who formerly lived in New York and Far Hills, N. J., was 65 years old.
The thirty-first world marksman championships opened today with impressive ceremonies on the new rifle ranges outside of this city.

Ernie Quigley, National League supervisor of umpires, will go on the air with the umpire's side of the story on Monday. He will be interviewed over station WEAF at 6:35 by Sports Commentator Ford Bond.

A criticism of the State Mortgage Commission for entering objections to a reorganization plan for the Nassau-Suffolk Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company under Section 77B of the Federal Bankruptcy Act was voiced yesterday by Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn.

Sentences of ten to twenty years each in State's prison were imposed by Judge Donnellan in General Sessions yesterday on two holdup men who pleaded guilty when about to be tried last July 14, after Assistant District Attorney John L. MacDonnell's revelation that they had plotted an -outbreak of prisoners from the prison ward at Bellevue Hospital the week before.

Miss Mary Patricia Cox, daughter of Mrs. William J. Cox of Germantown and the late Mr. Cox, was married this evening to Thomas Lee Grier, son of Dr. and Mrs. George Grier of Pittsburgh. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David Holmes, rector of St. Andrew's Church.

A plea for unity in the labor movement to enable workers "to combat with greater effectiveness their enemies, the reactionaries," was made last night by Vito Marcantonio and several labor leaders at a meeting of District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers of America. The meeting,

Mrs. Phyllis Fellowes Colmore Waid of Norwalk filed suit for divorce in Superior Court today against Dan Everett Waid, 73, architect, of New York and Old Greenwich, on grounds of "intolerable cruelty."
The John Ericsson Society will today lay a wreath at the statue of John Ericsson on the anniversary of his birth. But they of Swedish descent,

Existing contracts between the B. M. T. and twenty-one employee groups, under the representation plan set up in 1920, are contracts with a company union, the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, charged yesterday.

Mrs. Edwin Sprague Marston of 303 Lexington Avenue has announced the marriage of her daughter, Mrs. Edna Marston Beeckman of Newport, widow of R. Livingston Beeckman, one-time Governor of Rhode Island, to Archibald Gourlay Thacher of this city and Glen Cove, L. I., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Thacher of Boston.

The League of Nations Mandates Commission began its session on Palestine today, hearing in private a long statement on British policy by W. G. A. Ormsby-Gore, Colonial Secretary. He put the British Government on record here in favor of partition but did it with deference to the opposition the Royal Commission's plan provoked.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor "did the Lido" last night-and part of this morning. They returned to their hotel early today after dancing for three hours at the Pergola night club, topping off a full day of recreation, their first of a week on this famous beach.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 28: Holmes, Lieut. Comdr. F. S., the Herbert, to Naval Recruiting Station, Macon, Ga., in charge. Day, Lieut. D. L., Naval Academy, to the Saratoga. Worthington, Lieut. J. M., Washington, D. C., to Naval Academy.

The Spanish Government freighter Andutz-Mendi, little more than a charred hulk after the guns of two unidentified submarines had set her afire, brought her dead into the port of Le Grau du Roi tonight.

Turpentine firm, 33c; sales, 214 barrels: receipts, 569 barrels; shipments, 3,565 barrels; stock, 32.236 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 650; receipts, 3,177; shipments, 2,311; stock, 73,280. Quote--B to G. M. $7.80-.82 1/2; N. $7.85; WG, $7.90; WW, $8.60-.70; X, $8.70.

The Chief, considered by many the potential juvenile champion, and Esposa, best mare of her age now in training, are expected to be the favorites in the United States Hotel Stakes and the Saratoga Handicap, features tomorrow, the first Saturday of the Spa meeting. Each race will gross about $10,000.

Plans for a national federation of "independent" unions were projected into America's labor picture tonight. Eighty delegates, described as from more than a dozen States, gathered behind closed doors at the call of the Independent Chocolate Workers of Hershey.

The Browns were on exhibition at the Stadium yesterday for the first time under the new deal-the Jim Bottomley regime-but, against the Yankees, and to some 6,567 cash customers, they looked just the same.
The Imperial Airways flying boat Cambria landed in Botwood Harbor at 7:30 A. M. (E. D. T.) today, completing a transatlantic flight from Foynes, Ireland.

Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES. The Adjutant General released the following orders today: Vincent, 1st Lt. Roy F.. having qualified. is placed on duty. He is to report to Commanding General 54th Brigade for assignment to headquarters as aide.

In a mountain's life a century is less than the trembling of a leaf, yet it is fitting that the first recorded ascent of Mount Marcy by white men, the hundredth anniversary of which falls next Thursday, should be fittingly celebrated. One looks back to those simpler
The name of the late John D. Rockefeller was placed on the jury lists of the town of Richford today as an all-time tribute.

Miss Mildred Lucille Farquhar, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David C. Farquhar of Monessen, Pa., was married here yesterday afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church to Ernest Thompson Lyons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest J. Lyons of 395 Riverside Drive. The Rev. Martin D. Hardin Jr. performed the ceremony.

Supporters of Representative Christopher D. Sullivan, who have claimed for several months that they were in sight of a majority vote in the Tammany executive committee, will have their chance next week.

A bill abolishing the dual measurement system for determining tolls of vessels passing through the Panama Canal, and restoring to the President the right to promulgate rules which was originally granted in the Panama Canal Act of 1913, was passed by the House today and sent to the Senate.
Engine trouble caused a German Lufthansa mail plane to land on the sea 185 miles off the West African coast today. The plane was en route to South America.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation reported today a cash balance at the close of business on June 30 of $1,763,775, receipts in June having aggregated $44,207,510, compared to expenditures of $42,443,735 in the month.

An assertion that United States census-takers erroneously report a considerable number of young Negro males as females in the decennial censuses was made here today at the Population Congress by Dr. T. Lynn Smith of Baton Rouge, La.

Two women who will be aboard the competing yachts during the America's Cup races off Newport were the best of friends today-on land. Gertrude Vanderbilt-she will sail for the first time in an international cup race on her husband's Ranger tomorrow, keeping the log-chatted gayly last night with Phyllis Sopwith, who will be at her husband's side when the race starts, holding a stop-watch.

A new store structure designed to reflect the architectural lines of buildings in the 1937 Paris Exposition will be opened next Monday in Brocklyn by Russeks-Fifth Avenue, Inc., women's wearing apparel. Designed in the modernistic

The Governors of Iowa and Wisconsin will come to grips at noon tomorrow in a "tall corn" matching contest. Governor La Follette had transported into Iowa tonight specimens of Wisconsin's towering corn to put in the front yard of his host, Governor Kraschel.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 819,000 bales, against 855,000 a week ago, 882,000 two weeks ago, 860,000 three weeks ago and 759,000 a year ago; of which American 284,000 bales, against 301,000 a week ago, 315,000 two weeks ago, 325,000 three weeks ago and 280,000 a year ago.

Figures made public here yesterday by the Motor Vehicle Bureau show a rise in both deaths and injuries in New York State due to automobile accidents for the first six months of the year compared with a like period in 1936.
Two Frenchmen were condemned to death today for what Insurgent Spanish officials charged was a plot to infest their territory with typhoid and sleeping sickness epidemics.

Santa Claus appeared in the picket lines yesterday. Nearly 250 striking electrical workers adopted this novel July anachronism when they picketed the offices of several electrical companies, in support of their demands for union recognition, higher wages and improved working conditions.

The report that 100,000 radio sets had been purchased for distribution in China, and that daily broadcasts were carried on as a measure of language unification, was unconfirmed yesterday in New York among the radio manufacturing concerns from whom such purchases likely were to have been made.

Ruel Perley Smith, who was night city editor and one' of the Sunday editors of The New York World until his retirement ten years ago, died yesterday at Caledonian Hospital, Parkside Avenue, Brooklyn. Death was caused by pneumonia which followed an operation. Mr. Smith was 67 years old.

Two thousand shipyard strikers and sympathizers sat down on the trolley tracks outside the Hamilton Avenue police station in Brooklyn late yesterday afternoon to protest the arrest of several strikers in a clash with the police.
After fifty years on passenger trains between Stamford and New York, Michael Downey of 2,905 Summer Street, Stamford, retired today. He is the third oldest in

Those rural playhouses will devote next week pretty thoroughly to the testing of new plays. Fourteen of the untrodden dramas are currently listed for the great experiment, the group, alphabetically arranged, looking like this:

The whole population of the Soviet Union was called on today to act as informers against suspicious neighbors in order to strengthen Bolshevist vigilance against spies and saboteurs and help the government "smoke out all Fascist agents and destroy them as mad dogs."

In the absence of many pastors who will be on vacation through August, their churches will be in charge of visiting pastors, starting tomorrow. Guest preachers. will continue to be heard in many pulpits. The Collegiate Reformed

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "While the sales of wool in the Eastern seaboard markets have shown comparatively little change, there has been a distinct increase in the quantity of wool purchased by the dealers in the Far West.

Sheridan Ave (9-2,457), w s. 177n of 167th St, 102x100; Samuel M. Klein to Pearl Kritzler, 1,530 Sheridan Ave; mtgs $143,000. Fox St, (10-2,717) w s, 361 n of 165th St, 100x100; Gurian Realty Corp to Joseph B. Miller, trustee, 40 Wall St.

There was little change in the character of the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange except a further slackening in the trading pace. Dealings proceeded at an average rate of only a little more than $1,000,000 an hour, total transactions amounting to $5,861,900, compared with $6,169,500 on Thursday.

A bomb exploded with a terrific detonation at 2:15 A. M. today fifty yards from the police barracks on Devonshire Street. First reports indicated no one was injured, but residents of a wide area of the city were awakened in terror. Families clad in nightclothes
William F. Fearon, a retired stock broker, died today at the Union League, where he had lived for twenty years. He was 77. He survived all the immediate members of his family. He was a member of

Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont, New Jersey State champion, who recently lost her Shore title, regained winning form today and captured the one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Morris County Golf Club.

The second day of the celebrations of King Farouk's investiture was marked with the same enthusiasm shown at yesterday's memorable ceremonies when the young monarch ascended the throne. During the royal procession yesterday from the palace to Parliament the King rode through the modern European section of Cairo.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 30.--Out in the open sea off well-named No Man's Land and the bluff sand dunes of wave-pounded Block Island, another British yacht tomorrow will start the sixteenth attempt to recapture the America's Cup, taken eighty-six years ago by the schooner America in a race around the Isle of Wight, off the south coast of England.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.;

You can't separate a sailor from superstition and good luck tokens. Ranger's forecastle is an example. The professionals have a cherished head of a dog called Fido, from Rainbow. The head once fell from its perch and got thoroughly damaged, but the hands mended it as best they could and it's still doing business.
Discovery that Resolution "Island," Arctic formation north of Labrador, is not one large island but 500 small ones was reported today by wireless from the expedition of Commander Donald B. MacMillan.
Albert N. Gates, who was engaged in the insurance business for thirty-five years, died at his home here yesterday after a long illness. He was 50 years old.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are July 29 unless specified: Portland to San Francisco: Astoria, Chicago, Indianapolis, Minneapolis. Marblehead, New Orleans, Northampton, Pensacola. Quincy. Relief. Richmond, Salt Lake City, Trenton, Tuscaloosa. At Balboa: Babbitt, Taylor.

Paul Schmidt upheld the honor of Estonia by winning first prize in a field of eight in an international chess masters tournament concluded today. Schmidt had a score of 5 1/2--1 1/2, one point ahead of his countryman, Paul Keres, Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia and G. Stahlberg of Sweden. These three all scored 4 1/2 points.

The skippers of the contending America's Cup sloops today received final instructions by letter from the race committee of Edmund Lang, Walter L. Coursen and George M. Pynchon of the New York Yacht Club.

TIENTSIN--Japanese spokesmen said Chinese forces had been routed from a district 100 miles wide extending from the Yungting River, west of Peiping, to Tanku. The brigades that attacked Tientsin were in retreat after suffering heavy losses.
Flanked by a vast Ladies' Day crowd of 38,000, whose shrieks were more or less bound to be disconcerting, the Giants put in something of a hysterical afternoon today as they

The National Labor Relations Board late today ended its six weeks' hearing of the Ford Motor Company on charges of violating the Wagner act and of unfair labor practices. Permission was granted to Louis J. Colombo Sr., Ford attorney, to present further rebuttal testimony within ten days.
Cotton mill activity declined more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index eased to 130.5 from 134.0. This compares with 123.2 for the week ended July 25, 1936.

Johnny Bellis, 135, New Haven, Conn., stopped Eddie Alzek, 135, New York, in 1:20 of the third round of a scheduled ten-round bout at the Long Beach Stadium tonight. A crowd of 2,000 saw Referee John Walsh stop the fight after Rellis

A good-sized audience was seeing a movie last night at the Greenwich Theatre, Greenwich Avenue and West Twelfth Street, when the picture suddenly vanished from the screen and the house lights went on. The sound machine scratched

Mrs Blanche Goldfarb, a leader in Jewish philanthropic, welfare and religious circles, was married to Isaac Gilman, a paper manufacturer, on Wednesday morning in the penthouse suite of J. David Stern at the Post Building.

Senator Vandenberg of Michigan has written a letter to President Green of the American Federation of Labor, defending his proposed amendments to the National Labor Relations Act as accepting "the new American concept of statutory collective bargaining."
J. Clarence Davies has arranged, for the estate of Louisa Davies, a first-mortgage loan of $40,000 at 4 per cent on the business property, 60x90, on the n w cor of 3d Ave and 151st St.
The Board of Tax Appeals decided today that Edward S. Harkness of New York City was $154,321 deficient In his 1932 income tax payments. The Bureau of Internal Revenue had assessed him $154,844.

The Senators shelled Earl Whitehill and Lloyd Brown for eighteen hits to defeat Cleveland, 13 to 2, while Jimmy De Shong held the Indians to six hits to score his eleventh pitching victory of the year today.

Asserting that President Roosevelt had been misinformed when he defended the National Labor Relations Board Tuesday, Representative Rankin of Mississippi accused the board today of having set up "intolerable inquisitions" which threatened to "wreck Southern and Western industry."

Plans for altering buildings in Manhattan were among the construction projects submitted yesterday. The changes will be made in housing properties. Filing was heavy in Queens, where many homes will be erected.
The Buffalo Bisons defeated Jersey City in both ends of a double-header today, taking the first in thirteen innings, 6-4, and the second in seven innings, 2 to 1.

MANHATTAN BROWN, KATHARINE L. (May 23, 1936). Gross assets, $164,123: net, $150,028. To Henry Douglas Brown, husband, residue. Chief assets, transfers, $125,922. Lott and Livingston, attorneys, 164 Montague St., Brooklyn.
The Board of Estimate, with every member a candidate for reelection or election to a higher office, met yesterday at City Hall in a session steeped in politics.
A joint Congressional tax committee, in agreement on proposed methods for sealing revenue-law loopholes, arranged today to put their recommendations into bill from by early next week.
Governor Murphy's attempt to press a revised industrial relations bill through the special session of the Legislature which convened at 2 P. M. today is apparently doomed to failure.

Two five-story walk-up buildings containing thirty apartments at 207 and 209 West 115th Street were sold by the Tornado Realty Company, Melville Levy, president, to a client of Edward Gould, attorney.

The glass bottle manufacturing industry has agreed to complete unionization of all its employes and will cooperate with the Glass Bottle Blowers Association of the United States and Canada, an A. F. of L. union, in bringing about the unionization as speedily as possible.

At a meeting of the Board of Regents of the University of the State of New York at 80 Center Street yesterday, Dr. James Byrne of 25 Sutton Place announced his retirement as chancellor because of "health and personal affairs."
Italy's desire to improve relations with Britain was eloquently emphasized today by the seizure of a humorous paper for printing sarcastic remarks about Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden.

The Newark Bears smashed their way back into the victory column tonight as they defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 6 to 4, behind the pitching of Steve Sundra, who was credited with his twelfth victory of the campaign.

The Cornell-Dubilier Electric Corporation has notified the New York Curb Exchange that it will offer shareholders of Dubilier Condenser Corporation of record of Aug. 3 the right to subscribe at $10.75 a share to one share of Cornell-Dubilier common stock for each ten shares of Dubilier Condenser common stock held.
The fourteenth German radio exhibition was opened here today by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels, who announced that a new "people's radio" would be sold at 59 marks, beginnine today.

For a consideration of $3,000, a mortgage on 63 James St on which there is now due $16,750, was assigned by Henry W. J. Bucknall to Charles J. Rinaldi. A $3,500 mortgage on 277 Madison St was assigned by Aaron Kramer to Louis Zacher.

A revised bill to regulate bondholders' protective committees under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 was introduced in the House today by Representative Lea, chairman of the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, who said the committee would consider the revised measure in place of the original one.

A second successive triumph by the Eight-Meter yacht Norseman today virtually assured the Royal Canadian Yacht Club, Toronto, of retention of the Commodore George H. Gooderham Cup, one of the two principal trophies for which Lake
Ending abruptly a quiet conference over division of household properties, Alfredo Codona, former aerialist, killed himself today after firing five bullets into his former wife, Mrs. Vera Eruce Codona
Champion Johnny Levinson of Kennebunk, Me., won two matches today to gain the semi-final round in defense of his New England amateur golf title at Ekwanok.

The Procter Gamble Company reported yesterday for the year to June 30 a high record net income of $26,803,339 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and a reserve of $592,524 for surtax on undistributed profits. This was equal after

Funeral services for Tom Bodine, editor and publisher of The Paris Mercury, will be held here tomorrow after his request that his body lie in state in the newspaper office "while the presses are running" has been fulfilled. He died last night
It was so warm at the North Pole that four Soviet weather observers had to haul snow for drinking water, they reported today.

Total net sales of 547 manufacturers in the United States increased 11.7 per cent in June, 1937, over June, 1936, while 1,105 wholesalers reported an increase of about 15 per cent, the Commerce Department announced today through a joint survey of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce and the National Association of Credit Men.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
The July grand jury recommended today that Chicago high schools "insert in their curricula a course in criminology, particularly in regard to sex crimes." Adding an oral

James J. Cummings, retired leather manufacturer who was in business in Newark for many years, died today in his automobile while being driven home from the seashore, where he had suffered an attack of acute indigestion.

The fifty-eighth annual Northfield General Conference of Christian Workers will open tonight at East Northfield, Mass., for sessions lasting two weeks, ending Aug. 15. The final three days of the conference will be devoted to a celebration of the 100th anniversary of the birth of Dwight L. Moody, evangelist, who founded the Northfield Schools and Conferences in 1880.

With the early response to August promotional events showing progressive improvement, retail trade here made a good comparative showing this week. Department store executives estimated the average gain for the local area at 8 per cent or better for the week.

To enforce its demand for a closed shop, the United Sugar Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, called a sit-down strike today at the plant here of the National Sugar Refining Company of New Jersey, halting all production.

The two abutting four-story apartment buildings at 152-54 Kensington Avenue and 269 Jewett Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., which occupy an entire blockfront on West Side Avenue, have been sold by the Realty Rights Corporation to an investing client of the Bedford, Pavitt Company, Inc., for cash above a mortgage of $117,000.
Who rests content with Lethe's kiss. In fixed and final attitude, Shall know the glory of eternal bliss And the cloistered song of solitude.
For a month now scanners of the mackerel skies of international politics have observed a hole in the clouds in one storm area. Tension between

Farmers of the Central New Jersey potato belt who are desirous of getting the latest official information on potato prices, car movements, loadings, holdings, digging and the weather will have a new service, beginning Monday.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP).The Treasury has five field representatives working to stimulate the sale of "baby bonds," officials said today. They keep in touch with

Thanking the Cardinals, Bishops, and the clergy of this country, on whom he had called during his fourmonth visit, the Most Reverend Louis Shvoy, Bishop of Szekesfehervar (Alba Regia), Hungary, said yesterday that the thirty-fourth Eucharistic World Congress in Budapest next year would be a manifesstation of the closest possible solidarity of the Catholic world.

The Bank ofCanada today announced the sale, by tender, of $25,000,000 of Dominion of Canada short-term treasury bills, dated to expire on Nov. 1. Average price of the accepted bids was 99.83902 and the average yield .633 per cent.

Liquidation developed in corn futures on the Board of Trade here today and all deliveries declined to or within a small fraction of a cent a bushel of the permissible limit of 4 cents a bushel. Oats and soy bean futures

A total of $4,976,526.59 in departmental budget estimates for 1938 has been presented at hearings before Assistant Director of the Budget Kenneth Dayton, a resume yesterday of the first three sessions showed. This figure represents an

The Cash Office of Foreign Credits, Budapest, which recently announced an offer to resume partial interest payments to foreign holders of sixty-five issues of Hungarian municipal, ecclesiastical and private long-term bonds, has notified holders that it is trying to make arrangements with paying agents for the various issues for

Mrs. F. S. Harris's Breezing Along, reserved off the early pace set by Gilbert Elston, came from behind today in a stretch drive to win the Air Line Hostess claiming purse, mile and a sixteenth feature at Suffolk Downs to pay $5.60.
Price increases of $15 to $35 on several models of the 1937 Ford cars were announced today, to go into effect Monday.

Miss Lolotte Chelsea Taintor of 584 Jefferson Avenue died this morning after a brief illness. She was born in this city sixty-four years ago, the daughter of the late Charles Chelsea Taintor and Margaretta Haines Taintor.
Word has been received here of the death on Wednesday at Sitka, Alaska, of Professor Frederick B. Loomis of Amherst College, geologist and paleontologist, at the age of 63. Professor Loomis was on a

Thirty-six present and former employes of Seth K. Ames, former head of a dairy products chain, would receive legacies ranging from $1,000 to $50,000 under his will just filed in Middlesex Probate Court. To Grace Grant of Bangor,

PARIS, June 30.--For the first time in history the French Government today adopted a ruling which set limit on extra budgetary expenditures for the coming year. By this measure George Bonnet, Finance. Minister, expects to take a large step toward obtaining a truly balanced budget instead of a fair balance of regular expenditures and a sliding scale on supplementary credits which, in reality, maintains the budget deficit constantly.

A transition from the manufacture of explosives to other manufacturing fields as the more important phase of its activities was reported by the Hercules Powder Company in its statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to cover registration of an issue of no-par value common stock valued at $4,471,350.

In as thrilling a women's tennis match as Seabright has seen in many years, Miss Alice Marble of Los Angeles, the national titleholder, averted disaster by the thin margin of a stroke today to score her first victory in four meetings with Miss Jadwiga Jedrzejowska, the champion of Poland.

A new $40,000 municipal bathhouse at Hudson Park, on Long Island Sound, will be opened tomorrow by City Manager Irving C. Brower, Mayor Harry Scott and other city officials. The last concrete walks on the approaches were laid at noon today.

In what might be called a prelude to the America's Cup Race, the Eastern Yacht Club ran a contest today for the English challenger Endeavour of three years ago, the then defending Rainbow and the 7-year-old campaigner Yankee.

Habitual hunters of heavyweight title bouts (there are some here) suffered acutely from nostalgia tonight. There was none of the mining-camp atmosphere of pre-battle evenings in this stronghold of the elite. Neither of the principals declared, "I'll take him in four heats. I never felt better in my life." Neither even voiced the old saw, "May the best boat win."

Class 1, Model Saddle Horses-First, S. M. Stewart's b. m. Myra Stewart; second, Raymar Farm's ch. m. Mountain Sparkle; third, Trillora Farm's ch. g. First Ace; fourth, Raymar Farm's ch. m. Broadway Melody.

Miss Elizabeth Dixon Clark, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Austin Clark, gave a large supper tonight on the beach in front of the Southampton Beach Club for members of the OxfordCambridge tennis team, who will play here tomorrow at the Meadow Club against the Meadow Club team and the United States Junior Davis Cup squad.

New bond financing this week was restricted exclusively to the tax-exempt field with a total of $43,812,000 in new issues placed on the market. This compares with a total of $60,795,000 in new bonds placed last week, and with $66,060,168 offered during this week a year ago.

The Military Affairs Committee of the Senate at a meeting yesterday morning deferred until the next session of Congress consideration of a series of bills seeking to investigate or restrict exports of scrap iron and steel.
Mr. and Mrs. Garrett Van Siclen Ryerson of 1,808 Newkirk Avenue, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Ryerson, to Norman Edward Pym Codrington, son of

The Securities and Exchange Commission authorized today the Lone Star Gas Corporation of Delaware to borrow $10,000,000 from a group of banks and permitted a subsidiary, the Lone Star Gas Company of Texas, to borrow $6,000,000.

Miss Geraldine Schwabe, daughter of Mrs. Henry Salz of 1,225 Park Avenue and the late Joseph M. Schwabe, was married yesterday afternoon at the home of her mother to Leo H. Hirsch Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo H. Hirsch, also of this city.

Churning wakes of foam through Long Island Sound and Buzzards Bay, most of America's Atlantic Coast flotilla of pleasure yachts today and tonight were steering courses for Newport to find somehow sea room for anchoring in a harbor already jammed and overcrowded with earlier arrivals who wouldn't miss a cup race for all the salt in the ocean.

The total of round-lot transactions on the New York Stock Exchange for the week to July 3. showed 622,420 more shares sold than in the previous week and member trading increased from 20.27 to 21.56 per cent of the total, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

A proposal for new rates for electricity supplied by the Queensboro Gas and Electric Company was filed today with the Public Service Commission which it is estimated would save users $223,000 annually.

In an effort to determine the opinion of lawyers on the question of a constitutional amendment limiting the power of the Supreme Court or granting additional power to the Federal Government, the National Lawyers Guild announced yesterday a referendum of its members on the subject was under way.

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard yesterday dismissed a suit for an injunction and accounting brought by Miss Susan Lawrence Davis against the Macmillan Company, publishers of Margaret Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind."

The University of the State of New York was created before the Constitution of the United States was adopted and has for more than a century and a half been governed by a Board of Regents. The Legislative Manual of the

Virginia Cherrill of the movies was married today, after waiting ten minutes for the bridegroom, to the ninth Earl of Jersey at the Chelsea Register Office, a couple of miles from the Caxton Hall Register Office, where she was married to Cary Grant, the actor, in 1934. The Earl also had been married before.

Murray McConnel, penthouse in 115 E 90th St, through Culver, Hollyday Co. H. Shelby Elliott, duplex in cooperative building at 155 E 72d St, through Brett Wyckoff, Inc., agents; Helen Harbeck, in 145 E 49th St. through the Cruikshank Co.; Edward S. Kleinmann, in 60 E 96th St, through Pease Elliman, Inc., agents; Port Burke, Inc., brokers.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Willis Phelps were dinner hosts last night at their apartment in the WaldorfAstoria. The couple, who celebrated their birthdays, had as their guests their son and daughter-inlaw, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond W. Phelps; the latter's aunt, Miss Mae Bentley of San Francisco; Miss Edith Lewis and Mrs. Kenneth Phelps of Larchmont, N. Y.
Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES. The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated July 29:
Parisians have seen the cost of living rise 22 per cent in the last year, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce said today.

The Bureau of Air Commerce granted Jimmy Mattern today a permit, effective "early next year," for a flight across the North Pole to Moscow, and the pilot said tonight he intends to take off next June or July on the flight.

The marriage of Miss Annette Flanagan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Flanagan of Brooklyn and this community, to George Duncan Fraser of Omaha, Neb., son of Mrs. William Fraser and the late Mr. Fraser, took place this afternoon in the formal gardens of the Crescent Hamilton Country Club.

The report of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania for the twelve months to June 30 shows a net income, after all expenses and charges, of $10,871,180, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $8.70 a common share, comparing with a net of $9,418,444, or $7.38 a common share. in the year to June 30, 1936. Gross revenues for the twelve months amounted to $67,483,751, as compared with $62,939,561 in the preceding comparable period.
Harold Davidson, the former rector of Stiffkey, who was clawed by a lion Wednesday night while talking from the cage as a side show performer at Skegness, died of his wounds today.

Referee Oscar W. Ehrhorn yesterday signed orders approving the sale for $7,250,000, to the International Match Realization Company, Ltd., of Bermuda, of a substantial block of assets held by the Irving Trust Company, as trustee in bankruptcy for International Match Corporation.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Lt. Col. Fred M. Green, Coast Artillery Corps, will proceed on or about Aug. 1 from New York, N. Y., to Fort Totten, N. Y., for temporary duty in connection with Organized Reserves activities at that station, and upon completion of this temporary duty, on or about Aug. 14, he will return to his proper station, New York, N. Y.

A motion to withdraw the answers of Charles G. Dawes and the City National Bank to a suit by stockholders of the old Central Republic Bank and Trust Company to recover $8,000,000 was filed today before Judge James F. Fardy.
Awards of air-mail contracts on four recently advertised routes were announced today by Postmaster General Farley. They were:

Few of the Summer homes in the city have not one or more guests for the America's Cup yacht races and they with their hosts will be out tomorrow to see the first of the series between Ranger, the defender, and Endeavour II, the challenger. The harbor was filled with yachts tonight and the majority of them had guests aboard.

It may be doubted whether any performance of Mozart's "The Magic Flute" in all the 146 years of its history ever has been awaited with such high pitched anticipation as tonight's at the Festspielhaus under Arturo Toscanini.

Miss Marion E. O'Connell, daughter of the late Representative David J. O'Connell and the late Mrs. Mary Agnes O'Connell, died yesterday at her home, 1,489 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, after a short illness. A former registered nurse,
Ministerial Director Hoffmann of the Air Ministry announced at a meeting of airport directors here tonight that a revolving dirigible hangar planned for Frankfort on the Main would be completed.

Mrs. Margaret Emerson sent word today to Brill Brill, her auctioneers at Holmwood, that an offer of $15,000 for the 162-acre farm made yesterday by Helm George Wilde of New York City would not be accepted. For that reason farm implements were not placed on sale today, as scheduled.

Usually there is something for the harassed suburban and country dweller to worry about. We mentioned a few days ago the Japanese beetle, that voracious and unwelcome alien which brings harm to more than 200 species
The Soviet Russian Government agreed yesterday to use 100,000 square feet of space in the New York World's Fair, 1939, for displays of the Russian Government and Russian industries.
Joshua Clifton Mallalieu, president for the last seventeen years of George W. Millar Co., Inc., paper merchants, died after a long illness at his home, 168 Kilburn Road, here today. His age was 62.
The Northeast Harbor fleet sailed its final race of the July series today with forty-six boats bucking a southerly breeze to cross the finish line.

The annual Village Improvement Society Fair, held on the public playground here this afternoon, was thronged with hundreds of visitors from all the Hamptons. Mrs. William R. Maloney, general chairman, was aided in planning the fair by Miss Mary Pruyn, Mrs. Winthrop Gardiner, Mrs. Howard Morris, Mrs. J. W. Hand and Mrs. Jeremiah Huntting.
The closing exercises of the Citizens Military Training Camp were held this morning on the parade grounds.

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden expressed his belief today on the eve of the threemonth adjournment of Parliament that the Spanish situation would not change decisively one way or another in coming months.

Ten physicians, including the husband of a Tammany politician; seven attorneys, a high-pressure insurance agent, called a "conservator"; another insurance agent and twenty policy holders accused of submitting claims for simulated disabilities were indicted yesterday for mail fraud and conspiracy.

Forrest McMullen is retiring as a partner of Bennett Brothers Johnson, effective today. Neisner Brothers, Inc. common stock, no par value, has been stricken from listing and registration. It previously was suspended from dealings upon changing to $1 par value.

Two film celebrities' homes were robbed of jewelry and other valuables estimated at $33,000 in daring burglaries early today. Police reported about $25,000 in jewelry and expensive table furnishings were taken from the home of Gary Cooper, and that gems worth $7,863 were stolen from Sol Wurtzel, producer.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days.
Whether Skipper Sopwith or Skipper Vanderbilt carries off the America's Cup is still open to settlement, but neither will leave here emptyhanded. The city of Newport has

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 5,000, including 1,500 directs. Hogs from 230 pounds down and packing sows were 10c-15c higher than Thursday's average; butchers, 240 pounds up, were steady to 10c higher; bulk good and choice 180-230 pounds, $12.85-$13.10; top, $13.20; 150-170 pounds, $12.75-$13; 240-300 pounds, S12-S12.85.

The mother and the estranged wife of Stanley Allen Martin Jr., 29-year-old automobile salesman, charged with strangling Mrs. Florence Jackson, attractive 37-year-old Jackson Heights matron, on a lonely road in Queens early Tuesday, came to his aid with legal counsel yesterday, as the body of his victim was being, buried in Evergreen Cemetery, Ridgewood.

Sussex, beaten by an innings and five runs by Lancashire, relinquished the runner-up position to Middlesex in the English county cricket competition today. Middlesex defeated Worcestershire by an innings and one run yesterday.
Over-the-counter dealers yesterday appeared completely calm following the New York Curb Exchange's rule changes, which were generally interpreted as an attempt to cut into their field.

MANHATTAN BUTTNER, BERNHARD (July 22). Estate, less than $2,000. To Max Buttner, father, Thuringen, Germany, residue. Morris Steinhardt, 650 West End Ave., and Stephen Lamberger, 104 W. 70th St., executors.

Competition in the Eastern Polo League will enter its eighth week tomorrow with eight of the twelve teams in the circuit scheduled to see action. The only unbeaten outfit, Evergreen Farms, will attempt to make the Bethpage Polo Club its sixth league victim when they come together at the Bethpage State Park in Farmingdale, L. I.

From away back in the deep shadows of impending defeat, young Bobby Murray of Montreal fought his way into the final of the men's singles in the Canadian lawn' tennis championships today and averted what would have been the tournament's major upset.

The National Labor Relations Board announced today that it had certified the American Radio Telegraphists Association as the exclusive bargaining agent of the "live traffic" employes of R. C. A. Communications, Inc., in the New York metropolitan area.

Former Queen Victoria Eugenia of Spain, heavily veiled, motored alone from Germany today to pay a visit to former Kaiser Wilhelm of Germany. She remained indoors with the former Kaiser and was not seen walking in the grounds.

Chinese Central Government troops numbering 50,000 are reported moving north from Paoting. Their main bodies are at Chochow, about forty miles south of Peiping, and advance parties have reached Changsintien. twenty-five miles farther along.

An additional step in the program of the Linen Trade Association to stamp out false and misleading advertising of linens was taken yesterday, when the organization sent a lengthy bulletin to members, outlining how the word linen should be used and citing some of the objectionable practices.

A renewed demand for short-term credit for commercial and industrial purposes and, on the other hand, an increased demand for investment securities by investors, other than the weekly reporting member banks, were reflected by developments in the money market in the last month, according to The Monthly Review of credit and business conditions, issued today by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

To sports Editor of The New York Times: I'm afraid that the men who cover sports in the New York area lose their sense of perspective, especially on baseball. When it is either the Yanks or the Giants they see in action, they must forget the punishment that occasionally is visited upon some of the outlving sectors.

ALFRED, N.Y., July 30 (AP).--Alfred University received its ancient thirty-five-chime carillon today with bells and heraldry. Shirt-sleeved faculty members, alumni and villagers formed a parade to bear the carillon from railroad car to campus, while from church and college hall a chorus of bells pealed a welcome.
Trade will reach a "highly satisfactory level" in the last three months of the year, the American Federation of Labor predicted today.

By HENRY BRADY Broadway, 5,008-16: 6-story brick apartment and stores, 118.7x70xirreg; Ignatius Fischl against Isham Park Corp; due, $58,020; subject to mortgage of $185,000; to plaintiff for $185,500.
The Warner Brothers Company will conduct a five-day corset training course in the Hotel Astor starting on Monday.
Ed (Dutch) Brandt, pitching a brilliant two-hit shut-out for the Pirates, defeated the veteran Guy Bush and the Bees, 1 to 0, today in one of the year's tightest mound duels.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 24 amounted to 70,980 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 905 cars, or 0.1 per

Increase of the purchasing power of wage-earners so that more goods produced by industry could be consumed was urged by Secretary Perkins in a radio address tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System.
Orrick Johns, poet, novelist and former editor of The New Masses, married here today Mrs. Doria Berton Jordan of New York.

The original gong used by Major Bowes in his radio hour clanged tonight at Oakland Farm, the Portsmouth home of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt, in connection with the amateur hour in which members of the Summer colony were the performers. The "hour" followed a large dinner given in the open by Mr. and Mrs. Vanderbilt.

A campaign to enforce the law prohibiting truck drivers from working more than ten consecutive hours or ten hours in fourteen in a split working period was announced yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 30 (AP).--Arthur Rogers Boyden, feature writer of The Evening Gazette, died here today of a heart attack at the age of 54. He had been a member of The Gazette staff since last Spring, when he returned to the paper, where he became a reporter at the age of 18.

Officials of a number of industrial concerns and civic associations of New Jersey attended funeral services here today for John White Howell, an associate of the late Thomas Alva Edison in the development of the incandescent lamp.

Thirteen cruising yachts set sail at noon today in the Bayside Yacht Club's seventeenth annual race to Block Island and return, one of the blue ribbon long distance events of the local season. While the fleet
The two-week Franco-American ceremonies for the formal dedication of the American battle monuments abroad opened here today with several gatherings.

On the eve of the first race for the America's Cup, the city of Newport was humming with activity. A harbor filled with craft of every sort added to the population that has been growing steadily during the past few days with the arrival of visitors from many sections of the country.

Arlington Park will become the racing ground tomorrow for the classiest 2year-olds on the American turf. Eleven have been named to race three-quarters of a mile in the richly endowed Arlington Futurity, which will have a gross value of close to $50,000.

Federal steamboat inspectors today began an inquiry into the fire which wrecked the Chesapeake Bay liner City of Baltimore, causing the loss of two lives and the rescue of ninety passengers and crew in Chesapeake Bay, off Seven Foot Knoll, last night. Two persons are reported missing.

The group of Federal Theatre Project supervisors and others studying at the Vassar Experimental Theatre this evening put on Arthur Arent's "One-third of the Nation." It is the story of the housing problem in the United States, done in the manner of the living newspaper's productions.

Max Marston of Philadelphia, a six-time winner, and Jimmy Lee of Danbury, Conn., Georgetown's 1937 team captain, today took command in opposite halves of the draw after winning first and second round matches in Schenecossett's eighteenth annual invitation tournament.

Southern Senators united today in a strong attack on the Wages and Hours Bill as one which could destroy business, large and small, by "administrative fiats," and as a measure to crush the economic advance of the South.
The International Longshoremen's Association has issued charters to the United Licensed Officers Association and two groups of unlicensed maritime personnel, it was learned yesterday. The officers'
The State Supreme Court ruled today that the marriage of 12-year-old Virginia Deremer to Ernest B. Johnson of Mankato, Minn., did not remove her from jurisdiction

The writer of the following letter, a New York lawyer, was a member of Congress from 1905 to 1911 and again from 1915 to 1917. He was a delegate to and official parliamentarian of the Republican National Convention of 1916.
Thirty dead and forty injured was the casualty list tonight for yesterday's railway wreck at Villeneuve-Saint-Georges, outside Paris.
The Davis Cup went West today. The tall, red-haired boy who won it, Donald Budge, carried it aboard the train at Waterloo Station and started it back to its original home in the United States.

Operators were active yesterday in the purchase of apartment properties in the Bronx. Samuel Preiser bought the sixstory elevator apartment house on a plot 200 by 100 feet at 2,850 Claflin Avenue through Bailenson Chinick, brokers. Assessed at $285,000,
Oleomargarine production in the United States shows a drop of 4,000,000 pounds from the half-yearly figures of 1936, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce stated today.

This is the story of a man who gave but did not receive. On the desk of Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne in Albany the other day was a simple, hand-written note from Frank A. Weichbrodt of Rochester.

A blue-ribbon jury in the Brooklyn Supreme Court returned a verdict last night of guilty of murder in the first degree against Fred J. Hull for the killing of Samuel Drukman on March 3, 1935. Hull thereby faces a mandatory sentence of death in the electric chair, although eighteen months ago he was convicted of second degree murder for the same crime and sentenced to serve from twenty years to life imprisonment.
Secretary Perkins decided today that the minimum wage for seamless hosiery mill employes working on Government orders shall be 35 cents an hour, or $14 for a 40-hour week.

Events in the Far East throw fresh light on the defects of an American foreign policy prescribed by an inflexible law which attempts to anticipate all possible emergencies regardless of when and where and in what circumstances they may arise and what their impact on our own affairs may be.

Some of the dues paid by members of Chicken Drivers Local 167 to their union went into the bank account of a fictitious woman and were used to pay personal bills of Arthur (Tootsie) Herbert, business agent, while he was temporarily "away" in jail, the jurors in the poultry racket trial were told yesterday.

Natives brought word here today that the two New York City youths who set out last year in a canoe for Nome, Alaska, had passed a village on the Yukon River a week ago and were two weeks ahead of schedule.

On Monday evening Ozzie Nelson and his orchestra, with Shirley Lloyds as vocalist, will start an engagement on the roof of the Hotel Astor. They are replacing Ted Lewis, who has been in charge for the last month. Featured in the revue will be Lathrop Brothers and Virginia Lee, dancers and singers; Bob Dupont, comedian and juggler, the Olympic Trio and several others.
More than 100 boats started in almost a dead calm today in the first races on the two-day program of the Chester River Yacht and Country Club.

National Aviation CorporationJune 30: Indicated liquidating value, $7,616,216, equivalent to $15.95 a share after allowing for estimated normal Federal tax on unrealized appreciation, compared with $7,668,712, or $16.07 a share, on Dec. 31, and $7,292,410, or $15.27 a share, on June 30, 1936.

Roy D. Chapin, Secretary of Commerce under President Hoover and former president of the Hudson Motor Car Company, left a net estate of $7,311,616, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday by Deputy Commissioner Jacob I. Manicoff. Mr. Chapin died on Feb. 16, 1936, of pneumonia in Detroit after a short illness.

One of the largest groups of sunspots in history is now moving across the surface of the sun, the Carnegie Institution of Washington said today. The "spots" form a chain 125,000 miles long and cover an area of 3,800,000,000 square miles. They can be seen without a telescope if a piece of smoked glass or dark photographic film is held in front of the eyes.

Danno O'Mahoney, 225, Ireland, pinned Benny Feldman, 280, New York, with a back flip and body hold after 14:36 of the wind-up match of a wrestling show at the Coney Island Velodrome last night, The Associated Press reported.

An invitation to the United States to send a plane over the polar route from this country to Russia was extended yesterday by Major Andrei Yumasheff, co-pilot of the Russian plane which recently made a record-breaking flight from Moscow to California.

Mrs. Miriam L. Cohn's Mountain Sparkle, 4-year-old chestnut mare, was one of the outstanding stars on the opening day of the fourth annual Long Branch Horse Show on the grounds of the Raymar Farms estate today.

Negotiations at New York between the Brazilian Finance Mission and the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council failed to materialize in an immediate agreement, and the matter will receive further study in Brazil, according to a joint statement by the council and the mission made public today at the Brazilian Embassy.

General and Mrs. J. W. Kilbreth of New York were dinner hosts tonight at their residence, Sunset Cottage. Guests included Miss Gertrude Sampson, Edward Ilsley, Mr. and Mrs. George Batcheller, Mr. and Mrs. J. Brooks Fenno, Mr. and Mrs. Timothee Adamowski and Dr. and Mrs. W. E. Patterson.

George S. Beckwith of Pine Plains, a Spanish War veteran, who was associated for thirty-seven years as statistician and accountant with a wholesale paper manufacturing firm, died here Tuesday night of heart disease. He was 61 years old.

C. William Pfeil, who retired last Oct. 1 after serving as Tax Assessor of this township for twenty-nine years, died in Presbyterian Hospital, Newark, last night after an operation. He was 64 years old.

Sometimes a general state of affairs is much more clearly understood if one typical section of it is detached for close study. Much light may be thrown, for example, on the present economic difficulties in France by considering the stagnation in the building industry there and its causes.
The navy is expected to ask Congress to appropriate funds at its present session for naval auxiliary construction authorized in a bill signed by President Roosevelt today.

By a vote of more than four to one, with the representatives of two Assembly districts not voting, the executive committee of the New York County Committee last evening endorsed Mayor La Guardia for renomination on the Republican ticket. The action was taken on the recommendation of Kenneth F. Simpson, county chairman.

(In John Masefield's wake) I must go down to the seas again (and I hope the waves are small), And all I want is a wide ship that doesn't rock at all, And a mild breeze from sun-up through noontime to gloaming, And a slight spray-but no chop-and none of that foaming!
Michael Nicholas Morrissey, for twenty-five years active in the hotel and restaurant business here, died of heart disease at his home today after a long illness. His age was 44.

Installation of structural steel and ornamental iron and bronze work on some of the units of the Williamsburg Housing Project and some public buildings throughout the city is at a standstill as a result of a strike of iron and bronze craftsmen.

With Manager Mickey Cochrane in uniform for the first time since his skull was fractured by a pitched ball May 25, the Tigers lost a 6-5 teninning game to the Red Sox today, narrowing their third-place lead to only two games over Boston.
By way of emphasizing that she has recovered her early season form, Totem, the seven-year-old sixmeter aspirant for Gold Cup defense honors, today joined Rebel as a double victor,

Repretentative Clare E. Hoffmain (Rep.) of Michigan charged in a speech here today that the Senate Civil Liberties Committee "deliberately and maliciously failed to spread upon the record the true happenings at Chicago when John L. Lewis's organizers sent ten of their dupes to their deaths" at the Republic Steel Corporation riot.

Paris Winter openings got under way today with a bang as three important houses held showings. Up to the present time no very radical changes in silhouettes have appeared. Shoulders are smartly square. Lines are reasonably modified.

Phil Farley of Montreal today reached his first final for the Canadian amateur golf championship, and will tackle a formidable five-time champion, C. Ross Somerville of London, Ont., in the 36-hole wind-up tomorrow.

By JAMES R. MURPHY Boynton Ave, 1,353, dwelling, 25x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Esther Morris Goldstein; due, $19,460; to plaintiff for $500. Van Nest Ave, 1,203, dwelling, 20.6x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Maria Donatone; due, $5,596; to plaintiff for $500.

The Anti-Dumping Act of 1921 will not be invoked against Japan for alleged dumping of ammonium sulphate on the United States market, according to a recent ruling by the Treasury Department, made public today. Appraising officers who
Crop prospects have improved in Alberta, but crops in a wide area of Saskatchewan will be almost a total loss, according to the Bank of Montreal.

Left alone a few moments in a bathtub of the family home at 15 East 115th Street, Charles Pantoga, 17 months old, was drowned last night. Discovered by an older sister in the tub filled with water, the child was rushed to Harlem Hospital but died after an hour and a half in a respirator.

In honor of the Pittsfield Horse Show judges and exhibitors with their guests the annual horse show ball was held tonight at Pittsfield Country Club with 300 attending. It was the most important ball of the midsummer at Pittsfield. One hundred and twenty-five attended a dinner given by the Horse Show Association in advance at the clubhouse.
Mayor La Guardia asserted yesterday that the City Park Department under Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, had set a "world's record" in opening and maintaining new playgrounds.
Pensioned On his own application: SERGEANT-- Adolph E. Jaworsky, 48th Precinct, at $1,750 per annum. Appointed Oct. 9, 1911.
Napoleon spurred on his soldiers to victory on the Nile by reminding them that forty centuries looked down upon them from the

Sales in the air-conditioning industry will double last year's total of $50,000,000, according to J. K. Knighton, sales manager of commercial air conditioning for the Kelvinator Division of the NashKelvinator Corporation.

Mrs. Eva Bryant Taggart, widow of former United States Senator Thomas Taggart and mother of Thomas D. Taggart, Democratic National Committeeman for Indiana, died today at her home here of pneumonia after a long illness.

Adding a 68, four under par, to a similar score fashioned yesterday, Victor Ghezzi, tall professional of the Deal Golf Club, held a fourstroke lead over the field today at the halfway point in the New Jersey State open golf championship.

In the first transfer of the property since 1890 the five-story double flat at 426 East Eighty-third Street, in Yorkville, has been sold by the Anna Kunker estate to Rose Grossman for $10,000 in cash. Arthur Lichtner and Schindler Liebler were the brokers.

Regulation U, which prevented banks from making loans for buying or carrying any stock registered on a national securities Exchange in an amount exceeding the maximum loaning value of the collateral as prescribed from time to time, which now stands at 55 per cent, has been amended by the Federal Reserve Board to be retroactive, affecting loans made before May 1, 1936, as well as those of that date and thereafter, the board announced today.
Herman Mueller, a member of the Philadelphia Orchestra for twentyeight years, died at his home here yesterday after a year's illness. He was 65 years old.

Mrs. J. LeRoy Warner of this city, formerly of Brooklyn, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Doris Ann Warner, to John Conley 2d, son of Mrs. Louis D. Conley, also of this city and Ridgefield, Conn., and the late Colonel Conley. The announcement was made last night at a dinner given by the bride-elect's mother on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis
Sale of about $20,000,000 in preferred stock is contemplated by the Continental Can Company, Inc., O. C. Huffman, president, announced yesterday.

The Italian liner Conte di Savoia will carry a large list of notables for Mediterranean ports today. They include Fulvio Suvich, Italian Ambassador to the United States, with his wife; Prince Mikhail Alexandrovitch Goundoroff; A. G. Spalding, sports manufacturer;
Civil Service Commissioner Paul J. Kern announced yesterday that the commission had adopted a resolution abolishing promotional examinations for lower grade clerks. The resolution, he said,
General Sessions Judge Streit granted yesterday the request of District Attorney William C. Dodge for psychiatrists to examine Robert Irwin, sculptor and former

New railway loans for China totaling [Pound]7,000,000 at 5 per cent were negotiated today by the Chinese Government with the British and Chinese Corporation associated with the China Finance Corporation in Shanghai.
