Belgrade official circles intimate that the Government intends to continue its struggle against the Orthodox Church without relaxation. The next move is to prevent the election of a new patriarch until such time as the church is prepared to bow to the Government.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Oakley Fayerweather of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Fayerweather, to Maurice Shillington, son of T. Courtney Shillington of Belfast, Ireland.

The Garden City Publishing Company, Inc., Garden City, N. Y., has stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue "advertising or selling any book under a name or title different from that under which it previously had been published and sold," the commission announced today.

A plan to sell at cut prices those newspapers that have editorially opposed price maintenance, as exemplified by the Feld-Crawford law and the Miller-Tydings bill, is under consideration by the American Book Sellers Association and will be submitted to the Toilet Goods Association and the National Association of Retail Druggists, Dr. Crichton Clarke of the book group, and an ardent advocate of fair trade laws, revealed here yesterday.

With completion of his final round trip between New York and Philadelphia today, Thomas N. Watson, 70-year-old conductor; will end nearly forty-eight years of active service with the Pennsylvania Railroad.
5th St, 741 E, 34.6x97; Henry Stern to Manufacturers Trust Co., consideration $4,000, foreclosure. Avenue C. 154, 24x83; Esther Israel to Katherine Greenberg, 422 E 6th St; mtg $5,000 ($3).
Immediate concern over the plight of Americans in Peiping and Tientsin was less acute. today as a result of official reports from both cities that conditions were quieter and all Americans safe.
Payrolls in the furniture industry rose 45 per cent in the first six months of this year over the similar period of 1936, Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants, reported yesterday.

The council of the Actors Equity Association, following a special meeting at Equity headquarters, 45 West Forty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon, announced that with minor reservations it had approved the proposed constitution of the American Federation of Radio Artists.
Stocks closed steady and mixed in second slowest trading of the month; steel shares the feature; turnover, 615,000 shares. United States Government bonds higher, other issues firm;

Completing the new issues of George VI coins in Canada, the silver dollar and fifty-cent pieces are now in general circulation. The dollar is the same as that brought out in 1935 to commemorate the silver anniversary of King George V, except that it now bears the image of George VI. The new fifty-cent piece

An investing syndicate headed by William H. Jeffers has bought the four-story apartment and store property on the southwest corner of Mamaroneck Avenue and Quarropas Street, White Plains, Westchester. The building has

Four of the Scottsboro boys saw their first major league baseball game yesterday at the Yankee Stadium. Even though they said the game was "swell" and "fine-anddandy," they appeared to be unimpressed.

With the 1936-37 cotton season ending today, indications are that the export movement of United States cotton for the season just closing will be about 500,000 bales less than for the previous season.

National Tinsel Manufacturing Co., 30,000 sq. ft. in 19-27 West 21st St; Rubman, Ackerman Co., Inc., furs, in 134-40 W. 29th St; Jacob S. Levine, gifts and novelties, in 693-97 Broadway; M L Hess, Inc, broker.

The Continental Bank and Trust Company has been appointed trustee for $1,400,000 of certificates of the Second Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, following reorganization of the issue in the Federal court.

The Administration won a temporary victory in its fight for legislation continuing the present sugar control system today when Representative Jones, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, agreed to redraft his compromise bill to make it provide for unlimited imports of refined sugar from Hawaii and Puerto Rico.

Stockholders of the Transamerica Corporation will receive today their pro-rata share of the distribution of 2,297,840 shares of stock of Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association, which has a present cash value of $126,000,000, based on Bank of America market quotations.

Nineteen corporations and two individuals, accused by the government of being a monopoly in the $7,000,000-a-year household and industrial brush manufacturing trade, consented yesterday to an injunction sought by Homer S. Cummings, United States Attorney General, in Federal court here.

The "protection" which Myles A. Paige, the city's only Negro magistrate, promised Mrs. Dottie Morris when she appeared before him last week accused of the "abduction" of her 6-year-old son was continued yesterday when he refused to jail her pending the arrival of documents from Fayetteville, N. C.
The reduction of the village of Las Rozas, about ten miles northwest of Madrid, to a shambles of smoking ruins in an Insurgent air raid was witnessed by your correspondent this afternoon.

Quotations of foreign currencies varied only slightly in exceedingly dull trading in the foreign exchange market here yesterday. Sterling eased off 1/8 cent to close at $4.9711-16, while the French franc was unchanged at 3.75 cents.
Sir Hubert Wilkins returned from Europe yesterday confident that his seventeen-year-old ambition to see meteorological stations established in the south polar regions is now near realization.

The eleventh annual Pittsfield horse show opened at the Polo Grounds, Holmesdale, today with 1,000 attending.. All parking places were sold and competition was keen, with an entry list of 103 horses. Twenty-five classes were run off.

Further bitterness developed in the feud between Mayor S. Davis Wilson and representatives of the State Administration today when it was disclosed that city detectives had raided a hotel room and seized memoranda belonging to an attache of the legislative committee assigned to investigate the court system here.

Louis Bromfield has completed the last few pages of his new novel, "The Rains Came," during his voyage from France last week and since his arrival here. He will return to Europe early in August to stay until October. The novel will be published this Autumn by Harpers.
Dr. Charles D. Steenken, superintendent of the Maryland State Samtarium, died yesterday at Salisbury, Md., at the age of 66. For some years he was in practice in Baltimore.
After an early decline to the lowest levels for the cotton year which ends today, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and closed 1 point off to 4 points up.

The marriage of Miss Kathryn Charlotte Pierce, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Pierce of Milwaukee, to Roger Sanderson Hewlett, son of James Monroe Hewlett of Lawrence, L. I., and the late Mrs. Anna Willetts Hewlett, will take place on Tuesday in All Saints' Episcopal Church in Beverly Hills, Calif.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $5,842,240, to be represented by sixty-four municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $14,579,315 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the
The Maine-owned brown horse Hanover Peters, with P. H. Stuart of Mechanic Falls at the reins, scored his second Grand Circuit victory in the $600 3:12 trot today.
R. C. Norberg of Philadelphia won the Arthur H. Fenn Memorial Cup golf tournament today by chalking up a 4-and-3 verdict over P. T. Wadsworth of Montclair, N. J., in the final match.

Theodore Kiendl has been appointed chairman of the grievance committee of the New York City Bar Association, it was announced yesterday by former Secretary of State Henry L. Stimson, president of the organization.

Captain Newton Harris White Jr., U. S. N., and Mrs. White have come to the Weylin from Newport News, Va. Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Duff will leave the Beekman tomorrow for Coburgh, Ont., where they will visit Mr. and Mrs. George Oliver at Dungamon Farm.

Two men hidden in an alcove on the twenty-fourth floor of the Nelson Tower at 450 Seventh Avenue waylaid Isadore H. Pollack, a supervisor for the J. G. White Realty Corporation, at 1:50 P. M. yesterday and after clubbing him on the head with a blunt instrument fled with a $2,400 payroll.
A jeweler filed suit today for $100,000 against the estate of Colonel Edward H. R. Green, thus joining a list of litigants that includes two women and five States.

Assurance that the Navy Department would continue "to assist private industries that will be of service during war" has been given by Charles Edison, Acting Secretary of the Navy, to Francis G. Hunter, president of Local 1 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America.

The newsreel cameraman will receive his hour or so of glorification on the screen today with the arrival at the Globe of "I Cover the War," a melodrama set against the background of the desert of Mesopotamia. John Wayne plays the cameraman and is assisted by Gwen Gaze, Don Barclay and Pat Somerset .... "The Gold Racket"
A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. John R. Miller of Kew Gardens, Queens, on Wednesday at the Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L. I.

PEIPING, Saturday, July 31.--Japan's mechanized army, led by fifty tanks and supported by heavy artillery, broke down the last resistance of General Sung Chehyuan's vaunted Thirty-seventh Division, captured Marco Polo Bridge and marched almost unresisted into Changsintien, a strategic railway center twenty miles southwest of Peiping yesterday.

Industrial issues generally fared well in an active stock market today on the eve of the long bank holiday recess. Gilt-edged stocks mostly were steady, although China's and Japan's obligations gave up the major part of yesterday's rally. Brazilians and German issues, on the other hand, were firmer.
Trade movements were steadier this week, with retail sales advancing from 3 to 7 per cent over the total of the week preceding, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Paced by the Dons fine junior eight, Toronto sweep-swingers dominated the second day of the fifty-fifth Royal Canadian Henley Regatta today, but two United States crews qualified for the finals of the senior eight, most important event on the three-day program.
President Roosevelt left Washington tonight to spend the week-end on his yacht the Potomac. Because of the crisis in the Far East, he was undecided until late this afternoon whether or not to go.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and the Nanking Government played their game of war with Japan behind a wall of enigmatic silence yesterday. The immediate decisive action against Japanese invasion indicated by Chiang Kai-shek's warlike statement Thursday night not having materialized, observers are inclined

A report that President Roosevelt might promote a Federal Circuit Court judge to fall the vacancy on the Supreme Court created by the resignation of Justice Van Devanter gained some credence today and the name of Judge Sam G. Bratton of the Tenth Judicial Circuit was again prominently mentioned.

Detectives arrested Roy G. Ward, 38, of Hollywood, on a worthlesscheck charge today, then booked him on suspicion of murder on his own statement that he killed Alfred (Jake) Lingle, Chicago newspaper reporter, in 1930.

The marriage of Miss Dorothea Loebman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter T. Loebman of Garden City, to William Howard Gengarelly, son. of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Gengarelly of Glen Cove, will take place here on Aug. 29 in the Cathedral of the Incarnation.
LITCHFIELD, Conn. - Activity here is reaching its Summer peak. The Litchfield Cowboys will meet -the Washington Townies in a Western Connecticut League baseball game. here today.

The annual Ausable Club water sports carnival will be held next Saturday, with the winner of the largest number of points having his or her name inscribed on the club shield. Wildwood Cottage has been opened by Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Hunsaker of Boston, who are entertaining her sister, Miss Melanie Avery of New York.

A defense of Italy's attitude toward the Spanish conflict was expressed yesterday by Fulvio Suvich, Italian Ambassador to the United States, who sailed on the liner Conte di Savoia with his wife. They will have a month's vacation at home, returning to Washington in September.

The entire [Pound]107,351 estate of Lord Ormathwaite, an old friend of Queen Mary and the late King George V and former Master of Ceremonies to the royal household, is left in equal shares to the wife and two sons of his valet, Frederick Spary.
The war strikes deep here. The people are grave and anxious. There is a hurried and harassed air about the town that was not noticeable in Barcelona; which I visited before coming here.

An optional mortgage-life insurance plan which concerns the payment of the unpaid balance of a mortgage in the event of death of the wage-earner, as well as the continuance of monthly payments on a mortgage in case of disability, is now being offered by several mortgage lending institutions.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Rumsey Cowdrey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Lathrop Cowdrey of this place, to Frederick Blumers, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Blumers of Yonkers, N. Y., has been announced by her parents.

THEIR professional activities have been so tightly braided these past dozen years that there is a considerable legion of theatre conscious folk hereabouts who can't 'distinguish between Noel Coward and John C. Wilson.

The American Indian Federation asked Congress today to let the Indians run their own affairs. Tribal chieftains, in a sharp resolution. criticized Federal legislation designed to "help" the Indians and again attacked the administration of John Collier, Indian Commissioner.

The marriage of Miss Marietta L. Collins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Collins of this place, to Thomas J. Farrell of Brooklyn, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Farrell, took place this morning in the Church of the Infant Jesus, Port Jefferson, L. I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Henry Roex.

JOHANNES STEEL is the journalist who created a sensation with his articles on foreign affairs in The New York Post. He has the reputation of having forecast the Nazi blood purge that saw the end of Roehm and the power of the Brown Shirts along with the liquidation of von Schleicher and the counter revolution from the right.

Converts commemorated a century of English Mormonism today on the banks of the River Ribble near here. Heber J. Grant, president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints in the United States, unveiled a bronze plaque marking the spot where Heber Chase Kimball baptized nine persons in 1837.

The annual Elkan Naumburg memorial concert was given on the Mall in Central Park last night by the Naumburg Orchestra, under Jaffrey Harris. This yearly event held on the anniversary of the death of Mr. Naumburg, who donated the bandstand to the park, is contributed by his sons, Walter W. Naumburg and George W. Naumburg.

Speaking before thousands of men and women of all political parties who desired to learn the aims of the recently formed Republican Action party, Mariano Puga, its president, said the existing democratic system was obsolete and inadequate to meet present problems.
Fred B. Snite Jr. celebrated his twentyseventh birthday today as a "very cheerful" prisoner in the "iron lung," which has kept him alive for sixteen months.

Bumper crops and continued industrial recovery will bring the best Fall season for- department and specialty stores since 1929, the National Retail Dry Goods Association predicted yesterday in announcing the results of a nationwide survey,

While the Floating Hospital of the St. John's Guild was completing the first half of its season yesterday, the seventieth annual report of the organization, which strives "to afford relief to the sick children of the poor of New York City without regard to creed, color or nationality," was made public.
A fifteen-hit attack enabled the New York Athletic Club baseball team to down the Montclair Athletic Club, 9 to 6, today. Jack O'Connell,

Jassa Salganik, a portrait painter, died yesterday afternoon at his residence, 106 West 179th Street, of cancer, at the age of 50. Among the prominent persons painted by him are the late President Taft, the late Vice President Charles Curtis, Cardinal Hayes and Cardinal Mundelein.

The preparation and sale of souvenir books is an old custom which the Democratic National Committee took over last year to defray campaign expenses. Its volume, 384 pages, printed on good coated stock and well illustrated, was called "The Democratic Book 1936." It contained many things:

Announcement was made today by Mr. and Mrs. Duane Elson Kent of this city of the engagement of their elder daughter, Miss Helen Myrtle Kent, to Sanford Stowell Witherell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Leslie Witherell of Shoreham.

Miss Estelle L. Rose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond S. Rose of Rock Ridge, Greenwich, was married to Sherman Van Dien Stewart, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Stewart of Ridgewood, N. J., this afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Hughes of Ridgewood performed the ceremony in the home of the bride's parents.

THE same missionary fervor that supplied the Massachusetts Bay Colony with its first printing press enabled the New World to return the compliment to the Old nearly two hundred years later by setting up an American press on the island of Malta in the Mediterranean.

Governor LaFollette of Wisconsin conceded victory today to Governor Kraschel of Iowa on the latter's assertion that he could produce an Iowa stalk of corn two feet taller than the tallest Wisconsin could offer. He made the concession as he looked at an Iowa "skyscraper" whose height, in actual measurement, was 16 feet 51/2 inches, as against the Wisconsin entry's mark of 13 feet 11-3 inches.

SOUTHAMPTON, N. Y. - Tennis Week will open tomorrow on the courts of the Meadow Club. Although tennis traditions in Southampton go back much farther, this year's tournament will be the forty-seventh annual one under the sanction of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.
Dried-up security markets took a heavy toll in Illinois concerns doing business with the public in the year ended on June 30.

Members of the Greenwich Unit of the New York Junior League, of which Mrs. Simeon B. Chapin Jr. is chairman, are engrossed at present in raising funds through private donations for several league projects in this community.

Miss Rodeene Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roderick Lee Johnston of Plainfield, was married to Oliver Arnold Johnson of the same city today in All Saints Episcopal Church here by the rector, the Rev. Willis Parker.

Housing will remain a direct concern of the Federal Government for at least twenty years to come if the Wagner-Steagall bill, now pending in Washington, biecbxmes a law. The chances are that it will ie a perma-nent concern, for though tlhe bill limits the Government's liability to twenty years, its backers are thinking in long-range terms.

WILLEM VAN HOOGSTRATEN, the sixth and final conductor of the season at the Stadium, will direct his initial concert Tuesday night. Soloists this week at the Stadium are Jascha Heifetz, who will be heard Monday and Tuesday evenings, and Grace Castagnetta, pianist. on Saturday.

The tennis tournament scheduled to begin here on Monday afternoon has attracted many visitors to this colony. At the Woodstock Inn are Mr. and Mrs. George W. Caye of Yonkers, N. Y., Mr. and Mrs. William King of New York, Mr. and Mrs. E. B. Gaylord of Winsted, Conn.,

The Society of St. Johnland will be the beneficiary of the eighth annual North Shore Horse Show, which will be held this year on Aug. 20, 21 and 22 on the grounds of the Old Field Club, Stony Brook, L. I. There will be six sessions, two of which will be held at night under floodlights.

More than half of all the radio receiving sets owned in the world are within the borders of the continental United States, according to the electrical division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domextic Commerce of the United States Department

New Jersey College for Women has awarded 241 scholarships to deserving students of high scholastic standing for the coming year. Dean Margaret T. Corwin today announced the names of sixty seniors, sixty-four juniors, sixty-two sophomores and fifty-five incoming freshmen who are scholarship recipients.

Miss Edna E. Zielenbach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Zielenbach of this city, became the bride of Richard J. Higgins, son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Higgins, also of this city, in St. Genevieve's Catholic Church here this morning. The Rev. Bernard Peters of St. Benedict's Preparatory School, Newark, officiated.

BUK ULREICH has just completed two murals for the new postoffice at Columbia, Mo., which will be installed at once. This mural commission was carried out under the Treasury Department Art Project at Washington.

It is believed in Wall Street that the Hungarian Government will be able to fulfill the obligations incurred in the recent temporary settlement calling for a resumption of partial service on her external obligations because of the marked improvement in Hungary's exchange position and the caution exercised by her financial administration in making new committments.

So thick it dripped like rain, a murky fog blanketed the world's strangest, weirdest, most bizarre sports gallery late today as the spectator fleet crawled at slow speed into Newport, tired but contented.

President Winfred G. Leutner of Western Reserve University has announced a gift from Dr. Joseph P. Chamberlain, Professor of Public Law at Columbia University, of 500 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of Cleveland Cliffs Iron Company, worth about $46,000, to be added to the endowment of the university, the income to be used for the School of Applied Social Sciences.

COMMENTING on the fact that the State of Arizona reported 18.4 per cent of all drivers invoived in fatal automobile accidents as "had been drinking," while New York placed in this category only 1.8 per cent, the National Safety Council says:

A team of Whites and a Blue quartet played to an 8-all tie in a members' polo match on Waterbury field of the Meadow Brook Club today. A gathering of 200 spectators saw J. T. (Tom) Mather, who was at back for the Whites, deadlock the count at 8-all late in the sixth and final period on a short poke during a melee at the Blues' goal-mouth.

"In Praise of Ladies" I. B. S. wishes to recover the poem written while at colI. lege in 1922 entitled above, she thinks. It was an answer to C. P. Pullen's "In Praise of Boys," which began: "Thank God for boys! For the urge in them and the surge in them."

MANY of his readers, the old gentleman says, may still have some ties, how ever slender, with that almost forgotten era which immediately preceded Franklin D. Roosevelt's second term as President of the United States;

John J. Dineen, business man ana former theatrical operator, died this morning at his Summer home, Hampton Beach, N. H., according to word received here. Mr. Dineen retired from the theatrical business when he leased his local theatre to the Warner Brothers in 1935 and since that time has done much to build up Hampton Beach, where he had extensive holdings. He is survived by two daughters, one son and a brother.

Captain Robert Patrick French Darby MacGrath, formerly of the British Army and for the last ten years personnel director of the Melville Shoe Corporation of New York, died early yesterday at his home at 230 East Forty-eighth Street after a brief illness. A veteran of the Boer and World Wars, in both of which he was wounded, Captain MacGrath died of pneumonia following an operation on his arm.

Two new wings added to. the Agriculture Department's home are said by officials to have wrested the title of world's largest public office building from the Commerce Building, which forms the base for the cluster of government edifices known as the "Federal Triangle."

Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha prepared a new Cabinet list today for King Farouk. He submitted his Government's resignation, as required by the Constitution when a new King takes the Egyptian throne. He was immediately empowered to form a new one. Few changes were expected.

Mills College has obtained $400,000 toward its eighty-fifth anniversary endowment program in which $1,000,000 is sought for the improvement of teaching, Frank W. Wentworth, college treasurer, reports.

Mrs. Georgine Thomson of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marjorie Grimshaw Thomson, to Harry Lee Barton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Barton, also of Upper Montclair.
Falling from his pony, which stumbled and rolled over on him, Lord Louis Mountbatten, a cousin of King George, dislocated his shoulder during a polo match at Cowdray Park, Sussex, today.

The railway movement of the Southwest crop of Winter wheat, now drawing to a close, was described as "the swellest job" by Clyde M. Reed, former Governor of Kansas and chairman of the Trans - Missouri - Kansas Shippers Advisory Board, in a statement released by the Association of American Railroads.

IT took no Federal law to shorten the long hours that the housewife used to spend in her kitchen. Rather it was the competitive genius of her commercial servants-the butcher, the baker and the grocer.
Four years ago this week the World Economic Conference was winding up its largely futile sessions, while Great Britain and the United States went their separate ways in monetary policy.

A bridge party, tea and fashion show will be held here on Aug. 10 at the Outpost Inn under the field auspices of Connecticut Pioneer Branch of the National League of American Penwomen. The inn's tree nursery will provide the setting for the fashion show, which will be known as "Fall Tree Fashions."

America's point-seeking and trophy-winning outboard drivers will do precious little resting during this month of August. Hundreds of miles on the race courses and thousands of miles in trucks and trailers getting from one regatta to another will make globe trotters out of them all.

A. P. HERBERT has done it A professional humorist serving his first term in the House of Commons, he has carried through to the statute books the long-overdue divorce reform and thus achieved an unheard-of triumph.

Next Thursday will mark one year since the executive council of the American Federation of Labor ordered the suspension of the unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization for taking part in a "dual" movement which was held to be an act of treason to the A. F.

BEAGLES Winners. Dogs and Best or Winners (not exceeding thirteen inches)-Florence McCandless's Charmac GaY Lad.

An unidentified man, about 28 years old, bought a safety razor blade in the candy store of Israel Minkowitz, 466 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday. He cut his throat eight times with the blade and collapsed. Minkowitz summoned police and an ambulance but the man was dead when the surgeon arrived.

Bois Dore, the home here of Mrs. William Fahnestock, was the scene tonight of a large ball, at which Miss Marsyl Stokes, daughter of Mrs. Henry Drummond-Wolff of London and Newport and of Sylvanus Stokes of Washington, was presented to society by her mother and stepfather. Mrs. Fahnestock, greataunt of the debutante, is away at present because of mourning in her family.
There is nothing quite as old as the shell game. But Ray Loring dropped in from Vandalia, Ohio, yesterday to cast some new light on the subject.
Federal regulation of interstate commerce, even though a small percentage of a concern's output actually crosses State lines, was upheld in a decision of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today.
TAMMANY HALL, so buoyantly con fident of its power when it dominated a smaller and younger City of New York, is nowadays a place of anxiety and dissension.

Nicholas Bayard Neilson, a former vice president of the United States Steel Corporation and a descendant of Colonel Henry Rutgers, for whom Rutgers University was named, died here yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. John H. Bonsall. He was 81 years old.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Henderson, daughter of Daniel M. Henderson of 360 Riverside Drive and South Orange, N. J., and the late Mrs. Henderson, to H. Woodward McDowell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ezra O. McDowell of Maplewood, N. J., took place yesterday afternoon in the American Women's Association Clubhouse, 353 West Fiftyseventh Street.

The marriage of Miss Alice Marie Quinn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Quinn, to J. Peter Jaffe, son of Mrs. George E. Ratsey of Greasen Point, Mamaroneck, took place here this afternoon at the home of her parents.

Miss Lola Elizabeth Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarke Lewis of this place, was married this afternoon in the First Presbyterian and Trinity Church of South Orange to Frederick Charles Verinder, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Verinder, also of South Orange. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. George A. Edminson.

A $100,000 fund and thousands of pickets to aid the strike of shipyard workers here were pledged yesterday by leaders of a score of international C, I. O. unions at a closed meeting at C. I. 0. headquarters, 1,133 Broadway.

ALTHOUGH this volume is concerned primarily and ostensibly with that poetry which builds itself around the old myths, it is in a sense a critique of English poetry from the eighteenth century until the present;
Finland's official participation in the Delaware Tri-Centenary Jubilee next Spring continues to be the subject of lively discussions in Finnish circles here and in the United States.

The engagement of Miss Viola Hewit Buell, daughter of William H. Buell of this city and the late Gertrude H. V. Buell, to Roswell Parker Angier Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Roswell P. Angier, also of New Haven, has been announced by her father.

COWES WEEK begins tomorrow, and though there will be grievous absences this year, the great regatta still retains the prestige which has raised it above all the other yachting events in the European calendar.
HYANNIS, Mass--With the Summer season at the halfway mark, Cape Cod's colonies are in the midst of a crowded calendar of sporting and social events which will continue though Labor Day.

THESE are days of adventure for American tourists in Europe. On all sides adventure is to be found and it takes many forms: trains that "go bump" in the night and pant to an uneasy halt at guarded frontiers; customs guards who greet you with a Machiavellian politeness;
St. Louis at New York-Koupal vs. Chandler. Detroit at Boston (2)-Lawson and Auker vs. Newsom and Wilson. Chicago at Philadelphia (2)-Lyons and Dietrich vs. Caster and Thomas.
WASHINGTON. - Federal reclamation projects will have room for a population of at least a million when fully. developed;- according to a Tecent estimate of John C. Page, Commissioner of Reclamation.
TODAY Perole String Quartet, directed by Joseph Coleman, concludes a Beethoven cycle: WOR, 11:30 A. M.12:30 P. M.
William Ziegler Jr.'s consistent mare Esposa was a driving winner in the thirty-fifth running of the $10,700 Saratoga Handicap as .12,000 persons cheered to the echo to see a favorite in front.
When Summer School closes next week at the New Jersey State Teachers College at Montclair classes will begin for those who prefer to take their education through first-hand observation.
In a fit of anger, Michel Ploquin, 19 months old, today killed his sister, Angele, 2 months old, by hitting her over the head with his feeding bottle. Angele died in her crib from a fractured skull.

Agriculture and Interior Department spokesmen, in letters to Chairman Harrison of the Senate Finance Committee, outlined today their objections to pending sugar control legislation. Acting Secretary of Agriculture Wilson suggested that the deadlock might be broken by dealing in a separate bill with proposed limitations on refining in Hawaii and Puerto Rico.

Freaky race results of the most unusual kind for Barnegat Bay prevailed this afternoon as all classes battled against the time limit in the baffling northeast to easterly breezes in the weekly championship regatta of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association.

William Court, 52 years old, poultry farmer, who served as justice of the peace of Brook Haven Township from 1921 to 1935, shot himself to death with a revolver about noon today in a corn field on his farm here.

It costs more for the average working man with a wife, a son and a daughter to live in Washington than in any of fifty-nine other cities studied in a survey made public today by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Works Progress Administrator.

To the Drama Editor: More than a year ago the Dramatists' Guild's new contract was adopted by the playwrights and accepted by a majority of theatrical producers. It now seems to me that it has added a new chapter to that unfinished, dreary tome, "What's Wrong With the Theatre?"

Scores of luncheons today featured the first Saturday of racing here and among them was one given by Mrs. Dodge Sloane at her cottage for Mrs. Thomas M. Bancroft, Mrs. Thomas I. Laughlin, James L. Bush and Douglass W. Paige.

In a warlike atmoshere several thousand delegates to the seventh world conference of the World Federation of Educational Associations were wel comed here today by Hidejiro Nagata, former Cabinet Minister and president of the Japan Educational Association.

James J. Braddock, former heavyweight champion of the world, has purchased for his home a dwelling containing nine rooms, with a twocar garage, at Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, North Bergen, N. J. The house, which occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet, was bought from Matthew Heine.
NEXT Thursday the Empire State's highest mountain, Mount Marcy, is giving a party to celebrate its first hundred years as a historical summit.

The marriage of Miss Virginia D. Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Murphy of Richmond Hill, Queens, to Peter E. Duffy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter E. Duffy of Butler, Pa., took place yesterday morning in Holy Child Jesus Church, Richmond Hill.

When Mayor S. Davis Wilson, Incited to wrath over a telephone wire-tapping episode, announced his candidacy for Governor the other day, he seized upon an opportunity which he himself could not have designed more fittingly to suit his purpose.

Just after Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, wearing a light sporting jacket and jaunty soft felt hat, had shut the door of No. 11 Downing Street behind him today and started his vacation it became known that he had brushed aside diplomatic custom and had written a "personal letter of friendship" to Premier Benito Mussolini.

A seashore home containing several novel and distinctive features has been designed by William Lescaze, New York architect, in cooperation with George Daub for Lloyd A. Good of Philadelphia in Harvey Woods, a tract of land facing the Atlantic Ocean in the Barnegat Bay section of New Jersey.
The Right Rev. Albert A. David, Bishop of Liverpool, does not like professional baseball and if he had his way England would have none of it.

Reservations have been made by about 1,000 manufacturers, retailers and buyers for a Fall millinery fashion show to be held next Tuesday at the Pavillon Royal, Valley Stream, L. I., directed by Seymour Mittelmark under the auspices of the Millinery Stabilization Commission. Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia has accepted an invitation, tendered in recognition of his service to the millinery industry, to attend as guest of honor.

Under a combination of hedging operations and commission-house selling, prices on the Cotton Exchange yielded 5 to 8 points yesterday and closed the cotton-year at the lowest quotation of the twelve months. All three near deliveries sold at, or below, 103/4 cents and in new low territory for the week. Week-end profit-taking by the short interest absorbed contracts, holding fluctuations within a range of 10 points.

TOPNOTCH air racing pilots of the country are busy tuning up their planes with an eye on the $81,000 prize money awaiting the fastest craft and best fliers in the National Air Races at Cleveland Municipal Airport Sept. 3 through Labor Day, Sept. 6.

"Years are a joke," said Henry Ford Thursday, on the eve of the seventy-fourth anniversary of his birthday. He had been asked the question, "How does it feel to be nearly three-quarters of a century old?"

One hundred and fifteen civil engineering students from City College are ranging Van Cortlandt Park and the surrounding streets this Summer solving surveying problems under severely practical conditions.

THE Fourth International Congress of the International Union for the Scientific In vestigation of Population Problems, which opened in Paris on Thursday and closes today, once more focuses attention on many vital 'problems concerning the life of man on this little planet in the "back yard of the universe."

Comparatively few amateur gardeners fully realize that the rose garden, under normal conditions, may be made to make a Fall showing quite equal to that of June. Though there may not be as many blossoms, the blooms are likely to be even finer.

Minimum construction requirements have been established in the areas served by twenty-seven insuring offices of the Federal Housing Administration in twenty States, announced H. P. Vermilya, director of the technical division.
Governor La Follette of Wisconsin urged progressives of Iowa today to form a new party and work for a political realignment throughout the nation.

A flying craft which resembled in appearance an ordinary tapered wing airplane left Boulevard Airport yesterday, circled the field and landed, just as a conventional plane would do. A few minutes later the pilot, George Townson, took off again, rose 1,500 feet and then released the upper wing, which began rotating and enabled the new machine to float to earth as a gyro.
The Fair Labor Standards Bill, as passed by the Senate,. includes the following major provisions governing maximum hours of labor, minimum hourly wages, child labor, and other related matters:

THE world's most representative collection of postage stamps and covers directly associated with music is being assembled by Theodore E. Steinway of New York, one of America's foremost philatelists, and will undoubtedly have a place of honor at future national stamp exhibitions.

The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the Chicago Great Western Railroad Company today to assume obligation and liability in respect to not more than $1,500,000 of equipment-trust certificates, Series D, to be issued by the American National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, as trustee,. and sold at 100.135 and accrued interest.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Imbrie, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Charles K. Imbrie of this place, to Rieinald Werrenrath Jr., son of Mrs. Ada Werrenrath of New York and Reinald Werrenrath, took place here this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church, of which the bride's father is pastor. Dr. Imbrie performed the ceremony, during which the bridegroom's father, the well-known American baritone, sang "O Perfect Love."
Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth Bradford of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Bradford, to John Kirk Train Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. John K. Train of Savannah, Ga.

The first major rally of the week, set in yesterday on the stock mar-ket. With shorts scurrying to cover commitments over the week-end, prices, under the leadership of steel and motor shares, staged a moderate recovery.

Miss Frances Irving Holbrook, daughter of Mrs. Robert Scandrett Holbrook of this place and the late Mr. Holbrook, was married here this afternoon at the home of her mother, to Nelson Childs Freeland of New York and Sea Girt, N. J.,

Dr. Jeanne Gobeaux-Thonet, a Belgian university librarian said today that she was "pleasantly surprised" to see that all Americans were not wealthy persons who do nothing but drink and smoke and get divorced." "Most of us see the American movies and get entirely the wrong impression." she added.

James Henry Lanfear died here yesterday, six months short of the 100-year goal he had hoped to achieve. "I'm sure I'll become a centenarian," he had said at his ninety-ninth birthday celebration last Jan. 18. Survivors are a son and a daughter, seventeen grandchildren and twenty-one great-grandchildren.
Toward the end of Summer women begin to seek a few accessories that will tone up their wardrobes--accessories that they can wear at the beginning of Fall in town.

The first four seeded players, all of the Trinity Club, gained the semi-final round of the national A. A. U. one-wall handball championship tourney at the Ravenhall Baths .in Coney Island yesterday. Dave Margolis, defending champion, defeated Ben Turner of the Ravenhall A. C., 21-18, 21-15.

New buildings to provide decent housing for low-income families are not essential to a solution of the problem, according to Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, who suggests rehabilitation of existing structures as a means of furnishing homes of minimum standards.

Mrs. Eugene C. Clark of Yonkers entertained tonight with a dinner at the Hay Harbor Club for Mr. and Mrs. M. A. Long, Major and Mrs. Alexander G. Pendleton, Dr. and Mrs. Robert L. Dohme, Mrs. John A. Topping, Miss Helen Ferguson, Mrs. Ross T. Graham, Mrs. Emmett Schultz, Mrs. Frank N. B. Close and Mrs. W. O. Finkbine.

A GREATER degree of steadiness featured retail trade generally last week, with the improvement in volume noted in some sections suggesting an early termination of the slackness of recent weeks. Consumer response to August promotions of fors and home furnishings was encouraging. gains ranging from 7 to 15 per cent were reported for these events, despite spottingess due to the promotions getting off to a slow start in some areas.

There were indications last week that Britain was making headway in restoring her friendship with Italy, a friendship rudely jarred by the Ethiopian adventure two years ago and further jeopardized this year by a clash of interests in Spain and the Mediterranean.
EDDIE CANTOR, the man who regards the business of making people laugh as a pretty serious affair; is well into his first venture at Twentieth CenturyFox, where he is making "Ali Baba Goes to Town."

Representatives of unions not associated with the C. I. O. or A. F. of L. and interested in the formation of the Independent Federation of Independent Unions, hope to have 1,000,000 members by the end of the year, they said today.

A FINNISH play brought to London by Ammer Hall, whose experiments are always interesting, has had a mixed reception. "Women of Property" is domestic drama of the Ibsen school, and it may be that a certain naivete in the statement of its problem is rather the fault of its adapter, Frank Davison, than of Miss Wuolijoki, the Finnish author of the-play.

THERE'S hardly a town in this country that hasn't the makings of an orchestra." Thus George King Raudenbush, currently conducting the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra at Lewisohn Stadium. "Opportunities for young, aspiring American conductors abound in every State. Radio has educated the ??al population in the musical classio?? and has created a real

A plea for the rehabilitation of the area in the Navy Yard section of Brooklyn has been made by Ben LeRoy Stowell, chairman, and Anna May Mason, associate chairman of the Navy Yard District Section of the Brooklyn Committee for Better Housing.

Miss Dorothy Belle Brush, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs.-George E. Brush of Huntington, was married to Robert Spengler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Spengler of Canandaigua, N. Y., tonight at the home of the bride's brother, Harold E. Brush.
General Gen Sugiyama, War Minister, repeated before the House of Peers yesterday that future developments in China depended entirely upon the attitude of the Chinese.
The concert of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra given at Lewisohn Stadium last night under the direction of George King Raudenbush attracted an audience of 3,500 persons.

Wooden ships and iron men, they used to say. Gloucester's famed "bankers" no longer slide out to sea to fish the foggy Grand Banks off Newfoundland, but the passing of those graceful schooners has not meant the disappearance of the "men of iron."

To the Art Editor: THE Guggenheim gesture and the pages of controversy which it has engendered in THE TIMES are timely. The particular value of Mr. Guggenheim's gift .is- that it will give socalled -abstract art a new and important standing among critics,
ONCE, while browsing among the bookstalls of Charing Cross Road, two titles by different authors caught my eye, one "How to Manage Motor Cycles," the other on "How to Manage Women."
The eighty-fifth annual convention of the American Phamaceutical Association will open at the Hotel Pennsylvania Wednesday, Aug. 18, and will continue until Saturday, Aug. 21.

THEATRE ARTS MONTHLY devotes its August issue to a single big theme, admirably handled. This is called "The World in the Mirror of the Theatre," covering an extensive period "from the Renaissance to modern times."

Leon Trotsky from his Mexican exile today predicted the Sino-Japanese conflict would hasten a "military catastrophe and social revolution" in Japan and that Soviet Russia eventually would give aid to the Chinese.
With more than 1,500 delegates expected to attend, the program for the United States Building and Loan League's convention in Los Angeles, Oct. 6 to 8, is beginning to take shape.

When the 8,042,700 board feet. Soviet regime does something well it frequently does it superlatively well. This week diplomats and foreign correspondents were permitted to inspect the Soviet's greatest construction project - the MoscowVolga Canal.

The New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners has granted permission for a motor bus line to operate from the Long Hill Country Club Estates on Fairmount Avenue, Chatham, to the Chatham and Summit depots of the Lackawanna Railroad, thus providing direct service to Newark and New York.

With the brilliant coronation season ending, members of the Anglo-American society will leave in the next few days for the Continent, Scotland and the Cowes regatta. The Goodwood race meeting, which rivals the Ascot as a society function, has attracted many visitors.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 30, unless specified: At Guantanamo Bay: Badger, Decatur, Dickerson, Herbert, Leary, Tattnall, Tillman. At San Diego: Brant, Drayton, Lamson. At Port Angeles: Goff, Reuben, James.

The oldest mainsail in Ranger's very extensive sail-locker was the wing that brought victory .to Harold S. Vanderbilt and his cup defender today. Aboard Vara after the race the American skipper waxed enthusilastic about this- sail and observed that in one respect- the opening contest of the match with. Endeavour II was, an anniversary, for it as the seven ty-fifth time that ancient main was used.

The days of the high failure rate among New York City school children are over and a definite policy has been adopted to provide the type of instruction to eliminate an excessive number of "left-backs" among the pupils, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.

The American educational system spoon-feeds and pampers the student, tending toward mechanization of his mind by its lack of emphasis on thinking ability, the Rev. Gustave Dumas of the Fordham Graduate School declared to Fordham Summer session students in a special lecture on French secondary education yesterday.

Joseph P. Day announced last week that approximately 104 real estate holdings of six national banks in the hands of receivers in Westchester will be sold at auction at the New York Naval Militia Armory, 270 Main Street, New Rochelle, on successive Saturdays beginning Aug. 21.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Mary Hasson of this city of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary A. Hasson, to John A. Condran, son of Mrs. Margaret Condran, also of this city, and the late James Condran. A daughter of the late John Hasson, Miss Hasson is Past Grand Regent of Court Bayley, Catholic Daughters of America.

In a light southeast breeze and over a triangular course on the North Shrewsbury River, thirty-six sailboats in six different classes raced today in the Monmouth Club regatta, directed by Peter Bentley.

The 300-acre estate known as "Gwynn Careg Farm," with a Georgian Colonial residence of thirty-five rooms at Pomfret Center, Conn., has been sold by Mrs. T. Morris Murray to Mrs. J. A. Olin Archibald of New York City and Charleston, S. C. The property was held at $250,000.

A Senate inquiry committee today appointed Colonel Lawrence Westbrook, former assistant WPA administrator, as a special investigator for its inquiry into the activities of the American Cotton Cooperative Association.

COHEN-ROSENBLOOM-Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Rosenbloom, 697 West End Ave., announce the engagement of their daugnter, Helen, to Mehein J. Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Cohen, 6,645 Woodwell St., Pittsburgh, Pa. COHN-MILLER-Mr. and Mrs. Ben S. Miller of Brooklyn, N. Y., announce the engagement of their daughter, Clare Louise, to Dr. Archie Cohn, son of the late Frank and Mollie Cohn of this city.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 29: CAPTAINS Bastedo, P. H., Washington, D. C., to command the Quincy. in October. Woodson, W. B., Hingham, Mass., to duty as Naval Aide to President, Washington, D. C. Court, A. B., Navy Yard, New York, N. Y., to United Drydocks, Inc., New York, N. Y.; Mariners' Harbor, S. I., Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Co Kearny, N. J., as Superintending Constructor.

Adolph Edward Wuppermann, president of the Angostura-Wuppermann Corporation and brother of the screen stars, Ralph and Frank Morgan, died at his home here this morning. He was 65 years old. Mr. Wuppermann had been president of the company, which makes Angostura Bitters, for the last ten months, having succeeded his mother,

Regulation of forwarders by the Interstate Commerce Commission if they continue in their present role as "an important factor in the national transportation scheme" was recommended today by William J. Walsh and Glenwood W. Rouse,

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Morris I. Goldman of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Goldman, to Armand L. Zimmerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Zimmerman of New Haven, Conn.
Plans for the construction of a canal through the Isthmus of Ofqui which blocks an inner waterway near the coast in Southern Chile will be executed soon, it was an nounced today.

A British gunboat and a Government apology have ended Liberia's crisis over. the price of rice. Liberia accused European dealers of charging more than the legal price. The traders complained they were arrested and hustled through the streets like common criminals by native police, and when they appeared in court no charges were preferred against them.
Pathfinders Lodge, organized Summer camp for girls on Otsego Lake, now in its twentieth year under the direction of Miss Valerie Doucher, produced here tonight Wagner's "Die Walkuere" in pantomine.

Sand Man, a 7-year-old chestnut gelding owned by Morton Govern of Rye, N. Y., who has been competing consistently well in shows this season, captured the hunter championship which climaxed the Long Branch Horse Show today. Tupelo, owned by Julius Bliss, was held in reserve.
College graduates of 1937 are "going to get a break, the first since 1930," Ernest V. Holt, president of the Albany Chamber of Commerce, told 586 Albany business college seniors.

UNDAUNTED by refusal of the Irish Free State to grant them permission to establish a seaplane base in Ireland, German aviation officials plan further development of the catapult ship to gain a place in the North Atlantic air transport trade.

The Soviet press, whose ranks are now being zealously combed for publico enemies," is one of the most powerful means that the government and Communist party possess for influencing the people, for informing them of Kremlin policy, for launching desired campaigns and for exposing faults of execution in Kremlin orders.
PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- With morning semi-finals and after noon finals the three-day annual golf tournament at the Wyantenuck Country Club, Great Barrington, is closing today.
The second division of the Super Homes development at Thirty-ninth Street and Fiftieth Avenue, Sunnyside, Long Island City, will be opened today.
Buffalo made it three in a row in its series with Jersey City today, defeating the Little Giants, 3 to 1, behind the effective six-hit pitching of Ken Ash.

THE fourth Annual Berkshire Symphonic Festival opens this Thursday night at Tanglewood, between Lenox and Stockbridge, Mass. As at last season's festival, all of the concerts will be given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky.
MR. WILKINS'S historical novel, an English and amateurish "Anthony Adverse," concerns the alleged plots to prevent the accession of Queen Victoria.

A survey to ascertain the wages of building labor throughout the country has been completed by the United States Department of Labor. It covers 5,450 contractors employing 186,000 workers in 105 cities in forty-eight States and the District of Columbia, and was made during September, October and November, 1936.

A lop-eared hound-dog, which answers to the name of. Hulda, eats snuff and smells out forest fires, was missing today in the Northwest woods. Loggers in Southwest Washington, who for two Summers followed her barks to fires, are worried.

According to the almanac, Summer is at the floodtide, with another eight weeks before Autumn begins. The vacation period is only half finished; the lassitude of the outdoors is only beginning. But the rhythm of the seasons,

Stating that there is a distinct trend away from the rental of homes toward the purchase of suburban residences, Philip Zvirin, vice president of Boehm Co., brokers, points out that there is an increasing demand in the eastern part of Westchester County for homes in all price classes.

The Steel Workers' Organizing Committee today termed a one week's loss of' wages sufficient penalty for forty-three of its members who laid down their tools in "insubordination" at the Brackenridge plant of the Allegheny Steel Company on July 23.
AN appropriation of approximately $385,000 has been authorized by the Government of Argentina for the purpose of improving and extending the Federal network of radio communications in that country.

The Mortgagees Realty Service, which is the real estate division of the Home Title Guaranty Company, as agent for many individual and institutional investors, reports the sale of 108 properties in the metropolitan area since Jan. 1.

A campaign for stricter enforcement of the law relating to the filling of certificates covering the operation of a business under assumed trade names is being launched by the Commerical Credit Council, 299 Madison Avenue. The aid of credit managers is being solicited, M. L. Martin, executive director, said yesterday, as in many instances the registered trade name certificates filed in the County Clerk's office are incomplete or inaccurate.

One may imagine that Tokyo is not much worried by General Chiang Kai-shek's statements that China will fight the Japanese invaders "to the last man" and will not surrender "one inch of Chinese territory." But Tokyo would be very much interested if General Chiang sent 100,000 or 200,000 troops to fight the Japanese in North China.

Adding another impressive victory to her unbroken string of triumphs, Flornell Spicypiece of Halleston, all white wire-haired fox-terrier bitch owned by Stanley J. Halle's Halleston Kennels of Chappaqua, N. Y., today captured the top laurels in the third annual Ox Ridge Hunt Club all-breed dog show.

Miss Marie E. McGhee, daughter of Mrs. John McGhee of this place and the late Mr. McGhee, was married to Charles H. Judge, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Judge of Baldwin, here this morning in the Church of the Holy Redeemer. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John J. Mahon, the rector, who was also celebrant of the nuptial mass that followed.

BENEATH the, hard, brittle surface of our somewhat monotonous American life there are warmth, color and variety in the folksong music and dances of Old World origin, surviving among the varied racial groups, who brought them from their native lands when they came to make their homes in the Western World, as well as in the newer expressions which have grown up as a result of life lived here.

THE three women who have written the charming books that lie before me are not of pure German descent, but deeply German in their sentiments; yet they are of such fundamentally different natures as can hardly be found anywhere except in colorful Germany.

While patrolling his beat on Broadway in the vicinity of the Mercer Street police station at 3 A. M. yesterday, Patrolman Vincent B. O'Gorman noticed a tall, thin youth carrying an unwrapped ten-pound Virginia ham under his arm and six bottles of soda pop in his coat pockets. "What have you there?" asked O'Gorman.
The Public Works Administration estimated today that it had contribute to the building of stadiums, auditoriums, swimming pools, tennis courts and recreational equipment costing $75,000,000.

Japanese air raiders bombed twenty trains filled with Chinese Government troops rolling northward yesterday from Paoting, the capital of Hopeh Province, toward the Japanese lines just south of Changsintien, near Peiping, according to Japanese press reports from Nanking today.
Detectives said today there were discrepancies in the story of Roy G. Ward, 38, held as a suspect in the murder of Alfred (Jake) Lingle, Chicago newspaper reporter, in 1930.

Group tests for extra-sensory perception carried on at New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance at Washington Square East since March, 1936, the results of which were learned yesterday, revealed that volunteer Girl students taking part in the experiment achieved a 50 per cent higher score than the men students.

There has been so much of the off-again-on-again nature about reports of the progress of the Farm Bill that are reaching the Corn Belt that farmers trying to keep up with them must be a little dizzy by this time.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul Foster Clark of Boston have as guests at Tree Top, their place here in the Bald Peak Colony Club,, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bissell of Suffield, Conn.; Mr. and Mrs. Taylor Chewning of Washington, D. C.; Mr. and Mrs. Malsom Jenny of Brookline, Mass., and Mr. and Mrs. Helmuth Kiesewetter of South Orange, N. J.

The Garden Club of Manchester will hold its seventeenth flower show on Thursday afternoon. Governor George D. Aiken will open the exhibition with a short address. Both the exterior and the lounges of the Equinox House will be decorated with blooms and native evergreens, and a special dance floor has been placed on the front terrace.

The new Wagner Housing Bill was attacked today as "objectionable" in several particulars by George H. Davis, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States. The measure, he said, raised the "whole question of the desirability of interference of the Federal Government in matters of community responsibility and local home rule."

Welton Welton, Inc., Frank J. Welton, president, bought from interests represented by John C. Hoenninger, attorney, the fourstory and basement dwelling at 121 East Sixty-first Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues.

Travel on the North Atlantic services of the French Line in the first six months of this year was 31.68 per cent higher than a year ago, it was announced yesterday by Henri Morin de Linclays, resident general manager of the line in the United States and Canada.

MINKS, foxes, skunks, squirrels are no longer in retreat. They and many more of the furry family are out in the open in all of their Winter glory. What a glamorous array they present! Furs have graduated into a new class.

A plan of reorganization which will relieve the Second Presbyterian Church of some of its difficulties in the financing of its sixteen-story church, school, and apartment structure at the southwest corner of Central Park, West and Ninetysixth Street has been completed under section 77 B of the Bankruptcy Act.

Jack Rutherfurd of Miami, Fla., pushed his Ma Ja II to almost a mile a minute clip over rough water today to win the second heat of the unlimited event for speed boats and make a clean sweep of the race in the ninth annual Chester River Yacht Club regatta.

The body of 8-year-old Paula Magagna was found yesterday lying across a baby carriage in the cellar of the tenement house at 349 Stockholm Street, Brooklyn, where she lived with her father and mother and two brothers.

Grand circuit horse racing, ringing down the curtain on a two-weeks program, pulled up stakes tonight and headed for the Agawam track at Springfield, Mass. Last appearances of the light harness sulkies in today's brushes over the egg-shaped "kite track," produced no upsets.
While hedge shears are not kept quite as constantly in use as the lawn mower during the Summer months, most formally clipped hedges need at least three clippings per season.

AMERICA is at war again. No machine-gun serenades or artillery orchestrations have announcedd it; yet over millions of acres of field and pasture, of garden and woodlot, of orchard and primeval forest, a crucial struggle is raging. Man's everlasting Summer engagement with the insects is reaching its 1937 climax.
Buffalo's 11-day meat strike was at a deadlock as union representatives of 1,800 striking butchers and meat cutters tonight accused three major packing plants of Wagner act violations.

Difficulty in obtaining timely deliveries of medium and better grade dresses will be experienced by retailers who do not place orders for a substantial share of their season's requirements when they make their initial commitments, Morris Kolchin, executive director of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc., declared yesterday.

This hasn't yet received the seal and official sanction of the New York. Yacht Club technical committee but it is offered cheerfully as a good glossary for yachting use in light airs. The definitions were obtained from a man wearing a sailor suit and a pained expression.
Virginia Democrats will nominate a State ticket, candidates for the House of Delegates and one candidate for the national House in the party primary Tuesday.

Mrs. Wayman Adams of New York, wife of the portrait painter, heads a group of women of the Summer colony in a movement to aid the Elizabethtown Community House through a series of "vanishing" luncheons. Each participant will give luncheons for one less in the number of guests invited to each preceding luncheon.

The big chap with the clipped brown mustache said that the ship was ready to go and, as he was master of the ship, .there was nothing to do but pile abroad in a hurry. He was Pilot-Captain Clarence Robey of a big Douglas skyliner.
Demolition work on the partlydemolished six-story bank building at 247 Broadway, southwest corner of Murray Street, has been resumed after a stoppage of more than three months.
Sheriff John Hallum said tonight that Chester Bryant, 13 years old, had confessed to burning the Rural Center Point school house twice because he "didn't like his school and his teacher."

Charles Wick, 62 years old, a retired letter carrier, was found dead in bed, fully clad, at 11 A. M. yesterday in a furnished room at 306 Carlton Avenue, Brooklyn. An ambalance surgeon believed he had died of a chronic stomach ailment. On delivery of the body to William J. Lanning, undertaker,
There were five of them in Brenton Cove this morning, their tall masts swaying slightly as they lifted in a gentle swell, but the eyes of the world were on only two.

Assets of the twelve Federal Savings and Loan Associations in the Philadelphia district on July 1 amounted to $5,856,411, an increase of $435,359 over the previous month, and a gain of $1,184,233 over the previous quarter ending April 1, last.

France protested to Italy today against Italian press attacks. Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos demanded that the Italian Ambassador, Vittorio Cerruti, tell the source of Italian newspaper allegations that France was permitting volunteers to cross her frontier fight for the Spanish Government and furnishing arms to the Valencia Administration.

GILBERT SELDES, author and critic, who prepared the ad aptation of "The Taming of the Shrew" for the WABC Shakespearean cycle, to be broadcast tomorrow night at 9 o'clock, found that his attitude in doing so was not one of reverence for the Bard.

The wildly hysterical celebrations held in Shanghai, Tientsin, Canton and other large cities of China Wednesday when the populace was cruelly deceived with false reports of supposed Chinese military victories would seem to indicate that the whole Chinese nation was seething with hatred of the Japanese.
A stranger interrupted Senate debate on the Wage-Hour Bill today, shouting from the gallery that he wanted to be heard.

STROUDSBURG, Pa--With half of the Summer season in the background, the Poconos and the Delaware Valley are enjoying one of the finest seasons they have had in a number of years. Resort houses and tourists' camps are filled to capacity and the many State camps located within easy driving distance of the center of the resort areas are being visited by thousands of people.
Considerable activity in the Red Bank section of New Jersey is reported by Ray H. Stillman, broker. Eight sales of various properties in that vicinity were recently made through his office.
THERE was a quiet little meeting at the White House last week which set aviation circles in Washington a-gossiping at great length.

A resolution asking President Roosevelt to reconsider the question of recognition of Soviet Russia and deploring religious persecution in that country was adopted last Tuesday at a joint meeting of the Russian National League of America, the All Russian Peasant League and the Russian Imperial League.
To keep the armed. forces out of politics, War Minister Eurico Dutra issued today a general army

The marriage of Miss Norma Lillian Crandall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Crandall of Overbrook, Pa., to John Whitfield Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Taylor of Glen Ridge, N. J., took place here today in the Berlin Congregational Church. The Rev. Frank J. Knapp, rector of Christ Church, Montpelier. performed the ceremony.

Carl R. Gray Jr., who said he tried to "wean myself away" from the railway business, took over the main throttle of the Omaha line today, continuing the Gray family succession to high executive posts in the industry.

The Right Rev. Benjamin Brewster, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Maine, and a descendant of Elder Brewster, leader of the Pilgrims, announced tonight that he had resigned from the Maine Society of Mayflower Descendants because it frowned on his activities in the American Civil Liberties Union.

WILLIAM K. HOWARD, one of the few directors ever to order a producer off a Hollywood set and get away with it, popped into the United Artists office a few days back just in time to rescue this usually patient listener from a harangue by one of the public relations gentlemen there on why the fact

Francis J. Gorman, president of the United Textile Workers of America, returned yesterday on the President Roosevelt of the United States Lines from the International Labor Conference at Geneva, Switzerland, accompanied by Mrs. Gorman. After the conference Mr.
The Evening Standard, independent news-paper owned by Lord Beaverbrook, today attacked the Oxford group movement as "exhibitionist" and called upon churches to discourage it.

Militant members of the House of Representatives, loyal to Governor Murphy and his legislative program, started today a three-day plan of action which they hore will make illegal te adjournment of the Republican controlled Senate, which broke up a special session.
Eddie Mayo's pinch single in the ninth with the bases loaded lent a storybook touch to a 9-7 triumph of the Bees over Pittsburgh today.

WASHINGTON. - Financed by WPA filnds, an inventory of State, local and other non-Federal records is nearing completion.. Particular emphasis has been placed on the examination of county records, hitherto an almost unexplored field.

A total of 345 business and professional men of the metropolitan area, who are reserve officers in the Seventyseventh Division, principal New York City unit of the army reserve, will assemble tomorrow in Camp Dix for two weeks' service,

ROMANTIC is a term so broad in its implications asto embrace, at any rate in some degree, nearly the whole vast realm of the arts. With a spirit of romance the very impulse itself of artistic creation seems to be suffused. And in most painting there appears a hint, at least,

Behold what a fire a little word kindleth by its absence. The other day "not" dropped out of this sentence in an editorial in the first edition of the Sunday TIMES: For years and years Southern newspapers have asked Southern farmers to put all their hopes in one crop.

Ardmore C. C. of Philadelphia today lost an exhibition cricket match to a team from the Brooklyn C. C., the latter scoring by a margin of four runs, with three wickets to spare. Ardmore batted first, compiling ninety-one runs,

The national junior polo championship opened on the historic field at Narragansett Pier today after a lapse of many years with a well-played, exciting match in which Narragansett, captained by Gerald Dempsey, defeated the San Mateo four of California 11 to 9.

Plans are being made to erect a large taxpayer structure, estimated to cost $500,000, on the old Postoffice site on Broad Street, between Raymond Boulevard and Academy Street, Newark, N. J., by the Metropolitan Realty Holdings Corporation, Isadore Wolff, president.

Sales of "Consumer Protection Labels" of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board last week were the highest ever recorded for the corresponding week of any previous year, both under the Recovery Board and the NRA, it was reported yesterday by F. Nathan Wolf, executive secretary.

Five men trained in Nova Scotia and backed by the commission government, are spreading the cooperative movement through Newfoundland, slightly more than a year since it made its first organized appearance.
HOT SPRINGS, Va.-Seventyfive shooters, many of them of national ranking, are competing in the finals for the Clark Challenge Skeet Trophy on the two Homestead skeet fields today.

The wheels of progress so far as the Giants are. concerned virtually came to a -complete standstill today as Tex. Carle-. ton, Chicago's tall and willowy right-hander, held Colonel Bill Terry's pennant wagon shackled to what looked like an old-fashioned hitching post. Meanwhile Cholly Grimm's sleek machine thundered by until it was practically out of sight.

The thirteenth international interdenominational young people's conference, a feature of the Summer conferences held at the Assembly Hall here, opened tonight, with seventy-five delegates from New England States, New Jersey and Pennsylvania as well as Long Island.

FOR some years Warner Brothers, with the aid of their production manager, Irving Asher, have been making modest but entertaining quota pictures at their studios at Teddington on the Thames. During this time Mr. Asher, now known as England's No. 1 talent spotter,
Winners of three scholarships and one partial scholarship to the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel here were announced today by Sister Mary Edmund, the dean.

Redeeming a dismal showing in last week's Yankee handicap, A. C. Compton's Clingendaal equaled the track record today, while winning the $5,000 added Independence Handicap before 23,000 fans at Suffolk Downs. The gelded son of Pharamond II was clocked in 1:37 1-5 for the mile and paid $8 for $2 in the mutuels.

Fred J. Hull was sentenced yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers in Brooklyn to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison during the week of Sept. 5 for his part in the slaying of Samuel Drukman on March 3, 1935. Under the law the case must be reviewed by the Court of Appeals before the date of execution.
Tourist travel overseas and shipments of California's canned processed foodstuffs both neared their peak today as shown by great activity along the San Francisco waterfront.

LANDING HAWK was a 10year-old Indian boy. but his story does not belong only to early history. He was a modern youngster. And he learned the ancient ways of his tribe and his people when he went with his parents to the ceremonial of the Winnebagoes, as it is held each Summer at the Wisconsin Dells.
A word of warning against "socialized" or "State medicine" in the United States came this week from a group of American physicians doing advanced medical study in Vienna.

Montauk Manor is thronged with guests, staying here and attending the yacht races off Newport. Among those leaving on their yachts from the Montauk Yacht Club are Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Todd on the Katrina, Livingston Short on the Stella Polaris, Ethelbert Low on the Akele III, and Livingston Sullivan and guests on the Arliss.

The irrepressible Joe DiMaggio and the tall Arkansan, Bill Dickey, stroked three hits yesterday at the Yankee Stadium that were good for six runs against St. Louis pitching, and had the additional effect of throwing some 11,944 fans into spasms of Joy.

Two horses won the $45,000 Arlington Futurity today. Running the first dead heat in futurity history, Tiger, entry of Mrs. Ethel V. Mars of Chicago, and Teddy's Comet, carrying the colors of Emerson V. Woodward, Houston, Texas, raced six furlongs to a deadlock in the richest juvenile stake of the year, climaxing the highly successful thirty-day Arlington Park meeting.

A more intelligible explanation of the crisis undergone in Russia by the Stalin dictatorship is now available. Hitherto embassies and legations in Moscow have sent their respective governments the most divergent interpretations of what happened to Marshal Mikhail N. Tukachevsky and the seven generals of the Red Army on June 11 and the continuous chain of repressive measures that have not yet come to an end.

Defying the wishes of Senator Guffey and other Democratic State leaders, John B. Kelly, the party's city chairman, announced today that the local Democratic organization would offer no opposition to thereelection f six Republican judges of the Common Pleas and Orphans' Courts whose terms are expiring.

The President's troubles with Congress these days arise from a combination of causes. But a primary one is that he has at no time been able to persuade a substantial number of Democrats that any "emergency" exists which justified enlarging the Supreme Court, or that quick action on certain other items in his program is essential.

MORNING EVENTS Class 16, Limit Horsemanship, Riders Under 17 Years of Age-First, Miss Jean Girdler; second, Arthur Plaut Jr.; third, Miss Barbara H. Henderson; fourth, Miss Joanne Huggins; fifth, Miss Ann Louise Campbell; sixth, Miss Maryl Riter. Class 20, the Horsemanship Trophy, A. S. P. C. A.-First, Thomas Mott Jr.; second, Arthur Plaut Jr.; third, Miss Nancy Greenwald.
Federal Government supply contracts under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act amounted to $3,233,620 in the week ended on July 29, the Department of Labor announced today.

Max Marston of Philadelphia, veteran of more than two decades or tournament warfare, and Jimmy Lee of Danbury, Conn., 22-year-old Georgetown University golf star, today blasted their way into the final of the eighteenth Shenecossett men's invitation tournament.

Calling attention to suggestions recently made by several municipal taxing bodies that real estate taxes be increased, Philip W. Kniskern, president of the First Mortgage Corporation of Philadelphia, says that real estate is- already overburdened with taxes.

About 2,000 Americans who have the good fortune to be in France at this time will go as guests of the United States Government to Montfaucon today. There they will witness the dedication by General John J. Pershing,

John O'Callaghan, a trucking and hauling contractor here for twenty-five years, died in St. Agnes Hospital yesterday in his seventieth year. Coming to this country from Ireland a half-century ago, he was president for twelve years of the County Kerrymen's Association. At one time he was chairman of the Twenty-sixth Ward Democratic Executive Committee. Surviving are his widow, a daughter, Mrs. Catherine O'Malley; a brother and two sisters.

Ground has been broken at Franklin and Stewart Avenues, Garden City, L. I., for the erection of a one-story building to contain seven stores. Completion is expected by Oct. 1. Including land, the structure will cost $100,000.

RECOGNIZING itself as the "sole trustee for broadcasting in Britain," the British Broadcasting Corporation in its journal, The Radio-Times, asserts it is bound to give its listeners the best whereever it is to be found. Home talent has succeeded in this aim.

Harold S. Vanderbilt's Ranger, defending the America's Cup, triumphed easily over T. O. M. Sopwith's Endeavour II in the first race of the series off Newport yesterday. The British yacht finished 17 minutes 5 seconds behind, the margin being the biggest in a cup match for fifty years. Endeavour II fell behind in the first few minutes of the contest and after that the American craft drew steadily away.

Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the large dinner and supper dance held tonight at the Meadow Club in honor of the Oxford-Cambridge tennis team, who played here earlier' in the day against the Meadow Club team and the United States Junior Davis Cup squad.

NEWPORT.-Regardless of the America's Cup races this city is going horticultural this week Tuesday is to be the weekly garden day for the benefit of the Civio League; for the first time the formal Italian planting in the gardensof Chetwode,

Mr. and Mrs. Barrett Wendell 3d, who were married on Thursday in Nantucket, Mass., are at the Weylin. Mrs. Wendell is the former Miss Margaret Mitchell, daughter of Leeds Mitchell of Chicago and Mrs. Day Mitchell of New York. Mrs. T. Halsted Myers left the Savoy-Plaza yesterday for Waterville, Me.

Dennis J. O'Connell, president of the East River Mill and Lumber Company for nearly twenty years, died on Friday at the Webb Institute in the Bronx, ten days after he had suffered a paralytic stroke. Mr. O'Connell was 62.

Miss Gladys Candler Hinckley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Hinckley of Providence and Whale Rock Point, will be married to Arnold Porter, son of Dr. Emery M. Porter of Providence and Mrs. Mary Bradley Porter of Washington, in the Church of St. Peter's-bythe-Sea here on Saturday afternoon by the Very Rev. Philemon E. Sturges, dean of the Cathedral of the Church of St. Paul in Boston.

SCHOLARS and laymen alike for ages have been curious about the origin and development of the human races.
