Much of the rapidly accumulating and detailed information regarding man cannot and should not be fully interpreted until we possess an adequate basis in the form of comparative data on apes and monkeys for the proper evaluation of the findings for man.

The Nassau Driving Club held its seventh matinee series in the interest of harness racing over the halfmile track of the Fair Grounds today. Two races of three heats each were held, with close finishes.
Miss Alice Washburn and Mrs. Vera Amrein arrived here today in their 18-foot sloop Scud, completing a cruise begun June 26 from New York, where both are teachers.

Syracuse University's new $500,000 Maxwell School of Citizenship building, under construction for a year, will be opened for classes in the Autumn. Although much remains to be completed on the interior of the structure, J. D. Baum, supervising architect, assured Dean William H. Mosher, director of the school, that the building would be ready.

The marriage of Miss Katherine Doane Pier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Pier of Lawrence and New York, and Fred Whitcomb Farwell, son of Professor and Mrs. Herman Waldo Farwell of Leonia, N. J., took place this afternoon at Trinity Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Dr. John W. Suter, rector of the Church of the Epiphany of New York, officiated.
Uneasiness prevails in Peiping despite the ejection of Chinese troops in this area. The nervousness is attributable to uncertainty over the city's political future.

Tension resulting from Sino-Japanese hostilities in Northern China increased in central provinces today with Japanese nationals preparing to evacuate some sections. Japanese residents, including the consul, boarded a gunboat and a commercial steamer at Chungking preparatory to a trip down the Yangtze to Hankow. Their journey was held up, however, to permit temporary transfer of- Japanese property to Chinese authorities.

A sidelight on the current dullness in the security markets was afforded at a luncheon meeting last week of the Cashiers Association of Wall Street, which comprises the cash-keepers of brokerage and bond houses.

THE publishers' advance announcements for the Fall season are not very exhilarating. Nobody is likely to forego his vacation in order to be able to afford any selection of the books advertised. Some, however. are fairly certain of being well received.
Wilmuth A. Armstrong, 32-yearold advertising salesman, plunged to his death yesterday morning from a window on the fifteenth floor of The Daily News Building, 220 East Forty-second Street.
Swimming splendidly from the very start, Miss Mavis Freeman of Port Washington and the Women's Swimming Association, a member of last year's Olympic team,

YOUR Aunt Emma and your Uncle Theodore simply will not talk about syphilis. To them it is the price that the immoral pay for sinning, and this though half the cases are innocently contracted through kissing, using contaminated dishes and utensils, handling infected paper money and in a hundred other innocent ways.

New York will soon hear Rayen Quitral, Indian soprano discovered in an Araucanian settlement in the far south of Chile some months ago, now become the sensation of the season here after many concerts in which the extraordinary volume and beauty of her voice astonished critics.

The present year may set a record for low mortality among American wage-earners, it was said yesterday by statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. They based their conclusion on the mortality experience of the company's 17,500,000 industrial policy holders.

The Seventy-fifth Congress of the United States was called to order on Jan. 5, nearly seven months ago, for one of the most trying sessions in recent years. The months in Washington, spent in prolonged committee meetings and in floor debate, have produced little except bitterness and frayed nerves.

This village will honor the memory of Alice Freeman Palmer, former president of Wellesley COllege, during its centennial celebration, which started today. Officials announced that Thursday had been set aside as Alice Freeman Palmer Day in honor of the educator after whom a school here is named.

A bill to make a few changes In the Jurisdiction and procedure of the lower Federal courts has taken the place of the rejected proposal for reorganization of the Federal judiciary directed primarily at the Supreme Court of the United States.

Purchasing in the New York wholesale market last week was marked by a sustained trend toward conservation, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. Buying budgets appeared to have been closely figured and there was no tendency to "splurge" on purchases.
Manufactuerers of Summer clothing fabrics last week were developing plans for introduction of numerous new weaves for 1938 to capitalize upon the sharp increase in sales of lightweight men's suits in

The West Side Club of Buffalo and the Undine Bargemen from Philadelphia moved on today toward the United States national regatta after a tune-up test with the oars that almost wrecked the equilibrium of the
Congressional sharpshooters have opened fire on the National Labor Relations Board, presaging an apparent drive for amendatory legislation that will curb or modify its powers.

Huge storehouses, dotting the vast domain of the Church of Latter Day Saints, are filled with food and clothing for Mormons who stay off Government relief. The collection of fruit, vegetables, meat and clothing is a major project in the church's unique security program.

THE march of science across new radio frontiers is being pushed ahead by research triumphs in new vacuum tubes that function on tiny wave lengths and by novel aerials that "steer" the waves, according to Dr. Frank B. Jewett, president of the Bell Telephone Laboratories. "Efficiency" is the slogan of the research workers.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Anne Crawford Shirk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Arthur Shirk of this place, to John David Wiggin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Wiggin of Montclair.
After driving what he believed was--a friend's automobile from New York City to Hyannis, Mass., yesterday, Carlyle Moore, actor, of California, discovered the car did not belong to the friend.

THE American Bridge League's eleventh annual Summer tournament begins tomorrow afternoon at Asbury Park, N. J. The attendance is always large, drawing not only on New York but also on most bridge-playing centers as far west as the Mississippi.

The Republican party must adopt a humane program of its own, rather than be contented merely with taking advantage of the mistakes of New Deal philosophers, William S. Murray, chairman of the Republican State Committee, declared today at a convention of Ulster County Republicans.

The Department of Mines and Resources, in a new survey issued this week, reports that the Yellow Knife River area and the adjoining Gordon Lake area, in the Northwest Territories, is rapidly becoming a busy mining zone.

Residents of the New York metropolitan district who are at the Poland Spring House include Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer M. Singer, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard C. Hill, Mr. and Mrs. H. King Coolidge, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Ridder and Miss Mary Dexter of New York and Mr. and Mrs. William H. Clough and Mr. and Mrs. P. T. Wadsworth of Montclair, N. J.

Beginning Sept. 1, the Hudson Manhattan Railroad announced yesterday, a ten-cent fare will be charged for rides between the Hudson Terminal in downtown Manhattan and points in Jersey City and Hoboken. The new rate, the company said, would replace the sixcent fare now in force for rides between the points named.

A total of $6,632,945 on home mortgages in the metropolitan area has been advanced since Jan. 1, 1935, by the Serial Federal Savings Loan Association of New York City. George E. Palmer, secretarymanager, announced yesterday.

Fires are an almost unknown quantity here. W. J. Cox, fire chief in this town of 2,016 residents, said that a call to extinguish a rubbish blaze a few days ago was the first in more than twelve months.
AT the very beginning, as soon as you read "It is a long, thin island," on the first page, you are sure that this is going to be a fascinating and unusual book.

The International Railway Company was authorized today by the Public Service Commission to substitute buses for trolley cars in Niagara Falls. Approximately thirty-five buses of twenty-fivepassenger capacity will replace the present twenty-six trolley cars, the commission said.
The Rochester Diocese of the Roman Catholic Church invoked ancient canon laws today to celebrate masses for James W. Loucks, Civil War veteran who died more than three years ago at the age of 90.

THERE are more reasons for congratulation upon the increasing popularity of the piano than those of trade. Speakers at the thirty-sixth annual Music Industries Convention, held last week in this city, gave figures of piano sales that betokened a changing attitude toward the instrument on the part of the public: an advance-is not "in volume" the word?

The New York Athletic Club tennis team triumphed over the Lenox Hill A. A., 6 to 3, at Travers Island yesterday. R. E. Johnston played excellently for the home team defeating Steve Lackey, 6-1, 6-4 and then pairing with John Flanagan to down Charles Mantler and John Blazo, 6-0, 6-2.

A $1,388,800 bridge to connect two of North Carolina's rich farming and fishing peninsulas and afford them an outlet to northern markets will be built across nearly three and a half miles of open water of Albemarle Sound, on the northeastern coast of North Carolina, Federal road authorities have revealed. Preliminary work has been undertaken.
Nine hundred mice-and not a single cat-figured in the annual show of the British National Mouse Club, held recently at St. Albans near London.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Eleanor Baldwin Longyear, daughter of Mrs. Charles Longyear of this place and the late Mr. Longyear, to John Keen Wallace of New York, son of the late James N. Wallace. The wedding will take place here on Oct. 1.

Reports come from New England States that the lobster is in danger of extermination in those waters and this is confirmed by officials of the Bureau of Fisheries. The acute situation Was laid to the lack of enforcement of lobster conservation measures of the various States and lack of uniformity among such measures.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Tomorrow. Coca-Cola Co. (com.). Coca - Cola International Corp. (com.)

Completing the marksmanship tests this morning with the firing of musketry problems, the 2,100 upstate Guardsmen encamped here at Camp Smith are on a leave of absence from noon today to taps at 10:30 o'clock tomorrow night.

Father Knickerbocker, who, has been in the restaurant-owning business off and on for a long time now, is extending his service to Summer visitors to New York City's parks. Cafeterias, cafes and carrettinas are appearing where they did not exist before.
Scoring three runs on Les Scarsella's ninth-inning homer, a Cincinnati rally fell short today and the Reds lost a free-hitting contest to the Phils, 10 to 8.

The list of the French liner De Grasse, due this morning from Havre via Southampton, includes R. Castro Beach, Minister from Costa Rica to the United States; F. Brire, French Consul at Boston; the Right Rev. C. Beardsley, Lord Bishop of Leicester, England; W. Hullihen, president of the University of Delaware, and Mrs. Hullihen;

THIS department has often queried Mr. Dexter Fellows, the greatest living authority on that vernal phenomenon, the circus, about the persistence, in the face.of new art conceptions like cubism, surrealism, etc., of that tableau staple of the big show, the living statues.

THE subtitle of "He Did Not Die at Meyerling," which J. B. Lippincott Company will publish in September, is "The Autobiography of a Hapsburg Who Became an American and Lived to Clear Up an Historical Mystery."

Making a most auspicious start in the biennial team tournament of the International Chess Federation and in defense of the HamiltonRussell trophy, possession of which they acquired at Prague and retained at Folkestone and Warsaw, the United States team tonight defeated Lithuania by the one-sided score of 3 1/2-1/2.
Elsa Alsen, dramatic soprano, has been appointed director of the Cecilia Music School of Madonna House, it was announced yesterday. She succeeds Mrs. Hedi Katz, who has resigned.

METRO has resumed conversations with Universal anent the purchase of the rights to "The Hunchback of Notre Dame." The latter will sell, it is understood, for a substantial cash settlement plus the services of Robert Montgomery for one picture.
Mrs. Edwin F. Mack of Chicago and Mrs. George A. Busch of Buffalo were tea hostesses after the putting tournament on the green at Westport Inn this afternoon.

To the Radio Editor: In the comprehensive report of the National Resources Committee it appears that more stress is placed upon the potential effects of television than upon the present and more immediate effects of radio.
The twenty regularly operating airlines in the United States carried 110,842 passengers and flew 5,811,404 miles during June.

THOSE who say melodrama is dead speak for themselves, not for the Italian masses. Latest proof: the crowds at the Teatro Adriano for the opera bill now running here, sponsored by the Ministry of Popular Culture and the city of Rome. Manifestly,
The National Labor Relations Board served a complaint today charging that the Weirton Steel Company of West Virginia employed terrorism against the steel workers' organizing committee.

The Americans and some others who are fighting with the Loyalists in Spain take their bridge seriously during off moments close behind the battle lines. The same goes for ping-pong. And there are some bitter contests on the makeshift baseball diamonds, where bullets as well as baseballs fly through the air.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0 affiliate, won a decisive victory last night in the collective bargaining referendum of employes of the four operating units of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System.

The body of an unidentified man, trussed with ropes and chains and with the framework of a pin-ball machine lashed to one arm, was recovered today from Swan Lake, four miles from here. Coroner Lee R. Tomkins said that the man had been stabbed and had been dead more than two weeks.

An international peace movement sponsored by the Veterans Division of the World's Fair will be opened at a Constitution Day dinner at the Hotel Commodore on Sept. 17, it was announced yesterday by Milton Solomon, chairman of the division.
MANCHESTER, Vt.--The climax of the garden season will be observed on -Thursday by the Manchester Garden Club with the eighteenth flower show, to be held at the Equinox House.

Behind the effective pitching of Monte Stratton, the White Sox defeated the Athletics, 2 to 0, today in the opener of a three-game series. Stratton allowed seven hits and registered his fourteenth triumph of the year against four defeats.

Four rounds of boxing against as many sparring partners served today. as the official start of Joe Louis's training for his bout with Tommy Farr, English heavyweight titleholder, at the Yankee Stadium on Aug. 26.
The Rev. Anthony J. Kroeger, pastor of St. Edward's Catholic Church of Lowelll, Ind., was killed near this place today in an automobile accident which injured five other persons.

Developing furtherr the British Government's Palestine policy before the Mandates Commission in a private session today, Colonial Secretary W. G. A. Ormsby-Gore added little to his previous public argumentation.

Younger members; of society devoted to polo, many of them children of internationally known players, are developing small estates and settling an area of about ten square miles in Old Westbury, Westbury, the Wheatley Hills and. Brookville sections of the North Shore to a point where the colony has become, probably, the most celebrated polo-playing area in the world.

For the benefit of the campaign to "Send a Child to Camp This Summer," the Children's Welfare Federation, 435 Ninth Avenue, is sponsoring a series of entertainments, the first a night baseball game and vaudeville show to be held at Farmers Oval, Sixty-eighth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Place, Glendale, Queens, on Thursday, according to an announcement yesterday by Alderman A. Newbold Morris, treasurer of the federation.

Entries for the Lackawanna Kennel Club dog show, which will be held here next Saturday, indicate that last year's mark of 900 will at least be equaled. A feature of the show will be the "Parade of Nations," in which the participants will be girls attired in the native costumes of countries represented by the dogs.

Charles W. Baker Jr., president of the Delaware Steeplechase and Race Association, has announced that a total of $6,300,000 was wagered in the pari-mutuel machines during the twenty-four-day meeting which was concluded a week ago yesterday at Delaware Park, Wilmington.
TO understand why this book seems so authentic, and why it is written with such certainty and force, it is necessary to know something of Mr. Lamson's own story.

Another week of manoeuvring in the confused city political campaign broughtthe following results: (1) Mayor La Guardia accepted for his ticket two candidates put forward by Kenneth F. Simpson, New York County Republican chairman-Dr. Joseph D. McGoldrick for Controller and Newbold Morris for President of the Council.

A survey of tenement house modernization on the lower East Side by Joseph Platzker, secretary of the East Side Chamber of Commerce, reveals that for the first half-year period this year, 312 tenements, chiefly of the old-law type, were thoroughly repaired and put in proper sanitary condition at an aggregate cost of $1,327,275.

Four apartment buildings which will be known as Kent Manor are nearing completion in the Forest Park section of Kew Gardens, L. I., and four model apartments in the first unit have been furnished and are now open for inspection.

Jacob L. Zucker of 4,818 Clarendon Road, Brooklyn, who had been in the service of New York State for twenty years and was active in Brooklyn communal affairs, died on Friday in the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn after an illness of three months. He was 43 years old.

Despite wars and rumovs of wars, strikes and legislative uncertainty, the odd-lot trader, the "little man" in Wall Street, has been bullish on the stock market all through 1937. From the week which ended on Dec. 26, 1936, to that which closed on July 24. 1937,

IN recent years, and particularly since the onset of the depression, Socialists, Communists and all the apostles of "planning" have been deriding laissez fire and the principles of economic liberalism.

In a town gone, almost completely "Toonerville" for the occasion, the Pelham Manor street car, which twenty-two years. ago inspired Fontaine Fox's Toornerville- Trolley" cartoons, ended forty years of service tonight while more than 1,000 Pelham citizens gathered at the station to be cheering pallbearers at the "last rites."

Joseph Goldsmith of Manhattan, a real estate broker, Felix J. Was. selle of Brooklyn, an architect, and Joseph A. Marck of Queens, a civil engineer, have been named as candidates of the Taxpayers party for election to the City Council in their respective boroughs. Reuben J. Wittstein has been named by this party for Municipal Court Justice in, the Fifth Manhattan District.

The case against three officials of Local 167 of the Chicken Drivers Uhion, charged with embezzling funds of their organization, was completed yesterday by Jacob J. Rosenblum, assistant to Thomas A. Dewey, special prosecutor.
Pete Appleton, veteran right-hander recently promoted from relief work, today held Cleveland to five hits and the Senators won their second straight game from the Indians, 3-0.

GUILD HALL, East Hampton, offers, until Aug. 31, an invitation show of oils and watercolors, among the artists represented being Guy Viggins, Carle J. Blenner, Julius Delbos, Celine Baekeland, Edwin H. Denby, Leopold Seyffert, Irving Brokaw and Elizabeth Curtis.
Fourteen-year-old Rita Weaver of Troy, N. Y., carried off individual scoring honors today in the Northern New York championship swimming meet.
John A. Van Zelm, New York stock broker and treasurer of the Larchmont Yacht Club, died of pneumonia today in his home here at 99 Mount Tom Road. He was 40 years old.
FRITZ REINER, who has been conducting the New York Philharmonic Symphony concerts at Lewisohn Stadium, is a most surprising person.
A socially prominent young New Yorker, Thomas Le Boutillier, played hero today in the rescue of a girl whose sail boat capsized at the Freeman Cup races off the Port of Rochester.

Slightly more than $500,000 in new capital was assured today for the Propper-McCallum Hosiery Company. This operation is designed to complete the financial reorganization of one of the city's major industries.

Two sharp criticisms of John L. Lewis and his Committee for Industrial Organization as "communistic" and "irresponsible" are presented today in a debate on industrial unionism from the viewpoints of two labor leaders and a leading industrialist.
Endeavour II's wind hunt coming home in today's race, when she stood high on one broad reach and then jibed over on another, was what has been calledd tacking downwind..

On the eve of the August Bank Holiday there was scarcely sufficient business day to test any financial market here. The stock markets were closed. After moving between $4.97 3/8 and $4.97 7/8 to the pound, the dollar closed at $4.9713-16.
The most Momentous session of Parliament for many years-virtually came to an end today when both houses adjourned for a holiday of almost three months.

Charges that Dearborn police "stood passively by" during a riot near the Ford Motor Company, May 26, formed the basis tonight for a third official inquiry into the beating of nearly a score of union members.

J. Edward Breuer, agent for the Van de Carr property at Copake Lake, N. Y., scheduled to be sold at auction on Saturday afternoon, Aug. 14, and Sunday afternoon, Aug. 15, reports the sale of a large plot fronting the lake to Samuel Zasuly, president of the Camp Copake Lake Corporation. He has also sold four lots overlooking the lake to William Hindley of the Bronx.

Ranger needed 34.4 miles to sail her thirty-mile race today, according to the navigators on the bridge of the Coast Guard cutter Chelan, who used stadimeters, anemometers, range finders, peloruses, parallel rules and plenty of pencils and scratch paper in recording the movements of the sloops on a government chart.

Eleven British and American writers and literary advisers are serving as the faculty of the second annual Olivet Writers Conference, now in session for two weeks at Olivet College, with an attendance of forty.
Two New York women will be among the Radcliffe alumnae honored by -having rooms in the new undergraduate dormitory, Ella Lyman Cabot Hall, named for them.
MOUNT Washington, the "Grandstand of New England," will probably have on its frosty, bald summit the largest gathering in its history on Saturday, Aug. 14.

Thomas N. Watson, 7O-year-old conductor on the Pennsylvania Railroad, who has been riding trains for eight months more than forty-seven years, completed his last run yesterday and then announced he would take a vacation. He plans to travel around the country for. a couple of months on trains.
As the fires of another undeclared war flamed around Peiping and Tientsin last week the scope of immediate Japanese ambitions in Asia became more clearly defined.

Evan B. Stotsenourg, former indiana Attorney General and former State Highway Commissioner, died here today at the age of 72. A former law partner of United States Senator Sherman Minton, Mr. Stotsenburg suffered a heart attack in Indianapolis last Summer while serving as a Highway Commission member.

Miss Sheila Starr, daughter of Mrs. Edward Starr of 26 East Ninety-first Street and the late Mr. Starr, was married to Dr. Edward McPherson Armstrong of New York yesterday morning in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Lockhart Amerman.

Trading in all lines of cotton goods was reduced to a minimum last week and opening of Spring lines of some types of goods were postponed as the industry nervously awaited the Government's cotton crop estimate, which will be published at noon of Aug. 9.

Four men convicted of high treason by the People's Tribunal were executed today. One was Ernst Oppitz of Sagan, Silesia, a former noncommissioned German calvary officer, who was reported to, have had treasonous contacts with Polish agents.
More than 200 couples attended the regular week-end dance at the Pine Orchard Yacht and Country Club tonight, which was preceded by several cocktail parties and dinners.
Babe Dahlgren's long drive over the leftfield wall for his fifteenth homer, following George McQuinn's double in the eighth inning, gave the Bears a 2-to-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs today.
Poundung two Detroit pitchers for fifteen hits, the Red Sox slugged their way to a 12-1 victory today to climb within one game of the third-place Tigers.

The fourth new building for Colby's new Mayflower Hill campus was assured this week when subscriptions for the Roberts Memorial Union reached $301,830. This amount came from 1,353 Colby alumni who have made gifts to build this students' union building as a memorial to President Arthur J. Roberts.
Mohandas K. Gandhi predicted today that prohibition would return to the United States. His prediction was part of a statement outlining plans to make India bone dry within two years.
Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANTS--Howard C. O'Leary, from 3d Division to 18th division, assignment to desk duty discontinued.

Statistics compiled by the Bureau of Census reveal that in the first five months of the present year a total of 13,243,810 asphalt shingle squares were shipped for use as fire-resisting roofing material.

The marriage of Miss Marguerite Estelle Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Thompson of this place, to Robert Stanley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Stanley, also of Port Washington and New York, will take place here on the morning of Aug. 14 in the Port Washington Methodist Episcopal Church. The ceremony will be performed by the pastor, the Rev. Richard Hegarty.

THE greatest woman ever produced in this country," Theodore Tilton called Lucretia Mott, and Roberta Campbell Lawson says of her in the introduction to the present book, "She was the real founder and the soul of the woman's rights movement in America and England. She was the outstanding feminine worker in the struggle to rid our country of slavery.
Petty "chiseling" on the part of neighborhood stores retailing price-controlled liquors has reached the point here where action by both distillers and retailers is being discussed,

North Street, the fifth thoroughfare to have been laid out in the town of Plymouth, will recall its historical past on Aug. 12, when a Colonial Fair, sponsored by the Antiquarian Society of Plymouth, will be held from noon until 6 P. M.

KINGS LOESCH, ELIZABETH (Jan. 6). Estate, $6,000 real. To husband, Joseph, executor, of 925 E. 29th St. WEITZNER, MORRIS (May 6). Estate, not less than $10.000 and not more than $20,000 personal. To mother, Gulcia Weitzner of Poland.

Japan's optimism concerning its etficient and quick mopping-up process of the Chinese area in Tientsin and even in the Japanese concession is not justified as a result of an inspection of those sections in the city.

A "Jury School Kit," giving detailed instruction on how to conduct a jury school for women, was issued today by the New York League of Women Voters, through its department of government and legal status of women, of which Miss Jane Smith Cramer, Brooklyn attorney, is chairman.

MUSICAL offerings at Lake Chautauqua this week open with a concert this after noon by the Chautauqua Symphony, under Albert Stoessel, with Pauline Pierce, Hellen Van Loon, Warren Lee Terry and Gean Greenwell as soloists.

KINGSTON.-In addition to its lakes, its well-known trout streams, its mountains, trails, camp sites, golf courses, tennis courts and harbors, Ulster County, to an ever widening cross-section of vacationists and students.

The new Highway Safety League announced today the organization of its first chapter in this village. The move, said Dr. E. Lester Jones of Albany, president of the league, is the first step in a campaign to establish chapters throughout the State.

The Public Utility Commission indicated today that it would extend its investigation of natural gas rates and service to 104 companies serving 750,000 customers in thirty counties. Dates and places of hearings for twenty-two companies were announced as follows:

BLATT-WIENER--Adele, daughter of Mrs. Wiener and the late Dr. Robert Wiener of New York and Deal, N. J., to Mr. Lionel M. Blatt, attorney, son of Mrs. Minnie Blatt and the late Bernard Blatt. FREED--GRILL-Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Grill, 1,501 Teller Ave., Bronx, announce the marriage of their daughter, Selma Zelda Grill, on Wednesday, July 28, 1937, to Irving Freed, son of Mr. Harry Freed, 27 West 72d St., New York City.

Mr. and Mrs. J. M. Wright gave a luncheon today at the Mount Washington for Mr. and Mrs. E. Livingston Potter of New York, and The Wilderness, Umbagog Lake, and their house guests, Mrs. Raymond G. Keeney of Hartford, Conn., and Mrs. N. V. Sigfield of Buffalo, N. Y.

Miss Margaret Jewitt Chamberlain, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lynn Closser Chamberlain of Maplewood, was married to Brewster Huntington Gere, son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Gere of Syracuse this afternoon in the Maplewood Woman's Club. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Fred Clare Baldwin, staff minister of Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church, East Orange.

An attempt will be made this week to pave the way for the ultimate union on a cooperative basis of all agencies in the five borough which now are offering guidance to children in the vacation season, it was announced last night by the Rev. Walter M. Howlett, secretary of the Metropolitan Federation of Daily Vacation Bible Schools.

The French Line steamer Carimare will leave Havre this month for a three-month cruise during which she will serve as a meteorological service station in midAtlantic for the collection of information to be used in improving the safety of transatlantic air services.

ON VISIT: James E. Denton, an Oklahoma farmer who recently killed an escaped convict and wounded the convict's bad-man companion, visited New York last week. "I came without a coat," he told callers, "but I've got a tie, although I don't use it most of the time."

Impressed with the city's recent accomplishments in providing service at the foreign-trade zone it operates on Staten Island, foreign trade organizations started last week to enlist the support of exporters,

Although the humble canna has of recent years been held somewhat in disdain by those who consider themselves artistic gardeners, it has many excellent qualities. For one thing, it continues to bloom for weeks, even for months, on end; and for another it is remarkably free from both insects and diseases.

In a letter to THE TIMES, Jacob L. Darwin, former executive secretary of the Code Authority for the button jobbers' or wholesalers' trade, refers to the recent complaint issued by the Federal Trade Commission against the Covered Button and Buckle Creators, Inc.,

Sanborn G. Tenney, Berkshire manager of Previews, has purchased the property known as Peace Valley Farm near Williamstown, Mass., from Mrs. Filomena Burro of North Adams, Mass. William A. O'Hearn of Getman O'Hearn of North Adams acted as broker.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Lt. Col Lanphear W. Webb Jr., Medical Corps, will proceed on or about July 31, 1937, from New York, N. Y., to Camp Dix, N. J., for temporary duty in connection with Organized Reserves activities, and upon completion of this temporary duty, on or about Aug. 14, 1937, he will return to his proper station, New York. N. Y.

BAR HARBOR, Me. - The month of August will be an active period from both a social and sports standpoint on Mount Desert Island and the various island Summer retreats. The majority of the Summer residents have already arrived.

Isidore Nagler, general manager of the Joint Board of Cloakmakers Unions, has become a co-chairman of the stabilization committee of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board and will head a "conference group" of coat trade executives who will confer with chain, mail order and other retail bodies.
The Senate passed the Wages and Hours Bill late today by a vote of 56 to 28, after crushing most of the important amendment proposals put forward at the close of sharp and sometimes bitter debate.

Queena Mario, Metropolitan ??pera star. who is occupying the Aymar Embury house this season, gave a cocktail party there this afternoon after the tennis matches at Southampton, for her nephew, Harry Van Rennsselaer, who is a member of the Junior Davis Cup team. Among the guests were Mr.

Dr. Theodore P. Appel, Secretary of Health under two Governors, died today after a heart attack at the age of 66. He was appointed to the Cabinet of Governor John S. Fisher in 1927. He also served later under Governor Gifford Pinchot.

Plans for a nation-wide attack on communism and other "legions of irreligion" will be presented to the triennial general convention of the Episcopal Church at Cincinnati in October, the Rev. Theodore S. Will, rector of St. John's Church of Hampton, Va., announced today.

John Talbot defeated Robert Talbot, 7-5, 6-2, 6-3, in the semi-final round of the Staten Island men's singles tennis championship at the Clifton T. C., Arrochar, yesterday. Kennedy Randall Jr., seeded second, eliminated Eugene Phillips, seeded fifth, 6-2, 6-3, 6-3.

A flying tackle made by Charles Cooke, aged 22, of Lowell, who weighs 220 pounds and is a varsity tackle at Bates College, put Emile W. Wesson, 28, also of Lowell, into the hands of the police today. He was charged with breaking and entering.

The biggest fleet of the season turned out today as competition for the August cups of the Yacht Racing Squadron of the Country Club of Westhampton Beach got under way on Moriches Bay. Sixty-six boats slid over the starting line, but they were greeted by very. light breezes out of the east and southeast.

IN rather more substantial lists than usually are made up for August, overtures predominate. Of what may be called the genuine type, introductions to opera, are those of Weber's "Der Freischuetz"' and "Euryanthe"

LIFE OF JOHN KEATS. By Charles Armitage Brown. 8vo. New York: Oxford University Press. $2.50. A portrait of Keats by an intimate friend. CHARLES LAMP AND HIS CONTEMPORARIES. By Edmund Blunden 16mo. New York: The Macmillan Company. $1.25.

A preliminary list of twenty-nine winners of State scholarships provided for children, of soldiers, sailors or marines who enlisted from New York State and died while serving in the armed forces of the United States or as a result of such service, was announced today by the State Education Department.

Dr. William Taylor Wyckoff, a retired Philadelphia dentist, who had practiced in that city for fifty years, died at his home in Ocean City today at the age of 78. He was graduated in 1887 from the old Philadelphia Dental College, forerunner of the Temple University Dental School,

Republican supporters of Mayor La Guardia were somewhat worried yesterday as to whether he would be willing to enter a contest in the party primary, as it became evident that the Mayor would not be endorsed by the Bronx and Queens organizations.

China's plight today reminds us that there is good nationalism and bad nationalism; just as there were good corporations and bad ones under Theodore Roosevelt; and even as there are honest profits and unreasonable profits under Franklin Roosevelt.

The marriage of Miss Celestia Whitney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Whitney of this place, to William L. Thomson of Burlington, Vt., son of the late Mr. and Mrs.G. A. Thomson of Somerville, N. J., will take place on Saturday afternoon at Craftsbury Common, Vt., with which many of the prospective bride's forebears were associated.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Protzman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Charles Protzman, to Jesse Webb, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Everett Webb, took place today at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Redeemer. The ceremony was fr performed by the Rev.' Charles A. Hensel.
Police today investigated a report of a Radcliffe College girl that the May Day desecration of Plymouth Rock was the work of Harvard College students.

The hardest thing about seeing the America's Cup..race today off Newport was to decide Whether the big show was ahead or behind. Ahead, skimming over the bluegray Atlantic, were the tall, slim racers of which one man said, "Boy, when I see a boat like that I think of a Follies' beauty."

Tennis will occupy the center of attention for members of the Summer colony of Mount Desert Island and its Summer retreats of Bar Harbor, Northeast Harbor and Seal Harbor for the next fortnight. Beginning Monday the annual maritime tennis tournament will commence at the Bar Haubor Club

Dates have been announced for several debutante parties which will take place during the early weeks of September. On Sept. 11 Miss Mariana Lloyd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Lloyd, and Miss Frances Berking, daughter of Mrs. Max Berking, will be presented to society.

Mykola Lysenko's. opera "Taras Bulba," based on Gogol's story of that name, was produced in a new version at the Kieff Opera recently where it proved one of the outstanding successes of . the Ukrainian opera season.

The British Government is convinced that further consolidation of the much-advertised Rome-Berlin axis would constitute a grave menace to the peace of Europe. Premier Neville Chamberlain is keenly interested to use every occasion offered to weaken the Berlin-Rome combination.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher in training in, day secondary other than Junior high schools, in the subjects indicated, be issued, as of July 29, 1937. to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefor.

Miss Elsie Jeanne Schumaker, daughter of L. J. Schumaker of Elkins Park, was married this morning to Albert C. Britt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin T. Britt of Rydal. The ceremony was performed by the Rt. Rev. Thomas F. McNally in the rectory of the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Jenkintown.

Blown in all her splendor and sailing sheer above the sea, -the defender Ranger today won the first race of the sixteenth British struggle to regain the America's Cup, which dates back nine years before Abraham Lincoln became President.
C. R. (Sandy) Somerville, dour Scot from London, Ont., won his sixth Canadian amateur golf title today by defeating Phil Farley of Montreal by 2 and 1 in their 36-hole final.

Eight hundred music teachers and supervisors of twenty-five States will assemble at New York University, Wednesday, for a four-day Alumni Reunion, under auspices of the department of music of the School of Education, Washington Square East.

Bond prices fluctuated irregularly within narrow limits yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, Trading, from time to time, was almost at a standstill. Total transactions in the two-hour period amounted to only $2,712,100, compared with $2,732,500 on Saturday the week before.
An order to cease work went out today to Illinois members of the Progressive Miners of America after a collapse of negotiations for a new contract with the Coal Producers Association.

N0 industry is undergoing a more, radical and rapid change than that of the coach trailer. After the first spurt -of business, which brought scores of-,new companies into the trailer' manufacturing field, the more responsible companies have set about analyzing their markets. The results of this analysis to date lave brought , some innovations which may alter considerably' the merchandising- policies of the industry.

H. M. S. York, flagship of Vice Admiral Sidney J. Meyrick, sent here for the America's Cup races as the official representative of the British Navy, will dress ship Wednesday morning at 8 o'clock and will fire a salute of twenty-one guns at noon in honor of the birthday anniversary of Queen Elizabeth.

A tract of about five acres of waterfront property at Douglaston, L. I., has been purchased by a syndicate organized by Thomas J. Buckley of 512 Fifth Avenue, this city, for immediate improvement with artistic homes ranging in price from $10,000 to $14,000.

Johnny Levinson, the New England amateur champion from Kennebunk, Me., became the first repeater in that sectional golfing competition today by defeating Eddie Lowery of -Newton, Mass., 2 and 1, in the eighteen-hole final at Ekwanok.

Plans for construction of a dam and development of water resources at Cypress Lake to feed the irrigation projects at Eastend and Valmarie in Southwestern Saskatchewan are under consideration, J. G. Gardiner,

The Government has announced a reduction in the import duty on gasoline from 10 to 9 cents a gallon pending an adjustment of the wholesale prices with representative oil companies here. Wholesalers had announced a price increase of 1 cent a gallon.

The Federal Government has profited to the extent of $11,326,385 through the sale of municipal bonds accepted as security for loans made by the Public Works Administration, a report by Charles J. Maxcy, chief accountant of the PWA, showed today.

Debits to individual accounts as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended July 28 aggregated $8,369,000,000, or 6 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week, and 12 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

A different light on the outbreak of last May in Barcelona and the suppression of the P. O. U. M. which was reported to have resulted in the death of 600 and the wounding of 1,400 was thrown by Fenner Brockway, general secretary of the British independent labor party, in a statement he issued here today in connection with the arrest of J. M. Escuder,

Alexander Knight, a former executive of the Strawbridge Clothier store here, died at his home in Ambler today. He was 91. He was born in Germantown and was in business until 1914. He was a member of a commission appointed by former Governor Pennypacker to select the site of the present home
OLYMPE BRADNA should be counted among the wonders of the day, for despite two years in Hollywood she remains her natural self-a vivacious and wholesome young lady of 17 with large brown eyes,
Bermuda's new racing fleet of five international One-Design Class yachts was completed yesterday with the arrival of the last four boats from Norway.

The Senate's refusal again today to attach the Wagner-Van Nuys AntiLynching Bill to another piece of legislation means, according to Senator Copeland, that the bill has "no chance" for enactment as separate legislation.

Miss Lynda L. Dickinson, daughter of Mrs. Lynford M. Dickinson of New York and Noroton, will be married to Richard Lewis Linkroum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard G. Linkroum of Hackensack, N. J., and Darien, on Sept. 25, in the Noroton Presbyterian Church with a reception to follow at the Dickinson house.

A FTER considerable delay all of the long-awaited British coronation stamps are now available to American collectors. The last arrivals are the sets of Papua and Territory of New Guinea. Each series has four values, and the designs are similar to those used for the adhesives of Nauru. The coronation set of New Zealand, consisting of three values and surcharged for use in Cook Islands and Niue, has been received.

THE peacock feathers which figure in this story are not the lethal weapons. (Some day we may have a mystery yarn in which the victim is tickled to death, but this is not it.) Neither do the peacock feathers supply the motive for the murders.
DIPLOMATIC: Political appointments through most of American history have characterized our diplomatic service.

Faced with the greatest crop disaster in the history of its western prairies, Canada, which a year ago still had a surplus it could not sell, this year, even with its new crop and the balance of its old surplus combined, will be able to play only second fiddle in the world export market.
Renewed outbursts of violence which resulted in injuries to six men marked one of the city's two truck strikes today, while Federal and State labor conciliators sought to arrange settlements.

Opponents of rigid college entrance requirements are claiming a preliminary victory for their cause. They see it in the announcement that some 900 boys and girls who by special dispensation entered the leading colleges of the country last September without examination or the usual credits have won just as good grades in their freshman year as their classmates trained in the traditional subjects.
The work by the Non-Intervention Committee has reached a stage in which it may be described as having achieved success in a broad field while failing to reach its Immediate objective.
The Twenty-third Street Association points out that the new Madison Square postoffice on Twentythird Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, will be officially opened about Sept. 20.

Retail trade advanced to higher levels in most of the important trading centers last week. Gains of 8 per cent or more were estimated for leading department stores here. Buying continued heavy in the South, with clearance events stimulating the demand for merchandise.

Holding that the Moredall Realty Corporation, owner of the Capitol Theatre, had infringed on the copyright of the play, "Dishonored Lady," by exhibiting the motion picture, "Letty Lynton," in 1932, Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson ordered the corporation to pay all damages, costs and profits from the picture to the play authors.

Southern reaction to the Scottsboro case compromise is as varied as the fates meted out to the defendants. It is as varied as are present-day social, economic and political opinions in the South. On Birmingham's downtown streets last Monday a radio interviewer found that every passer-by he halted was strongly convinced that the four Negroes who were released should have been prosecuted.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 30: MAJOR GENERAL Reed, W. L., the Inspector General, one month leave, Aug. 1.

A spectacular fire of unknown origin swept through the Foremen-Bladas Lumber Company yard at 11 South Street here this morning, destroying lumber valued at between $25,000 and $50,000. To protect the near-by crude oil tanks of the Texas Oil Company a general alarm calling all available fire apparatus to the scene was sounded.
Newport's Summer colony was almost deserted today, for everybody that could get away was out to see the first of the America's Cup races.

Nearly one hundred girls between the ages of 17 and 19 are traveling this week from every corner of the globe toward Camp Andree, national Girl Scout camp near Briar cliff Manor, N. Y., where they wil assemble, Aug. 9, for the first inter national encampment of Girl Scout and Girl Guide delegates ever held in the United States.

State Motor Vehicle Commissioner Arthur W. Magee announced Friday that there were 552 automobile fatalities in New Jersey in the first six months of this year, an increase of 126 over the corresponding period in 1936.

Surrealism, futurism and other so-called modern forms of painting are expressions of inefficiency, according to Abel G. Warshawsky, portrait and landscape painter who sailed early yesterday on the Holland-America liner Volendam. Mr. Warshawsky said that one of his last portraits was of Irving Thalberg, the film director, completed just before Mr. Thalberg died. The canvas is to be presented soon to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

A gesture interpreted as a move to appease Nationalistic and Leftist factions was made today in the announcing that seven prominent in-. tellectuals, who had been imprisoned for weeks In Soochow on charges of subversive activities based on their advocacy of a united front with the Communists for war with Japan, had been released on bail. This was hailed with much popular enthusiasm.

When the General Motors Corporation reported last week that there were just ten days during the second quarter of this year on which its plants were wholly free from one kind of "outlaw" strike or another, it emphasized a question of increasing concern to American industry.

Losses in five of its components caused THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity to drop three points for the week ended July 24, and it now stands at 107.1. The figure was 110.1 for the previous week, and 101.3 for the corresponding week last year.

The weathered old lightship which for years flashed a warning to mariners on Stone Horse Shoal in Vineyard Sound, and was recently superseded for a more modern craft, is being outfitted as a whaler and presently will cruise the Atlantic in quest of whales.

In point of importance as a subject of new legislation for the prevention of tax avoidance, the personal holding company appears to have taken first place. This is indicated by the fact that the holding company was the first to emerge in Chairman Doughton's

The ten - story Twenty- eighth Street Arcade Building at 121-123 East Twenty-seventh Street, running through to 118 East Twentyeighth Street, will be sold at auction Wednesday in the Vesey Street salesrooms under foreclosure proceedings.

Purchase of the old Kessel farm, which is said to be the last remaining farm property in Glendale in the Woodhaven section of Queens, has been made by Oscar F. Schmitt and Charles Raedle, operating as Van Dine Homes, Inc., for immediate improvement as a new home community.
Rising world prices, due to the civil war in Spain, have added a new incentive to the adulteration of olive oil by unscrupulous importers and have prompted revival of the Olive Oil Association.

The Republic Steel Corporation announced today that improvements costing about $1,000,000 for the Youngstown plants are to be put under way. The program includes rebuilding and enlarging of blast furnace No. 3 to increase capacity from 500 to 850 tons daily and later to 1,000

Miss Harriet Maria Root is the woman who answers America's questions as chief of the United States Information Service. Members of Congress telephone her to find out who's who in the capital. Plain citizens write to ask her about poison ivy, etiquette and American history.

The Japanese Army in North China at dawn today resumed its attempt to clean out "the nests of Chinese snipers" in this area. The planned aerial review by Japanese Army planes which was intended to awe and intimidate the Chinese populace was postponed because of a low ceiling and bad flying conditions.

Breaking of ground for the new library to be erected by the College of New Rochelle on the campus here, at a cost of $300,000 will take place early this week as soon as demolition of the four frame resident halls on the proposed site is completed, it was announced today.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, today attributed General Motors Corportion's decrease in net earnings for the second quarter of 1937 in part to effects of what he termed "backward and unlightened labor policy during the period from 1933 to 1937."

FOR thousands of years the little town of Santa Eulalia lived its quiet, subtropical existence, washed by the blue waters of the Mediterranean. Here civilizations had lived and died and here, also, various races had merged, until in the twentieth century the village was peopled by hardy fisher-folk

Mrs. Marie Louise de Hasperg, wife of Gustave de Hasperg, died yesterday after a long illness at her residence, 993 Park Avenue. Besides her husband, who has not used his German title of baron since becoming an American citizen, she is survived by a daughter, Mrs. Dorothy Norris of 55 East Seventysecond Street. Originally Marie Louise Thompson of Baltimore, Mrs. de Hasperg was formerly the wife of Alfred E. Norris.

Jesse (Old Pop) Haines today edified a ladies' day crowd of 11,135 and relieved Onkel Franz Frisch's headache greatly by pitching the gas-house gang into a third-place tie with the Pirates as the Cardinals beat the Dodgers, 4-3.

Spiegel, Inc., reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on June 30 a net income of $3,490,665 after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. This was equal to $2.48 each on 1,275,658 common shares after preferred dividend requirements and it compared with a net profit of $2,657,694, or $9.46 a share, on 253,000 common shares for the preceding twelve months.

CONTRAST between light and dark woods is an interesting decorative device seen in this season's furniture, on display in newly arranged store ensembles. One light piece, for example, is used in a room in which the rest of the furniture is in the traditional dark walnut or mahogany, or the contemporary brown woods, such as macassar ebony. Even in the same piece of furniture both light and dark woods are used.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Hackett of New York, who are passing the season at Saranac Inn, have sent out invitations to their annual informal reception, which will be held next Saturday in the Casino. Largest of the parties of each season here, the event is welcomed as introductory to many other smart events annually scheduled through August.

Many of the members of the St. Regis camp colony will join in the intercamp tennis tournaments which will be played during August on the different private courts. Miss Katharine G. Brewster is with her mother and sister at the Brewster camp on Spitfire Lake.

The success of Colonel Fulgenclo Batista, Chief of Staff of Cuba's army, in putting into effect his recently announced three-year plan for economic and social reconstruction in the island will depend largely on the extent to which he is prepared to use the power Which,
A new threat arose from an unexpected quarter today in the trial series noon. among the Six-Meter boats for the honor of defending the Gold Cup.

An effigy of Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA administrator, escaped a trial by fire in Columbus Circle yesterday afternoon in the presence of about 5,000 persons who had gathered to protest against wholesale reductions begun recently in the rolls of the WPA.
The drive to end the Congress session quickly, quiescent during the last two days of debate in the Senate, began anew tonight following the passage of the Administration's Wages and Hours Bill.
The National Labor Relations Board today said that recent elections by shoe workers in Lewiston and Auburn, Me., factories did not give the bargaining rights of those workers to the C. I. O.

One hundred and fifty teachers from public and private high schools throughout the country are creating today on the campus of Sarah Lawrence College a Summer session "workshop," which is unique in that there are no grades, credits, required class attendance or written examinations.
Double tragedy wrote an epitaph today over the ruined career of Alfredo Codona, 43, once worldrenowned master of the flying trapeze.

Eight transients were killed and eight others were seriously injured early today when a transcontinental freight train was derailed on the Canadian National Railway's main line, 97 miles northwest of Sudbury.
Our newest film expedition to Africa has already had its baptism of adventure, nearly costing the lives oftwo of my dearest friends and avoiding that tragedy by something less than a hairbreadth.

William L. Root, who will be 80 years old on Aug 29, is still doing business at the same old standafter fifty-two years. The veteran Theresa merchant recalled how a sprained back which he suffered while lifting stone caused him to seek a different career, and how he established his store at the behest of the physician who attended him.

Miss Louisa Thompson MacGill, daughter of Mrs. J. Charles MacGill and the late Mr. MacGill, was married to J. Wistar Huey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Wistar Huey of Ruxton, today by the Rev. William Wilton Shearer at St. Timothy's Protestant Episcopal Church. The ceremony was followed by a reception at the Catonsville home of Mrs. MacGill.

Three Indianapolis men were under arrest on congregating charges here tonight after police halted picketing of the State headquarters of the Works Progress Administration by about 100 members of the Indiana Workers Alliance.

Mrs. Margaret Biddle of Pennsylvania, wife of A. J. Drexel Biddle Jr., Ambassador to Poland, paid $20,000 for Democratic souvenir convention books, autographed by the President, according to a summary for Pennsylvania made public today.

The grain markets showed a heavy undertone today, the one exception being September corn, which was bid up as much as 2 cents a bushel on buying by cash houses and shorts as the result of receipts of only four

August, the month of the National Sweepstakes regatta at Red Bank, will find skippers quitting their favorite courses and haunts along the Sound, Great South Bay and the Hudson and exploring the two Shrewsbury Rivers. No near-by waterway is having a greater boom in popularity this season.
The Western Union Telegraph Company announced yesterday that, effective today, the cost of cable night- letters between the United States and Havana would be reduced.

Nine Negroes accused of bootlegging on a pre-repeal scale and popularizing fiery "King Kong" whisky at five cents a pony in Harlem were sentenced in Federal court yesterday by Judge Sidney S. Mize. Six of them went to jail and the three others. including two women, received suspended sentences.

The Spencer-Kellogg plant here, largest linseed-oil refinery in the United States, was tied up this afternoon by a sit-down strike called by the United Linseed and Vegetable Oil Workers Industrial Union of the C. I. O. in a dispute over the progress of negotiations for a contract.

Joseph Stalin's ruthless campaign against Fascist traitors, Trotskyists and industrial saboteurs in Russia has now reached the Karclian Soviet republic, where a through purge occurred last year, resulting in the deposition and deportation of leading administrators.

The project for an interborough express highway between Brooklyn and Queens, now before the Board of Estimate, is called by Edward A. MacDougall, president of the Queensboro Corporation, one of the most important improvement plans that has been suggested in the city for some time.

Coast Guard headquarters was informed just before last midnight that the Yankee, a 780-ton. steamship ordinarily operated as a.ferryboat between New London, Conn., and the eastern tip of Long Island, had grounded on Gin Beach, near Montauk Point, in a fog. -A subsequent message, however,

Donald Hawley of Orange, defending his laurels here and seeking his fifth successive title in the State this season, gained the final of the North Jersey tennis championship at the Westfield T. C. today. He defeated William Lurie of Brooklyn, last year's metropolitan public parks champion, 6-0, 7-5.

The Canadian men's singles lawn tennis title remained in California today when Walter Senior of San Francisco battled through five sets to defeat Bobby Murray of Montreal, 2-6, 6-3, 6-2, 3-6, 6-2, in this year's final.

Frank Bloom, trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board, declared at a hearing of charges against the Todd Shipyards Corportion and its subsidiaries here yesterday morning that "this case has reached a point where all records are being broken as far as perjury is concerned."

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday at Blue Hill, Me., of Dr. Frederic Bierhoff of 88 Central Park West, a urologist who had been practicing surgery in this city for more than forty years. His widow is the former Hannah Newbore Younker.

President Roosevelt expresses admiration for the accomplishments of President Kemal Ataturk of Turkey in reconstructing that country since he became Pesident fourteen years ago, and the Turkish leader declares that Turkey and the United States share the same ideals, in an exchange of letters made public yesterday.

Lyon Boston, son of the late Charles A. Boston, former president of the American Bar Association, resigned yesterday as an assistant district attorney on the staff of District Attorney William C. Dodge to resume private practice. He is to rejoin the firm of Miller, Owen Otis Bailly, of which former Governor Nathan L. Miller is senior member.

Just three years ago this month the President, by Executive order, established the Plains Shelterbelt Zone and outlined a plan for the planting of a "belt" of trees about 100 miles wide and 1,000 miles long from the Canadian border to Amarillo, Texas. The primary purpose of this "belt" was to protect the soil against wind orosion and to help hold moisture in the ground.

A genuine demand exists for medium-priced homes in the lower Flatbush area of Brooklyn, state Match Brothers, builders of the Brookshire home community at Bedford Avenue and Avenue V. More than sixty homes have been sold there in the last two months, they report, the houses ranging from $5,000 to $6,000 in price.

The last formal parade and review of the 1937 Camp Dix Citizens Military Training Camp regiment will be held tomorrow, with the cadet regimental staff in command. Special plans have been made to accommodate the largest group of visitors of the season.

Dr. William H. Weston, retired New York physician, died yesterday after a week's illness at the home of his daughter, Miss Zady P. Weston of 249 West Eleventh Street. He was born in Hancock, N. H., eighty-seven years ago, and received his M. D. from the College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1879. Besides Miss Weston, he is survived by his widow, Mrs.

Miss Cynthia M. Wickwire, daughter of Mrs. C. Leonard O'Connor of this place and the late F. R. Wickwire, was married here tonight in the First Presbyterian Church to James D. Taylor Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Taylor of Syracuse, by the Rev. Lindsay S. B. Hadley.

With the performance of "Goetterdaemerung" last night the repertoire of operas in the Wagner Festival was concluded. "Parsifal," "Lohengrin" and the four Ring operas will be repeated until the festival closes Aug. 21.

LEWISOHN STADIUM'S Wagner Festival, which concluded last Tuesday night, attracted a total attendance of about 81,000. Spread over five performances, this is not an impressive number, and the Stadium Concerts management, though somewhat disappointed, is seeking consolation in the following general observations:

Before sixty-five horrified members of the congregation, Fred W. Simmons, 40, an El Centro hatchery owner, shot and killed Dr. O. L. Webster, a Holtville physician, and then killed himself today at the altar of the Seventh Day Adventist Church here.

Retirement of Herbert Brownell and Jr., a leading member of the Assembly since 1933, became known yesterday when it was learned that the Republican organization of the Tenth Manhattan Assembly District had designated MacNeil Mitchell for nomination to that office. Mr. Brownell was not a candidate for renomination.

The week's debate in the Senate over the Wages and Hours Bill has revealed more clearly than anything else the fact that little is known about the extent to which it will affect the industry and economy of the country.
The police in Northern Ireland and the Irish Free State searched today for a factory that they believed had supplied extremists opposed to British rule with explosives for a new outburst of violence.

At least five times the splendid palace that stood at the gate of the fortress city of Megiddo on the Palestinian plain was nearly destroyed by invading armies. Five times it was rebuilt. The field of Armageddon lay on the military road connecting Egypt with the East. It was always a field of battle,

Professor, Highway Engineering, University of North Carolina IN spite of the efforts of cities, State organizations and various safety associations to reduce the accident toll, figures for the first five months of the present year indicate that fatalities resulting from motor vehicle accidents were 17 per cent greater than for the corresponding period in 1936.

Captain Charles. O. Brooks, master of the burned steamship City of Baltimore of the Chesapeake Line repeated in testimony today before the Federal board of inquiry his statements suggesting that the rapidly spreading fire had been started deliberately.

Nearly $750,000 is being spent in renovating and modernizing the Hotel Commodore at Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street. According to Frank J. Crohan, president of the hotel company, the changes constitute the first major structural and renovating job since the hotel's erection in 1918-19.

The War Department announced today that the following residents of New York State had accepted appointment in the Officers Reserve Corps: First Lieutenants Bernard M. Friedman, 231 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, medical.

The two four-story multi-family dwellings at 343 and 345 East Seventeenth Street have been converted into one building five stories high with one common entrance. The structure will be numbered 345 East Seventeenth Street.

ALEXANDRIA BAY-Thousand Islands cruise spielerss" are megaphoning new attractions in the St. Lawrence this Summer. They include castles and cottages on island retreats that range in size from mere perches to Wellesley, twice the size of Manhattan and the second largest island in the Thousand Island group.

Frederick G. Dexter, former manger of the Newark (N. J.) agency of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of the New York, died Friday night at the Dover General Hospital at Dover, N.. J., after a long illness. Mr. Dexter was 56 years old and was the son of George T. Dexter, formerly vice president of the insurance company. Surviving are his widow, Marie G. Dexter, and a brother, Leon Dexter.
National advertisers are definitely optimistic about Fall prospects and have substantially increased their advertising budgets for the remainder of the year, a survey revealed here yesterday.

Motion picture operators at two neighborhood movie houses came out of their projection booths yesterday morning after an all-night sit-down with . agreements which give them a thirty-hour week and pay increase of about 50 per cent.

Dudley Roberts Jr., medalist in the qualifying round played last weekend, continued his march toward the final rounds in the tournament for the Charles H. Dickerman Memorial Cup on the Maidstone Club course today defeating Dr. F. C. Carr, 2 and 1.

The British Board of Boxing Control emerged from a lengthy conference today to announce that it had decided to recognize the Tommy Farr-Joe Louis bout "as the final elimination contest for the world heavyweight championship." The winner, the solons decided, would have to meet Max Schmeling for the crown.

AN experimental program for older boys, combining vocational and hobby pursuits with adventure and exploration, is being conducted this Summer in Treasure Valley, the Worcester Scout camp at Paxton, Mass. The experiment has been devised and is directed by Paul Siple, who represented the Boy Scouts of America on the Antarctic expeditions of Admiral Byrd.

George Z. Medalie, former United States attorney, sailed yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia for a vacation on the Riviera. He and Mrs. Medalie will meet their two children, Arthur, 17, and Gladys, 15, who have been on a conducted tour abroad. They will return early in September.

The Hackensack Water Company reports that during the past year 14.55 miles of mains were added, in contrast to 12.76 miles in the previous year. Connections for new houses aggregated 871, connections in streets to be improved, 387, and old connections replaced, 664, making a total of 1,922 new connections, as against 1,701 for 1936. Most of the new work was in various sections of Bergen County, N. J.

The Director of the Mint will deliver next week 50,000 half dollars to the United States Antietam Celebration Commission here, commemorating the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Battle of Antietam, which was fought at Sharpsburg, thirteen miles south of here, Sept. 17, 1862.

Official announcement has now been made that Captain Fanger, commander of the Deutschland when it was bombed by Spanish fliers in May has been dismissed from his post and given a land command. He will be replaced by Captain Wenneker, until recently naval attache at Tokyo.

Miss Alice Corneille, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Corneille of Englewood, N. J., was married here this afternoon to Michael Hart Cardozo 4th, son of Ernest A. Cardozo of New York and the late Mrs. Emily Wolff Cardozo. The ceremony took place at the Summer home of Justice W. Charles Poletti of the New York Supreme Court, who performed the ceremony.

The marriage of Miss Margaretta Millar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Millar of this city, to Maxwell Brace Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Brace of Syracuse, took place here this afternoon in Calvary Church. The ceremony was performed by the Right Rev. Edward H. Coley, Bishop of Central New York, and the Rev. D. Charles White.

Lawson Little, the former amateur king from San Francisco, shot into the lead in the St. Paul $5,000 open golf tournament today with a halfway mark total of 140 strokes, but once again it was Light Horse Harry Cooper of Chicago who furnished the drama.

The Summer place which is occupied but a comparatively short period each year presents its own peculiar problems when it comes to the question of planning a garden to surround it. These problems, however, can be solved.

IT is certain, finally, that Walter Huston will be .swinging East from California to be in a new play next season, and if you have nothing better to do this morning you can try to figure out just what this will be. Mr. Huston doesn't quite know himself, but he has an idea, or rather several ideas, which he sets down as follows:
Both the Insurgent and the Government high commands today reported an Insurgent victory in Eastern Spain, where General Francisco Franco is trying to drive a wedge between Madrid and Valencia.
The universal exhibition which is to be held in Rome in 1940 is already making great strides toward completion. It will be, in fact, a milestone in the Eternal City's expansion toward the sea.

All is activity at Tanglewood midway between Lenox and Stockbridge where the fourth annual Berkshire Music Festival is to be held for the coming two weeks starting next Thursday. Six concerts are to be given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra-on Aug. 5, 7, 8, 12, 14 and 15.

Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kennedy's Audwill Stables of Southboro, Mass., won twenty-seven prizes and led all competitors by a wide margin in the two-day Pittsfield Horse Show that ended tonight. Twelve were first prizes, five second, six third and four fourth.

More than a hundred of the best young soapboxers in New York to City competed yesterday afternoon in the second annual championship derby. A soapboxer, according to the rules of the derby, is a boy not more than 15 years old who has built an engineless vehicle out of odds and ends costing not more than $10.

The National Maritime Union has y instructed its district council to ask the ship lines operating from the Atlantic, Gulf and Great Lakes ports to negotiate a new wage agreement for unlicensed sea-going personnel to become effective on Sept. 30.

Thomas E. Colleton, New Jersey FHA director, announces that during the three years activity of that office in the State, more than 12,000 insured mortgage commitments have been authorized representing about $60,000,000 in investments by private lending institutions.

Full compensation-for Smithfield hams, delivery of which to officials of the Republic Steel Corporation was prevented by "lawless acts" of strikers, must be made by the Government, Senator Byrd asserted today.

Two police sergeants of the Coney Island station received minor injuries last night in the course of a free-for-all fight between Gentiles and Jews on the beach at the foot of West Thirty-sixth Street, Coney Island.

Two Long Beach patrolmen and a young woman will be arraigned in Bronx Magistrates Court today, charged with extortion. The complainant, who alleges the men and the woman conspired in an attempt to force him to pay $2,500 "hush money," will be arraigned on a Sullivan Law charge.

IF it is true, as a recent estimate has it, that there are something like 6,000,000 dance students in the United States, then it must also be true that there are approximately 5,000,000 with definite expectations of making Fred Astaire and Eleanor Powell slink furtively out of the studios of Hollywood into a shamefaced oblivion almost any day.

Agreement to demands for immediate enforcement of the neutrality laws could draw the United States into war with China or Japan within an hour, Senator Lewis, a member of the Foreign Relations Committee, assured the Senate today at approximately the same time that dispatches were quoting Foreign Minister Koki Hirota as telling the Japanese Parliament that the United States apparently did not intend to apply the neutrality program.

A motion for a new trial by the landlord of a three-family house against whom a jury in the City Court had rendered a verdict for damages due to injuries sustained by one of his tenants was denied recently by Judge Livoti, before whom the case was tried.

High taxes will soon eliminate most night clubs in Mexico City, thus depriving tourists of their only entertainment after dark. Owners claiming the cabarets are unprofitable except on Saturday nights have applied for authorization to close the rest of the week.

IT is certain, finally, that Walter Huston will be .swinging East from California to be in a new play next season, and if you have nothing better to do this morning you can try to figure out just what this will be. Mr. Huston doesn't quite know himself, but he has an idea, or rather several ideas, which he sets down as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some member of your editorial staff has been very much misinformed as to the Colorado-Big Thompson Reclamation Project, the appropriation for which has been included in the pending Interior Department Appropriation Bill, as is evidenced in an editorial, "A Bad Precedent," in your issue of July 25.

So startling was Ranger's superiority on all points of racing that the American sloop, 2-to-1 choice beforehand, promptly was made a prohibitive betting favorite to keep the ancient America's Cup in this country, where it has been ever since it was captured by the schooner bearing its name in British waters back in 1851.

QUEENS CONNOLLY, JOHN T. (Sept. 2, 1936). Assets. $39,611 gross, $87,843 net. To wife. Minnie S. Connolly. Outstanding holdings in real and personal property. Marinus Willett, attorney, 161-10 Jamaioa Ave., Jamaica.

Hospital Commissioner S. S. Goldwater reported yesterday the final step in the transfer of the care of mentally defective children to the State. Eighteen children, the last of 1,500 who were once inmates of the now razed Children's Hospital on Randalls Island, were transferred from their temporary quarters in the Children's Reception Hospital on East Eleventh Street. to a State institution at Newark, N. Y.

The land at the southwest corner of Broadway and Fifty-first Street on which the Capitol Theatre stands has been purchased by the MetroGoldwyn-Mayer interests, Major Edward Bowes and Messmore Kendall, who control the Capitol Theatre Building and have a long-term lease on the site.

Passenger ships left port last week bound for Europe in many instances with near-capacity lists, indicating again that the traveling public has broken with the tradition that the eastbound season closes with the week of July 4.
THE radio industry is geared to produce millions of new receiving sets, and the merchandisers expect to sell at least 9,000,000 instruments as the record of 1937, and an all-time high.

Automotive trade circles speculated today over the possibilities of a general car price increase in the wake of a first--definite announcement--by the Ford Motor Company and producers' complaints of "rising costs."

A team composed of Meadow Club players and members of the Eastern junior Davis Cup team defeated the combined Oxford-Cambridge team by a score of six matches to three in a tennis tournament today on the Meadow Club courts.

More than 10,000 members of the Junior Inspectors Club, boys and girls from 6 to 18, are meeting each week this Summer in schools, community houses, Y's, and Department of Sanitation buildings throughout the city, and under the direction of WPA councilors are active in baseball. basketball.
HERE is a plump, readable, generously illustrated volume which from now on will probably have to be on the shelves of any student who wishes to know the human history of America.

THE last hot and depressing days of the Staatsoper's season were somewhat enlivened by the joint guest appearances of Elizabeth Rethberg and Ezio Pinza and so what might have been about as diverting as a second-class funeral took on a certain edge.

A mural painting to depict the importance of the written word upon past and future generations of men will be placed in the new library building now in process of erection on the campus of Franklin and Marshall College.

IN that movement-partly political, partly economic and partly cultural-which is sometimes described as the Scottish Renaissance, few novelists are taking a more important share than Neil M. Gunn. None who comes to mind at the moment is producing a body of work so likely to wear well.

Howard Nott Potter, a retired architect, formerly a partner in the firm of Snelling Potter of New York, died here today at his home, The Sea Horse, of a stroke suffered on Thursday. A member of an old and distinguished American family, Mr. Potter was a son of the late Clarkson Nott Potter,

American yacht clubs topped Canadian opposition, five class championships to four, in the classes featuring international competition as the three-day rendezvous of the Lake Ontario Lake Yacht Racing Association was concluded off the port of Rochester today.
THOUGH Summer suns are still hot, travel companies are completing Winter cruise plans with itineraries that cover wide fields.

About 3,000 persons gathered here today to honor the memory of Dr. William Holmes McGuffey, author of the "McGuffey Readers by Grades." The occasion was the centenary of the publication of third and fourth readers.

President Roosevelt was cruising on the Potomac River today but planned to put into the marine base at Quantico, Va., tomorrow to participate in an international broadcast dedicating an Amnerican battle monument at Montfaucon, France.

Miss Barbara Moody, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Henry Herbert Moody of this place, was married here this afternoon to John Baxter Weller, Son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Weller of Chester, Pa., in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector emeritus, Rev. James Alnutt Smith.
