Full compensation-for Smithfield hams, delivery of which to officials of the Republic Steel Corporation was prevented by "lawless acts" of strikers, must be made by the Government, Senator Byrd asserted today.

Two police sergeants of the Coney Island station received minor injuries last night in the course of a free-for-all fight between Gentiles and Jews on the beach at the foot of West Thirty-sixth Street, Coney Island.

Two Long Beach patrolmen and a young woman will be arraigned in Bronx Magistrates Court today, charged with extortion. The complainant, who alleges the men and the woman conspired in an attempt to force him to pay $2,500 "hush money," will be arraigned on a Sullivan Law charge.

IF it is true, as a recent estimate has it, that there are something like 6,000,000 dance students in the United States, then it must also be true that there are approximately 5,000,000 with definite expectations of making Fred Astaire and Eleanor Powell slink furtively out of the studios of Hollywood into a shamefaced oblivion almost any day.

Agreement to demands for immediate enforcement of the neutrality laws could draw the United States into war with China or Japan within an hour, Senator Lewis, a member of the Foreign Relations Committee, assured the Senate today at approximately the same time that dispatches were quoting Foreign Minister Koki Hirota as telling the Japanese Parliament that the United States apparently did not intend to apply the neutrality program.

A motion for a new trial by the landlord of a three-family house against whom a jury in the City Court had rendered a verdict for damages due to injuries sustained by one of his tenants was denied recently by Judge Livoti, before whom the case was tried.

High taxes will soon eliminate most night clubs in Mexico City, thus depriving tourists of their only entertainment after dark. Owners claiming the cabarets are unprofitable except on Saturday nights have applied for authorization to close the rest of the week.

The Rev. D. J. Jenkins, Negro minsister, who founded an orphanage here that has housed and trained 5,000 Negro boys and girls during the last forty-five years, died here last night. He was 74-years old. The orphanage taught some of its inmates to play brass instruments, and the bands toured the United States.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry LaFayette Duncan of Trion, Ga., have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Bettye Grace Duncan of 16 Park Avenue, this city, to Harvey A. Baum of New York and Grantwood, N. J. The marriage will take place on Saturday at the Church of the Transfiguration here. The rector, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, will perform the ceremony.

Adventures of a talking automobile, which winks its headlight eyes and weeps an occasional gasoline tear will be flashed on classroom movie screens from coast to coast this Fall, in a campaign to influence elementary school children to be more careful in traffic.

The mandates commission, which has just begun its examination of the Palestine problem, the knottiest question it has yet faced, is one of the more independent and influential of the League of Nations' permanent organs.

A little more than two months after it started, the strike against "Little Steel" has arrived at a point which pokesmen for the companies regard as a complete victory for them, and which the Steel Workers Organizing Committee considers a ??.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in slightly larger volume than during the preceding period. The most important redemption announcements were for industrial and foreign obligations.

A Negro, identified by the police from papers found in his pockets as William Rivers, 35 years old, of 310 West 150th Street, was killed at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon by an uptown train of the Independent Subway System, in the Second Avenue station at East Houston and Allen Streets. Witnesses declared.

Seventeen persons including five women and two children were slightly injured this afternoon when a fishing schooner rammed and sank a launch in mid-harbor during the celebration welcoming the gunboat Cuba.

LONDON. --The reputation of Khartum in the Sudan for blue sparks and "crackling" has been getting a scientific investigation of late. It seems always to have been recognized that hair was likely to follow the comb in Khartum. Silk shirts, when taken off, were likely to jump up and stick to their wearers.
THE events of the past few days have proved, if more proof were needed, that John Nance Garner is not the sort of Vice President immortalized in the character of Throttlebottom.

Stores and shops of many descripticns are being picketed in the midtown Broadway and Fifth Avenue districts, because -of a variety of disputes, at least one so ancient that the pickets cannot remember why they are picketing, and even union leaders have to look it up in a file, it was disclosed yesterday by a survey of the Times Square sector.
Senators Gillette of Iowa and Clark of Missouri, Democrats, jointly urged Congress today to provide for crop loans this year, in advance of any general farm legislation.
June, four-year-old German police dog, sentenced to death by a Municipal Court judge, tonight was free under an appeal of her owner to the Superior Court.

That breeders and fanciers are increasing the practical use of their dogs aside from show. competition is revealed in the semi-annual standing of breeds compiled by the American Kennel Club. The report shows that there has been a particularly notable advance in registration among breeds best adaptable as watch dogs.

CHINA revisited makes a definite impression. The Chinese have regained their morale. They have taken heart again. The whole nation has had a regeneration of spirit. The change within a few years has been so swift and complete as to be almost incredible.

Picketing came under official ban in this Southern steel capital today when Police Chief Luther Hollums announced his intention to enforce the Alabama law which, he said, forbade this practice common in labor disputes. In an order to all police and detectives the chief said:

President Anastasio Somoza has accepted the resignation of Dr. Vicente Vita, managing director of the Nicaraguan National Bank, who found himself unable to cooperate with the Government. The President stated he would accept the resignation of any other official who felt he could not cooperate, as none was indispensable.

Joyce Carroll Hall, 3 years old, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norham F. Hall of 227 First Street, HoHoKus, N. J., was drowned today in Beaver Lake, six miles from here, where the family has a Summer home.
Hundreds of persons who were brought into the world by Craig Stewart Thomson will gather in this small Rock River Valley town tomorrow to honor the memory of their "country doctor."

With a fleet of 103 yachts starting and more than 90 finishing, the Stamford Yacht Club held its annual regatta today under cloudy skies and with a light wind which started southeast by east and shifted to the northeast, flattening out entirely at times in the late afternoon.

Mr. and Mrs. Jacob F. Parliament of this community have sent out invitations for the marriage of their niece, Miss Muriel Mary Parliament, daughter of the late Dr. David Halsey Parliament, a lieutenant in the Medical Corps in the World War, and Mrs. Parliament, to Herbert John McClain, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. McClain, also of Flanders. The ceremony will be performed at the Methodist Episcopal Church on Aug. 15.

Months ago, when it was apparent that employer-employe relations throughout the country were in such a state of flux that a crisis was not far away, Edgard J. Barcalo, president of the Barcalo Manufacturing Company, decided it was time to develop a constructive program in his plant to prevent a breakdown in confidence between management and workers that had been forty years in the making.

JULY, being the seventh month of the seventh year of the seventh decade after Lincoln's election (note the seven letters in his name), had all the portents in its favor. But that didn't seem to be protection enough.

Trailing eight strokes at the start of the final round, Craig Wood of Rumson today tied Victor Ghezzi of Deal for the New Jersey State open golf championship with a total of 278, ten strokes under par for the seventy-two holes over the. Shackamaori- Country Club course.

Striking miners voted today to return next week at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's mines in Johnstown and Heilwood, Pa. President James Mark of District No. 2 of the United Mine Workers said he advised the men to return to work following a conference with officials of the Industrial Collieries, Bethlehem subsidiary.

WHITTLERS interested in nature find bird-carving an absorbing hobby. All that is needed for this pastime is a block of wood, a common jack-knife, and a child's set of water colors. Bird pictures suitable for patterns are found in books and magazines or may be purchased from the Audubon Socity. Bird-carving is not difficult, although it requires considerable time and patience.

Bolivia abandoned today her experiment in State socialism and returned to the democratic-republican form of representative government. President German Busch's new Cabinet voted unanimously to reinstate the Constitution of 1880, which had been in effect since the nitrate war with Chile until it was abolished by Lieut. Col. David Toro's regime in May, 1936.

Two men died as a result of an automobile crash in front of 129 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers, at 3:15 A. M. yesterday. Hyman Alth, 50 years old, of 36 Post Street, driver of a bakery truck, was killed, and his helper, Solomon Auslander, 20, of 12 Stanley Place, suffered severe cuts and bruises and was treated at Yonkers General Hospital.

The engagement of Miss Katherine Mary Dowd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Dowd of this place and Fayetteville, N. C., to Dr. Charles J. Crawley of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents. Miss Dowd is a graduate of St. Joseph's Academy, Brentwood, and St. Elizabeth's College.

Louis L. Fink, 67-year-old New York Central engineer who has been riding trains for thirty-six years without getting much of anywhere, retired today so that he could do some traveling that would take him "places."

A new lake has been added to the Erskine Lakes chain in the Ramapo Mountain region of upper Passaic County, N. J., in the purchase by the Ringwood Company of Pines Lake with its shore properties near Pompton and nearly in the center of Passaic County.

Harbor police dragged the Potomac River today for. the body of Leona Beck, 16 years old, who plunged 100 feet from a bridge after her mother reprimanded her for keeping late hours, according to a report made to police by the mother.

Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Richmond Place of The Port, this place, and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Richmond Place, to Monroe Woods Gill, Son of Mr. and Mrs. William Everett Gill of Cambridge and Camden, Me.

Because twenty of its horses were "down with the flu," Weequahic Park's trotting races were called off today. Paul Keim, acting secretary of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey, sponsor of the races, said it was the first time in twenty years that a matinee was called off for illness of horses.

A new three-story building but equivalent in height to the average four-story structure is being erected on the plot fronting twenty-five feet at 12 West Fortieth Street, opposite the New York Public Library for W. H. Hall, Inc., furriers.

Charles E. Hires, root beer manufacturer, who developed a business with a capital of $5,300,000 out of roots, bark and berries, died at his home in Haverford early today in his eighty-sixth year. - He suffered a stroke yesterday as he was preparing to go on a fishing trip.

Whether holders of Alleghany Corporation bonds of 1950 would improve their position by accepting a "junior security," as proposed in the plan for its absorption in the Chesapeake Corporation is questioned by Theodore Prince.

The marriage of Miss Katrina Auchincloss, daughter of Mrs. Edgar Stirling Auchincloss of 123 East Sixty-ninth Street, New York, and this place to Royal Elting Mygatt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic E. Mygatt also of New York, and Washington, Conn., took place here this afternoon at Keewaydin, the home of the bride's mother.
AMONG other institutions and folkways emerging from the trials of lean years-or in a few cases failing to emerge-are the country clubs.

The marriage of Miss Marion Elizabeth Pardee of Glen Ridge, niece of Miss Mary Pardee of Grand Haven, Mich., to Harold Hawkey, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Hawkey of Upper Montclair, took place today in the rectory of the Immaculate Conception Church, Montclair.

The steamer Andrea Luckenbach set a new record today when she went through the Panama with cargo of 8,836,000 board feet of lumber from Longview, Washington, to Providence, R. I., via Poughkeepsie, N. Y. The cargo consisted -largely of Douglas fir.

A mother who had not seen her twin 6-year-old daughters for several years was compelled in Domestie Relations Court yesterday to contribute $25 a month for their support, although her estranged husband already is contributing a like sum.

One of the clauses in the new building code which met with considerable objection during the discussions on the code changes in the Board of Aldermen was that permitting welding instead of riveting in steel construction.

The following foreign service changes made since July 24 were announced today by the State Department: David Williamson of Colorado Springs, American Foreign Service Officer. state Department, designated Second Secretary of Embassy at London.

Rose manuals generally advise full sun for roses, though, quite inconsistently, they also suggest shelter from wind as most desirable. Free air circulation is demanded, principally as a mildew-preventing essential.

To clarify the legal status of Connecticut brokers who sell property in New York State, G. LeRoy Kemp, president of the Connecticut Association of Real Estate Boards, asked the New York Division of Licenses to define the ruling. The following reply was received from A. S. Wechsler, acting chief of the New York License Division:

Mrs. Mary Toms Erwin of Durham, N. C., daughter of the late Clinton White Toms, once president of the Liggett Myers Tobacco Co., was married here today to Edmund McCullough Cameron of Durham at the Summer home of her brotherin-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. John Adams Buchanan. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Donald Stewart, pastor of the Presbyterian Church of Chapel Hill.

Some 40,000 Germans from Poland, Czechoslovakia, Austria and Rumania joined here tonight with 500,000 Reich Germans in a wild demonstration for the unification of all Germans into one nation. The occasion was the congress of German choral societies.

Close of play scores in first-class English cricket games started today follow: Surrey 264 (Squires 54, Holmes 53, Brooks 52 not out. Butler four for 70); Nottinghamshire 51 for one. at the oval. Yorkshire 246 (Sutcliffe 122, Mitchell 71, Pollard five for 59); Lancashire 59 for one. at Sheffield.
Three of the crew of the Spanish Government freighter AndutzMendi, which was set afire by the cross-fire of two unidentified submarines, were rescued today by a fishing boat.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. W. Hall Headington of 210 East Sixty-eighth Street of the engagement of Mrs. Headington's daughter, Miss Grace Allen Toucey, to Oscar Credelle Turner, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Duncan Turner of Birmingham, Ala.

Miss Mildred Mary Hallahan, daughter of Mrs. Timothy Hallahan of West Brighton, S. I., and the late Mr. Hallahan, was married there yesterday afternoon in the Sacred Heart Church to S. Spalding McSheehy, son of Mrs. Edward B. MeSheehy, also of West Brighton, and the late Mr. McSheehy.

Dr. E. M. Corthell fought a meningitis epidemic in scattered Indian villages today while he radioed Instructions to his wife on the care of patients whom he had left behind in the Mountain Village hospital.

The fiftieth anniversary - tournament of the Seabright Lawn tennis :and- Crickets Club. came -to a.: close today with the first default registered in memory in the final of the mien''s singles' without a blow being struck. : - - :

When the republic came into being in 1931 there was a movement backed by some Left Wing political leaders to discourage the public's love for bull-fighting because it was thought that Spain's great national sport was too traditionally identified with the monarchy.

The marriage of Miss Lois Emily Procter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percy L. Procter of South Orange, to Victor Carl Bonardel of Union, took place this afternoon in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Eric M. Tasman, rector of the Church of the Holy Communion, South Orange. Miss Margaret Brennan of Newark was maid of honor.
The theories of race propounded by German scientists were combated in communications from several Americans to the World Congress on Populations here today.

The statue of Captain John Ericsson, which .stands in Battery Park, was decorated with a wreath yesterday afternoon to mark the 134th anniversary of the birth of the Swedish-American inventor of the famous Civil War batteship Monitor. The John Ericsson Society of New York gave the wreath.
Hopeh Province, the heart and nerve center of North China, is a land of fertile plains and teeming cities. It is as large as Czechoslovakia, as populous as Spain.

While clergymen here have adopted "no consistent line of action" in regard to labor disputes, the clergy generally throughout the country have been on the side of labor, the National Conference of Jews and Christians reported yesterday.
Waterlilies and cannas are making a brilliant seasonal debut at New York Botanical Garden. The two pools of lilies, surrounded with cacti and other succulents, lie south of the main conservatory.

Chief Scout Lord BadenPowell styled the Boy Scout movement as the "Junior League of Nations" in his reply to an address by Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands, opening the fifth world jamboree at Vogelnzang today.

Because of a readjustment in computing fares, the new local passenger rates, effective today on the Long Island Railroad, will be 5 cents less on one-way coach tickets between the railroad's terminals in New York and Brooklyn and more than forty different points on Long Island, A. H. Shaw, general passenger agent, announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY.-With sailing becoming increasingly popular in this vicinity; much interest is being shown in the world championship moth boat regatta which will be held' in the Back Bay here Aug, 13, 14 and 15.

The Socialist party called all France to an observance today of the anniversary of the death of Jean Jaures, "apostle of Socialism and martyr to peace," who died July 31, 1914, under the gun of an assassin.

"Stolen," through a ruse, by her father from the home here of her maternal grandparents, 22-monthsold Patricia Anne Hayes was flying tonight to Newark, N. J., where the plane is expected to arrive tomorrow morning.

Iron first and g now bread. Within four days the Reich has taken over control of iron ore production and requisitioned the 1937 crops of wheat and rye, thus drastically advancing the aims of the four-year plan and the march toward a totalitarian State.
John L. Lewis has set out to build a political machine which, it was said by associates today, he hopes will make him the dominating factor in the choice of the next President of the United States.
Beef and pork continue upward in price. As cold storage supplies of poultry begin to run lower, the Department of Markets predicts that chickens will also soon cost more.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John M. Daley of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Regina Daley, to Warren S. Fogel, son of Mrs. Warren S. Fogel and the late Mr. Fogel.

The Federal Housing Administration, points out Miles L. Colean, director of the large-scale housing division, is as interested in improving the housing conditions of the renters of the country as in making home ownership possible for those who can afford to buy or build homes.

The marriage of Miss Katharine Greenwood Wayt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hampton Heiskell Wayt of The Orchard, this city, to William Rodes McDowell Woodbury of Altavista, Ratse Va., son of Mrs. Coryton M. Woodbury of Staunton, took place here this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church.

The age of capitalism has brought with it a conceited notion that mankind can make itself secure against the hazards of existence, but no safety lies ahead, the Rev. William J. Kenealy declared yesterday in a sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Dr. Joachim Prinz, German rabbi and author of several books, who is recognized as a leading scholar and writer, arrived yesterday on the French liner De Grasse accompanied by his wife. He will tour American cities in behalf of the United Palestine appeal, which is seeking $4,500,000 for the settlement in Palestine of Jews from Poland, Silesia and Germany.
Liquidation in the corn and oats markets featured trading in grains here last week, with the active deliveries dropping to a new low level since July, 1936.

The Oxford-Cambridge tennis team, which was defeated 6 matches to 3 yesterday in Southampton, reversed the order today by defeating members of the Maidstone Club, 5 matches to 2. The eighth match, an exhibition singles, saw John W. Wharton of Cambridge bowing before Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan of Boston in straight sets 6-1, 6-3. Mrs. Fabyan is here for the Maidstone Club's annual women's invitation gold cup tournament which starts tomorrow.
A man who identified himself as John M. Hayes, 33, of Mahwah, N. J., was arrested today as he and his 28month-old daughter, Patricia Ann, landed at an airport on the way to the East from California.

George Blumenthal, banker and president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and of Mount Sinai Hospital, has presented to the New York Public Library a valuable collection of original editions of the works of Anatole France, Andre Gide, Paul Valery, Pierre Loti, the Comtesse de Noailles, Lamartine and other French authors.

The body of an elderly man killed last night by a hit-and-run driver on Route 4 was identified today as that of John Madden, 60 years old, of 147-25 Sixteenth Avenue, Whitestone, Queens. When killed, Madden was on the way to the home of his brother, Thomas, who died at his home on Midland Avenue here Friday.
The Rev. Dr. Charles Roads, a retired Methodist Episcopal clergyman and author, died yesterday in the Methodist Episcopal Hospital here after a short illness. He was 82 years old.

Cooperation among Protestants in aid of the WPA adult education program of the Board of Education is urged in a statement sent out yesterday by the Rev. Walter M. Howlett, secretary of the Deapartment of Religious Education the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

A man describing himself as George White, producer of George White's Scandals, was arrested here today on a charge of careless driving of an automobile, and when arraigned before Magistrate Frank O. Breder, was fined $5 and costs of $1.50.

For the third successive week, cotton prices last week registered large declines. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 32 to 44 points, following losses of 80 to 84 points in the previous week and of 33 to 38 points the week before that. The total net decline in the three weeks was 152 to 162 points, or $7.60 to $8.10 a bale.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 92.3, which compares with 92,3 a week before, 92.5 two weeks before, 92.9 three weeks before and 92.5 four weeks before.

Timely hits by Paul Waner and Lee Handley with the bases loaded, coupled with Russ Bauers's relief pitching, gave the Pirates an 8-4 victory over the Bees today. The game was tied at 4--all in the last half of the seventh when Paul Waner singled to center with three on.

An automobile left the road and crashed into a tree early this mornnig after sidewiping a stanchion at the side of the road, causing the death of one occupant and serious injuries to the other. James Borrone, 65 years old, of 231 Prospect Street, Hoboken, a retired detective sergeant of the Hoboken police force, was killed almost instantly.

Hundreds of persons in pleasure boats and on Westchester County beaches saw a small seaplane fall into Long Island Sound off the southern tip of Fort Slocum near New Rochelle late yesterday afternoon carrying the pilot, who held a student's flying license, to his death.

The Junior Group of the PostGraduate Hospital will give a dance on Aug. 27 at the Belle Haven Beach Club, Greenwich, Conn., to aid the crippled children's ward of the hospital. Plans for the dance were discussed by committee members on Thursday at a tea at the residence of Mrs. Noel Armstrong of Greenwich.

For the first time in many years as Congress nears the end of a session the task of cleaning up the legislative slate with dispatch rests with the House. The wage and hours measure which passed the Senate on Saturday will go tomorrow to the House Committee on Labor, which has about reached agreement on a bill which differs materially from that passed by the Senate.
Giovanni Durante, violinist, and Nicola Rossi, accordionist, of a two-man band on one of the Yonkers-Alpine ferryboats, have surrendered to swing, with a shrug.

A father and his son and a husband and wife were drowned at about 7 o'clock last night when their rowboat overturned in Jamaica Bay 300 feet from the city pier at the foot of Rockaway Parkway, Canarsie. The mother of the boy was rescued.

Although it was expected the order for the excommunicating of all Cabinet Ministers and members of Parliament who voted for ratification of the concordat with the Vatican would be read today in all Orthodox churches in Yugoslavia, for technical reasons this was not done.

A mystery story of an unusual sort is on the Dodd, Mead list for mid-August. The title is "Hamlet, Revenge!" and it is a story of murder in an ancient castle during a revival of Shakespeare's plays. Those who know Shakespeare's writings fairly well may make the best guesses as to the outcome. Michael Innes is the author.

If our Russian friends from across the back of the North Wind were to make an inspection of what the regional planners call New York City and Its Environs they would probably be pleased to see that though we are not under a dictatorship of the proletariat we do have the equivalent of what in Russia are called Parks of Culture and Rest.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kent Newton of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Newton, to Charles Augustus Kirkland Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Kirkland of East Orange, N. J.

The Hudson Manhattan Railroad's plan to charge a ten-cent fare between downtown Manhattan and Jersey City and Hoboken was termed "ridiculous and outrageous" in a statement today by Mayor Frank Hague. The fare is now 6 cents between those points.

A suit against the State of Antioquia has been instituted in the Superior Court at Medellin by Alfonso Palau as the holder of defaulted dollar bonds of the State. His holding consists of bonds from the loan of 1925 contracted with Blair Co. and from the loan of 1927 arranged with the International Acceptance Bank and secured by a mortgage on the Antioquia Railway, which is owned by the State.

Harry L. Paddock, former United States consul at Amoy, China, and a retired naval officer, died here today of pneumonia. He was 57 years old. Mr. Paddock, a former Califor- he nian was an engineer with Admiral Dewey's squadron in the SpanishAmerican War, with the rank of lieutenant commander.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Sawyer Dexter of this city have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Frances Juanita Dexter, to Platt Walker Dockery of New York, son of Colonel Oliver H. Dockery Jr., U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Dockery of Newark, Ohio. It took place here on July 24 in St. Mark's Episcopal Church. Bishop Lewis B. Whittemore officiated.

The French liner Normandie established a new east-to-west crossing record last night, Captain Pierre Thoreaux radioed as his vessel passed Ambrose Light at 11:59 P. M., having made the voyage from Bishop's Rock, England, in 3 days 23 hours and 2 minutes.

The problems of man are generally divided into two parts, the Rev. Austin Pardue, rector of Gethsemane Church, Minneapolis, said yesterday in the first of a series of four sermons he will preach at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at Soventy-first Street.

The marine mystery will continue relentlessly. British sailors have been luffing or tacking in pursuit of the America's Cup ever since 1851 or thereabout and the latest pursuer was nearly lost in a thickening fog with night coming on in the first encounter of this series. Skipper Vanderbilt had skimmed home ahead of him with the defender.

The New York A. C. nine bowed to the Long Island City Club, 11-9, in a free-hitting contest at Travers Island yesterday. The losers made three runs in the third when Stanley Norton drove a homer with two mates aboard.

A long list of handicap changes and additions, as approved by the board of governors of the United states Polo Association, was announced yesterday. These ratings were adopted by the organization's handicap committee at its July meeting and, except for intracircuit and intercircuit play, are now in effect.

Stormy weather spoiled the closing day of the international aviation meeting here this afternoon. Before the storm one of the two remaining international competitive events had been won by the Czechoslovak army and four fliers of the British army had given an impressive exhibition of their skill in formation acrobatics.

A strong finish in the last twenty yards enabled Charles Crosby of the St. George Dragons to gain the 100-yard free style honors over Anthony Steinhauser, unattached entrant, in the feature race of the A. A. U. water carnival held at the Broad Channel Bathing Park in Queens yesterday. The victor was clocked at 0:58.9, a distance of onehalf yard separating him from the runner-up.

Playing without their manager, coach and first-string catcher, Philadelphia split a double-header with Cincinnati today, winning the second game, 3 to 2, behind Clyde Passeau's five-hit pitching after the Reds took the opener 5 to 1.

Before the largest gathering of visitors to visit Camp Dix since the World War, estimated at 18,000, the Citizens Military Training Camp regiment here held its final formal review and parade this afternoon.

One of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd's assistants on his Antarctic flights, Christoffer Braathen, crashed to his death, together with his wife and three other persons, while flying over Oslo Harbor today.
Five persons drowned today when an automobile crashed through a fence along a highway and plunged into Indian Lake, fifteen miles north of Bellefontaine. One woman survived.
Japanese and European demands for gasoline and other petroleum products have pushed Los Angeles Harbor petroleum exports during July to the highest figure since March, 1932, it was made known today.
The first recording of bird sound by radio has been made by W. A.- 0. Gross, director of the Bowdoin College scientific station here.

Dr. and Mrs. Louis Faugeres Bishop entertained 100 this afternoon at Bishopgate for games and cocktails. Those present included their house guests, Mrs. Jefferson Penn and Mr. and Mrs. John B. Kreischer; Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Sutphen, Mr. and Mrs. Clarence F. Alcott, Mr. and Mrs. Walter B. Duryea, Dr. and Mrs. John F. Erdmann.

A sweltering, sticky, breezeless Newport harbor which didn't cool off until twilight gave the floating gallery of yacht spectators a Sabbath chance to catch up on their sleep today and make it a real day for rest.

Dudley Roberts Jr. won the Maidstone Club golf championship today for the Charles H. Dickerman memorial cup on the Maidstone course, defeating Harry Brower, 1 up. Roberts was never down and at the fourteenth hole was 2 up.

The volume of retail trade sales in June was 4.8 per cent more than in June, 1936, which had shown a rise of 4.7 per cent over 1935. In May there was an exceptionally large rise amounting to 13.2 per cent owing to the Coronation celebrations and the Whitsun holiday.

Miss Marjorie Fitzpatrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Fitzpatrick of East Orange, will be wed on Aug. 14 to John Hodgins, son of Mrs. Margaret Hodgins of New York. The ceremony will be performed in Our Lady of All Souls Church here by the Rev. Leo M. McManus, assistant pastor.

E. Roland Harriman, chairman of the managing committee of the National Economy League, declared today that for the last seven years the Federal Government had been spending two dollars for every dollar it had taken in.

Pronounced improvement in sentiment is taking place in the securities market here. The change in the last week or two has been all the more impressive because it has occurred at a time when, normally, market activity is down to a minimum.

Good hands and horsemanship classes are among the new divisions added this year to the eighth annual Pocono Mountains Horse Show, which will be held on Aug. 19, 20 and 21 at Mount Pocono, Pa. The event, of which the Monroe County General Hospital in East Stroudsburg will be the beneficiary, will take place in an arena atop Mount Pocono, which is generally referred to as the "Arena in the Clouds."
The stock market opened the week with a moderate reaction in steels, electricals, engineering shares and breweries, with the public utilities steady.

State police who braved the jeers of a fashionable Westport charity audience yesterday in arresting Herman W. Reich of Bridgeport on gaming charges for the operation of slot machines at the annual bazaar of the Women's Towi Improvement Association have summoned Mr.

Buster Logan, Newark cyclist who recently won the American dirt track bike title at Weequahic Park, annexed the quarter-mile national amateur championship event last night at the Coney Island Velodrome. The race was held under sanction of the American Amateur Bicycle League. August Chizzolin placed second and Lloyd Thomas third.

Dr. Henry Hardin Cherry, president of Western Kentucky Teachers College for thirty years, died today from injuries suffered in a fall three weeks ago. His age was 72. Dr. Cherry was president of Southern Normal School before the Teachers College was established.

The Congress Theatre and office building on Broadway, Saratoga Springs, N. Y., has been purchased by Walter Reade from theBrackett estate for $200,000. The property is 100 by 165 feet and was bought subject to the leasehold of the Congress Theatre Corporation.

Difficulties in naming a Fusion ticket to run with Mayor La Guardia, acceptable to all the parties and groups that it was hoped to unite, increased yesterday, and there continued to be no certainty that the Mayor would engage in a primary contest for the Republican nomination.

Under the swastika banner, 10,000 GermanAmericans, paid tribute to their homeland today at the observance of "German Day" by the Rochester Federation of German Societies. While visiting dignitaries and officers of the federation joined in the stiff-armed Nazi salute, a German band blared the new and the old German national anthems, and German-American choral societies sang songs of both the old and new regimes.

The future governmental and administrative structure of North China depends entirely upon the nature and extent of military developments. And since Japan's North China policy remains fixed and unalterable, the military developments will depend upon the decisions Nanking must make.
The second of the series of Wagner concerts being presented by the Federal Music Project was given before a sizable and appreciative audience last night at the WPA Theatre of Music.

The Washington and Columbus (Ohio) units of the American Newspaper Guild have agreed on the phraseology of the referendum questions to be submitted to the Guild membership, the Washington unit announced tonight.

Robert L. Riggs of Los Angeles, fourth ranking player of the country, who won the Seabright Bowl last week and the Newport Cup last year, will endeavor to add the Southampton Bowl to his collection this week in the annual Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.
Although traffic across the boundary between Ecuador and Colombia at the village of Rumichaca not heavy, Colombian customs guards have a device to save them labor.

Robert Harriss, Queens Recovery party chairman in 1933, announced yesterday that he had accepted the chairmanship of the Citizens and Businessmen's Committee of One Thousand being formed to support Senator Royal S. Copeland, Frank J. Prial and Borough President Samuel Levy, Tammany candidates for the Democratic nominations for Mayor, Controller and President of the Council.

With no America's Cup race to watch today, the visiting yachtsmen and other guests in the Summer colony thronged the beaches and the country club. There was also much entertaining both ashore and afloat.

The Shrewsbury polo team triumphed over Burnt Mills, 8-7, in a close polo match played on Shrewsbury Field today. Cyril Harrison tied the count at 7-all in the final chukker and a minute later scored the winning tally for Shrewsbury on a free shot.

Deals in the upper Manhattan area featured the week-end realty activity, the largest transaction being the sale of the six-story apartment house at 515 West 183d Street, northeast corner of Audubon Avenue. occupying a plot 75 by 100 feet.
Raw milk, sold as pasteurized, was held responsible tonight by the New York Health Department for gastro-enteritis outbreaks in two children's camps at Otsego Lake.

A young man identified through Civilian Conservation Corps camp records as Regis Schwer of Muncie leaped to his death from an airplane here today. The plane, flying at about 1,000 feet, was piloted by Ledger Reed. Schwer went to the Municipal Airport this afternoon and asked to be taken for a ride over the city.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's much-discussed interview Tuesday with Count Dino Grandi, the Italian Ambassador, had a wider objective than mere restoration of friendly Anglo-Italian relations, it was reported tonight in usually well-informed circles.

The official wind forecast for Block Island Sound, where the second of the America's Cup races will be held tomorrow, predicted light southerly winds, about four miles per hour, increasing in force in the afternoon.

More than 40,000 persons attended the performances of operetta last week at Randalls Island Stadium, where "The Firefly" will open tomorrow night. Two thousand seats have been added, bringing the total number of chairs to 10,000 for each performance.

There has never been a great achievement without a dream preceding it, the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Campbell of the Central Avenue Reformed Church, Jersey City, said yesterday in the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street.

August, September and October are the traditional months of manoeuvre for most of the world's armies, and the 1937 manoeuvres-some of which will start this week-may help to write military history in several countries.

LILO LINKE is a tall, not very heavy woman, with yellow hair and blue eyes. According to one admirer, she looks "like the goose-girl of German fairy tales." She was born in Germany in 1906 and grew up on ersatz food, coming to a forced maturity earlY in the fratricidal struggles that followed the war.
Confessional pastors in Berlin announced today that some sixty Protestant pastors and lay readers were now imprisoned, ten more having been arrested during the past week.
The Senate's approval of the new Wages-and-Hours Bill has not been accomplished without a show of much more opposition than was originally anticipated by the sponsors of the measure.

The engagement of Miss Harriet Schurz Tompkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie J. Tompkins of 1,165 Fifth Avenue and Diamond Point, Lake George, N. Y., to John Kempster Thomas, son of Mrs. Christina Thomas of London, England, and the late J. K. Thomas, has been announced by her parents.

Supporters of Representative Christopher D. Sullivan will attempt this afternoon to elect him leader of Tammany in place of the late James J. Dooling at a meeting of its executive committee, called over the head of William P. Kenneally, its chairman. The meeting has been set for 2 o'clock at Tammany Hall.

Hundreds of persons who had planned to go to Jacob Riis Park by bus via the new Marine Parkway Bridge were inconvenienced yesterday when the Green Bus two Lines, operating a route connecting Brooklyn and the Rockaways, suddenly interrupted service.

Flashing a powerful attack, the First Division quartet recorded its fifth successive triumph over Fort Hamilton and gained its tenth verdict in twelve times out by capturing the non-league match yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn. Before a crowd of 4,000, the winners outrode and outhit Fort Hamilton throughout to win by the comfortable margin of 11-5.

Mrs. R. Wentworth Van Rensselaer will return from Melton Mowbray, England, next week and will be at the Savoy-Plaza. Sir Robert Craigie, the British Ambassador to Japan, Lady Craigie and Robert Craigie Jr. will arrive from London on Aug. 9 and will be at the Weylin before leaving for Japan.

The business situation in France is viewed in financial circles here with less pessimism than it was a few weeks ago. No doubt there still remain at home as well as abroad many reasons for concern, but the Chautemps Government is inspiring more confidence among financial circles now,

The same light variable airs that have plagued Long Island Sound yachtsmen all season were in evidence this afternoon at the special regatta held by the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club and all but ruined the day for a fleet of fifty yachts and skippers.

The Bureau of Municipal Research today announced opposition to a commission form of government for Philadelphia and advocated a city manager system. A City Charter Commission now is at work on a proposed new basic law, which, the bureau suggested, should include the "effectiveness" of the present Council-Mayor system and the "advantages" of manager government.
The Brooklyn C. C. conquered the Crescent A. C. in a championship fixture of the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association today, 164 to 82.

Victory in the central Long Island Sound eliminations among Star Class boats appeared to rest safely with Charles Stetson's Windward from Cedar Point as the result of today's contests, although two races are yet to be sailed at Pequot and Cedar Point.

A combination of circumstances, including unusually benign weather over the North Atlantic and the beginning of the pre-season rush of home-bound American tourists, started customs and immigration officials yesterday upon what promised to be a busy period.

Mrs. Annette Augusta Morse, wife of Frank H. Morse of Lehman Brothers, New York bankers, died here today at her home. She was born thirty-six years ago in Jersey City, a daughter of Mrs. Mary Leslie and the late William Leslie.
(Figures in parentheses indicate par.) Bayside (71)-Harry Lanzer made a holein-one on the 150-yard fourteenth with a No. 7 iron while playing with Robert O'Rourke and C. P. Hall.

The Orpington Estates, A. Simon, president, announce that a certificate of occupancy has been granted by the Bureau of Buildings for the nineteen-story apartment house at 5 Riverside Drive, south corner of Seventy-third Street, overlooking the Schwab residence plot.

The worst hail and electrical storm in years today ripped through the heart of this fertile Connecticut Valley farming section, doing damage growers estimated in the "neighborhood of $75,000" to tobacco and truck crops.

Details of tests made with small model hulls of sailing yachts, including Harold S. Vanderbilt's America's Cup defender Ranger, in a specially-built towing tank, were made public yesterday by the Stevens Institute of Technology through its president, Harvey Nathaniel Davis, in a pamphlet entitled "Towing Tanks and Hulls."

Resumption of Russian exports of gold to this country have caused no surprise, although the recent gold scare was intensified by Moscow's shipments of the metal. Gold coming currently from France is attributed to operations of the Exchange Control Fund.

One person was killed and four others were injured this afternoon when an automobile proceeding along Route 2, near here, got out of control and plunged over a bridge over Route 6 to the road below. Joseph Nellilo, 9 years old, of 548 East 183d Street, the Bronx, was killed instantly.
Dr. J. M. Hanley, dean of the medical profession in Chillicothe, Ohio, died at his home there, according to word received here today. He was 81 years old.

Although a conservative attitude marked purchasing of women's apparel in the New York wholesale market last week, substantial quantitles of-merchandise were ordered for August sales, back-to-school promotions and regular Fall business.

Christ's words, "Follow thou Me," which gave His discouraged and bewildered disciples new courage and strength to carry on, should be the basis of a deep-rooted devotion to His sacred cause for every Christian, the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fiftyfifth Street.

The flow of milk into twelve Northern New York Sheffield condensing plants slowed to a comparative trickle today as the Dairy Farmers Union launched a strike for higher prices. Quietly picketing main plants at Canton and Malone, the dairymen confined their campaign to persuading non-strikers to join in the boycott.
A milestone in baseball was passed or closely approached, according to the point of view, at the Stadium yesterday, when the Yankees took their farewell of the hapless St. Louis Browns.

Mrs. Gamaliel Cyrus St. John of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret Luer St. John, to Elbridge Cleghorn Gale of Boston and Eastern Point, Gloucester, Mass., son of Mrs. Arthur Ernest Gale of Boston and Haverhill, Mass., and the late Dr. Gale.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Montague Adams of West Hartford have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Adams, to Malcolm V. Lane of Schenectady, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl R. Lane of this place.

As one of the musical events of the Columbia University Summer session a choral concert will be given tonight at 8:15 in McMillin Academic Theatre on the campus by the choir of the Pius X School of Liturgical Music of the College of the Sacred Heart, which will be assisted by the Summer School Schola of that institution. The Rev.

Expectations of an upturn in business in the Fall are greater now than a month or two ago, whefi labor troubles and political uncertainties were at their worst, the National City Bank says in its August letter.

Trading was moderate in the cotton futures market here last week. Liquidation by tired longs, impressed by the prospects for a large crop, caused prices to ease off to new low levels for the season in the first part of the week, the near positions dropping below the 11cent mark.

"Indolence and routine mismanagement among manufacturers who lodk to the government when they should look to themselves"; labor troubles and the failure of plant owners of a few years ago to recornize rayon as a substitute for
There was a round of entertainment throughout the day here for Sunday guests. Many luncheons were given at various estates, including that of Mr. and Mrs. William de Wilder Atkinson at Ballyshear.

How many eyes in the after-days of the World War (and some through tears) searched the maps of France to find the names of the places where their dead lay in the silent fields of white crosses once the scene of battle-theirs whose loss no gold stars or other memorials can requite! How many!

Senator Harry F. Byrd resumed today his attack on the spending by the Resettlement Administration, especially in connection with the seven homestead projects in his own State. Some time ago the Senator charged that the Resettlement Administration was spending $1,500,000 to build 250 home units in Virginia.
End-of-themonth expansion caused money market conditions to become considerably narrower and rates rose for outside accommodation from 5 to 51A per-cent and for call money from 4 1/4 to 5 per cent.

George Connor of San-Bernardino, Calif., averaging slightly over a mile a minute, won the featured 25-mile auto event on the Fair Grounds dirt track before 10,000 spectators today. His time was 25:54.5.

The general trend in boys' delinquency was downward in large population areas of the country from 1930 through 1934, but the proportion of boys referred to institutions in 1934 for stealing, 46 per cent, was the highest of the recorded period, according to an annual report on juvenile court statistics, made publie by the Children's Bureau of the Labor Department.

ALLAH DETHRONED, by Lilo Linke. (Knopf, $5.) A journey through modern Turkey. THE LIFE AND DEATH OF A SPANISH TOWN, by Elliot Paul. (Random House, $2.50). The story of a town in Spain through the immediate past.

Attempts of various advertising media to impress upon advertisers the value of year-round advertising are gradually beginning to bear fruit, according to comment here. The sharp rise in radio billings this Summer is the result of the chains' efforts to prevent any letdown and shows that, apparently, advertisers were impressed with the radio promotional campaign.

The late Rev. Dr. William M. Kephart, who died Tuesday, was eulogized yesterday as the spirit of eternal life" by the Rev. Carlos Fuller, who occupied the mourningdraped pulpit of the dead pastor at the North New York Congregational Church, East 143d Street near Willis Avenue. the Bronx.

The American Christian Conference on the Jewish Problem today made public a cable sent to the Mandates Commission of the League of Nations at Geneva, protesting against the persecution of Jews and the partitioning of Palestine.

A three-day white elephant sale, the second event of the season sponsored by the Ann May Alliance for the benefit of the Fitkin Hospital at Neptune, will be started here on Thursday. The sale will be under the general chairmanship of Mrs. Henry A. Haines, founder and president of the Alliance.

Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union and one of the original members of the Committee for Industrial Organization, denied today a published report that there was an impending split between himself and John L. Lewis.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Lapham of Brookline, Mass., gave a party on the lawn of the Mountain View here today, and at a tea that followed Miss Alys Downing and Mr. Wendell J. Curtiss assisted. Mr. and Mrs. Walter O. Smith observed Mr. Smith's birthday with a dinner party.

An eleventh-inning home run by Dixie Walker and the pitching of Bill Dietrich and Vernon Kennedy brought the White Sox two victories over the Athletics today. Walker's hit, one of seven made off George Caster in the entire first game, provided the winning margin in a 4-3 decision.

This was no day off for the men who make up the crews of the America's Cup contenders, particularly for those aboard the defender Ranger. After Harold S. Vanderbilt had taken her out in the morning with a full complement of hands aboard there was work enough to keep them busy the better part of the afternoon.

Thomas McGrath, a young man whose only singing experience had been with small dance orchestras, will leave here tomorrow for Hollywood as the protege of Lily Pons, the opera star, for voice training that Miss Pons expects will carry him to grand opera.

L. K. Elmhirst, president of the International Conference of Agricultural Economists, arrived yesterday from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Georgic. He will make preliminary arrangements for the next conference, which will open at McDonald College, near Montreal, Aug. 28, 1938. He said 300 of the leading agricultural economists would attend.

A holiday spirit pervades Germany just now and with it a certain atmosphere of peace, contentment and good-will The unsatisfactory harvest has been forgotten; the Government is attending to that, so all will be well. It may be necessary to pull in the famous German belt a little tighter, but the Germans are used to that.

A clearly defined fir gerprint on a goldfish bowl found in the baby carriage in which the body of 8-yearold Paula Magagna was discovered in the cellar of the tenement I house at 349 Stockholm Street, Brooklyn, where she lived, was the clue that led police last night to predict an early arrest of her murderer.

The Bradford Construction Corporation of this city is preparing to erect four single-story brick-andconcrete factory structures on the four and one-half acre site formerly owned by the A. F. Brown Company, machinery manufacturers, in Elizabeth, N. J., at Port Avenue and Third Street. The property was recently acquired by the Bradford concern in foreclosure proceedings. The new buildings are estimated to cost $500.000.

The United States Maritime Commission today announced the advertising of bids for the construction of a vessel of its own design "which will give this country the finest and safest ship on the seas." The new vessel will be built for the United States Lines and will replace the Leviathan, which was withdrawn from service two years ago.

Announcement was made at a tea yesterday afternoon of the engagement of Miss Pauline Nancy Watts, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Watts of Revonah Manor, Stamford, to John Carman Inch, son of Mr. and Mrs. William John Inch of Toronto.

A thirtyday - duck - hunting season, with changes in dates and zones, was announced today by the Department of Agriculture. The previous two seasons also were limited to thirty days, to cut down the annual kill and speed the department's waterfowl restoration program.

The default and arbitrary reduc-i tion of interest on its obligations by the Canadian Province of Alberta was in part the result of a definite policy of the Aberhart Administration, rather than of necessity, according to the Institute of International Finance, in a bulletin on Alberta issued today.

A well-balanced Long Island quartet, headed by Stewart Iglehart, galloped to an 11-to-7 victory over Westbury in a special high-goal exhibition polo match on the Meadow Brook Club's Cochran Field today. The winners never trailed, although Westbury managed to tie on four occasions.

The league-leading Newark Bears clinched their season's series with Toronto today by winning both ends of a double-header. The Bears were forced to travel twelve innings before chalking up a 6-5 triumph in the opener, but they made short work of the Leafs in the second game, scoring a 10-2 decision as Jack Fallon and Joe Beggs gave up only four hits between them.

Declaring they would "fight fire with fire," officials of the American Federation of Labor tonight launched a drive to take thousands of workers in the textile, rubber, electric machinery, automobile and other industries from the rival Committee for Industrial Organization.

The franc showed a considerable tendency this week to strengthen in the foreign exchange market. "This improvement does not seem to be due to the repatriation of funds on a large scale but probably is attributable principally to the liquidation of speculative commitments as a result of the narrowing of the discount rate in forward francs.

Imperial Airways' flying boat Cambria landed in Montreal Harbor at 1:47 P. M. today, completing the second leg of the crossing from Foynes, Ireland, to the base at Port Washington, L. I. She is scheduled to take to the skies again at 9 A. M. tomorrow.

Life, laughter and love are a practical trinity that should be substituted for the theological conception of the Father, Son and Holy Spirit, the Rev. John Paul Jones declared in a sermon yesterday morning at Union Presbyterian Church, Eightieth Street and Ridge Boulevard, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

Gaining a clear lead under true conditions and increasing the margir in spotty going, Briggs S. Cunningham's Lulu won its fourth triumph in the Gold Cup trials today off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club and thus brought the series, which has been in progress for a week, to a conclusion.

Eduardo Santos, recently nominated Liberal candidate for President and consequently leader of the party, last night named a national campaign committee of six principals and six alternates. This committee will choose a seventh member as the representative of labor.
Lucius N. Littauer, philanthropist, has set up ten scholarships, valued at $200- each, to be awarded to young women who show talent in art and ability In designing, it was announced yesterday.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 85 per cent of capacity, up 3 points from the rate of the preceding week, and 2 points above that in the week before. So far as July is concerned, the expected "Summer lull" in steel has not yet developed.
Reford Champion, 30 years old, believed to have come here from Californian was found dead in his furnished' room at 299 Eighth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Today we are still emerging from depression. Preceding this depression came a boom. Business fears are now subsiding and the danger of a boom revives. A normal preventive would be increased interest rates. This is a weapon the use of which should stop the boom in its inception. But for various reasons this weapon is now blunted and not readily available.

Congressional leaders, viewing the first signs of an impending World War veterans' pension onslaught on Congress, fear that the movement may gain sufficient strength next session to merit committee consideration, and agree that it might become sufficiently strong within a few years to saddle the nation with a system that might eventually cost an estimated $20,000,000,000 by 1996.
Following is the text of the address made by General John J. Pershing today at the dedication of the American Monument at Montfaucon, France, and made public here:

Contractors are still chiseling on the payrolls of the Works Progress Administration here, a group of Queens home owners and taxpayers charged yesterday in a communication to the Board of Estimate. Francis A. Rogers, chairman of the executive committee of the Home Owners and Taxpayers Association, Inc., of Queens, made public a resolution adopted by the organizatioir and sent to the Board of Estimate.
The New York Athletic Club tennis team scored its seventh victory in nine times out this season by downing the Westchester Country Club, 7-2, on the Winged Foot courts at Travers Island yesterday.

When the world powers are prepared to make the same sacrifices for peace that they make for war, when through cooperation they are able to ease the economic tensions that lead- directly to war, peace will become a reality rather than a dream, the Rev. Thornton Penfield of the First Congregational Church, Saginaw, Mich., said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

Signs are appearing in the steel industry that the bottom of the Summer lull has been reached and that July probably represents the low point in buying, according to the magazine Steel, which adds that the quiet condition is likely to continue through part of August, with the latter part of the month expected to show an upturn as Autumn programs get under way.

Dalconm Ave (18-5595), e s, 101 ft n of Harding Ave. 50x100; Lina Laub to Anton Laub, 1.271 1st Ave. Clinton Ave. 1,988 (11-3093); Milly Kleinman to Bella Benjamin. 785 E 181st St. 154th St (9-2376). n s, 270 ft w of Washington Ave, 25x100; Vincenzo Vinci to John Werle, trustee, 957 Forest Ave; mortgage, S12,000.

Encountering stout resistance on the part of the teams representing Sweden and Norway in the second and third rounds today, the United States players, who are defending the Hamilton-Russell trophy at the congress of the International Chess Federation, made less headway than had been expected.

Edwin H. Denby of New York was host at the Bar Harbor Club buffet this evening. His guests included Mr. and Mrs. A. Fitzroy Anderson, Mr. and Mrs. Ulric Dahlgren, Mr. and Mrs. F. B. Kellogg, Mr. and Mrs. Newell G. Bradley, Mrs. William Thornton, Miss M. Lilly Beall, Miss Virginia Bradley, Theodore Marburg, Lee Gron and Dr. Frederick T. Jack.

Sheriff St, 62, 25x100; Edward Weinfeld to Harry Lerner, 105 W 40th St; conaideration, $11,138, foreclosure. Lewis St, 158. 24x100.5; trustee will of Robert R. Willets to 158 Lewis St Realty, Inc. 158 Lewis St.: two-thirds interest, consideration, $4,666. Bleecker. St. 15, 22.6x63.6; Appel Realty Corp, to Harry Appel et al, 2,773 37th St. Brooklyn.

The Government will renew its attack tomorrow on the contention of seven kidnapping suspects that they did not flee justice after abduction of John J. O'Connell Jr. A Federal law stipulates that prosecution must be started within three years of a crime, and because indictments against the eight were

The Giants made a terrific bid today to stem the tide which is sweeping them away from their National League pennant goal. Melvin Ott, after a one-day rest on the bench, unfurled two home runs to bring his seasonal total up to twenty-two, and big Harry Danning, Gus Mancuso's understudy, crashed another with Sambo Leslie on base.

The two top-ranking seeded stars were eliminated in the semi-finals of the national A. A. U. one-wall handball tournament at the Ravenhall Bathing Park, Coney Island, yesterday. Dave Margolis, Trinity Club, defending champion and seeded first, bowed to Harry Goldstein, a club mate. Goldstein, 1934 titleholder and ranked fourth, won at 21-15, 21-5.

Young Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., uncorked two potent samples of his Winter form over the Keller course today and collected the $1,200 victor's share of the eighth annual $5,000 St. Paul open golf prize money.

Frederic Hans von Rosenberg, who was Foreign Minister of Germany in 1923 and hd served in diplomatic posts abroad, is dead at the age of 63. After serving as Foreign Minister for less than a year, from November, 1922, until August, 1923, Herr von Rosenberg was sent to Stockholm the following May as his country's diplomatic representative.

The Rev. Paul Schulte, former German war flier now known as the "flying missionary," landed at North Beach Airport in a new plane last night after a flight from Detroit in which he made a forced landing on the Hudson River to escape an electrical storm.

Caught in a landslide of tons of granite, two youths were crushed to death today when the rim of a 100-foot rock ledge from which they were viewing the sea gave way. The dead were Herbert Anderson, 18, and Chisley Elroy Jr., 17, both of Belmont.

Hearings to guide the National Bituminous Coal Commission in its duty of setting wholesale prices and regulations under the Guffey-Vinson act will be held here, commencing on Tuesday morning, in the Hotel Carlton, the commission announced today.

The maritime supremacy of Salem, Mass., whose fast sailing fleets were known throughout the world in the early days of the United States, will be commemorated in the first public works allotment under the historic sites legislation, Secretary Ickes announced today.

The trend toward an increase in corporate stock flotations and at the same time a reduction in the volume of bond financing was emphasized last month. Bond flotations were sharply curtailed, while stock issues, although slightly, smaller in volume than in-June, D were the largest for any July since 1929.

Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, reported yesterday that 128,061 patients were treated in city hospitals in the first six months of this year. Though this figure is nearly 2,000 lower than that for the corresponding period a year ago, the number of patient days was 3,242,824, nearly the same as last year.

Two Long Beach, L. I., policemen and a young woman who were arrested on Saturday on a charge of suspicion of extortion made by a beauty parlor operator were held yesterday by Magistrate Raphael Murphy in Bronx Magistrate's Court in $10,000 bail each for a hearing on Thursday.

The Japanese Army again dominates the East Hopeh "puppet State" area, especially the capital, Tungchow. Large forces swept the city yesterday, routing the Chinese troops occupying the administration buildings. [A Japanese column was reported to have advanced to a point thirty-five miles southwest of Peiping, according to The Associated Press.]

Peiping continued in virtually complete isolation from the outside world as Japanese Army units, scattered throughout the surrounding countrystde, began mopping-up operations yesterday against the remains of the Twenty-ninth Army and gendarmes to clear all Northern Hopeh of anti-Japanese elements.

Jean's Beauty Salon, store at 400 E 50th St; Lang Industries, Inc., in 140 Cedar St; Art Metal Co., in 101 Park Ave; Sherley Chase, in 130 W 42 St; Edward Weinberg. in 50 W 46th St; Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker.

Guy Harold Holliday, lawyer and educator, for the last twelve years secretary of the Harvard Law School, died today at his home at the age of 70. He was for twenty years assistant clerk of Suffolk Superior Court and was a prominent Mason.

The dedication of a granite column here today in memory of the soldiers who died in the Americans' greatest battle in the World War became an expression of the devotion of the people of France and the United States to peace.

Leeway, the old Dickerson estate of thirty-five acres in the town of Lewisboro, Westchester County, has been bought by Mr. and Mrs. R. E. Lee of New York, who are improving the farmhouse for a Summer home.

The Red Sox today jumped into third place, ousting Detroit by beating the Tigers, 11 to 4, in the first game of a twin bill. The second game was called because of the Massachusetts Sunday Sports Curfew Law with the teams deadlocked, 2-2, at the end of the tenth.

This may be a fateful week for a famous philanthropic society. Followers of the Hon. Christopher D. Sullivan, the ancient and well-beloved Representative in Congress of the Thirteenth district, have asked the chairman of the Tammany executive committee to call a meeting.

The weekly average of French wholesale prices on July 24 was 576, against 570 on July 17 and 537 on June 26. The index of world prices of twenty-two raw materials in terms of gold was 54.8, compared with 54.9 the previous week.

The Santa Barbara team of California became a threat in the national Junior polo championship at the Narragansett Polo Club today by defeating the Bostwick Field team, 9 to 8, after three minutes of play in an extra period. The winning goal was scored by Alec Bullock, who sent through the deciding shot when the ball was neatly centered on a back shot by Eric TyrrellMartin.

Miss Sally Skinner will be married Saturday afternoon at the home of her father, William Converse Skinner of Farmington, to Franklin Patrick Kearney, son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. D. Kearney of Oldstones, Farmington. The Rev. L. Mark Brewster will officiate.

An imposing array of bridge experts from New York, the Middle West and the South will compete in the national masters' pair championship, blue ribbon event of the eleventh annual tournament of the American Bridge League, which opens here tomorrow.

R. U. Whipple, Columbia Medical School student, guided his 34-foot cruiser Edraul to another victory in the Western Long Island motor cruising championship today. The event, which took a fleet of nine craft on a thirty-mile voyage to the entrance of Northport Bay, was sponsored by the Sands Point Yacht Club.

France's foreign trade for June is regarded here as decidedly unsatisfactory. Figures that have just been compiled show that imports in June amounted to 3,807,000,000 francs, compared with 3,050,000,000 in the preceding month and 1,830,000,000 in June, 1936. At the same time, exports reached 1,997,000,000 francs, against 1,750,000,000 in May, 1937, and 1,155,000,000 in June last year.

New low levels for the season and since July, 1936; were recorded in the corn market the last week, the continued favorable crop prospect and estimates indicating that the 1937 yield might be the largest since 1932 being the dominating influence.

The Denver Refiners, under the management of Rogers Hornsby, former boss of the Browns, defeated Grover Cleveland Alexander's Springfield (Ill.) team, 8 to 7, in ten innings in The Denver Post tournament today.

A South Shore Polo Club quartet could not cope with the speedy attack of the Bethpage Knaves today at Hazard Field and bowed, 9-4. Alex Robinson, No. 1, and Fred Miller, No. 2, scored three and two goals, respectively, to lead the invaders' drive.

The first nineteen steel companies to report for the first half of 1937 showed net income nearly three times that for the same period of 1936. Four companies whose reports had much detail--United States Steel, Bethlehem, National and Jones Laughlin--showed operating income more than double that

A police ban on picketing in this Southern steel capital brought a demand today from a leader of the Committee for Industrial Organization that law enforcement authorities force industry to hew to the line of labor legislation.

One immediate effect of the war scare in the East is to distract the attention of the imperial powers from Spain to their interests in other parts of the globe. This is inevitable, because the chronic malady of Europe is what sion. The smallest of the continents is not a real Continent at all, geographically or politically. It is an octopus, a little body with immense tentacles.

The Black Diamond Steamship Corporation announced yesterday that it had filed with the Circuit Court of Appeals a petition requesting a review of an order issued on July 21 by the National Labor Relations Board, which directed the company to reinstate thirty-five engineers formerly employed on its ships.

The engagement of Miss Martha Elizabeth Williams of Carlisle to Harper Randolph Leming, son of Andrew Leming of Loveland, Ohio, has been announced by Miss 'Williams's parents, Mr. and Mrs. J. Elder Williams. The wedding will take place here on Aug. 10.

On clear nights this month, when the Finsler Comet may be seen, a six-inch reflector telescope will be placed on the grounds of the Hayden Planetarium, at Central Park West and Seventy-ninth Street, Dr. Clyde Fisher, head of the planetarium, announced yesterday. Use of:

General Francisco Franco's Eastern army today thrust a widening wedge into vital territory near the junction of Teruel, Cuenca and Valencia Provinces, roughly 100 miles east of Madrid. The Insurgents claimed further important gains in that sector, where for months they have been trying to interpose a barrier between Madrid and the temporary seat of the government at Valencia.

The presence in Nanking yesterday of General Han Fu-chu, virtual dictator of Shantung Province, is certain to have an important bearing on Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's challenge to the Japanese invasion of Hopeh.

A dinner dance which followed the County Fair here was held last night at the Sands Point Bath Club, where Mr. and Mrs. William S. Butler gave a dinner for their daughter, Miss Doris Butler. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. William Dunn and Edward Johnson.

Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Merrill Hoyt of Roland Park, Baltimore, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ouellette Hoyt, to John E. P. Conley Jr., also of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. P. Conley of Waverly, N. Y.

Mr. and Mrs. H. M. Holderness of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elise Holderness, to Dr. Henry L. Shepherd of Farmington, son of Mrs. Henry L. Shepherd of Fort Worth, Texas. Miss Holderness attended the Oxford School of Hartford and Miss Wright's School in Bryn Mawr, Pa., and was graduated in 1932 from Pine Manor Junior College.

W. F. Young's cutter Venturon won the seventeenth annual Bayside-Block Island auxiliary handicap race for the second successive year, finishing the 225-mile contest at 5:54 A. M. yesterday. Her elapsed time of 35 hours 51 minutes 25 seconds was the best recorded by the six reported finishing among the eleven cruising yachts, which started shortly after noon on Friday.

The index of German wholesale prices on July 21 stood at 106.5, against 105.4 on July 14, 106.3 on July 7 and 106.1 on June 30. In the first six months of 1937, Germany's wholesale price index, based on the average of 1913 as 100, ranged between 106.2 on March 17 and 105.2 in the first week of January.

Friends of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene du Pont today described as an "open secret" the report that their daughter, Miss Aimee du Pont, younger sister of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., would be married early next year to Walter Wickes Jr., son of a retired Baltimore physician.

Dr. Leo Mayer, 140 W 79th St through Samuel A. Herzog. Harold Raufman, in 336 Central Park W through Pearce Mayer; Melville Lord, Moe I. Katz, Margaret Lobsenz, Moses Galpeer, in 27 W 96th St; Edgar A. Levy. broker. Tillie Eisenstein, in 600 W 164th St; Louis F. Garcia, in 2,316 Andrews Ave. the Bronx: Oscar Shein. in 58R West End

S. N. Behrman's new play now has a title, "Wine of Choice," and it has a definite place on the Theatre Guild's schedule for the coming season. As Mr. Behrman will be in Salzburg until the latter part of August, no one has been cast definitely, though the rumors have muttered about Ina Claire and Herbert Marshall. Not long ago Mr.

Fifty thousand office workers will become eligible at once for old-age pensions, the Government announced today, under a new decree extending old-age and disability benefits previously enjoyed only by industrial and agricultural employes.
Hormones from the pituitary gland might be used in the near future to overcome inferiority complexes and possibly develop backward, retiring individuals into geniuses,

South Berkshire week-end entertainments revolved about the Wyantenuck Country Club, where the tournament ball last night attracted more than 300 persons. Mr. and Mrs. Rodney S. Jarvis had thirty guests at a dinner at Wheelbarrow Hill Farm, and Mr. and Mrs. George M. L. La Branche Jr. entertained fifteen at Green River Farm, North Egremont, for their guests, Mr. and Mrs. A. Richard Diebald of New York.

Roger Wilkinson's Gallant Boy scored its second straight victory among Class A craft in the second canoe-sailing race for the championship of the Association of Canoe Clubs of Sheepshead Bay on Jamaica Bay yesterday.

The engagement of Miss Katharine Pritchard Colt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Colt of this city, formerly of Hazleton, to Reginald Hathaway Johnson Jr., son of Reginald H. Johnson of Cambridge, Mass., has been announced by her parents.

Sailed over a forty-mile course, the annual all-night race of the Bay Head Y. C. was won early this morning by W. C. Arkell's Vim, which finished at 6:15 o'clock after sailing through six drawbridges and ghosting through the lightest of easterly breezes. Gilbert Rose's Southwind placed second.

Swift Co., Chicago meat packing louse, has leased 100,599 square feet of space at the New York World's Fair and will assemble an exhibit dramatizing the story of meat, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.

As an aftermath to the disappearance of Sadao Miyazaki, a Japanese seaman, Admiral Denshichi Okohchi, issued a public apology yesterday. The admiral said he was making the statement for the "commotion" caused when the seaman was thought to have been kidnapped about a week ago.

If important discoveries in the field of prevention are not made, mental disease will soon supersede physical disease as the paramount health problem in the United States, Dr. Horatio M. Pollock of Albany, N. Y., warned today as the World Population Congress closed.

The Jersey City Giants snapped their five-game losing streak today when they captured both ends of a double-header from Buffalo before a crowd of 5,734 by scores of 3 to 2 and 6 to 3. Don Brennan, who relieved Walter Brown in the seventh inning of the opener, was credited with the victory when Jersey City pushed across the winning run in its half of the same round.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on July 28 at 84.7, compared with 85 a fortnight before, 84.3 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Anton C, G. Hupfel, president of the J. Chr. G. Hupfel Brewing Corporation, 229 East Thirty-eighth Street, died yesterday at his residence, 148 East Thirty-seventh Street, of a complication of ailments at the age of 68. He had been ill intermittently for a year and a half.

Epicea, 8-to-5 choice from P. Wertheimer's stable, today won the Prix de Caen by two lengths from S. J. Unzues's Lucrecia, with third place going to James Hennessy's Chezgaby. The Prix de la Municipalite went to Jules Fribourg's Durazzo by a half-length margin over Robert Kahn's Quai d'Orsay.

Insurgent officials reported today that two Frenchmen convicted by a military court of plotting to spread disease germs in Insurgent Spain had been executed by a firing squad in Pamplona. Louis Chabrat and Jean Boujennec were charged with aiding an international plot to spread typhoid and sleeping sickness in General Francisco Franco's territory.

To safeguard Canadian neutrality, orders-in-council have been approved banning enlistment for Spain, prohibiting the export of munitions to that country and forbidding such exports to any other country without permits. The orders-in-council became effective yesterday and were made public today.
Bringing to a climax the tension of a day of fighting and bombing, the Sunday evening calm of Tientsin was abruptly broken when an earthquake of considerable duration and intensity shook the city.

The American Radio Telegraphists Association announced yesterday that John L. Lewis, C. I. O. leader; Harry Bridges, West Coast maritime labor leader, and Representative Maury Maverick of Texas were among the speakers scheduled for a mass meeting the association will hold at the Hippodrome on Aug. 12.

The list of the French liner Non mandie, due today from Havre, ineludes: Princess BrindaKapurthala, Count jean de Gramont, Baron and Baroness d'Estournelles de Constant, Mrs. A. Clifford Tower, Mrs. and Mrs. Cyrus Adams, Simone Simon and Lily Damita.

Donald Hawley of Orange, former New York University captain, gained his second leg on the challenge trophy of the North New Jersey tennis championship when he defeated John H. Curtiss of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., Cornell University tennis instructor, in the final at the Westfield Tennis Club today, 6-3, 6-3, 6-3.
Reuben Clark Jr., former United States Under-Secretary of State,. today told young British Mormons that the growth of the church was up to them.
