Bob Feller baffled the Senators today with all the speed that earned him a "boy wonder" ranking last season and the Indians triumphed, 11 to 2.

Ready for their second race tomorrow in the America's Cup match, T. O. M. Sopwith's challenger Endeavour II and HaroldS. Vanderbilt's defender Ranger lay snugly at sunken iron mushrooms tonight, their crews concerned chiefly about what the weather will offer.

Pleased with the success of previous efforts to bring a "bit of country" into the lives of pavementbound New York youngsters, the Department of Parks will set a vine-enclosed garden on an auto trailer for a tour /of city playgrounds today. Adults may get some pleasure out of the exhibit, too.

A movement has been started in Ossigning to discard the special village charter and make Ossining a thirdclass city, with Village President Howard Dunscomb and former Village Trustee Harry M. Carpenter favoring a study of the plan.

Policemen and firemen on vacation were recalled, future leaves were canceled and all members forbidden to leave town by order of Mayor Henry Wissel here today as a third factory in this industrial center went on strike and C. I. O. organizers predicted more strikes to come. Fire lines have been stretched in all struck plants and men are stationed in them twentyfour hours a day.

Urging serious study by retailers, garment manufacturers and dry cleaners of the pre-shrinkage of woolen and worsted fabrics in women's and children's garments, the National Business Bureau, Inc., released yesterday its preliminary findings of a recent survey indicating a marked lack of information and growing interest in this subject on the part of store executives.

Clinton Ferguson, Boston outboard motor boat pilot, swept the surface of Saranac Lake of all opposition today in the amateur events of the twenty-seventh annual Saranac Boat and Waterways Club regatta.

Grand Concourse (11-3159); n e corner of Field P1, 196x84; 2,356 Concourse Realty Corp to Henry Lichtig. trustee. 21 E 40th St; installments, 4 to 5 per cent; $240,000. Brook Ave, 549-51 (9-2294); Bella L. Burgoyne to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; $10,400.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Ernstein of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beatrice Ernstein, to Waiter Townsend Ransburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Ransburg of New York.

The American Potash and Chemical Corporation of Trona, Calif., one of the three major potash producers of the country, has been ordered by the National Labor Relations Board to offer reinstatement with back earnings to nineteen employes alleged to have been dismissed for union activities.
Men are buying more expensive suits and overcoats this year than last, preliminary estimates of Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce on sales of chain men's wear stores indicated today.

The creation of more flexible railroad capital structures with lessened fixed charges is recommended in a report made public yesterday by Dr. Irving Bussing, economist of the Savings Bank Trust Company.

Support of a move for repeal of the capital gains and losses tax as unsound economically, an obstacle to recovery and an incentive to tax evasion was urged upon Secretary Morgenthau today in a letter from Representative Celler of New York, sponsor of a bill to do this.

Seven State Representatives and one State Senator held today what they hoped would be considered the first legal Sunday session of the Michigan Legislature in history. In the Senate John C. Wickstrom, Upper Peninsula Democrat, mounted the Lieutenant Governor's rostrum, called the empty chamber to order, declared the Senate in session and then announced adjournment, subject to the call of the chair.

State Controller Morris S. Tremaine said today that public indebtedness "has reached a pretty high point," and emphasized the need of immediate reduction "to prepare ourselves for future depressions, which are sure to come."

Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Lucius Hart of this place and Waterbury gave a party here last night at Fence Creek cottage at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susanne Chase Hart, to Philip Hale Conklin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leander Hull Conklin of 393 Park Avenue, New York.

The powerful Evergreen Farms quartet of Eatontown, N. J., the lone unbeaten combination in the Eastern Polo League, had a close call today at Bethpage State Park in recording a 13-12 triumph over the home four.

Because of the enthusiasm aroused here over their performances in the recently previewed "Dead End," the six lads from the Broadway production who played in the film version have been placed under contract by Samuel Goldwyn and will be featured in "Street Corners," a story about newsboys. Writers will be assigned to the yarn this week, to work with H. C. Potter, who will direct.

El Salvador is sending a military mission to Czechoslovakia, according to reports of newspapers received here. The purpose of the visit is not stated. War Minister Jose Reyes appointed Colonel J. Arturo Castellanos head of the mission with Captain Hector Montalvo and Lieutenant Manuel Molina Morales as members.

As expected, with the Bank Holiday at hand, the circulation of the Bank of England this week reached a new high record of [Pound]498,338,710. The week's increase of [Pound]5,205,349 was due solely to vacation currency demands.

Celebrating the 103d anniversary of the British Emancipation Proclamation, West Indians in Harlem met yesterday afternoon and evening at the Renaissance Casino, 138th Street at Seventh Avenue. Resolutions were adopted urging political, economic and social reforms In the Caribbean islands.

Mr. and Mrs. Horatio Shonnard of New York arrived here late yesterday by seaplane. Mr. and Mrs. Frederick B. Ayer are here on their boat, Shadow, to fish. Mr. and Mrs. W. C. Robinson of Pittsburgh have arrived on their yacht, Solano, and have brought guests for the fishing.

Francis E. Cullen, a lawyer widely known in Northern New York, for many years prominently identified with Democratic circles, died in the Oswego Hospital this afternoon, after a week's illness of pneumonia, He was 61 years old.

Five railroad brotherhoods will begin tomorrow a count of votes of their members on a strike for a 20 per cent increase in wages. The tally will include the National Brotherhoods of Firemen, Trainmen and Engineers, the Order of Railroad Conductors and the Switchmen's Union.

A plea for a return to McGuffeyism as a means of settling State and individual problems was made here this afternoon by Paul O. Yoder, Lieutenant Governor of Ohio, at the closing session of the centenary celebration of the third and fourth readers written by William Holmes McGuffey when he was a member of the faculty of Miami University in Oxford.

Taking one consideration with another, a Congressman's lot is not a happy one when it comes to 1937 labor legislation. It is not that the issues are so complex, but that there are so many labor leaders. "Several Senators were puzzled and undecided as to how they would vote on the wage bill," said our Washington news the other day, "because of the division of opinion among officials of the American Federation of Labor."

The Soviet Union recently has been speaking softly about most things-except aviation-but today the important organs of the Soviet press burst forth with a concerted boast of the Soviet's military power such as has not been heard since before the execution of Marshal Mikhail Tukhachevsky and seven other generals of the Soviet army.

The annual honor roll of Princeton University, released today 'by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar of the university, reveals that 528 undergraduates, or 22.9 per cent of Princeton's total enrollment, attained general averages of first or second group for the academic year 1936-37.

Business was dull all this week on the Bourse, because of the holiday season, while the professional traders were inclined to caution on account of the uncertainty concerning repercussions from the Spanish civil war and the outbreak in the Far East.

John Talbot, unseeded, upset the second-seeded Kennedy Randall Jr. in the final round of the Staten Island men's singles championship at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, S. I., yesterday, 6-4, 6-4, 2-6, 3-6, 7-5.

Mills in Western Germany, because of increasing orders for export, particularly to smaller South American countries, and because of a shortage of raw supplies, have been diverting raw cotton from home orders. This, in turn, is holding up domestic deliveries.

Symptoms of war fever are now unmistakably showing through Tokyo's Summer somnolence. Outside the popular plebeian Buddhist temple in the Asakusa section today hundreds of women and girls stood completing "thousand stitch girdles" to send to husbands and brothers at the front.

It is the exception rather than the rule when most of the fishermen from a single port are assembled under one roof. That occasion, unusual in the annals of the sport on Long Island, came to pass today.

Dividends declared in July were the largest for that month in six years. The total of $281,481,096, representing declarations by 984 companies, compared with $375,851,284 voted by 1,503 corporations in the preceding month and with $261,774,877 declared by 880 companies in July, 1936.

The National Socialist League of War Wounded assembled at the Olympic Stadium here today to hear Henri Pichot, president of the French Federal Veterans Union, speak in the name of fourteen delegations of foreign veterans. Great Britain, Italy and Rumania were represented, in addition to France.

The trial of thirty practitioners of religion, Including a Bishop and two former nuns, on charges of fascist counterrevolutionary activity is disclosed in the current issue of Bezbozhnik, the organ of the League of Militant Godless. The date of the trial and the outcome are, not indicated.

The old paddle-wheel steamer Yankee crept into Montauk Harbor early yesterday after she had grounded at night in a thick fog while carrying more than 400 passengers who had embarked in the hope of observing the America's Cup races at Newport on Saturday.

The largest party of the Saratoga racing season was the luncheon given at the Saratoga Golf Club today by George H. Bull, president of the Racing Association. Mr. Bull's guests were Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin, Mr. and Mrs. David O. Wagstaff, Robert C. Winmill, Charles H. Thieriot, Mr. and Mrs. Robert McMullen,

Swart, Duntze Co., affiliated with Swart, Brent Co., will start today at 40 Exchange Place a general securities business, specializing in bank and insurance stocks. A majority of the personnel comprises the former bank and insurance stock department of G. M.-P. Murphy Co.

Steel company heads were blamed for the gravity of the strike situation by the Rev. C. Newman Hogle of the Vanderveer Park Methodist Episcopal Church of Brooklyn, who preached the sermon yesterday at the Broadway Temple Methodist Episcopal Church, 174th Street and Broadway.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek called on the women of China today to fight Japan "according to their ability." The Wellesley-educated wife of the head of the Central Government, herself secretary-general of his air forces, declared that "today the women of Spain are occupying the fighting lines."

Rolling billows of smoke, skyrocketing flames and showers of sparks caused by a three-alarm fire in the Claremont Park district of the Bronx attracted more than 25, 000 persons to the area late last night as the blaze destroyed a group of low frame buildings on Webster Avenue near 172d Street.

Max Marston of Philadelphia won his seventh title since 1926 in the Shenecossett men's invitation golf tournament today by defeating Jimmy Lee of Danbury, Georgetown University star, 4 and 2, in the 36-hole final.
Typical Summer weather yesterday brought millions outdoors, jamming beaches and parks in the metropolitan area and choking roadways leading to them with traffic.

Bruno Walter entered the Salzburg Festival picture last night by conducting Gluck's "Orpheus." He was warmly greeted by an audience which, if it did not completely fill the Festspielhaus, was engrossed and obviously pleased.

The world's wheat markets were on the downgrade the last week because of readjustment from an old to a new crop basis. The crop-scare period apparently is ended as far as North America is concerned, as the crop is known within a relatively few million bushels.

Music inspired by plays of Shakespeare made up the novel and stimulating program presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under George King Raudenbush, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. The concert was attended by 2,000 persons.
The Rev. Thomas Blake, an ordained deacon of the Methodist Episcopal Church and a retired banker, died on Saturday in his home at 726 Rugby Road, Brooklyn, of a heart ailment. His age was 84.
Accused of the theft of $5,000 in jewelry in 1934, Edward McMahon, 43 years old, of 404 West Twentythird Street, who said he was a WPA worker, was arrested at his home at 9 o'clock last night.

Captain Samuel D. McAlister, United States Army, retired, died early this morning in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, on his third attempt to take his life. Captain McAlister, who was 60 years old and lived at 11 Beech Street here, died of an overdose of sleeping tablets taken Wednesday night, according to Dr.

Gifford Pinchot, twice Governor of Pennsylvania, was reported today to be preparing for another attempt next year to realize his ambition to sit in the Senate. He lost the Republican Senatorial nomination to William S. Vare in a three-cornered primary of 1926 and he was defeated for the nomination in 1934 by former Senator David A. Reed, who lost in the general election to Joseph F. Guffey, Democrat.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes, depreciation and other charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

Thomas Morgan, 43 years old, of 62 Bartholdi Avenue, was seriously injured today when, police said, he fell out the window of his bedroom and dropped fifteen feet to the ground. Morgan was taken to the Medical Center with a broken right knee, broken left arm and possible fracture of the skull.

The official measures taken in regard to the exploitation of cereals and iron ore have induced considerable nervousness in financial circles as is usual following intervention by the State in trade or finance.
Secretary Wallace blamed the "Old Guard" today for sidetracking his Ever. normal Granary Bill, but expressed hope for passage in the next two weeks of his crop insurance measure.

Protesting the War Department's recent refusal to improve Jones Inlet, the owners of mere than 500 private and commercial pleasure boats using the waterway cruised in a single line nearly six miles long from Freeport to Zach's Bay this afternoon.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler reviewed 30,000 foreign-residing Germans here today. Nearly all were citizens of Czechoslovakia, Poland, Austria and other Danubian countries. The crowd's violent enthusiasm, as last night, again broke through all regulations.

Sales of American aircraft, engines and spare parts rose 53.3 per cent during the first six months of 1937 as compared to the corresponding period of 1936, it was announced yesterday by Leighton W. Rogers, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month showed the largest turnover since last April, but the smallest for any July in fourteen years. Sales last month, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 20,715,369 shares, compared with 16,443,293 in June and 34,786,729 shares in July,

Our recent plaint that the British Empire (pardon, Commonwealth of Nations) had come to a pretty pass, quizzically enough the Khyber, when it had to call out Shirley (Wee Willie Winkie) Temple to keep peace on the border is further justified by the testimony of "I Cover the War," the new debunker of Mr. Kipling at the Globe.

ALLEN--Louise, on July 31, 1937, at her late residence, 207 East 202d St.. Bronx, beloved wife of Frederic. Funeral service Monday, Aug. 2, 8 P. M. ARMSTRONG--Suddenly, on July 31, Wilmot M., beloved husband of Dorothy, father of Jean and brother of Spencer Armstrong. Funeral service at Universal Chapel, 597 Lexington Ave., this afternoon at 2 o'clock. p
The annual memorial program in honor of John Philip Sousa was played by the Edwin Franko Goldman Band on the Mall in Central Park last night, before an audience estimated at 35,000 persons.

A window and a door glass were smashed early today by milk bottles hurled against the home of the Rev. Reginald B. Naugle, pastor of the Resurrection Lutheran Church, who yesterday asked "divine guidance" for the newly formed Independent Labor Federation of America, at Hershey.

More settled conditions ruled in the money market through July than in any month since last February. Quotations for all classes of accommodation in July remained stationary at rates carried forward from June.

"My arm's sore-I shouldn't pitch," was the great Jerome Herman Dean's plaint in the dugout early today. He didn't pitch very well and Brooklyn routed him in the seventh to beat the Cards in the opening game of a double-header, 7-3.

Trapped in a crashed airplane, Major Guy Hart Moates, flight surgeon at Langley Field, Va., burned to death today as his 19-year-old son and others looked on, unable to rescue him. The army plane, piloted by Lieutenant William R. Enyard, Air Corps Reserve, Langley Field, hita tree as it was taking off, skimmed over the top of another, banked sharply and crashed in a clearing near this army post.

Some 3,000 members and friends of the German-American Bund of New Jersey visited Camp Nordland today to swim, hike, picnic and drink beer. There was no marching, swastika waving or anything that might be offensive to anti-Nazi groups.
Commonwealth Edison CompanyQuarter ended June 30, 1937: Net income, $3,278,146, equal to $2.03 a share, against $2.060,576, or $1.28 a share, in the same period last year. First six months of 1937:
The question whether a man can become illegally drunk on a beverage legally non-intoxicating in Kansas was raised today for decision by the State's higher courts.

Weakness in cottonseed oil largely offset the effect of continued strength in hogs as a market influence here in lard last week, and future deliveries of the latter closed unchanged to 20 cents for 100 pounds lower, compared with the preceding week.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,619,334,400. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

Lee Shubert, who returned late last week from his annual play-buying excursion to the Continent, yesterday announced his season's intentions toward the Broadway theatre. The list is comparable to a movie firm's, as it includes some sixteen new productions in the musical and the straight dramatic fields plus the Irish Players with a repertory of ten plays.

The Red army was gathered today at the foot of the Carnic Alps, ready to strike swiftly at the Blue army deployed along the valley and plains of the Venetia region. The two armies are waiting the zero hour for the beginning of this year's war manoeuvres, which take place in North Italy from tomorrow until Aug. 9 and on the Island of Sicily from Aug. 12 to 19.

Visiting yachtsmen filled in the time between cup races by sailing dinghies in Brenton Cove today. A Larchmont skipper, Jim Merrill, provided the highlight when Dunker, owned by Mrs. Helen Hill, was dismasted.

A collision between two street cars at Livingston and Court Streets, in the Borough Hall section of stop Brooklyn, injured fourteen persons at five minutes after midnight today and tied up traffic at the intersection for three-quarters of an hour.
Commonwealth Edison CompanyQuarter ended June 30, 1937: Net income, $3,278,146, equal to $2.03 a share, against $2.060,576, or $1.28 a share, in the same period last year. First six months of 1937:

Although liberty and freedom are usually spoken of as things to be either denied or affirmed, they are more truthfully things to be won, the Rev. Adam W. Burnet said in his sermon as guest preacher yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street. Mr. Burnet is rector of the Westbourne Presbyterian Church, Glasgow, Scotland.

Miss Mildred Wilson Woodruff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving W. Woodruff of Maplewood, will be married on Oct. 8 to Harry L. Hesse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis H. Hesse of Roselle Park. The ceremony will take place in the evening at Prospect Presbyterian Church here. The pastor, the Rev, Arthur Nelson Butz, will officiate.

Government inquiry into rumors of recruiting here of aviators for Chinese service against Japan appeared imminent today following statements of The Los Angeles Times that Russell L. Hearn had enlisted 182 men to join the Chinese forces.

Elizabeth H. Dexter, former director of the family service division in the Emergency Relief Bureau, will assume today her duties as head of the family service department of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities. She will take the place of Miss Elizabeth Dutcher.

A bridge party will be given the afternoon of Aug. 11 at the Nassau Hotel on the Boardwalk at Long Beach, L. I., under the auspices of the Godmothers' League. Many of the members of the organization spend their Summer vacations near that community.
The question whether a man can become illegally drunk on a beverage legally non-intoxicating in Kansas was raised today for decision by the State's higher courts.

Weakness in cottonseed oil largely offset the effect of continued strength in hogs as a market influence here in lard last week, and future deliveries of the latter closed unchanged to 20 cents for 100 pounds lower, compared with the preceding week.

Gold received here in July, as reported daily by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, amounted to $67,204,900, the smallest amount for any month since February, when $64,123,400 arrived. Last month's imports compared with receipts of $185,583,600 in the preceding month and $8,799,100 in July, 1936.

Two of the Coast Guard's small but busy squadron of rescue planes are here for the cup series, one from the Cape May (N. J.) station that is soon to be transferred to Floyd Bennett Field on Jamaica Bay and the other from the Salem (Mass.) hangars.

Frank Kovacs of Oakland, Calif.; Isadore Bellis of Philadelphia, and Seymour Greenberg, Chicago southpaw, paced the field into the third round of the national junior boys' tennis championships as 193 entrants began play today on the Culver Military Academy courts.

Returning home from a stay at Asbury Park, N. J., because she was alarmed by lack of any word from her husband, Mrs. Ethel Fish of 225 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, found his body at 5 P. M. yesterday in the living room of their apartment.

Captain Alfred M. Moore, master of the United States liner American Banker, and Theodore Christensen, chief officer, will receive awards of the Life Saving and Benevolent Association of New York this afternoon on the deck of the vessel,

Play in the national junior championship will be resumed tomorrow afternoon when Cocie Rathborne's Meadow Brook Pelicans enter the play, meeting the Santa Barbara team of California in the semi-final match.
Nine persons were killed today when an Italian commercial plane crashed in flames near the airport here. All were believed to be Italians-five passengers and a crew of four.

Jacob Schoolhouse, assistant inspector of buildings and grounds for Columbia University, died Sunday at his residence, the Hotel Narragansett, Ninety-fourth Street and Broadway, from the effects of a stroke suffered a week ago. He would have been 80 years old next Saturday.

Passage at this session of Congress of legislation continuing the sugar control system beyond the present year was thrown further in doubt today when the House Agriculture Committee rejected an Administration proposal that provisions governing future refined imports be deleted and incorporated in a separate bill.

Each of the following Reserve officers Is ordered to active duty Aug. 1, at Plattsburg Barracks, N. Y., for training: Major John deB. Greene, Inf.-Res., 24 Peyster St., Albany, N. Y. 2d Lt. Jacob H. Bloss, AG.-Res., 514 Scott Ave., Syracuse. N. Y.

William B. Gillette, widely known painter and etcher, died Saturday after a short illness in a hotel here. His age was 73. Mr. Gillette, best known for his painting of marine life and his studies of birds and animals, also was an etcher of note.

Suffering a bit from the after effects of sea sickness but otherwise in "perfect" condition, an okapi, a giraffe-like creature from the Belgian Congo, which has never before been seen in this country, arrived here last night aboard the steamship Pennland.

Mayor Charles Gold failed to receive the support of the Democratic organization of Long Beach here tonight as it designated eight candidates for city offices to run in the primary election next month. After heated debates Louis F. Edwards was designated for the office of Mayor.

With one of the largest votes ever recorded at a special election in the history of the district, voters of Union Free School District 3 at a meeting tonight in the high school auditorium registered their approval of a project to spend $750,000 for a new junior high school.

Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan expects no show-down between HenryFord and organized labor this Summer. Mr. Murphy stopped ten minutes at Allegheny County Airport today en route home by plane from Washington, where he was a cruiseguest of President Roosevelt over the week-end. He-said:
Lord Tweedsmuir is Governor General of Canada, but when he wants to cross the Arctic Circle he is in the same position
The memorial commemorating the St. Mihiel offensive by American troops and one of the most beautiful of American battle monuments in France was officially dedicated.

In a swift move that caught taxpayers associations by surprise, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors granted 10 per cent salary restorations this afternoon to fifty county employes receiving more than $3,000 annually.

Windsor, near Binghamton, N. Y., is having a centennial celebration this week and has set aside one day in honor of a school girl named Alice Eloisa Freeman, who was a student in the Windsor Academy, and who at the age of 27 became president of Wellesley College.

The United Gas Corporation, one of the members of the Electric Bond and Share utility system, announced yesterday that its subsidiary, the United Gas Public Service Company, would withdraw from the field of gas distribution so as to concentrate on other branches of the. oil and gas industry.
Despite rumors that the Government soon will fall, the Yugoslav Cabinet feels safe. A member of the Cabinet tonight assured this correspondent that the Government would not resign

After a six-year suspension, religious services were resumed Sunday at Jalapa, capital of the State of Veracruz. The cathedral there, which was the only church with a priest authorized to officiate, was crowded throughout the day.
Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergen assented today to transference to White Plains of a suit to determine whether an election for Surrogate shall be held in Westchester in November.

That was an affecting scene in Tammany Hall yesterday afternoon. For months the executive committee has been jangling and wrangling about the choice of a leader, provisional or permanent. Monday there was a grand burst of concord.

A welcome from land and sea greeted Harold S. Vanderbilt as he guided the Ranger back to her berth tonight. From the moment the America's Cup yacht crossed the finish line until she reached her mooring, the handsome white sloop, her skipper and crew were roundly cheered.

Jacob Bartscherrer of 178 Evergreen Avenue, Brooklyn, a Republican and a former Commissioner of Records, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in the Summer City Hall at College Point as a member of the New York City Alcoholic Beverage Control Board to fill the vacancy resulting from the recent resignation of Frank C. Bellucci.

Stockholders of the Newark Consolidated Gas Company, an underlying concern, voted today to merge with the Public Service Electric and Gas Company. The Newark company was the last in a group of five underlying concerns that approved the merger.

The use of copper and its alloys this year by many of the leading consuming industries will establish a new high record, the Copper and Brass Research Association said yesterday. It estimated that this year's use of brass pipe and copper tubing, which in 1936 established a record of 94,000,000 pounds, would exceed 100,000,000 pounds.

Rear Admiral Walter Fitzhugh Worthington died yesterday at his home here, where he had lived since his retirement in 1919. His age was 82. Besides his active service, which included the Spanish - American War, Admiral Worthington...
Opposition by Southern members of the House to any sort of wages and hours legislation will be stronger than that shown by Southern Senators, according to indications today.
Society leaders here say a greater number of debutantes will be presented the coming season at the Cotillion than last year. Among those from New York, New Jersey and New England will be:

A stipulation dropping the suit brought against the Securities and Exchange commissioners by the Bagdad Copper Corporation will be filed in Federal District court for the Southern District of New York today.
The South African Airways is planning to establish an air service covering the whole of Africa south of the equator, it was learned today.

The Rules Committee has recommended House consideration this week of legislation to place dependent "gold star" parents and widows of World War soldiers on a pension basis. This would supplant war risk insurance payments, which expire during the next three years.

The following have been suspended from dealings: Nashville, Florence Sheffield Railway Company first-mortgage 5 per cent fifty-year gold bonds, due on Aug. 1, 1937; Government of the Argentine Nation external sinking-fund 5 1/2 per cent gold bonds, issue of Feb. 1, 1928, due on Aug. 1, 1962, which have been called for redemption;
The children of the lower East Side awoke yesterday morning to find that once again the Park Deapartment had brought them the opportunity to see things that grow in the country.

Ed Genetive, home club amateur, and Stanley Remsen, diminutive assistant pro at Bethpage, collaborated for a superb 31, 33-64, eight shots below the regulation figures, to capture the amateur-pro best-ball event staged by the Long Island P. G. A. over the Wheatley Hills Golf Club course today.

Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert E. Fuller of Boston arrived yesterday on the Normandie and have joined their daughter, Miss Harriet S. Fuller, at the St. Regis. Mrs. Homer B. Davis, wife of Lieut. Comdr. Davis, U. S. N., of Washington, has come from Coronado, Calif., to the Waldorf-Astoria, accompanied by her son, Richard Davis.
The Aluminum, Company of America carried to the Supreme Court today its fight against anti-trust proceedings by the Federal Government in New York.
Far up in the picturesque mountains of Spain's ancient kingdom of Aragon, one of the strangest offensives of the civil war is heading no one knows exactly where.

A midsummer concert series to be given on playgrounds of 200 public schools will be inaugurated today, Mme. Yolanda Mero-Irion, executive secretary of the Musicians Emergency Fund, announced yesterday.

Operations of the American steel industry this week are scheduled at 85.5 per cent of theoretical capacity, a gain of 1.2 points, or 1.4 per cent, over last week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. It is the highest rate since the week of May 24. A month ago the rate was 67.3 per cent of capacity.

The insistent jingle of the telephone bell broke the early morning silence. It was Dr. Ben Handelsman, of local origin, calling from Lake George to report on the freshwater situation in that neck o' the woods.

A $50,000 gift from Mr. and Mrs. Jacob F. Schoellkopf Sr. of Buffalo to the Boy Scouts of America was announced here yesterday by the national Scout office. Mr. Schoellkopf is president of Schoellkopf, Hutton Pomeroy, dealers in investment securities. Formerly he was a leading manufacturer of aniline colors.

An agreement has been reached between the city and county of the Dallas Levee Improvement District and the bondholders' committee on a plan for refunding the $6,000,000 of 5 1/2 per cent bonds of the district, in default since 1931, it was announced yesterday.

Eighteen screen printing and embossing establishments have agreed, in writing, to refrain from serving both converters and the garment trade at the same time, Edmund Wright, executive director of the Textile Converters Association of America, Inc., announced yesterday. Firms listed were D. and S.

Dr. Robert M. Hopkins, general secretary of the World's Sunday School Association, returned yesterday on the Bremen of the North German Lloyd Line after spending nearly four months in South Africa arranging for the World's Sunday
A plan for improving the status of holders of certificates of beneficial interest of the City Certficates Corporation was ratified today by the directors of the corporation.
Stocks closed irregularly higher; turnover, 789,270 shares. United States Government and other bonds moderately lower; transactions, $4,629,300.

The Mandates Commission of the League of Nations decided today to base its examination of the Palestine problem not on the British partition proposal but on the assumption underlying it-that the mandate is unworkable.

Dmitry Bogmoloff, Soviet Ambassador to China, protested today to Shinrokuro Hidaka, Japanese charge d'affaires in Nanking, against a raid upon the Soviet Consulate General in Tientsin by White Russians yesterday.

A thorough survey of this market with a view to determining what German products will find ready sales here is necessary preliminary to any increase in trade between the two countries, Harry Tipper, executive vice president of the National Foreign Trade Association, asserted here yesterday.

The entire estate of George Barton French, retired broker and financier, was left to his widow, Mrs. Katherine Gordon French, under his will, filed for probate today in the office of Surrogate Robert S. Pelletreau.

Sam Minery, 16-year - old Ridgewood Country Club caddie, playing in a tournament for the first time, today won the New Jersey State caddie championship with a total of 79, 76--155 over the Colonia Country Club course and earned the right to lead New Jersey's team of eight in the metropolitan champonship at Sunningdale Aug. 16.

Supreme Court Justice Peter P. Smith in Brooklyn signed on order yesterday requiring the officers of two associations made up of employes in the New York City Department of Sanitation to show cause on Friday why the books of the associations should not be examined and an accounting rendered to its members.

During the twenty-one months since it began active operation, the National Labor Relations Board has handled 5,136 cases involving 1,639,568 workers, including 1,284 new cases in I June and 1,064 in May.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having been in New York only a few months, after years spent in the Middle West, I find activities here most refreshing. The mere fact of feeling free to write a letter to a newspaper is comforting.
A $2,000,000 mortgage on the twenty-six-story office building at 111 John Street has been placed for the 111 John Street Corporation through the Paul Hammond Company. It runs for twenty years,

Colonel Ogden J. Ross announced today that the State Flood Control Commission, of which he is chairman, would undertake next week a twoday inspection of Federal flood control projects in Central and Southern New York.

Drafted to plug holes in legislation, which until recent years, allowed almost unrestricted entry into this country, the new immigration act came into force today. It clamps down tightly on all immigrants.

Representative Allen, Republican of Illinois, tonight called the Social Security Board's withdrawal of oldage assistance grants to Illinois "an act of political reprisal against Governor Horner for his recent open opposition to the Roosevelt scheme to pack the Supreme Court."

The marriage of Miss Margaret Murray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Murray of this city, to Donald W. Fraley, son of Mrs. Fanny Fraley, also of Elizabeth, and the late John W. Fraley, will take place next Saturday afternoon in the Greystone Presbyterian Church here.

Influenced by large crop estimates and reports of favorable weather over the week-end, cotton prices continued to lose ground yesterday. Under the pressure of persistent selling the staple declined $1 a bale to end with a loss of 18 to 22 points.

Colonel Wait Chatterton Johnson, U. S. A., who served in the infantry and was an international authority on athletics, died at the post hospital at Fort Ethan Allen this morning. He had been on sick leave from recruiting duties at Fort Bliss, El Paso, Texas. His age was 60.

A new legal attack on the Market Department's policy of restricting peddling was started yesterday by the United Peddlers of the Bronx, Inc., an organization purporting to speak for about 650 hucksters who frequent the Bronx, Harlem and Yorkville. They sell their wares from motor trucks or wagons drawn by horses, not pushcarts.

The executive board of the United Democratic Club of the Second Assembly District, Brooklyn, and the Independent Citizens Committee of Brooklyn have endorsed unanimously former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, David L. Block announced yesterday.
Representative Christopher D. Sullivan was elected leader of Tammany yesterday at a meeting of its executive committee to succeed the late James J. Dooling.

Leonard Prince, fibre, in Ruppert Building, 535 5th Ave; Comic Favorites, Inc, in 369 Lexington Ave; Edmond S. McConnell, in 155 E 44th St; Seiberling Rubber Co, in 549-51 W 52d St; Dr Stewart C Schwenk, dentist, in 3-5 E 53d St; Jack Siegel, hos??ery, in 385 5th Ave; Meyer Sklansky, furniture, in 549-57 W 54th St; Cross Brown, Co. broker.
Carl von Ossietzky, pacifist and Nobel Peace Prize winner, was interviewed by correspondents today in a North End sanatorium for the first time since he received the prize.

A detachment of 200 midshipmen, members of the junior class at the Naval Academy, were en route today to Newport, R. I., and the international yacht races. The group left on a month's training cruise aboard the gunboat Erie and the destroyers Claxton, J. Fred Talbott, Roper, Fairfax, Jacob Jones and Manley.

The week-end's law enforcement drive at Coney Island brought before Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto of Brooklyn yesterday forty peddlers, charged with hawking wares illegally at the beach; ten concessionaires, charged with violating a sanitation ordinance, and seven other defendants, accused of undressing on the beach.

The touring Marylebone Cricket Club of England was held to a draw by an all-Toronto eleven today in its first match on Canadian soil. G. C. Newman, captain of the visiting team, declared in mid-afternoon, with the score at 251 runs for four wickets, the home players compiling 189 for seven in reDlv.
Dr. Gustavus Adolphus Eisen, Swedish - born scientist, an authority on archaeology, geology, biology, anthropology and other fields of learning, observed his ninetieth birthday yesterday.
It now develops that, although there is yet no Antony for "Antony and Cleopatra," there is an opening date--Oct. 12, in Rochester. At first the talk was Oct. 1, in the South.

Commercial failures in the United States totaled 158 for the week ended July 29, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure compares with 148 the week before and 175 in the corresponding week of last year.

Mr. and Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs, who have a large house party at Rose Cliff, entertained with a dinner there tonight. Roderick Terry had dinner guests at Linden Gate and Mrs. Lorillard Spencer was a dinner hostess at the Muenchinger-King.

New York State cut today a $7,661,491.26 tax melon representing receipts from the motor fuel levy for the threemonth period ended June 30, sending $1,684,612.96 to the fifty-seven up-State counties and $421,153.23 to New York City.
Christopher (Christy) D. Sullivan, chosen yesterday as the new Tammany leader, is the last of the great Tammany Sullivans and a comparatively modest one.

Movements o: livestock in the Chicago markets today, reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 11,000 including 2,500 directly The market generally was 10 to 15 cent higher than Friday's average;

German tourists willing to go abroad for a few days with nothing more than the 10 marks allowed them by the Reich are now forbidden to do so. Groups of such tourists in the past have taken their own food and have slept in inexpensive hotels. Round-trip railway fares could be paid in marks at home.

Turpentine firm, 32 c; sales, 187 barrels; receipts, 491 barrels; shipments. 112 barrels; stock, 32,825 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 605; receipts, 2,015; shipments, 3,069; stock, 66,256. Quote: B to K, $7.75: M, $7.80; N, $7.82 1/2; WG, $7.85; WW, X, $8.60.

Plans were filed yesterday for the construction of public schools at 1,064-86 Lenox Road, in Brooklyn, at an estimated cost of $715,000 and at 7,301-23 Fort Hamilton Parkway, costing $690,000. Other plans filed related to alterations. The list follows:

Fairmount P1 (11-2959). $ $, 351 ft w of Southern Blvd. 100x103; Emek Realty Corp to Mar-Gene Realty Corp, 349 E 149th St: mtg, $148,176. Bronx River Ave, 1,241 (14-3769); Gilia Corp to Martha Feinberg, 1,241 Bronx River Ave; mtg, $11,500.

Striking employes of the Gale Manufacturing Company were enjoined today from picketing the plant or interfering with non-striking employes. The injunction, issued by Circuit Judge Blaine W. Hatch, also included striking employes of the near-by Albion Malleable Company.

Mr. and Mrs. Woodson R. Oglesby will hold a debutante supper dance for their second daughter, Miss Kate Oglesby, at Blantyre, Lenox, on the night of Aug. 21. Miss Oglesby attended the Fermata School at Aiken, S. C., and Miss Porter's School at Farmingtom, Conn.

Gaining their fourth consecutive victory in the team tournament of the International Chess Federation at the Grand Royal Hotel here today, the United States players moved up into fourth place in the race for the Hamilton-Russell trophy, below Czechoslovakia, the Netherlands and Poland.

Nonunion miners went to work at the Sunshine Silver Mine today through a picket line of C. I. O. mine union members. Armed guards from the Shoshone County Sheriff's office stood near by. Deputy Frank Pearce, county jailer, estimated the pickets at "a couple of hundred" and said the nonunion men outnumbered them four to one.
The Maryland Jockey Club announced today that 113 two-year-olds, the largest number in five years, have been nominated for the Pimlico Futurity, to be run Nov. 6.

The possibility of a break between Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff, and the Liberal party loomed tonight when Colonel Batista publicly condemned the attitude assumed by .some Liberal leaders during last night's meeting of the party's national assembly.

Liberals who vigorously opposed the President's Supreme Court plan and expressed doubts over the wisdom of the Wages-and-Hours Bill now have an opportunity to applaud a genuinely progressive measure brought forward by the Roosevelt Administration.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 28: Increases of $44,000,000

A vigorous campaign against weak and unsound banks has been undertaken by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Leo T. Crowley, chairman, declared today. Banks which insist upon unsound practices or maintain an unsound financial structure must be weeded out, he said.

Although the Senate Judiciary Committee's proposed amendment to the Sumners Bill, H. R. 2260, covering procedure in the lower Federal Courts and the Supreme Court, has been carefully drawn, the measure still contains several defects and should be further corrected and amended, in the opinion of the Committee on the Judiciary and the Senate of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

CONNOR, MARY A. (April 30). Estate, about $3,000. To the Irish Historical Society of the City of New York, a copy of the History of Ireland written in 1680; St. Joseph's Academy, Emmetsburg, Md., portrait and $500; Newark Museum, Newark, N. J., one oil painting; Trinity College, Grafton St, Dublin, Ireland, portrait of Denis Mulcahy and two of Dr.

B. H. Whinston of New York has been appointed architect for the development of the former A. F. Brown Company plant in Elizabethport, N. J. The project will include the erection of several one-story buildings at an approximate cost of $500,000.
Sales of copper in the export market yesterday were made at 14.50 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports. Business was only moderate because of the bank holiday in Great Britain.

Edward Neville Dalton, a retired examiner and clerk in the city's finance department and member of an old Brooklyn family, died here yesterday at his home, 284 Rocklyn Avenue. He was 79 years old. Mr. Dalton retired in 1934 after serving the city for forty years.
John Erskine has written a fictional account of the life of Francois Villon that will be published by Bobbs-Merrill on Aug. 16. It is called "The Brief Hour of Francois Villon."

The President has a little list which is not for publication-for the present, at least. It is a roster of fifty-one Senatorial names set down by the late Democratic leader, Joseph T. Robinson, and handed to the President as the voting strength of the Logan-Hatch Supreme Court substitute proposal.

The Genesee Cup competition among teams of four representing counties, the first event on the program of the New York State Chess Association which opened yesterday at Cazenovia Seminary, was won by Schenectady with a total of 13 out of a possible 16 points.

Clearance sales of men's clothing and furnishings last month proved disappointing, retail executives admitted here yesterday. With the exception of gabardine, tropical worsted and a few other types of lightweight clothing, most divisions failed to better last year's figures.

Lynn Waldorf bf Northwestern University took the lead today in the poll to select a coaching staff for the collegiate football team in their game with the Green Bay Packers at Soldier Field the night of Sept. 1.
The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today the expulsion of Michael J. Meehan, colorful Wall Street figure, from the three national security exchanges of which he is a member.
Buying activity was reported as "unusually good for the first day" at the Fashion Accessory Show, which opened yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker. About 200 buyers registered during the day.

Nicholas Kelley, member of the law firm of Larkin, Rathbone Perry, general counsel to the Chrysler Corporation, yesterday was elected a vice president and director of the corporation, according to an announcement by Walter P. Chrysler, chairman of the board. Mr. Kelley will continue as member of the law firm.

Onethird of Philadelphia's truck drivers, estimated at about 8,000 men, went out on strike today in answer to an unexpected and peremptory call by strike officials in protest against the hiring of guards, described as "thugs," for trucks hauling goods of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.

Although there was heavy traffic over the last week-end the number of automobile accidents and injuries in the city showed a marked decrease from the corresponding period last year, it was announced yesterday by Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler.

The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston reported today business activity- in New England in June and distribution in the same month, as measured by department store sales, were higher than in the same month a year ago.

The Glidden Company of Cleveland, manufacturers of paints and varnishes, filed for registration today with the Securities and Exchange Commission 64,004 4-5 shares of no-par value common stock to be offered by warrants to common stockholders and 14,395 17-25 shares to be offered by warrants to preferred stockholders.
Mrs. Reginald Fincke heads a group here in charge of arrangements for a musical event the night of Aug. 12 at the home of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Clark on Ram Island. The artist will be Yolanda

A field of 191 entrants representing sixty-one cities and twenty-four States and Territories will begin play in the sixteenth amateur public links golf championship over the Harding Memorial Park course at San Francisco next Monday, according to The Associated Press.

Little Mayoress Lau, 6 years old and prettier than a Chinese doll, probably has not yet heard the fable of Pandora and how that little girl loosed all the troubles in the world when she opened the mythical forbidden box.
Three thousand children, orphans from New York City and Brooklyn institutions, will arrive here tomorrow morning for an all-day outing on the beach as guests of the Mayor's Welfare Committee.
Circuit Judge Homer Ferguson issued a temporary injunction today forbidding "packing" of restaurants of the Brennan, Fitzgerald Sinks chain by members of the Waiters, Waitresses and Cooks Union.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Eleanor Grace Hubbard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Hubbard of Detroit, to Franklin Cole Loranger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eli J. Loranger of Larchmont.

Seventy-five Girl Scouts, representing Puerto Rico and every State in the Union, arrived at Camp Andree here today and began preparations for the international Girl Scout jamboree that starts Aug. 10 at the camp. It will be the first jamboree of its kind in America and will mark the silver anniversary of girl scouting.

When the Bowery Savings Bank sold to 824 7th Ave, Inc, August Dreyer, president, the n w cor of 7th Ave and 53d St, 25x100, the bank took back a purchase money mortgage for $40,000, to be paid in five years, on selling price of $85,000.
Rhode Island's jewel industry began operation today under a State minimum wage law for men and women providing that manufacturers pay their workers at least 30 cents an hour.
The Municipal Civil Service Commission, it was learned yesterday, has withdrawn a resolution placing proportional representation vote canvassers in the non-competitive civil service classification.

Arthur Forbes was in a serious condition with a cracked skull today because he failed to heed his wife's call to supper. Police said Mrs. Forbes told them she called her husband but he continued blissfully asleep on a couch.
Hearings opened today before the Select Committee of the Senate on President Roosevelt's plan for reorganization of the executive branch of the Federal Government.

The board of directors of the General Motors Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $1 a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 13 to stock of record of Aug. 12, besides the regular quarterly dividend of $1.25 a share on the $5 preferred stock. The number of common shares outstanding is 42,740,649.

Attorney General Bennett clarified his recent opinion concerning private hospitals caring for emergency cases. "Nowhere in my opinion is anything said from which the conclusion might be drawn that emergency treatment might be denied by a hospital, public or private," he declared.

The Treasury's current $50,000,000 weekly issue of 273-day bills sold at an average interest rate of 0.467 per cent, compared with 0.485 per cent last week, and the companion issue of $50,000,000 135-day went for 0.228, compared with 0.372 per cent last week, Wayne Taylor, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, announced tonight.

Edwin S. Webster of Boston, a director of Stone Webster, Inc., gave away 55,200 shares of that company's capital stock on June 11, leaving his holdings of this stock at 91,742 shares at the end of the month, according to the monthly report of the Securities and Exchange Commission on transactions and holdings of officers, directors and principal stockholders, made public today.

A smaller decline than allowed for seasonally was registered in automobile production last week, and the adjusted index has advanced to 104.9 from 99.7. This compares with 121.9 for the week ended Aug. 1, 1936.

Operators of three strike-bound packing plants denied today that they had violated the Wagner Labor Relations Act by refusing to bargain Collectively with employes. They challenged leaders of the Committee for Industrial Organization to call an election to determine whether the union represented a majority of the workers.
Michigan extended an enthusiastic welcome tonight to the most Rev. Archbishop Edward Mooney, who will be installed tomorrow as the First Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit.

The collateral behind the Alleghany Corporation's $24,387,000 of 5 per cent bonds of 1950 was worth 53 per cent of their face value yesterday, according to an appraisal by the Guaranty Trust Company, trustee for the issue. The indenture prevents the declaration of dividends unless the ratio of the collateral is 150 per cent.

Mrs. Nanette Nixon Smith, wife of Edgar Smith, the librettist, died yesterday morning of a heart attack at their home, 36-14 208th Street, Bayside, Queens, at the age of 63. A son, Edgar Nixon Smith of Bayside, also survives.

Movements ?? vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 2, unless specified: Vladivostok to Chefoo, Aug. 1; Alder Barker, Whipple. At San Francisco, July 31: Astoria, Chicago, Minneapolis, New Orleans, North ampton, Pensacola, Portland, Quincy Richmond, Salt Lake City, Trenton, Tu??caloosa.
The Ministry of National Defense is considering proposals submitted by Italian shipyards for construction of two modern cruisers.

Douglass B. Simonson, in Hotel Carlyle, 35 E 76th St; Mrs. Alice Wade Robinson, through Henry Fippinger, Inc, in 419 E 57th St.; Dr. Philip Reichert, in 27 E 79th St; Potter, Hamilton Co, Inc, broker.

A feeling of unity among the Chinese has produced an "arrogance" which provoked the present outbreak with Japan, according to Eiji Amau, Japanese Foreign Office spokesman during the Manchurian crisis of 1931-32, and now his country's Minister to Switzerland.
Alfred A. Knopf Jr., 19 years old, only child of the book publisher, has been missing since Monday, July 26, and is being sought by the police of seven States, it became known yesterday.

Although the factional fight in Tammany, so far as nominations for city-wide candidates are concerned, has been in no way ended by the election of Representative Christopher D. Sullivan as leader, the belief was expressed last evening that the warring groups in the Wigwam could get together on its borough and county ticket.

Federal Judge Robert A. Inch, in Brooklyn, signed yesterday an orler fixing Aug. 17 as the date for a public sale of fifty-eight buses beonging to the Tompkins Bus Corporation, which had been operating routes on Staten Island.
Bahama Negroes whose forebears were slaves feasted and danced today to the beat of goatskin drums in celebration of a century of freedom, but the festivities lacked some of their old flavor.

Six large real estate firms on the East Side have organized the East Side Real Estate Brokers Soft Ball Association with the object of playing games three days a week on the playing field of the Home Thrift Association at East End Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street.
Great Britain's retired Prime Minister, Earl Baldwin of Bewdley, was crippled by rheumatism today--his seventieth birthday.
The Standard Steel Spring Company has notified the New York Curb Exchange of the declaration of a 100 per cent stock dividend on the common stock payable at the close of business on Aug. 10.
A story of trees which yield "luscious red wine" was brought back from the tropical jungles of lower Mexico today by Llewelyn Williams, curator of botany at the Field Museum.

Four men convicted July 20 of conspiracyy to put out of business bakery owners who refused to maintain price schedules fixed by trade association were sentenced yesterday to indeterminate terms of not more than three years in the city penitentiary by Special Sessions fudges William R. Bayes, Max Solo??mon and Bernard A. Kozicke.

Ranger's speed with wind which horny-handed old salts call merely light breezes got as high as 11.1 miles per hour on the third tenmile leg of today's triangular race, according to Lieutenant William Childress, navigating officer on the Coast Guard cutter Chelan. On this same reach Endeavour II was plotted as doing 10.6 m. p. h.
The trustees of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway Company offered today to settle claims filed against the road by its

The Bureau Navigation released the following orders day, dated Juy 30: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Haff, T. G., to duty as Engineer Office the Oklahoma. Smith, H. H., the Tennessee, to duty a Executive Officer of the Argonne.

The dividend of $1 a share on General Motors common stock was about in line with Wall Street expectations. Added to the $1 dividend declared out of first-quarter income, the corporation has paid out $2 of the $2.48 earned on its common stock for the first half of 1937.

More interested in a piece of candy she was eating than in the teeming traffic in Second Avenue, 6-year-old Eileen Napier of 1,846 Second Avenue started to cross at Ninety-fifth Street yesterday afternoon without noticing that the lights were against her, and she was killed.

Miss Helen Jacobs, former United States and British tennis champion, arrived on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania last night. She is going to East Hampton, L. I., to play in the Maidstone Club tournament, and after that does not intend to appear on the courts until the Wightman Cup matches.

Thirty-two steamship lines whose unlicensed sea-going personnel will participate in the next six weeks under the supervision of the National Labor Relations Board in the election of a labor-bargaining agency, petitioned the board yesterday to permit the employes the broadest possible freedom in making their selection.
The Democratic National Committee is conducting another book sale to wipe out its $216,000 deficit of June 1 last and finance its current expenses.
A. James Cronly, a retired police lieutenant of Freeport, died at the wheel of his automobile early tonight while it was parked on the Merrick Road, near Main St. He was 72 years old.
Among the 1,534 passengers arriving yesterday from Europe on the French liner Normandie were several members of the dramatic and film stages returning from vacations.
The French liner Normandie came up the harbor yesterday morning with the blue pennant flying from her main truck, denoting that she had made another record crossing to New York.

Governor Frank F. Merriam took under advisement today the application of Essex County, N. Y., officials to extradite John Montague, crack amateur golfer and friend of movie stars, on charges of being involved in a roadhouse robbery seven years ago.

More than 15,000 persons who packed Lewisohn Stadium last night to hear Jascha Heifetz as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under George King Raudenbush, were drenched by a cloudburst a few minutes before 9 o'clock.

Dollar volume of orders placed in the wholesale market here last week was substantially above that of the corresponding week last year, although the buying policy of retailers remained conservative, the research and statistical department of the joint board, Dress and Waist Makers Union, reported yesterday.

The naval attaches of two foreign countries were among the spectators at the second America's Cup race off here today. One was Rear Admiral Robert Witthoeft-Emden of Germany, who has been a guest at the Muenchinger-King.

Overtures made by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, which is conducting the strike of 12,000 shipyard workers in the New York-New Jersey area, now nearly two months old, to have the dispute settled by negotiation were flatly turned down yesterday.

Paul Townsend and Jackson Townsend, sons of Senator John G. Townsend of Delaware, fishing on their private cruiser Jackpau, under the command of Captain Bill Hatch and First Mate Bill Rodney, had as their guests Lou Gehrig and Bill Dickey of the Yankees today.

Representatives of New York and Toronto stock brokerage houses with branches here protested at City Hall today against the new civic levy of $108 on individual members of firms. Last year the same tax was exacted from each firm only as a whole.

An important step in British foreign policy, consisting of quieting Italian fears of Britain as a first step in renewing concord between the four major Western European powers, has been taken by Neville Chamberlain, Prime Minister.

Eighty year-old A. Lawrence Lowell, presi dent emeritus of Harvard Univer sity, was reported tonight in "good' condition at Phillips House of Mas sachusetts General Hospital, suffer ing a fractured nose, fractured wrist and cuts on the chin resulting from an automobile accident.
Although Saratoga's mud was at its treacherous worst today, public choices drove home first in such order that not a word was said by the form players about the Spa being the graveyard of favorites.

More than 700 orphans or Nassau County were entertained here today by the Nassau County Police Department. They came in buses from five county institutions and enjoyed a program of swimming, a picnic luncheon, races, a marionette show, a special pool show with clowns, and other features.

DENTAL LABORATORY MECHANIC, $2,000 a Year (for filling the position of dental mechanic); ASSISTANT DENTAL LABORATORY MECHANIC, $1,440 a Year (for filling the position of assistant dental mechanic); DENTAL HYGIENIST, $1,620 a Year (for filling the position of oral hygienist).

More of the coming Winter's styles were launched today, with Chanel and Alix both showing fine collections. One thing is certain: While the clothes are immensely exciting, the silhouette so far is sensible and wearable.

Miss Elinor Janet Lutz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Lutz of this place, was married to Richard Edison Condit, son of Mr. and Mrs. Watson S. Condit, also of East Orange, this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.

Mike Turnesa, Fairview professional, and his amateur partner, Herbert Deitz of Elmsford, tied Tom Kerrigan, Siwanoy pro, and James A. Boyle with cards of 64 today to take the honors in the Westchester P. G. A. one-day best ball golf tournament at the Ardsley Country Club.

In the hope of preventing the scheduled increase in the Hudson tubes fare from going into effect, the Jersey City Chamber of Commerce sent letters today to the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company, which operates the tubes, inviting their representatives to a conference with the chamber or to hold a public hearing to discuss the matter.

Holding off the final drive of the favored Drowsy from the Greentree Stable, the Tall Trees Stable's Navarre had a nose the better of the former in the camera finish that decided the Cambridge Purse, mile feature at Suffolk Downs before a crowd of 15,000 today.

Less than forty hours after two women were seized on a charge of stealing nearly $200 early Sunday morning from Edward W. Klumple, a salesman, of Charlotte, N. C., in a taxicab, Assistant District Attorneys Hastings and Firestone presented evidence against the suspects to the grand jury with a request for a grand larceny indictment.

Dr. Otto Dibelius, one of the sharpest critics of Nazi church policy, was arrested today along with his secretary, a woman. He is to be tried on Aug. 8 because of an old open letter regarding the Jewish origin of Jesus.

The Rev. Dr. George Sherwood Dickerman, Yale '65, a retired Congregational minister, who was one of the half dozen oldest Yale alumni, died here today at his residence, 469 Edgewood Avenue. He was born at Mount Carmel, Conn., ninety-four years ago.

Mrs. William R. Irwin of Rye, N. Y., arrived today to visit Mrs. E. Louise Vanderbilt, who will give a dinner for her on Wednesday. Mrs. Albert F. Jaeckel will entertain at luncheon for the visitor on Friday.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 31:

Awards on bids for more than 3,000,000 yards of cotton cloth of various kinds for the Works Progress Administration were approved today by the Procurement Division of the Treasury Department. The awards follow:
The report of the Radio Corporation of America and subsidiaries for the first half of this year, issued for publication today, shows a net income, after all expenses and charges, of $4,647,386.
Colonel Matt Winn opened his beautiful Lincoln Fields race track today and a crowd of 10,000 saw H. H. Cotton's 4-year-old Pompa race to victory in the featured Lincolnshire Country Club Handicap.

Settling in over the hangar of the Pan American Airways base here, the British flying boat Cambria came to rest a short distance out on Manhasset Bay at 11:58 A. M. today, completing the second westward crossing of the North Atlantic by Imperial Airways.

Immediate danger of hostilities spreading to Central and South China was said by the Nanking Government to exist, notwithstanding that it was relatively quiet in the Peiping-Tientsin area, in a message to the Chinese--Embassy today.
Finsler's comet, with a head eight times larger than the earth and a tail more than 2,000,000 miles long, swept tonight through the northern sky toward its maximum brilliancy.
Clerical work in itself is not an industry, according to a decision that the Court of Appeal handed down today.

A huge white cake decorated with fir trees of green icing was placed on display at noon yesterday in the offices of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York at 4 Irving Place. The cake will be distributed among 2,800 mothers and children on Wednesday and Friday when they go sailing on the Floating Hospital of the St. John's Guild of New York.

Clinton St, 18, 25x100.2; John H. Breen to Dry Dock Savings Institution, consideration $1,000, foreclosure Avenue C, 117-19, 38.8x83; Louis Reck Jr to New York Life Ins Co, consideration $1,000, foreclosure.

A number of dinner parties preceded the Monday dance at the Kimball house at Northeast Harbor tonight. Mrs. Ledyard Cogswell Jr. of Loudonville, N. Y., entertained there for thirty-four in honor of her daughter Dorothy.
The House sent to the Senate today legislation granting consent of Congress to a minimum-wage contract ratified by Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Rhode Island.
Under provisions of the Greafter New York Charter and on police surgeon's certificate: PATROLMAN Walter F. Heuschkel, Motorcycle Precinct 1, at $2,250 per annum. Appointed Jan. 5, 1921.
Russian meteorologists at the refueling base here for a transpolar passenger-carrying flight to the United States were sending weather reports to Moscow every six hours today.

Mrs. Caroline Foote Griffin, who came with her parents to California in 1857, married an army officer and later helped tend sheep in what is now Hollywood, is dead here at the age of 82 and will be buried tomorrow. Not long ago Mrs.

A heavily built white man, between 30 and 35 years old, with a clean-shaven face, was seen coming coatless from the cellar of 349 Stockholm Street, Brooklyn, a few minutes before the body of 8-year-. old Paula Magagna was found there, it was disclosed yesterday by detectives seeking her murderer.

Denouncing the county and borough ticket picked by the New York County Republican Executive Committee as a "partisan Republican ticket," the Citizens Non-Partisan Committee, which is headed by Samuel Seabury, pledged itself yesterday to work for the election of a non-partisan Fusion slate.
John K. Moffett has resigned as a second vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company to become vice president of the Illinois Glass Company, with headquarters in Toledo.

As Coast Guard cutters approached the cup yachts this morning it was just barely possible to see their wraithlike forms and for a while even the color of the hulls could not be distinguished through the fog. Then A Ranger's white body appeared as a ghostly gray as they got closer and observers could tell which was which.

Dozens of motorists who had received summonses for parking without lights and had come to Bronx Traffic Court to pay their fines were pleasantly surprised. yesterday when Magistrate Frank Oliver dismissed the charges on the ground that a local ordinance signed by the Mayor last. week legalized parking without lights.

Plans have been completed for a countywide convention of Young Democrats, to be held Sept. 10 and 11 at the Hempstead Elks Club, it was announced here today by Herman J. Herbert Jr., president of the Young Democratic Clubs of Nassau County.
The House passed today and sent to the Senate a resolution declaring Congressional consent to a compact between New York and New Jersey for creation of the Palisades Interstate Park Commission.
The Federation of Kosher Butchers postponed yesterday until Labor Day their threatened "price strike," which was to have been called in protest against the prices retailers pay wholesalers for meat.

The Government's decision, announced yesterday, to extend old-age insurance to white collar workers-heretofore limited to manual workers-and to equalize sick benefits as between office and factory workers, was hailed by the Soviet press as an example of "Stalinist care" of the people in contrast to. conditions of workers under capitalism.

Miss Virginia Guilfoil and Captain A. F. Shea took low gross honors today over the Hotel Champlain Golf Club course in the mixed foursomes prelude to the annual women's international tournament to begin here tomorrow.

In order to clear away uncertainties regarding the French stand on the Spanish question, the Foreign Office today published the text of the French reply to the recent British questionnaire. This action comes as reply to charges by Count Dino Grandi, Italian Ambassador in London, of ambiguity on the part of France.

Sixteen members of Michigan's House of Representatives and one Senator went through the motions of holding a session today, continuing a movement to keep a special session alive although the Senate adjourned sine die last Friday.

Bela Kun, organizer of the short-lived 1918 Bolshevist regime in Hungary and one-time member of the executive committee of the Communist International, has been arrested, according to reliable but officially unconfirmable reports.

Endeavour II may have been beaten as much by a lobster pot today as by Ranger. Whether she was or not will be known by daybreak tomorrow, when the British yacht is hauled out at Herreshoff's at low tide and her underbody given the once-over.

It's not only surprising but downright incredible that so few accidents and mishaps occur in this fleet of spectator yachts, which includes fullrigged ships, super yachts, excursion vessels, one sedate Liverpool freighter that became a spectator because the Coast Guard wouldn't let her steer across the cup course, launches, catboats and even outboards.
Thomas J. McManus, former president of the Ohio State Federation of Labor, died at his home here today after a short illness. He was 71 years old.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a net profit of $7,101,458 after interest, depreciation, Federal and State income taxes and other charges, but before depletion and the Federal surtax on undistributed profits.

John McDiarmid of Princeton, seventh in the national ranking, was the victim of the first major reversal in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament today as the forty-seventh holding of' this grasscourt fixture got under way at the Meadow Club.

The Welsh estate of the Marquess of Londonderry, where Owain Glyn Dwr (Owen Glendower) became Prince of Wales in 1402, today was the scene of the opening of the Royal Welsh National Eisteddfod, the historic Welsh festival of music, poetry and other literature. An audience of 8,000 was present.
Waterfront activities ceased for thirty minutes today in most major Pacific Coast ports in what the Maritime Federation of the Pacific termed a protest against labor policies of Italy and Germany.

A crowd of 70,000 jammed White City Stadium today to see the United States track and field team in action, but at the end of three hours of mediocre competition they decided their own team was pretty good.

While patches of blue sky looked down through fog banks as if in genuine sympathy for a badly beaten loser and occasional sun rays peeped through the haze as if to cheer him up, 500 floating grandstands carrying 25,000 seagoing spectators, said it with horns, whistles, sirens and bells when they cheered T. O.

Angelo Hirsch of New Rochelle, president of G. Hirsch Sons, 119 West Fortieth Street, importers of dress materials, died Sunday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 74. He was president of the board of trustees of the Stuyvesant Polyclinic Hospital at 137 Second Avenue.
Jersey City stretched its winning streak to three straight today by defeating the Rochester Red Wings, 5 to 4, in the opener of a five-game series.
F. Fernandez and Z. Mandiola, both 21-year-old Costa Ricans, jumped overboard from the British freighter Hopestar at the entrance to the Panama Canal this morning.

Seafaring men saunter along Thames Street, which is hard by the waterfront here, and tell strange tales of what goes on ashore and afloat. Walking the length of Thames Street, a good listener can get fourteen different accounts of what went on before, during and after any race in any America's Cup series, including the current Sopwith-Vanderbilt seagoing struggle.
Five persons were injured today, a 6-year-old boy seriously, when a team of straining horses broke the whiffletree in a pulling contest and plunged into the spectators.
" Goodbye to 'altitude addle,' " said Major Carl Greene, chief of the engineering procurement branch of the Army Air Corps, Wright Field, as he climbed from the army's "coming thing in aviation."

The midsummer bank holiday in Great Britain, which closed all markets in that country, brought about a lessening in the trading volume in the local foreign exchange market yesterday, but short covering tended to advance the price of most foreign currencies in terms of the dollar.

An appeal to the State Liquor Authority to use its powers to halt petty price "chiseling" by retailers of packaged liquors is under consideration by organized groups of liquor retailers here, spokesmen for the trade groups admitted yesterday.

Officials of. the Orleans Levee District, La., will consider tenders on Aug. 23 for a new issue of $2,280,000 of refunding bonds to be dated Oct. 1, 1937, and to mature serially on April 1, 1938 to 1959. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 4 1/4 per cent.

China faces a tragic choice. Either it acquiesces in Japan's present methodical, piecemeal dismemberment of China or it risks, unprepared, a general war with a fully prepared invader. No middle course appears possible. For the Japanese High Command no longer disguises its purpose.
A crowd of white men rode into Statesville in thirty automobiles early today, surrounded the county jail and demanded that Sheriff John Moore turn over a Negro prisoner.
The Board of Tax Appeals determined today that Ellen C. duPont Meeds of Wilmington, Del., was $1,902 deficient in 1933 income taxes. The Bureau of Internal Revenue had assessed her $4,644.

Figures showing general world tendency to increase available currency, which is very strong if bank deposits are included in the composition of money, appear in the League of Nations Year Book, "Money Review," out today.
8th Ave, 725, 4-story tenement, 25.1x75; Bank for Savings in the City of New York against M. H. Harris, Inc; due, $108,066; taxes, etc, $100; to plaintiff for $50,000.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Walker entertained at dinner at the Gideon Putnam yesterday for WPA Administrator Harry L. Hopkins and Mrs. Hopkins, Mr. and Mrs. William F. Stafford, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Shaw and Mr. and Mrs. Martin C. Sweeny.
The State of Ohio is preparing to grant reciprocal exemption of public utilities taxes to New York truck owners, Charles A. Harnett, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, announced today.

Fire that caused an estimated damage of $150,000 broke out in the machine shop of Fyfe's Shipyard on Hempstead Harbor before noon today. Five Fire Departments, from Glenwood, Glenhead, Glen Cove, Sea Cliff and Roslyn,

THE newspaper correspondents in the field have written the most memorable pages on what this war has meant to Spain. There have been many informed and authoritative books about it: and some good ones. But you know that nothing you have read in a book has equaled the day-by-day dispatches Herbert L. Matthews sends from Madrid.

Making her first appearance in a Summer theatre, Anna May Wong took the leading role tonight in "Princess Turandot" at the Westchester Playhouse here. A capacity audience was present. The play, by John Gerard and Lawrence Langner, is based on the eighteenth century comedy by Carlo Gozzi.

The entrance of R. H. Macy Co., and leading rayon producers into the field of motion pictures was disclosed yesterday when Paul M. Hollister, Macy advertising manager, and Walter Wanger Productions, announced the opening at Radio City Music Hall on Aug. 19 of the all-Technicolor feature production, "Vogues of 1938" by Sam and Bella Spewack.

The Bourse was slightly more active today with domestic industrial securities well traded in. The fact that London's Stock Exchange was closed for the bank holiday deprived the floor here of arbitrage transactions, and this was considered one of the factors contributing to improved business.
Operators and investors in housing properties in Manhattan and the Bronx furnished the major share of the activity in real estate reported yesterday.
The Angriff, which customarily says things a higher authority thinks but avoids openly expressing, appears today

Tribute will be paid to the manager of the Giants on Aug. 28, which will be set aside at the Polo Grounds as "William H. Terry Day." A group of faithful followers of the New York National League club has arranged the celebration under the direction of Mrs. Dorothy K. Earle, chairman and treasurer of the organizing committee.

" San Quentin," Warners' newest contribution to the virile cinema, is this morning's arrival at the Strand. Featuring Pat O'Brien, Humphrey Bogart and Ann Sheridan and directed by Lloyd Bacon, the film has the California penal institution for its scene.

S. Garton Churchill of Great Neck, L. I., and Mrs. Dorothy D.
