Roberts, Mrs. John Gardner and Travers Le Gros of Brooklyn led the field at the close of the first session of the national mixed-team-of-four contract bridge championship played here today as the opening event of the annual week-long Summer championships of the American Bridge League.
Resignation of Cully A. Cobb, who since 1934 has been in charge of the Administration's agricultural adjustment and soil conservation programs for cotton, was announced by that agency today.

The Committee for Industrial Organization took its first step to organize the 500,000 employes in the national communications field yesterday when the American Radio Telegraphists Association' opened its third annual convention at the Hotel Edison.
Eighteen men and one woman were arrested today as police dispersed about fifty American Newspaper Guild strikers at The Seattle Star entrance. Each was released on $25 bail for hearings tomorrow.

Announcement over the week-end of an increase in Ford car prices focused attention of the advertising field on motor budgets on the 1938 models, as it now becomes apparent that other makers will probably follow suit.

Hearings on charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the registration statement covering 225,000 new shares of Austin Silver Mining Company common stock had contained false and misleading statements, and that the shares had been manipulated, began yesterday before John F. Davidson, trial examiner, at 120 Broadway.

Decision on the naming of a trustee for the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, a $4,000,000 utility holding company here, was put over today until Thursday by Federal Judge William H. Holly, after lawyers representing conflicting interests had opposed and urged such an appointment.

Senate fears that President Roosevelt might wait until the end of the present session and then make a recess appointment to fill the Supreme Court vacancy created by retirement of Justice Van Devanter broke into the open with a tempest of debate in that body today.

The finding of J. Rhodes O'Reilly, special master, that there was nothing improper about a referendum in which 54 per cent of the stockholders of the Cities Service Company voted to accept a settlement of $1,250,000 offered by Henry L. Doherty, executive head,
Fire broke out today in the room where a Federal board of 'nquiry was hearing testimony on the blake which destroyed the. bay steamer City of Baltimore Thursday evening with the loss of three lives.
Completing their strong finish. the Czechoslovaks took the final event in the international aviation meeting today from their only rival--Germany.

Sale of the fifteen-acre estate with large farmhouse-type dwelling known as Peacedale, Bernardsville, to Raymond E. Hartz, vice president of the Estate Planning Corporation of this city, featured the deals in New Jersey reported yesterday.
Colby College will seek a million dollars from Maine citizens and Summer residents for its new Mayflower Hill campus, President Franklin W. Johnson announced today.

Henri Morin de Linclays, resident general manager of the French Line for the United States and Canada, has been designated an Officer of the Legion of Honor by the Department of Foreign Affairs, according to an announcement yesterday by Marcel Olivier, board chairman of the French Line in Paris.

Removal of members and officers of the National Labor Relations Board for allegedly "supporting and upholding the Committee for Industrial 'Organization" was demanded tonight on the floor of the Massachusetts Federation of Labor's convention.

The Misses Stokes and Szechenyi are among the junior members of society who have been active during the Summer at Newport. Miss Stoke' is a daughter of Mrs. Henry Drummond-Wolff of New York and England, who with Mr. DrummondWolff and her daughters, is occupying Oak Haven, Newport.

Employes of the East Side Omnibus Corporation and the Comprehensive Omnibus Corporation, voting yesterday on union representation, voted 220 to 78 in favor of the Omnibus Employes Welfare Association.

" On Your Toes," by Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart, the sixth in the season's schedule of Shubert productions of operettas and musical comedies, was presented here tonight on the marine stage by Fortune Gallo, director of the San Carlo Opera Company, before an enthusiastic audience of 8,000.

Starting the day's festivities with a parade on Surf Avenue, more than 1,000 uniformed Boy Scouts invaded Steeplechase Park, Coney Island, yesterday for the ninth annual outing of their Brooklyn council.

Stephen Thomas Mason Jr., the biggest surprise winner of the 1937 Big Ten outdoor track championships and captain-elect of the University of Michigan's 1938 team, died today at the home of his parents in Grosse Pointe of pneumonia after an illness of three weeks. He was 21 years old.

Mrs. Henry Prentiss Forbes, widow of Dr. Henry P. Forbes, who was dean of the Theological School of St. Lawrence University, Canton, N. Y., died here yesterday at the age of 86. Funeral services and burial will take place in Canton. Mrs. Forbes was born in Vernon,

Major Gen. Stanley D. Embick, Deputy Chief of Staff of the United States Army, laid a wreath on the German war memorial on Unter den Linden today. He was accompanied by the United States military attache and his staff.
The first of the monthly index numbers of commodity prices, cornpiled by Dun-Bradstreet, shows an average decline of 4 1/4 per cent from July 1, to the lowest figure reached this year.

Ranger, apparently white queen of the seas and an American queen at that, today won her second straight of the America's Cup races, and in doing so administered to the challenger, Endeavour II, the worst defeat over a triangular course of thirty miles in the long history of the prized trophy.

John McD. Murray, president of the New York Produce Exchange announced yesterday that trading in linseed oil futures would star on Exchange on Sept. 1. The contract calls for 60,000 pounds of bull linseed oil.

Headed by Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan of Boston and Miss Jadwiga Jedrzejowska, champion of Poland, the annual women's invitation tennis tournament started today on the turf courts of the Maidstone Club.
The grain markets on the Board of Trade here continued on the downgrade today, with favorable crop reports and hedging pressure the dominating influence.
The Commercial Investment Trust Corporation and subsidiaries report a combined net income of $11,573,865 for the first half of 1937, compared with $9,757,387 for the 1936 period.
The "strip-tease" charge stayed under cover as National Labor Relations Board examiners opened hearings today on charges that the Clover Fork Coal Company of near-by Kitts violated the Wagner act.
By applying copper sulphate, New Jersey has killed about 500,000 elm trees in the last ten months in an effort to eradicate the Dutch elm disease.
Middlesex defeated Sussex by an innings and 351 runs in the only first class county cricket match concluded today. The scores:
The Aurora Borealis, leaving only the low southern sky unvisited, flashed brilliantly during several hours this morning over the gorge and the outlet of the Niagara River.

The Canadian Government will this week consider whether the regulations approved by the Cabinet last week, to prevent enlistment in the contending forces in Spain and to check the movement of munitions to that country, are to be extended to the Sino-Japanese struggle.

Lou Camps, Bronx lightweight, with victories over Joe Archibald, Johnny DeFoe and Johnny Horstmann, will see action against Willie Davis in the principal bout of eight rounds at the Queensbor?? Arena tonight. Each of the boxers seeks a match with Henry Armstrong.

Strikes starting throughout Quebec Province today left in idleness nearly 10,000 men and women and closed nine big plants which union organizers said were makers of 70 per cent of Canada's basic textile products.
The opening of the Cowes regatta, Great Britain's premier yachting event, was overshadowed today by Endeavour's second defeat in the America's Cup series.

Columbia University's celebrated baseball course, in which Joe McCarthy, Bill Terry, Lou Gehrig and other baseball luminaries will assume professional mantles and teach the fine points of the game to Columbia students for three weeks, began yesterday.

Following a conference with John L. Lewis here today, Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, announced that his organization was now able to guarantee definitely observance of contracts with manufacturers and able and willing to discipline its membership, in the event of any failure to carry out union agreements.

Miss Frances Waring Lefferts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Raymond Lefferts of 45 East Eightysecond Street and Setauket, L. I., has completed plans for her marriage to John McCormick, son of Mrs. Edward McCormick of Brooklyn and the late Mr. McCormick, which will take place on Sent. 6.
Grand Circuit racing returned to Western Massachusetts today for the first time in forty-four years, and for the first time with parimutuel wagering, as a six-day meeting opened at Agawam Park.

Extension of the undeclared war between Japan and the Chinese to the region northwest of Peiping on the highway to Mongolia was indicated today by Japanese reports that Chinese troops were massing at Kalgan, Chahar Province, and Chinese reports that Japanese planes had bombed Nankow Pass.

John Joseph Hughes Jr., 26 years old, of New York, who killed an 33-year-old German, a total stranger, in the streets of Berlin on last Feb. 27 and was declared insane by a State alienist, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen as a deportee, in charge of two attendants from a hospital at Bremerhaven.

The undeclared Japanese-Chinese war was interjected in the conference of the World Federation of Educational Associations as it opened its formal sessions today despite the efforts of foreign delegates to maintain an atmosphere of impartiality.
BERLOWITZ--Lena. Services Park West Memorial Chapel, 79th St. and Columbus Ave., Wednesday, 11 A. M. BIENENZUCHT--Adolph, beloved brother of Sarah, Abraham and Ray. Funeral private.

Miss Frances Waring Lefferts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Raymond Lefferts of 45 East Eightysecond Street and Setauket, L. I., has completed plans for her marriage to John McCormick, son of Mrs. Edward McCormick of Brooklyn and the late Mr. McCormick, which will take place on Sent. 6.
Grand Circuit racing returned to Western Massachusetts today for the first time in forty-four years, and for the first time with parimutuel wagering, as a six-day meeting opened at Agawam Park.

Following a conference with John L. Lewis here today, Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, announced that his organization was now able to guarantee definitely observance of contracts with manufacturers and able and willing to discipline its membership, in the event of any failure to carry out union agreements.

Extension of the undeclared war between Japan and the Chinese to the region northwest of Peiping on the highway to Mongolia was indicated today by Japanese reports that Chinese troops were massing at Kalgan, Chahar Province, and Chinese reports that Japanese planes had bombed Nankow Pass.

John Joseph Hughes Jr., 26 years old, of New York, who killed an 33-year-old German, a total stranger, in the streets of Berlin on last Feb. 27 and was declared insane by a State alienist, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen as a deportee, in charge of two attendants from a hospital at Bremerhaven.

A new industrial relations department has been established by J. T. Trenholm Co., insurance advisers, under the direction of Gustav R. Stahl, who has been an associate editor of Barron's Financial Weekly.

Governor Blanton Winship, returning from New York and Washington today, announced a determination for Puerto Rico to realize its $100,000,000 annual tourist possibilities. He asserted the island's attractions were worth more yearly than its dominant sugar industry.

Salzburg's "Don Giovanni" has had its ups and downs, but for all of that it remains one of the festival's proudest achievements. If there are features of the production to which exception may be taken, if the casts sometimes vary widely in merit, nevertheless, Bruno Walter's treatment of the masterpiece probably is without its equal in the contemporary lyric theatre.
Stockholders of the Dewey Almy Chemical Company will vote on Aug. 13 on a plan for simplification of the capital structure, it was announced yesterday.

Locking himself in the record room of the East. River Savings Bank branch at 295 Broadway, corner of Reade Street. William F. Rumph Jr., assistant secretary of the bank, shot and killed himself at 11:03 A. M. yesterday.

The United States probably will export more than 600,000 automobiles and trucks during 1937, Alfred Reeves, vice president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, said yesterday afternoon upon his return from Europe.

Two great French influences on current fashion and decorative trends are Christien Berard and the Paris Exposition, according to Joseph B. Platt, director of the bureau of style and design, Marshall Field Co., manufacturing division, who returned yesterday on the Normandie.

Members of the Actors Equity Association who disobeyed instructions from their organization not to participate in a one-day stoppage, May 27, on the Federal Theatre Project will have to answer to the Equity Council next Tuesday. Thirty-eight actors, it is said, are involved.

President Roosevelt opposes Congressional acceptance of the New England Flood Control compact unless Congress reserves to the Federal Government all power rights arising from any reservoirs or dams built at government expense.

A certain amount of anxiety is felt here over two unauthorized appearances of German warships in Norwegian waters in the past ten days. Conern is also shown over a sudden unexplained interest of both the German and the Russian Governments in maps of the Norwegian coast.
State Auditor Walter R. Darby disclosed today in a report covering the first six months of the current year a continuing improvement in the municipal financial situation in New Jersey.

The State Mortgage Commission issued a statement yesterday in which it characterized as "unfair and unjustified" the remarks of Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn last Friday when he criticized the commission for objecting to a reorganization plan for the Nassau-Suffolk Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company under Section 77B of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Four new linemen have been added to the roster of the New York Football Giants and will report to Coach Steve Owen when pre-season training opens at the Blue Hill Coutry Club in Orangeburg, N. Y., on Aug, 16, it was annuonced yesterday by John V. Mara, president of the local eleven.

In its first decision approving reorganization of a Class I railroad under the terms of Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act, the Bureau of Finance of the Interstate Commerce Commission recommended today that the Western Pacific Railroad Company proceed with a proposed plan that will have to be approved by the commission and court before being put into effect.

Life would still be possible if the American lobster became extinct, but for persons with competent digestions and sound gastronomic impulses it would be perceptibly less pleasant.Cold boiled, with mayonnaise; hot broiled with butter; mingled in salad with the kindly caper;

The Board of Tax Appeals absolved today twenty-two transferees of the Barnsdall Corporation Class A stock and Warrant Syndicate, New York, of 1928 income tax liabilities aggregating $5,081,487 assessed by the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

Clinton L. Bardo, former general manager of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, and shipbuilding executive who was an outspoken opponent of the New Deal while president of the National Association of Manufacturers in 1934 and 1935, died shortly after noon yesterday in the Bronx Hospital, 1,276 Fulton Avenue, at the age of 69.

Word was received here today of the death yesterday in Paris of George Pick, president of the investment banking firm of that name and a La Salle Street financier. His age was 68. With his wife and a son, Grant, he had been in Europe for the last year.

Robert Lovett Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Taylor of Oak Hill Farm, this place, and Miss Else Zorn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Zorn of Tompkinsville, S. I., were married yesterday afternoon at the bride's home.

Bob Kunhardt of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, Greenwich, piloting Rumour, crossed the finish line first in a fleet of seven yachts at the Indian Harbor Club today, to win top rating in the first day of the club's annual junior regatta.

Working frantically with ropes, sledge-hammers and pickaxes after two young girls had fallen five floors from the roof of a tenement into a narrow shaft at 1,413 York Avenue, police and firemen succeeded in freeing the victims yesterday after efforts that included

An emphatic denial that Harvard University had any connection with a fiesta held here tonight for the benefit of the Spanish Loyalists was made today by Jerome D. Greene, secretary to the Harvard Corporation.

The report of the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois and subsidiaries for the twelve months to June 30 shows a net income, after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, of $4,561,969.
Rudolf Friml's operetta, "The Firefly," the second offering of the Summer season at the Municipal Stadium, Randalls Island, will begin a week's run tonight, closing Sunday evening.

The Berlin branch of H. A. Brassert Co., received the contract awarded by the German Government to build and put into operation three complete new iron and steel works. These works will be located on the native ore deposits. One plant will be located in North Germany near Brunswick, one in Bavaria and one in Baden. These plants are being built in accordance with the Government's program to increase the use of native resources.
As Japan's war preparations went steadily forward, it became known today that the nation's adverse trade balance on July 31 had reached the unprecedented amount of 720,000,000 yen.

The Senate put in four hours of debate today on the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill, and prepared to consider tomorrow three amendments by Senator Walsh which he proposed after a conference with President Roosevelt.

A drive to find employment in private industry for every employable ex-service man now on the WPA Federal Theatre rolls has been launched by the War Veterans of the Federal Theatre, an organization of more than 300 veterans employed on the project, it was announced yesterday.

The Yankees will meet the Chicago White Sox, their outstanding American League pennant rival, in a double-header at the Stadium today, and the occasion will serve to open a new chapter in an unparalleled player record.

Establishment of a new price line of fur-trimmed coats at $9.75 to replace the $8.75 range, which will be discontinued, was determined upon at a meeting of eighteen manufacturers representing the bulk of production of the former $8.75 line at the offices of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board yesterday afternoon.

Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey marked up another victory yesterday in his warfare on industrial rackets in New York City, as three officials of Local 167 of the Chicken Drivers Union pleaded guilty to embezzlement of union funds.

Alfred H. Schoellkopf, president of the Niagara Hudson Power Corportion, was elected yesterday chairman of the board of the new Niagara Hudson Public Service Corporation. The corporation was formed last week upon consolidation of twelve operating utility units of Niagara Hudson Power.

The Berlin branch of H. A. Brassert Co., received the contract awarded by the German Government to build and put into operation three complete new iron and steel works. These works will be located on the native ore deposits. One plant will be located in North Germany near Brunswick, one in Bavaria and one in Baden. These plants are being built in accordance with the Government's program to increase the use of native resources.
As Japan's war preparations went steadily forward, it became known today that the nation's adverse trade balance on July 31 had reached the unprecedented amount of 720,000,000 yen.

The Senate put in four hours of debate today on the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill, and prepared to consider tomorrow three amendments by Senator Walsh which he proposed after a conference with President Roosevelt.

Prices of bonds reflected a somewhat better undertone yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, despite the dullness of the session. In a total turnover of $4,629,300, compared with $5,861,900 on last Friday, most of the representative groups scored modest advances. Exceptions were certain of the secondary railroad loans and United States Government obligations.

Alfred H. Schoellkopf, president of the Niagara Hudson Power Corportion, was elected yesterday chairman of the board of the new Niagara Hudson Public Service Corporation. The corporation was formed last week upon consolidation of twelve operating utility units of Niagara Hudson Power.

Ross (Sandy) Somerville, Canadian amateur golf champion, said tonight he would compete in the United States amateur tournament in Portland, Ore., this month. Somerville captured the Canadian title last week at Ottawa for the sixth time.

Something of a social sensation was created at the Royal Yacht Squadron's regatta today when a woman wearing bright blue linen trousers strolled across the club lawn. Spectators, among whom was Queen Victoria's daughter, Princess Beatrice, stared astonished at the unconventional attire.
German currency circulation climbed to a record height since the post-war inflation when it reached 7,106,000,000 marks on July 31, according to a Reichsbank statement issued today.

Magistrate August Dreyer, sitting in Felony Court yesterday, discharged William Carvill, 18 years old, who said he had no home. He was charged with burglary in consection with the theft of $2 worth of food and soda water from a restaurant where he was formerly employed.
The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today requests by the General Motors Corporation and E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. for confidential treatment of their 1936 bonus lists.

The League of Nations Mandates Commission, after but the first few days of hearings on the scheme for the partition of Palestine, has already shown its independence and its intention to make a thorough study before drafting recommendations to the Council. Refusing to be hurried,

Park Ave, 911, 14-story apartment, 102.2x 147.6; Brooklyn Trust Co, trustee, against 911 Park Ave. Corp: due, $2,029,202; taxes, etc. $9.340: to plaintiff for $1,000. Houston St. 269-71 E. 6-story tenement, 37:4x61.1 irregular; Mortgage Commission of the State of New York against Jolen Holding Corp: due, $41,212; taxes, etc, $1,830; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Staging a Garrison finish, the team of Phil Abramsohn, Mrs. Ann Naiman, Morrie Elis and Mrs. Estelle Drescher of New York won the national mixed team-of-four championship of the American Bridge League as the first event of its annual Summer championship was completed here today.

Captain Alfred M. Moore and Theodore Christensen, respectively master and chief officer of the United States liner American Banker, received awards of the Lifesaving Benevolent Association of New York yesterday afternoon for their work in directing the rescue of the captain and crew of the foundering British schooner Mabel A. Frye in a gale off Newfoundland last October.
Making amends for a failure in his only previous appearance in Chicago this season, Mose Goldblatt's Dnieper raced' to victory today in the Winnetka Handicap, one-mile featureevent at Lincoln Pields.

Manhattan 48th St, 18-20 W, 49x90.5; for 2-story offices and stores; Tonto Realty Corp., 22 W 48th St, owner; B. Robert Swartburg and William F. Bennett Jr., architects; cost, $35,000. Alterations 93d St 60 E; to 5-story private residence; Byron C. Foy. 405 Lexington Ave, owner: John R. Pope, architect; cost, $3,000.
Police recovered from the Potomac River today the body of Michael L. Eidsness Jr., widely known philatelist.

Earle Brucker's homer into the left field stands in the fifth inning gave the Athletics a 2-to-1 victory over Detroit today. Three Philadelphia hurlers outpitched the veteran Tommy Bridges. Herman Fink, who hurled the fourth, fifth and sixth innings, received credit for the triumph.
A youthful New Jersey girl whose progress up golf's ladder has been remarkable, walked off with honors in the seventh oneday tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association today.

Boston police, following the lead taken by the authorities of Salem and Brookline, raided the South End Mothers' Health Office and visited the State headquarters of the Birth Control League of Massachusetts, 3 Joy Street, late this afternoon, taking a quantity of literature in both places.

A State-backed program, which Governor William Langer said was intended to prevent "grain gamblers from robbing" North Dakota growers of "millions of dollars" in selling their wheat, became effective today.
Senator McKellar told the Senate today that there was no hope for legislation to carry out the President's request that first, second, and third class postmasters be put under civil service.
At the request of Secretary of State Hull, the House Foreign Affairs Committee reported favorably today a bill to prevent picketing of foreign embassies and legations in the District of Columbia.

Women's ready-to-wear clothes valued at $1,000,000, including 150 lines from more than 100 manufacturers, will be offered tomorrow and Thursday at the second annual Boston "Market Week" in the Hotel Statler, under the sponsorship of the Boston Wholesale Garment Association.

Stanley A. Martin Jr., held without bail on a murder charge, and his wife, Mrs. Evelyn Martin of 1,228 Clay Avenue, the Bronx, from whom he had been estranged since Sept. 25, 1936, were reconciled yesterday in the Long Island City jail.

A solid schedule of play in the second day of the national junior and boys' tennis championships at the Culver Military Academy today found the junior singles stars perched in the third round and the boys' singles aces in the fourth.

Copies of telegrams sent from the offices of Klopstock Co. for the account of the Austin Silver Mining Company between Jan.'l, 1936, and April 1, 1937, were ordered subpoenaed yesterday as the hearings on charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission against the Austin company were continued here.

Much interest has been occasioned in England by the repeated surpassing of all precedent in the Bank of England's note circulation. The last weekly statement reported it at [Pound]498,000,000, and the London prediction is that it will pass [Pound]500,000,000 before the "holiday demand" is ended.

Stanley Howe, secretary to Mayor La Guardia, conferred at City Hall yesterday afternoon with a group of prominent citizens on preliminary plans for observing Constitution Day in this city on Sept. 17. Arrangements were made to form a committee to direct the city-wide observance.

Clement Moore, senior partner in the New York cotton brokerage firm of Robert Moore Co., 44 Beaver Street, died here today at his residence of pneumonia. He was born in Cincinnati eighty years ago, a son of Robert Moore, who established the firm at Cincinnati in 1846 and moved to New York in 1868.

Alliance Investment CorporationJune 30: Net assets $2,183,849, equal to $220.03 a share on the preferred stock and to $5.64 a common share before provision for taxes. On Dec. 31 net assets were $2,541,637, equal to $254.17 a share of preferred and to $7 a share of common stock.
Mr. and Mrs. William Wade Vert of this place have announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of their daughter, Miss Gertrude Mary Vert,

The national assembly of the Liberal party dissolved quietly today following Colonel Fulgencio Batista's stern rebuke yesterday of control of the party by political leaders and officials of the Machado regime.
Senate investigators asked a Chesapeake Ohio Railway attorney today for proof that $15,000,000 worth of preference stock recently issued by the line was not "wholly illegal."

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company estimated yesterday that its consol dated net income for the six months to June 30 was $32,000,000 after depreciation, depletion, interest and Federal income taxes, but before providing for the surtax on undistribute profits. These earnings, which include the company's equity in undistributed income

The wedding of Miss Marjorie Vail, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Vail of Greenwich, to William Frederick Timmins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Timmins, also of Greenwich, will take place Aug. 31 in the First Congregational Church, Old Greenwich. The Rev. Alden S.

Exemption from the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 of certain securities to be issued and sold by the International Paper and Power Company in connection with a change in capitalization was granted by the Securities and Exchange Commission today. As described by the commission, the exemption will apply to:

Luncheon meeting, Kiwanis Club, Hotel McAlpin, 12:30 P. M. "The Constitution," Major John Vernou Bouvier. Luncheon forum, Progressive City Committee, at Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street, 12:30 P. M. "Politics on Parade," Maurice P. Davidson.

Two mortgages held by the Bowery Savings Bank from the Bridges Creek Realty Corp, Sylvia Gelman, president, have been consolidated as a single lien for $48,300 on 142-44 Henry St and 20 Rutgers St and extended to July 1, 1942, 4 1/2 per cent, $115.75 to be paid off quarterly during the .ast two years.

President Roosevelt has made tentative plans to go to Hyde Park, N. Y., to spend next week-end at his mother's house there, he said today. Mr. Roosevelt emphasized that his going was conditioned on the Far Eastern situation and also on what happened. in Congress during the next few days.

Miss Dorothy Hodgman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Theodore Hodgman of 57 West Fifty-eighth Street, was married to Norman Randell yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. James's Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street. The Rev. Frederick A.
Miss Moira Archbold, daughter of Mrs. Anne Archbold of Washington, gave the largest party of the season at the Bar Harbor Club this evening.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Helen Hays Ashbrook, daughter of Mrs. Frank Gifford Tallman of Wilmington, Del., and Alexandria, N. Y., and of Donald S. Ashbrook of New York, to J. Taylor Woodward, also of New York, son of Mrs. J. Taylor Woodward of Baltimore.

The Commodore Law Cup was retained by the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today as Robert Kunhardt skippered his craft to two first places and one-third to insure the victory despite the fact that two more races are scheduled to be run off tomorrow.
Tired and suffering from rheumatism, Earl Baldwin of Bewdley, retired Prime Minister, celebrated his seventieth birthday quietly today with a family reunion at Astley Hall, his country mansion here.

Fred J. Hull, sentenced to die in Sing Sing the week of Sept. 6 for the murder of Samuel Drukman in Brooklyn, arrived at the prison today and expressed strong hope of winning another trial and being acquitted. Hull,

The five-story American basement house at 126 East Seventy-ninth Street was leased by the estate of Emma J. Forbes to Mrs. Marie Jarka. Douglas Gibbons Co. were the brokers and Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., represented the owner.

Cuba's oldest newspaper, the morning Diario de la Marina, together with the noon Alerta and the evening Avance, today published plans to divide all profits of the three papers, on a half-and-half basis, between the owners and 600 workers.

The largest audience in the history of the Lewisohn Stadium concerts was present last night when Jascha Heifetz appeared for the second consecutive evening as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under George King Raudenbush. It occupied all the regular seating accommodations, plus thousands of seats specially placed for the occasion. The box office estimate was given out as 18,294.
Thomas Horan, 43 years old, of 358 East Twenty-third Street, was drowned yesterday in the Bronx Park Lake when he fell out of a rowboat. His body was recovered.

Governor Murphy and House and Senate leaders agreed tonight to call the Legislature into session again Thursday in the hope of advancing the administration program which collapsed last week with the Senate's unorthodox walkout. Telegrams will be sent to all legislators immediately, asking them to reconvene.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City assumed the leadership today in the campaign to prevent the Hudson Manhattan Railroad from increasing from six to ten cents its tube train fare between Hudson Terminal in lower Manhattan and Jersey City and Hoboken stations.

Federal officials made public today the names of ninety-eight persons, including a well-known criminal lawyer, a former police chief and five women, indicted on June 9 as members of a bootleg liquor and alcohol conspiracy which allegedly flourished in several Eastern States.

United States and Hungarian chess players came to grips today in the fifth round of the biennial team tournament of the International Chess Federation at the Grand Royal Hotel. Each side scored two points.

The foreign exchange market moved yesterday within narrow limits. The pound sterling rose to 4.98 1/2 duplicating its high for the year, first reached on July 20, but closed at $4.983/8, unchanged from the previous day.

The report of the American Power and Light Company .and subsidiaries for the twelve months to June 30. issued for publication today, shows a net income, after all expenses and charges, of $11.251,309, compared with $9,302,104 in the year to June 30, 1936, an increase of $1,949,205. At the same time gross operating revenues of the system rose to $95.137.379 from $86,298,612.

Elder Ave, 100x100; State Mortgage Commission against 1.171 Elder Ave Co; due. $ 125,883. taxes, etc, $9,587; to plaintiff for $1,000. By GEORGE J. KEARNS Robertson PL, 25x100; Jacob Setina against Leo Kleinert; due $4,471; taxes, etc, $482; to plaintiff for $1,000.

The bodies of two young girls who died Monday night after they had fallen five floors from the roof of the tenement at 1,413 York Avenue and been trapped in a narrow shaft between that building and the one next door, will be buried close to each other tomorrow in St John's Cerietery. Brooklyn.

As a matter of strategy the Republicans, including those in Congress, remained silent while Democrats fought out the first stage in the battle over enlarging the Supreme Court. Now they are free, and led by Senator Vandenberg, they are making good political capital of their freedom.

For the second successive day the pupils of the new baseball class of Teachers College, Columbia University, missed the chance of hearing "big league" baseball figures lecture when Irving (Bump) Hadley, pitcher for the New York Yankees, failed to appear to take the rostrum for yesterday morning's lecture.

Alfred A. Knopf Jr., 19-year-old son of the book publisher, who "hitch-hiked out West" to "make his own way," was located in Salt Lake City yesterday after police alarms reporting him missing had been broadcast.

Objections to an accounting of the $2,917,665 trust fund set up for the benefit of Thomas Franklyn Manville Jr. by his father were disclosed yesterday in Surrogates' Court in a petition by his wife, Marcelle Edwards Manville, who asked Surrogate James A. Delehanty for onehalf of the fund.

You couldn't describe the atmosphere around the British camp today as being overcast with a pall of gloom. Undoubtedly T. O. M. Sopwith and his party on the Philante are not as chipper as they would be if they had two victories under their belts instead of facing the uncomfortable fact that if Endeavour II doesn't win four races before Ranger wins two more the America's Cup will repose in Tiffany's vaults awhile longer.

Exemption of the new securities of the International Paper and Power Corporation by the SEC yesterday had a buoyant effect on the old securities, with the preferred issue 2' points higher and the common stocks strong.

Miss Gracyn Wheeler and Miss Carolin Babcock of California, second and fourth in the seeded list, each dropped a set today as the eight top favorites came through to their allotted brackets in the quarter-finals of the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club.
The all-star boxing show in which Barney Ross, Lou Ambers and Sixto Escobar will defend their titles will be held at the Polo Grounds Sept. 23 instead of Sept. 17, the date originally scheduled.

Madison Square Garden announced last night that it planned to stage a fifteen-round bout on Sept. 30, probably at the Garden Bowl in Long Island City, between John Henry Lewis, the light-heavyweight champion, and Bob Pastor, New York heavyweight, The Assoelated Press reported.

Tied up by two of Eastern Canada's cleverest spin bowlers, Marylebone narrowly escaped defeat today. Playing against the Toronto Cricket Club in the second match of the tour, the Englishmen struggled successfully in a race with the clock and when

53d St, 46 W, 17.6x100.5; trustee will of Wilbur B. Marple to Charles Allen Marple, Watertown, Mass. 74th St, 168-172 E, 90.2x102.2; Joseph F. Condon to Bernard L. Touroff, trustee, 40-20 22d St, Queens; consideration $25,000, foreclosure. Platt St, 4-6, 57.9x53.81/2 trreg; Harry Casper to Charles F. Noyes, 119 E 55th St; mtg $18,000 ($7).

The Rivoli's "You Can't Have Everything," besides being a run-of-the-mill musical show with Alice Faye, Don Ameche and the Ritz Brothers, will go down in history-and we are careful not to say how far down-as the first time a striptease artist has appeared before her public without revealing anything, not even her ability.

The defending champion, Sam Gilpin, of Merion, paced the favorites into the fourth round of the Eastern States men's tennis championship today by beating Ellwood Snyder, former Franklin and Marshall College star from Lancaster, 6-1, 6-1.

180th St (15-4008), s w c Morris Park Ave, 152x100; 31st St Properties, Inc, to Laurbon Realty Corp, 19 W 44th St, mtg $222,300. Pell St (18-5626), n s, 200 w of City Island Ave, 37x95; Giovannina Marino to Adelaide R. Rosenfeld, 167 Reville St. 169th St (10-2612), s s. 219 e of Fulton Ave. 34x104; Jacob Mlodinoff to Simon Borodkin, 1,683 Boston Rd: mtg $11,000.

General Bill Lee muffled Philadelphia bats with three-hit pitching today and joined in a brisk home-run assault on Sylvester Johnson to lead the National League pace-making Cubs to a. 4-to-1 victory in the opening game of the series. The triumph, the Cubs' fourteenth in their last seventeen starts and Lee's twelfth of the season, required only 1 hour 27 minutes.

Miss Rose Marie de F. Edmunds, daughter of Mrs. Gustave A. Heckscher of Islesbrook, Strafford, has completed plans for her marriage on Sept. 25 to Burnham Grosvenor Chapman, son of Mrs. George McMurtrie Godley of Long House, Greenwich, Conn.
A client of Robert Smith, attorney, has sold the four-story apartment house at 8 Longview Avenue, White Plains, Westchester, to David S. Meister.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission, despite an adverse ruling by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., plans to hold a qualifying examination for proportional representation canvassers, Commissioner Paul J. Kern said yesterday.

Detroit became the seat of the seventeenth Catholic Archdiocese in the United States and the Most Rev. Edward Mooney was enthroned as Michigan's first Archbishop today with the pomp and solemn pageantry of the Catholic Church.

Driving in all their runs with homers, the last a blow by Bill Dickey with the bases full that won the second game, the Yankees yesterday tossed the White Sox seven games off the American League pace by taking a double-header.

The construction of parallel spur lines through meadowland here by the Central Railroad of New Jersey and the Pennsylvania Railroad continued at a faster pace today, with the reason for the activity on the part of both lines still undisclosed.

All was quiet on the Red Mill front here this morning as 1,000 guardsmen of the Tenth Infantry, stationed at Camp Smith, refrained deferentially from firing blank cartridges in their dawn manoeuvres five miles east of the camp so the sleep of the Red Mill residents might be undisturbed.

Erla, brown mare owned by W. N. Reynolds of Winston-Salem, N. C., and driven by Will Caton, captured the feature race, the Single G Handicap Stake for pacers, at Agawam Park today, the second day of the Grand Circuit meeting here.

An extensive national advertising campaign in newspapers and magazines will be launched by Pinaud, Inc:, for a new liquid to be applied to the face before shaving with electric razors. The preparation, called "Set-Up" and retailing at $1 a bottle, is claimed to make the hairs on the face stand up better, thus facilitating shaving.

The naval situation is still vastly embarrassing in this area and is spoken of only in low tones up side streets. Everybody feels very sad, indeed. Mr. Thomas Octave Murdoch Sopwith and his more or less silent partner, Mr. Frederick Sigrist, have taken a lot of trouble and spent a lot of time and money

The annual sales of yearlings began tonight before a large crowd which was only sparsely sprinkled with bidders who saw thirty-nine head pass under the hammer for a total of $38,925, an average of about $998.

The Senate dragged through another day of debate today on the WagnerSteagall Housing Bill. Senator Barkley, the majority leader, engineered an agreement limiting debate, by which the measure was brought to within comparatively easy striking distance of a final vote.

We are informed by the watchers of the skies that while on any clear, dark night during the latter half of the year, and especially after midnight, a dozen or more meteors may be seen hourly, but that one week from tonight one or more a minute will probably be seen, again assuming that the night is clear and dark. As to meteors in general,

TIENTSIN-Japanese armies drove south from Tientsin and Peiping toward the advancing Chinese armies. Planes made wide flights over the military centers of the Chinese. More reinforcements came from Manchukuo. Page 1.

The "strip tease" charge passed out of the picture today while Irvine G. McCann, presiding over the National Labor Relations Board, heard charges that the Clover Fork Coal Company violated the Wagner act, voiced flat disbelief of the testimony of Ben F. Unthank.

Johnny Stone's single with the bases loaded broke up a twelve-inning pitching battle between Wesley Ferrell and Elon Hogsett today and brought Washington a 3-to-2 triumph over the Browns. The Senators scored a run in the third on Ferrell's double and an infield out, and the Browns tied the count in the fifth on West's single and Vosmik's triple.

Governor Francis P. Murphy of New Hampshire, representatives of the British War Veterans Association and several directors of the Melville Shoe Corporation were among 1,200 persons who attended a funeral service yesterday morning for Captain Robert Patrick French. Darby MacGrath at St. Agnes's Roman Catholic Church, Forty-third Street near Third Avenue.

Japanese spinning stocks dropped another 5 yen today and rayons fell about 3 yen. [The yen is quoted at about 29 cents.] Financial quarters attributed the declines to the undeclared war in North China and the consequent loss of Chinese markets.

The marriage of Miss Clarinda Rosemary Moser, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Oran A. Moser of Rocky HIill, and Dr. Daniel Miner Rogers took place Monday afternoon in the Rocky Hill Congregational Church. Dr. Rogers is the son of Dr. and Mrs. William L. Nute, missionaries in Turkey, and the grandson of Mrs. Daniel O. Rogers of Sunnyledge, New Britain.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry F. Guggenheim have as their house guests former Senator Frederic Collin Walcott of Norfolk, Conn.; Dr. and Mrs. E. Terry Smith of Hartford and Mrs. Philip C. Jessup of New York. They entertained at a dinner for them last night at Arrowhead Inn.

North Carolina and Princeton will merge their tennis forces for the first time to face the Oxford-Cambridge team next week on the turf courts of the Point Judith Country Club at Narragansett, R. I., it was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell. '21,
Sixty inmates of the Hoerdt Asylum for the criminally insane, near here, overpowering four guards in a bid for liberty, proceeded to set the buildings afire today.

A contra-seasonal increase in steel ingot production last week sent the adjusted index, forward to 126.8, its highest point since the week ended Sept. 9, 1929. It was 128.2 for the previous week and 111.7 for the week ended Aug. 1, 1936.

First-string members of the San Jose polo squad from Argentina, who are here for the national open championship tourney next month, practiced as a unit for the first time on Long Island turf today and outscored a White side, 9 to 3, at Mitchel Field.

One of the largest dinners was given here tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Augustine L. Humes, who are guests at the Muenchinger-King. They entertained at the Clambake Club. There were a number of luncheon parties today.

In eight slashing rounds Lou Camps of the Bronx won a decision over Willie Davis of Mexico in the main bout at the Queensboro Arena last night. A crowd of 6,000 saw the fight. Camp weighed 132 and Davis 132 1/2.

The Justice Ministry announced today that the Rev. Martin Niemoeller would be tried Aug. 10, 12 and 16. The announcement says: "From the number of trial days it may be assumed the Niemoeller case will receive a thorough examination."

Frederick Larkin, inspection engineer with the public buildings branch of the procurement division of the Treasury Department, Was today appointed chief of the foreign service buildings office of the State Department, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation several weeks ago of Keith Merrill.

Miss Elise W. Woodward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Graham Cox Woodward of this city, will be married to Anthony Cuthbert Hopkins of Haddonfield, N. J., on Aug. 11 in the Church of St. Luke and the Epiphany.

With packs on their backs, scores of persons have been passing through here for several days, headed for the summit of Mount Marcy, where on Thursday at noon there will be a celebration of the first recorded ascent by white men 100 years ago.

James H. Price of Richmond, Lieutenant Governor and prominent Shriner, today won the Democratic nomination for Governor by a landslide vote in a State-wide primary. Returns from 1,238 precincts gave Mr. Price 96,832 votes to 11,130 for State Senator Vivian Page of Norfolk.

Addressing thirty-one rookie policemen who had gathered in Bronx Magistrate's Court to acquire a working knowledge of court procedure, Magistrate Edgar Bromberger yesterday advised them to study law and to "be honest and straightforward."

The Long Island Golf Association had another of its one-day amateur tournaments today over Bethpage State Park's tricky Black course, with public links golfers comprising most of the field and walking off with virtually all of the honors.
Dr. Louis Dapples, international banker and president of the worldwide Nestle chocolate concerns, died on Saturday in Genoa, Italy, according to word received here yesterday. He was 69 years old.

Mrs. Herbert Thorn King, who returned on the Aquitania, has joined Mr. King at the Pierre, where they will be before going to Tuxedo Park. Mrs. J. Joseph Alexandre of the Westbury has gone to Edgartown, Mass., for the rest of the Summer.

R. P. Mills Co., Ltd., which deals in mining securities, was charged today before Judge Jules Desmarais with two infractions of the Securities Act of Quebec. Counsel for the firm appeared at arraignment, and trial was set for Aug. 18 in Summary Conviction Court.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union' petitioned the Common Pleas Court today to force an employer to move his factory back to this city from Johnstown, to which it was transferred on July 4.

Expectations of an early Supreme Court nomination to fill the vacancy created by the retirement of Justice Van Devanter were raised today by a remark of President Roosevelt which indicated that he might not take advantage of his constitutional prerogative of making a recess appointment.
Richmond Theatre opened its new season last night with a farce comedy, "The Fight's On," the work of three American authors, Hagar Wilde, Ernest V. Heyn and Elliott Nugent.
Twenty gasoline tank cars exploded today in the heart of the Sinclair Refining Company storage plant at East Chicago. Eight men were burned or injured in the explosions and the fire that followed.

Two Oriental Girl Guides, Ruth Sumi Sakurai of Tokyo, Japan, and Chang Hseuh Min of Peiping, China, were guests of honor tonight at an old-fashioned. American outdoor picnic at Sagamore Hill, home of Mrs. Edith Kermit Roosevelt and the late President Theodore Roosevelt.

Estimates on the 1937 grain crops made by statisticians here and given to the trade today were about in line with expectations showing a W.inter wheat crop of 648,000,000 bushels and a Spring wheat yield of 193,000,000 bushels, an aggregate of 840,000,000 bushels, or 44,000,000 less than was suggested by the Government on July 1.
The Treasury Department wound up the first month of the new fiscal year with a deficit of $249,384,405.92, or more than twice the deficit at the close of business on July 31, 1936.

Two American women, victims of one of the largest jewel thefts in Paris in many years, tonight posted an offer of 250,000 francs as a reward for information leading to the recovery of their stolen gems.

Along the far-flung waterfront: Mr. and Mrs. William A. Thomson of this city have just returned from Fredericton, N. B., and are telling any one who will listen about their seven-day sea jaunt at the camp of Fred W. Fairley just above Boiestown.

Rentals of apartments for Fall occupancy are maintaining a brisk pace, reports from brokers regarding properties In scattered parts of the- city revealed yesterday. The east side of the midtown section led in the number of contracts for residential space reported.
This city, so military and maritime, even calls its "Y" building the Army and Navy Y. M. C. A. Uniforms are everywhere, and it takes praotice to distinguish them.

Some three-quarters of a century ago a little girl was helping to tend sheep on her father's ranch on the rolling hills, very green after the Winter rains, golden brown during the dry season, near the shores of the Pacific Ocean and not far from the old Pueblo de la Reina de los Angeles. At the age of 2,

The big tuna made their first appearance in numbers off the New Jersey coast this afternoon, when Mrs. Eugenie Marron of Ridgewood, N. J., brought a 309-pounder to gaff after a battle of nearly five hours.

Judge Charles Harwood, newly appointed district judge of the Canal Zone, left today by Pan American airplane for Miami and New York. Judge Harwood had breakfast here. He expected to dine in Miami today and he hopes to have breakfast at his home in Rye, N. Y., tomorrow.

Elmer Layden of Notre Dame went into first place today in the poll to select a head coach to direct the College All-Stars against the Green Bay Packers at Soldier Field Sept. 1, piling up a 640,992-point total to displace Lynn Waldorf of Northwestern.

Labeling of pharmaceutical products to reveal all active ingredients will be required of manufacturers under a new regulation of the Food and Drug Administration, W. G. Campbell, chief of the administration, revealed today.

Miss Jean Sears, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry F. Sears, was married this afternoon to Archibald Stevens Alexander of Bernardsville, N. J., at The Cove, Summer home of. the bride's parents here. The Right Rev. Philip M. Rhinelander, retired Bishop of Pennsylvania, performed the ceremony in the presence of the two families.

Assemblyman Phelps Phelps announced yesterday that he had written Park Commissioner Robert Moses asking that swimming and wading pools be built on the lower West Side. Mr. Phelps said the pools would put an end to drownings near the West Side piers.

The attck on the Soviet Consulate in Tientsin Sunday night, which is featured in the Soviet official press today as a Japanese-inspired "bandit raid," is interpreted by Soviet spokesmen as indicating the Japanese have found the Soviet border too wellguarded and thus have turned to easier fields.

County Judge Peter J. Brancato in Brooklyn suddenly interrupted a robbery trial at which he presided yesterday, severely scolded the de fendant and then urged him to plead guilty to a lesser charge and save himself about seven years' imDrisonment.

Farmers in the western part of the "dust bowl," where annual rainfall is only ten inches, must turn to grazing an. give up the idea of raising grains if they are to live on the land, according to Dr. Chester A. Reeds, curator of geology of the American Museum of Natural History.

THIRDD MILITARY AREA The following Engineer Corps Reserve officers, recently released to this Military Area for assignment, are assigned to units therein as indicated: To 54th Engineer Bn. (Sep.), R.A.I.: 1st Lt. Charles H. Balfour, 993 Chestnut St., Union, N. J. 2d Lt. George A. Cowee Jr., 225 W. Milton Ave., Rahway, N, J. 2d Lt. Harry S. Traynor, 410 Rahway Ave., Elizabeth, N. J.

Plans of the Southern Railway to sell stock or securities convertible into stock to obtain an indicated amount of about $30,000,000 were announced in a letter sent yesterday to stockholders by Fairfax Harrison, president. The company last sold stock in 1926.
Yachts in the spectator fleet will put on their best bibs and tuckers and go completely swank tomorrow morning in honor of two birthdays.

In St. John's Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Eugenie H. Grew, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Randolph C. Grew of Boston and Manchester, became the bride of Alexander Cochrane, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Douglas Cochrane of Boston and Northeast Harbor, Me. The Rev. Bradford H. Burnham, rector, officiated.
"The Last Plays of Maxim Gorky," a dramatic cycle depicting some of the social forces at work in Russia in 1917, will be brought out by International Publishers in September.

Bids for the construction of the building that will house the city's exhibits at the New York City World's Fair in 1939 and for the paving and drainage of a road leading to the boat basin off the fair site at Flushing Meadow Park, Queens, were announced yesterday by the Department of Parks.

Improvement in the relations between Italy and Britain has never failed in the past to focus Italian attention on the at possibility of a resurrection of the 1933 four-power pact which Premier Benito Mussolini considered one of his most brilliant diplomatic triumphs but which died before ever having had 'time to show what it could do.

Edward P. Johnson, former Mayor of Somerville, died suddenly today in Bradford, Vt., according to word received here late tonight. His age was 63. A Summer resident of Bradford, Mr. Johnson was stricken while visiting the office of a friend.

G. B. Treysman and A. E. Santasiere of New York, favorites, led the field in early rounds of the New York State chess tournament played here tonight. Santasiere, several times State champion, defeated G. Shainswit and Professor E. B. Adams of New York. Treysman won his match from. G. Garfinkel of Buffalo.

Price reductions averaging 5 to 10 per cent and in a few instances running somewhat higher were announced yesterday on the standard owel lines of Cannon Mills, effective today on goods for delivery during August, September and October. While the move was not unexpected in the trade, the extent of the declines caused some surprise.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The New Deal theory most recently voiced by Secretary Perkins, that high wages mean high consumer buying power, contains a grain of truth. Mass production implies mass consumption, and mass consumption, when employment is general, can be furthered by high wages.

The infant mortality rate for last week was the lowest ever recorded in the history of the city's Health Department and deaths from all causes were fewer than in any seven-day period this year, Health Commissioner Rice announced yesterday.

Burleigh Grimes came back from St. Louis this morning empty handed and left Forbes Field this evening in the same condition. His Dodgers dropped both ends of a doubleheader to the Pirates, 5-4 and 10--4, and these defeats, coupled with the Reds' victory over the Giants, tumbled the Kelly Greens into seventh place, only a game and a half ahead of the Phillies.

A new wage agreement was signed yesterday by representatives Af the towboat industry of the Port of New York and the newly organized United Marine Division of the International Longshoremen's Association, to be effective until Sept. 30, 1938.

A son and mother from Waukegan, Ill., spending a vacation in New York City, were the objects. of a police broadcast at 8:20 o'clock yesterday morning. All patrolmen were urged to be on the alert for an automobile bearing Illinois license plates to notify Everett Denman that his father had died suddenly and that he and his mother should return to Waukegan.

Plans for the modernization of Eleventh Avenue, long known as Death Avenue, by removal of the abandoned New York Central surface tracks, widening the roadway from 60 to 70 feet and resurfacing from Thirty-seventh to Fifty-ninth Streets are pending before the Board of Estimate.

Miss Pat Cumming of Westfield swept through two matches in straight sets today to win the girls' laurels in the New Jersey junior tennis championships at the Trenton Country Club. Miss Cumming, Northern New Jersey girls' champion and former national junior doubles' titleholder, be defeated Miss Betty Rhoads of Trenton in the final round,

The Police Anchor Club was host yesterday to 1,600 orphans at Manhattan Beach. The club is composed of Knights of Columbus members within the department. The children, who were taken to the beach in buses under a police escort, were selected from the Protestant Federation and the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, both of Manhattan;

Mrs. Helen von Epler Paine, millinery, store in building at southwest corner of Madison Ave and 54th St; Milhouse, Inc., store for luncheonette at 304 E 45th St; Walter Samuels, Inc., brokers. James S. Sutton. decorative and domestic linens, store in 532 Madison Ave. through Butt, Gilliam McVay, Inc.. and Leonard J. Beck, Inc., brokers.

The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday fell below that for the preceding week and for the corresponding week of last year, according to the listings published in THE TIMES.

With the announcement today of France's new consolidation bonds, to be issued tomorrow, Finance Minister Georges Bonnet entered the third phase of his plan for the financial restoration of the nation. The first two steps were the increasing of taxes and the cutting of extra budgetary expenditures.

Laurette Taylor had the role of playwright as well as actress tonight. when an enthusiastic audience saw her in "At the Theatre" in Walter Hartwig's Colony Theatre. The comedy which Miss Taylor wrote was presented tonight for the first time.

Fleetfooted Terry Moore, St. Louis Cardinals' centerfielder, beat the Boston Bees today with a home run. With the score tied at 2-all, Moore came up in the seventh inning with Leo Durocher and Mickey Owen on base.

Representatives of retail grocers' organizations within the city failed to arbitrate their trade differences with owners of delicatessen stores concerning the hours of Sunday trade, at a special hearing yesterday in the Bar Building, 34 West Forty-fourth Street.

Paramount's "Artists and Models," a musical extravaganza with Jack Benny, Ben Blue, Judy Canova, Gail Patrick, Ida Lupino, Yacht Club Boys, Martha Raye, Richard Arlen and several radio bands, is the newcomer at the Paramount this morning...The Little Carnegie Playhouse begins a return engagement of "Showboat" with Irene Dunne,

Vaiden B. Sweeney, former mechanical superintendent of The Journal of Commerce, died yesterday at his residence, 3,612 Farragut Road, Brooklyn, after a twoday illness. He celebrated his eightieth birthday on July 23.

William Henry Sudduth 2d gave a tea yesterday in the Garden of the Ambassador for his brother-inlaw and sister, Captain and Mrs. William M. Miley, who are here from San Antonio, Texas. The other guests included the host's fiancee, Miss Muriel Selden, and her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lynde Selden of Greenwich.

Up in Botwood, Nfld., where transatlantic survey planes arrive and depart, S. B. Kauffman, operations 'inspector for Pan American Airways; was impressed with the pea-soup fogs that roll in from the Newfoundland banks in early morning and decided to explore their extent by boat.

Drastio rules to forbid fraud or deceit by brokers and dealers in over-thecounter markets were promulgated today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, to be effective on Oct. 1. The rules, which define manipulative, deceptive or fraudulent practices which would violate the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, apply to transactions in all kinds of securities, even exempted government, State and municipal bonds.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Eleanor Gray, daughter of Mrs. Arthur R. Gray of 435 East Fifty-seventh Street and Garrison, N. Y., and the late Rev. Dr. Gray, to David Howell Cheney of this city.

President Roosevelt still favors the kind of dollar which will have the same buying and debt-paying power from one generation to another, according to a letter produced by Senator Thomas today before a subcommittee of the Senate Agriculture Committee. The letter was written last May as a personal communication of the Oklahoma Senator.

The Bacardi Corporation of America, incorporated in Pennsylvania with offices in Philadelphia, moved today in the United States District Court to establish the right to manufacture rum in Puerto Rico and to market both in this island and the United States.

Exports through Los Angeles Harbor increased 50 per cent in July over July, 1936, and imports were up 27 per cent, the Los Angeles County Chamber of Commerce reported today. Industrial employment showed a gain of 17 per cent over July, 1936, with payroll increases of 29 per cent.

Although no summonses will be issued for parking without lights in the city's streets, thanks to a recent change in the Traffic Law, "tickets" will be issued to motorists who park more than the one hour allowed by law, Police Commissioner Valentine declared yesterday.
A long-projected scheme for a national British theatre was brought a stage nearer today with the purchase of a building site in South Kensington, London.
John J. O'Connell Jr. put the last word in the record today of the government's case against eight men on trial for his abduction in 1933.

Eddie Gerard, noted Hockey player and coach, was reported tonight to be slightly improved although he was still in a serious condition following an operation for a throat ailment his physician said was affecting his breathing.
The Massachusetts Federation of Labor, one of the nation's largest, tonight was cleft by the demand of an important faction for unification with the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Thomas Craddock Hughes, attorney for the reorganization trustees of Prudence Company, Inc., sought to prove yesterday at a hearing before Special Bankruptcy Commissioner Adolf Kiendl in the Federal Court in Brooklyn that dividends paid on preferred stock of the corporation on May 1, 1932. were taken from capital instead of from surplus.

Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Aug. 2 unless specified: Drakes Bay to sea, California, Idaho, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Tennessee, West Virginia. San Diego to San Francisco via San Pedro, Chandler, Hovey, Perry, Southard. San Diego to San Francisco, Concord, MlIwaukee. At Hampton Roads, Aug. 3, Mallard, Texas.

Transfer PATROLMAN-Peter Laibach, from recinct to 23d Precinct. Temporary Assignment PATROLMAN-John V. Scully, fro Traffic A to 19th Division, for duty raided premises squad, for 12 days. Leaves Without Pay

Blau-Linnett Appraisals, a firm which will devote itself entirely to real estate appraising, has been formed by John A. Linnett, formerly Counsellor of Ratables for the City of Newark, N. J., and Leslie Blau, of Leslie Blau, Inc., Newark and East Orange real estate brokers.

The Port of New York Authority opened proceedings yesterday for the appointment of commissioners to appraise parcels in Union City required for the approach to the new Lincoln Tunnel to midtown Manhattan as follows:

Clyde N. Roby, Eastern sales manager of the Nash Motors Division of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, has been transferred from Kenosha to this city, where he will make his headquarters. Reisner-Kantrowitz, resident buyers, are now representing the Jay Wholesale Co., Inc., which has while stores here and in Syracuse and Harrisburg.

Mrs. Genevieve Boardman, a member of the State committee of the Veterans of Foreign Wars Auxiliary and a past president of the Queens Auxiliary, the V. F. W., died Monday in She Hamilton Private Hospital, Brooklyn, after an appendectomy. Her home was at 168-16 119th Avenue, Jamaica.

Sir Herbert Hughes-Stanton, president of the Royal Society of Painters in Watercolor, died here today at the age of 67. A noted landscape painter, his water-color pictures of famous places are in the National Gallery here and in many prominent collections abroad.

Gregory Mangin, fifth in the national ranking, made his exit from the Southampton invitation turf court tennis tournament at the Meadow Club today and Robert Riggs and Frank Shields both had narrow escapes as play-reached the quarter-final round.

Lefty Grove pitched the Red Sox to withing two and one-half games of second place today as the Fenway millionaires humbled the Indians, 13 to 2, with a 15-hit barrage, while the White Sox were losing twice to the Yankees.

Kidnappers tore Donald Horst, 2 1/2 years old, from the arms of his mother this afternoon and shortly afterward telephoned a demand for $5,000 ransom. With no clew save the license number of the automobile used by the abductors, the police broadcast messages asking that Fred Ewert, a chauffeur for Dr. John A. Rose, business partner of the father of the missing boy, be detained for questioning.

The Board of Trade of Kansas City, Mo., and thirty-three of its members filed today an appeal in the Supreme Court challenging the constitutionality of the 1936 act broadening Federal regulation of commodity exchanges,

A suggestion that the warring Democratic factions in New York City withdraw both Senator Royal S. Copeland and Grover A. Whalen in favor of a compromise candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor was reported last night to have been blocked by Representative Christopher D. Sullivan, the new leader of Tammany.

Canada's external trade increased to $1,851,365,000 in the twelve months ended on June 30. This was a gain of 23.8 per cent over $1,494,863,000 in the preceding twelve months, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics said in a review published today.

Tonight's concert of the Goldman and on the Central Park Mall will feature the Music Memory Contest. Charles Henry Doersam, organist, will be heard in a recital at the Riverside Church this afternoon at 4:30 under the auspices of the Columbia University Summer session.

Rex Martin, former Assistant Director of Airways of the Bureau of Air Commerce, who was a passenger on the airliner found wrecked near Cristobal today, had been sent to Latin America as aeronautical adviser after the resignation of Eugene L. Vidal as Director of Air Commerce last March.

Circulation of petitions to designate Mayor La Guardia for nomination in the Republican primary was begun last night in Queens at a meeting in the Jamaica Chamber of Commerce Building, attended by more than a hundred men and women.

The discovery that a bill intended purely as an amendment of administrative provisions of the existing tariff law now embodies a proposed change in one of the law's rate provisions as well greatly disturbed importers here yesterday.

Commercial failures declined in three groups, including the retail division, in the week ended July 29 in comparison with the same period last year, according to the report isued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

President Roosevelt conferred with William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, on. wages-and-hours legislation, said at a press conference that he was opposed to crop loans to peg declining prices without production control and announced that he would make a radio address on Sept. 17 on the occasion of the
Buying activity continued good at the Fashion Accessories Show yesterday, as additional buyer registra tions brought the total attendance up to that of previous events.

Mrs. Cora Lyon Canning, wife of Franklin V. Canning, president of Sweets Laboratory, Inc., 423 West 127th Street, died yesterday at her home, 122 Arleigh Road, Douglas Manor, Queens, after an illness of three months.

The league-leading Bears extended their victory streak to five games tonight as they defeated Buffalo, 8 to 4, before a gathering of 17,816, largest attendance in this city's seven-year history of night baseball.

About 1,500 persons crowded into St. Aloysius's Roman Catholic Church, Onderdonk Avenue and Stanhope Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning as funeral services were held for Paula Macagna, 9 years old, who was found murdered on Saturday in the cellar of her home at 349 Stockholm Street.

Using a plane for the first time in his reign, King George VI flew here today from Windsor to visit the camp for public school and working boys he established at Martlesham Heath fifteen years ago when he was Duke of York.

Third in the series of inaugurations of monuments to commemorate America's sacrifices in the World War was the dedication of the Somme-Py Memorial today. Harry W. Colmery, National Commander of the American Legion, took the occasion to sound what struck listeners as a warning when he said that Americans were greatly worried over the European war danger.

Plans for a campaign to unionize 10,000 Government workers in this area weer announced today by the United Federal Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, which established an office with Alfred J. Van Tassel of this city as its director.

MANTATTAN BOSTWICK, CHARLES A. (July 25). Estate, more than $10,000. To Nina Payne Bostwick, widow, executrix, 212 E. 48th St. CARY, WALTER (July 2). Estate, more than $10,000. To Catherine Cary, niece, 340 E. 72d St., temporary estate in onethird residue, one-half of principal at 25 and remainder one-half at 30; Harriet C. Jones, sister. 1.363 North Prospect Ave.

At issue of 20,000 shares of convertible $5 preferred stock of the Sharon Steel Corporation of no par value is being offered today by an underwriting group headed by Speyer Co. and Hemphill, Noyes Co., at $101.50 a share.

Under the patronage of the Habsburg Archduchess Magdanela, the second "International Women's Week" will open in Budapest tomorrow with an attendance of several hundred womeri drawn from sixteen nations. Dr. Magda de Spur, who made a tour of this country last Winter to invite American organizations of women to attent, will be chairman.

Both the Association of the Bar and the New York County Lawyers Association have endorsed for renomination nine justices of the Municipal Court whose terms expire this year. Six of them are Democrats, three Republicans. The principle of bipartisan endorsement of justices, when they have served a fll term with satisfaction,

Miss Margaret Manson Weir, daughter of Mrs. David Manson Weir of Steubenville, Ohio, has chosen Aug. 27 as the date for her marriage to William Prescott Bonbright 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Bonbright of Grosse Pointe, Mich.

A track meet sponsored by the Athletic Development Committee of the Metropolitan Association of the A. A. U. will be held at Macombs Dam Park on Sunday afternoon. Among the events to be contested is a 220-yard handicap run and a running high jump event for women.

July having run through almost the whole gamut of meteorological phenomena, the Weather Bureau checked its files yesterday and decided that the night-making storm that broke over New York City in mid afternoon on July 12 was the prime freak.

Huelva celebrated today the anniversary of Columbus's departure in 1492 on the voyage that resulted in the discovery of America. Officers of three italian destroyers here visited the monastery of La Rabida, the refuge of Columbus before his voyage. Count Campaldo,

After opening virtually unchanged from Monday's close, prices on the Cotton Echange rallied yesterday to end with gains of 5 to 8 points. With continued hot, dry weather in the Southwest, where the crop is reported beginning to need rain, and prices off 2 cents a pound in less than a month, there was less disposition to reduce obligations before the government estimate on Monday.
The stock markets reopened today after the long bank holiday with a generally firm tone. Gilt-edge stocks improved; while little change occurred in foreign bonds.

President Roosevelt through the New Deal is putting into effect in this country the "doctrines of Karl Marx and of the Second and Third International," the national affairs committee of the National Repuiblican Club declared in a resolution adopted last night.

Daniel Reichlin, 16 years old, of 262 West Duncannon Street. Philadelphia, died today in Atlantic City Hospital here, the second victim of the overturning and burning of the family car Saturday night at a Black Horse Pike traffic circle.

The United States Army is seeking 1,000 men to fill vacancies in the garrisons of the Panama Canal Zone, Major A. W. Gower, in charge of recruiting at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street, announced yesterday.

Taxicab drivers in the Times Square district revealed last night that employers representing about one-quarter of the industry were cooperating with the Transport Workers Union of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, in a three-week experiment of "one-shift stagger system" cab operation as a preliminary to ratifying a unionization contract.

Five persons climbed down a fire escape two stories to safety yesterday afternoon when a fire which routed twenty families was discovered in a six-story tenement house at 185-187 Avenue C, near Eleventh Street. Two persons were injured.
Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha announced his fourth Cabinet today as follows: Premier and Interior MinisterMustafa Nahas Pasha. War-Seif El-Nasr Pasha. Foreign Affairs-Wassif Ghali Pasha.

Japanese hopes that Chahar Province would be easily won over by "political means" were dashed yesterday when it became known that troops of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Central Government armies had penetrated the province from the northwest and were digging in at Nankow, a railway center thirty miles northwest of Peiping.

A firmer tone in United States Government obligations yesterday, following the mild setback on Monday, was more than offset by a resumption of a downward trend in quotations throughout the list of domestic corporation bonds in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Welsh National Eisteddfod continued today on a sun-bathed mountainside, before a throng of 10,000. Officials predicted attendance records for the week-long musical festival would be broken.

The severest typhoon in recent years held coastal and harbor shipping at virtual standstill today along the entire east coast of China. Transoceanic steamers stayed at sea to ride out the blow, officially termed of "violent intensity."
Trade journal defendants in the Federal Government's oil anti-trust cases asked Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone today to grant an additional bill of particulars of the indictment.

Making his move at the far turn, C. R. Fleischman's Scatter Brain outlasted D. McDonald's Ruffy in the stretch drive today to win the Weymouth Purse, mile and a sixteenth feature at Suffolk Downs. He paid 6-1.
Bernard Shaw's "Candida" was presented by the Forty Niners tonight, with Madalyn O'Shea in the title role, before a large audience at the Chase Barn Playhouse.
Victorious over Sussex by an innings and 351 runs in the English county cricket competition yesterday Middlesex drew into first position when Yorkshire went under by five wickets to Lancashire today.

The Treasury statement which THE TIMES publishes this morning shows for the month of July a Government deficit of $250,000,000. July is the first month of the new fiscal year 1937-38. During this fiscal year it was originally President Roosevelt's hope to achieve a "layman's balance" of the budget-that is, a balance in which current revenues would cover all expenditures except payments into the sinking fund for the purpose of debt reduction.

Miss Kathryn Pierce, a descendant of President Franklin Pierce, today became the bride of Roger Sanderson Hewlett, member of one of New York's oldest families, at All Saints Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William M. Fleetwood. After the ceremony a reception was held in the garden of the Hotel Leighton.

Thomas Tavenor, retired member of the decorating firms of Roux Co. and Hamilton Bell Co., died late Monday at his home, 32 Washington Square, at the age of 91. Mr. Tavenor was born in Plymouth, England, and came to this country in 1876. For many years he was with the Roux firm, which decorated many of the homes of prominent New York families.
Mail addressed to "Panama, Canal Zone" intended for residents of this city will be returned to the sender without delivery after Sept. 1, according to Postmaster Manuel de Jesus Quijano.

A new highway connecting Asmara, Eritrea, and Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, 800 miles distant, was officially opened Sunday. Actually the road had been open to traffic since July 1 to test its endurance during the big rains.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum in the United States on July 24 amounted to 307,551,000 barrels, the Bureau of Mines reported today. Compared. with a week before, this total represents an increase of 412,000 barrels, comprising an increase of 472,000 barrels in stocks of domestic crude and a decrease of 60,000 in stocks of foreign crude.

The President and Congress tonight to be headed for another finish fight over a major Administration policy as Mr. Roosevelt refused to yield in the face of a determined drive by Southern and Western delegations in the Senate and House for renewal of the commodity loan program to stem present and prospective declines in farm prices.

The wreckage of a Pan American-Grace Airways flying boat, due here last night from Cafl, Colombia, with eleven passengers and a crew of three, was found today by a navy plane twenty miles at sea from Cristobal.
