General paralysis of its trucking facilities threatened Philadelphia tonight, for the second time in a month, as sympathizers of striking freight haulers put terrorist methods into effect throughout the city in an apparent attempt to "pull a everything off the streets."

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 2: MAJOR GENERAL Birnie, U. Jr., Chief of Field Artillery, three days' leave, Aug. 5. COLONELF Delterick, L- L., Q. M. C., Columbus. Ohio, to retirement. LIEUTENANT COLONELS

The first foreign travelers arriving in Tientsin from Manchukuo in five days report the Japanese in Mukden, Dairen and Hsinking are extremely nervous over possibilities of conflict in the new empire of Manchukuo.
As the showings gain momentum it develops that it is to be a season of extreme elegance in fabric and inventiveness in detail of design and combination of colors.
A plea by the Archbishop of YorK for unity of Christendom in solving modern-day problems marked the opening session today of the Second World Conference on Faith and Order.

The crew representing the yacht squadron of the Westhampton Bay Country Club sailed into the lead in the Gulden Trophy series today as the competition neared its close. Cedarhurst, yesterday's leader, dropped back to third place as Point o' Woods took over second

Joseph Lazzari, father of Carolina Lazzari, leading contralto of the Metropolitan and Chicago Civic Opera Companies of more than a decade ago, died last night in St. Raphael's Hospital, New Haven, after a long illness, at the age of 75.

The daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,591,900 barrels, compared with 3,576,400 in the preceding week, an increase of 15,500, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Aug. 2 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Great relief was expressed here over the recent evacuation of more than 100 refugees from the Chilean Embassy in Madrid after energetic appeals to Spain by the League of Nations and the Chilean Ambassador to London, Augustin Edwards.
Subpoena powers for the House Immigration Committee were demanded on the floor today by its chairman, Representative Dickstein of New York, to aid the exposing of Nazi propaganda in this country.

The Blreau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 31: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Ingersoll, F. M., Dental Corps, orders of June 1 and June 30 revoked, to continue duty at Naval Training Station, Great Lakes, III.

New York City's next budget will be the largest in the city's history with an estimated increase of about $30,000,000 over the city's 1937 expense budget, according to preliminary estimates now being made by Mayor La Guardia and Controller Frank J. Taylor.

Volleys of stones and fire-crackers were hurled at the police yesterday by shipyard strikers in the biggest mass picketing demonstration yet staged in the vicinity of the Robins Drydock and Repair Company plant, at the foot of Dwight Street, Brooklyn.

The engagement has been an- MIS nounced of Miss Barbara Anne Carrington, daughter of Mrs. Ellsworth Torrey Carrington of 52 Berkeley Avenue, Newark, and Edgartown, Mass., and the late Mr. Carrington, to Robert Heurtin Halsey Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert H. Halsey of 17 East Eighty-ninth Street, this city.

Miss Henrietta Throop Hall, daughter of Mrs. Henry Throop Hall of this city, was married today to James Frederick Green, son of John F. Green of Kansas City, in Dwight Memorial Chapel at Yale University. The Rev. Dr. Sidney Lovett officiated.

Westra, owned by A. C. Connell, won the famous King's. Cup race today in the Royal Yacht Squadron's regatta on the Solent as Twelve-Meter yachts competed for the historic trophy instead of the bigger Class J craft.

Governors Island, Evergreen Farms, Monmouth County Country Club, Shrewsbury and Burnt Mills survived their first round matches in the Monmouth County Club's annual 10-goal polo tournament which got under way today on three dif. ferent fronts.

Charles F. Chapman of 780 Riverside Drive, knit goods merchant, since 1894 president of the Crescent Company, 49 East Twenty-first Street, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a fortnight's illness.

For the first time since 1924, when the Medwick team came out of the West to win both the junior and open championships, a California four galloped into the final of the national junior championship today when Santa Barbara turned back the Meadow Brook Pelicans, 13-7.

Thorvald Stauning, Denniark'x 64-year-old Premier, has a broken leg and will be laid up for at least five weeks. Late last night he was showing a number of friends a short cut across sand dunes to the main road from his seaside bungalow
The city of Utica, N. Y., will consider tenders on Aug. 9 for a new issue of $500,000 of certificates of indebtedness. The certificates will be dated Aug. 10 and be payable on Dec. 10.

Preparations for the National Sweepstakes Regatta on the North Shrewsbury River in Red Bank, N. J., on Aug. 14 and 15 are being rushed by the regatta committee so that all will be in readiness when the opening speed boat event gets under way.

Rudolf Friml's operetta, "The Firefly," was presented last night at the Randalls Island Stadium by Fortune Gallo. The second of the season's schedule of Shubert productions of operettas, it attracted an audience of 6,000.

John J. Quinn, home club star who was runner-up a few weeks ago in the Crestmont Golf Club championship, today toured the Crestmont layout in 73 strokes to win the third and final one-day tournament of the Metropolitan Golf Association season.

A nation-wide silk strike will start Monday unless a collective agreement is signed with manufacturers before that time, it was announced here today by Carl Holderman, regional director for the Textile Workers Organizing Committee of the C. I. O.

The old United States liner Leviathan, which has been gathering rust and verdigris for the past two years at her Hoboken pier, may experience a renaissance of her former bluewater glory, it was learned yesterday.
Norbert Kleinke, young Rochester right-hander, shut out the Jersey City Giants with three hits today, 1-0. Kleinke retired in order the last fourteen men to face him, fanned six and walked two.

Clinton W. Areson, chief probation officer of the Domestic Relations Court in New York, has purchased a plot on Chimney Point Road at the Candlewood Lake Club, Candlewood Lake, Conn., through the Robert E. Farley Organization, which will build a fiveroom log cabin for him.
An upper respiratory infection today put Emilie Dionne on the quintuplets' sick list and isolated her from her four

Twenty leading American millinery designers presented a collection of 120 Fall hats, many designed especially for the occasion, at a dinner and fashion show held last night under the auspices of the Millinery Stabilization Commission at the Pavillon Royal, Valley Stream, L. I. More than 1,000 manufacturers, buyers and retailers of millinery were present.

The Security Commission's investment trust investigators inquired today into the thirty years of uninterrupted dividend payments by the Alexander Fund of Philadelphia. W. Leonard Alexander, whose fatheir, W. Wallace Alexander, founded the fund in 1907, acknowledged that dividends sometimes were paid out of capital as well as earnings,

How tall do hollyhocks grow? Some, it appears, grow pretty high. Having read recently in THE NEW YORK TIMES that Julius Untermann of 61 Orchard Street, Tuckahoe, N. Y., had a 10 1/2-foot hollyhock in his garden, Mrs.

The Right Rev. Thomas Casady, Episcopal Bishop of Oklahoma, and Mrs. Casady have announced the engagement of their only daughter, Miss Frances LeBaron Christabel Casady, to the Rev. Jonathan Goodhue Sherman of Farmingdale, L. I., rector of St. Thomas Church, Farmingdale.
Thirty advanced and thirty-three baccalaureate degrees were conferred at the University of Notre Dame this evening at commencement exercises bringing to a close the nineteenth Summer school session.

Repeal of the capital gains tax with respect to sales or exchanges of capital assets held for more than one year, repeal of the $2,000 limitation upon deduction of capital net losses, and amendment of the corporate surplus tax provisions of the Revenue Act of 1936, were recommended in resolutions passed at a meeting here yesterday of the Consumers Goods Industries Committee, of which George A. Sloan is president.
Mrs. Arthur B. Claflin gave a luncheon followed by bridge today at her home in the Shinnecock Hills for Mrs. LounsberyAlexander and Mrs. T. Charles Farrelly, who are passing the week with her.

Miss Marian Dolan, 19 years old, of 2,044 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, was adjudged a modern Venus yesterday at a beauty contest in Steeplechase Park, Coney Island. Miss Dolan was a runner-up in a similar contest last year.
Mayor La Guardia of New York, appearing as a witness before the House Banking and Currency Committee today, urged the passage of the Wagner-Steagall measure for lowcost housing and slum clearance.

President Roosevelt will make a radio speech on Sept. 17, in celebration of the 150th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution, the White House announced today. The speech will be made from a stand at the base of the Washington Monument and will be carried over the principal broadcasting systems.
The Cardinals announced today they had released Paul Dean on option to Houston of the Texas League. A few minutes later it was stated the release had been held up temporarily.

The Australian Government today banned the Hollywood film "The King and the Chorus Girl," which concerns a farcical monarch abdicating a mythical kingdom for the love of a chorus girl. The play was written by Groucho Marx.

The Italian speed-boat ace, Count Theo Rossi, tuned up his two Gold Cup Class boats with Abyssinian names-Alagi and Aradam-today in preparation for an attempt tomorrow to surpass the world record of 140 kilometers per hour held by Maurice Vasseur of France.

Broward County voters stamped their approval, 3,419 to 340, today on the proposed $1,300,000 Hollywood horse racing track, which would be the third within twelve miles of Miami. Miamians had no choice in the referendum, for the plant would be located just north of the Dade (Miami) County line.

Three masked raiders ransacked the home of Sir Dawson Bates, Home Minister, last night. The police blame Irish independence extremists. The raiders apparently sought documents detailing terrorism which broke out when King George and Queen Elizabeth visited Northern Ireland last week.

The Vatican has granted to the Insurgent government in Spain the right to have a diplomatic representative to deal with its Secretariat of State. Whether this will be followed by full recognition of General Francisco Franco is not clear.
The National Socialist purge of static art in Germany that Chancellor Adolf Hitler announced at the dedication last month of the House of German Art was definitely set in motion today.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora announced yesterday that the date for the sentencing of Arthur (Tootsie) Herbert, David Diamondstone and Harry Frankel, officials of the chicken drivers union who pleaded guilty to embezzling union funds, had been set forward to Aug. 12.

Miss Virginia Guilfoil, medal and match play champion of the Syracuse district, with long driving and steady putting captured the medal in the qualifying round of the women's international invitation tournament over the Hotel Champlain golf course today when she carded a brilliant 77, 2 under women's par.
Harry Balsamo, the hard-hitting subway brakeman from Harlem, will test his punching ability against Al Diamond in the feature ten-round bout at Dyckman Oval tonight.

Magistrate Pinto paid a $1 fine for a peddler yesterday in Coney Island Court. The defendant, Nathan Goldfarb, 59 years old, of 1,516 West Tenth Street, Coney Island, had been charged with selling his wares in a restricted area.

Mrs. Marjorie Oelrichs Duchin, wife of Eddy Duchin, the orchestra leader, and a member of a socially prominent family of New York and Newport, died early yesterday morning in the Harbor Sanitarium, 667 Madison Avenue, at the age of 29.

After being hauled out of water today up at the Herreshoff shipyard in Bristol, Harold S. Vanderbilt's defender Ranger and T. O. M. Sopwith's challenger Endeavour II were ready for their third America's Cup race tomorrow.

Among the passengers sailing for Europe today on the French liner Normandie are Sir Herbert Marler, Canadian Minister to the United States, and Lady Marler; Walter Edge, former United States Ambassador to France; General Yang Chu-cheing of the Chinese Army; Lieut. Col. Emmanuel Lombard.

The Westchester contracting firm of M. Barnett Sons began work yesterday on the construction of the new Arnold Constable store on the southeast corner of Main Street and North Avenue, New Rochelle, according to George E. Hite Jr., chairman of the board of the, department store. It is expected the building will be completed in October.
Throngs Flock to See Animal That Looks Like Giraffe and Zebra, but Is Neither
Anson Strong Brooks, 84, a prominent figure in the lumber industry of the nation, died today at his home here after a two months' illness.
New Summer styles for mounted policemen were put into effect, at least temporarily yesterday as 400 patrolmen on horses and 400 on motor cycles "tried out" a new type of blue brouse.

New York's eight-day period for filing of primary designating petitions began today, the first step toward setting up the machinery for the November general election. The primary election will be Sept. 16 and the general election Nov. 2.

Turpentine firm, 32c; sales, 166 barrels; receipts, 595 barrels; shipments, 55 barrels; stock, 33,365 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 1,240; receipts, 3,193; shipments, 1,335; stock, 68,114. Quote: B to WG, $7.75; WW, X, $8.55.

The possibility of a vast cooperative organization that would include all the important craft and labor unions in the amusement industry was indicated yesterday after a conference in the offices of the Actors Equity Association.

Insurgent troops, driving southward through government lines on the Teruel front, concentrated today on cleaning up captured territory south of Albarracin, thirty-five miles west of Teruel and 118 miles east of Madrid.

The Zionist World Congress, faced with its. gravest problem-that of formulating a Jewish policy toward the Palestine partition proposaland divided as perhaps never before-opened here tonight with the largest attendance in its twenty sessions.

Trapped under a fifteen-ton combination scoop and gondola car on which they were working underground on the Sixth Avenue subway project at Herald Square, three sandhogs were saved from possible death at 9:20 A. M. yesterday by the quick action of their fellow laborers.
Cleveland Electric Iluminating Company and Subsidiaries-Twelve months to June 30:

One odds-on favorite lost and another won in the featured races today. The $2,625 Saratoga Sales Stakes saw the 7-to-10 favorite, Maetall, falter in the final drive to bring up second, beaten a neck, back of Joe W. Brown's surprising Spillway, who was held at 10 to 1. Mountain Ridge was third.
State Referee Samuel C. Shaw died this afternoon at his home here. He was 71 years old and had been ill for several weeks, having returned home recently from a Bridgeport hospital.

The committee of stock list of the New York Stock Exchange has authorized the listing of 16,515 additional shares of the Lehman Corporation on official notice of issuance. The shares are issuable to Lehman Brothers for $570,620 in cash under the terms of the management agreement between the firm and the corporation.
Johnny Page, young Los Angeles and Chicago boxer and former resident of Dallas, Texas, died tonight, almost twenty-four hours after being injured in a bout with Eddie Zivic. Pittsburgh lightweight.

From Guam in the Pacific Ocean came a radio appeal today for information to prevent soil erosion. R. G. Oakley, a Guam agricultural official, asked the Plant Quarantine Bureau here to have G. L. Crawford, soil conservationist at the MaSaguez Experiment Station, inform him what grasses or plants would prevent erosion on a watershed.

Arthur E. Farrell of H. M. Byllesby Co., Chicago, has been unanimously selected by the nominating committee of the National Security Traders Association as president for the fiscal year beginnig Oct. 1. Recently he was elected president of the association for the unexpired term of J. Gentry Daggy, who resigned as president.

James J. Braddock, former world heavyweight champion, dropped in today to have a look at Tommy Farr at the camp where the British challenger is preparing to meet Joe Louis at the Yankee Stadium Aug. 26 for the title Jimmy recently lost to Louis.

The conference organized by the Australian Council for Educational Research, which was endowed by the Carnegie Corporation of New York, opened tonight. It will close at Perth Sept. 16 after meetings in all the State capitals and in Canberra.

The House adopted today, without discussion, the conference report on the District of Columbia Tax Bill carrying as a rider the MillerTydings bill for retail price maintenance. The measure was sent to the Senate, where the price maintenance bill was originally attached to the tax proposal.

Builders planning an apartment house on upper Madison Avenue rounded out yesterday the site for the structure by purchasing from H. Pelham Robbins the four-story house at 19 East Eightieth Street. The buyer is the 29 East Eightieth Corporation, representing the Oshlag interests. Oshlag Freund and Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., were the brokers.
Experts say that with the ejection of Christopher D. Sullivan as leader of Tammany Hall the course of empire in that organization, so to speak, retraces its path to south of Fourteenth Street.
A charge against John M. Hayes of Mahwah, N. J., accused of stealing his own child, Patricia Ann, 2, from the home of his mother-in-law in San Francisco,. was continued today until Aug. 12.

Supreme Court Justice Albert Conway in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that Robert F. Mullins must pay $4,922 to the Broadway-Patchen Corporation or be adjudged guilty of contempt of court and liable to imprisonment.

Some one has stolen the late Viscount Byng's decorations, orders, medals and snuff boxes. Thorpe Hall, the residence here of the late Governor General of Canada, was entered during the night and the ground floor rooms ransacked.

Order Changed Paragraph III, Special Order 134, July 27, 1937, in so far as it relates to the Department Band reporting for practice on Aig. 7, is changed to read: Aug. 6. Launching Members of the department and their families are cordially invited to attend the launching of the U. S. S. Honolulu at -he Brooklyn Navy Yard at noon Thursdty, Aug. 26.

Shipping along the North Atlantic Coast watched tonight for the 40-foot Halifax sloop Phantom, unreported since she sailed out of Lunenburg, N. S., Friday for the America's Cup races off Newport, R. I.

Three of the most beautiful objects in, the far-flung heavens that man is privileged to see-the planet Venus, the moon and a comet-combined to stage two glittering spectackles yesterday. One of the displays will be repeated daily for about a fortnight, but the other will not be visible again for several years.

The National Labor Relations Board ordered the Suburban Lumber Company of Oaklyn, N. J., and the Calvert Distillers in Maryland, today, each to reinstate six employes discharged for union activity; warned both companies to improve their relations with the complainant unions, and further warned the distillers to dissociate themselves from the Employes Representation Plan created by them at their Relay, Md., plant.

Pressed to the need for extreme measures, Skipper Bill Terry hauled his Giants into drydock today and gave them an astounding going over, but to no immediate avail. Master Melvin Ott was transplanted from right field to third base. Hank Leiber,

The Sino-Japanese crisis in the PeipingTientsin area was regarded today as having passed out of the military into the political phase, in which efforts presumably will be made for adjustments, but with what result it was considered impossible to forecast on the basis of present advices.

Mrs. Grace Rowley Mellon filed suit for divorce today in Common Pleas Court against William Larimer Mellon Jr. on grounds of desertion. Mr. Mellon is son of the chairman of the Gulf Oil Corporation and grandnephew of A. W. Mellon, former Secretarv of the Treasury.
The Democratic and Republican city committees announced today their designees for Yonkers offices to be filled at the municipal election next November.

Prospects for a peaceful adjustlent of the Sino-Japanese dispute Hopeh were seen here today ith the revelation that the Japan-Ambassador, Shigeru Kawagoe, had actually left Tientsin for shanghai and Nanking with the inntion of attempting to negotiate modus viviendi in North China.
E. V. Siedle, real estate broker, has moved his office to a new building on Third Street, Rye, N. Y.

John Ostrom, an inspector in the Labor Department's Immigration Bureau, was assigned yesterday to examine passengers arriving on the Holland-America liner Veendam. When Johan Oosterom, an Amsterdam painter and decorator, appeared with passport and other papapers the inspector left his desk and asked an associate to pass on the case. The man was his father,

The estate of Carolyn L. Van Hoosen has sold a four-acre tract on the south side of Jericho Turnpike, opposite Bostwick Po1o Field, at Westbury, L. I., through Payson McL. Merrill Company, Inc., and John A. McKenna Jr. There is a nine-room, three-bath dwelling on the property.

A protocol between Chile and Bolivia will be signed this week, it is reported in well-informed circles today, the substance of which will be mutual concessions to permit Bolivia more freedom in the use of the Port of Arica, Chile, making. it her principal outlet to the Pacific. Chile,
An investor bought from the Mar-Gene Realty Corporation, Harry Glick, president, the sixstory elevator apartment house for EAST fifty-three families at 860 Fairmount Place, the Bronx.
Albert Nelson Cheney Fowler, Glens Falls business man, author and playwright, died suddenly today in his home here at the age of 65. For many years he was associated with the B. B. Fowler Company.

Archduke Otto visited the Austrian Boy Scouts camp at Vogelenzang today. Accompanied by the Chief Scout the exiled Archduke also visited the camps of Hungary and Rumania. Other royal guests now in The Netherlands, King Gustaf Adolf of Sweden and Prince and Princess Chichibu of Japan dined with Princess Juliana tonight.
The Treasury Department, seeking to save premium payments to private companies, plans to handle its own insurance on future shipments of currency and securities.

The New York Telephone Company, controlled by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, reported yesterday a net loss of telephones in service of 2,383 during July, as compared with a net loss of 9,319 instruments in July, 1936, and one of 14,486 in July, 1935.
A misunderstanding of President Roosevelt's intentions in regard to the Wages and Hours Bill temporarily halted its legislative progress tolay.

Having devoted most of his life to theatrical producing, A. H. Woods is about to invade a somewhat different field in the theatre. He is organizing and intends to open in November a school for acting. Call it the National Academy of Modern Acting, the aim of which would be to "train persons of definite talent for the Broadway theatre." In the meantime,

Authority to borrow $5,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the loan to be used to retire maturingg obligations, was asked today of the Interstate Commerce Commisison by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company.

The deal by which Germany was allowed to purchase 100,000 bags of Brazilian coffee for resale to Central European countries was canceled today by Acting Finance Minister Villela. Mr. Villela informed the Bank of Brazil that, regardless of the stage of the negotiations, they should be ended.

The State executive committee of the American Labor party will formally nominate Mayor La Guardia for re-election at a meeting tonight. This will be a legal nomination, as under the Election Law a new legal political party, before there is opportunity for enrollment of its members, nominates candidates for elective office by action of its duly authorized committee.

Exports as well as imports of the United States increased sharply in June compared with the corresponding month of 1936, but the outflow in June showed a decrease from that in May. General imports, however, were up slightly from May, the monthly review by the Department of Commerce showed today.
Stocks closed lower; turnover, 897,060 shares. Domestic and foreign bonds lower: government issues higher; transactions, $5,781,250.

Movements of livestock' in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 10,000, including 1,500 directs. Good and choice hogs from 230 pounds, down strong to 10c higher than Monday's average;

A jury tonight announced the awards for the prizes of $50 each given by Mrs. Carl A. de Gersdorff in connection with the twenty-ninth annual Stockbridge exhibition, which will open at the Berkshire Museum, Pittsfield, tomorrow afternoon with the varnishing day reception.

A solemn high memorial mass was sung in the Church of the Holy Innocents in West Thirty-seventh Street near Broadway yesterday morning for the eight firefighters who lost their lives in the fire and explosion in the sub-basement of the Ritz Tower at Fifty-seventh Street and Park Avenue on Aug. 1, 1932.

More than 100 children between the ages of 4 and 12 years "played host" yesterday to their parents, visiting student teachers and professors from New York University and officials of the Child Study Association of America at the Summer play school in the Little Red School House, 196 Bleecker Street.

On a day that saw the favorites sternly challenged in every instance Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan of Boston, Miss Gracyn Wheeler of California, Miss Jadwiga Jedrzejowska of Poland and Mrs. Sylvia Henrotin of France came through to the semi-final brackets in the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club today.

Gross assets. $1,850; net, $1,850. To wife, Mary Ferrante. Chief assets, real estate, $1,850. Bennett E. Aron, attorney, 186 Joralemon St. JUNGE, ANNA C. (Oct. 1. 1934). Gross E assets, $1,742; net, $1,218. To mother, Mary J. Junge and sister. Alma M. Kearney. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $1,667.

George Graint, assistant manager of the Hamburg American Line in London, one of the survivors of the Hindenburg disaster, sailed last night on the Hamburg American liner Hansa to recuperate at his home in London.
Wayne LaMaster, the Phillies' southpaw ace, stopped the runaway Cubs today by shading Larry French in a hurlers' duel, 2 to 1.

Purchase for investment of a hotel propertyy on Madison Avenue featured real estate activity in Manhattan yesterday. Joseph Wald, who has been operating hotels in this city for more taan thirty years, bought The Warrington and annex at 161 Madison avenue and 28 East Thirty-third Street, which form an "L" around the southeast corner and are assaesed this year at $307,000.

J. Butler Wright, Ambassador to Cuba, has come from Washington to the Weylin. Mrs. Wright and the Misses Mary and Edith Wright, who are expected to arrive today on the Manhattan, will join him at the hotel.
Although the real wheel of a threeton truck passed directly over his head today, Samuel Ripley, 38-yearold garbage collector from Beachwood Borough, was virtually uninjured.

In preparation for a greatly expanded radio production, advertising and sales program this Fall, the StewartWarner Corporation held here today a national convention of distributors and introduced the company's 1938 line of radio receiving sets.

Gandhi's policy of conciliation is at last being vindicated. The All-India Congress (independence) party has about completed Cabinets in the six provinces where they commanded majorities in the elections early last Spring.

John Ladd, 14 years old, of 150 East Seventythird Street, New York City, was a much surprised and delighted young man today, for when he walked into the Field Museum Clifford C. Gregg, director, and Stanley Field met him with outstretched hands and gave him a $500 life membership.

Tranquillin Advertising Art, floor, in General Electric Building, 570 Lexington Ave; Cushman Wakefield, Inc, broker. Douglas Leigh, Inc, sign advertising, in International Building, Rockefeller Center. Henry L. Seidman, C. P. A. school, in 115 W 45th St; Simon-Morris, furs, in 50 W 29th St; Allen Goldstein, ladies' wear, in 370 Seventh Ave; Arthur Eckstein, Inc, broker.
The three-story clocks of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company Building at Madison Avenue and Twenty-third Street--all four of them--are getting a well-deserved rest.
"Distinguished Gathering," that London melodrama by James Parish, which has reposed in the offices of Pearson Baruch and Ayer Minis, is now the property of Crosby Gaige.

Louis Charwat, public accountant who prepared the registration statement of the Austin Silver Mining Company, was examined further yesterday in the Securities Exchange Commission hearing on charges that the statement contained misrepresentation and that the stock was manipulated.
Branch offices of the Birth Control League of Massachusetts, beset by police raids, prepared tonight to discontinue operations on recommendations of its executive board.
Mrs. Sarah Sonneborn Mandelbaum, widow of Colonel Seymour Mandelbaum, financier and philanthropist, died today at Mercy Villa here at the age of 74.

The directors of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., voted yesterday to offer to common stockholders the right to subscribe to 150,383 shares of additional common stock at $37 a share, on the basis of one new share for each ten shares held, the gross proceeds to be approximately $5,564,000.

Playing against a United College eleven today, the Marylebone Cricket Club team registered the third successive draw of its Canadian tour. After piling up 238 for six wickets, the English team declared, the collegians losing eight wickets for 133 runs when time was called after two hours' batting.
Attorney General Cummings said today that Federal agents were investigating several large oil companies in the East to determine whether they were violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

A common front for peace in the schools of the world was urged today by Herbert S. Houston of New York, commissioner to the Far East for the New York World's Fair, before the World Education Federation meeting in Tokyo.

Miss Lucy Cave, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Blackwell Cave of Mount Rainier, was married to the Rev. Carlton Matthai Harris, son of Mrs. Carlton D. Harris and the late Rev. Dr. Harris, last evening at the Brentwood Methodist Episcopal Church, of which Mr. Harris is pastor.

Close of play scores in English first-class cricket matches started today: Kent 332 (Todd 135, Ames 93); vs. Nottinghamshire, at Canterbury. Yorkshire 288 for four wickets (Sutcliffe 109, Mitchell 100); vs. Leicestershire, at Leicester.
Donald korst, 2% years old, was turned over to the authorities early today by his unwed father and mother, who seized him yesterday from the home of his foster-parents, Mr. and Mrs. Otto Horst.

Samuel Hopkins Miller, former town official, retired farmer and descendant of two of Long Island's pioneer families, died here this morning in the home in which he was born eighty-four years ago and where he had lived all his life.
Behind the steady pitching of Southpaw Vito Tamulis, the pacesetting Newark Bears today rolled their latest victory streak to six games as they defeated Buffalo, 6 to 4.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 9,000, including 2,000 directs Lighter weight butchers were strong to cents higher than Tuesday's average;

Foreign cotton sentiment was influenced by the agitation in Congress for some form of Government assistance in marketing this year's large crop and an advance in prices abroad started an active covering movement on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday.

Various compilations show that the steel industry is operating at the best rate for the period before or since the depression with the exception of 1929, when August output averaged 95.31 per cent of the capacity of 60,990,810 gross tons then available.
Port authorities here were reported today to have arranged to sink ships in the mouth of the Ming River as a barricade against a feared Japanese naval attack.
Representative Fish of New York, whose Congressional district embraces Hyde Park, where President Roosevelt spends most of his holidays, introduced the following resolution today, without comment:

Manufactured and natural gas utility revenues amounted to $64,904,700 during May, as compared with $60,557,900 in May, 1936, an increase of 7.1 per cent, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Gas Association.

General Blanton Winship, Puerto Rico's bachelor Governor, for almost two hours this afternoon outlined his housekeeping and gardening methods at 400-year-old La Fortaleza to 100 4-H club girls none of whom had ever before been in San Juan, though few live more than thirty miles distant.
The Sterling National Bank and Trust Company has been appointed trustee under the mortgage indenture of Bevoc, Inc., securing an issue of $540,000 of first mortgage bonds.

Mainhmttan Alterations Amsterdam Ave. 329-35; to 5-story and penthouse offices, store and memorial chapel; Riverside Memorial Chapel, Inc, premises, owner; J. M. Berlinger, architect; cost, $50,000. 1st Ave, 2,314; to 4-story tenement and stores; estate of Lina M. Vooth, premises, owner; George Dress, architect; S10.000.
Payments on open credit accounts receivable of department stores were 46.4 per cent in June of this year, against 47.6 per cent the corresponding month in 1936.

State and municipal financing for July amounted to $53,377,948, compared to $43,934,202 in the same month of 1936. For the first seven months of 1937 the total was $673,906,725, against $678,682,527 for the same period last year.

At the next meeting of trustees of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway a formal contract probably will be drawn between the road and trustees of the Chicago, Rock Island Gulf Railway, a subsidiary, it was reported here yesterday in informed quarters. The same trustees act for both systems.

Thirteen drivers of coal trucks were arrested and committed to the Warren County jail here today as New Jersey opened a drive to enforce the recently enacted law to stop the transportation of bootleg coal from Pennsylvania's anthracite fields. All the drivers drew sentences of sixty days when they were unable to pay fines of $100 and costs.

Edward G. Buckland, chairman of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, received $15,216 and Howard S. Palmer received $14,000 salary as trustee and presiFdent in 1936, according to a report filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Leaving two notes, one ascribing his act to his nephew's treatment of his son, John H. Siebold, 77year-old printing ink manufacturer, took his last order a little before noon yesterday and then leaped to his death from the fourteenth floor of the Scribner Building.

The talk by "Republican orators and the newspaper writers attached to anti-Administration papers" about "an unbridgable gulf and an incurable rift in the Democratic party is the veriest moonshine," according to Postmaster General Farley.

Freman 1st grade William F. Gatens, Engine 280, retired on his own application for physical disability, on an annual pension of $2,250. Captain James E. McManus, of Engine s 219, having performed duty continuously for more than twenty years, is, on his own application retired on an annual pension of $2,250.

The record sum of $159,074,222 will be needed by the Board of Education to carry on its activities next year, according to the itemized report of its committee on finance and budget, made public yesterday. The total represents an increase of $14,584,658 over this year.

A uniform sales note proposed by the Textile Fabrics Association for use of cotton goods converters has met with some objections from the Association of New York Representatives of Dry Goods Wholesalers, the fabrics group was informed yesterday.

The winners of the Davis Cup are returning today on the Manhattan of the United States Lines. The team is headed by Don Budge. Other members of the team on board are Gene Mako, Bryan Grant Jr., Frank Parker, Walter L. Pate, captain of the team, and Wayne Sabin.
The first eight seeded players tonight occupied the eight quarter-final brackets as play ran remarkably true to form today in the national junior tennis championships.
SMALL TALK, by Harold Nicolson. (Harcourt, Brace, $2.) Essays. EITHER Is LOVE, by Elisabeth Cragin. (Harcourt, Brace, $2.) A short novel.
American photographers were beaten over the head and pushed about by Japanese troops today to prevent them from taking pictures of troop movements in this conquered city.

Public officials of New Jersey are as much mystified as the general citizenry regarding the purpose of the Pennsylvania Railroad and the Central Railroad of New Jersey in laying parallel stretches of track into the waste lands of the meadows east of highway Route 25.

The taxpayer containing fourteen stores at 1,713-1,731 University Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by John P. Dauth to Gertrude Mosbacher. It occupies a plot 175 by 100 feet and was held at $300,000, according to Roeser-Feltner, Inc., brokers in the deal in conjunction with Harry T. F. Johnson, cobroker. Samuel Reynolds represented the seller and Jesse Erich the buyer.
The earliest traces of man's existence in Palestine-and, it may be, almost the earliest evidence of man in the whole. world-have been discovered in deposits now known as the Bone Beds of Bethlehem.
The call issued yesterday for a national silk strike to start Monday was extended today to include 15,000 silk throwsters working chiefly in Pennsylvania and New Jersey.

The Vatican today refused either to confirm or to deny a statement from Salamanca, Spain, that the Holy See had officially recognized General Francisco Franco's government. It limited itself to saying that the Cardinal Archbishop of Toledo continued to maintain the contacts of the Holy See at Salamanca as hitherto.

Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation, who arrived in New York yesterday after a brief vacation at Wianno, Mass., said that in his opinion there would be no serious labor troubles in the steel industry for a long period.

The House Labor Committee voted today to recommend for passage the Wages and Hours Bill already passed by the Senate, with important modifications which appeared certain to complicate the work of the Conference Committee.

An army Bellanca transport with a crew of six crashed in the jungles on a mountainside while on a routine flight yesterday, 180 miles from the canal near the village of Remedios, in the Province of Chiriqui.

COMING in off the sea with a following wind, it was a couple of lines from John Masefield that suggested the next port of call. Among other things, the Poet Laureate of England wrote: "Of the maimed, of the halt and the blind in the rain and the cold-- Of these shall my songs be fashioned, my tales be told."

President Roosevelt vetoed a bill to change the name of the Chemical Warfare Service to Chemical Corps; conferred with Senator Barkley, the majority leader; received a report from Aubrey Williams, Assistant Works Progress Administrator, on conditions in the drought States; approved the plan to place employes of the Bituminous Coal Commission under civil service, and inspected proposed sites for the new Naval Hospital.

During the first six months of 1937, 368 advertisers invested a total of $106,232,392 in magazines, radio and farm publications, an increase of $18,215,178, or 20 per cent over the like period of 1936, according to a survey in Printers' Ink, out today.

The 16,000 hardy music lovers who were exposed to Monday night's torrents returned in full number to Lewisohn Stadium last night to hear the postponed program, in which Jaseha Heifetz played the Tchaikovsky concerto with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Emma Grandon Wheeler, daughter of Mrs. Roy B. Wheeler of Pasadena, Calif., to Donald Poinier of South Orange.
The prosperous state of Sweden's national finances is shown in figures issued today by the Ministry of Finance covering the financial year which ended on June 30.
A strong American track and field team dominated the first day's competition in the Stockholm athletic games, which opened at the Stockholm Stadium last night.
Buying beyond expectations marked today, the second day of the "Market Week" being held at the Hotel Statler by the Boston Wholesale Garment Association.
First Race-Sailed Saturday, July 31, over thirty-mile windward-leeward course, won by Ranger, timed in 4:41:15, with margin 17 minutes 5 seconds; Endeavour II timed in 4:58:20.

Dr. Charles Upson Clark, director of the Summer session at City College, was introduced yesterday to sixty members of the Summer staff of the college's School of Business at a luncheon given for him at the George Washington Hotel, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

Invitations have been sent out by Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Louis Lacrosse of this place for the wedding of their daughter Miss Josephine Lacrosse to John Brandon Wherry, son of Dr. Elmer G. Wherry of Newark, on Aug. 21.
Directors of Chautauqua Institution announced today that 7,000 persons gathered in the Summer cultural colony's amphitheatre had contributed $50,000 toward a $1,000,000 endowment fund.

Chatterton Ave, a a 404.10 w Castle Hill Ave, 25x105.7; Mortgage Commission State of N Y against Max Nochman; due, $11.330; taxes, etc, $421; to plaintiff for $1,000. 178th St, E, a c c Vyse Ave, 6-story brick tenement, 100x42.5; Mortgage Commission State of N Y and Title Guarantee and Trust Co against Becram Construction Corp; due, $81,602: to plaintiff for $1,000.
The Flintkote Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the thirteen four-week periods ended on July 17 a net income of $1,358,868 after Federal, State and foreign taxes.
Ascribing his longevity to what he termed the "four browns," Dr. William H. Vail, the second oldest alumnus of Princeton University, celebrated here today his ninetysecond birthday.

Funds for building two more 35,000-ton battleships are to be asked of Congress by the Navy Department in the Appropriation Bill for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1938, Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations, announced today, Tentative construction plans also call for the building of two light cruisers of 7,050 tons each to replace ships of the Omaha class.
The Trorlicht Duncker Carpet Company, Inc., has taken a lease on the building at 630-32 West Fifty-second Street, through to 635-37 West Fifty-first Street, through Williams Co., Inc., brokers.
Democratic Senators are looking forward to next Tuesday, when they propose to drop all their "splits" and controversies and join in honoring Senator Barkley, their newly elected leader.
A ten-round contest between Leonard Del Genio, Harlem welterweight, and Bobby Pacho of California tops the card at Madison Square Garden tonight. Three eights, a six and a four round out the program.

De Sota, a bay colt owned by Paul Bowser, the Boston wrestling promoter, and driven by Tom Berry, won the American Stake for 3-yearold trotters, purse $8,523, today. The race, a final prep for the $40,000 Hambletonian at Goshen, N. Y., next week, attracted a field of ten hopefuls, but one of them, Shirley Hanover, reared and landed on her back at the start of the race and had to be withdrawn.
The child-labor provisions or tne Hours-and-Wage Bill as passed by the Senate contain an inconsistency, the American Retail Federation points out in a bulletin issued yesterday analyzing the measure.

Mrs. Stella M. Crater, wife of Supreme Court Justice Joseph Force Crater, who dropped out of sight just seven years ago tomorrow, came to New York yesterday from her home in Belgrade Lakes, Me., for a radio audition-a microphone interview about her husband's strange disappearance.
The Presidential campaign in 1940 will be a contest between a Democrat and Senator Vandenberg of Michigan, Republican, Postmaster General Farley predicted in an interview today.

"Stella Dallas," Samuel Goldwyn's-remake of the Olive Higgins Prouty drama, with Barbara Stanwyck in the title role and John Boles, Anne Shirley and Alan Hale in supporting parts, makes its initial appearance at the Radio City Music Hall today....

An increased demand was accompanied by a general improvement in prices yesterday in bonds traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Obligations of the carriers especially were sought after and the downward price trend was reversed in this group with major fractional gains the general rule.
The National Mediation Board announced tonight a settlement of the wage dispute between the representatives of fourteen non-operating railroad unions and the Class I railroads of the country.

Senator Frederick Van Nuys of Indiana, one of the Democrats who fought President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the Supreme Court, announced today that he would be a candidate for re-election in 1938.
Dr. Samuel King Johnson, for many years a veterinarian in New York, died suddenly at his home here last night of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 83 years old.

Mvements vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 3 unless specified: At Chefoo: Alden, Barker, Paul Jones, Whipple. At San Diego, Aug. 2: Humphrey King, Sands. At Newport, Aug. 4: Claxton, Erie, Fairfax, Jacob Jones, fanley, Roper, J. F. Talbott.

Miss Janet Olcott, daughter of Mrs. Chauncey Olcott, will be married to William Gerard Cavanagh, son pf Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Cavanagh of Roslyn, L. I., tomorrow at St. Peter's Catholic Church by the Very Rev. Patrick F. Scully, the rector.
Mrs. Marion P. Fhinny of 952 Fifth Avenue, New York City, reported to State police today that jewelry valued at $11,000 had been stolen from her Summer cottage here.

Undeterred by the presence of two smiling policemen and the glare of house lights, thirty members of the newly organized Society for the Booing of Commercial Advertisements in Motion Picture Theatres made their debut at Little Rock's largest theatre tonight.

Today's frequent tacks on the windward leg gave the navigators on the cutter Chelan an afternoon of constant plotting, without respites from their chart work, to record the courses sailed by Ranger and Endeavour II.

Thomas Blower, 22-year-old worker in a Nottingham cigarette factory, swam the English Channel today from Cap Gris Nez to Shakespeare colliery beach, between Dover and Folkestone, in 13 hours 29 minutes.

Turpentine firm. 32c; sales, 144 barrels; receipts, 403 barrels; shipments. 231 barrels; stock, 33,537 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 898; receipts, 1,726; shipments, 1,548: stock, 68,292. Quote--B to N, $7.75; WG, $7.90; WW, X, $8.65.

Forty strike pickets sighed dejectedly yesterday afternoon in front of the Fleischer Studios, Inc., producers of the "Popeye" and "Betty Boop" cartoons, at 1,600 Broadway, between Forty-eighth and Fortyninth Streets. A pet idea of the striking artists had gone up in the air-literally.

The President barely concealed a note of triumph yesterday when he said he would not consent to a renewal of crop loans unless conditioned on the kind of Federal production control which the New Deal has sponsored.

BASEBALL New York Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 161st Street and River Avenue, Bronx ........3:15 P. M. Newark Bears vs. Buffalo Bisons, at Ruppert Stadium, 262 Wilson Avenue, Newark, N. J. ................ 3 P. M. Jersey Giants vs. Rochester Red Wings, at Roosevelt Stadium, Danforth Avenue near West Side Avenue, Jersey City..3 P. M.
The market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $4,511,266,965 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange.

Dr. Friedrich Dibelius, Confessional leader, was released from jail today to prepare for his trial Friday. He will be tried before an emergency court. The nature of the charges is still a secret, but it is believed the decree against "malicious attacks on the State" has been invoked.
A rapid transit tournament with fifteen entries was the feature event today at the annual meeting of the New York State Chess Association at Cazenovia Seminary.

A few hours after the close of a police inquiry in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of brutality by the police in the strike at the Robins Drydock and Repair Company plant, Peter Burban, 52-year-old striker and central figure in the investigations, was beaten by three men in front of his home in Red Hook.

A complete picture of conditions, rates of pay and hours worked-by employes in the grocery manufacturing line will be available for the first time in the history of that industry when hundreds of questionnaires sent out by the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., last week have been tabulated,

Members of the Summer colony and their tennis week guests filled Parrish Memorial Hall tonight when the Southampton Players under the direction of Theodore St. John opened their fourth production for this season with the presentation of "Is Zat So," a comedy by James Gleason and Richard Taber.

SHANGHAI--Emergency conferences by Chinese Government leaders were going on at Nanking. Chiang Kai-shek met with the nation's highest military leaders to decide on a course in face of the Japanese invasion.

Lou Gehrig, the Yankees' $36,000a-year first baseman, who left Columbia College as a youth to become one of baseball's outstanding players, returned to his alma mater yesterday in the role of professor.
Frederick R. Lehlbach, former Republican Representative from the Twelfth New Jersey District, died this morning at his home here at the age of 61. He had been ill for some time with heart disease.

Hopes for revival of non-intervention in Spain, held in official circles for a few hours today, were shattered tonight when the Russian Embassy denied current reports that the Soviet Government was willing to modify its stated objections to the British proposals.

The revamped Giants still seemed to be painfully dragging an anchor today, drifting aimlessly. But in the seventh inning they moved into what might be described as a favorable wind. There was a wild pitch and there was an error.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Jane Taylor Whitney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Taylor Whitney of this place, to Geoffrey V. Azoy, son of Mrs. Anastasio C. M. Azoy of East Orange, N. J., and the late Mr. Azoy.

A sales gain of 20 per cent in the first seven months of this year was reported yesterday by Walter A. McNeill, president of Schrafft Sales Corporation, at the opening of a new showroom and warehouse at 231 Varick Street.

The American Labor party is proud to present to the electorate of New York the present Mayor, Fiorello H. La Guardia, for reelection in the current municipal campaign. He is the greatest Mayor the City of New York has ever had.

The naval commandant in the Canal there was evidence indicating that Zone reported to Washington today an explosion occurred aboard the Pan American-Grace airliner that crashed into the sea off Panama.

Miss Eleanor Thibaut, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Thibaut of this place, has chosen the afternoon of Sept. 10 for her marriage to Charles Francis Smithers, son of Mrs. Oscar Gubelman of New York and the late Charles Smithers.

Five million men, women and children in New York State are benefiting or are enrolled to benefit under the provisions of the Social Security Act, according to a report made public yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg. New York Regional Director of the Social Security Board.
President Roosevelt motored for an hour along the upper reaches of the Potomac River today to inspect two of four sites being considered for a new $4,800,000 naval hospital.

Mrs. Hope Yandell Hanger of Parsonage Lane, Greenwich, was married this morning to John W. Haynes of Rye, N. Y., in a ceremony at the home of the bride. The Rev. William Edwards of New Canaan, Conn., officiated. Only the immediate families were present.

Maurice P. Davidson, chairman of the Progressive City Committee, composed of independent civic groups favoring progressive local government, predicted yesterday that Republican voters throughout the city would support Mayor La Guardia by a ratio of about 7 to 1 in the coming election.

John E. Aldred, head of the New York banking firm of Aldred Co. and its affiliate, the Aldred Investment Trust, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that diversifying of investments is not always the best policy.

A tentative plan has been prepared by an "organization group" of preferred stockholders of United Investment Assurance Trust with a view to the possible recovery of losses incurred by the stockholders.
Two developments added interest today to the campaign for the Republican nomination for Governor of New Jersey.

This lively little port was buzzing today with talk about tuna. On its piers and in its tiny streets one topic persisted. And while some of its merchants and artisans made ready for an influx of anxious anglers, others arranged their affairs so that they could slip away to stalk the leviathans.
Coroner's Physician J. M. McMeans said today a post-mortem examination disclosed that Johnny Page, Chicago lightweight boxer, died of a brain hemorrhage.

The marriage of Miss W. Gladys Nagel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Delos Nagel of Brooklyn and Indian Brook Farm, Newton, N. J., to Frank Rylands Pitt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Pitt of Brooklyn. took place yesterday morning in St. John's Church, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gordon D. Pierce.
Though there is little likelihood that a new farm bill will be adopted before Congress adjourns, President Roosevelt has not lost his interest in the theory of a planned economy for agriculture.

New opportunities for American distillers and distributors of distilled spirits are offered in Alaska, Hawaii and non-contiguous territories of the United States, according to the Department of Commerce, largely because of increased tourist traffic.
Discovery today by Dr. Edwin T. Hubble at Mount Wilson Observatory, Pasadena, Calif., of the year's third new comet was announced tonight by Dr. Harlow Shapley of Harvard Observatory.

The principal foreign exchanges weakened in terms of the dollar yesterday. The pound sterling declined cent to $4.971 5/6and the franc was down 1/8 point to 3.75 1/4 cents. Franc futures, which have lately been improving, were somewhat weaker with a discount of 8 1/2 points under the spot rate quoted for the ninety-day option, against 7 5/8 points on Tuesday.

Edward M. Cook Jr. of Upper Darby, Pa., and John C. Kunkle of Harrisburg won the men's pair championship and Mrs. Robert B. Fuller and Mrs. Mabel Ervin of New York the women's pair championship as these two events were ended today at the Summer tournament of the American Bridge League.
Luncheon, Rotary Club, Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. "Capitalism and Regimentation," James H. R. Cromwell. Metropolitan Museum of Art, 4 P. M. "Ancient Glass," Edwin L. M. Taggart.
Is it only a passing illusion, or is there really some ground for believing that these last few weeks we have heard and seen

General Jose Miaja tonight declared the Insurgent armies had lost 20,000 men battling the Government offensive west of Madrid and suffered a disastrous collapse of morale, due to the Government's surprise attack.

The 147th anniversary of the act of Congress that established the Revenue Cutter Service on Aug. 4, 1790, was celebrated yesterday by the 10,000 officers and men of the United States Coast Guard, successor of the original service.

The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows: In the cotton belt temperatures ranged from moderately subnormal in the East to decidedly above normal in the Western portion of the belt. Widespread substantial rains occurred in the Eastern sections, but elsewhere the weather was mostly fair, with little or no precipitation.

State banks which are members of the Federal Reserve System are subject to the Unemployment Insurance Law and applications made by them for refunds of tax payments should be denied, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. ruled today in giving an opinion to Glenn A. Bowers, head of the division of placement and unemployment insurance. Mr.

As an elephant never forgets, a bear apparently never remembers. The elephants seemed to know Captain Ronald Cheyne-Stout, director of the Central Park Zoo, when he inspected their cages yesterday after a week's vacation.

The report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., for the twelve months ended April 30, 1937, shows a net income, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, of $41,892,538. Gross revenues of the company for the period aggregated $66,032,387, and operating expenses amounted to $34,628,619. No comparisons are available.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 2: Grisham, Lt. Cmdr. C. F., the Oklahoma, to home, relieved from all active duty, about Sept. 1.

10th St, 367-369 E, 40x94.9; Metropolitan Savings Bank to Irmaretta Realty Corp, 291 Broadway, care of M. J. Le Boyer ($50). 51st St, 556 W., 20x75.4; Franklin Savings Bank to Helen L. Torpis, 414' E 81st St ($10). 63d St. 336 E, 25x100.5; Vincent Ryan to A. M. A. Servicing Co, Inc, 1,475 Broadway, care of M. S. Meyers, mtg $18,000 ($5).

Retail food costs declined slightly during the month ended July 13, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1923-25 average, was 85.9 compared with 86.2 on June 15. and 84.0 on July 14. 1936.

Acting in the face of opposition, the Securities and Exchange Commission unanimously insisted today upon the appointment of an independent trustee in the reorganization proceedings of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act before Judge William H. Holly of the Federal Court in Chicago.

Dr. Eberhard Hanfstaengl, director of the Berlin National Gallery and as such an outstanding museum director and art expert in Germany, has become one of the victims of the new art purge ordered by Chancellor Adolf Hitler in his recent Munich speech and initiated by Col. Gen. Hermann Goering yesterday.

The Hospital for Joint Diseases cared for 33,863 patients in 1936, it was shown in the thirtieth annual report, made public yesterday by its president, Frederick Brown. The hospital is one of nine being supported this year by the New York-Brooklyn Jewish Charity Federation drive for $6,250,000.
Payments on open credit accounts receivable of department stores were 46.4 per cent in June of this year, against 47.6 per cent the corresponding month in 1936.

George Jeffcoat of the Dodgers left for St. Louis tonight to consult Dr. Robert Hyland concerning a possible operation for the removal of his appendix. The pitcher had been in a Brooklyn hospital until he rejoined the club in St. Louis.

Charles Stetson brought the Pequot Yacht Club's junior crew home first today in the fifth and final race of the series for the. Commodore Law Cup off the Indian. Harbor Yacht Club Cold Spring Harbor was second.

Henri Morin de Linclays, resident director of the French Line, sailed yesterday on the Normandie on a combined business and pleasure visit to France. Mr. de Linclays said the company was planning no additions to its present tonnage because the entire fleet of transatlantic ships was classed as either new or "young tonnage" and that no replacements would be necessary for some years.

"Rural uplift and improvement of the condition of the peasantry," in words of the official communique, formed the chief topic of conversation when Mohandas K. Gandhi and the Viceroy; the Marquess of Linlithgow, had their long-awaited meeting today.

President Roosevelt's insistence on crop control legislation as a prerequisite to a renewal of price-pegging commodity loans split the Senate and House into warring factions today and threatened further to complicate adjournment plans.

California took the opening game of the Rathborne Memorial Cup tournament at the Narragansett Polo Club today when Lindsay Howard's San Mateo team surprised Bostwick Field by winning with a last second goal by Charles S. Howard Jr., 6 to 5.
The thirtyeight-foot Canadian sloop Phantom, unreported since she left Lunenburg, N. S., Friday en route to the America's Cup yacht races at Newport, R. I., passed through Cape Cod Canal today.
Three men were hurt, one seriously, late today, when a charge of dynamite exploded prematurely at the plant of the Pennington Trap Rock Company in Pennington, near here, where they were employed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The tension has relaxed and a feeling of relief is being experienced which is gratifying to all who still have confidence in a democratic form of government, whether they belong to the Democratic party or the Republican party. All may view the early adjournment of Congress with more equanimity, and more hope for the subsidence of antagonisms during the ensuing intermission.

Complete divorcement of the dollar from any theoretical or practical connection with gold would so dislocate international currencies that the "monetary managers" would be willing to come to agreement on a "common denominator," the Thomas subcommittee of the Senate Agriculture Committee was told today by Rena Leon, monetary expert of Princeton.
Bernie Friedman, Merion, Pa., seeded seventh, was upset by Louis F. Kruger in a three-hour fourthround match in the Eastern States men's tennis championship today. The scores were 10-8, 2-6, 6-3.

Miss Frances Bancroft of Wilmington scored a surprise victory over Miss Laura Pittenger, Philadelphia, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3, today in a quarterfinal match in the women's Eastern States clay court tennis championships.

Martin Gilbert of New York denied today allegations made by the Securities and Exchange Commission that he was only a figurehead underwriter of stock issued last year by the Trenton Valley Distillers Corporation of Detroit.

Gus Dorais of the University of Detroit regained first place today in the all-star football coach voting with 878,373 points. Dorais, the early leader in the balloting to select a coaching staff to prepare the College All-Stars for their battle against the Green Bay Packers on Sept. 1 at Soldier Field,

After evading investigators for two years, Joseph R. 'Simon, described by Attorney General Bennett's office as a race track tipster, was held here yesterday for removal to Saratoga County, where he was named in indictments in 1935.

A contract for 10,000 square feet of space in the New York World's Fair of 1939 has been signed by the Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc., Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair corporation, announced yesterday.

Lawrence, Blake Jewell, Inc., have arranged for York Enterprises, Inc., a first mortgage of 5150,000 on the six-story and basement apartment at 159-63 E. 88th St. The Kingsboro Mortgage Corp., as principal, has made. first-mortgage temporary building loans aggregating $287,500, as follows: $82,500 for the Joyfed Realty Corp.

Just as soon as possible after he returned yesterday from the country to his tenement home at 1,435 First Avenue, near Seventy-Fourth Street, 20-month-old Kenneth Golden clambered onto a chair in the kitchen.
The Liberal party has formally proclaimed Eduardo Santos its candidate for President in the next eleations. The Conservatives have no candidate.

Coming around his field with a show of power flashed by no other 3-year-old at the meeting, Burning Star from the Shandon Farm today won the $6,575 Saranac Handicap by a nose in a fighting finish with Forty Winks.

With a sparkling round of 81, only a few strokes above women's par for the course, Mrs. Ray M. Torgerson of Queens Valley today gained the honors in the one-day tournament of the Long Island Women's Golf Association at the Creek Club.
Superintendent Edward W. Fallon ordered police today to keep a sharp lookout for watch-charm pistols after an inch-long weapon, capable of seriously wounding a person, had been seized.
Eight days after her 102d birthday Mrs. Anna M. Mulford Irelan died today at the home in Ventnor of her daughter, Mrs. Frank K. Walsh.

Senator McKellar, chairman of the Committee on Postoffices and Post Roads, told the Senate Tuesday that there is no hope of passage by the Senate of the bill requiring that first, second and third class postmasters be appointed without term by the Postmaster General in accordance with the provisions of the Civil Service Act and rules.

Representative Dickstein of New York City inserted in the Congressional Record today an additional list of persons he said "are spreading unAmerican propaganda throughout our country," and a group of firms he said were dealing in German securities "without a permit either from the State or from the Securities Exchange Commission."

Undercover agents brought from the West Coast to trap Pompeo Perfetto, dealer in counterfeit money who was arrested last week and held In bail of $3,000, have broken up a source of supply of the notorious Sicilian Syndicate, Captain William H.-Houghton, chief of the Secret Service, announced yesterday after the arrest of seven other members of the gang.

Retail parcel deliveries in the metropolitan area in. the week ended July 31 increased 11 per cent over those for the corresponding 1936 week, the United Parcel Service reported yesterday. The gain for the four week ended July 31 was 8 per cent.

A collective bargaining referendum for the 3,500 taxicab drivers, mechanics and garage men employed by the National Transportation Company, Inc., will be held next Tuesday, the State Labor Relations Board announced yesterday.

Following furtheir disturbances among Basque refugee children-this time among girls at a Roman Catholic charity home in Manchester-the British Government informed the committee responsible for bringing 4,000 Basque children to Britain that coneditions at Bilbao will soon be sufficiently normal for their return."

The all-day Saturday closing which has been in effect during the Summer months in the offices of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, Inc., will be continued the year around, James H. McGraw Jr., chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

The first anniversary of the Metaxas regime was solemnly celebrated today throughout Greece. Officially organized ceremonies and celebrations took place in every city and town, and Premier John Metaxas' achievements were lauded.

The stock markets here were quiet but better in tone today, although some sections suffered from profit-taking. Gilt-edge issues were in demand, while foreign loans were dull. International issues, under the lead of United States Steeel, recovered, and the section advanced.

Nat Andrews, who went the route for the Red Wings in the opener, set the Jerseys down with seven hits, no two of which came in any one inning. The youthful righthander walked three and struck out three. Glen Gabler, who started and finished for the Jerseys, was touched for ten hits by the Wings but loose support on the part of his mates handicapped his work considerably.
The twice-amended and long-delayed plan of reorganization of the Standard Gas and Electric Company is to be changed once again, this time radically, it was learned yesterday.

Aspirin and common sense Imparted daily in strong doses cured a native couple of "devil-devil." When the couple fell ill they consulted a witch doctor, who told them they were victims of bhnone-pointing."
"Rumors that the Bulgarian Government has concluded'an agreement with Germany are quite unfounded and are malicious fabrications," Premier George Kiosseivanoff told Bulgarian newspaper men today.
The Government today categorically denied rumors of its pending resignation. Despite this denial, however, this city is buzzing with rumors of a new Cabinet of National Peasant party Ministers.

Grover A. Whalen withdrew last night as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor in favor of former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney, who announced his willingness to run as the candidate of the Democratic organizations of the four counties outside of Manhattan against Senator Royal S. Copeland, the candidate of Tammany.
Backlogs of steel orders are steadily declining, affording better deliveries to customers, but are still substantial enough to assure acontinued high rate of production through August, Iron Age says.

There was no longer any question in the mind of T. O. M. Sopwith tonight that his second quest of the America's Cup had come to grief, that it was doomed to the frustration he met three years ago with the smaller and older yacht Endeavour.

General Yang Fu-cheng, rebellious military leader of Shensi Province in China at the time he and Marshal Chang Hsueh-liang kidnapped Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, sailed yesterday on the French liner Normandie to continue in England and France his studies of military and economic conditions in Europe and the United States.
Chicago at New York-Stratton vs. Chandler. St. Louis at Washington-Walkup vs. Weaver. Detroit at Philadelphia-Auker vs. Smith.

Commenting on published reports that an increase of $30,000,000 in next year's budget was indicated, Joseph Goldsmith, president of the Taxpayers Union, wrote to Mayor La Guardia yesterday reminding him that when he ran for the Mayoralty four years ago he promised to cut the city budget by $50,000,000.

Officials of St. Paul, Minn., awarded yesterday to two different banking groups two new issues of bonds aggregating $665,000. Phelps, Fenn Co. and the Wells-Dickey Company of Minneapolis, on a bid of 100.04 for 2.4's, won $500,000 of sewer bonds maturing on Aug. 1, 1940 to 1967.

William Dodd, Ambassador to Germany, said today that despite the tragic experience of the World War, the nations of the world, and especially those of Europe, were rushing madly into debt as they armed for another world war that would probably destroy civilization.

Mike Jacobs gained virtual control of big time boxing in New York City yesterday when he leased Madison Square Garden and the Garden Bowl for two Winter seasons and as many Summers, while the Garden moved out of the fight game's richest field, which it dominated since Tex Rickard leased the old Garden.
Fred Berger, in conjunction with George E. Polhemus, attorney, who has been associated with F. W. Scutt Co., Inc., has organized firm to be known as Jamaica Brokers, Inc.

Severe fighting is believed imminent at Nankow, thirty miles northwest of Peiping, between Chinese Government troops and an advancing Japanese force, the Chinese Embassy here was informed today by the Nanking Government.

Augmented today by a grim, gray line of four-stack Navy destroyers which arrived in Newport with Annapolis midshipmen on their training cruise and quite naturally took them offshore this afternoon for the cup race, the spectator fleet had its best afternoon of the series.
John M. Hayes of Mahwah, N. J., accused of abducting his daughter from her grandmother in California, won temporary custody today of the child, who is 28 months old.

It was a "human fly" burglar who last Sunday night victimized three United States women in a de luxe Avenue Montaigne hotel, according to a preliminary police inquiry, which indicates the burglar must have entered from outside, and the apartment is located on the fifth floor.

An accounting made public in the Surrogate's Court yesterday reveals how a net estate of $50,000,000, left by William Rockefeller in 1922, is growing in capital value at the rate of $1,000,000 a year, for the benefit of his infant and unborn greatgrandchildren, who are to be the first to divide it.
President Roosevelt approved today a plan of the Bituminous Coal Commission to put almost all its employes under Civil Service through non-competitive examination.
The cabled summary of the League of Nations year-book on the world's financial trends illustrates the difficulty of drawing definite conclusions from present known phenomena.

It has been widely rumored that Samuel Goldwyn was made unhappy by Alva Johnston's study, "The Great Goldwyn." However, Random House, the book's publishers, report that Mr. Goldwyn has given more than a thousand copies of the book to friends, and is still sending in additional lists.

Many of the leases for apartments reported yesterday involved suites in the Park Avenue zone, as well as on Riverside Drive and West End Avenue. The list follows: Mrs. Ethel F. Ford, through Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, in 280-90 Park Ave; Miss P. Moir, through Golet Realty Co. in 144 E 45th St; Butler Baldwin, Inc, broker.

Appealing to the voters of the city to support a progressive, honest, and efficient administration and prevent the return of a corrupt Tammany clique to control of the city government, the State executive committee of the American Labor party nominated Mayor La Guardia for re-election last night.

PATROLMAN--Charles F. Carvin, from 60th Precinct to 11th Precinct. Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN--From precincts indicated to office of second deputy police commissioner, Division of Licenses, assigned to duty as inspectors of licensed hacks, for 11 days, Oscar W. Ryan, 28; Robert M. Maston, 32.

The trio of juniors representing Westhampton won the fifth annual competition for the Guiden Trophy today and permanently retired the trophy. Represented by A. C. Nagle Jr., M. R. Fink and E. Edward Nash, the club scored 58 points, one more than the runner-up, Point O' Woods. The Narrasketuck crew was third.
Engineering construction awards in July gained 14 per cent over the same month of last year, but fell below the high volume of May and June this year, according to Engineering News-Record.

A partnership to be known as Ionard S. Gans, Zeckendorf, Morrir Company, consisting of Leonard So Gans, William Zeckendorf and Herbert Jacques Morris, has been formed to take over the business of Leonard S. Gans Conipany, Inc.
The District of Columbia tax bill carrying the Miller-Tydings price maintenance rider, went to the White House today after Senate approval of the conference report.
Mrs. Violet D. Schmidt, wife of Professor Edward C. Schmidt, head of the Department of Railway Engineering in the University of Illinois, died Monday after a long illness. She was 70 years old.
Henry Oliver Thompson, for many years prominent in legal and club circles, died last night at his home in Riderwood, near Baltimore, at the age of 72.

Harris Hammond, son of the late John Hays Hammond, who earns $20,000 a year, must pay $160 a month to liquidate a judgment for $1,838,755 against him, Federal Judge John C. Knox decreed yesterday, signing a garnishee order.

First Baseman Henry Davis's triple in the sixth inning with the bases loaded today gave St. Louis a 5-to-3 triumph over Washington. It broke up a pitching battle between Oral Hildebrand and Jimmy Deshong.

The World Conference on Faith and Order decided today to determine a common ground upon which all Christianity could take a stand before moving on to a discussion of seemingly irreconcilable differences of opinion.

Patricia, Countess of Jersey, first wife of the ninth Earl of Jersey, who married Virginia Cherrill, the actress, on July 30, has announced her engagement to Robert Filmer Wilson, London stockbroker. Lord and Lady Jersey were granted a final divorce decree July 19.

An auction sale of all interests of the late Florenz Ziegfeld in seventytwo of his best-known theatrical productions, scheduled for tomorrow in the Westchester County Courthouse, was postponed to Sept. 29 today by Surrogate William J. Sheils.

The three Russian fliers who established a world distance record in June when they flew from Moscow to California sailed yesterday on the French liner Normandie. They said they were returning to their homeland with the impression that if the friendly international feelings observed in the United States could be transplanted in other nations there would be no fear of war.
The British yachts out for the America's Cup race presented a pretty spectacle today, all dressed up in honor of Queen Elizabeth's birthday anniversary.

The stage is all set at Tanglewood, midway between Lenox and Stockbridge, for the first Boston Symphony concert tomorrow night at 8:30 in the fourth Berkshire Music Festival. Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, conductor, and Mrs. Koussevitzky are at the Berkshire Hunt and Country Club, Lenox.

Miss Ruth Hughes Aarons of New York was accorded top position among America's women stars for the fourth straight year, Reginald G. Hammond, chairman of the United States Table Tennis Association's ranking committee, announced today.

Former President Hoover recommended, in a letter made public today, that support be given in the 1938 elections to national legislators, Republican or Democratic, who have "actively attacked" President Roosevelt's Supreme Court plan.

The Rev. and Mrs. Lewis G. Morris were hosts at a dinner at Spalding Inn today in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. N. Ringe and T. B. N. Ringe Jr. of Philadelphia. Mrs. Sterling Elliott also gave a dinner there.

United States and British petroleum companies operating in Mexico in a public statement today characterized as "grossly unfair and misleading" the recommendations issued last night by the Government investigating committee that the wages of 18,000 oil workers should be raised $7,000,000 annually.

The Eastern College all-star football team was strongly reinforced today when Vannie Albanese, captain of the 1937 Syracuse University team and for the last three years its leading ground-gainer, accepted an invitation to join the squad.

Everett Johnson Peck Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Peck of New York and Bridgehampton, L. I., is at the Newport Hospital, badly injured as the result of an airplane crash at Newport Airport yesterday morning.

A four-for-one split of the Commonwealth Edison Company capital stock and the issuance of sufficient additional new shares to acquire the outstanding common and preferred shares of the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois has been approved by the Illinois Commerce Commission.

The drive for quick adjournment of Congress appeared to be fast bogging down tonight with new controversies developing over the remaining items on the Administration's legislative slate, and President Roosevelt letting it be known that he was waiting with a veto for the compromise Sugar Quota Bill supported by a powerful group in the Senate and House.

The marriage of Miss Lilia E. Arguedas, daughter of J.
