Arthur Arguedas, Bolivian Vice Consul, and Mrs. Arguedas of Forest Hills, to Paul Andrew Springer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Otto Springer of Columbus, Ohio, took place yesterday morning in the rectory of the Church of Our Lady, Queen of Martyrs, in Forest Hills. The Rev.

Robert R. Young, head of America's largest railway system, testified before a Senate investigating committee today that he paid $15,000 for "a flock" of Democratic National Convention books and would have "taken soap wrappers if they had offered them to me."

A gala reception, including a parade behind a military band, will be given for the United States Davis Cup team when it returns this afternoon aboard the United States liner Manhattan, bearing with it the international tennis trophy which is coming back to the country of its origin for the first time since 1927, according to The Associated Press.

MUNICIPAL BOOKBINDER--Salary: $2.240 per annum; pension; fair sick leave. Vacancies: One vacancy; one appointment made from last list. Ages: 21 through 45, on Aug. 17. Applications: Received to 4 P. M., Tuesday, Aug. 17, Room 1400, Municipal Building, Manhattan. Subjects and Weights: Experience, weight 4, 70 per cent required; practical test, weight 6, 75 per cent required;. 75 per cent general average renuired.

With play in the singles at a standstill for the day, two rounds of doubles were run off in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament before large galleries at the Meadow Club today, two of the four seeded American teams going down in defeat.

The Nicholson File Company has sold to the Murphy Door Bed Company of New York a part of its plant at Paterson, N. J., consisting of about 122,000 square feet, with a one-story factory building whose floor space totals approximately 40,000 square feet, and a railroad siding.

Joe Louis and James J. Braddock met today for the first time since they parted in the ring at Comiskey Park in Chicago, where the heavyweight championship went to the Detroit boxer. It was as if there had never been a fight between them.

Deposits by the public in the 420 banking institutions of Pennsylvania increased $41,315,707 in the year ended on June 30, according to a report made public yesterday by Luther Harr, Secretary of Banking. In the period the number of bank depositors rose 129,148 to a total of 3,849,548.

There is a tendency in French political circles-at first inclined to view Italo-British rapprochement with skepticism or anxiety-to await developments more calmly. There must have been assurances forthcoming from London that the talks with Rome would not in any way jeopardize the Anglo-French working agreement. That was the fear apparent in early comment.

Recording their seventh and eighth straight victories-their longest winning streak. since Tom Yawkey purchased the club in 1933-the Red Sox twice came from behind today to down the Indians, 8 to 6 and 6 to 5, and approach within one game of the second-place White Sox.

Charles Swart, president of the Decatur Chapter of the American Newspaper Guild, announced tonight that members had voted 6 to 4 to end a strike against The Decatur Herald and Review, morning and evening newspapers here.
The War Department was notified today of the death in Burlington, Vt., yesterday of Colonel Frank E. Hopkins, retired, at the age of 63.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Klemann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Adam Klemann of Montclair, was married this afternoon in the home of her parents to Perry Speer Huntoon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel White Huntoon of East Orange.
Manuel Rivas Vicuna, Liberal politician, former Premier and former chief of Chile's delegation to the League of Nations, died today. He was 57 years old.
Some unsuspected power in Brooklyn bats was released today as the Dodgers outscored the Pirates, 10-7, and regained a sixth place tie with the Reds. The paid attendance was 1,594.

Judge Lynn B. Griffith told' four convicted steel strike bombers today that they did "not represent union labor" but "a loathsome fanaticism," and sentenced them to serve one to twenty years in Ohio State prison.

Expansion of a downtown area into a wholesale paper center was indicated in a deal reported yesterday by Spear Co., Inc., brokers, who leased the five-story building at 418-22 West Broadway, through to 9k96 Thompson Street, to the A. G. Nelson Paper Company, now at 220 West Eighteenth Street.
Queen Elizabeth returned with King George VI to the highlands of her youth today for her first birthday anniversary as Queen and the traditional royal holiday at Balmoral Castle.

Electric power production declined less than seasonally last week, but the adjusted index remained unchanged at 106.5 after the adjustment for long-term growth. For the week ended Aug. 1, 1936, it was 103.9.
The opening of the Fall school term for millions of children brought to view today an apparent new anti-Semitism drive in German education.

Fifty-seven yearlings were sold tonight for $121,300 in a sale which lasted almost until midnight. The top price of $9,600 was paid early by John Hay Whitney for a bay colt by Pharamond II and out of Great Gossip. This youngster was sold by W. L. Nutter and Hal Price Headley.

Crestfallen and shy, Alfred A. Knopf Jr., 19-year-old son of the publisher, arrived this afternoon at Newark Airport by plane, homeward bound from a Western hitchhiking trip taken with $15 and without parental permission.

John J. Hughes Jr., 28 years old, who was returned to this country from Germany after being accused of murdering an elderly man on a Berlin street, was admitted to the psychiatric division of Grasslands Hospital here today.

Leander Langrall, one of the leaders in the fruit and oyster canning industry in Baltimore, died early today at the Atlantic City Hospital, where he was taken Sunday evening after being taken ill while on vacation. He was 79 years old.
Village officials here today found themselves with two lawsuits on their hands because they had destroyed a noble old oak tree, a pride of the residents. The suits involve $25,000.

Painters, sculptors and members of society in the Berkshire and Litchfield Hills and Southern Vermont assembled at the Berkshire Museum this afternoon for the varnishing day reception of the twentyninth annual Stockbridge exhibition.

Players preparing for the national open polo championship at Meadow Brook next month took part in a practice match at Schiff Field today, with the Reds, consisting of three members of the Aknusti quartet, which is entered in the open, and J. H. (Jock) Whitney's White riders battling to a 5-5 deadlock.
The purge of "enemies of the people" by the Soviet Government, economic organizations and the Communist party has extended into another constituent republic--Tadjikastan.

It would be easier to track down criminals if police knew their nicknames, Edward P. Mulrooney, State Correction Commissioner, believes, so he has ordered New York prison officials to record these monickers.

By JAMES R. MURPHY 84th St. 270. W, 5-story brick -club building, :3.8x102.2; Central Hanover Bank Trust Co against Republican Organization Club 3f the Seventh Assembly. District, Inc. lue, S29,908, taxes, etc., $540; to plain1Lf for $27,545.

The British Palestinian policy gained its first ground today when Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the World Zionist Congress, made an eloquent though guarded plea in favor of the partition principle to the biennial congress here.

Wonder of the sea so far, the great Ranger today won her third straight race in the America's Cup series. She defeated the challenger Endeavour II, 4 minutes and 27 seconds over a windward and leeward course of thirty miles.

Aaron Gold of 1,400 Clinton Avenue, the Bronx, was the only person of 4,302 who turned in papers in the Goldman Band music memory contest on the Central Park Mall last night whose score was 100 per cent.

The Yale Alumni Weekly, privately owned publication, will hereafter be published under the direction of the Yale Alumni Board in order more closely to consolidate the magazine with alumni interests, it was announced today.
Traffic through the Panama Canal decreased slightly last month, the War Department reported today.
Clubbing three pitchers for seventeen hits, the Detroit Tigers defeated the Athletics today, 11 to 7. It was the Bengals' first victory in seven starts.

IF you would like to know a little more about America, spend half an hour or so reading "Dear Mr. President" (Dutton, $1). This is a brief selection of letters salvaged from the White House mail. It was compiled by Ben Whitehurst, former chief of the Correspondence Division, FERA and WPA. Mr. Whitehurst tried to find the funniest letters, and many of them are funny.

While the United States chess players in the international team tournament at the Grand Royal Hotel completed two unfinished matches with Yugoslavia in the fourth round and Argentina in the sixth today, winning the first by 3-1 and the second by 2 1/2--1 1/2, Poland moved into first place.

Equity Corporation-Net assets on June 30 were equivalent to about $8,273.65 for each $1,000 principal amount of assumed debentures, $90.42 a preferred share, and $2.24 a common share. This compares with net assets equivalent to $3.12 a share on the common stock on Dec. 31 and to $2.10 a common share on June 30, 1936.

John E. Joyce, referee in bankruptcy, sitting yesterday as a spew cial master, recommended that the amended plan of reorganization for the Warner-Quinlan Company be confirmed. He listed the assets of the company at $12,398,972 and its liabilities at $18,492,402.

Governor Lehman declined today to make any comment on the fact that President Roosevelt's Court Bill had been sent back to committee. The Governor recently wrote to Senator Wagner that he was opposed to changes in the United States Supreme Court.

Eustace Conway, a lawyer here for more than fifty years, died Tuesday at his home, 40 Monroe Street, in Knickerbocker Village. He was 78 years old. Mr. Conway, who had been an invalid for several years following a fall, was the victim of pneumonia.

President Roosevelt served notice on Congress today that he would veto the Sugar Control Bill, scheduled to be taken up in the House tomorrow, if it were passed in its present form with restrictions on imports of refined sugar from Hawaii and Puerto Rico.
The Cabinet approved the supplementary budget for North China today, amounting to 408,000,000 yen, of which the navy gets 100,000,000. The total asked for North China to date is 517,000,000 yen.

Twenty-six agreements constitute the results of the month's conferences here between Bolivian and Chilean economic experts, brought together to draw up a pact to foster trade between the two countries with special privileges and mutual concessions.

The Gaylord Container Corporation of St. Louis has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 100,000 shares of outstanding $50 par value 5 1/2 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock and 810,000 shares of $5 par value common stock, the commission announced today.

Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, attacked yesterday the moves of the Loyalist government in Spain to try opponents on charges of sedition. "Every government at war has a right to deal drastically with spies and traitors." he said.

By a standing vote announced by Speaker Bankhead as 205 to 0, the House passed and sent to the Senate late today the so-called Gold Star Mothers' Bill, adding an estimated $8,952,000 to the annual cost of the Veterans' Administration.

The American Smelting and Refining Company yesterday advanced the price of lead 1/4-cent a pound to 6 1/4 cents at New York. The St. J Joseph Lead Company made a similar price rise to 6 1/4 cents here and to 6.10 cents at East St. Louis.
The Winter forecast of elegance continues in the Paris showings. Patou's collection excels in evening gowns. There are several sensational black ones.

Mills H. Husted's Rumour won the weekly Atlantic Class race at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today, finishing more than 2 minutes ahead of H. R. Kunhardt Jr.'s Lotus. There was a light southsouthwest wind throughout the race.
Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Langhorne of Washington gave a dinner this evening at Saltair, their Summer residence, in honor of Mr. and Mrs. - Chauncey G. McCormick of Chicago.

The Japanese moves in North China are being watched with the keenest interest and some anxiety in the principal European chancelleries. But that is all. Neither interest nor anxiety is likely to produce active interference--diplomatic or military.
The Chase National Bank, as trustee, is notifying holders of the Virginia Electric and Power Company first and refunding mortgage bonds, Series A, 4 per cent, due on Nov. 1, 1955,

Estate, $900. To Mae Riener, niece, 1,904 Gray St., Houston, Texas, residue. Peter L. Beggi, 216 E. 83d St., executor. COBURN, RALPH G. (June 21). Estate, less than $10,000. To Katherine R. Coburn, former wife, Wareham, Mass., residue. Ralph G. Coburn Jr., son, executor, 54 Chestnut St.. Boston Mass.
Experts and others who have been out for all three cup races got their first real close-up of the rivals today from the deck of the Coast Guard cutter Argo.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney-the T. stands for Titus-is perhaps best known to this generation of New Yorkers as a former Supreme Court Justice and the present head of the Amateur Athletic Union. His public career, however, traces back through a long succession of posts almost to the time when he was admitted to the bar in 1899.

The Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill was amended today by the Senate to limit the cost of family dwellings to $4,000 each, a provision Senator Wagner said might prove paralyzing to a slum clearance and low cost program for cities of the East because of the relatively high construction costs.
State Labor Commissioner John J. Toohey Jr. reported today that manufacturing employment during June rose 0.2 per cent, while average weekly payrolls declined 1.2 per cent in comparison with May.
Gentlemen: I told you when I expressed the willingness to accept the Democratic designation for Mayor that if a more available candidate could be found I would yield in his favor.

Mrs. Chandler Cudlipp and James Wideman Lee 2d gave a supper party last night at the home of their mother, Mrs. Ivy L. Lee of 911 Park Avenue, for Miss Virginia Street and their brother, Ivy L. Lee Jr., whose marriage will take place on Aug. 14 in the Church of the Incarnation.
Jake Powell came out of a discouraging batting slump yesterday to give the Yankees a ninth-inning victory over the White Sox in a storybook finish to an exciting ball game.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition Filed-Against NUOVA MONDO MOTION PICTURES, INC., 630 9th Ave., by Salvatore Do Genaro, for $712; Leo Seligman, $3,335; Leon Fromkess, $20,963. Judge Leibell appointed Joseph I. Carroll receiver under $5,000 bond. Judgments were obtained recently against the corporation by Consolidated Film Industries, Inc.; De Luxe Laboratories, Inc., and Du Art Film Laboratories, Inc. A schedule sale of assets to satisfy the judgments was stayed.

President Roosevelt today vetoed a bill to change the name of the army's Chemical Warfare Service to "Chemical Corps," on the ground that it would tend to dignify a branch of the army engaged in studies of a type of warfare "inhuman and contrary to what modern civilization should stand for."

More than 100 men, including State and village policemen and volunteer firemen, joined in a search here tonight for 2-year-old Thomas Chasas, who disappeared at 8:30 P. M. from the home of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Peter Chasas, on Locust Avenue.
There was a smoker at Newport Beach tonight for the sailors of H. M. S. York, which is in port for the America's Cup races as the official representative of the British Navy.

Canadian wheat in store in the week ended on July 30 was 33,285,281 bushels, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. This was nearly 2,000,000 bushels below the 35,196,133 the previous week and 87,000,000 lower than the 120,770,919 in the corresponding week of 1936.
Recovery from steel strikes, The Iron Age reports, is shown by July pig-iron production, which totaled 3,498,858 gross tons, against 3,107,506 tons in June, when many furnaces were idle.

This ancient Chinese city has taken on the appearance of celebrating a French holiday. French flags are everywhere. The native flagmakers were swamped with orders for flags of their various countries to fly from their homes and motor cars for protection.

Miss Elizabeth Lippincott, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Lippincott of Sydbury House, Wynnewood, was married this afternoon to William Hamilton Coulson, son of William Coulson of Durham, England, and the late Mrs. Coulson.
Church bells tolled throughout Belgium today to remind the nation that twenty-three years ago German troops crossed the frontier, drawing Belgium into the World War.

Smoldering antagonism between the United Automobile Workers and the Independent Association of Chrysler Employes flared into violence this afternoon at the Plymouth Motor Company plant and ten men were injured before the plant was closed.

Mrs. Prudence Paine Livingston, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert C. Paine of Thompson, Conn., and widow of Tracy K. Livingston, was Married to Roman Kwiecien of this city yesterday afternoon in the Chapel of St. Ambrose in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward Hawkins.
Salvadorean consuls are required by a recent decree to procure copies of commercial invoices of all goods before legalizing consular invoices for exportations to El Salvador.

Lady Higloss, a speedy mare from Miss A. Doris's stable, the nom de course of Mrs. Harvey Campbell, finally came into her own at Suffolk Downs today by winning the Continental Handicap, six-furlong feature, to pay $12.20 for $2.

C. G. Pfeiffer, president of the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., and Harry Radcliffe, secretary of the organization, left last night for Washington to gather first-hand information on the status of legislation on the tariff and other laws affecting imported merchandise.

One or more persons may make a contract for exploration and exploitation of the Government's petroleum lands, according to executive decree clarifying Article 3 of the law of 1936 amending the petroleum code of 1931.

A little paper published for the passengers aboard certain Lake Erie steamers (and bearing the inviting name The Lake Erie Breeze) relates with pride that the late President Cleveland often visited the Put-In-Bay waters of Lake Erie on fishing trips, and it revives the story of a famous conversation" with his fishing companion Samuel L. Powers.

Mrs. Juliet White Hilliard and Eugene Williams Allen were married at noon today at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. William Henry Smith, by the Rev. W. F. Carpenter, rector of Christ Church, Haymarket, Va. Mr. Allen, a native of Brooklyn, is a member of the county Agricultural Advisory Board and director of the People's National Bank. His bride is the daughter of the late Rev. Dr. Robert Baker White of Greenwich, Va.

State Senator Philip M. Kleinfeld of Coney Island was designated yesterday by the Brooklyn Democratic organization's executive committee as the party's choice for Borough President. The committee also designated Sheriff Peter J. McGuinness for the office of Register and Assemblyman James V. Mangano for Sheriff.

A fiverun rally in the ninth inning, capped by Manager Frankie Frisch's pinch single with the bases full, gave the Cardinals a 7-to-6 victory over the Bees today. The victory enabled St. Louis to tie the Pirates for third place in the National League.

Reports of a sale of Russian wheat to Greece and submission in London of samples of grain from the former country unsettled the world's markets in wheat early today, with Liverpool at one time showing a decline of 5 cents a bushel from Tuesday's levels.

David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, sailed yesterday on the Normandie of the French Line for Salzburg, where he plans to confer with Arturo Toscanini, Italian conductor, on a series of radio broadcasts to be given in the Fall.

MEN'S DOUBLES First Round William Robertson and I. A. Powell defeated Leads Wetherel and Robert Kamrath,, 6-4, 7-5. Second Bound John Van Ryn and Modeste Alloo defeated Robertson and Powell, 4--6, 8-6, 7-5; Charles Harris and Harold Surface
George E. Thompson, secretary of the Yale University Alumni Fund since 1918, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Cheshire. He was 63 years old.

Paul Scott Mowrer, editor of The Chicago Daily News, has been elected chairman of the provisional board of governors of the American Press Society, a professional association of newspaper men and women now completing its organization.

A picket line of children, 200 strong, successfully protested here this morning the City Council's decision to discontinue improving a vacant lot at Burnside and Carroll Streets for use as a playground.

Price movements of commodity futures were generally higher in moderate activity on the local markets yesterday. On the cash markets all the grains, cocoa, raw sugar, lead, tin, silk, rubber and cotton advanced, but flour, eggs, lard and wool tops fell.

Plans for the reorganization of he International Seamen's Union, Ihich include its continuance as a time affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, have been virually completed after a series of conferences here and in Washingon, it was announced yesterday.
Phil F. Miller of French Lick Springs, Ind., broke 498 today to win the amateur 500-target championship of the fifteenth annual T. Clarence Marshall shoot today.

If present estimates hold, the city's expense budget for 1938 will run about $30,000,000 higher than the level reached this year. The additional money will have to come from somewhere, and it cannot be manufactured on printing presses at the City Hall.

Harry Balsamo, slugging subway brakeman, gave Al Diamond of Paterson a beating in gaining the decision in their ten-round feature bout at Dyckman Oval last night. Though he threw his famed right many times, he could not drop his rival but had him wavering in the ninth.

Three years ago Wilbur Rothar, who lived with his wife and eight children at 316 East 155th Street, the Bronx, journeyed to Roosevelt Field, L. I., in the hope of seeing Amelia Earhart make a routine landing in her plane.

Acting Finance Minister Villela denied today that United States pressure caused the cancellation of the deal with Germany for the purchase of 100,000 bags of coffee for resale in Central Europe. He said Brazil's action was dictated by convenience.
An officially announced settlement of the sympathy strike of 10,000 truck drivers and warehousemen failed to end this city's troubles.
The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated Aug. 3: LIEUTENANT COLONEL Phillips, H. F. Med. Corps, Edgewood Arseal, Md., about Oct. 30, to Ft. Ontario, N. Y.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel D. Riddle entertained at a luncheon today for Mr. and Mrs. Morton L. Schwartz of New York, Mrs. Norman Whitehouse, Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Hopkins, Herbert Bayard Swope, George H. Bull and Carter Bowie.

Leave of absence is granted to Captain Terence J. Smith, Engr.-Res., five days, Aug. 3, 1937; Captain Allen W. Haskell, C.A.*Res., one month, Aug. 14, with permission to leave the United States. Paragraph 21, Special Orders 165. July 19, 1937, relating to 2d Lt. Joseph J. Longohardl, Inf.-Res., is revoked.

Driving into a stiff breeze from the lake side, Miss Maureen Orcutt, twice runner-up for the national title, and Miss Virginia Guilfoil, Syracuse champion, swept through their first-round matches in the annual women's international invitation golf tournament at the Hotel Champhain Golf Club today.
Very few cases of infantile paralysis have been reported in New York City so far this year, Dr. William H. Best, Acting Commissioner of the Department of Health, reported yesterday.

Miss Virginia Kelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Kelly of this city and Lawrence, L. I., has chosen Aug. 25 as the date for her marriage to Luke A. Burke, son of Mrs. Luke A. Burke, also of this city, and the late Mr. Burke.

Domestic sales of electric household refrigerators in the first six months of this year amounted to 1,586,449, valued at $135,925,937, according to the report issued yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

The marriage of Miss Lucy Margaret Jackson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Jackson of Mount Vernon, to Donald Chadwick Dayton, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Nelson Dayton of Minneapolis, took place here this afternoon at the Westchester Country Club.

Turning in a fine 83, Mrs. Edmund S. Whitman of the Wykagyl Golf Club took low gross honors in the weekly Westchester-Fairfield one-day golf tournament held today at St. Andrew's Gold Club. Mrs. Whitman was out in 43 and played the incoming nine in three fewer strokes.

Retired Battalion Chief John Kirwin, formerly of the 18th Battalion, residing 2,916 Philip Ave., Bronx, died Aug. 4. Funeral will take place from the above residence, at 9:30 A. M., Saturday, Aug. 7.q
Surprising even admirers by her speed and finishing ability was the Pharamond II filly Creole Maid, who today captured the twentieth running of the $4,050 Schuylerville Stakes.
City, State and Federal contributions to New York City's schools and colleges will exceed $240,000,000 for the coming year, school officials estimated yesterday.

Mlle. Jadwiga Jedrzejowska, champion of Poland, gained the final round of the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club today. Following her hardfought match of yesterday with Miss Dorothy Bundy, the Polish girl overpowered Miss Gracyn Wheeler of Santa Monica, Calif., 6-0, 6-3.

Tiebout Ave, 2,160-80 (11-3143); Tillie Feldman to Bonafide Estates, Inc, 295 Madison Ave. Elder Ave (14-3739), w s, 100 ft s of Westchester Ave, 100x100; Gerald Dwyer, referee, to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp, trustee. White Plains Rd (17-5081), w s, 99 ft S of 240th St, 49x102; York Development Co, Inc, to Franklin Title and Mortgage Guaranty Co of New York, 551 5th Ave.
The Congressional committee appointed to study "tax avoidance" has now brought forward its report, with the recommendation that a new bill be adopted in order to close existing apaoles."

The Pennsylvania Railroad, which has been staging a frantic rail-laying race the past four days with the Central Railroad of New Jereey across the waste stretches of the Jersey meadows east of highway Route 25 near Linden, gained an important legal victory over-its rival company here today when State Highway

While sterling and the currencies allied to it advanced yesterday in terms of the dollar, the franc and other Continental exchanges were softer. The pound gained 5-16 cent to $4.98 1/4, carrying the Scandinavian currencies up a point and the Japanese yen also up a point to 29.05 cents.

A report that case goods sales at the Summer furniture markets this year fell 28 per cent behind those of last Summer, was questioned here yesterday on behalf of the New York Furniture Exchange, Inc., by Thomas R. Murtaugh, general manager.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday a net income of $5,243,629 from all operations in the fiscal year ended on June 30. This represents an increase of $1,769,204 over the preceding twelve months.

Major General Fox Conner of the First Corps Area, warned vessels today to use caution while proceeding through Nantuckets Roads, as mine and cable laying operations were underway in the section between Peddock's Island and Hospital Shoals.

The extensive automobile, aviation and shipbuilding interests controlled by E. L. Cord of Chicago are scheduled to pass into the hands of a banking group comprising Emanuel Co. and Schroeder, Rockefeller Co. at a meeting to be held here today.

David C. Lewis, Municipal Court justice in the Seventh District of Manhattan, charged last night that the Democratic party designation in his campaign for re-election was denied to him because he refused to receive communications from district leaders regarding cases before him.

According to The Daily Herald, the mammoth car which Captain George Eyston is building at Wolverhampton with the idea of capturing the world land speed record will be fitted with two 3,000-horsepower engines and have eight wheels, on the principle of the double bogie truck.
NEWS OF METROPOLITAN REAL ESTATE

The New York County grand jury indicted Wilbur Rothar, 42-year-old Bronx janitor, yesterday for attempting last Monday to extort $2,000 from George Palmer Putnam under a pretext of delivering from a gun-running vessel Amelia Earhart, wife of the publisher, believed to have been lost in the Pacific in her recent world-girdling airplane flight.

Careful daily study of THE NEW YORK TIMES or New York Herald Tribune as the best method of continuing education in current events which will change the social scene within the next decade was advocated by Dr. Charles Maxwell McConn, dean of Lehigh University, when he addressed 253 members of the Summer session graduating class at the Pennsylvania State College tonight.

Dusty Hanover, bay colt owned by the Hanover Farms of Hanover, Pa., and driven by Henry Thomas, won all three heats of the American Stake for 3-year-old pacers, the feature Grand Circuit race at Agawam Park today.

Brilliant pitching by Joe Beggs, who was credited with his fifteenth victory of the year, enabled the Newark Bears to reach a winning streak of seven games for the fifth time this season as the Buffalo Bisons, 1936 champions, were vanquished, 4 to 2, today.
A misunderstanding was all that prevented Archie San Romani, chunky little flyer from Kansas, from setting a new world record for the mile today at the Stockholm athletic games.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Jane Holzman, daughter of Mrs. Asher Holzman of 480 Park Avenue, and the late Mr. Holzman, to William J. Bratter, also of this city.

It was disclosed here last night that at noon today President Roosevelt will present the Collier Trophy, one of the most coveted awards in American aviation, to Pan American Airways in recognition of its "establishing of the transpacific air line and the successful execution of extended overwater navigation in the regular

Scout Louis Thompson of Troop 2, New Haven, Conn., is recovering from a successful appendectomy performed in the Vogelenzang Field Hospital yesterday. The operation was performed by a Netherland surgeon assisted by American doctors.

John F. Kerwin,. former battalion chief in the New York Fire Department, died Wednesday night at his home, 2,916 Philip Avenue, the Bronx, after a long illness. Mr. Kerwin, who had retired on March 1 because of ill health, after thirtythree years in the Fire Department, was 59 years old.
Bimbo, a 20-month-old black chimpanzee from the African Gold Coast, surveyed the New York skyline from the starboard rail of the liner Manhattan yesterday as the vessel came up the river to her pier.

A new method of treating measles is foreshadowed in a German medical weekly announcing that two German physicians have succeeded in producing cultures of so-called measles virus that would permit a direct attack on the measles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: T. H. P. Sailer in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES says that Japan is acting in violation of the Nine-Power Treaty and has no more right "to set up governments under her control in North China" than we would have to do the same in North Mexico.

SLOW THE MAN DOWN: THE YACHTSMAN'S READER, edited by Eric Devine. (Doubleday, Doran, $3.) Articles, stories, essays and adventure yarns about ships and the sea, Mr. Devine is the author of "Midget' Magellans," containing the stories of long voyages made in small boats.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Col. Hoxie H. Smith, Inf.-Res., 40 E. 54th St., New York, N. Y., 77th Division, is ordered to active duty, Aug. 20. He wilt proceed to Camp Perry, Ohio, reporting not later than Aug. 22 to the executive officer, Natitina, Matches, for duty as team captain of the Organized Reserves rifle team.

The accounting of the $50,000,000 estate of William Rockefeller yielded several interesting sidelights yesterday, upon further examination of the ten huge volumes that represent the first report made to the Surrogate's Court in the fifteen years since Mr. Rockefeller's death.

Plans for stepping up the retail prices of all General Motors automobiles were announced today. Following closely upon the price increase announced by the Ford Motor Company and the statement of General Motors' chairman, Alfred P. Sloan Jr.,

Negotiations between representatives of the Greek Government and the League Loans Committee and the British Council of Foreign Bondholders, concerning a final settlement of the service of the Greek external debt, have ended without an agreement having been reached, according to advices received here from London by Speyer Co.

During the week ended Aug. 4, member bank reserve balances decreased $140,000,000. The reduction in member bank reserves resulted from increases of $81,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks,

Southpaw Edgar Smith of the Athletics almost won his first game of the season today, but with two on and two out in the eighth Hank Greenberg hit a slow ball out of the park to give Detroit a 5-to-3 triumph.

The weekly resume of engineering construction awards, as reported in The Engineering News-Record, shows that contracts for $44,041,000 were let in the seven-day period ended yesterday. Compared with the $53,253,000 total reported in the the $53,253,000 total reported in the same week of last year, this is a dron of 17 per cent.

New York City's free swimming pool service caused Federal Judge Julian W. Mack to authorize Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, to amend a lease which will mean a loss of $3,200 a year to the company.

Wheat prices-in North-Dakota have increased above the regular market prices during the last two days, State mill and elevator officials said today, after introduction of a program which Governor William Langer said would bring "honest prices" for lightweight wheat.
A greater decline than allowed for seasonally took place in lumber production last week, and the adjusted index has receded to 87.2 from 91.2. For the week ended Aug. 1, 1936, it was 81.3.

An extensive athletic program held for 1,800 C.M.T.C. youths from New York, New Jersey and Delaware as a feature of the celebration of the twentieth anniversary of Camp Dix ended here today with the presenstation of gold, silver and bronze medals to the winners of team events.

Department stores in this area are planning to reduce "back-to-school" promotion of children's wear in late August and September and spread such advertising over the Fall months, controllers said yesterday. They have found that in other years, promotion expenditures of this kind have run out of proportion to the volume of business.

Three unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor and one C. I. O. organization joined yesterday in issuing a strike call to 3,000 employes in forty-four automats of the Horn Hardart Company, effective today.

A factory building and four small storage sheds, property of the Perfectoloid Company, manufacturers of cellulose products, at 424 New Bridge Road, here, went up in flames this afternoon in a fire that attracted hundreds of spectators and caused a loss estimated at $50,000.

Miss Rosalie Benziger of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas C. Benziger of Summit, N. J., was married yesterday morning to Oswald MacCarthy of New York, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Charles D. MacCarthy of Geneva, N. Y., in the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.
In the custody of America's first triumphant international tennis squad since 1926, the Davis cup was brought back home yesterday after reposing overseas for a decade in France and England.

YOU may remember that a couple of years a ago an unusual journal by Elizabeth Etnier, a young New Yorker still in her twenties, attraeted a- good deal of attention when it appeared in The Atlantic Monthly. It was a crisply written and beautifully. candid account of adventurous voyaging along the coast toward Bermudas blue suburbs with her husband, Stephen Etnier, the artist, in a sehooner they strenuously mailed.

Although not one of the twenty-six agreements reported on Tuesday to have been signed by the representatives of Bolivia and Chile may in itself be of general interest, the news of such a comprehensive international accord is welcome.

A heated dispute over the number of Negroes the American Labor party should have on its New York County executive committee interrupted an otherwise harmonious first convention of the New York County division of the party in the Manhattan Opera House last night.

A gunman ventured below Fulton Street, the old police "deadline," yesterday afternoon, ahd on the twenty-sixth floor of the Equitable Building, 120 Broadway, held up a messenger and escaped with $139.
The fourth annual Berkshire Symphonic Festival began tonight an expanded career at its new permanent home here, the beautiful 200acre estate known as Tanglewood.

In the wake of the America's Cup series the suggestion has been made from several sources that Harold S. Vanderbilt and T. O. M. Sopwith exchange yachts and sail a match over the same courses used in the series off Newport.

A flying boat with a wing-spread greater than that of the largest commercial plane ever constructed by the Sikorsky Aircraft Corporation has been virtually completed at the plant here for the navy and will undergo flying tests in a few weeks.
Rejecting a proposal for conciliation, the Massachusetts Federation of Labor today supported its leaders' "declaration of war" against John L. Lewis and the Committee for Industrial Organization.

While the study of psychology increased in most countries, it declined in. Germany dining the last four years, according to -an address by J. B. Mailer of Columbia University, before the International Congress of Psychology, which has just ended.
David Jaret Co has arranged two building loans of $6,500 each on the two 2family brick dwellings which it is proposed to erect on the n s of Colden Ave, 150 ft n of Mount Morris Park Ave, the Bronx.
Compliments and kind words of appreciation were sent tonight by Chairman Edmund Lang of the New York Y. C. race committee to Captain J. F. Hottel, commanding the Coast Guard patrol force.

The shrill chirping of a score of sparrows near the Pythian Temple on West Seventieth Street brought housewives and other residents of the north side of the 100 block on the run yesterday morning to their rear windows. There, stretched out unconcernedly along the top of a fence, lay a six-foot gopher snake basking under the eyes of the winged spectators.
A new record for gliding was established tonight when a young Hamburg aviator landed at Wasserkuppe in Thuringia after making the flight from Wasserkuppe to Berlin and return by a roundabout route.

Miss Maureen Orcutt played the championship brand of golf that has made her one of the game's greats today over the course of the Hotel Champlain Golf Club to defeat Miss Virginia Guilfoil in the semi-final round of the women's international invitation tournament, 1 up on the eighteenth hole.
Mrs. Mary Boccawsini, 27, died at 3:15 A. M. today and physicians at once delivered her unborn baby. The baby was alive.

Corrected figures for odd-lot transactions of odd-lot dealers and specialists in stocks, rights and warrants on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on July 31, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed sales exceeded purchases by 81,671 shares, as follows:

Not since their victory over Lithuania on the opening day have the chess players representing the United States in the international team tournament made such a gain as they did today in the eighth and ninth rounds, in which they defeated Finland and Belgium by the same score, 3 1/2 to 1/2.

Violence broke out anew in the strike of shipyard workers when strikers and sympathixers threw atones, shouted and jeered at workers of the Robins Drydock and Repair Company as they left the plant at the toot of Dwight Street, Brooklyn, late yesterday afternoon.

Grave-diggers tossed aside their shovels and grave attendants quit their water sprinklers today to go on a strike which stopped all burials in Kansas City. Demanding recognition of their union, an A. F. of L. affiliate, they "picketed" all cemetery gates. Ten funerals were conducted today but none of them ended in burials.

Movements of naval vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 4, unless specified: At San Francisco; Barry, Borie, Broome, California, Childs. Dallas, Gilmer, Goff, Hopkins. Idaho, Reuben James, Langley, Long. Memphis, Mississippi, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Trever, West Virginia. Williamson. Zane.

A million volunteer watchers are wanted to count the Persoid m??teaors, which will make their annual appearance the nights of Aug. 11 and 12. The call was issued today by Professor Charles P. Oliver, University of Pennsylvania astronomer.

A net profit of $3,286,116 is reported for the second quarter of 1937 by the International Paper and Power Company and subsidiaries, excluding International HydroElectric System and subsidiaries, as compared with a profit of $665,217 for the second quarter of 1936.

A large number of the Summer colonists of.Mount Desert Island attended the annual fashion show held at In-the-Garden for the benefit of the Mount Desert Island Hospital this afternoon. Mrs. A. Mansfield Patterson of New York announced the events, while Miss Marion Baker of New York assisted.
Six members of the New York Congressional delegation joined today with half a dozen other House Democrate in a drive to enact legislation for the relief of home owners.
Governors Island and Burnt Mills gained the semi-finals of the Monmouth County Country Club's annual ten-goal polo tournament by running roughshod over their opponents in the quarter-finals today.

Fred Kuser, a founder of the Walter Automnobile Company here and its president from 1903 to 1908, when it was merged into the Mercer Automobile Company, died tonight at his home in Hamilton Township of a stroke suffered two weeks ago. His age was 79.

Police of the Wilson Avenue precinct in Brooklyn yesterday enlisted the help -of 500 boys, members of the Police Athletic League, to run down clues to the murderer of Paula Macagna, 8 years old, who was found strangled in the cellar of her home at 349 Stockholm Street last Saturday.

William E. Sill, Sr., associate counsel to the State Tax Department, announced today that he would end his service of twenty-two years in that deapartment on Sept. 1, owing to ill health. His resignation follows that of Seth T. Cole, who will engage in private practice.

The former policy of admitting two classes yearly to the State Merchant Marine has been abandoned and hereafter one class will be entered in October, Captain J. H. Tomb, U. S. N., retired, superintendent of the Academy, announced today.

Metropolitan Music Co, musical instruments, floor in 222 4th Ave; Philip London, feathers, in 693-97 Broadway; Irving Seligman, beauty equipment, in 148-56 W 23d St; PM. L. Hess, Inc, broker. A. L. Diament, Inc, antique furniture, store in 32 E 53d St; Frederick Fox Co. Inc. broker.

In the city of Mozart's birth Wagner tonight was king. At-the Festspielhaus before a tremendous audience occurred a performance of "Die Meistersinger" so glorious, so enrapturing, so incandescent that it diminished everything else even the finest-that has been done in the current festival thus far.

A "violent rise in prices that will go too far and will be followed by a violent decline" is now "practically inevitable" for any country that "continuously adheres to a gold currency" or to "any fixed price of gold, regardless of what that price may be," Professors George F. Warren and Frank A. Pearson of Cornell University predict in their new book, "World Prices and the Building Industry," made available for review purposes today.
Unless Governor Lehman of New York acts on behalf of John Montague, golfing friend of screen actors, Governor Merriam of California probably will order him. sent East for trial on robbery charges.
Analyzing the causes of a revolutionary movement that overthrew his government a few weeks ago, the former President of Bolivia, Colonel David Toro, now residing in Arica, said:

Dr. Chaim Weizmann's Palestine partition policy gained considerable momentum in the Zionist congress here today. In fact, it gained so much that its supporters and some of its adversaries believe it already has a majority and will get a favorable vote by Monday.
Reports that the Chinese are hiring American air pilots, ordering American bombing planes and buying American shipping have evoked a quick and unfavorable reaction here.

The effort to emphasize the excellence of "German" art as revealed in the first national exhibition of the Third ,Reiho in the New House of German Art in Munieh by contrasting it with an exhibit of "degenerate" or modern art has had a startling result.
Volunteer firemen from Wyoming and three adjoining counties, bulwarked with drum and bugle corps, gathered here today for the big parade of Attica's centennial and old home week celebration.

Control of exchange and exports is repealed by an Ecuadorian decree dated July 31 and said to be effective immediately, but there is a continuance of the requirement for prior permits on all imports except those specially named as exceptions in the decree, the Commerce Department stated today.

Frank C. Fisher's fishing trip on Lexington Avenue looked a little fishy to Patrolman William Koster early yesterday morning, so he watched Mr. Fisher fish a while, noted that he got a bite every time he cast and then arrested him.

The Hamburg - American liner Deutschland, arriving today from German and Channel ports and Cobh, has among her passengers Bertita Harding, Mr. and Mrs. W. Wheeler Williams, Guillermo Valenzuela, Thomas 0. Walton, Professor K. H. Williamson, Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. Feick, William J. Henwood, Carl Lundgren, Mr. and Mrs. W. S. Carter, Merrill Ulman and Mr. and Mrs. John C. Lord.

Reports came today from both sides in the Spanish civil war that Santander, last important Government-held city on the Bay of Biscay coast, faced a crisis. Government sources said that officials of Santander were considering evacuation of civilians.
Forty-one refugee children from Spain who are -to find homes with families in various parts of Switzerland arrived in Geneva last night.
The House of Representatives today approved a bill raising the registration tax levied on foreigners living on the island from $1.40 to $3.
Two present officers of the Trenton Valley Distillers Corporation of Detroit expressed strong criticism today of promotion methods alleged to have been used by the company in the past.

Keen interest has been shown by heads of large organizations of Women in the State in the conference called at Vassar College for next Thursday to consider a unified plan for jury schools for women next Fall, according to Miss Vera McCrea, president of the State Federation of Business and
First Race--Sailed Saturday, July 31, over thirty-mile windward-leeward course; won by Ranger, timed in 4:41:15, with margin 17 minutes 5 seconds; Endeavour II timed in 4:58:20.

A visitor from Albany with an hour to spend in New York dropped by to tell a tale. "After you hear this," he began, looking first at a time table and then at his watch, 'you'll be convinced that it isn't only game which needs protection."

The United States Steel Corporation has signed contracts giving the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and the Order of Railway Conductors exclusive bargaining rights for 1,200 of the employes of its subsidiary, the Union Railroad Company, union officials announced today.

Sixteen resident buying organizations, through their association, have agreed to incorporate fair trade practice provisions in all orders placed by them, it was announced yesterday by the Millinery Stabilization Commission, Inc.

Today was Ladies Day, and Pie Traynor's Pirates must have been self-conscious in the presence of 2,000 feminine fans. For they perpetrated six errors to lose the series final to the Dodgers, 9-6. Not one of the Brooklyn tallies actually was earned, although three were so scored.
President Roosevelt discussed farm legislation with a Congressional delegation; signed the bill to establish a cancer research institute;

Departing from the Broadway scene at the end of next week (Aug. 14) will be "Tovarich," which has comfortably occupied the Plymouth Theatre since Oct. 15 last. It had been confidently expected to continue through the Summer.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
Three persons were killed and forty-one injured in three explosions in New Jersey yesterday. The explosions, in widely separated districts, were unconnected and seemed in each case to be accidental.

Arthur Ridley Glore, a member of the firm of Evins F. Glore Sons, Inc., heating materials distributors, died in Utica, N. Y., yesterday while on a business trip, according to word received here today. Mr. Glore.

After nearly five hours of discussion, leaders of rival unions of licensed maritime officers failed last night to effect a compromise which the Labor Relations Board hoped might bring about the release of three ships of the American West African Line which are tied up by a strike.

B. J. Becker and Theodore A. Lightner of New York, veteran contract bridge stars who won the masters' pair championship here two years ago, jumped into the lead this afternoon as the first of the three sessions in this even was played at the American Bridge League's Summer tournament here.

What everybody wanted to know after the final race today was whether T. O. M. Sopwith would challenge again for the America's Cup, and on this point only was the British yachtsman vague when interviewed after his defeat.

In connection with rumors that the late Patriarch Varnava *had been poisoned, the Belgrade police chief issued today a statement signed by seven physicians who had treated him during his last illness. The statement completely denied these allegations.
The Royal Yacht Squadron acted today to guard against further shocks like the one. administered .by Viscountess Hinchingbrooke last Tuesday.

Charles S. Reed 2d, United States Charge d'Affaires here, was notified by the Foreign Office today that Hubert D. Harrison, correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, would be permitted to remain here. By direction of Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch the municipal authorities have renewed his residence permit.

Fred (Buzz) Borries, Slade Cutter and Bob Dornin, trio of stars in the Army-Navy game of 1934, the first won by the Navy in thirteen years, have arrived in Annapolis and will assist Head Coach Hank Hardwick this Fall. The three classmates now hold the rank of ensign.

The defense in the John J. O'Connell Jr. kidnapping trial was concluded today for eight men accaused of the four-year-old crime. A two-hour defense surrebuttal marked the end of the ten weeks' trial and the Federal jury was excaused until Monday, when opening summations will be heard. Meanwhile, Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant scheduled arguments for tomorrow.

Production of all types of wool goods is estimated in the trade at about 4,000,000 yards weekly, according to a report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. While some mills are curtailing production, others are stepping up activity, especially on women's wear.
An official Japanese intimation that the undeclared Japanese-Chinese war might be extended as far as the. Yellow. River was received here today by foreign diplomats.

The Eastern All-Star squad of 1937 graduates that will play the New York football Giants at the Polo Grounds con the night of Sept. 8 was increased to nineteen today with the addition of three linemen from Temple University.

The grain markets on the Board of Trade here staged a strong upturn today. At no time were prices more than a small fraction of a cent a bushel below Wednesday's finish. While the best figures on wheat and corn were not maintained, due to profit taking, wheat closed with net gains of 1 to 2 1/4 cents, with the September leading.

Federal Judge William H. Holly postponed today his decision on the appointment of a trustee for the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, $400,000,000 utility holding company, after attorneys for the corporation had presented a new plan of recapitalization which they said would take the company out of reorganization under Section 77B of the amended Bankruptcy Act.

Her ropes wind-stiff from the pull of her lofty sails as she swept through a churned sea full of life, Harold S. Vanderbilt's Ranger today won her fourth straight race and thus brought about the sixteenth successful defense of the America's Cup for the New York Yacht Club.

William J. Macbeth, sports write for The New York Herald Tribune for thirteen years and a former sports editor, died. in the Saratoga Hospital here this afternoon after being taken seriously ill a few days ago. He would have been 53 years old on Aug. 19.

Just a century to the day after the first recorded ascent of Mount Marcy by white men, some 200 persons stormed this highest- peak in the Adirondack Mountains today. Some stormed its slopes swiftly, Many more struggled slowly up the wooded trails to the rocky summit.

Striking Farmers in Northern New York were warned today against disorderly action in their fight against the Sheffield plants by Holton V. Noyes, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets. The farmers have been withholding milk from the plants for several days.

The demand for most meats lacked action and in a general way trading was slow, though as usual, even on a dull market, some cuts were in fair demand. Beef showed little change; veal and calf were mostly steady; lamb declined; pork loins advanced; other pork cuts mostly steady.
Six thousand pieces of jewelry and a large amount of securities and art objects which disappeared in Barcelona have been recovered by the Spanish Government.

Factional Democratic warfare increased in intensity yesterday, following the substitution of former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney for Grover A. Whalen as a candidate for the Mayoralty nomination against Senator Royal S. Copeland, choice of Tammany.

A final accounting of the estate of Mrs. Florence Adelaide Pratt, Singer sewing machine heiress, showed yesterday that her heirs have received $5,883,787 and that the executor, the Guaranty Trust Company, had on hand a balance of $665,394 on June 30.

Suites in apartment houses on the West Side figured prominently in renting activity yesterday, when continued to add to their agents continued to add to their rosters at the brisk pace set early in the week. Mrs. Clara Clemens Gabrilowitsch, widow of Ossip Gabrilowitsch, the pianist and conductor, and daughter of Samuel Clemens (Mark Twain),

Rochester Catholic officials tonight disclosed that a proposal to sell St. Patrick's Cathedral and adjoining property to the Eastman Kodak Company was awaiting further action by three separate church corporations affected in the proposed transaction.
ON HIS OWN APPLICATION PATROLMAN-Hugh J. Smith, Shield No. 3629, 112th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 2, 1895. Assignments PATROLMEN-Harbor Precinct, designated as Acting Sergeants:

Despite President Roosevelt's ultimatum that he would veto the measure unless it was made to conform to the Administration's view, the House sugar bloc decided today to press for immediate passage of the Sugar Control Bill with its controversial provisions limiting imports of refined sugar from Puerto Rico and Hawaii.
The Cardinals got 11 hits off Danny Macfayden today, but the Bees' righthander bore down in the tight spots and, aided by three double plays, pitched a 4-to-1 triumph.

Mrs. William H. Woodin gave a buffet supper for fifty persons tonight at her home on the dunes in honor of the visiting tennis players taking part in the annual women's invitation tournament at the Maidstone Club.
Stocks closed irregularly lower; turnover, 794,760 shares. United States Government bonds irregular; other issues firm; transactions, $7,166,000.
America's Cup remains in America, in the custody of the' New York Yacht Club, which has successfully held it since it was captured overseas eightysix years ago.

Japanese authorities have effectively succeeded in cornering the handling of all official news and news photos of this North China war as an exclusive monopoly for their own nationals. Arriving in large numbers from Manchuria and Japan,
Kipling's phrase--"the liner she's a lady"--is nowhere more applicable on the wide world of waters than to the ancient but still sprightly Aquitania, dowager queen of the seas.

A movement for a special session of Congress in the Fall to consider general farm legislation gained rapid headway today as the drive for a quick adjournment of the present session sank farther in the mire of controversy and delay.
The District Attorneys of the five counties of the city submitted 1938 budget requests totaling $2,122,394 yesterday at a hearing before Kenneth Dayton, assistant budget director.

Callfornia's domination of junior tennis circles continued today as three young Pacific Coast racket wielders swept into the semi-final bracket of the national junior championships at the Culver Military Academy.

The protective committee for preferred stockholders of the Schulte Retail Stores Corporation has mailed to stockholders the conclusions of a survey conducted by S. D. Leidesdorf Co. showing the need of a new merchandising Program for the stores.

Mr. and Mrs. Otto Horst hired a lawyer tonight and tomorrow they will start their legal fight to regain custody of their foster son, Donald, 2 1/2 years old, who was abducted on Tuesday by his natural parents.

A $48,715,525 bill to improve rivers and harbors won the approval of the Senate today. Before passing the measure, which it had received from the House, the Chamber added projects totaling more than $15,000,000.

Sultry weather yesterday accounted for the death of one person and the prostration of three others in the metropolitan area. The thermometers soared to 85 degrees in mid-afternoon after a low of 69 at 6:30 A. M.. with the humidity high.

James H. R. Cromwell, banker and co-author of a recent book on capitalism, rejected measures of the Federal Administration as "cockeyed theories," in addressing members of the Rotary Club at luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Commodore. He declared that "the future existence of capitalism, without which democracy and personal and economic liberty cannot

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, said yesterday that he questioned the sincerity of Assemblyman Phelps Phelps's public appeal for swimming and wading pools on the lower West Side. In a letter to Mr. Phelps, Mr. Moses wrote that he was in accord with Mr. Phelps in his desire for more recreation facilities for 'the lower West Side, but added:

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 4: MAJORS Jabelonsky, C. H., QMC, Fort McClellan, Ala., to Fort Monroe, Va. Loughlin, C. C., Infantry, Fort Moultrie, S. C., to Spartanburg, S. C., detailed at Wofford College. Persons, W. B., Signal Corps, relieved from further additional duty with the Army Group, Washington, D. C.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended Aug. 5 were announced today: MAJORS McLean, J. D., Headquarters, to Army Industrial College, Washington, D. C. Hatfield, G. D., Quantico, Va., to Army Industrial College, Washington, D. C. Livingston, R., First Marine Brigade, Quantico, Va., to retirement, Oct. 1.

The assertion of Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation, that John L. Lewis, head of the Committee for Industrial Organization, was "on the down grade" brought ridicules of the statement yesterday from John Brophy, executive director of the C. I. O.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow;

President Roosevelt today signed a bill creating a national cancer institute under the Public Health Service and authorizing an appropriation of $750,000 for construction of a building and one of $700,000 annually for research.

Turpentine firm, 32c; sales, 81 barrels; receipts, 284 barrels; shipments, 168 barrels; stock, 33,653 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 862; -receipts, 2,107; shipments, 4,035: stock, 66.364. Quotes: B to M, $7.75; N, $7.77 1/2: WG, $7.90; WW, X, $8.50-65.

Word was received here today of the death in Georgetown, Me., of Charles F. Read of Wellesley Hills, clerk and treasurer of the Bostonian Society of the Old State House, Boston, for more than thirty years.

After a grueling nine-hour trip a train from Tientsin arrived at the Peiping Chienmen station yesterday evening. The main purpose of the trip was to establish the extent of damage to tracks and railway communications.

A reduction of 299,113 in Works Progress Administration rolls between June 19 and July 17 was reported The rolls were cut from a total of 2,580,297 on June 19 to 2,281,184 on July 17. The reductions included men in CCC camps and on public roads and other employes taken

The American Smelting and Refining Company and the St. Joseph Lead Company yesterday advanced the price of lead 1/4 cent a pound. The new price is 6.50 cents a pound at New York and 6.35 cents at East St. Louis. A similar price rise was made by these concerns on Wednesday.

Yachtsmen turned the ocean back to the swordfish, sharks and tuna today. Even the sea gulls, which had been chased in all directions by the droning airplanes watching the America's Cup races, now can safely return.

The spectator array at the fourth and final race of the America's Cup series was swelled today by 200 midshipmen of the third-year class of the United States Naval Academy, who arrived aboard a division of destroyers on Wednesday on their annual cruise. The middies were taken out to see the race on the destroyers.
Senator Logan, Kentucky Democrat, proposed legislation today intended to remove any doubt about the existence of a vacancy on the Supreme Court.

A first degree arson indictment against Domenick Calve of Noroton Heights, Conn., was dismissed today by Acting County Judge J. Gordon Flannery after the State had rested its case against him and two other defendants. Calve is also under indictment on five charges of second-degree arson.

The Interstate Commerce Commission granted today the petition of John Carson, consumers' counsel to the Bituminous Coal Commission, for permission to intervene in the rehearings on the reorganization of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway, which is controlled by the Chesapeake Ohio.

David Polland of Brooklyn and George Treysman of Manhattan today shared the lead in the State championship at the annual meet Four games ramain incompleted, including the important one between A. E. Santasiere and Polland.
Searchers today failed to find the bodies. any of the fourteen persons aboard the Pan American-Grace airliner Santa Maria,. which crashed into the sea twenty miles from Colon'on Monday.

Fashion history has been launched by Molyneux and Schiaparelli. These two great designers displayed much that Is new in silhouettes. While Molyneux stressed his -.uual slim line for daytime, in fact more restrained than before, he presented an entirely different evening picture.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:
Tenants of a 252-unit apartment, build as a PWA slum clearance project faced a rent increase today and threatened a controversy that finally may go to PWA officials.

Heavy property damage is reported from the Consolacion del Sur district of Pinar del Rio Province, which was swept this afternoon by a sixty-mile-anhour wind, accompanied by lashing rains. No casualties have been reported.

Joe Taylor, Glasgow City Councilman, grabbed the official mace at Council meeting today and sprinted from the Chamber. Other members chased him, When they finally caught him, Taylor had hidden the mace--symbol of authority--and wouldn't tell where it was.

An inter-union fight that caused 21,000 workers to be idle tonight may resuit in the first National Labor Relations Board election affecting employee of one of the "Big Three" of the automobile industry.

With gestures of satisfied finality, Police Commissioner Valentine and District Attorney Dodge returned yesterday afternoon from a trip up Long Island Sound on the Dock Deapartment tug Manhattan. The only cargo aboard as the tug chugged back toward Pier A, the Battery, was an old club, inscribed: "This is the club that knocked out Dollie Lyons, 1888."

The development of super-markets, beginning in a moderate way on the West Coast several years ago, and reaching epidemic proportions during the depression, has increased further in the last few years, and this method of food distribution now has spread to most parts of the United States, Gordon C. Corbaley, president of the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc.,

Fortyseven suggestions for amending existing tax laws along eight broad lines, to prevent evasion and avoidance, were submitted to Congress today by the joint committee which has been studying the situation President Roosevelt outlined in his message of June 1.
Although apparently none too confident in the possible outcome, Colonel Bill Terry made a noble experiment in the interests of medical science today and came up with a most startling result.

In a joint statement of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries, a balance of $6,327,168 is shown for the corporation, for the twelve months ended on June 30, compared with $5,071,009 in the preceding year.

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Aug. 4 were announced today: Hodges, Jr. Lt. E. T., reassigned to aeronautical organization and detached from the Galatea and New York Division, and nrdered to Salem air station.

Fifteen. PanGerman athletic associations in. Upper Austria were dissolved today by government order and another forty will be similarly treated in the next few weeks as a result of Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's campaign against illegal Nazi activities in this part of the country.:

Argentina's polo forces, preparing for their assault on our national championship, cantered through another easy game on Mitchel Field today and turned back opposition which consisted of their two spares and Ivor Balding and Lieutenant Royden Beebe. The score was 11-2.

The Red Sox took over second place in the American League today by conquering the Cleveland Indians, 5 to 4, for their ninth straight victory, not counting a tie game Sunday; a clean-up of the four-game series and the thirty-first triumph in their last thirty-seven home games.
Edward J. McNally, a public school principal in Manhattan for thirty years, died suddenly yesterday at his Summer home, Oakwood Heights, S. I. He was 65 years old.

Frank admission that the Securities and Exchange Commission, to some extent at least, is on a "fishing expedition" in the case against the Austin Silver Mining Company was made yesterday afternoon by Pierce W. Bradley of SEC counsel.
Backing up Bucky Walters's four-hit pitching with a three-run first-inning flurry off Clyde Shoun, the Phillies subdued the league-leading Cubs again today, 4 to 2.

Percival Mullikin, publicity director and manager of the information bureau of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce, and former city editor of The North Shore Daily Journal, died Wednesday afternoon at the Flushing Hospital after a long illness.
An agreement "in principle" for a loan of f20,000,000 to China has been concluded here by Dr. H. H. Kung, Chinese Minister of Finance, according to a report circulated today.

Plans were filed last month in Manhattan for twenty-nine new buildings, Samuel Fassler, Commissioner of Buildings, announced yesterday. The new structures comprised twenty-seven projects, the estimated cost of which was $1,725,800.

Mr. and Mrs. Morton L. Schwartz entertained at a luncheon today at the Gideon Putnam for Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Livingston Mills, Mrs. J. Norman de R. Whitehouse and Philip S. P. Fell. Mr. and Mrs. Schwartz gave a dinner at Arrowhead Inn last night for Mr. and Mrs. Arthur White of Warrenton, Va.; Herbert Bayard Swope, Mrs. Dodge Sloane and Mrs. James Simpson.
It the good Herr Julius Streicher doesn't watch his step he may be putting notions into the heads of little German boys and girls.

Chairman Wheeler of the Senate Railroad Finance Investigating Committee today criticized Robert R. Young's plans for merging the Alleghany and Chesapeake Corporations, the dominant holding companies in the 23,000-mile transportation system which he controls.

In an effort to keep as close as possible to the headlines, Lippincott is hurrying through "The Far East.Comes Nearer" for publication this month. The book, which purports to -tell "the inside story" of recent events in Eastern' Asia, is the work of Hessell Tiltman. It was originally scheduled. for Fall publication.
To a local political situation which was already sufficiently confused, the sudden withdrawal of Mr. Whalen and the sudden advance of Mr. Mahoney add still more confusion.

Ira F. Thompson, associate justice of the California State Supreme Court, died of a heart attack last night at his home in Berkeley. He was 52 years old and had a notable career as a lawyer and jurist. Born in Wisconsin in 1885, he came with his family to California when a boy.

For the fourth day the Senate debated the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill, adopting an amendment by Senator Tydings limiting the subsidies and loans from the proposed Housing Authority to any one State to 20 per cent of the $700,000,000 authorized to be spent during the next three years.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee recommended today the ratification of a convention with Canada reducing the standard rate of taxation on nonresident aliens and foreign corporations. The reduction would be on a reciprocal basis. The pact was signed here Dec. 30, 1936, and President Roosevelt sent it to the Senate Jan. 11.

Antonio Ortiz, 32 years old, an unemployed laborer, was held on a charge of kidnapping at the West 123d Street police station early this morning after he had taken a 4year-old boy from near his home at 107 West 119th Street.
The report of the Joint Congressional Committee on Prevention of Tax Evasion and Avoidance follows: To the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled:

Vice Admiral Sidney G. Meyrick of the British Navy, commanding officer of the America-West Indies station, who has been here aboard H. M. S. York for the America's Cup races, and other officers of the ship gave a dance aboard the cruiser tonight.
The Railway Rates Tribunal today granted the request of Great Britain's four major railways for a 5 per cent increase in fares and freight charges. The increase will be effective Oct. 1.

Saverio Turiello, Italian welterweight, pounded out a decision over Frankie Cinque of the West Side in the main event of ten rounds last night at Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn. A crowd of 5,500 saw the bouts.

The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company announced to stockholders yesterday that it planned to arrange for $25,000,000 of new capiital through the issuance of convertible debentures, which first would be offered to common stockholders on terms to be fixed by the directors.

" Bronco" Charlie Miller let down his hair today and told why he had never permitted a barber to shear it in all his eighty-eight years. Miller. who lays proud claim to the title of "last of the pony express riders," made the explanation to a crowd of the curious in
Most of the United States Fleet, which is based on the West Coast, is expected to pay about a twoweek visit to New York during the World's Fair, it became known yesterday.

Leonard Del Genib of Harlem, who has grown from a lightweight to a welterweight, outfought Bobby Pacho, Los Angeles Mexican, at Madison Square Garden and gained a deserved verdict at the end: of their ten-round bout.

The American General Corporation, investing company, reports net assets at $32,907,506 as of June 30, equivalent to $162.76 a share of preferred stock and to $13.62 a share of common stock, compared to $16.11 a common share on Dec. 31 and to $12.31 a share on June 30, 1936.

Former Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia has been "compelled" to cancel plans for publication of his memoirs, Michael Joseph, his publisher, disclosed today, adding that the Emperor's decision was based on counsel of his "political advisers."

The wind freshened slightly before the start of the third day of the Royal Yacht Squadron's regatta today. Sir W. Burton won one of the most important events of the day when his Marina captured the class for 12-meter yachts.

The body of Thomas Chasas, 2-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Chasas of Locust Avenue, Babylon, was found this morning shortly before 7 o'clock in the creek adjoining his home after an all-night search. The child disappeared last evening while at play with two older sisters, Joan and Helene.

The committee of judges for the 1937 Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Award- a prize of $2,500 awarded annually for the best manuscript on any political, economic or social phase of contemporary American life--was announced yesterday at the Garden City, L. I., headquarters of Doubleday, Doran Co., which is sponsor for the competition.

One must go back to 1933, to the period before. the Reserve System began its great open-market operations to expand reserves, to find a time at which member banks of the system had a smaller volume of excess reserves than the $700,000,000 reported for last Wednesday in the current banking statistics.

President Roosevelt told Representative Bert Lord of Afton, N. Y., in a letter made public today, that the volume of shoe imports from abroad does not "suggest the existence of an emergency situation calling for immediate action which might conflict with the general policy of building up our international trade."
Mrs. Ethel Hoagland Brown, wife of Judge Thomas H. Brown of the Hudson County Court of Common Pleas, died after a short illness in the Monmouth Memorial Hospital Here early this morning.
Some 525 "fresh-water sailors" tanned from the tropic sun steamed in from the sea yesterday aboard seven destroyers that had taken them on a two-week training cruise.

A special meeting of stockholders of the McGraw Electric Company has been called in Wilmington, Del., on Sept. 8, to reclassify each common share of $5 par value into two common shares of $1 par value and to authorize additional capital consisting of 20,000 preferred shares of $100 par value and 250,000 common shares of $1 par value, making the total authorized common shares 750,000 after the reclassification proposed.

Willem van Hoogstraten, conductor of the Portland Symphony Orchestra of Portland, Ore., made his first appearance of the season as director of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night at Lewisohn Stadium.

E.K. Van Aernam of Crossett, Ark., was reelected president of the American Retailers' Association last night and the approximately 2,000 members here turned to selection of Fall merchandise for their stores in twenty-eight States.
The stock market generally was bright today, with most sections reflecting gains. Gilt-edge bonds, although not much changed, continued firm, although the Far Easterns eased among the foreign loans.

Development of a new photoreceiving machine no bigger than a console radio cabinet, which engineers say gives a better picture than the present three-piece apparatus requiring about three times the floor space, was announced'yesterday by The Associated Press.

Eighteen victims of Spain's civil war arrived here yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan as refugees. Among them was a family of seven, separated from father and husband -who had to remain in Santander to await a call to arms, and three sisters who have a distant relative in Bridgeport, Conn., who may, or may. not be city.
Abram Davega, vice president in charge of advertising and sales promotion of the Davega-City Radio Stores, yesterday celebrated completion of his thirtieth year with the company.

Reports that a delegation of Southern representatives, after a visit to the White House, had obtained a promise of governmental assistance in marketing this year's large harvest if Congress would agree to pass crop. control legislation during the present or coming session, caused further active covering on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and prices ended with gains of 9 to 13 points.

Many parties were given in connection with tonight's Boston Symphony Orchestra concert at Tanglewood, midway between Lenox and Stockbridge. One of the largest house parties is that of Mr. and Mrs. William Felton Barrett of Rye, N. Y., at Sky Farm, North Egremont.

The six-story Washington Irving Apartments, on the northwest corner of 151st Street and Broadway, 99.11 by 150 feet, were sold at auction yesterday to the plaintiff, the Greenwich Savings Bank, for $235,000.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Leighton K. Brill, son, 9,984 Durant Dr., Beverly Hills, Calif., jewelry, precious stones, household effects and life estate in residue with power of appointment; Joan and Barbara Smith, 25 Ridge Dr., Great Neck, $2,500 each; Howard E. Reinheimer, executor, 983 Park Ave., jewelry, precious stones and $12.000.
Cleveland at New York-Feller vs. Gomez. Chicago. at Boston-Lee vs. Wilson. Detroit at Washington-Poffenberger or Lawson .vs. Weaver. Other clubs not scheduled.
Charles L. Belcher, a patent attorney with the Ford Instrument Company for nineteen years, died on Wednesday at his home, 87-11 143d Street, Jamaica, after a long illness. His age was 60.
The St. Louis Browns fell on Pete Appleton with a heavy early attack today to defeat the Washington Senators, 7 to 4. The victory gave the Browns two out of the three-game series.

The outstanding credit of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City expanded $29,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the condition statement of the banks issued yesterday.

Public examination of the following concerns will be held beginning on Monday in connection with a study of investment trusts and investment companies, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today:

Mrs. Catherine Sample of Miami, Florida State women's tennis champion, defeated Mrs. Helen Vose, also of Miami, today to win the women's singles final of the sixteenth annual maritime tournament. The scores were 6-3, 6-2.

Fireworks displays, including hanging chains of fire, aerial waterfalls and other reproductions, will be presented every Friday at 9 P. M. throughout August beginning today at Jacob Riis Park, Queens, it was announced yesterday by Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks.
