John P. MacDonald, former manager of a number of hotels and secretary to the late George C. Boldt, owner of the old Waldorf-Astoria, died after a brief illness yesterday morning- in St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, Queens. His age was 56.
The Federal Government tonight was removed from the direct scope of a drastic bill of Alberta's social credit government to license banks and control some of their activities.
Democrats who have been fighting the administration do not expect an effective handsoff policy in renomination contests they may have at home against favorites of the Government at Washington.

The Yale Puppeteers, who have amused White Mountain audiences for ten years, gave tonight their farewell performance at the Littleton Opera House, a musical revue of twenty numbers, at which new portrait puppets shown included

Rental charges ranging from $4.73 a week for a two-room apartment, to $6.61 for one of five rooms in Williamsburg Houses, the nation's greatest slum clearance and low-rent housing project, are stipulated in lease documents Secretary Ickes, Public Works Administrator, submitted for execution today to the New York City Housing Authority.

The two six-family apartment houses at 2,160 and 2,164 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, have been sold by Flora Shotz to Jenny Adler for cash above a first mortgage. The buildings are on plots 30 by 100 feet each, and contain suites of three and four rooms. R. M. Dinsmore Co., Inc.,

The Duke and Duchess of -Windsor .have bobbed into the news again with gifts of money to British causes. The Duke sent a check for [Pound]100 toward the establishment of a permanent show ground at Leicester for the Leicester Agricultural Society. From Lido Venezia he wrote:
Irate residents of Lawrence Park West, Yonkers, resorted to litigation here today to halt the "bedlam" caused by construction of New York City's new Delaware aqueduct.

Cooperation against bolshevism, to be effected by China's entering the German-Japanese pact against the Communist International, is a fundamental principle of Japan's policy on China, Foreign Minister Koki Hirota told members of the House here yesterday.

Wiry little Frank Strafaci, golf's mighty atom, and his sturdy partner, Joe Thompson, set the pace for a field of eighty-eight teams in today's qualifying round of the John G. Anderson Memorial tournament played annually at Winged Foot Club to perpetuate the memory of one of the game's foremost characters.

Western New York wheat farmers are beginning to employ a type of mechanical harvester which has been used in the Grain Belt for more than ten years, it was revealed today by Henry L. Pagen, Erie County agricultural agent.

Miss Janet Olcott, daughter of Mrs. Chauncey Olcott of Inniscarra, this city, and 17 Sutton Place, New York, was married to William Gerard Cavanagh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Cavanagh of Roslyn, L. I., at noon today at St. Peter's Catholic Church by the Very Rev. Patrick F. Scully.

The report of Stone Webster, Inc., and subsidiaries, for the twelve months to June 30, which is being mailed to shareholders today, shows a net income of $2,067,219, after interest, amortization, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges.

With pork and hog prices soaring to the highest levels in eleven years and shipments of live hogs from farm to market dropping to record lows, Chicago's vast live-stock and meat industry today found itself face to face with the long-predicted consequences of -the drought.

Charles Nicholson, designer of the beaten America's Cup challenger Endeavour II, tonight sent the following cablegram to his company in Gosport: "Olin Stephens has made astonishing progress as a designer and deserves to win. All very kind about our defeat."

Max Schmeling, conqueror of Joe Louis, will in all probability get his long-delayed crack at the world heavyweight title. Acting on a cablegram received from Maxie, Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club announced yesterday that he was prepared to stage a championship fight between Schmeling and the winner of the Joe Louis-Tommy Farr battle early in October.
James Ware Bedell Jr., former advertising executive of several magazines, including The New Yorker and Town and Country, died yesterday at his home, 41-42 Forty-second Street, Sunnyside, Queens.

101st St, 75 E, 25x75.11; Rona Building Corp to Rose Sobel, 1,259 E 13th St, Brooklyn: (50c) also conveys 73 E 101st St, 25x75.11. 101st St. 305 E, 25x101: Joseph F. Murray to Newburgh Savings Bank, consideration $4,000, foreclosure.

John Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, today called upon James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, to tell the public whether President Roosevelt would seek a third term.

A plea for plain speaking and the frank fulfillment of responsibilities in the present Chinese crisis was made by Wang Ching-wei, chairman of the Central Political Council, in a broadcast speech the text of which was carried in practically all papers yesterday.

Mrs. Carlotta G. E. Surbrug, widow of John W. Surbrug, tobacco and candy merchant, died yesterday at the Summer home of her daughter, Mrs. Alexander Eakin, at Blackpoint, Conn., after a brief illness.

Moderate improvement extended yesterday throughout most of the major groups in slightly more active trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. The little activity that developed was centered mostly in the corporate section with secondary railroads leading the irregular course to generally higher levels.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer R. Goldsmith of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Fuller Goldsmith, to James C. Myers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Myers of Hartford, Conn.

A truce announced just before 2 o'clock this morning delayed for seventy-two hours a threatened strike of drivers for the Yellow Cab Company, which would have crippled seriously the city's transportation system.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."

Lazard Freres Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $157,470 of public improvement and delinquent-tax bonds of the city of Utica, N. Y., on a bid of 100.15 for 1.60s. The bonds are to be dated Aug. 1, 1937, and to mature serially on Aug. 1, 1938 to 1952.

The J. C. Penney Company reported yesterday for the first six months of this year the largest volume of sales for any similar sixmonth period in the company's history. The total of $115,312,686, compared with gross sales of $105,818,363 in the same preiod of 1936, an increase of 8.97 per cent.

Forced to share the only "iron lung" available here, Billy Hackler, 13. Muskogee, Okla., died of infantile paralysis last night after twenty-four hours' treatment. Billy Epperson, 14, of Tulsa, who alternated with young Hackler in the contrivance, has shown steady improvement since being placed in the chamber July 15.

Colonel Jake Ruppert wasn't at the Stadium yesterday on his seventieth birthday, so the Yankees gave him a suitable gift by remote control. They leaped all over the White Sox in a slam-bang game, 13 to 8, prodded the hapless crew of Jimmy Dykes into third position in the American League and maintained a nine-game lead over the Red Sox, their new pursuers in a discouraging chase.

William H. Sortor, president of the H. P. Cole Company and a leading coal merchant in Bergen County, died last night at his home here after a long illness. He was a director of the Sunrise Oil Company of New Jersey and the Englewood Loan and Building Association.

Rochester's oldest practicing trial lawyer and oldest Past Master of Rochester Lodge of Masons, Phile. tus Chamberlain, died this afternoon in Highland Hospital here following an emergency operation at the age of 82.

Howell T. Manson, president of field the Dollar Savings Bank, announced yesterday plans for enlarging the bank's Fordham office at 2,516 Grand Concourse. The adat 2,516 Grand Concourse. The addition will be of polished red granite, with bronze doors and windows, and will match the rest of the building.

A truce announced just before 2 o'clock this morning delayed for seventy-two hours a threatened strike of drivers for the Yellow Cab Company, which would have crippled seriously the city's transportation system.

Problems of the Georgia penal systern mounted today with a legislative investigation of the recent death of two convicts and a dozen fresh escapes on the record. Sheriff M. L. Davis announced the filing of murder warrants against Warden R. L. Killian and Guard Luther Ward of the Atkinson County chain gang,

This week again was marked by divergent price movements, with declines outweighing advances. The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices slipped off 0.2 point to 94.9 on Aug. 3 from 95.1 (revised) on the Tuesday previous.

It seems unlikely that historians of the future will find Olive Higgins Prouty's "Stella Dallas" among the imperishables of literature. It is too dated a piece for that, too apt to grow sere and withered by time.

The waterfront estate of Donald Hearn Cowl, prominent yachtsman and former department-store ecutive, on the tip of the promontory known as Barkers Point, on the Sands Point Peninsula, jutting into Long Island Sound, bas been sold to the Kathlands Development Corporation, a private holding company.

Because Richard Gallagher, 52 years old, of 249 Ninety-first Street, Brooklyn, had "gone straight" for twenty years, Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato refused yesterday to permit him to plead guilty of second-degree robbery and accepted instead a plea of guilty of petty larceny. The defendant was remanded for sentence.

John B. Swinney, managing director of the Uptown Retail Guild, Inc., announced yesterday that the Class B members, consisting of the larger stores in the Guild, have voted to discontinue all discounts to purchasing agents beginning Sept. 1.

Since girls crashed the gate of the very first rally, of the Boy Scouts of England, appearing before Lord Robert Baden-Powell in uniforms they had made themselves and demanding a place in the new outdoor game, they have been taking initiatives.

The Meadow Brook Pelicans rode into the final of the Rathborne Memorial Cup tournament at the Narragansett Polo Club today, halting the favored Narragansett team, 12--11, after 31/2 minutes of play in an extra period.

The marriage of Miss Mary Frances Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Henry Clark of West Orange, to Rusling Wood Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ruling Wood of East Orange and Sea Girt, took place this afternoon in St. Agnes Episcopal Church, East Orange. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. J. K. Spencer of Mystic, Conn.

The Federal Government dropped its action today against twelve Philadelphia bankers and lawyers indicted in connection with the collapse of the $132,000,000. Philadelphia Company for Guaranteeing Mortgages.

Plans are on foot to gather a modest sum for rebuilding the "Habitation of Port Royal," near Annapolis in Nova Scotia. It was there that the "Order of Good Times" flourished with good food and good cheer when the little clearing on which the habitation stood was the only civilized spot save one in all the continent north of Florida and Mexico.

Truck crops in Pennsylvania are late, but developing satisfactorily, the Federal State Crop Reporting Service of the State Department of Agriculture reports. The southeastern celery center reports excellent conditions. Tomatoes are in good condition throughout the State.

The B. M. T. appealed yesterday to John L. Lewis, head of the C. I. O., to respect the contracts which the company, under its employe-representation plan, made with the spokesmen for its workers two years ago and which will not expire until December. 1938.

The volume of checks cleared through banks of the country this week increased considerably over that of the preceding comparative period, due largely to the inclusion of settlements incident to the first of the month.

Arthur S. Draper, former assistant -editor of The New York Herald Tribune and later editor of The Literary Digest, will join the staff of the Department of Labor in September. He will be attached to Secretary Perkins's office and do some special writing.

The Hudson River Day liner Peter Stuyvesant will carry up the Hudson today 1,000 crippled and disabled men and women for a day's outing at Indian Point Park, N. Y. Those going on the trip are students and former students of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, 400 First Avenue, or others who have been aided by it.

Senator the Wheeler called upon the Democratic National Committee today 'to halt such a "deplorable practice" as soliciting campaign donations from Robert R. Young, a New York Re railway executive, at the time faced a Senate investigation.

The spirit of Manitou will be invoked for the first time in 110 years on the Shinnecock reservation when the United Indian Tribes of the Americas hold a pow-wow this week-end on the reserve near Southampton, L. I. The ceremonies will be under the auspices of the Shinnecock Presbyterian Church.

Mrs. Ivy Lee will give a small dinner on Aug. 13 at her home, 911 Park Avenue, for Miss Virginia Street and Ivy Lee Jr.. whose marriage takes place the following day. The guests will include the members of the bridal party.
Paramount's "Blonde Trouble," an adaptation of Ring Lardner's "June Moon," opens at the Criterion tonight with Johnny Downs, Eleanore Whitney, Lynne Overman and others in the cast....

Whether the first known case of 'bacteriologicalcal" warfare is fact or. fiction may soon be definitely known, because Colonel Bouguennec, retired artillery officer and father of one of the two Frenchmen now held at Irun as "carriers,"

The mistake made yesterday by scorers of the international shooting competition in declaring the Finnish team the winner of the world championship with the 22bore rifle at fifty meters, instead of the United States team, drew profuse apologies in the newspapers today.

Incorporation of the Progressive Grocers Association of -New York, Inc., an organization of Greek retailers, has been sanctioned by Supreme Court Justice Edward J. McGoldrick, it was announced yesterday by former Judge Charles A. Oberwager, counsel to the group.
Governor Lehman today named Mrs. Elizabeth Ross Haynes, Negro, of New York City, to the State Commission to Study the Economic and Social Conditions of New York's Urban Negro Population.

Don Brennan's effective relief pitching gave the Jersey City Giants a 4-3 victory over the Rochester Red Wings in the final game of a five-game series today. Brennan took the mound at the start of the fourth after Waltes. Brown, who started, was forced to retire because of a pulled muscle in his right leg, and limited the Red Wings to three hits and one run over the remaining distance.
Mrs. Edward Van Ingen gave a dinner, followed by bridge, tonight at the Maples for Mrs. Henry White of Elm Court, Lenox, Mass., who is passing , the late season at the Meadow Club.

The marble figure off a woman, representing the muse of Edgar Allan Poe, which stands opposite Poe's statue on City College campus, was daubed with lip rouge and other cosmetics yesterday in what was apparently an effort to make the Greek figure appear "modern."

There was a gain of more than 2 points in the index of business in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The index of business, adjusted for seasonal changes, stood at 120.3 per cent of the 1923-25 average.
Nineyear-old Anna Catherine Dill of Lebanon, Ohio, was listed tentatively today as a victim of the rare and dread Rocky Mountain, or spotted fever.

The four-story building containing sixteen apartments at 7 Broadway Terrace, at 191st Street, was sold by Karl C. Brett, attorney, to a client of Jesse Richman. The sale was negotiated by Leon Stein, who was the broker in the sale of the property to Mr. Brett about two months ago.

Essex defeated Worcestershire by 121 runs in a first-class county cricket match concluded at Worcester today, a day ahead of schedule. Bowlers were on top throughout, the victors making 198 and 165 against the Sauce County's 82 and 160.

In recognition of her services in stimulating better decoration of American homes, Mary Margaret McBride has been named winner of the 1937 award of the Wall Paper Institute, G. Fred Beaudry, president, announced yesterday.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 3: Blalkely, Rear Admiral C. A.; so much of the orders of May 3 assigning him to duty as commander of Carrier Division 2 is revoked.

J. Warren Alford of this place, executive secretary of the Associated Bankers Title and Mortgage Company of the. Oranges, died last night at Hanover, N. H., where he was stricken on a vacation trip. Mr. and Mrs. Alford were returning from a stay at Lake Morey, Vt.

Ninety five per cent of the increase of 18,513,593 pesos in Cuban export trade for the first five months of 1937 over the same period of 1936 was accounted for by an increase of 17,628,274 pesos in shipments to the United States, the Commerce Department said today after receiving advices from the commercial attache at Havana.

Miss Lucetta Plum, daughter of Mrs. William Terhune Plum of Locust, will be married to Lester Butler Churchill, son of Mrs. Lester Butler Churchill of Rumson, at St. George's - by - the - River Episcopal Church Rumson, on Sept. 18.

Marooned on a sand bar in Long Island Sound off West Haven when their chartered 38-foot yawl Remora went aground last night, six vacationing Bergen County, N. J., residents were rescued with their skipper this morning after spending hours battling mosquitos and horseflies.

Murray Alden Osteller has joined Nat Rosenthal Associates, Inc., as fur buyer, according to announcement yesterday by Nat Rosenthal, president. He was formerly with Scott Furriers, Boston, and was previously associated with the Syndicate Trading Company.

Louis D. Kilgus, contractor formerly associated with his father, Frederick Kilgus, in the construction business, died at his home last night. He was 58 years old. The Kilgus firm constructed a number of buildings in Newark, including the Mosque Theatre building.

Arthur L. Parmelee, treasurer of the New York, Ontario WesternRailroad, died suddenly last night of a heart attack at his home, 423 Westminster Avenue here. He was 72 years old. He had been in apparent good health and had passed yesterday at work in his New York offices at 370 Lexington Avenue.
Funeral services for Mrs. Marjorie DeLoosey Oelrichs Duchin, wife of Edwin (Eddy) Duchin, the orchestra leader, were held yesterday forenoon at her home, 2 East Sixtieth Street.

Six buildings at the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street, a plot 118.4 by 100.8 feet, have been sold by Emanuel Ornstein to the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, trustees for Waldorf Astor and John Jacob Astor, through Duff Conger, Inc., brokers.

Purchase of a site for an apartment house and sales of multifamily dwellings made up activity in the Bronx yesterday. As the site for a six-story elevator apartment house to accommodate forty-five families, the vacant plot, 75 by 156 feet, at the northeast corner of Kingsbridge Road and Heath Avenue was sold by Armstrong Brothers, brokers for the Melrose Central Corporation.
Victor Grand, 81 years old, a retired tailor of 130 West Eightyfourth Street, reported to detectives yesterday afternoon that he had been robbed of $5,000, his life savings. by three confidence men.

A registration statement covering $28,900,000 of first mortgage bonds due on Aug. 1, 1962; $1,600,000 of serial notes, of which $160,000 will mature on Aug. 1, 1938 to 1947, and 16,000 shares of $100 par value cumulative first preferred stock,
Minister of Justice Jose Carlos ,de Macedo Soares emphatically de-nied today that the Government contemplated again decreeing a state of war-that is, modified martial law.

Two Americans, Harry S. Martin of Boston and James A. Hunter of Peoria, Ill., worked unceasingly today to aid Chinese victims in this devastated city, which was the scene of one of the bitterest fights of the undeclared war between Japan and China.

The general level of wholesale prices continued unchanged for the week ended on July 31, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, remained at 87.5, and compared with 80.3 on Aug. 1, 1936.
The Post-Gazette said today that Dorothy Moore Davidson, former University of Kentucky student, had received $200,000 for her eleven-day marriage to Philip J. Davidson, heir to a million.
BLONDE TROUBLE, based on the play "June Moon," by Ring Lardner and George S. Kaufman: screen play by Lily Hayward; directed by George Archainbaud; aParamount production; at the Criterion.

Six Japanese families, comprising twenty persons, arrived here today to start an experimental cotton farm to demonstrate the practicability of production in Costa Rica and to teach the natives the principles of cotton-growing.
Five detectives have been demoted to the uniformed ranks as a result of the investigation of police aid given to ambulance-chasing lawyers, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday.
A 13-year-old girl was killed today and two companions escaped by falling between the rails when they were trapped on a bridge over the Natchaug River here by a New Haven Railroad passenger train.

The new plan of recapitalization for the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, $400,000,000 utility holding company, presented to the Federal court here yesterday by Fred B. Odlum, head of the Atlas Corporation of New York, was presented in detail by Mr. Odlum in a letter to stockholders of the holding concern.
Heartened by its first technical court victory in Massachusetts, the Birth Control League today sought funds to carry its battle to the United States Supreme Court if necessary.

Benjamin Pollock, last of the "Juvenile Drama" publishers, died here today at the age of 80. For sixty years, using the same stones that had been in his workshop for 100 years, he made toy theatres and printed sheets of characters immortalized by Robert Louis Stevenson in his essay "Penny Plain and Twopence Coloured."

Serious complications in the relations of the United States and foreign governments have been narrowly averted as a result of picketing of foreign embassies and legations here, Representative McReynolds of Tennessee, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, said today in a statement defending the anti-picketing bill his committee has reported favorably at the request of the State Department.

After a day of temporary truce apparently based on a misunderstanding, a strike in the Automat food shops of the Horn Hardart Company was called again yesterday, to be put into effect today by the members of Local 302 of the Cafeteria Workers Union.

It appears that Palestine will turn out to be a hornet's nest for the British Government. When the report of the Royal Commission was published it was said the Cabinet had accepted the findings and would proceed with the plan for partition of Palestine.

Dr. Chaim Weizmann in today's private session of the World Zionist Congress made clearer what improvements in the present offer of an independent Jewish State he hopes to gain by negotiation if the Congress--as seems surer every day--authorizes him to negotiate for the partition of Palestine.

More than 3,000 Negroes started a near-riot last evening at the end of a pier at 132d Street and the Hudson River as they attempted to board an overcrowded excursion boat for a moonlight sail up the Hudson River.

Fred Ewert, 35-year-old ex-convict missing since the abduction of Donald Horst last Tuesday, was arrested early today. Police Sergeant Frank Janousek said that Ewert readily admitted aiding the abductors "as a favor."

Eddie Cantor today sold Twentieth Century-Fox the story for his second picture with the organization, "Sing While You Sleep." The idea was suggested by Eddie Davis, one of Cantor's radio writers, and developed by the author and the comedian.

Funeral services for Percival Mullikin, publicity director and manager of the information bureau of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce, who died on Wednesday, were held last night at the Hallett Homestead, 36-08 147th Street, Flushing, Queens.

Seabiscuit, 4year-old son of Hard Tack-Swing On from the stable of Mrs. C. S. Howard, despite a burden of 130 pounds, tonight appeared the favorite among fourteen entries for the $50,000-added Massachusetts Handicap tomorrow at Suffolk Downs.

Eugene Braun, 69 years old, of 430 Sussex Street, this city, died today in St. Joseph's Hospital here, the second victim of a blast which yesterday wrecked the moulding plant of the Worldbestos Brake Lining Company here.

The Strong legislative committee, which will seek to determine if man's economic life ends at 40, held its first session here yesterday. Senator Prichard H. Strong of Rochester, the chairman, announced that it was an organization meeting.

The marriage of Miss Mabel Virginia Dewar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert D. Dewar of Garden City, L. I., to Robert Warner Morrell Jr., son of Robert W. Morrell, also of Garden City, and the late Mrs. Morrell, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration. The ceremony was performed in the presence of relatives by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray.
Airplane bomb attacks on British, Italian and French steamships were reported today at sea thirty miles northwest of Algiers. At least three unidentified planes participated in the attacks.

A woman of 77 walked up the gangplank yesterday of the coastwise steamer George Washington of the Old Dominion Line attired in the costume of a belle of the early Eighteen Eighties. A sturdy man of 84, wearing the gray bowler hat and shoestring tie of a late nineteenth century swain and a Prince Albert coat, escorted her.

Representative Beiter of Williamsville, N. Y., urged the House Banking Committee today to place administration of the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill under the Department of the Interior in order to safeguard the program "from waste and extravagance."
Congress agreed today to accept a bequest of undetermined size from James Reuel Smith of Yonkers, N. Y., to help reduce the public debt.

Two lawyers for the Trenton Valley Distillers Corporation of Detroit testified today at a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission that incorrect underwriting information was included in a stock registration statement filed by the company.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Long Island Railroad Company to abandon 3.32 miles of its roadway in Brooklyn because passenger and freight traffic on it had dwindled to a point where operation was no longer warranted.

The Irving Trust Company, as trustee in bankruptcy for the International Match Corporation will begin on Aug. 19 the disbursement of the dividend of $7,252,367 recently authorized by Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee, from part of the proceeds of the public sale of the principal remaining assets in the bankrupt estate, it was announced yesterday.

Miss Almeda Broun, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving S. Broun of 330 East Forty-eighth Street, was married last evening to William Henry Seward Jr. of Auburn, N. Y., in St. Agnes Chapel, West Ninety-first Street. The Rev. Robert Shellenberger performed the ceremony.

The text of President Roosevelt's proclamation of a commercial agreement between the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and diplomatic letters on the subject of the amount of goods Russia would buy from the United States in the coming twelve months are as follows:

Tuesday's report by the Department of Commerce on this country's foreign trade during the first half of 1937 emphasizes strikingly the great change in our visible trade balance. The surplus of merchandise imports over exports, $147,321,000, was wholly unprecedented for any corresponding period; it compares with an export surplus of $235,389,000 in 1935 and $477,744,000 in 1934.

The general tone of the stock market, although quieter today, continued firm. Giltedge issues were steady, and among the foreign some week-end covering by bears was responsible for a slightly firmer trend, this being especially noticeable in the Far Eastern.
Paris police have been asked to search for Jean de Koven, 22-year-old American girl dancer who disappeared two weeks ago from her Left Bank hotel where she was staying with her aunt.

The Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill proposing a $700,000,000 program for low-cost housing and slum clearance was passed by the Senate today, 64 to 16, and sent to the House where its sponsors hope to remove an amendment considered too drastic a limitation on expenditure of funds for family units.
John P. Barry, who had lived at Rockaway Beach, Queens, since 1875, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 170 Beach Eightyseventh. Street, at the age of 82. He broke his hip eight weeks ago.

Esther J. Porter, widow of William H. Porter, a member of J. P. Morgan Co., left a gross estate of $6,626,896, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed here today with Surrogate Leone D. Howell. Mrs. Porter was a resident of Glen Cove and died in Manhattan May 23, 1934.

Mrs. Alfreda Mitchell Bingham of Salem, Conn., former wife of Hiram Bingham, one-time United States Senator from Connecticut, was married to Henry Gregor, also of Salem, here yesterday morning in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building. The ceremony was performed by Deputy City Clerk Thomas Barry. A religious ceremony will be held today in this city.

Mrs. Edith Kermit Roosevelt, widow of President Theodore Roosevelt. attended a picnic party tonight on Stehli's Beach on Long Island Sound, given by the Edith Kermit Roosevelt Women's Republican Club of Oyster Bay in honor of her seventysixth birthday.
The Insurgents' Teruel drive in Northwestern Spain has been stopped, government commanders declared tonight, and the initiative has passed to the government in that battle area.

Among the 180 players listed to tee off in the qualifying round of the forty-first national amateur championship at the Alderwood Country Club, Portland, Ore., on Monday, Aug. 23, are six former winners of the title, two of whom have also won the open crown.

John R. Crews, Brooklyn Republican leader, announced yesterday that Peter Seery had been designated for Kings County Sheriff and A. David Benjamin for Register after conferences with the Brooklyn district leaders.

It will be a pretty far cry from that last New Year's Eve opening which it had originally planned, but the new International Casino, latest of Broadway's bigger night spots, seems pretty certain now of getting under way before this month is out-has, indeed, roped off the evening of Aug. 25 for its grand premiere.
Four-year-old James Banker spent twenty minutes in a mail box with a pair of men's galoshes tonight before the postman came around and delivered him to his father.

Postmaster General Farley, whose resignation from the Cabinet has been persistently rumored for about two years, is now somewhat more confidently expected to, resign soon after the adjournment of Congress, according to close friends and associates.

The Rev. Dr. George T. Linsley, rector emeritus of the Church of the Good Shepherd of this city and for thirty-five years a leader in the affairs of the Episcopal diocese, died early today at his Farmington home. He was 73 years old.
An agreement for complete temporary abandonment of Hankow's Japanese Concession was reached at conferences this morning between the Japanese Consul General Mr. Matsudiara and Mayor T. K. Wu.

While several bricklayers watched yesterday morning, three men approached Nicholas. Marrano, a contractor, as he was about to enter the apartment house he' is building at Pelham Parkway and Bronx Park East, the Bronx, held him up and escaped in a waiting automobile with a $4,500 payroll. A fourth thug remained at the wheel of the car.

Representations that specified books enable a person to operate immediately a producing mail-order business without previous experience and to increase his income by $100,000 "or any other definite or fabulous sum" will be discontinued by Prosperity Publishers, Inc., 697 East 219th Street, New York, and its president, Albert G. Illich, under a stipulation entered into with the Federal Trade Commission and announced by the commission today.

Cotton mill activity declined slightly last week when a sharp drop was seasonal and the adjusted index has advanced to 141.9 from 130.5. It was 135.5 for the week ended Aug. 1, 1936. Trading in cotton gray goods improved moderately this week, but was below production.

Mrs. Carlos M. de Heredia, vice president of the Berkshire Festival Association, had a luncheon party today at Wheatleigh, Lenox, in honor of Dr. and Mrs. Serge Koussevitzky. The other guests included Mrs. Nicholas Brown, Mr. and Mrs. Owen Johnson, Mr. and Mrs. Olin Downes, Miss Gertrude Robinson Smith, Mrs. Herbert S. Darlington, the Misses Sibyl M. Darlington and Helen Knox; Giraud Foster and Gardner S. Morse.

Louis Walter Caldwell, formerly connected with hotels here and in Florida, California and the Bahama Islands and a former broker, died yesterday at the age of 57. Mr. Caldwell retired from the brokerage business a year ago because of ill health.
An automobile out of control this afternoon in Weequahic Park here crashed into two benches killing a 6-month-old baby and seriously injuring four women and two other infants.

Representatives of various forestry organizations urged the Senate Reorganization Committee today to prevent removal of the Forest Service from the Department of Agriculture to the Department of the Interior, which under the bill would become the Department of Conservation, or to some other department.

Earl of Oakland, 7-year-old chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. Ralph K. Trix of Lake Placid, won the Westbury Hotel Trophy in the saddle horse class, with the Kilkare Farm's chestnut mare, Vanity Box, a close second, today in the fourth annual Sagamore Horse Show.

Bail was denied Antonio Ortiz, 32 years old, in the Felony Court yesterday on his plea of not guilty to the charge of kidnapping Milton Lopez, 4, from in front of his home at 107 West 119th Street last Thursday evening.

Followers of John L. Lewis and William Green, at a meeting which broke up early this morning, laid plans for the formation of a united front in this area by the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization.
The First National Bank of Jersey City has been appointed transfer agent in Jersey City for 6,000,000 common shares of United CigarWhelan Stores Corporation.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 780,000 bales, against 819,000 a week ago, 855,000 two weeks ago, 882,000 three weeks ago and 734,000 a year ago; of which American 278,000 bales, against 284,000 a week ago, 301,000 two weeks ago, 315,000 three weeks ago and 272,000 a year ago.

Agreements have been concluded with the Western Provinces and will soon be effected with the Eastern Provinces by the Dominion Government to increase the employability of 200,000 unemployed for whom jobs are to be found.

Clever Hanover, a bay horse owned by H. Toothaker and H. Litchfield of Somerville, Mass., won the 2:12 class trotting event on the Grand Circuit program at Agawam Park today. Clever Hanover, with Vic Fleming up, won the first two heats and then was drawn.

The volume of round-lot sales on the New York Stock Exchange increased 1,660,370 shares in the week ended on July 10, compared with the previous week, and on the New York Curb Exchange the turnover exceeded the earlier week by 335,430 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Mrs. James B. Duke, who was joined during the day by her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. James H. R. Cromwell, gave a large dinner in their honor tonight. Mr. and Mrs. Cromwell arrived from Bar Harbor, where they had been the guests of Mr. Cromwell's mother, Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury. They are planning to remain here only over the week-end, for they will sail soon for Honolulu.

Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont, holder of the New Jersey State championship, today won another Women's New Jersey Golf Association one- day tournament when she scored an 80 over the Forest Hill Field Club course.

All the church bells in Belgium tolled last Wednesday to remind the people that on the morning of Aug. 4, 1914, following the refusal of the Government to permit free passage to the German armies, a patrol of Uhlans crossed the border at Gremmenich and led the march up the undefended valley of the Vesdre to the ring of forts that held them at Liege for nearly a fortnight.
Abe Feldman, 180, East Side, knocked out Tony Celli, 175, New Haven, Conn., in 2:40 of the eighth round of the main bout listed for ten rounds at the Long Beach Stadium tonight.
A contract ending a labor dispute between C. I. O. union workers and the Spencer Kellogg Sons linseed oil plant here was ratified unanimously tonight by 381 men at a union meeting.

Representative Celler of New York announced today that he had telegraphed President Roosevelt urging the Chief Executive to veto the District of Columbia Tax Bill, now before him, because of the MillerTydings rider providing for legalization in interstate commerce of contracts for retail price maintenance, where State laws permit.
A starved dog led neighbors today to the body of Henry C. McMillen, 62 years old, a retired New York and Washington newspaper man. Mr. McMillen apparently died of a cerebral hemorrhage Tuesday night.

Australia's favorable trade balance for the year ended June 30 is [pound]35,657,000, compared with [pound]23,655,000 for 1935-36 and [pound]16,106,000 for 1934-35. Imports of merchandise for 1936-1937 totaled [pound]90,485,000, an increase of 8.3 per cent.

Mrs. E. Greenough Scott, daughter of the late George W. Woodward, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, died at her home here today. She was 99 on Jan. 1. Funeral services will be held Monday afternoon.
Vincent Astor, who knows well what Rhode Island lobsters are like, is going to try to raise some of them in the waters off his Bermuda estate.

The New York Produce Exchange announced yesterday the election of the following to regular membership: Charles J. Hughes of Charles Hughes Co.; Conrad F. Sauer Jr. of the Hermitage Realty Investment Corporation, Richmond, Va., and Robert Stern of Louis Stern Sons, Inc., Kearnv. N. J.

President John F. Gatelee of Springfield, champion of a "war to the finish" against the Committee for Industrial Organization, was elected tonight for the fourth time to head the Massachusetts Federation of Labor.

The arrival here today on a week's visit of eleven German submarines and the mother ship Saar under Captain Zur See Loycke, the largest foreign fleet ever to visit Finland, provoked a violent attack by the Russian newspaper Izvestia.
Dr. Charles P. Sylvester, Boston physician and former chairman of the State Board of Registration in Medicine, died here today at his Summer home at the age of 59.

The will of Mrs. Marshall Field, filed-in District Court today, names a niece and nephew as the principal beneficiaries of an estate valued at almost $5,000,000. They are Mrs. Katherine S. Beveridge, widow of the Senator, and Spencer Eddy of Paris.

Grain markets on the Board of Trade here turned sharply downward today on scattered liquidation by tired holders. At no time did wheat show any tendency to rally and the finish was within a small fraction of the lowest level with net losses of 2 1/2 to 3 cents a bushel.
Large tax claims are pending against the NY PA NJ Utilities Company, according to the annual report of J. I. Mange, president, which was issued yesterday.

The directors of the Union Bag and Paper Corporation voted yesterday to authorize $10,000,000 of convertible debentures, of which $7,000,000 would be issuable to stockholders under subscription rights, and a four-for-one split-up of the common stock, subject to the approval of stockholders and registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Mexico City police telegraphed authorities of Puebla and Veracruz State towns today in quest of news of Louis Marden, photographer, of Washington, D. C.

Senator Wagner voted for the housing bill bearing his name when it came to a final test in the Senate yesterday, but he must have done so with a heavy heart. The bill as it now goes to the House carries at least three provisions which may not have been intended to bog it down and render it futile but which will certainly contribute to that result.

An agreement between the United Shipyards of Staten Island and the Marine Workers Metal Trades Council, an American Federation of Labor union, was signed yesterday and promptly attacked by the C. I. O. union as "merely another phase of the 'back to work' movement."

When Louis Ornite, 25 years old, of New York, left the hospital at Escorial several days ago with five Government militiamen to pick up wounded and dead in the Brunete sector he was unfamiliar with the roads and unaware of the exact positions of the contending forces.
The use of the Real Estate Auction Room at 18 Vesey Street has been offered without charge to candidates in the Fall election for meetings every day, except Wednesday, at 12:30 P. M.

The Senate passed today and sent to the House a bill by Senator Copeland authorizing the Commissioner of Lighthouses to mark wrecked or sunken vessels and charge the cost to owners. It also would empower him to establish navigation aids and markings on inland waterways.

Members of the Salvation Army from eleven States will gather at Ocean Grove, N. J., today for a week-end of religious services in the auditorium. The program will include a festival of music tonight at 8:15 o'clock, in which the Salvation Army's Band will play.

106th St, 68 W, 4-story brick tenement and stores 25x100; Greenwich Savings Bank against Emily W Scott; due, $25,000; to plaintiff for $20,000. 114th St 108 W, 5-story brick tenement, 26.3x100.11; Greenwich Savings Bank against Edward W. Gardner Jr; due, $18,948; to plaintiff for $15,000.

A primary petition designating Municipal Court Justice Edward Cassin of 35 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, as Democratic candidate for re-election from the Sixth district, Brooklyn, was filed yesterday with the Board of Elections.
A resolution to encourage the withdrawal of the Fifteenth United States Infantry from Tientsin, China, was introduced in the Senate today by Senator J. Hamilton Lewis of Illinois.

Polish chess players still led in total points scored in the international team tournament at the Grand Royal Hotel after many adjourned games from the fifth, sixth, seventh, eighth and ninth rounds had been played today. The Netherlands advanced to second place.
William H. Brainard, who would have been 100 yers old next April 9, died here today. He was formerly in the trunk and leather goods business.

The United States Rubber Company reports a net income of $4,500,609 for the six months ended June 30, after provision for current charges, but before the estimated surtax on undistributed profits. This is equivalent to $1.29
Resident Commissioner Quinten Paredes of the Philippines said today that passage by the Senate of the Adams bill was a "surprise" and "most unfair."

Willem van Hoogstraten conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the second time' this season at the Lewisohn Stadium last night before an audience officially estimated at 2,800. The principal offering consisted of Beethoven's "Eroica" symphony.

Police of the Marine Division were searching the waters off Beach Thirty-sixth Street, Far Rockaway, early this morning for two youngmen and a woman who were reported in the ocean after their cabin cruiser capsized.

A revised version of his bill to create a commission to investigate the national relief problem was introduced in the House today by Representative Maverick of Texas, with 26 other Representatives named as co-sponsors.

Officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission continued yesterday their study of how the property of the Austin Silver Mining Company, bought at a public sale in 1930 by William E. Marshall for $1,000, managed to rise to a valuation of $475,000 on the books of the company at the end of 1936.

ALFORD-Suddenly.. on Aug. 5, 1937, at Hanover, N. H., J. Warren, beloved husband of Florence Mahin Alford of 479 Springdale Ave., East Orange, N. J. Services at The Colonial Home, 132 South Harrison St., East Orange, Saturday afternoon, Aug. 7. at 2:30.
The three-story brick Denzer Building, at 685-7 Bergenline Avenue, Union City, N. J., has been sold by the Hudson Trust Company to an investor, the Second Jersey Corporation.

Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court signed yesterday an order returnable on Aug. 16 temporarily enjoining the Cities Service Company from disposing of 312,500 shares of its common stock, pending an appeal from Federal Judge Clancy's approval of the settlement of a suit against
The Department of Parks announced yesterday a harmonica contest to be held on the Mall in Central Park at 8:30 A. M. Wednesday, Aug. 25, in which children and adults are invited to participate.

Miss Maureen Orcutt crowned a week of brilliant play on the Hotel Champlain golf course today with a 4-and-3 victory over Miss Marjorie Harrison, recent winner of the Vermont championship, in the final round of the international invitation tournament for the Frank W. Regan Trophy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with much interest THE TIMES editorial "Southern Opposition" relating to-the wages-and-hours legislation. Your position is, I believe, sound and your general conclusions should appeal to thoughtful people in the South and elsewhere.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Georgic, leaving today for Cobh, Southampton, Havre and London, includes two members of the American Jewish Committee who will attend sessions of the Jewish Agency for Palestine at Geneva. They are Sol M. Stroock, lawyer, and Dr. Solomon Lowenstein, executive vice president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies.

The 1,381 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $47,158,995,201 par value as of Aug. 1, had a total market value of $44,296,135,580, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday.

With about twenty-five persons chasing him over a route dotted with women and children, a fleeing hold-up man who flourished a pistol and forced a motorist to carry him part of the way was captured yesterday afternoon in Brooklyn by a policeman on his way home after being excused from duty because he was ill.

A move to strike from the Wages and Hours Bill its Section 8 (a), giving to the proposed Labor Standards Board control over intrastate industries where it deems them in direct competition with the interstate flow of goods, will be made by Representative Ramspeck of Georgia, when the measure reaches the floor of-the House.

Summer theatre groups at Cornell presented "Traffic Signals" in Willard Straight. Theatre on the university campus tonight. This two-movement play was written by Professor A. M. Drummond of the Deapartment of Public Speaking and director of the university theatre.

Mrs. Payne Whitney is entertaining at a house party for the week-end racing Mr. and Mrs. Warren Leslie, Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson, John McLean and Henry Evans of New York and Mr. and Mrs. James Dobson Altemus of Philadelphia.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 5, unless specified: At Balboa: Babbitt, Taylor. At New York Yard: Badger, Decatur, Dickerson, Leary, Tillman.

The anniversary of the death of Ben Jonson, great Elizabethan dramatist of 300 years ago, is being commemorated by special newspaper tributes and a performance of his most famous comedy, "Every Man in His Humour," at the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre tonight.

Until the new charter provisions become effective on Jan. 1, 1938, and pending revision of building rules and regulations to meet requirements of the new Building Code, the Board of Buildings will continue to "carry on" under its own rules, Chairman Samuel Fassler declared yesterday.

Although an early advance in prices on the Cotton Exchange here carried October above the 11-cent figure for a time yesterday, an improvement of more than $2 a bale from the low levels of the week put the market into a zone offering a supply of contracts. As a result, a reaction left the list with net losses of 7 to 16 points on the day.

The consolidated net income of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., and subsidiaries for the year ended on June 30 last after all charges, including reserves, was $4,914,187, it was reported yesterday.

That General Francisco Franco is trying actively to unify his support by moving to restore the Spanish monarchy is indicated by reports here from authoritative sources that he has sent an envoy to Portugal to ask Don Manuel Falconde, the Carlist leader, to support Don Juan, Prince of Asturiss, for King.
Heinrich A. Pickert, Detroit police commissioner, told the convention of the Military Order of the Purple Heart today that present labor trouble was not necessary.

President Roosevelt awarded the Collier Trophy to Juan T. Trippe, president of the Pan American Airways, in recognition of the transpacific line; held a press conference devoid of spectacular news; and left later for Hyde Park for a week-end at his mother's home.

Cooperative apple and fresh fruit advertising campaigns will reach a new high this Fall, according to plans announced yesterday by numerous groups. Using as much newspaper space as an increased budget will permit, the New York and New England Apple Institute will launch the most vigorous campaign it has ever undertaken.

Trading was generally only fair to slow in the wholesale markets. Slaughter-house business was fair to mostly slow. The lamb market was weak to slightly lower, steer cuts steady to higher, other classes little changed. Trading opened slow on kosher meats with beef steady, veal slightly stronger, lamb steady to weak, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Miss Natalie Willard, a sister of Mrs. Robert Goelet, and Captain James C. White, U.S.A., attached to the Twelfth Infantry at Washington, who are to be married on Monday, filed their marriage intentions with the City Clerk yesterday afternoon.
The temperature here today was nearly 4 degrees below freezing, with an overcast sky limiting visibility to one or two miles.
The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue and sell $1,660,000 of equipment trust certificates.

The Transport Workers Union appealed yesterday to John L. Lewis, chairman of the C. I. O., to reject the request of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation that he recognize and respect existing contracts between the company and its employes under the employee representation plan approved by the Federal courts in 1920.

The full session of the world conference on faith and order was called tonight to hear a statement by two German delegates regarding certain references made in a statement submitted last Tuesday by Dr. H. S. Leiper of New York.

Harvard University eventually will benefit from a trust fund established by Joseph Lee, often called "the father of the American playground system," whose will has just been filed today with the Register of Probate.

Forty-six head were sold for $230,000 tonight at the annual yearling sales. The total was the highest reached so far this year. The yearlings were from the Claiborne and Ellersiie studs of Arthur B. Hancock.

Dissolution of the old New York Stock Exchange partnership of Neilson O'Sullivan on Aug. 5 was followed by formation of a new firm of the same name, comprising C. Frederic Neilson, C. Frederic Neilson Jr. and Joseph E. McKenzie.

Miss Martha Elizabeth Bucher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Bucher of this place, was married tonight to Jules William Beuret Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules W. Beuret of Mount Vernon, N. Y., in the Grace Episcopal Church in Nutley. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Charles P. Tinker, rector emeritus.
Laidlaw Co., New York, has received authority from the State Banking Department to continue business as private bankers with capital of $1,500,000.

MANHATTAN DUTTON, ELIZABETH S. (July 9.) Estate, more than $10,000. To John A. Dutton, brother, executor, 325 West End Ave. HOENNINGER, GRETCHEN (June 13). Estate, less than $2,000. To Louise M. Fauser, niece, Village of Hawthorne, N. Y., executrix.

G. Hall Roosevelt has joined the executive staff of Commercial Investment Trust, Inc., a subsidiary of Commercial Investment Trust Corporation, it was announced yesterday. He was formerly with General Electric and chief financial officer of the city of Detroit.

138th St (10-2566), s s, 338 ft e of Cypress Ave, 40x100; 702 East 138th Street Realty Corp to Dollar Savings Bank; installments, 5 per cent; $18,000. Tenbroeck Ave (16-4367), w s, 200 ft s of Astor Ave 99x100; Schpowal Construction Corp to investors Syndicate, 250 Park Ave; installments, 6 per cent, building loan; $16,500.

Baby day in the Bronx arranged by the Board of Education and the WPA might have been a more complete howling success if the irate mothers had not indulged in howling over a strange series of mistakes in making the chief award.

A Highland County jury in Alleghany County Circuit Court today found Charlie Mundy guilty of a charge of assault and battery while a member of a mob, and fixed his punishment at two years in the penitentiary.

The city of Buenos Aires, Argentina, has sold to a syndicate of Buenos Aires bankers an issue of 40,000,000 pesos of 4 1/2 per cent and 1 per cent amortization peso bonds at a net price to the municipality of 90.25, according to the Argentine Information Bureau.

MANHATTAN BROWN, UDETTA D. (May 4, 1936). Gross assets, $34,606; net, $30,555. To Orella D. Brown, Edthel D. Brown and Aneita D. Brown, sisters, specific bequests and one-seventh residue each; Herbert D., Kenneth D. and Stanley D. Brown, brothers, one-seventh residue each; Isoline D. Ray, sister,

Dr. Amos William Butler, former secretary and executive officer of the Board of State Charities and known nationally as the author and coauthor of many social welfare laws, died here yesterday at the age of 76. Dr. Butler had been in illhealth for the last year.
Orray Taft, formerly a cotton buyer for New Orleans and New York interests and the oldest living graduate of Brown University, died on Thursday in St. John's Hospital. His age was 92.
Legislation reorganizing the Magistrate's Court here and giving the Governor the right to appoint a chief magistrate was upheld in two decisions handed down today by Common Pleas Court 7.

Governor Rivers moved today to invoke a Federal statute to compel other States to return escaped prisoners to Georgia, including James Cunningham from Massachusetts and Robert Elliott Burns from New Jerse.

The fourth United States Circuit Court of Appeals reversed today a lower court and denied the West Virginia Power Company an injunction to block a governmental power project on New River near Hinton, W. Va. The lower court had upheld the power company, and the Government appealed.
With a crowd estimated at 60,000 lining Beach Avenue and the Cape May Boardwalk, the tenth annual baby parade and jubilee carnival was held here this afternoon.
Daniel J. Kieley, former chief of the State Division of Aviation, was fined a total of $155.20 in Providence courts today for Motor Vehicle Law violations dating from Sept. 3, 1936, to date.

The Roosevelt Administration continues to insist on early action to restore crop-control -- which vanished when AAA was held to be unconstitutional. The reason why it attaches so much importance to this proposal has been clearly indicated.

To sports Editor of The New York Times: Surely the most tragic question that ever has been asked in yachting circles was that by Mr. Sopwith the other day in regard to his Endeavour II making a poor showing: What is wrong? he wanted to know.

Through the resignation yesterday of General Chang Tze-chung, its acting chairman, the Hopeh-Chahar Political Council is left without a head. In a farewell message General Chang, who pleaded ill health, requested the five council members to form a standing committee to carry on its duties and, assume responsibility.
Deputies Sergio Fernandez and Armando Cells charged today that powerful interests were hampering the inquiry into their allegations of maladministration in the semi-official guano corporation.
Mrs. Julia Almond Keller, known to the New York millinery trade for many years as Madame Keller, a designer of hats, died here yesterday at her home at the age of 93.

The severe penalties apparently including shooting inflicted on peasants for such trivial offenses as stealing a few heads of wheat from collective farms on which they worked were attributed to "Trotskyist-Bukharinist traitors" by Andrei Vishinsky, Attorney General, in a statement widely published in the Moscow press today.

Sales in local department stores this week made gains ranging from 3 to 5 per cent, according to estimates here yesterday. This represents a better showing than in the early part of July, but is about even with the average daily gain for July as unofficially estimated.

The price of zinc was advanced 1/4 cent a pound in the domestic market yesterday to 7.25 cents a pound at East St. Louis. A decline in stocks of the metal to 13,561 tons at the end of July from 44,955 tons at the end of last year was a factor in the price rise.
The Argentine Civil Court of First -Appeal has ruled that an unborn baby has property rights which must be respected in any distribution of an estate before it is born.

A rich gold mine is reported discovered in the Matto Grosso jungle. The report was brought to Rio Bonito, in Goyaz State, by Anton Nery, a Placerr, who brought in a large gold nugget as evidence. He said the mine may- be another Eldorado and the richest in Brazil.

Locked in the strangling grasp of Arctic ice floes, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police schooner St. Roch staggered toward Coronation Gulf in a fierce northwest gale tonight after rescuing the crew of the foundered Hudson's Bay schooner Fort James.
The Yanks topped the Indians, 7 to 6, at the Stadium yesterday in a ten-inning ball game that lasted 3 hours 29 minutes and held more excitement than is ordinarily crowded into a season's schedule.

Hanns Kerrl, Church Minister, failed today in an attempt before an emergency court here to prove that Dr. Friedrich Dibelius, Confessional church leader, had deliberately misrepresented him in a letter. The court found Dr. Dibelius not guilty.

America's team of horsemen, composed of Captain Milo H. Matteson on Masquerador, Captain Harold A. Isaacson on Dinger and Lieutenant James A. Curtis Jr. on Renzo, provided its finest performance of the week at Dublin's famous horse show today.

No sooner had Lee Shubert made the announcement last Sunday that Eddie Cantor might be appearing for him in a new musical slated for September, 1938, than the wires were set to humming between Broadway and the West Coast--between this column, specifically, and Mr. Cantor.
Miss Nancy Byers gave a large dinner tonight at Sandymount for her father, J. Frederic Byers, to celebrate his birthday.

Three harness race drivers were injured, one seriously, in a pile-up in front of the grandstand today at the Mifflin County Fair. Five thousand spectators witnessed the accident during the 2:24 pace. George T. Satterfield, 70, of Harrington, Del., suffered a fractured skull. Walter Garrison, 73, of Bridgeton, N. J., had a fractured hip and contusions;

Joseph Lesser, who is serving a ten-year term in Dannemora State Prison, admitted to. Assistant District Attorney P. Francis Marro at the institution yesterday that he had no information that would help solve the disappearance of Joseph F. Crater, Supreme Court justice.

Miss Cynthia Holbrook, daughter of Mrs. Charles J. Alexander, who with Captain Alexander is here for the Summer from Nassau, B. W. I., celebrated her birthday tonight by entertaining at the Devon Yacht Club's weekly dinner dance.

The new Germany's sweeping march toward totalitarianism by way of the FourYear Plan received another tremendous impetus today when Col. Gen. Hermann Goering, who is in charge of the plan, ordered State control of all the Reich's forests and lumber supplies.

Saks Co. of New York and Chicago and the National Plywood Company of New York have agreed in stipulations with the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue certain "false and misleading representations in the sale of their products," the commission announced today.
A huge "iron lung" breathed life into Charles Hunt, 24-year-old Los Angeles automobile worker, here tonight after a 121-mile race against "inevitable death" in 100degree heat.

Walton Ave (11-2826), s e cor of 176th St, 102x26; Dickey Realty Co, Inc, to Ambon Realty Corp, 580 5th Ave, mtg $35,000. Hollywood Ave (18-5422), s e cor of Otis Ave, 105x50; Helen Stotchik to Stockmore Holding Corp, 521 5th Ave. 23; Willis and 3d Ave Holding Corp to Irving Trust Co.

The will of Mrs. Charles E. H. Phillips, widow of the one-time president of the Phillips Chemical Company, bequeaths the Phillips home, Denhurst, in the Glenbrook section, with park land adjoining and furnishings, to the Stamford Home for the Aged. Judge J. Walter Madigan accepted the will for probate today. Mrs. Phillips died July 26.

With Mike Higgins contributing two homers and driving in four runs, the redhot Red Sox continued their batting splurge today by walloping the White Sox, 7 to 3, in the series opener for their tenth straight victory, not including one tie game.

William Atkinson Johnston, professor emeritus of Massachusetts Institute of Technology since 1933 and co-author of several textbooks on engineering, died today at his home in Belmont. He was in his sixty-ninth year.

Cautious batting, enlivened in the late afternoon with some spirited hitting, gave R. C. Matthews's Canadian eleven a first innings total of 288 in its two-day match against the touring Marylebone Cricket Club team today. The visitors had lost one wicket for seven runs when bad light stopped the action.

Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney and his first cousin, John Hay Whitney, appear to have between them victory in the Special, famous sporting test founded by their forebears, which will be run tomorrow for the thirty-fifth time.

Arthur D. Johnson, vice president of the Phoenix State Bank and Trust Company and treasurer of the Hartford Metropolitan District Commission, died today at his Summer home in Grove Beach, Clinton, Conn. He was 56 years old.

Plans for a housing operation in the Castle Hill section of the East Bronx were announced yesterday. As a site for improvement with four one-family dwellings a triangular plot fronting on Turneur, Zerega and Norton Avenues, overlooking Westchester Bay, was bought by a Bronx builder from the Castle Hill Estate, Inc., through Edward B. Shanahan, sales manager.

The Glenn L. Martin Company today announced a "unilateral agreement" with its employes which provides for a minimum wage of 40 cents an hour, a forty-hour, five-day week and vacations with pay for those qualified.

Registration of an issue of 18,000,000 shares of capital stock of Golden Conqueror Mines, Inc., of Manitou, Col., stopped by order of the Securities and Exchange Commission on July 15, 1935, and subsequently made effective after amendment by an order of Jan. 3, 1936, was suspended today by order of the commission for "misrepresentation of a material fact."

Dry goods wholesalers are attempting to reduce the unusually heavy inventories now in hand by three methods--intensive selling efforts to their retail accounts, reduction of buying operations and resale of goods to one another-it was learned here yesterday in wholesale buying offices.

Breaking out of their batting slump with a barrage of thirty hits, totaling fifty-three bases, the Cubs routed the Bees, 12 to 6 and 6 to 2, in a double-header before a Ladies' Day crowd of 33,608 today and increased their league lead a half-length to five and one-half games.

Word was received here today of the death at Naples, Me., of Richard Henry Lee, direct descendant of General (Lighthorse) Harry Lee, and a cousin of General Robert E. Lee. Mr. Lee was recently retired
Further perturbing news reaches the Japanese Army headquarters here concerning the purported arrival of Nanking troops in the Kalgan region, 100 miles northwest of Peiping.

A steering committee for the formation of a new trade association in the silk and rayon field met here yesterday and perfected plans for a general meeting to which all manufacturers in the North are to be invited, to be held next Wednesday afternoon at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

President Roosevelt today presented the Collier Trophy for Distinguished Service to Aviation to Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American Airways, in recognition of their "establishment of the transpacific airline and the successful execution

Circumstances surrounding the purchase of $1,000,000 in bonds of the Wanamaker Store by the board of City Trusts in 1929 were related today to a legislative investigating committee by William L. Nevin, president of John Wanamaker and at that time director of the Trusts board whose dealings are under scrutiny.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that a group headed by Robert R. Young, who, with associates, controls the Alleghany Corporation, had applied for the approval of a new partnership.
Only eight of a class of 136 failed to qualify at the June examinations for licenses as physicians and surgeons, the State Board of Medical Examiners announced today.
The Senate Railroad Finance Committee heard two New York Stock Exchange experts express sharply conflicting views today on a plan for reorganizing the Van Sweringen transportation "empire."

A somewhat steadier undertone was apparent in trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Nevertheless, both in activity and price changes, the market's record for the day seldom has been less demonstrative. Total transactions in all bonds dwindled to $5,424,000, compared with $7,166,000 on Thursday.

The new compromise bill for "procedural" reforms in the lower Federal courts, agreed upon in principle as a substitute for President Roosevelt's ill-fated program for enlargement of the Supreme Court, will be called up in the Senate tomorrow.
Share prices drifted lower yesterday in dull trading. The best resistance to the decline was made by copper and automotive issues, which closed higher on the day, mostly by fractions.

Eugene Young Sayer, president of the E. Y. Sayer Engineering Corporation and the Dairy 'and Food Industries Service Company, Inc., died in Harlem Hospital yesterday morning after a short illness. His age was 65 and he lived at 360 Central Park West.

A persisting dispute between the United Automobile Workers of America and the Chrysler Corporation tonight blocked prospects of early reopening of the big Plymouth plant on whose operations more than 20,000 workers are dependent for employment.

Trade advanced with more uniformity this week, all of the leading centers reporting gains in retail distribution over the preceding week, the increases ranging from 3 to 8 per cent, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
The Senate passed and sent to the House today the Adams Bill to repeal a $23,862,750 dollar devaluation "profit" to the Philippine Goverment.
Tests of the army's new substratosphere plane continued at Wright Field today, and, army men said, would probably last for several days.

An airplane crashed in a nose-dive tonight in a field five miles from here, killing two occupants and seriously injuring a third. The dead were Joseph Baran, 28 years old of Drums, and Stanley Kamarasky, 24. of West Hazleton.

A new commercial agreement between the United States and the SovietUnion, by which the latter agrees to increase her guaranteed purchases from the United States to $40,000,000 in the next twelve months, was announced today by the State Department.
Long Jim Barnes, Crescent A. C. golf professional, was the guest of honor at a dinner tendered by members on the lawn of the club's country estate tonight. More than 300 attended.

Revocation of the American citizenship of Fritz Kuhn, on the ground that his naturalization was fraudulent in that he took the oath of allegiance in December, 1934, with a mental reservation and has since been serving the German Government in this country, was requested today by Major Julius Hochsfelder of New York, in an interview with Henry B. Hazard, assistant to the Acting Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization.
Reports that Budget Director Leo J. McDermott would resign under pressure by Sept. 1 were described as "unjustified" yesterday at the office of the Budget Bureau in the Municipal Building.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 4: CAPTAIN Jacobs, W. F., from office of the Governor, Panama Canal, to command the New Mexico in October.

The body of George Carey, 67 years old, for forty years a private investment banker, with offices in New York City, was found here this afternoon floating in North Pond, near Parsonage Hill Road. Assistant. Medical Examiner George P. Olcott of Essex County investigated and gave a verdict of suicide.
The engagement of gold in London for shipment here in substantial amounts was resumed yesterday after a lapse of a month in which almost no shipments had been made.

David S. Warfel, a Lancaster contractor, revealed tonight that he had received an apology from the Democratic National Committee because of "veiled threats" which, he said, a party solicitor made in asking him for a contribution to the Democratic campaign fund last Fall.

Except for a swelling stream of voluntary contributions to war funds, now nearing 10,000,000 yen, warlike signs have almost disappeared here, and reservists joining their units are no longer seen on the streets.

Carl Owen Hubbell, whose fortunes these past two weeks have been going up and down with astounding rapidity, soared to a new high today when he became the first pitcher of the year in either major league to achieve his fifteenth pitching victory.

Trade practice rules for the popular priced dress manufacturing business, comprising about 500 manufacturers who employ some 60,000 persons in the manufacture of approximately $135,000,000 worth of goods annually, were announced today by the Federal Trade Commission subject to modifications after a hearing here Aug. 24 at which objections will be heard.

Rain squalls and blinding sunshine alternated today in ushering in the sixteenth annual regatta of the Miles River Yacht Club, Maryland power boat classic that is coming more and more to be recognized as one of the important sailing fixtures as well.

Miss Nancy S. Parent, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Parent of Inglewood, Calif., was married this evening to John Frederick Crowther, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice L. Crowther of Pelham Manor, in the garden of the Poundridge estate of the bride's aunt, Mrs. Robert J. Bender of Pelham Manor. The rector of St. Matthew's Parish of Bedford Village officiated.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 5: Rutherford, Col. H. K., Ordnance Dept., 14 days leave, Aug. 7. Munson, Lt. Col F. G., Judge Advocate General's Dept., 14 days leave, Aug. 12. Bruce, Major A. D., Inf, General Staff Corps, 1 day leave, Aug. 21.

Yesterday's price of $34.76 an ounce for gold in London marked the first occasion in a month that a worth-while profit had been available on shipments of bullion from that market to this. As a result almost all of the gold available in the bullion market there was taken for shipment here.
Women from many nations, including more than a hundred from the United States, joined a campaign today for "peace, emancipation and freedom" in Budapest's second International Women's Week.

An eighteen-year low level of stocks of old crop wheat on farms and in interior elevators and mills and total wheat stocks of both old and new crop wheat in commercial centers and merchant mills and elevators was estimated in a summary by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics today.
A definite labor policy is gradually emerging in the United States, Frances L. Perkins, Secretary of Labor, told an audience of 2,500 persons at Ohio University's Summer session commencement.

Owen B. Hunt, State Insurance Commissioner, declared at a hearing in his office here today that Pennsylvanians were being defrauded of about $10,000,000 a year through an "insurance racket" operated by more than 100 unauthorized companies.

Miss Eleanor Campbell, 26 years old, was discharged by Magistrate Andrews in Felony Court yesterday because of the refusal of three other women residents of the Tudor City apartment house at 333 East Forty-third Street to sustain police suspicion she was responsible for the recent series of minor thefts in their homes.

State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $12,611,564, to be represented by one State and forty-nine municipalities. This compares with the revised total of only $6,542,240 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $28,636,404.

Miss Mary Rose O'Connor, daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. John E. O'Connor of Fall River, Mass., was married yesterday in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral to Francis E. Sullivan, son of Daniel Sullivan, also of Fall River, by the Rev. Henry S. Hammer.

Sailing instructions for the New York Yacht Club cruise, on which Harold S. Vanderbilt's successful America's Cup defender Ranger and T. O. M. Sopwith's defeated challenger Endeavour II will meet again, were issued today by Edmund Lang, chairman of the club's race committee.

Werner von Crome, chief London correspondent for the Berlin LokalAnzeiger, revealed today that he and two other German journalists in London had received notification from the British Home Office that their permits to remain in Great Britain would not be renewed.
President Roosevelt left here by train late tonight for Hyde Park, where he will spend the week-end at his mother's house, returning here Monday morning.
The government announced today it was about to issue a series of decrees to curb heavy imports, which were said to be setting up "ruinous competition" to certain French industries.
Housewreckers began yesterday the task of razing the Marshall Field mansion at 4-8 East Seventieth Street, which several months ago was sold to a syndicate for two twelve-story apartment buildings.

The Dearborn Safety Commission voted today to cite six members of the Police Department on charges of neglect of duty during disturbances attending a union attempt to distribute handbills at the gates of the Ford Motor Company plant May 26.
Jersey City handed the Montreal Royals their fourth straight setback today when they subdued the visitors, 4 to 1.

Reaping will be general in the Canadian prairie provinces in about ten days, according to the Bank of Montreal. "Rains, varying from scattered showers to downpours," the report continued, "have been beneficial in Manitoba and Alberta and at a few points in Saskatchewan."

Sixteen teams took part this afternoon in the first round of knockout play in the team-of-four competition at the American Bridge League Summer tournament here, which was marked by the elimination of the strong quartet of Theodore A. Lightner, Edward Hymes Jr., B. J. Becker and Sam Fry Jr. of New York.
The Government has not yet taken any action in the matter of selecting a successor to Georges Bonnet, Finance Minister, as Ambassador to Washington.

Pensioned ON THEIR OWN APPLICATIONS PATROLMEN-Bernard P. Allen, 16th Division, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 1, 1909. George R. McGill, 1st Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Aug. 7, 1912.

THROUGH a majority of the weeks since June 26, 1933, a historical novel has led all bestseller lists. After Hervey Allen's "Anthony Adverse," published by Farrar .Rinehart in June, four years ago, have come "Gone With the Wind," by Margaret Mitchell; "Drums Along the Mohawk," by Walter D. Edmonds, and "Paradise," by Esther Forbes. Now Kenneth Roberts's "Northwest Passage" is in the lead, selling some tens of thousands of copies weekly.
For the second consecutive week new bond financing this week was restricted exclusively to the taxexempt field, corporate borrowing of any description again being conspicuous by its absence.

All the skill and ingenuity at the command of the Philadelphia General Hospital was devoted today to keeping alive the tiny girl born by posthumous Caesarean section after her mother, Mrs. Mary Boccawsini, died at 3:15 A. M.

Mrs. Lucille Bacon Legg, wife of George Albert Legg, vice president of the Legg Simon Corporation, an artificial flower concern, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital, where she had been ill for several months.

The smashing brand of tennis produced in California swept coast net stars, with one exception, to all finalround brackets of the national junior and boys' championships at the Culver Military Academy today.

The deal by which control of the Cord Corportion is to pass from it founder, E. L. Cord, to New York banking interests still was surrounded by an air of mystery today as the center of negotiations moved here. All parties to the deal maintained strict silence.

The 107th Infantry and 105th Artillery, forming General Blakesley's brigade from Greater New York, were kept under constant scrutiny by the 102d Observation Squadron, 27th Division Aviation, in the final 24-hour problem closing two weeks' training for all units at Pine Camp.

Humidity recordings remained above 60 per cent of the saturation point throughout the hottest hours of yesterday, the Weather Bureau announced, making the day one of the most oppressive of the year, although the temperature reached only 86 degrees.

The American Unitarian Association announced tonight it had received word from Oxford, England, of the election of the Rev. Dr. Louis C. Cornish of Boston, president of the association for ten years, as president of the International Association for Liberal Christianity and Religious Freedom.
Miss Anne Wisner, daughter of Captain and Mrs. Roger Wisner, gave a dinner tonight at the home of her parents in Beach Lane here before the Junior Assembly at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club.

Greenwich St, 232-34, 42.5x76.5; Nathaniel R. Kaplan to General Theological Seminary, consideration $5,000, foreclosure. 9th St, 60 W, 25x93.11; 60 West 9th St. Corp. to Rotunda Realty Corp, 52 William St, mtg. $20,750 ($8.50). 117th St, 329 W, 25x92; Nyamco Associates, Inc, to Bank of New York and Trust Co, mtg, $10, 800 held by bank.
