Macmillan reports that one week after publication "And So-Victoria," by Vaughan Wilkins, has gone into its fifth printing, a total of 100,000 copies. This is a historical novel, the first work by its author, a story of the family quarrels of the Hanoverian dynasty.

Melvin Walker, American high jumper, broke the world record today with a leap of 2.08 meters (6 feet 9 29-32 inches). Walker missed his first two tries for the new record height, then skimmed over on the third attempt, barely touching the bar. He received a tremendous ovation from the crowd.

The Committee for Industrial Organization has issued a charter to the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Association, under the presidency of - Harry Bridges, Pacific Coast longshore leader, it was learned yesterday.
Chinese scholars believe Peiping's centurieslong reign as a center of China's culture and learning is ended. They say Japanese domination, will destroy freedom to teach.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:-"Although there is distinctly less buying in the west, there has been a little more interest shown on the part of certain mill buyers in the eastern market. On the whole, however, the market is rather slow, with prices keeping generally on the levels set in the West a week or ten days ago.

Charles (Gus) Dorais, University of Detroit football mentor, swept into a commanding lead today in the poll to select coaches for the Collegiate-Green Bay Packers football battle Sept. 1 at Soldier Field.
A cloudburst hit Hamilton early tonight. City officials were besieged with reports of flooded cellars and streets. Damage probably will reach thousands of dollars.

Dark-complexioned, long - tressed Mary Bou, 11 years old, of 239 Grand Avenue, Brooklyn, was picked from a line of thirty-six youthful bathing beauties yesterday and selected for the title of "Little Miss Brooklyn" for the second consecutive year at the third annual jamboree of the Police Athletic League's Brooklyn units of the Juvenile Aid Bureau.
Stocks irregularly lower; turnover, 677,880 shares. United States Government bonds higher; others steady; transactions, $5,424,000.

The New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad soon will ask holders of its $16,000,000 of first mortgage 4 per cent bonds due on Oct. 1 to acquiesce to their extension for a period of years, possibly ten.

It has been the heartening history of American enterprise, traditionally bold and energetic, that every now and again an undertaking of unusual magnitude or one characterized by a strong appeal to the imagination marches to a successful conclusion with such steadiness and ease that its real difficulties are obscured.

Ferd S. Salmon, who died at his home, 25 East Eighty-sixth Street, last June 13, named his brother, Walter J. Salmon of 16 East Sixtyninth Street principal beneficiary in his will, which was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.
C. E. Smith, Bituminous Coal Commissioner, minimized tonight the importance of a division of opinion within the commission which led last week to Chairman Charles F. Hosford Jr.'s offer to resign.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 31 amounted to 782,660 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 11,680 cars, or 0.2

A plot 70 by 86 feet at the northeast corner of Northern Boulevard and 165th Street, Flushing, Queens, was sold by the Lexbaskert Holding Corporation to a client of the Halleran Agency, as broker. It will be improved with a business building.

Two former United States Senators from New Jersey and other well-known personages of this State attended a funeral service here this afternoon for former Representative Frederick R. Lehlbach, who died Wednesday in Washington.
Colonel George F. Baltzell, a distinguished officer of the army, died today at Marianna, Fla., the War Department announced. He was 62 years old on June 3.
Dr. Edward C. Mann, who received a Congressional award for his efforts to save President McKinley from an assassin's bullet, died here last night. He was 62 years old.

A row of flats in Harlem will be modernized at a cost of $80,000, it was learned yesterday, when an investor acquired the last parcel in the assembling of a large property near the Wadleigh High School.

China and Japan were among the heaviest purchasers of arms, ammunition and implements of war from the United States during July, according to the monthly report on exports issued by the State Department today.

Death Announced Fireman 1st grade Fred Gerner, of Engine 96, died Aug. 5, in the discharge of duty, while operating at fire at White Plains and Lafayette Avenues, Bronx, Aug. 5; Funeral will take Place from his late residence, 170 Sound View Ave., Bronx, at 2 P. M., Monday Aug. 9. Interment at Woddlawn Cemetery.
A battle over cocktails broke today in Georgia, where prohibition forces for a generation have fought off legalization of whisky.

The fourth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today upheld the right of Greenwich County, S. C., to build a $2,852,000 hydroelectric plant at Buzzard Roost with Public Works Administration funds and denied the Duke Power Company an injunction to halt the development.

" Dr. Henri Reuel," self-avowed copper and oil mining expert, who escaped last Thursday from Federal agents in Birmingham, Ala., was identified here yesterday by William Power Maioney, Assistant United States Attorney, as Joseph R. Weil, the notorious Yellow Kid. He is said to have swindled victims out of $10,000,000 in the last thirty years of his operations as a confidence man.

At a time when grayed veterans of the "war to end war" are dedicating in France monuments and memorials to those who died for a dream that is dead, The Associated Press brings us the last sardonic commentary on man's relations with his fellow-man.
The Berkshire Symphonic Festival, which paused for rest today, will resume tomorrow night here at Tanglewood. At that second concert Serge

A new type submarine mine, fired by an electric impulse from shore, was used with impressive success here today by Headquarters Battery 7 of the 152d Coast Artillery, stationed at Fort Hancock, in a target practice held a mile off shore in Sandy Hook Bay.

D. S. Polland of New York City took the lead in the championship tournament of the New York Chess Association tonight when he defeated G. N. Treysman, also of New York, to break a tie. Two rounds remain to be played tomorrow, with Polland now two full points ahead of Treysman, his nearest competitor.

Middlesex remained at the top of the first-class county cricket standing today by defeating Somerset by an innings and 113 runs. Lancashire, Nottinghamshire, Glamorgan, Surrey and Yorkshire were other victors, while Derbyshire won on the first innings only over Northamptonshire.
SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petition 803 BAR GRILL CORP., 803 6th Ave., -- Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $39,129 and assets of $28,583.
Ruby E. Zioncheck, widow of the late Washington Representative in Congress, got her gun and took the situation into her own hands today after police sought in vain for a prowler she reported.

The first meeting of the unofficial committee tamed by Governor Lehman to prepare data for the use of the State Constitutional Convention to be called in April. 1938, was held yesterday in the home of the Governor, at 820 Park Avenue.

All residents of Purchase may tap the new pipe line installed near their estates by the Westchester Joint Water Works No. 1 if they consent to enlargement of the water district and its assessment area, according to Munn Brewer, counsel for the water-works, today.
The Cardinals gained undivided possession of third place in the National League race today by defeating Philadelphia, 10--7, while Pittsburgh was losing to Carl Hubbell and the Giants, 6--3.

The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill to regulate receivership fees and procedure in the Federal courts. The bill, introduced by Senator Borah, would make agreements between lawyers and interested parties on fees in receivership and bankruptcy cases illegal.

Tomorrow morning at 11 o'clock Robert Riggs of Los Angeles and Jiro Yamagishi, champion of Japan, will face each other in what promises to be one of the finest matches seen on the Meadow Club turf in years.

Federal Judge Marcus B. Campbell in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that a labor dispute angle could not be considered in the hearing of a libel action brought by the American West African Corporation to gain possession of its freighter, the West Irmo, from a crew of twentyfive men who are conducting a sitdown strike aboard the ship; which is docked at the foot of Pioneer Street, Brooklyn.

A mortgage for $113,005 on 350-54 W 12th St, held by the Mortgage Commission and the Union Guarantee and Mortgage Co from the Edot Realty Corp, Aaron Bell, president, was extended to July 1, 1940, at 5 per cent.

The Bears extended their victory streak to eight games as they beat Rochester, 8 to 6, in the twilight half of a double-header tonight but the longest string of the year was broken as the invaders gained a 4-3 verdict in the nightcap behind Howard Krist's seven-hit pitching.

The current stalemate in Spanish non-intervention was intensified rather than improved by the meeting today of the Non-Intervention Committee chairman's subcommittee, which lasted one hour. The subcommittee established a "technical subcommittee" and then adjourned until it is called by Lord Plymouth, its chairman.

A claimant to the $20,000,000 estate of Henriette E. Garrett today asked the Orphans Court to have her coffin searched to see whether a will was hidden there when she was buried nearly seven years ago.

The downfall of last year's winning pair, Tommy Goodwin and Joe Gagliardi of the home club, furnished the highlight of today's first two match-play rounds in the John G. Anderson Memorial four-ball tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

George Ehret Burghard, in 1 Gracie Square; Mrs. piles Dover, through Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., in 151 E 83d St; Archibald F. Bogle, in 346 E 52d St; Edward J. Finley, in 230 E 48th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., broker.

The Rev. Dr. Andrew R. Osborn, formerly of the faculty of the Biblical Seminary in New York, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Edmonton, Alberta, will be guest preacher at morning services the rest of this month at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

The bands played well and the fireworks boomed tonight, but the Dodger bats had little dynamite in them, so Burleigh Grimes's boys dropped their only night game of the season to the Reds, 3-1, and were forced into a six-place tie with Charley Dressen's crew.

Playing in her best form of the week, Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan of Boston defeated Mme. Sylvia Henrotin of France today to gain the final round of the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club. The score was 6-2, 6-3.
Republicans supporting Mayor La Guardia expressed increasing confidence yesterday that he would enter a contest for the party nomination, although they admitted that they had no direct word from him.
James Rossevelt reported today that Massachusetts WPA expenditures averaged substantially higher than those in other States of comparative population.
Republicans supporting Mayor La Guardia expressed increasing confidence yesterday that he would enter a contest for the party nomination, although they admitted that they had no direct word from him.
James Rossevelt reported today that Massachusetts WPA expenditures averaged substantially higher than those in other States of comparative population.

Checks exchanged at the principal clearing houses of the country in July aggregated $28,792,500,051, an advance of 0.3 per cent over the preceding month and 5.5 per cent in excess of the total in July, 1936.
The Pan American Airways Clipper 3d swooped down to the placid water of Botwood Harbor at 5:50 Eastern daylight time tonight after completing the first commercial daylight flight across the Atlantic.

Carl K. Withers, Commissioner of Banking and Insurance of the State of New Jersey, announced yesterday that through his counsel, Peter Hofstra of Paterson, he had filed in the Court of Chancery an accounting as trustee of the Mortgage Guaranty Company of Passaic County.

That the National Electric Products Corporation signed a "closed-shop" contract with the American Federation of Labor, only after that organization "had threatened a nation-wide boycott" of the corporation's goods, was the testimony of I. A. Bennett, vice president in charge of sales, before the National Labor Relations Board today.
The Tigers batted out a 10-to-3 victory over Washington today. The Senators got nine hits off young Jake Wade, scoring one run each in the fifth, sixth and seventh innings.

Officials representing nine municipalities in Hudson County drew up a petition protesting the scheduled fare increase on Hudson tube trains operating between Downtown Manhattan and points in Hoboken and Jersey City, at a conference at City Hall here today.

Heedless of President Roosevelt's veto ultimatum, the House passed the controversial Sugar Control Bill today by an unrecorded vote of 165 to 55, after champions of the domestic producing and refining industries rode roughshod over an amendment by Chairman Jones of the Agriculture Committee designed to delete provisions unacceptable to the Administration.

Mrs. Charles Page Perin of 755 Park Avenue and Mrs. John Slade of Oyster Bay have left for a motor trip through New England. Mr. and Mrs. F. Shepard Cornell have returned to 430 East Fiftyseventh Street after passing several weeks at Lake Winnepesaukee, N. H.

The Alberta Legislature ended its special session today after a four-day period of drastic social credit legislation. The major measure of the session was an act to license bankers and gain control of banking policies in the Province, an enactment considered likely to lead to the widest repercussions of any provincial statute in Canadian history.
Mrs. Mathilde Doehner and her two sons, all of whom were burned in the Hindenburg disaster at Lakehurst in May, left the Beach Borough Hospital today for their home in Mexico City.

The marriage of Miss Grace Adelaide Wilcox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Wilcox of Glen Ridge, to Albert John Lender, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Lender of Bloomfield, took place this afternoon at Marlboro Inn, Montclair. The Rev. Harry L. Everett of the First Congregational Church, Jersey City, performed the ceremony.

Giovanni Maiani of Milan, Italy who owns Muscletone, the Euro pean trotting champion, is slated to arrive here on Monday aboard the North German Lloyd liner Europa He is coming to complete negotiations with E. J. Baker, owner of Greyhound, the American champion, for a match race between the two horses in this country.

Steel production in the United States in July was 4,556,596 gross tons, a gain of 9 per cent over June, when output was 4,183,762 gross tons. Because of the threeday Independence Day holiday observed in many plants, the increase does not represent- fully the extent of the recovery from strike conditions, the American Iron and Steel Institute points out.
A 'bill to limit jurisdiction of Federal courts over suits involving the collection of State taxes won Senate approval today and went to the House.

John P. Knapp, 38 years old, for fifteen years a financial writer on The Wall Street Journal, was accused by Mounted Patrolman William L. Robinson in the Felony Court yesterday of being one of two men who at 1:25 o'clock in the morning attempted to rob him in the vestibule of the apartment house in which Mr. Knapp and his accuser live at 319 West Eighteenth Street.
New outbreaks of violence on Cleveland's smoldering strike front today resuited in injury to two men and arrest of six others.

Due to the inability of the Mexican Government to supply gasoline, fifteen United States Army planes, including ten pursuit ships and five bombers, are still waiting at BrownsvilleTexas, en route to Panama, where canal defenses are being strengthened.

The roar of the city, which every one talked about but no one did much of anything to -stop until Mayor La Guardia swung into action twenty-two months ago, appears to be abating if the volume of complaints to the League for Less Noise may be taken as an indication of the public temper.

FIRST MILITARY AREA Colonel Edward E. McCammon, Infantry, will proceed on or about Aug. 9 from Syracuse, N. Y., to Plattsburg Barracks, N. Y., on temporary duty in connection with the training of organized reserves, and upon completion of this duty will return to Syracuse, N. Y.

Diplomatic speeches, dominated by their common interest and their common welfare against communism, were exchanged today by Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Marques Antonio de Magaz, the Spainish Insurgent's first Ambassador to Germany.

Senator King told Vice President Garner today he should remain on the job when the Senate is in session. Mr. King was protesting a ruling by Mr. Garner which took him off the floor during debate on the Wagner Housing Bill.

Mrs. Madeleine R. Chapman of 262 Central Park West, who was long a leader in charitable and social welfare work, died yesterday. She was the wife of William P. Chapman Jr., senior member of the law firm of Sackett, Chapman, Brown Cross.

A fire of undetermined cause early this morning almost destroyed the twelve-room Summer home of Frank C. Henderson on Conklin Lane here. Mr. Henderson, who is a member of the Coffee and Sugar Exchange, with offices at 66 Beaver Street, New York, estimated the value of the house and its furnishings at $500,000.
In the matter of silver mugs this country feels differently from the young woman who didn't give her friend

The New York Maritime Council charged last night that Atlantic coast shipyards had conspired to force ship lines to use yards whose employes are on strike, despite the preference of the liens for yards which are not affected.

Four favorites reached the semi-finals of the twenty-ninth annual Yahnundasis Golf Club invitation golf tourney today. Jack Ahern of Buffalo, medalist yesterday with a 2-overpar 72, will play R. J. (Dick) Govern, former Hamilton College links leader, and Henry J. Kowal, formerly of Colgate University, will tackle R. A. Barringer, Schenectady, last year's medalist. Ahern and Kowal are slight favorites.

Describing the eruption as the most violent in thirty years, a group of mountain guides arrived in Arica today and declared that the extinct volcano Tacora, situated close to the Chilean-BolivianPeruvian frontier, is throwing out rocks and smoke.
As a protest against awarding contracts by the Board of Education to nonunion shops, painters were called from work yesterday on twenty-eight school buildings in Brooklyn and Manhattan.

Plans for the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Eightieth Street, the site of which was completed on Tuesday, were filed yesterday. Details of this and other plans follow:

Henri B. Rainville, former Speaker of the Quebec Legislature, prominent Canadian utilities corportion executive and a king's counselor, died here today at the Jeanette Apartments on the Boardwalk. He was 85 years old on April 5.
Arthur Gould Walton, shoe manufacturer in Chelsea for twenty-five years, died today at his home in Wakefield.

Declaring that "practically all socially minded persons agree that those who toil should enjoy more of the joys and comforts of life," James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx, said yesterday he would vote in favor of a five-day week for city employes.

Commodity futures were stronger yesterday on the local exchanges. In the cash markets, corn, rye, cocoa, zinc, standard tin and rubber advanced, while wheat, flour, eggs, lard and cotton declined. Cocoa futures advanced 15 to 18 points, with sales 5,595 tons.

Arrived by written word and wire: A measure of excitement occurred off the Fire Island lightship a day or so ago when Peter De Natale was host to a party of six anglers aboard the Viking II out of Freeport. In the course of the day the boys landed eight tuna, two bonitas and a blue, all sizable.

A 26-yearold English widow today forfeited a fortune to marry again. Mrs. Jacqueline Esther SebagMontefiore became the wife of Geoffrey Myddleton, a physiologist four years her junior, in a simple ceremony at the Caxton Hall Register Office.

Patrolman 'John Ryan of the Second Precinct was shot and dangerously wounded about 4 o'clock this afternoon when he went to disarm a youthful camper who had been one of a party firing rifle shots across a golf links.

Cloudbursts, thunderstorms, lightning and scattered showers in some parts of the country offered only temporary relief yesterday from the oppressive heat and high humidity which has spread throughout the nation for the last few days.
A plan to have the State of Georgia present a Bible to every school child has backfired so furiously that its proponents are seeking to drop it without loss of face.

PLANS for the Labor Day week-end, the last long holiday of the Summer season, are taking shape. Several large ocean liners will make a cruise to Bermuda, leaving New York harbor on Sept. 3 and returning on Sept. 7. Nova Scotia, too, will be a favorite objective for the four-day interlude before one settles down to the Fall and Winter "business as usual."
Dr. Paul Monroe, Professor of Education at Columbia University, was re-elected president of the World Federation of Educational Associations today as its seventh world conference drew to a close.

FROM the travel experiences which were the basis for his "Royal Road to Romance," "The Glorious Adventure" and other popular volumes, Richard Halliburton has made for young people a selection of his most striking

Miss Margaret Fitzgerald has been appointed chairman of the general committee for the benefit fashion show, to be followed by a bridge party and tea, which will be held at the Outpost Inn here on Tuesday afternoon. .
A 91-year-old woman and her niece died today in a fire,, which -had trapped them on the second floor of their home.
One of the most important outdoor events of the Shelter Island season, the fourth annual all day water carnival, was held today at the New Prospect Beach Club.

The roll of arrested Protestant pastors and lay leaders has been increased by twenty-seven during the last ten days, according-to a bulletin sent out by brotherhood councils to members of the Confessional movement.

The Duke and Duchess of Kent, who have been traveling in Poland, have arrived here. They will remain until tomorrow, when they will go to Wasserleonburg Castle to visit the Duke and Duchess of Windsor. From there they expect to go on to Yugoslavia.

A question to be answered here after 1 P. M. tomorrow is: Do the Newark policemen know their groceries? From that time until midnight, and during the same hours every Sunday hereafter, they are to be the umpires of the great grocerydelicatessen squabble.

PLANS for a Westchester "newused" car show to be held at the County Center on Bronx River Parkway in White Plains were made public last week by William E. Taylor Associates. The show will run from Sept. 10 to 17.

Criticism of some of the provisions of the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill, which was passed by the Senate last week, was voiced yesterday by F. Montefiore Levy, lawyer and a former School Commissioner of this city.

The Germans made their last despairing bid for World War victory on July 15, 1918, with a final offensive on the Marne. It was broken quickly and completely. Three days later the Allies launched the first of the series of great offensives destined to end the conflict.

The marriage of Miss Doris Edwards Payne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edwards Payne of Maplewood, to Robert Simmonds Carr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Simmonds Carr, also of this place, took place at noon today In Prospect Presbyterian Church, Maplewood. The Rev, Arthur- Nelson Butz, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

A novel four-story building without windows has just been completed for the Hershey Chocolate Corporation at 117-19 West Twentyfirst Street running through to 116 West Twenty-second Street and the firm has moved into the new structure, which will be used for office and warehouse purposes.

The possiability of using the Bank for International Settlements as the nucleus for a world gold reserve, such as the Royal Bank of Canada proposed this week in its monthly letter, has been the subject of informal discussions this week among government economists and fiscal officials.
Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan, in an interview here today, said that President Roosevelt was "stronger than ever" and that there was "appreciable sentiment for a third term for the President."

Miss Elizabeth Van Antwerp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Van Ant werp, was married to Lucius Beebe, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Russell Beebe of Weston, in Grace Episcopal -Church . here this afternoon. The Rev. Frederick R. Morris, rector, performed the ceremony, which was witnessed by a notable gathering. from- the North Shore, New York and Boston.
The Catholic Church declined today the personal invitation of the Archbishop of York to send delegates to the second World Conference on Faith and Order in session here.
Fire swept the fifty-three-foot market boat Augusta C. Quinn early today near Seven-Foot Knoll in Chesapeake Bay. Three persons aboard were taken off by a motor boat.
The Senate joined the House today in approving a $35,000 authorization for continuing the Commerce Department's national safety and accident prevention campaign.

ADELMAN-Dr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Adelman announce the birth of a daughter, Alice Elizabeth, on Aug. 3 at the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn. BAUM-To Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Baum, a son, on Aug. 1, 1937, at Park East Hospital.
Approval was given today by the Public Utility Commission to a plan proposed by Allendale, Bergen County, for elimination of four Erie Railroad grade-crossings in that municipality.

The Governors and legislators of four New England States are perplexed and somewhat resentful over the interposition of President Roosevelt to prevent the formal "consent" of Congress to the flood control agreements which have been formulated under the compact clause of the Constitution.
THE Gershwin memorial concert tomorrow, and the appearance of Harold Bauer and Albert- Spalding as soloists on Thursday's program, are features of the last week but one of the Stadium season.

Looking over a list of devices which included a keyhole funnel, non-skid garters and a non-leaking bullet-proof vest, Albert G. Burns of Alameda, Calif., made this observation today: "Yes sir, this has been one of the greatest years for inventions since they opened the Patent Office."

The marriage of Miss Evelyn Louise Assmus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Assmus of this place, to Arthur Ward Huntting, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Percival Huntting, also of Nutley, took place this afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church. The Rev. L. Harold Hinrichs, pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

WITH the recent appearance of Alfred Einstein's revision of the Koechel cata logue, the -Mozart literature has become immeasurably enriched. Long anxiously awaited, the new Koechel more than fulfills expectations, representing the invaluable results of a stupendous amount of research and labor on the part of its compiler.

Lester P. Barlow, an inventor demanded in a letter to President Roosevelt, made public today, the removal from office of six Federal officials, including three Cabinet members, as a result of a hearing held here recently by the National Labor Relations Board.

Little "Mr. and Mrs. Yorkville," who were chosen the most beau- the tiful babies in Yorkville, sat on Benny Leonard's lap yesterday afternoon and forced a new role on the retired lightweight boxing champion.
A suspect in the kidnap-slaying of 10year-old Charles Mattson of Tacoma, Wash., was being questioned here tonight, police disclosed.

The day after the arrival of a large German submarine flotilla here which caused the resumption of a violent anti-Finnish campaign in the Soviet press, it was announced that Foreign Minister Rudolf Holsti contemplates an official visit to Berlin. It is assumed that Dr. Holsti obtained the Cabtnet's authorization to pay the visit. He already has visited London, Paris and Moscow.
Henry J. Kowal of Bridgeport, Conn., won the twenty-ninth annual Yahnundasis invitation golf tournament today with a 2 and 1 victory over Dick Govern, former Hamilton College star.

Seven hundred employes of the National Sugar Refining Company of New Jersey, meeting tonight, ratified an agreement between company officials and the union, a C. I. O. affiliate. Two hundred workers will return to work tomorrow and 700 more will be re-employed within the next week.

Miss Mary Conneen, daughter of Andrew M. Conneen Jr. of South Orange, will be married to Charles M. Denise Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Denise of Bethlehem, Pa., on Oct. 2 in Our Lady of Sorrows Church here.
When Government agents rubbed out "Ma" Barker and her son, Fred, with a hail of bullets in 1935 they also, the Senate agreed today, shot $2,500 worth of holes in a Florida residential property.
One hundred and twenty-nine judges have been licensed by the American Horse Show Association, according to the official bulletin just issued by the governing body, with more names being added daily.

The Staten Island Zoo has just acquired eighty-nine new specimens, and according to the law of averages, about half of them are, potentially, very dangerous. The entire group . occupies a pint-size mayonnaise jar. The specimens at present are just reddish-brown specks, but if they do not eat each other up, they will some day be black widow spiders.
